column2: With his resignation as President of the Board of Aldermen Joseph V. McKee becomes a private citizen for the first time since 1918, when he was elected as a young Democratic Assemblyman from the Bronx.
The postponed premiere of "Hilda Cassidy," now listed as the work of Henry and Sylvia Lieferant, will take place this evening at the Martin Beck Theatre.

PITTSBURGH, May 3. -- The steel industry is gaining momentum daily, and schedules this week in this district will approximate 30 per cent of capacity, according to leading producers. Many plants have resumed operations in the last few days.

The United States is "surely committed to revolution" unless the liberal forces of the country, by experimentation in industry, move toward a drastic change in industrial control, Professor Rexford G. Tugwell, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture and a member of the Columbia University advisory group enlisted by President Roosevelt, declares in his book "The Industrial Discipline and the Governmental Arts," issued by the Columbia University Press.

PARIS, May 3. -- Dissension among the 600 members of the American Chamber of Commerce in Paris, resulting from the activities of its radio import license committee, probably will lead to the chamber's complete reorganization.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The Administration's emergency railroad bill setting up a Federal coordinator of transportation to direct and compel elimination of wasteful practices will be sent to Congress tomorrow accompanied by a Presidential message asking prompt passage.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- In urging passage of the Wagner bill to establish a national employment system. Secretary Perkins told the Senate Committee on Education and Labor today that only twenty-four States have employment bureaus and that Federal offices should be established in States where no employment systems existed.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- President Roosevelt, in a proclamation today, officially designated May 14 as Mothers' Day. He urged the churches and welfare organizations to do everything possible "for the relief of mothers and children who may be in the need of necessities of life."

An American delegation headed by HENRY MORGENTHAU Sr. sailed for Europe yesterday to represent this country in a new conference at Geneva. Its purpose is to discuss means of improving markets and prices for wheat, and to prepare recommendations on this question for the forthcoming World Economic Conference.

BALTIMORE, May 3. -- Wise Daughter, the Everglade Stable's fleet juvenile filly by Wise Counselor -- Wise Mother, romped to a four-length victory over C. V. Whitney's High Glee today in the $2,500 added Pimlico Nursery Stakes. Another Whitney entry, Hooligan, took the show.

Hugh Baker, former president of the National City Company, is being sought for questioning by United States Attorney Medalie in the case against Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank, who has been indicted for income tax evasion, but is still the object of a Federal grand jury inquiry.

He Died Poor. SANCHEZ CERRO, slain President of Peru, is reported to have left a personal estate of $30. Possibly one should wait for confirmation of the story, but on the other hand cynics might do well to wait before dismissing the tale as absurd in the annals of Latin-American politics.

State and Federal unemployment relief funds, totaling $1,106,549, were allocated during April to fifteen State departments to provide additional full time and part time jobs for about 40,000 men and women, it was announced yesterday by Harry L. Hopkins, chairman of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, which disburses the State's unemployment relief funds.
BERLIN, May 3 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of April 29 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

Chairmen of the various committees charged with responsibility for successful conduct of the sixth annual Albany-to-New York outboard motor boat race on May 14 held a final check-up meeting last night at the Hotel Lexington and reported everything in readiness for the event.

Time and the stress of Democratic Congressmen have led Postmaster General PARLEY to modify his policy, declared when he was only double-chairman, in regard to recommendations for Federal office. Candidates, he said, must be approved by the local and State committees.

After having held substantial amounts of cash, short-term Treasury notes and bank and brokerage house credits since April, 1930, the First Chrold Corporation is now fully invested and expects to continue in this condition, according to Gerald M. Loeb, manager of the company, which is a speculative investing company.

The traditional requirements for a bachelor of arts degree at Columbia College, established more than thirty years ago, have been modified by the enactment of a faculty ruling "unique in American collegiate administration," Dean Herbert E. Hawkes announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- For the seventh time since the government built its vast war-time power and nitrate project at Muscle Shoals the Senate passed today the Norris bill for its operation by the government. New provisions have now been added, however, to carry out President Roosevelt's program for power, navigation and flood control development or the whole Tennessee Valley.
WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The Professor drew a circle on a sheet of paper. He had been asked what was the economic philosophy of the President's "brain trust."

A system of Police Department espionage, in which plain clothes men responsible to various superiors would check on each other, was outlined yesterday by Police Commissioner Bolan In a talk at Police Headquarters. On Saturday it was announced that the commissioner planned to restore the vice squads known throughout the Police Department as "inspector's men," which were abolished by Commissioner Mulrooney following revelations by Samuel Seabury, of abuses in connection with his magistrates' courts investigation.

ALBANY, May 3. -- A considerable reduction in the cost of city government in New York State is shown by a survey of 1933 budgets made by the New York State Conference of Mayors, whose results were made public today.

Mayor O'Brien pledged his support to the proposed tunnel between Brooklyn and Staten Island yesterday in a speech to 400 Staten Island residents who called at City Hall to urge speedy action on the project.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Relative to the controversy over the development of the old reservoir site in Central Park, may I suggest that the city avail itself of some of the benefits of Nathan Straus Jr.'s visit to Germany in the Summer of 1931, when he inspected many of the parks of that country and observed how the Germans blended esthetics of landscaping with esthetics of the human body?

LONDON, May 3. -- Sir Edwin Dodd died suddenly today in Bromley at the age of 73. For many years he was a member of the Baltic Exchange, and throughout his life he was active in philanthropic work. Last Monday Sir Edwin spoke at the Shaftesbury Society festival when the Princess Royal received purses and distributed prizes.
WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Movements of vessels follow: all dates are May 2, unless otherwise specified:

HARWICHPORT, Mass., May 3. -- Fof the safe return of 10-year-old Peggy McMath, kidnapped yesterday, her parents issued an appeal to the underworld today, banned police activity for a forty-eight-hour period and pledged every dollar they could get for ransom.

Mortgages for $70,000 were consolidated as one lien and extended to March 15. 1936, at 5 1/2 per cent until March 15. 1933, and 5 per 'cent thereafter, covering 43 Park Av., in an agreement made between Samuel L. Fuller and another and the Seamen's Bank for Savings.

BOSTON, May 3. -- Word was received here today of the death in Asheville, N.C., of Professor Frank William Rane, who during his long career was particularly prominent in the fields of horticulture, agriculture and forestry.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Some twenty-five of the twenty-seven former directors of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company participated in a pool headed by Joseph W. Harriman to purchase the bank's stock, Henry E. Cooper, Harriman's successor as president and now conservator of the bank, testified this afternoon before a Senate Judiciary subcommittee.

BERLIN, May 3. -- Thomas Mann resigned today the chairmanship of the Bavarian section of the Society for the Protection of German Authors at Munich, saying he intended to withdraw into complete seclusion.
WASHINGTON, May 3. -- An assertion that the United States was gaining ground in the fight against the depression was made today by Secretary Roper in a statement on business conditions.

BALA, Pa., May 3. -- Mrs. William du Font's Red Sea carried off the blue ribbon in the class for 4-year-olds suitable to become hunters at the opening of the annual Philadelphia horse show on the grounds of the Philadelphia Country Club Polo Field today.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- In a final appeal for revision of the home mortgage bill now before a Senate banking and currency subcommittee, D. E. McAvoy, chairman of the Long Island division of the Home Mortgage Advisory Board, informed the subcommittee today that his group would prefer no legislation at all on this subject rather than enactment of the pending bill.
LONDON, May 3. -- Prime Minister MacDonald returned to England today with what he called a message of hope.

Blackfish, sea bass, striped bass and flounders now are being taken by salt-water anglers in near-by waters. Poor weather in recent days has kept most of the fishermen on shore, but every indication is that good sport is just ahead.
The sudden resignation of Joseph V. McKee as President of the Board of Aldermen and his announced retirement from active political life met with varying reactions yesterday.

The fight to block the plan of Park Commissioner Sheehy to construct athletic fields on the old reservoir site in Central Park will enter a new phase today when leaders seeking to preserve the park as a breathing space for all the public will meet to plan a definite line of action.

The new Park Commissioner has been accused of ignorance of his job, and now says that he pleads guilty if it means "giving the kids "in Manhattan an opportunity for "healthy outdoor fun." No further demonstration is necessary. A man who can say that with reference to a needless and wholesale intrusion upon the peace and beauty of Central Park shows in the act that he does not know what city parks are for.

The rabbinical assembly of the Jewish Theological Seminary, in annual convention at the seminary. 122d Street and Broadway, was urged yesterday to foster a compulsory course in "social problems" for all prospective rabbis at the institution.

DUBLIN, May 3. -- The oath of allegiance to King George, mandatory on members of the Free State Dail and Senate, was removed by the Dail this evening after one of the stormiest and most acrimonious sittings in its record.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 3. -- The Central Bank issued a bulletin today which draws a none too favorably picture of existing conditions in the economic field, although it admits certain indications point toward "improvement in business, probably leading to a greater revival and expansion, although within very reduced limits, provided, of course, the unexpected does not intervene, bringing new difficulties."

DERBY, Conn., May 3. -- The Illness of William Garnsey, Yale varsity stroke, today caused Coach Ed Leader to make three changes in the crew which will race Columbia and Pennsylvania in the outstanding event of the annual triangular regatta for the Blackwell Cup next Saturday.
Purchases of residences by executives of large manufacturing firms featured the suburban realty trading reported yesterday. Both Westchester and Long Island properties were included in the turnover.

Back in 1908 Tom Cassidy could list his real and personal property as a wife named Hilda, a girl called Mamie and a cigar-store Indian that remained anonymous. The years passed and two decades only discarded the Indian. The women remained the same, in their several loyalties, and they stuck to Tom for what is called love, down along Third Avenue.

Owen D. Young resigned as a director and as chairman of the executive committee of the Radio Corporation of America and as a director of all subsidiary companies of the corporation, thus performing the obligation imposed by the Federal court in Wilmington, Del., in its consent decree of Nov. 21, 1932, requiring a complete separation of the interests of the Radio Corporation and the General Electric Company.

The possibility that the earth is more than 2,000 million years old, several hundred million years older than is indicated by present astronomical, geological and radioactive methods, was presented last night at the Gould Memorial Library, New York University, University Heights, by Dr. John C. Merriam, president of the Carnegie Institution of Washington.
In a setting of literary person ages, gathered at the dinner of the Friends of the Princeton Library at the Hotel Plaza last night, the Pulitzer Prizes for Literature in 1932 were awarded.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- The Standard Gas and Electric Company reported today for 1932 a consolidated net income of $7,656,000, equivalent, after dividends on the senior stocks, to 59 cents a share on the common stock outstanding. This compared with $15,417,000 in the preceding year.

BOSTON, May 4. -- Archibald MacLeish gave up a brilliantly promising Boston law career to produce poetry and magazine articles. "Conquistador," which won him the Pulitzer prize, is his sixth book of verse.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Roosevelt will address the nation by radio at 9:45 o'clock Sunday night, reviewing in a "fireside talk" the achievements of two months of his administration and outlining what he hopes to accomplish in domestic and international affairs.

Old Honus Wagner, famous shortstop of the Pirates for eighteen years, was honored by the citizens of Brooklyn yesterday and even the hotly contested ten-inning game with the Dodgers, won by Pittsburgh, 2 to 1, took second place In the interest of the 12,000 fans gathered at Ebbets Field.

Since Argentina is our leadingcustomer in South America, interest has naturally been stirred by the new trade agreement between that country and Great Britain. On one side, it assures a market in England for goods of great importance to the Argentine export trade.

Dry Goods Jobbers Buy Freely. While dry goods jobbers paid less attention to Fall goods this week than last week, they covered requirements freely for sixty days in advance on staple styles which had just begun to move up in price, reports yesterday indicated.

Representatives of thirty civic, artistic and business organization unanimously voted their opposition yesterday afternoon to Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy's plan to convert the old reservoir site in Central Park into baseball diamonds and other athletic fields.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read the interesting letter of George W. Bristol in which he refers to adjusting automobile accident cases in a manner similar to workmen's compensation cases, and concludes: "But no one seems to have taken the initiative."

BASLE, Switzerland, May 4 -- Following is the balance statement of the Bank for International Settlements giving its condition as of April 30, as made public here tonight. Figures are in Swiss gold francs at par 19.3 cents.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 4. -- The Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra and the Eastman School Chorus gave the third of the concerts of the Eastman School of Music festival in the Eastman Theatre tonight. Dr. Howard Hanson made his first appearance as festival conductor.

LONDON, May 4 -- The huge sum of u200,000,000 is to be added to the British exchange equalization fund, bringing the total of the account that can be drawn upon to stabilize the exchange rate of sterling to u350,000,000. [At yesterday's exchange rate this total would be $1,368,500,000 and the amount of the increase $782,000,000.]

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial on the "Gilded Age of Recreation," in which you class the age of marathons, walkathons, endurance contests, , with, the age of prosperity, brings up a few interesting questions. And I took my fifteen minutes' rest in every hour and a quarter to type this standing up because I believe there are two sides to the question of walkathons.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Application to the steel industry of the proposed 30-hour week would not increase employment or buying power, but would, on the contrary, increase costs and lead to the closing of plants, Robert P. Lamont, president of the Iron and Steel Institute, told the House Labor Committee today.

Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, commander of the Twenty-seventh Division of the A.E.F., will be grand marshal of the march to be held here on May 10 under the auspices of the American Jewish Congress in protest against the treatment of Jews in Germany by the government of Adolf Hitler.
The Community Councils of the City of New York, Inc., announced yesterday that it was preparing formal charges seeking the removal of Milo R. Maltbie as chairman of the Public Service Commission.
VIENNA, April 26 (AP) -- Signs of anti-Semitism have become more widespread recently in Austria as the increasing strength of Chancellor Hitler's National Socialists is reflected here.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 4 -- Farmer delegates from eighteen States in convention here voted late this afternoon to take a holiday Beginning May 13 from the job of feeding the people of the United States. They are the militant minority from these States, and considerable disturbance is expected in the milk deliveries to such cities as Chicago and New York.
LONDON, May 4 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

MONTREAL, Que., May 4 (Canadian Press) -- Common stockholders of the Beauharnois Power Corporation accepted today the "Montreal Power" plan for reorganizing the financial structure of their company which had been endorsed by its bondholders.

The extensive public improvements program of the city's emergency work and relief administration in Queens and the Bronx, where 26,000 men are at work in the erection and restoration of buildings, in landscaping, road construction and in other permanent projects, was viewed "with satisfaction yesterday by officials of the work relief organization on a 114-mile tour of inspection.

The Manufacturers Trust Company announced yesterday that, in connection with the final steps of its liquidation of ten small banks in this city, it had forwarded to the twenty banks in the Clearing House Association and to the private banking firms of J.P. Morgan Co. and Speyer Co. checks in full payment of loans advanced by them to facilitate the payment of depositors of the ten banks.

BERLIN, May 4 -- The next great National Socialist demonstration, it was announced tonight, will take place on May 27 and 28 and the scene will be Dusseldorf, which is as close to the French frontier as such a demonstration could easily be staged.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Senate and House conferees reached a complete agreement on all parts of the farm relief bill today except the cost-of-production section. The clash over the one section will force reconsideration of the measure in the House on Monday, with consequent delay of the inflation program incorporated in an amendment to this measure.

Rear Admiral Frederic R. Harris, formerly general manager of the Emergency Fleet Corporation, urged the maintenance of a powerful merchant marine as essential to the prestige of the United States in its "spheres of influence" and to assure the right of fair competition for American goods in world trade, in a nation-wide broadcast yesterday over the Columbia network.

A demand for a united front In the American Jewish protest against German anti-Semitism was voiced yesterday by the rabbinical assembly of the Jewish Theological Seminary at the closing session of its annual convention at the seminary, 122d Street and Broadway.

Winners of the medals given annually for heroism to members of the New York Fire Department were announced yesterday by Fire Commissioner John J. Dorman, who said Mayor O'Brien would make the awards at City Hall some time next month.
Although they fluctuated somewhat irregularly, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward a quarter cent from the opening figures yesterday and ended with gains of 2 to 9 points.

THE Stanford track and field squad will soon be headed east-ward for the intercollegiates at Cambridge toward the end of this month. The Penn Relays bolstered up the hopes of the East, but when those big boys from the Coast start stepping along the track and throwing things on the field it's hard to keep up with them as a rule.

Several hundred persons, many of them Cubans, filled the auditorium of the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, last night, at a protest meeting organized by exiled Cuban students and professors against the government of President Machado.
Profiting by Cubs' errors, the Giants yesterday won both games of a double-header from the National League champions at the Polo Grounds.

It is doubtful if any dance audience has ever before had such a demanding program set before it as that with which Martha Graham closed her season's activities last night at the Guild Theatre. Fortunately for Miss Graham, she has built for herself a large public which is willing to follow obediently into whatever regions of rarefaction she chooses to lead them, and as a reward for this responsiveness she almost never disappoints them.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Corporations paying more than $17,500 salary to any officer, director or employe shall not receive loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the Senate decreed today in passing and sending to the House a bill increasing the corporation's borrowing power by $50,000,000 and authorizing it to buy or lend on preferred stock of insurance companies.

ALBANY, May 4. -- Governor Lehman in a veto memorandum today branded as "a breach of faith and contract" a proposal embodied in two bills affecting non-matriculated students at Hunter College and the College of the City of New York, which provided for payment Into the city treasury of tuition fees paid by such students.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 4 -- Bolivia has begun, 100 days after starting an offensive against the Paraguayan key position of Nanawa, also called Ayala, a final drive to surround it, according to a General Staff bulletin today.

MADRID, May 4. -- Premier Azana conferred with President Alcala Zamora for more than an hour today at the National, formerly the Royal Palace, In the presence of members of the Cabinet and left without making a statement.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- The extent of the public interest in the wheat market surprised the Board of Trade today. Many local professional operators were inclined to expect a rather sharp decline after yesterday's bulge had been lost swiftly, but buying by commission houses was steady from the start.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Walker D. Hines of New York, former director general of railroads, has been designated chief of an American group of economic experts to cooperate with the Ministry of National Economy at Angora for the restoration of business and industry in Turkey.

PARIS, May 4 -- A tribute to President Roosevelt and the United States was delivered today by Paul Claudel, former French Ambassador to Washington, who will soon take up his duties as the Ambassador to Belgium. Speaking at the weekly luncheon of the American Club here, M. Claudel said:

Some of the world's best known economists and politicians are the subjects of "Essays in Biography," by John Maynard Keynes, just published by Harcourt, Brace. The well-known studies of Clemenceau and Wilson, which Mr. Keynes included in his "Economic Consequences of the Peace," written immediately after his resignation from the Supreme Economic Council in 1919, are reprinted.
BOSTON, May 4 (AP). -- Si Johnson, Cincinnati right-hander, today held the Boston Braves to one hit as his team-mates batted out a 4-0 victory.

Prices of bonds surged forward again yesterday on the Stock Exchange except in the case of leading foreign loans, which closed irregularly lower. Gains of 1 to 5 points made by a long list of domestic corporation bonds enabled many of those issues to attain the best prices for the year to date.

President ROOSEVELT'S message to Congress yesterday goes no further than to present in concrete form proposals for the railroads which had already been foreshadowed. First, the "recapture" provision of the Transportation Act of 1920 -- whereby half of a railway's earnings in excess of 6 per cent on property valuation shall be sequestrated into a " general railway fund " for disposal by the Government -- should be repealed.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Delay in the administration of justice in the Federal courts, particularly In the completion of appeals in criminal cases, was criticized today by Chief Justice Hughes in his annual address before the American Institute of Law.

CLEVELAND, May 4 (AP) -- The Indians allowed the Senators a fourrun lead in the first inning today, but staged a rally in the ninth to win, 6 to 5, and go into a tie with the White Sox for second place.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Following is the text of President Roosevelts speech tonight before the Chamber of Commerce of the United States:

CHICAGO, May 4 -- The President is expected to officiate at the formal opening of the Great Lakes to the Gulf waterway, a ceremony which will mark the completion of the canal from Chicago to the Illinois River.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a hwole to be at the highest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure.

A Fifth Avenue realty deal reported to involve more than $1,000,000 was consummated yesterday, when the two six-story buildings at 693-95 were sold by the Atraina Realty Corporation, A. Traina, president, to the 693 Fifth Avenue Corporation for investment.

A merger affecting several hundred sportsmen's clubs in New York State is in prospect. Elwood M. Rabenold, president of the New York State Fish, Game and Forest League, is active in negotiating the alliance which would unite the clubs in his organization with a number of the chapters of the Izaak Walton League of this State.

The gold holdings of the Federal Reserve System rose $39,232,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the weekly report of the system published yesterday revealed. This made a total gain of $752,000,000 in gold since March 8 and lifted the bank's holdings to $3,435,570,000, a high record since September, 1931, and, except for a few weeks in that month, the largest gold reserve ever held by the Federal Reserve Banks.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The policy of the government toward agriculture does not contemplate merely a temporary solution of difficulties through newly created agencies and consolidations, but proposes to put the industry on a "more satisfactory basis by making permanent provision for meeting farm credit needs in an adequate and businesslike manner," Henry Morgenthau Jr., chairman of the Federal Farm Board, told members of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today.
Resales by financial institutions featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.
GENEVA, May 4 -- The Disarmament Conference committee on security unanimously adopted today the Belgian plan for quickly identifying an aggressor.

Except for silver futures, which continued to lag, prices in local commodity markets moved higher again yesterday, following the trend in other markets. Contract sales were somewhat greater in number than on Wednesday, but still below the high levels of tne year.
Allowing only three hits, all singles, and fanning eight, Bob Coombs of Duke University shut out the strong Fordham nine, 3 to 0, before 2,500 spectators at Fordham Field yesterday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 4. -- In the fifth annual New York State intercollegiate tennis championship tournament, which started today. Donald Hawley of N.Y.U., Leonard Hartman, Columbia; Paul W. Peavy Jr. of Colgate and Ramey Donovan of Fordham won two matches each and advanced to the semi-finals in the singles.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Broadened to provide retroactive repeal of the recapture features of the interstate commerce act, a more flexible rule of rate-making and extension of the jurisdiction of the Interstate Commerce Commission to include holding companies, the administration's emergency railroad program was transmitted to Congress today, along with a message from President Roosevelt asking adoption during the present session.

To the Editor of The New York Times: From such understanding as may DC possessed by a farmer, I protest the arguments advanced by Professor Irving Fisher in relation to "inflation" as they were given in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Irving Fisher has long been Professor of Economics at Yale University.
MONTREAL, May 4 (AP). -- The champion Newark Bears scored a 9-to-2 victory over the Montreal Royals today and gave big Jim Weaver his sixth straight triumph on the hill.

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook issued an order yesterday restraining the independent bondholders' committee headed by Lewis H. Pounds and George Gordon Battle from further actions in connection with mortgage bonds issued by S.W. Straus Co., now in default.
TIENTSIN, May 4 -- Partially revealing Japan's plans for renewed military incursion in North China, an official spokesman at the headquarters of the military attache said today:
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

Two beaming women put their heads through the door of the new police booth on Times Square Island yesterday afternoon, looked as wicked as their weight permitted and asked the weary patrolman in charge:

They gave Honus Wagner the key to Brooklyn on the steps of Borough Hall yesterday at 12:30 and from then until late last night all of Flatbush belonged to the man rated as the greatest shortstop baseball has ever known.

LONDON, May 4 -- Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald gave the House of Commons today his promised account of his visit to the United States. Rising amid cheers from the crowded benches, he read a typewritten statement of only a few hundred words outlining the salient features of the Washington conversations.

The continued strength in United States Government bonds in the face of the nation's avowed inflationary program, the prospect of new flotations for public works and the abrogation of the payable in gold clause is a leading feature of the current bond market.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Roosevelt began the third month of his administration today, celebrating "the occasion by sending to Congress his plan for an emergency reorganization of the railroads, followed by a conference at the White House with banking and currency experts to perfect his plan for a more permanent solution of the banking problem.
The official direction of the New York Stock Exchange was taken over yesterday by several youthful employes of the Exchange as part of the annual observance of "Boys' Day."

George S. Vari Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance told the State Chamber of Commerce at its annual meeting yesterday that plans for the reorganization of the mortgage guarantee companies now under the control of the department would not be approved unless "the fundamental purpose was the greatest protection possible for the holders of guarantees."

Five firemen, trapped on the roof of a five-story loft building at 316 Lafayette Street, fell three stories when the front and side walls collapsed after a spectacular three-alarm fire in the structure early this morning. All were injured, two of them seriously.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 4. -- Many luncheons were given today on the Cascades Club terrace, overlooking the first tee, before the golfers set out for their afternoon round in the Old Dominion golf championship. Among those entertaining were Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Stone, Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Zerega, Stanley D. McGraw, Mrs. Henry S. Broadwater and R.A. Stranahan.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- High lights of the administration's emergency railroad bill, transmitted to Congress today, are as, follows:

An attempt to work out a broad trade agreement for stabilization of the garment industry was begun yesterday by the Dress Institute of America in the belief that President Roosevelt's program for industrial control would make such action advisable.

Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, was asked yesterday by the City Affairs Committee to aid in reviving the United States Housing Corporation as part of the Federal program of public works. Paul Blanshard, executive director of the committee, announced that a letter had been sent to Miss Perkins.

Aside from the current news developments, which were of a generally encouraging character, the markets had the benefit yesterday of a variety of prophecies bearing on the address delivered last night by President Roosevelt before the United States Chamber of Commerce.

Many rumors and some positive assertions regarding agreements between President ROOSEVELT and Prime Minister MACDONALD were dissipated by the latter in his speech in the House of Commons yesterday as a returned traveler. As usual on such occasions, Mr. MACDONALD was benevolently cloudy.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- In asking George Peek of Moline, Ill., to aminister the farm-relief bill, the President has turned to a man of deep practical experience in that field. Those who are worrying over the ascendency of professors in administration councils may be somewhat calmed by this reflection.

Although he sustained his first and only defeat of the tournament in the final match, Edgar T. Appleby of New York yesterday became the first American to win the world's amateur 18.1 balkline billiard championship. He succeeds Albert Corty of France.

Six boy inmates of the Passaic Home and Orphan Asylum at River Drive, Passaic, N.J., arose from their cots yesterday morning to find themselves widely hailed as heroes for their exploit in saving a commuter express train, at the risk of their lives, from being wrecked in a washout.

Confidence that President Roosevelt's sole aim in exercising the powers granted to him under the inflation amendment to the farm bill will be to restore business in this country, and hence to aid the world generally, was expressed yesterday by Frederick H. Ecker, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, at the annual convention of the company's district managers.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 4 -- Teletype machines clacked in New Jersey police offices today, as they spelled out the mysterious disappearance of Richard S. Bethell, 32 years old, of 24 Laurel Place, Montclair, son and heir of the late Union Noble Bethell, former vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4 -- The clash between the East and the West for victory in the fifty-ninth Kentucky Derby is likely to be more pronounced than in recent years due to the developments at Churchill Downs today when W.R. Coe's Ladysman took the track for a slow early morning gallop.
There were many dinners given at the St. Regis last night in connection with the opening of the roof garden. Mr. and Mrs. Rezin Davis were hosts to the following:
LONDON, May 4 -- The text of Prime Minister MacDonald's statement to the House of Commons today on his economic discussions with President Roosevelt was as follows:

Miss Marion Lloyd, metropolitan titleholder and a member of the Salle d'Armes Vince, vanquished Miss Dorothy Locke, the national champion, in a fence-off last night to capture the premier honors in the women's invitation foils tourney of the Salle d'Armes Vince.
Applications for listing on the New York Stock Exchange of the following stocks have been received by the committee on stock list and probably will be acted upon at its next meeting:
LIMA, Peru, May 4 -- Peru's ssassinated President, General uis M. Sanchez Cerro, was buried today with all the honors the reublic could give him.

RYE, N.Y., May 4. -- Miss Frances Snyder, the Apawamis girl who made such a sensational debut in golf two years ago by defeating Mrs. J.L. Anderson and the defending champion, Mrs. Martha Parker Amends, in the first two rounds of the district championship, today walked off with the honors in the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association's inaugural at the Westchester Country Club.

Liveright, Inc., book publisher of 31 West Forty-seventh Street, was thrown into bankruptcy by an involuntary petition filed yesterday. Three creditors alleging claims totaling $3,474 signed the petition. Although his name has continued to be used, Horace Liveright, one of the founders of the company, has not been connected with it since the Fall of 1930.

BERLIN, May 4 -- The Nazi government would enlarge the scope of the 1936 Olympic Games, scheduled to be held in Berlin, by the addition of a contest in the drama, in which all nations might participate. The ultimate aim is to make this a permanent feature of the games.

A six-run rally in the ninth inning broke up a pitching duel between Irving Spanier and Anton Karl and enabled the City College nine to upset Manhattan, 7 to 1, at Manhattan Field yesterday. A crowd of 1,200 persons saw the Jaspers receive their second defeat in seven games this season.

HARWICHPORT, Mass., May 4 -- Desperate at the failure of all attempts to establish a contact with the kidnappers of Margaret McMath, abducted from her school here Tuesday, William Lee, spokesman for the family, tonight offered himself as a hostage to those who had taken the girl.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The progress of the discussions here, principally political today between President Roosevelt and the Italian mission was considered so satisfactory tonight that Guido Jung, Italian Finance Minister and head of the mission, postponed his departure from Washington from tomorrow night to Saturday night.
PARIS, May 4 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
Contemplating mournfully the departure of Mr. McKEE from politics, Chairman MACY involves himself in his own virtue and dedicates himself to unsparing war against Tammany and its Republican allies:
NEW YORK. Dr. and Mrs. J. Henry Lancashire are at the Savoy-Plaza from Washington, where they passed the Winter.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 4 (AP) -- Jersey City completely ruined the Bisons' homecoming today by taking both halves of the double bill, 8 to 3 and 7 to 6.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Seven generations of mortal men have passed since the English Parliament, in 1695, took courageous and far-sighted action in doing away with the economic evils arising from a debased medium, of exchange.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Total allocations in the Treasury's offering Tuesday of 2 7/8 per cent three-year notes amounted to $572,419,200. Subscriptions totaled $1,202,043,500. including $1,058,400,500 in cash and $143,643,000 in maturing certificates of indebtedness.

HAVANA, May 4 -- The Cuban Government plans to release 200 political prisoners now being held in Principe Fortress here, before the arrival next Sunday of the new United States Ambassador, Sumner Welles, it was learned today. The unexpected release of such a large number of enemies of the Machado government is characterized here as a gesture designed to give the United States Government the impression that political conditions on the island are improving.
PARIS, May 4 -- Former Premier Edouard Herriot will reach France tomorrow to be greeted by the question "What have you brought back from Washington?"

Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Parmelee System, Inc., told civic workers at a luncheon at the Hotel Commodore yesterday that unless the Mahon taxi-control ordinance is passed, the taxi business will become the "happy hunting ground of the racketeer and the muscleman."

BERLIN, May 4 -- Yesterday's fluctuations in the stock market were followed by sharp declines at today's session of the Boerse. The volume of business was small, but the absence of buyers caused an average slump of 4 per cent in the most favored securities.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- After the second conference within ten days with President Roosevelt on the Glass banking reform bill by the Senate subcommittee of the Banking and Currency Committee, Senator Glass reported today that he was going ahead with his legislation after making revisions to meet objections.

Bank clearings in twenty leading cities of the country lagged considerably behind the progress made at this time last year, according to the report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., for the week ended on Wednesday. The total for the week was $4,504,913,000, or 15.6 per cent below last year.

ALBANY, May 4 -- Retail merchants will be able to deduct from their personal or corporation tax the amount they pay the State under the new 1 per cent retail sales levy, Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission, ruled today.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 4 (AP) -- Utilities, Inc., of 60 Wall Street, New York, was denied authority today to sell 20,000,000 shares of common stock in Ohio by Securities Commissioner John W. Powers.

Gold medals of the National Institute of Social Sciences will be presented to Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War; Evangeline Booth, Commander-in-Chief of the Salvation Army in the United States, and Clifford W. Beers, founder of the mental hygiene movement, next Thursday night at the institute's dinner at the WaldorfAstoria.
Five Manhattan properties and seven parcels in the Bronx were included in the foreclosure auctions yesterday. The results were as follows:

Hans Kindler, conductor of the Washington (D.C.) Symphony Orchestra, will direct one week of the concerts by the Philharmonic-Symphony at the Lewisohn Stadium this Summer, it is announced by Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman of the concerts.

The seventeenth-century home of Klaes Arents Vecht which was used as a fort by Lord Stirling during the Battle of Long Island was discovered yesterday morning by excavators of the Brooklyn Park Department who have been digging for several weeks, under orders predicated on historical data.

John Ford Darling, one of the directors of the Midland Bank of London, who retired as managing director after the war to devote himself to banking and currency problems, is to return to England today on the Majestic, after a special trip to this country to suggest the formation by the United States and Great Britain of a $1,000,000,000 gold and silver pool.

American banking and finance face the most alarming prospect in their history, and the prospect of inflation is of incalculable danger to our country, Dr. H. Parker Willis, Professor of Banking at Columbia University and a part author of the Federal Reserve act, told an audience of business men yesterday at a conference of the New York Sales Executive Club at the Hotel Roosevelt.
Five Manhattan properties and seven parcels in the Bronx were included in the foreclosure auctions yesterday. The results were as follows:

Hans Kindler, conductor of the Washington (D.C.) Symphony Orchestra, will direct one week of the concerts by the Philharmonic-Symphony at the Lewisohn Stadium this Summer, it is announced by Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman of the concerts.

The seventeenth-century home of Klaes Arents Vecht which was used as a fort by Lord Stirling during the Battle of Long Island was discovered yesterday morning by excavators of the Brooklyn Park Department who have been digging for several weeks, under orders predicated on historical data.

Silence Best Treatment? It is the firm belief of the Steuben Society that American Protests against antiSemitism in Germany are entirely out of place. This position, if one may judge from the statement issued by the National Council of that organization, is based on the following facts:

John Ford Darling, one of the directors of the Midland Bank of London, who retired as managing director after the war to devote himself to banking and currency problems, is to return to England today on the Majestic, after a special trip to this country to suggest the formation by the United States and Great Britain of a $1,000,000,000 gold and silver pool.

The pamnhlet report of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana and subsidiaries shows as of Dec. 31 last total current assets of $228,134,756 and current liabilities of $24,682,368, compared with $243,687,229 and $28,789,500, respectively, at the close of 1931.

The New York Central Railroad plans to cut fares between Cincinnati and Louisville and St. Louis in response to competition by other lines. This action is a step in a movement toward lower fares started early this year.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Prosecutions will be directed against hoarders of substantial sums of gold, Attorney General Cummings said today, but common sense precludes the enforcement of the Presidential proclamation penalizing small hoarders.

American banking and finance face the most alarming prospect in their history, and the prospect of inflation is of incalculable danger to our country, Dr. H. Parker Willis, Professor of Banking at Columbia University and a part author of the Federal Reserve act, told an audience of business men yesterday at a conference of the New York Sales Executive Club at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Snugly nested on board the Italian liner Conte di Savoia when she sailed yesterday afternoon for Italy was a boat that can travel twice as fast as the big steamship. It was John Wanamaker's Gold Cup racing motor craft Louisa, which is to compete in the international regatta on Lake Garda, Italy.

LANGLEY FIELD, Va., May 4 -- Striking advances in safety and efficiency in relation to aircraft and to aircraft engines, made possible by the year's work in research at the Langley Memorial Laboratory here, were revealed today by the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics at the annual engineering conference.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended May 3, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,436,000,000, a decrease of $21,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $594,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

BALTIMORE, May 4 -- The Justa Farm Stable's Reverence scored by two lengths over the Dorwood Stable's Greatorex in the Mount Alto Steeplechase, a two and a half mile event for registered hunters at Pimlico today. Mrs. J.H. Whitney's San Romolo was third.
PHILADELPHIA, May 4 (AP) -- The Cardinals, in a big fifth inning, pushed five runs across the plate -- their total for the day -- to hand the Phillies a 5 to 2 defeat today.

Mr. NORMAN THOMAS'S protest against the proposal of certain private interests to build a $40,000,000 toll bridge between Old Ferry Point in the Bronx and Whitestone Landing in Queens draws public attention to the fact that the Board of Estimate is apparently giving this discredited enterprise serious consideration.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Delayed because of a jam in the bill-drafting organization of the Senate, the bill providing broad powers to a governmental board to supervise industry was further changed today in some respects.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 2:

Waving a tambourine, former Goveronr Smith asked yesterday afternoon in a radio speech broadcast by Station WOR that his auditors "come across for the Salvation Army's United Appeal." He said that a month ago the Army "started out to raise $1,100,000 for relief of distress here in New York" but that "the record" showed that the half-way mark had not been reached.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The text of President Roosevelt's special message to Congress today recommending emergency railroad legislation was as follows:

Joseph V. McKee's announcement of his withdrawal from politics and his acceptance of the presidency of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company was accepted yesterday in political circles as giving Mayor John P. O'Brien opportunity to show what he can do in office and to stand or fall upon public judgment of his record between now and election.

The Brooklyn Ash Removal Company, unsuccessful bidder for the contract for the removal of garbage and ashes in Brooklyn, filed its announced suit to restrain the Board of Estimate from awarding the contract to Samuel Rosoff's Manhattan Ash Removal Company, in Supreme Court yesterday.

All markets displayed quiet but confident strength yesterday. Stocks advanced to the highest price levels of the year and bonds added substantially to their recent gains in the most active trading in some weeks. Commodities generally commanded better prices.

DETROIT, May 4 -- With Vernon Gomez turning in a two-hit performance on a windswept diamond, a no-hit affair for eight innings, the Yankees today righted themselves to the extent of upsetting the Tigers, 5 to 2, to get an even break in the only two engagements of the series.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Roosevelt took an optimistic view of the industrial situation based on the recent rise in commodity prices and industrial output, in a speech tonight before the Chamber of Commerce of the United States. He also reassured business by promising its leaders government cooperation in stamping out unfair competition in wages, overproduction and working conditions.

VIENNA, May 4 -- A reported Nazi plan for a putsch designed to add part or all of Austria to the German dominion of Adolf Hitler caused Chancellor Dollfuss's newspaper, the Reichspost, to warn those responsible "what dangerous complications could ensue for Germany."
BERLIN, May 4 -- A decisive improvement in German-Polish relations will result, it is believed, from Chancellor Hitler's conversations yesterday with Dr. Alfred Wysocki, Polish Minister to Berlin.

The identities of members of the New York Stock Exchange who participated in recent sales of two seats there, one for $125,000 and the other for $150,000, the highest price paid so far this year, were made public yesterday by the Exchange.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Cuban situation was aired in the House today by Representative Fish, who charged that assassination and torture had become the common practice of the Machado government, with the result that "a veritable reign of terror" existed.
LEMARS, Iowa, May 5 (AP) -- Lifting of martial rule in Northwestern Iowa next week was indicated today by authorities.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., May 5 -- At May Day ceremonies President Marion Edwards Park of Bryn Mawr College announced the award of scholarships, prizes and fellowships today.

CHICAGO, May 5 (AP) -- An income tax crusade against gangsters and their alleged police and political allies, who have squeezed millions of dollars from legitimate business through outlaw labor unions and racketeering trade associations in Chicago was under way tonight in charge of Leslie E. Salter, special Assistant Attorney General.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- A disagreement on the cost-of-production guaranty plan tonight was the only obstacle to be surmounted before the administration farm relief-inflation program can be sent to the White House.

One of the most brilliant and rare types of solar halos, the like of which has not been seen here in many years, was visible over New York and vicinity yesterday. It caused noon-day pedestrians to stop and gaze upward at the sight. Astronomers peered at the spectacle and noted its size, shape and characteristics in their records.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS. W. Va., May 5 -- Mr. and Mrs. William C. Grauer of Cleveland, under whose direction the Whits Art Colony will be held this Summer, are here to make plans for the activities of the colony which will open June 1.

HAVANA, May 5 (AP) -- An American aviator who saw service in the World War was to have been the keystone of last week's abortive revolutionary plot, which was designed to gain control of all the western section of Oriente Province, it was learned here today.
Following the investment purchase on Thursday of two business buildings on Fifth Avenue, another investment deal on the east side was announced yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5 -- Twenty-two thoroughbreds -- one filly and twenty-one colts -- have been named for the fifty-ninth running of the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs tomorrow. It is estimated that a crowd of more than 50,000 will see the race.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Railroad credlt, to aid which a total of $336,000,000 has been loaned by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, will be aided to the extent of $352,000,000 through the retroactive repeal of the recapture provisions of the interstate commerce act, as provided in the administration's emergency railroad bill, sent to Congress yesterday.
The opening of "They All Come to Moscow" has been postponed from next Tuesday until next Thursday evening at a theatre as yet unannounced.

A warrant for the arrest of Joseph Marinelli, Tammany captain of the Twenty-third Election district in the Second Assembly District, and a brother of Alderman Albert Marinelli, who with Christopher D. Sullivan shares the Democratic leadership of the Assembly district, was issued yesterday by Federal Judge John M. Woolsey.

If the dollar falls, in terms of francs, it is argued that France will be able to buy more American goods, to the great advantage of our farmers and manufacturers. But will France buy more goods? A dispatch from Paris gave two reasons why depreciation of the dollar would fail sensibly to benefit our trade with France.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 5 (AP) -- Jersey City made it three straight over Buffalo by skipping off with today's game, 2 to 1. Two unearned runs, resulting from misplays by Koenecke and Marshall in the seventh, gave the visitors the decision over Slim Brewer.

LONDON, May 5 -- Prime Minister MacDonald broadcast to the world tonight an account of his Washington visit in which he said that he and President Roosevelt had agreed that if the World Economic Conference were to be fruitful the war debts question must be settled as quickly as possible and "certainly before the conference ends."
Cul's opera, "Mlle. Fifi." will be presented by the Ladies Musical Aid Society at its clubhouse, 150 West Eighty-fifth Street, tonight, under the direction of Eugene Plotnikoff.

Although the proposed arbitration proceedings to determine the responsibility of the twenty member banks of the New York Clearing House Association to make good all deposits in the closed Harriman National Bank and Trust Company are still under discussion, it was learned yesterday that an alternative now actively under consideration is a suit by the conservator of the bank, as representative of the Treasury.

An undertone of firmness continued in the time money market, three-four months' funds moving forward a fraction. Business was small, however, and covered only routine requirements. Stock Exchange call money remained at 1 per cent, while the usual concessions prevailed in the Street market.

To the Editor of The New York Time: The State's 1 per cent sales tax goes into effect today. With it it is hoped that the financial condition of the State of New York will be improved. However, it brings to my mind an odd sign that I noticed outside a gasoline station on the Dixie Highway northbound from Huntsville, Ala.:

BERLIN, May 4 -- The next great National Socialist demonstration, it was announced tonight, will take place on May 27 and 28 and the scene will be Dusseldorf, which is as close to the French frontier as such a demonstration could easily be staged.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Action to defeat the alleged cement trust was taken today by Secretary Ickes, who charged in a complaint filed with the Federal Trade Commission that the "trust" had entered into an agreement to raise prices to the government.

An ambitious schedule of State and municipal financing has been arranged for next week, with new issues aggregating $14,666,209 listed for award. This amount compares with this week's total of $3,814,925, of which only a small percentage attracted bids, and with the weekly average of $10,663,338 for the year to date.

With Wall Street drawing hopeful, if possibly unwarranted, inferences from President Roosevelt's address on the night before, the markets engaged yesterday in another broad advance which, in the case of stocks, bonds and commodities, was well sustained.

A court order was asked yesterday in Brooklyn to compel the parents of Benjamin Rogalski, 15 years old, of 630 Fifth Avenue, to permit an operation on the boy for a serious hernial condition which, Board of Education officials held, may become fatal if further aggravated.

To the Editor of the The New York Times: Every thrifty citizen who has followed the old-fashioned tenets of saving for a rainy day, keeping out of debt and building up a bank account will be in sympathy with your correspondent Mary J.M. Meeker.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the German Reichsbank, arrived here today to begin a search with President Roosevelt for the particular part his country might play in the world-wide effort to raise commodity prices.
Mile. Michele d'Idier, 15 years old, of Grenoble, Prance, arrived on the liner Lafayette at 11:40 Thursday morning. She was a stowaway.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Republican forces in the Senate are preparing to attack the expected requests by President Roosevelt for authority to negotiate tariff and debt agreements in preparation for the economic conferences.

HANOVER, N.H., May 5 -- With John Jackson at Pennsylvania and Way Thompson of Dartmouth, both veterans, on the mound, the Quakers today shaded the Indians, 3 -- 2, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game.

The New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, with a membership of 100,000, was urged yesterday day to support President Roosevelt in his plea for increased wages and improved working conditions by boycotting the products of sweatshops and factories where wages are low and conditions poor.
The coordination features of President Roosevelt's railroad message were praised yesterday by Howard S. Cullman, Commissioner of the Port of New York Authority.

BERLIN, May 5 -- Helen Keller, Jack London, Judge Ben Lindsey, Upton Sinclair and Morris Hillquit are among the American writers whose books are slated for public burning at an inquisitional stake on the Berlin University campus next Wednesday.

The New York City Beer Control Board, at an organization meeting yesterday in the offices of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, 80 Centre Street, elected James C. Quinn, Democrat, of Brooklyn, as chairman. The board is scheduled to hold its first business meeting on Monday at the offices of the State Board.

On his arrival here yesterday on board the Deutschland, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, was asked about a report that a committee was being organized in Germany to come to the United States to conduct counter-propaganda against the reports of atrocities committed against Jews.

Cardinal Hayes of New York and Cardinal Mundelein of Chicago will participate tomorrow morning at 10 o'clock at a pontifical high mass of thanksgiving in celebration of the one hundredth anniversary of St. Nicholas Church, 125 Second Street, the oldest German parish in the archdiocese of New York.

BERLIN, May 5 -- After a day of stagnation and fluctuations in the stock market, the government statement that no more interventions in business are to be volunteered by the Nazis and others anxious to please the administration caused a strong rally at today's session of the Boerse, helping stocks to recover at least part of what was lost yesterday.
ON the faded page of an old newspaper file the following Item was noted:
PARIS, May 5 -- The dollar today reached its lowest point in relation to the franc since its depreciation started, closing at 21.20 after having touched 20.01.
Numerous small residential properties were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 5 -- Two entrants from New York City, Leonard Hartman of Columbia and E. Ramey Donovan of Fordham, today advanced to the final round of the singles in the New York State intercollegiate tennis tournament.

BALTIMORE, May 5 -- J.W.Y. Martin's good mare Con Amore scored an effortless victory in the featured Arlington Purse at Pimlico today. She finished three lengths in front of Mrs. J.H. Whitney's Sugar Cake, with Miss Mary Corning's Illusive half a length further back.

Lewis H. Pounds, chairman of the independent bondholders committee for bonds of S.W. Straus Co., announced yesterday that the committee would appeal from Supreme Court Justice McCook's order restraining it from taking any further action in connection with the bonds and appointing James W. Gerard.

The Frackville Manufacturing Company, pajamas and underwear, will move from Worth Street to 1,182 Broadway, near Twenty-eighth Street, owing to the general northward trend of the company's business, Butler Baldwin, the brokers, reported yesterday.

In a suit for a share of a purported payment of $600,000 by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in 1931 to settle a stockholder's action against the company and its directors for the return of bonuses paid to the officers. Supreme Court Justice Valente directed yesterday the plaintiff, William Rosenblatt, a Wall Street operator, to give particulars to the members of the law firm of House, Holthusen McCloskey, as defendants.

MONTREAL, May 5 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals made it two out of three for their series against the Newark Bears, International League champions, by coming from behind in the seventh inning to gain a 7-to-5 victory in the closing game today.

Except the Union Pacific Railroad, the traditional large holders of New York Central stock as a group slightly increased their commitments in 1932, according to the list of the twenty largest stocKholders of the Eastern line at the end of 1932.

Under a continuation of the aggressive buying that has been in progress several weeks, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced yesterday a quarter cent into new high ground. Profit-taking was heavy, but the market absorbed tens of thousands of bales at each point advance and ended at the top at gains of 24 to 26 points after one of the most active sessions in recent years.

Indications of a battle between official and financial interests in the matter of protecting the holders of mortgage bonds and certificates guaranteed by the National Surety Company were seen last night when a committee headed by C. Prevost Boyce of Baltimore refused to withdraw in favor of the committee of State insurance commissioners formed by George S. Van Schaick, New York State Superintendent of Insurance.

Good catches of sea bass now are being taken along the New Jersey shore, according to anglers who visit that section of the coast in search of salt-water fish. The sea bass are big fellows, too, and provide plenty of fight.

Gains of 1 to 10 points by the majority of the domestic corporation issues featured dealings in the listed bond market yesterday. United States Government bonds continued strong, but leading foreign loans were irregularly lower. Total transaction in bonds on the Stock Exchange approximated $19,000,000, representing the heaviest day's business since mid-April.

Smith in Reserve. ALFRED E. SMITH, as some of the experts view the situation, is the permissive authority and reserve power vested in the hands of Messrs. CURRY and McCOOEY for dealing with any emergency that may arise.

LONDON, May 5 -- Albert St. John Harmsworth, whose pluck in fighting pain, both mental and physical, for twenty-seven years was somewhat like that of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, will be buried in London, probably alongside his famous brother, Lord Northcliffe, at Finchley.

With a show of belligerence rather than of fear, the four poultry men who voluntarily went to jail for safety less than two weeks ago, testified yesterday in Bronx Special Sessions against seven alleged strong-arm followers of Joseph Weiner, reputed racketeer boss of the poultry business.

PARIS, May 5 -- The unification of the five leading commercial air lines of France into a subsidized company in which the government would hold 25 per cent of the capital stock was brought a step nearer today with the announcement by Pierre Cot, the Air Minister, that he would receive competitive bids for the constitution of the new company.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- The name of Alexander W. Weddell of Richmond, is expected to be sent to the Senate soon by President Roosevelt as Ambassador to Argentina.

Pressed by European selling, the dollar fell to a new low in foreign exchange yesterday. The pound sterling reached $4 for the first time since Sept. 23, 1931, and the French franc rose to a premium of 21.2 per cent over parity at 4.75 cents, the highest price on record for the present currency.

Japanese women in native costume demonstrated classical and modern Japanese flower arrangements before more than 200 members of garden clubs of the metropolitan area at the Nippon Club, 161 West Ninety-first Street, yesterday afternoon.

Aaron Davis, neighbor of the McMaths, who acted as New York agent for the family in an attempt to make contact with the kidnappers, got word of the child's return in his rooms at the St. Nicholas Club as soon as she was back.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 5 -- Burton H. Etherinston of Philadelphia, president of the senior class of Princeton University, will head the class day committee of the graduating class, it was announced today.

HARWICHPORT, Mass., May 5 -- Margaret (Peggy) McMath, 10 years old, who was kidnapped Tuesday from the Harwich Centre school-house, was returned safely to her parents today after her father, Neil C. McMath, had paid $80,000 to the unidentified persons who took her away.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- A "constitution" for industry providing the maximum of self-government through collective agreements made by labor and capital, freed from the restrictions of the anti-trust laws, was proposed by the American Bar Association today to Secretary Perkins and Senator Wagner.

Joseph V. McKee's withdrawal from politics should be an advantage to the anti-Tammany fusion movement, James E. Finegan, independent Democrat, declared yesterday. Mr. Finegan, a lawyer with residence in Brooklyn, was the fusion nominee for Controller in 1925, led the "No Deal" judiciary fight in 1931 and was one of those who filed charges against Mayor Walker in 1932.
The address of Prime Minister MacDonald, giving an account of his recent conversations with President Roosevelt in "Washington, as heard by radio here yesterday, follows:

MINEOLA, L.I., May 5 -- A permanent endowment fund of $200,000 is given to the French Institute in the United States, 22 East Sixtieth Street, under the will of Ormond G. Smith, member of the publishing concern of Street Smith, filed for probate today with Surrogate Howell here.

The Army mule, the Navy goat and a drum corps invaded the Metropolitan Opera House stage yesterday when the sophomore class of Hunter College won the annual interclass song competition with its presentation of an Army-Navy football game.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, May 5 -- The broad lines of the National Socialist plans for the national memorial celebration in the Rhineland a fortnight hence of the death of Albert Leo Schlageter having been decided, the details are now being carefully worked out with a thoroughness characteristic of the great Nazi organization.

BERLIN, May 5 -- A ratification protocol providing for the renewal of the Russo-German treaties, comprising the Berlin agreements of 1924 and 1926 and the arbitration pact of Jan. 25, 1929, was signed in Moscow today by Dr. Herbert von Dirksen, the German Ambassador, and N. N. Krestinski, Soviet Deputy Foreign Commissar.

After hearing arguments yesterday from Nathan Straus Jr. for immediate approval of the Hillside model housing project in the East Bronx the Board of Estimate postponed action until Tuesday pending further study.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., May 5 -- Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock Springs scored an 82 at the Crestmont Golf Club today to win first gross prize in the opening competition of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association.

Tom poherty, who has been an I.R.T. motorman for more than fifteen years, left a special report at the transportation office of the elevated division before he went off duty at 1 P. M. yesterday. It read:

Lack of practical training at sea hampers most of the executives of American steamship lines and creates friction which will be eliminated only when marine education is developed in the United States on lines similar to those of foreign nations, said Captain J.H. Tomb, superintendent of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy, in an address yesterday broadcast by Station WINS.

Major Monte D. Stone, 42 years old, of the New York Athletic Club, was ordered yesterday to pay his 60-year-old wife, Mrs. Grace W. Stone, $12 a week in order to prevent her from becoming a public charge.

Ray Kolp's entrance into the baseball game at the Polo Grounds yesterday as a pitcher for the Cincinnati Reds proved to be just too bad for the Giants, and Terry's men lost, 8 to 5, in the series opener.

Trade and industrial revival broadened appreciably during the week, with retail distribution easily holding its previous gains and wholesale buying extending beyond the customary period of seasonal activity, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Acting on a promise of President Roosevelt that he will support passage of the Glass banking reform bill through the Senate at this session. Senator Glass today made plans to obtain preferred status for the measure on the Senate calendar.

GENEVA, May 5 -- Germany notified the disarmament conference today that if submarines were not abolished, she would reserve the right to demand submarines, too, on the second reading of the convention. She also proposed several amendments to the naval and air chapters.

The Summer theatre zone traffic regulations are to go into effect Monday, it was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Bolan after a conference with hotel, business and theatrical interests. Last year the Summer regulations were not effective until May 30.
MEXICO CITY, May 5 -- The American Davis Cup tennis team went far today toward clinching its opening round match with Mexico by winning the first two singles contests in decisive fashion.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., May 5 -- Students at Bryn Mawr College held their annual May Day pageant today, all the traditional features of the event being carried out, including the crowning of the "Queen of the May." The honor this time fell to Miss Josephine Williams of Jenkintown, Pa., president of the senior class.

The annual art show of students of the School of Fine and Applied Arts of Pratt Institute opened at the Institute on Ryerson Street, Brooklyn, yesterday, with announcement of awards and the moving of the winning pictures into places of honor.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The doors of more than 2,000 schools have been closed against 290,000 children, and data from all parts of the country indicate a threatened collapse in education for lack of funds, according to reports presented at the annual meeting today of the American Council on Education.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 5 -- Bolivia desires a continuance of efforts to halt the war with Paraguay and believes if Paraguay could be induced to define her claims in the disputed territory the act would be "decisive," according to a message sent to five neutral American capitals tonight.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., May 5 -- Wearing a bright red coat to which was pinned a white ribbon bearing the word "striker," Mrs. Gifford Pinchot today joined the picket lines of a group of juvenile garment workers who are on strike against "sweat shop" conditions in Allentown and Northampton factories.

Fordham Prep maintained its lead in the Manhattan C.H.S.A. A baseball competition by beating St. Ann's Academy, 8 to 4, yesterday at Fordham Prep Field. Manhattan Prep moved into a tie for second place with Mount St. Michael's High by defenting All Hallows Institute, 14 to 13, at Van Cortlandt Park.

Subpoenas were served yesterday on J. P. Morgan and ten of his twenty partners to appear in Washington on May 23 to explain publicly to an investigating subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency just how the private banking firm of J. P. Morgan Co. operates.

Subjecting Ken Auer, Fordham's pitching ace, to his first defeat in two seasons, during which he had achieved twelve triumphs, a hard-hitting Columbia baseball team vanquished the Maroon, 8 to 3, yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial "Medical Patents" touches upon a very important subject which has not received the attention it merits. Until very recently it was considered unethical for a physician to patent anything related to the practice of his profession.

Morris R. Cohen, who has taught philosophy at Yale, Harvard, Johns Hopkins, Columbia, the University of Chicago and the College of the City of New York, is the author of "Law and the Social Order,"which Harcourt, Brace has just published. In it he attempts to mark out the legal institutions that block the road to "a better social order."

Aldous Huxley talked of writing and writers yesterday. The English author, grandson of Darwin's defender, Thomas Huxley, and grandnephew of Matthew Arnold, is here for a short time on his way back to Europe from Guatemala and Mexico. He had intended to stay here three weeks, he said, but the death two days ago of his father, Leonard Huxley, in England probably would change his plans.

Frederick H. Ecker will celebrate today the fiftieth anniversary of his entrance into the service of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, during which time he has risen from a mail clerk to president of what is now the largest financial institution in the world.
ALBANY, May 5 -- The State Milk Control Board issued an order today directing dealers to pass along to the producers any profits accruing from the minimum retail prices fixed for milk and cream.

Undreamed-of treasures in the realm of science still await the explorer, despite the fact that only a few small virgin areas remain, Dr. George H. Sherwood, director of the American Museum of Natural History, said yesterday in his annual report on the museum's expeditions.

Racing: in the metropolitan area will be inaugurated today at Jamaica, with the renewal of the Paumonok Handicap as the opening-day feature. The Jockey Club has scheduled 150 days of racing for this year and while it is a decrease over previous years, the schedule still gives the Empire State the longest season In the country.

LONDON, May 5 -- Despite further long conversations today between Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large, and Prime Minister MacDonald, the chances of America's proposed tariff truce being adopted by the time of the opening of the World Economic Conference on June 12 seem remote.
Plaintiffs bought in fifteen Manhattan and Bronx properties at foreclosure sales yesterday. The results follow:

Collecting twelve hits from the offerings of Xavier Rescigno, the strong Duke University nine extended its string of victories over Northern teams to three straight at the expense of Manhattan, which it defeated, 5 to 2, at Manhattan Field yesterday.

LONDON, May 5 -- The dollar sterling rate fell today to $4 for the pound, a result of the operations of Continental European speculators who were quick to take advantage of the latest American developments. This was the lowest since the fall in sterling when England left the gold standard in September, 1931, Tonight's closing figure was $3.98.

Carrying on from where they had left off on Thursday, the Pirates yesterday made it two straight over the Dodgers by winning, 4 to 2. They strengthened their hold on first place and dropped the Flat-bush crew into sixth place. About 5,000 attended.

R.C. Holmes has resigned as chairman of both the Texas Corporation and the Texas Company, and C.B. Ames, president of the American Petroleum Institute, has been elected as his successor. Mr. Ames will resign as head of the institute on Monday to devote his entire time to the business of the oil companies.

Curious ideas, with a fine mixture of misinformation, are afloat about the obligation, or contract, assumed by a government in issuing bonds. Thus it is said that "the American holder of a British sterling bond receives paper pounds and nothing else."

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Expressing sympathy with the principles of the thirty-hour-week bill, but arguing for a modification to include all kinds of public and private employment except agricultural and household workers, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation, told the House Labor Committee today that "more flexible" provisions and a minimum wage would be necessary to make the measure effective in increasing work.

The New York Guaranteed Mortgage Corporation, recently formed for the protection of holders of mortgage certificates, yesterday notified Governor Lehman that its board of directors had been chosen and that active work would be directed from its headquarters at 60 East Forty-second Street.

Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission, said yesterday that the 1 per cent State sales tax law, which went into effect May 1, was, in his opinion, "the most difficult tax law that I've ever had to administer." Mr. Graves made his declaration in prefacing a talk to a group of New York editors and correspondents of business and trade newspapers and periodicals at the McGraw-Hill Buildings.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- According to a well-informed source, the delegates at the Geneva conference are proceeding on a clear but hitherto misrepresented understanding among the President, Prime Minister MacDonald, Edouard Herriot and Dr. Guido Jung with respect to political security.

ALBANY, May 5 -- Governor Lehman rounded out his legislative program for the protection of holders of guaranteed first mortgage certificates through the approval today of two bills providing for procedure by the Banking Superintendent, the Superintendent of Insurance and groups of certificate holders in the reorganization or liquidation and in the administration of the assets of defaulting guarantee corporations so that these may be conserved for the benefit of all on a ratable basis.

HAVANA, May 5 -- Fifty-one political prisoners were released today from Principe Fortress. Among them were many students and professional men, including Dr. Adolfo Mendez Penate, a professor at Havana University and a brother of Colonel Roberto Mendez Penate, one of the leaders in the 1931 rebellion.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 5 (AP) -- Spring storms killed at least thirtyfour persons in Alabama and South Carolina today, injured more than 300 and sent streams in the Mississippi delta roaring back to flood stage.
