To the Editor of The New York Times: Recent visits of prominent foreign statesmen and articles written by special correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES indicate that President Roosevelt and his administration have attained the confidence of all nations, his own more than any other.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- A bogus priest was questioned for hours here tonight regarding his knowledge of the disappearance and murder of Mary Helen O'Connor, 15-year-old Queens schoolgirl whose body was found in a copse near Massapequa, L. I., last Feb. 2.
BOSTON, May 5 (AP) -- Walter (Huck) Betts, Braves' pitcher, today started an eleventh inning rally to break up his pitching duel with Charlie Root and gain a 2-1 decision over the Cubs.

To the Editor of The New York Times. I read with a great deal of Interest the letter of Dr. "Warren Coleman, in THE TIMES, which lays heavy strictures on the Celler-Copeland bill. Most of the criticisms of Dr. Coleman are well taken. He little realizes, however, that legislation is usually the result of compromise.

While disappointed that President Roosevelt did not give some clear indication on Thursday night of the use which he expects to make of the broad authority which Congress is granting him, Wall Street found meat enough, for the purposes of yesterday, in what he did say.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Early enactment of the bill providing $500,000,000 of Federal funds for outright unemployment relief grants to States was predicted today as conferees of the Senate and House agreed on two minor differences in the respective bills.

With hundreds of examples of their art and skill on display, the annual Boys' Hobby Show of the West Side Y.M.C.A. opened its doors to the public yesterday afternoon in the north social room of the Y.M.C.A. building at 5 West Sixty-third Street.

Ending many months of delay and debate the Board of Estimate adopted yesterday resolutions committing the city to cooperation with the State in the construction of two new parkways in Queens, costing between $6,000,000 and $7,000,000.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., May 5 -- Despite reports to the contrary, no Labrador gold rush is under way or even possible until June.

Dr. Wilhelm A. Valintiner, director of the Detroit Museum of Art, sails today for Rome on the Italian motor ship Vulcania. Also departing is Cantor Izso G. Glickstein of Temple Mischan Tefila, Roxbury, Mass., who goes to Palestine to study the origin of Hebrew music.

John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, announced yesterday that eighteen miles of new subway, consisting of extensions into Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx, of the Eighth Avenue line would be opened for operation not later than Oct. 1.

A new plan to obtain the immediate release from jail of two of the nine Negroes awaiting a second trial on a charge of attacking two white girls near Scottsboro, Ala., two years ago, was announced yesterday by George W. Chamlee, one of the defense attorneys, upon his arrival here to confer with officials of the International Labor Defense, the Communist organization which is supporting the attempt to save the defendants from the electric chair.

LONDON, May 5 -- The effects on the war debts of the United States gold clause suspension and the suspension itself are discussed at considerable length in a letter by Frederic H. Hamilton, a noted London financier, which The London Times is publishing tomorrow in the most prominent position on the editorial page.

CAMP DIX, N.J., May 5 -- Fortyfive recruits of the Citizens' Conservation Corps were dismissed from camp here today and returned to their homes in Newark by special train, after they had refused to work and had called upon other members of their company to "go on strike."

TOKYO, Saturday, May 6 -- A tripartite commission, formed of representatives of Japan, Soviet Russia and Manchukuo, to investigate and dispose of all disputes between the Soviet Union and Manchukuo, including the disagreement over the Chinese Eastern Railway, has been proposed by Japan.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Full endorsement of the Roosevelt administration's program to assist industry was given by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today in resolutions adopted at its closing session.
NEW YORK. Colonel and Mrs. E. Vivian Gabriel and the latter's daughter, Miss Jean Preston, have left the Pierre for Random Farm, their country place in Mount Kisco.

BERLIN, May 5 (AP) -- Marking the end of the Nazis' adaptation of German trade unions to the new regime, organized office workers and employes held a rally tonight in the Lustgarten at which they heard Robert Ley, president of the States Council, give assurance that there would be no tampering with the rights of union members.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 (AP) -- Once again Pepper Martin was a thorn in the side of a Philadelphia baseball team when he scored four runs and hit safely four consecutive times in the Cardinals' 5-to-3 victory over the Phillies today.

NEWARK, N.J., May 5 -- A court attack by the dry forces of New Jersey on the constitutionality of the State convention for ratification of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, to which delegates will be elected May 16, is planned, the Rev. James K. Shields, Superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League of New Jersey, said today in issuing a statement charging wholesale frauds in the petitions filed to nominate wet candidates to the convention.

In spite of profit-taking, most commodities traded on local exchanges closed with email gains yesterday, folio-wring the trend in other markets. Silver turned about after several successive declines, while sugar turned downward. For the most part the trading volumes were below the average of recent weeks.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 5 -- The Eastman School of Music Festival came to a close tonight with a performance in the Eastman Theatre of two ballets, "Princess and Puppet," by Burrill Phillips, a graduate student of the school, and "La Guiablesse," by William Grant Still.

Elmer F. Andres, State Industrial Commissioner, announced yesterday that he had invited a group of citizens to serve as a minimum wage advisory committee. The step was preliminary to the setting up of machinery to administer the newly enacted minimum wage law signed recently by Governor Lehman.

DES MOINES, May 5 (AP) -- A reign of terror induced by threats of violence was spreading over Northwest Iowa farms when National Guardsmen were called into action last week, Attorney General Edward L. O'Connor charged today.

Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, arrived here early yesterday morning on the liner Deutschland, bringing with him the greetings of Chancellor Hitler to President Roosevelt and assurances of Germany's eagerness to cooperate with the United States and other nations in the efforts for world rehabilitation initiated by the President.

WARSAW, May 5 -- "Peace or war?" the question that Marshal Pilsudski put to Premier Voldemaras of Lithuania at Geneva six years ago, has now been addressed to Chancellor Hitler of Germany and he has answered "peace," as M. Voldemaras did, in Polish opinion.

Several thousand of the lower east side's population mingled yesterday with, many persons prominent in political activities to pay last tributes to Papa Joseph Burger, who died in his eighty-fifth year Wednesday in the Rockefeller Institute.
LOS ANGELES, May 5 (AP) -- The strange, three-day funeral of Miss Margaret Keith ended late yesterday with a concert of classical music.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The administration bill for the supervision of traffic in investment securities was unanimously passed by the House of Representatives late this afternoon in the general form suggested by the President. Adoption by the Senate without material change is expected.

The row in New Jersey over the State Highway Commission could have been avoided if the Legislature had heeded the recommendation of the Princeton University's State Survey that the highway engineer be made executive head of the road department, and that construction programs be left to a non-salaried board of works.

TRENTON, N.J., May 5 -- In a joint answer to charges of neglect of duty, inefficiency and failure to economize, preferred against them by Governor Moore, State Highway Commissioners Abraham Jelin and Firman M. Reeves asserted today there was not the "slightest foundation" for the accusations.

LONDON, May 5 -- The first big move of the United States for giving the World Economic Conference a constructive send-off by means of a tariff truce failed today to gain the support of the British Government.
ALBANY, May 5 -- The State Tax Commission today warned retail merchants that it is a violation of law to advertise the fact that they are absorbing the new 1 per cent retail sales tax.

BERLIN, May 5 (AP) -- General Hans von Seeckt, former Chief of Staff of the German Reichswehr, has quietly slipped out of Germany to help the Chinese Army, at the invitation of the Chinese Government.

Cotton Goods Prices Irregular. Buyers are somewhat confused by the price situation in cotton goods, which seems to be irregular, and are doing a good deal of shopping before making commitments. A variety of prices exists on most styles, but some of the mills with the lowest quotations are beginning to follow the upward trend and the gap between various ranges is being narrowed.

Bankers here said yesterday that when Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, returned to this city from his conferences in Washington with President Roosevelt, the question of scaling down interest and sinking-fund payments on long-term German dollar bonds, amounting to about $1,000,000,000, was almost certain to be taken up.
S.M. Crothers of Philadelphia annexed the amateur championship of America at double targets over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday, breaking 172 out of 200 targets.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is a curious and rather shameful fact that whereas the Federal Government spends millions of dollars in furthering the activities of all kinds of commercial projects, there exists no single board or commission to deal effectively with unemployment.

The sputtering which still mars many a radio concert and many a transatlantic address, and which is known as "static," has always been of extraordinary interest to physicists. It is one of the most effective means they have of testing the electrical condition of the atmosphere.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday that John H. Williams had been appointed assistant Federal Reserve agent here by the Federal Reserve Board. Professor Williams has been Nathaniel Ropes Professor of Economics at Harvard University.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

Mayor O'Brien announced yesterday that he would be glad to receive the delegation that thirty civic, artistic and business organizations voted on Thursday to send to City Hall to protest against Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy's plans for converting the old reservoir site in Central Park into athletic fields.

It is odd how saintly men so' easily become corrupted. It is strange that even the children of light should enlist in the armies of the Prince of Darkness. It is past belief that young reformers, filled with zeal, should end by selling their souls to the Power Trust.

PARIS, Saturday, May 6 -- Former Premier Herriot was received with enthusiasm when he reached Paris early today from his special mission to Washington. Premier Daladier, Finance Minister Bonnet and several hundred other prominent persons, both friends and political opponents, were on the platform of the Gare St. Lazare to greet him, and thousands in the streets outside cheered and swarmed around his automobile as he left the station.

DARIEN, Conn., May 5 -- Century Country Club players, led by Mrs. R.P. Limburg, carried off the honors in Class A in the first team match tournament of the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association at the Wee Burn Club today.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 3:

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- More orderly but apparently as determined as ever, parishioners of the Catholic Church of Our Lady of Good Counsel continued tonight to stand guard at the church building where, since Wednesday, they have held captive one of their Augustinian priests as a protest against the transfer of him and fellow Augustinians to another parish on orders of Cardinal Dougherty.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I never see the word "spirea" in print -- your editorial of this morning, for instance -- without a feeling of resentment that this should connote the lovely, fragrant flowering bush I knew in my childhood in Arkansas as "Martha Washington's bridal wreath."

OTTAWA, May 5 -- A silence of more than two years engulfing the personnel of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police post at Bache Peninsula, Ellesmere Island, which is within 11 degrees of the North Pole, was broken today by a message from Corporal H.W. Stallworthy, non-commissioned officer in charge, reporting that he and his two companions, Constable R. W. Hamilton and Constable A. Monro, were alive and well.
JOSEPH STALIN is today dividing the Soviet spotlight with Klimenti Voroshilof, head of the Red Army, who, since the beginning of 1933, has risen remarkably in importance.

Traders in the speculative markets, in making the usual weekend adjustments in their accounts, had in mind yesterday the fact that President Roosevelt is to deliver a radio address tonight and that what he says may influence the movement of securties and commodities tomorrow.

JUST as Linda Tresor, the gay young belle of a small Ohio town, was in the first rapturous stages of an engagement she inadvertently learned at a family reunion of the secret rift in the family circle. Her father and her mother's younger sister, Clodagh, had at one time long ago been lovers.

Dog-show exhibitors will be busy during the next few days in making out their entries for the seventh annual show of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club, to be held on the polo field of Giralda Farms in Madison, N.J., on Saturday, May 27.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Slumping government revenues from income taxes, which point to the possibility of large delinquencies and evasions, have resulted in a decision by the Internal Revenue Bureau to conduct an intensive drive against these conditions.

CHICAGO, May 4. -- Chicago and the Middle West have not yet discerned a definite uptrend in the cost of living because of the Roosevelt inflation program, but economists here say a gradual rise already has been occasioned by the discussion of the program prior to

THE author of this book, journeying far into the interior of Alaska, just north of the Arctic Circle, has discovered a community where the depression is only a far-away echo, where there is almost no race prejudice, where there is no warfare between labor and capital, where every inhabitant is a free and unhampered individual -- in short, a community which is described as "the happiest civilization of which I have knowledge."

OMAHA, May 4. -- While soldiers keep the rural peace in the centres of disorder in Western Iowa, the organizers of farm discontent are gathered in Des Moines to plan further mass demonstrations of protest. That means more possible trouble on the horizon just as the disorders which culminated in an assault upon a State judge are being cleaned up.

PARIS. CHARLES SEIGNOBOS, who is one of the oldest professors of history at the Sorbonne, has published a "Histoire sincere de la nation francaise" (Rieder) that merits the attention of those who are interested in the history of institutions and ideas.

PARIS. IT is a long time since Jerome Blum has exhibited in New York. Now he speaks of showing again. Perhaps his American dealer, whoever that lucky fellow may be, will persuade him to hang the recent work done in Concarneau and some of the painting of last Winter in Paris.

Many theorists have contended that the working time of labor should be shortened so as to provide employment for a greater number. Their contention has been that existing machinery, with relatively few operators, can now turn out more economically the work which many men formerly performed, and, in addition, deliver a surplus.

IN Brazil coffee has been destroyed to reduce the supply and raise the price. Overproduction of sugar is just as marked. Instead of burning cane or beets, the chemists and physicists of both Europe and America are trying to find new industrial uses for sugar.

More than 200 members of the Consolidated Home Owners Committee of Long Island obtained the support of Mayor O'Brien and Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens yesterday for their campaign to have the Legislature declare a moratorium on mortgage payments.

The coin museum of the Chase National Bank, which exhibits a collection of currency rated as one of the greatest in the world, has added emergency "money" from communities in all parts of the country. The new collection of paper, buckskin, sheepskin and wooden scrip, and the inevitable wooden nickels, numbers several hundred specimens.
CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, May 6. -- Luther A. Brewer, political leader, newspaper publisher and art patron, died here today after a week's illness. He was 74 years old.

THE word "buckaroo" is evidently a Southwestern corruption (as the grammarians would term it) of the Spanish vaquero -- literally, a cowherd. But the hero of this zestful and salty tale has been graduated from the ranks of the cowboys and has become a sergeant in the Texas Rangers; he is called a buckaroo only playfully by his fun-loving companions, or in spiteful derision by his enemies.

WARRENTON, Va., May 6. -- The Virginia Steeplechase gold cup became the permanent property of the Flying Horse Farm, Hamilton, Mass., owned by Sumner Pingree, when The Prophet came in first today in the field of seven, five of which finished.

CLEVELAND, May 6. -- Under a leaden sky and a heavy mist that isolated Cleveland's mammoth arena from all view of the outside world the Yankees gave the Indians quite a turbulent battle today, but came out second best.

PARIS, May 5. -- French comment regarding President Roosevelt's decision that the gold clause in bonds would be temporarily disregarded was much calmer than that in London, and only a few papers even discussed the matter. That does not mean, however, that the French have not been critical or disappointed, but there is a distinct impression that they had expected such action.

PARIS, April 20. MARCEL ACHARD'S new play is often a diverting entertainment. To say that it is worthy of the author of "Marlbrouck" and "Jean de la Lune" would be an exaggeration. It has neither the fantasy of the one nor the tender sentiment and richness of characterization of the other.

BERLIN, May 6. -- The National Socialists have gained a measure of unification in the Protestant churches under an agreement just reached by church leaders, but domination of these churches by the Nazis has, at least temporarily, been postponed.

THE relative "greatness" of Sir William Orpen it is no doubt too early to attempt to establish. He died in 1931, and while his position among contemporary British artists is fixed beyond dispute, the abiding value of his art remains to be tested.

Governor HERRING of Iowa acted with courage and decision in proclaiming martial law in seven counties where excited farmers had taken the law into their own hands. In two he established military courts. The region is one in which the Farmers Holiday Association made itself conspicuous by ill-judged and futile "strikes."

WASHINGTON. THE legal staff of the United States Treasury has been engaged during the last few days upon a perplexing problem involving the so-called gold clause in the financial obligations of the United States Government, amounting to almost $22,000,000,000, and the same provision in about $75,000,000,000 worth of other contracts in this country.

ATBANY, May 6. -- The State's surplus is estimated for June 30 next year at $3,485,110, Governor Lehman said today in a statement giving a detailed account of New York's financial condition at the end of the 1933 session of the Legislature.

Poly Prep's squad hopes to make a strong bid for the team honors in the annual St. Paul's School invitation interscholastio track and field meet on Saturday afternoon at Garden City. Poly won the laurels in 1931, but last year finished in a tie with Sayville High for third place, behind Hempstead High and La Salle Military Academy, which finished first and second, respectively.

"STORM BEACH" is a historical novel dealing with the group of Jews who lived in Charleston early in the nineteenth century, and with the Carvalho cian in particular. Abraham Carvalho bad brought his family there from Haiti during the bloody uprising of Haitian Negroes, and the Carvalhos had become part not only of the Jewish colony but of the city itself.

Officials of the State division of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform said yesterday that they would sponsor the observance of Ratification Week, beginning tomorrow with the dual object of getting out as large a repeal vote as possible in New York State and raising money for educational work in behalf of ratification of the repeal amendment in States where the issue is considered doubtful.

Realty Associates, reports Thomas H. Long, in charge of home sales for that corporation, are now operating seven separate small-home developments in Brooklyn and Long Island. They are, respectively, at Flatbush Centre and Gerrittsen Beach in Brooklyn, Ridgewood Plateau in Queens, Stewart at Garden City and Hewlett Manor, Bay Park and Freeport-Merrick Estates in Nassau County.

A mechanical table which is believed to have been made for Marie Antoinette by the celebrated French cabinetmaker, Jean-Henri Riesener, has been purchased by the Metropolitan Museum of Art and placed on exhibition in its room of recent accessions.

PARIS, May 6. -- The International Governing Commission of the Saar Basin took steps today for a stricter policy and measures in an effort to suppress the irritating incidents that have been so frequent lately between the Hitlerites and the French in the region.

AN ancient Greek sage once said: "Know thyself!" Fashion says: "Be yourself!" Perhaps the two are one and the same. At any rate when making the best of such endowments as nature has given you, study yourself. Be individual!

Both human and mechanical endurance will be put to their severest test in motor boating next Sunday morning when the annual outboard race down the Hudson River from Albany is held. This veritable steeplechase of the water will be the sixth one of the 132 miles from the Albany Yacht Club to the Colonial Yacht Club at the foot of West 152d Street.
A "hardtime reunion" of the Hunter College class of 1904 was held yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. Fifth Avenue and Ninth Street. A 99 cent economy luncheon was served to more than 100 members.

AN enthralling novel might be written about the adventures of a woman in the business world. But, in spite of the current accretion of tales about women executives, women in department stores, women managing chain restaurants, women striving for honors in the arts and professions, a really impressive novel of the woman of affairs is yet to come.

CAMP DIX, N.J., May 6. -- Numerous complaints from recruits in the Citizens' Conservation Corps continued here today following the action yesterday by Brig. Gen. H. L. Laubach in checking an attempt to throw the camp into insurrection and in ejecting forty-five "strikers" who were sent to their homes in Newark last night after they had started wild disorder in a mess hall.

MAHATMA GANDHI, who has been planning another "unconditional and irrevocable" fast, began last year to employ this method of obtaining political reforms. On Sept. 20 last he undertook a hunger strike in Yerovda jail in connection with reforms in the "untouchability" system in India.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 6. -- Brought here by airplane from Philadelphia, where his fondness for posing as a priest got him into trouble with the authorities, James Gavagan, 23 years old, convinced the Nassau County police tonight that he was innocent of the murder of Mary Helen O'Connor, a student at the Bishop McDonnell High School in Brooklyn, whose body was found in Massapequa Feb. 2.

HAVANA, May 2. -- The "ley de fuga" (law of flight) under which Cuban authorities are accustomed to kill prisoners, both common and political, claiming they attempted to escape, is merely an ironical term applied to summary executions and does not exist on the statute books of the republic.

BERLIN. UNTER DEN LINDEN -- "the Linden" to most American and British tourists, who hate a long name and reduce it whenever possible -- extends through the heart of Berlin, from the Brandenburg Gate to the Lustgarten, a full kilometer, two-thirds of a mile.

Both retail trade and the wholesale markets here were featured by a high level of activity last week. Seasonal retail sales climbed close to last year's figures, with the prospect of rising prices now exerting marked influence upon consumer purchasing.

Women interested in the work of Stony Wold Sanatorium, headed by Mrs. Duncan R. Linsley and Mrs. Kenneth T. Wilson, have arranged two events in behalf of the sanatorium for this week, one, a dinner dance to be held on Wednesday night in the roof garden of the St. Regis and the other, a tea dance in conjunction with a bridge party on Saturday at the Central Park Casino.

CONRAD AIKEN has changed a little since he wrote "Blue Voyage," his first and only other novel: he has become gentler and more tolerant toward his characters, less given to the post-war habit of destroying a whole life for the stark passion of a moment; he has intensified his psychological realism and delved more profoundly, into Joyce; and he has become even more impressively the master of his own technique.

THE current London Studio contains a detailed and illustrated analysis by Alfred Yockney of the water-colors in which James McBey chronicled his journey through Spain. Several pages are given over to a consideration of the mural decorations of Radio City.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Calling for the overthrow of the "capitalistic" system of government and the "return to the people of the nation's wealth" if sinister and probable revolution are to be averted, Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President in the last election, and Senator Lynn L. Frazier of North Dakota opened the two-day Continental Congress for Economic Reconstruction today.

INDIVIDUALS whose brilliant tal- ent -- genius, if you like -- has been thwarted often seek compensation in attempting to mold others to the form of their unrealized ideal. But the subjects of this proselytizing rarely respond as desired.

DINGHY racing, begun fifteen months ago, has swept yachtsmen off their feet like green water over topsides. Started as a Winter pastime, it is being carried on this Spring and is being scheduled for the Summer by all the large yacht clubs.

A protest against the proposal to ask teachers to serve without pay in the city Summer schools this year was unanimously adopted yesterday by the High School Teachers Association at a meeting at the Hotel Astor. The resolution referred specifically only to Summer high schools, but Dr. Frederick Houk Law, the president, called it a "resolution in defense of the dignity of teachers," and expressed the hope that other associations would take similar action.

In an earlier work by the same author the term "Great Technology" was employed to denote the advance made by man during the past century in mastering nature and the material conditions of human existence. Now the term is extended to include "the norms and modes of living of a potentially great culture which looms just over the horizon."

Having completed purchases for sales this month, retailers have cut down orders for current merchandise, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. This, however, was counteracted by the unusually large volume of orders received for staple Fall goods for future delivery in anticipation of further price advances.

H.V. MARROT, who has been entrusted with writing the official life of John Galsworthy, would appreciate receiving communications from any who have personal reminiscences and anecdotes bearing on any period of Galsworthy's life or any phase of his activities.

AMERICAN musical conditions are undergoing a change which will work to the advantage of native art. This change is due primarily to economic conditions. They tend to lower the market price of the European artist of reputation.

A strip of the flag which Admiral Peary carried on each of his Arctic expeditions, the same flag which swathed his infant daughter, Ah-ni-ghi-to, after her birth in Greenland, was re-entrusted to Mrs. Marie Paary Stafford, the "Snow Baby," yesterday, on the anniversary of the famous explorer's birth, by the American Geographical Society, of which her father was president.

COMMISSIONER HARNETT of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles clarified last week the amendment to the vehicle and traffic law enabling New York motorists to use the previous year's registration plates during the January following.

BREMEN, May 6. -- The two chief Hanseatic cities, Hamburg and Bremen, have joined hands through the instrumentality of their Nazi administrations for cooperatively reorganizing their shipping interests, Mayor Markert of Bremen told newspaper men today.

BERLIN, May 6. -- The National Socialists have decided on a further widening of their plans for the memorial services in the Rhineland to mark the death of Albert Leo Schlageter, who was shot to death ten years ago by the French occupation forces in the Ruhr.

With the dollar recovering sharply in the foreign exchange market, stocks turned downward yesterday and closed with the widest losses since the recent advance began. Bonds and several of the commodities, notably wheat, had a moderate setback.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 6. -- Five champions were adjudged at the final performance of the ninth annual New Haven Horse Show tonight.

FROM Robert E. Sherwood's Moharesque comedy, "Reunion in Vienna," MetroGoldwyn-Mayer has produced a conspicuously clever motion picture, in which John Barrymore's performance is really deserving of that too often glibly used word, "excellent."

HARRISON, N.Y., May 6. -- War Bride, chestnut mare owned and ridden by Mrs. Lewis L. Strauss of White Plains, N.Y., today captured the championship in the saddle division of the third annual Harrison Horse Show, held on the grounds of the Kentucky Riding Academy.

THE Nazis of Adolf Hitler, or members of the National Socialist German Workers party, according to latest estimates, number more than 1,000,000. When the roster reaches 2,000,000, according to present party plans, the membership book will be closed.

EAST NORWICH, L.I., May 6. -- Several hundred relatives and friends attended the marriage of Miss Louise Miller, one of the twin daughters of former Governor and Mrs. Nathan L. Miller of 625 Park Avenue and East Norwich, to Douglas Robinson, son of former Assistant Secretary of the Navy Theodore Douglas Robinson and Mrs. Robinson, this afternoon at Norwich House, the family's country home here.

IT has been remarked that the existence of living beings on a planet or a star is impossible, and yet it is. In somewhat the same way, one may reflect that to describe popularly in one volume almost all the manifestations of that life, that planet and that star is also impossible; and yet Mr. Garbedian has accomplished it, and with rather more than fair success.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 4. -- Acting under laws enacted in 1925 and 1933, the State Penal Board will farm out surplus convict labor to raise funds to operate the penal system, which is in debt. The laws require the State to retain control of the convicts at all times; to guard, house and feed them, as well as to establish rules for hours and conditions of work.

PARIS, April 27. -- "Misrepresentation" of the French Foreign Legion in popular fiction and Hollywood films is alleged to have gone so far that Philippe Ortiz, an American citizen whose 19-year-old son is now serving in that famous military body, has organized a Franco-American society "for dissemina- tion of the truth about the legion."

SAN FRANCISCO, May 4. -- When the Assembly at Sacramento voted yesterday to sustain Governor Rolph's veto of the race track hill the action was not an endorsement of the versatile Executive's high stand on what he described as "moral" grounds.

IF a machine existed for the production of novels without the hindrance of an artist's imagination, its work would resemble this collaboration of ten successful writers upon a scenario given them by Polan Banks. A situation, sensational in the same degree as a tabloid news story, is fed into the machine.

TOKYO, May 6. -- It was stated on good authority today that Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Commissar for Foreign Affairs, in conversation with Ambassador Tamekichi Ota of Japan last Tuesday had offered to sell the Chinese Eastern Railway in Manchuria to Japan for 300,000,000 gold rubles (about $153,000,000 at par).

BERLIN, April 21. -- Representatives of the foreign press were invited today by the director of the political division of the Berlin police administration to inspect evidence offered in support of the contention that, despite repressive measures, the Communist spectre still menaces Germany, and that German Communists have been and still are actively engaged in instigating and keeping alive what here goes by the name of "atrocity propaganda against Germany."

The Manhattan freshman track team defeated Gorton High School, 56 to 25, yesterday at Glen Park in Yonkers for its second victory of the season. William Eipel led the victors in scoring with 13 points, winning the high jump and broad jump and placing second in the shot-put.

Inflationary influences, as registered by a further sharp drop in dollar exchange, swept cotton prices into new high ground for the season yesterday, and at 8.95 cents a pound October contracts were a cent above the opening price of the previous Saturday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 6 (AP). -- Yale scored two victories today, defeating Princeton, 7 1/2 to 1 1/2, and Pennsylvania, 8 to 1, to make a clean sweep of three Eastern Intercollegiate League golf matches played on the Elis' home course this week-end.

ATLANTA, May 4. -- While Tennesseans and Carolinians were drinking their 3.2 beer and the brew was moving in the general direction of Florida, the Governor of Georgia attempted to slake the thirst of his constituents with stale and unprofitable hopes.

Cooperation with the Board of Education to bridge the gap between the police and the schools in dealing with juvenile delinquency in will be the policy of the Police Department under Commissioner James S. Bolan, he told members of the New Tork Principals Association last night at their dinner Symposium on juvenile delinquency at the Hotel Croydon, 12 East Eighty-sixth Street.

Rumors that France and Holland would abandon the gold standard over the week-end, spreading rapidly through all financial markets here yesterday morning, brought a sharp rally in the dollar and led to heavy selling in the Stock and commodity Exchanges.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- President Roosevelt and Sigrnor Guido Jung, Italian Minister of Finance and personal representative of Premier Mussolini, today reached a complete agreement on essential international action necessary for raising world commodity prices and thus ending the depression.

WASHINGTON. PRESIDENTS must keep in condition. Hoover, like Cleveland, sought to maintain health by fresh and salt water fishing, and also by medicine-ball. Coolidge pitched hay, waded brooks for trout and for a while tried a gym horse.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6. -- Eddie Loughlin of Harvard pitched the Crimson to its second Eastern Intercollegiate League victory over the University of Pennsylvania today. Three home runs contributed largely to the 3-to-2 count, though ten hits were made off Loughlin and a like number against the two Penn pitchers, Kelley and Sked.

Exchange of checks at the leading clearing houses of the country in April totaled $16,687,949,739, a gain of 1.4 per cent from the March return, which itself was smaller by 10.5 per cent than the February total. However, compared with April, 1932, there was a loss of 26.9 per cent.

THIS is National Music Week and the broadcasters will celebrate it with several special concerts. The Preakness and Gene Tunney are on radio's sports calendar. Among the week's speakers are Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Secretary of Labor Perkins, Edward P. Mulrooney and Gates W. McGarrah, who will discuss international banking by short wave from Switzerland.

Plans are now being made for the annual shipboard party for the benefit of the Flower Hospital. It will take place on May 24 on board the liner Majestic at Pier 59, West Eighteenth Street, and the various features will include dinner, bridge, a performance by theatrical stars and general dancing.

The Children's Orthopedic and Surgical Ward and the Social Service Department of the New York Post Graduate Hospital will be the beneficiaries of a fashion show to be held on Tuesday afternoon at the home of Paul D. Cravath, 36 East Seventy-second Street.

A.D. Theobald of the faculty of Northwestern University and director of education and research for the American Savings, Building and Loan Institute, predicted rising real estate prices in addressing the delegates of the district conference of the United States Building and Loan League in Chicago last week.

THIS book is, indeed, as its compiler describes it, "a literary curiosity," for it does what no other work, either by one person or several, has ever tried to do before -- to get what might per- haps be called the low-down on the vitality of humor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read, with keen interest, the article in THE TIMES last Sunday about the nostalgia for the Victorian era; but I admit, frankly, that I am rather fed up on this "yen" for the dear, dead days beyond recall.
The Metropolitan Golf Association will open its season on Tuesday with the first of the nine one-day tournaments it will sponsor for its members in the various districts during the year.

GRANT MITCHELL appears as Richard Barthelmess's father in "Central Airport" at the Strand. He was born in Columbus, Ohio, June 17, 1874, and served scholastic terms successively in Ohio State University, Yale College and Harvard Law School.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- In full expectation of an early trade agreement between Argentina and the United States, according to wellinformed sources here, Tomas A. Le Breton and Ambassador Felipe Espil completed their discussions here today with President Roosevelt, Secretary Hull and experts of the State Department.

An impressive string of victories that started in 1932 was kept intact yesterday when the four-oared crew of Choate School defeated the Columbia freshman four on the Harlem River. The Choate outfit now has been victorious in ten consecutive races -- six last season and four this year.
DARMSTADT, May 4. -- A copy of a remarkable letter being circulated to the German press by the Government Press Department here has come into the hands of this correspondent.

MOTORISTS planning to tour through Long Island this season will find a number of new improvements in the network of roads on that popular motoring ground. Counties, cities and townships have cooperated in enlarging highway facilities for the accommodation of the enormous army-at-the-wheel which will invade the island during this and coming months.

LONDON, May 5. -- In Germany, where the art of politics just now consists mainly in supplying bigger mass meetings and bigger jails, and where Karl Marx is anathema -- largely because he neglected to choose what Chancellor Hitler calls Aryan ancestors -- it probably would be seditious to mention the Marxian doctrine of economic determinism, especially since the ruling powers regard economic problems as secondary and easy to solve.

A survey of the Negro population in the upper Harlem area shows that congestion increased during the decade from 1920 to 1930. The survey was made by the committee on land utilization of the New York Building Congress, in cooperation with the Architects' Emergency Committee, under the supervision of Arthur C. Holden and Thomas S. Holden.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 6. -- The opening intercity tournament lacrosse matches of the United States Women's Lacrosse Association, were held this afternoon, at the Greenwich Academy field, Greenwich. Philadelphia won from New York by a score of 10 --1, and Baltimore defeated Boston, 6 -- 5.

Approving in principle the suggestion for a Federal law establishing a shorter work week and minimum wages in industry, a special committee of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., last week went on record against passage of the Black bill in its present form.

A conference of 300 educational leaders in the metropolitan area on the problem of improving education during the depression will open next Friday evening in the Horace Mann Auditorum, it was announced yesterday at Teachers College, Columbia University.

LAUGHTER has been the subject of much theory, conjecture, philosophy, physiology, but Henri Bergson's simplification, long since demoded, seems to get closest of any to the tricky comic spirit. We laugh because we are amused and we are never amused except by what is human.

MR. NORMAN DOUGLAS must have a lot to look back to. He has wandered about the world. He has seen behind the facades of diplomacy and has had the delights of bobemianism. He has known all sorts of people from statesmen and men of letters to tramps.

WASHINGTON. IN the Washington scene today Frances Perkins, the first woman to hold Cabinet office, stands out prominently. As Secretary of Labor she takes a leading role in the effort to solve problems growing out of employment.

OSLO, Norway, May 6. -- News came from Spitsbergen today that the Soviet salvage steamer Rouslan had been overwhelmed in an Arctic gale off South Cape and apparently had sunk with the loss of the entire crew of thirty-three.
HARWICHPORT, Mass., May 6. -- Details of the proceedings by which Peggy McMath, was freed by her kidnappers were given today by State Police Commissioner Needham as follows:

GOING over the ground covered in last week's resume of recent orchestral disks to discover what has been happening during the same period in the instrumental department, it must be admitted that the contents of the last few domestic lists have not been very striking in this respect.

HARWICHFORT, Mass., May 6. -- Two brothers, Kenneth and Cyril Buck, were under arrest tonight charged with the kidnapping of Margaret McMath, 10, from a school house here Tuesday. The $60,000 ransom they obtained from her father, Neil C. McMath, for the child's return yesterday, had all been recovered.

Despite public misconception there is no magic in the word "guarantee," said George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance of the State of New York, discussing the mortgage guarantee situation at the annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York Thursday evening.

Horace E. Payson, an authority on varnish and enamels, founder and president of the Payson Varnish Company, 804 East 141st Street, the Bronx, died yesterday of heart disease at his home at 18 Beach Avenue, Larchmont, N.Y., in his eighty-third year.

To the Music Editor: Last Wednesday night the writer had the pleasure of attending the performance of Cimarosa's "The Secret Marriage" at the Juilliard School concert hall. Mr. Downes's article on English texts for foreign operas came somewhat as a surprise.

Representatives from seven colleges for women participated in the second annual symposium on the dance in college held yesterday in the gymnasium of Barnard College. More than 1,000 students, faculty members and guests attended the dance demonstration, which was given by student groups from Barnard, Mount Holyoke, New York University, Russell Sage, Smith, Wellesley and Vassar.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6. -- Harvard's varsity track team showed balance and power today as it recorded a 79 1/3-55 2/3 victory over Princeton in the first meet between the two universities in the Harvard Stadium since 1925.

NESTLING in a woody suburb of Indianapolis is a charming, rustic building known as Foster Hall. It is a music hall dedicated to the purpose of preserving, as completely as possible data concerning the life and career of America's most beloved composer of melodies, Stephen Collins Foster.
Congratulatory resolutions have been sent by practically all of the real estate bodies in New York City to Joseph V. McKee on his election as president of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

BERLIN, May 6. -- The Crusade of the German studenthoods against the "Un-German Spirit" in print and picture got under way in all the German university centres today. In Berlin it opened with a formal attack on Dr. Magnus Hirschfeld's "Institute for Sexual Science," which has long been a place of interest for some tourists as well as a centre for scientific research.

HEIDELBERG, May 3. -- There is great rejoicing at the 300-year-old Inn Gasthaus auf der Hirschgasse, where, since the end of the sixteenth century, Heidelberg students have fought their ceremonial duels -- the mensur. For the Hitler government has restored the students' cherished privilege of dueling.

American friends of Germany will wish all good luck to Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, head of the Reichsbank, who has arrived in Washington as the representative of his country in the White House talks which President Roosevelt is holding preparatory to the World Economic Conference. A rare opportunity is presented Dr. Schacht to do immeasurable good for the Reich.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- A rough draft of the national industrial recovery act, designed to achieve Federal coordination and control of production, was completed today by the experts who have been drawing up the plan, and was sent to Senator Wagner for study and review before he submits the measure to President Roosevelt, presumably Monday.

Contending that the John T. Brady Company, contractors, had not had sufficient time to enter a bid on the removal of ashes and garbage in Brooklyn, John E. Dordan, president of the company, began legal action yesterday to block the award of the contract to the Manhattan Ash Removal Company, of which Samuel Rosoff is head.

AS THE EARTH TURNS," by Gladys Hasty Carroll, is an interesting addition to the so-called soil novel of America. Its background is Maine and its characters remnants of the old pioneering stock of this country, those who for one reason or another have remained behind in loyalty and devotion to the land that belongs to them, or, perhaps, more rightly speaking, the land to which they be- long.

Price advances ranging from 3 to 10 per cent in food and merchandise markets, created by the inflation movement, have not yet extended to retail stores but may be expected to do so in the coming sixty to ninety days, according to a survey by THE TIMES yesterday.
FIFTY years ago I entered Yale as a freshman; this year I retire, after forty-two years of college teaching, one at Harvard and the rest at Yale.

The fight launched by an indignant public against Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy's plan to develop the old reservoir site in Central Park with baseball diamonds and athletic fields gained fresh impetus yesterday when the City Club and the West End Association joined the concerted attack.

The St. Regis Paper Company reported for 1932 a net loss of $311,684 after depreciation, taxes and charges, contrasting with a net profit of $1,411,015 in 1931. Net sales, royalties, rentals and other operating revenue were $8,185,971, against $13,249,823, a decline of 38 per cent, and operating income after costs and expenses was $629,630, against $1,565,516.

HOLLYWOOD. AN interesting cinema program is scheduled to come from Columbia, which, until this year, has been denied a major studio rating by the local residents. Damon Runyon's "Madame La Gimp" with May Robson, Lawrence Hazzard's "A Man's Castle," two Broadway plays, "The Party's Over" and "Twentieth Century," and Al Rogell's yarn.

HARWICH, Mass., May 6 (AP). -- Mrs. Cyril Buck, shaken by the sudden denouement of the kidnapping of Peggy McMath which placed her husband under arrest, today declared she retained the utmost confidence in his innocence.
MOSCOW, May 5. -- The Soviet is successfully weathering another squall in its stormy career. That is in Moscow and other big cities.

Ushered in by rain, a cold wind and a muddy track, the metropolitan racing season opened at the Jamaica course of the Metropolitan Jockey Club yesterday with a crowd of about 5,000 in attendance. The Faumonok Handicap, the feature, was captured by Pilate, the 5year-old chestnut horse which is owned and trained by Andy Schuttinger, in his day a noted rider of the turf.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Establishment of a definite relationship between the currencies of the major countries and the perpetuation of such stabilization through an international balancing of budgets are urged in a report on monetary and trade policies made public today by a special committee of the American Section of the International Chamber of Commerce.

The golf season began in earnest during the past week as far as most of the leading women players of the metropolitan district were concerned. The initial one-day tourney of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association caused officials to be highly optimistic as the entry list, compared with the same event a year ago, was almost doubled.

SO much already has appeared about Picasso. And yet the project here handsomely begun (devoted mainly to reproductions) involves the first systematically exhaustive survey of his art that has been undertaken up to the present time.

Trade associations, executives and lawyers, who returned late last week from the meeting of the United States Chamber of Commerce and the American Trade Association Executives in Washington, expressed themselves as greatly surprised at the agreement among previously divergent groups on current business problems and the anxiety of leaders for government action to help business.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 5. -- Much in the manner of European Cabinets, Rochester's government switched hands in the midst of a financial crisis last week with a suddenness that left its citizens bewildered with a new deal they never expected.

Henry Seidel Canby, editor of the Saturday Review of Literature and delegate of the American branch of the International Literary Association, "P.E.N.," sailed yesterday with Mrs. Canby on the Italian liner Vulcania for Italy. He will go from Italy to Ragusa, Dalmatia, to attend a meeting of the "P.E.N." at which H.G. Wells, president of the British section of the association, will preside.

LONDON, May 6 (AP). -- Since Great Britain abandoned the gold standard eighteen months ago, the resulting economic and financial advantages have placed this country in a more sound position than at any time since the World War, according to the authoritative opinion of financial and business leaders.
The Rice Brothers' chestnut mare Sally, competing under extremely adverse conditions, captured the knockdown and out class in the first annual Clove Lake horse show at West Brighton, S.I., yesterday.

THE earth radiates heat into space. As it cools off the temperature of its deeper strata must fall and the molten components of the interior "freeze." Professor Ernest Janecke draws interesting conclusions from this process in Forschung und Fortschritte.

Passage of the Inflation bill caused no great surprise. But along with, it there has arisen in some quarters a protest against criticism of the bill's proposals. The President, we are told, by permitting Congress to give him these dangerous powers averted a stampede by Congress into outright fiat-money legislation.

LONDON, April 21. THERE is a law in England that a wife cannot be called upon to give evidence against her husband, and it is, I think, an equally good rule, which I purpose to observe, that a critic must not give evidence in favor of his wife's play.
ANDOVER, Mass., May 6. -- A powerful Harvard freshman team which won nine first places and swept the broad jump, defeated Andover, 78v -- 48, in the annual dual track meet today.

WILL ROGERS, in his second "unofficial report" to the American people concerning economic and political activities, promises to give WJZ's audience "some first-hand dope" from the White House at 9 o'clock tonight. At the conclusion of his first broadcast in the current series last Sunday he said he would visit Mr. Roosevelt and "tell you all" tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- A gigantic plan designed to put at least 3,000,000 men back to work in private industry on a specified date was revealed here today, reported as having the backing of twentyfive chosen representatives of 56,000 manufacturers.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 6. -- The Naval Academy won from William and Mary in a track and field meet here today by 81 2-3 to 44 1-3, the Middies winning firsts in nine out of fourteen events and tying in another. In the mile and two mile runs both hurdles and the quarter mile the Navy took all three places.

Disposition to take profits sent the bond market on the Stock Exchange irregularly lower in the brief trading period yesterday, when transactions mounted to $9,614,000, a figure which would come close to a normal full day's business.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Former directors of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company who participated in a stock-purchase pool managed by Joseph W. Harriman deny that they knew of any manipulation of the bank's funds by Harriman in connection with the pool.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 6. -- Ten to 15 per cent of college students suffer from mental difficulties. President Angell of Yale said today at the celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the pioneer mental hygiene unit in this city, May 6, 1908, by Clifford W. Beers, a graduate of the university.

MEMBERS of the Seventh Regiment, in their annual church parade today, will march with colors that have not rippled to a breeze since the days of the Civil War. Some of these flags and standards are tattered and torn, some are sewed in silken nets to keep their shreds intact, while the newer ones are bright and firm.

TWO doctrines have governed the course of physical science in our time. One, the Theory of Relativity, has transformed our conception of time and space and of mass and energy; the other, the Principle of Indeterminancy, has enthroned Free Will.

ALBANY, May 6. -- Completing action today on the 884 thirty-day bills, Governor Lehman handed over to Lieutenant Governor Bray the reins of the State Government and left for a two weeks' fishing vacation on the West Coast ot Florida.

Mlle. Michele d'ldier, the 15-yearold stowaway from Grenoble, France, who captivated detectives, court attendants, a judge and immigration officials with her pretty French accent, turned out yesterday to be just Mary Whittier, runaway high school girl of Hazleton, Pa.

It wax predicted that when President ROOSEVELT addressed the Chamber of Commerce of the United States on Thursday night he would assure the American business world that he does not dream of a wild plunge into inflation. This was not really to be expected of him on that occasion.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will speak at the third annual Mother's Day luncheon to be given by the president and board of directors of the Maternity Centre Association on Friday in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. More than 500 men and women already have accepted invitations for the event, which has been planned by Mrs. John Sloane, Mrs. Kenneth O'Brien, Mrs. E. Marshall Field and members of their committee.

A major development likely to result from inflationary price trends in the merchandise markets is broad use of the price guarantee, according to a survey just completed by the Grey AdvertisingService, 128 West Thirty-first Street.

WASHINGTON. WITH the Twenty-first Amendment -- for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment -- already ratified in two States and with the machinery in motion for a vote on ratification in many others, the time is rapidly approaching when the fate of the repealer will be known.

DERBY, Conn., May 6. -- In the last twenty yards of as bitterly fought a race as the Housatonic course has ever seen, Yale's varsity crew found the strength somewhere to stand off Pennsylvania's brilliant tight and complete a clean sweep of the Derby Day regatta for the Yale navy today.

TROY, N.Y., May 6 (AP). -- Outclassing a field of 400 athletes from the pick of 43 high and preparatory schools in the east, Nott Terrace High School of Schenectady, defending champions, today won a record shattering twelfth renewal of the Interscholastic track and field games of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.

HANOVER, N.H., May 6. -- Four Dartmouth-Brown-Columbia triangular meet records were broken on Memorial Field today as Dartmouth's track and field athletes won. Dartmouth scored in all events except the quarter and half mile runs and totaled 67 1/2 points, against Columbia's 38 and Brown's 29 1/2, to take the third annual meet.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 4. -- With cotton topping 8 cents a pound for the first time in nearly a year, and prospects for a good crop bright, the farmers of the lower Mississippi Valley, for the first time in two years, are beginning to see daylight.

BALTIMORE, May 6. -- Stepenfetchit, carrying the silks of Mrs. John Hay Whitney, accounted for the mile and three-sixteenths on the tenth running of the Dixie Handicap at Pimlico today. The four-year-old son of the Porter splashed to a length victory over William Ziegler Jr.'s Keep Out.

There is a distinct and very vital difference between an assignment of lease and a sublease, points out Clarence M. Lewis. Restrictions against assignment, he says, have never been favored by the courts and since the earliest times express covenants against assignment have been strictly construed.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 6. -- Providence College defeated Holy Cross, 5 to 2, today, the Friars registering three of their tallies by home runs. Marion hit two, one off the right-field fence and the other to deep left, and Quinton lifted his over the barrier in right.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- When the President begins his radio speech tomorrow night it is likely that he will have many millions of listeners. But perhaps the most attentive auditors will be those members of a certain group of 531 Americans who can manage to locate a loud-speaker.

The Bureau of Motor Vehicles was ready yesterday for the issuance to city motorists of more than 1,000,000 automobile driving licenses beginning tomorrow morning. The 1933-1934 credentials must be used by all those who operate a car in this State on and after June 1.

Undeterred by a continuous downpour, the minor colleges of the metropolitan district staged their first annual track and field championships at Boys High Field yesterday under the auspices of Brooklyn College. The persistent rain and a heavy track militated against good performances, but Savage had little trouble in annexing the team title.
Strong opposition to tax-exempt housing was voiced at a meeting of the Association of Harlem and Bronx Property Owners, Inc., last week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Not all heroes in the world have the patience or good fortune of Richmond Pearson Hobson. After almost thirty-five years, Congress awards him the Medal of Honor and President Roosevelt pins it on his breast.

DUBLIN, May 5. -- Now that President Eamon de Valera, has removed the oath of allegiance to the king from the Free State Constitution the question arises as to what further symbols of the link with Great Britain Mr. de Valera wishes to remove before declaring a republic.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor announces that its index number of wholesale prices for the week ending April 29 stands at 61.5, as compared with 60.4 for the week ending April 22, showing an increase of approximately 18-10 per cent, each group sharing in the advance.

TULSA, Okla., May 6 (AP). -- The Standard Oil Company of Indiana today cut prices for crude oil in Oklahoma and Kansas to 25 cents a barrel. The Stanolind Crude Oil Purchasing Company, a subsidiary, made the announcement. Previous prices ranged on a gravity scale to a 52-cent top.

LIGHT affects plants and animals. Indeed, light and life are almost synonymous. Without light plants would not produce chlorophyl -- the green coloring matter of foliage. The whole mysterious process of converting the gases of the atmosphere and the mineral salts in the ground into waving grass and trees that toss their branches in the wind would come to an end if light were blotted out.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine article on "Shakespeare the Man: A New Portrait," reiterated the commonly accepted belief that Shakespeare's grave has never been desecrated. Leslie Hotson, the author of the article, said that Shakespeare's epitaph is "a blessing and a curse" by which "all are halted" because it is "as effectual today as it was three centuries ago."

WARSAW, May 5. -- The Soviet envoy here, Antonoff Owsiejenko, was received Monday by Marshal Pilsudski, a distinction reserved for a few diplomats on very important occasions. The same evening a special Soviet trade mission headed by Deputy Trade Commissioner Boyeff arrived in Warsaw to study Polish economic and industrial conditions.

Fifty institutions in the higher education field that have appeared in the Northeast of late point to a significant development. Few of them are more than five years old. Sixteen have appeared in the last two depression years. The parents of 5,000 young men and women have chosen to use these institutions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was to be the last college lecture of a great man. His last class sat intent and silent. What would the beloved master say in the final hour? What from his store of great learning? What from his unexcelled wisdom?

THIS is a college novel of the twenties, that unique post-war decade with which both social historians and popular writers are sure to be greatly concerned fifty years or so hence. Stockley is obviously the University of California.

BELLE FOURCHE, S.D., May 4. -- Feeling its way with characteristic caution, business, in the agricultural and stock-raising States of the West, is for the first time in months definitely pulling itself out of the depression.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Violation of the wage agreement between the Illinois Central Railroad and the Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employes was charged today by F.H. Fljozdal, president of the employes organization.

IT has been thirty years since the first motion-picture drama flickered on the screen in Union Square. Before that event there had been "living pictures" for seven years or so. Prizefighters pummeled and clinched, fat men were chased by bathing beauties, cross-eyed comedians were plastered with pies, and Catchem Stuffem operated their sausage mill, dogs going in at the top and "dogs" pouring out below, while the painted stage-set flapped in the breeze.

BARCELONA, April 21. -- A world disappointed with itself and filled with disquieting fears of the future must look for sound rebuilding not to the regulated machine or the unchained worker or the liberated woman but to the emancipated child.

FOR the last few years the most widely circulated literature on the "economics of the depression" has been presented to the public by writers whose authority was variously derived from important business connections, vague analogies with past economic history, or personal intuition, with a smattering of statistics from governmental agencies to lend a "scientific" color.

A contract bridge team of four representing the Barnard College Club won the intercollege club championship last night at the final round of a tournament participated in by representatives of the alumnae of ten women's colleges. The match was held at the Women's University Club, 106 East Fiftysecond Street.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP). -- The Shipping Board approved today the proposal of the United States Lines to lay up the Leviathan for the 1933 season. The order permits the omission of the seven transatlantic runs the ship would have made this year.

BERLIN, April 21. WITH the production of Richard Billinger's "Rosse" at the State Playhouse the connection of Leopold Jessner with this theatre comes to a definite end. And, as this director is of Jewish extraction, it is probable that he will find no employment anywhere in the German theatre.

With the completion last week of the New York Edison-Niagara Hudson Power electrical interconnection, all the important power resources in the northeastern section of the United States were linked in one gigantic network of 11,540,000 horsepower, with an additional 1,233,000 horsepower in contiguous Canada, making a total of 12,773,000, a force without parallel anywhere in the world.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 6. -- Yale defeated University of Pennsylvania, 92 to 43, in their annual track meet today. The athletes were handicapped by the rain.

LOS ANGELES, May 5. -- Stimulated by renewed confidence springing from a more ready public disposition to take advantage of favorable opportunities at hand, business in this region, generally, is on a gradual upgrade. This progress is seen in a larger volume of investment money, increased buying and consequent stock reductions that, through replenishments, are expected to bring appreciately higher commodity price levels, especially in the next Fall season.

DES MOINES. WITH one ear still cocked toward Washington, and with the other catching the national echoes of the rioting at Le Mars, the American farmer is dropping his seed into the ground, that the Republic may eat in 1934.

Holdings of Erie Railroad stock on March 11 by the First National Bank interests had declined 4,900 shares from the total held on March 12, 1932, according to the report filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission. Other large interests in the Erie were for the most part unchanged.

ROME, May 5. -- Never before have Italians been so conscious of being descendants of the ancient Romans as they are today. Not the least of the effects of the spiritual revolution achieved by fascism, along with the material revolution, is the reawakening of the Italians' pride of race.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP). -- Administration leaders predicted tonight that the farm relief bill, with its inflation and mortgage financing additions intact, would be in President Roosevelt's hands for approval late Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP). -- Pennsylvania won its battle today against Ohio restoration of a longstanding differential on coal rates to Northeastern Ohio between shipments from the Pittsburgh and the Eastern Ohio districts.

A study of Hebrew chronological tables convinced Archbishop USSHER that the earth was created in 4004 B.C. Not to be outdone in exactness, a ribald commentator remarked that the time must have been 4 A.M. Now comes a committee of the National Academy of Sciences with the latest of its annual reports to assure us that the age of the earth is of the order of 2,000 million years.
PARIS, May 6 (AP). -- The Bourse was closed today. Following the regular custom it will remain closed on Saturdays during the Summer.

AKRON, Ohio, May 6. -- Seven members of the Joint Congressional Committee investigating the naval airship Akron's crash arrived in Akron today for an inspection of the ill-fated ship's new twin sister, the Macon.
WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 4:

ROME. IN the Middle Ages the pilgrims who traveled to Rome to benefit by the special Holy Year indulgences conceded by the Popes undertook a difficult Journey. Means of transportation were almost entirely lacking and all but the wealthy had to come the whole distance on foot.

Miss Helen Hicks of Inwood, former holder of the women's national title, and Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches are placed at scratch on the 1933 handicap list released yesterday by Mrs. A.G. Hupfel, handicap chairman of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

PARIS, May 6. -- Former Premier Herriot today gave Premier Daladier and President Lebrun a full verbal account of his visit to Washington, supplemented by a voluminous written report covering the whole field of the economic conversations there.

REVAL-TALLINN, Estonia. ONE of the interesting musical events of the coming Summer in Europe will be the Estonia Song Festival -- Laulu Pidu -- in Reval-Tallinn, the capital of the young Baltic republic, on June 23 to June 27.

An increase in the number of jobs obtainable for unemployed men quartered at Gold Dust Lodge, the Salvation Army shelter at 40 Corlears Street, was reported yesterday by Adjutant Andrew Laurie, the superintendent, on the basis of placements last week.
WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

The attention of many persons in society here is directed this week to the first two royal courts in Buckingham Palace, London, on Thursday and Friday. At each of these traditional and glamourous functions, eight American women will be presented to their Majesties King George and Queen Mary, who at the same time will receive many debutantes of the London season and other women of prominence in London society and court circles.

ONCE again a daring theft has startled the world of art. This time the Brooklyn Museum was the victim of wholesale plunder, ten notable paintings having been taken from a fourth-floor gallery at night, and now museum authorities all over the country are concerned with the problem of throwing additional safeguards around their collections.

After having been missing for 165 years, the petition that led to the establishment of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University has come to light in a mass of pre-Revolutionary material recently discovered in the Columbia University vaults.

Parts of several foreign bond issues composed the largest part of the announcements made last week of bonds to be retired before maturity. The calls were principally for payment in future months, but three small lots were added to the list for May.
ROME, May 6. -- What little is known here of the conversations between President Roosevelt and Signor Jung has caused much satisfaction in Italy.

An increase of $6,901,216,655 in the market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange occurred in April, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by the Exchange. This was the largest gain for any month since August, 1932, when the increase was $7,287,742,341.

June garden roses, technically known as hybrid perpetuals, are well adapted for planting in the home garden. Only a few years ago they were considered the most important class of roses, but have recently been overshadowed by the ever-blooming hybrid tea roses.

KIEV, Russia, April 25. -- In Moscow it was said that Kiev was suffering most from the food shortage of all the great Russian cities and that there was considerable unemployment there. This may have been true a month or six weeks ago -- in fact, a local official virtually admitted as much -- but it is not true now.

A PLAN to bring the beauty of Riverside Drive Park and Garden Court apartments to the slum sections of Manhattan was presented by Andrew J. Thomas, architect, at a special meeting of the East Side Chamber of Commerce Thursday evening.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 4. -- Oregon, Washington and Idaho will be major beneficiaries of the great Columbia River development selected by President Roosevelt with the St. Lawrence and Muscle Shoals projects as the three most important waterway undertaking for the future of the United States.

MEXICO CITY, May 6. -- The United States Davis Cup team, headed by Wilmer Allison, second ranking player of his country, clinched its series with Mexico today when John Van Ryn and George M. Lott Jr. scored a victory in the doubles over the veteran, Alfpnso Unda, and the young lawyer, Eduardo Mestre, by scores of 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1 and 7 -- 5.

LOS ANGELES, May 6 (AP). -- In a dual meet which resulted in one world's record being eclipsed and another tied, the University of Southern California Track and Field team gained revenge over Stanford today, defeating the Indians by 72 to 58 before 10,000 persons.

BOSTON, May 4. -- The Rhode Island General Assembly ended its annual session after midnight on the morning of April 21, leaving undone much important work. At a special election last Monday the people expressed their will upon two matters of much moment which their legislators had referred to them -- the $3,000,000 bond issue for unemployment relief and the verdict of the State on the amendment for the repeal of prohibition.
HARWICHPORT, Mass., May 6. -- General Daniel Needham, State Commissioner of Public Safety, late today gave out the following account of Kenneth Buck's confession of the kidnapping of Margaret McMath:

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial, "Erica," recalls an equally illuminating one which appeared a few years ago under the same caption, and in which were these words: "Some one has whimsically suggested that the northern threshold of the Western Hemisphere, which was first crossed by Leif Ericsson (nicknamed Leif the Lucky, son of Eric the Red), might well be called Erica."

BASLE, May 5. -- The Bank for International Settlements will assemble Monday in circumstances that its farsighted founders never dreamed would confront the instiution, at least in their lifetime, let alone in three years.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 6. -- Blue-water sailors, or the yachtsmen who head off shore and stay there, gathered today at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. It was the annual Spring rendezvous of the Cruising Club of America.

CHICAGO, May 6. -- Uneasiness by local, Eastern and scattered longs over what President Roosevelt might say in his broadcast tomorrow night, and rumors from Paris via London that France might go off the gold standard over the week-end, caused heavy profit-taking and week-end evening-up today on the Board of Trade.

The "slight but definite upturn" which President Roosevelt told the Chamber of Commerce of the United States had been felt in most industries during the last few weeks apparently has already been reflected in the unemployment relief situation in many parts of the country, according to a survey by The Associated Press.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 6. -- Cornell's track and field forces swept to victory over Colgate and Syracuse on a rain and wind swept track today, scoring 90 points to 24 1/2 for the Maroon and 20 1/2 for the Orange.

WASHINGTON. THE administration economy plan which, among other things, apparently precludes future Assistant Secretaries for Air in the War and Navy Departments, not to mention reduction in officer personnel and complete elimination of officers who have "grown old" in the "young" air services, has thrown an atmosphere of discouragement around the two air services.
The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange decreased 49,544 shares to 1,415,330 shares in the four weeks between April 3 and May 1, it was announced yesterday.

PARIS, May 5. -- Mme. France, who used to be a revolutionary, is just now regarding the world from the window with something of consternation. The old lady is disturbed by the rush and shouting of schoolboys in the street.
THE disconsolate Miniver Cheevy, who "mourned Romance, now on the town, and Art a Vagrant," might be less gloomy in New York these days.

ONE Winter's evening more than forty years ago it was my privilege to witness at the famous old Berlin Singakademie a scene that stands out in bold relief among my musical recollections covering half a century.

THE American reader of Mr. Freeman's new novel must bear in mind the deeply rooted English tradition of life on the land, of ownership and occupancy reaching back through many generations. Thus, and thus only, can he come to a full understanding of the story of "Pond Hall's Progress" and put himself imaginatively in harmony with the book.

Prices reacted generally yesterday in the local commodity markets, all staples except silver and coffee losing ground. In most cases also trading was slower. In the cash markets, several commodities made new high prices for the year, while most of the others were firm.

COTTON days are here again! It is good news for many reasons. Economy is one of them, but we have heard so much about economy that it has almost lost its news value. Beauty is another, and, to our way of thinking, more important.

Prints by Durer, Rembrandt and Whistler will be included in an auction sale to be held at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Friday evening. The sale will comprise the collection of Mrs. L.F. East on of La Crosse, Wis., selections from the collections of Mrs Ira Davenport and Alexander M. Hudnut of this city and from the estate of the late Willis Vickery of Cleveland, Ohio.

The Royal Scot, one of Europe's finest railroad trains, which holds several non-stop records between London, Glasgow and Edinburgh, will be exhibited at the Grand Central Terminal next Friday, and at the Pennsylvania Station on Saturday.

Reconciled to the passage of the farm, bill in its present form, processors of the raw materials involved said yesterday that their main concern was over the administration of the act and the amount of the tax which is likely to be imposed.

MOST industries are recognized by their sounds; the steel mill has its crashing anthem, the motor works its roar, the shoe factory its whirring song. But in the brewery the nostrils rather than the ears are assailed.

The five-man team of the Fort George Horseshoe Club traveled from Washington Heights yesterday to the Bronx and administered an overwhelming defeat to the horseshoe pitching team of the emergency crew at the Bronx Park police station on their home grounds.

TIENTSIN, May 6. -- The North China situation has been further entangled by the action of Ho Yingching, the War Minister, in removing an entire division -- five trainloads -- of Chinese troops from the Lwan River region to the area north of Peiping, where Japanese advances in the vicinity of Nantienmen and Miyun threaten the routes to Peiping.

J.H. Kretchman of Hamilton, Ont., won the twenty-eighth annual national amateur clay target championship over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday, breaking 192 out of 200 targets.

ONE of the most ardent of pedestrians, Dr. John H. Finley, who has also taken many times to wings, pays tribute to the high calibre of airline pilots. His most recent trip across the continent and back was made to deliver the Charter Day address at the University of California at Los Angeles.
