The major activities of leading trade associations during a period of the most depressed business conditions the country has ever experienced were outlined during the week, in the annual competition of the American Trade Association Executives, which was won by the Cotton-Textile Institute, Inc., of which George A. Sloan is president.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 6. -- Racing on the Severn today for the first time since 1897, Cornell lost to the Navy's varsity crew by a quarter of a length. The midshipmen covered the mile and a half in 7 minutes 38 seconds and Cornell was timed just a second slower.

IN history an in daily life, it is the dramatic which captivates attention and imagination. Perhaps the principal reason why the Byzantine Empire has been regarded with indifference tinged by contempt is that its best qualities were the undramatic ones of a conservator.

FOR God's sake, a pot of small ale!" bawls Christopher Sly in the seldom performed Induction to "The Taming of the Shrew"; nor could the practical jokers' "twenty caged nightingales," singing never so sweetly, quite persuade Christopher Sly that he had been suddenly transformed into a noble lord.

WOODS HOLE, Mass., May 6. -- Life became a strange nightmare to little Margaret (Peggy) McMath from the time she was kidnapped from school at Harwichport last Tuesday afternoon until she was returned to her father early Friday morning.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6. -- E.R. Bradley scored his fourth victory and his second in succession in the Kentucky Derby when his Broker's Tip won by a nose in a driving finish with Mrs. Silas B. Mason's Head Play before 40,000 persons at Churchill Downs today.

EXPERIMENTS are under way on a new plan for blind landing by the Sperry Gyroscope Company and Eastern Air Transport, employing the radio beam, locator horns and small floodlights in a sort of triple-check system to bring the pilot in safety to a hidden runway.

CHICAGO, May 6. -- With the opening of the World's Fair still three weeks away, the exposition grounds presented today a picture of much activity, with throngs of visitors inspecting the sprawling building's which have sprung up like flowers after a Spring rain.
Formation of a definite scheme for the laying up or scrapping of vessels is being urged in London by a deputation from the Baltic and International Maritime Conference.

LONDON. THE first of the season's five courts is to be held at Buckingham Palace next Thursday evening. Not since 1930 have five courts been held. Ordinarily two are held in May and two in June, but this season there are to be two this week, two next week and a fifth on June 23.

THE most impressive item picked up along the Spring highways of the Rialto concerns George S. Kaufman and Alexander Woollcott. They are at it again, or they will be at it again during the Summer. The proposal now is for a collaboration on a new play, the design being original.
NEW YORK. Major Sir William Cope of London arrived on the Aquitania and is at the Plaza.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The action of the United States on gold, slow demand here for Japanese products, particularly silk, and threatened tariff increases in British India, present a less favorable outlook for Japan's future export trade, the Department of Commerce said today.

CHICAGO, May 6. -- The robot airplane pilot has been perfected so that it actually flies an airplane, according to P.G. Johnson, president of United Air Lines, who said today that the instrument was being installed on the sixty new Boeing high-speed transport planes which are being placed in service on the line.

About 500 Communists in buses, trucks and private automobiles left Union Square shortly before 6 P.M. last night for Washington, where tomorrow they hope to present to President Roosevelt and Congress a "Bill of Civil Rights," designed to put teeth into the enforcement of the thirteenth, fourteenth and fifteenth amendments to the Constitution.

Six orphan boys who saved 500 commuters from death or serious injury last Wednesday night by flagging an Erie express train at Passaic, N.J., during a storm, attended their first circus performance in Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon to find themselves one of its major attractions.

BALA, Pa., May 6. -- Steppin Fetchet, from Audrey's Choice Stable of Providence, R.I., won the five-gaited saddle championship of the Philadelphia Horse Show tonight. G. Berry Beaumont's Beau Twigg took the reserve in the $500 stake event.

BOSTON, May 6. -- Lynn Nelson, rookie right-hand pitcher of the Chicago Cubs, was the star today as the National League champions came through in the thirteenth inning to defeat the Braves, 9 to 6. It was the second extra-inning contest between the teams in as many days, Boston winning in eleven frames yesterday.

The teachers in Chicago who had shown such patience for months can hardly have bettered their cause by the unseemly demonstration they have made in desperation. The whole country has been in sympathy with them in their unhappy plight. They have made extreme sacrifices that children might not suffer even if the public failed to do its part.

WHEN the broadcasters realized back in 1922 that radio showmanship was a business and not a philanthropic endeavor, they began to seek a source of revenue. Numerous panaceas were proposed. There were suggestions that listeners be taxed.

LONDON, May 6. -- After he had packed his bags to go to Geneva, Norman H. Davis, President Roosevelt's special Ambassador, received new instructions today to stay in London and do his atmost to impel Great Britain to agree to an immediate tariff truce.

OLAN NOR, Inner Mongolia. AOUND their yurt fires the Mongols are pondering gravely and with not a little worry the effect on their destiny of the unsolved problems confronting China and Japan and the nations of the West which have political, commercial and territorial stakes in the Far Cast and especially in Chinese Central Asia.

ST. LOUIS, May 6 (AP). -- Lefty Grove, pitching ace of the Philadelphia Athletics, was knocked out of the box today by the St. Louis Browns, but the Mackmen piled up four runs in the third inning and won, 8 to 6.

LONDON, April 24. -- Carlyle's old house in Cheyne-row, Chelsea, where the author of "Sartor Resartus" and "Hero Worship" lived for nearly fifty years, is in need of an endowment fund to put its permanent maintenance beyond anxiety.

FOLLOWING a business at the last week-end which was reported as the best since Christmas, retail volume during the week again exceeded the figures of a year ago on several days. Seasonal merchandise lines were active, but there was a brisk demand also on Summer goods.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Reason and common sense having waged a hopeless struggle against this rank insanity of armaments, the thought has occurred to me that a proportionately insane solution might reveal itself as the right remedy.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 6. -- Boston University bunched eight hits off Sullivan and Sweeney, Brown pitchers, in two innings today and defeated the Bears, 7 to 1. Corson limited Brown to six hits, two being made by pinch hitters.

WHEN the moving pictures were still dumb Charlie Chaplin could make the whole world rock with his antics in the "Gold Rush." Then came the first American talkies. Although Frenchmen and Italians flocked to hear Al Jolson in the "Singing Fool," it was purely out of curiosity.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 6. -- The State Milk Control Board announced today that it would act next week to establish by zones the minimum prices to be paid to producers for milk and cream. This move was designed to stave off the threatened State-wide milk strike, tentatively set for the latter part of the week.

STOCKHOLM, April 15. WITH its production of "Mourning Becomes Electra," the Royal Dramatic Theatre here in Stockholm scores another triumph of an unusually lustrous season now soon drawing to a close.

CAMP PHARI, Tibet. -- The news that his Holiness, the Dalai Lama, had at last sanctioned a renewal of the attempts on Mount Everest was as welcome as unexpected, and by the end of August last year the Mount Everest Committee was hard at work with preparations.

HANOVER, N.H., May 6. -- Bob Miller, Dartmouth pitcher, was ineffective today and Yale gained a six-run lead in the first inning, which enabled the Blue to defeat Dartmouth, 9 to 4 in an Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball game.

GENEVA, April 19. -- The depression has caused all previous records in arrears to the League of Nations to be broken now by millions instead of hundreds of thousands. The latest figures show that on March 31 twenty-six member States, or nearly half, were behind in their dues to the League for a total of 23,613,589 gold francs, or $5,062,753.

A comprehensive plan which involves the quick selling at low prices of the home properties in Bergen County, N.J., which have been taken over in foreclosure proceedings by the United States Agency, the holding corporation for the United States Mortgage and Title Company, has been perfected by the agency officials in cooperation with more than 150 real estate brokers in all parts of Bergen County.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 6. -- Using many of last season's outstanding football players, headed by Summerfelt, Pottenger and Lincoln, the Army lacrosse team today defeated Yale, 6 to 3. The visitors led throughout, although a strong defense held West Point to a single goal at the intermission.

EXETER, N.H., May 6. -- The Exeter track team scored a 74 1/2-to52 1/2 victory over the New Hampshire freshmen in its first dual meet of the outdoor season today. Hamelin Turner of Great Neck, L.I., established a new Exeter shot-put record of 52 feet 6 inches.

RECENT events have drawn attention to the sanitation problems of the city. The most important was the abolition of the commission of three which was originally created to manage the Department of Sanitlion and the appointment of George McAneny to be head of that important branch of the municipal government.

Stephen P. Duggan, director of the Institute of International Education, announced yesterday a list of fourty-four appointments of American students for study in France during the academic year of 1933-34.

Edward J. Fenlon, Ph.D., in a letter to THE SUNDAY TIMES, voices objection to the space and emphasis given Dr. George W. Crile's paper. He cites men prominent in science and philosophy who have held views similar to the doctor's on mind and sensation, and he repudiates his claim that his so-called dynamos are generators of mind.

WHEN the bottom dropped out of the aircraft market early in 1929 -- to remain out for the next three years, and perhaps four -- the builders who were able to stay in business turned their engineers and designers loose on their own and announced that this "period will be devoted to development and engineering."

PRINCETON, N.J., May 6. -- The Princeton varsity and junior varsity rugby fifteens conquered the first and second teams of the New York Rugby Club on rain-soaked Poe Field today. The Tiger varsity triumphed by 11 -- 0 and the jayvees blanked the visitors. 3 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- A retail credit survey by the Department of Commerce for the period from July to December, 1932, made public today, showed that sales by 415 reporting stores had dropped to $509,125,548, a decline of 23.9 per cent in dollar volume as compared with the corresponding months in 1931.

To the Music Editor: In regard to the letter of Mr. J. Horace McFarland printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES Sunday, April 30, under the caption "Music in Harrisburg, Pa.," I wish to point out that Mr. McFarland neglects to mention the Harrisburg Symphony Orchestra, of which I am the conductor, and without which "Music in Harrisburg, Pa.," can hardly be discussed.

In behalf of the recently organized woman's committee of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, a reception will be given on Tuesday afternoon at the home of Mrs. J. Frederick Talcott, 16 East Sixty-sixth Street. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt is honorary chairman of the committee and Mrs. Ancell H. Ball is chairman, assisted by Miss Louise G. Zabriskie.

A movement to compel international consideration and relief of the problems facing the persecuted Jews in Germany received impetus last night when the American branch of the Jewish Agency for Palestine adopted a resolution calling for the creation of a commission of the League of Nations to finance and execute a plan for the colonization of Palestine by expatriated Jews.

BROADCASTERS are likely to err if they put a prominent person on the radio chiefly because of his name. And these speakers find themselves beset with various problems because they are too busy to prepare properly their broadcast speech, according to Virginia S. Sanderson of Ohio State University in discussing "Civil Government for Schools" at the recent meeting of the Institute for Education by Radio.

ST. LOUIS, May 4. -- The soft-coal regions of South Illinois, embraced in a half-dozen or more counties within a radius of 125 miles of St. Louis, have been the scene of bitter conflict between miners' groups since last August and accumulating violence indicates that the situation is one that may well be regarded as of major interest to Governor Horner of Illinois.

Yachtsmen will follow with interest the 12-meter situation that develops in Norway this Summer during the golden jubilee regatta of the Royal Norwegian Yacht Club. This is because of the arrangements to hold an international regatta for the sloops on this side of the Atlantic next year, with the prize the new trophy of the North American Yacht Racing Union.

Marked headway in merchant cooperation has been made in Louisville, Ky., in the comparatively short period in which unified action by retailers on major questions has been taken, it was reported yesterday by Harry W. Schacter, president of the Kaufman-Straus Company, Inc., of that city.

LONDON, May 5. -- Cooperation, not conversation, is what people here desire with the United States. Hence Prime Minister MacDonald's statement of the results of his visit in Washington leaves the public un- satisfied.

WHITE PLAINS, May 6. -- Remarks made during the week by Mrs. Eugene Meyer, chairman of the Westchester County Recreation Commission, and by others connected with her organization, indicate that there will be firm opposition to any recommendations by the Board of Supervisors to abolish the commission.

AFTER a brief vacation at his home in Cannes, Maurice Chevalier has returned to New York. In a few days he will be joined by Norman Taurog and Gene Fowler, who are plotting a new picture for the cheery Frenchman.

PARIS, May 4. -- The Paris midseason showings continue to approve the nonchalant mode with loose swagger coats for all hours. They range from barely hipbone-length ones chez Maggy Rouff to Lanvin's full-length but long slender belted coats; many houses show them with afternoon ensembles.

BUFFALO, May 4. -- The tax rate of the city of Buffalo for the fiscal year 1933-34 will be the lowest that has been levied since 1909-10. The actual figure is $20.47 per $1,000 of valuation. Rates in other recent years have been: 1932-33, $23,62; 1931-32, $27.94; 1930-31, $29.40; 1929-30, $29.40, and 1928-29, $26.30.

The question of whether New York's three city-supported colleges, Hunter, the City and Brooklyn, shall hold their regular Summer sessions this year on funds saved by the Board of Higher Education is now before the Board of Estimate.

Many pastors will preach today on some of the national questions arising from the depression for which solutions are being sought at Washington. "Life Service Sunday" will be observed in many churches. A few Presbyterians are expected to touch on the resignation of Mrs. Pearl M. Buck as a missionary in China.

CHICAGO, May 6. -- Increasing opposition to the proposed national farm strike is developing throughout the nation's agricultural area, Edward A. O'Neal, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, reported today in disclosing results of a survey.
AURORA, Ill., May 6 (AP). -- Regulars at Exposition Park have been heartened by the fact that only six favorites have run out of the money in the Aurora mud all week long, and today was no exception.

ALBERT SPALDING, violinist, will be soloist at the annual Westchester County Music Festival to take place May 19 at the County Centre, White Plains. He will play works of Veracini, Beethoven, Bach, Debussy and Szymanowski.

JANE JONES was in that stage of development which often causes so much acute agony to the grown-up looking on from outside, who perceives only too clearly the physical and mental awkwardness of a young girl at the age when she is no longer a child to roll on the grass and climb trees and is not yet a grown person to be accepted into maturer circles.

About $3,000,000 in beer taxes were collected in New York City during the first month after the sale of 3.2 beer was legalized, according to figures issued yesterday by Julius Liebman, president of the New York State Brewers Association.

1896 and 1933. ALLAN NEVINS'S life of GROVER CLEVELAND, which is this year's Pulitzer Prize biography, has today a double timeliness. It is timely in the sense that every fine piece of work has permanent relevance and value.

In aid of the National Hospital for Speech Disorders a duplicate bridge party will take place tomorrow night at the Ambassador. Many bridge experts have promised to take part in the exhibition play which will be a feature of the evening.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Statistical data covering the week ended on April 29, assembled by the Commerce Department, show further progress in productive activity, featured by another sharp rise in steel ingot production. Automobile production moved upward and the estimates for the week indicate that not only the output in April was substantially in excess of that in March but also was larger than a year ago.

THIS is the second issue of the "Social Work Year Book," the first having appeared in 1929. Future editions, it is planned, will appear at intervals of two or three years, as need for them develops and conditions warrant. This second issue in considerably larger than was the first and contains changes and additions that increase its value.

THE Municipal Art Commission, which again appeared before the public recently by calling illegal the city's project of turning the site of the lower reservoir in Central Park into an athletic field without first obtaining its approval, is the first guardian of the city's esthetic appearance.

NATURE took a hand in celebrating Irvin S. Cobb's return to the air last Wednesday night. As the zero hour approached for the wit of Paducah to actuate the microphone the skies became darker and the lightning played a static Spring song in the clouds.

New York and Brooklyn department store newspaper advertising during April totaled 2,851,519 lines, an increase of 3.7 per cent over the total of 2,749,060 lines in the same month a year ago, according to Media Records, Inc. The figure also represents an increase of 6.8 per cent over the total of 2,669,224 lines in March, with the later data of Easter being an important factor in this comparison.

THE centenary of the hansom cab will be celebrated this Summer at York, England. Joseph Aloysius Hansom, the man in whose fertile mind the idea of the vehicle germinated, was born at York in 1803. His design for what he called his "Patent Safety Cab" brought him u10,000.

AMERICA'S total burden of long-term debt is probably about $134,000,000,000 -- something more than one-third of the country's estimated total wealth instead of about two-thirds, as some pessimistic calculators have put it. Such is the conclusion which emerges from the survey of debts versus income in the United States just completed by the Twentieth Century Fund under Evans Clark, director of the fund, assisted by George B. Galloway.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of April 30 G.J. Drolet, statistician for the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, makes some startling statements concerning the great increase (58 per cent) in diabetes mortality in the past thirty years.

WHAT happened in later years to those whom Jesus Christ raised from the dead? Did they grow old and die, or did they live on, always young, untouched by time and decay, never to pass again through these dark portals from which they had once emerged?

GENEVA, May 6. -- The League of Nations Advisory Committee on the Leticia conflict decided this morning to ask Peru what her intentions had been in sending a cruiser and two submarines through the Panama Canal into the Caribbean Sea.

Relics of the days of New York's volunteer fire companies have been placed on exhibition by the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West. They include minature models of the types of engines, hose-carts, trucks and other apparatus used in early days.
BERLIN, May 6 (AP). -- Former Chancellor Heinrich Bruening surprised political circles today by starting his political comeback by being chosen chairman of the Catholic Centre party.
WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Irving H. Hoover, known familiarly to thousands of statesmen as "Ike" Hoover, celebrated today his fortysecond year of service at the White House, where he is now chief usher.

BOSTON, May 5. ACCORDING to precedent, the Spring season proceeds briskly and is far from end. Before it is half done "Of Thee I Sing" will have made the longest run of the theatre year. True, only four weeks, but a month in these days and in this town signifies. . . .

BERLIN, May 5. -- The complaint that the American consulate in Berlin failed to afford protection to American citizens agaist Nazi persecution, as made through the American Jewish Congress in New York by Alexander Adler and Maurice L. Saunders does not accord with the facts in the case as they are known here.

LONDON, May 6 (AP). -- The Winter League soccer season came to a close today with little interest in the final matches, as nearly all the places previously had heen decided and the day's contests merely completed the schedule.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 6 (AP). -- Miss Helen Jacobs, United States tennis champion who hopes to add both the French and Wimbledon titles to her collection this year, started her European invasion rather inauspiciously as she lost today to Miss Dorothy Round, England's second ranking player, in the final of the British hard court championship.

The order of Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler on the application of George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, to liquidate the Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company, by which the court directs that a workable plan be submitted within fifteen days by the company showing that it can be rehabilitated was filed yesterday in the County Clerk's office.

THE four papers in this volume were presented by Mr. Drinkwater last November before the Institute of Arts and Sciences, Columbia University. They are all linked closely together and as a whole make a survey of the modern turbulent world from the author's personal viewpoint, and present, interwoven with the survey, his credo concerning its significance and its possible future.
The fly fisherman will come into his own within a short time in the Eastern section. Warmer weather is bringing forth hatches of flies and soon the bait fishermen will be pushed aside.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP). -- Wirt Franklin, president of the Independent Petroleum Association of America, issued tonight a statement asserting that the petroleum industry had lined up "with practical unanimity" in support of proposed legislation to create a Federal control over the oil business.
CHICAGO, May 6. -- Can any one use Millie, the mule, to whose sterling performances grand opera patrons have thrilled for twelve years and more?

IT is a custom in the united States for each new administration to make radical changes in the nation's diplomatic personnel abroad. The custom has been followed by President Roosevelt. At the same time two great European countries, Germany and France, have chosen the occasion of a shift from one administration to another for appointing new Ambassadors to Washington.

Now that our bonds, along with our currency, have been detached from, a gold basis, the question arises: Will our corporations and municipalities return to the practice of issuing gold obligations? The preponderance of opinion at the moment is that they will not.

The three men rearrested for malicious mischief Friday night, after their acquittal in Bronx Special Sessions on charges of conspiracy to coerce resulting from an investigation of racketeering in the poultry business, appeared yesterday before Magistrate Klapp in Morrisania Court and were freed in bail of $1,000 each for a hearing Tuesday.

Failures in the lives of physicians and other professional men have been the result in many cases of their inability to handle accounts of their clients, and the "sucker lists" of brokerage concerns show a preponderance of professional men because they lack adequate knowledge of business procedures, Dr. Joseph C. Myer, retiring president of the Commercial Education Association, told the annual Spring conference of the organization yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

LONDON, May 6. -- The dollar continued downward in the foreignexchange market today. The rate on New York opened at $3.99 to the pound, compared with yesterday's closing at $3.98, but in subsequent dealings renewed selling developed and the rate weakened to $4.05, the lowest since Great Britain left the gold standard.

WASHINGTON. THE action of the Senate in attaching the Thomas inflation amendment to the farm relief bill as a rider has served to revive controversy over the wisdom of this form of legislative procedure.

CHICAGO, May 4. -- The wishful whistling of the optimist has been heard so frequently in the last three years, and with so little justifying reason that the public is inclined to be skeptical of any portents upon which the unconquerable spirit of hope attempts to base prediction, of improving times.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- President Roosevelt will not transmit to Congress in the near future any message relating to war debts, but will await the completion of the pending administration programs before making any request, should he finally decide to do so, regarding European obligations to the United States.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 6. -- The first of a aeries of garden days opened yesterday for the benefit of the Westchester County Children's Association, and the Westchester Society for the Prevention or Cruelty to Children.

ALBANY, May 6. -- Governor Lehman today vetoed three bills, of which one was introduced by Senator Burchill and two by Senator McNaboe, to prevent any corporation, subject to the general corporation law and the banking law, from acting as receivers in bankruptcy, trustees or custodians.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Days of sneezing and wheezing and sleepless nights will be ended or relieved, for sufferers from pollen hay fever and pollen asthma, if they can afford air-conditioning apparatus for their homes and offices, according to a report made today by Dr. Leslie N. Gay of Johns Hopkins University before the Society for the Study of Hay Fever and Asthma.

VIENNA, May 6. -- Chancellor Dollfuss and War Minister Vaugoin arrived at Salzburg today for the Christian Socialist Party rally. They were greeted with showers of stones thrown against their train by Nazis resentful over the order yesterday against the wearing of Hitlerite uniforms.

DETROIT, May 6 (AP). -- Earl Whitehall, late of the Tigers, and Carl Fischer, a former Senator, met today in their first game against their old team-mates and Whitehill won, pitching Washington to a 6-to-2 victory over Detroit.

As an aid to the understanding of the art, culture and home life of European peoples, exhibitions of handicraft are increasing in popularity. In spite of modern industrialism, there are still many country folk who keep alive the age-old crafts.

LONDON. RICHARD SUNNE has been expressing his surprise that Agnes Repplier. "most fascinating of Philadelphians," is apparently little known in England today. When Sinclair Lewis was awarded the Nobel Prize, he protested -- so he tells us in Time and Tide -- that, if it was thought necessary to give it to an American, there was Agnes Repplier.

EACH year there are fewer countries that have not been brilliantly audited by Andre Siegfried. In this skillful and informing book he adds a whole new continent to the earlier panels of his screen of civilization. The day when he must weep like Alexander begins to loom just as he is reaching the perfection of his technique.

TWO years ago the author or this small but effective volume created a stir in financial circles by making an extremely gloomy prognosis of the financial situation in Europe and predicting three calamitous events without which, he stated, the world crisis could not end.

HAD the Titanic been equipped with the "fog-eye" that Commander Paul H. Macneil demonstrated on the Queen of Bermuda recently one of the most appalling marine disasters of history would have been averted. The instrument is all that its name implies.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 29 amounted to 535,676 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 42,706 cars, or 8.7 per cent, more than for the preceding week, but 18,521 cars, or 3.3 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 239.066 cars, or 30.9 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

THE sound concentrator microphone has made its appearance in Hollywood as one of the newest aids to the making of talking pictures. It looks like a big saucer. About three feet in diameter, its centre holds an especially sensitive microphone.

WHEN the Theatre Guild unveils "The Mask and the Face," which W. Somerset Maugham has done into English from the Italian of Luigi Chiarelli, tomorrow night at the Guild Theatre, the occasion will have about it the golden glow of a jubilee.

The next week-end sees the continuation in rowing of the newest of the sport's regattas, the MidAmerican crew races at Marietta, Ohio. This is the third annual program and brings together this season the varsity and junior varsity crews of Marietta College and Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

The Junior League of New York will be represented by Mrs. Lewis L. Delafield Jr. and Mrs. Oswald B. Lord at the annual conference of the Junior Leagues of America to be held May 15-19, inclusive, in Philadelphia. Owen D. Young will be the principal speaker at the opening dinner on May 15 at the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel there.

RADIO has changed the art of public speaking in the past decade. The old approved style of platform oratory in vogue at the opening of the century and later has given way to a more intimate, conversational manner of delivery and the microphone has played an important part in this new fashion in speech.

Eighty-one promotions in the City College R.O.T.C. unit were announced yesterday by Colonel George Chase Lewis, Professor of Military Science and Tactics. Austin J. Bonis, who last year held the Naumberg Scholarship for Foreign Study, was named Cadet Colonel.

THAT most valuable reference book of the stage -- John Parker's "Who's Who in the Theatre" -- has just come out in its seventh edition and in 1,890 pages. It contains biographical material of every one of any note here and in England, and its accuracy may be shown by the fact that the material in question was submitted to all of the subjects whose addresses could be found.

NINO MARTINI, Italian tenor, steps from the radio studio to the Metropolitan Opera, thereby reversing the path of the majority who up to now have traveled from the opera, concert or theatrical stage to the domain of the microphone.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP). -- President Roosevelt and spokesmen of European war debtors were said in high quarters tonight to be unagreed on the issue of relief, and what steps the Chief Executive will recommend to Congress remained highly problematical.
FOUR men were seated at the luncheon table yesterday. Along came another fellow who paused long enough to say:

NORWALK, Conn., May 6. -- The Rev. Dr. August Field Beard will be 100 years old Thursday. He is the oldest living graduate of Yale University and of Union Theological Seminary, and the oldest living clergyman of the Congregational denomination.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 6. -- The Hill School team captured the thirty-seventh annual Princeton University interscholastic track and field meet for the fourth consecutive year in Palmer Memorial Stadium today. The Pottstown (Pa.) squad amassed 40 points, 3 1/2 more than Newark Prep. Mercersburg and St. Benedict's Prep. tied for third with 25.

The 1933 Legislature passed, and Governor Lehman subsequently approved, a measure empowering the City of New York to condemn the area necessary to open Exterior Street, between 144th and 146th Streets, in the Borough of the Bronx, through the property owned by the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company.

HARBIN, Manchuria, May 6. -- The latest note of Li Shao-ken, Manchukuoan chairman of the board of the Chinese Eastern Railway, to S.M. Kuznetsoff, Soviet vice chairman of the board, is milder in tone than Mr. Li's previous notes.

Morris Ziferblatt, an elderly baker, of 1,494 Crotona Parkway East, the Bronx, appeared as complainant in the Tombs Court yesterday against William Cuban, 50 years old, a cloak operator, of 1,144 Tinton Avenue, the Bronx, in one of the most unusual charges ever to come before Magistrate Aurelio.

The policy of President Roosevelt in regard to women in the diplomatic and consular services is to treat them as equal to men, Mrs., Ruth Bryan Owen, Minister to Denmark, indicated yesterday at a luncheon given in her honor by the American-Scandinavian Foundation at its quarters, 116 East Sixtyfourth Street.

WASHINGTON. WHEREVER you go in Washington today you come upon crowds of people. All day they wait in long queues outside the public galleries of Congress. Or they huddle in little groups in the corridors of the Capitol, in the corridors of the State Department, in the White House waiting rooms, around oddly casual dining rooms, in the milling lobbies of hotels.

With a heavy rain falling all through the meet, piling the water inches deep on the cinder path and making the jumping and throwing pits for the field events dangerously slippery, Temple University conquered City College in their annual dual meet at the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday, 90 -- 36.

Reorganization plans for the Missouri Pacific Railroad were laid before the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in a preliminary discussion in Washington, according to a dispatch to Dow, Jones Co. yesterday.

BERLIN, May 6. -- Dr. Heinrich Bruening, former Chancellor, was chosen leader of the Centre party by its executive committee today in place of the prelate. Dr. Ludwig Kaas, who has retired from politics.

The unconfirmed report that President Roosevelt may visit London during the World Economic Conference turns the mind bachward to the last time an American President took part in international discussions abroad.

THERE is something oddly anachronistic about this volume of short stories by the prolific Mr. Phillpotts. His tales of Dartmoor yokels belong to another, and simpler, age than that of Hemingway. Kay Boyle and William Faulkner.

THE author of this book has chosen to tell the story of the Northmen by portraying some of the dominant individuals of that race during the most adventurous period of its existence. He begins with Snorri Sturlasoh, who was not an adventurer in the accepted meaning of the term, but whose sagas are the sources of much of our information concerning the heroes of the North.

In an effort to relieve communities throughout the country which find themselves in straitened financial circumstances because of emergency relief payments made to their citizenry and the slowness of tax collections, the United States Conference of Mayors has presented to Congress a petition asking that the leading powers of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation be broadened, according to advices received yesterday by municipal bankers here.

VOLUMES have been written about the Bronte family, and about Charlotte especially. From the "Life" of Charlotte by Mrs. Gaskell down to the present day, biography after biography, has issued from the press.

VOLUMES have been written about the Bronte family, and about Charlotte especially. From the "Life" of Charlotte by Mrs. Gaskell down to the present day, biography after biography, has issued from the press.

IT is apparently becoming something of a tradition that each season the dance schedule shall be adorned with one spectacular European personality whose accomplishments abroad can reasonably be expected to elicit the enthusiasm of what is perhaps the most critical dance audience in the world.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is proposed to inflate the currency by the issue of two or three billion paper dollars, backed by government bonds, the dollars to be used for the purchase of government bonds and 4 per cent of them retired annually.

Several graduates of more than fifty years ago were present yesterday at the luncheon commemorating the diamond jubilee of Holy Cross Academy, at 343 West Fortysecond Street, which was founded by the Sisters of Charity as an academy for young girls in the Fall of 1858.

MEXICO CITY, May 6 (AP) -- Hopes that the new Vera Cruz State Legislature, which meets this month, will modify the rigid clerical law of that State has stirred the faithful throughout Mexico to efforts toward reopening of the many churches of Vera Cruz, closed now nearly two years.

MEXICO CITY, May 6 (AP) -- Hopes that the new Vera Cruz State Legislature, which meets this month, will modify the rigid clerical law of that State has stirred the faithful throughout Mexico to efforts toward reopening of the many churches of Vera Cruz, closed now nearly two years.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6. -- Cloudy skies, the threat of rain and an occasional faint sprinkle failed to dampen or dim the color of the Kentucky Derby throng here today. More statesmen and political leaders, both from Washington and State capitals, were in evidence than in recent yean, but the som -- ber blacks of frock coats were eclipsed by the gay colors of frocks and even of feminine macintoshes and umbrellas.

Men and women prominent in many walks of life gathered in the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon at a service "in grateful memory of" the Rev. Dr. Henry van Dyke, the pastor from 1883 to 1900, who died at his home in Princeton on April 10.

BERLIN, May 7 -- Industrialists and business men in Germany will not be surprised if the foreign trade statistics for April, which are now being compiled for publication on May 16, show a material drop in exports as a result of foreign reprisals against the boycotting of Jewish business establishments by the National Socialists on April 1 and the government's anti-Semitic policy in general.

Before the circus reached Gideon, there were only thirteen cannibals. Now there are fourteen and, to confound the mathematical certainties even more, Flandrin is missing out of his wagon. A search for the corpus delicti reveals a pool of fresh blood in a room and a bullet hole neatly drilled through a window.

Bigger Than Economics. Dr. HJALMAR SCHACHT, head of the German Reichsbank, who is now in this country to discuss economics with President ROOSEVELT, made a straight-from-theshoulder radio talk on landing in New York.

"The Mask and the Face," a drama adapted from the Italian of Luigi Chiarelli by W. Somerset Maugham, will be presented tonight as the fifth and final play of the season of the Theatre Guild at the Guild Theatre.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., May 7 -- His Elegance, the chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. Bernard F. Girnbel of Port Chester, and ridden by Miss Caral Gimbel, today added to the long string of victories he has scored in horse shows in the East when he carried off the championship for hunters at the third annual Lawridge Horse Show, held on the estate of Robert Law.

OAKLAND, Cal., May 7 (AP) -- The key route interurban-ferry terminal five miles out in San Francisco Bay, at the end of three miles of open trestle, was crippled by a $3,000,000 fire last night. Company officials who surveyed the damage today, however, said service would be resumed Tuesday for the system's 15,000 daily commuters.

GENEVA, May 7 -- The odd phrasing of Germany's amendments to the naval chapter of the British draft disarmament convention covers, there is reason to believe, a German plan to demand the right to build one 26,000-ton capital ship before the 1935 naval conference as a matter of equal rights in connection with the Dunkerque, which France is building against the Reich's porket battleship.

Activity in the wholesale markets last week centred on requests for Summer merchandise, with a steady stream of mail and telegraphic requisitions received in all departments. The large number of requests for Summer items exceeded anticipations.
Yesterday was a perfect Spring day, but the beach correspondents who break out in a rash of statistics about the time that forsythia breaks out in bloom, were unwilling to let it go at that.

BASLE, May 7 -- The election of Leon Fraser of the United States to the presidency of the Bank for International Settlements at the board meeting tomorrow, despite the United States being off the gold standard, was assured at the monthly meeting of the governors of central banks here this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Affirming his willingness to return to the United States should his government desire him to negotiate a future trade agreement, Dr. Tomas le Breton, Argentine Ambassador to France and special envoy to President Roosevelt's economic conversations, departed today for New York to sail Wednesday for his Paris post.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Socialist party leaders, who are the prime movers in the "continental congress" which has been in session here, initiated today a movement toward a possible coalition on certain "specific issues" with the Communist organization within the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- A surgi- cal operation on mosquitoes, so delicate that it must be performed under the microscope, is the latest step in treatment of a dreaded form of human insanity, known as paresis.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In my opinion, mortgages on properties within the greater city of New York are sound, conservative investments, and, even though put to the most severe tests, will survive if the owners and mortgagees will be reasonable and cooperate in working out the problem which mutually affects them.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The text of President Roosevelt's radio address as broadcast was as follows:
The election of 110 students by thirty Hunter College sororities was announced yesterday by Rita Warsehauer, president of the PanHellenic Association at Hunter.
NEW YORK. Dr. Fabio Lozano, Minister from Colombia to the United States, and Dr. Fabio Lozano Jr., Minister from Colombia to Mexico, are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- An attack on administration policies on the ground that nothing which has yet been done has helped to bring about economic recovery was made today by Representative Watson of Pennsylvania, member of the Ways and Means Committee.

Governor LEHMAN kept for his last vetoes the three bills making it illegal to appoint the Irving Trust Company as a receiver in bankruptcy. These measures had a powerful backing, partly disinterested and partly selfish, so that they could not be stopped in the Legislature.

PARIS, May 7 (By The Canadian Press). -- Within five weeks 3,000 Jewish refugees from Germany have sought assistance in Paris. They are of all kinds -- professors, doctors, lawyers, students, work- men -- and still they come at the rate of 200 a day.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $3,245,484,100. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

PARIS, May 7 -- A plea for budgetary balance to protect the franc and avoid the possibility of a gold embargo or inflation is made to-night by Frederic Jenny, financial editor of Le Temps. M. Jenny, one of France's important financial authorities, can be said in a case like this to speak for the Government and the Bank of France.

There will be many changes in the open seasons for hunting in New York State this Autumn. The Conservation Department has just announced a list of the more important alterations effected during the recent session of the Legislature at Albany.

With illustrations on every page and some 120 tips about golf shots and clubs, "Cut Your Score! The Book of Commonsense Golf" has Just been published by Viking. It was written by George F. Lardner and contains a foreword by Francis Ouiniet.
CHICAGO, May 7 (AP) -- The White Sox and Red Sox divided a wellplayed double-header before 20,000 fans today, the home team taking the opener, 4 to 3, and the visitors the second, 3 to 2.

The first week's operation of the new State retail sales tax, which went into effect last Monday, has eliminated any fear of hardship to merchants, or to the public through its administration, because of the promptness with which the State Tax Commission has ruled on questions, it was said yesterday by Wesley M. Dawson, director of the Manhattan office of the tax bureau.

An appeal to citizens to resist intimidation by racketeers and cooperate with the Police Department in an effort to defeat the criminal element that is preying on private business was made yesterday by Commissioner James S. Bolan.

An individual display of confidence and courage in the present era of economic stress will be a strong contribution to the world's recovery from the depression, the Rev. Dr. Cleland B. McAfee, a secretary of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, said yesterday in his sermon at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- As the House prepares to reject tomorrow the Norris-Simpson crop production guarantee amendment, the Senate is expected by Democratic Congres- sional leaders to recede and thereby complete legislative action on the farm relief-inflation measure.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- Raisers of hogs found the market for their product better last week, as compared with recent weeks. There were lighter supplies than in the previous week, but the run was heavier than in the same period in the two preceding years.

Trading in commodities on local exchanges last week produced irregular results. Rubber, hides, coffee, cocoa and wool tops closed with net gains, while sugar, silver and silk futures ended lower. Cash prices continued to advance, with new high levels made in several commodities on most days.

PEIPING, May 7 -- An unidentified assailant entered the Wagons-Lits Hotel today, proceeded to the second floor and shot General Chang Ching-yao, former Governor of Hunan Province, who, the police report, was involved in a North China monarchist restoration movement.

How trade associations can obtain many of the benefits which industrial planning contemplates is dealt with in "Can Business Govern Itself?" by Edgar L. Heermance, published today by Harper. The book contains an introduction by Gilbert H. Montague, an authority on anti-trust laws.

ALBANY, May 7 -- The Dunnigan bill designed to permit use of a portion of the Fort Schuyler property at Throgs Neck in the Bronx as a base for the Merchant Marine Academy was signed by Governor Lehman before leaving for Florida.

VIENNA, May 7 -- The Austrian Government, anxious to prove it does not lag behind the Nazis in "anti-Marxism," carried out today mass arrests of Communists, of whom Austria possesses only a few thousand. The police rounded up 600.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 7 -- The class day committee for Rutgers University's annual commencement was appointed today by Albert B. Wiley of Amltyville, N. Y., president of the senior class.
The Brooklyn soccer team held the first-place Brookhattan team to a 1-1 tie in an American League game at Starlight Park yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- Oliver Day, 53 years old, a hired hand on a dairy farm at Plato Center, near Elgin, killed his employer, John Schmitz, early today and then compelled the victim's daughter, Loretta, 17 years old, to shoot and fatally wound him.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- General reduction of normal tank wagon and service station prices of motor gasoline of all grades in amounts ranging from 2.2 to 3.0 cents a gallon was announced tonight by the Standard Oil Company of Indiana.
HOLLYWOOD, May 7 -- The black shadow of the kidnapper's hand extracts thousands of dollars from film celebrities every year.

Westchester has come to be a synonym for the finest county community spirit. Particularly striking is its provision for the better use of leisure. The County Park Commission and the local agencies under it have not only added greatly to the beauty of this stretch of suburban country between the river and the Sound, but have provided many places and facilities for recreation.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- That speculative markets can turn from extreme inactivity to unusual activity within a remarkably short time has been demonstrated most forcibly by the action of the grain markets, with wheat in the lead, in the last four months.

BERLIN, May 6 -- Industrial reports for the week are satisfactory, but the Boerse reflected the nervousness of business concerning the government's and Nazi party's semi-socialistic measures and at first bonds and later stocks showed considerable declines.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Translation of the Washington administration's proposal for an international tariff truce into actual negotiations has proved to be not so easy as apparently was expected during the recent discussions here.

HAVANA, May 7 -- Sumner Welles, the United States Ambassador to Cuba, arrived in Havana this evening on the United Fruit steamship Peten. He was met by high Cuban officials and the United States embassy and consular staffs as well as a large number of prominent members of the American colony.

Clifford Vaughan's "Translations of Music From the Orient" were given last night at the Barbizon by the composer, or, more accurately, the "translator," and a small instrumental ensemble. It has been Mr. Vaughan's intention, according to a program note, to "bring to the Occident the true spirit, rather than the letter, of Oriental music in an idiom easily comprehended by the Western ear."

If a Federal "coordinator of railroads" is appointed, he will find a profitable opening here in the port of New York. Twelve years ago the States of New York and New Jersey, in solemn compact, expressed the "confident belief" that a "better coordination "of the terminal, transportation "and other facilities of commerce "in, about and through the port" would result in "great economies."
MEXICO CITY, May 7 -- The "United States Davls Cup team captured the final two singles matches today to sweep its first-round match with Mexico in the North American zone by the score of 5 to 0.

LONDON, May 6 -- The fresh phase of instability upon which the markets have entered since America abandoned the gold standard is attracting widespread attention and leading in some directions to unexpected results. The further currency adjustments now in progress are strongly influencing commodity prices, the general trend of which is upward.

The right of rabbis to preach on matters pertaining to the social and economic order, rather than on the purely religious, was defended yesterday by speakers in a symposium of social justice at the opentap session of the twenty-first convention of the United Synagogue of America.

Never in the lifetime of any one now living has Western civilization been so near to disaster as it is today, the Rev. Dr. Lewis T. Reed, formerly pastor of the Flatbush Congregational Church, and general secretary of the pension board of the Congregational and Christian Churches, declared yesterday in a sermon at the Manhattan Congrefational Church, Broadway and eventy-sixth Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of the "money functions" is still, I suppose, that it serves as a measure of value. Value is obviously a much more complex thing to measure than, for instance, length; but in practice even so simple a dimension as length has its complications too.

BERLIN, May 6 -- The annual report of the Deutsche Disconto Bank for 1932 shows a net profit of 27,000,000 marks, against 23,000,000 marks in 1931. The dividend was passed and the profit used for writing down assets. Administration costs were reduced from 112,OOO,OOO to 92,000,000 marks.

Civic, artistic and business organizations numbering thirty-three made ready yesterday to push their fight to save the thirty-four-acre site of the abandoned lower reservoir in Central Park from conversion into baseball diamonds and other sports encroachments.

Jerry Bernstein, 2 years old, toddled into the garage alleyway yesterday afternoon, as Morris Soodak, 23, of 2,827 West Twenty-third Street, Coney Island, backed his car toward the street. The child was knocked down and died en route to the Coney Island Hospital.

How secondary financing of small homes through the United States Construction Credit Union will be worked out, if the plan is put in operation, is described by Alien E. Beals in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports. The union is seeking a $25,000.000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to aid building construction projects on the instalment plan.

The annual report of the United Gas Corporation for 1932 shows a consolidated net income of $5,566,039 after all charges, taxes and depreciation, equivalent, after full dividend requirements on the $7 preferred stock, to $2.73 a share earned on 884,680 shares of no-par $7 dividend second preferred stock.

Forty-eight sets of letters and numerals have been awarded to members of the past season's varsity and freshman indoor track, swimmingr, rifle, gymnastic and freshman basketball teams at New York University, it was announced yesterday by Graduate Manager Albert B. Nixon.

TOKYO, Monday, May 8 -- Twenty-four hours' reflection on Foreign Commissar Litvinoff's offer for the sale of the Chinese Eastern Railway by the Soviet Union to Japan has enabled Japanese officials to develop a high degree of sales resistance, which is elaborately displayed in the press this morning.
Bernard Rubinger. Charles Wohlstetter and Stanley L. Ballin have formed the firm of Rubinger, Wohlstetter Co. to deal in bank stocks and unlisted securities at 120 Broadway.

BOMBAY, India, May 7 -- Against the advice and entreaties of all his friends, Mahatma Gandhi prepared tonight to begin at noon today a twenty-one-day fast, which his doctors predict will be fatal to him.

A junior committee under the direction of Miss Katherine Thurber Is aiding plans for the Spring Festival of the People's Chorus of New York, to be given on Thursday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, The event will mark the seventeenth anniversary of the chorus, which was organized during the World War by Lorenzo Camilieri and has been directed by him ever since.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Roosevelt legislative program will have been approved in its entirety in the House by the end of May, Speaker Rainey declared today in reviewing the legislative situation. Foreign debts and the thirty-hour week were not on the program, said Mr. Rainey, and he had no reason to expect that they would be added.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 7 -- The final matches today in the intercity tournament of the United States Women's Lacrosse Association resulted in Boston winning from New York by 14 -- 0, and Baltimore defeating Philadelphia, 5 -- 13 Baltimore beat Boston, and Philadelphia conquered New York yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 7 (AP) -- Newark turned back Rochester in both contests of today's doubleheader before 11,000 fans to win by 7 to 6 and 7 to 2. The Bears thus took first place in the International League race, passing Baltimore and the Red Wings.

Further defaults by debtor nations, credit breakdown of the defaulting countries, further outright departures from the gold standard and consequent destruction of international trade will be the result of failure to adjust the war debt problem, it was declared yesterday by D.B. Robertson, president of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen.
Harvard and Tale each won a game in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League race last week and gained on the first-place Columbia nine, which was idle in league competition.
LONDON, May 7 -- In an angry editorial, The London Times warns the Hitler government that its present policy at Geneva may result in Germany's isolation from the rest of the world.

Under the auspices of the Democratic Junior League of New York, a bridge party in conjunction with a fashion show will be held on May 20 at the Ambassador for the benefit of the Mayor's Official Committee on Relief of the Unemployed and Needy.
CLEVELAND, May 7 -- For a few fleeting hours today the Indians manoeuvred themselves into first place in the American League by upsetting the Yankees in the first half of a double-header, 7 to 6.
St. Paul's Lutheran Church, Crotona Avenue at 178th Street, the Bronx, celebrated its thirty-fifth anniversary yesterday.

PARIS, May 6 -- The voting by Congress of the full powers in regard to monetary measures demanded by President Roosevelt caused no surprise in financial circles here, but the impression prevails that the inflationists' plans are meeting strong opposition in the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- A national recovery bill, combining proposals for industrial control and for public works, probably will go to President Roosevelt Tuesday for his consideration. The present plan is to combine the recovery bill with a public works measure calling for the expenditure of about $2,500,000,000.

HARWICHPORT, Mass., May 7 -- Dramatic re-enactment of the kidnapping of Margaret McMath, during which the dirty, torn trousers which were given her for a pillow and the rope used to bind her hands and feet were found, today virtually completed the State's mass of evidence against Kenneth and Cyril Buck of Harwichport, both now lodged in Barnstable County jail.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 7 -- Broker's Tip and Head Play, which battled to a nose finish in the fifty-ninth Kentucky Derby yesterday, will clash again on Saturday in the PreaKness, it became known today.

NEW HAVEN, May 7 -- Professor Irving Fisher's Index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 59.2, which compares with 58.6 a week ago, 57.1 two weeks ago, 56.8 three weeks ago and 56.2 four weeks ago. This week's average is the highest of the year to date; the average of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.

BERLIN, May 7 -- Frau Katz, daughter of Philipp Scheidemann, the Socialist who proclaimed the German Republic and who is especially unpopular with patri- ots, was found with her husband dead of gas poisoning in her dwelling in Berlin this morning.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is amazing that any one at this late day should even pretend to believe that our cherished Central Park is not maintained for the use and benefit of all the people. Not so long ago the representative New York press successfully opposed a high-minded project, having wealthy sponsors, because it would involve a comparatively slight encroachment upon the park's space.

PITTSBURGH, May 7 -- Production of steel ingots last week was at a rate of about 20,000,000 gross tons annually, double that of last August, and while there had been doubt that the recent sharp increase in demand for steel was permanent, this has been resolved.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 7 -- In the final sailing dinghy regatta of the season in this end of Long Island Sound Feather and Snowball emerged victorious today off the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

BERLIN, May 7 -- The latest Ger- man indoor sport in the new era of popular enlightenment presided over by Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels is to compare the Hitler dictatorship with the powers recently granted to President Roosevelt in the United States, entirely, of course, to the American disadvantage.

PEIPING, Monday, May 8 -- Combined Japanese and Manchukuoan forces have pushed Chinese troops eight miles south of Peitaiho, coastal town south of Shanhaikwan and Chinwangtao, foreign legations here were advised today.
BOSTON, May 7 (AP) -- A crowd of 35,000 today saw the Chicago Cubs bat out a double victory at the expense of the Braves and thereby step into fourth place. The scores were 11 to 2 and 5 to 2.

The largest baseball crowd to find its way to the Polo Grounds in a long time, estimated at 40,000, yesterday saw the Giants take both ends of a double-header from the Cincinnati Reds and advance a few percentage points in their bid for the National League lead.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- President Roosevelt, in a radio speech to the nation tonight, said that he would use the wide currency powers granted him under the pending inflation legislation only "when, as and if" he considered it necessary In order to raise commodity prices to the extent that the dollar of today would equal in purchasing power the dollar of pre-depression times.

SUSSEX, N.J., May 7 -- Four little girls on their way to Sunday school this morning noticed a bulky bag on the bank of Beaver Brook as they waited for a bus on Hamburg Turnpike near Route 32. With. horror they discovered that the bag contained the body of a man.
LONDON, May 7 -- The British Government is now awaiting some assurance of a moratorium on war debts before committing itself on President Roosevelt's proposed tariff truce.

DETROIT, May 7 (AP) -- The Tigers won a slam-bang first game, 10 to 9, from the Senators on a wild pitch in the tenth inning today, only to drop the nightcap, 6 to 2, before the six-hit pitching of Wally Stewart.
Preaching on "The Cost of Common Sense" yesterday morning in the Madison Avenue Methodist Church, at Sixtieth Street, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman said:

Former Representative F.H. La Guardia, fusion nominee for Mayor in 1929, issued a statement yester- day calling on the anti-Tammany forces to get together to present a complete fusion ticket for the city election. Major La Guardia, who announced a month ago that he would support Joseph V. McKee for Mayor if the latter would announce his position by May 1, said that the fusionists should not be dis- couragred by Mr. McKee's with- drawal.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 7 (AP) -- Finance Minister Gustavo Ross announced today the government's new plan for the reorganization of Chile's nitrate industry which is similar in outline to Cosach, the nitrate monopoly ordered liquidated last January.

The chief causes of waste in foreign missions are lack of training and overwork among missionaries, it is declared in the first instalment, made public yesterday, of excerpts from the forthcoming reports of the fact-finders whose researches largely formed the basis for the recent report of the Appraisal Commission of the Laymen's Foreign Missions Inquiry.

ALBANY. May 7 -- The transplanting in New York State waters of seed or mature oysters of the Japanese or any species other than those technically known as Ostor Virginica is forbidden in a conservation bill signed by Governor Lehman.

Young men and women of society, as well as prominent members of the musical and theatrical worlds, are interested in the success of the Primavera Ball in behalf of the philanthropic enterprises of the Italian Historical Society, which will take place on Thursday night on board the Rex at the foot of West Forty-sixth Street.

Speaking last night at services in the Broadway Temple, Commissioner Bolan dwelt at length on the work of the Police Department In crime prevention and in reducing racketeering. He said a noticeable decrease had been shown in the crime statistics of the city, as compared with last year.

BASLE, May 7 -- An intention to maintain the gold standard was reaffirmed today by representatives of France, Germany, Holland and Switzerland at a session of directors of the World Bank for International Settlements, preliminary to the annual meeting tomorrow.

BOSTON, May 7 -- A boycott by the American people of the products of all German industries, with the withdrawal of their patronage from German ships and their refusal to visit Germany, was recommended here today by Samuel Untermyer as the "obvious remedy" in dealing with the anti-Semitic activities of the National Socialists and the Hitler regime.

NEW ORLEANS, May 7 -- There was broader trading in cotton last week than for a considerable time. Not only were there much greater trade buying and price-fixing as well as more professional trading, but also a decided pick-up in outside speculation, which had been lacking.

PARIS, May 7 -- Public disappointment that Edouard Herriot brought back from Washington nothing tangible was widely reflected in the press today. In fact, it would be difficult to find a kind word for him in all Paris's thirty-odd newspapers.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- Chicago's labor union and racketeering war was marked today by a counter-revolution in which the ousted Sheridan-Booth faction of the Chicago Coal Teamsters and Hikers Union regained control without the use of guns.

Frau Nelly Neppach figured prominently in German tennis circles during the seasons of 1925 and 1926. She won the women's singles championship of Germany in 1925 and participatel in several tournaments on the Riviera during the early months of 1926.

Mrs. HENRY W. PEABODY, that martyr of truth who shook from her feet the too moist dust of Massachusetts, still exercises great influence. As chairman of the Women's National Committee for Law Enforcement she directs the few but fit New Jersey faithful to cry out against the enormity of Three Point Two by dealing only at stores that don't vend it.

An exhibition illustrating the use of plant forms in ornament is to be opened to the public tomorrow at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Members of the museum have been invited to visit the show this afternoon.

The American proposal for a tariff truce has not met with prompt acceptance. It called for an armistice in the trade war during the whole period from the date of summoning the World Economic Conference to final adjournment of that gathering.

THE Yale varsity swimming teams have won nine straight league titles, and Bob Kiphuth has been the coach all through this successful splashing campaign. To show their appreciation, the winning team of this year held a dinner recently and presented Coach Kiphuth with a handsome edition of "Lysistraia."
Small housing properties comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- To win the cooperation of consumers in his administration of the farm relief bill, Secretary Wallace has drafted a plan through which he aims to remove the projected processing taxes on farm commodities from the realm of possible profiteering.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 7 -- Reflation is the only practical way for America to get out of the depression and Congress is on the right track, Professor Irving Fisher, Yale University economist, declared here today in an address before the joint convention of the National Federation of Men's Bible Classes and the New Jersey State federation.

ALBANY, May 7. -- Thus far this year 8,819 new stock corporations nave been chartered by Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn, he reported today. This is a decrease of 696 for the first four months, January alone showing an increase from the 1932 figures.

Miss Amelia Earhart, transoceanic flier and holder of the women's transcontinental record, announced yesterday that she had resigned as a member and as vice president of the National Aeronautical Association, of which former Senator Hiram Bingham of Connecticut is president.
The most significant sentence in the joint statement issued by President ROOSEVELT and the delegate of Italy after their conversations is the following:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 7 -- The election of a new president of Harvard University to succeed Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell is expected to be announced following the joint meeting of the corporation and board of overseers of the university tomorrow.

MANCHULI, Manchuria, May 7 -- George C. Hanson, United States Consul at Harbin, on the western lines of the Chinese Eastern Railway, said today that danger of a Russo-Japanese war over the railroad was remote. Despite reports to the contrary, evidence of Japanese and Soviet troops concentrations in the border districts were lacking, he said.

As there was reason to expect from past experience, the vote for the Inflation bill, conferring discretionary powers on the President, has been followed by a rapid speculative rise in prices. Last week's advance of 3% cents a bushel for wheat and 7% cents for corn brought the July deliveries respectively to 30% and 20% cents above the year's lowest.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You recently published a letter which commented on the courageous speech Senator Glass made in opposition to the plan of the administration on inflation. The record made by Senator Glass, going back as far as the establishment of the Federal Reserve Banks, is of such unusual brilliancy that anything he might say on the question of inflation should be carefully weighed by all citizens.

ELLSWORTH, Me., Monday, March 8 (AP). -- The greater part of the city of Ellsworth appeared doomed early this morning by a fire which swept through the business district, destroying more than fifty buildings on both sides of the main street and then invaded the residential sections, where, by 2 o'clock nearly 200 dwelling houses were ablaze.

Nearly 35,000 fans jammed Ebbets Field yesterday and stayed there for four and one-half hours to see the Dodgers and Cardinals divide a double-header. Hundreds sat or stood in the runways, and for the first time this season the green curtains were dropped from in front of the lower centre-field stand to allow that tier to be filled.

LEEDS, N.Y., May 7 (AP) -- An airplane with jammed controls hurtled down from the sky at Spooky Hollow in the Catskill Mountains late today, dashed its way through 300 feet of treetops and was wrecked, bringing injuries to its three occupants.

Captain Stephen Darius and Stanley Girenas, two Lithuanian fliers who are to take off from Floyd Bennett Field for Kaunas, Lithuania, on May 20, the anniversary of the Lindbergh flight to Paris, landed last night at Newark Airport from Chicago.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- President Roosevelt will resume tomorrow his discussions, preliminary to the World Economic and Monetary Conference at London, with foreign envoys, meeting Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, head of the German Reichsbank, and Dr. T.V. Soong, the representative of China.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 7 -- Just what happened during that wild stretch drive in yesterday's Kentucky Derby, which resulted in a nose victory for Broker's Tip over Head Play, will always be a matter of debate, but a narrative of the rough-riding affair could be pieced together today from the accounts of, many veteran turf experts.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- Activity in all lines of trade and industry has increased steadily hereabout for more than a month and a continuation is expected. There has been a return of confidence, accompanied by a strengthening of prices of raw materials and commodities and a steady expansion of credit by many banks.

Leaders in the three fields in which the late Dr. Felix Adler, founder of the Society for Ethical Culture, distinguished himself -- religion, education and social welfare -- joined last night in paying tribute to his memory at special exercises at the society's meeting house, Central Park West and Sixty-fourth Street.

LEEDS, N.Y., May 7 (AP) -- An airplane with jammed controls hurtled down from the sky at Spooky Hollow in the Catskill Mountains late today, dashed its way through 300 feet of treetops and was wrecked, bringing injuries to its three occupants.

Captain Stephen Darius and Stanley Girenas, two Lithuanian fliers who are to take off from Floyd Bennett Field for Kaunas, Lithuania, on May 20, the anniversary of the Lindbergh flight to Paris, landed last night at Newark Airport from Chicago.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- President Roosevelt will resume tomorrow his discussions, preliminary to the World Economic and Monetary Conference at London, with foreign envoys, meeting Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, head of the German Reichsbank, and Dr. T.V. Soong, the representative of China.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 7 -- Just what happened during that wild stretch drive in yesterday's Kentucky Derby, which resulted in a nose victory for Broker's Tip over Head Play, will always be a matter of debate, but a narrative of the rough-riding affair could be pieced together today from the accounts of, many veteran turf experts.

BERLIN, May 8 -- Through official interpretation of the law for purgation of the civil service, more light was thrown today on the question of which public officials were to be removed as non-Aryan or politically unreliable.

Few Americans pass through Munich without visiting the Deutsches Museum, which does for science and engineering what the art museum does for painting and sculpture. Nine miles of exhibits. Sixty thousand things to see. Nearly 400 separate rooms and halls.

Sales of the General Motors Corporation to dealers in the United States last month made a total of 74,242 cars, compared with 45,098 in March and 69,029 in April, 1932. It was the first month since January in which sales to dealers ran ahead of those in the corresponding month of last year.

Captain D.T. Smith, master of the Colombian liner Colombia, said yesterday he had a crew as staid and steady as any ever sailing the Caribbean, but something went wrong with the ship out of Cartagena, Colombia, last week. It began one morning when the passengers arose unusually early and appeared at the ship's dining room before the head waiter had his white jacket on.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 8 -- Yale's traditional tap day exercises apparently became history today when a notice, signed by the 1934 student council, asked all members of the junior class to remain in their rooms Thursday from 5 P.M. to 7.

The voters of Jersey City will go to the polls today to elect a Mayor and four city commissioners. Officials estimated that widespread interest in the election would result in the casting of about 125,000 votes, or about 25,000 more than were cast in the election four years ago.

I. Horowitz and A.W. Dake last night won their games in the third round of the trial tournament in progress at the West Side Y.M.C. A. Horowitz leads in the standing, with three straight victories, and is followed hy Dake, with 2 1/2 points.

Plans for welding the various groups interested in the nomination of an anti-Tammany fusion ticket into one working unit will be discussed today at a luncheon conference. The participants will include former Governor Charles S. Whitman, chairman of the Republican Mayoralty Committee; Raymond Ingersoll and Maurice P. Davidson, representing the City party, and Joseph M. Price, head of the Independent Fusion Committee.
Although prices on the Cotton Exchange improved $1 a bale at one time yesterday, the market encountered more profit-taking and closed around the bottom at losses of 17 to 19 points.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 8 -- A shortage of $250,000 in the accounts of the County Treasurer as public aministrator was disclosed here today by William A. Davidson, County Attorney. Most of the money, he explained, belonged to widows and children whose interests were in the hands of the Westchester surrogate.

Problems confronting real estate interests, with emphasis upon the influence of Federal inflation methods upon realty values and future market conditions, will be discussed by many prominent speakers at the forthcoming convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards in Chicago, beginning Monday, June 12, and continuing through the week.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- President Roosevelt will be the final arbiter of the form which the national industrial recovery act will take working out details over which various groups in the government and industrial and labor interests have disagreed.
The quotations are for three-four months' paper.
Fifty-two drivers of outboard motor boats yesterday had entered for the race down the Hudson River from Albany, which will be held on Sunday.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 8 -- Theodore J. Zeller, a contractor, shot and killed Knight I. Faucett, proprietor of the Model Laundry, and Faucett's son, Jack, after an argument in the laundry at 421 Madison Avenue, Plainfield, early tonight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There are a few features of the proposed bill to insure bank deposits advanced by Senator Buckley that, I think, are fundamentally unsound and which, if enacted, might wreck the entire plan.

Mayor O'Brien heard protests yesterday by representatives of twentynine real estate and civic organizations against the granting of taxexemption for the building of model tenements in the Northwest Bronx by the Hillside Housing Company, but would not disclose his attitude toward it.

RIVERSIDE N.J., May 8 -- Mrs. Marion B. Rein, supervising principal of the schools here, was ordered suspended tonight at a special meeting of the Board of Education on five charges presented by the Riverside Taxpayers League. A hearing was set for May 25.

Joseph H. Choate Jr., a member of the New York City Beer Control Board, discussing the prospects for ratification of prohibition repeal yesterday, said that "it is not beyond the bounds of possibility that the job may be done this year." Mr. Choate who is also a member of the Voluntary Committee of Lawyers, an anti-prohibition organization, spoke at a luncheon of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, at the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Considerable quantities of silver might be employed as subsidiary currency throughout the world under existing laws, but while a number of countries and colonies have limited the amount of silver which may be issued, fiftynine of them have not In circulation all the silver that is legally issuable, according to a survey made public today by Herbert M. Bratter of the Depart-ment of Commerce.

What the commission houses call a "mixed market" developed on the Stock Exchange yesterday as Wall Street sought to judge the status of the President's inflation program. Speculators were wary; they could not tell from the President's radio address what he had in mind in the way of a definite monetary policy.

LONG BEACH, L.I., May 8 -- Corporation Counsel David B. Tolins announced today that the city of Long Beach had started suit in Supreme Court in Mineola to force a syndicate of bond houses to complete an agreement made in June, 1931, to buy $560,000 of city bonds, $116,000 of which remain in the city's hands.

Consolidation of the city's building inspection services into one unit to replace the seven previously existing proceeded yesterday in all boroughs.
