Samuel Fassler, Manhattan Building Superintendent, who heads the new board, said the change would, save taxpayers between $25, 000,000 and $50,000,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Regulation of the future sale of securities along the lines recommended by President Roosevelt was approved today by the Senate. The House having already passed a similar bill, the way was opened for an immediate conference and an agreement.

A movement designed to mobilize the spokesmen of Christianity in the United States and of college professors in American universities against anti-Semitism in Germany was started yesterday by groups of clergymen and social scientists through the National Conference of Jews and Christians, an organization striving to promote amity and cooperation among members of different creeds and religions.

General Francesco de Pinedo, famous Italian ace and hero of previous Atlantic crossings by air, plans to take off from Floyd Bennett Field by Saturday of this week, weather permitting, on a solo nonstop flight which he hopes will take him at least as far as Bushire, Pershia, 6,200 miles away, and wrest the distance flight record from Britain, it was disclosed here yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 8. -- The will of Anton G. Hodenpyl. filed here today, disposes of an estate of more than $1.000,000. with Annie P. Hodenpyl, widow of the testator, the principal beneficiary. Mr. Hodenpyl was a banker and member of the firm of Hodenpyl,Hardy Co., New York City investment security dealers.

The New York Edison Company and the United Electric Light and Power Company planned to replace all direct current supply with alternating current within twenty years, according to testimony given before the Public Service Commission yesterday by Ralph. H. Tapscott, vice president of both companies.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- Gaston B. Means was placed on trial today, and on the witness stand sat Mrs. Evalyn Walsh McLean clutching a little black handbag containing a rope of diamonds two feet long and Jewelled bracelets worth a king's ransom.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- A parade of 3,000 whites and Negroes sought from President Roosevelt and Congressional leaders today intervention to free the nine Alabama Negroes convicted of criminal assaults in the Scottsboro case.

The Veterans Expeditionary Force, a new bonus army whose leaders declare that they will not permit it to be run out of Washington as was the B.E.F. last year, completed plans here yesterday for a march on the national capital beginning tomorrow.

GREENVILLE, S.C., May 8 -- More than 9,000 employes in twenty Piedmont South Carolina textile mills received 10 per cent wage increases today, reflecting better business conditions and "appreciation of the loyalty" of the workers.
The City College freshman track and field team opened its season by defeating Evander Childs High School, 52 to 47, yesterday at the Lewisohn Stadium. The victors won six first places.

An offer good until May 20 to holders of Blue Ridge Corporation preference stock to exchange their shares for common stock of the Atlas Corporation was announced yesterday by L. Boyd Hatch, executive vice president of Atlas. Atlas acquired control of Blue Ridge through deals last month that gave it control also of the Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation, now the Pacific Eastern Corporation, and the Shenandoah Corporation.
NEW YORK. The Spanish Ambassador, Juan Francisco de Cardenas, is at the Ritz-Carlton.

Steamship men have exhausted all artificial means of stimulating trade and can really do nothing now but sit back and wait for better times, according to Axel Carlander, chairman of the board of the Swedish-American Line, of Gothenburg who sailed yesterday on the liner Kungsholm after a brief trip here.
Several flats were included in the New Jersey realty turnover, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- President Roosevelt's second radio address outlining his views on economic measures, inflation and world problems, was hailed over the nation by Republicans and Democrats alike as a clear and sincere exposition of the present situation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Although the American farmer is clearly entitled to the sympathy which has been given to him for all that he has suffered during this depression, he is no more to be pitied than are the millions of others invarious occupations who do not happen to be organized into blocs and, therefore, have not been favored by Congress with special legislative favors.

On the basis of cabled dimensions of the new Class J yacht launched on April 26 at Gosport, England, W. Starling Burgess, designer of the America's Cup defender Enterprise, yesterday figured her to be the most powerful racer of her size ever built.

Disappointed by the action of Governor Lehman in signing the Dunnigan bill which authorized him to negotiate a lease of the Fort Schuyler site from the Federal Government for use as a ground base of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy, the Bronx Chamber of Commerce appealed yesterday to Mayor O'Brien to make another effort to preserve the site for park purposes.

Eight hundred and eighty golfers, the majority or them professionals, will tee up in the forthcoming sectional qualifying rounds for the United States open championship and compete for 117 places, it was announced yesterday by Prescott S. Bush, chairman of the championship committee of the United States Golf Association.

While replenishing their Spring wardrobes at the expense of a clothing merchant they had held up a few minutes previously, two young men, with four new suits and two overcoats, were interrupted yesterday afternoon by two patrolmen in answer to an alarm that the robbers had unwittingly turned in.

POONA, India, May 8 -- Beginning a solemn three weeks fast of "purification" which brought his release from Yerovda prison today, Mahatma Gandhi issued a dramatic announcement late tonight, calling off the Indian civil disobedience campaign and anti-British boycott for one month.

TRENTON, N.J., May 8. -- Dr. Henry Andrews Cotton, medical director-emeritus of the New Jersey State Hospital here, and internationally known psychiatrist for his pioneer work in the treatment of the insane, died suddenly of a heart attack at the Trenton Club this afternoon.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., May 8 -- Mr. and Mrs. E. F. Johnson entertained at dinner in honor of Dr. and Mrs. George Albee at Kates Mountain Club. Mr. and Mrs. C.C. Schliffler gave a dinner at the club for Mr. and Mrs. T.J. Davis.

In the first message of a campaign of advertising in daily and weekly newspapers throughout the country, beginning today. Henry Ford declares that "a great thing has occurred amongst us" and "we have made a complete turn-around and at last America's face is toward the future."

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Radio Commission won an important, victory today when the Supreme Court upheld the commission's power to license operation by a broad-casting station in an under-quota State on a frequency previously given to a station in an over-quota State.

HARBIN, Manchuria, Tuesday, May 9 -- A wholesale shakeup was made in the personnel of the Manchukuo side of the Chinese Eastern Railway today and was described by Manchukuo authorities as a significant prelude to action against the Soviet if the latter continued disregarding the reiterated Manchukuo demands.

Money market was featureless. Quotations for all classes of accommodation carried into the new week unchanged from those which prevailed last week. Business was small in all sections. Stock Exchange day loan rate remained at 1 per cent.

Uncertainties in the foreign exchange market, which reflected belief that a change in the status of European gold currencies was likely, helped to shape the course of the security and commodity markets yesterday. In spite of denials that abandonment of the gold standard was contemplated in France or Holland, the exchange market gave credence to the recurring rumors.
A reduction to 2.75 cents in the basic passenger fare throughout the country will be discussed by railway presidents and passenger traffic officials at a meeting in Washington on Thursday.

A survey of sixty-nine industries by representatives of the City Free Employment Agency indicated a gradual improvement in recent weeks, according to a report made yesterday by Edward C. Rybicki, director of the agency, to Welfare Commissioner Frank J. Taylor.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- Overwhelming approval was given by the Senate today to President Roosevelt's choice for Controller of the Currency -- J.F.T. O'Connor of California -- a few minutes before Senator Reed, Republican, of Pennsylvania, voiced belated criticism on the ground that the nominee had no banking experience.

Many New Yorkers now are fishing in the Eastern Provinces of Canada, according to information from the Dominion, despite the fact that weather conditions have been unsettled and that stream sand lakes are exceptionally high.
OKLAHOMA CITY, May 8 (AP) -- Twenty-six oil companies, operating 218 wells in the Oklahoma City field, agreed tonight to offer no more crude oil for sale at the present price of 25 cents a barrel.

HAVANA, May 8 -- A message from President Machado recommending passage of a bill permitting the Cuban Government to coin an additional $6,000,000 in silver against which an equal amount of silver certificates would be issued was read In the House of Representatives this afternoon.
TOKYO, May 8 -- The renewed Japanese offensive south of the Great Wall will not extend to Peiping or Tientsin, the War Office told The Associated Press today.

BERLIN, May 8 (AP) -- General Werner von Blomberg, Minister of Defense in the Hitler Cabinet, said in an interview today that Germany was willing to go to any limit to assure the success of the disarmament conference, but he added that "the time for the dictation of an ultimatum is past."

HALIFAX, N.S., May 8 (Canadian Press) -- Only the weatherly qualities of the Bluenose and the seamanship of her skipper and crew saved the racing Nova Scotian fisherman from driving ashore in the Strait of Canso in a howling squall. W.R. Macaskill, Halifax yachtsman who made the trip on the famous schooner from Halifax to Caribou Cove, related its adventures on returning home.

Wage increases of 5 per cent, affecting thousands of employes in automobile plants and affiliated industries, and salary rises of 10 per cent by one New York Stock Exchange firm were announced yesterday, in support of President Roosevelt's program to revive business and increase purchasing power.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 8. -- The Manhattan College varsity crew will make its first appearance in intercollegiate competition when the New Yorkers race the Princeton third varsity eight on Lake Carnegie tomorrow. The race will be over the Henley distance.

BERLIN, May 8 -- The Boerse was weak today. Stocks declined, although only a small amount was offered. Banks and speculators were extremely reserved.Shares of the building industry lost most of their recent spectacular gains. I. G. Farben moved five points below Saturday's Quotation, while Siemens-Halske dropped 8 per cent.
Ivan Studies Rations. In the courtyard of the rolling-mill "Red Dawn," somewhere on the Volga, the Communist orator addressed the noonday crowd.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 -- The annual report of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia for 1932 shows net earnings available for distribution of $3,270,834, compared with $884,172 in the preceding year.

Sharp declines in French Government and municipal loans featured a fairly general drop in foreign bonds yesterday in an irregularly lower market on the Stock Exchange. French Government 7 1/2s closed with a net loss of 10 points and the 7s with one of 7 3/4 points, although at one time the former issue showed a fall of 11 1/2 points.

Four books which were Christmas presents from King George and Queen Mary of England to the late Czar Nicholas of Russia are on display in the window of the Himebaugh Browne bookshop, 4 East Forty-sixth Street. They have special bindings and were presented on four successive Christmas days.

The concert of the New Chamber Orchestra under Bernard Hermann, scheduled to present six new American works at the New School Wednesday evening, has been postponed until Wednesday. May 17. owing to the death of the conductor's father.

Although believing that some sort of Federal regulation is necessary to restore prosperity to the oil industry, the directors of the American Petroleum Institute, after an all-day session, adjourned late yesterday to meet again on Thursday morning, without taking any definite action.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, May 8 -- According to information received here, Soviet shipyards in Leningrad are working at high speed to prepare the naval fleet for the forthcoming Baltic manoeuvres, which are said to be planned on a larger scale than ever owing to unsettled international conditions.

SALISBURY PLAINS, L.I., May 8 -- Walter Kozak, professional at the Pomonok Country Club and the holder of the Long Island open crown, began the season auspiciously today when he and his partner, E. Leonard Beard, tied for the lead in Long Island Golf Association's inaugural event of the season.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 9 --Posters bearing the slogans "Drive the British From Asia," "Down With Britain, Violator of World Peace," and "Defend Asia for the Asiatics" are displayed on many walls and billboards here today.

GENEVA, May 8 -- An attempt to end the delay in the disarmament conference was the outcome of a talk today between Arthur Henderson, president, and the United States, British, French, German and Italian delegates.
LONDON, May 8 -- After a long controversy the control of Boots Pure Drug Company has passed from the United States to Britain by the exercise of an option involving u5,400,000.

For the first time since the beginning of the depression, steel operations last month were at a higher level than in the corresponding month of the preceding year, according to the monthly statistics of the American Iron and Steel Institute.

WASHINGTON, May 8 --Opposition by legitimate consumers of alcohol and whisky to the proposed consolidation of the Prohibition Bureau and the Bureau of Industrial Alcohol may be met by a change in the name of the combined organization to the Bureau of Alcohol Control, Attorney General Cummings said today.

BUENOS AIRES, May 8 -- Argentina and Chili, in long, sharply worded notes tonight, notified Bolivia of the termination of their good offices toward mediation of the Chaco dispute with Paraguay, declaring Bolivia's attitude toward their friendly efforts for peace was unjustified and holding Bolivia responsible for continuance of the Chaco war, which is described as an unprecedented example contrariness and stubborn opposition to every effort to bring about peace.

LONDON, May 8 -- With dramatic suddenness the British Government dropped its attitude of veiled hostility to President Roosevelt's proposed tariff truce today and grave Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large, the first real encouragement he has had since coining to England.

Prices in local commodity markets were lower yesterday with the exception of silver futures, which were slightly higher. Coffee prices were also firm in expectation of good prices to be obtained by the Farm Board. For the most part, trading volumes were small.

In his account of the parts of an ideal teacher, Professor PALMER, himself a teacher for forty years at Harvard, used to say that the last infirmity to be overcome was the desire to toe remembered. He will doubtless be longest remembered by what he wrote of anotheras an ideal teacher, ALICE FREEMAN PALMER, his wife.
To the Editor of The New York Times: On this, my first visit to New York City, I desire to express a few thoughts that come welling up with a spontaneity seemingly worthy of expression.

PROVIDENCE, May 8 -- Rhode Island formally ratified today repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, which it had never ratified and which it had consistently fought throughout the thirteen years of national prohibition.

TROMSOE, Norway, May 8 -- Three survivors of the Soviet salvage ship Rouslan who, after the steamer sank with the loss of twenty men, drifted five days over Arctic wastes in an open boat, told their story on arriving here today.

One does not wonder way enthusiastic approval of the President's radio address on Sunday night flooded the White House yesterday. Both in manner and substance what Mr. ROOSEVELT said was admirably conceived. By his simplicity of speech and unostentatious geniality of attitude, he was able to give the millions who listened in the impression of sitting down with him quietly in his library to talk public affairs over.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- A wave of general buying lifted prices of hogs as much as 25 cents a hundred-weight today, and the close was at the best prices of the day and with the general average up 20 cents from Saturday at $4.20 and within 5 cents of the best level of the year.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Evidence of improved sentiment throughout the country, specifically in the farming regions, was reported today to the directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation by loan agency managers, here for a two-day session.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- In its drive for economy, the Navy Department has tentatively decided to place the entire fleet on a so-called rotating plan, under which a third of the ships would be taken temporarily out of service.

Preservation of the regulatory code set up by the late Board of Taxicab Control is essential if the taxicab business is to be conducted in the best interests of the public, according to a letter sent to THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday by Morris Markin. president of the Checker Cab Manufacturing Corporation, an affiliate of the Parmelee System, Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- Ensnarled by a technicality, the House was forced today to delay its foregone rejection of the "cost-of-production" amendment to the farm relief-inflation bill which leaders had hoped could be sent immediately to the Senate for final action.

GENEVA, May 8 -- The armament business, which one of the leading disarmament delegates recently privately declared to be the "real root of the armament problem," received its first serious treatment here in months today.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., May 8 -- Kenneth and Cyril Buck, Harwichport brothers, pleaded not guilty today in the kidnapping of 10-year-old Margaret McMath and were held in $100,000 bail each for hearing May 22.

Harold B. Shaffer, also known as Harry B. Schaeffer, who was alleged to have used his office as vice president of the Alien Typewriter Company, Inc., of Allentown, Pa., now in receivership, to defraud seventeen men of between $4,000 and $5,000 under pretext of giving them employment, was arrested on a grand larceny charge yesterday afternoon in District Attorney Crain's office.
CHICAGO, May 8. -- Arriving here today determined to find out whether the White Sox are really in earnest about their first-division aspirations, the Yankees were more than agreeably surprised.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 8 -- Fifteen thousand Fascist troops, instead of the 10,000 previously reported, were reviewed by President Alessandri yesterday, and other thousands, it was revealed today, took an oath of loyalty throughout the country.

Harry Murch, 16-year-old leader of a juvenile gang in Queens, went on trial In the Queens County Court yesterday on a charge of first-degree murder for the binding, gagging and fatal stabbing of William Bender, 12, of 6 Bergen Landing Road, Richmond Hill Circle, in a vacant house last Jan. 31.

The refusal of the National City Bank to renew a ninety-day $1,000,000 loan to the Faramount-Fublix Corporation in February, 1932, which put the corporation's "entire line of credit in jeopardy," and the beginning of negotiations which resulted late in March, 1932, in the renewal of the corporation's entire $9,500,000 bank loans, were described yesterday before Referee Henry K. Davis, 140 Nassau Street, by Ralph A. Kohn, Paramount-Publix treasurer.

BUCHAREST, May 8 -- Anti-Semitic disorders occurred, in many parts of Rumania today. In the village of Suczawa, in Bukowina, anti-Semitic peasants attacked and disarmed gendarmerie who tried to prevent the holding of prohibited demonstrations by the "Iron Guard" of Professor Cuza, Rumania's Hitler.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The State Department's secret code bill was back on the Senate calendar tonight, awaiting action in the somewhat indefinite future, after having been swiftly approved and then recalled.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The initiative taken by Bolivia in intimating to the Neutrals' Commission here that new conciliation proposals looking to settlement of the Chaco dispute with Paraguay would be seriously considered, was regarded in Latin-American circles heer today as distinctly encouraging.

MADRID, May 8 -- Premier Manuel Azana acted swiftly and unexpectedly today to rid the country of some of its most troublesome reactionary Generals on the eve of a vote in the Cortes to pass a gag law which will establish a virtual dictatorship dominated by the Socialists, with their trade union.

The disturbances that followed the advent of the Hitler regime in Germany have resulted in a general drop in attendance at German films here, according to reports gathered from theatre managers and cinema officials yesterday.

Another investigation into the bail-bond situation in Federal court, where the State law limiting interest payments to 3 per cent does not apply, seemed likely yesterday after Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard had informed one surety company he would no longer accept its bonds.

BALTIMORE, May 8 -- G.H. (Pete) Bostwick, wealthy young sportsman and gentleman jockey, was injured today when his mount, Thomas Hitchcock's Creek, fell during the running of the Raceland Steeplechase at Pimlico.

Led by E. Ramey Donovan, Fordham's tennis team turned back Manhattan, 8 to 1, on the Ram courts yesterday. Donovan defeated Charles McCarthy, 6-4, 6-3, in the No. 1 singres match, and paired with Norman Watterman to vanquish Callahan and Sullivan, 6-1, 6-1, in the doubles.
BALTIMORE, May 8 -- The Kentucky Derby winner, Colonel E. R. Bradley's Broker's Tip, arrived in Baltimore from Louisville today to start training for the $25,000 added Preakness at Pimlico Saturday.

The stock holdings of Gebroeders Boissevain of Amsterdam in the Southern Pacific Company were increased in 1932. according to the Iatest list of the twenty largest stockholders. The Home Insurance Company appears on the new list with 15,000 shares. Dominick Dominick have 14.381 shares and Moore, Leonard Lynch 12.332 shares.

If inflation is not carefully and courageously curbed, the United States will experience a crash worse than that of the last three years, said John T. Madden. Dean of the School of Commerce of New York University, at the annual meeting of the State Society of Certified Public Accountants last evening in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- While a bullish construction was placed on President Roosevelt's speech of last night, the response was feeble in trading in wheat today on the Board of Trade. The recent rush of public buying had dwindled and longs showed more disposition to take profits.

Supreme Court Justice Charles J. Dodd of Brooklyn signed an order yesterday temporarily restraining V.E. Graham Co., Inc., 29 Broad-way, from doing business as stock brokers and ordering them to show cause Thursday morning why the injunction should not be made permanent.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The passage of legislation giving the President additional powers to economize by abrogating transportation contracts, furloughing army officers at half pay and retiring civil service employes who conclude thirty years of active service was predicted today when the House, by a vote of 202 to 156.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today. dated May 5:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 8 -- James Bryant Conant, Sheldon Emery Professor of Organic Chemistry, was named by the Harvard Corporation today to be the next president of Harvard University. Confirmation of the choice will be laid before the board of overseers on June 22.

The Phoenix Cereal Beverage Company, which was enjoined several months ago by Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson from manufacturing beer of more than one half of 1 per cent, may now make beer containing not more than 3.2 percent by weight, if it obtains a permit to do so, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled yesterday.
Eddie Ran, Polish welterweight, stopped Benny Levine of Newark in the final round of the scheduled ten-round feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- President Roosevelt will receive limited authority to deal with war debt payments during the recess of Congress, in the opinion of Democratic leaders.

Health Commissioner Shirley W. Wynne announced yesterday that he was prepared to enlarge the New York City "milk shed" to insure the city of its daily supply of milk, in the event the farmers now supplying the city carry out their threat of a milk strike.

PEIPING, May 8 -- The resumed Japanese attacks against North China, designed to shatter resistance along the Great Wall by reoccupying the Lwan River triangle, carried an invading unit today within firing distance of Lwanchow, while an additional Japanese unit moving from Haiyangchen along the Mandarin Highway has occupied Lulung, where the road crosses the Lwan River.

LONDON, May 8 -- Renewed sus-pension of gold payments by the United States left the world wondering and bewildered, Rupert Beckett, chairman of the Westminster Bank and president of the Bankers Association, declared at the association's annual dinner tonight.

SHANGHAI, May 8 -- The Russian proposal to sell the Chineses Eastern Railway to Japan has aroused the strongest opposition of the Nanking Government, which announced today it would issue a statement tomorrow declaring its intention to resist the plan.

While fifty persons were within a few feet of him, a thief opened a show window in the jewelry store of Betteridgre, Inc., 545 Fifth Avenue, at the corner of Forty-fifth Street, yesterday afternoon and took two diamond and platinum bracelets valued at $10,500.

Pastors should cease taking long Summer vacations if they want the laity to hold them in respect, the Rev. Edwin Bradford Robinson, pastor of Grace Congregational Church, Holyoke, Mass., declared at a seminar of the Congregational and Christian Ministers' Federation of the Metropolitan Area of New York yesterday at the George Washington Hotel.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 8 -- By scoring 7 points in today's interclub matches at the Century Country Club the Class A team of the Greenwich Country Club went to the top of the list in the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association race.

MUNICH, May 8 -- An investigation into alleged discrimination against German goods in the outside world, conducted by the Munich Chamber of Commerce, leads to the conclusion that something like a boycott of German exports actually now prevails, but "this boycott has not been originally or chiefly incited by the attitude of the German Government on the Jewish question."
TORONTO, May 8 (AP). -- Toronto won both ends of today's double-header against Jersey City, 7 to 4 and 7 to 2.

Aside from the seven original subscribers of its capital, membership in the Bank for International Settlements is limited by statute to central banks in countries "whose currencies satisfy the "practical requirements of the gold "or the gold exchange standard."

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 8 -- In the opening matches of the Long Island interclub series of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association today, the players of the Salisbury Country Club assumed the lead in the Class A group with a 4-point aggregate.

Winchester Noyes was re-elected, president of the American Seamen's Friend Society yesterday at its 105th annual meeting at 72 WallStreet. The society's work during the year in sixteen ports of the world included relief for destitute seamen and the shipment of 354 loan libraries on merchant ships.

Four years before the World War started Norman. Angell advanced in his book "The Great Illusion" the thesis that warfare between modern industrial States was harmful to the victor as well as to the defeated. He said that a nation's trade could not be won by force of arms and that a province or even half a continent won in war was a poor bargain.

PARIS, May 8 -- The French press, commenting on President Roosevelt's radio speech, evinced hope that any devaluation of the dollar will be only a temporary measure and that the Executive will be able to carry the country through any period of inflation.

A five-cent tax on each subway ride, a ten-cent vehicular toll charge on the four East River bridges, a five-cent passenger fair increase on municipal ferries and an adequate tuition charge for students in city colleges are proposed by Controller Berry in a report to the Board of Estimate as a means of obtaining for the city additional yearly revenues of from $60,000,000 to $75,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It may not be without interest at the present moment to have stated a few facts with reference to the effect of Central Park on property values, and consequently on the returns to the city treasury by way of taxes.

One by one names are added daily to the imposing list of those who are protesting against turning part of Central Park into cinder-tracks and dusty baseball diamonds. The City Club's letter is particularly effective because it comes from an organization which has always taken an active part in the campaign for more playgrounds.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 8 -- Rough riding in the Kentucky Derby Saturday brought suspension today to the Jockeys who rode Broker's Tip, the winner, and Head Play, the second colt.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Germany, China and Belgium discussed world economic conditions with the United States Government here today. The German mission, consisting of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, head of the Reichsbank, and Dr. Hans Luther, German Ambassador to the United States, had the heaviest day

The Martin B. Brown Printing and Binding Company, criticized last year by Joseph V. McKee, then Acting Mayor, as holding a monopoly on city printing, was one of the bidders rejected yesterday when the Board of Elections swarded to the Isaac Goldman Company, low bidder, two contracts for materials to be used in the repeal election on May 23.

James Butler's Star Fire, making her second start of the year, scored on easy victory in the Boulevard Purse, the mile and seventy-yard feature race, at the Jamaica course yesterday and paid her backers at the rate of 15 to 1.

On June 5 Chicago will elect twenty-one judges of the Circuit Court, one of the Probate Court and one of the Superior Court. For years the Chicago Bar Association has made no bones about expressing bluntly its opinions of candidates for judicial office.

Prices for the return engagement of "When Ladies Meet," which comes next week to the Royale Theatre, will range from 25 cents to $1 for all performances. The top price for tickets to "Counsellorat-Law," also opening Monday at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre, will be $2.

PARIS, May 8 -- Without making a definite decision, the French Cabinet council today considered a proposal made by Edouard Herriot in his report on Washington talks that France should at the earliest moment make the war-debts payment of $19,000,000 to the United States which Parliament deferred last December.

The first suit to be filed against the banks of the New York Clearing House Association to establish their liability for deposits in the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company was brought yesterday by the Weaver Street Improvement Corooration, a depositor.
American sources of modern art are illustrated in an exhibition which the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, will open to its members today and to the public tomorrow.

The generic division of mankind into the ranks of those who passionately delight in the works of W. S. Gilbert and Arthur Sullivan and those who treat said classics with polite tolerance is apt to play strange tricks with critical judgment.

Richard Whitney was re-elected president of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday for the fourth, consecutive term. The nominating committee renominated him more than a month ago, virtually assuring his re-election. E.H.H. Simmons was his predecessor.

The Continental Bank and Trust Company is trustee and fiscal agent for $437,500 of the Maryland Apartment Building ten-year cumulative income sinking fund mortgage bonds and also successor trustee and fiscal agent for $220,000 Glenwar Realty Corporation first mortgage 6 per cent serial gold bonds.

ASKED to comment on the extraordinary number of low-hit games being pitched this season, with fellows like Parmelee, Schumacher and Berly coming through with one-hitters or two-hitters, Rogers Hornsby said briefly: "They're still using the lively tall in the American League."

The sixth trial in the series of more than 100 indictments obtained by the District Attorney against election inspectors for alleged violations of the law at the election last Fall began yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Daniel V. McNamee.

ST. PAUL, May 8 -- Declaring that President Roosevelt in his two months in the White House has "worked miracles of accomplishment," Postmaster General Farley told Minnesota Democrats at a Jefferson dinner here tonight that no "orgy of inflation" is to be expected in the President's currencymeasures.

WASHINGTON, May 8 --The administration railroad bill is not offered as a solution of transportation problems, nor does it put the government Into the transportation field. Secretary Roper told the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce today.

Coincidentally with Mayor O'Brien's announcement yesterday that he would grant a hearing of several hours as soon as possible to opponents of the projected baseball diamonds and other athletic developments on the Central Park Reservoir site, the Park Association's advisory council met with Park Comimissioner John E. Sheeny in an effort to reach a compomise.

The deliberate depreciation of a country's currency in foreign exchange, far from helping, is definitely harmful to the export trade of that country, according to Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank.

BASLE, May 8 -- Unshaken faith in the gold standard and in political and economic as well as financial internationalism, as one way out of the depression, psrmeated Gates W. McGarrah's third annual report as president of the Bank for International Settlements at the general assembly here this afternoon.

ST. LOUIS, May 8 (AP). -- Bob Boken, substitute second baseman, hit a homer in the twelfth inning and scored behind Schulte to give Washington a 10-to-8 victory over the St. Louis Browns in the first game of the series today.

OTTAWA, May 8 (Canadian Press) -- News broadcasting in Canada is restricted to matter authorized by The Canadian Press except in the case of local news, which must be obtained by arrangement with local newspapers, under regulations made public today by the Canadian Radio Broadcasting Commission.

Shoe merchants were told yesterday at the semi-annual style conference of the National Shoe Retailers Association at the Hotel Astor that they have an excellent opportunity to increase unit sales during the Fall and Winter season because women's types are so definitely styled for specific purposes.

The building of insurmountable barriers of trade at every frontier is the primary cause of the world-wide depression, Claude G. Bowers, newly appointed Ambassador to Spain, declared yesterday before a small gathering of executives of the Spanish Chamber of Commerce.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Movements of vessels follow: all dates are May 6, unless otherwise specified:

The Theatre Guild last evening added itself -- and the corporation -- to the list of those who have brooded about philosophy in a villa overlooking the Lake of Como. It did soin "The Mask and the Face," the translation courtesies (out of Luigi Chiarelli) being by way of W. Somerset Maugham.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Domestic consumers will be relieved of the tax on electric power after Sept. 1, under the terms of the House tax measure as rewritten today by the Senate Finance Committee and scheduled to be reported on Wednesday.

Police Commissioner James S. Bolan walked into a private room at Roosevelt Hospital yesterday and ordered Patrolman Thomas P. Glennon Jr., paralyzed last Christmas morning by gangsters' bullets, to appear at City Hall on June 1 and have Mayor O'Brien pin the William McClain Freeman Medal for police valor on his chest.

Ellsworth Vines, national tennis champion, will Join the Davis Cup forces of the United States in the final round tie of the North American zone, to be played with the winner of the match between Cuba and Canada which starts tomorrow at Hot Springs, Va.

After re-election as president of the Board of Education at the board's annual meeting yesterday, Dr. George J. Ryan expressed the opinion that the public schools had withstood "the successive shocks of the depression" and that the time was "not far distant" when the erection of new buildings and other work interrupted by the need for economy would be resumed.

BERLIN, May 9. -- A huge bonfire of books, the culmination of the National Socialist students' campaign against the "un-German" spirit will be touched off tomorrow night in a square in front of Berlin University, in the presence of the Minister of Public Enlightenment, Dr. Goebbels, who will deliver an address on "the symbolic significance" of the gesture.

The West Side Association of Commerce and the New York Florists Club joined yesterday the concerted fight of civic, artistic and business organizations against Park Commissioner Sheehy's plans for developing the Central Park reservoir site with athletic fields.
The Wheatley Stable's Iseult and James Butler's Apprentice divided the spotlight at Jamaica yesterday, both winning in a manner to Indicate that they are in fine form and may go far.

A situation in which home owners throughout Connecticut faced loss of their property it they were unable, because of the depression, to pay taxes would be met this week by emergency action of the Connecticut Legislature, it was learned last night.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Several sections of the administration rail-road bill were criticized at the hearing today before the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee, and Joseph B. Eastman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, who has been mentioned as coordinator to put the bill into effect, admitted that parts of it were so loosely drawn that he did not know what they meant.

Two young men who partly earned their college expenses received the Prix de Rome awards in arcliitecture and landscape architecture yesterday In the annual competitions judged at the Grand Central Art Galleries.

Meeting objections raised by the national transportation committee and other critics of the railroads, the railroads of the East announced yesterday that beginning on July 1 they propose to eliminate "a large number" of circuitous routes. The committee, which had been headed by the late Calvin Coolidge, asserted that a waste arose from rail-roads sending freight over round-about routes in order to retain as much of the "haul" as possible for individual companies.

Charges of fraud in the five-year contract awarded by the city to the Manhattan Ash Removal Company for the removal of garbage and ashes in Brooklyn, were made and denied before Supreme Court Justice Valente yesterday in three suits to set aside the contract.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As an instance of the crying need for additional regulation of certain public utilities, my own recent experience with an "independent" electric lighting company will serve. Locating among my papers a receipt for $10 given to me several

The United Synagogue of America added its support yesterday to the movement for a united American Jewish front in the face of Nazi anti-Semitism. At the closing of the organization's three-day convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania, a resolution was adopted urging the appointment of a committee to bring about the unity of leadership, held essential.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey yesterday announced that, effective July 1, all men employes at the age of 60 years would be retired, except under special conditions which in no event could apply to those beyond 62 years of age.

Honorary membership in the Advertising Club of New York was conferred yesterday upon President Roosevelt. Colonel Charles A. Lindbergb and Adolph S. Ochs at the annuel meeting. Grover A. Whalen was re-elected president of the club.

An attempt by two robbers to hold up a Long Island City cigar store, only two doors from the rented quarters of the Queens County Court and just around the corner from the County Court House building, resulted last evening in the killing of one of them and the wounding of the other by their intended victims.

LONDON, May 9. -- Prime Minister MacDonald announced in the House of Commons today that there was "every prospect of an agreement" between Great Britain and the United States on an immediate tariff truce.

PURCHASE, N.Y., May 9. -- Mrs. Leo Federman of Glen Oaks continued the pace she sat last week in a Long Island competition by annexing low gross honors in a Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day event at the Century Country Club today.

L.F.Loree, president of the Delaware Hudson Company, listened to questions about the company's purchase of $11,000,000 in New York Central stock raised by two stockholders at the annual meeting of his company yesterday, reassured the objectors and concluded the discussion by announced that luncheon was about to be served.
Fifteen Manhattan and Bronx properties were bought in by the plaintiffs in foreclosure actions yesterday. The results follow:

HAMILTON, N.Y., May 9. -- Colgate defeated Lafayette by pounding two pitchers for twelve hits, 12 to 1, today. A heavy barrage of long drives in the eighth was good for seven runs. 2?or the home team Van Heusen was effective, scattering the losers' safeties nicely, and he was not scored on until the ninth.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 9. -- A general retail sales tax of 1 per cent and a State income tax ranging from 1 to 5 per cent were included in a financial program approved here today at a conference of State Senators representing both political parties.

BALTIMORE, May 9 (AP). -- In a sensational head finish, Euryalus, sporting the silks of G. R. Fleischman's Tedlu Stable, defeated Mrs. John Hay Whitney's Sugar Cake in the six-furlong feature at Pimlico today.

With traders disposed to mark time, either because of weariness or caution, or both, the share market yielded the spotlight yesterday to the commodity markets, Wall Street seemed to have lost interest, for the time being, in the futile business of guessing how far the President will go with inflation.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Regulations for the distribution of medicinal liquors were issued by the Industrial Alcohol Bureau today providing that physicians may prescribe thirty-day supplies of spirits and wines in ordinary cases and a ninety-day supply in exceptional cases.

Final preparations were made here last night by leaders of the Veterans' Expeditionary Force for the start today of a march to Washington where with other contingents they intend to demand immediate bonus payment, restoration of veterans' disbursements and farm and unemployment relief.

Two men suspected of being the agents of an "association" which exacts tribute from fish dealers throughout the city were arrested yesterday on charges of attempted extortion at Fulton Market, the centre of the fish industry in the metropolitan area.

There are many anglers who would not waste their time fishing in streams and rivers; for them the real thrills are to be found upon some broad lake, or some small, quiet lake that lends peace and contentment to the art of hooking a bass, trout, a musky or a pike.

Centeral Park Patrons. Children belong in Central Park, but they have no exclusive title to it.If we insist on thinking of groups and not of the people of the city as a whole, there is another group which is entitled to consideration.

"$25 an Hour," a new comedy by Gladys Unger and Leyla Georgie, based on an outline by Erno Balogh, will open this evening at the Masque Theatre. Georges Metaxa, Olga Baclanova and Jean Arthur are featured in the cast. Thomas Mitohell, who staged the play and is associated in its presentation with Alfred E. Aarons will depart for Hollywood tomorrow.

Halted as he was at work last night on his scaffold in the Great Hall of the seventy-story RCA Building in Rockefeller Center, Diego Rivera, the celebrated Mexican mural painter whose communistic leanings have frequently enveloped him in controversy, was informed that the fresco on which he was engaged, and which he had regarded as his masterpiece, was no longer acceptable to the Rockefeller family.

Agreement for united action by the three organizations seeking to bring about the nomination of a fusion ticket to wrest control of the city government from Tammany was reached yesterday at a conference at the office of former Governor Charles S. Whitman, 4O Wall Street.

Although ultimate repeal "seems to be in the offing," the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform and similar groups face a fight for years to come to achieve and hold for the people the goal of "true temperance," Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, said yesterday at a ratification week luncheon of the women's organization at the Hotel Commodore.

Pledging his administration to "no deviation from the policy of the five-cent fare," Mayor O'Brien curtly rejected yesterday Controller Berry's proposal for a five-cent tax on subway rides as part of a program to aid the city's credit.

LONDON, May 9. -- Norman H. Davis, President Roosevelt's special Ambassador, gave the Hitler government a piece of America's mind today during a long and friendly talk on disarmament with Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, Chancellor Hitler's chief adviser on foreign affairs, who is visiting London.
WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 6:

GENEVA, May 9 -- The bureau of the arms conference decided today to give the parley a few days' sick leave pending consultations between two doctors, Captain Anthony Eden of Great Britain and Rudolf Nadolny of Germany. If these progress, Captain Eden will consult some other colleagues, notably Hugh R. Wilson of the United States, Rene Massigli of France and Signor di Sorga of Italy.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 9 -- The season's Initial one-day golf tournament of the New York Athletic Club attracted 129 players today to the Winged Foot links.

The Controller boldly enters the Forbidden City of transit finance. For years citizens have been traveling in the subways for five cents, though that sum has barely covered costs on the old lines (leaving out the elevated) and is not nearly covering them on the new.

R.B. White, president of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, was elected yesterday president of the Western Union Telegraph Company at the regular meeting of the board of directors to succeed Newcomb Carlton, who was elected chairman of the board and senior officer of the company.
While the midtown garment centre furnished the largest number of business leases reported yesterday, rentals in other sections of Manhattan were of outstanding interest.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the editorial "A County Model" THE TIMES grows enthusiastic in endorsing the work of the WestChester County Recreation Commission, tells us that "Westchester has come to be a synonym for the finest county community spirit," and

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The Wagner $500,000,000 relief bill for direct grants to States was finally approved by the House today without a record vote after Republican opponents had failed to reject a special rule prohibiting points of order against the conference report.

Cleveland, Ohio. A new issue of $500,000 City of Cleveland (Ohio) 4 1/4 per cent electric light system bonds, dated April 1, 1913, and due on April 1, 1948, will be placed on the market today by a syndicate composed of Lehman Brothers, Estabrook Co., Otis Co., Inc., Hannahs.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Edgerton Parsons is giving a farewell tea tomorrow at her home, 21 East Sixty-sixth Street, for her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Carl Frederick Fayen, who will leave in a few days to make their home in Pasadena, Cal., for two years.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9. -- Secretary Wallace appealed here today for farm bill support from the industrial East, declaring that the "rules of the game" had been changed and that "a continuing spirit of cooperation and unconquerable desire for social justice" was demanded, in order to "place a disorganized economic order upon a stable basis.

The Board of Estimate, meeting yesterday in Committee of the Whole, balked at reapportioning the cost of a local improvement in Queens after Deputy Controller Prial discovered that nine of the property owners petitioning for relief were banks and mortgage companies.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I wish to correct several statements made by Henry L. Caravati, executive secretary of the National Council of Catholic Men, in his letter to THE TIMES. Mr. Caravati states that at Congressional hearings twenty-one responsible

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am eleven years old and go to public school and expect to graduate next year. Last night I was very anxious to listen to our President, Mr. Roosevelt, in his radio talk. But my regular bedtime is 9 o'clock and I was so sleepy I just
Factory employment in New York State in April increased 2.2 per cent over March, and payrolls were 4.4 percent higher, it was announced yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews,State Industrial Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- In a final plea before a Senate banking and currency subcommittee considering the home mortgage bill passed by the House, D.E. McAvoy, secretary of the Home Mortgage Advisory Board, today asked that home-owners receive substantially the same relief that is provided for farm owners in the farm-mortgage section of the agricultural relief bill.

WASHINGTON, May 9. --Among his other executive abilities, the President has a card-index type of mind. This is very useful to him. It saves time and waste motion, and it rarely turns up a blank. But frequently it causes -wonder and worry to those friends and advisers whom he seemingly has tucked away in separate mental envelopes, for use if, when and as wanted.

A protest march in which more than 100,000 persons are expected to participate will be held today under the auspices of the American Jewish Congress to expres the indignation of American Jews and Christian sympathizers against the policies of the Hitler government in Germany.

Helen Keller, noted worker among the blind, who is both blind and deaf herself, declared last night in an open letter to German students, given out through The Associated Press, that, although her books and those of ''the best minds in Europe" might be burned, the ideas in them "will continue to quicken other minds."

To the Editor of The New York Times: I cheerfully accept W.J. Cobb's criticism, and would be the last to ignore the value of the 123-odd billions of dollars of long-term debts in the United States as assets to the lenders. At the same time, looking at the

MADRID, May 9 -- Nine persons were killed and many injured in Anarcho-syndicalist bombings in Spain today, but a general strike called by these outlawed rivals of the Socialist nion was a flat failure, despite the fact that it paralyzed activities in twenty Spanish cities and retarded business in many more.

Thomas Beer's "The Wall and the Arrow," a novel with a political background that Alfred A. Knopf had planned to publish this Spring, probably will not be ready this year. Mr. Knopf will publish a collection of short stories by Thomas Beer in the Fall.

To CHARLES W. ELIOT, at that time a teacher of chemistry in the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a friend wrote the year before his election as president of Harvard College that it was only in such a place as Cambridge and its atmosphere of learning and its memories that one might hope for a university --

Business in the money market was confined to three-four months' money at 1 and 1'4 per cent, respectively. Other maturities were negected. On the Stock Exchange, day loans continued at 1 per cent. Commercial paper and acceptances were quiet and unchanged in discount.

LONDON, May 9 (AP). -- Scores at the conclusion of first-class cricket games in England, which started Saturday and ended today, follow: At Leytnn-Warwickshire defeated Essexby an Inning and 6 runs. Warwickshire. 295 (Ord. 77) ; Essex, 94 and 195 (Pearee, 79; Paine, 5 for 27 and 6 for 68).
Timely hitting and flawless play in the field enabled the Manhattan nine to down Upsala, 5 to 3, at Manhattan Field yesterday afternoon.

Not one of the present members of the Newark City Commission, with the exception of Commissioner Meyer C. Ellenstein, was among the first five candidates in late returns early this morning from the local election held in Newark yesterday.
BOSTON, May 9 (AP). -- Fred Frankhouse's curve ball subdued the league-leading Pittsburgh Pirates today as the Braves evened the series with a 7-to-0 victory.

The chorus of the Metropolitan Opera will appear with another organization for the first time in its history when it will join the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra this Summer in two programs at the Lewisohn Stadium, it was announced yesterday.

The new United States liner Washington will sail today at noon from Pier 61, North River, on her maiden trip to Cobh. Plymouth, Havre and Hamburg with about 750 passengers. Nearly 300 passengers had been booked yesterday in cabin class, setting a new mark for cabin sailings on the Atlantic this year, and applications for space continued to arrive at the offices of the lines at 1 Broadway.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- Prices of hogs were steady to 15 cents higher today despite larger supplies, and the day's average rose 10 cents to $4.20, the highest since Sept. 14 and a recovery of $1.40 from the season's low. Arrivals were swelled by trucked-in hogs, because of the sharp upturn on Monday.

All was cryptic last night In Parlor C at the Hotel New Yorker as twenty-five ordinarily sane professors, mathematicians and school principals assembled at a greenbaize topped table and went mildly berserk in a mental way for a few happy hours.
WASHINGTON, May 9. -- President Roosevelt discussed world economic conditions with T.V. Soong, special representative of China, and conferred with Senator Glass on banking reform legislation.

A group of oil executives including Walter C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, is expected to be In Washington today with a view to obtaining some information as to the proposed general industries bill to determine whether its powers will be sufficiently broad to enable the oil industry to get along without some special legislation.

Johnnie Miller, 10 years old, told the judge and the crowded court of Queens County yesterday afternoon at the trial for first-degree murder of his chum, Harry Murch, that he saw Harry kill William Bender last Jan. 31. Harry is 16, and the victim was 12 and sickly.
CHICAGO, May 9. -- Postmaster General Farley made addresses today before the Mail Advertising Service Association and at the dedication of a memorial to Mayor Cermak.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- With the promised support of President Roosevelt behind it the revised Glass bill, designed to correct abuses in banking practices and to insure bank deposits, will be introduced in the Senate tomorrow and immediately referred to the Banking and Currency Committee, which is expected to report the measure back to the Senate in a few days.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- John F. Curry, leader of Tammany Hall, and John H. McCooey, the Brooklyn Democratic leader, visited the White House early today on their return from the Kentucky Derby and spent some time with Louis McHenry Howe, secretary to the President.

Debutantes or this and former years are aiding Mrs. Duncan R. Linsley in arrangements for the dinner dance to take place tonight in the Roof Garden of the St. Regis for the benefit of Stony Wold Sanatorium. The benefit is given under the auspices of Auxiliary Six of the sanatorium, located at Lake Keeshaqua in the Adirondacks, which offers care and treatment to young business women suffering from pulmonary tuberculosis.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- President Roosevelt will be called upon tomorrow to determine the form of the proposed national industrial recovery act, to bring about a "partnership" between industry and the government in the fight against the forces of depression.
BERLIN, May 9 (AP). -- The Reichs bank's statement as of May 6 shows the following changes, in reichsmarks:

The consensus among real estate men and realty interests regarding Controller Berry's plan to increase the city's revenue by the imposition of a five-cent tax on every subway tare and a ten-cent fare on the East River bridges and municipal ferTies, is that not only the city's transit facilities, but the city itself should be put on a paying basis at once.

VIENNA, May 9 -- The visit to Vienna next Saturday of Dr. Hans Frank, the Bavarian Minister of Justice; Hans Kerrl, President of the Prussian Diet; Dr. Robert Ley, President of the Prussian State Council; Wilhelm Kube, Prussian State Minister, and three other Prussian officials will bring the hostility between the Hitler and Dollfuss governments to a head, if the language of Chancellor Dollfuss's organ, the Reichspost, this morning is to be credited.
BARNSTABLE, Mass., May 9 (AP). -- A complete withdrawal of previous statements that "other parties" were involved with him in the kidnapping of Margaret McMath was made today by Kenneth Buck.

The administration of immigration laws would be aided by a codification of the existing statutes and court decisions, in the opinion of Colonel Daniel W. MacCormack, recently appointed Commissioner General of Immigration, who addressed the members of the American Arbitration Association at a luncheon in his honor yesterday at the Hotel Commodore.

ALBANY, May 9 -- The Public Service Commission's contention that certain allegations in the suit of the Associated Gas and Electric Company against the commission did not constitute a sufficient array of facts to constitute a cause of action has been denied in a decision just handed down by Supreme Court Justice F. Walter Bliss.
LONDON, May 9. -- Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald's statement to the House of Commons today on his talk with President Roosevelt regarding disarmament and European security was as follows:

The annual report of the New England Public Service Company shows consolidated gross operating revenues of $18,564,011 for 1932, a decrease of $1,379,983, or 6.92 per cent, as compared with 1931. Net earnings after expenses, general taxes and depreciation amounted to $8,866,582, a decrease of $160,387, or 1.77 per cent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: William Bierman complains in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES that it is unjust to consider it unethical for a physician to patent a medical invention, and suggests as a remedy that such inventions should be turned over to the American Medical

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Renewed efforts to end the war in the Chaco region between Bolivia and Paraguay were blocked today by the failure of the Argentine and Chilean envoys here to attend a meeting called by the Commission of Neutrals.

Holders of preferred stock of the Illinois Power Company have been advised that the electric plant of the Illinois Electric Power Company has been conveyed to Illinois Power, that the street railway property of Illinois Power has been conveyed to Illinois Electric Power and that the name of that company has been changed to Springfield Transportation Company.

Officials of the National Committee to Aid the Victims of German Fascism announced yesterday they would file a protest with District Attorney Crain today regarding the attempt of two detectives from his office to raid the offices of the committee at 75 Fifth Avenue.

PARIS, May 9. -- After a long session this morning, the Council of Ministers, under the chairmanship of President Lebrun, failed to come to any definite decision on a wardebt settlement, chiefly because they found themselves directly opposed to American views.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., May 9 -- A proposal to have Governor Lehman of New York act as a preliminary referee in the fight between the Lehigh Valley juvenile strikers and operators of shirt factories over "sweatshop" conditions was taken under consideration today.

Buyers' Arrivals Dropped. A drop in the number of buyers visiting the market during the week ended yesterday was noted in comparison with the figures for the preceding week and for the same period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 9 -- Professor William Lyon Phelps, who today closed a forty-year period as a member of the English faculty of Yale University, received an unusual ovation this afternoon when he concluded his teaching career with the final recitation of his annual class in Tennyson and Browning, which he has given since he began his faculty career.

A suit by the State of New York which if successful would have cost the city a huge loss in taxes, thrown hundreds of men out of work, disrupted the terminal facilities of Brooklyn and left the State in possession of a "white elephant" in the form of a piece of East River waterfront property was disclosed in Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The thirteenth annual statement of the United States Government Life Insurance Fund notes that the assets total over $572,000,000, of which $89,000,000 is loaned to policy holders at 6 per cent interest. The other $483,OOO,000 is invested at
WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The War Department issued The following orders today:

ST. LOUIS, May 9 (AP). -- Bob Boken, substitute second baseman, duplicated his performance of yesterday by batting in two runs in the final inning today to permit the Washington Senators to take the second game of the series from the St. Louis Browns, 7 to 5.
PLANDOME, L.I., May 9. -- Walter B. Thoren, representing the Shore View Club, was the winner the opening one-day tournament of the year for the Metropolitan Golf Association today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Peter Bolingbroke's complaint on the subject of "Pullman Economies" came to my attention as I returned from Chicago on the New York Central's train 6 the very day it appeared in your columns. Although I have not yet been

After devoting a good part of its meeting yesterday to hearing arguments for and against the granting of tax exemption for the Hillside model housing development in the northeast Bronx, the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate voted to consider the matter again at an executive session today.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- President Roosevelt's request for authority to decrease or increase tariffs in "bargains" with other governments for international trade has been completed. It will be submitted to Congress as soon as the tariff truce, which has been proposed to the other nations by the United States, is assured of success, according to leaders who will handle the measure when it reaches Capitol Hill.

Spring activity in the apartment rental field was reflected in numerous leases reported yesterday. All sections of Manhattan were represented, in addition to localities in the other boroughs. The rentals included the following:

Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve, speaking for the last time to this year's graduating class at Barnard College, told the seniors yesterday that "any kind of work if done honestly and well has dignity" and asked them "to aim finally at the higher achievements, the more difficult, the more responsible tasks."

Several proposed changes in the constitution and by-laws of the Actors Equity Association, the chief of which would amend those documents to limit actors not citizens of the United States to alien membership, except those already qualified to resident membership, after June 1, will be presented at the twentieth annual meeting of the association, to be held at the Astor Hotel on Friday, June 2, at 2:30 P.M.

A motion asking to have $12,000,000 in interest and amortization payments of subway bonds for 1933 paid out of the income of the Eighth Avenue line and not from tax funds was filed yesterday in the Supreme Court by Harold Riegelman, counsel for William Church Osborn and August Heckscher, taxpayers.

POONA, India, May 9 -- A prominent Bombay physician, called today to attend Mahatma Gandhi on the second day of his proposed three weeks fast, found the 63-year-old Indian Nationalist leader weak after a severe attack of nausea.

"I'm glad you mentioned Bernle," said Detective Vance. "Yep, he's still in baseball. He's with, the Rochester club, and I'm the cause of it in a way. You know about my famous Homosassa hunting and fishing preserve in Florida? Yes, of course, finest hunting and fishing in the world. Personal service. Innkeeper Arthur C. Vance sets a delicious table. Hunting and fishing expeditions organized for guests; game guaranteed.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Despite the government's demand that gold be returned to the Federal Reserve Banks and the Treasury there was still $658,094,142 in gold and gold certificates outstanding April 30, according to the Treasury's monthly circulation statement issued today.

A new action in behalf of all of the depositors of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday against the officers of the New York Clearing House Association, the members of its clearing house committee and Eldon Bisbee, its counsel, to hold them responsible for alleged agreements to guarantee that the depositors in the bank would be paid in full.

Nine men believed to have been hired by cordial shop men to plead guilty in prohibition cases in place of actual defendants who were absent from court and to serve short terms in the Federal House of Detention were adjudged in contempt of court following the discovery yesterday that they were impostors.

Bishop William T. Manning announced yesterday afternoon in his annual address at the 150th convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York in Synod Hall of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, that Harry Fayne Bingham, sportsman and philanthropist of this city and Newport, R.I., had given to the diocese his 475-acre estate at Esopus, N.Y., with half a mile fronting on the Hudson, and on which there are twelve dwellings.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 9. -- Manhattan College made its debut in intercollegiate crew racing on Lake Carnegie today when the Green varsity heavyweights and 150-pounders and the second 150-pounders raced against Princeton and Hun School crews.

General Francesco de Pinedo, Italian transatlantic filer, who plans to take off from Floyd Bennett Field on Saturday to fly as far toward Karachi, India, as his fuel and his own powers of endurance will let him, will be in Hartford, Conn., today for final tests at the Pratt Whitney plant of the 525-horsepower Wasp engine with which his special long-distance airplane will be equipped.

When George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance; the National Surety Company and the National Surety Corporation appear before Supreme Court Justice Edward J. Gavegan today to show cause why the plan of reorganization of the National Surety Company should not be set aside, representatives of the committee headed by C. Prevost Boyce will be present to oppose the reorganization unless changes are made for the benefit of creditors whom it represents.

TRENTON, N.J., May 9. -- Because of options included in offers, the issuing authorities of the State House Commission rejected today two bids for the proposed sale of 55,000,000 bonds for emergency relief. The officials will meet in a few days to determine the next step for marketing the securities, which are a part of the $20,000,000 issue approved by the voters last November.
WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Eugene Black, Governor of the Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank, is definitely slated to succeed Eugene Meyer as Governor of the Federal Reserve Board.

Robert Worth Bingham, newly appointed United States Ambassador to Great Britain, is sailing today to take up his diplomatic duties. He will leave on the new United States liner Washington on her maiden voyage to the Channel ports.

SALISBURY, N.C., May 9 (AP). -- Judge Wilson Warllck signed a judgment in Superior Court here today approving plans for distributing the estate of Smith Reynolds to charity after his first and second wives and their children have divided $5,000,000 equally.
Jim Browning of Missouri, recognized in New York State as the world's heavyweight wrestling champion, successfully defended his title before a crowd of 8,000 in the New York Coliseum last night.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 9 (Canadiani Press). -- E.N. Rhodes, Minister of Finance, gave notice today in the House of Commons that he would ask authority to borrow up to $750,000,000 this year for the Dominion Government, but, he said, this did not necessarily mean that borrowings of that amount would be carried out.

PARIS, May 9. -- In a conference today under the chairmanship of Premier Daladier, in which Cabinet Ministers, colonial Governors and their technical assistants took part, a movement was started by which it is hoped to strengthen the ties of France's vast colonial "empire" and to make it ultimately a selfcontained economic unit.

The regulations under which licenses may be obtained for the retail sale of 3.2 per cent beer and wine were made public yesterday by Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board. The board has not decided if it will permit the sale of beer over bars, Mr. Mulrooney said.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt headed, a gathering of 800 men and women who paid tribute to Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen, daughter of the late William Jennings Bryan, at a dinner in the Hotel Commodore last night, on the eve of her departure to take up her duties as Minister to Denmark and Iceland.
The market value of bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange increased $799,595,047 during April, according to the monthly compilation prepared by the Exchange.

No doubt it will be disputed hereafter whether the turn for the better in trade and prices was primarily a result of "inflation talk." Speculators have admittedly been busy, since Congressional debate on the inflation bill, in bidding up prices, on the ostensible theory that fiat-money issues would quickly follow the gold embargo.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Whatever war debts authority the President decides to seek from Congress he will request for the period of the World Economic and Monetary Conference only, will agree to refer any provisional settlements back to Congress for approval and will not dispatch his message on the subject until a few days before the end of the present session.

The New Jersey Legislature alternates between fits of industry and frequent adjournments. The Newark News makes a comparison with the Pennsylvania Legislature, which, it says, "grossly cheated" the people by adjourning the other day until 1935 " after a session of only eighteen weeks."

AURORA, 111., May 9 (AP). -- Black Mammy, 21 to 1 shot, a 6-year-old mare owned by Mrs. S. J. Orr, raced to a surprise victory today in the Exposition Park Hotel Purse, top event of the program at Aurora.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Federal Judge James A. Lowell of Massachusetts, who is threatened with impeachment because of the way he freed George Crawford, a Negro wanted in Virginia for murder, seemed destined today to be rebuked by the Supreme Court on a quite separate score.

Although trading In bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday was on a diminished scale, amounting to $12,719,000, the market was steadier than on Monday. United States Government bonds closed unchanged to 6/32 point higher, foreign loans showed rallying tendencies and domestic corporation issues averaged a shade higher for the day.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 9 -- Bolivians attacked Paraguayan forces by land and by air at seven points in the Chaco region yesterday, inflicting casualties in every encounter, according to a General Staff bulletin today.

An accounting in the estate of Mrs. Helen L. Phelps Stokes, widow of Anson Phelps Stottes, banker and philanthropist, who died June 28, 1930, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday, showed that the executors, Isaac Newton Phelps Stokes, 953 Fifth Avenue, and Harold Phelpa Stokes, 100 William Street, sons of the decedent, have collected a total of $1,022,875.20 and paid out $979,812.50, leaving a balance of$43,062.70.

Declaring that world trade as a stimulus to business recovery has been eliminated for a long time, Paul M. Mazur, vice president of Lehman Brothers, said yesterday that it would be a wiser course for this country "to forget internationalism for at least a generation."

BERLIN, May 9 -- Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Popular Enlightenment and Propagand, summoned the managers, actors and art directors of the German theatres before him at the Kaiserhof today and unfolded to them his theory of art.
HAKTFORD, Conn., May 9. -- Beer sales in Connecticut will become legal tomorrow under the terms of a proclamation signed today by Governor Cross, acting under the new liquor control act.

Secretary HULL stated yesterday that this Government is to conduct negotiations about the war debts. This does not mean that their discussion will be thrust into the World Economic Conference. Prime Minister MACDONALD asserted that it would not be, and Secretary HULL intimates that it will be outside the conference but contemporary with it.

MONTREAL, May 9 (AP). -- The Montreal Royals chalked up their sixth straight victory and took undisputed possession of second place in the International League today by trouncing Jersey City, 8 to 4, in the series opener.

Albert C. Simonson of the Marshall Chess Club was the first to win a game in the fourth round of the United States team trial tournament at the West Side Y.M.C.A. last night. His opponent, Robert Willman of the Manhattan Chess Club, succumbed to a King's side attack in thirty-two moves.

Albert C. Simonson of the Marshall Chess Club was the first to win a game in the fourth round of the United States team trial tournament at the West Side Y.M.C.A. last night. His opponent, Robert Willman of the Manhattan Chess Club, succumbed to a King's side attack in thirty-two moves.

The pamphlet report of the Standard Power and Light Corporation for 1932 shows a net income of $1,860,323 after depreciation, taxes, charges, underlying preferred dividends and minority interest, including $1,011,263 due from the Deep Rock Oil Corporation, in receivership, and before deducting $413,991 net loss on securities sold during the year.
Sale of a North Bergen factory by a bank featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

The foreign exchange market was thrown into confusion yesterday by the uncontrolled fluctuations of the pound sterling, which alternately rose and fell in dollar valuation through a range of 5 1/2 cents. Having closed in London at $3.95, the pound sterling opened here at about two cents lower, fell to $3.90 3/4 and then abruptly rallied to $3.96 1/4, only to turn acutely weak again.

Unanimous opposition to abandonment of the city's policy of free public higher education, as proposed in Controller Berry's report to the Board of Estimate, was expressed yesterday by members of the Board of Higher Eduaction. Although few cared to discuss Mr. Berry's tuition fee plan directly because no details have been announced, all those interviewed agreed that the city had been fully recompensed in good citizenship for its maintenance of the public college.

Guy Endore, whose horror novel, "The Werewolf of Paris," published by Farrar Rinehart, has sold 6,000 copies in six weeks, wrote the book in six weeks, he said yesterday. He spent about two weeks preparing to write it, wrote the fifth chapter first, then the first chapter and then the last one.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 9 -- The Minnesota Farmers Holiday Association, meeting at Montevideo, voted a resolution today stating that the members would not pay debts or interest until "the dollar is an honest measure of value" and demanding that the government take over all banking and declare a national moratorium of mortgage foreclosures on farms and city homes.

MEXICO CITY, May 9 -- Ambassador and Mrs. Josephus Daniels were welcomed to Mexico tonight at a dinner at the Churubusco Country Club by a gathering representative of all phases of American life here.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation quarterly report, sent to Congress today, showed 2,409 authorizations for the last three months, totaling $50,525,996,40, and cancellations of withdrawals in the same period of $7,950,587,60.

Claude G. Bowers, newly appointed Ambassador to Spain, who will sail today for Madrid, was honored yesterday by more than twoscore newspaper executives at a farewell luncheon given by Maurice R. Teshnor, editor of Freeson Magazine, in the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP). -- The tragic but familiar story of the kidnapping and death a year ago of his world-famous son, Charles 4k. Lindbergh Jr., was related calmtoday to a packed court room by Colonel Lindbergh.

NEWARK, N.J., May 9. -- The proposed court attack on the constitutionality of the New Jersey convention for ratification of the prohibition amendment, to which delegates will be elected next Tuesday, was dropped today at a meeting of the dry campaign committee at the office of the Anti-Saloon League of New Jersey.

Fordham Prep strengthened Its lead in the Manhattan division C. H.S.A.A. race by defeating Mount St. Michael's High, 5 to 2, yesterday at Fordham Prep field for its fifth triumph in as many C.H.S. A.A. baseball games. The victors staged a five-run rally in the fifth inning to win, with Sherman Mitchell's triple with the bases full the outstanding feature.

Price movements in local commodity markets were irregular yesterday, silver slumping and sugar recovering somewhat. Cocoa was weak. Trading volumes were generally light. Most of the important cash prices were somewhat lower.

Resting after the speculative excitement of the last few weeks, the share market gave itself up yesterday to a leisurely appraisal of the forces that have shaped its recent course. Fluctuations were confined to a narrow area and the volume of business on the Stock Exchange fell off sharply.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Prosperity Shop, Inc., of 1,279 Third Avenue, telephone 'Rhinelander 4-6369, receives gifts of unwanted or not-needed articles of any description and sells them for the benefit of free hospital work, the feeding of children of the
