WASHINGTON, May 9 -- A new bonus march converged on Washington today as the government made plans to house a group due tomorrow in an abandoned army post ten miles from the city.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP). -- President Roosevelt played the role of referee today, quietly ruling on Senate and House differences over his giant Tennessee Valley program and flattening obstructions to speedy enactment.

The revised brokers' commissions on bonds selling at less than $10 each on the New York Stock Exchange, which were recently approved by the governing committee of the Exchange, have been ratified by the members of the Exchange and will become effective today.

The Triborough Bridge Authority named recently by Mayor O'Brien will draft a request for a $35,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to complete the span linking Manhattan with the Bronx and Queens, it was announced yesterday.

While Park Commissioner Sheehy made ready to open the first baseball diamond on the Central Park reservoir site Saturday morning at 10 o'clock, F.H. La Guardia, former Republican candidate for Mayor, announced his opposition to the projected conversion of the thirty-four-acre tract into athletic fields.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10. -- Nearly 20,000 Jews marched five miles through the heart of the city late today in an anti-Hitler demonstration. Carrying banners denouncing the present German Government as a "double-cross" and a foe of progress, the marchers, who included patriarchs with long, flowing beards, smooth-faced shopkeepers and business men, and hundreds of women and children, ended their parade with a mass meeting in Reyburn Plaza.

The Broadway squad of plain-clothes patrolmen, organized about eighteen months ago to cope with the rapidly growing number of beggars and peddlers in the midtown district, has been unusually active for the last week, arresting thirty to fifty persons each day.

MADRID, May 10. -- By a majority which was obtained by having the nina members of the Cabinet join in the voting. Premier Azana's Left Wing coalition government, dominated by the Socialists with their strong trade union, today gagged the upper and middle-class parties in the Cortes, which the Opposition insists has outlived its mandate from the people.

There was an ironic fitness in the announcement that the Ger man Minister of Enlightenmen Was to make an address on the "symbolic significance" of the book bonfires in Germany. They certainly symbolize something! Such an exhibition of the new national spirit, silly and shameful as it seems, bespeaks a mass-movement plainly touched with insanity.

5th Av., 140, southwest corner of 10th St., 27.10x160; twelve-story office and stores; Seamen's Bank for Savings against Phoenix Commercial Co.; due, $254,275; costs. $511; taxes, $13,004; to the plaintiff for $220,000.

Looking fit enough to step on the Davis Cup firing line on instant notice, Ellsworth Vines of Pasadena, Gal., national tennis champion, returned to New York yesterday for the first time since he successfully defended his title at Forest Hills last September, when he defeated Henri Cochet of France in the final.

LONDON, May 10. -- The dollar was steadier today in the foreign-exchange market here after closing yesterday at $3.95 3/4 to the pound, and kept mostly in the neighborhood of $3.95, although it improved to close at $3.93 3/4. Francs were firm but Dutch guilders cheapened slightly.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Strenuous objection to the pending rail road consolidation bill was voiced by railway labor today, Donald R. Richberg, general counsel for the Railway Labor Executives Association, telling a Senate committee that economic recovery would be retarded, railway service to the public reduced and 50,000 to 300,000 employes thrown out of work.

GENEVA. May 10. -- A concession by Italy ended one of the oldest disarmament quarrels today when the effectives committee entered into its thorniest problem, namely, whether such organizations as the Blackshirts, the Brown Shirt Storm Detachments and the Steel Helmets should be counted as soldiers, and, if so, in what proportion.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The nomination of Eugene R. Black, governor of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, for membership on the Federal Reserve Board was sent to the Senate today by President Roosevelt, who intends to designate him for governor of the board after the nomination has been confirmed.

CHICAGO, May 10. -- An increase of 30 cents a hundred pounds, or about two-thirds of a cent a quart, for the producers supplying the Chicago area was won today by the Pure Milk Association, representing 17,800 dairymen.

ALBANY, May 10. -- Of the 1,786 law students who took the March bar examination, 645 were successful, it was annouced today by John Kirkland Clark of New York, Philip J. Wickser of Buffalo and Rollin B. Sanford of Albany, comprising the State Board of Law Examiners.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with a great deal of interest your editorial "One Bridge at a Time."

LONDON, May 10. -- Mrs. Ray Atherton, wife of the Charge d'Affaires of the United States Embassy in London, will present four New York women at the third and fourth royal courts of the year in Buckingham Palace on May 17 and 18. Fifteen Americans altogether will be presented.
WASHINGTON, May 10. -- President Roosevelt and a group of advisers discussed the national industrial recovery act and selected a committee to prepare a draft of legislation.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 10. -- The Connecticut House today concurred on a Senate amendment to House Bill 747 designed to protect home owners in New Haven and Greenwich from losses of property for non-payment of taxes. This bill, introduced in January by Representative Edward Platt of Sherman, had already passed both Senate and House, but it came back to the House yesterday from the Senate with, a third amendment and was tabled.

The outlook for transportation was discussed last night at a meeting of the Economic Club in the Hotel Astor by Leonor F. Loree, president of the Delaware Hudson Railroad Company; Walker D. Hines, Director General of Railroads during the World War, and Alfred H. Swayne, vice president of the General Motors Corporation.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward sharply yesterday and closed at the top, with gains of 26 to 29 points. October ended the day within 5 points of the high record made last week and at the highest closing price of the year.
NEW YORK. Miss Mary Pearsall Field gave a luncheon yesterday at the Plaza.

The American Power and Light Company and subsidiaries report for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28 net income of $7,535,125, comparing with full preferred dividend requirements of 59,649,846 for the period, of which $6,834,272 has been paid.

NEWARK, N.J., May 10. -- Information obtained by the government as a result of the double murder at the Elizabeth-Carteret Hotel on April 12, when two alleged beer-runners were killed, constituted the testimony as the actual hearing opened in a Federal court room here today in the proceedings brought by the Bureau of Industrial Alcohol to revoke the 3.2 beer permit issued to the Harrison Beverage Company of Harrison, N.J.
The address of Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan during the anti-Hitler demonstration yesterday follows:

LONDON, May 10 (AP). -- Following are the Board of Trade figures for the month of April: Exports of British products, u26,390,000; re-exports, foreign goods, u3,530,000; total exports, u29,920,000; total imports, u51,150,000; excess of imports, u21,230,000.

Four of the nine defendants in prohibition cases who were absent from Federal Court last Monday, when nine other men appeared for them and pleaded guilty, were surrendered yesterday by the Concord Casualty and Surety Company, which had written their bonds of $1,000 each.

PERHAPS Jack Dempsey, the Boy Promoter, signed up the wrong fighters. It was said that Jack had cornered the fight of the year when he signed Max Schmeling and Max Baer for their June debate at the Yankee Stadium, but, according to some witnesses, the fight of the year was held on Sixth Avenue the other night with no tickets of admission required and standing room only available.

The New York contingent of the new bonus army, numbering 193 war veterans, assembled in Union Square yesterday morning, collected a few $1 bills and some change, listened to the aims of its leaders -- "immediate payment of the bonus and repeal of the vicious national economy bill" -- marched to the Eternal Light, where wreaths were placed by the leaders, and then set out for Washington.
Details of various leasehold transactions in Manhattan became known yesterday through announcements by brokers and the recording of contracts at the Register's Office.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial the other day emphasizing the fact that a depreciated dollar will not necessarily mean expanded exports from the United States when foreign nations raise tariffs or apply quota restrictions to imports, suggests another point which appears to be often over-looked.

Supreme Court Justice Valente reserved decision yesterday on the application of creditors of the Natipnal Surety Company to set aside the plan for reorganizing the company as the National Surety Corporation on the ground that it is unfair to the creditors and policy holders.

The subcellar office of the eccentric and wealthy Edward Albert Ridley at 63 Alien Street, where a man was murdered two years ago, was the scene of a second and a third murder yesterday, and this time it was the 88-year-old Ridley himself -- known all over the east side for his odd dress, his reputed millions and his Whitmanesque beard -- and his secretary, Lee Weinstein, who were the victims.
PARIS, May 10. -- The newspaper polemics avoked by the war debt question have been cleverly turned against Edouard Herrlot by those of his foes who question the success of his mission to Washington.

PARIS, May 10. -- The terms of the proposed world tariff truce were discussed at length today in a conference of Premier Daladier and Finance Minister Georges Bonnet with P. Elbel and Robert Coulondre. French experts who accompanied Edouard Herriot to Washington.

Economic Developments. WASHINGTON -- President Roosevelt indicated yesterday that he would contribute to the proposed world tariff truce by withholding the imposition of tariffs authorized in the farm-relief bill. T. V. Soong said China and the United States were in general accord in their silver policy and China could not go on the gold standard.

Unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation increased 23,572 tons last month to 1,864,574 tons on April 30, it was announced yesterday. It was the first gain reported by the company since October, 1932.

The new United States cabin liner Washington sailed at noon yesterday on her maiden voyage to the Channel ports with 750 passengers, among whom were two newly appointed Ambassadors, Robert Worth Bingham, going to England, and Claude Bowers, going to Spain.

CHICAGO, May 10. -- More than 50,000 Chicago Jews joined today in a parade and demonstration in a protest against persecution of their race in Germany by the National Socialist party of Chancellor Adolph Hitler. The demonstration was staged as an expression of sentiment against the burning of the works of Jewish authors by Nazis and to condemn the choice of Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, anti-Semitic leader, as Germany's envoy to the World's Fair here.

The Concord Surety and Casualty Company, threatened by Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard with a loss of business in Federal court, consented yesterday to reduce its charge for writing bail bonds from 4 per cent to 3 per cent, the maximum fee allowed in State courts under the Jaw.

Legislation looking toward the greater protection, of game animals, birds and fish received more attention throughout the country this year than ever in the past, according to several surveys which have Just been completed.

All hail once more to our trusty and well-beloved old friends, Mr. DEBTS PICKETT and Dr. CLARENCE TRUE "WILSON, research secretary and general secretary respectively of the Methodist Board of Temperance, Prohibition and Public Morals.
Announcement of a rate cut yesterday by the Commodore, New Yorker and Pennsylvania Hotels brought a varied reaction among other hotels of the city.

Politicians in New Jersey's two largest municipalities were reticent yesterday over the overwhelming defoat meted out to the Newark city administration and the equally overwhelming victory accorded the Jersey City administration in Tuesday's commission elections.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Unless a miracle changes It fundamentally, the pending legislation for the regulation of interstate dealings in securities is going to result in a deplorable burden upon the country's business enterprises.

NEW CASTLE, Del., May 10. -- Talking of his project to set a new long-distance airplane flight record as if it were nothing more than a hop to Chicago, General Francesco de Pinedo outlined here today some of his plans for the most extraordinary flight ever undertaken in the annals of aviation.
DETROIT, May 10 (AP). -- The Athletics neared the .500 mark in the standings today by winning both engagements of a double-header from Detroit, 3 to 2 and 6 to 4.

Through eerie, dark caverns, clouds of soot that begrimed them from head to foot, and a two-ply brick wall of the apartment house at 648 Amsterdam Avenue, at Ninety-first Street, the six members of Police Emergency Squad 5, under Sergeant Albert Schroff, went yesterday to the rescue of Tiger, a 25-pound cat that had fallen down a flue.

Sentences ranging from two months in the workhouse to an indeterminate period of six months to three years in the penitentiary were imposed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice McNamee on five election inspectors previously convicted of violating the election laws in making their returns of the vote cast last November.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 10. -- Thick weather apparently scared off the Women's Long Island Golf Association players today, for only a handful of them turned up for the tombstone tournament, the second one-day event of the season, at the Hempstead Golf Club.

BOSTON. Mass., May 10. -- Under the terms of the farm bill the increase in the cost of bread to consumers would be about 1 cent a loaf, the Secretary of Agriculture, Henry A. Wallace, said today in an interview here.

On the eve of Tuesday's city election in Newark few political prophets doubted the success of Mayor CONGLETON and his fellow-Commissioners, EGAN, GILLEN, HOWE and ELLENSTEIN. The Mayor's record seemed to assure his election.

BERLIN, May 10. -- By order of the State prosecuting attorney in Berlin, the entire property of the German Socialist party throughout the Reich, including its newspapers, their publishing plants and the property of the Reichsbanner, has been attached to serve as security for eventual claims of the trade unions.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 10. -- A far deeper significance than that attaching to a mere party contest marks the referendum to be held in New South Wales on Saturday to determine the future of the Legislative Council, the second chamber in the State Parliament.

ALBANY, May 10. -- An increase of 1 cent a quart in the minimum price for home-delivered milk in New York City, or from 10 to 11 cents, was announced today by the State Milk Control Board in an effort to prevent a threatened strike by up-State milk farmers.

Police Commissioner Bolan's recent assurance of protection for those who would come forward with complaints against racketeers resulted yesterday in the indictment of three officers of the Five Boroughs Truckmen's Service Association at 225 Lafayette Street on charges of coercion, conspiracy and assault.

At the request of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation the New York Stock Exchange has postponed until May 24 the hearing scheduled for yesterday by the governing committee on the company's methods of issuing financial reports to stockholders.

The Union Pacific Railroad is considering a move to consummate its proposed intercompany merger under authority of State commissions, it was disclosed yesterday. The Interstate Commerce Commission approved recently the plan on the condition that the company be prepared to absorb certain independent short lines, which condition the railroad does not wish to follow.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The proposed national industry recovery act was discussed by President Reosevelt today with Cabinet members, Congressional leaders and other administration advisers, and the decision was reached to formulate a measure which would adjust differences of opinion and make unnecessary the adoption by Congress of other legislation, dealing with stabilization of production and prices, hours of work, public works construction and like proposals.

Arthur S. Draper, assistant editor of The New York Herald Tribune, has resigned to become editor-in-chief of The Literary Digest, it was announced yesterday. He will succeed Dr. William Seaver Woods, who had been editor of The Digest since May 1, 1905.
WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued tie following orders, dated May 8:
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 10 (AP). -- The league-leading Newark Bears handed the Bisons a double defeat today, winning by 7 to 3 and 8 to 2.
"They All Come to Moscow," a comedy by John Noble Washburne and Ruth Kennell, will have its premiere this evening at the Lyceum Theatre. The Players Theatre is presenting the attraction.

Mrs. Robert Owens, mother of sixteen children, whose family was adjudged the largest in the city and will be honored at the Parents' Day exercises in Central Park on Sunday, said yesterday while preparing luncheon for the brood in their cottage, in Middle Village, Queens, that it would be Impossible for all members of the family to be present at the exercises.

A recommendation by the board of directors of the Cotton-Textile Institute, Inc., that during the emergency period the work week in cotton mills shall not be in excess of forty hours has received the support port of mills representing 10,000,000 spindles, or one-third of the industry, George A. Sloan, president of the institute, reported yesterday in a telegram to President Roosevelt.

Led by Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan as grand marshal, about 100,000 Jews and many Christian sympathizers marched in a parade yesterday from Madison Square to the Battery in protest against the treatment of Jews in Germany.

The time when "Jane Eyre" was criticized as coarse and heathenish and "Vanity Fair" as too true to life to provide a moral, and when Darwin was asked to write more about pigeons and less about his theory of the origin of species is told of with humor and detail in "At John Murray's," by George Paston, just published by Duttons.

During the last year, preceding March 4, we had taken "the longest step toward communism ever taken by any country in the world except Russia, and there would have been no other way out If we had permitted the old policy of deflation to continue," Henry T. Rainey, Speaker of the House of Representatives, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the general conference of the Tanners Council of America in the Waldorf-Astoria.

Columbia continued to set a dazzling pace in the Eastern Inter collegiate Baseball League yester day when it defeated Princeton 7-0, before 500 spectators at Baker Field. The Lions have been victorious in seven of their eight league contests.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Business activity has broadened its upward swing, although substantial improvement is necessary if the present movement is to be more than temporary, Secretary Roper stated today. He based his observations on information obtained by his Division of Economic Research.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Residents of the capital, particularly members of Congress, breathed a little more easily tonight as the vanguard of what had been described as an army of communistic bonus marchers turned out upon arrival to be a bedraggled group of unemployed ex-service men, attracted here by the promise of something to eat, a place to sleep and opportunity to air their grievances at a convention.

The New York Young Democratic Club, after two hours of acrimonious debate, last night adopted a resolution calling upon former Governor Alfred E. Smith to assume command of the Democratic party in the city and to begin and direct a campaign for political, social and economic betterment.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- An advance of $200,000 was made available by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today to Nassau County, N.Y., for meeting current emergency relief needs. The action was taken upon application of Governor Lehman.

AMHERST, Mass., May 10. -- Writing in the Amherst Graduates' Quarterly, issued today, on "The Coolidge I Knew," Justice Harlan F. Stone of the Supreme Court declares the smooth functioning of the governmental machinery in the Coolidge administration was not a manifestation of "Coolidge luck," but the result of, "the constant vigilance and wise action of one of the most competent administrators who has held the Presidential office."

CHICAGO, May 10. -- The Yankees were forced to make a rather hasty revision of an earlier estimate of the White Sox today when the Chicagoans, feeling very much at home in a wintry blast, treated the world's champions to quite a drubbing.

The Primavera Ball under the auspices of the Italian Historical Society will take place tonight on board the Rex at the foot of West Forty-sixth Street in aid of the international educational program of the organization. An entertainment will be given after midnight by stars from the theatrical and musical worlds, among them Jimmy Durante of "Strike Me Pink"; Tullio Carminati of "Music In the Air," Nino Martini, Ramon and Rosita and Dolores Cassinelli.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 per cent for the best names. Tuesday -- 2 per cent for the best names. Quotations are for three-four months' paper.

A resolution expressing "deep sympathy with those who are suffering in Germany" and calling up on "Christians everywhere to voice disapproval of anti-Semitic discrimination" was adopted yesterday by the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York at its 150th convention in Synod Hall, at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Speeding the six furlongs over a sloppy track in 1:121-5, G.H. (Pete) Bostwick's Blind Bowboy easily captured the featured Fleet Purse at Jamaica yesterday. He made a show of his opposition, winning by eight lengths with Jockey Hank Mills in the saddle and four others trailing.

ALBANY, May 10. -- Revocation of licenses of several New Tork taxicab companies is sought in an order served today directing Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, to show cause why a writ of mandamus should not be Issued to compel such action.
WELLESLEY, Mass., May 10 (AP). -- Miss Jean Henderson, 19, of 3 Lafayette Place, Yonkers, N.Y., a sophomore at Wellesley College, died suddenly tonight from what doctors believed was an embolus.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Governor Lehman proclaimed May 12 as Hospital Day and urged the public to "renew personal interest in the work of our hospitals."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 10. -- Yale today overcame a four-run deficit in the eighth inning, pounding La Flamme of Colgate for five runs to win, 8 to 7.

Developments In domestic business held the attention of the security markets yesterday, other considerations having been set aside temporarily. Stocks and bonds advanced sharply in trading that was considerably more active than on the day before.
BUENOS AIRES, May 10. -- Paraguay declared war against Bolivia today, giving a triumph to force over arbitration and over the elaborate twentieth century machinery for maintaining peace.

Maturities of city securities aggregating $16,000,000 which fall due on Monday were the subject of a conference at City Hall yesterday attended by Mayor O'Brien, members of the Board of Estimate and representatives of the banks that have been lending the city money.

The pamphlet report of the United States Electric Power Corporation for 1932 shows a net loss of $538,953 applicable to stocks of the United States Electric Power Corporation. There was a balance of $398,609 available for the corporation's charges after depreciation, taxes and charges of underlying companies.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 10 (AP). -- Gilbert Nunns, youngest member of Canada's Davis Cup team, and Dr. Jack Wright, Vancouver veteran, will carry the Dominion's colors in the singles matches tomorrow against the tennis stars of Cuba.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 10. -- President Ayala signed a decree today declaring Paraguay was at war with Bolivia, establishing martial law throughout the republic for the duration of the war, and ordering notification sent to the League of Nations and all governments.

NEWARK, N.J., May 10. -- Rocking Moon, the big chestnut mare owned by Mrs. R.L. Benson of Princeton, N.J. and ridden by Thomas Spincks, won the blue ribbon in the open jumping as the thirteenth annual Newark horse show opened tonight in the Essex Troop Armory.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a communication to THE TIMES Harry Goldsmith writes: "May I ask the young voters who are disgusted by the way the city is run by Tammany why we can't organize our own political group and force a change in the system?"

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Notification of Paraguay's declaration of war against Bolivia was formally given today to the United States Government by Dr. Enrique Bordenave, the Paraguayan Minister here. He called on Francis White, Assistant Secretary of State, late this afternoon, and explained to him the reasons which had led his government to take this step.

Seth Low Junior College of Columbia University, 375 Pearl Street, has awarded insignia to thirty-one students participating in extra-curricular activities during the last year. To Eugene V. Soloff, a junior, was granted a special award for general service.

The Roof Garden of the St. Regis was the setting last night for a dinner dance in behalf of Auxiliary Six of Stony Wold Sanatorium. The auxiliary is one of several which defray the expenses of needy young women at the sanatorium or supplement what their parents or guardians can afford to pay.
Purchase of a Jersey City apartment house by a New York group featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

Preface to Murals. An apotheosis of LENIN on the walls of Rockefeller Center is about as appropriate as a frieze of swastikas over the doors of a synagogue. DIEGO RIVBRA'S mammoth fresco in the RCA building has been rejected by the owners because the picture of the Soviet leader is likely to offend many people and stir up controversy.

LONDON, May 10. -- Provisional arrangements here tonight called for a meeting at 3 P.M., tomorrow, of the organizing committee of the World Economic Conference at which approval of the tariff truce proposal can be formalized and it can be sent with the conferees blessings to the governments of other nations of the world with a recommendation for their prompt acceptance.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 (AP). -- The Reds balanced their won and lost columns today as they batted out a double victory over the Phillies to raise their percentage to 500 and sink the Phillies deeper into the cellar. The scores were 10 to 7 and 4 to 3.

A ticket headed by Alfred E. Smith for Mayor, Robert Moses for Controller and Norman Thomas for President of the Board of Aldermen was proposed last night by Major F.H. La Guardia, the Republican Mayoralty nominee in 1929.

BERLIN, May 10. -- At the much-heralded labor congress today Chancellor Hitler failed to disclose what the new organization meant for German labor. His long and, in part, striking speech contained not a single specific statement concerning the matter, and even his allusions to it were vague.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The Chinese delegation to the World Economic Conference will be "in general accord" with the United States on its silver policy, it was stated tonight by T. V. Soong, Chinese Finance Minister and head of the Chinese delegation to London.
The text of Bainbridge Colby's speech at the Hitler protest meeting in Battery Park follows:

BALTIMORE, May 10 (AP). -- An outsider and a public choice divided the honors at Pimlico today as J. F. Adams's Rehoboth, quoted at nearly 8 to 1, captured Class A division of the graded handicaps and M.J. Lacey's Sweeping Light, paying $4.80 for $2, won a driving victory in the Arundel Purse.

Thomas Hitchcock Jr., American international polo captain, announced yesterday some of the plans for the coming Long Island season. An important feature of the campaign will be that games are to be shortened from the old regulation of eight periods to contests of six periods.

Civil service reform nas been vietorious in a number of recent court cases. Dr. WALKER, hero of the medical chapters of the Seabury investigation, lost his job with the Board of Education by court order. Only the other day a Supreme Court justice laid down the law to "disabled" veterans seeking preference in the face of a record revealing no demonstrated incapacity.

VIENNA, May 10. -- The Dollfuss Cabinet was reconstructed tonight. Dr. Karl Buresch, former Chancellor, replaces Dr. Emanuel Weidenhoffer as Finance Minister, the latter becoming general director of the Creditanstalt.

Fears of residents of New Jersey who earn their living in New York that the introduction of an Income tax in that State would result in their having to pay a double tax were allayed yesterday by Roy H. Palmer, income tax expert of the New York State Tax Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The government crop report as of May forecasts the smallest Winter wheat production of any year wince 1904, and the highest percentage of abandoned acreage on record. Acreage abandonment is estimated at 32.2 per cent of the area sown last Fall.

The Merchants Ladles Garment Association, comprising the wholesalers in the cloak and suit Industry, began preparation yesterday of formal demands to be presented to the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, it was announced by Maxwell Copeloff, executive director of the association.

About 4,500,000 gallons of preprohibition whisky and about 8,000,000 gallons of "new crop" whisky are available in government warehouses to meet the demand for medicinal spirits that probably will result from the new regulation, effective Monday, permitting physicians to prescribe from thirty to ninety days' supply of liquor for patients.
With the exception of sugar, which was weak, commodities on local exchanges rose yesterday to irregularly higher price levels. In the cash markets, most of the leading staples were higher.

POONA, India, May 10 (AP). -- Mahatma Gandhi was described tonight by his own physician, as "exhausted but not unduly ill" from the fast he began on Monday. The physician was surprised and disappointed at the rapid decline of Mr. Gandhi, who embarked on a three weeks' fast in protest against untouchability.

Eighty-six employes of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York and its affiliated gas and electric companies have received meritorious service awards for saving lives or for acts of conspicuous bravery in 1932, the company announced yesterday.

Chancellor BROWN in his recent Phi Beta Kappa address said that man cannot know himself save as he knows man, and cannot know man save as he knows humanity at its best. He may occasionally find that best in "some rare friend" -- in an incomparable friendship in which are found the supreme interpretations of human quality.

Neat strips of sheath paper carefully blanketed from public view yesterday Diego Rivera's uncompleted fresco, with its head of Nicolai Lenin, in the great hall of the RCA Building In Rockefeller Center.

BERLIN, May 10. -- In most of the German university towns tonight the enthusiastic studenthoods are ceremoniously burning "the un-German spirit" as exemplified in literature, pamphlet, correspondence and record. It is all being done to the accompaniment of torchlight parades, martial music and much patriotic speechifying -- the British Guy Fawkes Day intensified a thousandfold.

After the comparative quiet of the day before Wall Street turned interestedly yesterday to the contemplation of business prospects. Transactions on the Stock Exchange showed an increase of nearly 70 per cent by comparison with the day before.

LIVINGSTON, Tenn., May 10 (AP). -- Tornadoes swept through the Cumberland River Valley in Tennessee and Kentucky last midnight, killing at least fifty-four persons, injuring scores and leaving a heavy but unestimated property damage.

Alfred Aarons and Thomas Mitchell tossed their newly incorporated hat into the production ring last evening. Before an audience dressed mainly in orchids, they removed the covering from "$25 an Hour," a comedy by Gladys Unger and Leyla Georgia.

In little more than an hour after it had received the award of the Issue of $5,000,000 State of New Jersey emergency relief bonds yesterday afternoon, the syndicate headed by the National City Company announced the closing of the syndicate books, all the bonds having been sold out of syndicate account.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The combined farm relief and so-called inflation bill passed its final stage in Congress today, when the Senate gave up its fight for a guarantee of "cost of production" to the farmer, the one feature inserted in the bill by the upper house against the advice of the administration.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Despite a wide disagreement as to what was being done, the Senate today passed without a record vote its own bill prohibiting the publication by government employes of code messages transmitted by foreign governments.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 10. -- Army defeated New York University at baseball today, 8 to 5. The cadets began their run getting early, unlimbering a heavy attack on Vavra, the Violet's starting pitcher, and concentrating a steady fire in his direction until he was relieved with nobody out in the third.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- In 1934 there will be heard in the land Republican campaign assertions that the President has put Congress and the Constitution on the shelf. Regardleas of the success of his policies, this argument is certain to be made, although it will come with greater force if the condition of the people is not much improved from today.

For the first time since the week ended June 14. 1930, electric power production last week exceeded the total of a year ago for the country as a whole. The Edison Electric Institute reported 1,435,707,000 kilowatt-hours against an output of 1,427,960,000 in the previous week and 1,429,032,000 for the corresponding week last year.

TIENTSIN, May 10. -- Three Japanese brigades, accompanied by aerial bombers, have crossed the Lwan River in North China, beyond the large triangle they declared they would make into a neutral zone, and today were sweeping rapidly southwestward in the direction of Peiping.

Seventy seamen, sixteen of them aliens, disgruntled by orders to clean their dormitory in the T.M. C.A. Seamen's House at 507 West Street, hurled chairs, books and other missiles at detectives and patrolmen who dislodged them from the building yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 10. -- Prices for wheat were most erratic today on the Board of Trade, but at no time were they so low as at the finish yesterday. The East bought early and turned seller on an advance of around 2 cents a bushel from the previous close.

ST. LOUIS, May 10 (AP). -- The Browns, pounded Whitehill for four hits, including two doubles, to score five runs in the eighth inning and shut out the Senators, 5 to 0, today. Two walks and Manush's error also contributed to the scoring. White-hill allowed only two hits in the first seven innings.

In the first raids of their kind in this city since 3.2 beer became legal, a squad of six Federal agents last night visited restaurants in which they reported finding spirits as well as beer being dispensed to customers.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 10. -- The State sales tax was held un-constitutional today by the State Supreme Court, all seven members of the court joining in the opinion.

After hearing read an alleged confession in which their 16-year-old boy, Harry, told how he had stabbed to death William Bender, 12, on Jan. 31, Daniel C. Murch and his wife Mary took, the stand in Queens County Court yesterday afternoon and tried to convince the jury that the boy was younger than the police maintain.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 10. -- Washington and Lee won from the Naval Academy nine, 12 to 8, today in a ten-inning game marked by loose fielding and hard batting.
WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The government's statistics indicated that for the first time in the twentieth century production of all wheat in the United States may be less than estimated domestic needs.

Members of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform continued yesterday, with open-air meetings and other ratification week activities, throughout the city and State, to urge all voters to go to the polls on May 23 and cast their ballots for repeal delegates.

F.E. Williamson, president of the New Tork Central Railroad, was elected yesterday president of the Toronto, Hamilton Buffalo Railway, a subsidiary of the New York Central, to succeed the late J.N. Beckley. Mr. Williamson, whose salary as head of the parent company was $80,000 on March 1, 1932, will receive no additional pay from his new position.

PARIS, May 10. -- Commenting on the fall in French obligations in the New York market, the Journal des Debats declares the reason for this decline is that it has been reported in New York that the French Government will not make service payments in gold.

Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank and affiliated companies, will go on trial in Federal Court here this morning on the charge of evading payment of Federal income tax for 1929 and 1930. United States Attorney George Z. Medalie will prosecute and Max D. Steuer will defend him before Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 10. -- With fifty attorneys present and a fiveton truckload of documents and contracts dumped into the court room as evidence awaiting introduction in the case, the Victoria Amusement Company of this city began today before Federal Judge J. Boyd Avis its attempt to prove charges of unlawful restraint and monopolies against virtually all of the film-producing companies in the country.

HAVANA, May 10. -- Two hundred and twenty out of 300 students of the General Machado Industrial School at Hancho Boyeros were expelled today for refusing to march in a parade of the Florida State Convention of the American Legion, which is meeting here.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- For the sixth time since its establishment the Navy Department and its Marine Corps face the possibility of a sweeping reorganization. Orders have been issued by Secretary Swanson appointing a board to consider and make recommendations relative to reforming the Navy Department and the amalgamation of the line of the navy, of the Marine Corps and of "certain or all" staff corps.
WASHINGTON, May 10. -- With a formal declaration against Bolivia, little Paraguay today placed the issue of the legality of war squarely before the statesmen of the world.

The city's credit has been "completely shattered and destroyed" because its affairs have been administered by men skilled in politics but ignorant or careless of sound financial principles, Samuel Untermyer declared last night in a radio talk over station WOR.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP). -- The government completed its case today against Gaston B. Means and Norman T. Whitaker, alias "The Fox," on trial for conspiracy to swindle Mrs. Evalyn Walsh McLean, who sought to ransom the Lindbergh baby, but the prosecution failed to get before the jury an alleged confession by Whitaker.

At a time when various ways of "raising the price level" are being discussed, the Harvard Business School has just contributed an instructive study of methods already employed in an attempt to attain that end. Thirteen commodities, having an aggregate market value of upward of $15,000,000,000 in 1929, are dealt with.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP). -- Postmaster General Farley has accepted an invitation of the Democratic National Congressional Committee to explain to Democratic members of the House tomorrow night the delay in making postmastership and other patronage appointments.

LONDON, May 10. -- The Daily Herald tonight gives a sensational account of a "polite but unfriendly" talk between. Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, head of the Nazi Foreign Affairs Bureau; Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary and Viscount Hailsham, Secretary for War.

Within a week or ten days after President Roosevelt signs the farm bill the new Federal Farm Credit Administration will be prepared to begin the refinancing of farm mortgages, for which $200,000,000 is provided, according to Henry Morgenthau Jr., chairman of the Federal Farm Board and Governor-designate of the Farm Credit Administration, in an address at the luncheon of the Advertising Club of New York yesterday.

With the presentation of testimony relating to service interruptions and accidents in the Brooklyn Edison Company, the hearing on a complaint of thirty customers that labor policies and practices of the company endanger the adequacy and continuity of service was closed yesterday by Public Service Commissioner George R. Van Namee.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Defalcations of bank presidents are common matters to the office of Controller of the Currency, and the reported irregularities in the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company were merely a routine subject, John W. Pole, former Controller, told a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today.

TOKYO, May 10. -- The Soviet-Manchukuoan - Japanese frontier commission which Japan proposed last week would exercise functions comparable to those of similar commissions in Europe, Constantin Yureneff, the Soviet Ambassador to Tokyo, was told today.

For the first time in recent financial history, at least, a committee was organized yesterday to protect holders of bonds of one of the States of the Union. The group was formed to safeguard the interests of investors in highway and toll-bridge bonds of the State of Arkansas, now outstanding in the amount of approximately $91,000,000. It is composed chiefly of representatives of the principal holders of the bonds rather than of the bankers.

GENEVA, May 10. -- The League of Nations wheat committee began its study of the export problem today with a preliminary exchange of views, which was hampered by the absence of the Argentine delegate, who arrives tomorrow.

TRENTON, N.J., May 10. -- Senate President Emerson L. Richards of Atlantic County made today his third unsuccessful effort to obtain passage by the upper house of the Assembly bill to permit Sunday sale of beer when authorized by local governing bodies.

Harry Murch, 16 years old, was found guilty of murder in the second degree by a Jury last evening in Queens County Court. He stabbed William Bender, 12 years old, with a potato knife on Jan. 31 in a deserted house on Mauretania Avenue, Richmond Hill Circle, Queens.

A suicide compact between two married graduate students of Columbia University was discovered late last night when the husband, Edgar F. Grossman, 39 years old, impatient over the slow action of poison they had taken, ended his life by shooting himself in the bathroom of their one-room apartment at 546 West 113th Street.

An investigation to determine whether thirty-five known instances of substitute appearances in Federal Court on the bargain day prohibition calendar during the last six months had been the result of a conspiracy entered into between members of a cordial-shop syndicate and bondsmen in the Federal Building has been ordered by Arthur H. Schwartz, Assistant United States Attorney, it was revealed yesterday.

NORWALK, Conn., May 11. -- The Rev. Dr. Augustus Field Beard, oldest living graduate of Tale University and the oldest Congregational clergyman in the country, celebrated his 100th birthday at his home here today, receiving hundreds of letters, telegrams and cables from America and Europe and oral felicitations from many callers.

PARIS, May 11. -- The French Government definitely decided today that it would agree to ask the Chamber of Deputies to authorize payment of the Dec. 15 instalment of the war debt to the United States if Washington in its turn would agree to a debt moratorium during the World Economic Conference, when negotiations toward a final settlement would take place.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 11. -- The annual Westchester County Junior Music Festival was opened tonight at the County Centre here with a chorus of 1,400 boys and girls from thirty-eight high schools in the county and a high school orchestra of 250 pieces giving a long and ambitious program.

The need for continuing organized community relief work to supplement the Federal appropriations made possible by the WagnerLewis relief bill was emphasized yesterday by John Stewart Bryan. whose selection as president of Community Chests and Councils, Inc., was announced at the headquarters of that organization in the Graybar Building, 420 Lexington Avenue.

Nomination of former Governor Alfred E. Smith for Mayor and Harvey D. Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company for Controller by both Democratic and Republican parties was urged last night by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, at a meeting of the New York County Republican Committee at the Palm Garden, 306 West Fiftysecond Street.

The application of George Henry Payne for retirement as Tax Commissioner, which appeared yesterday on the Board of Estimate calendar for action today, indicated the probability that Thomas W. Whittle, Bronx Republican Assembly District leader, would be appointed as his successor, and that John J. Knewitz, Bronx Republican, leader, had won his fight with W. Kingsland Macy. Republican State Chairman, to bring about Mr. Whittle's appointment.

The book bonfires of the Nazis probably will have little effect on the book trade here. Most of the writers whose books were burned are safely out of Germany and in free communication with their American publishers. They will continue writing and their books will be published here.

The fight against Park Commissioner Sheehy's plan to convert the Central Park reservoir site into athletic fields gained fresh momentum yesterday when the Sixth Avenue Association joined the protest. There now are thirty-four organizations opposing the projected encroachment on the park.

MOSCOW, May 11. -- In a written statement handed to the press tonight, Maxim Litvinoff, Commissar for Foreign Affairs, cleared up some of the mystery surrounding his conversation with Ambassador Tamekichi Ota of Japan about the Chinese Eastern Railway, and what Russia was going to do about the Mukden and Peking treaties, concerning which it had received a memorandum from the Chinese Government.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- As the first major move under the administration's program for adjusting the farm mortgage debt of the country to a lower level, Henry Morgenthau Jr., who is to head the Farm Credit Administration, said today that he had called a conference for Monday with representatives of twenty-five life insurance companies holding about $3,000,000,000 face amount of such securities.

Another step toward the restoration of game birds is marked by the affixing of Governor A. Harry Moore's signature two days ago to a piece of legislation that had passed the New Jersey State Legislature.

PARIS, May 11. -- American moves toward the remonetization of silver are finding no echo here yet, Raymond Patenotre, Under-Secretary of National Economy, told the writer today. M. Patenotre, Who is France's chief champion of bimetalism, is more than ever convinced, however, that the world ultimately must use silver concomitantly with gold or the monetary crisis will recur periodically.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 11. -- A cordial understanding has now been reached between the different interests involved in Cosach, the Nitrate Corporation of Chile, and the nitrate industry in general, particularly since liquidation of Cosach was decreed in January, it was revealed today at a luncheon in honor of Horace Graham, one of the liquidators, who will leave tomorrow for the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- President Roosevelt today remained firm in his opposition to a cash bonus for World War veterans, in the face of the presence of a new group of bonus marchers, a visit from members of the House Ways and Means Committee to sound him out on the subject, and a revolt in his own party in the House on veterans' benefits.

PITTSBURGH, May 11. -- At least 200,000 miners will never make a living at their old trade again, involving about half a million people formerly dependent on the industry, Clarence E. Pickett, executive secretary of the American Friends Service Committee, reported today to the American Mining Congress.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- An investigation of charges of income tax law violation against Andrew W. Mellon, former Secretary of the Treasury and Ambassador to Great Britain, will be made by the Department of Justice.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Liberalization of the home refinancing bill was urged upon the administration today by a delegation representing about 500,000 families who are home-owners in the New York metropolitan area. Their appeal, supported by Senator Wagner and some House members, was presented to Colonel Marvin H. McIntyre, assistant secretary to the President, who assured them that Mr. Roosevelt would carefully consider their suggestions.

As quick a formal distribution of a municipal bond issue as ever will be effected was recorded here yesterday. A syndicate headed by the Guaranty Company of New York and the National City Company received at noon the award of $4,000,000 city of Buffalo (N.Y.) bonds and announced immediately the closing of the subscription books.
Two witnesses were questioned yesterday when the grand jury opened its investigation into charges that racketeering had been revived by fish handlers in Fulton Market.

Youth is genius. By dint of it Mr. PHILIP YORKE, late of Cambridge University, is literally forcing the drama upon selected villages in the Southern English counties. In a second-hand motorbus he found the predestined vehicle of his idea.

GENEVA, May 11. -- The disarmament conference reached a deadlock on effectives tonight, one of the several on major issues that it is almost certain to have before it completes discussion of the British draft treaty.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "Keeping the Faith" paid a well-deserved tribute to a gentleman of intelligence, experience and high integrity, qualities to which, fortunately, public opinion is becoming more attentive under the refinement resulting from the economic; financial and social suffering endured in increasing measure during the last four years.

The awarding of 108 sets of letters to members of nine City College athletic teams featured the Charter Day exercises held at C.C. N.Y. yesterday in celebration of the eighty-sixth anniversary of the founding of the college.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 11. -- Leonard E. Teed, an employe of Westchester County for thirtyfive years, who had retired as Deputy County Treasurer on April 29, surrendered to Sheriff Thomas Reynolds this afternoon on a warrant by District Attorney Frank H. Coyne charging grand larceny in connection with a shortage of $250,000 in the accounts of the County Treasurer as Public Administrator.

CAMBRIDGE. Mass., May 11. -- Boston University staged a threerun ninth-inning finish today to beat Harvard, 10 to 8. John Ulman's home run with two runners on broke down the Crimson's onerun lead and decided the thrilling contest.

All the members of the election board of the Second Election District of the Nineteenth Assembly District, who were on trial before Supreme Court Justice McNamee for intentionally making a false return of the votes cast last November, were cleared yesterday.

Because the city colleges have proved a "blessing" to the community and the weight of public opinion demands their retention, no economic or political upheavals can halt the progress of free higher education in this city, Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, told more than 2,500 faculty members, students and guests yesterday at the institution's eighty-sixth annual Charter Day exercises.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Minot Amory, accompanied by Miss Gloria Baker and Alfred and George Vanderbilt, have returned to the Waldorf-Astoria from a world cruise.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Representatives of railroad executives today told members of the Senate committee conducting hearings on the railroad consolidation bill that they would cooperate with the coordinator in carrying out the provisions of the act if it were adopted, but that they looked upon it as an operating bill and not as one under which financial reorganization should take place.
Fordham's nine returned to its winning stride yesterday after two setbacks and vanquished Colgate, 12 to 5, at Fordham Field before a crowd of 3,000 persons.

More inquiries and complaints were handled by the National Better Business Bureau, Inc., in the last twelve months than in the preceding year, according to the annual report of Edward L. Greene, general manager. Mr. Greene said that in spite of reduced income the bureau had issued approximately the same number of bulletins and booklets in the year as in the previous year.

On the heels of his dismissal from Rockefeller Center, Diego Rivera, noted Mexican artist, received a telegram yesterday canceling his commission to paint a huge mura for the General Motors Building at the Century of Progress Exposition in Chicago.

Joseph V. McKee, retiring President of the Board of Aldermen, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner given at the Hotel Astor by the Sons of Knickerbocker and attended by 1,500 business and civic leaders, fully as many, his admirers said, as would have attended the function had Mr. McKee not recently announced that he was "through with politics."

The names of brokers who made arrangements in the last week for the sale of their memberships in the New York Stock Exchange at prices ranging from $135,000 to $150,000 were made public yesterday by the Exchange.
To the Editor of The New York Times: If you play in the sunshine, you tan. If you handle mud, you are soiled. If you look at a star, your eyes are open, even when all else is darkness around you.

Portraits of the William H. Vanderbilt twins, Anne and Elsie Vanderbilt, received ribbons for healthful youngsters at the exhibition of children's portraits now on view at the Reinhardt Galleries for the benefit of the Children's Welfare Federation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 11. -- Yale's denatured Tap Day exercises, at which annually the four senior societies elect members for the coming year, were held this afternoon, when a radical innovation went into effect in the withdrawal from the campus of the ritual and pageantry which has marked the selection of the juniors since the societies were formed.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 11. -- Canada moved to within one match of victory in the first round of the North American zone Davis Cup play with Cuba by winning both of today's singles matches in impress sive fashion.

Of the 1,401,078 apartments in New York City 201,406, or 14.4 per cent, are unoccupied, compared with a percentage of 12 per cent a year ago, it was shown by a report of a survey by the Tenement House Department made public yesterday by Commissioner Charles F. Kerrigan.
BERLIN, May 11. -- The Countess of Oxford and Asquith's interview with Dr. Rosenberg, as published in London, at first stirred the government-controlled German press.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to correct a slight error in the article of your Buenos Aires correspondent in regard to the West Coast. He declares that if Chile put an embargo on the import of arms from Arica to Bolivia, Bolivia would reassert sovereignty over Arica; that any Bolivian move to retake Arica would involve Chile in the war.

Leading Christians of this country expressed their sympathy with American Jews in their grief for their persecuted brethren In Germany at a private meeting yesterday of the National Conference of Jews and Christians at the Centre Club, 120 Central Park South.

The Government's May forecast, published yesterday, confirmed prediction made a month ago of the smallest crop of Winter wheat since 1904. The yield is placed at 337,000,000 bushels. This is a drop of nearly 30 per cent from last year's figure and of nearly 60 per cent from that for 1931.

LONDON, May 11. -- King George was unable to attend the first of the season's five royal courts, held in Buckingham Palace tonight. An attack of rheumatism in his left shoulder prevented his wearing his uniform. The King was in normal health otherwise today, observing his usual routine.

CLEVELAND, May 11 (AP). -- Young Mel Harder pitched and batted the Indians into an exclusive claim on first place in the American League today as Cleveland defeated Boston, 4 to 1. The victory gave the Indians a half-game lead over the Yankees, who were rained out at Chicago.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 11. -- Mrs. Edward Stevens of the Round Hill Club of Greenwich won the one-day tournament of the Westchester-Fairfield Women's Golf Association at the Woodway Country Club today. She turned in the low gross score of 85, to lead in a field of ninety-three players.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The decision of the French Government to ask the Chamber of Deputies for authority to pay the December Instalment of that country's debt if this country in turn will agree to a moratorium pending further discussions during the World Economic Conference was definitely influenced by this government, it was learned authoritatively tonight.

HAVANA, May 11 (AP). -- The United States Government believes a necessary factor in the rehabilitation of the world is "the mutual agreement on reciprocal trade agreements," Sumner Welles said today after he had presented his credentials as Ambassador to Cuba to President Machado.

LONDON, May 11. -- The tariff truce which Norman H. Davis hoped to inaugurate today with the solemn agreement of the eight nations composing the World Economic Conference Organizing Committee appeared tonight to be indefinitely delayed, with even the bare chance that efforts to bring it about may fail altogether.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The Veterans Administration began today a restudy of every new regulation issued on March 31 last affecting the compensation of serviceconnected World War veterans suffering from specified injuries incurred in line of duty.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- In line with the administration's program to bring about an upturn in business, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation is planning to speed up loans for self-liquidating projects and its board will consider several tomorrow.

The Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company, serving the Fifth Ward and the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens and several villages in the vicinity of Hempstead in Nassau County, will reduce immediately its electric rates to save consumers $200,000 a year, according to an announcement yesterday by Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission.

Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen, the United States Minister to Denmark, sailed yesterday for her new post there on the steamer Scanstates of the American Scantic Line. The ship departed from Pier D in Jersey City after an enthusiastic sendoff by several large groups of women admirers of Mrs. Owen.

George W. Wickersham, former Attorney General and chairman of the Hoover commission which bore his name, aligned himself yesterday with, that faction of the Republican party in Manhattan which is seeking to unseat Samuel S. Koenig as county leader.

A collection of furniture, antiques and imitations, seized by customs authorities when brought into the country in violation of the customs laws, netted $10,139 at public auction yesterday morning at the appraiser's stores, 201 Varick Street.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The national industry recovery bill, combining a gigantic plan for Federal control of industry and a $3,300,000,000 public works program, coupled with either a manufacturers' sales tax or a "breakfast-table" levy to amortize bonds for the latter, was completed in its essential particulars today.

TIENTSIN, May 11. -- Explaining the Japanese strategy In the eastern section of North China, a spokesman at the headquarters of the Japanese garrison here said today that the Japanese were advancing rapidly westward along the Mandarin Highway, intent on occupying the entire highway from Shanhaikwan to Tungchow, which is only ten miles east of Peiping.

ALBANY, May 11. -- The State milk control board will probably announce tomorrow the fixing of a minimum price to farmers of at least $1.75 per hundred pounds for 3.5 butterfat Class 1 milk, Henry S. Manley, counsel to the board, said tonight over Radio Station WGY.

GEORGE J. RYAN, who has been a member of the Board of Education for fifteen years, this week was elected its president for the twelfth time. He has thus surpassed in length, of service every predecessor in this high and responsible office.
ATLANTI CITY, N.J., May 11. -- Awards for poetry and prose, drama, essays and reviews, were made here this evening at the annual convention of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs.
WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 9:

SEAMAN WATSON, the bartender on leave, who planned to make an effort to lift the featherweight crown from the dusky head of dapper Kid Chocolate at the Garden this evening, will have to wait until next Friday night. The championship bout was postponed for the second time yesterday when the Cuban reported a case of ptomaine poisoning. Despite the delay things are looking up. Pugilists are returning to work.
LONDON, May 11 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

LONDON, May 11. -- The meeting of the organizing committee of the world conference, which had been summoned for today to ratify the tariff-truce formula, suddenly was postponed until tomorrow. There had been a delay, it was explained, in the final instructions reaching committee members from their governments.

A report filed in the Supreme Court yesterday in an accounting of the estate of Mrs. Mary Gertrude Abbey, widow of Edwin A. Abbey, disclosed that the American Academy in Rome has declined a gift of $150,000 in trust to establish scholarships in mural painting in memory of her husband, and that the money is now to go to the National Academy of Design which had already received the bulk of the residuary estate.

A campaign to reduce the cost of government in New York State, by reorganization of local governments through a Constitutional amendment and by repeal of laws imposing mandatory expenditures, was announced yesterday by the New York State branch of the National Economy League.

Thursday, May 11, 1933. A fractional advance in 90-day money, to 1 1/4 per cent, and an easier tendency in choice name, short date commercial paper, which eased to 1 3/4 from 2 per cent, offered the only interesting developments of the day in the money market.

Special registration of voters wishing to ballot on May 23 in the election of delegates to the State convention to act on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment has increased so fast In the last two days, it was announced yesterday, that fifty extra clerks have been assigned to the work.

"The River War," published today by the Scribners, was written thirty-five years ago by Winston S. Churchill, the second book he published. Commenting in an introduction on this "renewed lease of life," he writes that "a generation has grown up that knows little of why we are in Egypt and the Sudan" and that "uninstructed and ignorant impressions color the decisions, not only of Parliaments but of Cabinets."

The E.R. Marshall committee representing holders of 5 per cent debentures of the National Public Service Corporation mailed yesterday a letter urging immediate deposits of the debentures to further the committee's plan to reduce to possession the collateral securing the issue, consisting principally of a two-thirds interest in the Jersey Central Power and Light Company.

PEIPING, Friday, May 12. -- At daybreak yesterday the Japanese launched their long-expected general offensive against the Chinese south of Nantienmen, on the Peiping-Chengteh (Jehol City) Road, but, despite incessant aerial strafeing and artillery barrages unprecedented in Chinese military history, the Japanese failed to dislodge Nanking's divisions of regulars.
MONTREAL, May 11 (AP). -- Jersey City baited the Montreal winning streak after six straight victories today by taking the second game of the series, 3 to 1.

ITHACA, N.Y. May 11. -- Cornell won its third game in a row today, defeating Ithaca College, rival city nine, 8-2, with fifteen hits. Cornell drove two Ithaca hurlers to cover with eleven blows in the first three innings.
LONDON, May 11. -- No responsible person will write dogmatically as to the consequences on world conditions of America's departure from the gold standard.
PARIS, May 11 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The War Departmen issued the following orders today:

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The expected 9,000 war veterans for the coming Veterans National Rank and File Convention stood at a mere 1,000 tonight, but the same spirit that has indicated serious friction between two opposing groups was becoming more and more manifest.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP). -- The Supreme Court was called upon today to decide whether $2,500,000 annually is an exorbitant compensation for the president of the American Tobacco Company.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- After their first day of consultation with President Roosevelt and State Department experts. Alberto J. Pani. Mexican Finance Minister, and his acompanying experts said tonight that they found themselves in general accord with the Americans on the policies to be followed at the World Economic Conference.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 11 (AP). -- The Newark Bears made it three straight over the Bisons by capturing today's game, 12 to 9. Gil English featured for the Bisons by walloping three homers with a walk in between for a perfect day at bat, while Crouse contributed a fourth homer for Buffalo.

With the arrest yesterday of a man for whom they had searched for months, detectives of the automobile squad believed they had virtually broken up an "automobile ring" which had stolen 500 automobiles in eighteen months and shipped 125 of them to various parts of the world.

Fortune smiled on the Dodgers through gray skies at Ebbets Field yesterday and they came from behind to record a ninth inning triumph, over the Reds, 7 to 6, to the entire satisfaction of a gathering of 6,500 fans.

Only routine changes, reflecting a continuance of the favorable trend in progress since the bank holiday, were reported in yesterday's weekly statement of the Federal Reserve System. The system showed a further rise of $6,564,000 in gold holdings, carrying its reserves of the metal to $3,442,134,000, which, except for the $3,485,739,000 reported on Sept. 16. 1931, is the highest total on record.

Negotiations of the nine major steamship lines operating between Hamburg, Bremen, Antwerp and Rotterdam and ports on the North Atlantic ranging from Portland to Hampton Roads for an agreement on rates on freight westbound have been successfully completed after five years of intermittent discussion, it was announced yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., May 11. -- An unsuccessful attempt by the government to link Irving Wexler, better known as Waxey Gordon, beer operator and fugitive on an income tax charge, with the operation of the Harrison Beverage Company of Harrison, N.J., marked the second day of testimony in the proceedings brought by the government to revoke the 3.2 beer permit by the brewery.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP). -- Henry T. Ewald of Detroit, chairman of the board of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, said today at the association's session that economic surveys indicated that consistent advertisers had felt the depression less than non-advertisers.

The name of Charles E. Mitchell, not so long ago a mighty one in Wall Street, was called by the court clerk in the United States District Court at 10:40 o'clock yesterday morning, and the former chairman of the National City Bank was brought to trial on the charge of evading Federal income tax payments of $858,429.68 for 1929 and 1930.

The gelded son of Angon from Zephyr, Lansquenet, which bears the colors of W.L. Johnson, defeated half a dozen younger rivals in the fourth race, which had the place of honor on the program at Jamaica yesterday. Coming on strongly through the stretch, the 7-year-old passed his opposition to win by two lengths, with Pending second and Quick Step third.

BERLIN, May 11. -- The Boerse opened today with the prospect of another rise, but sales of relatively large amounts of Gelsenkirchen, Mannessman and I.G. Farben shares by a big bank which is close to the government, reversed the tendency, especially in mining and iron stocks, Farben later recovered its initial losses, but on the whole, business became extremelyquiet.

Lord Duveen, art dealer, will sail tonight on the White Star liner Olympic, departing for Cherbourg and Southampton. Others hooked for this ship include Sir Guy Granet, former chairman of the London, Midland and Scottish Railway, and the following:
Retail store leases yesterday showed a continued demand for locations of this type, forming the bulk of business rental activity.

NEWARK, N.J., May 11. -- Jumpers once more provided the spectacular features of the thirteenth annual Newark horse show, the second session of which was held in the Essex Troop Armory tonight. A field of twenty-seven took part in the fault-and-out open competition in which the action is always rapid and decisive.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Improvement of the vocational education and occupational opportunities of Negroes in New York City was urged today by Franklin J. Keller, director of the National Occupational Conference, at the opening of a conference on the economic status of the Negro, sponsored by the Julius Rosenwald Fund of Chicago.

BOGOTA, May 11. -- El Tiempo is optimistic as to the possibility of a peaceful solution of the Leticia dispute with Peru as a result of a visit Alfonso Lopez will make to Lima for a personal conference with the new President, General Oscar Benavides.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 11 (AP). -- Battleship, Mrs. T.H. Somerville's 6-year-old stallion, ridden cleverly by Carrol K. Basset, today won the Billy Barton Steeplechase, a trying test over nineteen fences and three miles at the Pimlico track.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Exemption of municipally owned power plants from paying a 2 per cent tax on gross receipts proposed for privately owned companies was written into the tax bill today by the Senatea.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 11. -- A continuous annual increase in interest and amortization charges on the bonded debt of Westchester County until 1940 was predicted today by E.M. Alien, president of the Westchester County Taxpayers' Association, who based his statement on a survey of the county's fiscal affairs just completed by the association's accountants under Dr. Lionel D. Edie of Scarsdale.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 11. -- Around Old Hilltop, where the Pimlico race track is located, there is a feeling among some turfmen that the Preakness Saturday will not be just another duel for Colonel E.R. Bradley's Broker's Tip and Mrs. Silas Mason's Head Play.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 11. -- A total of 139 athletes, including plebes, received insignia for participation in Winter sports at the United States Military Academy, it was announced today by Major Ludson D. Worsham, graduate manager of athletics.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent issue of THE TIMES there was an editorial commending the unselfish spirit in which Charles J. Rhoads and J. Henry Scattergood undertook the work of administration of Indian Affairs as Commissioner and Assistant Commissioner, and in praise of the nonpartisan character of their administration.

The sudden spread of talk about "default" or "repudiation" in connection with Government bonds is producing an uneasy feeling in various parts of this country. Americans don't like either the words or the things that lie behind them.

The increased demand for imported beverages which has followed the legalization of beer and ale here will result in the erection of a large industrial building in Long Island City, it was learned yesterday, when the real estate firm of Roman-Callman announced the sale of a site for the new structure.

A national Industrial planning commission to assure rehabilitation was outlined yesterday before the Rotary Club at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore by Charles E. Stuart, the engineer to whom George Bernard Shaw alluded in his speech here as having made "the very remarkable report in which the Russians had explained to them how to do it."

Mystery piled on mystery as the police continued yesterday to seek the murderer of Edward Albert Ridley, aged and eccentric millionaire who kept an office in the spooky subcellar at 63 Alien Street, and his secretary, Lee Weinstein.

Dorothy Thompson, correspondent and writer, and the wife of Sinclair Lewis, returned on the Italian liner Rex yesterday after spending several weeks in Europe, mostly in Germany. She came back with many of her ideas about Hitler and the Nazi movement radically changed.

Prices of domestic bonds rocketed yesterday on the Stock Exchange in the heaviest trading since Sept. 24, 1931, the total being $23,235,000, compared with $16,030,000 on Wednesday and with $24,213,000 on Sept. 24, 1931. The rise swept THE NEW YORK TIMES averages of domestic railroad and industrial bonds to new high points for the year.

Percy A. Rockefeller, reputed to be one of the largest and most influential stockholders of the National City Bank, resigned as a director of that institution on April 11 because of ill health, it was disclosed yesterday.

PEORIA, Ill., May 11. -- The socalled "Lindbergh law" was invoked today in sentencing six reputed members of an Illinois-Iowa kidnapping gang convicted of complicity in the abductions of Adhemar Huughe, East Moline, and Fred De Filippi, Spring Valley.

HANOVER, N.H., May 11. -- Dartmouth tallied eight times in the sixth inning to turn back New Hampshire today, 16 -- 6. Bob Miller was shelled off the mound in the fourth with the score tied at 4 -- all, but Way Thompson subdued the visitors the remainder of the game.

BERLIN, May 12. -- A new form of peasant landholding, inalienable, unmortgageable and inheritable only by the holder's eldest surviving child, has been created by the Prussian Government. It constitutes a revolutionary innovation on existing land tenure and inheritance.

ASCUNCION, Paraguay, May 11 (AP). -- Messages applauding Paraguay's declaration of war against Bolivia poured into the Foreign Ministry today, but many industrialists and others with interests in the disputed Gran Chaco area expressed great concern.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 11. -- Mayor Frank Frankel and Councilmen Frank Waldron and John E. Hoey of the city of Long Beach were indicted here today by the Nassau grand jury for misappropriation of public funds. The three men will be arraigned tomorrow before County Judge Cortland A. Johnson here.

Increased speculative activity on the Stock Exchange and in the other markets was accompanied yesterday by a further wide advance in prices. The more aggressive operations carried stock prices 1 to 5 points higher; wheat rose nearly 3 cents a bushel, net, and cotton, more than $1.50 a bale.

With bank clearings in this city in the week ended on Wednesday greater than they were a year ago, the decline for the country at large was reduced sharply in comparison with the similar gap a week ago, according to the weekly compilation made by R.G. Dun Co. Without the New York totals, the spread remained large.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- An agreement between the Munson Steamship Line and the Prince Lines, Ltd., was approved by the Shipping Board today providing for the maintenance of equal rates on cargo, except linseed, refrigerated cargo and open-rate commodities, from Montevideo and Buenos Aires to New York.

More than 38,000 individual donors were represented by a total of $340,057.02 in gifts to the Salvation Army, it was announced yesterday at a meeting of leaders in the United Appeal campaign at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway. The meeting marked the close of five weeks of solicitation.
Donald Shearer and William Gottlieb, both left-handers, collaborated at the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday to give New York University's baseball team a 4-2 victory over the City College nine.

Winners in the New York State division of the contests conducted by the National Federation of Music Clubs were Jerome Rappaport, piano; Marion Janet Clayton, organist; Genevieve Rowe, coloratura soprano; Edward Austin Kane, tenor, and Byrd Elyot, violinist.

The presidents of the Eastern railroads will meet here a week from today to take definite action on reducing the basic passenger rate, which has held at 3.6 cents a mile since the cessation of wartime government control. This step is a sequel to a conference on passenger rates by presidents representing all parts of the country in Washington this week.

Copyright, 1933, by The Associated Press. A rush of buying in the cotton goods and other textile markets has brought the industry the greatest volume of business in recent years, textile interests report.

ROME, May 11. -- How 25-year-old Camilla Agliardi of Drescia was smuggling out facsimiles of secret Italian naval documents to agents in Yugoslavia and France by hiding them in framed paintings was revealed tonight with the announcement that the sentence of death passed on the girl by a special military tribunal probaly would be commuted to life imprisonment by King Victor Emmanuel.

Helen Westley of the Theatre Guild company will replace Helen Salinger in the role of the maid in "Biography," at the Avon Theatre on Monday evening. Miss Salinger is obliged to "leave the cast on account of illness.

Commodities advanced yesterday on the local exchanges, some making sweeping gains and others moving forward slightly. Sugar, silver and coffee were in the latter group, while rubber, cocoa, silk, hides and wool tops were strong. In the cash markets many new high prices for 1933 were made.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The administration's plan to save $53,000,000 in the navy's budget during the coming fiscal year took a long step forward today when Secretary Swanson ordered a sharp curtailment of shore establishments.
Under the broadest buying in many years prices on the Cotton Exchange continued to advance and ended at the top yesterday, with gains of 30 to 34 points.
