The Pitcher bill, passed by the Legislature last month, in effect made milk a public utility. The industry was placed under a board of control, which was directed to fix minimum wholesale and retail prices to stores and consumers and authorized to fix minimum prices to producers.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- In response to a request from the League of Nations, the commission of neutrals will meet here tomorrow morning, under the chairmanship of Francis White, Assistant Secretary of State, to consider possible cooperation with the League in a speedy settlement of the situation created by Paraguay's declaration of war against Bolivia.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Elimination or reduction of widespread and excessive restrictions upon trade by joint action of the world's governments is declared essential to the restoration of normal international commerce in a report prepared by a special committee of the American section of the International Chamber of Commerce.

The steamship Rex of the Italian Line, at the foot of West Fortysixth Street, was the scene last night of a brilliant entertainment, the Primavera Ball, held under the auspices of the Italian Historical Society In behalf of its international educatlonal program.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The participation of thirteen of the present directors of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company of New York in the pool made up of former directors to buy the bank's stock was indicated today in a letter from Henry E. Cooper, conservator of the bank, to Senator Stephens, head of the subcommittee investigating the reasons for the delay in prosecuting Joseph W. Harriman.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Complaints by Congress members over delays in appointing their constituents as postmasters, internal revenue collectors and to other jobs, are being met with, declarations that the President is devoting himself to economic problems and cannot yet take up patronage distribution.

LONDON, May 11. -- The Countess of Oxford and Asquith, the widow of the late Prime Minister, has written for The News-Chronicle her story of her interview last Monday with Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, Chancellor Hitler's personal representative, which caused a stir both here and in Germany.

LONDON, May 11. -- Repercussions of events in the Far East and Germany upon disarmament and the prospects for world peace coupled with the remarkable visit by Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, envoy of Chancellor Hitler of Germany, have aroused a greater British public interest in foreign affairs than at any time since the World War.
Savings banks were represented by bidding at foreclosure auctions yesterday and bought in several of fourteen Manhattan and Bronx ofperings. The results follow:

Judge Freschi in General Sessions yesterday imposed sentences of five to fifteen years in Sing Sing on Herman Nerenberg alias Newberg, 30 years old, and Lawrence Ganze, 32, on their pleas of guilty to manslaughter April 27 in the beating of Achilles Mirner, a Parisian jeweler, in their "clipjoint" speakeasy in West Seventyfourth Street last Oct. 31.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP). -- Under oath in a Federal court, Gaston B. Means testified today that two men told him they tried twice unsuccessfully to deliver the kidnapped Lindbergh baby in Washington on March 8, 1932, and that two weeks later they showed him in Aiken, S.C., a child represented as the ill-fated victim.

GENEVA. May 11. -- The League of Nations wheat committee in its second day's session, although still handicapped by the absence of the Argentine delegate, Carlos Brebbia, who is expected tomorrow, made two things clear. One is that the United States has swung from a position in the extreme rear to the extreme vanguard.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 (AP). -- An unemployed truck driver, said by the police to have demanded $75,000 in a series of letters to the Pennsylvania Railroad under threat of blowing up passenger trains with nitroglycerine, was arrested tonight. He had a loaded pistol.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended May 10, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,348,000,000, a decrease of $88,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of 5453,000.000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.
WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended May 10 were announced today:

CHICAGO, May 11. -- Prices for grains and provisions soared today on the Board of Trade, new high marks for the season being established for all deliveries. Sensationally low estimates by the government on the crops of wheat and rye, passage of the farm relief bill with its declared intention of restoring prices to the 1909-14 average and more heavy rains over the Corn Belt brought a wave of buying that swept all before it.

With domestic business expanding and the legislative aims of the Roosevelt administration approaching accomplishment, Wall Street threw off restraint yesterday and again turned to the business of bidding up stocks and commodities. In this process it had the assistance of an "outside public," the size of which was variously estimated.

BERLIN, May 11. -- In an article in the weekly Leipziger Illustrierte Zeltung, Baron Constantin von Neurath, the Foreign Minister, attempts to shift responsibility for the failure of the disarmament conference from German shoulders to those of other great powers.

The Giants fought to the last pitch at the Polo Grounds yesterday in the opening game of their series with Pittsburgh, but their battle was in vain. The Pirates romped off with the honors, 7 to 6, and had the added distinction of humbling the great Carl Hubbell.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have come to the conclusion that patriotism is really dead, and this is why:
Sale of a Jersey City brewery featured the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.
PARIS, May 11. -- New details regarding the Franco-Colonial conference opening next Thursday were learned today which make it evident that the discussions will have a threefold character.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- In May, 1932, President Hoover and Secretary Mills were active in organizing Federal Reserve District committees to stimulate the expansion of credit. Under Mr. Mills's personal inspiration, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York had formed a group with, the purpose of siphoning into business the money transferred to the banks by the Federal Reserve Board in Washington during its government paper purchasing campaign.

TROMSOE, Norway, May 11. -- Three of us from the Soviet ship Rouslan, which was lost in the icy Northern Ocean, are safe here in Tromsoe, but the nineteen other members of the crew of our vessel are gone.

BERLIN, May 11. -- Following the recent "coordination" of the Mosse concern, the publishers of the Tageblatt, by the National Socialists, the latter are now reaching out for the Ullstein concern, one of the largest publishing houses in Germany.

WESTFIELD, N.J., May 11. -- John Cashman of the Old Westbury Golf Club won the Spring golf championship of the New York Curb Exchange today at the Echo Lake Country Club, turning in a card of 82 for the 6,890-yard course.

Dry Goods Boom Worries Jobbers. A few dry goods wholesalers expressed the fear yesterday that the heavy demand for merchandise was threatening to develop a "runaway" market and that distributers were beginning to overload themselves with goods.

GENEVA, May 11. -- The League Council was convoked today on appeal from Bolivia in a special session to consider the declaration of war in the Gran Chaco dispute. If It should accept the Bolivian view It would mean a recommendation to world powers to sever economic and financial relations with Paraguay, as Bolivia charged that in declaring war yesterday Paraguay had placed herself outside the League covenant and incurred the sanctions in Article XVI.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- President Roosevelt signed the Wagner $500,000,000 unemployment relief bill today. The measure allots half of the amount as a direct relief to the States, and the remainder will be distributed on a basis of $1 of government help for every $3 the States spend for relief.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Authority to acquire control of the Central Railroad Company of New Jersey by regaining ownership of 145,000 shares of capital stock of that road was sought in an application filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the Reading Company.

BERLIN, May 12 (AP). -- The Nazi regime Is preparing new efforts to help the farmers, one suggested plan being the complete cancellation of farm debts. Under this plan, first mortgages, where they exceed 60 per cent of the value of the farm, will be reduced to that amount.
BALTIMORE, May 12 (AP). -- An unpublished pen drawing by Rembrandt has been found in the Garrett collection, owned by Ambassador John W. Garrett and his brother, Robert Garrett.

CLEVELAND, May 12 (AP). -- The Philadelphia Athletics routed Wes Ferrell in the ninth inning to win the first game of their aeries with Cleveland today, 7 to 3. Thus the Yankees, who did not have a league game scheduled, coasted back into the league leadership.

The Actors Fund of America held its fifty-first annual meeting and election of officers yesterday afternoon at the Lyceum Theatre. For the year ended May 1 receipts totaling $151,824.38 were reported, while disbursements were $179,930.30, making a deficit of $28,105.92.

Although he had been regarded as a bachelor, Lee Weinstein, secretary to the aged and eccentric Edward Albert Ridley, with whom he was murdered on Wednesday in Ridley's underground office at 63 Alien Street, had a wife, the police discovered yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- President Roosevelt and Germany's representatives at the economic conferences here are agreed that there can be no solution of the world's economic problems without military disarmament. This attitude was succinctly expressed today in a joint communique issued by the President and Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, at the termination of their discussions.

Evidence of the sustained vigor in the upswing of busines is becoming more pronounced, even though the period of normal seasonal expansion has been passed, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The confident stride which progress now has assumed, the review states, reveals the general feeling of assurance that the current revival rests on a firm foundation which has been built slowly and solidly during the last two years.

Herman Metz, former Controller of New Tork City, returned from Germany yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. Mr. Metz said he went over with a group of German-Americans to give the German Government an accurate picture of the effect in this country of the political upheaval in Germany.

The formation of a graduate school having day sessions at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, to be called "The University in Exile," which will employ as instructors fifteen Jewish and liberal professors recently ousted from German universities has been started, it was revealed yesterday.

BERLIN, May 12. -- Chancellor Hitler today summoned the Reichstag to convene next Wednesday, in order that he might make an impressive and solemn declaration before the whole world of Germany's desire for peace.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- A brave little contingent of women and children from the New York metropolitan area, who made a "mortgage march" on Washington yesterday, trooped into the White House office today to plead with President Roosevelt for a moratorium on mortgages and enlist his help in preventing them from losing their homes.
GENEVA, May 12. -- The Big Five decided today to try to solve by public diplomacy the arms deadlock that their private talks had reached last night.

Simultaneously with the signing by the President of the Farm Relief-Inflation bill yesterday, the movement of the security and commodity markets became more deliberate. Speculative activity was curtailed and the range of fluctuations narrowed.

As Park Commissioner Sheehy announced yesterday that he would throw out the first ball this morning to open his athletic centre or the Central Park reservoir site, the Merchants Association of New York City filed with Mayor O'Brien its protest against such use of Central Park.

Acceptance by the eight nations represented at London, where they are preparing for the World Economic Conference, of President ROOSEVELT'S proposal that there be a tariff truce until that conference has finished its labors, is of happy augury.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The outlook for agriculture is better than it has been at any time in the past four years, but the outlook for the Negro on the farm as well as in industry and the professions is far from encouraging, according to experts who today addressed the Conference on the Economic Status of the Negro, under the auspices of the Julius Rosenwald Fund.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 12. -- Fiscal officers of Westchester County assailed today the statement made public yesterday by E.M. Allen, president of the Westchester County Taxpayer's Association, in which he had declared the county had "borrowed itself into the Sheriff's ante-room."

The estate of Clarence Whitman, textile commission merchant, who died May 14, 1931, was appraised yesterday at $1,874,397 gross and $1,700,700 net, of which $1,298,865 was the value of securities, while his residence property at Katonah, Westchester County, was valued at $470,300.

Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals directed the I.R.T. receivers yesterday to pay the $813,660 interest due on April 1 on the first consolidated 4 per cent mortgage bonds of the Manhattan Railway Company.

NEW YORK. Captain and Mrs. A. Clement Lope sailed last night on the Olympic for a visit in England on their way to El Fashar. Darfur. in the Sudan, where Captain Hope is in political service. Mrs. Hope, before her marriage on April 29, was Miss Elizabeth Hale Wallace.

The National Power and Light Company reports a net income of $8,043,716 for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28, equal after preferred dividends to $1.16 a share earned on 5,454,701 common shares, and comparing with $10,731,222, or $1.66 a share on 5,450,181 common shares, the year before.

BERLIN, May 12. -- The Reichstag, which recently was dismissed for the next four years by the Nazi regime, has been, suddenly summoned to assemble next Wednesday in special session to hear a statement from the government on German foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP). -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation tonight approved a $700,000 loan at 5 per cent to enable the city of St. Louis to build two railroad approaches and complete a third to the municipal bridge across the Mississippi River.

The four men convicted last Friday of conspiracy to coerce as a result of an investigation of racketeering in the poultry business were sentenced to the penitentiary yesterday in Bronx Special Sessions. A penitentiary sentence extends from six months to three yars, depending on the behavior and record of the prisoner.
CANNES, France, May 12. -- The police here believe they have discovered an important traffic in large quantities of arms and munitions smuggled from the Riviera to monarchists in Spain.

Before the new regulations governing veterans' relief become effective, on July 1, President ROOSEVELT wishes to ascertain whether "the cut in compensation of service-connected World War veterans with specific injuries has "been deeper than was originally "intended."

For the conservative salt water angler who has waited all Winter for the first sign of good fishing, these are days to test his patience. If he can no (longer resist the opportunity of getting out into the sunshine and enjoying a breath of salt air, perhaps he will decide to disregard the size of his catch.

On my return from Russia at the end of March. I stated in an interview in Berlin that everywhere I went in the Russian villages I heard the cry: "There is no bread, we are dying," and that there was faming in the Soviet Union, menacing the lives of millions of people.

WATERTOWN, Conn., May 12. -- Gordon Hoover, Hotchkiss School's pitching star, yielded only two hits to Taft School's batters today and shut them out, 1 to 0, at Rockefeller Field for his third victory of the season.

TIENTSIN, Saturday, May 13. -- Overcome by superior Japanese artillery and mechanical equipment, the Chinese defense north of Miyun, on the Peiping-Chengteh (Jehol City) road, broke yesterday and the troops fled in confusion toward Peiping.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Affixing his signature to the farm relief-inflation act today, President Roosevelt not only made effective one of the greatest phases of his legislative program, but became empowered with the widest range of authority over the economic affairs of the nation ever granted to a President in peace time.

ABOUT noon yesterday Freddy Lindstrom took a look at the dull gray sky. "Does that mean more rain?" he asked. "You know, I'm a stranger around here now." Then he went on to talk about baseball. He said:

To stop making America "appear as a laughing-stock to other nations" and to "make honest citizens of us once again," the Eighteenth Amendment must be repealed, women workers in the Ratification Week campaign of the New York State division of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Feform were told yesterday at the fifth luncheon of the week at the Hotel Commodore.

PARIS, May 12. -- France's reservations to acceptance in principle of the tariff truce during the forth-coming economic conference were explained today by qualified spokesmen in the Ministries of Foreign Affairs and Commerce. The principal reservation concerns protection against "all dumping of foreign products on our market."

NEWARK, N.J., May 12. -- The name of Jack Dempsey, former heavyweight champion, and of Abe Lyman, orchestra leader, were read into the record here today at a Federal hearing in proceedings for revocation of the 3.2 beer permit of the Harrison Beverage Company of Harrison, N.J.

MONTREAL, May 12 (AP). -- The Royals suffered their first shutout of the International League season today when Charley Perkius, Jersey City southpaw, let them down with two hits in the first game of 'a doubleheader before 3,500 and the visitors triumphed, 5-0.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt gave her unqualified endorsement yesterday to the work of the Maternity Centre Association to reduce the loss of mothers' lives in childbirth, in an address at the association's annual Mother's Day luncheon at the Waldorf Astoria.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Sentiment has been improved in the United Kingdom by recent manifestations of financial strength and measures taken to improve trade and industry, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly review of economic conditions abroad.

ALBANY, May 12. -- The official order increasing by 1 cent the price of milk in New York City was issued by the State Milk Control Board today. Tomorrow, the board announced, it will fix the prices which are to be paid to producers. Today's order annuls two previous regulations.

The Ford Motor Company has sold its interest in the Universal Credit Corporation, its automobile finance company, to the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation, which does a general financing business, for $30,000,000, it was announced yesterday.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 12. -- The Princeton nine hit its stride today and gave Williams a sound beating, 15 to 2. Taking the lead in the first inning, the Tigers clouted the ball hard throughout. The Purple did not tally until the eighth.

With profit-taking acting as a restraining influence and with Wall Street weighing the inflation possibilities, now that the legal framework finally has been set up, the share market furnished tame entertainment yesterday. The wild surges of the previous day were missing.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Assurance of cooperation, in regard to the Chaco war between Paraguay and Bolivia was sent to the Council of the League of Nations today by the Commission of Neutrals, which has been exercising its good offices for peace between the two countries.

Blondy Ryan found a home run in his system yesterday and Hal Schumacher pitched another superb game at the Polo Grounds. Added to this was a gala day at bat for Sam Leslie, completing the explanation of a Giant victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates, 11 to 3, in the second clash of the teams fighting for the National League lead.

There is no cause for worry in the fact that socially superior classes have fewer children while socially inferior classes have many, according to Louis I. Dublin, statistician and vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

An increase in profit-taking created a more two-sided course of prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Fluctuations were frequent over a range of nearly a quarter cent, and after establishing new high records for the movement, the list ended a point lower to three points higher than on Thursday.

KENT, Conn., May 12. --Kent School's smooth-stroking eight registered a triumph in the opening race of the second annual Kent regatta today on the Housatonic, defeating Hun School of Princeton, N.J., by a length over a one-mile course.

"In Topics of The Times," under the caption of "Justice and Propaganda," you referred to the Scottsboro demonstrations in Washington by the Communist forces as detrimental to the hopes of the nine Negro youths incarcerated in an Alabama prison awaiting retrial.

In the observance of Mother's Day sponsored by the Maternity Centre Association, Mrs. SLOANE, its president, recalled that it was the anniversary of the birth of FLORENCE NIGHTINGALE and expressed the need of another Florence Nightingale to tell the world that there is "no better place for a "mother than to be in a good hospital and how she can be sure she "is selecting a good one."
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 12 (AP). -- Newark made a clean sweep of the four-game series and handed the Bisons their fifth straight reverse by walking off with today's battle, 17 to 8.

LONDON, May 12. -- A partial armistice in the world's economic warfare was declared today when eight nations, including the United States and five other great powers, pledged themselves to a sweeping tariff truce to take effect immediately.

Representative Hamilton Pish Jr. asserted last night that the extraordinary powers granted to President Roosevelt by Congress constituted "an American dictatorship," based upon the consent of the governed and not upon violence and terror.

The Controller is the city's chief financial officer. He speaks with exceptional authority. General BERRY'S recent statements, describing the emergency or series of emergencies which have beset the city, and still hold it as though in a state of siege, contain a solemn warning.

Diego Rivera's controversial mural in the R.C.A. Building in Rockefeller Center went into an eclipse of indefinite duration yesterday under a blank canvas covering. The job of putting up this new covering was begun Thursday afternoon and yesterday it was completed.

PARIS, May 12. -- Abandoning her recent attitude of forbearance and aloofness toward Hitlerism, France let it be known today through her spokesman, Foreign Minister Joseph Paul-Boncour, that she was now prepared to take a strong aggressive stand and join all the foes of Nazidom in an effort to crush the National Socialist regime by peaceful means.
Leading from start to finish, J. H. Louchheim's Fancy Flight easily captured the Rosedale Stakes at Jamaica yesterday in what was her debut for 1933.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 12. -- Despite two three-putt greens on the first three holes and a water hazard penalty on No. 12, Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock Spring scored an 84 at the Upper Montclair Country Club today to win the low gross prize in the weekly tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association.
PHILADELPHIA, May 12 (AP). -- In two big Innings today, the Phillies sent three pitchers to the showers under a seven-run barrage to defeat the Cubs, 8 to 4.

Regretting the attitude taken by the American Jewish Committee and the B'nai B'rith in opposing an economic boycott of Germany by Jews in reprisal for the anti-Semitic policy of the Htiler government, Samuel Untermyer appealed yesterday for unity on this question and again urged the application of the boycott as the only road left for the Jews in fighting for the rights of their oppressed German brethren.

The Seventy-first Regiment will hold its annual Mothers' Day service tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock In St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. About 1,200 officers, enlisted men and veterans will assemble at 3 o'clock in the armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, in full dress uniform, and will march to the church.

For the first time since he went on trial last Monday for stabbing William Bender, 12 years old, on Jan. 31, Harry Murch, 16, who was found guilty of murder in the second degree by a Queens County Court jury Thursday night, wept yesterday upon being informed by his father, Daniel Murch, of Lulu Street and Philbert Avenue, Richmond Hill Circle, that his mother was ill.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 12. -- Princeton will be a slight favorite to capture the Carnegie Cup for the first time since 1927 when it meets the Cornell and Yale crews tomorrow on Lake Carnegie. The rival oarsmen took their final spins today in preparation for the mile and three-quarters test.

James M. Loughborough, former army Captain and secretary fo the International Cat Society, was discharged for lack of evidence when the East End Avenue cat-snatching case came to trial yesterday before Magistrate William C. Dodge in Yorkville Court.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 12. -- Cuba, in an underdog role, upset the favored Canadians In their doubles match in the North American zone Davis Cup series today, with Captain Ricardo Morales, Cuban ace, starring in a great uphill victory, 4-6, 0-6, 6-4, 6-4, 10-8.

In the second of a series of radio addresses on the problems and importance of the merchant marine, Captain R. Drace White, supervisor of the Port of New York, emphasized yesterday the importance of a powerful fleet of merchant ships in the defense of the nation.

The complete program for the Parents' Day exercises to be held tomorrow afternoon on the Central Park Mall was announced last night by Uncle Robert, children's radio entertainer. Uncle Robert said he expected that 50,000 would attend.

Facts about writing for the all-fiction or "pulp paper" magazines and tales of the working habits of some of the world's most prolific writers were told yesterday following the regular Friday meeting of the American Fiction Guild.

An unparalleled crisis in unemployment relief in New York City threatens to throw thousands of families into the streets, according to a committee, headed by James Myers, of the Federal Council of Churches, who sent a letter yesterday to all pastors in the city, urging them to call the attention of their congregations to the situation on Mother's Day tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 10:

About 500 of the 600 employes at the Naval Supply Depot, Third Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, will be laid off July 1 as a result of Secretary Swahson's order to curtail shore establishments, it was estimated yesterday by Captain J.F. Hatch, officer in charge.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- President Roosevelt received Ambassador de Laboulaye of France. presumably in reference to the war debt situation and signed the farm relief bill and the $500,000.000 unemployment relief bill.

Another seasonal spurt in activity marked the suburban realty turnover yesterday. In addition to an outstanding Staten Island residential deal, numerous housing transactions in Westchester and New Jersey were reported.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Greater protection for the short line railroads in proposed operations under the administration railroad consolidation bill was asked today by E.J. Jones, counsel for the American Short Line Railroad Association, before the Senate committee conducting hearings on the measure.

CHICAGO, May 12. -- Action of a small group of teachers today threatened to halt plans for the immediate payment of three months' salaries in cash to 14,000 teachers and 4,000 other school employes. As the school board met and passed a resolution paving the way for the purchase of $12,627,000 in 1932 school tax warrants by Chicago bankers, the leaders of the teachers insisted on proceeding with plans for a parade and demonstration tomorrow.

Count Heinrich Apponyi, nephew of the late Count Albert Apponyi, the noted advocate of international peace, is sailing tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. Others leaving for the Channel ports include Professor James Bryant Conant, recently appointed president of Harvard University; Frank Shields, tennis star; Mr. and Mrs. F. L. Hutton, Williamson S. Howell, first secretary of the United States Embassy in Paris; Sir Alexander and Lady Fay Muir.

PARIS, May 12. -- French Finance Ministry officials and all financial experts continue to announce the firm intention of France to maintain the gold standard and warn against the dangers of France's being drawn into a world inflation movement.
Defaulted properties in scattered Sections of Manhattan and the Bronx were bought in at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Many of the holdings went to banks. The results follow:

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- A $6,000,000 retrenchment program for the United States Coast Guard to meet the requirements of the economic program was announced today by Rear Admiral H.G. Hamlet, commandant.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The French Ambassador, Andre Lefevre de Laboulaye, late this afternoon called on President Roosevelt to inform him of the decision of the Daladier Government to ask the Chamber of Deputies to authorize payment of France's deferred Dec. 15 war debt instalment if this government would agree to a debt moratorium during the tenure of the World Economic and Monetary Conference.

A cablegram revealing that President Roosevelt has been asked to intervene in the foreign exchange situation as it affects American interests in Brazil was made public here yesterday by Leslie E. Freeman, 70 Pine Street, counsel for the American Chamber of Commerce for Brazil.

Bonfires for Radios? How will strong-arm governments in the future go about the business of burning microphones of which they disapprove? To put it the other way about, will science succeed in devising an underground broadcasting system?

Although the volume of trading in bonds on the Stork Exchange yesterday fell considerably short of that of the previous day, prices continued to advance, with THE NEW YORK TIMES averages of rail-road and industrial bonds climbing to new highs for the year, and United States Government bonds unchanged to 20-32 point up.
Alfred E. Smith continued yesterday to withhold comment on the attempts to get him to become a candidate for Mayor.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers:

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Representative Heartsill Ragon of Arkansas, a member of the Ways and Means Committee, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to be judge for the Western District of Arkansas. His nomination was confirmed without discussion.

BASLE, Switzerland, May 12 (AP). -- Germany has informed the Bank for International Settlements that she intends to pay on June 1 the interest on the dollar, pound and kronor portions of the international young 5 1/2 per cent loan on the basis of the face value of these respective currencies instead of upon the gold basis.

BERLIN, May 12. -- The Nazi revolution, today struck the great Ullstein publishing house, one of the largest and best organized in Europe, which issues more than half a dozen daily newspapers, about twice as many weeklies, and several of the best-known monthly magazines in Germany, in addition to books.

Cardinal Hayes issued a letter yesterday, which will be read at all masses tomorrow, warning Catholic parents that the faith of their children may be affected if they are sent to non-Catholic Summer camps and asking them to place their boys and girls in Catholic camps.

Small Spring Clearances Rule. Retailers here wound up the season in Spring apparel during the week with comparatively small clearances. The size of these events was judged the smallest in nearly a decade, owing to the small stocks on hand and the continued emphasis on the flow of small but steady quantities of new merchandise during the course of the season.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 12. -- Business men, university professors and clergymen debated for hours today whether to ask the churches of America to withdraw their chaplains from the army and navy.

Speaker RAINEY must be jealous of the Postmaster General. Mr. FARLEY called a meeting of Democratic Representatives. It was held Thursday night. Every Democratic Representative not out of town or on a sickbed responded to the call.

The choice of a higher subway fare or discontinuance of unemployment relief must be made by the city administration between now and June 10, Controller Berry implied yesterday in a letter to the Board of Estimate.

Tonight's closings in the Broadway playhouses include "Alien Corn," starring Katharine Cornell, at the Belasco Theatre, and the revivals of "Springtime for Henry" at the Ambassador and "As Husbands Go" at the Forrest. Miss Cornell will open a brief road tour in her vehicle on Monday in Boston.

Benjamin Roman cannot be a physician, else he would not in his letter published in THE TIMES urge the medical profession to secure patents on their medical inventions, interest capital therein and effect their exploitation. To the credit of the medical profession be it said that such a procedure would seem almost a sacrilege, a turning from high ideals to those less worthy.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The House refused today, 227 to 115, to authorize an investigation of the motion-picture industry. Chairman Warren of the Committee on Accounts charged that the proposal was only "a joy ride to Hollywood" which would cost the taxpayers probably $250,000.

Hugh B. Baker, who resigned as president of the National City Company at the time Charles E. Mitchell resigned as chairman of the National City Bank and subsidiaries, appeared at the Federal Building on Thursday and was questioned in connection with the income tax evasion charge against Mr. Mitchell, it became known yesterday.

The Treasury's latest circulation statement shows that at the end of April $658,000,000 was still outstanding in gold and gold certificates, despite the Government's demand for their return. But it would be a mistake to conclude that this figure represents the amount now in hoarding.

Mrs. Florence F. Dalsimer of 210 East Sixty-eighth Street, who will be 55 years old next July and is a grandmother, is a candidate for a master's degree in educational psychology at New York University at the June commencement, It was disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 12. -- President Roosevelt today approved a comprehensive program for placing 274,375 men in emergency conservation work camps in national and State forests by July 1.

LOS ANGELES, May 12 (AP). -- Telling a story of the "mental cruelty" of a "jealous and suspicious" husband, sun-tanned Joan Crawford, one of the movies personifications of the modern American girl, obtained a divorce today.

Although thirty-three municipalities will be in the market next week with new bonds, the amount is only $3,727,760, compared with this week's revised total of $15,501,209, and with a weekly average of $10,917,863 for the year to date. Next week's small aggregate is due to the fact that until the last few days the municipal bond market was unable to absorb new issues readily so that communities generally refrained from entering the market.
WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:
Yale's tennis team, defeated Columbia, 8-1, yesterday on the South Field courts. Len Hartman, Columbia ace, turned in the only Lion victory when he defeated Moorhead, 7-5, 5-7, 6-2.

The northwest corner of South and Moore Streets, known as 8 South Street, near the Whitehall Ferry, has been sold by Mrs. Lillian B.Landers and Mrs. Mary L. Scruggs to the Denison Realty Corporation, understood to be acting for James Gilles Dartt.

ST. PAUL, May 12. -- Officers of the National Farmers Holiday Association announced after a long conference this afternoon that the nation-wide farm strike planned for tomorrow had been indefinitely postponed.

BERLIN, May 12. -- The Boerse was very weak today following publication this morning of the government's plan for financing its public works program through a domestic loan. Financial circles fear Germany's capital market is not in condition to absorb such a loan and that for this reason the loan might be made compulsory.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- President Roosevelt signed the farm relief-currency inflation bill today. The ink was scarcely dry before Secretary Wallace set his staff to solving one of the most serious questions of the many-sided farm program -- the distress in the milk industry, just now most critical in the Chicago territory.

An immediate temporary reduction of gas and electricity rates in the Bronx was demanded yesterday by Mayor O'Brien in two complaints against the Bronx Gas and Electric Company, a subsidiary of the Consolidated Gas Company. The complaints, drawn by Corporation Counsel Hilly, were sent to the Public Service Commission after Mayor O'Brien, in the presence of newspaper men and photographers had signed them.

ST. LOUIS, May 12. -- George Pipgras, star right-hander of the Yankee pitching staff for the past six years, and Billy Werber, utility infielder, were sold outright today to the Boston Red Sox. The deal was made on a strictly cash basis, but though the amount of money involved was not revealed, it is understood to have been about $20,000.

Two former champions, Cyril Walker and Johnny Farrell, are among the 110 golfers who will play at the Cherry Valley Club on Monday in the metropolitan preliminary qualifying round for the national open championship. Pairings and starting times were announced yesterday.

LONDON, May 12 (Canadian Press). -- The cricket match at Oxford between the West Indies team and Oxford University ended today in a draw. Neither eleven was able to complete its second innings within the time limit.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 12. -- Mayor Frank Frankel of Long Beach, and two of the city's councilmen, Frank Waldron and John J. Hoey, pleaded not guilty here today before County Judge Cortland Johnson, on charges of misuse of public funds. All were released in $5,000 bail each.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Bids will be opened Tuesday in New Orleans on 19,306 bales of cotton held in foreign ports by the Cotton Stabilization Corporation, Henry Morgenthau Jr., chairman of the Farm Board, announced today. The cotton is all that remains of the 1,300,000 bales acquired with Farm Board funds in an attempt to peg the price, which brought the board a loss estimated at $94,000,000.

HARBIN, Manchuria. May 12. -- Japanese military headquarters here announced today that the Soviet Consul at Pogranichnaya had demanded the release of one Vorobieff, the customs chief, alleging that, inasmuch as the arrest was made by Manchukuo frontier police who are Japanese subjects, the incident would arouse anti-Japanese sentiment in the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The "Right Wing" of the bonus marchers, who came here to demand payment of their bonus certificates and to demand restoration of government compensation, continued today to oppose, but vainly, the alleged Communist leadership of the "Left Wing," which is comfortably quartered at Fort Hunt, Va., an old army reservation on the banks of the Potomac River, about twelve miles from the capital.

Price movements in local commodity markets were irregular yesterday, with sugar, cocoa, rubber and wool tops moving higher, while silver, silk and hides were lower. Coffee was irregular. Trading was in good volume. In the cash markets, most prices were higher.

AMHERST, Mass., May 12. -- The junior promenade, leading social event of Amherst College, was held tonight. Smith, Vassar, Mount Holyoke and Wellesley were among the women's colleges represented at the party, which drew more than a hundred couples.
LONDON, May 12 (AP). -- The American women from outside New York presented at the second royal court onight were:

Rabbi Jonah B. Wise of Central Synagogue, Fifty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue, chairman of the 1933 fund of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, returned yesterday on the Leviathan of the United States Lines from a trip abroad, where he made contact with English and Continental Jewish leaders for the refugees from Germany in European centres.

Dr. Hermann Schmitz, executive of the I.G. Farbenindustrie, a member of the board of the German Railway, the United Steel "Works and other German industrial groups, issued a statement on his arrival here yesterday on the Europa in which he said that the recent policies adopted in Germany were on a "sound" basis.

NEWARK, N.J., May 12. -- Sergeant Frank Wise of Red Bank, N.J., tonight carried off the Instructors' Perpetual Challenge Cup, one of the leading military trophies of the thirteenth annual Newark Horse Show, triumphing in a horsemanship competition against forty-five rivals.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The House today passed the independent offices bill appropriating $543,573,936 to finance the Veterans Administration, the Federal Trade Commission, the Interstate Commerce Commission, and other establishments for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

Yesterday was the Dodgers' field day at Ebbets Field, but the Cincinnati Reds appropriated it for themselves by winning the ball game, 7 to 3, thereby spoiling somewhat the golden Jubilee celebration for both Manager Carey's athletes and the 10,000 fans.

LONDON, May 12. -- Foreign Minister Sir John Simon, meeting the German Ambassador, Leopold von Hoesch, at the season's first royal court at Buckingham Palace last night, expressed his regret at the removal of the wreath placed in behalf of Chancellor Hitler on the cenotaph here.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Emmanuel Levin, self-styled member of the Communist party, was saved from possible injury tonight by the hasty intervention of police when he attempted to address a meeting of the "right wing" of the bonus army.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP). -- With an assertion that the body which Colonel Lindbergh identified as that of his kidnapped son was in reality "a plant" and not the "real Lindbergh child," Gaston B. Means today brought to a climax his strange account of the Hopewell tragedy.

SCARBOROUGH - ON - HUDSON, N.Y., May 12. -- By winning 7 1/2 points from their rivals, Westchester Country Club and Greenwich, the members of the Century Country Club today put their team at the top of the Class A list in the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association interclub competition, which comes to a close on Monday.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The $168,000,000 tax bill continuing emergency levies on gasoline and electric energy until June 30, 1934, was passed by the Senate late today, after several attempts to amend it had failed, two of them on tie votes.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Due largely to the bank crisis, unemployment increased in the first four months of the year, according to trade union reports given out today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

The millions of life insurance policy holders and savings bank depositors saved their money over a period of years during which its purchasing power fluctuated widely. But they were saving gold dollars of the same gold content, and what they saved, no one, least of all the President of their country, should take away from them to pay the debts of others.

England, since the reign of Queen Elizabeth, has recognized the service rendered the country by inventors and has seen fit to stimulate and reward them by granting them letters patent. Our government has pursued the same policy. By its fruits the system is judged to be beneficial.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 12 (AP). -- A plan to coordinate the jewelry manufacturing industry based on sales allotment, has been worked out by manufacturers here and in Massachusetts and the New England Manufacturing Jewelers and Silversmiths Association, according to heads of the latter organization.

GENEVA, May 12. -- The committee of the four great wheat-exporting nations was completed today by the arrival of the Argentine delegate, Carlos Brebbia, and moved strongly toward solving the problem of price raising by reduction of acreage rather than by export quotas.

BRUSSELS, May 12. -- Too exhausted by a violent battle in the Chamber last night before plenary powers were voted to the Cabinet to govern for three months and to negotiate for Belgium at the World Economic Conference, the Ministers tonight postponed until next week a Senate debate scheduled for tomorrow.

Extension of bonds of the St. Paul, Minneapolis Manitoba Railway for ten years with a down payment of $38.10 for each $1,000 par value of the issue was proposed yesterday in a letter sent by the First National Bank to large holders of the securities.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Charging that Dean C. Acheson of Maryland, President Roosevelt's selection for Under-Secretary of the Treasury, has been a member of a law firm "affiliated with the house of Morgan," Senator Couzens held up the confirmation of Mr. Acheson in spite of efforts by Democratic leaders to force approval of the nomination in the Senate tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- A decision was reached today by the framers to include in the national recovery bill a "re-employment tax," to be applied, practically without exemption, to manufacturers to meet the interest and sinking fund requirements of the $3,300,000,000 bond issue provided in the public works sections of the measure.

Five men were charged with murder, Dr. Frank A. Manzella, former Republican Alderman from the Twentieth District in Harlem, was held in $10,000 bail as an accessory after the fact and two others were detained as material witnesses yesterday after an inquiry into charges that a derelict man had been murdered to collect $1,788 for which the defendants had had him insured.

BALTIMORE, May 12. -- The much-disputed question of the hairline finish in the Kentucky Derby will come up for settlement tomorrow when the two principals in the argument, E.R. Bradley's Broker's Tip and Mrs. Silas B. Mason's Head Play, and nine other 3-year-olds meet In the forty-third running of the $25,000 Preakness over one and three-sixteenth miles at Pimlico.
The most encouraging signs of revival in retail trade in nearly two years are seen in the figures covering sales volume of both department stores and chain systems for April, issued during the week.

Germany boasts many great names in what used to be called mental philosophy. They have pushed psychological studies deep and wide. But they have never seemed to be able to read accurately the international mind. This has been a national defect which has more than once led to enormous political blunders.

Wall Street's philosophical view of yesterday's markets was that a corrective reaction was in order and that the moderate decline had improved the technical position. Trading on the Stock Exchange was unusually active for a Saturday -- 2,273,617 shares, as compared with 2,094,000 on the previous Saturday.

Home owners engaged in making substantial improvements to their property this Spring already number 18,150, according to Morton Bodfish, executive manager of the United States Building and Loan League, who announced yesterday the results of the league's national survey of modernization and repair loans.

RONGBUK, May 11 (By Wireless From Base Camp via Gangtok). -- The Everest climbing expedition left Kampa Dzong according to plan. After two uneventful marches across typical Tibetan country -- sandy hills and brown rock outcrops -- with views of the snowy Lhonak Mountains to the south, we reached Tinki Dzong, where we halted a full day.

IN the Spring the professional commentator upon music may clean up his desk and even his correspondence, and have a good time doing so. Valued material, long thought vanished, may come to light in this process. The clippings that he wants to keep are sorted out.

THE swift march of events in the economic life of this and other countries has turned some popular writers into economists and some economists into popular writers. By the same compulsion publishers have begun to compete with newspapers for the quick favor of readers seeking information about things affecting their dally existence.

In order to raise funds to furnish the new orthopedic department of the Columbus Hospital, the Junior Auxiliary of that institution will give a shipboard party on June 1 on the liner Rex, which has been placed at their service through the courtesy of the Italian Line.

A MODEST first novel which lays no claims to be anything more unusual, this story tells of the spiritual rehabilitation -- through manual toil and human contacts -- won by a youthful stock broker after his failure in Wall Street and a bitterly disappointing love affair.

States voting against repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment may thereafter reconsider such negative action and ratify, according to Howard Lee McBain, dean of the graduate faculty of Columbia University, one of the speakers at a luncheon of the New York State Division of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.
CANON CITY, Col., May 13 (AP). -- Deep mountain gulches which for years had echoed nothing except the howls of night-prowling animals resounded today to picks and shovels.

SHANGHAI, April 18. -- Even though Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang, one-time war lord of Manchuria, has sailed for Italy accompanied by a large retinue the furore created in China by the disappearance of immensely valuable art treasures from the Summer Palace near Peiping has not died down, and the scandal over the sale of the Tientsin Naval Hospital still occupies columns in the Chinese press.

As today is Mothers' Day by proclamation of President Roosevelt, virtually every church will take part in the tribute, which has been paid annually on the second Sunday in May since President Wilson in 1915 issued a proclamation setting aside the day.

GENEVA, May 13. -- Adolf Hitler's sudden decision to convoke the Reichstag to hear his statement on disarmament Wednesday, together with Rudolf Nadolny's departure for Berlin this afternoon, caused a decision here to postpone until Thursday the big disarmament debate set for Monday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 13. -- Leading from flagfall to wire, under a masterful ride by Jockey Gilbert L. Elston, the Audley Farm's Miss Patience, a fleet daughter of High Time, accounted for the thirty-second running of the $5,000 added Bashford Manor Stakes, feature of today's card at Churchill Downs.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 13. -- In tribute to the memory of Dr. J. Fred Wolle, who has been called the apostle of Bach's music in this country, hundreds of out-of-town visitors joined local music lovers this afternoon on the campus of Lehigh University to hear the chorales played by the trombone choir in the church steeple.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP). -- Mrs. Roosevelt was asked in a letter from a score of women and mothers today to intercede with the President in behalf of the efforts of the Home Owners Mortgage Committee, which yesterday sent a delegation to the White House to request a mortgage moratorium.

A new plan to provide low-cost housing which involves the partial use of existing antiquated structures by modernizing methods is advocated by Robert Helmer, a registered architect and member of the firm of Halsey, McCormack Helmer of this city.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One can hardly study the business indices these days without feeling that the future is brighter than it has been at any time during the last four years. Wages are being increased. Buying power is advancing.

ONCE more Mr. Sinclair is on the attack. This time in his "feature picture in twentynine reels" he takes the life of William Fox, movie emperor for more than a decade, to document another assault on that current scapegoat, the banker.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Prices of all basic commodities standardized as to quality always would have been uniform from the earliest days if each competitor had quick and positive knowledge of the prices named by his competitors.

WEST ISLIP, L.I., May 13. -- With about seventy-five individual entrants and ten teams taking part, the annual two-day New York State Skeet trapshooting championship event got under way on the Babylon Skeet Club's traps today.

LONDON, May 13. -- The British Ambassadors in Rome and Berlin have reported to their home governments that Premier Mussolini's breach with Chancellor Hitler has been widening ever since the visit to Rome last month of Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Reich Aviation Minister.

OTHER FIRES" is the third, but by no means the last, volume of Maxim Gorki's panoramic novel which is intended to depict half a century of Russia's life, from the assassination of Emperor Alexander II in 1881 to our days.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 13. -- The first annual horse show of the Rockwood Hall Country Club was held today on the estate of the late William Rockefeller. The program, which included twenty-four events, was under the direction of Arthur Naul of the American Association of Horse Shows.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 13. -- Lincoln E. Rowley, City Clerk of East Orange for the last twenty-six years and a widely known authority on children's recreational centres, died at his home, 62 Beach Street, this city, today after an illness of several weeks.

Increased movement of freight by motor truck from steamship and railroad terminals and continued reductions of grain shipments outbound are noted by the Port of New York Authority in its monthly summary of transportation conditions in the port district.

A rare and hitherto unknown manuscript, said to be the work of Paul Gauguin, the great French impressionist painter, and written as a periodical journal during the last months of his life in the South Seas, was revealed last night by Jo Mielziner, scenic designer, who returned to New York with Mrs. Mielziner aboard the Holland-America liner Statendam from a trip around the world.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We have recently been reminded often in the daily papers of the opportunities afforded of seeing Japanese cherry blossoms here and there in Greater New York. The other day, when I had business in the city, I purposely went around by Central Park that I might enjoy the cherry blossoms there.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Details of the reductions in import duties under the convention between Can- ada and France, signed yesterday at Ottawa, were reported to the Commerce Department today by Lynn W. Meekins, American com- mercial attache.

Few new announcements were made last week of bonds to be paid before maturity. Those called for payment in May were all municipal bonds, while those for future months were principally industrial bonds. Only one of the new calls was for an entire issue, the others being part retirements, most of which were to satisfy sinking fund requirements.

MORE completely equipped than any other scientific testing ground of its kind, Langley Memorial Laboratory, operated at Langley Field, Va., by the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, has once again given proof that the research conducted there is not of the academic or purely theoretical sort, but alive, practical and applicable to the factual problems of aviation.

Two events of interest to horse lovers and racing enthusiasts have been arranged for the near future. The first of these will be the Spring meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association, to be held on Saturday afternoon at the United Hunts course near Roslyn, L.I., on the estate of the late Hugh A. Murray, adjoining the place of Edward F. Hutton.

WHEN an Assistant Secretary of Agriculture writes a book that fact is not always news, but when the Assistant Secretary happens to be one of the little group of serious thinkers who are helping to form a historic Presidential policy the gentle reader should sit up and take notice.

STOP and think for a moment of the Summer and your plans for It. Are you going to the mountains or the seaside, to travel abroad or at home? Are you going to stay at your desk and week-end, and do a lot of restaurant dining on sweltering nights?

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Expansion of business activity continued on a somewhat broader scale during the week ended May 6, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

DODGE CITY, Kan., May 10. -- The liquor issue has returned to Kansas to worry political leaders, because they say it will dominate every election from the county up. So long as the public showed no in- terest in prohibition affairs, local issues were uppermost at elections.
Plans for the reorganization of the various mortgage guarantee companies are being considered by the Superintendent of Insurance of the State of New York.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 12. -- Cleveland, by formal appeal of its City Council, has asked President Roosevelt to make it the national laboratory for a Federally financed model housing and slum-clearance program.

An excess of market value of the collateral behind the Alleghany Corporation's bonds over the market value of the bonds is shown at present quotations. This $200,000,000 company and the Pennroad Corporation, an affiliate of the Pennsylvania Railroad, are the two most important organizations which are likely to be affected by the pending Federal legislation for the regulation of holding companies.

Books That Burned. Nazi bonfires have consuined a great many books not mentioned in the dispatches. These volumes are by far the most important ones burned, from the standpoint of Germany's own best interests.

The date for the benefit garden party in the interests of the Travelers Aid Society, originally scheduled for May 27, has been set forward to Saturday of this week, at which time the beautiful estate of Paul D. Cravath in Locust Valley, L.I., will be opened to the public for a nominal admission fee.

ROME. THE position of unrestricted capitalism as the ideal economic system has been challenged in many countries on the ground, among others, that it does not provide the machinery whereby employers and workers may obtain recognition of their respective rights and aspirations, except by a kind of guerrilla warfare, which is euphemistically termed the "free play of economic forces."

ALBANY, N.Y., May 13. -- Seventy-five motor boats, a fleet made up of seventy outboards and five 125-cubic inch piston displacement hydroplanes, were entered tonight for the race tomorrow morning down the Hudson River from here to New York City.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Some years hence, when the President lets his mind revert to the exciting weeks that followed his inauguration, he may conclude that the most extraordinary development of the period was the swift and wholesale change of attitude toward the momentous administration measure known as "the national recovery act."

MODELS of a new line of Terraplane Special sixes, on 113inch wheelbase, were placed on display by the Hudson Motor Car Company yesterday. The new cars, described as the "longest and roomiest sixes in the low-priced field," are presented in seven body types.

In order to take full advantage of the opportunity provided by the proposals for stabilization of industry in the national recovery act, trade associations will require an outside agency to act as an effective clearing house for economic information and as a medium of cooperation, Virgil Jordan, president of the National Industrial Conference Board, told THE TIMES yesterday.

Belief that the economic recovery can be accomplished without inflation of the currency is being expressed in a strong body of financial opinion. This view, based largely upon returning confidence as reflected in the substantial improvement which already has taken place in business and industry, is voiced with particular emphasis in the week-end comments of bankers and of investment and commission houses.

HERE is a book more fascinating, if that is possible, than the dictionary. More over, it is something new under the sun, which the dictionary isn't, and so has the added allurement of novelty. It was surely a happy inspiration that set Joseph Nathan Kane at the task of producing so intriguing a volume, and a dogged resolution of almost superhuman force that kept him at work so incessantly grilling until it was finished.

Unification of the city's subway system, with a self-sustaining fare, would serve to put the city's credit back on a sound basis and would relieve real estate of a part of its heavy tax burden, Lewis H. Pounds, former president of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board, told the members of that organization last week in the last of the lecture series held under the board's auspices.

IT was an odd family arrangement that led Frank Morgan, now to be seen at the RKO Roxy in "The Kiss Before the Mirror," to assign himself to ignoble parts. His younger brother Ralph, having revolted against the parental command to apply himself to the manufacture of bitters, had gone on the stage to play heroes.

THE temper of the Massachusetts Bay Colonv in the latter part of the seventeenth century can hardly be considered apart from the history of the Mather family, notably Richard, Increase and Cotton. These three Puritan worthies, rock-ribbed conservatives all, tireless preachers and prolific scribblers, storm centres of civil and religious controversies, typified the spirit of the time.

BY crumpling up his toes in his shoes as he walks and by arising from a seat with great effort and much groaning, an actor can make people believe he is at least ten years older than he really is. The advice comes from Charles Dudley, head of Fox's make-up department, who has aged most of the Fox players with the aid of grease paint and a little advice.

HARTFORD, May 11. -- Wet Connecticut, which never did ratify the Eighteenth Amendment, a month later than most of the rest of the country, finally has legal 3.2 per cent beer on sale, for this week the Governor proclaimed in operation the elaborate control machinery and declared sale permissible by those who obtain the proper authority.

BUENOS AIRES, May 13. -- President Justo issued today a decree signed by all members of the Cabinet declaring Argentina's neutrality in the Chaco war between Bolivia and Paraguay. The decree provides that Argentina's neutrality shall be governed by The Hague conventions of July 29, 1899, and Oct. 18, 1907, covering the rights and duties of neutrals in the case of war on land or sea, and also other Hague conventions concerning neutrality.

Prominent men and women who have been identified closely with the work of the Big Brother movement are taking an active interest in Big Brother Week, which will open tomorrow at Alfred Dunhill's Shop, 514 Fifth Avenue. A percentage of all sales there this week will be donated to the Big Brother Movement.

THIS is a book on practical etiquette for the young girl who, up to now, has been hard put to it to choose between the less Chesterfieldian suggestions of her peers concerning her conduct. It cannot be classed as fiction or as a parody on the books of its kind that have preceded it.

Announcement last week by the Board of Transportation that the section of the new municipal subway in Queens would be opened as far as Roosevelt Avenue and Broadway by Oct. 1 has led to predictions by realty interests that this improved transit service would foster considerable activity in sales and rentals in the territory to be served by the line.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP). -- Cotton consumed during April was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 470,685 bales of lint and 54,731 of linters, compared with 494,167 of lint and 50,082 of linters in March this year and 366,481 of lint and 52,174 of linters in April last year.

IT has long been a practice among publishers, especially in France and England, to lay a piece of string within the paper in which a periodical is wrapped. The wrapping is torn open by pulling one of the free, exposed ends of the string.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I observe that in Great Thoughts, the London monthly magazine, for May three columns are devoted to an interview with Philip de Laszlo, an artist well known in the United States, who has painted, among eminent men, portraits of the Pope and the Archbishop of Canterbury.

A message from the Jews of Germany to those in other lands was made public here yesterday by Rabbi Jonah B. Wise of Central Synagogue, Fifty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue, who arrived from Europe on Friday.

CALIFORNIA'S giant redwoods, some of them perhaps 2,500 years old, are young compared with a cypress tree in Mexico, which has lived, according to the estimate of a timber engineer, 4,000 years. Upon this ancient wonder the Indian village of Santa Maria del Tule recently bestowed the title of "oldest living thing in the world."

TARRYTOWN ON HUDSON, N. Y., May 13. -- Prince Charming, stalwart bay gelding, owned by the Warfield Farms and shown by Jim Maloney, captured the Hunter Championship at the first horse show held by the Rockwood Hall Country Club on the club's grounds today.
ROCHESTER, Pa., May 13. -- A temporary injunction to end a blockade of trolley cars by police on order of the Rochester City Council was issued today in the Beaver County Common Pleas Court.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The Federal Reserve Board is ready to go along with President Roosevelt in promoting the administration's program to restore the confidence of business and bring about economic recovery.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP). -- The startling version of the Lindbergh kidnapping given by Gaston B. Means was likened by Federal prosecutors today to the creations of history's great tale-spinner, Baron Munchhausen.

A little square camp building in which the electrical wizard Charles Proteus Steinmetz worked out in rough notes and manuscripts many of the formulae and circuits which sped the advance of modern engineering has been set up on the banks of River Rouge and will become a part of Henry Ford's museum of Americana, it was announced yesterday.

READERS who enjoyed (as who did not?) the author's delightful "Swallows and Amazons" and "Swallowdale" win be quick to welcome a third volume dealing with the same boys and girls. Here we find on board a little green schooner named Wild Cat, bound for the Caribbean, Captain Flint (or Uncle Jim), his two nieces, Captain Nancy and Mate Peggy; Captain John, Mate Susan, Able Seaman Titty and Ship's Boy Roger.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 13. -- Yale's freshman track team turned back the Princeton yearlings today by 74 1-6 to 60 5-6.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 13. -- The 121st annual commencement of the Princeton Theological Seminary will be held tomorrow, Monday and Tuesday. There will be special exercises in memory of the Rev. Dr. Francis Landey Patton, for many years a professor at the seminary, later its president, and also for a decade the president of Princeton University.

GENEVA. THERE seems to be a general belief that about all that is needed to make a League audience rise and cheer are the words: "Peace, peace!" The impression is abroad that because the League represents an ideal its halls are thronged with enraptured, impractical idealists.

AMONG recent currency happenings was the total obliteration of a unit that had been for centuries the money of account for more than 300,000,000 people. Without benefit of headlines, conferences or recriminations, noted only in agate type in tables of foreign exchange, the ancient Chinese tael, and with it the candareen -- both part of the romantic record of the logs of the earliest voyagers to Cathay -- vanished from quotations and authorized use.

Ellsworth Vines of Pasadena, national tennis champion, lost to Captain Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, yesterday as the Davis Cup team worked out at Court House on East Sixty-fourth Street preparatory to leaving for Canada.
MANILA, April 10. -- The surrender in Jolo, on April 7, of Moro Imam Saccam brings to a conclusion a Moro uprising which has engaged the attention of the Philippine Constabulary since Oct. 8.

FOR many years A.E. Housman, author of "A Shropshire Lad" (1896) and "Last Poems" (1922), has declined to publish any of his writings except for scholarly editions of classical works, just as he has usually refused to permit extracts from his two volumes of poetry to be included in anthologies.

OTTAWA, May 11. -- A new third-party political movement is taking definite form in Canada and its development is being watched with some concern -- or at least with considerable interest -- by the old parties. Third parties in this country are born of hard times.
To the Editor of The New York Times: What right has a holder of a bond with a gold clause to be paid in gold coin of the weight and fineness specified in the contract?

JOHN PRIOLEAU is an Englishman who has motored much in Europe. As motor editor of several London papers and as one merely seeking his pleasure on the open road he has gone hither and yon in an automobile all over Europe, and into Africa and Asia as well, until he seems abundantly qualified to give counsel and advice to other motorists.

Los ANGELES, May 12. THE late Spring theatre is flourishing in town. Two outstanding New York successes are chalking up something like local records for themselves and there is more than the usual amount of theatrical activity in general.

Michael Malloy, the stationary engineer who, the police say, was murdered by a Bronx gang that profited by insurance policies taken out in his name, survived six attempts to murder him before the gang finally killed him by gas, District Attorney samuel J. Foley charged yesterday.

VIENNA, May 13. -- The Bavarian Minister of Justice Dr. Hans Frank, the president of the Prussian diet, Hans Kerrl, and the Bavarian State Secretary Dr. Freissler arrived by airplane in Vienna today. They were promptly informed by a police official that their visit was not desired but they delivered party speeches before 5,000 Nazis in a Vienna suburb tonight.

Winning six of the fifteen events, representatives of Frederick Douglas Junior High School retained the city P.S.A.L. junior high outdoor track and field championship in the annual meet yesterday morning at the General George W. Wingate Athletic Field in Brooklyn.

RADIO voices and music are now pictured by pen and ink. Science has made it possible for every broadcaster to know what his voice "looks like." Musicians can "see" the patterns of melody after the tunes have passed through the microphone.

To the Dramatic Editor: You have had no letters lately denouncing the critics. No one has written to say that they are the sons of the wild asses of Ell, or to suggest they should be boiled in something not overly soluble. Molten lead is, I think, the usual formula.

ON the ice-clad coast of Northern Canada a great herd of reindeer is resting after an 1,800-mile trek which began in November, 1929, and has involved incredible hardships for the Lapp and Eskimo herders who accompanied the animals.

C.C.N.Y.'s baseball team combined seven hits with eleven passes and three errors to score an 11-3 victory over the Long Island University nine yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium. This triumph improved City College's season average to six games won and six games lost.

Price trends in local commodity markets were irregular again yesterday, with several of the staples easing off slightly. There were gains, however, in sugar, cocoa, hides and wool tops. Coffee, silver, silk and rubber closed lower. In the cash markets prices were slightly lower.

The reminiscences regarding Colonel CHARLES E. STAXTOX on the occasion of his death last Monday emphasized the happy turn in his speech of July 4, 1917, at LAFAYETTE'S tomb in the Picpus Cemetery, when he concluded by saying, simply, "LAFAYETTE, we are here." This will always have a place among familiar quotations, but most Americans have assumed that PERSHING said it.

BOSTON, May 13 (AP). -- The Cardinals reached Pitcher Socks Seihold and Relief Pitcher Ed Fallenstin for five runs and six hits in the first inning and eventually beat the Braves, 8 to 2, today. Walker allowed six hits to the Braves, two of which were home runs by Spohrer and Berger.

MASON'S ISLAND, Conn., May 13. -- Two racing dinghies which had never sailed in competition before took first and second places in Class B in the opening eight races of the intersectional dinghy regatta held today by the Mason's Island Yacht Club.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 13. -- Holding that the sale of 3.2 per cent beer in Kansas would "appear" to be in violation of the Federal beer law, Judge Richard J. Hopkins upheld in United States District Court here today the barring of the beverage by the State's dry law.

A NEW light may have been thrown on kidnapping in the United States the other day when the police closed in on the men involved in the abduction of little Margaret McMath of Harwichport, Mass., and found, instead of a group of desperate gangsters, two Cape Cod mechanics.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 13 (AP). -- A "new system of attacking our unemployment problem, the broad principle of which would be to use a part of our present vast relief expenditures to extend credit to private industry," was proposed by Mayor Rolland B. Marvin in a letter written today to Governor Lehman.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Mar 10. -- The attention of Southern California citizenry wanders. There's so much to look at under the "big top" that concentration seems difficult. Perhaps that is one reason the clowns get such a big play.

BERLIN, May 13. -- Germany's decision to make payment of amounts falling due under the Young plan on Tuesday not in gold but in bills of exchange, as communicated by the Reich Finance Minister to the Bank for International Settlements, is justified on the grounds of alleged British and American precedents.

Except for the customary Saturday realizing which produced a moderate reaction, the influences in the markets yesterday were largely of a negative character. Stocks, bonds and commodities drifted downward, but the final list of prices disclosed few changes of consequence.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 13. -- Yale today blanked Cornell, 2 to 0, and 1 to 0, both games being limited to seven innings by agreement, to tighten the Eastern Intercollegiate League race.

GENEVA, May 12. -- The League of Nations arms conference has now a month left before the League's World Economic Conference opens. It may be useful to consider the prospects of these two world meetings, as seen from Geneva and Basle.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- President Roosevelt instructed Secretary Wallace today that, because of the American pledge of a tariff truce pending the outcome of the World Monetary and Economic Confer- ence and the foreign policy involved, he is not to undertake any acreage-reduction program or levy processing taxes as provided in the emergency farm relief legislation without his consent.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Prohibition enforcement activities decreased last month, as compared with March and April, 1932, according to figures issued today by Major A.V. Dalrymple, director of the Federal Dry Bureau.

For the second time this season the Dodgers were forced yesterday to end an extra-inning game without a decision having been reached. They played the Reds ten innings to a 1-1 deadlock and then the contest was called by agreement to permit the visitors to catch a train.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 13. -- Sweeping both of today's singles matches in straight sets, Canada defeated Cuba in their Davis Cup tennis series, four matches to one.

A scientific expedition to explore one of the least-known large areas remaining in the country, a tract of between 1,000 and 2,000 square miles spreading across the Utah-Arizona border, to report on its possibilities as a new national park, is being organized, Ansel Franklin Hall, chief forester of the National Park Service, announced here yesterday.

THE upheaval which has taken place in Germany is often referred to by enthusiasts as a national renaissance. In a sense it is. For it marks a rebirth of Prussianism, though in a somewhat altered form. The new Prussianism, like the old, is thoroughly militaristic, extravagantly Pan-German, bitterly anti-liberal and antidemocratic.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP). -- Widows of twenty-four officers and enlisted men who lost their lives in the Akron and J-3 airship disasters, petitioned the Senate today to restore the double pension which widows of flight officers and men were entitled to prior to passage of the economy act.

Of the more than twenty formal candidates for the presidency of Hunter College, only seven remain under serious consideration, it became known yesterday. With Tuesday set as the date for a final selection by the Board of Higher Education, two-thirds of the applicants have been eliminated by the board's Hunter College administrative committee.

NOT entirely of the East, nor yet altogether of the West, partly Jewish, partly Christian, partly Mohammedan, where the civilization of the Crusaders was imposed on that of the ancient Greeks, and modern Fascist Italy now rules, the Island of Rhodes is a place of striking and picturesque contrasts.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 13. -- Princeton and Yale, two of America's oldest track and field rivals, battled to a tie in their annual dual meet at Palmer Memorial Stadium today.

ALBANY, May 11. -- The Temporary Emergency Relief Administration has allocated $390,700 to the Conservation Department, which will enable the department to continue work on several worth-while projects in State parks during May, Lithgow Osborne, Conservation Commissioner, said today.

PARIS, April 28. MANY years have passed since the production of a new play by Henri Bernstein first became an event in the Paris theatrical season; but, although "La Rafale," the earliest of his great successes, dates as far back as 1905, a new play from him is an event still.

The establishment by the United States of a monetary unit, which would have a constant purchasing power not for gold or silver alone but for these two commodities combined with hundreds of others which the country produces and consumes was urged here yesterday by Warren M. Persons, consulting economist, in order to assure a stable general price level.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 13. -- Almost 1,000 persons visited Plant- ing Fields, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Coe, this afternoon, and paid a small admission to help the funds of the New York City visiting committee of the State Charities Aid Association.
