High above the banks of the East River, a Bavarian beer garden will be set up on Wednesday night for the diversion of those who subscribe to a party now being arranged in behalf of unemployed draftsmen of the architectural profession.

THE legal beer faucet has now been turned on for more than a month, and the gurgle of its noisy stream has spelled good news to industry, capital and labor. While it is yet too early to judge whether the highly optimistic prophecies of the brewers regarding the effects of the prodigal's return were warranted, or whether the gloomy prophecies of the drys would more accurately reflect the situation, certain conclusions can be drawn.

Factory-built and standardized houses, according to the plans frequently proposed by over-enthusiastic builders or prospective builders, received little sympathy at the hands of Professor H. Vandervoort Walsh of the Columbia University Department of Architecture in his address at Chicago last week before the National Conference on the Renewal of Home Building.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Secretary Hull plans to press next week economic conversations with foreign diplomats resident here and to conclude discussions with T.V. Soong of China and Alberto J. Pani of Mexico, special representatives to the discussions.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., May 13. -- Virginia's track team triumphed over Navy today, 64 1-10 to 61 9-10. Captain Billy Lauck gave a sparkling performance in his last home appearance, winning the mile in 4:15.7 and then taking the two-mile.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP). -- Senate and House differences over the administration's Tennessee Valley development-Muscle Shoals bill were fully composed in conference today, and Senator Norris, whose fifteen-year ambition for government operation of the wartime Alabama project is about to be realized, said he would seek Senate approval Monday.

Diego Rivera, noted Mexican mural painter, revealed last night in an address in the Town Hall that when he came to the United States he came not solely as an artist but to use his art to advance the cause of the proletariat.

Among the many trades which have experienced an upturn in business because of the legalization of beer are hotels and restaurants, and improvements to existing facilities, remodeling of other business structures for restaurant use and construction of breweries have brought considerable work to the building industry.

THE anti-trust laws, which President Roosevelt proposes to relax in order to halt cutthroat competition and raise wages, have played a part in government policy for more than four decades. The original Sherman anti-trust law, enacted in 1890, was prompted by price raising through agreements, combinations and other artificial methods.

PARIS, May 11. -- As the mid- season advances more collections endorse unanimity in waistlines and a diversity of shoulder treatments. Patou approves high and wide stiffened wing effects on daytime coats and dresses, and huge leg-o'-mutton sleeves for dressy wear.

A plea for college credits and degrees for capable students regardless of their previous condition of academic servitude is the upshot of a survey of the abilities of 5,500 adult students in extension courses at the University of Minnesota, made by Professor Herbert Sorenson and recently published by the university's press.

MADISON, Wis., May 13. -- Wisconsin's milk strike went into effect today. While only nineteen of the seventy-one counties were affected, the supplies of Milwaukee and other large cities near Lake Michigan were tied up.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 13. -- Not only Cambridge, and a family of some 70,000 Harvard alumni, students and faculty, but probably the entire world of education will now focus its attention on another Harvard experiment.

IN 1892 the number of lynchings in the United States reached the appalling total of 255, of which 100 were white persons. From this peak the number steadily declined until in 1929 the total was ten. In the intervening period the lynching of white men had almost disappeared and such outbreaks of mob violence practically had been localized in the South.
LONDON. WITH the approval by the House of Commons of the proposal of the Chancellor of the Exchequer to increase the Exchange Equalization Account from u150,000,000 to u350,000.000.

BRUSSELS, May 4. -- Bitter complaints about the increasing boldness of lions in the Congo that are killing natives, stealing cattle and reducing the supplies of game, have led to investigation. It appears that for the last two years, lions have been going in for intensive breeding.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Relative to recent efforts by many good citizens to place the United States on a parity for defense with other nations, particularly in sea defense, the writer of a letter recently published in THE NEW YORK TIMES gives it as his judgment that "It [these efforts] is unfortunate from a psychological point of view."

LONDON, May 12. -- Germany Nazi rulers have done themselves no good by sending Dr. Alfred Rosenberg. Chancellor Hitler's private adviser on foreign affairs, on a more or less official mission of enlightenment to England.

TORONTO, May 13. -- Newark broke even with Toronto in their twin bill today. The Leafs captured the first game, 2 to 1, to stop the Bears' six-game winning streak. Luke Hamlin turned in his fifth straight for Toronto.

To young Tommy Tyburn, who has fallen upon bad times and has been compelled to take an active interest in the antiques business upon which the family fortune is founded, comes a beautiful young woman who offers to sell him the Seven Bad Men.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 6 amounted to 523,819 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 11,857 cars, or 2.2 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 10,132 cars, or 1.9 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 221.921 cars, or 29.8 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

Notable penthouse gardens in New York will be opened to the public for the first time on May 23, in an unusual series of garden days that are being arranged by members of the New York City Committee of the Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation in behalf of that organization.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 13. -- Rutgers seniors, although they expect financial difficulties will prevent them from marrying for periods varying from five to fifty years, will prefer college women as their life mates when they do, unless they are "pseudo-sophisticated artificial and too incompetent."

Justice Harlan F. Stone of the United States Supreme Court has acquired the marble "Sitting Figure" by Maurice Sterne, painter and sculptor, which attracted much attention last Winter in the retrospective exhibition of Mr. Sterne's work at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.

BALTIMORE, May 13. -- Leading practically from start to finish, and beating off his opposition decisively in the stretch run, Mrs. Silas B. Mason's Head Play today won the Preakness Stakes before a throng estimated at 40,000.

No new principles of rate-making are laid down in the latest valuation controversy to reach the Supreme Court of the United States -- Los Angeles Gas and Electric Corporation v. Railroad Commission of California. Years ago the court decided that rate-making should be a flexible process, capable of adaptation to varying conditions.
Heavy week-end profit-taking caused frequent and nervous fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the final quotations were 10 to 15 points lower than on Friday.

Travis Jackson came out of the coach's box at the Polo Grounds yesterday in time to thrill some 10,000 fans with a single that gave the Terrymen a victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates, 2 to 1, in eleven innings.

THE American publishers of this book have called it "sensational." At any rate it gives full measure of intellectual excitement, audacity and wit -- qualities which have been none too apparent since the time of Lucian in theological controversy.

It has been scientifically determined, according to Mr. FREDERICK OSBORN of the American Museum of Natural History, that what the Gilbertian song says of certain others is true of us: On the whole we are Not intelligent.

The technique of ship design applied to the construction of modern passenger liners must be revised in important details for cargo ships, according to George S. Baker, superintendent of the William Froude laboratory at Teddington, England.

An old English mace has been presented to Columbia University as an emblem of the authority of the president and board of trustees of the university. Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, announced yesterday.

BERLIN, May 13. -- The Boerse closed the week with a slump which carried the stock average down about 2 per cent. The political situation in which Germany finds herself as a result of the Geneva deadlock, together with the government's plans for financing huge public works and reducing the interest on agricultural inlebtedness, has produced uncertainty in financial circles, which caused a general selling wave today.
TO President Roosevelt is due the revival of an old tradition that political platforms are to be taken seriously by those elected upon them.

ISTANBUL, May 12. -- Until a few months ago feeling was growing here that the spirit of nationalism which has been the mainspring of the new Turkey was waning, particularly among Turkish youth. Two recent incidents show the spirit not only is alive but still plays a most important part in the country's life.

"SWEET AUBURN! loveliest vil- lage of the plain," the poet's vision for which, THE TIMES Magazine recently reported, thirty American towns have been named, is to undergo material restoration. British newspapers note that a project for rebuilding at least the rectory is being promoted by Henry L. Gavan.

THE old volume, bound in calfskin and bearing the date 1833 on the title page, contained among other interesting articles a book review entitled "The Turf." The book under review was, according to the notice at the head of the article:

THERE is little enough in these lyrics of human loves and nature's loveliness to remind one of the author of "Sanctuary." "Man comes," says Mr. Faulkner (reminding one, instead of the author of "A Shropshire Lad").

NEWARK, N.J., May 13. -- Piloted with spirit and skill by Miss Hennie Mecklin, Jolo, the gray gelding from the stable of Mrs. R. L. Benson of Princeton, N.J., tonight won the open jumping competition at the closing session of the thirteenth annual Newark Horse Show.

CURRENT exhibitions in local galleries cover an unusually wide range. Academic and modernist; etchings, watercolors, murals; work by painters just emerging and by a famous artist now dead; all these and other factors combined to make the week interesting, apart from memorable stirrings in the art world discussed in adjoining columns.

DANZIG, May 13. -- The political tension created by the expected victory of the National Socialists in the election scheduled for May 28 has led to an open conflict between the Socialists and the National Socialists and police that threatens to create a grave problem for the League of Nations, which is responsible for Danzig's fate.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 13. -- Army defeated Notre Dame on the track today, 74 to 52. Bruce Epler, victor in the high hurdles and broad jump, was the Army's chief pointgetter.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13. -- Operation of the "Gates plan" at conducting athletics at the University of Pennsylvania has demonstrated the fundamental soundness of the policy and it should be continued in all its phases, declared Dr. E. Leroy Mercer, dean of the Physical Education Department, in a report today.

ONE of the foremost authorities on the man-like apes is Dr. Robert M. Yerkes. His laboratories in the department of com- parative psychology at Yale are virtually apartments for chimpanzees. In Florida he has a bungalow colony of anthropoids.

BERWYN, Pa., May 13. -- One of the most thrilling finishes the event has seen in several years marked the four-mile cross-country race for the Radnor Hunt Cup at the Radnor Hunt Club's annual Spring race meet today at Chesterbrook Farm.

The recently announced plans for the rehabilitation of the Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company, one of the largest American companies, merits general approval and should have the active support of every claimant of the company, former Senator Joseph S. Frelinghuysen, a director, said in a statement issued yesterday.

THE Christian ascetic ideal involving suppression of the sex instinct has long been a popular theme of fiction, more especially with Protestant writers -- Hawthorne, Hardy, the Brontes, Andre Gide, to name a random few. Here we have that theme treated from the point of view of a broadminded modern, familiar with the psychoanalytic school and Dr. Stopes.

JUNE has a way of turning the radio spotlight on Chicago. It is the month of the radio trade show and last year the month of roses made the Windy City the vortex of broadcasting when all loud-speakers were focused on the national political conventions.

The "Lee-Philllps" portrait of George Washington, attributed by several authorities to Gilbert Stuart, will come up at auction here Thursday night in a collection of paintings consigned by Mrs. L.F. Easton of La Crosse, Wis.; Arthur Nicholson of Wey bridge-on-Thames, Surrey, England, and other owners.

BERLIN, May 13. -- Chancellor Hitler, using the Reichstag as an international sounding board, will defend Germany's foreign policy when he addresses that body Wednesday and will lay the blame for the deadlock in the Geneva disarmament conference where the Nazi government thinks it belongs.
Despite excellent pitching by Bill Gottlieb and faultless work afield by its opponents, the Fordham University baseball team registered a 2-to-1 triumph over N.Y.U. yesterday.

WASHINGTON. THE nation's documents and records, now lying exposed to fire and other hazards, in many a departmental storeroom, will find a safe home, noble in its promotions and modern in its equipment, with the completion of the Archives Building, now under construction, at Seventh Street and Pennsylvania Avenue.

Two battalion chiefs and nine other firemen were overcome by illuminating gas last night while fighting a blaze in the cellar of a five-story tenement at 509 Ninth Avenue, at Thirty-eighth Street, which started after a boiler of the heating plant exploded.

HANOVER, N.H., May 13. -- Way Thompson, veteran Dartmouth pitcher, attempted to take both games of the Columbia Eastern Intercollegiate League double-header today but dropped the second contest, 7 -- 5, after he had gained the verdict over the brilliant Ray White in the first game, 3 -- 2.

Because of the relation of silver to other commodities, it is believed here that some plan will be evolved at the forthcoming World Economic Conference in London through which silver will receive an improved status in the monetary systems of the important commercial nations.

ABOUT seventy-five miles north of the main highway that crosses the upper part of the State of Arizona is a land that in spite of its barrenness is fantastically beautiful. Characized by clean-cut buttes and sculptured mesas.
The names of 1,328 golfers representing 162 clubs appear on the handicap list of the Metropolitan Golf Association released for publication today.

In the early hours of dawn, just when day was creeping over Moscow's blue sky and the golden eagle perched on the Uspensky tower was coming forward to catch the first rays of the morning sun, a shot rang out through the Kremlin -- Nadejda Halliluieva, the wife of Russia's dictator, lay dead.

RETAIL trade was well maintained at its improved level during the week and some large establishments have been exceeding last year's figures quite regularly. Demand is reported to be of a general character, although the early call for Summer goods has been a feature.

SENOR RIVERA is establishing a front-page record. It seems no time at all since the sensational affair at the Detroit Museum, with the alarming talk of whitewash on the score of "blasphemy." Last week came the even more sensational climax at Rockefeller Center.

MANY features of the practice of medicine as followed in America made a deep impression on Dr. M.E. Binet, a prominent French physician of Vichy, who recently made a visit to New York and other large cities of this country.

CHICAGO, May 13 (AP). -- Bob Boken, Washington's sensational recruit infielder, again played a major part in helping the Senators gain a 5-to-4 victory over the Chicago White Sox today in ten innings of the delayed series opener.

ROME, May 12. -- Of all the sports that have won the favor of Italian youth since fascism rendered physical fitness fashionable, none exceeds in popularity association football (soccer). Hundreds of thousands of persons each Sunday watch the championship matches at the principal cities, while even at small country centres large crowds gather on holidays to cheer local boys to victory over their opponents from neighboring villages.

One of the unusual shipboard parties of the late Spring season will be held on May 24 on board the Majestic, Pier 59, at the foot of West Eighteenth Street, for the benefit of Flower Hospital. A varied entertainment will be given, including a dinner dance, bridge and midnight divertissements by Broadway entertainers.

TRENTON, N.J., May 13. -- New Jersey voters will go to the polls Tuesday to perform a double duty. They will nominate candidates for the Legislature and many county and municipal offices and also elect delegates to the forthcoming State convention for action on the question of repeal of national prohibition.
BERLIN, May 12. -- The new peasant land law, which will be promulgated in Prussia next week, is the first Nazi venture in changing laws on property.

BERLIN, May 13. -- It would be difficult to exaggerate the effect on thoughtful Germans of the unexpected summoning of the Reichstag for Wednesday to hear a speech by Chancellor Adolf Hitler on the Geneva disarmament conference and Germany's policy in relation thereto.
CHICAGO, May 13. -- The Junior League's Enchanted Island concession at the Century of Progress Exposition was officially launched today with the breaking of a bottle of milk over Magic Mountain.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Improvement of the status of the Negro race, under present and future conditions, was discussed from widely varying points of view at the clossing session here today of the Rosenwald fund conference.

THE antique hooked rug, a naive expression of the industry and ingenuity of the American housewife of a century or two ago, still holds its own among quaint household furnishings retaining a real flavor of the American past.

Into the Dickensian atmosphere surrounding Edward Albert Ridley, the aged and eccentric millionaire who had his real estate office in the subcellar of 63 Alien Street, the police interjected yesterday a modern underworld note by declaring that a room on the same subcellar level had been used by bootleggers for a cutting plant.

GERRY WAYDE, piqued by Nicholas Hulme's indifference, sets out to make him notice her. Gerry is the spoiled and pampered daughter of an M.P. and a mother whose sole ambition for her daughter is a brilliant marriage.

Steady activity featured the wholesale markets here during the week, according to the report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. Orders were placed for Summer merchandise and for staple Fall goods to be bought at prevailing prices.
WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Charles J. Brand, who was appointed today as co-administrator of the farm relief act, is a resident of Washington and a native Minnesotan.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP). -- Robert L. Lund, president of the Manufacturers' Association, who headed a delegation conferring today at the office of Director of the Budget Douglas with the sponsors of the national recovery bill, said afterward that millions of jobs probably would be created under the plan.

BOSTON, May 10. -- The mobilization of the Citizens' Conservation Corps for New England rapidly goes forward. The quota for the six States is 16,750, about half of whom are to come from Massachusetts, with Connecticut having an allotment of 3,250 men.

After some months of preparation, a new and improved weekly index of business activity is now presented by THE NEW YORK TIMES. Besides the addition of two series, making it more representative of the sum total of industrial activity in the United States, the revised index will be found superior to the original index in several respects.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The name "Hoover" has been dropped by the new administration for the great dam in the $165,000,000 irrigation project now under way in the Colorado River, which is hereafter to be known as "Boulder Dam."

ALTHOUGH he finds the Protestant churches of America torn by internal dissensions, dismembered by warring doctrines, threatened from without by powerful forces, and lacking both, in courageous leaders and in the spirit of worship, the Rev. Mr. Leary feels nothing like despair for the cause he loves and serves.

Retail trade maintained last week its recent gains, with the difference between current dollar sales volume and that of the comparative period a year ago being steadily narrowed. Despite somewhat unfavorable weather conditions, several leading stores here had dollar sales in excess of the same week of 1932.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 13. -- For the second time this season Princeton's varsity and junior varsity rugby teams today scored a double victory over the first and second Harvard teams. The varsity triumphed, 16 -- 3, and the jayvees won. 6 -- 0.
WALLINGFORD, Conn., May 13. -- Rowing under difficulties, the Choate School first and second fouroared crews defeated Columbia's freshman first and second shells today on Community Lake.

NOW that the current theatrical season is drawing to a comparatively mute and even inglorious close, it is properly time for some one whose faith in the legitimate theatre is still unshaken, despite the terrific shocks of the past, to scurry up to the masthead and descry the happy isles of the future.

Despite the heavy volume of outpayments during the three years, 1930-32, the life insurance companies have not only increased their investments, but also have accumulated cash holdings two and one-half times as large on Dec. 31, 1932, as on Dec. 31, 1929.
PHILADELPHIA, May 13 (AP). -- Orders have been received at the Philadelphia Navy Yard that the Naval Reserve will be on a volunteer basis after next Saturday.
Two plans for the development of the seven-block Chrystie-Forsyth Street area were submitted to the Board of Estimate last week for consideration.
Unconfirmed reports have been received from England that two more drivers are considering bringing motor boats to this country to race Gar Wood and his Miss America X.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa., May 13. -- The part played by volunteers in two outstanding phases of Franco-American relations, a century and a half apart, was praised by Andre de Laboulaye, the French Ambassador, in an address here today dedicating a tablet to the memory of General Louis La Begue Duportail, a French engineer who served as an aide to Washington.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 13. -- Washington and Lee won from Army on the diamond today, 5 to 1. Jarrett held Army to two hits, one a circuit drive by Kilday in the seventh for the cadets' only run. Jarrett struck out ten and was well supported in the field.

As part of a campaign to bring about wider knowledge of foreign affairs among its members, the American Legion, Department of New York, has completed the mailing of an outline for study in the 900 posts of the State, Bird Rees, chairman of the department committee on foreign relations, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 11:

TO provide for the steadily in creasing demand for beer in this country, plans have just been perfected to construct one of the largest breweries in the East at Manville, Somerset County, N.J., west of Bound Brook and a few miles northwest of New Brunswick.

Material benefit should accrue to the American marine insurance business from inflation, according to I. Edwin Tanenbaum, an organizer of the marine and seamen's insurance division of the Treasury Department in 1917 and now an investment counselor.

The pastel, charcoal and watercolor art of children ranging in age from 4 to 15 years was on display yesterday at Wanamaker's department store, while prizes and cups were awarded in the Annual Wanamaker drawing competition for school children, in the store's auditorium.

The prospect of one of the most interesting entertainments of the Spring is seen in plans now being made for the May Ball, which will be given on May 22 at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street, for the benefit of the two rest rooms and canteens opened here in January by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt for unemployed girls.

A fanciful entertainment continuing throughout the day and night and known as the Maytime Festival will be given on Tuesday at the St. Moritz for the benefit of the Actors' Fund of America, of which Daniel Frohman is president.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 11. -- Since the announcement that President Roosevelt had selected Robert H. Gore to be the next Governor of Puerto Rico there has been a strenuous effort by party leaders to get sufficient information about him on which to base an estimate of the man with whom they will be called on to work.

Hearty approval was voiced last week by the Real Estate Board of New York of the action of Governor Lehman in signing the McCall bill, which creates a new Board of Buildings and merges under one head the functions of the several departments having to do with buildings under construction as well as the Bureau of Fire Prevention.

CARICATURE and the art of the cartoon have long been honored in this country for their contributions to history. The more ardent admirers have made notable collections marking, step by step, the rise of our political parties and their fall, the changes in government, the reactions of the people, the fashions of a period, the storms over favorites, the manners of society, the subterfuges of enforced economy, the excesses of wealth, games, dances, social errors.
WASHINGTON, May 13. -- For the first time since early in 1930 government receipts are beginning to exceed those of the year before.

Postmaster General James A. Farley made his first public appearance yesterday at a philatelic gathering since becoming a member of President Roosevelt's Cabinet when he opened the New York stamp exhibition on the eleventh floor of Gimbels department store.

MILAN, April 18, 1933. THE "Second National Exhibit of Contemporary Music" organized by the Fascist Musicians Syndicate, with the collaboration of the Academy of St. Cecilia, was inaugurated by Bernardino Molinari at the Augusteo in Rome some days ago with four novelties, broadcast from the seven major Italian stations.

Frank Calder was re-elected president and Frank Patrick made managing director of the National Hockey League at the annual meeting of the board of governors at the Hotel Lincoln yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, May 13. -- The Penn Athletic Club continued its winning streak up to six games in a row by beating the University of Pennsylvania today, 8 to 5.

In deference to its own plan for a tariff truce, it was reported last week that the Roosevelt Administration would refrain meanwhile from imposing new duties on farm products entering the United States from foreign countries. Authorization for such duties is contained in the "farm parity" bill.

The encroachment of athletics in the heart of quiet Central Park became an accomplished fact yesterday as the first baseball diamond on the old reservoir site was thrown open to the accompaniment of shouts, trampled grass, mud, speeches and the grinding of newsreel apparatus.

SPOKANE, Wash., May 11. -- The Spokane Park Board has an appli- cation pending before the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a self-liquidating loan of $92,000 for the completion of a second municipal golf course known as the Indian Canyon course.

The fall at the dollar in foreign exchange has resulted in an unstable condition in the foreign exchange market which could explode at any time in a violent rally of the American monetary unit hack to par, or even above par, according to banking experts.

THE contest touching the immediate use of a hideously devastated area in the heart of Central Park -- the 34-acre dump occupying the space formerly covered by the waters of the lesser of the two reservoirs that mirrored back the sky so agreeably -- invites attention to the present state and uses of the park in relation to the original vision of the park and the uses for which it was designed.
ALTA VISTA, like Hollywood, is in California without being precisely of it. Its people are the exotic flowers among the vegetables of a tropical luxuriance.

WATERTOWN, Conn., May 13. -- The Choate School of Wallingford, Conn., with a powerful array entered in the field events, swept through to a decisive victory with 49 1-3 points today, in the sixth renewal of the triangular track and field meet with Loomis Institute of Windsor, and Taft, the home team, on Rockefeller Field.

HOLLYWOOD. WHEN "Paddy, the Next Best Thing" goes before the Fox cameras next week the studio will embark upon a rather delicate project. With "Cavalcade" Fox triumphed through an all-English cast which brought praise from the country which gave Hollywood the play.

IT is said that stage mothers are among the most obnoxious pests in the theatre business, but it is not credible that Kitty, the gross specimen drawn here by Mr. Ropes, could ever have had a close counterpart in life -- that is, without ending her days in jail or by being murdered.

WESTCHESTER'S ninth annual music festival, directed by Albert Stoessel, will take place on Friday evening at the County Centre in White Plains. A choral ensemble of 1,500 voices will take part and Albert Spalding will be the soloist.

General Hans von Seeckt, it is learned from an authoritative source in Berlin, will not, as was recently reported, go to China to aid the Chinese Army against the invading Japanese, but will make a tour of the world with his wife, who throughout his career has, according to some observers, been his inspiration, and to others quite the reverse.

PARIS, May 13. -- A conference on the dollar and the probable effect of its depreciation on French Commerce was held today by Finance Minister Georges Bonnet with the financial experts who accompanied Edouard Harriot to Washington. It was stated no decisions were taken.

ALICE IN WONDERLAND" will be brought to the screen by Paramount as a result of contracts signed last week for the cinema rights to the Carroll classic. With Norman Taurog, director of the latest Chevalier picture, at the helm, Alice's extraordinary adventures in the land of whimsy will be filmed with music and a cast which will include Charles Ruggles, Alison Skipworth, Charles Laughton, Jack Oakie and Mary Boland.

BASLE, May 11. -- The gathering of all the important central bankers of Europe here last Monday for the annual general meeting of the Bank for International Settlements provided the first opportunity for taking the financial pulse since the dollar left the gold standard.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 13. -- President Alessandri signed a decree this afternoon declaring Chile's neutrality in the Chaco war. The document, the terms of which are similar to Argentine and Brazilian declarations, will be released tonight simultaneously with those of the other two countries.

AN automobile trip through Europe! To some it means the thrill of venturing into the unknown; to others it means returning to the charm and simplicity of the "old country"; to all it holds out a peculiar lure and enchantment.

THE world premiere in concert form of "Merry Mount" will be one of the important events of the Ann Arbor May Festival, which will take place in the Michigan city this week, from Thursday to Saturday. Howard Hanson's opera, which has an original libretto by Richard Stokes, will have its premiere on the operatic stage at the Metropolitan next season.

VIENNA, May 12. -- The events of the past fortnight are reflected in the Austrian situation with sudden clearness as a fight between Chancellor Hitler of Germany and the Dollfuss government here for the soul, and eventually the body, of this country.

The Cherry Valley Club at Garden City, L.I., will be an exceptionally busy place during the next week. Tomorrow the sectional qualifying round for the national open will be held there, but beginning on Thursday, for over a week, the women golfers of this area will be the principal players over this wellknown links.

INCLUSION of through streets of towns and cities in the Federal-aid road program is receiving the active advocacy of such organizations as the American Road Builders Association, the American Association of State Highway Officials and the Asphalt Institute.

THE program with which Martha Graham concluded her season's activities last week was of a character to render incredible the fact that less than ten years ago dancers were almost exclusively concerned with interpreting Mendelssohn's "Spring Song" and the like.
PHILADELPHIA, May 13. -- For the fifth consecutive year Pennsylvania beat Cornell on the track today, 70 1/2 to 64 1/2.

PHOENIX, Ariz., May 11. -- The decision just handed down by the Arizona Supreme Court declaring the sales tax law unconstitutional not only nullifies an unpopular law, but may have a far-reaching effect on legislation here. Owing to the unusual grounds on which the decision is based it will be of interest in all States with constitutional provision for a referendum.

IN the dry intermountain country of the great Southwest, a dusty, mesa-broken land, where pasturage was scant at best, old John (Red Horse) Dunn had devoted fifteen strenuous years to the herculean task of building a cow kingdom -- "a kingdom on the grand scale of the old days, when a man could cut out 5,000 beeves in the Fall work, and 5,000 again in the Spring, and never miss their number."

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The Glass bill for strengthening banking laws and insuring deposits was unanimously approved today by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, and a House committee began study of the Steagall bill, which is similar except for one point.

The extension of bonds of the St. Paul, Minneapolis Manitoba Railway, proposed in a letter issued by the First National Bank may provide a test of the possibility of effecting readjustments of the obligations of carriers without recourse to the railroad provisions of the bankruptcy law, in the opinion of Wall Street observers.

The Great Northern Railway is negotiating with the Northern Pacific and the Union Pacific for a reduction in the number of passenger trains between Seattle, Wash., and Portland, Ore., now operated under a pooling agreement, according to the report for 1932 of W.P. Kenney, president of the Great Northern.

Business activity in the metropolitan district last week showed a general improvement over the week before and the corresponding week last year, according to a survey of manufacturing, wholesale and retail operations made yesterday by the New York Credit Men's Association especially for THE TIMES.

BESIDES being of exceptional interest, "A Judge Takes the Stand," which the learned author, Joseph N. Ulman of the Maryland Supreme Court bench, characterizes as "an effort to draw a picture in broad outline of law as it is, of 'law in action,' " has a highly laudatory purpose.
WOOSTER, Ohio, May 13 (AP). -- Mother's Day, a day of flowers, sermons and remembrances, provided a piece of news today about an ideal mother.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 13. -- Rutgers scored its fourth victory in five starts today, defeating Stevens before a large preparatory school day crowd, 8 to 0. Thompson and Resnick held Stevens to three hits.

ALBANY, May 13. -- Milk pro- ducers in the State will receive 4 cents a quart, or $1.88 for 100 pounds, for Class 1 fluid milk after Tuesday, the State Milk Control Board announced today in fixing the minimum price. This applies to milk from a radius of 200 miles of New York City.

RECOGNIZING the enormous cost of soil wastage by erosion and excessive loss of rainwater as run-off from unprotected cultivated slopes and from overgrazed ranges and pastures, Congress recently made provision for studying the whole problem of erosion and for developing practical methods of control.

DUBLIN, May 11. -- In the move toward an Irish Republic the next step to be taken by Eamon de Valera's government following abolition of the oath to the British Crown is the exercising of all the remaining provisions of the Constitution which the President regards as "inconsistent with our sovereign rights."

IT was during the World War that X-rays were first applied in detecting hidden flaws in castings. The method proved so successful that it is now specified in inspecting armor-plate, rudder-posts, shells, indeed any heavy metallic masses on the soundness of which industrial efficiency and life itself depend.

The crisis in public relief was discussed yesterday at a conference between Welfare Commissioner Frank J. Taylor and a committee of the Bronx Tenants League. To the demands presented by the committee Commissioner Taylor replied that the problem was primarily financial and was being made increasingly difficult as the ability of the city to raise money for relief decreased.

For a new Cabinet officer, HAROLD LOY ICKES is delightfully outspoken. He says what is on his mind just as if he were not a politician. Think of a Secretary of the Interior announcing in a public speech that the American people do not know how to use their parks! "Their idea of wild flowers is to pick them up by the roots," he told a group of park-lovers dining together the other evening.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Secretary Swanson ordered 169 officers of the Medical Corps of the Navy today to report for immediate duty in connection with the hospitalization and medical attention of the Civilian Conservation Corps.

LIKE scores of other engineers in the employ of the great communication companies of Europe and America, Dr. Karl G. Jansky of the Bell Telephone Laboratories has been studying static, disturber of the radio peace.
WASHINGTON, TO make a house a home is still the greatest gift a woman has to give. To make a home under any and all conditions, with whatever is at hand, is genius."

Swinging into stride as the field entered the stretch, Samuel R. Rosoff's Billy M., a maiden making the second start of his career, turned loose a tremendous burst of speed to forge to the front and win by a length in the twenty-first running of the $2,500 added Youthful Stakes at Jamaica yesterday.

HANOVER, N.H., May 13. -- Dartmouth's brilliant lacrosse team continued on its undefeated way today, turning back a strong Yale combination, 3 -- 1, to mark the first Green victory over the Blue in any college sport this year.

BERLIN, May 1, 1933. THERE is talk now of securing for the still conductorless Leipzig Gewandhaus Herr Eugen Jochum. That such a suggestion is even possible indicates to what a pass things have come by the elimination from German musical life of men like Bruno Walter, Otto Klemperer and Fritz Busch.

In a prepared statement dealing with the German private debt and questions of banking and currency, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, announced last night that he intended to call at once a conference in Berlin of rep- resentatives of holders of German obligations in the various countries, with a view to deciding on the best way of meeting the problems surrounding these private debts.

To the Dramatic Editor: Considering all the obstacles it has had to overcome, the present theatrical season must, I suppose, be congratulated for coming out as well as it has. There have been no great plays: the two outstanding successes have been nothing but very skillfully polished mediocrities, technically superb but artistically second-rate.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 13. -- For the tenth successive year and the fifteenth time in sixteen meets, Harvard's track team swept to victory over Dartmouth today, recording a 93 1/2-to-41 1/2 triumph in the Harvard Stadium. It was the second largest score in the history of the series, Harvard having a winning margin of 101 -- 16 in 1906.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 13. -- Harvard beat Princeton, 12 to 5, today in a loosely played Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game, both teams totaling eleven errors.

LONDON. GREEN trousers are to be the thing in London this Spring. Not the green trousers which elderly and impecunious schoolmasters sometimes affect, but trousers which are intentionally and esthetically green, real paeans of joy to greet the Spring.

MUENSTER, Germany, May 13. -- Vice Chancellor Franz von Papen, reappearing on a public platform at a Stahlhelm reunion tonight after a long period of silence, dwelt on the critical state of Germany's foreign relations, which he attributed to the outside world's inability to comprehend the spiritual meaning of the German revolution.

CHICAGO, May 11. -- A legislative jam is no new phenomenon in the General Assembly of Illinois, nor peculiar to it among State Legislatures. But the jam which now threatens at Springfield, as the ses- sion nears its end, is of more than ordinary significance because of the many important bills which seem likely to be caught in it.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 13. -- Lacking rivals for its crews today, the Naval Academy staged a junior regatta of three races on the Severn.

PASSERS-BY glancing in at the florist's window may not realize at what expense some of the delicate blooms have been created or how costly the rarest varieties are. What are the costliest flowers? Florists agree that first place must be given to the orchids; unusual orchids sometimes bring hundreds and even thousands of dollars for a single plant.

Debutantes of this and recent seasons are working toward the success of the ball in behalf of the Dancers Club, which will take place on Friday night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. During the evening they will sell programs and souvenirs.

LONDON, April 27. I HAVE been wondering, since I saw it, on what grounds "When Ladies Meet" has been popular in America. Has it been liked for its story or for its quips? Has it been taken seriously or half-seriously as a discussion of modern love or have New York audiences forgiven it its nonsense on this subject for the sake of the neatness of its lighter passages of dialogue?
WESTCHESTER awaits this season's motorists with seventy-five miles of landscaped parkways and 127 miles of county roads, 111 miles of which are paved with concrete. Some of this mileage is new.

DIEGO RIVERA faces the biggest battle of his embattled lifetime for the sake of a piece of painted wall on the elevator bank of the RCA tower in Radio City. The stake for Rivera is not financial; he has been paid in full -- $21,000 for 1,071 square feet of fresco, spread out upon one large wall, and two smaller flanking panels.

HERE is a book crammed with information collected from a field including in one perspective the semiape who ranged the tree-tops and the strap-hanger whose lodging for the night is a cubicle in a steelframed filing case for human beings such as the most up-to-date of our modern cities provide.

NEW LONDON, Conn., May 13 (AP). -- On their way to Mystic, Conn., for dinghy races over the weekend. Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Gibbs of Long Island City were overcome by monoxide gas fumes on their cruising power boat Kitty Lee today.

PARIS. MIDSEASON collections do not wear their hearts on their sleeves; one must delve beneath the surface to divine their sartorial emotions. They are primarily designed for smart private clients; therefore, these emotions generally turn out to be trustworthy and lasting, rather than of the sensational, flash-in-the-pan variety.

NEW LONDON, Conn., May 13 (AP). -- On their way to Mystic, Conn., for dinghy races over the weekend. Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Gibbs of Long Island City were overcome by monoxide gas fumes on their cruising power boat Kitty Lee today.

PARIS. MIDSEASON collections do not wear their hearts on their sleeves; one must delve beneath the surface to divine their sartorial emotions. They are primarily designed for smart private clients; therefore, these emotions generally turn out to be trustworthy and lasting, rather than of the sensational, flash-in-the-pan variety.

IN "Grand Canary" we have the third venture by the author or "Hatter's Castle" and "Three Loves" in the field of fiction. A.J. Cronin, it will be recalled, is a London physician who has deserted medicine for the novel -- not, we take it, because he likes medicine less, but because he likes authorship more.

BERLIN. THE book market is flooded with travel descriptions, entertaining and boring, erudite and superficial, written with artistry or dilettantism. Among these volumes Alma M. Karlin's "Einsame Weltreise" occupies a particularly prominent position because of the author's remarkable personality, to which, in turn, we may ascribe the curious circumstances that marked the beginning and course of her travels.

Postmaster General James A. Farley -- "Jim" Farley to Democrats from Maine to California and back again -- held court last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Commodore. Thirty-five hundred of his friends crowded into this and adjoining rooms to attend a testimonial dinner for him and yet they made an intimate affair of it.

ROSLYN, L.I., May 13. -- With wet grounds causing postponement of the opening of the Meadow Brook Club's polo season, a round robin match was held at Fisher Field today, and the honors went to Tommy Hitchcock's White quartet, which downed J. Watson Webb's Red outfit, 6 to 3, and Winston Guest's Blue combination, 5 to 4.

Domestic production of crude oil in March was 75,302,000 barrels, the largest for that month since 1930 and an increase of 12.1 per cent from the 67,189,000 barrels produced in March, 1932, according to William J. Kemnitzer, petroleum technologist, who bases his figures on data of the United States Bureau of Mines.
President Roosevelt deserves and needs the profound appreciation of the French people, for within the United States there is also "aggressive and egotistical nationalism."

THIS latest tale by Ben Ames Williams resembles a short story rather than a novel. The action takes place in a space of twenty-four hours, it turns upon a single situation and it involves directly only three characters. In spite of this, the story does not have an air of being deliberately padded or spun out.

LONDON, May 12. -- In France, Britain and other countries of Europe there is a great deal of ominous talk about the inevitability of another war. Recently, when Chancellor Hitler's Nazis began their campaign of brutality and intolerance, taking their leader at his word -- the flaming slogens of his election speeches -- there was something like a panic in Paris.

THE sponsors of A Century of Progress Exposition, to open in Chicago on May 27, will emphasize at this fair the dependence of all of the developments in engineering and industry during the past 100 years upon the pure sciences of physics, chemistry, biology and geology.
IN a somewhat unexpected preface to this volume of tales -- which is her first since "Mother Knows Best" -- Edna Ferber makes several generalizations about the short story.

The figures of the North Atlantic Conference on passenger traffic to and from all ports of the United States and Europe, including the Mediterranean, for this year up to May 6, show a drop of about 20 per cent compared with the same period in 1932, which itself was not a good year for travel.

MARIETTA, Ohio, May 13. -- Before a cheering crowd of 13,000 which lined the Ohio River banks for more than two miles, Massachusetts Institute of Technology's varsity swept to a length and onehalf victory over Marietta College today in the annual mid-America crew race.

SIGNING by Governor Lehman of the measure requiring the use of safety glass in motor vehicles places New York as the third State to require the installation of this protective feature on its registered cars. Massachusetts and Michigan already have laws calling for the use of non-shatterable glass in automobiles.

The figures of the North Atlantic Conference on passenger traffic to and from all ports of the United States and Europe, including the Mediterranean, for this year up to May 6, show a drop of about 20 per cent compared with the same period in 1932, which itself was not a good year for travel.

MARIETTA, Ohio, May 13. -- Before a cheering crowd of 13,000 which lined the Ohio River banks for more than two miles, Massachusetts Institute of Technology's varsity swept to a length and onehalf victory over Marietta College today in the annual mid-America crew race.

SIGNING by Governor Lehman of the measure requiring the use of safety glass in motor vehicles places New York as the third State to require the installation of this protective feature on its registered cars. Massachusetts and Michigan already have laws calling for the use of non-shatterable glass in automobiles.

How intelligence tests can be used to help the college girl who is failing in her work is one of many questions we are attempting to answer at Hunter College by establishing a bureau of educational guidance. After a year and a half of experimentation, we have decided to maintain it as a permanent feature of the education department, under the supervision of Professor Mary F. Higgins, the organizer.

Born a princess, married to a member of a famous family, the Countess DE NOAILLES, who died in Paris the other day, was probably not widely known in this country as a poet and novelist. To a foreigner her volumes of verses, her main title to literary distinction, may seem curiously old-fashioned; a replication or revival of the romantic movement of a hundred years ago.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The national recovery bill in the form decided on by its drafters was laid before President Roosevelt tonight, Senator Wagner of New York taking the completed measure to the White House. There followed a conference lasting until nearly midnight, in which the President, Senator Wagner, Secretary Dern, Director of the Budget Douglas and Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee took part.

GOVERNOR LEHMAN'S action in signing the Dunnigan bill, designed to permit use of a portion of the Fort Schuyler property as a base for the Merchant Marine Academy, revives the controversy regarding the disposal of this area.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The article on "Inflation" by Professor Irving Fisher, published in THE TIMES of May 1, would be startling and full of foreboding for the future if its assumptions could be shown to be well founded. May one who has tried to study the facts, and who has reached quite different conclusions, ask a few questions?

AFTER thirty stage-struck years, spent largely in aisle seats, Mr. Nathan has noticed that the popular theatre is not quite as imaginative as one could desire. It bubbles with banalities. This, Mr. Nathan reveals, has been going on since Ibsen's day.

Borrowing a page from the California system of piling up points in the field events. New York University romped off with team honors in the metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships, which were resumed after an eight-year lapse at Baker Field yesterday.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Charles A. Van Rensselaer has left the Pierre to pass the Summer at the Piping Rock Club.

JOHN MOODY, founder of Moody's Manual of Investments, president of Moody's Investors Service and author of many books on financial subjects, has written an unusual sort of autobiography. For, successful business man and authority on finance though he is, that is not the phase of his life story that stands out in his mind and in his book as the important part of his life.

Apparel and alcoholic liquors were involved in a suit by Haas Soeurs Inc., Fifth Avenue gown shop against the former Mrs. Lucy Cotton Thomas, widow of Edward Russell Thomas, capitalist and sportsman, and now Mrs. William M. Magraw of 995 Fifth Avenue, in which a judgment for $4,761 was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday for a balance due the modistes for gowns and hats.

THE romantic picture of the scarlet-coated "Mountie" of the Canadian Northwest, riding a spirited horse, may soon be displaced by a far more ordinary, humdrum sight. For mechanization is reaching up into the cold lands ruled by this efficient force of men.

ODESSA, Russia, April 26 (by Mail to Paris). -- Autumn-sown grain in the Central Black Earth region and the Ukraine wintered better and is in better shape than is generally realized in Moscow. This the writer can affirm, not only from visual evidence from a train, but from conversations with all sorts of persons, from officials to peasants traveling in "hard" coaches.

BERLIN. SO much turbulent political water has flowed by in recent weeks that a flood is about the only word to describe it. And it has washed up the German film industry very efficiently. The Hitler government has made it quite clear that the German film world is going to be completely reorganized and that the Jews will have little more to do with it either as producers, directors or actors.
CHICACO, May 12. THIS week marks the theatrical season's "high" in Chicago -- eight playhouses are in operation. Here is the list of attractions:

THIS book appears in good sea- son, now that millions are asking why we are not better led by organized religion and when many thousands are seeking paths of spiritual progress which they may follow without ecclesiastical guidance.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 11. -- The sale of 3.2 per cent beer since it became legal in North Carolina on May 1 has exceeded the most enthusiastic expectations of State tax experts, but the erection of dry barriers around certain localities is becoming a legislative pastime.

CHICAGO, May 13. -- Traders in wheat on the Board of Trade showed an increased disposition today to go slowly in taking a decided stand on the market. Brokers on the floor attributed this to the desire to know more about the administration of the farm relief law and also to the weather in the Canadian Northwest, where conditions were much more favorable for Spring seeding, which is being rushed.

THE theory that more often than not the late D.H. Lawrence was the victim of his friends may not be without some grain of truth. Certainly, he provided enough copy for them. Since his death in Southern France some time ago good-sized books about him have appeared from the pens of J. Middleton Murry, Catherine Carswell and Mahel Dodge Luhan.

LONDON. WHILE every one agrees that there are too many books, it is equally true that there are not enough. The editor of Books of the Month has teen inviting several prominent authors to suggest a book they would like to see written.

Today is Mother's Day. With florists' shops crowded with blooms awaiting delivery, confectioners' stocks at a high peak, and the telephone and telegraph companies ready to handle the expected rush of messages, New York was prepared last night for the annual observance.

ASTRANGE advertisement in a Chicago newspaper is the starting point from which Ford Harling becomes involved in a murder mystery, but really the story begins further back, when Harling loses a promissory note belonging to his employers in San Francisco.

DETROIT. SPEED as opposed to new rules is likely to be the deciding factor in the Indianapolis 500-mile race of 1933, scheduled as usual for May 30. Drivers and designers of the racing cars are reasonably confident that the new record of 104.144 miles an hour which was set in the race of last year can be exceeded.

WITH the majority of producers and writers asserting their conviction that the sparser the dialogue the more interesting the picture, there came to the Radio City Music Hall last week a film which easily outdid all others in the abundance of words and yet it held the attention of the audience throughout its length.

The decision of the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois granting to the Illinois Bell Telephone Company a permanent injunction against the enforcement of an order of the Illinois Commerce Commission prescribing lower telephone rates in the city of Chicago is likely to be a governing decision in other rate cases affecting Bell System companies, in the opinion of executives of the system.

On a pistol range underneath a police eauipment store at 5 Centre Market Place yesterday five men prepared themselves for reprisals from friends of the racketeers they helped to send to the penitentiary.
WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Movements of vessels follow: all dates are May 12, unless otherwise specified:
THERE is no doubt that our country and its people have entered upon a new phase. What is that new phase to be and above all what is its influence to be upon the American dream?

Bond prices were mildly reactionary yesterday on the Stock Exchange and trading during the two-hour period amounted to $8,175,000, compared with $9,614,000 on the previous Saturday. As measured by THE NEW YORK TIMES averages, leading foreign loans did better than domestic corporation issues.

RADIO this week swings more to music and dramatizations than talks, and that is usually the sign of Summer encroaching on the microphone. Mothers' Day is the theme of several broadcasts today. New programs of the week bring Mischa Levitzki, pianist; Everett Marshall, baritone, and Gladys Swarthout, soprano, to the radio realm, and Pauline Lord has a role in an invisible drama.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 13. -- Yale's varsity crew cleared this port tonight headed for New London and the four-mile race there against Harvard next month still undefeated, victor in both of its sprint engagements of the season.

Textile, winner of the city P.S. A.L. championship the last two years, defeated the High School of Commerce nine, 12 to 4, at George Washington High School Stadium yesterday to take the lead in the Lower Manhattan-Richmond division of the current race.

During the next few weeks the thought of fishing the inshore waters of Long Island will be uppermost in the minds of most local salt-water anglers. The varying species of game fish that frequent both the inshore and offshore waters during the year attract thousands of fishermen.

PARIS, May 12. -- After nearly a month of calm, during which France stood still more or less patiently, letting Britain fight it out for her at Geneva, the French government sent a political electric shock through Europe on Friday.

IN this sensitive story Gertrud von le Fort tells of the sixteen Carmelite nuns of Compiegne. guillotined during the Reign of Terror, and of another once a nun, but set apart from her companions by a strangely differing destiny.

IT was the Commandant of In Salah, French military post in the Sahara, who was speaking, paraphrasing in prose a poem the exact lines of which had escaped his memory. "The Sahara," said Estebe, "has a thousand faces, a thousand aspects.

Establishment of an American corporation of foreign security owners under Federal auspices, as provided for last week in an amendment to the securities bill by Senator Hiram Johnson of California, is viewed in some quarters as filling a long-felt need and furnishing a means for remedying a situation with which independent private committees are finding it increasingly hard to cope.

Valentin F. Boucas, secretary of the Brazilian Committee of State and Municipal Foreign Loans and a member of his country's delegation to the London Economic Conference, issued a statement here yesterday in which he recommended that American bankers and holders of defaulted Brazilian State and municipal bonds, which are outstanding in the amount of $200,000,000, cooperate at once with the Brazilian Government in reaching some readjustment.

BERLIN, May 13. -- The German Government has raised the duty on lard from 50 to 75 marks [the mark is worth 27.56 cents] per 100 kilograms [220 pounds]. This is a 50 per cent increase and aims directly at throttling the importation of lard, but its essential object is to stimulate the consumption of German butter with which the market is flooded.
BERLIN, May 11. -- The complexities of the mooted Protestant church reorganization in Germany have been further complicated by a new group of reformers styling itself the Young Reformatory Movement.

PARIS, May 13. -- Edouard Her- riot, who as France's special envoy went to Washington to discuss eco- nomic and other problems with President Roosevelt, says in an article in the newspaper L'Information tonight that he won over Mr. Roosevelt to the French side on several points in the disarmament question.

Lieut. Col. Ulysses S. Grant 3d was elected governor general of the Order of Founders and Patriots of America at the annual meeting of the general court of the society yesterday at City Hall. The meeting was held in the committee room of the Board of Estimate.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The only discernible effect today of the war debts conversation between the President and the French Ambassador, Andre Lefebvre de Laboulaye, late yesterday was a crop of rumors, which the White House patiently denied.

DALLAS, May 12. -- Texas is fac- ing the problem of either voting a $20,000,000 bond issue for relief purposes or having what relief work is being done here seriously crippled by withdrawal of Recon- struction Finanace Corporation aid.

The proposed public works program, which is one of the important administration relief measures, includes in its scope, points out Harold J. Rosen, secretary of the Rosen Building Corporation, some private or semi-private work, such as slum elimination.

Scoring once in the first half and twice in the second, the French Rugby Club triumphed over Harvard University's fifteen, 9 to 0, yesterday at Memorial Field in Flushing. Fine defensive work by both teams featured the engagement.

The Merchants Association of New York announced yesterday that with the unanimous approval of its board of directors it had filed a protest against enactment, in its present form, of the Federal securities bill with the members of the Conference Committee of the House and Senate in Washington.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- After consideration of the taxation features of the administration's industrial control and public works bill, President Roosevelt has decided that the sales tax will be the least oppressive way of raising the $220,000,000 necessary for the interest and amortization of the $3,300,000,000 in bonds to be issued for public works projects.

PARIS, May 13. -- Financial observers here do not understand exactly what monetary plan President Roosevelt is driving at and the impression given is that he has not formed a very definite plan as yet. His recent declaration is viewed here as not throwing much light on the subject.
MEXICO CITY, May 14. -- Plans are rapidly taking form to launch the campaigns of the aspirants to succeed President Abelardo Rodriguez, whose provisional term expires Dec. 1, next year.
Written in the Stars Of issues and processes now working themselves out on the front Page may be predicted without undue hazard that the near future will see the following outcome:

Privation and hunger had written a black chapter of hopelessness and desperation on the face of the young man who walked up the steps of the Oak Street police station early last evening, whipped an automatic revolver from his pocket and tossed it on the Lieutenant's desk.

An economic boycott of Germany until the rights of German Jews are restored and the discriminations to which they are subjected under the Hitler regime are ended, was proclaimed in the name of the 2,000,000 Jews of the metropolitan area at a conference of Jewish organizations held yesterday at the Hotel Astor under the auspices of the American League for the Defense of Jewish Rights.

Despite man's manifest shortcomings, God retains His faith in the human race, the Rev. Dr. Ernest E. Youtz of the Tompkins Avenue Congregational Church, Brooklyn, said yesterday in his sermon at the Manhattan Congregational Church, Seventy-sixth Street and Broadway.

More than 1,000 employes of the Customs Service participated in a communion service at St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church, yesterday morning, and afterward at the Hotel Astor heard Postmaster General Farley refer to their part in the "new deal," which he said had begun to show tangible evidence of a return of confidence.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (AP). -- Samuel M. Vauclain, Republican, declared he did all he could to defeat Franklin D. Roosevelt for President, but now is "thoroughly loyal to him" because his efforts "have begun the upswing."

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP). -- Under the white marble arch of the Arlington Cemetery amphitheatre which says "We here highly resolve that these dead shall not have died in vain," American war mothers today held their own version of Mother's Day services.

LONDON, May 13. -- Gold imports during April were u19,975,757, while exports totaled u3,660,987. Of the imports u5,023,900 was from South Africa, u5,197,257 from Germany, u3,969,634 from Australia, u2,891,947 from India, u1,078,315 from France, u799,614 from Holland and the balance from other countries.

A schedule of minimum fees for managing buildings in this city has been adopted by the Real Estate Board of New York. The decision to fix a standard basis of compensation for running buildings came as the result of almost five years of urging by owners and management agents who found that price "chiseling" by competing agents and "shopping around" on the part of owners had reached an intolerable stage.

The day widely observed yesterday in America in recognition of mothers will doubtless in time find a place in the world's calendar -- even in that of the Orient. In a little book by RUTH FRANCES WOODSMALL, on " Eastern Women Today and Tomorrow" there is hopeful evidence, gathered in her years of intimate experience of the Orient, that a fundamental change in attitude toward women is transforming the social system of the East.

ALBANY, May 14 (AP). -- As the State prepared tonight to embark on its experiment in fixing milk prices for the farmer's benefit, a member of the State Milk Control Board said that some farmers within ten days will be feeling the effects of the artificially supported price scale.

GENEVA, May 14. -- A controversy in the arms conference appears likely over provisions in the British draft disarmament treaty which seem to open the way for Krupps and other German munitions makers to return to the armament business.

TIENTSIN, Monday, May 15. -- Tientsin today was alive with unverified reports of impending developments in the Chino-Japanese conflict. One that is causing anxiety is that the Japanese have handed the Chinese an ultimatum demanding that the Chinese forces evacuate the Tientsin area and also Tangku, on the seacoast thirty-five miles east of Tientsin.

Two former holders of the national open golf championship, Cyril Walker, victor in 1924, and Johnny Farrell, winner in 1928, are among the 109 players who will compete in the New York district qualifying round for the open, to be held today at the Cherry Valley Golf Club in Garden City, L. I. Fifteen places have been allotted to this district.

BERLIN, May 14. -- For the first time since Nazi methods brought Germany into her present state of national awakening, signs of uneasiness among her Nazi rulers as to the course ahead have been noticed.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Discovery in a gorilla of a brain of higher type than ever before found in an animal, nearer the human brain weight than any similar ape's brain on record, was announced today by the Smithsonian Institution.
The role of the mother in modern American life was stressed yesterday in many "Mother's Day" sermons in the churches of the city.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 14. -- About a hundred members of the board of governors of the Investment Bankers Association of America arrived over the week-end for a two-day meeting The members, a large number of whom are accompanied by their wives, gave many dinners and luncheons last night and today.

PITTSBURGH, May 14. -- The official report of production of Bessemer and open-hearth steel ingots in April, made by the American Iron and Steel Institute, showed an average rate for the month of 24.56 per cent of capacity, or somewhat larger than the average of its weekly estimates made during the month.

MONTREAL, May 14. -- Production of newsprint in Canadian mills increased about 10,000 tons in April from the March total. The April production was 147,759 tons, against 137,078 in March and 176,660 tons In April last year, according to the report of the Newsprint Service Bureau.

NEW HAVEN, May 14. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 59.5, which compares with 59.2 a week ago, 58-6 two weeks ago, 57.1 three weeks ago and 56.8 four weeks ago. The present average is the highest of the year to date;

BUENOS AIRES, May 14. -- The improvement in the business situation continued throughout last week, with grain prices, except corn, continuing to rise under continued active buying for export markets. Wool trading also was active, with prices higher.

"This draft for industrial undertakings provides for an average forty-hour week. The undertakings covered are the same as defined by the Washington convention [of 1919], except that handling of goods at airports is included, owing to the development of the latter, and that an additional clause reserves coal mines for a separate convention, and that no reference is made to transport by sea or inland waterways.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The "bugle bird" described in THE NEW YORK TIMES as having mystified passengers on a ship from Colombia by sounding the bugle call and anticipating dining room calls is a troupial, of which there are specimens in Central Park Zoo.

The New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., held its May and final meeting of the season at the Hotel Astor yesterday morning, the usual demonstrations being followed by the annual luncheon at which sixty-five members and their guests were present.

PARIS, May 14. -- A warning that France must take decisive measures particularly concerning her budgetary deficit if she wants to avoid being forced off the gold standard will appear in tomorrow's Agencie Economique under the signature of Pierre-Etienne Flandin, former Finance Minister.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $3,245,323,100. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

CHICAGO, May 14. -- Prices of wheat have advanced to the level of 75 cents a bushel, which was the objective in the minds of most traders when the upturn started. From the low point of the season quotations are up 31 1/8 to 32 1/2 cents, with a net gain of 1/4 to 3/4 cent for last week.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The victory of Hitlerism in Germany has crystallized tendencies that have been at work in Europe for years and has brought about political realignments that have split Europe into two camps -- that of the revisionist powers and that of the powers which demand preservation of the status quo -- according to a report by Vera Micheles Dean, made public today by the Foreign Policy Association.

Registering his third victory in as many starts, Roy Farmelee, Giant right-hander, yesterday hurled the Terrymen into a deadlock with Pittsburgh for the National League lead. It was the Giants' third straight conquest of the Pirates.

It is ingeniously proposed to call the levy on manufactures, or any other form of excise taxation necessary to pay the interest and amortization on the bond issue of $3,000,000,000 for public works, "an unemployment tax." This is intended to make it smell sweeter to the labor unions.
Reports from Canada indicate that with the warmer weather good fishing is expected in many of the favorite spots in Quebec and Ontario.

Defeating Princeton by 12 to 5 on Saturday while Columbia was losing the first game of a double-header with Dartmouth, Harvard went into a tie for first place with the Lions in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League. Columbia has won eight games out of ten played, while Harvard has won four out of five.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. John Lord Boatwright will return today from Richmond, Va., and will be joined at the Pierre by Mrs. Boatwright's daughter. Miss Dorothea Onativia, who will be married to Ross Todd on June 5.

The passenger revenues of the Eighth Avenue subway for the year ending Sept. 10 will fall nearly $1,000,000 short of the estimate made by the Board of Transportation a year ago last February, according to figures covering the first eight months of operation.

NEW ORLEANS, May 14. -- Great activity marked the cotton market here last week, and despite considerable realizing and liquidation of old long interest, as well as much short selling by ring traders, the increased trade buying and price fixing, more speculative purchases and extensive short covering more than absorbed the offerings.
RONGBUK, Tibet, May 14 (by wireless from base camp via Gangtok) . -- The establishment of Camp 3 is now virtually completed.

The annual review of legal education issued today by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching finds the depression has cut down the attendance at degree-conferring law schools in the United States from 46,397 in the Autumn of 1928, to 39,417 in the Autumn of 1931 -- a drop in three years of 6,980, or 15 per cent.

Mother's Day should be celebrated by aiding needy mothers, Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, declared last evening in an address over National Broadcasting Company network. She was introduced by Mrs. John Henry Hammond, who, in turn, had been introduced by Dr. John H. Finley.

The subjugation and inglorious history of women for 1,800 years was largely due to the sweeping statement in the Old Testament that women were responsible for the evil in the world and therefore were condemned to bring forth their offspring in sorrow and be only the property of man, the Rev. John L. Davis declared yesterday in his sermon at the Washington Square Methodist Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

FORT KNOX, Ky., May 14 (AP). -- Facing each other across the Ohio River at Cincinnati, two mythical armies were locked in combat today, and Cincinnati was technically a mass of smouldering ruins as the army war games got under way in this area.

For Catholics "there can be no genuine education which is not religious, and no religious education which is not Catholic," the Rev. George D. Bull, Graduate Professor of Philosophy at Fordham University, declared yesterday afternoon in the principal address at the third annual convocation of all the Fordham faculties, in the college auditorium on the campus, Fordham Road and Third Avenue.
BOSTON. May 14 (AP). -- The Braves divided a twin bill with the Cardinals before 20,000 fans today, being shut out in the first frame. 4-0. but coming back to take the second, 8-4.

NORWALK. Conn., May 14. -- The Rev. Dr. Augustus Field Beard, whose one hundredth birthday was Thursday, celebrated today by preaching in clear, ringing tones at centennial services in the First Congregational Church.

A 65-year-old man was killed instantly early yesterday when he was run down by a taxicab operated by William Kaminsky, 24, of 3,894 Park Avenue, at Third Avenue and 152d Street, the Bronx. The victim was identified several hours later as Christian Juhl of 498 East 163d Street.

BARCELONA, May 14. --The negotiation of a new trade treaty between the United States and Spain with the object of opening the potentially rich Spanish market to American commerce will be one of the major concerns of the new United States Ambassador to Spain, Claude G. Bowers, who is due in Madrid on May 19.

General SHEKMAN touched the high mark of finality in declining a public office. He said that if he were nominated for the Presidency he would not accept, and if elected he would not serve. Ex-Governor SMITH'S statement yesterday about the New York Mayoralty does not quite attain that complete positiveness, but comes near enough for all practical purposes.

Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, declared yesterday that absolute repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment was the only way to eliminate the gangster. He said prohibition gave the criminal of the United States a knowledge of his power and how to apply it, and that he would not give it up without a struggle.

LONDON, May 14. -- The joint select committee of Parliament on Indian Constitutional Reform will start its work on Tuesday in association with a group of Indian consultants. Its task will be to study the British Government's general scheme for "responsible self-government with safeguards," as outlined in the recent White Paper which emerged from the three round-table conferences.
CINCINNATI, May 14 (AP). -- The Reds defeated the Cubs, 5 to 3 and 1 to 0, today and advanced to third place in the National League race.

It is also proposed, according to the broadcast, to exact paying of "time-and-a-half for overtime," with overtime limited to sixty hours a year. As in other provisions, latitude is permitted to take care of special cases.

Albert C. Simonson of the Marshall Chess Club continued in the lead yesterday in the United States chess team trial tournament, the ninth round of which was contested at the rooms of the Manhattan Chess Club. His opponent, Dr. M. D. Hassialis, failed to appear and the game was forfeited to Simonson, who now has won 7 and lost 2.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Another conference among congressional leaders, representatives of industry and labor and government heads is contemplated by President Roosevelt in a move to baring about unity before sending the industrial control and public works measure to Congress.

From Mr. ALFRED Z. REED'S " Annual Review of Legal Education," just issued by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, it appears that the number of students attending degree-giving law schools in the United States decreased between the Fall of 1928 and that of 1931 from 46,000 to 39,000-only 15 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The assistance of Bernard M. Baruch, who has interested himself for years in the solution of national economic problems, is being sought by the administration in placing in operation the emergency farm relief legislation.
Feldhusen crossed the finish line a few hundred yards before Walier, who thought he had won. He had not seen Feldhusen under the Riverside Drive shore. Both are professionals.
CLEVELAND, May 14 (AP). -- The Cleveland Indians moved back into possession of first place in the American League today by taking a double-header from the Philadelphia Athletics, 3 to 0 and 5 to 3.
