DETROIT, May 14 (AP) -- The Red Sox crashed through with a five-run drive in the ninth inning today to win the first game of a double-header, 6 to 1, then threw away the second with six errors, 3 to 2, although the Tigers got only five hits.

Hack Wilson hit a home run in the ninth inning with the bases filled at Ebbets Field yesterday to win a dramatic and bitterly contested game from the Phillies and send the Dodgers westward last night in fifth place. The score was 8 to 6.

Alfred E. Smith, former Governor and Democratic nominee for President in 1928, took himself out of the Mayoralty race yesterday by issuing a statement that he was not a candidate and would not accept a nomination from any party or group.

More than 1,500 members of the New York Federation of Postoffice Clerks and other Federal employes held a mass meeting yesterday afternoon in Town Hall to discuss the new economy bill and Its resultant 15 per cent cut in wages for all government workers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Danube, formerly the northern frontier of the Roman Empire, became several centuries later the bulwark of the Christian Europe of the Middle Ages against the invading Turk. It has always been the great channel through which the barbarian invasions coming from Asia and the Orient penetrated to the very heart of Europe.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I will be 90 years old tomorrow. Friday, and am celebrating the event with a trip to Manhattan to ponder over boyhood memories. I was born on a farm on the site of the Hotel McAlpin. It was beautiful country in those days, with a view of both rivers.

A child health pageant in observance of the immunization of the one millionth New York City child against diphtheria will be held on the east meadow in Central Park this afternoon with Mayor O'Brien and leaders in public health, medicine, education and social welfare work joining in the exercises, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, Health Commissioner.

Orders for cotton and linen apparel featured seasonal buying activity in the wholesale markets here during the week. Retailers continued to cover staple needs for Fall and Winter, but sought to do so at or near the low prices which recently prevailed.

" Nature," maintained DAVID HUME, " will have her rights." So she will, nor does she omit sometimes to come to the help of man by doing her duty. When she does, as Mrs. Dombey was exhorted to do, "make an effort," she leaves the best devices of lawmakers looking rather puny and futile.

MASON'S ISLAND, Conn., May 14. -- Repeating his victory of the opening day, Waldo Howland of Boston in the Plover today won the coast Class B dinghy sailing championship and the Henry B. Plant Trophy when he placed first in four out of seven races.

Mayor John P. O'Brien yesterday afternoon addressed some 10,000 persons who turned out, despite lowering skies, for the annual celebration of Parents' Day on the Central Park Mall. A band composed of 600 public school boys, directed during the celebration by Dr. Walter Damrosch and Edwin F. Goldman, gave the Mayor a three-minute ovation with trumpets and kettle-drums when he stepped up to guarantee "the protection of childhood."

LUCERNE, Switzerland, May 14. -- The International Broadcasting Union of which Vice Admiral Sir Charles Carpendale, controller of the British Broadcasting Corporation, was elected president for the ninth successive year, has concluded its annual Summer meetings with several important decisions.

ELMSFORD, N. Y., May 14. -- Frank Bowden, New York A. C. star, advanced to the semi-final round of the Hudson Valley men's tennis championship today with victories over S. V. Brubans, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, and Ernest Koslan, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1, on the Fairview Country Club courts.

Radical groups that assembled last night in Irving Plaza, East Fifteenth Street and Irving Place, to organize a "unified front committee" to protest against the veiling of the Diego Rivera murals in Radio City, booed and hissed one another before they united in a plan of action.

Three successes are coming back tonight for return engagements along Broadway. They are "Of Thee I Sing." the Pulitzer Prize winner of a year ago, with William Gaxton, Victor Moore and Lois Moran in the cast, which opens at the Imperial: "Counsellor-at-Law." with Paul Muni, at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre, and "When Ladies Meet," with Frieda Inescort and Herbert Rawlinson, at the Royale Theatre.

Fifteen years ago today an old army "jenny," equipped with a 150-horsepower engine and carrying 100 pounds of mail, left Washington, D. C., for New York by way of Philadelphia. President Wilson and Postmaster General Burleson looked on as the seventy-five mile an hour plane took off.
The increasing effect of birth control in the United States appears to have caused a significant change in the average age of marriage, the committee on social trends made known yesterday.

The Seventy-first Regiment marched to St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, from the armory at Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, yesterday for its annual Mother's Day service, at which the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, the rector, told the officers and men that cuts in national defense appropriations would be a test of their patriotism.

CHICAGO, May 14. -- A heavy volume of buying of all classes of merchandise, combined with advancing prices in many lines which have been selling decidedly too low, a greater volume of employment in virtually all lines, particularly in manufacturing, and an advance in wages of 5 to 25 per cent, make the best business picture that the Middle West has seen in several years.

Representatives of thirty-five organizations and many prominent individuals opposed to Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy's plans to develop the abandoned reservoir site in Central Park with cinder-surfaced athletic fields are expected to voice their objections at a hearing before Mayor O'Brien at City Hall at 10:30 o'clock this morning.

George W. Hodges of the Standard Statistics Company, former member of the investment firm of Remick, Hodges Co. and former president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, has been named president of the Better Business Bureau of New York City, according to an announcement made yesterday by the bureau in connection with the submission of its annual report.

ALBANY, May 14. -- Persons not regularly engaged in business or trade may be subject to the new 1 per cent sales tax, and even "swapping" of property may make the participants liable to the impost, according to regulations governing collection of the tax issued by Mark Graves, head of the State Tax Commission, today.

PEIPING, Monday, May 15. -- That the Japanese plan a major assault today upon Miyun, about 40 miles north of this city, was revealed by officers of Lieut. Gen. Yoshikazu Nishi's detachment holding Yunglo and Shihsia, which is about 60 miles northeast of Peiping.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Establishment of a non-partisan non-political planning agency to coordinate the programs which have been put forward for the rehabilitation of industry was suggested today in a study placed before administration leaders and members of Congress by Howard E. Coffin, former member of the advisory commission of the Council of National Defense and Charles E. Stuart, chairman of the planning committee of the New York Board of Trade.

Steel operations gained an additional 3 points last week to 36 per cent of capacity, the highest rate since June. 1931, according to the magazine Steel. The virility of the increase since the banking holiday has convinced the industry, the magazine says, that "the present improvement is deeper rooted than a belated Spring rise."

TOKYO, May 14. -- Four Major Generals commanding infantry brigades in the Japanese drive west of the Lwan River report they are making steady progress in the direction of Fengjun and Tsunhwa, Rengo dispatches from the North China front announced today.

LONDON, Monday, May 15. -- The speech of Vice Chancellor von Papen of Germany in Muenster Saturday night is accepted here as a grave warning at the outset of a week that The DailyMail says will be "critical for Europe and for civilization."

Proposals looking to a world-wide reduction of working hours are embodied in a report of the agenda of the seventeenth International Labor Conference, opening in Geneva in June. The report was broadcast yesterday by the League of Nations radio station and was picked up by THE NEW YORK TIMES wireless in the Times Annex at 229 West Forty-third Street.

"In One Ear," by Frank Sullivan, is published today by Viking with such back-jacket "blurbs" as "What can you expect of a man who's always befuddled?" by Robert Benchley, and "Frank Sullivan is an author who will live, unless he gets some disease," by Harpo Marx.
WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls last week are given in the appended tabulation:

Problems of home and national importance, the inadequacy of relief facilities for unemployed and misgovernment by Tammany Hall were points of discussion in the Rev. Dr. Robert Searle's sermon yesterday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street.

Net income of the United Gas Corporation for the year ended on Feb. 28 was $5,116,135, equal after full dividend requirements on the $7 preferred stock to $1,967,475 available for $7 second preferred stock, of which 884,680 shares are outstanding.

To the Editor of The New York Times : It is encouraging to find in your columns letters from widely separated parts of the country which indicate great interest in our fiscal policy. Some of these have mentioned Professor Fisher's article of May 1 on reducing the value of the dollar.

A concert will be given tomorrow afternoon at the home of Mrs. George F. Baker, 75 East Ninety-third Street, under the auspices of the benefit committee of the Camp Fire Girls Camps of Greater New York. Mrs. Lorillard Spencer is chairman of the committee and Mrs. F. Kingsbury Curtis, treasurer.

The "opera-master," a new device which synchronizes phonograph records of grand opera with screen projections of English translations of the text, along with still pictures of the opera plot, was demonstrated for the first time yesterday at the Hotel St. Moritz by its inventor, Albert E. Wier, musical editor for the publishing houses of D. Appleton Co. and Charles Scribner's Sons.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 14. -- Mrs. Richard C. Kettles Jr. of Bronxville and her sister, Mrs. George A. Anderson, gave a luncheon today at the home of the former, before the field trials of the Cocker Spaniel Club at Brookville. Harold B. Johnson, president of the club, and Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Hubbs were among the thirty-five guests.

ELKHORN, Wis., May 14 (AP). -- Enraged farmers, waging their milk strike, today battled through dense clouds of tear gas south of Mukwonago to dump six truck loads of milk destined for the Chicago market.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 14. -- Benton H. Grant of New York City has been voted by the senior class of the Sheffield Scientific School of Yale University the member who has done most for Yale, who is most to be admired, who is most brilliant and who is most likely to succeed.

Modification may be made in the proposed $35,000,000 tax bill with, its sales and income levies, to be introduced in the New Jersey Legislature when it reconvenes next Monday, May 22, as the result of a conference yesterday of the advisers to the New Jersey legislative taxation committee and Mark Graves, president of the New York State Tax Commission.

Dealing with racketeers is as treasonable as trading with the enemy in time of war, Police Commissioner Bolan asserted yesterday. Essentially, he said, those who are responsible for racketeering are those who submit to the racketeers' terms.

The church, if it had the opportunity, could do much to dissuade many persons from suicide, the Rev. William T. Walsh, rector of St. Luke's Protestant Episcopal Church, Convent Avenue and 141st Street, asserted in his sermon yesterday morning.

HARBIN, Manchuria, May 14. -- An American who left New York last Winter to invest his savings in a trip to Soviet Russia arrived in Harbin today and told of a series of bandit encounters after he had fled from Vladivostok. The man said he was John Herm, 55 years old, a seaman, of 2,055 Powell Avenue. the Bronx.
THIS is good for a brisk argument as often as two fans gather in a group and start discussing baseball. Here are a few outfields for contemplation:
VIENNA, May 14. -- Considerable disorder marked a parade of 30,000 members of the Heimwehr from all parts of Austria through Vienna today, 560 arrests being made.
BERLIN, May 14. -- All energies of the Hitler government were concentrated today on the foreign situation in preparation for a defense before the world of Germany's armament policy.

ST. LOUIS, May 14. -- On this murky afternoon, with a leaden sky overhead and heavy going underfoot, the Yankees concluded their first Western invasion of the year with anything but a triumphant flourish.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14. -- Declaring that action had superseded inaction in fighting the depression. Senator Walsh of Massachusetts, speaking today at a communion breakfast given by San Domingo Council, Knights of Columbus, said that public men had reawakened to the belief that the best way to combat economic ills was a concept of government based upon principles of justice, equality and truth.

At least two murder stories with a World's Fair background are scheduled to appear shortly. "Murder at the World's Fair," by Mary Plum, is to be brought out May 20 by Harper's. "The World's Fair Murders," by John Ashenhurst, will be published in June by Houghton Mifflin.

TIENTSIN, May 14. -- While the tide of Japanese military invasion rolls resistlessly southward, preceded by waves of Chinese refugees, the Tientsin foreign concessions are beginning: to swarm with political schemers, both Chinese and Japanese, all intent upon profiting from the situation.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP). -- A survey of one manufacturing plant, which shows that in this particular instance both workers and employer benefited by adoption of the 6-hour day, has been made by the women's bureau of the Department of Labor.

In the midst of debates on disarmament, tariff trucea and debt revision the needs of international radio would seem to be the least of Europe's worries. Yet the outcome of the International Radio Conference that is to begin today its session in Lucerne, Switzerland, is viewed with an apprehension or a hope of which it is difficult to conceive in a country like ours, living in ethereal peace with its neighbors.

The building at 26 Broadway, long known as the "Rockefeller address," will lose its most famous tenants early in July, when John D. Rockefeller Sr., John D. Rockefeller Jr. and their personal staffs will move to the fifty-sixth floor of the seventy-story RCA Building, the main unit in Rockefeller Center.

PARIS, May 13. -- Fluctuations in the pound and dollar at the beginning of the week were attributable to confusion caused in Europe by the United States action in abandoning the gold standard. It is not surprising that, after the failure of the strongest currency in the world, the public should end by suspecting all currencies still attached to gold.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Fifty years and more of diplomacy is climaxed by a declaration of war on Bolivia by the Government of Paraguay. Any one at all familiar with the diplomatic history of this dispute must realize the utter futility of continuing the old and discredited attempts to settle the Chaco controversy by conferences and accredited diplomatists of the directly or indirectly Interested parties.

Cox's boathouse at Hudson River and 200th Street, together with the 150 craft it contained, was destroyed by fire early yesterday morning. The proprietor, Richard Cox, and his wife, who lived on the second floor in the central one of the three frame buildings composing the plant, barely escaped with their lives.

PARIS, May 14. -- Following the announcement by Foreign Minister Paul-Boncour Friday that France intended to pursue a stronger policy toward Nazi Germany, discussion has been reopened here on a possible return to the Young Plan of reparations payments and the measures that might be necessary to take to compel Germany to pay under that plan.

MOSCOW, May 14. -- The Soviet Central Executive Committee in a decree today called for the first issue of the new internal State loan. The loan will total 3,000,000,000 rubles in ten-year bonds of two classes, one bearing 10 per cent interest and the other receiving varying money prizes in the State lotteries.

Long-term debts of American industrial, public utility and financial corporations have risen more than 150 per cent since pre-war years, according to a study made by the Twentieth Century Fund in connection with its investigation of the nation's internal indebtedness.

CHICAGO, May 14 (AP). -- The Senators and White Sox engaged in a pair of slugging battles today and wound up where they started, the Senators winning the second game, 11 to 9, after losing the opener, 10 to 8.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 14 (AP). -- Rochester twice defeated Jersey City today in a surprising comeback to form, 3 to 1 and 8 to 2.

Nurses from all parts of the city gathered at dusk yesterday at the old synod house of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, where, after a slow procession across the rain-soaked grounds, they joined in the ninth annual Florence Nightingale memorial service.
BALTIMORE, May 14 -- Colonel E. R. Bradley's Brokers Tip, which ran last in the Preakness yesterday, after winning the Kentucky Derby week ago, probably will not run again before next Fall.

The selection, by a committee of which the Prince of Wales is honorary chairman, of twenty-five British students who will spend two years at American universities under the fellowships provided by the Commonwealth Fund was announced yesterday on behalf of the fund.

TORONTO, Ont., May 14. -- The Nipissing Mining Company, Ltd., operating company for the Nipissing Mines Company, Ltd., reports for 1932 a net loss of $321,961, after various adjustments, against a net loss of $131,002 in 1931, with a decline in earned surplus from $2,870,821 on Jan. 1, 1932, to $2,538,860 at the end of the year.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 14. -- A five-point program for curtailing county relief work was announced today by Supervisor J. Russel Sprague and Albert S. Roberts Jr., who had been appointed recently to investigate relief work in the county with a view to effecting economies.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 14. -- About fifty representatives of New Jersey Industries were told at the close of the week-end meeting of the New Jersey Trade Association executives here today that within the next few weeks business might be granted the greatest powers of self-protection in history.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Treasury officials and other fiscal experts of the government are discussing plans for financing the $5,200,000,000 administration program to bring about economic recovery and give relief to States and their subdivisions.

PARIS, May 14. -- The urgent need of disarmament to calm Europe and to facilitate world reconstruction will be urged by 'Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large, tomorrow when he confers with Foreign Minister Joseph Paul-Boncour upon the situation created by Germany's armament demands.

Recognition of the Soviet Government by the United States and cooperation between the two countries were urged yesterday as essential to world economic rehabilitation and the preservation of peace by thirty-five economists, educators and engineers in a letter to President Roosevelt.

POONA, India, May 14. -- Mahatma Gandhi today celebrated the seventh day of his "irrevocable" fast by a reconciliation with his eldest son, Hiraldal Gandhi, with whom the father had not been on speaking terms for a long time.

WARSAW, May 14. -- The menace of intervention in Danzig by the League of Nations and the possibility that Polish troops might be moved into the Free City on the League's behalf appear to have had a sobering effect on the Nazis there.

CHICAGO, May 14. -- Hog prices have taken an upward turn, advancing almost $1 a hundredweight in the last few days. The top at Chicago was $4 at the close of the week, an advance of 67 per cent from the lowest level of the past Winter and 38 per cent above that of a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14. -- The Philadelphia Summer Concerts Association has announced the names of six of the conductors who will lead the Philadelphia orchestra this Summer during the fourth season of outdoor concerts in Robin Hood Dell, Fairmount Park.

A decided irregularity prevailed in the price movements of commodity futures traded on local Exchanges last week. Rubber, hides, cocoa and wool tops were up for good gains for the week, while silver was off sharply and sugar, coffee and silk also lost ground.

BERLIN, May 13. -- Reports during the past week by manufacturers and associations is favorable and new hope is given to heavy industries by the proposal of the Reich Labor Minister, Seldtes, to issue an internal 1,500,000,000-mark loan for the purpose of financing public works.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, May 14. -- A gathering of 6,200 members of Adolf Hitler's black-uniformed Elite Guard, assembled here today for a field day, was chiefly interesting for its revelation of the military organization of the guard.

LONDON, May 13. -- Sterling exchange continues its erratic course owing to the rapidly shifting views concerning the future of the dollar and gold currencies. These views change almost hour to hour, but one fact is very clearly emerging -- that is, the prestige of sterling is steadily increasing throughout the world.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (AP). -- Miss Pauline Beck of Milwaukee won first prize in the portrait section of the fine arts exhibition, held today as an opening feature of the annual conference of the Association of Junior Leagues of America, Inc.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 14. -- President Terra's junta approved today a Constitution project to submit to the contemplated Constituent Assembly providing for the establishment of a parliamentary form of government instead of the modified Swiss commission form which Dr. Terra, recently overthrew.
LIMA, Peru, May 14 (AP). -- Peru declared its neutrality today in the war between Bolivia and Paraguay.

Marcus Loew's Theatres, Ltd., which is affiliated with Loew's, Inc., reports for the year ended Jan. 5 a net income of $88,107 after depreciation, amortization, interest and other charges. This was equivalent, after 7 per cent preferred dividend requirements, to $5.64 a share on 6,539 preferred shares, compared with $112,831, or $8.94 a common share, the year before.

Following a hearing held by Mayor O'Brien at City Hall yesterday on Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy's projected athletic fields on the Central Park reservoir site, Mr. Sheehy announced that he would hold up his plans for "a little while."

FREE CITY OF DANZIG, May 15 (AP) -- Danzig Nazi leaders gave assurances today that if they came to power after the election May 28 the treaties between Danzig and Poland would be fully respected. These assurances were given to Helmer Rosting, the League of Nations High Commissioner.

The creation of the Film Productions Corporation as a subsidiary of the Paramount Publix Corporation in March, 1932, to take over the obligations of Paramount Publix and establish new credit when the company was facing a financial crisis, was described yesterday by Ralph A. Kohn, treasurer of the company, at a hearing in voluntary bankruptcy before Henry K. Davis, Federal referee, at 140 Nassau Street.

The Associated Operatic Artists, a cooperative company organized to give a short season of grand opera at popular prices, gave its opening performance last night of Verdi's "H Trovatore" at the Forest Theatre. There was a very large audience and the reception of the individual artists and the performance on the whole was enthusiastic.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 15 -- A par-smashing second round over the Cherry Valley course today put Johnny Kinder, young New Jersey open champion, at the head of the metropolitan qualifiers for the national open championship. A field of 104 teed off.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 16 -- With the occupation of Miyun, an important strategic centre on the main road between Chengteh (Jehol City) and Peiping, the Japanese have passed from the mountainous terrain which protects the Great Wall to the edge of the Peiping plain.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals, by a two-to-one decision, ruled yesterday that the Radio-Keith-Orpieum Corporation and Samuel L. Rothafel could not use the name "Roxy" on the new theatre in Rockefeller Center, since that name was still the property of the theatre at Fiftieth Street and Seventh Avenue, which Mr. Rothafel organized in 1925.

HAVANA, May 15 -- A rebel band of eighty or more men attacked and ransacked this morning the small town of Taguasco, on the border of Santa Clara and Camaguey Provinces, northeast of the city of Sancti Spiritus, according to reports from that district.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Grenville T. Emmet and her daughter and son, Miss Pauline Emmet and Grenville T. Emmet Jr., will sail May 24 for Italy, where Mr. Emmet will join them early in July.

DUNBAR, W.Va., May 15 -- The play which the Anti-Saloon League is taking on the road in West Virginia to sway votes against repeal in the June 27 election, opened in this industrial town tonight with a cast mainly of local dry sympathizers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The great English economist, Alfred Marshall, in developing his law of marginal utility, said: "With every increase in the amount of a thing which a man has, the eagerness of his desire to obtain more diminishes."

"Shareholders of Columbia System will be interested to know that to provide for the payment of taxes there has been set aside from the revenues of these companies in 1932 an amount equivalent to approximately 69 per cent of their combined net income, after deducting ordinary operating expenses, regular provision for reserves and taxes, interest charges and preferred dividends," Philip G. Gossler, president of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, says in his quarterly report.

PARIS, May 15 -- A full-page advertisement in this morning's Paris Herald presents "a friendly protest against the recent California State law prohibiting the use of foreign materials in the execution of public works contracts." The advertisement is signed "an American importing company doing business in the United States."

Holding that there was urgent need for municipal tax collectors ratter than more tax receivers if municipal credit was to be maintained, the municipal securities committee of the Investment Bankers Association in its interim report made yesterday to the board of governors of the association in White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., and made public here, declared that in the demand for economy in government the ability to collect taxes had sometimes been lost sight of.

Characterizing the proposed national industrial recovery act as "an advanced step in social evolution heralded by manufacturers, labor and the informed public as logical, sane, workable and inevitable," Raymond L. Collier, managing director of the Steel Founders Society of America, predicted yesterday that on the passage of the act, trade associations will emerge as the leading planning agencies for their respective industries.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Gold hoarders are evidently awaiting definite action by the Treasury and the Department of Justice for enforcing the Presidential order to surrender gold to the banks. Returns of the metal, as indicated by the Federal Reserve statement, have been slow for several weeks, although the gold reserves have been increased.

The Republic of Panama yesterday notified the National City Bank, as fiscal agent for Panama 5 per cent bonds due in 1963, that it had decided to suspend temporarily the payment of the interest due yesterday on the bonds of this American dollar issue.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 15 -- Winning eight out of ten matches in the final phase of the competition today at the Westchester Hills Country Club, the well-balanced Century Club combination captured Class A honors as the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub tournament came to a close.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 15 The annual commencement of Prlnceton Theological Seminary will be held tomorrow at 10:30 A. M. at the First Presbyterian Church, when the degree of Master of Theology will be awarded to thirty-five candidates, and the degree of Bachelor of Theology to forty-five candidates.

BERLIN, May 15 -- The second phase of the disarmament conference in Geneva has been brought to an end. Its proceedings were marked by a mood of increased nervousness, engendered by the fact that deliberations had shifted more into the political field than was the case throughout the first phase, while the technical aspects of the problem receded into the background.
TORONTO, May 15 (AP) -- The league-leading Newark Bears made their hits count to the best advantage today to humble the Maple Leafs, 7-4, for their second victory in the three-game series.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 15 -- In view of the uncertainty of conditions in the bond market, the Westchester Board of Supervisors granted today to the county's fiscal officers power to extend certificates for six months rather than take them up by a proposed issue of bonds, if satisfactory bond terms cannot be obtained.

A revival of "It's a Wise Child," one of the late David Belasco's last productions, will take place this evening at the Hudson Theatre. Harlan Briggs, Alice Frost, May Voltes and Hugh Cameron will be in the cast.

PITTSBURGH, May 15 (AP) -- Fred Lindstrom's triple with the bases full was the sparkplug of an eleven-hit attack that sent the Pittsburgh Pirates bounding back into first place undisputed in the National League with a 5 to 4 victory over the Phillies today.

Marcus Schussheim, defending champion, reached the third round in the national table tennis title tournament last night at Gimbels. He drew a bye in the first round and then triumphed over George Silver of Philadelphia, 21 -- 17, 21 -- 12.

The economic boycott against Germany proclaimed by organizations representing the 2,000,000 Jews of the metropolitan area assumed nation-wide proportions yesterday when the office of the American League for the Defense, of Jewish Rights, 729 Seventh Avenue, the organization that took the lead in proclaiming the boycott, was swamped with telegrams pledging support of the movement.

James Capel Co., care of J.P. Morgan Co., appear among the twenty largest stockholders in the Pennsylvania Railroad on Dec. 31. Other new names on the list are the Union Pacific, Fahnestock Co., the Bank of New York and Trust Company and Dutch interests.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Federal Reserve Board today resumed publication of its weekly condition statement of reporting member banks in leading cities. The statement covers banks in ninety leading cities instead of 101 leading cities as formerly, and shows figures as of Wednesday, May 10.

PARIS, May 15 -- Prices tumbled on the Bourse today, the market reacting unfavorably to various influences. A hesitant covering tendency shown by speculators was attributed to the crisis faced by the disarmament conference and the sudden convocation of the Reichstag, together with concern felt generally over Germany's present attitude.

The dinner Mr. and Mrs. William C. Breed will give tomorrow for Charles Davila, the Rumanian Minister, in their apartment at the River House will be marked by the presentation by Mrs. Lawrence Bottomley to Mr. Davila of the celebrated architects' china tea set, which is being sent by Mrs. Breed to Queen Marie of Rumania.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Mrs Roosevelt's Summer plans, as announced at a press conference this morning, include a trip to Los Angeles early in June to see her son, Elliott, now established there, by way of prelude to her vacation with the other members of her family at Hyde Park.

That prices can be raided or the burden of debts be relieved by inflation is sharply denied by J. Laurence Laughlin, political economist, in "The Federal Reserve Act: Its Origins and Problems," published today by Macmillan.

New Jersey voters today will elect delegates to the State repeal convention and vote for county and municipal officers and primary candidates for the Legislature. All counties vote on repeal convention delegates, seven counties select Senate nominees, twenty-one choose Assembly nominees, twenty vote for Freeholders and there are Mayoralty candidates to be elected in sixty municipalities.

GLENEAGLES, Scotland, May 15 -- Miss Enid Wilson, twice women's golf champion of Great Britain, today announced she would make one more effort to win the United States crown, and then -- win or lose -- would retire from competitive golf.

While the markets must have been impressed yesterday by the various week-end developments testifying to the broad industrial expansion, the downward reaction in stock, bond and commodity prices indicated that the German attitude toward foreign investments was a more direct influence.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- A proposed draft of legislation revising the present food and drugs act was submitted to the Department of Justice today for review by Rexford G. Tugwell, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture. The most important provision of the proposed draft is the expansion of the act to include cosmetics and to regulate the advertising of foods, drugs and cosmetics.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Secretary Hull, James M. Cox, candidate for President in 1920, and Senator Pittman, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, were selected today by President Roosevelt to be members of the delegation to the World Economic Conference at London.
PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -- The text of the outstanding part of the speech delivered tonight at the convention of the Junior Leagues of America By Owen D. Young follows:

Three shows, all of which won their several laurels in previous local incarnations, came back to Broadway last evening, to salute Spring with popular prices. They were "Of Thee I Sing," which was the first of the musical histories to capture a Pulitzer Prize; "Counsellor-At-Law" and "When Ladies Meet."

Representatives of six burlesque theatres summoned to confer with License Commissioner James F. Geraghty at his office yesterday were informed that "your productions are unfit to be produced." He warned them that unless the shows were changed to his satisfaction within twenty-four hours their licenses would be revoked.

A sharp break in silver futures was the feature of trading in local commodity markets yesterday, as prices of all staples reacted from the levels reached in rallies last week, for the most part, trading was in restricted volume. Cash prices were steady.

Interest in the share market, and in bonds and commodities for that matter, was sharply reduced yesterday. Speculative operators found it difficult to chart their course, so they remained on the side-lines or played the safe "favorites." Public participation was much narrower than it has been in the recent past.

In Lord TRENCHAKD'S first annual report as Commissioner of (London) Metropolitan Police, the searcher for new social trends has a moment's happiness. In 1932 the number of umbrellas found in public conveyances and deposited with the police was less by 5.500 than in the previous year.

Belief that resentment against Chancellor Hitler's regime in Germany would lead to a permanent severance of trade relations between American import houses and their German sources of supply grew in trade circles here yesterday as buyers for American importers -- both Jewish and Christian -- sought information about possible suppliers in Japan, England, Czechoslovakia and Holland.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., May 15 -- With more than half the State reporting incomplete returns, Wyoming's precinct conventions tonight had elected 334 delegates pladged to repeal to 40 for retention of the Eighteenth Amendment.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The governing heads of New York City scarcely can label Samuel Untermyer as a harsh critic of their methods of administration, for, until a day or two ago, they had been getting on rather famously.
For the first time since the trophy was lost to France in 1927, the United States Davis Cup team as a whole will not be entered at Wimbledon this year.

LOS ANGELES, May 15 (AP) -- Federal Judge William P. James handed down a decision today adjudicating all pending claims against the Richfield Oil Company and its principal subsidiary, the Pan-American Petroleum Corporation, clearing the way for sale of the properties.

Awards of merit were presented yesterday to nearly thirty of the eighty-two exhibitors in the competitive classes at the New York stamp show on the eleventh floor of Gimbel's department store. The grand trophy, a silver cup given by the Gimbels for the best exhibition in the competitive series, was awarded to R.A. Barry of this city for his lot of United States issues with many original covers from 1847 to 1887, inclusive.

W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, issued a statement yesterday attacking John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, for an alleged deal by which Mayor O'Brien will appoint Thomas W. Whittle, a Bronx Republican Assembly District leader, Tax Commissioner in place of George Henry Payne under an agreement with John J. Knewitr, Bronx County Republican leader.
A two-run attack in the tenth inning enabled St. John's College to defeat the Brooklyn College nine, 3-1, yesterday at Dexter Park, Brooklyn. The losers had tied the score in the ninth.

VIENNA, May 15 -- The German Government sharply protested today against the unfriendly reception given by the Austrian Government at the flying field here Saturday to the Bavarian Minister of Justice, Dr. Hans Frank, and his two Nazi colleagues and received an equally sharp reply.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -- A plea for active cooperation by the United States in settling the affairs of a troubled world was voiced here tonight by Owen D. Young in an address opening the convention of the Association of Junior Leagues of America.

MILWAUKEE, May 15 -- Fresh disorders marked the third day of the Wisconsin milk strike today as pickets continued to operate on roads in the affected area, covering fourteen counties along Lake Michigan and the Fox River Valley.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In connection with measures now before Congress to add another tax burden on the electric power industry, the following data should be of general interest:

Harold E. Wittemann, once a wealthy Brooklyn real estate dealer and builder, was found guilty yesterday afternoon of both counts in an indictment charging perjury and concealment of assets in a bankruptcy proceedings by a jury before Judge Marcus B. Campbell in the Federal Court in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The President, in a public address to the peoples of the world tomorrow, will plead for the preservation of peace through concerted action for disarmament at the Geneva conference and will explain for the first time the extent to which the United States is willing to go to accomplish this.

With a minimum of upsets, the field which will compete for the national open golf championship at Chicago June 8, 9 and 10 was completed yesterday in the annual nation-wide sectional trials, played on twenty courses, including the metropolitan.

LONDON, May 15 -- The stock markets today were dominated by anxieties regarding the European situation and prices generally were lower. Developments in Germany continued to be a source of uneasiness and German bonds weakened. British funds declined further and Indian Government bonds also fell, due to political uncertainties in India.
AUBURN, Me., May 15 -- Fire which started in a garage at 2:30 P.M. today caused a loss to the community estimated at more than $1,000,000 tonight when the blaze was under control.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The number of receivers chosen throughout the country for the same bankrupt concern will be greatly reduced under an important order issued by the Supreme Court today on application of New York lawyers.

Critics of Commissioner SHEETY'S plans for diminishing the area set aside for park purposes in crowded Manhattan by turning the old Central Park reservoir site into a mess of playgrounds, baseball fields and cinder-tracks laid their case before Mayor O'BRIEN yesterday.

Because of recent heavy withdrawals, State Superintendent of Banks Joseph A. Broderick put the Westchester Trust Company of Yonkers back on a holiday basis yesterday. The bank, which reopened without restrictions after the bank holiday, is one of the largest in Westchester County.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- When Congress reassembles next Winter there will undoubtedly be set in motion a bipartisan effort to liberalize the procedure of the House of Representatives. The Republicans will support it because they are in a minority. But many Democrats, who during this session have been prevented from exercising more than a voting membership, will also demand the change.

Charles Weidman, one of the most gifted of mimes and usually a witty and inventive choreographer, suffered a disturbing lapse in "Candide," which opened a week's engagement at the Booth Theatre last night under the management of Michael Myerberg.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 12:

Keyes Winter, Republican leader of the Fifteenth, or "silk-stocking" Assembly District, has decided to resign, it was learned yesterday. A meeting of the election district captains has been called for tomorrow evening at the clubhouse. 122 East Eighty-third Street, and a meeting of the county committee of the district to elect Mr. Winter's successor will he held later.

First-degree murder indictments will be sought today against the five men accused of murdering Michael Malloy, a stationary fireman, last Feb. 22 to collect the $1,788 for which they had insured his life. This announcement was made yesterday by District Attorney Samuel J. Foley, who declared he would call twenty witnesses before the Bronx grand jury.

THE stout but husky visitor came in and said in a belligerent tone: "Say, who is this Max Schmeling?" He was informed that Max Schmeling was a fighter, a heavyweight and a former world's champion. "Yes, yes," said the visitor impatiently. "Everybody knows that. But what makes every one think he's a man-eater, a destroyer?

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- A joint resolution calling for a "scrutinizing study and re-examination of all income tax returns, for the years 1931 to 1932 inclusive," was introduced in the House today by Representative McSwain of South Carolina.

PARIS, May 15 -- The menace of Nazi Germany to world peace and what can be done about it formed the subject of discussion today between Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador-at-Large, and Joseph Paul-Boncour, French Foreign Minister.

Samuel Seabury, it was learned yesterday, continues to be averse to accepting the fusion nomination for Mayor, but has agreed, in response to pleas of the fusion leaders, to postpone a definite decision for a few days.

NEWARK, N.J., May 15 -- Carrying out the wishes of the Newark conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, Bishop Francis J. McConnell redistricted today the territory of the conference, reducing the number of districts from four to three and eliminating the Elizabeth district.

Some "modification of interest requirements" for debentures of the Associated Gas and Electric Company may become necessary, notwithstanding that the interest is fully earned, J.I. Mange, president, says in the company's annual report, issued yesterday.
The New York Curb Exchange has removed from dealings securities of fifteen companies, it was announced yesterday. Among those removed were four bond issues.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 14, unless otherwise specified:

Prices of bonds of domestic corporations and of the United States Government moved irregularly lower yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange while foreign loans were unsettled by the weakness in German Government State, municipal and corporation issues.
TIENTSIN, May 15 -- The Japanese armies in North China swept forward with great speed on all fronts today, capturing several towns and driving the Chinese out of strongly fortified strategic centres.

Quiet prevailed in the money market with all rates remaining unchanged. Stock Exchange call loans renewed at 1 per cent and continued at that figure throughout the day, with outside money quoted at 3/4 per cent and governments at 1/2 per cent.

Removal from the cast side of the slaughter-houses "that could be so much more efficiently carried on elsewhere" was urged last night by Thomas Adams, director of the Regional Plan, in an address at the Panhellenic Club. Mr. Adams spoke before members of the club and of the First Avenue Association.

RENO, Nev., May 15 -- Mrs. Marguerite von Braun Savell-Miles-Rogers filed for divorce here late today against Henry Huddleston Rogers, Standard Oil man, charging cruelty. She asked for restoration of her former name, Marguerite Basil Miles.

Rivera's Wrong Pew. Can it be that DIEGO RIVERA, in designing Wrong a Lenin fresco for the walls of a Rockefeller building, was thinking of 26 Broadway instead of Sixth Avenue and Fiftieth Street? From the famous downtown address the personal offices of the Rockefeller family will soon move to the seventy-story building in Rockefeller Center.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The spirit of harmony that prevailed at Fort Hunt yesterday, after the arrival of about 200 bonus marchers who had held out against joining those they termed "Communists" was threatened today when factional strife broke out between the smaller group and the leaders of the "left wing."

BALTIMORE, Md., May 15 (AP) -- The Princeton Steeplechase, the feature attraction on a rather ordinary program at Pimlico today, saw an outsider earning major honors in the two-mile jumping test when T.H. McCreery's Sardaneza, ridden by E. Ball, scored over the eight jumpers that opposed him.

Congress will doubtless complain again about the Federal Reserve's indifference to the "need for more money." Thursday's weekly statement of the Reserve banks showed that, since March 15, their regular note circulation has decreased $942,949,000, while their issue of the special Reserve notes, authorized by the Emergency Banking bill of March 9, has been only $62,805,000.

Checks totaling $500,000 were distributed yesterday by the United Hospital Fund to fifty-six voluntary hospitals in New York City, division of the fund being in proportion to the amount of free work each hospital has done during the last year.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange were set back more than a quarter cent a pound yesterday, but the reaction induced buying and the list closed with losses of 14 to 20 points. Beneficial rains in several dry counties of Texas and political developments in Europe caused heavy selling at times.

The eight-story Hotel Raleigh Hall at the southwest corner of Sixth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street, hought by Benjamin Winter about a month ago, has been leased by him to John Nicholas, hotel operator, at a reported total rental of $250,000.

The one-millionth child to be immunized against diptheria in New York City was innoculated yesterday afternoon during ceremonies preceding a health pageant, attended by nearly 5,000 children and grown-ups, in Central Park.

Ed (Strangler) Lewis registered a surprise victory over Jumping Joe Savoldi, former Notre Dame football star, in the feature wrestling exhibition at Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 6,000 saw Lewis receive credit for the triumph while his opponent lay helpless on the floor outside the ring.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The case against Gaston B. Means and Norman T. Whitaker neared the stage of jury consideration tonight with Leo A. Rover, the prosecutor, staking the outcome on whether the five men and seven women in the box believe the bizarre version of the Lindbergh kidnapping told to them by Means.

Advertising, coupled with mass production and mass distribution, will pull the world out of the depression and prevent another slump, Edward A. Filene of Boston declared yesterday at a luncheon of the New York Advertising Club.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 15 -- C.C.N.Y. gave the Rutgers baseball team its second defeat at the season today by winning, 6-2. Phil Cooperman pitched effectively for the visitors, yielding only five hits and holding the home team scoreless except in the third inning.

The laundry Industry, one of the largest employers of women, will be the first to be covered in New York State by operation of the recently enacted minimum wage law, according to an announcement yesterday after the first meeting of the Minimum Wage Advisory Committee at the State Department of labor, 80 Centre Street.

Establishment of bonded areas similar to that in Rockefeller Center in other important cities of the world as a means of promoting international trade is favored by Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, and Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, in letters just received by officials of the Rockefeller development and made public yesterday.

BERLIN, May 15 -- German newspapers with one accord report today that the outside world is feverishly awaiting Chancellor Hitler's pronouncement before the Reichstag on the subject of armaments, and they seem to derive great satisfaction from that statement.

The police suffered a defeat in the war against gambling when Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz issued an injunction yesterday against Police Commissioner Bolan and members of the department, restraining them from seizing slot machines unless they actually see them used for gaming purposes.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- While asserting that they wished to cooperate in administration of the emergency farm mortgage law, executives representing twenty-nine of the leading life insurance companies holding farm mortgages told Henry Morgenthau Jr., farm board chairman, today that they were opposed to any general writing down of mortgages or their wholesale exchange for Federal Land Bank bonds under the terms of the new legislation.

GENEVA, May 15 -- The League Council, in a special session today, dealt for the first time in the history of the League of Nations with a case of undisguised war. its proceedings were dominated, however, by the fact that it already had been dealing off and on since 1928 with this particular case of Paraguay versus Bolivia as "hostilities."

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- One third of all combatant ships and aircraft of the navy will be placed in rotating reserve commission on July 1 because of the President's demand for rigid economy, under orders issued today by Rear Admiral William V. Pratt, Chief of Naval Operations.

The Transit Commission and Corporation Counsel Arthur J.W. Hilly have advised the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate to reject the resolution offered on April 28 by Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee calling upon the city to become a party in the Interborough receivership proceedings, with Samuel Untermyer as special counsel.

To the Editor of The New york Times: On May 16 the Board of Estimate will take up the question of a Summer session at the city colleges. There is, at the present time, a sum of $145,000 in the hands of the Board of Higher Education, accumulated from fees paid by students.
A book of stories by Pearl S. Buck will be published June 22 by John Day under the title, "The First Wife and Other Stories." The title story will be about one-third the length of the volume.

Columbia University's Alma Mater, arms outstretched in welcome to her students, looked down from her position in front of the main library of the university yesterday on a lively campus, when more than 1,500 of her students participated in a five-hour strike and demonstration.

Francis T. McEneny, chief examiner for the Board of Aldermen, who was removed from office by Joseph V. McKee on May 19, 1931, for concealing his participation in the sale of school sites to the city, was reappointed to his old post by Mr. McKee yesterday a few hours before the Aldermanic President resigned his position.

With the exception of the performance given by Harry Rosenthal and Lee Patrick-both of whom, strangely enough, were members of the original cast -- the revival of "June Moon," which alighted at the Ambassador Theatre last evening, comes so far from hitting the mark set for it by the original production that one might almost assume the director, the actors and every one else concerned were aiming in the opposite direction.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- A reminder of the heated 1928 political campaign was given to Bishop James Cannon Jr., today, through an Appellate Court's ruling that he must stand trial on charges of violating the corrupt practices act.

In order to end the lowering of wage and working standards because employers have been calling in larger numbers on relief agencies for workers, the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration has worked out a plan in cooperation with State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews whereby the administration will finance, out of State relief funds, the personnel necessary to staff employment offices in selected communities throughout the State, it was announced yesterday.

Electrical energy in the form of radio waves, which scientists believe come from a point so remote in space that it requires between 30,000 and 40,000 light years for the waves to reach the earth, was heard last night by radio listeners throughout the United States.

BERLIN, May 15 -- Germany will declare a partial transfer moratorium on her foreign indebtedness by the end of this month. This was confirmed today by one of the highest Reichsbank officials. It is also evident from the unanimous comment made by the press and by foreign and domestic financial circles on the statement issued Saturday by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, upon his departure from New York for Germany.

Miss Louise Alice Williams, Southern diseuse, will present sketches and cabin exhortations at the Waldorf-Astoria this afternoon, assisted by Philip W. Whitfteld, baritone, who will sing a group of Colonial songs.

Staples Lead in Buying Here. Orders for staples for advance delivery were again numerous in the market here yesterday, but retailers did not place much reorder business on seasonal merchandise. Mail orders received by the resident offices were described as fair.

LODI, N.J., May 15 -- With a deep wound in the left side of the head, the body of Mrs. Mary Moll, 68 years old, a widow and a native of Poland, was found about" 5:30 P.M. today in the kitchen of her home at 221 Union Street here by her daughter-in-law.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The task of deciding finally on the taxes which are to be imposed to provide $220,000,000 annual interest and sinking fund requirements for the $3,300,000,000 public works program contained in the national industrial recovery bill would be sent to the Congressional leaders by President Roosevelt.

LONDON, May 15 -- Members of the Cabinet had a busy half hour in the House of Commons today handling another bombardment of questions, the third within a week, on the German situation and the disarmament crisis.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The rare occurrence of the Senate convened as a court to sit in impeachment proceedings was seen today when Federal Judge Harold Louderback of San Francisco was brought to the bar to stand trial on charges of granting excessive fees, and other misdemeanors in connection with receiverships.

Seven eight-oared crews, bringing into action sixty-one athletes, brought an hour of rowing to the Harlem River yesterday in the annual intramural regatta of the Manhattan College Navy. Two coxswains did double service.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Secretary Hull sounded a warning today that the world as a whole will gravitate toward bankruptcy unless the principal topics on the agenda of the World Economic Conference are dealt with in a fundamental way without delay.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Without comment and in a tersely worded order, the Supreme Court today rejected the petition of the New York Dock Railway Company and others which seek to enjoin the Pennsylvania Railroad from extending its services by operating motor trucks from the New Jersey waterfront railheads into Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan.

The life and habits of Lee Weinstein, the secretary of Edward Albert Ridley, who was found murdered with his employer in the subcellar office kept by the 87-year-old eccentric at 63 Alien Street, became yesterday the central point of police scrutiny.

After a month of discussion, the member lines of the United States Intercoastal Steamship Conference have rearranged most of their tariff schedules and will file them with the Shipping Board prior to June 1, when the ship lines will forfeit the right to alter rates unless the board is notified at least thirty days in advance.

The proposal made at the meeting in Atlantic City of trustees of the Church Peace Union and the World Alliance for International Friendship to ask the churches of the United States to withdraw chaplains from the army and navy "as an expression of the church's abhorrence of war" was sensibly referred to the trustees' executive staff for a report during the Summer.

The success of the James Butler thoroughbreds at the Jamaica meeting continued yesterday when Star Fire, a daughter of Vulcain, won the Bridgehampton Purse for the Seventh Butler victory of the meeting. Running the fastest mile and seventy yards of the session over a fast track, Star Fire surprised many who had backed Joseph E. Widener's Golden Way.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was interested in reading the letter of "Neighborhood Druggist" in THE NEW YORK TIMES, which seeks to justify the charges made for prescriptions. There is no need for justification.

A committee of artists and writers who regard the dismissal of Diego Rivera, radical Mexican mural painter, from Rockefeller Center as a possible infringement of an artist's right to complete a contract met yesterday afternoon with Rivera in the office of his lawyer, Philip Wittenberg, 70 West Fortieth Street.
PARIS, May 15 -- The United States, France and Great Britain are actively preparing to face Germany with a common front of opposition against her rearmament.
Housing properties comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday:

A substantial reduction of gas rates at this time would be "unwarranted, unreasonable and contrary to law," according to an answer filed with, the Public Service Commission yesterday by the Bronx Gas and Electric Company, a subsidiary of the Consolidated Gas Company.

TRENTON, N.J., May 15 -- Income and sales taxes, against which there has been a rising tide of protest since they were suggested recently, will not be necessary if Governor Moore and Senate President Emerson L. Richards are successful in an appeal to be made for $71,000,000 of Federal funds.

Four members of the jury selected last Thursday to try Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank, on charges of evading payment of 1929 and 1930 Federal income taxes, were dropped from the jury without explanation yesterday.

As a result of the sudden failure in London of "The Day I Forgot," the Actors' Equity Association received yesterday a cablegram from Dorothy Hall). American' actress, who appeared in the star role, requesting funds to return to New York.

Head Play, second by a nose in the Kentucky Derby and winner of the Preakness, arrived at Jamaica yesterday and is a sure starter in the Wood Memorial on Saturday. Mrs. Silas B. Mason, owner of the colt, was present when he was unloaded following the trip in a special car from Baltimore.
Those who tried to be on hand early for any run of weakfish in Peconic Bay on Sunday found a great many other fishermen with the same idea in mind.
PARIS, May 15 -- A conference will open here tomorrow between Rumanian, Dutch, British and American oil interests at which the fate of the recent international accord will be settled.

BERLIN, May 15 -- Private assurances such as have been received by interested Americans that the anti-Jewish governmental attitude has undergone or is about to undergo a radical modification cannot be confirmed officially. Specifically it has been reported to have been arranged here that ousted Jewish lawyers not included in the greatly restricted quota permitted to practice might continue their office work provided Christian colleagues appeared for them publicly.

A tie for first place between Reuben Fine and Albert C. Simonson of the Marshall Chess Club developed in the tenth and semi-final round of the United States chess team trial tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club last night.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- The grain trade is awaiting the development of the government's program for farm relief. Until they know how prices for basic commodities will be advanced, leading operators are expected to go slowly in taking a stand on either side of the market.

RONGBUK, Tibet, May 15 (by Wireless from Base Camp via Gangtok) -- Dr. Raymond Greene, our senior medical officer; Tom Brocklebank, George Wood-Johnson, transport officer, and I have joined the advance party which established Camp 3 at a height of 21,000 feet.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 15 -- Three men were hurt, an ambulance and a fire truck damaged and three tents bowled over at Bowman Field today when three defense planes landing in formation figured in a series of accidents that marred the opening of the bombers' campaign to "destroy" Fort Knox from the air.

PARIS, May 16. -- Extreme disappointment unquestionably has been France's first reaction to President Roosevelt's statement of United States policy regarding disarmament which was conveyed to the French Government early this evening.

After moving irregularly yesterday morning, all commodities traded on local exchanges, except rubber, advanced rapidly in the afternoon and closed with gains on the day. Trading generally was quiet. Cash prices were irregular.

New Jersey salt-water fishermen have been somewhat cheered by recent activity in the Barnegat Bay region, and more particularly by the run of bluefish in Little-Egg Inlet. This early inshore period of bluefishing usually provides ample sport.

PHILADELPHIA, May I6. -- Contributions of A social and a financial nature made by Junior Leagues to aid cultural activities in their communities this country, Canada and Mexico increased during the last year as members sought to alleviate the financial burdens, carried by other organizations, according to reports presented today at the annual conference of the Association, of Junior Leagues of America.

MOSCOW, May 16. -- Jazz music is staging a remarkable comeback in Soviet Russia after years of virtual prohibition. Visitors here looking for the good old Russian folk music of the balalaika and the guitar have to hunt far and wide. In cafes, restaurants and amusement parks they find orchestras playing their version of American jazz in response to a popular demand.
TOKYO, Wednesday, May 17. -- Japanese reports said the Twentyeighth Infantry Brigade under Major General Teizo Hiraga occupied today the Chinese city of Kaiping, seventy miles northeast of Tientsin.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 16 (AP). -- Six candidates for the Kentucky. Oaks, inaugurated the same year as the Kentucky Derby and which will have its fifty-ninth running as Saturday's getaway feature, received their final tests for that $5,000 fixture under colors in the Orchid Purse, today's outstanding attraction at Churchill Downs.

An addition of nearly $200,000 to the city's income is expected by Commissioner of Markets Jere Ryan through the adoption of his plans for the various public markets throughout the city, the commissioner announced yesterday.

Columbia Warriors Rest. A bronze tablet at Columbia University marks the site of the Battle of Harlem Heights, one of the incidents punctuating GEORGE WASHINGTON'S retirement from New York City to New Jersey in 1776.
WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 15, unless otherwise specified:

Elliott O'Donnell, who lists In "Who's Who" as his recreation "looking for ghosts," is the author of "Ghosts of London," published here today by Dutton. He has been visiting haunted houses and studying the lore of the supernatural for more than forty years.

Stockholders of the L.M. Ericsson Telephone Company, at their annual meeting in Stockholm on Monday, elected Colonel Sosthenes Behn, chairman of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, a director of the company and approved a change in the by-laws permitting International to own a 35 per cent voting interest in the company, against 20 per cent previously authorized.

Arthur W. Dake of Portland, Ore., earned the right last night to represent the Manhattan Chess Club on the United States team which will be send to Folkestone, England, for the international tournament next month. Dake, by defeating Nathan Beckhardt of City College in a French defense lasting twenty-nine moves', in the final round at the Marshall Chess Club, attained a total of seven points.

Representative Loring M. Black Jr., representing the Fifth Brooklyn District for the last ten years, partly confirmed reports test night that he was ready to break with his county leader, John H. McCooey, and that he might seek a major place on the Democratic city ticket as an insurgent in the primaries.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- President Roosevelt is expected to issue a statement soon, urging the States to act promptly on the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. Thus far, while having advocated modification of the Volstead act, the President has refrained from commenting on repeal.

BERLIN, May 16. -- Germany's foreign trade balance for April shows an export surplus of 60,706,000 marks [about $16,389,000 at present exchange], as compared with 63,700,000 marks [about $17,199,000] for March. Exports decreased approximately 10 per cent, but this decrease was compensated for by an 11 per cent reduction of imports.
LONDON, May 16. -- David Lloyd George created a stir today with a fiery speech blaming the former Allies entirely for the present condition, of Germany and the sudden crisis over disarmament.

Wall Street showed as much Interest yesterday in President Roosevelt's disarmament message as in any of his previous pronouncements. Eagerly read and approved in the commission houses, in banks and other places of business, it immediately lifted the markets out of their lethargy.

Not yet content to allow only Spring to ride shyly along Broadway, the Messrs. Wee and Leventhal tossed forth another revival last evening. The scene was the Hudson Theatre, and the chief participant was Laurence E. Johnson's "It's a Wise Child," which the late David Belasco mounted first back in the Summer of 1929.

Alleged failure of retailers to give consumers the benefit of reductions in the costs of anthracite coal will be discussed today by a committee of anthracite coal railway presidents headed by J. M. Davis, president of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad.

To the Editor of The New fork Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 15 an article, "Amity With Russia Urged in Petition," gave some prominence to the views of Professor Dewey, Jerome Davis, Professor Gillin and thirty-two others who sent Mr. Roosevelt a petition urging Soviet recognition.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Milk producers and dealers claiming to represent 85 per cent of those in the Chicago metropolitan district agreed among themselves today at a conference with Secretary Wallace and George N. Peek, general administrator of the agricultural adjustment act, to increase the retail price of milk and cream as a stabilization measure if the Federal authorities sanction the rise.

Because nearly all of the leading professionals finished high up in the list in last year's national open golf championship at the Fresh Meadow Country Club and hence were excused from the 1933 sectional qualifying rounds on Monday, the upsets were rare.

CINCINNATI, May 16 (AP). -- Joe Mowry, a Minneapolis rookie the Reds angled for but did not get, celebrated his rise to the majors with a single and a triple today, providing two runs to help Boston defeat Cincinnati 6 to 3.

PARIS, May 16. -- As a national defense measure, the factories of Paris which produce materials useful for both war and peace purposes were ordered today to report to the "Passive Defense Bureau" upon their productive capacity.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- In a weird twelve-inning slugging battle, with the two teams using thirty-four players between them to produce the astounding total of forty-three hits, the Washington Senators today recorded an 11-to-10 victory over Cleveland.

Paul R. Meltsner, young American artist, whose paintings have been exhibited in many cities in the United States, is to be evicted from his studio at 240 West Fourteenth Street for non-payment of rent because admirers of his works have failed to translate their admiration into cash.
Luna Park, Coney Island's fantastic monument to man's hilarious moods, has fallen upon hard times.
A varied New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday included a factory, motion picture theatre, several taxpayers and scattered dwellings.

CHICAGO, May 16. -- Sunshine over the Corn Belt today and a forecast of fair weather for tomorrow more than offset all bullish influences in the grain markets on the Board of rade today, although possible overnight developments in Washington and abroad lessened speculative interest.
GENEVA, May 16. -- President Roosevelt's message to the world came today as a strong tonic to Geneva.

The stocks of forty-seven corporations were traded in as unlisted securities despite protests by their officers, it was disclosed yesterday at the public inquiry of Attorney General Bennett into the listing practices of the New York Curb Exchange.

LONDON, May 16. -- Premier MacDonald's personal endorsement tonight of President Roosevelt's appeal will, without doubt, be followed by a clear-cut official acceptance on the part of the British Government.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 16 (AP). -- Jersey City and Rochester closed the first home stand of the Red Wing season today with the home club beating the visitors, 4 to 3, for a third victory in four starts.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP). -- Direct testimony that Judge Louderback spoke of a receivership case he handled as "a plum" in which "fees might run into thousands of dollars" stirred the Senate today.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York filed a protest yesterday with Congress against legislation introduced in both houses that would obligate ship lines to extend service from major ports to other terminal points without added cost.

WASHINGTON, May 16. --A conference report on the Muscle Shoals bill was adopted by the Senate today, leaving only similar action by the House, expected tomorrow, to be accomplished before the bill is ready for the President's signature.
TORONTO, May 16 (AP). -- Ike Boone, Toronto right fielder, hit safely in his twenty-fourth consecutive game today and the Maple Leafs rounded out the afternoon with a 7 -- 2 victory over Newark.

LEYTON, England, May 16 (Canadian Press). -- The West Indies cricket team defeated an Essex eleven today by 136 runs. It was a two-innings match which began Saturday and was featured by the fine bowling of E. Martindale, who look 12 Essex wickets for a total of 105 runs.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May I comment on the news article in THE TIMES of May 13 which had for subject the American Fiction Guild?

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The budgetary economy wave now sweeping every branch of the naval establishment hit the naval reservists when the Navy Department today informed the commandants of all naval districts that pay for naval reserve drills and training duty will cease, on Saturday.

Four men were interviewed yesterday by the detectives investigating the murders of Edward A. Ridley, wealthy eccentric, and Lee Weinstein, his secretary. Since the murders last Wednesday 150 persons have been, questioned.

BUENOS AIRES, May 16. -- The Bolivian armies have begun a determined drive from the south and northwest for the recapture of Fort Arce, which Paraguay took in October in the Post-Boqueron offensive, which carried the Paraguayan arms almost to Fort Saavedra just before General Hans Kundt's return from Grermany to resume command of the Bolivian forces.

Declaring that the city is paying $7,000,000 annually to politically appointed employes who in many cases perform no essential service the Civil Service Reform Association made public yesterday a list of exempt employes, and at the same time attacked the appointment policies of Mayor O'Brien.

LONDON, May 16. -- Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald, in an impassioned speech before the Pilgrims Society, rose to the heights of his best oratorical style, not only to acclaim Mr. Roosevelt, but to defy his own critics in Great Britain with a challenge that he and his Cabinet colleagues of the national government proposed to adopt all means at their disposal to further European conciliation.

Rain and a lack of State-wide contests were responsible for light voting at the primary polls in New Jersey yesterday, although party leadership disputes in Bergen and Passaic Counties tended to draw out the vote In those areas.

A milk service bureau to aid in carrying out the price orders of the State Milk Control Board and in dealing with violations has been organized by the milk distributers of the city through the New York Milk Conference Board, it was disclosed yesterday by Harry A. Cronk, president of the conference board and of the Borden Farm Products Company.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Because of the pressure of domestic and international affairs, President Roosevelt will not go to Chicago May 27 to open the Century of Progress Exposition as tentatively promised. He has asked Vice President Garner to go in bis stead.

Charles E. Mitcbell, who resigned as chairman of the National City Bank and the National City Company, was portrayed in two sharply conflicting lights yesterday as lawyers for the government and for the defense delivered their opening addresses to the jury before Fedral Judge Henry W. Goddard at Mr. Mitchell's trial on the charge of evading payment of $850,000 Federal income taxes for 1929 and 1930.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The administration has decided to send Rear Admiral Montgomery M. Taylor, commander-in-chief of the United States Asiatic Fleet, to Japan on a good-will visit in his flagship, the 10,000-ton cruiser Houston.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Indications that business conditions in many parts of the country have been showing definite signs of improvement within the last few weeks were reported to the Federal Reserve Board today by its advisory council, composed of bankers from the twelve Federal Reserve districts.

PITTSBURGH, May 16 (AP). -- Pittsburgh, pounded three pitchers for an 8-to-4 victory today in taking their second straight game from the Phillies and maintained their half-game hold on first place as the Giants also won.
Charles G. Norris, whose novel, "Seed," sold 70,000 copies in the original edition, has a new novel, "Zest," published today by Doubleday, Doran. Rockwell Kent designed the jacket.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP). -- Gaston B. Means's version of the Lindbergh kidnapping failed to impress a jury in the District of Columbia Supreme Court and the former Federal agent and his codefendant, Norman T. Whitaker, were found guilty today of conspiracy to defraud through a ransom hoax.

Mayor O'Brien indicated yesterday that he was considering a compromise plan that would win the approval both of advocates and of opponents of Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy's plans to convert the Central Park reservoir site into athletic fields.

Fourteen detectives, five of them attached to Acting Captain Patrick J. McVeigh's main office squad, were ordered shifted to other assignments yesterday in the first shake-up of any consequence under Police Commissioner Solan's administration.

Dr. John Grier Hibben, like so many men of solid culture, knew neither affectation nor pose. Beloved by the thousands of students who knew him during the fifty years that he was connected with Princeton, he was serenaded and cheered upon his appointment as president in 1912 and the undergraduates sang:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Following the university training in economics, centring on the gold standard as a basis of sound currency, and a tenacious adherence to that standard in opposition to the unsound mania in favor of the coinage of silver at the arbitrary ratio of sixteen to one in 1896, I am now convinced of the fundamental correctness of that instruction, and my adherence to it in 1896.
THE mail vote should be counted every now and then, just to see how the trend is going. There is a heavy baseball tinge to it at this time of the year. As for instance:

A wide variety of manufacturing and business enterprises is covered in leases just signed for space in the Port Authority Commerce Building at 111 Eighth Avenue. The Port Authority yesterday announced six new tenants in the huge west side development.

Simultaneously with the departure for camps today of the first contingents of Civilian Conservation Corps men from New York, enrolment of 9,202 additional New Yorkers for forestry work in the corps will begin here at the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street, and in nine other centres throughout the State.

President ROOSEVELT'S message cabled yesterday to the heads of fifty-four Governments is broader in scope and more greatly daring in tone than even the words which President WILSON used to address to the world in the midst of the Great War.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 16. -- Two sharp earthquakes, hours apart and centred far from each other, shook San Francisco and Los Angeles, today.
WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 13:

Admiral PRATT, Chief of Naval Operations, does not share the panicky feeing of some who protest that the national defense is being wrecked when combatant ships and aircraft are ordered to rotate in commission, one-third to be withdrawn from service for a set period.

The Handicap Golfers Association of America, of which Max R. Marston of Philadelphia is president, announced through The Associated Press yesterday its plan to eliminate par as an arbitrary measurement of golf skill in favor of a more flexible, standardized system of handicapping and course rating.

PARIS, May 16. -- After twenty meetings at which the problems to be discussed at the World Economic Conference were examined, the French permanent committee of the economic council has submitted a detailed report to the French Government.
