Fordham Prep was routed from the leadership in the Manhattan division of the C.H.S.A.A. baseball competition yesterday when its nine lost to Mount St. Michael's High, 2 to 0, on the letter's field as rain halted the game at the conclusion of the fifth inning.

President Roosevelt's appeal yesterday for world peace had the effect of rallying foreign bond prices on the Stock Exchange, notably many of the German loans. Domestic corporation issues, however, were irregularly lower, while United States Government bonds closed irregularly higher for the day.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- To the peoples of fifty-four nations, including Soviet Russia, as participants in the Geneva disarmament and. London economic conferences, President Roosevelt today addressed through their rulers and heads of State an appeal for world peace by means of agreements to eliminate instruments of offensive warfare and an international pact of nonaggression.

The Rev. Dr. George U. Wenner, who served the parishioners of Christ Lutheran Church for thirtytwo years of the last century, will complete thirty-three years of twentieth century service to them today. Incidentally, he will celebrate his eighty-ninth birthday.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The text of the message on disarmament and economic peace cabled by President Roosevelt early today to the sovereigns and Presidents of the fifty-four nations participating in the General Disarmament Conference at Geneva and the World Monetary and Economic Conference to be held in London next month follows:
PRINCETON, N.J., May 16. -- Dean Luther P. Eisenhart of the Princeton University faculty issued the following statement here today:

ROME, May 16. -- The official text of President Roosevelt's proposals for reduction of armament had not yet been received by the Italian Government this evening. Official circles therefore were unwilling to assume any definite stand on the statement.
Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, associate superintendent of schools, was elected president of Hunter College by the Board of Higher Education last night. The vota was nineteen to one.
BOSTON, May 16 (AP). -- Mervin Shea, catcher recently traded by the Red Sox to St. Louis, today started the Browns' eleventh-Inning rally that defeated his former teammates, 3 -- 2.

Tuesday, May 16, 1933. Money market was featureless. Quotations were unchanged for all classes of accommodation, while business was small. Stock Exchange call loans held at 1 per cent, while 3/4 prevailed In the Street market.

LONDON, May 16. -- A descendant of the family of President George Washington will be among the six American women who will be presented on Thursday at the third royal court at Buckingham Palace. Seven Americans will make their curtseys on Friday.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 16. -- Plans for the first step in the expansion program of Princeton Theological Seminary were announced today at the 121st annual commencement, at which degrees were awarded to seventy-eight men.

Experiments with a new antitoxin by which he hopes to immunize human beings against pneumonia are being made by Dr. Arthur F. Coca of Cornell University in collaboration with the Lederle Laboratories in this city, while the preliminary results are being studled with interest by the scientific and particularly the medical, world.

The movement toward Increased employment and higher wages and salaries continued yesterday with the announcement by several industrial corporations and brokerage firms of the hiring of additional workers, and of pay increases ranging from 5 to 10 per cent.

CHICAGO, May 16. -- The Giants encountered an unexpected bit of generosity as they opened their first Western invasion at Wrigley Field today and downed the Cubs, 4 to 1. After being nicked for infield hits by Critz and Ott with one out in the first, Pat Malone issued successive passes to Leslie, Davis and Vergez, forcing in two runs, or enough to insure victory for the Giants.
BERLIN, May 16. -- Commenting on President Roosevelt's declaration today, the newspaper Acht Uhr Abendblatt says:

Somewhat saddened and greatly disillusioned about the alleged advantages of European travel, the two young women from Westfield, N.J., who stowed away on the Berengaria on April 16, returned aboard the same ship yesterday. They are Jane Orr, 19 years old, and Eleanor Carberry, 18, art students, whose determination to see the world eventually involved them in a teapot tempest with the London newspapers and the British police and port authorities.

After hearing twenty witnesses yesterday the Bronx grand jury returned first-degree murder indictments against five men charged, with killing Michael Malloy, a stationary fireman, for $1,788 insurance last Feb. 22. An indictment also was found against Dr. Frank A. Manzella, former Republican Alderman from Harlem, accusing him, of being an accessory after the fact and of having failed to notify the authorities of a suspicious death.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP). -- An inquiry into charges that J.P. Morgan Co. and other 'Wall Street banking interests control the nation's industrial structure will play a prominent part in the Senate's approaching investigation of private bankers.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- For four hours late today the three principal silver-producing countries of the world discussed at the State Department, through their representatives, possible modes of combined action at the London economic conference to stabilize the international exchange value of silver.
The premiums for the bonds, which all licensees must file with the State Alcoholic Beverage Board, were approved tentatively yesterday by the State Insurance Department.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins stirred an audience of more than 1,000 persons last night at the headquarters of the Grand Street Boys Association, 106 West Fiftyfifth Street, when he spoke on "A Christian Views New York Jewry."

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- One aspect of the President's plea to the world for peace through disarmament is the incidental reminder that, of the fifty-five nations concerned with the Geneva and London conferences, nineteen still retain a monarchical or semi-monarchical system.
Editorial comment in various parts of the country on President Roosevelt's message on disarmament, gathered by The Associated Press, follows:

Urging the necessity of speedy action on the adoption of a new building code for the city to stimulate building, a committee of the Merchants Association obtained from Mayor O'Brien yesterday a pledge that he would move without delay to have the code enacted into law.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 16 (AP). -- A victory of local importance resulted in the best race that was furnished at the Pimlico course today when the silks of Ral Parr landed in the winner's circle alter Ladino accounted for the mile and seventy yards of the Salisbury Purse.

Five gunmen of a gang of seven who perpetrated last year a series of bold hold-ups in Manhattan and Brooklyn, in some instances escaping by vising shields stolen from policemen and firemen, were sentenced to long terms in Sing Sing yesterday by Judge Collins in General Sessions.

Members of the high schools games' committee of the P.S.A.L., at their May meeting at the Hotel Astor yesterday, passed a ruling permitting boys on the senior high school baseball squads to play for amateur teams other than school nines.

WOODBRIDGE. N.J., May 16. -- Dr. John Grier Hibben, president emeritus of Princeton University, was killed this afternoon and his wife was critically injured when the car he was driving and a light truck loaded with beer collided on the superhighway near here.

NEWARK, N. J., May 16. --The Eureka Cereal Beverage Company plant In Paterson, one of five New Jersey breweries recently cited by the Bureau, of Industrial Alcohol to show cause why their 3.2 beer permits should not be revoked, was raided today by Federal prohibition agents who arrested two officers of the company on charges of illegally manufacturing beer and seized 5,800 barrels of brew.

GLEN COVE, L. I., May 16. -- J. P. Morgan, exhibiting in almost every class, won twelve ribbons in the first day's judging at the annual tulip show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society, which opened this afternoon at the Pratt Oval on the Pratt estate.

The possibility of a muddy track at Jamaica today will not deter Trainer Tom Hayes from working Mrs. Silas B. Mason's Head Play between the races in what will be a public trial for the Wood Memorial, to be run Saturday. The Preakness winner will take the track between the third and fourth races, according to present arrangements.

The amounts asked by Albert Goldman, Commissioner of Plant and Structures, from the revenues of the Brooklyn and Williamsburg Bridges for application to the operating expenses of those bridges are larger than the probable yield of the two spans for 1933, Deputy Controller Prial held in a report submitted to the committee of the whole yesterday.

A representative group of entertainers and concert stars are cooperating with, the committee now arranging the May ball to be held on May 22 at the Seventh Regiment Armory for the benefit of the two rest rooms and canteens founded in this city by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt for unemployed girls.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Heads of the revenue raising committees of House and Senate, who will be confronted with the task of finding new tax sources to finance public works loans in President Roosevelt's national recovery bill, frankly began a searching of minds today for some means of avoiding a sales tax.

Juries composed of forty-nine men and women prominent in the world of art, after reviewing yesterday morning the best work during the year of students at the New York School of Applied Design for Women, 160 Lexington Avenue, awarded a total of $1,100 in prizes and scholarships.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 16. -- Members of the Century Country Club today were considerably elated over the victory their women's Class A team scored in the interclub tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, which was concluded yesterday over the neighboring course at Westchester Hills.

President Roosevelt's message to the nations of the world asking them to "enter into a solemn and definite pact of non-aggression" gave encouragement yesterday to all the markets. Stocks advanced sharply and retained the better part of their gains, while bonds made an, irregular recovery.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a veteran of the SpanishAmerican and World Wars, and at present a reserve officer of the United States Army and formerly chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs of the New York Legislature, I say the act of Congress granting to President Roosevelt full power for a revision of the veterans' pensions and compensations of the Civil and SpanishAmerican Wars was not wise.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 17. -- President Roosevelt's message addressed to the Emperor was received by His Majesty, who immediately had a copy sent to Foreign Minister Yasuya Uchida. More copies are being prepared for study by the foreign office.
WASHINGTON, May 16.-- The War Department Issued the foliowing orders today. dated May 13:

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP). -- The North Atlantic Port Conference reaffirmed opposition today to the St. Lawrence waterway and decided to ask President Roosevelt to aid efforts to halt diversion of cargoes from American to Canadian ports.

ALBANY, May 16. -- The new 1 per cent sales tax is based on the gross sales, not the sales price less the cost of the goods. Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission, explained today in the second instalment of regulations governing the new levy.

Declaring that "an era of largescale philanthropy" at Columbia University had closed and that the university must depend on small gifts now, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, appealed yesterday to the 45,000 living Columbia alumni to support the alumni fund.

Secretary HULL expresses proper concern about the work of the coming World Economic Conference. But some of his remarks about commercial treaties seem out of touch with actual events. Alluding to the trade agreements recently signed by Great Britain and France and other nations, he spoke of their having brought about "an intolerable condition."

The largest foreclosure suit started in Hudson County, N.J., in recent years was commenced yesterday by the New York Trust Company and Boyd G. Curts against Fox-New England Theatres, Inc., the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.
WASHINGTON, May 16. --President Roosevelt's message was sent to the following sovereigns and Presidents of nations:

LONDON, May 16. --Within a few minutes after receiving a report of President Roosevelt's peace speech, Prime Minister MacDonald addressed a wildly enthusiastic gathering of the London Pilgrims Society who, under the chairmanship of the Sari of Derby, had assembled to welcome him home from his "voyage of good-will" to Washington.

PARIS, May 16. -- The Chamber of Deputies opened today what promised to be a historic series of meetings with more or less academic discussion of Franco-Soviet relations. The debate left the question in midair, but it is expected it will end next week with Parliament ratifying the already signed and promulgated treaty ot non-aggression.

A 2-year-old boy climbed up to the conductor's stand on the pulpit of the Greenwich Presbyterian Church, 145 West Thirteenth Street, last evening, picked up his baton and whacked it vigorously. Instantly one-sixteenth and one-eighth sized fiddles were tucked under sixteen small chins and tiny fingers curled around the violin bows.

Gold-Star mothers of the World War, who will sail at noon today on the President Harding for the first of this year's pilgrimages to the French battlefields, were conducted on a sight-seeing tour of New York yesterday morning.

The possibility of drafting Alfred E. Smith as a candidate for Mayor backed by a coalition of all parties in order to save New York City from financial disaster was set forth last night by James Marshall, chairman of the Republican advisory committee, at a meeting of the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street.

J.F. de Assis-Brasil, special envoy from Brazil to the economic conference in London and Ambassador to the Argentine Republic, arrived yesterday on the Berengaria on his way to Washington at the invitation of President Roosevelt to discuss tariff conditions and commerce in South America.

New York City and vicinity has been infested lately for the first time in its history with huge swarms of termites, also known as white ants, hitherto prevalent only in the tropics, the New York Entomological Society was told last night at a meeting in the American Museum of Natural History by George E. Sanders, entomologist, of the Bowker Chemical Company, New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The elaborate plans and pictures of the Andrew J. Thomas East Side Improvement appearing in THE TIMES are very interesting as an exercise in planning, and reflect credit on Mr. Thomas's ingenuity.
WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The text of the message President Roosevelt sent to Congress today informing it of his appeal to foreign nations for disarmament and economic peace follows:

The problem of New York hospitals that find their wards crowded while their private and semi-private rooms are only partly filled and the problem of the medical profession in relation to the free or nominal-rate services of dispensaries were outlined yesterday by Dr. Eleanor Conover, assistant director of the hospital information and service bureau of the United Hospital Fund.

Laily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,733,850 barrels, compared with 2,648,850 in the preceding week, an increase of 85,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute, Gains of 77,100 barrels daily in Oklahoma and 19,050 in the Conroe field in Texas were the most important changes.

ST. LOUIS, May 16. -- Johnny Frederick's fourth straight single, following some wild relief pitching by Dizzy Dean in the ninth inning, gave the Dodgers victory in the opening game of their initial invasion of the West with the Cardinals today, 6 to 5.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Spontaneous applause by members of the House of Representatives, Democrats and Republicans alike, when President Roosevelt's message on disarmament and economics was read today, signalized the virtually unanimous approbation of his action in dispatching It to the nations of the world.

A Maytime festival for the benefit of the Actors' Fund of America, which began at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon at the Hotel St. Moritz and ended at 5 o'clock this mornings, presented a varied program of entertainment.

GENEVA, May 16. -- The international wheat committee has decided to adjourn tomorrow to allow its members to consult their governments on the plan for reduction of acreage that they have succeeded in tentatively and broadly outlining here.

CHICAGO, May 16 (AP). -- Representatives of twenty mid-West States met in executive session today with officials of the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Tidewater Association to devise ways for obtaining ratification of the treaty with Canada for construction of the St. Lawrence seaway.

Alderman Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d, Kenneth Simpson, Frank McCoy, Walter S. Mack and Newbold Morris were mentioned yesterday as possible candidates to succeed Keyes Winter, Republican leader of the Fifteenth Assembly District, whose decision to resign resulted from factional difficulties in his organization.

Plaintiffs bought in fourteen Manhattan and Bronx properties at forced sales yesterday. The results follow: Columbus Av., 380-384, northwest corner or 78th St., 102.2x100. seven-story apartment: Bank of New York and Trust Co. against Antoinette Operating Corp.; due.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 16. -- Mayor Leslie V. Bateman waved a big stick at delinquent taxpayers today in the start of a drive by city officials to "keep Mount Vernon on the black side of the ledger." He started a five-fold campaign to collect taxes, declaring the city's financial condition required immediate action.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Brokaw and the Misses Edna and Marguerite Brokaw have left the Waldorf-Astoria to pass the Summer at The Chimneys, their place in Brookville, L. I.

GARDEN CITY. L.I., May 16. -- Calling upon the church to take the leadership in overcoming the social and economic problems of the day, the sixty-fourth convention of the Protestant-Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, meeting at the Cathedral of the Incarnation here, approved today the enactment of compulsory unemployment insurance.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Mrs. Roosevelt, accompanied by Louis McH. Howe, secretary to the President, visited the bonus camp at Fort Hunt late this afternoon, waded through mud ankle deep to inspect the site and food the men were eating, and then led them, in singing "There's a Long, Long Trail," after she had asked how many knew the words and they had shouted, "We all do."

If New York Republicans want an aggressive leader, their demand is more than supplied by Chairman MACY. He attacks not only Democratic, but Republican leaders. Many of us watched with satisfaction what seemed the graceful slide of GEORGE HENRY PAYNE, the historian of journalism, into a pension after fifteen years of ardent labor at his post.

Buyers' Arrivals Increased. A gain in the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday took place in comparison with the figure for the previous week and for the corresponding week a year ago according to the lists published in THE TIMES.
LONDON, May 16. -- A general call to the church, to support the government in its five-year plan to abolish slums has been issued by the Archbishops of Canterbury and York.

Publication of the list of the twenty principal holders of common stock of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad as of Dec. 31 last shows that in 1932 the holdings of George F. Baker were reduced to 60,000 shares from 83,328 and that his name dropped from seventh to twentieth place on the list.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter from Charles G. Tierney on "Mortgage Investments" is written from the viewpoint of wellto-do holders of mortgage certificates, but there are many people totally dependent on the income from their certificates for bread and butter.

TIENTSIN", Wednesday. May 17. -- A sudden and inexplicable lull on all fighting fronts coupled with statements of War Mnister Araki and General Muto that the Japanese Army will return to the Great Wall if the Chinese abandon their "provocations" has aroused conjectures n foregn and Chinese circles as to the possibilities of a secret compromise.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Speculation as to the meaning of President Roosevelt's action in addressing his foreign policy statement today to President Mikhail Kalinin of Russia was quelled when Mr. Roosevelt indicated that he had in mind no formal recognition of the Russian Government.

Support for the selection of Samuel Seabury as fusion candidate for Mayor is being received by leaders of the fusion movement, it was learned yesterday. This support has become evident through receipt of letters and telephone messages urging the selection of Mr. Seabury to lead the fight against Tammany.

LONDON, May 16. -- The "London League Loans Committee," of which Sir Austen Chamberlain is chairman, founded last year to protect the holders of bonds issued under the auspices of the League of Nations, has published its first annual report, which makes melancholy reading.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The slow and dreary progress of the impeachment trial of Federal Judge Harold Louderback of San Francisco has convinced some Senate leaders that a change must be made in handling such cases. When the Senate, sitting as a court, recessed this afternoon only three witnesses had been examined out of a possible forty from both sides.

Since political organizations live on patronage, they strive to keep for themselves positions which are "exempt" from the usual competitive examinations. Where the machine is powerful it usually manages to control the local Civil Service Commission and make certain that its jobholders are protected.
Thomas W. Whittle, former Surveyor of Customs, was appointed and sworn In yesterday, by Mayor O'Brien as the successor to George Henry Payne as a commissioner of taxes and assessments.

In a radio symposium on "Literary Freedom and Nationalism" last night, four prominent New York members of the American Centre of the P.E.N. Clubs, an International organization of authors, deplored the nationalistic spirit that recently led to the banning of some German authors and the burning of their books and the books of other writers.

In an effort to obtain favorable action by the Board of Estimate on the request of City College officials for funds to maintain Summer sessions, more than 250 students of Brooklyn, Hunter and City Colleges waited outside of City Hall yesterday while the board considered the request in committee of the whole.

MONTREAL, Que., May 16. -- Some hope for the future of the newsprint industry in Canada is expressed in the first interim joint report of the committees of bondholders and debenture holders of the Lake St. John Power and Paper Company Ltd., just forwarded to security holders.

Edward B. Sexton, for many years president of the Home for Old Men and Aged Couples, who died at 20 Fifth Avenue on May 11, 1932, left an estate appraised yesterday at $1,139,830 gross and $1,053,365 net, of which $1,078,429 was in securities.

Industry would cooperate with President Roosevelt's program by expanding the functions of trade associations, Charles F. Abbott, executive director of the American Institute of Steel Construction, predicted yesterday in an address to the Conference of Statisticians in Industry, held under the auspices of the National Industrial Conference Board at its headquarters in 247 Park Avenue.
Trading on the Cotton Exchange quieted materially yesterday for the first time in several weeks and prices held within a range of 10 to 15 points, ending 4 to 5 points lower than on Monday.

BERLIN, May 16. -- Completely reversing yesterday's downward trend, the Boerse today staged a lively rally, many stocks rising as much as 5 points, with Julius Bergcr advancing 10 points. Bonds, on the other hand, continued weak with the exception, of some dollar obligations of the government.
RIDGEWOOD, N.J., May 16. -- Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches captured the low gross prize in a one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Ridgewood Country Club today.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP). -- New Jersey, New York and Boston interests in the New York Harbor lighterage suit filed final briefs in the case today with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The Board of Estimate, meeting yesterday in committee of the whole, renewed its consideration of the proposals to build modern, low-rent, fireproof apartments in the sevenblock Chrystie-Forsyth Street area and also considered a new plan for developing the tract submitted by Maurice Deutsch.

Stockholders of the Chase National Bank approved yesterday the proposals originally advanced by Winthrop W. Aldrich, head of the bank, on March 8, for taking the Chase organization out of the securities business and reducing its board of directors from seventy-two members to thirty-six.

New Jersey municipalities governed by the commission form of government organized their city commissions yesterday and installed officials chosen last week. Mayor Frank Hague, State Democratic leader, took the oath of office for the beginning of his seventeenth year as Mayor of Jersey City and his twenty-first year as a member of the city commission.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Louis R. Glavis, who was removed from government service twenty-three years ago during the heat of the historic Pinchot-Ballinger feud of the Taft administration, has been called to direct the far-flung investigative activities of the Interior Department.

William Woodward's Dominus, which was not sent West for the Kentucky Derby, surprised most spectators at Jamaica yesterday when he tow-roped a field in which the Brookmeade Stable's Inlander was made a 7-to-5 favorite.

An increase of 20 to 30 per cent in the number of Metropolitan Opera subscribers for the coming season over the list of last year is anticipated, Earle Lewis, Metropolitan box-office treasurer, said yesterday. Mr. Lewis based his estimate on the long lines of old and new subscribers who have come to the Opera House in the last two days for personal interviews and on the large number of telephone calls during this period.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The securities regulation bill assumed a less drastic form today as conferees of the Senate and House worked to harmonize separate measures passed by the two Congressional bodies.

TORONTO. May 16. -- With indications pointing to almost a score of entries, observers around Woodbine Park today predicted that the seventy-fourth running of the King's Plate Saturday would be the most open one in years.

A campaign to break the "Communist reign of terror" in the fur industry of New "York was begun yesterday by the Fur Workers Union, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, when members of the union marched into the fur district, bounded by Sixth and Seventh Avenues, Twenty-third to Thirty-third Streets, and distributed circulars calling on all furriers to join in an attempt to restore former wage scales and working conditions.

BERLIN, May 16. -- Pending the delivery of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech to the Reichstag tomorrow setting forth Germany's attitude toward disarmament and other foreign problems attention here was concentrated today upon what President Roosevelt might say that might smooth the way for the Chancellor.

Albert H. Wiggin, chairman of the American, standstill committee, will sail for Germany on the Bremen on Saturday night to represent American short-term cerditors of Germany at the conference of that country's foreign creditors in Berlin, called for May 26 by Hjpalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, it was announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 17. -- Arriving here today on his way to Washington for economic talks with the President, Viscount Kikujiro Ishii of Japan, Privy Councilor to the Emperor, hailed as "great news" Mr, Roosevelt's world appeal to renounce aggression and unite for peace.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- A stormy session, with cries of "Throw him out" and "We want the bonus" so interrupting proceedings that "The Star-Spangled Banner" was twice played to restore order, marked the bonus convention held within the city limits this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- "Real progress" toward business recovery was reported today by two members of President Roosevelt's Cabinet, Secretary Woodin, who made his statement after conferring with members of the Advisory Council of the Federal Reserve Board, and Secretary Roper, who based his report on data obtained by the Department of Commerce.
The International Mercantile Marine Company reported yesterday a net loss for 1932, after interest and other charges, of $1,507,187, compared with a loss of $1,278,000 for the previous year.
WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Assurances of cooperation from heads of foreign governments on President Roosevelt's disarmament proposals were made public tonight at the State Department as follows:

BUDAPEST, May 17. -- The hopes of the Legitimists in Hungary, and in a certain degree of the Austrian Legitimists, for the restoration of Otto von Hapsburg as King of the the two countries, as a reply to the Hitlerite threat of German expansion, were dashed to the ground in a sensational manner in a speech by the Hungarian Premier, General Julius Goemboes, tonight.
PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP). -- A five-run rally in the eighth inning today gave the White Sox the opening game of the series with the Athletics by a 5-to-2 score.
Leases of entire buildings in Manhattan formed the bulk of realty activity yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The commanding officer of the airship Akron committed an error in judgment in "not setting such courses as would have kept him in the safe semi-circle" and avoiding the seven storm conditions finally encountered, a naval court of inquiry held today in an opinion made public by Secretary Swanson.

An American radio audience clearly heard the latter half of Chancellor Hitler's address yesterday before the assembled Reichstag at Berlin. The talk, which was an hour long, was carried in New York and throughout the country by WJZ's coast-to-coast network between 10:30 and 11 A.M. and over the coast-to-coast chain of WABC between 10:45 and 11 o'clock.

BERLIN, May 17. -- At 10 o'clock last night Chancellor Hitler shut himself up with his secretary and dictated his speech outlining German foreign policy, which he regarded as the most important of his life in many respects.

Impressed by the conciliatory tone of Chancellor Hitler's address to the Reichstag, by the multiplying indications of business expansion and by President Roosevelt's message to Congress recommending relaxation of the anti-trust laws in the interest of "fair competition," the security markets moved upward yesterday with renewed confidence.

Dollar exchange gained in strength yesterday. Except for the pound sterling and the mark, which rallied strongly following Chancellor Hitler's speech, all European currencies were cheaper in terms of the American unit at the close.

The Actors Equity Association cannot bring back Dorothy Hall to New York from her present station in London, it decided yesterday. That duty lies with Miss Peggy Fears, who produced "The Day 1 Forgot," which, ran three performances in England and left Miss Hall stranded there.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., suspended the public inquiry into the listing practices of the New York Curb Exchange yesterday for three weeks, following a request by William A. Lockwood, chief counsel for the Exchange, for time to present a plan to eliminate criticism of its unlisted department.

BERLIN, May 17. -- The Boerse continued its recovery today. Both stocks and bonds responded to the prospect of an easier international situation, which is thought to have been brought about by President Roosevelt's action. Though Chancellor Hitler's speech was not made until after the market had closed, it is considered to be a bullish factor.

Alfred Frank individually and as sole devisee of the will of Gretchen M. Frank gave a mortgage for $12,000, due June 1, 1936, at 6 per cent to the Teachers Building and Loan Association of New York City on 762 10th Av., and another for $2,000 due June 1, 1936, at 6 per cent on the same premises to the Southport Holding Corporation, subject to the above mortgage.

Mrs. Silas B. Mason's Head Play, pre-race favorite for the Wood Memorial on Saturday, stole the spotlight yesterday at Jamaica, where five of the six favorites got home in front. Head Play was worked a mile between the races and impressed observers with his speed and form.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP). -- Returning to orthodox baseball after their weird battle of yesterday, the Senators defeated the Indians today, 3 to 2.

WASHINOTON, May 17. -- An State Department experts continued silver discussions today with representatives of Mexico in preparation for the London Economic and Monetary Conference, Herbert Feis, economic adviser of the department, urged the House Foreign Affairs Committee to table three proposed resolutions giving explicit instructions on the silver question to the United States delegation to the conference.

While Diego Rivera and his Communist sympathizers and other supporters continued yesterday to denounce the veiling of his incompleted mural in the RCA building at Rockefeller Center, the Fine Arts Federation of New York, comprising sixteen art societies, launched a protest against "unfair competition and exploitation" by foreign artists.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The course of President Roosevelt's new foreign policy for the United States, under the encouragement of Chancellor Hitler's conciliatory address to the Reichstag and the favorable reception in Europe of yesterday's declaration, was charted more clearly today.

Ladenburg, Thalmann Co. increased their holdings of Kansas City Southern common stock from 10,768 shares in 1931 to 16,924 at the end of 1932, according to the list of the twenty largest stockholders. Hayden, Stone Co. increased their holdings from 17,010 common shares to 18,235 shares.
Ed Estwanick, Fordham's ace left-handed twirler, shut out the City College baseball team, 4 to 0, yielded only three hits and fanned eight at Fordham Field yesterday before 3,000 spectators.
GENEVA, May 17. -- The Overseas Wheat Committee adjourned today until May 29 with publication of a long communique.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP). -- Declaring of President Roosevelt's public works-industrial control bill that "no legislation has carried such possibilities of good or evil," Robert L. Lund, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said tonight in a statement that parts of the measure would "require revision."

In a lecture at Columbia Professor JULIAN HUXLEY expressed a low opinion of the social insects and ridiculed those who saw ants or bees ruling the world. It may be, as he said, that a termite is too small to be or any consequence, and that it stopped evolving millions of years before man appeared.
HAVANA, May 17. -- A gain in the strength of the rebels in the provinces of Camaguey and Santa Clara was apparent from reports today of several engagements with government troops.

Hope was expressed last June on the occasion of President HIBBEN'S Jubilee -- his fiftieth year as a graduate of Princeton -- that he might long give the world the benefit of what THOMAS CHALMERS would call the "elate independence" of his soul.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Mrs. Roosevelt took to the open road again today, motoring into Virginia to take luncheon with the ladies of the Senate at Stratford, ancestral home of the Lee family in Westmoreland County. There she commended the work of restoration in progress for the historic value of the home and the employment afforded by the work.

BERLIN, May 17. -- To a Reichstag assembled for a brief session, in which, all the German parties except the Communists were represented, Chancellor Adolf Hitler this afternoon stated the German Government's attitude toward disarmament and toward the world in general. And it is this:

NEWPORT, R.I., May 17. -- F. Frazier Jelke took the stand this afternoon in support of his suit for absolute divorce from his wife, Eugenia Woodward Jelke, in Superior Court and told of incidents leading up to the actual break in September, 1931, when she telegraphed him that it was better that they part.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP). -- The prosecutors of Federal Judge Harold Louderback succeeded over defense objections in writing into the record of his impeachment trial today evidence to show that while he was a State judge, the defendant named two friends, mentioned in the impeachment articles, to lucrative positions as receivers and appraisers.

An offer of new bonds of the G. E. Employes Securities Corporation is to be made next month to employes of the General Electric Company, Gerard Swope, president, announced yesterday. All new issues of such bonds will bear interest of 5 per cent, he said, and the additional 2 per cent hitherto paid by General Electric will be contingent on earnings of the company.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 17. -- In proclaiming neutrality in the war between Bolivia and Paraguay, Peru has declared its ports open to Bolivian traffic in accordance with existing commercial treaties, according to word received here.

A small field of golfers took part in the opening event of the Westchester County Golf Association at the Leewood Golf Club yesterday. Only thirty-nine players turned out for the tournament, an eighteen-hole medal-play event, and of these only a comparative handful were sufficiently proud of their efforts to post cards.
PHILADELPHIA, May 17. -- Salvage shops and tea rooms by which the Junior Leagues raise money in many cities were discussed at the convention of the Association of Junior Leagues of America today.

Warning that "the more the Jews here agitate, the more they irritate those now in power in Germany," Herman A. Metz asserted yesterday in an open letter to Samuel Untermyer that "they certainly are not helping their co-religionists by such action."
WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The right of every nation to subsidize its shipping will be insisted upon by America delegates to the congress of the International Chamber of Commerce in Vienna next month.
WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

LONDON, May 12. -- The King was unable to attend the third royal court in Buckingham Palace tonight because of the rheumatism in his left shoulder, and he will be unable also to attend tomorrow's court. His Majesty was in good health otherwise, and enjoyed a two-hour drive with the Queen this afternoon, seeing the beauties of London's parks.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 17. -- The fortieth annual May Festival opened tonight in Hill Auditorium, and in every way promises to compare favorably with the best that have gone before.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17. -- Penn- sylvania and Cornell split even in an Eastern Intercollegiate League double-header on Franklin Field today, the Red and Blue taking the opener, 5 to 2, but losing the second game, 7 to 6. Both were seven-inning contests.
WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress today on the national industrial recovery bill follows:
WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Following is the text of the national industrial recovery bill, carrying President Roosevelt's plan for the mobilization of industry and a $3,300,000,000 public works program:

PRINCETON, N.J., May 17. -- The suspense felt by faculty members and students at Princeton University on the condition of Mrs. John Grier Hibben, who was gravely injured in the automobile accident near Woodbridge, N.J., in which her husband, the president emeritus of the university, was killed Monday, was relieved tonight by the announcement that Mrs. Hibben was showing a slight improvement.

A preliminary injunction sought by the Attorney General to restrain V.E. Graham Co., Inc., securities dealers, from doing business as stock brokers, was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Johnston in Brooklyn. The court held that the, charge of misrepresentation was not proved and that the company, which has offices at 29 Broadway, was not a broker but a dealer in securities.
District Attorney Thomas C.T. Crain appealed yesterday to leaders in industry to help him stamp out racketeering. His office, he said, was prepared to do its part if it received cooperation.
NEW YORK. Brig. Gen. Cornelius Vanderbilt and Mrs. Henry G. Davis are returning from Panama next week.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Seeking to revivify and stabilize the nation's industry, President Roosevelt sent to Congress today an industrial recovery bill, combining a plan for Federal direction of business under codes of fair competition with an outlay by the government of $3,300,000,000 for public works to prime the pump of activity and employment.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17. -- The Francis Wayland Ayer Cup, awarded for excellence of typography in a competition in which 1,386 daily newspapers of this country participated, was presented here tonight to THE NEW YORK TIMES.
BOSTON, May 17 (AP). -- Dale Alexander, American League batting champion, today came out of his slump and gave a perfect exhibition at the plate while the Red Sox were defeating the Browns, 7 -- 3.

With leaders of the fusion movement continuing their quest for a candidate combining vote-getting strength with real ability to head their ticket, W. Kingsland Macy, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, said yesterday that he was hopeful that pressure of public opinion would persuade Samuel Seabury to accept the fusion nomination for Mayor.

With the exception of raw sugar, prices for commodities advanced yesterday on local exchanges. Trading was generally in increased volume as sentiment reflected the improved tone on the outside exchanges. All cash prices were higher.

BUENOS AIRES, May 17. -- In a long editorial today La Nacion enthusiastically hails President Roosevelt's message as something more than a call to disarmament, as opportune and as a clear definition of the world's perilous situation.

ROME, May 17. -- Chancellor Hitler's speech to the German Reichstag, following closely President Roosevelt's message, is regarded by Italy as one of the most important steps taken recently for clarification of the European situation and dispelling the threat of war.

Premiums written on casualty and surety insurance lines in 1932 by companies licensed to do business in this State totaled $625,631,620, or 20 per cent less than in 1931, according to the annual report of the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters.

Hardluck-on-River, the squatters' colony that grew up at the foot of East Ninth. Street almost two years ago, was a sadder place last night than it has ever been. Today it will pass entirely out of existence.

TULSA, Okla., May 17 (AP). -- Experts of the American Petroleum Institute estimated today a decrease of 5.6 per cent in the total motorfuel demand for the six months ending Sept. 30 and a decrease of 2.5 per cent in the demand for crude oil from United States fields.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The Glass banking reform bill was made the unfinished business of the Senate late today, but under an arrangement between Senator Glass and Senator McNary, Republican leader, was laid aside until the Louderback impeachment trial is ended, probably on Saturday.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 17. -- Mrs. Harrison Williams won two blue ribbons today in the decorative classes on the final day of the annual tulip show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society, which closed tonight, in the Pratt Oval on the Pratt estate.

Three officials of the Texas Company, including C.B. Ames, chairman; Harry T. Klein, vice president and general counsel, and Rodolfo Garrio, vice president, were elected directors of the Seaboard Oil Company of Delaware at the annual meeting of the latter company yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The President's official recognition today of the fact that the Eighteenth Amendment is before the States for repeal is the first time he has referred to the subject for many weeks. Not since his inauguration has the President even indicated that he knew repeal was pending.
WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Declines of $3,031,000 in exports and $6,859,000 in imports during April were announced today by the Commerce Department.
Indirect Soviet Recoginition. President ROOSEVELT lets it be known Soviet that by including the Moscow government in his peace appeal he did not have formal Soviet recognition in mind.

The Atlantic Coast Line was the only railroad to report yesterday an increase in net income after fixed charges for the first quarter of the year. It showed a net income of $316,597, or 38 cents a share of common stock, for the quarter, against a net loss of $119,542 in the same period last year.

A natiton-wide drive to pull municipal credit from its present low ebb will be started from this city in a few days by a group of representatives of insurance companies, savings banks and other large holders of municipal bonds, and bankers and officials of communities throughout the State.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Stephen Gibbons of New York, who has been associated with Secretary Woodin for many years, will be appointed Assistant Secretary of the Treasury to succeed James H. Douglas, who is being considered by President Roosevelt for the Federal Reserve Board.
TIENTSIN, May 17. -- Chinese Government and railway officials admitted today that the Japanese had occupied Tangshan, an important city sixty-five miles north of here.

The committee headed by W.F. Thiehoff, general manager of the Eastern lines of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, which will represent the managements at the coming railway wage negotiations, will meet in Chicago on June 1 to determine the form of notices to be served on the unions.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP). -- Congress gave its final approval to the administration's Muscle Shoals-Tennessee Basin development bill today, and only President Roosevelt's signature remains to be affixed. The House adopted, 259 to 112, the Senate-approved conference report embodying the principal provisions of the Norris bill.

The letters which Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank, and his wife exchanged to complete the tax-loss sale of 18,300 shares of National City Bank stock in 1929 were read to the jury yesterday afternoon at the trial of Mr. Mitchell before Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard on the charge of evading $850,000 income tax payments in 1929 and 1930.

A defense of President Roosevelt's "brains trust" and of professors generally was made before the luncheon of the Bond club yesterday by Dr. Robert Maynard Hutching, president of the University of Chicago, whose subject was, "The professor is sometimes right."
The annual commencement activities of the Biblical Seminary in New York, 235 East Forty-ninth Street, will be held on May 26, 28 and 29, it was announced yesterday.
April foreign trade in merchandise for a series of years compares as follows, (+) indicating excess of imports, (-) indicating excess of exports:
LONDON, May 17. -- The Prince of Wales added his appeal today to that given by the Archbishops of York and Canterbury yesterday for widespread support of the government's proposed attack on slums.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Count Sforza's letter concerning my article "Recent Biographies in Italy," published in THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review, has just been brought to my attention by an answer to it published in Vita Italiana and in Regime Fascista of Cremona.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 17. -- Nawbeek Farm of William M.M. Robinson of Paoli, Pa., gained two notable victories today during the opening sessions of the second annual Atlantic City Horse Show, winning the novice saddle horse championship with his chestnut mare Isabella Peavine, and repeating with the same 5-year-old in the Christian R. Lindback challenge trophy event.

Gertrude Wimmer, 18 years old, a student at Brooklyn College, committed suicide by gas poisoning late yesterday afternoon at her home, 285 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn. Her body was found on the kitchen floor by her mother when, she returned from work.

F.H. La Guardia, former Representative, who is expected to be a candidate for the Republican Mayoralty nomination, defends Congress from imputations of ineptitude and irresponsibility, and attacks the army and navy as the most effective lobbying organization in Washington in an article in the current issue of Scribner's Magazine, published today.

BERLIN, May 17. -- Chaplain Mueller of the Reichswehr, Chancellor Hitler's confidential man in church matters, has assumed the supreme direction of the militant Nazi German Christian movement with the acquiescence of the latter's leader. Pastor Hossenfelder, and by order of the Chancellor.

The program is Army vs. Harvard, a two-day battle with ten-man teams on the heights above the Hudson. The zero hour is 2 P.M. tomorrow, at which time a neutral official will toss in the first ordinate and the firing will immediately become general. Hostilities will be suspended Saturday evening at sundown and some time later, when he has checked up on the casualties, the referee will render a decision.
CINCINNATI, May 17 (AP). -- While the Reds were helpless before Ed Brandt's lefthanding, the Braves bunched singles and a home run for an 8-to-0 victory today, their second in as many days.
Ten years after she first won the national tennis championship, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody arrived in New York from San Francisco yesterday, en route to Wimbledon.
WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The essential provisions of the national industrial recovery bill were outlined this afternoon by Senator Wagner, one of its authors, in the following statement:

Holders of claims approximating $1,500,000 against the Globe Rutgers Fire Insurance Company have indicated willingness to accept new preferred stock as offered by the company's reorganization committee, according to reports from 5,000 brokers and agents throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Trade with China pulled the United States out of its first financial depression, T.V. Soong, Chinese Finance Minister and head of the Chinese mission to the London Economic Conference, told his radio audience tonight in an address over the National Broadcasting Company's system.

MADRID, May 17. -- The Republicans united their badly broken ranks in the Cortes tonight and voted into completion the religious law which definitely establishes Spain as a lay State by the overwhelming majority of 278 to 50.

Wiping out a machine-gun nest and repelling an air raid by covering their activities with a smoke screen, New York University students staged a sham battle at Ohio Field, University Heights, yesterday as part of the annual Military Field Day.

Keyes Winter, Republican leader of the Fifteenth Assembly District, submitted his resignation to his district captains last night and they immediately started the work of selecting a new leader for the district, the only Republican one in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The administration today was completing its program for financing the $3,300,000,000 public works plan which will go hand in hand with the national recovery act submitted to Congress.

Justice Daniel V. McNamee of Hudson, sitting in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, disposed yesterday of six of the remaining seventeen cases of election boards indicted for violations of the election laws last November when one member of each of the six boards assumed responsibility for the errors in the returns which led to the indictment of all the members.

Dr. Eugene A. Colligan took time out yesterday from acknowledging felicitations oh his election as president, of Hunter College to discuss education, modern youth, and the place of women in contemporary society.

For the first time in the history of prohibition, attempts to padlock the average small speakeasy or to prosecute retailers of bootleg liquor, unless the latter are gangsters or members of big syndicates, are expected to end in the Southern District of New York by July 1 coincident with the reduction here of the enforcement staff of George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, to skeleton proportions, in line with an economy plan.
WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 15:

John Dewey, educator and philosopher, has been selected as one of the ten "greatest Americans" whose life records, containing complete information of all kinds, will be maintained for coming generations on special materials by the Aristogenic Association, it was announced last night.

The stagehands unions and the managers are at loggerheads again, the present subject of controversy being a difference between a stock show and a so-called road show. As a result of it, John Golden announced yesterday that he would close "When Ladies Meet," after next week's performances; and the present proprietors of "Another Language" will meet with union heads today to decide on the status of that particular play.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Employment among manufacturing industries increased 1.6 per cent in April over the low level of the preceding month caused by the banking holiday, and payroll totals advanced 4.5 per cent in the same period, according to the monthly figures of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

LONDON, May 17. -- Distrust of the German Nazi government's intentions has gone so far in Great Britain that Chancellor Hitler's conciliatory words today failed to make much of an impression on the British Government. British officials were glad to hear his protestations of peace, but they placed little reliance upon them.

At the annual meeting yesterday of stockholders of the Consolidated Oil Corporation, Harry F. Sinclair, chairman of its executive committee, said there seemed to he a hope of improvement in the oil industry, which he implied would come through efforts now being made in Washington rather than through any measures that the industry itself might adopt.

BALTIMORE, May 17 (AP). -- Guy Cantrell held Newark to five hits today while the Baltimore Orioles batted out a 5-to-1 victory over the Bears in the first game of the series. Jim Weaver pitched for the visitors and suffered his first defeat of the season after eight straight victories.

Last night a crowd of women out of work filled the Town Hall with hopeful talk of busy hours and full pocketbooks soon to come. The "Hop Light Ladies" have no income and no work at the moment. But they have an office, without rent, in the Empire State Building, and they have the admiration of many prominent citizens for their courage and ingenuity.

Chancellor HITLER'S much trumpeted address to the Reichstag turned out to be a mild affair. It is true that, he recited with vehemence the long list of Germany's grievances. At great length and with an air of fierce determination, befitting a Nazi leader, he enumerated what he calls the mistakes and outrages of the Versailles treaty and dwelt upon the intolerable humiliations forced upon Germany which, she is now heroically resolved no longer to bear.

The New Chamber Orchestra under Bernard Herrmann presented English and American works at the New School last night, with an emphasis upon contemporary composition by that energetic organization known as the Young Composers Group.
Jersey City opened its home stand at West Side Park in Jersey City yesterday and lost a ten-inning game to Albany, 4 to 3. Legett's single, which scored Clark from second base, broke up the contest.

The movement now under way, with the cooperation, of city officials, to locate vacant plots and plots encumbered with obsolete buildings with a view to their transformation into playgrounds was hailed yesterday by friends of Central Park who are interested in the double problem of saving the park from destructive invasion and providing athletic facilities for the city's youth.

Raoul E. Grenade, commercial counselor of the Belgian Embassy, urged the reduction of American tariffs as an aid to trade between Belgium and the United States in an address last night before the Foreign Commerce Club at the Hotel Astor.

The proposals placed before Congress yesterday by the President have been foreshadowed. Believing that " a great cooperative movement throughout all industry" is needed in order to prevent unfair competition and "disastrous overproduction," he recommends that the anti-trust laws be liberalized to permit business men to make agreements concerning wages, hours and output.

GENEVA, May 17. -- Chancellor Hitler's speech generally is considered here more conciliatory than had been expected, even after President Roosevelt's message had increased hope of moderation and even by the minority which, before Mr. Roosevelt's move, had expected moderation.
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company acquired the twentystory apartment house at 480 Park Avenue at a foreclosure sale held yesterday in the Vesey Street Exchange. The auction results follow:
BERLIN, May 17 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of May 15 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:
Applications for wholesalers' licenses to sell 3.2 beer and wine are to be distributed beginning next Monday or Tuesday, it was announced yesterday by the State Alcoholic Beverage Board.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17. -- Fourteen men who have achieved distinction in scientific fields were honored when the Franklin Institute, at its annual Medal Day exercises, presented medals or certificates of merit to them or their representatives today.

In redemption of party pledges for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment all Democratic leaders in the State have been directed to get out the biggest vote possible in support of the list of "wet" nominees for delegates to the State convention on June 27, which will pass on the Congress resolution for repeal of national prohibition.
LONDON, May 17 (AP). -- The Americans presented at the third royal court tonight were:
WASHINGTON, May 17. -- President Roosevelt's message to the nations on disarmament and economic recovery was widely acclaimed today as the most effective peace utterance in recent years.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Modification of the proposed railroad bill so as to lessen the sacrifices by rail labor and gain the support of the unions was indicated today by the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee as it studied the bill behind locked doors.

MEDIA, Pa., May 17. -- Price McKinney's brown gelding Portrait won the Corinthian Plate Steeplechase, one of the feature events in the opening of the Rose Tree Hunt Spring meet today. Mr. McKinney rode his own mount.

John L. Ridley, a grand nephew of Edward Albert Ridley, the aged eccentric who was murdered in his underground office in 63 Allen Street, filed a caveat yesterday against the probate of his grand uncle's will in the office of Surrogate George H. Johnson at Elizabeth, N.J.

The roof terrace of River House, 435 East Fifty-second Street, last night became in effect a Bavarian biergarten for an entertainment arranged by several women of society in behalf of the Architects' Emergency Relief Fund. The event drew an attendance of more than 1,000.

PARIS, May 17. -- All France's objections to President Roosevelt's disarmament statement, which were so freely expressed in high quarters last night, were swept away this afternoon when Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large, assured Premier Edouard Daladier the statement was only the first step in the program of the United States for furthering world peace.

Ian Keith will leave the cast of "Best Seilers" after Saturday night's performance. His role will be taken over by Rex O'Malley. On Thursday of next week Mr. Keith will join "Hard-Boiled Angel" in Milwaukee, replacing "Walter Armitage.

Select New Brown for Summer. Selection of "Columbine brown" as a feature shade for Summer town wear promotion was announced yesterday by the Dress Creators League of America, comprised of makers of $10.50 lines. The color is a cocoa tone with a smoky surface.

BERLIN, May 17 (AP). -- Apart from Chancellor Hitler's own press, even former Democratic organs in Germany united tonight in hailing the Chancellor's speech as a truly statesmanlike pronouncement. Messages from the adherents to the Nazi movement, arriving at the chancellery, were full of pride and admiration.

Interest in the racing of the 12meter class of yachts this Summer gained impetus yesterday with the announcement that Bayard S. Litchfield's Cantitoe has been chartered by a syndicate headed by Van S. Merle-Smith of Oyster Bay.

Portrayal of the American wage-earner as naked to the winds of social adversity while social insurance is now protecting in one way or another some 700,000,000 persons of forty nations is the theme of Abraham Epstein's "Insecurity: a Challenge to America," published today by Harrison Smith Robert Haas, Inc., with an introduction by Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor.
MILWAUKEE, May 17. -- While half of Wisconsin's National Guard strength stood mobilized tonight authorities charged that milk strike violence had begun to assume proportions of organized rebellion.
BERLIN, May 17. -- Germany's total foreign indebtedness is estimated at between 24,000,000,000 and 25,000,000,000 marks, according to figures issued by the Reich Statistical Bureau today.

MONTREAL, May 17. -- Confident of the result, the United States Davis Cup players -- Elisworth Vines Jr., Wilmer Allison, George M. Lott Jr. and John Van Ryn -- today went through their final practice for the start tomorrow of their international series with Canada.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mrs. Sanger questions the truth or correctness of the statements set forth in my letter concerning the, attitude of various representative organizations and religious bodies toward artificial birth prevention and toward legislative efforts in Congress to amend the present Federal laws.

Wednesday, May 17, 1933. A fractional hardening in sixtyday money, which advanced to 1 per cent from 3/4, was the only variation in quotations reported out of the day's business in money. Other maturities continued steady. Stock Exchange call loans likewise showed stability at 1 per cent, but the usual trades off the board at fractional concessions were arranged.

ST. LOUIS, May 17. -- The Dodgers' invasion of the hinterlands continued to be a success today when they staged their third straight winning ninth-inning rally and made it two in a row over the Cardinals. The victory advanced Brooklyn to third place.
TOKYO, May 17. -- After a day spent in feverish though informal discussion, officials here were not ready tonight to express even qualified assent to President Roosevelt's peace proposals.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Concerning the letter from the president of the Indian Rights Association in THE TIMES of May 13, we progressive Indians do not consider that it is "fault-finding" to protest against a government bureau which, under Commissioner Rhoads, did absolutely nothing toward freeing the person of the Indian from the bureau's dictatorial control.

MOSCOW, May 17. -- President Roosevelt's message has met with "undisguised satisfaction" in official and political circles here, although no official statement will be given out until President Kalinin returns from his farm inspection trip in the Central Volga, region.
Several rentals involving entire floors in business buildings were announced yesterday. Brokers also report a number of store leases. The rentals follow:

PITTSBURGH, May 17 (AP). -- The Pirates cut loose with a heavy attack in the early inings and then with Hal Smith, rookie righthander, pitching effective relief hall, defeated the Phillies, 6 to 4, today to strengthen their hold on first place in the National League.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 17. -- Yale's baseball team defeated Providence College, 8 to 4, today, for the third consecutive year. The Eli batsmen pummeled two pitchers for twelve safeties.
WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Movements of vessels follow. All dates are May 16 unless otherwise specified.

MILWAUKEE, May 17. -- Mobilization of fourteen additional companies of National Guardsmen, attired in civilian clothes, was ordered by Governor Schmedeman this afternoon following an outbreak of disorder in the northern sector of the Wisconsin milk strike.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- President Roosevelt's bold effort to link government and industry in a partnership designed to restore prosperity attracted the immediate support of the vast Democratic majorities in Congress for the industrial recovery bill.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- The markets for grain on the Board of Trade while affected by the strength in securities, had a relatively heavy undertone today and moved up reluctantly. The trade was largely local, and outside interest showed no sights of increasing, despite bullish comment on corn from official sources and reports that rain and snow in Northern Alberta and Saskatchewan had prevented the completion of Spring wheat seeding.
These orders were issued in the Second Corps area:
The New York University baseball team defeated Stevens Tech, 14 -- 4, on Castle Point Field, Hoboken, yesterday, to gain its eleventh victory of the season.
The list of the Hamburg-American liner Resolute, which arrives today from a 36,000-mile cruise around the world, during which thirty countries were visited, includes:

CINCINNATI. May 17 (AP). -- Resolutions calling for exclusion and expulsion of all alien Communists, and for continued non-recognition of Soviet Russia until it "abandons propaganda," were adopted at the closing session today of the National Society of Sons of the American Revolution.
A joyous leitmotif thrummed its way into the depression last night. The Hop light Ladies held their first meeting at the Town Hall.

As returns on Tuesday's voting were tallied yesterday, it became evident that New Jersey, fifth State popularly to endorse repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, approached Rhode Island in, its aversion for prohibition. The incomplete total for the State last night was 414,958 for repeal to 62,967 against repeal, or about 6.6 to 1.

A permanent organization to study and "give constructive attention to" problems of household employment is to be formed during the Summer and start its activities next Fall, Dr. Benjamin R. Andrews, Professor of Household Economics at Teachers College, announced yesterday at the close of an all-day conference on home employment attended by educators and occupational authorities.

Chancellor Hitler's professions of peace as expressed in his Reichstag address yesterday were denounced as "hypocritical and dishonest" by Rabbi Stephen S. Wise in an address last night before a meeting of representatives of Jewish organizations at the Hotel Pennsylvania, at which delegates were chosen to the emergency conference of the American Jewish Congress to be held in Washington May 20 to 22.
GLENEAGLES, Scotland, May 17. -- Miss Enid Wilson, holder of the women's British golf championship for the last two years, appears headed for her third crown in succession.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced a quarter cent at one time yesterday, but the supply of contracts increased in the last hour and the market closed with gains of only 8 to 9 points.
WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Outstanding provisions of the national industrial recovery bill sent to Congress today by President Roosevelt follow:

To the Editor of The New York Times: All right-thinking persons should be grateful for your editorial "Words Not Liked." It agrees with what I have until now believed the general American attitude, and the sentiments expressed must certainly still be held by millions of our people, though recent events might lead a stranger to suppose otherwise.
PARIS, May 17. -- There its still no reason, external or internal, for France to consider abandoning the gold standard, Finance Minister Georges Bonnett told the Senate this morning.

While the "upward awing of iron and steel demand has lost some of its force," the national average of ingot production now approximates 35 per cent of capacity, compared with 31 per cent a weeK ago, according to the weekly review of The Iron Age.

Twenty-two workmen engaged in the construction of the new Union Club at 701 Park Avenue, corner of Sixty-ninth Street, received certificates of craftsmanship and gold buttons in exercises held at the building yesterday under the auspices of the New York Building Congress.

The first group of Gold Star mothers and widows to go to Europe this year sailed yesterday on the United States liner President Harding. There were 113 in the group, many of them so advanced in age and so feeble that they bad to be assisted to their cabins.

Considering the scope and importance of yesterday's news developments, the vigorous movement on the Stock Exchange seemed to Wall Street to be no more enthusiastic than the circumstances warranted. It was recalled that the market had performed more sensationally with less provocation.

LONDON, May 17. -- Vice Chancellor Franz von Papen of Germany, in a mild-tempered statement in The Evening Standard for British consumption, defends the Nazi foreign and home policy. He suggests the present regime may lead to a restoration of the monarchy.
BERLIN, May 17. -- Following in full is the address delivered by Chancellor Hitler to the Reichstag today on the disarmament and other international problems confronting the German Government:

With Vernon Gomez doing quite a turn of left-handed pitching and most of the other Yanks performing in a manner befitting their rank, the world's champions agreeably surprised a welcoming crowd of 8,000 at the Stadium yesterday.

Until this year stories of trout usually have been, told by the men anglers of the family. Heretofore the men have caused some consternation, perhaps, each spring by assembling their equipment in the living room and making one or more practice casts at imaginary trout darting over the rug.

Edwin R.A. Seligman, Professor Emeritus of Political Economy at Columbia University, in a letter to the Board of Estimate contended that exempting limited dividend housing corporations from taxes would benefit the city rather than deprive it of revenue, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- While a truce was declared in the bonus camp at Fort Hunt today between the two warring factions so that the chiefs could confer with administration leaders on a settlement of the "guest" privileges, four members of the House of Representatives offered to President Roosevelt a plan to raise money for immediate payment of the bonus through a luxury sales tax.

Stable currency and a favorable trade balance enabled Germany to reduce her foreign debts last year by about $400,000,000. But there remains $4,600,000,000 owed abroad by public agencies and private corporations. Approximately 45 per cent of this is money borrowed on short term.

NEW YORK. George Doubleday will give a dinner on May 26 at the Central Park Casino for Miss Mary Pat Kelley, whose marriage to his son, G. Chester Doubleday, is to take place on June 10 in St. Mary's Church, Manhasset.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP). -- A determined fight for "complete exoneration" was ordered today by Federal Judge Harold Louderback of California as the answer to five impeachment counts on which he is being tried by the Senate.

Lack of sympathy with the German Jews in "the unbelievable persecution to which they have been subjected" was charged yesterday to Herman A. Metz by Samuel Untermyer in a reply to Mr. Metz's open letter deploring anti-Hitler agitation.
Leases of space in the midtown area to firms in the auto trade featured leasing in Manhattan yesterday.

PARIS, May 18. -- Two former Premiers, Edouard Herriot and Andre Tardieu, both still powerful political figures, discuss President Roosevelt's peace message in their newspapers today. M. Herriot makes a plea for prudence and patience, seeing a happy augury for the future; M. Tardieu delivers a smashing attack on the President's statement, which he considers a dangerous snare for France.
WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Secretary Cordell Hull pushed ahead today with economic conversations preparatory to the world conference in London on June 12.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- As favorable comment on President Roosevelt's foreign policy statement continued to pour in from abroad today, officials and diplomats here endeavored to estimate to what extent the cause of world peace had been advanced by the Roosevelt statement and Chancellor Hitler's speech.
WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The War De- partment issued the following orders today:

The naval court of inquiry in the case of the dirigible Akron recommends, after condemning Commander McCORD for an error of judgment, that "no further proceedings be had in the matter." In the court's opinion, when the Akron took off for her last flight she "was in excellent structural condi"tion and generally embodied all "of the best features in design and "construction known to the art at "that time."

The proposal by Edwin R.A. Seligman, Professor-Emeritus of Political Economy at Columbia, to exempt limited-dividend housing corporations from taxes, elicited strenuous objections yesterday from Benjamin Winter, head of the realty firm bearing his name, and from Frank Fox, president of Realty Associates, Inc.

The bid of $2,000,000 made on May 9 through the reorganization committee of the International Combustion Engineering Corporation for property of that corporation was approved yesterday by Federal Judge Coxe, who also approved a reorganization plan sponsored by the same committee, composed of E.W. Stetson, Nathan L. Amster, Charles Hayden and R.E. McMath.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, May 18. -- Augusto Amaral, Brazilian financial envoy, left here yesterday on the second stage of his 4,800mile air journey to the United States to join in the conversations with President Roosevelt prior to the World Economic Conference.

Kid Chocolate, clever Cuban boxer who is recognized by the New York State Athletic Commission as the world's featherweight champion, will risk his crown against Seaman Tom Watson, holder of the British featherweight title, in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Mayor O'BRIEN and the Citizens Budget Commission deserve credit for two bills recently passed by the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly. One provides for an executive budget, the other for a capital outlay budget. They may not be perfect, but they are clearly a step in the right direction.

Commonwealth of Massachusetts. Leading a field of eight bidders, the Guaranty Company of New York obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of Commonwealth of Massachusetts revenue notes due on Oct. 25. The price was par, plus a premium of $11, for the notes as 1.65s.

BERLIN, May 18. -- After having discounted favorably the effect of Chancellor Hitler's speech, the Boerse was inclined to take profits today. As a result stocks were weak, the decline averaging about 2 points, but reaching in some cases 6 to 7 points.

The Board of Health is considering plans to delay enforcement of the ban on the sale of loose milk in restaurants, Health Commissioner Wynne said yesterday. He added that the order would be enforced against sales of loose milk in stores on June 1 as scheduled.

United States Attorney George Z. Medalle won yesterday his first clash with Max D. Steuer counsel for Charles E. Mitchell, over introduction of evidence at the former banker's trial on charges of evading payment of $850,000 income tax on his income of more than $4,000,000 for 1929 and 1930.

Contributions from parishes and special donations received in the 1933 appeal of the Catholic Charities of the archdiocese of New York totaled $793,366.45 yesterday, as compared with the corresponding final total of $956,421.86 in the 1932 appeal.
WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 17, unless otherwise specified:

Without any explanation, Mayor O'Brien has asked fo the resignation of John R. Crews, one of the two Republicans on the Board of Taxes and Assessments, it was disclosed last night. The mysterious move had leaders in both the Brooklyn Republican and Democratic organizations guessing as to the cause.

ALBANY, May 18. -- Activities of fifty milk dealers in the New York City area who are alleged to have violated the State Milk Control Board's order on minimum retail prices are to be scrutinized, the board announced today. Complaints also have been filed against a dozen up-State dealers.
BOSTON, May 18 (AP). -- Oscar Melillo knocked in five runs with a homer and a two-bagger today as the Browns defeated the Red Sox, 8 -- 2, for the rubber game of their series.

Johnny Alien, who forsook hotel clerking to startle the baseball world by winning seventeen games for the Yankees last season in his first year in the majors, made his belated 1933 debut for the world's champions at the Stadium yesterday and forthwith set at rest any fears that he may ever have to return to his earlier vocation.

Columbia yesterday brought to a close its competition in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League by defeating Princeton, 8 -- 1, for its second triumph, over the Tigers this year. The contest was scheduled to be played at Princeton, but because of the death of President Emeritus John Grier Hibben it was transferred to Baker Field.
The annual Police Department awards for deeds of conspicuous bravery during 1932 were announced yesterday by Commissioner Bolan.

MADISON, Wis., May 18 (AP). -- The Wisconsin milk strike was declared ended tonight and cessation of picketing will be accomplished tomorrow as soon as the arbitration committee of the Wisconsin Cooperative Milk Pool ratifies an agreement reached at 12 o'clock tonight.

In a finish so close that many spectators thought the second horse had won, John J. Robinson's Glidelia yesterday won the Artful Purse, feature at Jamaica. Fancy Flight was second, a scant nose behind the daughter of Lucullite, which made a charge through the stretch that electrified observers.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Authority for President Roosevelt to place on the retired list any commissioned or warrant officer of the navy and marine corps was sought in an administration bill transmitted to Speaker Rainey today and introduced by Chairman Vinson of the House Naval Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- President von Hindenburg of Germany, in replying today to President Roosevelt's appeal for peace, voiced sentiments expressed before the Reichstag yesterday by Chancellor Hitler. The German President's reply and those of other government heads were made public by the White House.

BOWIE, Md., May 18 (AP). -- Tred Avon, racing for Sylvester W. Labrot, defeated seven other performers of excellent grade in the Inaugural Handicap at the opening of the Southern Maryland Jockey Club's Spring meeting at Bowie today.
