GENEVA, May 18. -- Members of the League Council, meeting informally and secretly today, approved a plan for settlement of the Chaco war between Bolivia and Paraguay, drawn up by the committee of three headed by Scan Lester of the Irish Free State.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 18. -- A beautiful explosion shot out of the Travis bunker guarding the famous eighteenth green enabled George T. Dunlap Jr., Long Island amateur champion and Walker Cup star, to tie for the medal in today's qualifying round of the Garden City Golf Club's annual invitation tournament, one of the oldest events in the history of metropolitan district golf.
LONDON, May 18. -- The British Government is expected to make at least one reservation and possibly two when it accepts President Roosevelt's proposed non-aggression treaty.

Agitation that has been in progress a number of years among American artists for the protection of their interests against mediocre foreign painters and sculptors developed last night into one of the largest meetings of artists here this season.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Other seeds of recovery sown by this administration may not yet have ripened, but its economy patch is beginning to yield. Not until June 1 will the large slashes in pensions be visible, but many of the cuts in government costs have already taken effect.
From indications of the last few days, fishermen who have been down to Peconie Bay appear optimistic concerning weakfishing for this week-end.
ALBANY, May 18. -- Additional interpretations of the new 1 per cent retail sales tax were announced today by the State Tax Department.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- An investigation by Congress of alleged misuse of government property at Muscle Shoals by two private power companies with the acquiescence of plant authorities was in prospect today, following disclosures made by Secretary Ickes as President Roosevelt signed the Norris bill providing direct government operation and control of the huge Federal development.

The aim of the New York State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board to keep not only racketeers but bootleggers and liquor runners from participating in the legal beer and wine business was made doubly clear yesterday with the issuance of application blanks for licenses to sell beer and wine at wholesale.

Among topics discussed at meetings of the principals of the steamship lines and representatives in the North Atlantic Conference in the last two days, was that provision of the so-called "standstill agreement" between the German Reichsbank and New York banks with immovable credits in Germany which allows a 15 per cent discount to passengers traveling on German steamship lines and tourists in Germany.
BEFORE he wandered up to the Bronx to keep an engagement at the Yankee Stadium yesterday Manager Bucky Harris of the Detroit Tigers was trapped in his hotel and cross-questioned at some length.

TIENTSIN, May 18. -- "No one can do anything; the time for compromise has passed," declared a Japanese Army spokesman here today, in announcing the arrival of the vanguard of the central Japanese columns in North China at a village six miles from Tungchow, which is a suburb of Peiping, only thirteen miles from that city.

PARIS, May 18. -- By a huge vote, with only the Nationalists abstaining, the Chamber of Deputies adopted today a motion expressing approval of the non-aggression pact with Russia, which was promulgated by official decree some time ago.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- New Jersey's plea for Federal emergency relief was placed today before President Roosevelt and Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, by Governor Moore and State Senator Richards, with the backing of Senator Barbour.

George B. Sheldon, described by Federal investigators as a former liquor operator and associate of the late Larry Fay, was arrested yesterday on lower Fifth Avenue not far from the once prosperous but now defunct offices of the Sheldon Hosiery Company, where he and flye confederates were said to have taken in $100,000 in four months by the endless-chain system of salesmanship.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Passage by the House of President Roosevelt's industrial recovery bill by the end of next week was predicted today by Democratic Leader Byrns and Chairman Doughton, as the Ways and Means Committee began a study of four tax programs, submitted by Director of the Budget Douglas, with which to finance the $3,300,000,000 public works program contemplated in the measure.

For some reason Wall Street chose to assign a brief and unjustified "dividend scare" as the cause of the lively reaction on the Stock Exchange yesterday afternoon. When the United Corporation, concerning the dividend status of which no particular anxiety had been shown previously, announced that it had authorized the regular quarterly disbursement on common stock, the general list rallied sharply.

SCARBOROUGH, England, May 18 (Canadian Press). -- Sir Herbert Samuel, leader of Opposition Liberals in the House of Commons, tonight saw signs of a battle at the polls in which his party would place in the field not less than 400 candidates.

John Foster Dulles of the law firm of Sullivan Cromwell was chosen yesterday by representatives of Wall Street banks and banking houses which have marketed German dollar bond issues in the past to attend the conference in Berlin to discuss Germany's external debt.

Thursday, May 18, 1933. Money market ruled quietly and without change in either quotation or business. Stock Exchange call loans "were 1 per cent, time money 1 to 1 1/2 per cent for the short and distant periods, while acceptances and commercial paper were done at the prevailing discounts.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey reports for 1932 a consolidated net profit of $282,865 after expenses, taxes, interest, depreciation, depletion, amortization, retirements and inventory loss, equal to slightly more than 1 cent a share on the 25,740,965 capital shares of $25 par value.

With nine new States enacting old-age relief legislation thus far this year, the long battle for old-age pensions is half won, according to an announcement made last night at the dinner of the National Conference on Old Age Security, held at the Hotel Shelton.

BERLIN, May 18. -- Germany awoke today to find herself nearer the old basis of understanding, if not popularity, than she has been for many a day. Extracts of opinion from Europe and the United States on yesterday's proceedings in the Reichstag, prominently displayed in the morning newspapers, proved it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: What do the County Clerks of the five counties comprising the city do? I have practiced law for over twenty years and I have been unable to learn what services these men perform. I remember once insisting on seeing the County Clerk of New York County to compel a clerk to accept a paper for filing.

LONDON, May 18. -- Neville Chamberlain, a life-long believer in protective tariffs and economic nationalism, will be the leader of the British delegation in the World Economic Conference, it was announced today. Prime Minister MacDonald, who made the journey to Washington to consult President Roosevelt, will not take the active conduct of the British case.
WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 16:

MINEOLA, L.I., May 18. -- Following the recommendation of the Nassau County Board of Supervisors to reduce the emergency work bureau payrolls because of the county's inability to sell a bond issue, more than 10,000 men will be discharged this week, it was announced here today by Albert S. Roberts, chairman of the bureau.

Most of the commodities traded on local exchanges reacted yesterday and closed with moderate losses. Sugar, however, recovered losses of the preceding day and raw hides continued higher. Trading volumes were again reduced. All cash prices were lower.

Now that the general purposes of the national administration have been fairly well defined so far as the broad economic program is concerned, the security markets turned cautiously yesterday to a reconsideration of domestic business conditions.

British business men are interested widely in the recovery program put forward by President Roosevelt, H. Gordon Selfridge Jr., partner in the Selfridge department store in London, said yesterday. He arrived in New York Wednesday for a short stay in which he plans to observe business conditions in the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Announcement of a possible agreement on silver stabilization and the prediction of early resumption of normal trade relations between this country and Mexico ended the visit of the Mexican mission, headed by Alberto J. Pani, here today.

The portrait of George Washington, known as the "Lee-Phillips" portrait, and attributed by several authorities to Gilbert Stuart, brought $1,750 at auction last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc. The purchaser was F.H. Argyle.

The annual reception and garden party given by the president and trustees of the New York Zoological Society and the ladies' auxiliary of the organization was held at the New York Zoological Park yesterday afternoon. Tea was served on the lawn outside the administration building with music by a section of the Seventy-first Regiment band, Lambert Eben conducting.
Small housing parcels comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported, yesterday.

The garden party in behalf of the Travelers Aid Society will take place tomorrow afternoon in the gardens of Still House, the estate of Paul D. Cravath in Locust Valley. A feature of the party will be the appearance of Miss Ruth Page, former guest soloist danseuse of the Metropolitan Opera, who will present groups of dances during the afternoon.

LONDON, May 18. -- The stock markets today reacted favorably to Chancellor Hitler's conciliatory address to the Reichstag, although early advances were not fully maintained and the tone became irregular before the close. British funds were easier in tendency on profit-taking.

BERLIN, May 18. -- The Prussian Diet today adopted an enabling act transferring its legislative powers to the Goering Cabinet until April 1, 1937, in the same manner in which the Reichstag abdicated to the Hitler Cabinet, thereby completing the process of coordinating Prussia, with the Reich.
BERLIN, May 18. -- The program for national observance of the tenth anniversary of the execution of Lieutenant Albert Leo Schlageter by the French in the Ruhr occupation is rounding into shape.
Applications for listing of the following securities have been received by the New York Stock Exchange:

NEWPORT, R.I., May 18 (AP). -- F. Frazier Jelke, on the witness stand again today in the trial of his suit for divorce, said that within a few months after their marriage in 1931, Eugenia Woodward Jelke told him she would divorce him, that she screamed at and cursed him, bit his ear, tore his shirt and spent $8,000 for clothes.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 (AP). -- Behind the six-hit pitching of big George Earnshaw, the Athletics pounded four Chicago White Sox hurlers for fifteen hits and a 9-to-1 victory today. It was Earnshaw's first appearance on the mound since April 24.

To the rhythms of "Turn Around Me," and "Greensleeves," played by the Police Department Band, 3,000 schoolgirls of the Public Schools Athletic League yesterday afternoon danced and romped their way through the intricate evolutions of the annual park fete, in the sheep meadow of Central Park.

Publication yesterday of the national industrial recovery bill stimulated plans for the organization of three trade groups which desire, upon enactment, to come within its scope. They are the women's cloak, the dress and the men's clothing industries.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended May 17, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,286,000,000, a decrease of $62,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $342,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.
LONDON, May 18. -- The Americans presented at the court in Buckingham Palace tonight were:

Twenty-eight city-owned sites on which it might be possible to provide playgrounds have been disclosed by a survey made by Controller Charles W. Berry at the request of the Park Association of New York City.

Mr. and Mrs. Hugh E. Paine gave a dinner last night in the roof garden of the St. Regis for Miss Margaret Parsons and her fiance, John D. Duncan. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Merrill, Mr. and Mrs. Eli Whithey Debevoise, Mr. and Mrs. Franklyn E. Vilas, Miss Edith Parsons, Cornelius King, Lawrence Morris, Rene Boel, Carlyle Maw and Louis Timolat.

TOKYO, Friday, May 19. -- As part of what the press believes will prove a far-reaching shake-up in the diplomatic service, Toshio Shiratori, the Foreign Office's renowned spokesman, is being transferred to the post of Minister to Sweden.
PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- The annual conference of the Association of Junior Leagues of America, Inc., will vote tomorrow on whether non-partisan politics shall he considered among its activities.

Mrs. August Belmont is the first woman to serve on the board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Company. She was one of the five new members elected at the annual stockholders' meeting at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon.

Two anniversaries were celebrated yesterday by Milton Aborn, who is presenting a series of Gilbert and Sullivan revivals at the St. James Theatre. Fifty years ago, according to Mr. Aborn's records, he began an association with the musical stage as Sir Joseph Porter in a performance of "Pinafore" given by the Jones Opera Company at the Windsor Theatre, Boston.

BRANCHVILLE, N.J., May 18. -- Twenty tons of granulated sugar being transported by trailer-truck from Newark to Rochester and Syracuse were stolen early this morning on Route S31 where the highway leads up a hill through Stokes State Forest near here, it was reported to the State police in Newton today.

GENEVA, May 18. -- President Roosevelt's message and Chancellor Hitler's statement have changed the character of the much-postponed disarmament conference meeting, which is now scheduled for tomorrow afternoon.
WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended May 17 were announced today:

Contracts have just been signed for the publication in this country by Little, Brown Co., of Boston, of the War Memoirs of David Lloyd George, in four volumes. The first section of two volumes, covering the events which led up to the war and the war years of 1914-1916, will appear next autumn.
The French liner Paris will sail today for Havre carrying, among her passengers, the officers and men of the unlucky Saint Malo fishing schooner Notre Dame D'Uronea.

Behind the masterful pitching of Xavier Rescigno, sophomore right-hander, who allowed only three hits while striking out eleven men, the Manhattan baseball team downed St. John's for the second time this season, 5 -- 1, at Manhattan Field yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- A $230,000,000 naval building program, to begin Aug. 1 and continue for three years, is being planned by the administration under authority of the public works section of the national Industrial Recovery bill.

President HUTCHINS of Chicago University took as the text of his discourse before the Bond Club this indisputable proposition: "The professor is sometimes right." The trouble comes in the application. Professors disagree at least as often as doctors.

Futther improvement is shown in this week's report of the Federal Reserve System, published last night. In the week ended on Wednesday the system gained $25,474,000 in gold holdings, carrying its reserves of the metal to $3,467,508,000, a new high record since Sept. 16, 1931.

Boli of Blake, owned by F.B. Lord of Syosaett, L.I., carried off the major honors in the first annual specialty show of the Labrador Retriever Club yesterday at 61 East Seventy-sixth Street. Mr. Lord's 11-month-old entry, in addition to being declared the best Labrador retriever in the show, also took first prize in the limit class, dogs and bitches, and first in the open dogs.

PRAGUE, May 18 -- Dr. Alfred Meissner, the Czechoslovak Minister of Justice, announced in Parliament today that his government Would complain in Berlin about the passage in Chancellor Hitler's speech to the Reichstag referring to the trial of German National Socialists in Brno.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway resumed in April the upward trend in net income which it had Maintained with one interruption since October. The exception was March, when bank closings and unfavorable operating conditions resulted in a decrease.

"The Background of Science," by Six James Jeans, published today by Macmillan, ranges from stars to electrons and back again to explain the "two great upheavals in physical science" which are associated with the words Relativity and Quanta.

ST. LOUIS, May 18. -- Encountering their third southpaw pitcher of the series, the Dodgers today added Jim Mooney to their list of victims in unloading a thirteen-hit barrage to defeat the Cardinals, 14 to 5, and make a clean sweep of the three-game series.
LONDON, May 18 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

ALBANY, May 18. -- About 20,000 places now selling beer will go out of business when the new licenses go into effect on June 1. The State Alcohol Beverage Control Board is prepared to make a careful check on the applications which have been filed thus far and all that arrive in the next few days.
Cuts will be restored in the curbstone fronting a building at 2,306 to 2,312 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, under a court order issued yesterday.
PARIS, May 18 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Indictments against eight persons charging violations of the election laws last November were dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Daniel V. McNamee on motion ot Assistant District Attorney Henry Alexander and a plea of guilty was received from another defendant who took the blame for errors in the return from the Fifth Election District of the Seventeenth Assembly District.

A flexible price policy by manufacturers as a means of preventing unemployment and assuring business stability was suggested yesterday by Leverett S. Lyon, executive vice president of the Brookings Institution in Washington, at the closing session of the annual conference of the American Management Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Leaders of the anti-Tammany fusion movement had no progress to report yesterday in their attempt to draft Samuel Seabury as their candidate for Mayor. It was indicated that the leaders of the fusion group might have a statement within a day or two, and the prevailing opinion seemed to be that the chances were against Mr. Seabury's acceptance.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 18. -- A new season of polo was opened today at the Meadow Brook Club with three games, two of them played in six periods instead of the old eight, which is the length decided upon for club polo this year.

A group of sociological and welfare experts will be selected soon to work out plans to assist the hundreds of thousands of persons adrift in this country because of the economic crisis. This decision was reached yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the special committee on migratory youth at the Madison Square Hotel, 40 East Twenty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Aroused by the continued flood of gushing oil wells, the administration will reach out tomorrow for control to regulate production in this disturbed industry.

April Retail Collections Off. Retail collections during April showed a decrease of 0.85 per cent, according to the index of twenty local key stores issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc. The figure compares with a drop of 3.94 per cent in March and of 1.52 per cent in April a year ago.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Scientists of the Bureau of Entomology of the Department of Agriculture, commenting on the white ant or termite invasion of New York, asserted today that the best way to defeat these insects, where they are already established in buildings, is to cut off their contact with the ground.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- To adminster the almost unlimited powers over industry which would be conferred upon the government by the pending Industrial Regulation Bill, President Roosevelt has chosen Hugh S. Johnson, soldier, lawyer and manufacturer.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 18. -- In a joint telegram sent to President Roosevelt tonight, Thomas W. Martin, president of the Alabama Power Company, and Joe Conn Guild Jr., vice president and general manager of the Tennessee Electric Power Company, denied charges of misuse of government facilities at Muscle Shoals as "unqualifiedly false" and asked for an immediate investigation of them.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- The wheat pit on the Board of Trade was confronted today with a sudden influx of selling headed by houses with Eastern connections, and a lack of Aggressive support was disclosed. There was a small bulge early, but the upturn was shortlived, as persistent selling developed.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Abandonment of all but the voluntary domestic allotment plan of farm relief in aiding wheat producers under the provisions of the agricultural adjustment act, was urged in a report to Secretary Wallace today by fourteen associations representative of practically all growers of that commodity.

HAVANA, May 18. -- The revolt now in progress in Santa Clara and Camaguey Provinces spread southward today when fighting broke out in the small village of Omeja, east of Victoria de las Tunas, in Oriente Province, where rebels seized and ransacked a small Rural Guard post, carrying off arms and ammunition.

TOKYO, Friday, May 19. -- Japan's reply to President Roosevelt's message, to be dispatched to Washington next week, will constitute an acceptance in principle of the President's proposals and an intimation of her readiness to open negotiations with the other powers to translate his general ideas into practical form, a Foreign Office spokesman announced this morning.

Nazi Tragedy Averted. There is a rumor that immediately on the conclusion of Chancellor HITLER'S speech in the Reichstag he was waited upon by Messrs. GOERING, GOEBBELS, FRICK and other members of the Nazi high comnand.
Detectives have been assigned to guard the two young children of Leopold Stokowski, conductor of the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra, following a threat to kidnap them, it was disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- The Giants assisted in the celebration attending the raising of the 1932 National League pennant at Wrigley Field today by splitting a double-header with the Cubs before 12,000 fans.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 18. -- With the issue in doubt up to the final two matches, Long Island captured the metropolitan triangular team golf championship today over the Cherry Valley course by scoring 18 points to 14 1/2 for New Jersey and 12 1/2 for Westchester, the defending titleholder.
Mayor O'Brien traced the recent growth in the need for unemployment and home relief yesterday and described the city's efforts to keep up with it.

Higher education in American universities is being hampered by "a large amount of nursing," Dr. Robert Maynard Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, told a luncheon gathering yesterday in the Western Universities Club at 500 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Receipts from the beer and wine tax were $9,139,687 in April, while a few scattered tax payments in March for licenses brought the total for two months to $9,860,496, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.

The promise of stricter supervision of its 16,000 election officials at the special prohibition repeal election on May 23 was made by the Board of Elections yesterday at a meeting attended by representatives of the New York League of Women Voters.
WASHINGTON, May 18. -- New York was the leading beer-producing State in April, according to figures announced by the Internal Revenue Bureau today.

The dramatic rights to Edward Hope's novel, "She Loves Me Not," have been acquired by Dwight Deere Wiman and Tom Weatherley. Howard Lindsay has been commissioned to make the dramatization and the firm intends to present the play here in September.

MONTREAL, May 18. -- The United States Davls Cup team today jeopardized the chances of Canada's remaining in the international tennis competition as Ellsworth Vines, the national champion, and Wilmer Allison, No. 2 ranking player, swept through the opening singles matches in the North American zone final.

Among the passengers departing tonight for European ports on the Holland-America liner Statendam are Mr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Moody. Mrs. Moody is the former Helen Wills, tennis star, and is en route with her husband to play at Wimbledon.
Rising indices for the week ended on Tuesday and also for April were reported yesterday by The Annalist. The advance for the week was the sixth successive upturn.

BARNSTABLE, Mass., May 18. -- Kenneth and Cyril Buck of Harwich were indicted today for the kidnapping on May 2 of Margaret (Peggy) McMath, 10 years old. The special grand jury which investigated the case voted two indictments.

GEORGE MOORE once said that the English distribute tracts and the French medals. Americans have a passion for both. Wednesday might have been called Medal Day -- so many awards were made in recognition of achievement in various fields.

Lee Weinstein, secretary to the eccentric and wealthy Edward Albert Ridley, who was murdered with his employer in the subcellar office at 63 Alien Street, had been the head of a conspiracy by which more than $200,000 was stolen from the Dickensian real estate man, the police announced early today.

ATHENS, Ala., May 18 (AP). -- Writs of habeas corpus, directing that two of nine Negroes indicted in the "Scottsboro case" be brought into the Morgan County Circuit Court at Decatur June 1 for determination of their status were issued today by Judge James E. Horton.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP). -- An emergency plan for insuring all bank deposits up to $2,500 for one year, with a fund backed by the Treasury, was advanced in the Senate today as an amendment to the Glass bank bill. It had strong support from both parties.

With New York City showing a substantial improvement for the week over last year, the total decline from the 1932 period in bank clearings for twenty-one leading cities of the country was reduced to a small percentage. The figures show a continuation of the improvement reported for the preceding week, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The combination of declines in the grain markets and the best weather so far this season in the cotton belt depressed prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. The quotations went above 9 cents a pound for the October at one time, but offerings of contracts increased, as on Wednesday, and a decline of 30 points left the list with losses of 13 to 15 points on the day.

Rocco Demo, 31 years old, a taxicab chauffeur, of 224 Lafayette Street, was arraigned before Magistrate McGee in the Homicide Court yesterday on charges of homicide, driving while intoxicated and reckless driving. It was charged that his taxicab had sidewiped Engine 14 as it was returning from a fire, killing one fireman, critically injuring another and sending the engine company's captain to a hospital suffering from shock.

The annual marble contest for school children conducted by the Park Department was won in City Hall Park yesterday by Nunzio Aquilino, 15, of 990 Hart Street, Brooklyn, after Mayor O'Brien had declined to start the contest and his place was taken by Jack Dempsey, former heavyweight boxing champion.

A demand for the resignation of W. Kingsland Macy as chairman of the Republican State Committee has been made by its members from the Bronx. The move arose out of the recent controversy between Mr. Macy and John J. Knewitz, Bronx county chairman, over the appointment of Thomas W. Whittle as a Republican member of the Board of Taxes and Assessments to succeed George Henry Payne.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP). -- The Indians scored an extra-inning victory over the Senators today, winning, 6 to 5, for their first triumph of the three-game series.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 18. -- Twelve men were graduated from the New Brunswick Theological Seminary today during the commencement held here in Kirkpatrick Chapel. Diplomas were presented by Dr. W.H.S. Demarest, president of the seminary.

PARIS, May 18. -- The French colonial trade conference, aimed to prepare the French empire to enter the World Economic Conference at London as a unit, on a basis similar to that achieved at Ottawa by the British Commonwealth of Nations, opened today at the Ministry of Commerce.
PITTSBURGH, May 18 (AP). -- Pittsburgh made a clean sweep of the four-game series with the Phillies today, taking the final game, 6 to 2. Swetonic allowed only six hits.

The Spanish Constitution definitely declares Republican Spain to be a "lay State." This has generally been taken to mean simply that the Catholic Church in Spain was disestablished. But legislation has now moved to the point of "nationalizing" church property, and, instead of expelling the religious orders that remain, preventing them from having any place in the Spanish educational system.

In a final practice session before sailing tonight for England, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, British and French titleholder, won one out of three sets from Manuel Alonso yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

The New York County Lawyers Association went on record last night in condemnation of the award of all Federal receiverships to the Irving Trust Company, and in a strenuous debate advocates of the move assailed Governor Lehman's veto of bills that would have prevented continuance of the practice.

ATLANTIC CITT, N.J., May 18. -- Spectacular spills kept the spectators keyed up during the progress of the ladies' hunter class at the second day of the annual Atlantie City Horse Show today, but fortunately they were more fearsome to the onlookers than damaging to the participants.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 18. -- San Quentin's prison doors opened by court order today for Thomas J. Mooney, convicted of complicity in the dynamiting of a Preparedness Day parade here in 1916, to allow his transfer to the San Francisco County jail, pending trial at his own insistence on an unused murder indictment.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The message of the President to the public on May 7 indicates a leaning toward a relation between money and prices which may not receive universal assent. It is laid down that it has "an objective of raising commodity prices," and in the policy it is assumed that prices can be raised by an increase of money and credit, usually known as inflation.

The position of the Jew in Germany is a challenge to civilization. Rabbi Jonah B. Wise of the Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Avenue, declared last night at a dinner tendered to him at the Essex House. The dinner was arranged by the officers and members of the synagogue to mark his return from a visit to Germany, where he went as a representative of the American Joint Distribution Committee.
GARY, Ind., May 18 (AP). -- The blast furnaces of Gary's steel mills have started to roar, calling back to work in the "steel capital of the mid-West" more than 3,000 men.

Samue Untermyer, who for years has been a stanch, defender of Tammany Hall, joined the ranks of its critics last night. He declared that New York had been driven to the verge of bankruptcy by the "extravagance and incompetence of the management of the city, with its padded payrolls."
PHILADELPHIA, May 19 (AP). -- Driving two pitchers off the mound with a heavy barrage, the Athletics hammered ou a 9-to-2 victory over the Indians in the opener of a two-same series today.

Ministers and members of the Christian Church must face frankly "the fact that capitalism is un-Christian and unethical and then consider ways and means of replacing it with a system that is more in conformity with the principles of our religion," according to a report of the social service committee of the New York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

A comprehensive system of social insurance, covering health, old age pensions and unemployment, was advocated yesterday at the closing meeting of the National Conference on Old Age Security at the Hotel Shelton. The American relief system was compared with the British unemployment insurance scheme to the detriment of the former, on the ground that it was more demoralizing to the individual than the British scheme, with its regular payments to the insured.

This week's report on the country's foreign trade in April draws a picture of what is going on in the international exchange of goods. Except for last February, a short month, our April merchandise exports of $105,000,000 were the smallest of any month on the record since August, 1904; our imports of $88,000,000, with the same exception, the smallest since July, 1908.

Mayor O'Brien's demand that Tax Commissioner John R. Crews, one of the two Republican members of the Board of Taxes and Assessments, forward his resignation to City Hall was still unexplained yesterday. The Mayor said he could not appoint a successor until he had Mr. Crews's resignation, but the Brooklyn Tax Commissioner showed no inclination to give up his $10,800 job without an explanation.

The Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, the new Apostolic Delegate from Vatican City, will be formally welcomed by Cardinal Hayes at an elaborate ceremony in St. Patrick's Cathedral Wednesday afternoon at 4 o'clock. The delegate, who is now aboard the Conte di Savoia, is due here Tuesday.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- Activity in securities is attracting Eastern attention from the grain markets, and according to trade gossip much of the pressure on wheat on the Board of Trade has come from this class of traders, who were aggressive buyers when prices for wheat were much lower and the market was active.
NEW YORK. Lord and Lady Ashburton gave a dinner for Mr. and Mrs. Clarence H. Mackay last night at the Madison.

As a result of an injunction suit brought by a taxpayer, the Board of Estimate at its meeting yesterday deferred for three weeks action on an application by Nathan Straus Jr., in behalf of the Hillside Homes Housing Corporation, to exempt the property from a local tax on buildings and improvements.

Although a representative of the local stagehands' union had previously assured R.E.H. French, general manager for John Golden, that Mr. Golden's presentation of the Rachel Crothers play, "When Ladies Meet," now running at the Royale Theatre, came under the classification of a stock production, the national organization of stagehands has set aside that interpretation.
WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The long-expected bill to promote conservation of the nation's oil resources and establish joint State-Federal regulation of the industry reached Congress today.

ROME, May 19. -- "Without a radical reduction in intergovernmental debts and an adequate revision of international loans floated to effect payments under post-war treaties, it will be impossible to reach any improvement in the world's economic situation," says the budget report submitted today by Finance Minister Guido Jung.

The Standard Oil Company of New York will put into effect on Monday in the metropolitan area of New York a new schedule of gasoline quotations based on cargo prices at Gulf Coast ports. The service-station price here will be 14.2 cents a gallon, including tax, compared with the present price of 14.5 cents.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The story of the Times Square clock which has given good and faithful service to Broadwayites for half a century brings to mind the performance of another Broadway clock an account of which appears in "Maiden Lane: The Story of a Single Street."

MONTREAL, May 19. -- The United States Davis Cup team advanced another step in quest of the famous international tennis trophy today when George M. Lott Jr. and John Van Ryn defeated Marcel Rainville and Dr. Jack Wright of Canada to clinch the North American zone final and send the team into the inter-zone final against Argentina at Washington next week.

Three men were arrested, charged with assaults on policemen and another was accused of disorderly conduct yesterday during disorders by Communists at three home relief stations in various parts of the city. About thirty persons were beaten by the police, but none asked medical attention.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- An American delegation headed by Silas H. Strawn of Chicago will sail from New York tomorrow on the Bremen to meet with industrial and financial leaders from more than forty countries at the seventh general congress of the International Chamber of Commerce in Vienna during the week of May 29.

TIENTSIN, May 19. -- A Chinese Foreign Office spokesman declared today the semblance of cessation of hostilities, with the Japanese taking advanced positions and the Chinese withdrawing, positiveley did not involve a Chino-Japanese agreement.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 19. -- The combined choral societies of Westchester County joined here tonight in the presentation of the ninth annual music festival at the County Centre. Albert Stoessel was the conductor and Albert Spalding the guest soloist in a concert which drew on 1,200 men and women from twenty-seven communities in Westchester and near-by Connecticut.
Prices fluctuated irregularly in a 10-point range on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and ended 9 to 13 points lower than on Thursday.

BERLIN, May 19. -- Georg Bernhard, former editor-in-chief of the Vossische Zeitung, was expelled today "in ignominy" from the Reich Press Association. The association's "court of honor" passed sentence on the internationally known publicist as a result of a recent article in Herr Bernhard's Journal de Geneve on the persecution of Jews.
WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The War Department issued the following orders today: Walker, Col. R.W., Cav., to Fort Lewis, Washington.
CINCINNATI, May 19 (AP). -- Chuck Klein of the Phillies cracked a home run off Red Lucas today in the ninth inning to give his team a victory over the Reds, 5 to 4.

Just to show they have not lost their hand at it, the Yankees swung back to more robust measures than inside baseball at the Stadium yesterday. By cracking a couple of baseballs outside the playing arena they contrived to beat the Browns in the opener of a three-game series, 6 to 5.

An old man, infirm in mind and body and apparently bent on self-destruction, lost himself in the city yesterday despite frantic efforts by the Police Department and agents of the Department of Justice to find him and stay his hand. He was Joseph W. Harriman, former head of the Harriman National Bank, now awaiting trial in $25,000 bail on an indictment charging him with making false entries totaling $1,713,225.

The formation of a company to provide means for the liquidation of German blocked mark balances through the financing of imports to the United States from Germany was announced yesterday. The new company is to be called the Syndicate of American Creditors Owning German Blocked Accounts.
BERLIN, May 19. -- German stock brokers of the Jewish faith, about whose fate under the new dispensation there has been much uncer- tainty, will be allowed to continue their calling, it appears.

HAVANA, May 19. -- The Havana branch of the Chase National Bank of New York received the award today on its bid for handling the coinage of the new $6,000,000 silver issue to be made by the Cuban Government under the law passed by Congress on May 10.

The traditional questionnaire of the senior class at Columbia College, conducted by The Columbian, college yearbook, reveals that the average Columbia senior, who weighs 156 pounds and measures 5 feet 9 1/2 inches in height, expects to make a salary of $3,872 a year five years after his graduation.

HAVANA, May 19. -- From Santiago, capital of Oriente Province, twenty-five soldiers, armed with machine guns, were rushed to Baraco at the extreme eastern end of the island of Cuba today. An unconfirmed report said rebels again attacked and partly burned San Luis, in Oriente.

The executive committee of the board of trustees of the American Museum of Natural History approved yesterday the planetarium project laid before the trustees on April 1, it was announced yester- day by F. Trubee Davison, president of the museum.

Domestic corporation bonds were pushed higher on the Stock Exchange yesterday, many issues touching new highs for the year, while foreign loans and United States Government bonds finished irregularly lower. Trading was considerably slower than on Thursday, yesterday's turnover amounting to $12,297,000, against $15,697,000 on the pevious day.

Lacking fresh speculative incentive, the share market was passive yesterday, with an inclination to vacillate. Bonds, on the other hand, extended their recovery moderately in fairly active dealings, with some of the domestic corporation issues rising to the highest levels of the year thus far.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Definite agreement among nations interested in improving the price of silver on a six-point program to be worked out at the "World Economic Conference in London was revealed today by Senator Pittman, who has been appointed to the delegation.

GENEVA, May 19. -- Rudolf Nadolny, on behalf of Germany, told the disarmament conference today that Germany accepted the "British draft convention not only as hitherto as a basis of discussion but as a basis for the future convention itself."

Representatives of the non-German steamship lines of the Atlantic Passenger Conference discussed the rate situation with respect to the use of German marks., purchased in American banks at reduced prices under an agreement with the German Reichsbank in payment for transit on German ships, at a meeting yesterday afternoon at the Cunard Line office, 25 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Harry L. Hopkins, New York State Administrator of Relief, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to be Federal Emergency Administrator under the Wagner $500,000,000 relief act. He will assume his duties early next week.

HAVANA, May 19. -- Preparations were made throughout Cuba tonight to forestall any outbreaks tomorrow, the thirty-first anniversary of Cuba's independence, as reports came in of the first rebellious activities in Pinar del Rio Province, at the western end of the island.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP). -- Leaders of American Jewry in a statement tonight, on the eve of the convening here tomorrow of an emergency session of the American Jewish Congress, asserted that efforts to arouse public opinion against Adolf Hitler would be continued until Jews were restored "to complete equality with all other inhabitants of Germany."

BOCA GRANDE, Fla., May 19. -- Governor Lehman of New York, who is about to end his fishing vacation here, landed a hundred-pound tarpon today after a twenty-five-minute battle in choppy seas, thus bringing to twenty-one the total catch of his party.

The partners of the private banking firms of Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Dillon, Read Co. were served with subpoenas here yesterday to appear in Washington for questioning before the investigating subcommittee of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, immediately following J.P. Morgan and ten of his partners.

The State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board issued applications for licenses to brew beer yesterday and announced it would decide today or Monday if it will permit the sale and consumption of beer and wine at bars.

Citation of nineteen policemen for deeds of "conspicuous bravery" reminds us that peace also hath its valor. As the names suggest, the men cited came from different racial stocks, though the Celtic strain predominates. Five of the number were off duty and in civilian dress at the time of the action which won this recognition -- three of the five having been killed.

BERLIN, May 19. -- The Boerse was dull and weak today. Pending developments in Geneva, financial circles are inclined to adopt a waiting attitude, for which reason some favorable factors were disregarded. Stocks lost up to 6 points, losses of 2 to 3 points being common.
PITTSBURGH, May 19 (AP). -- The Braves checked the Pirates' winning streak after four straight games by unloosing an early attack that netted them a 5-to-3 victory in the series opener today.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Powers of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation are gradually being restricted by legislation in the administration's program for economic recovery, and if the National Industrial Recovery Bill, with its public works section, is adopted, the corporation will be found acting largely as fiscal agent for other governmental agencies.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 19. -- A unified banking system under control of the Federal Reserve in the place of the various State groups and also other regulations to strengthen the banking situation in the United States were seen by Governor A. Harry Moore in an address here tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Under recommendations made to Congress by the Federal Reserve Board today in its annual report for 1932, the Reserve Banks would be permitted to make loans to member banks for ninety days on properly secured promissory notes of the latter.

Reductions in freight rates on milk to points in the New York metropolitan area, averaging 19 per cent and effective July 1, were announced yesterday by representatives of the Eastern rail presidents, in conference here. The rate decrease will save dairy farmers $1,700,000 annually, according to an estimate of the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association.

Albert H. Wiggin, chairman of the committee of the German standstill creditors, will sail tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen for Berlin to attend the meeting called by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank.

The first concern in the United States to feel the effects of the "socialism" of the German Nazis, Rudolf 'Mosse, Inc., American subsidiary of the famous publishing and advertising house of Rudolf Mosse in Berlin, is in liquidation, it became known yesterday.

Samuel Seabury, who as counsel for the Hofstadter legislative com- mittee produced testimony which resulted in the resignation of James J. Walker as Mayor, declined yes- terday to accept the fusion nomination for Mayor. He announced, however, his willingness to support a fusion ticket to cut out the waste, extravagance and graft in the city government under Tammany rule.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 19. -- William Carlson, 33 years old, of 164 Bloomfield Avenue, Bloomfield, formerly a butler in the South Orange home of Orville G. Drake, a stock broker with New York offices at 74 Trinity Place, was arrested in Watsessing Park here this morning after, it is charged, he had threatened to kidnap and kill 2-year-old Orville G. Drake Jr. if the child's father refused to pay $8,000 for his son's protection.
Jersey City defeated Albany, 5 to 4, at West Side Park in Jersey City yesterday and broke a five-game losing streak.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP). -- An unqualified assertion that no share of the fees received by appointees of Federal Judge Harold Louderback went to him was put forward by the defense today in pressing the campaign of the California jurist for acquittal by the Senate of impeachment charges.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- President Roosevelt, pursuing the same humane tactics that have bewildered the bonus army since it arrived here last week to demand payment of their adjusted service certificates, received today a committee of three of their leaders and conversed with them for thirty-five minutes, while 1,000 others remained outside on Pennsylvania Avenue.

Preferring Sing Sing prison to the rigorous life of the Queens County jail, Harry Murch, 16-yearold slayer of his playmate, Willie Bender, 12, induced his counsel and parents late yesterday afternoon to drop an effort to obtain a stay of execution of sentence pending appeal.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- The threat of bankruptcy which has been hanging for several months over the Middle West Utilities Company, largest of the "Insull" holding companies, was definitely removed today when an agreement was reached by bankers, representatives of the noteholders and the general creditors contemplating eventual reorganization.
Home Art Protected. It is the aim of the newly organized Advance American Art Commission to defend the legitimate interests of the American artist against outsiders.
MANCHESTER, N.H., May 19. -- The Amoskeag Manufacturing Company closed its plant today after employes of two of its mills walked out in a dispute over wages. The shut-down throws 7,500 out of work.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The appointment of another "practical man" today as a Federal administrator, and the foreshadowed selection of another in the same category, served further to persuade those who have reared the ascendancy of educators in this administration that the President is drawing a distinction between planners and executives.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 19 (AP). -- Through a deposition taken in Paris on April 28, 1932, the testimony of Emil Harry Anderson, chauffeur, was read into the Jelke divorce trial record in Superior Court today in an effort to prove that F. Frazier Jelke of New York and Newport used "infamous language" to his wife, Eugenia Woodward Jelke, and in London struck her and raised a bump on her head.

The annual awards of the American Institute of Steel Construction for the three bridges adjudged to be the most beautiful built in the United States or Canada during the last year were announced yesterday.
Following is the statement of Samuel Seabury, declining to run for Mayor on the fusion ticket, but expressing willingness to help in the anti-Tammany campaign:

A consolidated mortgage, due $340,000, on 13-21 E. 22d St., was extended to May 10, 1936, at 5 per cent, until May 10, 1933, and at 4 per cent there after, in an agreement made between the Harlem Savings Bank and Fred Hirschhorn and another as trustees of the will of Charles Hirshon and Fred Hirschhorn.

Dinner invitations by the Borgias so often resulted fatally that the guests drew up wills along with their acceptances and the Borgias came down through history with extremely damaged reputations. Now in his "The Story of the Borgias," published by Dutton, L. Collison-Morley sifts the evidence and finds that while the Borgias undoubtedly deserved bad reputations their skill with poisons probably was overrated.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is a distinct effort to restrain one's enthusiasm over President Roosevelt's epoch-marking appeal to all the peoples of the world to unite their minds and their public policies for the advancement of the cause of international peace and for the restoration of prosperity and satisfaction to each and every nation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In regard to the controversy over the old reservoir site in Central Park, none of us will quarrel with tho idea of doing more and better for the "kids" than has hitherto been done. They ought to have been thought of two or three generations ago when Harlem was a village and vacant lots were cheap and plentiful.

AMHERST, Mass., May 19. -- Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War in the Wilson administration, in an address today to the undergraduate body of Amherst College urged that "some form of parliamentary responsibility" be observed in "these days when Congress has bundled up and passed over to a single person more power than any man ever had before who has walked the earth."

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Arthur E. Morgan, president of Antioch College, has been appointed by President Roosevelt to be chairman of the Tennessee Valley Power Authority, the supervisory body which is to direct the development of Muscle Shoals.

Nine election Inspectors who pleaded guilty to neglect of duty at the November election were fined a total of $1,950 yesterday and received suspended sentences of thirty days in jail by Supreme Court Justice Daniel V. McNamee. The court warned them that the slightest infraction of the election laws in the future would require the defendants to serve their workhouse terms.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With the promulgation of new deals in governmental affairs, might it not at this time, with the vacation season approaching, be advisable to attempt one in behalf of the public in the matter of accommodations in our national parks?
WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Movements of vessels follow. All dates are May 18, unless specified.

Confer on Fall Mail-Order Prices. Indications were seen yesterday that the prices to prevail in the Fall catalogues of the mail-order houses will show an advance. Conferences on the price questions of at least one leading mail-order concern were held yesterday, but definite decisions have yet to be made, it was said.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Drastic limitations on proposed railroad reorganization for the protection of labor were written into the Administration's Bill today before it was reported out of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee.

BERLIN, May 19. -- The conference of Germany's international creditors called to consider the German capacity to pay approximately 727,000,000 marks annually [the mark is worth about 27.2 cents at current exchange] on a total for- eign indebtedness of nearly 20,000,000,000 marks has been postponed from May 26 until May 29.

There will be a number of closings among the local theatrical offerings after tonight's performances. Chief among them is Noel Coward's play, "Design for Living," which has run seventeen weeks. The others are "Twentieth Century," closing after 152 performances; "Pinafore" and "Trial by Jury," after a fortnight's revival, and "Three-Cornered Moon," which ran a bit over nine weeks.

BOWIE, Md., May 19 (AP). -- A series of claiming races and one allowance affair formed the program at Bowie today. Below Cost, racing for the California sportsman, C.S. Bancroft, was winner of the fourth race. This was held as the best number of the afternoon and it found a half dozen under silks, with Uncle Donald the choice.
WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Senator Robinson of Arkansas, majority leader, said tonight that the Senate would be ready to adjourn on June 10.

LONDON, May 19. -- Sponsors of the Mount Everest climbing expedition, who might be expected to be the first to receive word from the climbers, have not been notified of any failure to reach the summit on the first attempt, as unofficially reported through news agencies.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- The annual stockholders' meeting of the Stewart-Warner Corporation was adjourned today to meet again on June 1 at Richmond, Va. The adjournment was agreed upon by C. B. Smith, president, and Oscar U. Zerk, a stockholder who is soliciting proxies in an attempt to replace the present management.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Organ- ized labor and capital joined today in suport of President Roosevelt's national industry recovery bill, the former signifying willingness to support a general manufacturers' sales tax if needed to make the program effective.
BOSTON, May 19 (AP). -- The Red Sox took a 3-to-0 lead in the first two innings of their game with the Tigers today, then had a relapse and dropped the tilt, 7 to 5.

BUFFALO, May 19. -- The closed staff policy prevalent "in many hospitals" was condemned today by Dr. Walter S. Goodale, superintendent of the Buffalo City Hospital, in an address before the annual conference of the Hospital Association of the State of New York.

Kid Chocolate, clever Cuban boxer, successfully defended his world's featherweight championship by defeating Seaman Tom Watson, holder of the British 126-pound championship, in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 19. -- Twenty of those who mill be graduated from the Naval Academy on June 1 will be commissioned Second Lieutenants in the Marine Corps, while eight others will be designated assistant paymasters, with the rank of ensign, in the Navy Supply Corps.

A nation-wide campaign to raise $2,000,000 in this country for the relief of Jews in Germany will be launched by the American Joint Distribution Committee, it was announced last night. The drive will be known as the German Relief Campaign of the American Joint Distribution Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Praising the national industry recovery plan as a move "against the com- mon enemy within," Bernard M. Baruch declared tonight that mobilization of public opinion was essential to success of the program.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Iron and steel exports from the United States increased during April by 25 per cent over the preceding month and were 73 per cent above the volume of shipments during the corresponding month last year, according to a Commerce Department report today.

Supposedly employed by a syndicate of cordial-shop operators, nine impostors have appeared in Federal court in the last several months as substitutes for sixty-six defendants in prohibition cases, David Marcus, Assistant United States Attorney, revealed yesterday after warrants had been issued for the arrest of two of the alleged proxies.
PARIS, May 19. -- "At the present time it would be a delusion to slow down our military preparations," Premier Edouard Daladier told the Senate today during a discussion of budgetary economies.

ST. LOUIS, May 19. -- A single by Pat Crawford, with one out and the bases full, in the tenth inning gave the Cardinals an 8-to-7 victory over the Giants today, providing a thrilling finish that delighted a crowd of 6,000.

ALBANY, May 19. -- Ice cream and other table ices are exempt from the State's sales tax, but are_taxable when served in ice cream sodas, according to the fourth instalment of the new regulations given out today by Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 19 (AP). -- It was triple integrals instead of triple threats as the cadets clashed with Harvard today in a battle of brains -- not brawn.

Eighteen horses, with Indigo receiving top weight of 158 pounds, have been named for the Bowman Steeplechase Handicap, feature of the United Hunts Racing Association's one-day Spring meeting, to be held this afternoon at the new Roslyn course.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- The Inland Steel Company announced today an increase of $3 a ton in the price of steel sheets for delivery in the third quarter of this year. At the same time local producers reported heavy orders for steel sheets for immediate delivery, which is expected to necessitate an early sharp advance in mill operations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The protagonists of repudiation of gold payments seem to forget, or perhaps deliberately overlook, the fact that the point in issue is solely and simply the question of whether or not the Government of the United States shall live up to its promise to pay its interest-bearing obligations in gold coin of the current standard of weight and fineness.
With the advent of improved fresh and salt water fishing, the local sporting goods stores reported an added volume of business this week.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP). -- Helping themselves to 17 safe hits, the White Sox opened a three-game series by defeating the Senators, 10 to 1, today.

Mrs. William H. Clyde gave a luncheon yesterday in the roof garden of the St. Regis for Miss Barbara Hall, who is to be married on May 31 to Southwick Victor. Other guests were: Mrs. Rodney Farson, the Misses Katrin R. Vietor, Mary D. Washburn, Margaret Robinson, Mary Dewart, Elizabeth B. Washburn, Penelope Hunter, Lois R. Barrett, Pauline Herrick and Miriam Hall.

Asserting that good radio prograins "will not appear out of thin air," Levering Tyson, director of the National Advisory Council on Radio in Education, suggested yesterday in his annual report submitted at a meeting of the council at the Waldorf-Astoria that a national radio institute be formed to produce and support entertainment to be broadcast in the United States.

The Central Park West and Columbus Avenue Association, with a membership including many owners of real estate in the neighborhood of Central Park, has joined the fight of more than forty civic, artistic and business organizations against Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy's plans for athletic fields on the Central Park reservoir site.

Over angry objections by Max D. Steuer, counsel for the defense, against "unfair tactics" and "poisoning the minds of the jury," George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, forced more evidence upon the record yesterday in support of his contention that Charles E. Mitchell defrauded the government out of his 1929 income tax by making a fake sale of 18,300 shares of National City Bank stock to his wife.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 19. -- Members of the Pennsylvania Bankers Association went on record today as opposed to any plan to guarantee or insure bank deposits, terming it "most unwise." Such a proposal is one of the features of the Glass-Steagall Banking Reform Bill, which is expected to come before the House of Representatives tomorrow.

After four weeks of discussion, the "United States Intercoastal Steamship Conference adopted yesterday a new agreement for the operation of freight ships of the twelve signatory lines, which it forwarded to the United States Shipping Board for approval. The terms, effective June 1, follow, in general those of the current conference agreement, according to Chairman Robert C. Thackara.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- General agreement on the desirability of enhancing and stabilizing the price of silver at the World Economic and Monetary Conference was announced by President Roosevelt and T.V. Soong, head of the Chinese mission to the conference, at the conclusion of their preliminary discussions here today.

Only two plays now on Broadway have the approval of the Catholic Theatre Movement, which prepares the Cardinal's white list, according to the Rev. Robert E. Woods, who spoke yesterday at the meeting of the Catholic Actors Guild at the Hotel Astor.

While the speculative markets seemed to be "expecting news," they were more or less disappointing yesterday to that section of Wall Street committed to the advance. Not only did the volume of business shrink, which disheartened the brokers, but operations for the rise seemed to be meeting considerable resistance.

Head Play, winner of the Preakness and second by a nose in the Kentucky Derby, and seven other 3-year-olds have been named for the $5,000 Wood Memorial, to be run today at Jamaica. The chestnut son of My Play and Red Head, which was purchased by Mrs. Silas B. Mason on the eve of the Kentucky Derby for $30,000, will endeavor to make more secure his claim to the 3-year-old championship.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- What was construed in administration circles as a veiled bid for recognition of Soviet Russia by the United States was contained in the reply that Mikhail Kalinin, president of the Soviet All-Union Central Executive Committee, made to President Roosevelt's message to sovereigns and Presidents of foreign nations on peace and disarmament.

RYE, N.Y., May 19. -- The Century Country Club completed its sweep of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub matches at the Westchester Country Club today by winning the Class B title play-off. Century previously had won Class A laurels.
WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Strict adherence to the regulations for exportation of gold has been enforced since the virtual embargo on gold payments was proclaimed by President Roosevelt.

First Round. Chocolate centred his attack on Watson's mid-section, crashing two hard lefts to the ribs to make the sailor retreat. Watson tried a light left to the face, but missed and had to take a right to the body in return.

The newest bizarre twist in the Ridley murder case -- the disclosure that the aged millionaire had been systematically robbed and tricked by Lee Weinstein, the secretary who was slain with him -- left investigators of the weird series of crimes divided last night.

IT'S high time to turn a glance up and down the college cinderpath. The "intercollegiates" at Cambridge are only a week away and that meet will come close to winding up the formal program, although the Oxford-Cambridge crowd will be over here for exercise and amusement in July.

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, May 19. -- The 55-year-old college president selected by President Roosevelt today to direct the vast Tennessee Valley development project is no mere theorist when it comes to taming wild lands and waters.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Perma- nent banking legislation came to the front in Congress today when Senator Glass opened a fight in the Senate for passage of his now celebrated bill and the House suddenly moved to take up its own banking measure tomorrow.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, May 19. -- The rebel forces that blocked the railway line between here and Quito yesterday appear to have been caught between superior government forces and this afternoon were falling back upon Riobamba after advancing in both directions from that midway town.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The wisdom of the administration's plans for naval retrenchment by retiring more than 500 officers, cutting the enlisted strength to 77,000 men and putting one-third of the combatant ships and aircraft in rotating reserve was challenged today by Rear Admiral Frank B. Upham, Chief of the Bureau of Navigation, in a statement before the House Naval Committee.

Cutting completely free from the Republican organization, former Representative F.H. La Guardia, fusion nominee for Mayor in 1929, declared last night that the leadership of the Republican party in city and State was ineffective and unsatisfactory, and asserted that it would be ridiculous and fatal to have the fusion candidate for Mayor picked by the present Republican leaders.
OKABENA, Minn., May 19 (AP). -- Two young women and two men bearing sub-machine guns robbed a bank of $2,500 today, endangering citizens' lives by scattering shots down the main street as they fled.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19. -- The Association of Junior Leagues of America at the closing sessions of its annual convention today heard the press characterized as "the most important influence" in the world at this time and adopted a resolution urging individual leagues to "undertake a program of civic and legislative instruction among themselves."

Price movements on local commodity exchanges were mixed yesterday. Silver, sugar, coffee, cocoa, silk and wool tops closed higher, while rubber and raw hides were lower. Except in the case of silver, fluctuations were narrow. Trading volumes were restricted.

PEARY LODGE, Greenland, May 19. -- As Spring comes to Peary Lodge the temperature is above freezing again for almost the first time since Autumn. The snow is disappearing rapidly and the upper part of the house is again in sight.

The Union Club, one of the oldest and most exclusive social organizations in this city, officially closed its clubhouse at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street last night, with a fare-well dinner and entertainment, attended by 400 members. In August the club plans to move into its new clubhouse at 701 Park Avenue, at Sixty-ninth Street.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 19. -- The elimination of Eddie Driggs, two-time winner of the event, and Jarvis Hicks Jr., co-medalist, featured the first and second match-play rounds of the annual Garden City Golf Club invitation tournament today.

PARIS, May 19. -- Many pointed and embarrassing questions were put to the Daladier government today in the Chamber of Deputies. When they are answered, as they will be by the end of next week, the world will know what France thinks about the great problems of the day and what policies she plans to pursue.

The improvement in business conditions that began in late March extended through April and the first half of May, according to the monthly report yesterday of the conference of statisticians in industry of the National Industrial Conference Board.

Four alternative ways or raising the money needed for the proposed public works program have been suggested by Mr. DOUGLAS, Director of the Budget. Three of them depend largely on an increase of income taxes, not in the upper brackets, where the surtaxes already go as high as 55 per cent, but in the normal rates.

Blanche E. Childs, welfare worker and conductor of the Bernadette Home at 306 West 109th Street, from which she and her thirty lodgers were evicted "Wednesday, pleaded not guilty to a grand larceny charge yesterday before Magistrate Brandt in West Side Court.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 19. -- By coming home in 36, two under par, Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches scored a 78 over the Englewood Golf Club course today to lead a field of seventy-five starters in a one-day competition of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association.
WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 17:

After creditors of the National Surety Company had met yesterday in the law offices of Lippman, Kleban Bernstein at 280 Madison Avenue, announcement was made that an appeal would be taken from the decision of Supreme Court Justice Valente, who granted the application of George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, to rehabilitate the company.

Telephone service to the Lehigh Valley, Erie and Jersey Central Railroad offices was almost completely cut off and service between Manhattan and Jersey City wag impaired when a pneumatic drill with which employes of the New York Steam Company were attempting to drain a manhole at Cortlandt and Washington Streets yesterday morning pierced a cable conduit, the New York Telephone Company announced.

Since Three Point Two is a non-intoxicating beverage, there was no good reason why it shouldn't be served at a bar, as are milk, coffee, tea, soda and other mild and peaceful drinks. Commissioner MULROONEY, with his characteristic tolerant common sense, points out that the real objection to the old-time saloon, improperly conducted, didn't spring from the bar but from the "back room."

For the six weeks from April 1 to the middle of May the North American Company's utility subsidiaries had an electric output of only 2 3/4 per cent less than in the same period of 1932, Frank L. Dame, president, says in his quarterly letter to stockholders.

In Mr. BARUCH'S address at Washington last evening he pointed out certain analogies between the War Industries Board, of which he was the head, and the Recovery Bill now before Congress. Describing himself as the "Ancient Mariner" of the first voyage into the uncharted sea of Government control of industry, he asserts that the great principle to be established and followed is "enlightened cooperation."

Reflecting the substantial improvement that has taken place in the municipal bond market in the last fortnight, new bonds in the amount of $11,470,777 will come up for award next week. This figure compares with this week's revised total of $7,727,760 and the weekly average for the year to date of $10,758,452.
BALTIMORE, May 19 (AP). -- Charley Devens had too much on the ball for Baltimore today and the Newark Bears scored their first victory out of three starts in the series by a count of 11 to 3.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 19. -- Timothy J. Callahan, vice president of the Commercial Trust Company of Jersey City, plunged to his death here early today from the window of his room on the tenth floor of the Hotel Ambassador. He was here to attend the annual convention of the New Jersey Bankers Association, of which he was a member.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 19. -- Continuing his long series of ring triumphs, the brown gelding Knight Bachelor tonight added to his successes the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall $1,000 championship stake for single-harness horses over 14.2 hands, which featured the third session of the annual Atlantic City Horse Show.
Arrangements were made yesterday for the sale of a membership in the New York Stock Exchange at $150,000, the same price as the last previous transaction, effected on Wednesday.
Leasing of buildings in the midtown section of Manhattan continues to feature the real estate market.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt expressed her satisfaction yesterday at the large sale of tickets for the May Ball to be held on Monday evening at the Seventh Regiment Armory for the benefit of the rest rooms and canteens for unemployed girls, which she founded at 22 East Thirty-eighth Street and 247 Lexington Avenue.

Charles E. Richardson, vice president and treasurer of the Fox Film Corporation, was elected yesterday trustee in the bankruptcy proceedings of the Paramount Publix Corporation at a hearing of creditors before Henry K. Davis, Federal referee, in his offices at 140 Nassau Street.

DUBLIN, May 19. -- Osmond Thomas Grattan Esmonde, a member of the Cosgrave party in the Dail Eireann and a son of Sir Thomas Grattan Esmonde, was the central figure in a burlesque enacted today outside Leinster House, where the Dail meets.

The rally in the dollar that has been under way several days picked up speed and strength yesterday, that monetary unit advancing to the best price in three weeks. Sterling fell 4 1/2 cents in dollar valuation to $3.85 3/4, or more than 20 cents below its recent high.

The second in a series of food exhibitions in behalf of the sick poor in the various Allied Municipal Hospitals of Greater New York will be held this week at the 258th Field Artillery Armory, 26 West Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx. Leading distributers and manufacturers will display samples of their products.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 20 -- William J. Mingle, printing equipment engineer, founder and president of the William J. Mingle Company of New York, died suddenly yesterday from a heart attack at his home here, 27 Berwyn Street.
CINCINNATI, May 20 (AP) -- A seventh-inning rally by the Cincinnati Reds failed today and the long-hitting Phillies won a rain-spotted game, 7 to 6.

GENEVA, May 20 -- The disarmament conference, meeting today, brought out that the French and their allies are not alone in holding disarmament depends on how far the United States is willing to go in enforcing peace against an aggressor.

Some price increases continue to be announced in staple and semi-staple lines, with buyers willing to pay moderate advances, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. They are resisting those advances being made to take advantage of the present situation, however, the report adds, and where they feel the advance is considerable they are preferring to purchase when and as they require such goods.

PARIS, May 18 -- The midseason sensation is Augusta Bernard's new tubular silhouette that elongates the figure from high narrow shoulders to a point about twelve inches from the ground, where grouped godets or pleats create a new back movement.

While manufacturers of consumers' products were enabled to reduce slightly the percentage ratio of distribution costs to net sales volume last year, the majority of them increased the percentage of their advertising and sales promotion, according to an analysis of the distribution costs of $12 manufacturers conducted by the Association of National Advertisers, Inc., in cooperation with the National Association of Cost Accountants and released yesterday.
Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Levy had a home last night. It was only the workhouse, but at least they could get food and could sleep in what was comfort compared to the hard seats of park benches.

KENT, Conn., May 20 -- The Kent School's rowing season, except for the entry of the first crew in the Royal Henley Regatta in July, came to an end today with two races between the second Kent crew, the fourth form crew and two eights representing Manhattan College.

A NEW chapter on disarmament opened last week. In a world-wide appeal, President Roosevelt set forth the views of the United States. Chancellor Hitler,in a speech to the Reichstag, presented the position of Germany.

MILTON, wasn't it, who wrote of every flower "that sad embroidery wears"? The phrase turns up unsolicited to a visitor wandering through the really superb exhibition of "Plant Forms in Ornament" at the Metropolitan Museum.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- President Roosevelt today proclaimed May 22 as National Maritime Day, the first steamer to cross the Atlantic Ocean having departed from Savannah, Ga., on that date in 1819. The President's proclamation follows:

ROME, May 20 -- In a determined effort to revive his four-power pact, on which Italy still bases her hopes for permanent peace in Europe, Premier Mussolini held conferences today with the British and French Ambassadors and with Captain Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Cabinet Minister.

HAVANA, May 20 -- Rural Guards late this afternoon stopped all west-bound traffic over the Central Highway at Artemisa in Pinar del Rio Province, forty-five miles west of Havana, lending color to reports that an expedition carrying arms and ammunition had landed during the past twenty-four hours at the small port of Las Martinas on the north coast.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 20 -- A class of 435 midshipmen will be graduated from the Naval Academy on June 1 and, should Congress enact legislation as expected, it will be the first to receive degrees from the institution.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Statesmen, educators and even those most insistent upon economy are relieved at the subsidence of the hysteria with which all public expenditures were attacked indiscriminately because the urgency of the need for retrenchment came upon us so suddenly.

In the interests of the Salvation Army's current united appeal for $1,110,000 for the maintenance of emergency and institutional relief activities here, a box luncheon will be held on Tuesday at the Ashford Hill convalescent and fresh air camp maintained by the Salvation Army at Greenburgh, N.Y. Miss Evangeline Booth, Commander-in-Chief of the Salvation Army in the United States, and Amelia Earhart will be guests of honor.

BOWIE, Md., May 20 (AP) -- Wise Daughter, which was one of the outstanding juveniles during the Winter racing season, added to her triumphs to earn her fifth score and her second victorious stake engagement in Maryland when she took the measure of the best youngsters that could be mustered to oppose her in the seventh running of the Bowie Kindergarten Stakes today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 20 -- A well-balanced Gorton High School track team, with 46 points to its credit, today won the twenty-eighth annual Westchester Inter- scholastic Athletic Association meet. The Yonkers school placed men in all except one of the eleven scheduled events.

EVANSTON, Ill., May 20 -- Willis Ward, 196 pounds of coordinated power and speed, staked Michigan to a working margin of 18 points and the rest of the Wolverine team rounded up enough to win the thirty-third Western Conference track and field championship today at Dyche Stadium before about 10,000 specators.

In two articles in The Journal of the American Museum of Natural History, ROBERT CUSHMAN MURPHY, Curator of Oceanic Birds, assembles the known facts concerning ambergris, which he calls floating gold. The beaches of the Seven Seas have been searched for it.
