ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 20 -- "Merry Mount," an opera in three acts and six scenes, with music by Dr. Howard Hanson, American composer, and libretto by Richard L. Stokes, had its world premiere performance here this evening in the sixth and last concert of the May festival series, the fortieth of these annual events.

OMAHA, Neb., May 17. -- The farm States are beginning to take notice of the fact that fortune has been trying to smile upon them for the past two or three weeks. The smile is still somewhat restrained, perhaps, but it is unmistakable and has been growing broader day by day.

The All-Jewish team defeated the All-Stars, 5 to 3, in an exhibition soccer game at Starlight Park before a crowd of 1,000 yesterday. The score was 2 -- 2 at half time. Sacks tallied three times for the winners.

PROFESSOR SWAIN remarks, with some obvious exaggeration, that the first years of the 1890s were "the most unlucky in modern history" to be born in because "a large part of the men born then were later butchered in Flanders or Poland."

Promotions of sports wear, old prints and pictures and new coats at off-prices were outstanding in local retail trade during the week, according to analyses by shoppers of the Meyer-Both Retailing Reporting Bureau.

A movement begun last Fall by the American Institute, one of the oldest scientific organizations in the country, brought 1,000 boys and girls from high schools in all parts of the city to the American Museum of Natural History yesterday for a discussion of matters that in most cases would have taxed severely the knowledge of their parents.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- To Princeton's varsity crew today went the oldest sprint race trophy that American rowing has, the Childs Cup, by right of a calm, well-measured Henley distance victory over the eights of Pennsylvania and Columbia.

Envy on the part of other French journalists is vainly trying to choke the cry rising in ever greater volume in L'Ami du Peuple and Figaro that their illustrious proprietor, M. FRANCOIS COTY, reform, save and run France. NAPOLEON I was born at Ajaccio in 1769.

With the volume of business on the Stock Exchange amounting to only a little more than half of that of the previous Saturday, the market yesterday provided Wall Street with dull entertainment. Price movements were narrow except in the last half-hour when the general list pointed sharply downward simultaneously with the unsettlement in wheat and cotton.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 20 Competitions for the rich championship stakes featured the closing session tonight of the second annual Atlantic City horse show in the Auditorium.

From the point of view that chemistry is only at the beginning of what it can do for health through nutrition there appear no problems of unemployment in the profession, and the science of chemistry, therefore, should be "increasingly emphasized," Dr. Henry C. Sherman, head of the chemistry department of Columbia University, declared yesterday on receiving the medal of the American Institute of Chemists, awarded annually for outstanding service to chemistry.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 20 -- Shenandoah Maid, a pray mare owned by Ernest Gossweiler of Pelham, carried off the honors in the hunters event, outstanding competition at the fifth annual Brush Farm show on the Brush Farm's grounds today.

Joseph W. Harriman, the indicted banker who disappeared Friday from a private sanitarium supposedly with suicidal intent, stabbed himself twice over the heart yesterday in the Old Orchard Inn, at Roslyn, L.I., where the police had found him a few hours earlier.

DUBLIN, May 19 -- The character of the Free State's recent budget, political observers say, portends another general election this year. Taken in conjunction with the action of the government this week in postponing the local election until November, all indications clearly point in the direction of a second appeal to the people by President de Valera in the Fall.
MAXWELL ANDERSON, whose play "Both Your Houses" won the Pulitzer Prize, is busily engaged at Paramount on a story which will present Dorothea Wieck in her American debut.

GENEVA, May 20 (AP) -- Without definitely committing himself, the delegate of Bolivia, Dr. Costa Durels, gave the impression to the League Council tonight at a public session that Bolivia would soon accept the Council's recommendations for settlement by arbitration of the Gran Chaco dispute with Paraguay.

The long-awaited Spring push of the Yankees which finally seemed to be on its way the past week ran into a difficulty at the Stadium yesterday. Fine left-handed pitching that spun off the long, lean arm of Wallace Hebert, a tall, young southpaw, bewildered the champions and astonished a crowd of 25,000.

Fifteen persons, including six women, were sentenced to jail by Magistrate Anthony Burke in Morrisania court yesterday for participating in a demonstration in front of a home relief station at 440 East 149th Street, the Bronx. Another got a suspended sentence.

HELSINGFORS, May 20 -- Dr. Klepper, former Prussian Minister of Finance and a prominent Socialist, who sought refuge in Finland from the persecutions of the Nazi regime, is now threatened with extradition since the German Government wants him on a charge of misappropriation of public funds for financing enterprises hostile to the Reich's policy.

The difficulties that have been experienced in recent years in financing mortgages and the discussions that have lately been held as to means of financing public works programs have directed attention to the methods employed abroad for meeting financial problems of this character.

Philip Cooperman, who was promoted to the varsity from the jayvee squad only a fortnight ago, hurled his second straight victory for City College at the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday when he set back Drexel Institute of Philadelphia, 5 -- 2.

FIFTY years ago -- on May 24, 1883 -- Brooklyn Bridge was opened for traffic and the process begun which has since deprived Manhattan Island of its true insular character. Up to the time this first bridge across the East River was completed the only way to reach New York City -- as it then existed, for the Greater City did not arrive until 1898 -- was by boat.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 20 -- Alexander Dean, who will be in charge of the productions of the Yale Department of Drama next year when Professor Allardyce Nicoll of England succeeds Professor George Pierce Baker as chairman of the department, said today that the course in production in the Yale Department of Drama will be divided into two sections next year.

ROME, May 19 -- Italians feel that President Roosevelt's message and Chancellor Hitler's speech to the Reichstag, the one following hard on the heels of the other, have done much to dispel that atmosphere of war that during the last few months had by almost imperceptible degrees been seizing hold of the European mentality.

CLEVELAND, May 20 -- Speaking before a joint meeting of the Associated Harvard Clubs and the Cleveland Chamber of Commerce today. Walter Lippmann discussed forces and policies which, he said, were putting the United States "in a position to make the largest and most fundamental contribution possible" to the economic stability of the world.

ANTWERP, May 10 -- Harry B. Talbot, construction superintendent of the Antwerp vehicular tunnel under the Scheldt, has been made a Knight of the Order of Leopold II; Thomas Clarke, assistant construction superintendent received the Order of the Golden Palm, and Joseph Weaver, assistant construction superintendent, the Order of the Crown.

GENEVA, May 19 -- Those who have been following the disarmament manoeuvres here for years feel that the problem -- which to them has made great progress in past years -- is now rapidly and hopefully getting down into the remaining essentials.

General JOHNSON, who is indicated as the President's choice as administrator, or "dictator," of the Industrial Recovery Law, made a shrewd observation about that measure. All depends, he said, upon the way in which it is administered. " Bad administration "could spoil the best bill in the world, "while good administration could make "a bad bill workable."

Patrolman James Cruise of Traffic D. assisted by an emergency squad crew and the marine division, played hide-and-seek yesterday with Jimmy Papst, 14-year-old west side boy, under the North River pier at Thirty-ninth Street. After four hours and still no Jimmy the police summoned the boy's father and his magic voice lured the lad from his hiding place.

THE Austro-American Institute of Education has announced "the inauguration this year of a comprehensive scheme of permanent music courses in Vienna for the special use of English-speaking musicians and musical students. Some of the courses, according to the prospectus, have already begun; others are beginning this week.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., May 17. -- Oklahoma's tax situation is a badly scrambled omelet, with great j uncertainty prevailing today as to just how much food will be left for the boarders when the dish is served to the taxpayers.

LONDON, May 20 (Canadian Press) -- The touring West Indies team scored 309 runs in the first innings against the Marylebone Cricket Club at Lord's today. The game was played on a good wicket while a large crowd watched under clear skies.

An increase in residential building contracts in the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains is reported by L. Seth Schnitman, chief statistician of the F.W. Dodge Corporation. This advance during the first two weeks of May represented an increase of 36 per cent over the first half of April.

HAVANA, May 15 -- Orders issued to censors of the Department of the Interior now supervising the publication of all newspapers in Havana since the recent removal of military authority show plainly that the rigid censorship to which the press of Cuba is subjected has not been relaxed.

MOSCOW, May 19 -- The Soviet Government will send more than 2,000 persons on scientific expeditions to the Arctic this Summer, but none of the groups will aim to reach the North Pole. Preparations for the departure of the biggest expedition of 130 persons are already afoot.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- International agreements for total disarmament, with drastic cuts meanwhile in appropriations for the army and navy, were urged today in nation-wide petitions presented at the White House and in addresses delivered tonight by Senator Borah, Miss Katherine Devereaux Blake of New York, Alma Gluck and Dr. Harlow Shapley under the auspices of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom.

Mr. Durante Denies It. To the Dramatic Editor: Hey! What is this stuff I read in your paper about me, Jimmy Durante, being an offshoot of this guy Dante? Don't never let no guy make no crack about there bein' another Durante back in 1265 who changed his name to Dante... why, the injustification of it... the irony of the thing!

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- A revised form of the Administration's Home Mortgage Relief Bill was favorably reported today to the Senate Banking Committee by a subcommittee which has been studying it for several weeks. The Banking Committee will meet Monday to consider the bill.

THERE are still many controvertial points about the career and writings of Edgar Allan Poe, and in "The Mind of Poe and Other Studies" Killis Campbell takes up some of these points, throwing fresh light on them and making certain matters clearer.

Expressing the view that the greatest contribution that the United States can make to world recovery and world stability is to "recover and stabilize herself," says Dr. Royal Meeker in an article in June Current History. He discusses the problems to be dealt with at the World Economic Conference and lays particular stress on a complete revision of the domestic money-banking-credit system of every country.

Unless the new Italian liner Conte Di Savoia is delayed by fog or stormy weather, according to her noon position yesterday, she will pass the Ambrose Lightship at 10 A.M. tomorrow and make the voyage of 4,061 miles from Genoa, including calls at Villefranche and Gibraltar, in 5 days and 20 hours, at an average speed of 28 knots, clipping sixteen hours off her schedule time of six and a half days.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The forward movement of business activity, although somewhat slower than in previous weeks, continued during the week ended on May 13, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

MILESTONES in the career of Fannie Brice hinge around the New Amsterdam Roof. It was here that the youthful Fannie first presented herself as a candidate for the chorus in one of Cohan and Harris musical shows, only to be shown the door and none too politely at that, according to Miss Brice.
CHICAGO, May 20 (AP) -- Coffers of thirty-three State treasuries held four and a half million dollars collected in taxes since beer was legalized April 7.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The "die-hard" element in the bonus camp at Fort Hunt, where more than 2,800 veterans demanding payment of their bonus certificates are encamped, out-manoeuvred the "conservatives" this afternoon and forced adjournment of the mass meeting called to formulate plans for evacuation of the camp on Monday morning.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letters you have published recently in relation to the law requiring the return to the banks of all gold coin, bullion and gold certificates held by American citizens and the power given to the President by Congress to reduce the value of the gold content of the dollar in his discretion have been very interesting and instructive.

STEADY growth of passenger travel and express traffic on the airlines operated in this country and to Canada and South America is indicated again by the report for the first quarter of 1933 issued by the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America.

Ideal Spring weather has inspired the planning of various garden days, when many estates in Long Island and Westchester, as well as several notable penthouse gardens and small gardens at the rear of city residences, will be open to the public.
Twenty-one gunners came to the traps of the Bergen Beach Gun Club, on the shore of Jamaica Bay, yesterday, and the field was led by L.J. Olds, who broke fifty straight targets.

After weeks of preparation, in which the various committees have received the cooperation of many persons in society and the theatrical and radio worlds, plans have been completed for the May Ball, to be held tomorrow night in the historic Seventh Regiment Armory, at Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street.

THE Supreme Court's decision in what is called "the Chicago radio case" is considered in radio circles to be of far-reaching importance to the broadcasters and to the public. Senator Dill heralds the decision as "putting teeth in the radio act."
I TAKE the floor to protest against the brutal and unwarranted treatment of the nationals of Jewish extraction in Germany by Adolf Hitler.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 20 -- Army defeated Manhattan College on the track today, 68 1/2 to 57 1/2. McGeough of Manhattan was a double winner, taking both the 100-yard and 220-yard dashes.

A sudden electric storm driven by a fifty-one-mile northwest gale climaxed a day of record warmth last night and caused the death of one man and the destruction of thirty-six farm animals in New Jersey, as well as of hundreds of trees in the metropolitan area.

HENRY GARAT, who makes his American talking picture debut at the Music Hall this week in "Adorable," comes of an acting family. His father was a boulevard comedian and his mother was a prima donna in the Opera Comique.
LONDON, May 19 -- The British Government is watching with unconcealed interest to see what kind of delegation President Roosevelt will send to the World Economic Conference.

IT has been estimated that if Richardson's virtuous heroine had actually penned the voluminous diary attributed to her in the story or "Pamela, or Virtue Rewarded," she would have had no time in which to fear seduction. But to a man like Richardson the limitations of time were no obstacle to accomplishment.

The brighter prospects now beginning to face retail trade in this country should not cause merchants to forget the "painful lessons" of the last three years, H. Gordon Selfridge Jr., partner in the Self-ridge retail enterprises of London and managing director of the Self-ridge Provincial Stores, Ltd., said during the week in an interview with a TIMES reporter.

EMPORIA, Kan., May 18. -- It is significant that the administration was able to loosen the cost-of-production amendment from the woof and warp of its farm-relief inflation bill and heave it out into oblivion with only a perfunctory struggle on the part of its backers.

IN the Gay Nineties if one passing an isolated farm heard the clamor and excited voices from a ringside, the yells from a football game or the spooky voices of a mystery drama, the house might have been doomed as haunted.

THE author of "His Monkey Wife" has, in this later novel, chosen a subject of much wider appeal and treated it from an imaginative and hypothetical viewport which has, though be discliams it, a strong scientific and historical backing.

NEW LONDON, Conn., May 20 -- The cornerstone of Windham House, the first dormitory given to Connecticut College by a county of the State, was laid this afternoon with impressive ceremonies in the presence of a large gathering of students, faculty and visitors from this and other States.

GROTON, Mass., May 20 -- Not as First Lady but simply as a parent, Mrs. Roosevelt came here today and saw the Groton crew win from Belmont Hill School a mile race on the Nashua River, with her son, Franklin Jr., stroking the Groton boys to victory.

SOME eleven months ago, after years of yearning, conflict broke out between Bolivia and Paraguay in the unmeasured wilderness of the Chaco Boreal. Three months later Peru and Colombia became involved in armed conflict in the upper reaches of the Amazon.

BERLIN, May 20 -- The verbal warfare between the Hitler Cabinet in Germany and the Dollfuss Cabinet in Austria over the question of whether Austria -- forbidden to join Germany by the Treaty of Versailles -- is to be coordinated with Germany through the agency of the National Socialist party, grew in intensity today.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 18 -- Parliament in its last days is battling valiantly over the very thin issue of redistribution. After each decennial census there is some necessary readjustment in the representation of the Provinces in the House of Commons, and some alterations in the boundary lines of constituencies.

TROY, N.Y., May 20 -- Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute defeated City College of New York in a track meet today by 75 to 51. Panzarella of the home team set new institute records for the discus throw and shot-put.

DETROIT, May 20 (AP) -- After three years of shrinking buying, the $2,000,000,000 automobile inchasing of passenger cars since the dustry reports increased public purbanking holiday and finds the out- look brighter.

THE response of United Air Lines to the new American Airways service between New York and Chicago is going to be prompt. This week, perhaps tomorrow, according to Philip G. Johnson, president, new schedules between New York and San Francisco, with radical reductions in flying time, will be instituted.

The claim of Mrs. Silas B. Mason's Head Play to the 3-year-old championship received a jolting setback at Jamaica yesterday when the Preakness winner ran third in a field of four, clearly and decisively beaten by the Catawba Stable's Mr. Khayyam and H.C. Phipps's De Valera.

Admiral Togo, the little Japanese spaniel that former Mayor Walker left behind when he went to Europe, returned to public life yesterday by winning a prize in the annual pet show at the Hamilton Place playground, 141st Street and Hamilton Place.

Copyright, 1933, By The Associated Press. WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Welcoming his assignment to direct the Tennessee Valley project as an opportunity to make a real addition to national development, Arthur E. Morgan said today he saw possibilities of its "aiding greatly in keeping the proper balance between city and rural population."

Is the National Socialist Government planning to reintroduce the goose-step into German education? It has already announced the reorganization of the schools of the Third Reich on a Nazi basis. Germany has for so long been a leader in the field of education that the world cannot but be interested in the fate of her school system.

BOSTON, May 17. -- In 1925 the Legislature of New Hampshire created a board of publicity, the members to serve without pay and to have $25,000 a year to spend. In 1931 the Legislature abolished this board and substituted for it a State Development Commission, also of three unpaid members, for which a somewhat smaller appropriation was made.

BROADCASTING from the Century of Progress constitutes one of the biggest "outside-the-studio" jobs ever attempted, with more than 150 circuits scattered throughout the fair grounds and the various exposition buildings to relay a picture of the show in words and music.

BERLIN, April 27, 1933 ALTHOUGH the Staatsoper's new production of "Rienzi," exhibited for the first time some time ago, was planned many months ago simply and solely as part of the Wagner memorial celebrations, the chance of giving the opera a bit of new publicity by placing it on a "timely" political construction was too good for some people to resist.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Warning to the American people not to expect the impossible of the World Economic and Monetary Conference and not to forget that domestic policy is of paramount importance, our foreign trade being only a small percentage of this country's entire commerce, was given tonight by Raymond Moley, Assistant Secretary of State and one of President Roosevelt's principal advisers on world affairs.

HAMBURG, May 20 -- This free city of Germany had two celebrations today. It installed in office Karl Kaufmann, the new Governor sent to it by the Hitler administration, and it welcomed to its port the new United States liner Washington.

PARIS, May 19 -- The present situation in Europe presents the beginning of dangers for France, but the great powers still have full means of control, and nothing is so tragic as the French Nationalists would have the world believe.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 20 -- With his speedy filly, Barn Swallow, never in danger of defeat, Colonel E.R. Bradley today added the Kentucky Oaks to his string of turf triumphs, climaxed this year by his fourth Kentucky Derby victory.

A belief that society needs trained women and that education should develop their individual powers is one of the predispositions with which Dr. Eugene A. Colligan approaches his prospective task as head of the largest women's collegs in the world.

SUMMIT, N.J., May 20 -- Taking two prizes in the class for jumpers, Miss Phyllis Clarke, daughter of Mrs. Isabella Clarke of Short Hills, was the outstanding entrant in the annual horse and dog show of the Kent Place School for Girls this afternoon, on the Union County Park Commission Grounds, Glenside Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The American Jewish Congress opened its emergency session here today with an appeal to President Roosevelt to make known publicly the government's attitude toward "discrimination and intolerance" practiced against the Jews of Germany by the Hitler government.
HOLLYWOOD SERGEI M. EISENSTEIN'S long-awaited silent film, "Thunder Over Mexico," reached the preview screen this week to be viewed by the townspeople with mixed, if unrestrained, emotions.
A judge granting a moratorium on a mortgage suit violates the Federal and State Constitutions as well as his own oath, according to Supreme Court Justice William Barman Slack.

GENEVA NORMAN DAVIS in London seeing MacDonald and Simon... Norman Davis in Paris talking with Daladier, Herriot, Paul-Boncour... in Berlin meeting with Hitler. Hindenburg, von Neurath... back from conferring with Mussolini in Rome ... Norman Davis in Geneva, in touch with every one, including Litvinoff, the Foreign Minister of the unrecognized power.

BUDAPEST, May 20 -- Professor Bleyer of Budapest University, whose students violently demonstrated against him a few days ago for his speech in the Hungarian Parliament in behalf of the German minority, was wounded in the forehead and arm today in a duel over the same incident.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Persons here familiar with the German official viewpoint were inclined to regret the campaign for a $2,000,000 relief fund for Jews in Germany, styling it another step in the series of misunderstandings about the Jewish situation in Germany which, they assert, has swept this country.

LONDON, May 4 THE spectator of a biographical play is on the horns of a dilemma. His foreknowledge of the play's subject is either too great or too small, and it is the weakness of biographical drama that it imposes this difficulty upon him.

PITTSBURGH, May 18 -- The Pittsburgh Flood Commission and business leaders of the district supporting it have received assurance from army engineers that the plan for storage reservoirs on the headwaters of the Ohio River as a means of flood control will be studied for possible inclusion in the Roosevelt public works program.

Frederick George Lueders of Summit, N.J., president of George Lueders Co., oil importers at 427 Washington Street, who died on May 4, left a New York estate valued at about $291,000 in cash and securities, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court.

The anterior lobe of the pituitary gland, situated at the base of the skull, is the master of human personality, Dr. A.S. Blumgarten, chief of the endocrine department, Lenox Hill Dispensary, told the Mental Hygiene Conference of Supervisors and Nurses of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service last week at 99 Park Avenue.

LONDON ONE of the most difficult problems of an autobiographer must be that of hitting upon a title which is not only so striking as to be easily remembered but so distinctive as to suggest the outstanding features of his book.

A two-day conference of leaders in relief work, described as one of the most important meetings from the viewpoint of welfare agencies to be held this year, was announced yesterday by the Welfare Council of New York City.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Eastern longs were again on the selling side of wheat today on the Board of Trade and liquidation broadened. Small pyramids were toppled over, and prices dropped 2 1/8 to 2 1/4 cents a bushel before support was sufficient to check the decline.

THE story of the thrilling first ten days of the Roosevelt administration is told by James Grey in "Ten Days: A Crisis in American History," to be published soon by Duffield Green. Besides telling what was done in those ten busy days, Mr. Grey ventures some prophecies as to whither our new President's program will lead this country, and perhaps the world.

ALBANY, May 20 -- A protest against his celebration of a "Pontifical Mass" at a meeting of the Catholic congress to be held in Philadelphia in October was mailed today to the Right Rev. James DeWolf Perry, presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church and Bishop of Rhode Island, by the Protestant Episcopal Laymen's Association in the Diocese of Albany.

SHANGHAI, April 25 -- Already the political pot in China is boiling and hissing, and dissension is rife concerning the National Congress of the Kuomintang, which is scheduled to open for a session of one week at Nanking on July 1.

THE arrest a few days ago of the alleged leader of an "international ring" of automobile thieves brought to public attention the campaign being waged all over the country to stamp out motor-car thefts. There is evidence that this form of racketeering is gradually being driven out, thanks to special Federal and State laws and to the vigilance of police agencies.

Commenting upon the obituary notices of Dr. Felix Adler, founder of the Ethical Culture Society, who died April 25, the current issue of The Cornell Alumni News takes exception to published statements that Dr. Adler was "banished" from Cornell in 1876 for his radical views.

PARIS ONE of Hilaire Hiler's canvases recently shown at the George Petit Galleries is framed by strips of an old suitcase. You remember with what affection you contemplated your old suitcase and its patine of used labels.

Strength in the sugar futures market and steadiness in crude rubber were the features of yesterday's trading in local commodity exchanges, where all other staples followed the general trend in outside markets to lower levels. Cash prices were lower.

LONDON, May 20 -- The real purpose of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, in coming to London, it was learned tonight, is to obtain a British loan that would prevent a default by Germany on her private debts.

LISTENERS complain that the radio show is "too choppy." It is interrupted too often. There are too many fifteen-minute broadcasts and a listener no more than sits back to enjoy a program than it ends.

NEVER before have the galleries at the American Fine Arts Building looked as they are looking now. The Art Students League has moved downstairs for its fifty-sixth annual exhibition and the rooms present a sight not to be forgotten.

Mayor O'Brien indicated yesterday that he might reach a decision by the middle of the week on the controversy over the treatment of the thirty-four-acre site of the abandoned lower reservoir site in Central Park An earlier decision has been made impossible by the press of official business at City Hall.

BERLIN, May 19 -- The stony road that must be traveled by the new Germany on its way toward economic reconstruction is illuminated by two governmental rescripts, one addressed by Dr. Alfred Hugenberg, the Minister of Economics, to the Reich commissar in his domain, Herr Wagrener, and the other from Herr Wagoner to the Nazi shop organizations.

IN deference to the tradition established during its last term in office, when Meatless, Sugarless and other days and weeks of self-denial punctuated the procession of time, the Democratic party wasted little time in proclaiming its Bankless Week.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Current trends in governmental finances indicate a reduction in the deficit for the fiscal year ending June 30 by more than a billion dollars as compared with last year, when the excess of expenditures over receipts was $2,880,184,000.

Left temporarily without a candidate by the refusal of Samuel Seabury to run for Mayor, leaders of the anti-Tammany fusion movement discussed yesterday the advisability of trying to prevent further discussion of men to head their ticket for a period of thirty days.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES of April 30 printed the report of our study of diabetes mortality in New York City during the last thirty years, noting especially that no measurable rise in the rate among men had taken place, when allowance was made for growth and aging of the city's population, but that there had been an ominous increase among women.

THE volcanoes which erupted recently in the State of Vera Cruz, Mexico, and in Alaska, are in that belt of volcanic activity which engirdles intermittently the huge basin of the Pacific Ocean. This ring of volcanoes may be traced, on this side of the Pacific, from Cape Horn to Alaska, while on the other sides the cones are found in Japan, the East Indies, New Zealand, and other islands.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Secretary of State Hull indicated today that the American position on the British disarmament plan, which contains a consultative agreement, would be stated on Monday by Norman H. Davis, chief of the United States delegation at the Geneva Arms Conference.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 20 -- Miss Rosa W. Rieser, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Willy Rieser of 28 East Seventieth Street, New York, was crowned "queen" at the May Day festivities today at Pembroke College in Brown University.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 20. -- A thunderstorm which broke at dusk and was followed by rain throughout the evening dampened the colorful annual junior promenade at Smith College.

SEAMAN WATSON, the ocean-going bartender from Newcastle-on-Tyne, ran into a big blow at the Garden on Friday night. It was an ill wind from Cuba that did the damage to the former featherweight champion of the Royal Navy. In the tenth round it took him on the superstructure and blew him down to the lower deck. But he managed to make port in a damaged condition.

Signs of recovery in business, whether temporary or permanent, have become too numerous to be disputed. They reflect not only the recuperation which was to be expected after the "banking panic" had been dispelled. Almost without exception, indices of trade activity have lately been showing up distinctly better than in 1932.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Raymond Moley, Assistant Secretary of State, in his address tonight over the Columbia Broadcasting System on the World Economic Conference, spoke as follows:

A NUMBER of new gasolines, with a higher anti-knock rating, are expected to make their appearance in the metropolitan market shortly. Last week the Tide Water Oil Company introduced a new type of "lubricating gasoline," and the Standard Oil Company of New York announced that it was ready to market a new motor fuel.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Summer schools in Spain have ample opportunity for students, both intermediary and advanced, on many subjects. Every chance is given to Americans to participate in study and at the same time to see the country.

ROME, Sunday, May 21 -- After a secret session lasting two and one-half hours, in which Premier Mussolini discussed his plan for salvaging his four-power peace pact, the Fascist Grand Council recessed early this morning, to reconvene Monday evening, when the discussion will be resumed.

ORIENTAL motifs, interpreted with a light touch, are growing in favor for period interiors. Graceful flowers and figures on the walls, with pastel color tones in upholstery and hangings, furnish a fitting background for delicate furniture forms and the bright glazes of pottery accessories.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 20 -- The Brown University baseball team came out of the doldrums today and scored a surprising 6 -- 1 victory over Yale.

ONCE again this column starts with the phrase to the effect that there is a possibility. On the present occasion the idea is that "Strike Me Pink" may depart the metropolitan area early next month and hie to Chicago. Lew Brown conceded one day last week that he was thinking of it, with the Oriental Theatre in mind and a $2 top on the schedule.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 20 -- When the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America opens here Thursday the outstanding issue is expected by many of the leaders to be the overture sent up to it from the Presbytery of Philadelphia, attacking the Board of Foreign Missions.

WHILE a slightly slower pace was observed in retail trade during the week, sales continued to be quite satisfactory. The demand was still of a general character in the merchandise lines, with Summer apparel and home furnishings in the lead.

TIENTSIN, May 20 -- "I won't make Tientsin a smoking shambles like the environs of Shanghai last year; if the Japanese want to take the city they may do so," said Governor Yu Hsueh-chung today, in commenting on the threat to Tientsin.

MOSCOW, May 20 -- In today's Izvestia Karl Radek devotes himself to the question of the Chinese Eastern Railway, explaining just why the Soviet "is not deceiving China" in offering to sell it to Japan.

More than 1,000 young choristers, representing the Sunday schools of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, passed through the Children's Arch in the nave of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday to participate in the annual service for the presentation of the missionary offerings to the funds of the diocese.

Joseph Dillaway Sawyer, author and retired merchant and realtor, died yesterday at his residence, 224 Riverside Drive, after a week's critical illness of heart disease, with which he had been afflicted for five years. His age was 83. Five children survive: Joseph Sawyer of New Rochelle, Mrs. Ethel S. Williams of Cambridge, Mass., and Wesley D. Sawyer, Mrs. Lilla S. Robertson and Mrs. Mildred Ruttkay, all of Stamford, Conn.

The famous little yawl Dorade, which won the transatlantic race from Newport, R.I., to Plymouth, England, two years ago, left yesterday on another trip abroad. She moved away from City Island at 5 P.M. to go through Long Island Sound bound for Bergen, Norway.

Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer in the Bronx ordered the Board of Standards and Appeals yesterday to reconsider its rejection last January of a gasoline station permit to W. Todd Parsons of Morristown, N.J. Mr. Parsons charged that the board had granted such a permit for a plot across the street from his own to a concern represented by William F. Doyle, veterinarian, who was an early witness before the Hofstadter legislative committee.

IN the Chauncey Keep Memorial Hall of Field Museum the history of the ascent of man from the ape, and his division into many races, will be told by skeletons, brain cases, charts and the 100 pieces of sculpture done by Miss Hoffman. The statues dominate, not only because of their number but because of their quality.

ROSLYN, L.I., May 20 -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney's Spar carried off the honors in the major event as the United Hunts Racing Association dedicated its new course on the estate of the late Hugh Murray under perfect weather conditions today.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- More than one-fourth of the authorized strength of the Civilian Conservation Corps was enrolled by midnight of Wednesday, it was shown today in a recapitulation of the progress made in the President's plan to put 274,000 men to work in reforestation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 20 -- With Keith Brown setting the tempo by scoring a pair of magnificent victories, Yale downed Harvard, 73 1/2 to 61 1/2, in their fortieth annual track and field games today to conclude its dual meet season unbeaten.

BRUSSELS, May 11 -- Owing to a rabies scare the various Burgomasters of the communes surrounding Brussels have ordered all dogs to be muzzled, and there are vague threats of making other animals, such as horses and the very elusive cat, wear muzzles, too.
THE eighteenth biennial convention of the National Federation of Music Clubs will begin its American Music Festival in Minneapolls this afternoon. It will continue during this week.

An attempt to extort a large sum of money -- believed to be about $100,000 -- from Henry M. Lyons of Bronxville under threat to kidnap his 4-year-old son, James, became known yesterday. The police of Bronxville, Mount Vernon, New York City and Boston are hunting for the extortionist.

IT was an alarming picture of the termite, miscalled "white ant," that George E. Sanders drew before the New York Entomological Society last week. A row of houses in Westchester County, a court house, several buildings in Northern New Jersey, an unnamed theatre near Times Square, buildings in downtown Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens, telegraph poles, furniture, are being literally chewed up.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 13 made a total of 531,095 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 7,276 cars, or 1.4 per cent, more than for the preceding week and 13,835 cars, or 2.7 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, but 215,962 cars, or 28.9 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP) -- Gene Venzke, University of Pennsylvania freshman and holder of the world's indoor track mile record, and James Healey, co-captain of the Penn team, failed today in their respective attempts to lower the world records for the three-quarter mile and 600-yard runs.

VIENNA, May 19 -- Whether the moderate foreign policy announced by Chancellor Hitler of Germany in his Reichstag speech will also apply to Austria or whether his government will continue to treat this country as a German province requiring only to be coordinated as soon as possible is a question of surpassing interest in Vienna.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 20 -- Harvard lost to Yale's champion junior class crew and freshman 150pound eight this evening on the Charles River.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 17. -- Along with the first real Spring weather of the season which has caused the farmers to become active, is the report of a general upswing of business in Missouri which gives promise of being a steady advance and not a mere seasonal spurt.

BERLIN, May 20 -- A report that the Jewish Congress in New York had announced a campaign to raise $2,000,000 to aid the suffering Jews in Germany was received in government circles today with an attitude which varied from indifference to surprise.

MONTREAL, May 20 -- The United States Davis Cup tennis forces completed their rout of Canada in the North American zone final without the loss of a set today as Ellsworth Vines of Pasadena, United States champion, and Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, scored decisive victories in the final two singles matches.

With the International motor-boat regatta planned for Florida next Winter and only the Gold Cup boats in this country available to meet the European twelve-liter craft expected to be brought across the Atlantic, there is talk of changing the regulations governing the Gold Cup motors to place them on even terms with the foreign boats.
The North German Lloyd liner Bremen sailed for Europe from her Brooklyn pier early this morning, carrying 1,010 passengers, 180 of them in first class.

In view of the indications that Germany will seek further concessions from her foreign creditors at the coming conference in Berlin on May 29, renewed interest has been attracted to the use that may be made of registered creditor balances in Germany -- the so-called "blocked marks."
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 20 -- Fordnam burled Army under a 21 to 2 score at baseball before 5,000 today. The visitors collected eighteen safe blows off three of the four Army pitchers used.
LE BOURGET, France, May 20 (AP) -- Colonel Lindbergh's landing at Le Bourget after his flight from New York will be celebrated tomorrow, the sixth anniversary of his arrival.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 20 -- The Massachusetts Tech varsity 150-pound and freshman crews defeated their Harvard rivals in races over the Henley and mile and three-quarter distances, respectively, on the Charles River today.

BRUSSELS, May 11 -- The triumvirate of strict Ministers of State who wanted to model Belgian coast resort bathing on that of a girls' boarding school' have been induced to change their minds by the chorus of complaints from interested groups.
Some acquaintances of former Governor Alfred E. Smith seem certain that he will be a dyed-in-the-wool fresh-water angler ere long.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 20 -- The Kirkland Town Laws, which will become effective in their entirety on the first of next year, will permit town governments to perform all functions now carried on by villages, according to a statement by Benjamin I. Taylor, majority leader of the Westchester Board of Supervisors and vice president of the New York State Association of Town Officials.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Legislation for relief of States and municipalities in financial difficulties took a tentative place today on the administration program.
MADRID, May 19 -- Premier Manuel Azana is being put in an apparently anomalous position by powers beyond his control.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Charges that bad faith had been displayed by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States and investment banks toward the administration's bill to control security issues, was made by Senator Fletcher, Banking and Currency Committee chairman, when he informed the Senate today that the conferees had agreed on the measure.

Profit-taking by speculative contributors to the two-month advance of security and commodity prices developed at the close of last week, providing the reaction that always is expected after any protracted movement in prices. This was viewed as a corrective movement and it occurred despite a multiplicity of favorable news in most industries, with respect both to real developments and also to better conditions expected as a result of the Washington administration's general industrial program.

Postmaster General Farley, speaking for the Roosevelt Administration as well as in his capacity as lead of the Democratic organizations in State and nation, will make radio appeal tomorrow evening for a large wet vote at Tuesday's special election, when 150 delegates are to be chosen for the State convention on June 27 to vote on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

FOR more than a century and a half wave after wave of temperance agitation and propaganda has swept over the country, culminating at fairly regular intervals in changes in the laws concerning alcoholic beverages, always tending toward enforced abstinence.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 18 -- Final passage of the Muscle Shoals bill on Tuesday of this week was greeted in Chattanooga with a city-wide burst of whistle blowing like unto the annual New Year chorus, while in the tri-city area about the shoals a big city celebra- tion was held and in other communities throughout the valley there was much rejoicing.

The Brooklyn Bridge, a monument to an engineering feat that astounded the country fifty years ago, will be the focal point of interest Wednesday, when Brooklyn will celebrate the semi-centennial it the span, completed in 1883 at a total cost of $25,000,000.

THE third annual American Folksong festival sponsored by the American Folksong Society will be held Sunday, June 11, at 3 P.M. Eastern Standard Time, in the foothills of Kentucky, at the cabin of Jean Thomas, writer of Kentucky mountain stories.
De Witt Clinton High retained its Bronx championship in the fourth annual track and field meet held among the borough's four P.S.A.L. schools at Rice Stadium, Pelham Bay Park, yesterday.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 20 -- The Princeton track team concluded its dual meet season with a 78 2-3 -- 56 1-3 victory over Cornell in Palmer Memorial Stadium today.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 20 -- Champion Nancolleth Beryl of Giralda, the famous 3-year-old pointer owned by the Giralda Farms of Madison, N.J., added another triumph to her record today by winning the best in show award in the thirtieth annual dog show of the Ladies' Kennel Association of America.

SANITY and wisdom are always to be expected from Norman Angell (he is presented to us now with the prefix "Sir," since he was knighted two years ago), and his last year's Halley Stewart Lectures do not disappoint us.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 18. -- In a little one-room cabin on a roadside near Adams Run, not far from Charleston, the Blind Boy lives, tills his tiny patch of ground, and uses a pair of unshod feet to "see" with. The Blind Boy, who is seldom known by any other name in his neighborhood, is a Negro in his early twenties.

PARIS, May 20 -- The problem of Premier Mussolini's four-power peace pact is near a satisfactory solution it is learned here from well informed sources. A text has been drawn up which is satisfactory to France, Great Britain and Italy, and all that remains is to get the German approval.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 20 -- Henry Picoli, home-club champion won the annual Garden City Golf Club Invitation tournament today by administering a somewhat un expected defeat to F. Paul Anderson, three-time winner of the New Jersey State amateur title, in today's final round, 2 and 1.

A nation-wide protest by students of American universities against the suppression of free speech and academic freedom by the Nazis in German universities, coupled with a protest against the discriminations against Jewish students and professors in Germany is being organized by students of the University of Cincinnati.

TO appreciate the practical value of the suggestions contained in this pamphlet one must know the general theory advanced by the author in his numerous works and which has exercised a considerable influence on the development of modern economic thought.

Columbia University will honor several hundred of its alumni, members of classes celebrating graduation anniversaries, at the 179th commencement day exercises on June 6, and will select the twenty-fifth alumni trustee of the university at that time, it was announced yesterday by C.E. Lovejoy, secretary of the Alumni Federation.

MR. WISE has written swiftly and ably about the war that the new German Government is waging against 600,000 of its own citizens. His short book has the contemporaneous quality of a weekly magazine and a background solidly based on history.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., May 20 -- A first prize of $50 in the Atlantic Monthly College Essay Contest has been awarded to Miss Virginia Hamilton of Montclair, N.J., Mount Holyoke senior. Honorable mention was awarded to her classmate, Miss Mary Lyon of Scarsdale, N.Y.
ORTHODOX anthropologists are shaking their professional heads over the Hall of Man (known as the Chauncey Keep Memorial Hall), which is being added to the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago.

THESE are parlous times indeed for the United States Army. Assailed on both flanks by strong pacifist lobbies, and with its centre being forced back by the administration's decree of enforced reduction in officer and enlisted personnel, not to mention other drastic economies.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- The cotton spinning industry was reported today by the Census Bureau to have operated during April at 95.7 per cent of capacity, on a single shift basis, compared with 93.9 per cent during March this year and 70.7 per cent during April last year.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Will the railroads survive? In the main, yes; in their entirety, no. The question as to the trouble with the railroad situation is a subject which is before the public eye -- the investing public, the public transporting property and the wage-earner.

Strength developed yesterday in United States Government bonds after several days of declining prices on the Stock Exchange. In the two-hour trading period transactions reached $6,271,000, of which United States Government issues accounted for $393,000.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor announces that its index number of wholesale prices for the week ending May 13 stands at 62.3 as compared with 61.9 for the week ending May 6, showing an increase of approximately six-tenths of 1 per cent.

SPRING is holding her annual garden reception and welcoming a very choice and dressy company. She seems as young and fair as ever. The way she keeps her looks is wonderful; he could not have looked younger when she held the first of these athomes of hers in the Garden of Eden.
PARIS, May 20 -- France's Davis Cup aces, including Henri Cochet, were routed unexpectedly today in the first half of the annual Anglo-French tennis matches.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 20 (AP) -- Boston College's well-balanced track team today successfully defended its New England championship by piling up a total of 29 1/2 points in the forty-seventh annual competition with seventeen rivals at Tech Field.

THE HAGUE, May 8 -- Before the end of the year, The Hague will have its planetarium without legislative action or State help. It is being erected and will be opened, it is hoped, by a member of the royal family, in September.
The development of our system of higher education was determined by the financial exigencies of particular institutions, rather than in accordance with any carefully thought out social plan.

PARIS, May 7, 1933 THE exodus of German Jews or liberal suspects continues. They reach Paris in great numbers and are given a good reception. The Israelite Alliance and the Painleve committee are constantly distributing aid, and the government has waived the restrictions concerning passport visas for foreigners.

RYE, N.Y., May 20 -- Covers were taken off the sails of the Long Island Sound racing fleet today for the special regatta of the American Yacht Club in celebration of its golden jubilee. Twenty-two craft in various classes appeared for the initial competition of the season, and the Sound was adorned with canvas from Scotch Caps over to the Long Island shore.

Several noted stars of the concert stage have offered their services for the first annual benefit concert of the Fourth Medical Division of Bellevue Hospital, which will take place on Wednesday night in the auditorioum of the French Institute in the United States, 22 East Sixtieth Street.
WEST POINT, May 20 (AP) -- Time was called at noon today on the last period of the Army vs. Harvard mathematical set-to with both teams embroiled in Pierce's table of integrals.

What Colleges Need. President BUTLER has warned 45,000 Columbia University graduates that now is the time for all good alumni to come to the aid of Alma Mater. The financial hurricanes of the last three years, says Dr. BUTLER, have wrought havoc among men of large means.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Wholesale commodity prices increased three-tenths of 1 per cent in April over the preceding month, marking the second successive advance in recent months, and the first increase in the period from March to April since 1928, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Emil Hagenflint, bartender on the Scandinavian-American liner United States, will compete his twenty-third year on the ship when it turns back for New York on the next trip. Before the liner sailed yesterday from the foot of Sixth Street, Hoboken, he stood with his foot on the ship's rail and bemoaned the fact that the long years had done little to him but make him a tea drinker.

Against her father's wishes but with the permission of the Supreme Court, 6-year-old Catherine Haus- ler will wear her white vell and march with her class this morning to the altar rail at St. Pancras's Roman Catholic Church in Glendale, Queens, to receive first communion.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Acknowledgments of President Roosevelt's appeal for disarmament and economic peace were received at the White House today from Emperor Hirohito of Japan and President Lin Sen of China.

WASHINGTON. TODAY 75,000 young men be- tween the ages of 18 and 25 are at work in the nation's forests or are on the way to forest work opportunities made possible by President Roosevelt when he attached his signature on March 31 to the emergency forestation and relief measure authorizing the use of a great civilian body for conservation work on the nation's vast timbered areas.

ADOLPHE" is one of the books which everybody has heard about. It is also one of the books which not many people seem to have read. Mr Barren's new translation can be regarded, then, as not merely a new translation but as a fresh assault upon the common reader's indifference toward a book which the French have considered a minor classic for over a hundred years.

WHEN old Uncle Tom lay dying -- as he has done many thousand times -- under the brutal lash of Simon Legree his final words, "You may kill my body, mas'r, but you can't kill my soul," were prophetic of the destiny in store for the most frequently played drama in the history of the American theatre.

WHEN a new author emerges with a story as original and distinguished and unimitative as "The Lady Who Came to Stay," one awaits his second novel with more than the usual interest. Can he do it again, or will he be reduced -- as so many promising first novelists have been -- to a sterile attempt to repeat his first success?

THE spectacular career of the Bank of United States and its dramatic crash are matters of recent memory. To the work of putting the whole story into clear, compact, readable style M.L. Werner has brought his notable gifts, already familiar to readers of his previous books, "Barnum" and "Brigham Young," for logical assemblage of material and clear, simplifying statement.

PARIS PARIS couturiers, having more or less settled the discussion of the waistline boundary -- the majority of them place it just a little below normal and just a little above the hipbones -- are now battling over the shoulder territory.

NATURE and man are cooperating to limit wheat production this year. Bad weather conditions damaged the American Winter wheat crop so seriously that, despite an increase over last year in the acreage sown, production is expected to be the smallest since 1904.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- During the last few weeks, despite weather that has established new records for persistent precipitation, more than a million and a quarter persons have paid a nominal admission charge to see the mere shell of Chicago's Century of Progress Exposition.

THE national industrial recovevery bill, now being framed by Congress, which proposes Federal supervision over industrial production, prices, wages and hours of work, directs attention to the progress which business has already made toward self-regulation.

THE division of all human nature into four categories, each with its own mental and physical characteristics, is the task undertaken by Howard Elcock, an Englishman who has brought to the United States the results of twenty-five years of research and study.

GENOA GIOVANNI COMISSO, who now publishes his first novel, "II Delitto di Fausto Diamante" (Milan: Ceschina, 1933), has already established a solid reputation as the foremost writer of the younger generation.

After a silence lasting for many moons, news was received yesterday from Upper Burma that Marmaduke M. Mizzle, the Mincing Lane caraway seed merchant, whose adventures have been printed in these columns from time to time, has arrived safely at Mejongyi on the banks of the Upper Irrawaddy which he describes as being about fifteen parasangs below Bhamo and somewhere in the latitude of Hades with the backdoor open.

THE Seversky Aircraft Corporation, whose president and chief engineer is Major Alexander de Seversky, is bringing to completion one of the most interesting amphibian planes yet devised in this era of all-metal construction and design.

WITH the collapse of values following the mad speculative post-war decade, farmers, planters, oil men and other producers of basic commodities the world over who had attained wealth by supplying a constantly rising market found themselves, like business men and manufacturers, suddenly impoverished.

LONDON. THE opening of the new Mond Laboratory at Cambridge is a reminder of the remarkable renaissance in physics which is sweeping forward beneath our very eyes. The new laboratory is a comparatively small and self-contained annex to the historic Cavendish Laboratory which once rose head and shoulders above the rest of the world's centres of research in pure physics.

An act to improve the navigability and to provide for the flood control of the Tennessee River; to provide for reforestation and the proper use of marginal lands in the Tennessee Valley; to provide for the agricultural and industrial development of said valley; to provide for the national defense by the creation of a corporation for the operation of government properties at and near Muscle Shoals in the State of Alabama, and for other purposes.

BERLIN, May 20 -- The restrictions on the freedom of the press in Germany, already drastic, will be further tightened by a law the Hitler Cabinet published today, effective June 1. It is one of sixteen laws adopted by the Cabinet in record time.

During the past week a conference committee of Congress has been seeking to reconcile two different versions of the Federal Blue-Sky Bill, providing a national system of regulation of the issuance and sale of securities. As adopted by the Senate, the measure contained a provision which would have made directors unconditionally liable both for criminal prosecution and for civil suits in case of misstatements or omissions of fact in connection with the issue of securities.

The sale and consumption of beer and wine at bars in licensed hotels, restaurants, clubs and beer gardens was authorized yesterday under additional regulations issued by the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board.

COLUMBIA, Mo., May 20 (AP) -- After praising President Roosevelt for taking "the offense out of defense," Major Gen. Johnson Hagood, commander of the Fourth Army and the Seventh Corps Area, told the Missouri department of the Reserve Officers Association today that the United States needs a new and simpler system of national defense.

OF wide interest to aeronautics and particularly affecting prospective air travel from the United States to foreign countries is the International Conference of Private Air Law "which convened last Monday in Rome. Delegates from many countries are attending, the United States being represented by three.

There has been an encouraging subscription for the dinner dance and entertainment to be held on Wednesday night on board the Majestic for the benefit of Flower Hospital. One of the features of the evening will be the appearance of several Broadway entertainers.

The quest for the hidden fortune of Lee Weinstein, the secretary who was murdered with his aged employer, Edward Albert Ridley, in their underground office in Allen Street, occupied the police yesterday. It was the tenth day since the double murder had occurred and the mystery was said to be no nearer a solution.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- A Century or Progress, Chicago's 1933 World's Fair, occupying more than 400 acres along the shore of Lake Michigan, will be opened formally and dedicated next Saturday morning by Postmaster General James A. Parley, representing President Roosevelt.
PARIS HATS seen at the midseason millinery openings aspire to positively dizzy heights -- particularly dizzy when worn by the wrong woman; and with high hats that happens easily.

President Roosevelt's public works program should have the united support of the people so that it may be speedily translated into action, the New York State Society of Professional Engineers declared at its annual meeting yesterday, in a resolution endorsing the President's proposals and the legislation sponsored by Senator Wagner to carry them out.

PARIS, May 20 -- After getting the Senate's version of what the budget should be, the Chamber of Deputies finance commission today altered it radically in several important points and it is now generally admitted that a political crisis is in the offing.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Increased wages for at least 10,000,000 workers within six months after the effective date of the National Industrial Recovery Act was predicted today by H.I. Harriman, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, during an interview in which he referred to the measure as the "Magna Charta of industry and labor."

THE waning season continues to offer exhibitions numerous and varied in the local galleries. Works by giants of the last century and fledglings of this, with many in between, came under the questing eye of the reviewer.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., May 20 -- Under the shade of the trees on Lawrenceville's handsome campus, the graduates of bygone days gathered and chatted today and then witnessed an elaborate snorts program to mark the school's annual alumni day.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 20 -- Holy Cross had little trouble in defeating Harvard today, 14 to 6, in a game featured by some free hitting.

Trade associations in all branches of industry are looking forward to increases in prestige and power on the adoption of President Roosevelt's program for the rehabilitation of industry, now before Congress. Their officers feel that the organizations probably will be designated as the intermediaries between the government and private business.

Although favored by a railway traffic report that exceeded expectations and by news that steel operations for the country are approaching 40 per cent of capacity, the share market ended a week of hesitancy yesterday by going into an emphatic decline.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 20 -- The Harvard Freshmen defeated the Yale Yearlings. 78 1/2 to 55 1/2, in their annual dual meet today, the Crimson Cubs gaining the majority of their points in the track events and the Elis scoring heavily in the field tests.

Card parties in aid of philanthropic organizations have been arranged for this week. Mrs. Leslie R. Palmer heads a group of women interested in the work of the Robins Nest, a home for convalescent crippled children in Tarrytown, who have planned a series of bridge parties in behalf of the home.

LOUISVILLE, May 18 -- New Federal regulations for the sale of medicinal liquor are expected to have a tonic effect on the Kentucky whisky business. To supply the anticipated increased demand, Kentucky warehouses now contain some 5,000,000 gallons of pre-war whisky and about 4,000,000 gallons manufac- tured since 1928, much of which is approaching the age of four years, which it must attain before being eligible for bottling in bond for the prescription trade.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics, aided by two home runs by Jimmy Foxx, swept the two-game series with the Cleveland Indians, by capturing today's contest, 7 to 2. They were Foxx's fifth and sixth circuit drives of the season.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Tenth National Oratorical Contest was won tonight by John M. Phillips, 18 years old, of Kansas City, Mo., before an audience which crowded Constitutional Hall.

BOSTON, May 19 IT is neither "too good to be true" nor "too true to be good," it is only a plain fact, once more repeating itself. Inflation or no inflation, there is money to spend in Boston on the theatre and a hearty will to spend it -- for the plays and players that seem worth the price.
The arrest of a burglar suspect charged with stealing 52 cents from a West New Brighton grocery store was responsible yesterday morning for the injury of three patrolmen.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- Bob Kelly performed splendidly in the relief role today to give Pennsylvania a 5 to 4 Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League victory over Princeton on Franklin Field before an Alumni Day crowd of 10,000.
ALBANY, May 20 -- When the Chicago Century of Progress Exposition opens Saturday, New York State will be represented by an exhibit featuring the scenic beauties of the Adirondacks.

On the Hamburg-American liner Albert Ballin, which arrived from Germany yesterday, was an Austro-Daimler-Puch Works railbus which will be tried out on the Long Island Railroad for speed and performance and then sent to Chicago for exhibition at the Century of Progress Exposition.

WHEN J.P. Morgan and his ten leading partners appear in the Senate Building at Washington in answer to subpoenas this week they will be confronted by a bland, good-humored lawyer who will attempt to draw from them the story of their private banking business and its effects upon America's economic life.

A plan for stimulating the sale of surplus cotton, copper and other raw materials through granting special tariff concessions on imported goods manufactured from American materials was offered here yesterday by Aaron Neumann, importer of upholstery fabrics and a member of the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Having ended today its hearings on the National Recovery Bill, the House Ways and Means Committee will meet in executive session Monday to decide what taxes shall be levied to back the $3,300,000,000 public works program.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The nomination of Arthur A. Quinn of New Jersey as Controller of Customs at New York City was sent to the Senate today by President Roosevelt.
WHILE the cry is often heard in these United States that the road is dead, a number of European countries are enjoying a healthy renaissance of theatrical interest in other than the largest cities.

Columbia's heavy-hitting nine defeated New York University, 13-7, yesterday before 1,000 persons at Baker Field. It was the twelfth victory of the season for the Morningside nine, which has lost only two games.

The Alleghany Corporation, top company in the Van Sweringen railroad holding structure, has reported for the quarter ended on March 31 a net loss of $344,161, against a profit of $264,099, exclusive of $11,941,105 loss from the sale of securities, which was charged to paid-in surplus, in the corresponding period last year.

LOUISVILLE, May 18. -- Governor Ruby Laffoon has made known to his friends his hope that the General Assembly, soon to be nominated in party primaries, and which meets next January, will confer with him dictorial powers to institute economies in State government.

BERLIN, May 19 -- Bismarck's Prussia and the Prussia that was the forerunner of imperial Germany formally passed into the keeping of National Socialism yesterday when Captain Hermann Wilhelm Goering, the iron man of Nazidom, precented himself to the recently elected Diet as Premier of the Reich's pivotel State.
PARIS, May 6 BEFORE speaking of the considerable number of new French plays I will say a word about three productions that are of foreign origin. One of them is the German Ballet of Kurt Jooss.

MR. SULLIVAN is a master of unmildewed humor in a world forlorn. He never lets his idolaters down. He touches nothing that he does not adorn with fresh insanities. He is content to leave the little corner he lives in a lot more baffling and improbable than it was before.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Albert Vander Veer and members of her family will leave 158 East Seventy-fourth Street on June 3 to pass the Summer at Grey Shingles, their place in Point O' Woods, L.I.
RADIO broadcasts this week have a foreign touch, with programs coming from London, Paris and the Argentine.

A FEW months ago we heard much of technocracy, the ruin that stared us in the face if the price system is much longer retained, the displacement of men by machines, and the necessity of abandoning our entire economic structure to make room for another based on "energy determinates."

Discriminatory features of the present naval pay bill, together with what naval officers describe as the "onerous and vexatious provisions" of recent economy acts, which make mandatory many inequalities in officers' pay schedules are striking "at the very roots of naval efficiency," the Navy Department believes.

IN latter-day Britain, three Jews have played a conspicuous part. All have been Liberals. All served in Cabinets. All justified their success by a faultless efficiency in administration. Lord Reading was Ambassador at Washington and Viceroy of India.

A survey of the leading investment counsel firms here discloses that in general clients are being advised to retain or increase their commitments in sound stocks and bonds owing to the improvement in business. The experts whose opinions were sought administer funds totaling several hundred millions of dollars.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- A declaration that bankers who "have got their arms up to the shoulders in the Treasury" are opposing the measure began House debate today on the Glass-Steagall Bank Reform Bill.

A DETECTIVE, be he professional or amateur, must necessarily be endowed with rather more than the usual human quota of curiosity concerning the people about him. That is why he observes them so closely and learns things about them that they believe to be known only to themselves.

An Innovation in philanthropic entertainments is being planned for Wednesday night, when the Association of Volunteers of the Welfare Council of New York will give a sidewalk dinner and fete at Chatham Walk, said to be the first sidewalk cafe in that section, at Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

Many pastors in their sermons today will commend President Roosevelt for what Commander Evangeline Booth of the Salvation Army described as his "bold and noble appeal on behalf of peace and international cooperation," and they will ask their people as citizens to support the Chief Executive in his efforts to reduce armaments and abate enmities and suspicions.

MR. COOK offers us in this volume a collection of verse unsual merit; one perceives almost immediately that he is endowed with the faculty of poetic perception and that he is intellectually sincere. He does not reach for frills and furbelows, or strain after conceits of figure and language.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 20 -- Two Syracuse eights repeated their earlier victories over Cornell on Lake Cayuga today. The Orange varsity, rallying in the final mile, won by half a length in 10:49, while the Syracuse junior varsity rowed to a four-length victory.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., May 20 -- Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip opened their estate, Beechwood, tonight for an encore dance to benefit the scholarship fund of the floating university of which Mrs. Vanderlip is chairman. Features included an auction sale, games of chance, a beer garden and an amateur entertainment.

The New York University track team closed its dual meet season and repulsed the Alumni, 95 to 49, at Ohio Field in a handicap meet yesterday. The varsity captured twelve first places out of sixteen events, making a clean sweep in five.

Beginning tomorrow, nine additional offices for the renewal of automobile driving license will be opened by the Bureau of Motor Vehicles in the metropolitan area. With the five main offices of the bureau, this will make a total of fourteen places issuing the 1933-34 credentials, which will be required for driving on and after June 1.
PITTSBURGH, May 20 (AP) -- The Pirates regained their form in the second game of a double-header with the Boston Braves today, defeating the visitors, 7 to 6, after dropping the first fray 4 to 2.

ATHENS, Ga., May 18 -- Oil portraits of five noted figures in the history of the University of Georgia, unveiled here recently, were presented to the university through J. Phinizy Calhoun, chairman of the memorials committee of the Georgia Alumni Society.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While theoretically any widely used commodity might serve as a measure of value, practically most commodities are not suited to such use, for various reasons, principally on account of their bulk. Two commodities, gold and silver, on account of their universal desirability and their comparatively small bulk, naturally came into use as money and as measures of the value of other commodities.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- A declaration that bankers who "have got their arms up to the shoulders in the Treasury" are opposing the measure began House debate today on the Glass-Steagall Bank Reform Bill.
GROTON, Mass., May 20 -- Groton. School's eight-oared crew rowed to a two-and-one-half length victory over Belmont Hill School on the Nashua River today.

BERLIN, May 20 -- The Boerse closed the week with the dullest session so far this year. Stock quotations which depended on desultory orders were irregular but on the whole rather firmer, although Use Bergbau dropped 7 points following a decline of 8 points yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- An effort to conclude their case by Monday was promised the Senate today by attorneys for Federal Judge Harold Louderback of California as they hammered into his impeachment trial more evidence that none of the fees paid officers of his court went to him.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 20 -- Yale and Harvard athletic officials conferred after the dual track meet today and tentatively selected the United States team which will meet the Oxford-Cambridge team in Cambridge, Mass., next July.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- After rushing to Washington from the steamer on which he arrived in New York from London yesterday, Dr. O.M.W. Sprague, financial expert, conferred here today with President Roosevelt and Secretary of the Treasury Woodin.

BOSTON, May 20 (AP) -- Henry Johnson, Boston right-hander, managed to hold Detroit to eight scattered hits, including a homer by Charlie Gehringer, and the Red Sox defeated the Tigers, 6-5, in the second game of the series today.
ALBANY, N.Y., May 20 (AP) -- Galloping home nearly a half mile ahead of his rivals, Dave Komonen of Toronto today won the National A.A.U. 25-kilometer run from Schenectady to Albany.

What do women college graduates like to get together to study through the years after they have emerged from academic halls? Parent education, answered the American Association of University Women at its convention in Minneapolis just closed.

UNIVERSAL'S "The Kiss Before the Mirror," a picturization of a play by the Hungarian Laszlo Fodor which was at the RKO Roxy, has the distinction of an unusually interesting theme and a most efficient portrayal by Frank Morgan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Our political friends in Washington, and other seats of power and income acquired by word of mouth, are telling us that unless the business world sets its house in order it will be necessary for the Washington folk and those in various State Assemblies to do so for the house of business.

Advances in raw materials in the textile field have been so sharp that current finished goods prices do not reflect full replacement costs, according to opinions expressed in the primary markets yesterday. Users of wool and cotton particularly have found that they could not advance quotations on their goods sufficiently to cover material costs without jeopardizing sales.
With three major events on the schedule, metropolitan district golfers, men and women, amateurs and professionals, are entering upon one of the busiest weeks of the year.

A stele, or slab of stone, used to mark a grave, which apparently dates from the Assyrian occupation of Samaria, has just been found by the expedition to Palestine, being conducted by Harvard University in conjunction with the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, the British School of Archaeology and the Palestine Exploration Fund, it was announced yesterday by Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach, presi- dent of the American Friends of the Hebrew University, at 71 West Forty-seventh Street.

OF the thousandns of motorists planning tours to Gettysburg over the Memorial Day week-end, those from New York and vicinity are especially fortunate in being able to include in the same trip several other historic shrines. One of the best and most direct routes between New York and Gettysburg passes close to both Washington Crossing and Valley Forge, scenes of vital episodes in the American Revolution.

TOO often has the law been discussed by busy practitioners of the profession who have neither the time nor the inclination to think deeply about it, nor the ability to doubt their own dogmatic assumptions, raised so easily into eternal verities.

Three New York Jewish medical students who have been attending the Anatomical School of the University of Vienna returned yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Albert Ballin. They asked that they remain anonymous because they intend to return to Vienna when the tension lessens.

The sufferings of the thousands of Chinese soldiers wounded in resisting the Japanese invasion have been recounted by Mrs. Wilma Cannon Fairbank, an American student who observed the reactions of some of those fortunate enough to react base hospitals in Peiping.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Senator Lewis of Illinois, Democratic whip and a member of the Foreign Rela-
