Calling of warrants of three municipalities for payment in the remaining days of May and of several large blocks of foreign government and domestic corporation bonds for payment in future months was announced last week among loans to be redeemed before their dates of maturity.
PARIS, May 20 -- The dollar rose today to 22.33 francs, closing at 22.23, which was one of the highest rates in months.

Silk flags and colored crepe-paper lanterns were hung out in the narrow streets of Chinatown yesterday by shopkeepers and housewives to greet the Symbolic Lion, who will emerge from his secret cave at noon today for the dedication of the Grand Charity Bazaar for China's War Refuges.

Experiencing the first sustained pick-up in sales in more than two years, exporters here yesterday were in disagreement as to what part the United States' departure from the gold standard on April 19, has played in reviving foreign interest in American-made products.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 20 -- Led by the brilliant all-around play of Tommy Hitchcock, the White polo team downed the Red quartet, 8 to 5, today in a practice game played on Cochran field of the Meadow Brook Club. A goal by the great internationalist late in the third period put his team out in front, 4 to 3, and thereafter it was never headed.

The New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, has placed on exhibition for the first time a large collection of original woodcuts, lithographs, photographs, manuscripts, books and other items dealing with the history of the New York Fire Department.

SPEAKING for the composer" in the quarterly Trend, Harrison Kerr voices complaints that are heard, not for the first time, of the hard lot of the serious composer, and his difficulties in making a living and getting his music played.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Original land grants covering homesteads in Kansas and other Middle West States during the '60s, and in many cases bearing the signature of Abraham Lincoln, specified that the government reserved to itself all title to any mineral deposits that might thereafter be developed on said land.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 19 -- The spirit of secession is abroad in Georgia. The descendants of the men who defied the Federal Goveminent in the Sixties have grabbed bung starters and begun a fight to get beer despite the refusal of Governor Talmadge to act in the matter of Democratic beer.

VANCOUVER, May 18 -- A quarter of a century ago, when Japanese immigration was beginning to cause anxiety in Canada, the British Government invited Canada, Australia, New Zealand and South Africa to declare their attitude toward a gentlemen's agreement offered by Japan, by which future immigration would be controlled.

LONDON, May 20 -- A tea party with the King and Queen at Windsor Castle is on the long list of entertainments prepared for delegates and their wives during the first month of the World Economic Con- ference.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 17. -- When the State Senate yesterday morning by a vote of 33 to 3 refused to consider the rejected primary bill which had been introduced and ballyhooed by the Hiram W. Johnson forces in State politics the senior United States Senator from California suffered the most significant rebuke he has received in public life in California.
One of the pleasantest features of a publisher's life before the advent of the literary agent was the direct personal association with his authors, which often led to long and intimate friendships.

WASHINGTON IN a somewhat antiquated office in the nation's capital sits a tall, gaunt man, with piercing dark eyes flashing behind pincenez, a man who in another week will head the world's largest bank and, in a large degree, control the destiny of America's farm population.

Period furniture, principally French and English, antique tapestries, Oriental rugs, silver, bronzes and other art objects from the estates of the late Walter H. Merrall of this city, Laura A. Curtis, and others, will be offered at auction on "Wednesday and Thursday afternoons at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Chicago banks have released the Middle West Utilities Company from obligations totaling $7,000,000 and have agreed to return to the company one-third of the securities they received as collateral for loans in the four-month period prior to the filing of the bankruptcy petition against the company.
MEDIA, Pa., May 20 -- Three spills marked an exciting steeplechase for the Gloucester Fox Hunters Plate at the Rose Tree Hunt Club's meet today.

ALTHOUGH there are large uncertainties in the international situation, and many problems pressing for solution at home, the improvement of business in the United States since early March has now become the largest and best-sustained advance since 1929.

ONE HUNDRED years ago tomorrow Edmund Kean -- accounted, next to David Garrick, the greatest of England's actors -- died in his forty-seventh year at Richmond-on-Thames, where in parks and gardens walk the pale ghosts of slim Romance and pudgy Royalty.

PERHAPS no happier combination of pen and brush could have succeeded in capturing and rendering so faithfully, both in words and in lines, the charm, color and certain intimate vignettes of Italian folk-ways than that presented by Mr. and Mrs. Arms.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Last Spring I was awakened at daybreak by a robin tapping on the window. I tried to drive it away, but it persisted, so I went back to bed.

PARIS, May 19 -- This momentous week closes with France not quite decided whether to rejoice or feel sad. Certainly the international situation, taken as a whole, has improved, but it is equally certain that France's position within the international sphere has been weakened.

PARIS, May 20 -- The French consider Germany's sudden acceptance of the MacDonald disarmament plan as a simple "manoeuvre." It is that word which crops up in all newspaper comment, and it is that impression that one receives in discussing the matter in official circles.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Increased income tax rates suggested to the House Ways and Means Committee by Lewis W. Douglas, director of the budget, as a means of raising revenue needed to finance President Roosevelt's public works and re-employment programs would add 50 to 100 per cent to the amount of tax now paid by persons of moderate incomes.

The conviction that Industry, by abusing privileges accorded under the administration's industrial control measure, will destroy any chance of continuing cooperative agreements after the expiration of the two-year period fixed in the law, sobered the enthusiasm with which trade groups and business leaders viewed the probable passage of the national recovery act last week.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Building operations, including operations and repairs, increased 21.2 per cent throughout the United States during April, to $29,756,038 in estimated costs, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

DR. POLLARD has produced a valuable and erudite summary of China's international relations from 1917 to 1931. This volume provides a complete and, within the limitations of any general summary, an accurate picture of China's effort to achieve international equality during a period of national transition, disturbance and misfortune.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 20 -- Unexpected opposition to a resolution condemning the guaranteed bank deposit feature of the Glass-Steagall Bill arose today in the closing session of the annual convention of the New Jersey Bankers Association in the Hotel Ambassador here.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 20 -- Wild Bill Cummings. Indianapolis automobile race driver, lived up to his nickname today when he topped a field of qualifiers for the 500-mile classic to be run May 30 with the sensational average speed of 118.521 miles an hour.
GENEVA, May 20 -- German anti-Semitism was unexpectedly assured today of a public airing in the Council of the League of Nations early next week.
BARCELONA, May 8 -- Time wasting is one of the salient accomplishments in Spain. Jn Barcelona it has created a profitable business.

BALTIMORE, May 20 -- Baltimore made it three out of four by trouncing Newark, 12 to 8, in the final game of the series today. The Orioles, led by Julius Splters, bombarded Tamulis and Miner for fifteen hits, two of which were home runs by Stroner and Smythe.

Despite the attitude of certain members of Congress who have declared themselves opposed to government subsidies for merchant shipping, the general attitude of the new administration and Congress is favorable to the merchant marine and to the continuance of the ten-year program of government aid for development at sea that was inaugurated in 1928, according to Captain David W. Todd, newly appointee commissioner of the United States Shipping Board.

The bill introduced in Congres on Friday for the purpose of remedying by joint State-Federal control the present unsatisfactory conditions in the petroleum industry is considered generally by oil producers to be the most far-reaching legislation yet proposed in this country for the regulation of any major line of business not a public utility.

Operations in the steel industry advanced last week 4 points to 40 per cent of capacity, the highest rate in two years, according to the magazine Steel. Asserting that "the base of the market structure broadens each week," the publication adds that a further gain in operations is expected this week.

Tammany's charter revision plans were termed "farcical" yesterday by Dr. William J. Schieffelin, of the Citizens Union. Dr. Schieffelin, in a letter to Mayor O'Brien, asked him to send back to the Municipal Assembly, for amendment, the local law calling for a vote this Fall on the appointment of a charter revision commission.

GENEVA, May 21. -- There are good indications here tonight that the Jewish question, to be put before the League Council this week by the petition of Franz Bernheim, may turn out much more favorably than has been expected. These indications are that whatever Germany's tactics may be, she will concede in the end, if not at the outset, to exempt German Silesia from all the Reich anti-Semitic laws and regulations.
PARIS, May 21. -- France was understood today to be ready to accept the MacDonald disarmament plan with some modification, after agreement at Rome for a revised Mussolini four-power pact.

The policy followed by Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, in his rate negotiations with the companies of the Edison electric system in 1930 is the basis for the charges made against him by the Community Councils of the City of New York, Inc., which recently petitioned Governor Lehman for his removal.

HOHOKUS, N.J., May 21. -- Champion Walnut Challenger, the star in the airedale kennels of Fred H. Hoe of New Brunswick, N.J., today was proclaimed best in the show at the second annual all-breed exhibition of the Ridgewood DOG Fanciers' Association, which was staged in the Bell-Ho Riding Academy.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 21. -- Members of the staff of the Harvard College Observatory transferred to the new astronomical station at Oak Ridge today the delicate photo-electric apparatus which is to send to Chicago an impulse from the light of the star Arcturus to open the Century of Progress Exposition.

LONDON, May 20. -- The Economist's fortnightly index number of average commodity prices in Great Britain, based on 1927 as 100, works out as of May 17 at 62.3, comparing with 61.4 two weeks previously and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931. when the gold standard was abandoned.

The Rev. Horace William Baden Donegan, who for the last four years has been rector of Christ Protestant Episcopal Church in Baltimore, was instituted yesterday morning as rector of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, one of the largest and most influential parishes in the diocese of New York.

The total of local and State long-term government obligations in the United States has doubled since the war and has now reached $18,685,000,000. The Twentieth Century Fund made the compilations in a special report yesterday in connection with its general survey of internal debts in the United States.

ROME, May 21. -- An agreement was reached here today among the representatives of France, Germany, Britain and Italy on Premier Mussolini's four-power pact, guaranteeing the peace of Europe for ten years. The text will now be submitted to the four governments for their approval.

LONDON, May 21. -- Lord Essendon, chairman of Furness, Withy Co., Ltd., today moved a step nearer dominance of the British shipping world with the announcement that his company had acquired a controlling interest in the Shaw, Savill Albion Co., Ltd., which operates twenty-two passenger liners and freighters between Great Britain, Australia and New Zealand.

The Yankees, who somehow never do things by half measures, were still backtracking at a fearful rate at the Stadium yesterday, and by literally falling all over themselves they dropped their final game of the series with the Browns, 8 to 4.

PARIS, May 20. -- It is worthy of note that rumors circulated abroad concerning the possibility of franc devaluation have been officially contradicted by the Finance Minister and have completely ceased.

The story of the rise of trying Wexler, better known as Waxey Gordon, to the rank of racket overlord, closely parallels that of the more notorious racketeers. He began his career as a hoodlum and petty thief, graduated into the ranks of organized gangland and, with the advent of prohibition, turned himself to the profitable task of supplying illicit beverages.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 21. -- The plan recently brought forward by Gustavo Ross, Chilean Minister of Finance, for the reorganization of the nitrate industry and involving Cosach, the Nitrate Corporation of Chile, promises to be a satisfactory basis for the solution of the problem, according to declarations made here yesterday.

BERLIN, May 20. -- Dr. Schacht's invitation to Germany's creditors to attend a conference to consider the problem of transfer service on foreign currency bonds created no sensation here, being regarded as the inevitable consequence of Chancellor Hitler's declaration that "the most important feature of the German nation's program is war against international finance and loaned capital."

ALBANY, May 21. -- The question of how the sales tax applies to containers and wrapping materials is treated in the fifth instalment of regulations issued today by Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission.

Frances Winwar, the wife of Bernard D.N. Grebanier, an Instructor in literature at City College, has won the Atlantic Non-Fiction Prize of $5,000 for her manuscript, "Poor, Splendid Wings," subtitled "The Rossettis and Their Circle." It was selected from more than 800 manuscripts.

Disapproval of the policy of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions regarding Mrs. Pearl S. Buck, novelist, who resigned as a missionary after her orthodoxy had been subjected to a Fundamentalist attack, was voiced in sermons here yesterday by two Presbyterian ministers.

GENEVA, May 21. -- Norman H. Davis, chief United States delegate to the disarmament conference, is devoting great care to the statement of Washington's position on the maintenance of international security, which he will deliver tomorrow.
AUTEUIL, France, May 21. -- Four Americana are among the eighty players entered in the eighth annual French Hard Court Tennis Championships which open here tomorrow and continue until June 5.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Securities Bill now before Congress has raised a storm of opposition in many quarters, and the Merchants Association of New York is especially prominent in its antagonism. The memorandum relating to the bill adopted by the directors and submitted to the conference committee of the Senate and House is remarkable for the clarity with which the situation is dealt with.

The Continental Committee on Technocracy has completed a nation-wide organization with a membership of 250,000, six regional divisions and more than seventy local units, it was announced yesterday at national headquarters, 1 East Forty-second Street.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 21. -- Freeland's Black Imp, the confident-looking jet-black spaniel owned by Mrs. Arthur Vogel of West Long Branch, N.J., won the highest honors in the Cocker Spaniel Club of Long Island's match show on the estate of Harold L. Johnson today.

A three-day tour of gardens in and around New York, arranged by the New York City Committee of the Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation, will start today with "Westchester Day." The proceeds will go toward the restoration and the preservation as a national memorial of Stratford Hall, the ancestral home of the Lees in Virginia.

Trying (Waxey Gordon) Wexler, one of the last of the really wealthy beer runners to enjoy freedom, was captured by Federal agents and State troopers yesterday. He was found in a rented hunting lodge on the margin of White Lake, in the Catskills, in Sullivan County.

The return of a long-lost sense of the value of human life and of "the solid dignity of daily worship of God" is noticeable in the world today, the Rev. Dr. Paul Scherer, pastor of Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West at Sixty-fifth Street, declared yesterday at the morning service.

Today, as the President's proclamation sets forth, is the anniversary of the departure in 1819 (from Savannah, Ga.) of the ship that made the first successful voyage across the Atlantic "under steam propulsion." The vessel was built at Corlaer's Hook, New York, but was bought in Savannah and christened by the name of that city.

"Both Your Houses," the play by Maxwell Anderson which won this year's Pulitzer Prize, will open a return engagement at the Ethel Barry-more Theatre this evening. Another opening is that of "Patience," the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta, which will be presented by Milton Aborn at the St. James Theatre.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP). -- The national capital, scene of many an investigation, began to show signs of excitement today over the approaching Senate inquiry into the banking house of J.P. Morgan Co. as those in charge announced everything was set for the opening of questioning Tuesday.

PITTSBURGH, May 21. -- While sellers of steel still report Increases in buying in various directions, they do not expect much further increase in the total until the usually dull Summer period is past, as some classes of consumption are in line for seasonal decrease in activity.

I.N. Phelps Stokes, president of the Municipal Art Commission, made an inspection tour of the Central Park reservoir site yesterday afternoon. He reported afterward that he did not regard as serious what Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy had done so far to provide baseball diamonds for "sandlot" leagues.
The best crowds of the season were reported yesterday at the beaches in and around New York City. Coney Island reported 500,000 persons at the resort, with thousands in the water and on the beach.

Man is still relegating God to the background, as he did before the World War, the Rev. Edward J. McQuade declared in a sermon at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and East Eighty-fourth Street, yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The true aspect of the case of the "bonus marchers" seems to be brought to light by their rejection of President Roosevelt's offer to enroll them in the reforestation army at $1 a day.
The New York Americans retained first place in the American Soccer League when they defeated the Brooklyn Wanderers, 5-1, yesterday at Starlight Park before 1,000 fans.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The 3,000 veterans who have been the "guests" of the administration here for more than a week while they held a convention to demand immediate payment of their adjusted service certificates will cease to be guests tomorrow, and for the most part will again become soldiers as they "sign up" for the reforestation corps.
President Roosevelt's efforts on behalf of world peace and cooperation in international economic activities were praised yesterday in the sermons of New York ministers.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- An attack upon the treatment of Jews in Germany by Chancellor Hitler and praise for Sir Eric Drummond, Secretary General of the League of Nations, for putting on the council's agenda a petition asking the abrogation in Upper Silesia of all Hitlerite anti-Semitic laws and regulations featured the second day of the emergency session of the American Jewish Congress here.
John F. Hylan, defender of the five-cent fare while he was Mayor, charged yesterday that the city administration was for an increased fare.

A penalty kick by Bill Mangan that rode straight between the uprights gave New York a 4-to-4 tie with Kerry in the last minute of play at the Polo Grounds yesterday as the international series between the four-time Gaelic football champions of Ireland and a selected local fifteen was resumed before a crowd of 50,000.

BERLIN, May 21. -- For several days the brown-shirted men who sell pictures of Chancellor Adolf Hitler and samples of Nazi doggerel as souvenirs in the Berlin restaurants have appeared without the usual large revolvers strapped to their waist belts.

Action that may be taken by the League of Nations on the question of the treatment of the Jews in Germany will not alter American plans for their relief, Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, national chairman of the American Joint Distribution Committee's relief campaign, announced yesterday.

Although democracy Is "at a discount" in many parts of Europe, there is little likelihood that France will follow the trend toward dictatorship, Andre Siegfried, French economist, author and professor, said yesterday in an international radio address.

CHICAGO, May 21. -- Displaying a reversal of form that contrasted with their feat of winning three straight from the Cardinals last week, the Dodgers dropped today's double-header with the Cubs, 7 to 6 and 6 to 3, the first game going ten innings.

Patrolman Daniel J. Daly of 4,012 Seventy-third Street, Brooklyn, was killed and three other persons were injured in a collision between two automobiles early yesterday morning on Woodhaven Boulevard, Queens. Daly, who was off duty, was driving one car and Mrs. Helen Moran of 62-50 Saunders Street, Rego Park, was at the wheel of the other.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 21. -- Stabilization of the electrical manufacturing industry, with special reference to the possible effect of the National Industrial Recovery Act, furnished the chief topic of informal discussion among members of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association today as they gathered from all parts of the country for the Spring meeting of their policies division tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 21. -- For the first time since before the Civil War the Northern Baptists and the Southern Baptists will meet together Tuesday in a national convention.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- There is scarcely a major problem, domestic or foreign, upon which positive action has not been taken" in the seventy-eight days since President Roosevelt took the oath of office, according to Mrs. Nellie Tayloe Ross, Director of the Mint and vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, who made a radio address today.

In "Recovery Through Revolution," a red-jacketed symposium on the revolutionary forces at work in all parts of the world and in all fields of thought, published today by Covici, Friede, the admission is made that the immediate prospect for revolution in the United States "is by no means exhilarating."

CHICAGO, May 21. -- Grain prices have reached a level where the most drastic constructive Influences are necessary to keep prices moving upward. Commodities in geleral, as well as wages in many instances, have advanced following the leadership in grains.

STOCKHOLM, May 21. -- The beginning of a Fascist movement in Sweden may have been seen here today when 50,000 citizens paraded in the greatest conservative and anti-Socialist demonstration in the country's history.

Petitions calling for additional protection for the varying hare or snowshoe rabbit, introduced in this State in large numbers several years ago, have been received by the New York Conservation Department.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP). -- The informal European approval of the Mussolini peace plan was hailed by American officials as an indication of increasing international harmony, auguring well for the London Economic Conference and the Geneva arms reduction parley.

A burst of speed in the final fifty yards enabled James Sullivan of the Millrose A.A. to win the handicap two-mile run, one of the feature events of the twenty-first annual track and field games of the Ninety-second Street Y.M.H.A yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium.

Representatives of the transatlantic steamship lines will confer in Washington today with the United States Shipping Board on the acceptance of "blocked marks" by the German member lines as payment for transatlantic travel. The Shipping Board on Friday summoned the member lines after their representatives had conferred three days in New York.

BUENOS AIRES, May 21. -- Whilf prices of all commodities are continuing the gradual firm increase which began two or three weeks ago, business men are particularly optimistic over the advance in wool prices and the remarkably improved tone in the wool market.

Aided by warm weather the Nation-wide promotion of cotton goods last week brought an excellent response from consumers. As a result, retailers throughout the country reordered heavily in the local wholesale markets. Better cotton dresses were wanted in dotted swiss for street wear, new embroidered printed voile for daytime styles and In a novelty nub voile.

Long averse to staying hitched, Major LA GUABDIA has now broken loose and is curveting and charging with his usual spirit. He cheers on "the dog fight" in the Republican party of New York. He pays off some of his grudges of 1929.

Beneath a benign, approving sun, the poets of Greenwich Village flooded into a half-block of Washington Square South yesterday, tacked their work upon a board fence and invited the passing public to read and buy. A good deal of reading and some buying was in progress until the sun disappeared.

The recovery in business activities, visibly under way since the middle of March, continued last week; in particular, it brought the country's current steel production to the highest since June of 1931; also, for the first time since October, 1929, it caused larger loadings of railway freight than in the same week a year before.

Prominent women and debutantes of this season will assist at sales in behalf of philanthropic organizations which will be held throughout this week at the Nearly New Shop, 713 Eighth Avenue. The week will mark the eleventh anniversary of the founding of the shop.

VIENNA, May 21, -- Suggestions which have appeared abroad of a huge boycott movement against the Jews here seem quite absurd to any one familiar with conditions in Germany, where every non-Jewish shop conspicuously labels itself "German establishment" and displays the swastika emblem.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21. -- After winning seven straight games from college teams the Penn A.C. nine bowed to the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club of Brooklyn in the opening of the Eastern Athletic Club League at the Phillies' ball park today, 2 to 1.

The Smithtown Polo Club of Smithtown, L.I., defeated the First Division four, 8 to 7, in a thrilling extra-period contest which marked the opening of the polo season at the Fort Hamilton army reservation yesterday.

Two boys at the oars of a rowboat fought a strong tide in Jamaica Bay for more than an hour yesterday in a vain effort to bring ashore a companion who had been wounded in the leg by a stray bullet and was bleeding profusely. Finally a launch observed their struggle and towed the rowboat to Canarsie.

Undergraduates at Barnard College have arranged for an all-college and alumnae bridge party and tea in aid of the Student Loan Fund on the afternoon of June 2 at Barnard Hall. The entire proceeds will be donated to the fund that is now being raised by the Barnard Alumnae Association for the assistance of needy students.
BERLIN, May 21. -- Five hundred tons of Marxist books and pamphlets have been confiscated by the police in public and private libraries and now are doomed to be converted Into pulp.

VIENNA, May 21. -- An appeal for cooperation in placing between 200,000 and 300,000 Jewish refugees from Germany was issued tonight from Vienna by Michael Williams, editor of The Commonweal of New York, a weekly review from the Catholic viewpoint.

NEW ORLEANS, May 21. -- There were periods of activity on the Cotton Exchange here last week, also times of hesitation and comparative quiet. Prices fluctuated about 45 points, or $2.25 a bale, advancing early and then declining, so that the October option closed about 34 points net lower on the week.

CHICAGO, May 21. -- Winter wheat in the Southwest has made good growth, especially in the eastern large area. In the eastern half of Kansam most of the wheat is jointed, but in the extreme western counties little jointing is apparent, the crop there having a late start and many fields becoming weedy.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Farm values on March 1 averaged 73 as compared with an index of 89 on the same date last year and 106 two years ago. the Bureau of Agricultural Economics disclosed today. Its index was based on the average for the pre-war years from 1912 to 1914.

Led by General Roman Gorecki, president of the Federation Interalliee des Anciens Combattants, 3,000 adults and 1,500 children of Polish birth or descent paraded yesterday afternoon through Greenpoint and Williamsburg to McCarren Park, where they joined with a crowd of about 5,000 other persons in patriotic exercises commemorating the establishment of a Polish Constitution on May 3, 1791.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP). -- Labor Department officials lay much of Pennsylvania's sweatshop trouble at the door of better child labor laws in New York.
LONDON, May 21.-- Four weeks after the ending of the engineers trial in Moscow, Great Britain and Soviet Russia are merrily waging an economic war, and both are losing.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Peter Augustus Jay, who have been at the Plaza, will go shortly to Breakwater, their Summer place in Bar Harbor, Me.

Barring some unforeseen handicap due to a change in weather or other causes, the Italian liner Conte di Savoia will reach the Ambrose Channel Lightship at 9:30 A.M. today. She will have made the voyage from Genoa, including the stops at Villefranche and Gibraltar, in 5 days 20 hours, an average speed of more than 28 knots.

LONDON, May 20. -- The business recovery in the United States of America is being followed with closest interest here. Statements by observers on the spot that the improvement is not entirely due to inflation and speculation are eagerly welcomed, because it is realized how much sentiment abroad will he favorably influenced by a recovery in the United States.

Joseph W. Harriman, founder of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, was virtually the prisoner of his bondsmen yesterday in the Nassau County Hospital, at Mineola, L.I., where he was taken after an effort to commit suicide.

Commodities traded on local exchanges moved in a relatively narrow range last week. Small gains in the middle of the week were in many cases reduced to small losses by the selling on Saturday. Raw hides were the only staple to close with a clear gain, while sugar was virtually unchanged.

NEW HAVEN, May 21. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on ICO as the average of 1926, is 60.6, which compares with 59.5 a week ago, 59.2 two weeks ago, 58.6 three weeks ago and 57.1 four weeks ago. The present average is the highest of the year to date; the average of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Congressional leaders, confronted tonight with the necessity of making some of the most important decisions since the Roosevelt administration assumed office, were prepared for a week of driving activity with June 10 set as the goal for final adjournment.
IT was Babe Ruth who looked up from the perusal of a newspaper to remark: "Hey, Whitey Witt is a wet delegate in New Jersey! What do you know about that!"

CHICAGO, May 21. -- Bound for Washington to discuss with President Roosevelt the attitude of Japan in regard to other countries of the Orient and for London to attend the World Economic Conference, Viscount Kikujiro Ishii, former Ambassador to the United States, and Eigo Fukai, vice governor of the Bank of Japan, arrived in Chicago today.

Chancellor HITLER'S favorable reference to the Four-Power treaty proposed by MUSSOLINI seems to have encouraged the head of the Italian Government to press forward with his plan. Its acceptance by England and Germany, as well as by France and Italy, is reported this morning.
WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls last week are given in the appended tabulation:

BUENOS AIRES, May 21. -- Telegrams from Formosa, Argentina, report the first detention of war materials bound for Bolivia since Argentina declared her neutrality in the war between Bolivia and Paraguay.

Supermen in a Hurry. HITLER'S appointee as Trade Union Commissioner yields to no one in his admiration for his chief. The commissioner's name is ROBERT LEY, and he told a congress of office workers the other day:

LIMA, Peru, May 21. -- Alfonso Lopez, Colombia's special envoy in the Leticia dispute, appears to have brought peace nearer by his conversations with President Benavides, but he nearly lost his life in an airplane accident this morning when he started home.

ST. LOUIS, May 21. -- The two veteran pitching mainstays of the Giants, Carl Hubbell and Freddy Fitzsimmons, tried today to break the string of reverses the team has experienced at the hands of the Cardinals this season, but had no success.

BERLIN. May 21. - Chancellor Adolf Hitler's national revolution is being accompanied by M. general increase in the cost of living that is beginning to arouse the populace and cause concern among Nazi leaders.

The same team that made a clean sweep against Canada will represent the United States in the North American-South American interzone Davis Cup final against Argentina at the Chevy Chase Club, Maryland, this week.

CHICAGO, May 21. -- Prices of hogs advanced last week from $5 a hundredweight to $5.40, reaching the top on Thursday and then reacted 10 to 15 cents. The highest price was $1 above the previous week's low and the best in about a year.
Governor Lehman urged all qualified citizens yesterday to vote at the special prohibition election tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP). -- The veteran Walter Miller, making his first start of the season, today, tamed the Washington Senators, allowing only two hits in pitching Chicago to a 6-to-0 victory. The victory enabled the White Sox to advance to third place as the idle Indians dropped to fourth.

Pleading "for a less superficial (appraisal of the Nazi movement than, is now prevalent," Samuel McCrea Cavert, general secretary of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, yesterday made public a statement on the situation. He analyzed the problems presented by the Nazi revolution as he saw it in Germany recently.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP). -- President Roosevelt devoted himself tonight on his return from a cruise down the Potomac River to the completion of his delegation to the World Economic Conference. He conferred with Senator Johnson of California.

CINCINNATI, May 21 (AP). -- The Phillies and Reds divided a double-header today, the Phillies taking the first, 3 to 1, and the Reds the second, 4 to 2, for their only victory in the four-game series.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Reopening of banks at a rate of more than 125 a week and a rapid decrease in applications for loans to banks from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation were cited by Jesse H. Jones today as evidence that the nation was recovering under President Roosevelt's leadership.

The "apparent disparity between what ought to be and what is," as evidenced by the success of dishonest bankers and the misrule of Tammany Hall, was cited as a reason for the growth of skepticism and irreligious feeling, in a sermon yesterday by the Rev. Dr. George Arthur Buttrick at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Some farm leaders agitating for the payment of benefits under the new Farm Act before the processing tax is levied contend that under a clause in the act the Secretary of Agriculture could pay money to the farmers out of Treasury funds before the tax is imposed to raise the money.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- On the awning-covered decks of the yacht Sequola, President Roosevelt and his guardian of Federal expenditures, Lewis W. Douglas, Director of the Budget, today drafted into near final form a wide governmental reorganization program through which they expect to produce savings of more than $300,000,000 during the next fiscal year.

The New York Athletic Club baseball and tennis teams scored triumphs at Travers Island yesterday, the nine defeating the Marlboro A.C., 5 to 1, and the netmen turning back the West Point officers, 5 to 3. The tennis match was the season's opener for the clubmen.

PARIS, May 21. -- Charles A. Lindbergh's landing at Le Bourget was re-enacted there tonight as a feature of the celebration of the sixth anniversary of the first New York-Paris flight. The Paris Chapter of the National Aeronautic Association of the United States staged the affair.

Led by the members of the Police Department, the entire Bronx division of the Holy Name Society turned out 16,000 strong yesterday afternoon and paraded over a two-mile route from the Grand Concourse and Tremont Avenue to the common on tie campus of Fordham University, where a mass meeting was held as the contribution of the society to the observance of Holy Year as decreed by Pope Pius.

CHICAGO, May 21. -- Although the Century of Progress exposition does not open until Saturday, the fine arts section, installed in the Art Institute, will hold a private view tomorrow afternoon and will, open officially to the public on Tuesday.

TIENTSIN, May 21. -- Although fighting has ceased completely on all fronts, the situations in Peiping and Tientsin continue tense. Chinese troops along the Shanhaikwan-Tientsin Railway continue to hold the line at Lutai, but the Chinese troops in the Peiping area are rapidly retreating from the north and east.

Samuel Untermyer consented yesterday to go before the League of Nations and the World Economic Conference to present the Jewish case against the Hitler government in behalf of more than 4,000,000 American war veterans.

Jersey City and Newark, clashing for the first time this season, divided a doubleheader before 12,000 spectators at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday. The Bears won the first game, 8 to 7, but bowed to the home club in the seven-inning nightcap, 3 to 2.

Samuel Untermyer consented yesterday to go before the League of Nations and the World Economic Conference to present the Jewish case against the Hitler government in behalf of more than 4,000,000 American war veterans.

ALBANY, May 21. -- State Controller Morris S. Tremaine in a statement issued tonight in connection with the nation-wide drive which is being undertaken with the slogan "Pay Your Taxes," asserted that the tax striker was really striking at himself "by destroying the credit of his municipality."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 21. -- Including an even dozen irrepressible frostbite dinghies, there were forty-five craft today in the Larchmont Yacht Club's first special regatta of the Summer season. Down through the list, including the star class, there were twentynine starters, seven more than in the opening races at Rye yesterday.

The ruling of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board on Saturday restricting the sale of beer and wine at bars will be protested to Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the board, by owners of coffee shops and sandwich and beverage stands, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO. May 21. -- Prices of lard advanced last week to the highest level since November, 1931. July lard sold up to $6.92 1/2 a hundredweight, or 7 1/2 cents higher than the previous week's close, and finished at $6.35, a net loss of 50 cents.
Amie McAllister gave a mortgage for $2.100, due Dec. 1, 1935, at 4 per cent, to Edmond A. Scott, on the north side of 138th St., 120 feet east of Edgecombe Av., 17 feet 6 inches wide.

LONDON, May 20. -- President Roosevelt's powerful appeal to the nations of the world and the German Chancellor's conciliatory speech brought about a marked change for the better in the financial markets, which have almost completely recovered from the depression which affected them at the beginning of the week, when the international political situation appeared to be very black.

The Electric Bond and Share Company reports for the twelve months ended on March 31 a net income of $12,009,396 after expenses and taxes, equal, after preferred dividends, to 68 cents a share on 5,267,147 common shares, comparing with $23,412,235, or $3.05 a share earned on 4,965,490 common shares, in the preceding year.

The possibility that a county grand jury would be asked today to hand up a John Doe indictment against the murderer of Edward Albert Ridley, wealthy eccentric, was indicated yesterday as Assistant District Attorney Harold W. Hastings prepared to present the case against the two accountants who, with Ridley's murdered secretary, Lee Weinstein, robbed the old man of $210,000.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The basic idea of the Roosevelt administration, its guiding conception, as expressed by members of it, is a new realization of the duty of the State to the individual and to industry, and a unification of national effort for the common good of the whole.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- A resolution urging President Roosevelt to propose a Senatorial investigation of the private manufacture of arms was adopted today by the convention of the Women's International league for Peace and Freedom here.
The waste pit of a Newark tannery became a subterranean lethal chamber yesterday afternoon, bringing death to five men and injuries to three firemen who braved the deadly fumes in a rescue effort.

MOSCOW, May 21. -- A definite bid for the establishment of normal relations between Soviet Russia and the United States was sounded editorially today in the newspaper For Industrialization, the organ of the Commissariat for Heavy Industry.

DETROIT, May 21. -- With an important refunding plan conference scheduled here for Monday, at which New York banking executives will be present, city officials find themselves distinctly out of tune with Eastern financial representatives on the proposal for a flat reduction of interest.

A full vote in Tuesday's special election in this State is much to be desired. Delegates are to be chosen for the New York Convention which will either ratify or reject the proposed constitutional amendment repealing Federal prohibition. On the general subject the citizens of this Commonwealth have repeatedly expressed themselves in the most emphatic manner.

RIDGE, Md., May 21. -- Father John LaFarge, associate editor of America and one of the founders of the Cardinal Gibbons Institute, made the principal address today at the unveiling of a memorial tablet erected in the entrance of the institute here, commemorating the prelate's "interest and generosity" in connection with the institution.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- In the House today an organized minority of members from both sides of the chamber opened fire on the Steagall Bank Deposit Guarantee Bill, companion measure to the Glass bill. Proposed amendments ranged all the way from a limitation to $10,000 of salaries within the Federal Reserve System to others involving foreign transactions, State banks and the ownership of stock by officers of banks and trust companies.

Stocks marked time yesterday as the progress of tax legislation in Washington was watched anxiously. Acute unsettlement in the wheat market, which carried prices at one time to the level of about three weeks ago, also tended to impair speculative confidence.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (AP). -- The Athletics won their fourth straight game, 6 to 5, today in a see-saw affair that opened a three-day stand with the Browns. Eddie Cihocki's single, scoring Foxx, in the eighth broke a 5-5 deadlock to decide the contest.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 22. -- In a motion filed in United States District Court today the Reconstruction Finance Corporation criticized several purchases and sales of property made in recent years under the Van Sweringen brothers' control of the Missouri Pacific Railroad and asked that a disinterested trustee or trustees be appointed to investigate the deals.

TIENTSIN, Tuesday, May 23. -- General Ho Ying-ching, Nanking War Minister, gave a formal order last night for the evacuation of Peiping by Chinese troops of the Nanking Government, whereupon the soldiers occupying the Eastern part of the city immediately began moving southward.

ALBANY, May 22 (AP). -- Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, today announced the creation of a committee representing employers and organized labor to aid him in administering the new Wicks Law requiring that prevailing wage schedules be made part of all public works contracts.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Professor O.M.W. Sprague, financial adviser to the Bank of England, has been asked to become financial and economic adviser to the United States Government and probably will accept, it was learned on high authority tonight.

In his testimony before the House Naval Committee on Friday, Rear Admiral UPHAM, Chief of the Bureau of Navigation, took a gloomier view of the effect on naval strength and efficiency of the Administration's program of economy than seems to be warranted.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP). -- From an invalid's chair before the Vice President's desk, W.S. Leake, a San Francisco healer, told the Senate today of his friendship with Federal Judge Harold Louderback, to whose defense be came in impeachment proceedings against the California jurist.

Dillon, Read Co. liquidated more than 500,000 common shares of the Seaboard Air Line Railroad in the last two years, according to the list of that road's twenty largest stockholders. The bankers acquired the stock as a result of an unsuccessful attempt at marketing it at the time of the Seaboard's most recent reorganization.

The Japanese contention that China is in chaos was vigorously denied last night by the Chinese Finance Minister, Dr. T.V. Soong, who spoke at the dinner of the China Society of America at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Samuel Seabury, who decline last Friday to permit consideration of his name for the fusion nomination for Mayor, was urged yesterday by W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, to reconsider his decision and lead the fight to "save the city from its present Tammany misgovernment" as a matter of public duty and a fitting climax to his work as counsel of the Hofstadter legislative committee.

LONDON, May 22. -- Derby dopesters were busy today trying to figure out what significance they should attach to Saturday's running of the Derby trial stakes at Lingfield. They recalled that the race was won last year by Tom Walls's April the Fifth, the horse that galloped home in the Derby itself.

GENEVA, May 22. -- Premier Mussolini's Four-Power pact is not near signature, Foreign Minister Paul-Boncour of France today assured France's allies, the Little Entente nations and Poland, who were much perturbed by reports from Rome. He spent with them most of his time outside the disarmament conference meeting, but his explanations left them apparently still dissatisfied.

A substantial increase in net operating income was reported by the Illinois Central Railroad for April. The net loss of the St. Louis Southwestern remained practically unchanged in April compared with a year before.

After more than forty years of as- sociation with the National Surety Corporation and its predecessors, William B. Joyce has relinquished his active executive duties, but re- tained his title as chairman of the board of directors. The corporation is the successor to the National Surety Company, which recently was taken over by the State Insur- ance Department for rehabilitation.

BERLIN, May 22. -- The early German reaction to the position of the United States on disarmament as postulated at the Geneva conference by Norman H. Davis fails to reflect an overabundance of enthusiasm. It is ungrudgingly admitted, however, that the American viewpoint represents an unmistakable desire to mediate in the present impasse, but that desire, it is said, calls for a searching examination before its various implications can be laid bare.

A distinguished gathering of more than 100 Catholic clergymen and laymen, including former Governor Alfred E. Smith, welcomed the Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, the new Apostolic Delegate, on his arrival here yesterday on the Conte di Savoia.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Every effort to do away with the principle of a dole will be made in the distribution of the $500,000,000 for direct relief provided in the Wagner Bill, Harry L. Hopkins, the new Federal Emergency Relief Administrator, declared today upon assuming his duties.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated irregularly in a range of a quarter cent yesterday and ended with gains of 8 to 12 points.

BOSTON, May 22. -- Roger W. Babson, head of the Babson Statistical Organizations, told the Executive Club of the Boston Chamber of Commerce at a luncheon today, that for the first time since 1929 his indices of business activity compare favorably with the corresponding month of the previous year and have carried the improvement above the levels of last September.

BERLIN, May 22. -- Germany will contest the right of the League of Nations to interfere with or even debate the anti-Semitic policy of the Hitler Government, if officially inspired press utterances are an indication of its stand.

BOSTON, May 22 (AP). -- The Red Sox today recorded their third successive victory by nosing out the White Sox, 3 -- 2, in the series opener. George Pipgras held the visitors to seven hits as he gained his second straight triumph since leaving the Yankees.

On a High Note. Chicago, "hog-butcher to the universe," opens her Century of Progress show in a somewhat unexpected manner. The curtain does not go up on the Spirit of Chicago pointing proudly to a panorama of the stockyards and saying "These are my jewels."

The salt-water anglers who tried their luck on Peconic Bay over the week-end returned with a number of interesting stories. But in all the accounts of sizable weakfish taken there was none to match the record-breaking catch reported by Fred J. Conzen of Brooklyn and Nassau Point.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP). -- Cries of "gag" rule arose in the House today as Democratic leaders sought to expedite the Glass-Steagall Bank Reform Bill by shutting down debate, and as a result of continued wrangling only a handful of the bill's provisions were approved despite seven and a half hours of consideration.

Two members of the United States Davis Cup team and a number of other ranking players will take part in the annual invitation tennis tournament of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, which will start on Saturday at South Orange, N.J.

The circus came to Henry Street last night. It was not billed as the "greatest show on earth," but it was received enthusiastically by more than 500 boys and girls whose flushed faces and shrill cries left no doubt how they felt about it. As a matter of fact, it was their own show.

Price movements in commodity futures on local exchanges were irregular yesterday, as the trading volume in most cases dropped sharply. Coffee, hides and silk closed higher; silver was mixed, while sugar, cocoa and rubber were lower.

Professor Lewis Freeman Mott's fifty years of service to City College were marked by the Associate Alumni of the institution last night with a testimonial dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt. Professor Mott, who as an instructor in the department of English since 1884 and chairman of the department since 1897, is the senior member of the college teaching staff, was graduated from City College in the class of '83.

KIEL, Germany, May 22. -- All German naval vessels in this area, from the "pocket battleship" Deutschland to the last tugboat, assembled here today to pay homage to Chancellor Hitler in a way in which no German Chancellor has ever been honored before.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was just reading J. Laurence Laughlin's letter, "The Gold Standard," in THE NEW YORK TIMES. He starts out with the alleged fact, after enumerating our various media of exchange, redeemable in gold -- United States notes, national banknotes, Federal Reserve notes, -- that "the value of each of these media depends on its redeemability in gold."

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- If Assistant Secretary of State Raymond Moley spoke over the radio Saturday night with Presidential inspiration, approval, or either, then an administration, famous for its informality, took a most informal means of announcing to the world an ostensible revision of its world economic policy.
Several taxpayers, in addition to numerous housing parcels, were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

PARIS, May 22. -- France will go to the World Economic Conference "in a broad spirit of conciliation and ready to make all reasonable concessions," declared Minister of Commerce Louis Serre, addressing the representatives of thirty-three nations having exhibits at the annual Paris Fair, in whose honor a luncheon was given today by the French Chamber of Commerce.
CHICAGO, May 22 (AP). -- The Phillies made their season's first appearance here profitable today, defeating the Cubs, 11 to 4.

There is still an Imperial Russian Chancery which confers ranks, degrees and decorations both civil and military. It is on the estate at Saint-Brience, France, of the Grand Duke Cyril Vladimirovich, who proclaimed himself Emperor of all the Russias nine years ago.
BOWIE, Md., May 22 (AP). -- Don Pedro, carrying the silks of Mrs. M. Segal, registered a surprise in the Valor Purse, a-mile-and-a-sixteenth event for the better-grade performers at Bowie today.

BERLIN, May 22. -- The Nazi-controlled German P.E.N. Club has decided to send a delegation to the International P.E.N. Club meeting at Ragusa, Yugoslavia to defy world criticism of the Nazi attitude toward liberal authors and fight the disciplinary action that may be proposed.

A plea to garment manufacturers and distributers to formulate their own code of business, ethics and labor agreements to offset government control was made last night at a meeting of the Merchants Ladies' Garment Association, at the Governor Clinton Hotel.

Semi-official explanations of the new theory of government about to be brought into force at Washington distinctly imply the end of American "rugged individualism." Paraphrasing the poet, the individual is to wither, and the State become more and more.

Widespread interest was aroused in realty circles yesterday over the decision handed down by Supreme Court Justice William Harman Black affecting the granting of a moratorium in mortgage suits. Justice Black's opinion, it is said, will have a far-reaching effect upon future cases to determine whether a defendant in a mortgage suit is entitled to a moratorium because of the unusual economic conditions now existing.

LONDON, May 22. -- Today's declaration at Geneva by Norman H. Davis, the United States Ambassador at Large, was hailed here tonight as an utterance of the highest importance. It means, according to British observers, that the disarmament conference is going to succeed, that the economic conference will meet in an encouraging atmosphere and that the whole train of world events has been set moving away from war and in the direction of organized peace.

PARIS, May 22. -- "Ambassador Davis's splendid exposition of the American thesis on disarmament, consultation and security conforms exactly with my conversations with President Roosevelt in Washington," Edouard Herriot told this correspondent this afternoon over the telephone from Lyons.

United States Government bonds were strong yesterday in an otherwise irregularly lower bond market on the Stock Exchange. Federal issues were bid up 1-32 to 9-32 for the active loans other than registered bonds in response to an item printed on a financial news ticker that the Federal Reserve Banks had actually begun substantial openmarket purchases of these issues.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP). -- Revised estimates of the 1932 cotton crop issued today by the Department of Agriculture placed production at 13,002,000 equivalent 500-pound bales and ginnings at 13,001,508, equivalent 500-pound bales, with yield of lint 173.3 pounds per acre picked.

AMHERST, Mass., May 22. -- Few people ever learn to read, "really read," Ray Stannard Baker declared in his address of welcome to delegates to the annual meeting of the American Association for Adult Education, in the Jones Library here today.
PEIPING, May 22. -- Peiping had a day of alarms today as the invading Japanese drew near.

United States Attorney George Z. Medalie continued yesterday to pile up circumstantial evidence on the legitimacy of Charles E. Mitchell's sale of National City Bank stock to his wife at the banker's trial for income tax evasion.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The inquiry into the affairs of the banking firm of J.P. Morgan Co. will begin tomorrow before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee. It has aroused more interest in Washington than any hearing in many years, as the present head of the firm has never been subjected to such public examination, and the only time the elder J.P. Morgan was examined was before the Pujo committee years ago.

Eddie (Kid) Wolfe. Memphis welterweight, and Paulie Walker of Trenton fought a ten-round draw in the main bout of the regular weekly boxing show at the St. Nicholas Arena last night, before a crowd of 1,500.

Professor HOUSMAN, the Shropshire Lad, gave the Leslie Stephen Lecture "On the Name and Nature of Poetry" at Cambridge the other day. To him poetry is rather physical than intellectual. If a line of poetry strays into his memory while he is shaving, his "skin "bristles so that the razor ceases "to act."

A class for school teachers at the Police Academy to train them to fight juvenile delinquency will be started this Fall, according to Police Commissioner Bolan, who spoke at the annual dinner meeting of the Lower East Side Community Council last night in the Y. M.C.A. at 8 East Third Street.

Summer Apparel Call Gains. Increased reorders for women's Summer apparel were reported in the market here yesterday, with the indications being that the week will be more active than last. Rising temperatures at the week-end brought the desired movement of Summer merchandise for retailers, who are reordering quickly.

MANCHESTER, N.H., May 22. -- Mobilization of the 197th Coast Guard Artillery Regiment was ordered tonight by Acting Adjutant General George Morrill in response to an appeal by Mayor Damase Caron following a riot of about 4,000 textile strikers late today at the main gate of the Amoskeag Mills.
Jumping Joe Savoldi, erstwhile football star at Notre Dame, evened his score with Ed (Strangler) Lewis. Kentucky veteran, in their finish wrestling bout at Madison Square Garden last night.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 22 (AP). -- John Tasker Howard, noted American critic, composer and author, defended American music and composers today and singled out Arturo Toscanini in citing alleged "discrimination" against them by "conductors in high places."

Modern youth wishes to enjoy freedom before it has found truth, Dr. Hugh Latimer Burleson declared last night in a baccalaureate sermon before the graduating class of the General Theological Seminary, at 175 Ninth Avenue. Dr. Burleson is the assistant to the presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church.
The Jews of this city will be called upon to contribute $1,000,000 of the $2,000,000 fund to be raised by the American Joint Distribution Committee for the relief of German Jews.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Two separate plans for circumventing the impasse reached by the administration in any attempt to place the agricultural adjustment act in operation in the face of the American pledge of a tariff truce pending the outcome of the World Economic Conference were under consideration tonight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Professor W.E. Kemmerer of Princeton, in discussing "Economic Factors in World Recovery," has recommended for America the balancing of its budget, the abstention from monetary inflation, and the definite cancellation of interallied debts.
Behind the superb pitching of their distinguished lefthander, Vernon Gomez, the Yankees opened a three-game series with the Indians at the Stadium yesterday with a 3-to-0 victory.

PARIS, May 22. -- The trend of prices was irregrular, while a feeling of uncertainty prevailed on the Bourse today. Reports of the possibility of imminent creation of a dollar stabilization fund by the United States caused much conjecture as to what would be the effect on the stock market.

Alumni attending the commencement exercises of the Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street, began their activities last night at the annual dinner under the auspices of the New York Alumni Club in the refectory of the seminary.

The desirability of rational and effective control over the production of petroleum has been increasingly apparent. Governor "Alfalfa BILL" MURRAY did not solve the problem when he called out the troops in 1931. Hastily adopted systems of State proration have for the most part broken down, while efforts of producers themselves to agree on methods of control have been thwarted largely by Federal legislation.

Monday, May 22, 1933. Money market was dull. Business was small and quotations for all classes unchanged from those which prevailed last week. Stock Exchange call loans continued at 1 per cent, with the usual concessions on governments and Federal checks ruling in the counter trading.

The trial of Isidor J. Kresel on charges of misuse of the funds of an affiliate of the Bank of United States, of which he was director and counsel, was adjourned to Sept. 15 yesterday by Supreme Court Justice George H. Taylor Jr., of Westchester County, in the Criminal Courts Building.

The Italian liner Conte di Savoia arrived at the Ambrose Channel Lightship at 10 A.M. yesterday after making the voyage from Genoa, including stops at Villefranche and Gibraltar, in 5 days 22 hours. She bettered previous records for the ocean crossing from Mediterranean ports by 14 hours.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial "Catholics in Spain" you reach the conclusion that the Spanish persecution of Catholics is not fairly compared to the persecution of the Jews in Germany.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The text of the speech delivered today before the general commission of the Disarmament Conference at Geneva by Norman H. Davis, chief delegate of the United, States, was made public by the State Department as follows:

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The State of Illinois was ordered by the Supreme Court today to furnish the money necessary for the Chicago Sanitary District to complete its sewage disposal plants by Dec. 31, 1938, the date effective under the decree issued by the court in April, 1930.

A pedigreed Irish terrier, with a green ribbon around his neck, was presented yesterday to former Police Commissioner Edward P. Mulrooney, now chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, at a luncheon given in his honor by the Advisory Crime Commission in the Cosmopolitan Club.

BERLIN, May 22. -- If Dr. Walther Ruppin, Nazi commissioner heading the Brandenburg Medical Society, could have his way no person of Jewish extraction would be allowed in the liberal professions, especially not in medicine. A manifesto issued by him stresses the confidential relations between doctor and patient and goes on:
FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., May 22. -- Colonel A.S. Cowan, commandant, presented diplomas to 48 officers and 147 enlisted men at the annual commencement of the Army Signal School here.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP). -- Shutting off a drive in the closing frames, the Senators today won a 6 to 5 decision from the Tigers in the opening game of their series.

The Friars' Club six-story home at 106-10 West Forty-eighth Street, occupied by the club since 1916, was bid in by the Bank for Savings yesterday at a foreclosure auction sale. Another feature of the Manhattan realty market was purchase of an additional east side parcel by the Denison Realty Corporation, Charles F. Noyes, president.
The text of an appeal last night by Postmaster General James A. Farley for a large vote for delegates committed to repeal follows:
Maritime Day was observed yesterday in New York and other cities to mark the 114th anniversary of the sailing of the Savannah, first steamship to cross the ocean.

About twenty members of the Food Workers Industrial Union descended on the plant of the Arrow Dairy Company at 118 Hudson Street early yesterday morning, wrecked butter and eggs being loaded on trucks and kidnapped six employes of the dairy.

PARIS, May 22. -- Charles Rist, French financial expert who accompanied former Premier Herriot to Washington, indicates in an article in tonight's Information how he considers temporary stabilization of the dollar and pound against the franc can be accomplished.
WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Leaving behind at Camp Hunt over 2,600 veterans recruited for the reforestation army, a remnant of about 350 ''die-hard" bonus marchers departed today.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- A resolution commending President Roosevelt's international and economic policies, but "deploring and regretting" his support of the prohibition repeal amendment and his "use of his high office and of the White House to advertise the beer business" was adopted here tonight by the Southern Baptist Convention.

A conference arranged by Representative William F. Brunner with L.K. Roberts, chief national bank examiner, and representatives of five banks in Queens was held yesterday at the office of the Controller of the Currency, 33 Liberty Street, for the purpose of planning a possible merger of the institutions whose operations have been restricted since the bank holiday.

Eighty-one players, the majority of them professionals, have entered the metropolitan open golf championship tournament, according to the list of pairings and starting times for the first eighteen-hole round at the Winged Foot Golf Club, Mamaroneck, N.Y., on Thursday, as announced yesterday by the championship committee.

Tony Rensa's single in the eleventh inning scored Hank Leiber, Giants' recruit, from second base with the winning run to give Jersey City its second straight victory over the Bears yesterday at West Side Park, Jersey City. The score was 4 -- 3.
CINCINNATI, May 22. -- With Hal Schumacher pitching another splendid game, the Giants today recovered their winning ways and rode rough-shod over the Reds.

ST. LOUIS, May 22 (AP). -- Pepper Martin, playing despite a sprained ankle that handicapped him in the field, hit a home run with two men on base to break up a pitching duel between Ed Brandt and Bill Walker and give the Cardinals a 3-0 victory over the Braves in ten innings today.

Hank Mills, still a boy in his teens but already a veteran of the saddle, had a narrow escape from serious injury yesterday in the Belle Harbor Purse at Jamaica when he tried to jam his mount Iseult through a space along the rail that was too small.

GENEVA, May 22. -- In the interests of peace and world recovery the United States agreed today to renounce isolation and, in certain cases, freedom of the seas, provided all the rest of the world would join it in reducing armaments.

Details of two plans, under an agreement with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, for refinancing mortgage loan companies whose bonds are secured by mortgages guaranteed by the Maryland Casualty Company and the United States Fidelity and Guarantee Company, were announced yesterday by investment bankers sponsoring the plan.
A revival of Ibsen's "Ghosts" will be presented this evening by George H. Brennan at the Sutton Theatre, 330 East Fifty-sixth Street.

Miss Caroline M. Gerrish, former headmistress and owner of the Gerrish Collegiate School, a girls' preparatory school organized in Englewood, N.J., and later moved to New York, and an active alumna of Vassar, died yesterday of influenza at her home, 310 West Ninety-fifth Street, after an illness of three months.

At the Annual General Court of the London Assurance held at their office, No. 1 King William Street, London, E.C., on May 10th, Mr. R. Olaf Hambro, the Governor, who presided, after dealing with the development of the organization, currency adjustments and other business, made the following statements: --

The May Ball given last night in honor of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt for the benefit of the two lunch and rest rooms established by her in this city for unemployed girls, was marked by military and naval pageantry. Staged in the historic Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, the ball was attended by one of the largest and most brilliant assemblies of New York society this season.

After a conference with Inspector Francis J. Kear and detectives working on the case, Assistant Chief Inspector John J. Sullivan admitted yesterday that the police apparently had come to a dead-end in their attempt to solve the murder of Edward Albert Ridley, wealthy eccentric.

For the first time in more than sixteen years the name of the Chase National Bank will appear today in connection with competitive bidding for a new municipal bond issue, signalizing the discontinuance of the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation as an active securities affiliate of the bank in accordance with action taken by stockholders of the bank on May 16.

CHICAGO, May 22. -- Liquidation of wheat on the Board of Trade, which has been in progress more than a week, was continued today. There was a little buying early in sympathy with corn, but the pressure was too heavy for the limited demand and prices dropped more than 2 cents a bushel from Saturday's final quotations to the lowest level since April 29.

ROME, May 22. -- The four-power pact for the preservation of Europe's peace, as agreed upon in Rome, is expected to be initialed by the participants in less than two weeks, according to a responsible Italian official. Its acceptance by France, Great Britain, Germany and Italy in virtually its present form is regarded as assured.
Premiums on bonds for retail beer sellers will be reduced materially as the result of action taken yesterday by Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Board.

The possibility of a challenge for the America's Cup by W.L. Stephenson, owner of the new yacht Velsheda, has aroused great interest in England. The sloop, built by Charles E. Nicholson, is the first one constructed under the changed cup rules and is really from the designs made for a Shamrock VI for the late Sir Thomas Lipton.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The combination of the declaration of United States policy by Norman H. Davis at Geneva and the informal agreement on the Four-Power Pact at Rome should give the disarmament conference practically a clear track, in the opinion of officials here.

HAVANA, May 22. -- The appearance of various new armed bands in many parts of Cuba indicates that the revolt against the Machado administration, far from being crushed, is increasing in momentum, and undoubtedly this week will see serious fighting.
PITTSBURGH, May 22. -- Reversals of form being strictly a Dodger dish, the Carey athletes today went into fourth place by defeating the league-leading Pirates, 3 to 0.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 22. -- The leading social event of the early Summer season here will be a supper-dance and Bavarian Biergarten party at the Greenwich Country Club next Monday evening for the benefit of the Stepney Fresh Air Home, Stepney, Conn.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP). -- By order of the White House, work has been halted on construction of a dam at the government's Muscle Shoals property for which the Hoover administration contracted in its closing days.

Sidney H. Levy, 17 years old, valedictorian of the graduating class at Lafayette High School, Buffalo, N.Y., has won a trip to Europe as first prize in the League of Nations Association's seventh annual competitive examination for high school students on the League of Nations.
WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 19:

Irving Wexler, better known as Waxey Gordon, wealthy beer distributer and all-round racketeer, pleaded not guilty to income-tax evasion yesterday. He appeared before Judge Goddard in Federal Court and was held in $100,000 bail until June 5, when a trial date may be set.

SHANGHAI, May 22. -- Official estimates put the number of Chinese residents of the native section of Tientsin who are now taking refuge in the foreign concessions at more than 150,000. At least 50,000 passed through the gates into the Japanese concession alone in the last three days.

AUTEUIL, France, May 22. -- The United States contingent of four in the French hard-court tennis championships -- Frank X. Shields, Miss Helen Jacobs, Mrs. Dorothy Andrus Burke and Miss Elizabeth Ryan -- was still intact today after the opening round of doubles.
Mayor O'Brien has discovered that virtually everybody in New York has a different idea of how Central Park should be used, he declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Characterizing the entry of the Port of New York Authority into the lighterage case before the Interstate Commerce Commission as "vicious partisanship," J.H. Tiffany, Attorney General of New Jersey, backed a request to the commission today to divide the Port of New York at the Hudson River for rate-making purposes.
TOKYO, Tuesday, May 23. -- Colonel Honma, spokesman for the War Office, at 10:30 A.M. today made the following statement to your correspondent.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 22. -- With seven of the fifteen ranking players of the Women's Eastern Lawn Tennis Association competing, the seventh annual women's Eastern clay court tennis championship tournament got under way today on the courts of the Montclair A.C.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 22. -- Dr. Mabel S. Douglass, dean of the New Jersey College for Women since its establishment in 1918, who has been on leave of absence during this academic year because of ill health, will not return to her duties, President Robert C. Clothier of Rutgers University announced today.

CHICAGO, May 22 (AP). -- Breaking away to a four-length lead, C. E. Davison's No More, a 5-year-old son of Friar Rock -- Once More, today won the $2,500 added Inaugural Handicap, feature of the opening program at Washington Park.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- A broad program to deal with the situation created in Germany by the attitude of the Hitler government toward Jews was formulated today by the American Jewish Congress in resolutions adopted at its closing sessions.

LONDON, May 22 (Canadian Press). -- The West Indies had scored 190 runs for the loss of seven wickets in the second innings of its match with the Marylebone Cricket Club at the close of play at Lord's today.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The $2,000,000,000 bill for refinancing home mortgages was reported favorably today by the Senate Finance Committee, after amendments greatly liberalizing this measure already passed by the House had been inserted.

Yesterday's address by Mr. NORMAN DAVIS at Geneva naturally followed the lines of President ROOSEVELT'S message to the world last week. The main points are the same, though they were emphasized and perhaps more clearly defined in detail by Mr. DAVIS.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Darwin P. Kingsley has returned to 660 Park Avenue after passing several months in Arizona and California.

Mr. MORSE CARTWRIGHT in his address yesterday at the opening session of the American Association for Adult Education asserts that the insinuation into education of "principles definitely Fascist in nature" is already taking place in this country.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 22. -- Miss Charlotte Glutting, New Jersey star, scored another triumph today when she led a strong field in the qualifying round of the women's metropolitan golf championship by registering a 79 over the testing 6,350-yard Cherry Valley course.

BERLIN, May 22. -- The Boerse began the week in a more optimistic mood, heartened, according to brokers, principally by the conclusion of the four-power pact. Covering by shorts lowered quotations on leading stock issues 1 or 2 points at the opening, but with some renewal of public interest most of the active list scored further advances.

IT was a registered letter and it looked important. It came in the wake of a sad Sunday that left thousands of native and naturalized New Yorkers dazed and gloomy. The Yanks had lost. The Giants were thrown heavily in a double-header. The Brooklyn boys had dropped two to the Cubs. Perhaps this important letter carried a message of hope or a plan for regaining lost ground.

Milton Aborn, the current impresario of the St. James, continued last evening his genteel delving into the catalogue of Gilbert and Sullivan. His most recent addition to the lore of Spring revival was "Patience," the history of the English literary uprising.

Although the fire insurance department of the London Assurance was again disappointing, reflecting partly conditions in the United States, the operations of the company over all its lines in 1932 were profitable, R. Olaf Hambro, governor, reported at the annual general court in London on May 10.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Although the expected final conference between President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull did not materialize today, it was believed that the administration bill giving the President power to negotiate reciprocal agreements at the London Economic Conference would be presented to Congress within the next few days.

The true condition of Joseph W. Harriman, now recuperating from superficial knife wounds, self-inflicted, was the subject of an acrimonious debate between his attorney, George S. Leisure, and United States Attorney George Z. Medalie yesterday when the indicted banker's case was called before Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard.

A new social philosophy that will subordinate the production of daily necessities to the building of a richer cultural life was envisioned yesterday afternoon by Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, in an address at Sherry's before 300 members of the girls' work section of the Welfare Council of New York City.

Nick Masters, a member of the American Olympic team in 1932, de- feated Bob Pastor, Golden Gloves champion, in a 175-pound class final of the amateur boxing tournament at the New York A.C. last night.
