Two small boys, playing last evening in a vacant house at 130-51 Fowler Avenue, Flushing, were chased from the building by a neighbor a few seconds before the structure collapsed.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- President Roosevelt's National Industrial Recovery Bill was broadened tonight to include a $700,000,000 tax program as the House Ways and Means Committee decided to provide new revenues to finance the $3,300,000,000 public works program and to make more secure the credit of the United States Government.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Secretary Wallace and George N. Peek, chief administrator under the Agricultural Adjustment Act, today selected as cotton production administrator C.A. Cobb, an Atlanta, farm editor. They named Guy C. Shephard of Evanston, Ill., a retired packer, to administer processing and trade agreement activities for packing house products.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As I have been a resident of Westchester County for a great number of years and still own property in that county, I am particularly interested in any public remarks made concerning it.

Announcement has been made by the officials of the Intercollegiate Polo Association of a new system of handicapping to be used this year in the intercollegiate championship at the Westchester Country Club at Rye, June 10, 14 and 17.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on May 17 shows increases for the week of $28,000,000 in loans and investments, $172,000,000 in net demand deposits and $21,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and a decrease of $47,000,000 in time deposits.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A morning of mid-May cloaked with fog would not have been selected for watching an ocean liner arrive at its North River pier. And yet, because of a request to meet certain passengers on one of the largest Cunarders, the writer witnessed some aspects of diffused light and color that seemed worthy of report to those interested in unusual atmospheric effects.

NORTH PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 22. -- Frank Richards, retired mechanical engineer and former editor of engineering publications, died here last night at the age of 94 in his home at 154 Sycamore Avenue. He continued to write until two weeks ago, when he submitted an article to The Compressed Air Magazine.
Two Industries have announced plans for action in line with Presi- dent Roosevelt's program for recovery.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The government reorganization plan which was reported completed and in the hands of the President, is still far from complete as to detail and will not be finished this week, it was said tonight on high authority.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 22 (AP). -- Al Aspen, driver, and Mitz Davis, mechanic, both of Philadelphia, escaped serious injury in a sensational accident today while trying to qualify for the 500-mile automobile race to be run May 30.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 22. -- Sympathetic consideration of the objects sought by the National Industrial Recovery Bill was urged upon the electrical industry today by Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, and J. S. Tritle, president of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association and vice president and general manager of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, in addresses before the policies division of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

FREE CITY OF DANZIG, May 22. -- German Nationalists expect to obtain dominance in the Free City's Volkstag in next Sunday's elections and form their own government. This, however, will be a formality, for they are already the masters.
Federal funds for completion of the Triborough Bridge and for other large public improvements here will be sought in Washington by two committees representing the city administration.

The voters of New York State will register today their stand on the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. The polls in the city will be open from noon to 10 P.M. for the balloting for 150 delegates to a State convention which will meet on June 27 to fulfill the voters' mandate.
New York State voted yesterday by a tremendous majority to ratify the Congressional resolution to repeal the Eighteenth Amendment.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Application for a loan of about $35,000,000 to complete the Triborough Bridge project, which would link Manhattan with the Bronx and Queens, will be filed with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation within forty-eight hours, according to Fred C. Lemmerman of the Triborough Bridge Authority and George H. Combs Jr., its counsel, who conferred today with Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the corporation, and the experts of the engineering division.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Reforestation camps for women, where they can be employed on emergency conservation work under the same conditions as men, though in different lines of work, may be established if women in sufficient numbers desire them, Mrs. Roosevelt said at her press conference today.

A Protestantism free from any alliance with the present industrial order and capitalistic system was advocated yesterday by the Rev. Dr. William P. Merrill, pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church, in an address to the alumni of the Union Theological Seminary at their annual meeting in the James Memorial Chapel, on the seminary grounds at Broadway and 120th Street.

TIENTSIN, May 23. -- Six hundred Japanse soldiers from the garrison in the Japanese concession in Tientsin completed this afternoon one of the most remarkable journeys in military history, having traversed eighty-eight miles of railway through territory occupied by hostile Chinese forces, which had been defeated by other Japanese armies, without a single shot being fired or a single hostile demonstration by the Chinese.
Nassau and Suffolk Counties, once considered dry strongholds, turned in unexpectedly large majorities for repeal of the prohibition amendment at yesterday's special election.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP). -- Saying the added tax burden in the National Industry Recovery Bill "should be cheerfully borne" because of the employment and benefits to flow from it, the Ways and Means Committee tonight filed its formal report on the $3,300,000,000 measure for House action Thursday.

BOSTON, May 23 (AP). -- With the Red Sox hitting into double plays almost every time they had a runner on base, Milt Gaston had little trouble hurling the White Sox to a 7-0 victory today to even the series.

Declaring that "the court may not require the author to put refined language into the mouths of primitive people," Magistrate Benjamin Greenspan in Jefferson Market Court dismissed yesterday the case brought by John S. Sumner of the New York Society for the Suppression of Vice against the Viking Press for publishing "God's Little Acre," a novel by Erskine Caldwell.
World Elect. Seniors If the nations were to go in for one huge Class Day questionaire, then the 1933 poll might read somethings as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: At the Continental Congress held in Washington more than forty States were represented by some 4,000 delegates, who came by hitchhiking, auto, truck and train, to give expression to a degree of solidarity and a unity of purpose for economic reconstruction which scarcely expected.

LONDON, May 23. -- The appointment of Professor O.M.W. Sprague as financial and economic adviser to the United States Government was acclaimed today by British opinion, which expects that as executive assistant to Secretary Woodin he will help devise the machinery, in the form of an exchange equalization fund, to control the dollar.

Authority to approve of sales agreements by which the distributer of a manufactured article agrees with the producer not to sell to any one who will not maintain the resale price agreed upon by the two parties, is contained in the pending Industry Recovery Bill, David L. Podell, who assisted in preparation of the measure, told the luncheon meeting of the Trade Association Executives in New York City at the Hotel Lexington yesterday.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 23 -- Aware of the "wholly and utterly revolutionary" nature of the proposed National Industrial Recovery Act, the electrical manufacturing Industry, by vote of its members tonight, became the first large industry to signify its intention of embarking on the new experiment of partnership between government and industry.

Acting, probably, upon the conviction that it is about time the theatre-going public should be treated to another taste of Henrik Ibsen, George H. Brennan brought forth a revival of "Ghosts" last evening. As it happened, he went as far east as the Sutton Theatre on East Fifty-sixth Street to unwrap the shrouded colossus and the consequence is that no one need feel the pangs of conscience in passing it up.

Lifelike puppets made from old stockings, tin-can locomotives and a variety of other articles were included in the vacation exhibit of work by pupils of the Ethical Culture School, 33 Central Park West, which was held yesterday under the auspices of the Parents and Teachers Association of the school.

DETROIT, May 23 -- A bond-refunding agreement that will save the city of Detroit $14,000,000 in the next thirty years was reached today at a conference of Acting Mayor Couzens, members of the City Council and B.A. Tompkins, representative of New York financial interests, who hold $175,000,000 in Detroit bonds.

Jacob Mellon and three other officials of the Affiliated Laundry Owners Club of Brooklyn, who are said virtually to control the laundry industry in that borough, were indicted on charges of conspiracy by the Kings County grand jury yesterday. They were arrested on bench warrants and arraigned before County Judge John J. Fitzgerald.

An industry-wide committee to represent cotton manufacturers in relations with the government with respect to the administration of the National Industrial Recovery Act and the Agricultural Adjustment Act has been selected, it was announced yesterday, following conferences between T.M. Marchant, president of the American Cotton Manufacturers Association; Ernest N. Hood, president of the National Association of Cotton Manufacturers, and George A. Sloan, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute.

The Rev. Richard A.D. Beaty will be instituted as rector of St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church, Twentieth Street, near Ninth Avenue, at 8 P.M. tomorrow, the evening of Ascension Day. Bishop William T. Manning will officiate and will preach the sermon of institution.

The rates charged by public utility companies throughout the State soon will be examined at pubic hearings of the Public Service Commission, Governor Lehman declared yesterday after a conference with Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the regulatory body.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 23 (AP). -- The East carried off major honors in the two remaining musical contests today under direction of the National Federation of Music Corps in biennial convention here.
TRENTON, N.J., May 23 -- When the Senate reconvenes tomorrow, it is expected that Governor Moore will submit four nominations to the State Highway Commission.

The Film Productions Corporation, subsidiary of the Paramount-Publix Corporation, functioned only to establish new credit for the parent company, according to testimony yesterday before Henry K. Davis, Federal referee in bankruptcy, at 140 Nassau Street.
PARIS, May 23. -- Mile. Suzanne Lenglen is ready to play Mrs. Helen Wills Moody any time "if it is made worth her while."

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- J.P. Morgan, immediately after being sworn for his testimony before the Senate Stock Market Investigating Committee today, said that the members of his firm desired to "help the committee as much as we can to perform their wishes," and that he had prepared a short statement of his own views regarding the duties and uses off private bankers, which he desired to read. Mr. Morgan's statement was then read by him.
The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

Vocational training for future tribal chiefs is planned in Basutoland, South Africa, according to Oswin B. Bull, director of technical education in the territory where 600,000 blacks live in peace under their chiefs and under the British Colonial Office commissioners.

PARIS, May 23 -- Any doubt that France intends to sign the fourpower pact was dissipated today when Premier Daladier emphatically expressed his intenion to do so during a budgetary debate in the Chamber of Deputies this afternoon. The subject came up quite extraneously in the course of a tiff between the Premier and his redoubtable Nationalist opponent, Louis Marin.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. of Wilmington, Del., have purchased for cash control of the Remington Arms Company, Inc., M. Hartley Dodge, chairman of the board of the Remington Company announced yesterday, according to The Associated Press.
Awards of 280 prizes, medals and special mentions were announced yesterday at the public opening of the seventy-fourth annual exhibition of the art schools of Cooper Union.

BEAR MOUNTAIN. N.Y., May 23. -- Executives or State parks from various sections of the country gathered at Bear Mountain Inn here today for the annual meeting of the National Conference on State Parks. They spent the day inspecting this section of Palisades Interstate Park and in informal discussions of administrative problems.

WARSAW, May 23 -- Poland is determined to obstruct the negotiations of the Mussolini four-power pact with all available means and will never recognize the treaty as enforcing peace in Europe, according to opinion unanimously expressed here.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 23. -- Manhattan College's baseball team scored a 6-4 victory over Upsala College today. Rescigno, star Jasper hurler, was called on when Karl weakened in the seventh and succeeded in checking the Vikings during he closing innings.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- This list of directorships or trusteeships held by members of the Morgan firm was given to the Senate committee today:

The complaint in the suit by the Vitt Realty Corporation of the Bronx to restrain the Board of Estimate from granting a tax exemption to the Hillside Homes Housing Corporation was dismissed yesterday. Supreme Court Justice Ingraham acted on the contention of the Corporation Counsel that because the complaint failed to give the location of the project, the suit must be rejected.

Running in the form which gained him a second place in the Paumonok Handicap. Okapi from the Brookmeade Stable of Mrs. Isabel Sloan, yesterday won the featured Mayfair purse at Jamaica. Held at 5 to 1 in a field of five, Okapi took the lead in the stretch and held on gamely to finish with three-quarters of a length to spare.
The taking of the seventeen-pound three-ounce weakfish in Peconic Bay has already whetted the enthusiasm of a number of fishermen who are out on the waters of the bay every day of the week.

CHICAGO, May 23 (AP). -- Routing Guy Bush in the fourth inning and continuing their furious slugging at the expense of Bud Tinning. Burleigh Gromes and Beryl Richmond, the Phillies today hammered nineteen hits, to defeat the Cubs, 9 to 5, for their second straight victory of the series.

"And after the earthquake a " fire, but the Lord was not in the "fire, and after the fire a still " small voice." That voice has been speaking through church ministrations in Long Beach, Cal., since the catastrophe. With 25,000 homes badly damaged or entirely destroyed the Episcopal Church called in thirty trained clergymen to survey the needs of those who had suffered from the earthquake.

Throngs visited five private gardens here which were shown yesterday under the auspices of the Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation's New York committee for the benefit of Stratford Hall, ancestral home of the Lees of Virginia.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Following is the text of J.P. Morgan's statement today to the Senate Banking Committee:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Under the title "Authority Over Pensions," in, THE TIMES of May 17, is a letter containing statements which are palpably incorrect and likely to cause military pensioners of the Civil War and the Spanish-American War to worry unnecessarily over their pensions.

An unemployment relief appropriation of $5,000,000 for June was added to the calendar of the Board of Estimate's Committee of the Whole yesterday and will be taken up in executive session, probably on Friday.

Orvil R. Whitaker, president of the Ahumada Lead Company, announced yesterday to stockholders that the board of directors had adopted unanimously a resolution that the company be dissolved. In a letter of explanation he wrote:
A military parade, a water pageant and a golden jubilee dinner at the Hotel St. George will mark the observance today of the fiftieth anniversary of the opening of the Brooklyn Bridge.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Abolition of frea lighterage in New York Harbor, as urged by New Jersey and some of its communities and business organizations, would mean the crippling of commerce of the port and would deprive the whole metropolitan area of the competitive rail facilities it now enjoys, according to Parker McCollester counsel for New York and the State Chamber of Commerce, speaking before the Interstate Commerce Commission today.

Three grand larceny indictments were returned yesterday against two men who are accused of helping Lee Weinstein to swindle his employer, Edward A. Ridley, 88-year-old wealthy eccentric, out of $210,000. Ridley and Weinstein, his secretary, were murdered May 10 in their sub-cellar office at 59 Alien Street and the crime is still unsolved.

The estate of George L. (Tex) Rickard, who died Jan. 6, 1929, was insufficient to pay his bequests in full, it was disclosed yesterday when Deputy Tax Commissioner Jacob Manicoff fixed the value at $453,223 gross and $166,662 net.
DETROIT, May 23 (AP) -- The Detroit News today says:

Ending a stalemate that had lasted more than a week, the share market resumed the advance yesterday along with bonds and commodities. On the Stock Exchange there were gains of 1 to more than 5 points, wheat recovered all of its loss of the day before and cotton added as much as $1.25 a bale to its open market value.
Approximately $500,000 postal money orders and certified checks has been received by the City Alcoholic Beverage Control Board from applicants for licenses to sell beer and wine at retail.

TRENTON. N.J., May 23. -- A plank written into the tentative platform at the session today of the Republican State Convention here declares against imposition of new taxes or further bond issues, but leaves the door open for either in the event of "extreme emergencies."

Requests to postpone the ban on the retail sale of loose milk, scheduled to begin June 1, were rejected by the Board of Health yesterday at its weekly session, according to Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, City Commissioner of Health. The ban, fought by the Community Councils and some other groups, will affect about 60,000 stores in the city.

The purpose of the economic program of the Roosevelt administration is the attainment of "an architecturally more harmonious national life," and "there is no cause for alarm" in the close government supervision of economic affairs which the program involves, Raymond Moley, Assistant Secretary of State, declared yesterday.

The possibility that attorneys for Joseph W. Harriman will offer a plea of insanity when he goes on trial for falsifying accounts of the bank bearing his name was suggested yesterday when the indicted banker, who recently tried to commit suicide, was brought back to the Regent Nursing Home, 115 East Sixty-first Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Much space has been devoted to the problems in city finance and financing which result from the failure of taxpayers, because of current economic difficulties, to meet promptly the taxes and assessments levied against their property.

CHICAGO, May 23. -- Resumption of talk of inflation just as the grain markets were well liquidated caused a sharp advance in prices today on the Board of Trade, wheat at the extreme gaining as much as 2 1/2 cents a bushel from yesterday's finish. Profit-taking, selling against offers and sales by local operators checked the advance, but the finish was near the top at net gains of 1 7/8 s to 2 3/8 cents.

The need of concerted action by real estate managers, brokers, architects and builders toward a solution of the housing problems of those unable to pay high rents is stressed in a statement issued by Peter Grimm, president of William A. White Sons, realty brokers and chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission.

The Oxford Movement in the Anglican Church stands for social reform as well as Catholic dogma and rituals, the Rev. Dr. Gregory Mabry, rector of St. Paul's Church, Clinton and Carroll Streets, Brooklyn, said yesterday before the alumni of the General Theological Seminary.

Lacking a genuine interest in women's fashions, the average man wields virtually no influence on feminine styles, members of the Fashion Group, holding their monthly luncheon meeting at the Hotel Ambassador yesterday, were told by leading retail executives.

BOSTON, Mass., May 23 -- The American Unitarian Association at its annual meeting here today voted to join with the Universalist faith in the formation of the Free Church of America. The matter will go before the Universalist General Convention at Worcester in October.

Taken unawares as they sat in the living room of their three-room flat in Ridgewood, Queens, early last night, a man and a young woman were shot and killed instantly, the victims, apparently, of gangsters.
Sir Josiah Stamp, chairman of the London, Midland Scottish Railways, director of the Bank of England and a noted British economist, arrived last night from London on the White Star liner Majestic.

Uncertainty as to the policies to be followed by the Federal coordinator contemplated by legislation pending in Congress was said yesterday to be delaying the move by the railroads to cut their basic passenger fare. Started by the Louisville Nashville, this policy was taken up by the Western lines.
CHICAGO, May 23. -- The strength of the American Federation of Labor was thrown behind Mayor Kelly and State's Attorney Courtney today in their battle to rid Chicago labor unions of racketeering.

CHICAGO, May 23. -- An increased run of hogs here met with a relatively slow demand today and the average dropped 15 cents to $4.85 a hundred pounds, while the top was off a like amount at $5. The upturn in lard appeared to have little effect on the general market, which was 10 to 20 cents lower, with some light weights and pigs off as much as 25 cents.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Japan would welcome a reciprocal trade agreement with the United States, containing mutual advantages and concessions, and is convinced of the desirability of stabilizing the yen, Viscount Kikujiro Ishii said on his arrival here to conduct his country's preliminary discussions with President Roosevelt looking to the World Economic and Monetary Conference.

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation reports for the twelve months ended on April 30 a consolidated net income of $9,611,187 after taxes, charges, depreciation, underlying dividends and minority interest, equivalent, after preferred dividends, to 2 cents on leach of 33,673,328 no par common shares, comparing with $20,293,035, or 33 cents a share, for the preceding year.

The St. Louis San Francisco Railway, with a loan of $3,805,175 from the Railroad Credit Corporation on Dec. 31, is the largest debtor of that organization, according to the Frisco's report for 1932. The second largest borrower from the corporation is the Missoui Pacific Railroad, with a loan of $3,000,000.

PARIS, May 23 -- Paris newspapers today were distinctly cool to the United States statement at Geneva regarding the extent to which it is willing to abandon its policy of isolation. So far as the moderate and Left press is concerned it is a surprising reaction, for there is no apparent lessening of the satisfaction felt in official circles.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- President Roosevelt's Industrial Recovery Bill, combining a far-reaching plan for Federal control of industry with a $3,300,000,000 public works authorization and a $700,000,000 tax program, was apparently all set tonight for a quick trip through the House before the end of the week.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation undertook a $35,759,598 revaluation of its assets at the end of 1932 based on recognition of the drastic change in world-wide economic conditions which has occurred since 1929, according to the pamphlet report issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON. May 23. -- There were some people in the Senate Banking and Currency Committee room today who heard the elder J.P. Morgan testify at the Pujo "money trust" inquiry twenty years ago. Among them was Senator Byrnes of South Carolina, a member of today's committee, as he was of the last one before which a Morgan appeared.
BERLIN, May 23. -- German misgivings with regard to the speech of Norman H. Davis in Geneva yesterday gave way today to praise combined with efforts to employ it as a weapon against France.

LONDON, May 23. -- British financial circles expect currency discussions now proceeding in Washington to result in a triangular stabilization agreement between the United States, France and Great Britain.

The National Society for the Prevention of Blindness. Inc., founded in 1908 with ten members, now has a roster of 16,600, according to its annual report made public yesterday. Its activities, confined originally to preventing blindness in New York State from ophthalmia neonatorum, commonly known as "babies' sore eyes," have become nation-wide and have been extended in collaboration with physicians and leaders in many fields.

Postmaster General James A. FarJey, Democratic State and National Chairman, in a telephone message to THE NEW YORK TIMES from Washington last night expressed gratification at the size of the majority for repeal. Mr. Farley as head of the Democratic organization worked actively for repeal and issued a radio appeal for a large vote for ratification.

WASHINGTON. May 23 (AP). -- Big Fred Marberry came back home today in an alien uniform and limited his former teammates to exactly three hits while pitching the Tigers to a 7-to-l victory over the Senator.

The New York Board of Trade urged in a letter yesterday that money necessary for amortization and interest to carry out the provisions of the $3,300,000,000 National Recovery Act be raised, not from increased taxes on income, but from other sources, "even though that implies a general manufacturers' sales tax."

SAN FRANCISCO, May 23 (AP). -- Louis Johnson, national commander of the American Legion, said in an address tonight that the Legion will "carry the flag" of government economy on where critics of the Legion "have thrown it down."

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 23. -- Two of the four seeded players, Baroness Maud Levi of New York and Miss Grace Surber of Jackson Heights, advanced to the semi-final round of play in the seventh annual women's Eastern clay court tennis championship tournament today at the Montclair A.C.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 23 (AP). -- Mrs. Eugenia Woodward Jelke, testifying in support of her cross petition for divorce, charged her husband today with a series of physical assaults throughout their nine months of married life.

Mr. BUEL was one of the first magazine editors who imparted a definite historical purpose to his publication. The Century Magazine was associated for years with the series of articles afterward republisned under the title "Battles and Leaders of the Civil War."

MANCHESTER, N.H., May 23 (AP) -- Rioting broke out anew in the Amoskeag mill district late tonight and thirty-nine persons were arrested. More than fifty civilians and a score of policemen and national guardsmen were injured by flying rocks.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Conditions at Ellis Island will be investigated, Secretary Perkins announced today. She said that the Labor Department also would go into labor conditions in the men's shirt industry.

A BIG fellow came striding through the lobby and stepped into the elevator. He had on a gray suit, a blue shirt, a striped tie and a light gray felt hat. Jack Dempsey, formerly the Manassa Mauler or the Tiger of Toledo, now the Boy Promoter of the Match of the Maxes, Schmeling and Baer.

PARIS, May 23. -- The dollar and the pound must be stabilized before tariffs can be adjusted or the world's disordered economic system begin to be straightened out, Georges Bonnet, the Minister of Finance, told the Chamber of Deputies today during a budget debate.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Colonel Clarence M. Young, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Aeronautics since Oct. 1, 1929, and an official of (that branch since its creation in 1926, asked President Roosevelt today to accept his resignation and name a successor by June 15.

One lawyer was released in $2,500 bail yesterday on indictments alleging the theft of $3,500 from the estate of a dead woman, and another was arrested In District Attorney Crain's office on an allegation by another woman that he had falsely used her signature on a legal document in a foreclosure proceeding in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Baptists of the North and South, divided eighty-eight years ago over the slavery issue, joined this morning in dedicating to the cause of religious liberty the National Baptist Memorial Church, the cornerstone of which was laid in 1922 by Charles Evans Hughes, then Secretary of State.

The Chinese Finance Minister, T. V. Soong, who is on his way to the World Economic Conference in London; at the head of the Chinese delegation, said in an interview here yesterday that the situation created by the Japanese-Chinese hostilities was a world question.

PEIPING, Wednesday, May 24. -- Despite reports of a truce between Chinese and Japanese in North China, reports from missionaries at Tungchow, thirteen miles east of here, said today that there was renewed fighting last night on the outskirts of the town, with ten Chinese casualties.
Vicki Baum is on her way here from Hollywood to work with John Golden, theatrical producer, on a dramatization of her novel, "Life Goes On."

A new type of streamlined, light-weight, motor-driven passenger train will be put into operation by the Union Pacific Railroad within six months as an answer to the competition of the highway bus and the airplane, it was announced yesterday.

The second day of the General Sessions conspiracy trial of Thomas Patrick Morris, 53 years old, a Brooklyn house painter, accused of fraud in claiming part of the $45,000,000 Wendel estate last Summer, brought out testimony, introduced by the State, that a marriage certificate, one of the principal documents supporting Morris's claim, had been printed on paper made twenty-four years after Morris had said it was issued.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- A verdict in store tomorrow, the Senate tonight came to the final chapter of the impeachment trial of Federal Judge Harold Louderback of California, after hearing his own story from the witness stand.

PEIPING, Wednesday, May 24. -- The reports of a truce as well as the assertions of Japanese that they were likely to enter Peiping today were not borne out by conditions observed by your correspondent yesterday on a 1 ng automobile circuit of the front.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Proceeding on the assumption that President Roosevelt will revise his former opinion that application of a processing tax on farm products covered by the Agricultural Adjustment Act is prevented by this country's pledge of a tariff truce pending the World Economic Conference, Secretary "Wallace authorized today the calling of an informal conference Friday of groups making up the wheat industry to consider "their recommendations for making the act apply to wheat."

A movement to preserve this country's historically or architecturally important buildings has been started by the American Institute of Architects with the opening of a national survey of these structures, according to an announcement yesterday.

Open hearing's designed to call attention to the large number of evictions of unemployed families and the number of dispossess notices being served will be held today and tomorrow under the auspices of a committee including leaders in religious, social and educational life, it was announced yesterday.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Minot Amory will give a dinner tonight at the Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Following hours of sharp debate, the House late this afternoon passed the Steagall Bank Deposit Guarantee Bill by a standing vote of 262 to 19.

VIENNA, May 23 -- "Catholic readers in Germany fear that Catholicism may be next in line for 'coordination, not only as a political party but as a religion," Michael Williams, editor of The Commonweal of New York, a review from the Catholic viewpoint, declared here today on his way from Berlin to Rome.

NEWARK, N.J., May 23 -- In the second meeting of the new City Commission since its election, resolutions were adopted dropping fifty-one employes from the municipal payroll for reasons of economy. The total annual saving to the city was placed at $72,880.
LONDON, May 23 (Canadian Press) -- The West Indies today defeated the Marylebone Cricket Club by 152 runs, scoring 309 in the first innings and 263 in the second to 246 and 179 for M.C.C.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The Postoffice Department, heretofore one of the most expensive government branches, will become a self-sustaining "business unit" in the fiscal year 1934, according to J.C. O'Mahoney, First Assistant Postmaster General.
ALBANY, May 23. -- Receipts from sales of supplies to manufacturers were divided into taxable and nontaxable items today in a ruling by Mark Graves, President of the State Tax Commission.

DUESSELDORF, May 23 -- Now that it ia certain that Chancellor Hitler will be here for the Schlageter celebrations, this city is making elaborate preparations to honor Albert Leo Schlageter, a Nazi executed by the French on May 26, 1923, for sabotage.

PLANDOME, L.I., May 23. -- Charles H. Mayo Jr. of the Lido Country Club and E. Leonard Beard Jr. of the Pomonok Country Club tied for the honors with scores of 78 In a one-day tournament of the Long Island Golf Association at the Plandome Golf Club today.

A campaign to rid the fur industry of all Communist and Left Wing labor organizations will be started by the American Federation of Labor with the aid and support of the city administration and the Police Department, it was announced last night at a meeting of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers Association.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 23 -- Burton H. Etherington Jr. of Philadelphia, president of the senior class of Princeton University, was voted "most popular" by his classmates in the annual elections of the graduating class, it was announced at the senior dinner held tonight in Madison Hall.
To the Editor of The New York Times: There has been a good deal in the papers lately about persecution. Now that the matter has come up, it might be well to bring it further into the light.

TORONTO, Ont., May 23. -- Gold produced in Ontario in April was valued at $3,681,801, a decrease of $377,447 from the high record of $4,059,248 reported for March. There were reductions in all camps, Porcupine showing one of 5268,147; Kirkland Lake, one of $94,520, and Northwestern Ontario, one of $16,980.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

While retail failures increased 12 to 273 for the week ended May 18 in comparison with the preceding week, the number was only 50 per cent of those reported for the corresponding week of 1932, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. A gain was also shown for the wholesale and jobbing group, with declines shown in the manufacturing and other commercial classifications.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 28. -- A tense struggle which nearly witnessed the elimination of Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches was a high light of the opening round of match play in the women's metropolitan golf championship at the Cherry Valley Club today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 23 (AP). -- Little known outside his classrooms at the Harvard University School of Business Administration until 1930. when he was selected by the Bank of England as its financial adviser. Professor Oliver Mitchell Wentworth Sprague has just turned 60 years of age.

BERLIN, May 23. -- An edict designed to put a stop to the growing disorganization of German business through interference on the part of self-appointed Nazi groups and "commissars" was issued today by Dr. Otto Wagener, Reich Commissar for National Economy.

The three members of the women's 1932 Olympic fencing team, Miss Dorothy Locke, Miss Marion Lloyd and Miss Muriel Guggolz, all of the Salle d' Armes Vince, qualified last night for the semi-final round of the national outdoor championships, which will be held in Chicago on June 23 and 24.

Open-air opera enthusiasts formally presented to Mayor O'Brien yesterday their suggestion for an amphitheatre site in the abandoned lower reservoir in Central Park, where Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy is building baseball diamonds and other athletic fields.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Secretary Woodin started the government on its credit expansion program today with authorization to the Federal Reserve Banks to buy $25,000,000 in government securities in the open market and thus release commercial credit.

Tentative plans for an unusual type of amusement centre to occupy the six upper floors and terraces of the seventy-story RCA Building in Rockefeller Center are being discussed and a survey is now under way, it was disclosed yesterday.

Blame for the stagnation in the construction of local improvements, particularly in Queens, was placed upon Controller Berry yesterday by George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens, who said the Controller had shown "obvious opposition to all local improvements" during the past few years.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,705,350 barrels, compared with 2,733,850 in the preceding week, a decline of 28,500 barrels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. A decline of 22,950 barrels in Oklahoma and a gain of 7,300 barrels in California were the most important changes.

Tuesday, May 23, 1933. Money market was quiet, as business continued along small lines and quotations for all classifications remained unchanged. Stock Exchange call loans were 1 per cent. and time money, 1 to 1 1/2 per cent. for the near and distant dates.

The condition statement of J.P Horgan Co., published yesterday in connection with the Senate inquiry, contained plenty of surprises for the Wall Street conamunity. It showed that the "house on the corner" holds much less in common stocks than had popularly been supposed and that it, like every one else, has suffered, severe losses during the last three years.

There are two parts to the program of new taxation recommended by the Ways and Means Committee of the House. The first is not a matter of instant concern. It proposes to extend until June 30, 1935, the special excises, the stamp taxes and the import taxes enacted last year.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- J.P. Morgan, head of the international banking firm which bears his name, paid no income tax in 1931 and 1932, nor did any of his partners.

BOSTON, Mass., May 23 -- After five hours of arguments by counsel for the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and the defense the United States Circuit Court of Appeals late today took under advisement the State's appeal from Federal Judge James A. Lowell's ruling of April 24 granting a writ of habeas corpus to halt extradition of George Crawford, a Negro, wanted in Loudon County, Va., for the murder of two men sixteen months ago.

LONDON, May 23 (Canadian Press) -- Backers of Lord Woolavington's Manitoba in the May 31 running of the Derby at Epsom were cheered today when the strapping bay colt defeated Mrs. J.B. Courtauld's filly, Solfatara, to head a field of eight in the Midland Breeders Foal Plate at Birmingham.

The Atlantic Passenger Conference will meet today in Brussels to consider the controversy which has developed in the last week over the acceptance of "blocked" marks by the German flag lines in payment of transatlantic passage. The meeting was desired by the German lines, whose traffic is favored by the sales of the marks at 15 per cent below the market price to passengers on German ships.

Cardinal Hayes and five Bishops will participate in the formal service of welcome to the Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, the new Apostolic Delegate, this afternoon at 4 o'clock in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The prelates will walk at the end of an outdoor procession of more than 2,500 vested clergy, uniformed men, robed students in Catholic colleges and representatives of Catholic organizations.
All commodities on Exchanges here except silver advanced in price yesterday with other markets. Trading was at reduced levels.

PHILADELPHIA. May 23 (AP). -- Featured by Lefty Grove's appearance in his third consecutive game and Jimmy Foxx's seventh home run, the Athletics won their fifth straight today, hammering two Browns' pitchers for twelve hits and an 8-to-6 triumpn.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Industrial corporations and railways which had a daily average balance of $1,000,000 or more with J.P. Morgan Co. over the five years from Jan. 1, 1927, to Dec. 31, 1931, were listed today at the Senate banking inqury as follows:
The opening of "The Climax," which is being revived with Guy Bates Post and Norma Terris in the leading roles at the Bijou Theatre, has been postponed from June 1 to June 5.

Most of the financial troubles of municipalities throughout the country will cure themselves as business picks up, David H. Wood of the municipal law firm of Thomson, Wood Hoffman said yesterday to members of the Municipal Bond Club of New York at their regular monthly luncheon meeting.

The validity of the franchises under which the Fifth Avenue Coach Company operates all of its routes, except the original line on Fifth Avenue between Washington Square and Fifty-seventh Street, was upheld yesterday by the Court of Appeals at Albany.

MOSCOW, May 23 -- The newspaper Pravda, official organ of the Russian Communist party, commenting editorially today on the four-power pact drawn up in Rome, attacks it in slashing Communist style. It sees the past as chiefly directed against the United States, with Great Britain as the prime mover and instigator.
Aggressive buying was resumed yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and prices advanced rapidly and closed with gains of 23 to 35 points.

BERLIN, May 23. -- Almost a complete stoppage of participation on the part of the public left the Boerse in the hands of professional traders today and the market showed neither animation nor a definite trend either way.
ST. LOUIS, May 23 (AP). --Tex Carleton weakened in the tenth inning today and allowed four consecutive singles, which brought in two runs and gave the Braves a 3-to-1 victory over the Cardinals.

When opened fifty years ago the Brooklyn Bridge was the engineering wonder of the world. Other suspension bridges now have longer spans and higher towers, yet it still stands as a technical and architectural masterpiece, a monument to the courage and tenacity of JOHN A. ROEBLING, and to the iron will and directive ability of his son WASHINGTON, who built it and almost died in the process.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 23. -- Major A.V. Dalrymple, national prohibition director, here on a tour of inspection, said that at least 50,000 speakeasies in the United States have been driven out of business by enactment of the new beer laws, including at least 10,000 in New York and as many more in Chicago.

BERLIN, May 23 -- The Kaiser Wilhelm Society for the Advancement of the Sciences, the foremost scientific organization in Germany, which conducts thirty-two research institutes, held its twenty-second annual meeting here today. It was presided over by Professor Max Planck, dean of German physicists, Nobel Prize winner and co-founder of the atomic theory.
GENEVA, May 23 -- The disarmament conference today ended the first reading of the chapter in the draft convention abolishing the most formidable army weapons, big cannons and big tanks.

If Charles E. Mitchell's sale of 18,300 shares of National City Bank stock to his wife in 1929 had been a genuine sale, Mrs. Mitchell could have resold the stock early in 1930 at a profit of more than $800,000 and thus nearly doubled her personal estate, the prosecution emphasized yesterday at Mr. Mitchell's income tax evasion trial.

The home-run firing of the Yankees, silenced during the past few weeks, broke forth anew yesterday at the Stadium with a bombardment which sent the skidding Indians down to fifth place in the pennant race.

TRENTON, N.J., May 23. -- Delegates to the Democratic State convention, which opened here today for adoption of a platform for the general election next November, were warned by the permanent chairman, John E. Toolan of Middlesex County, a candidate for the State Senate, that the party cannot depend on the success of President Roosevelt's administration at Washington to carry it to victory in New Jersey.

TRENTON, N.J., May 23. -- Delegates to the Democratic State convention, which opened here today for adoption of a platform for the general election next November, were warned by the permanent chairman, John E. Toolan of Middlesex County, a candidate for the State Senate, that the party cannot depend on the success of President Roosevelt's administration at Washington to carry it to victory in New Jersey.

The intervention of officers here of the American Federation of Labor in the feud between union fish handlers in Fulton Market and William Fellowes Morgan Jr., as head of the Brooklyn Bridge Freezing and Cold Storage Company, which a little more than a week ago brought a grand jury investigation of Mr. Morgan's charge of a resumption of racketeering in the market, appeared to be nearing a settlement yesterday.
LONDON, May 23 -- The British Government today replied to President Roosevelt's disarmament appeal of last week as follows:

A decision handed down by City Court Justice Charles E. Russell in Brooklyn characterizing City College as an institution supported by overburdened taxpayers largely to inculcate the doctrines of communism was termed an "unwarranted and a gratuitious insult unworthy of further comment" by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of, the college, yesterday.

VIENNA, May 23 -- The spread of National Socialism outside Germany seems for the present to have been definitely halted in the region where its extension would have been most dangerous to European peace. There is no immediate danger of Austria going Nazi and thus producing a situation that could have no other effect than bringing about "Anschluss" in its most sinister and most difficult form.

GENEVA, May 23. -- Another complaint against the methods of the German Nazis was laid before the League of Nations today. G.G. Knox, president of the League commission which governs the Saar territory pending a plebiscite in 1935, today strongly demanded that the League Council should adopt measures to protect German officials there against Nazi menaces.

Five animals among thirteen which arrived yesterday on the Black Diamond freighter Black Falcon were ordered held after the ship docked by the Bureau of Animal Husbandry in Washington. At the Custom House it was said the order had been issued under a ruling prohibiting the importation of certain cloven-hoofed animals which might bring African hoof disease into the country.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 23. -- Returns from 200 election districts out of a total of 359 in Westchester County in today's voting on repeal showed a total vote of 52,229 for, 4,135 against. This was a ratio of more than 12 to 1.
RICHMOND, Va., May 23 (AP) -- An inventory of home life was urged before delegates to the General Federation of Women's Clubs, meeting here today.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 23 -- Three games at the Meadow Brook Club and one at Bostwick Field brought thirty-two players into action today as the second week of the Spring season for Meadow Brook polo started.

Fifty Staten Island home owners caused disturbances in the First District Municipal Court at West New Brighton, S.I., yesterday when Judge John G. Clark gave John Krysoc, a World War veteran who has a wife and two small children, five days to pay the rent on his home at 135 Wooley Avenue, West New Brighton, or face eviction.

The Chase National Bank, heading a group of twenty banks and investment houses, obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $4,677,000 of Westchester County, (N.Y.) various improvement bonds due on June 1, 1935 to 1960. The price paid was 100.10 for the bonds to bear interest at 6 per cent.

Jesse I. Straus, Ambassador to France, will sail today for Paris with Mrs. Straus on the Manhattan of the United States Lines. Others sailing on the ship for the Channel ports include Warren Delano Robbing, United States Minister to Canada, and Mrs. Robbins; General Ramono Gorecki, Polish banker and head of the Fidac. and:

The Newark Bears, with Charley Devens pitching in fine form, shut out Jersey City, 7 to 0, at Jersey City yesterday, the victory enabling them to advance from third to second place in the International League standing.
EASTON, Pa., May 23. -- Hitting two Lehigh hurlers for twelve safeties, the Lafayette nine today defeated their Brown and White rivals, 12-2, in the first of a three-game series.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 23. -- With the simple words, "Thomas J. Mooney -- murder -- for trial!" San Francisco's Superior Court calendar was turned back nearly seventeen years this morning.

CINCINNATI, May 23. -- Roy Parmelee won his fourth game in a season's unbroken string of victories for the Giants today against the Reds, but wasn't in at the finish. The Giants' second successive triumph over Cincinnati was by a 6-to-4 score, thanks to effective relief pitching by Adolph Luque.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 23 -- An expedition of the Metropolitan Museum of Art of New York has discovered at Lisht, in Upper Egypt, a large and very fine mastaba, or Pharonic tomb, belonging to the chief priest at Ptah at Memphis.

Reinvigorated after its long pause, the stock market gave Wall Street more encouragement yesterday than at any time in the last fortnight. The revival of speculative interest brought out of hiding many traders who had shown no more than a mild curiosity in the last week or so.

The President of the Board of Trade, Mr. RUNCIMAN, was explaining in the House of Commons the other day the British trade agreement with Argentina. He waa pointing out how it fitted into the Ottawa treaties, and by the help of quotas, or, as they prefer to call it, " the regulation of quantities," a higher price level could he maintained for imported frozen meats and also for the domestic product.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- A new fight for the lucrative lake cargo bituminous coal trade was launched by principal Eastern trunk carriers today in briefs before the Interstate Commerce Commission seeking modification of the 1927 lake cargo ruling.

AUTEUIL, France, May 23 (AP). -- Americans won only three of the five matches in which they participated today in the French hard-court tennis championships, one of the defeats taking the favored American-German pair of Frank Shields and Fraulein Cilli Aussem out of the mixed doubles competition.

TIENTSIN, China, Wednesday, May 24 -- It is taken for granted here that the Japanese forces will occupy Peiping today, for while official and unofficial Chinese sources asserted that some form of truce had been signed which would obviate Japanese occupation of the city, Japanese here officially made a flat denial of the statements.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 24. -- A comprehensive project for social insurance, embracing life and disability insurance, unemployment insurance and old-age pensions covering all wage-earners in the electrical manufacturing industry, is contained in a questionnaire which the board of governors of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association voted today to submit to the association's members.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Members of the New York Child Labor Committee were particularly interested to read in THE NEW YORK TIMES the story of how sweatshops have been running away from New York's good Child Labor Laws and the vigorous enforcement of our State Labor Department.

Three hundred school teachers and a score of patrolmen battled yesterday in the meeting room of the Board of Education, 500 Park Avenue. Two emergency squads and a half-dozen other policemen were summoned to reinforce the six patrolmen and a sergeant who were attempting, without much success, to clear the room.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- After fruitless visits to the White House and Treasury Department, where they made pleas for Federal assistance in handling their financial problems, the Mayors of fifty large cities decided late today to carry their case to Congress and present resolutions tomorrow to Vice President Garner and Speaker Rainey.

Returns to date indicate that in general the railroads improved their earnings in April compared with March. Of the first twelve companies to report for the month, seven showed increased net operating income compared with April, 1932, although none of them had reported an increase in March over the preceding March.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 24. -- A rush of taxpayers in three Westchester communities to prevent the sale of their properties for nonpayment of taxes resulted today in the payment of nearly $350,000 in taxes in Scarsdale, Rye and Mount Pleasant.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- J.P. Morgan, immediately after resuming the stand before the Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee this morning, was asked to identify "as true and complete" a list of all names of individuals who were officers or directors of banks and who received loans from J.P. Morgan Co., or Drexel Co., during the five-year period from Jan. 1. 1927, to Dec. 31, 1931.

Fully accepted in England as an acute and sympathetic interpretation of our national life, a new book by Dr. L.P. Jacks, former principal of Manchester College, Oxford, called "My American Friends," has just been published here by Macmillan.

An application for the listing of 200,000 additional common shares of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company, to be issued in connection with the acquisition of the assets and business of the Illinois Glass Company, was approved yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

Supreme Court Justice Phoenix Ingraham decided yesterday that the payment of nearly $3,000,000 to be made this week for the condemnation award for the former Libby Hotel property may be in currency, although the bonds given for the property specified gold.

The Chase National Bank announced yesterday a write-down of about $55,700,000 from surplus and undivided profits account to provide for charge-offs against losses and for the establishment of additional reserves.

An elderly, gray-haired woman and a hotel maid brought about the arrest late yesterday afternoon of one of two men alleged to have held up a jeweler in Essex House, an apartment hotel at 160 Central Park South. Jewelry valued at $5,000 was recovered and $7,000 worth of other jewelry was taken by the hold-up man who escaped.
WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 22:

Plans for a nation-wide campaign to reduce the large annual toll of deaths from many forms of asphyxiation, many of which could be saved by prompt application of recently discovered methods for the treatment of such cases, were discussed yesterday by physicians and public health authorities at the New York State Conference on Problems Relating to Death From Asphyxiation, at the New York Academy of Medicine.

Final results of the "participation-in-war" poll of seventy colleges, made public yesterday, show 39 per cent of the 22,627 students voting opposed to participation in any war. An additional 33 per cent would take part only if the country was invaded.

George W. Eilperin, formerly chief field agent of the Brooklyn office of the Internal Revenue Bureau, a Brooklyn Republican leader and a brother of Magistrate Jacob Eilperin, has been decided upon by Tammany and Republican leaders as the choice to succeed John R. Crews are Tax Commissioner, it was learned last night from reliable sources.

Stimulated by the announcement that the government had started its credit expansion program and by additional gains in business activity, stocks rose 1 to 6 1/2 points yesterday to the highest levels in the last fourteen months.

Jewish Atomists Spared. A meeting of the Kaiser Wilhelm Society for the Advancement of Science, the foremost organization of its kind in Germany, has addressed a formal pledge to Chancellor HITLER "to cooperate joyously in the reconstruction of the new national State."

CHICAGO, May 24. -- Inflation talk continued today to dominate the wheat market on the Board of Trade, and prices moved up 2 1/4 cents a bushel in the early trading, with the public and houses with Eastern, connections fairly active buyers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 24. -- Spelman Prentice of New York City, grandson of John D. Rockefeller, and Theodore Dwight Woolsey, great-grandson and namesake of former President Woolsey of Yale, were today awarded athletic insignia for their work during the indoor sports season at Yale.

Avoidance of controversies within the church was urged by Presiding Justice Edward R. Finch of the Appellate Division. In an address yesterday at the annual commencement of the General Theological Seminary, held in the Chapel of the Good Shepherd on the seminary grounds in Chelsea Square.
Two taxicab drivers were locked in the West Forty-seventh Street Police Station last night charged by the police with a concerted attack upon Patrolman Peter Quinn of Traffie D.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Judge Harold Louderback of San Francisco, first Federal official to be tried on impeachment charges in twenty years, was acquitted by the Senate tonight on all five counts of the indictment brought against him by the managers appointed by the House.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- A list of favored participants in an issue of common stock of the Allegheny Corporation through J.P. Morgan Co. was put Into the record of the Senate investigation today by Ferdinand Peoora, counsel for the Banking Committee.

The sharp upturn in Manhattan realty trading in which Frederick Brown played a leading part with the purchase of a Fifth Avenue business building yesterday was shared by other operators who came into the market for well-located housing properties.

As the result of a decision yesterday by officials of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes regarding the classification of "When Ladies Meet." John Golden will be forced to close the Rachel Crothers comedy now running at the Royale Theatre on Saturday night.

LONDON, May 24. -- Viscount Snowden of Iekornshaw, former Chancellor of the Exchequer and for many years Ramsay MacDonald's closest colleague, delivered a scathing attack today on the Prime Minister in the House of Lords.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP). -- Lonnie Warneke and Gabby Hartnett, the Chicago Cub battery, took full charge of defeating Philadelphia, 5 to 2, today for the National League champions' only victory in the three-game series.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- Talk of the nation's railroads serving notice of a further reduction in union wages was heard here today and met a bristling response from spokesmen for organized railway workers.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Aid which New York City might obtain under the national recovery bill and its public work section in efforts to stimulate employment was discussed with Senator Wagner today by officials of the Emergency Work and Relief Administration of New York City, representing Mayor O'Brien.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP). -- Early voters in the ballot to name an American League team to face the National League's best in Chicago July 6 apparently would rather see Al Simmons of the White Sox than Babe Ruth.

HANOVER, N.H., May 24. -- Way Thompson turned in another brilliant game today, outpitching Eddie Loughlin of Harvard, Dartmouth winning, 5-2, and dropping the Crimson to third place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League standing.
NEW YORK. Wolmar Bostrom, the Swedish Minister, is at the Ritz-Cariton.

The receivers for the Wabash Railway are seeking a plan of adjustment for $12,379,800 of equipment-trust certificates which are outstanding. One plan under consideration calls for a moratorium on the payments of principal lasting through 1933 and 1934, but with payment of interest maintained.

Mrs. Clara A. Gerken, half-sister of the wealthy and eccentric Edward Albert Ridley, who, with his secretary, Lee Weinstein, was murdered in his Allen Street office on May 10, filed suit yesterday in Supreme Court asking that the rights of the heirs be fixed by the court and that the properties be sold and distributed among them.

With little debate, but by the large majority of 262 to 19, the House of Representatives has approved the Steagall Bill, amending present banking laws. Some of its major provisions are substantially identical with corresponding sections of the Glass Bill, now pending in the Senate.

Irving Williams Jr., Frank R. Bailey and Charles G. Benjamin have formed the firm of Williams, Bailey Benjamin, to transact a general investment securities business at 60 Wall Tower. They will maintain branch offices in Rochester, Buffalo and Elmira.

PARIS, May 24. -- In the face of a determined and unfavorable press campaign, Polish opposition and the anxiety of the Little Entente, the French Government remained fully decided today to sign the Four-Power pact when the final text is drafted, it was learned in authoritative quarters.

BERLIN, May 24. -- The Boerse today had much the same aspect as it had yesterday. Customers' orders were near zero and floor traders were apathetic and hesitant. Among divers explanations suggested for the stagnation, the dubious issue of the disarmament conference seemed to carry most favor.

BERLIN, May 24. -- The effort of the National Socialists to "coordinate" the German Protestant churches and put their 39,000,000 members into the service of an "awakened Germany" met a dramatic defeat today.
GENEVA, May 24. -- Press telegrams were brought to Norman H. Davis today in connection with a loan from J.P. Morgan Co. To inquiries he aid:

SOME of this may seem a little out of season, having to do with Notre Dame football stars, but it demands instant attention. Remember the Army-Notre Dame football game at the Yankee Stadium last Fall? A gray day, a great crowd and a great team in green jerseys scoring three touchdowns on an Army team that ruled a heavy favorite before the kick-off.

GENEVA, May 24. -- The upward swing in the hopes of the disarmament conference continued even more strongly today than yesterday. The day witnessed the removal of widespread fears that Great Britain sought to weaken her obligations under the League of Nations covenant.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 24. -- The mighty track forces from Stanford and Southern California, which threaten to make the intercollegiate championship meet on Friday and Saturday an intra-State battle unless the East's strongest standard bearer, Yale, reaches unexpected heights, today moved into Soldiers Field to work out the kinks that collected during their transcontinental trip.
The fifth and final candle-light musicale by Helen Schafmeister, pianist, will be presented tonight at the Waldorf-Astoria.

An inevitable result of Mr. MORGAN'S testimony will be to revive discussion of the taxing of capital gains as individual income and the deducting of capital losses as income losses. That this Federal law was from the first economically unsound and vicious has never been seriously disputed.

The roadway from Manhattan to Brooklyn was closed by a silk ribbon at the centre of the old Brooklyn Bridge for almost an hour at midday yesterday until Mayor O'Brien, escorted by a detachment of motorcycle police and a platoon of mounted men, ceremoniously advanced across the bridge and cut the ribbon.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced sharply again yesterday morning, but the supply of contracts increased as the October delivery went above the 9-cent level. Selling from Southern quarters and hedging against cotton recently released by the Red Cross caused profit-taking on the rise.

LONDON, May 24. -- Astute observers of the British political situation are wondering whether the MacDonald government will survive to see the conclusion of the economic conference. From all accounts, it is a bit of a gamble and some Parliamentarians are offering to bet on a general election the coming Fall.

BERLIN, May 24. -- Chancellor Hitler will not attend the Rhineland memorial celebrations for Lieutenant Albert Leo Schlageter, the "first soldier of the Third Reich," at Dusseldorf next Sunday, despite many previous announcements that he would join Hermann Wilhelm Goering, the Minister of Aviation, and Dr. Paul Joseph. Goebels, Minister of Propaganda, in paying homage to the man who was shot by a French firing squad during the occupation of the Ruhr in 1923.
Cardinal Hayes formally welcomed the Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, the new Apostolic Delegate, at a service in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon.

Artur Bodanzky, conductor of the Metropolitan Opera House, will sail today with Mrs. Bodanzky for Europe on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia. Others leaving for the Mediterranean on the ship are Mrs. Giovanni Martinelli, Henri Matisse, the artist; Laurence Stallings, the playwright, and Mrs. Stallings; R. E. Gillmore, president of the Sperry Gyroscopic Company, Lewis Milestone, motion picture director, and Paul Van Zeeland, Belgian banker.
Thirty-two persons were injured yesterday in a rear-end collision between two west side I.R.T. local trains in the Brooklyn Museum station.

City planning to provide better housing, particularly in unbuilt, outlying urban centres, was emphasized as an appropriate channel for the use of Federal funds at a conference yesterday of representatives of real estate, architecture and social welfare organizations at London Terrace, 405 West Twentythird Street.

GENEVA, May 24. -- Norman H. Davis's statement to the disarmament conference today, explaining the pledge of the United States to consult on violations of the peace and to refrain from hampering collective sanctions against aggressors, follows:

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- A powerful American Davis Cup team, supremely confident of its ability to meet the challenge of Argentina's trio, today contented itself with a brief but flashy tune-up for the opening matches tomorrow to the final American zone tie.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 3/4 per cent for the best names. Tuesday -- 1 3/4 per cent for the best names

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Unrestricted operations of J.P. Morgan Co., limited only by their judgment, which made possible large loans to bankers and gifts of "ground-floor" participation in stock flotations in 1929 to friends and business associates of the partners were disclosed today by Ferdinand Pecora, counsel for the Senate Banking Committee.

Rising markets reflected yesterday the revival of speculative and investment interest brought about by the administration's credit-expansion campaign and by the additional statistics testifying to the continuing improvement in business.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 24 (AP). -- Cadet John Steen Conner, for whom a widespread search had been under way since he disappeared Sunday night from the Military Academy, was found tonight wandering along the upper edge of the academy grounds.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., May 24. -- "Conditions today are immeasurably improved from those of a short time ago" was the note of optimisn with which Myron F. Converse, president of the Savings Banks Association of Massachusetts today welcomed several hundred delegates from all over the United States to the three-day conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

WASHINGTON, May 24.-- J.P. Morgan today gave to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee a list of all individuals who were officers or directors of banks and who received loans from J.P. Morgan Co., or Drexel Co., during the five years from Jan. 1, 1927, to Dec. 31, 1931. The names on this list and the bank with which each individual was identified, either as an officer or director, were:

Most commodities continued their upward trend in yesterday's trading on local exchanges. Silver, which had sold off on the preceding day, participated in the general advance. Trading was in better volume. Cash prices were higher.

An innovation in charity entertainments was held last night when the Association of Volunteers of the Welfare Council of New York gave a sidewalk dinner and fete at Chatham Walk, said to be the first sidewalk cafe in that section, at Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

HAVANA, May 24. -- Two young revolutionists, Eduardo Montalvo, 19 years old, and Felipe Velasco, aged 20, were killed at 2 o'clock this morning when a large dynamite bomb they were planting under a railroad bridge at Calderon Crossing, just outside of Artemisa, Pinar del Rio Province, was exploded by a bullet fired by rural guards.
New York City has relatively fewer physicians, undertakers and plumbers than formerly; men are replacing women as cooks; the nation is becoming more literary, with authors rapidly increasing.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP). -- The doors of baseball's hall of fame opened again today to Tommy Bridges, Detroit pitcher, but jus as in a previous game with the Senators his dream of a no-hit contest was spoiled by a single safety.

COLUMBUS, Ohio., May 24. -- Kindled with zeal for international evangelism, developed in three days of pre-assembly efforts, the Presbyterians of the United States gathered today for the 145th General Assembly, which opens tomorrow with a communion service at which a thousand communicants are expected.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The invitation to William H. Woodin, now Secretary of the Treasury, to buy 1,000 shares of the common stock of the Alleghany Corporation at $20 a share, $15 to $17 below the market price at the time of the offer, was put into the record of the Morgan investigation today.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The Federal Reserve Board's seasonally adjusted index of Industrial production rose 7 points from March to April, and in the latter month was 67 per cent of the 1923-25 average. A low of 58 per cent was reached last July.

Fines of $250 each were imposed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice McNamee on three Democratic election inspectors who pleaded guilty to neglect of duty at the polls last November. The court suspended sentences in the workhouse and warned them that "the sword of Damocles hung over their heads by a narrow thread."
"I don't want to make anglers, envious, but inasmuch as I have been unable to take any trips this season," writes A.G.T., "I can only stay in the city and dream of what is taking place in Maine.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Economy orders issued May 15 by Admiral William V. Pratt. Chief of Naval Operations, placing battleships, cruisers and aircraft on a one-third rotating reserve basis, effective July 1, were overruled by Secretary Swanson today, who declared that the Navy Department would effect economies by working on "the old form of increasing efficiency and at the same time decreasing costs."

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- A move for emergency legislation to plug up leaks in the income tax law developed in the House today following the disclosures yesterday before the Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee that J.P. Morgan and his partners paid no income taxes for 1931 and 1932.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- There will be no immediate stabilization of the dollar, since currency stabilization must wait on stabilization of world economic conditions, O.M. W. Sprague, financial adviser to the United States Government, said today after his induction into office as executive assistant to Secretary Woodin.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Federal officials are giving serious consideration to the creation of a coordinator of lighterage and other marine services in New York Harbor for bringing about economies not now possible because of the competitive situation.

What Wall Street described as a "secondary inflation market" aroused speculative enthusiasm on all the Exchanges yesterday. The day's developments touching the business situation would have been a powerful stimulus ordinarily, but there was an additional incentive in the announced intention of the administration to begin the purchase of government securities.

President Roosevelt was chosen by an overwhelming vote as the world's foremost personage by the senior class of the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science and the College of Engineering, in the annual questionnaire, results of which were made public yesterday.
The College of Pharmacy of Columbia University will hold commencement exercises in the McMillin Academic Theatre tonight when 120 seniors will receive the degree of Graduate in Pharmacy.

HAVANA, May 24 (AP). -- Believing Unted States Ambassador Sumner Welles would move soon to end political turmoil in Cuba, representatives of the various factions of President Machado's opposition met tonight to discuss refraining temporarily from acts of violence.

CINCINNATI, May 24. -- Manager Bill Terry removed himself from the Giants' hospital list today in a dramatic bid to bring his team victory over the Reds, but without success. Nothing he could do could offset the ineffectiveness of George Uhile and the Reds scampered off with the last game of the series, 3 to 1.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Recently you printed a letter from the president of the Indian Rights Association regretting that the press had published articles criticizing Indian Commissioner Rhoades and Assistant Scattergood. I wrote the articles referred to and everything contained in them was fact or opinion based on fact.

There will be no disposition among the New York Wets to infer too much from their easy and imposing majority in Tuesday's special election. Still, the absence or the failure of the old Dry emotional campaign and a sort of flattening out of the opposition may properly be noticed.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, announced yesterday that, with the approval of the board of trustees of St. Stephen's College, Annandale-On-Hudson, N.Y., Donald G. Tewksbury, Associate Professor of Education in Teachers College, had been invited to serve as acting dean of the faculty of St. Stephen's College for the academic year 1933-34.

The New York Stock Exchange announced last night that it would remove the preferred and common stocks of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation from its list on Aug. 23 unless the company agreed before that date to give stockholders what the Exchange deems to be "adequate information" concerning the position of the company.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 24. -- A directed verdict of acquittal abruptly ended Thomas J, Mooney's new murder trial here today on the longdormant 1916 Preparedness Day bombing indictment to which he has looked as a weapon in his fight for vindication.

Restoration of the city's credit by means of a balanced budget for 1934, predicated upon an $84,000,000 economy program and a 10 per cent cut in the tax rate, is proposed in a plan made public yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission.
Peter Grimm, chairman of the board of trustees of the Citizens Budget Commission, in introducing yesterday the plan to restore the city's credit, said in part:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I wonder if your readers could help us obtain the use of a large motor bus on Memorial Day so that a day's outing may be provided the eighty young business women who are guests at the Salvation Army's Unemployed Girls Hostel at 30 East Twenty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The presentation of the list of "favored customers" who obtained Alleghany Corporation stock from J.P. Morgan Co. at less than the market price threw the Senate Banking Committee investigation into an uproar today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 24. -- Fordham crushed Rutgers in the last intercollegiate game of the season for the Scarlet today, 17 to 6. The visitors scored three runs in the first inning and in the fourth knocked Jack Liddy out of the box when six runners crossed the plate.

A recommendation by Controller Berry that the city should give up the building used for the main plant of Brooklyn College at 80 Willoughby Street, Brooklyn, when the lease expires in September was received yesterday by the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund.
WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Economic matters occupied the entire stage at the first meeting between President Roosevelt and Viscount Kikujiro Ishii of Japan today, it was understood.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 24 (AP). -- Twelve young artists trod the musical scale tonight but only four reached the summit to win bags of gold and chances for national recognition.

TIENTSIN, China, Thursday, May 25. -- The Japanese now announce that it will probably be "several days" before the Japanese armies occupy Peiping. The Japanese were obviously disappointed at their failure to effect an entry Into the city thus far and were also considerably perturbed over the unexpected continuance and strength of the Chinese resistance.

A public request for bids on the Brentano book stores, now In receivership, is to be made today by the Irving Trust Company, receivers. If no satisfactory bids are received there is a possibility that liquidation of the stock of the world's largest book outlet may start on June 6.
WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Republican leaders tonight decided to force the manufacturers' sales tax to a vote in the House Friday on the administration's Public Works-Industrial Control Bill.

Broadway in the lower Eighties was thrown into a turmoil at 11:30 o'clock last night when gangsters in two expensive automobiles, at least one of which was equipped with bullet-proof glass, staged a running fight in which volleys of shots, believed to be from machine guns, were fired.

AUTEUIL, France, May 24. -- American players in the French hard - court tennis championships broke even in their four matches in doubles competition today to keep representatives in all three divisions. The victories were scored by Miss Helen Jacobs, the United States champion, and Miss Elizabeth Ryan, former Californian.

The pending readjustment in passenger tariffs may result in the establishment of different basic rates as between the East and the West, W.P. Kenncy, president of the Great Northern Railway, said yesterday. He indicated that a meeting of representatives of all railroads might be called within about two weeks to clear the situation.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The Senate Committee on Banking and Currency may have killed the proposed new income tax rise. When testimony before the committee from J.P. Morgan and his associates revealed the fact that twenty rich men paid no income taxes for the last two years, and little for 1930, the whole personal levy system was made to look both ridiculous and unjust.
