RYE, N.Y., May 24. -- New Jersey's three-year superiority in men's team match competition against Long Island and Westchester golfers came to an end today at the Westchester Country Club as the Long Islanders won the annual Stoddard Bowl triangular series to conclude New Jersey's reign, which started in 1930.

Three years ago more than 300 prisoners locked in a blazing firetrap were killed by fire and smoke. Long after the fire was well under way the prisoners were kept locked in their cells. That night the prison yard looked like a battlefield. A mutiny followed the fire.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP). -- Peru's acceptance of the League of Nations formula for settlement of her dispute with Colombia was viewed here today as the probable termination of the Upper Amazon

In a move toward the elimination of intercompany holdings in the aviation field, North American Aviation, Inc., has acquired enough more stock of the Western Air Express Corporation to give it actual control. It has taken all the stock owned by the Aviation Corporation of Delaware and now has 51 per cent.

Nassau County, N.Y., awarded yesterday a new issue of $5,000,000 of bonds, comprising $3,000,000 for home and work relief and 12,000,000 for the redemption of tax-anticipation notes, to a banking group headed by the Guaranty Company of New York.

The Court of Chancery in Wilmington, Del., in an order yesterday authorized the receivers of the American Commonwealths Power Corporation to take steps necessary to permit consummation of the plan of reorganization of the Dominion Gas and Electric Company, which owns important natural gas properties in Western Canada.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Immediate payment to depositors of 50 per cent of their credit balances in the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company of New York City was made possible today by a loan of about $7,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to Henry E. Cooper, the bank conservator.

A consolidated mortgage for $1,500,000 on 10-14 W. 57th St. was extended to May 17, 1937, at 5 1/2 per cent, to May 17, 1934, and 4 per cent thereafter, in an agreement between the New York Life Insurance Co. and the Delbe Realty Co., Inc., A.B. Bastedo, treasurer.
Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company and a director of the National City Bank, testified yesterday at the trial of Charles E. Mitchell on charges of income tax evasion.
WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

LINCOLN, May 24 (AP). -- William H. Thompson of Grand Island, former Nebraska Supreme Court judge, was appointed Senator from Nebraska today to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Howell. He is 79 years old and a Democrat.

The real estate market, which has shown a slow but steady upward trend during the last couple of weeks after lying dormant for months, was further encouraged yesterday by the return of Frederick Brown, operator and philanthropist, who celebrated the event by buying a Fifth Avenue corner in the midtown shopping zone having an assessed valuation of $1,750,000.
WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Following are leading points developed today in the investigation of J.P. Morgan Co. by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee:

Money market continued quiet and at quotations which have prevailed now without change for some time. Business, too, was along the small lines character in trading of the last several weeks. Stock Exchange call money remained at 1 per cent, while time money, commercial paper and acceptances were unchanged.

The latest report of the Citizens Budget Commission aims directly at restoration of this city's credit, without which it cannot continue to meet its payrolls, pay its bills when due, provide the large sums needed for unemployment relief and get ahead with necessary public improvements.
The program suggested by the Citizens Budget Commission for the restoration of the city's credit follows:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 24. -- Yale's baseball team defeated Holy Cross today, 6 to 2. A two-bagger by Cammarano in the second inning, following a pass to Murray, registered Holy Cross's first run, while Britt's triple in the fourth and Cammarano's second safety scored the second.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- A list of banks and trust companies in which J.P. Morgan Co. have maintained deposits since Jan. 1, 1927, together with balances of such accounts, was submitted to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee by Mr. Morgan today, as follows:

A class of 109 will be graduated from the Hebrew Technical Institute tonight at commencement exercises in Cooper Union. Dr. K. George Falk, president of the board of directors of the institute, will deliver an address. Dr. Edgar S. Barney, the principal, will award the diplomas and prizes.
The American Classic Players will present "Hate Planters," a play by Bertha Wiernick, at the Heckscher Theatre, 1 East 104th Street, this evening.

FALMOUTH, England, May 24. -- Breaking all records since the days of the clipper ships, Alan Villiers's four-masted barque Parma arrived here today, after an eighty-three-day passage from Australia, winning the windjammers' annual grain race for the second successive year.

CHICAGO, May. 24. -- The General Motors Corporation's $1,600,000 exhibit at the World's Fair was dedicated today. Leaders in science, education, industry and politics talked briefly at a luncheon, and then saw the wheels of an automobile assembly plant started by a cosmic ray with apparatus devised by Dr. Arthur H. Compton of the University of Chicago.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (AP). -- Lightning combined with thunder and rain failed to break up the Athletics-Browns game today with Philadelphia victor, 7 to 4, and then crashed into the right-field foul line structure and started a fire in the stand.

GENEVA, May 24. -- Germany succeeded again today in staving off the Jewish question in the Council of the League of Nations, this time on the ground that there would be a Cabinet meeting on it tomorrow.

Joseph E. Widener's colt Golden Way, which is expected by his admirers to cut a figure in the 3-year-old division this season, won the featured Montana purse at Jamaica yesterday in an encouraging manner. In his seasonal debut last week he was only third, but he scored over a field of higher quality in the Montana after being made the favorite at 7 to 10.

By a wet victory exceeding in its magnitude what had generally been expected and far more sweeping than that won in any of the five States that had voted on the question, President Roosevelt's home State has taken its stand at the head of the column of Commonwealths pledged to ratify the resolution of Congress for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 24. -- Chancellor Hitler and the Nazi party are fulfilling Bismarck's dreams of a united Germany, Dr. Hans Luther, the German Ambassador, told more than 1,000 persons attending the celebration of the sixty-seventh anniversary of the Wartburg Orphans' Farm School here this afternoon.

The transatlantic steamship lines operating to Channel and German ports, other than German lines, have warned tourist and passenger agents throughout the country that the sale of transatlantic passage on the German lines for "blocked" marks is a violation of agreements between lines and agents.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., May 24. -- The low-cost development of a beach park in Connecticut was presented to State park executives in session here today as an example of how park expansion to meet the needs of the public need not be stopped because of financial stringency.

Paul Blanshard, executive director of the City Affairs Committee, announced yesterday that the Brooklyn Bar Association would be asked to investigate the conduct of City Court Justice Charles E. Russell, who, in denying last Monday an application by a senior at City College to change his name from Jacob Itzkowitz to Jacob Bakur, charged that institution with inculcating Communist doctrines.

LONDON, May 24. -- The stock markets were active today, particularly the industrial section, where, following yesterday's rise in Wall Street, there was a demand for international shares. The trend was away from the gilt-edge stocks, where movements were mostly downward, and toward industrial partly as a result of American reports that movements for inflation already had been started.

The task of imparting to successive generations of American boys the language and traditions of his native France has proved so absorbing for Charles G. Sueur, Professor of French at the Collegiate School, 241 West Seventy-seventh Street, that he is able to pay little attention, to other activities of that historic institution.

Friends of Central Park who are trying to prevent the threatened encroachment of baseball fields and a running track on the old reservoir site in the heart of the tract were considering the possibilities yesterday of turning the Chrystie-Forsyth Street area on the lower east side into a playfield.

The first sale of a railroad under foreclosure since the depression began is scheduled for the New Orleans Great Northern Railroad on June 29. The line is controlled by the Gulf, Mobile Northern, in which the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad has a controlling stock interest.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- By a vote of 202 to 137 the House passed late this afternoon an amendment to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation Act, authorizing the corporation to purchase not in excess of $50,000,000 of stock of insurance companies and vesting authority in the corporation to fix maximum salaries of officers and employes of corporations to which it makes loans.

LONDON, May 24. -- Passengers from Great Britain to the United States will benefit by substantial rate concessions, announced today, as a result of appreciation of the pound sterling against the dollar.

LONDON, May 24 (Canadian Press). -- Princess de Faucigny-Lucinge's chestnut colt Rodosto, son of Epinard and winner of the Two Thousand Guineas last month, arrived in England today for its final Derby training. Rodosto was accompanied by three detectives and Jockey Brethes, whose first words were, "We are sure to win."

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 24. -- Two of the district's outstanding stars, Mrs. Leo G. Federman of the Glen Oaks Club, once a semi-finalist in the national, and Mrs. Marion Turpie Lake of the Old Country Club in Flushing, met with defeat in the second round of the annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship at Cherry Valley today.

John G. Jackson captured the President's Trophy at the Manhattan Club's annual golf tournament yesterday at the Oakland Golf Club, Bayside, L.I. He scored an 80. The trophy was won last season by William H. Hubbard. A field of 149 competed.

Exploitation of the public by sales at exorbitant prices of lots in the Muscle Shoals area and by misleading promises of employment was charged yesterday in a special bulletin by the Better Business Bureau of this city. Acceleration of activities by "high-pressure real estate operators" is reported by the bureau, which finds that President Roosevelt's warning that passage of the Muscle Shoals-Tennessee Valley Act would stimulate conscienceless land vending already has proved true.

The setting up of a virtual dictator with wartime powers to direct the Federal government's proposed public works program as a measure of unemployment relief and industrial revival was urged yesterday by Robert Moses, chairman of the State Public Works Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- E. Barrett Prettyman of Maryland, who was of counsel in the $34,000,000 Couzens tax appeal case and is regarded as an authority on income taxes, was appointed by President Roosevelt today to be general counsel for the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

TRENTON, N.J., May 25. -- The State Milk Control Commission made public today a tentative schedule of minimum prices, wholesale and retail, designed to give producers at least 40 per cent of the retail price. If adopted, the schedule will become operative June 1.

Additional returns made yesterday from Tuesday's special election of delegates to a State convention to be held on June 27 to ratify the Congress resolution for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, brought the aggregate vote reported for repeal delegates to 1,891,823 and that for dry candidates to 229,581, a majority for the repealist candidates of 1,662,242.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 25. -- Three games at the Meadow Brook Club and one at John Hay Whitney's Greentree Field in Manhasset featured today's play on Long Island among the high-goal poloists.

Diplomas were awarded to 120 graduates of the College of Pharmacy of Columbia University at exercises last night at the McMillin Theatre, Broadway and 116th Street. Dr. William Jay Sehieffelin, honorary president of the college, declared in a graduation address that young men and women of New York City should take an increasing interest in politics because of the present situation in city government.

HAVANA, May 25. -- A bomb under the Yaguasa bridge between Candelaria and San Cristobal, in Pinar del Rio Province, exploded at 2 o'clock this morning, causing considerable damage but no casualties. Traffic was detoured this morning but resumed over the bridge this afternoon.

LONDON, May 25. -- Continued activity in industrials marked today's session of the Stock Exchange. The demand for more speculative issues affected British Government securities, all of which continued to decline.

Concerted action to drive rackets out of the city and racketeers into prison was agreed upon at City Hall yesterday in a conference called by Mayor O'Brien and bringing together the heads of the city and State law enforcement agencies.

While the recent advent of weakfish in Peconic Bay has interested salt-water fishermen to the exclusion of almost all other species, it also is true that the fresh-water anglers now are seeking new species to conquer.
CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, Friday, May 26. -- An unrevealed hope-

PARIS, May 25. -- Press reaction today to Norman H. Davis's declaration at Geneva yesterday on how far the United States would be willing to go toward organizing world security is that the United States has agreed to abandon the doctrine of the freedom of the seas.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 25. -- After his election as Presbyterian Moderator, the Rev. Dr. John McDowell expressed the opinion that extremists among both Modernists and Fundamentalists were troublemakers.
BALTIMORE, May 25 (AP). -- Baltimore laid down a 15-hit attack to defeat Jersey City, 9 to 4, today in the second game of the series to even the score. Earl Mattingly held the visitors to eight hits.

The man who the authorities say was almost killed in an attempt to substitute his body for Michael Malloy, the stationary fireman, who was said to have been murdered for $1.788 insurance, was found yesterday in a "depression colony" at Twelfth Avenue and 133d Street.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP). -- A statement that the Akron was structurally defective when she took off from Lakehurst on her fatal flight last month and should never have been sent out was made today by Representative Boland before the joint Congressional committee investigating the disaster.

A summary of what German Jews have done in science, medicine, literature and the arts is given in "The German Jew, His Share in Modern Culture." The book was written by Dr. Abraham Myerson, Professor of Neurology at Tufts College Medical School, and Dr. Isaac Goldberg, lecturer at Harvard University.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 25. -- The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America today elected as Moderator, its highest officer, the Rev. Dr. John McDowell of New York, secretary of its Board of National Missions.

"The Judas Tree," by Nell Swanson, is an historical novel about the sixty-seven-day seige of Pittsburgh, where 200 women and children waited behind crumbling mud walls while kilted Highlanders fought their way through wilderness to fight off the Indians and save them.

PARIS, May 25. -- As a counter-manifestation to Nazi Germany's memorial tribute to Albert Leo Schlageter, "the first soldier of the Third Reich," the French Federation of Veterans of the Armies of Occupation of the Rhineland and the Ruhr announced today that it would stage a demonstration at the tomb of the Unknown Soldier Sunday.

IT seems to be a stampede for Stanford in the intercollegiate championships that will start in the Harvard Stadium today. When Dean Cromwell, coach of the Southern California track and field troop, chipped in with his vote for Stanford and volunteered the information that his boys hoped to land second place, the clerk of the polls locked up the booth and announced the tally as unanimous for Stanford.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Probable amendment of the pending arms embargo resolution to authorize withholding of shipments of arms from all belligerents and not from only one party to foreign hostilities was forecast in official circles tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

While the action of the railway stocks in "confirming" the recent dash of the industrial stocks through the so-called resistance levels was celebrated widely yesterday in market circles, the late unsettlement left little of the day's gains intact at the close.

Twenty-one certificates of stock valued at $70,000, all negotiable, were reported lost yesterday afternoon by Arthur Bergen of 67 East 120th Street, a messenger employed by Schatzkin Co., brokers, of 60 Broad Street. His employers were of the opinion that his pocket had been picked.

TIENTSIN, Friday, May 26. -- The Chino-Japanese truce and armistice negotiations were thrown into a furor yesterday by Japanese demands for recognition of the independence of Manchukuo, for an indemnity from China of all Japanese expenses in the expedition southward from Jehol and for immediate evacuation and permanent neutrality of the zone between the Great Wall and the Yellow River.
Following in fun is the address delivered yesterday by Charles M. Schwab to the American Iron and Steel Institute:
After losing a five-run lead, the St. John's College baseball team came from behind and scored two runs in the eighth inning to defeat Savage School, 8 to 7, at Carey Field yesterday.

Nine members of the old vestry of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, which was ousted in an election on April 18 after opposing the policies of the Rev. Dr. William Norman Guthrie, pastor, brought suit in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday to have the election of the new vestry set aside as illegal.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 25. -- The banking crisis and emergency legislation during that period have left the building and loan associations of the State stronger and more fundamentally sound that ever before, according to Louis J. Cohen of Newark, president of the New Jersey Building and Loan League.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- At the conclusion of their talks on the World Economic Conference, President Roosevelt and J.F. de Assis Brasil announced tonight that no discrimination was practiced by the Brazilian Government in assigning foreign exchange to foreigners doing business in Brazil.

A plea to members of the Republican County Committee of the Fifteenth Assembly District to support the forthcoming choice of a nominating committee for leader to succeed Keyes Winter was made yesterday in letters sent to members by Mr. Winter, Mrs. Helen L. Lorenz, co-leader, and A. Newbold Morris, president of the district club.
PARIS, May 25. -- Herbert W. McCoy, formerly of New York, was drowned today when a seaplane in which he was a passenger overturned and sank in Lake Berre, near Marseilles.

CHICAGO, May 25 (AP). -- Pat Malone stopped the Braves with two widely separated singles today, while the Cubs combined three of their seven hits with three errors to win the opening game of the series, 3 to 0.
GENEVA, May 25. -- Colombia and Peru signed an agreement today with the League of Nations Council to cease the Leticia war immediately.

The names of 1,200 clergymen of the Christian faith who have signed a petition protesting against anti-Semitism in Germany were made public yesterday. The signatories represent twenty-six denominations in forty-one States and Canada. The protest will be sent to leaders of a dozen Protestant denominations la Germany.

Dr. Mary E. Woolley, president of Mount Holyoke College, called last night upon leaders of the nation's school system to start a campaign of "education for peace" to supplant the traditional "education for war" that has characterized the past.

MANCHESTER, N.H., May 25. -- Revealing for the first time that he had been negotiating quietly for settlement of the Amoskeag mills strike here, Bishop John B. Peterson of the Manchester Diocese late this afternoon declared his work finished and presented an opportunity to the strikers to return to work Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Immediately after the Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee today resumed its inquiry into the banking, financial and securities sales practices of J.P. Morgan Co., Senator McAdoo of California of the subcommittee, received permission to read into the record a statement concerning the investments he had made through the Morgan firm.
Polo remains an eight-period game, at least for the championships of the United States Polo Association.

GENEVA, May 25. -- A move by Japan to strike from the draft of the proposed disarmament convention the limitations established by the Washington and London naval treaties marked the disarmament conference today. A second important feature was an objection by the British to the definition of the term "aggressor," on the ground that greater elasticity was required in determining responsibility for a breach of the peace than a fixed definition would permit.

When President Roosevelt called upon fifty-four other nations to join with the United States in blocking offensive warfare he in no way obligated this country to use other than moral force to preserve world peace. Senator Joseph T. Robinson, administration leader in the upper house and intimate of the President, declared last night at the annual dinner of the American Iron and Steel Institute at the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The return of railroad financing to private channels "within a few month at the latest" was predicted today by A.A. Berle, special assistant to the directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, in his first public statement since his recent appointment to that post at the behest of President Roosevelt.

Police Captain Amander O. Hayes, who has been in charge at the West Forty-seventh Street station for the last three years, applied yesterday to Commissioner James S. Bolan for retirement. Later he was notified that his application had been accepted and his retirement became effective at midnight.

Despite the handicap of a widely distributed inland population and the strength of foreign ship lines that have been long established, the United States has made definite progress in merchant shipping in the last five years, Kermit Roosevelt, president of the Roosevelt Steamship Company, said in a radio address yesterday.

LONDON, May 25. -- Conservative leaders in Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonaid's National Cabinet tonight put their backs to the wall and defied a formidable element in their own party that is attempting to upset the government.

Price movements in local commodity markets were irregular yesterday. In many cases, profit-taking resulted in small losses on the day. The gains that were made were slight. Cash prices also were irregular.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The details of operations by which J.P. Morgan Co. established revolving credits for banks in England, Italy, Spain and Japan, and the commissions paid to the firm, were put into the record today at the hearing before the Senate committee investigating the Morgan firm.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., May 25. -- Scoring 43, 41 -- 84, Mrs. Thomas Hucknall of Woodway annexed low gross honors today at Sleepy Hollow Country Club in the one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association.

Members of the New York State division of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform were urged yesterday at their annual meeting in the Hotel Plaza not to relax their efforts until thirty-six States had ratified repeal.

BERLIN, May 25. -- The Hitler Government will reject any move made at Geneva to place the Jews in Germany under the protection of the League of Nations in the manner in which national minorities are protected elsewhere, it was stated in government circles today.

Retailers to Discuss Trade Act. The National Industrial Recovery Act will be the major topic of discussion at the meeting of the board of directors of the National Retail Dry Goods Association next Wednesday, it was announced yesterday by Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director of the association.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- A bill providing facilities to make effective the President's recent order combining agricultural loan organ izations was introduced in the House today by Representative Jones, chairman of the Committee on Agriculture, and in the Senate by Senator Byrnea of South Carolina.

Cooperation with the Federal Government in its proposed public works program was pledged yesterday by the National Board of Fire Underwriters in a resolution unanimously adopted by several hundred delegates attending the sixty-seventh meeting of the organization in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- There have been and will be many revelations of methods of private banking more important than the J.P. Morgan Co. preferred "investor's" lists. Before the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency has finished with the Morgan partners and the partners in other firms, Counsel Pecora will have elicited a lot of valuable information for legislators intent on strengthening the laws.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Eighty-two Democrats in the House deserted the majority today to join 107 Republicans and five Farmer-Laborites in opposition to the 213 Democrats who voted for the special rule on the Industry Bill.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 25. -- Howard S. Cullman, Commissioner of the Port of New York Authority and president of the board of Beekman Street Hospital, expressed his "strenuous objection" tonight to a "recent movement, born of the economic crisis, to unionize nursing."

CHICAGO, May 25 (AP). -- The Chicago Federal Reserve Bank in its monthly report of department store trade said today that stores in Detroit with April sales 50 per cent more than in March led cities of the Seventh Federal Reserve District.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP). -- President Roosevelt transmitted to Congress today an Executive order abolishing the Board of Indian Commissioners.

Mayor O'BRIEN'S appointment of Mr. WILLIAM J. CAHILL as Commissioner of Correction, to succeed RICHARD C. PATTERSON Jr., who resigned last Fall, is said to "pres"age complete peace in the politi"cal picture throughout the city." So far as the prisons are concerned, it is apparently a peace without victory.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 (AP). -- Authority of the Controller of the Currency to levy 100 per cent assessments on stock in closed natlonal banks is absolute, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended May 24 as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,243,000,000, a decrease of $43,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $238,000,000 compared with the corresponding week of 1932.

After their impetuous advance of the day before, the speculative markets were quieter and more deliberate yesterday. Not only was trading less active, but movements were narrower and with unimportant net results, although price averages reached a new high mark for the Spring rise.

LIMA, Peru, May 25 -- The Peruvian Government today, upon the request of the League of Nations, ordered suspension of hostilities with Colombian forces in the Leticia district. The chairman of the League's Leticia committee was told by cable of this action by Foreign Minister Manzanilla.

PARIS, May 25. -- The repatriation of nearly 100 American war veterans and the relief of distress among thousands of others, many of whom with their families are actually facing starvation in France, is the goal of this year's poppy sale by the Paris post of the American Legion.

CHICAGO, May 25. -- Scattered liquidation in wheat developed toaday on the Board of Trade. Inflation of the currency was scarcely mentioned, and with no developments in Washington to stimulate public buying, an overbought condition was disclosed when unloading was started by some of those who had bought wheat yesterday.

AUTEUIL, France, May 25. -- With Miss Elizabeth Ryan winning two matches and Frank X. Shields accounting for one by default, the American delegation in the French hard court tennis championships today remained in the running for the title in each of the three divisions of the doubles.

PARIS, May 25. -- A political storm which may assume large proportions is brewing here over the four-power pact, it became evident today. Though government officials continue their preparations to sign the accord and firmly believe there is no reason for French opinion to be disturbed, the ranks of the opposition, which already are formidable, received a new recruit today in the person of Edouard Herriot, former Premier.

A committee consisting of repre- sentatives of large holders of the $368,000,000 of outstanding debt of the city of Detroit will be announced next week to deal offi- cially with the city in the matter of reducing the unwieldy debt service by means of refunding.
After having advanced about seventy-five points this week, prices on the Cotton Exchange came under pressure yesterday and ended with losses of 10 to 11 points on the day.

Confidence that the expansion in the steel industry, which has already more than tripled the rate of operations in about eight weeks, has not yet reached its peak was expressed by the heads of all the leading companies yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The House Committee on Foreign Affairs received today a concurrent resolution, introduced in the House yesterday by Representative Fish of New York, requesting President Roosevelt to make "friendly representation" to the German Government to respect the civic, economic and political rights of German citizens of Jewish origin.
Apples or Principle? Out of sixty-two counties in New York State six voted against repeal. But it exaggerates the Dry strength to speak in terms of counties.

DEVON, Pa., May 25. -- Locke Brown of New York City achieved one of the popular victories at the Devon Horse Show today when his Danum Woodbine and Knight Bachelor carried off the blue ribbon in the class for best pair of harness horses over 14 hands 2 inches.

Herbert L. Pratt, chairman of the Socony-Vacuum Corporation, told, stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting that he believed "the sincere endeavor on the part of the administration at Washington and within the industry itself to bring about a balance of supply and demand will result in an improvement in the situation."

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- J.P. Morgan gave the following explanation today to the Senate committee of the fact that he paid an English income tax in 1930, 1931 and 1932, although he did not pay income tax in the United States:
NEW YORK. Robert D. Coe, Third Secretary of the American Embassy at Istanbul, is at the Waldorf-Astoria.

RYE, N.Y., May 25. -- An important new era in banking, marking the segregation of commercial and thrift accounts, was hailed here today by Morris S. Tremaine, Controller of the State of New York, in an address to the forty-sixth annual convention of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations at the Westchester Country Club.
NEWARK, N.J., May 25 (AP). -- Newark's champion Bears went into a tie with Toronto for the International League leadership today by taking both ends of a double-header from Albany, 8 to 7 and 4 to 2.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt received more than 600 disabled veterans this afternoon at the garden party given annually at the White House for the men of the nation's wars under treatment in near-by hospitals.

The directors of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company yesterday elected William F. Humphrey president to succeed Axtell J. Byles, who resigned to accept the presidency of the American Petroleum Institute. They also elected Edward H. Salrin a director in place of Mr. Byles and placed Alden Anderson on the board to succeed Jackson E. Reynolds, resigned.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- A state merit showing the public offerings of foreign and domestic securities by J.P. Morgan Co. since the war, giving the prices at which they were sold and the prices at which they are now selling, was read into the record of the Senate committee today by George Whitney of the Morgan firm.

About 500 bankers and bond men are expected to attend the thirteenth annual field day at the Bond Club of New York today at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club. The sports program will include a golf tournament, baseball match, tennis, riding and amateur boxing bouts.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Here are a few problems that trouble the mind of an ignorant voter:

NEW HAVEN, May 25. -- Dr. Arnold Wolfers, Professor of Political Science at the Hochschule fur Polltic in Berlin and teacher of political economy at the University of Berlin, has been appointed Visiting Professor of International Relations at Yale, with assignment to the Graduate School.

BERLIN, May 25. -- The peaceful reorganization of Europe through the abolition of the national State and the substitution of the principle of federation combined with racial autonomy was proposed today by Vice Chancellor Franz von Papen in a speech before a huge gathering of "borderland Germans" on the Iburg in the Teutoburg Forest near Osnabruck.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The plea of the Mayors of fifty large cities for legislation providing for Federal loans and for municipal participation in the construction program contained in the public works section of the National Industrial Recovery Bill, was carried to Congress today when a petition was presented to Vice President Garner and Speaker Rainey.

Congress is said to be aghast at the discovery that deduction of capital losses under the law has cut the yield of income taxes in two. Members are now eager to plug that "hole." But its existence was known to everybody -- outside Congress.
"They All Come to Moscow" will close its engagement at the Lyceum Theatre after next Wednesday night's performance. The play opened at that house on May 11.

The right or a public agency to use dummy corporations in acquiring real estate for public use was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Albert Cohn in approving the methods of the Port of New York Authority.

Herman A. Metz, former City Controller, who recently returned from Germany, spoke last night before forty members and guests of the Pegasus Group, a literary cooperative association, at 58 West Fifty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP). -- A demand that Norman H. Davis be recalled as America's spokesman at Geneva and a declaration that the usefulness of Secretary Woodin "is ended" came in the Senate today from Senator Robinson, Republican, of Indiana, as a direct reverberation from the Morgan inquiry.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The Glass banking reform bill, providing for both temporary Federal in- surance of bank deposits up to $2,500 for a year, beginning July 1, and permanent deposit insurance thereafter, was passed in the Senate without a record vote late this afternoon.

Burlock E. Rabell, lawyer of the Wendel family for twenty-four years, was the sole State witness yesterday at the General Sessions trial of Thomas Patrick Morris, former Brooklyn house painter, accused of conspiring to obtain a share of the Wendel estate by posing as the son of the late John G. Wendel.

FRAMINGHAM, Mass., May 25. -- Three children, who at first appeared to be accidental victims of a fire which swept their Saxonville tenement home early today, were in reality beaten to death by their mother, who then fired the house in an effort to cover the crime, police reported after an investigation.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 25. -- Playing true to form, two more seeded players in the seventh annual women's Eastern clay court tennis championship tournament today reached the singles semifinals at the Montclair Athletic Club courts.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The administration narrowly escaped an upset in Congress today when the House leaders pushed through by the barest margin a special rule for consideration of the Industrial Recovery Bill, despite objections by some of the Democrats, the Republicans and the Farmer-Laborites to imposing new taxes on people of moderate incomes while the Morgan partners were able to avoid payments because of deductions allowable under the present law.

EDMUND KEAN died a hundred years ago, and in the same year EDWIN BOOTH was born. The coincidence suggested to a writer in The London Times a brief review of what might be called the rise and fall of romantic acting on the English-speaking stage.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Coordination of transportation facilities into an effective national system cannot be achieved without relaxing railroad regulation and imposing similar restrictions on competitive transportation agencies, the Interstate Commerce Commission was told today by R.H. Aishton, chairman of the executive committee of the Association of Railway Executives and chairman of the board of the American Railway Association.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- A spokesman for President Roosevelt today ordered the Secretaries of all departments except Commerce to submit, without further delay, final drafts of intended interdepartmental changes, in accordance with the administration's plan to save $312,000,000.
The Federal Reserve System has launched its credit-expansion program in cooperation with the administration's program for raising prices, it was disclosed yesterday.

President Roosevelt's proposed partnership of government and business was endorsed yesterday by Charles M. Schwab, who presided at the forty-second general meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute in the Hotel Commodore.

ROME, May 25 (AP). -- Pope Pius today made a pilgrimage to the Basilica of St. John Lateran, the "Mother Church" of the Roman Catholic world, where he was ordained as a priest fifty-four years ago. Leaving the Vatican, the Pontiff blessed a crowd estimated at 300,000 persons and attended mass at the Basilica.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 25. -- There were several occasions during today's quarter-final round in the women's metropolitan championship at Cherry Valley when the fate of the surviving top-notchers hung in the balance, but all came through successfully to insure some stirring matches tomorrow.

President ANGELL'S report confines itself to Yale, but is of wide interest. It has only incidental references to the affairs of the world at large. While the university has been seriously retarded in its progress, it has been far less affected than many other educational institutions, "to say nothing "of the rank and file of commer"cial enterprises."

George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, continued yesterday to attack Charles E. Mitchell's sale of 8,500 shares of Anaconda stock to W.D. Thornton as a "sham" at the Mitchell income-tax evasion trial.

The National Industrial Conference Board at its seventeenth annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria elected Howard Heinz, president of the H.J. Heinz Company, Pittsburgh, as chairman, it was announced following the closed meeting.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., May 25. -- Close supervision of public utility holding companies was recommended today at the annual conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks after C. F. Blanchard, public utility editor of the Standard Statistics Company of New York, had described how such holding companies had developed into "something of a racket" toward the end of the boom period.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith played school teacher late yesterday afternoon before nearly 4,000 school children, who did not seem to mind a bit staying after school to attend a class on municipal government, conducted by Mr. Smith after his own fashion in pedagogy.

A certified audit obtained by the receivers for the Willys-Overland Company reveals that the net loss of the company in 1932 was $6,627,917, according to a letter sent yesterday by the bondholders' protection committee to the bondholders. The net loss in the first six weeks of 1933, before the appointment of receivers, was $654,152.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith played school teacher late yesterday afternoon before nearly 4,000 school children, who did not seem to mind a bit staying after school to attend a class on municipal government, conducted by Mr. Smith after his own fashion in pedagogy.

A certified audit obtained by the receivers for the Willys-Overland Company reveals that the net loss of the company in 1932 was $6,627,917, according to a letter sent yesterday by the bondholders' protection committee to the bondholders. The net loss in the first six weeks of 1933, before the appointment of receivers, was $654,152.

A tour of city-owned sites where playgrounds might be provided instead of on the reservoir site in Central Park was made yesterday by members of the Park Association of the City of New York. The inspection trip convinced them both of the need of playgrounds and of the availability of sites elsewhere than in the park.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- During the examination of George Whitney by the Senate investigating committee today Ferdinand Pecora introduced letters from John J. Raskob, then chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and Charles Francis Adams, subsequently Secretary of the Navy, relative to the offering of Alleghany Corporation stock to them in 1929 by the Morgan firm.
LONDON, May 25 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Efforts to establish a $250,000 unemployment insurance fund for the 10,000 furriers employed in New York were announced yesterday by the Fur Workers Union, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Kenneth Collins, from all reports, is a capable merchandising man, but as quoted in THE TIMES this morning on "the average man's" attitude toward women's styles he needs, in my opinion, to take a course in applied psychology.
"Music From a Marxian Viewpoint" will be discussed tonight at the Pierre Degeyter Club by M.M. Agranov, continuing the series "Music and Its Relation to the Proletariat."

Professor John Dewey of Columbia University will be among the passengers departing for Europe today. Professor Dewey will sail on the Red Star liner Minnetonka. Others booked for this ship are Professor P.H. Buck of New Haven, John Anderson, dramatic critic, with Mrs. Anderson; James H. Foster, Assistant Commissioner of Public Welfare of New York State, and the following:

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- With Ellsworth Vines and Wilmer Allison putting on a show of tennis power whenever it was needed, the United States Davis Cup team today virtually assured itself another invasion of Europe by sweeping through the first day's singles with Argentina without the loss of a set.

When Viscount SNOWDEN complains to the House of Commons of the "ignorance and incapacity" of his sometime dearest friend the Prime Minister, the compliment in his familiar rasping style seems to show that his health is good.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Government costs in New York State in 1931 were $1,639,405,682, a per capita expenditure of $127,96. This exceeded by $250,671,379 the revenues collected, which totaled $1,388,734,303.
The underworld gunners who wounded three pedestrians Wednesday night in Broadway at Eighty-first Street as they poured shots into an armored enemy car seemed beyond the reach of detectives yesterday.

Immediate steps to set in motion the vast machinery of the new Farm Law are urged on the Administration. Fourteen associations representing wheat-growers have taken the lead. They ask specifically that use be made of those sections authorizing the payment of "benefits" to individual farmers in return for reduction of acreage.

Citing the reduction by the fire insurance companies of underwriting expenses in 1932 without impairing facilities and organization needed to protect the public, C.W. Bailey, president of the National Board of Fire Underwriters, addressing the annual meeting of the group at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, said this demonstrated the soundness of the stock-company system and the efficiency of company management.

A combination of brilliant pitching by Xavier Rescigno, timely hitting and daring base-running enabled the Manhattan baseball team to gain its most important victory of the season, a 3-2 triumph over the strong Boston College nine at Manhattan Field yesterday.

Charles D. Hilles, Republican National Committeeman, declared yesterday that President Roosevelt was placing the American nation under a new policy of government, with strong central control at Washington replacing loose supervision of many years' standing.

William J. Cahill, former Bill Drafting Commissioner, was appointed Commissioner of Correction yesterday by Mayor O'Brien, filling the vacancy left by the resignation of Richard C. Patterson Jr. about five months ago.

Although he got away winging, in a start which most observers thought made him a sure winner, Pardee, from the Belair stud, lost by a nose in the mile and seventy-yard test which had the place of honor on the program at Jamaica yesterday.

The directors of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation took no action yesterday toward payment of the quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock usually declared at this time. They issued, no statement, but it was understood that their decision was based on the corporation's loss of electric "load" and its policy not to pay common dividends, unless dividends on the preferred stocks of its subsidiaries are earned twice over.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- When the Senate inquiry into the affairs of J.P. Morgan Co. opened today. Senator McAdoo, who had been listed among those who received stock of the Alleghany Corporation at $20, read a statement showing that by his investments through the Morgan company he had lost $2,565.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- A list of those who in July, 1929, received an opportunity to buy stock of Standard Brands, Inc., before it was placed on public sale by J.P. Morgan Co., was put into the record of the Senate committee today. The list follows:

Attacks on the action of George McAneny, Sanitary Commissioner, in awarding the contract for the removal of refuse in Brooklyn to Samuel Rosoff's Manhattan Ash and Garbage Removal Corporation failed yesterday. Supreme Court Justice Valente denied an injunction on three applications to prevent the Board of Estimate from approving the Rosoff contract.

CINCINNATI, May 25. -- The Dodgers played their opening game with the Reds today under gray skies and drizzling rain, but their spirits were even damper than their soggy uniforms when the contest was ended.

From more than a score of witnesses, testifying before a fact-finding committee of clergymen and social workers, was drawn yesterday an account of the "perfectly frightful" conditions under which human beings are living in this city.

BOWIE, Md., May 25 (AP). -- Band Wagon carried the silks of Cary T. Grayson to an easy victory in the featured Mayor Jackson Purse, an allowance affair at six furlongs which attracted six starters at Bowie today.

Announcement by the Reserve Bank of a reduction in the rediscount rate to 2 1/2 per cent from 3 represented the only development of importance growing out of the day's business in the money market. The cut restores the rate to the level which ruled between June 24, 1932, and March 2 last.

MAMABONECK, N.Y., May 25. -- For a brief while during the first round of the metropolitan open golf championship at the Winged Foot Golf Club today the course record established by Bobby Jones when he won the national open in 1929 was in danger.

Samuel Untermyer and Mayor O'Brien conferred yesterday In the Mayor's office at City Hall on the city's precarious financial condition. Mr. Untermyer, it was learned, minced no words in telling the Mayor that the city must produce new revenues immediately, and Mayor O'Brien responded by announcing that a special meeting of the Board of Estimate would be held next week.

In the reaction that overtook the markets last week The Annalist weekly Index of wholesale commodity prices dropped 0.3 point to 90.7 on May 23, from 91.0 (revised) the week before. It is still, however, well above a year ago, when it stood at 86.3.

Mr. Untermyer, it was learned, minced no words in telling the Mayor that the city must produce new revenues immediately, and Mayor O'Brien responded by announcing that a special meeting of the Board of Estimate would be held next week.

In the reaction that overtook the markets last week The Annalist weekly Index of wholesale commodity prices dropped 0.3 point to 90.7 on May 23, from 91.0 (revised) the week before. It is still, however, well above a year ago, when it stood at 86.3.

SIMSBURY, Conn., May 26. -- Westminster School defeated Hotchkiss, 67 to 59, in a dual track meet today. Two of the feature performances were the victories of Moore. Westminster, in the quarter-mile run and Rossiter, also of Westminster, in the 120-yard high hurdles.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., May 26. -- President Roosevelt's plan for a Federal coordinator of railroads was endorsed here today at the closing session of the annual conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks at the New Ocean House.

KATAPAR, Tibet, May 26 (via Mount Everest Wireless Station). -- After a third reconnoissance of the north col wall of Mount Everest had been rendered abortive by wind and driving snow, our advance party, led by F.S. Smythe and F.E. Shipton, made a most determined effort and finally succeeded in reaching the ice platform between 300 and 500 feet below the skyline.
WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The text of the joint resolution introduced in Congress today with the intent of taking the United States off the gold standard by law reads as follows:
SLEEPY HOLLOW, N.Y., May 26. -- Miles away from ticker tape and office telephones, on the greensward of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, the Bond Club of New York held its annual gambol today.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Application of the domestic allotment plan for restoring the pre-war parity of wheat prices, and the imposition before July 1 of a processing tax of not more than 42 cents a bushel on the milling of that commodity, appeared certain of adoption by Secretary Wallace following a conference today between the administrators of the Agricultural Adjustment Act and represeptatives of the various branches of the wheat industry.

PARIS, May 26. -- President Roosevelt told him that the essential condition for a settlement of the war debts was for France to pay her deferred Dec. 15 instalment, Edouard Herriot told the Chamber of Deputies during the course of interpellations on the government's foreign policies, which continued today.

AUTEUIL, France, May 26. -- Miss Helen Jacobs, United States champion, seeking the title vacated by Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, today won her opening match in the singles competition as Miss Elizabeth Ryan, former Californian now living in England, paired with Mme.

A property near Rockefeller Center held in the T. Suffern Tailer family since 1909 has been sold by the Fulton Trust Company, as trustee, to an investor, it was learned yesterday. The property consists of a four-story converted dwelling at 21 West Fifty-first Street on a lot 22 by 100.5 feet, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

The first permanent licenses to sell beer were issued yesterday by the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, which, it was announced, has already received more than $1,000,000 in lees accompanying applications for licenses in this city. About fifty licenses were issued yesterday, all of them to places of established reputation.

CINCINNATI, May 26. -- Both Tony Cuccinello and Chick Hafey picked the same spot on the left-field wall over which to hit home rims today, but the Red outfielder's smash came in the ninth inning to break a 2-2 tie and give Carey's athletes their fourth straight defeat.

TIENTSIN, Saturday, May 27. -- June 1 has been tentatively set as the date for the formal organization of the Peiping Political Council, which is to become the administrative authority over an undefined area in North China, but probably including all of Hopei Province as well as Shantung Province.
A controversy of several months' standing was settled by the Board of Estimate yesterday when it authorized funds for the maintenance of free Summer sessions at Brooklyn, Hunter and City Colleges.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 26. -- First of the championship titles in the fifth annual horse show of the Boulder Brook Club was awarded today to the chestnut mare Jeunesse d'Or, exhibited by Godfrey Preece of Westbury. L.I., in the polo mount competition.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I suppose it may be taken for granted that violations of natural laws, whether in the physical, the moral or the economic realm, tend to the ultimate disadvantage of the wrongdoer, and if sufficiently long-continued will actually prove detrimental to him -- that is, false principles of action must eventually react to the injury of those who adopt them.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 26. -- Using pillow cases into which eye slits had been cut, as disguises, two gunmen invaded the second floor office of the Radio Condenser Company in South Camden this afternoon, herded eight young women and three men into a vault and escaped with a payroll of $11,790.

OTTAWA, May 26 (Canadian Press). -- The progress in Congress of the new gold measure will be closely watched in Ottawa. Monetary experts here expected that Washington would take some such action in view of the litigation which going off the gold standard and refusal to pay gold bonds in gold appeared to invite.

Though there is a fleet of more than 150 boats in Peconic Bay to take care of the weakfish anglers in that body of water, accommodations will be at a premium over the week-end, according to reports yesterday from New Suffolk.

PARIS, May 26. -- The Radical-Socialist group in the Chamber of Deputies refused to follow Edouard Herriot this morning in his opposition to the proposed four-power pact, and as a result Premier Daladier's hand has been greatly strengthened.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The Morgan hearing, which had been droning on through a dull, steaming morning, exploded just before adjournment today into a three-cornered row involving Senator Glass, Ferdinand Pecora, counsel for the committee, and Senator Fletcher, chairman.
The virtues of an early start -- matutinal's the word -- Are told in song and story of the famous Early Bird; And yet there is this little fact to make the sages squirm:

WASHINGTON. May 26 (AP).Among the committee amendments to the Industrial Recovery Bill passed by the House today was that transferring the existing 3 per cent electricity tax from the consumer to the producer.

NEW LONDON, Conn., May 26 (AP). -- At a special chapel at Connecticut College held today, instead of during commencement as in the past, winners of various scholastic prizes for the year were announced.

Led by the New York Central, several railroads issued reports yesterday showing increased returns for April compared with April, 1932. The New York Central reported an increase of $1,056,000 in net operating income for the month despite a decrease of $4,433,000 in gross revenue.
GENEVA, May 26. -- The text of the petition presented to the League of Nations Council by franx Bernheim, a refugee from German Upper Silesia, follows:

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- A slight gain in employment during the first part of May was announced today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, on the basis of trade union reports, but it was less than half that of April, when 600,000 persons returned to work, due to the recovery from the bank crisis.

CHICAGO, May 26 (AP). -- After tying the score in the seventh on Babe Herman's home run with one man on the Cubs went on to win in the tenth today, 4 to 3, for their second straight victory of the series over the Braves.
WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The war Department issued the following orders today:

Motion pictures exert a profound influence on the habits and behavior of children and are in conflict with the teachings of the school, home and church. This was the conclusion of twenty psychologists and sociologists who have completed a four-year-study under the auspices of the Motion Picture Research Council.

Headed by the City of Philadelphia, Pa., which will offer an issue of $10,000,000, twenty-six communities throughout the country will seek bids next week on new issues of bonds aggregating $18,572,334. This week's revised total amounted to $10,881,347.

If Governor SMITH could deliver such a "sermon" to all the million children of this city as he made on Thursday to several thousand of them, we could look forward to a cleaner city a few years from now -- and with less expense. The chief offenders are the "grown-ups."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 26. -- Miss Juliana Cutting, whose lists of guests have meant invitations for New York social functions to many university students, predicted today in The Yale Daily News "smaller parties, moderate drinking and better times had by all."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 26. -- After voting to discontinue The Presbyterian Magazine, the official organ of the church boards, because for three years it has had a deficit averaging $1,000 a month, the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America approved here today without debate or record vote a budget for the ensuing year totaling more than $11,000,000.

The unscrupulous marking up of material for retail sales under the guise of payments of a sale tax will be penalized by the State Tax Commission, according to Mark Graves, its president, who outlined the sales tax procedure yesterday at a luncheon of the Advertising Club at 23 Park Avenue.

All speculative markets responded excitedly yesterday to the overnight announcement of a reduction in the New York Reserve Bank's rediscount rate which, together with the fact that the Reserve banks have resumed the purchase of government bonds, obviously signalizes the formal opening of the credit-expansion campaign.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- An assertion that President Roosevelt would make a declaration of his attitude toward Secretary Woodin and other Treasury officials who are "messed up with the House of Morgan" was made by Senator Long In a Senate speech this afternoon.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 26. -- An avalanche of buying orders on the local stock market following the New York close, attributable to the Washington announcement of proposed action on the gold clause in contracts, caused the broadest general price advance in many months and set up several new highs for the year to date.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 26. -- Just by way of strengthening the conviction that it is going to romp off with the team crown in tomorrow's finals, Stanford blazed the trial in the qualifying trials at the Harvard Stadium as the fifty-seventh annual Intercollegiate A. A.A.A. track and field championships started under a broiling sun today.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 26. -- Miss Helen Hicks of the Inwood Club on Long Island and Miss Maureen Orcutt of the White Beeches Club in Haworth, N. J., arch-rivals in both district and national golf affairs, will meet in tomorrow's thirty-six-hole final match in the 1933 women's metropolitan championship.

Sir Arthur Salter, whose hook "Recovery" was a best-seller here last Summer, has finished a new book, "The United States of Europe." It Is mainly concerned with the work of the League of Nations during its first ten years.
Commercial Paper. Yesterday -- 1 3/4 per cent for the best names.

The United Spanish War Veterans, Department of New York, will hold their annual service in connection with Memorial Day tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The sermon will be preached by Mgr. John P. Chidwick, pastor of St. Agnesrs Church, who was chaplain of the battleship Maine when she was sunk in Havana Harbor.

Executives of iron and steel companies representing; about 80 per cent of the industry met at the Hotel Commodore yesterday and decided to defer action on the pending Industrial Recovery Bill. They adopted a resolution referring the matter to the American Iron and Steel Institute's executive committee, which is expected to meet in special session next week.

BERLIN, May 26. -- The Reich Government on April 26 passed a law restricting the attendance of "non-Aryans" in German schools and universities. It laid down principles in consonance with the non-Aryan clauses of the civil service act: Paragraph 6 of this school law read: "Enforcement orders are to be issued by the Reich Minister of the Interior."
Numerous apartment rentals, particularly on the upper west side of Manhattan, were reported yesterday. The list included the following:

Trade has again forged upward after the hesitation of a week ago, with the pace of recovery proceeding with a more confident stride and greater surety, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The rise in general business now has been lifted to a level sufficiently high to reveal its stability, which appears to be fortified adequately to withstand the usual seasonal recessions of the Summer months, the credit agency says.

LONDON, May 26. -- Horatio Bottomley, editor and orator, who wielded enormous power over the British masses during the war, died today, poor and obscure, at the age of 73 years. He underwent a serious internal operation last week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos the letter printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES from John Bigelow of Washington, I wish to point out that Mr. Bigelow seems over-optimistic as to the fate of the men around 60 years of age now on the pension rolls because of their service in the Spanish-American War, the Philippine insurrection or the China relief expedition.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 26. -- W.S. Meany Jr. of Tamarack carried off the low net prize in Class A of the Metropolitan Golf Association's one - day handicap tournament today at the Wstchester Hills Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Testifying before the Interstate Commerce Commission in opposition to any general reduction in freight rates, Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad today "staked his reputation" on the assertion that such a move would spell disaster to a majority of the railroads.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 26. -- A statement that with economic recovery the United States Navy would be second to none was made today by Henry Latrobe Roosevelt, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, at the graduation exercises of the Naval War College.

CHICAGO, May 26. -- A sensational advance in the prices of grains may take place tomorrow, according to brokers on the Board of Trade here, unless a second reading of the plan for abolition of the gold clause in contracts shows it to be much less bullish than appeared at first glance.
With the prospect of fair weather tomorrow, in spits of the risk of showers today, railroads, air lines and bus systems were preparing last night for the first real travel congestion in many months.
PARIS, May 26. -- The Chamber of Deputies voted its second budget this morning by 427 to 98, and it was immediately sent to the Senate, whose Finance Commission started examining it this afternoon.
Outside of a West New York apartment house, the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday was comprised of small residences.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 26. -- Six midshipmen of the graduating class, to whom Rear Admiral Thomas C. Hart, superintendent of the Naval Academy, will write letters commendatory of their contribution "by officer-like qualities and devotion to duty to the development of naval spirit and loyalty within the regiment," are these six ranking officers of the regiment:

The list of passengers sailing today for England and France on the French liner Ile de France includes Miss Anne Morgan, Mrs. W.K. Vanderbilt, Mrs. Henry P. Loomis, Princess Cantacuzene, Gloria Swanson, film actress, and her husband, Michael Farmer; Jean Tillier, general manager of the French Line in New York, and:

Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy announced yesterday his readiness to provide playgrounds in the Chrystie-Forsyth Street area, and along the southerly extension of Sixth Avenue, if he could get the permission of other city department heads.
NEWARK, N.J., May 26 (AP). -- Myril Hoag's eighth home run of the season gave Newark a twelve-inning 5-to-4 victory over Albany today.
There remains from the $500,000,000 revolving fund with which it started about $150,000,000 of "good assets," most of the loss having resulted from the board's stabilization operations.

CHICAGO, May 26. -- A Century o Progress Exposition, Chicago's five-month World's Fair celebration of the 100th anniversary of its incorporation as a village, will be formally opened tomorrow morning amid pomp and pageantry.

Although it was apparent that the share market yesterday was being swept by inflation fever, Wall Street assigned other developments to account for the broad advance. Among these was the declaration of regular dividends by several companies concerning whose action there had been some uncertainty.

LONDON, May 26. -- Foreign Minister Sir John Simon and Sir Austen Chamberlain, one of his predecessors, paid handsome tributes in the House of Commons today to the change in American foreign policy proclaimed by President Roosevelt in his disarmament message and implemented by Norman H. Davis's pledges at Geneva.

A warning against the practice of plastic surgery by unqualified persons in beauty shops and other places where proper surgical procedure is difficult or impossible was issued last night by the Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery meeting at the Academy of Medicine.

Several shows are ending local engagements after their performances this evening. The list includes "Counsellor-at-Law," closing a return engagement, as is "When Ladies Meet"; the Milton Aborn series of Gilbert Sullivan revivals, the current one being "Patience," and the Shakespeare Repertory Theatre.

On the introduction of a bill in the House of Representatives yesterday to invalidate the gold clause, in public and private obligations, stocks and commodities rose sharply, while the dollar declined in terms of foreign currencies.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 26. -- Miss Katrin Ruth Vietor was married here this afternoon to William W. Brainard Jr. of New York at Little Brook, the Summer home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Gunther Vietor, on Old Church Road, by the Rev. Dr. Karl Reiland, rector of St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square, New York.

GENEVA, May 26. -- The Hitler government virtually agreed in the Council of the League of Nations today to annul in Upper Silesia all Germany's anti-Semitic laws and regulations of which Franz Bernhelm, a refugee from that region, complained in his petition.

The bill regarding gold payments, which Representative STEAGALL announced yesterday, is not at all what he described. That it would place the United States "off the gold standard by statute" is possible; but the assertion that it "repeals the Gold Standard Act" shows ignorance.

HAVANA, May 26. -- Major Arsenio Ortiz, who has been in charge of operations against rebels in Santa Clara and Camaguey Provinces, arrived in Havana this morning to answer charges in connection with numerous killings of rebels. The news took Havana by storm, over-shadowing everything else in the capital.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Russell Owen's article in THE NEW YORK TIMES has a public significance in addition to the information which it reports. It brings into the daily newspaper that type of informative journalism so characteristic of THE TIMES.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a London dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES appears a short account of the annual report on public debt defaults by the Council of Foreign Bondholders, in which your correspondent refers to the State of Mississippi as having "defaulted on Civil War indebtedness."

A formal ruling designed to safeguard the insurance interests of those who buy automobiles through finance companies was made public yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance.

Tonight a star will turn on a myriad lights in Chicago, and the building's of "A Century of Progress" will stand illumined. Thus science will open the Fair, to dominate it thereafter. Since the Columbian Exposition of forty years ago it has transformed the environment and created almost a new social and economic order.

LONDON, May 26. -- A saving of about u2,500,000, it is estimated here, would be effected by the British Exchequer if the next instalment of the war debt is paid to the United States on June 15 in paper dollars instead of gold dollars, as the Steagall resolution in Congress would make possible.
After having declined nearly $2 a bale in two days, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced violently yesterday and made net gains of 39 to 42 points, virtually recovering the lost ground.

Adult education must be focused on concrete problems if it is to be effective in improving the economic and social order, speakers at a conference declared yesterday at Teachers College. The discussion ended a two-day meeting of 200 leaders in the adult education field.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The Bureau of Labor statistics of the United States Department of Labor announces that its index number of wholesale prices for the week ending May 20 stands at 63.0 as compared with 62.3 for the week ending May 13, showing an increase of approximately 11-10 per cent.
PITTSBURGH, May 26. -- Gus Mancuso's bat sang a lusty song of victory for the Giants at Forbes Field today in a plucky uphill battle against the Pirates.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- A Senatorial investigation of purchases of equipment by the Civilian Conservation Corps was proposed today in a resolution directed mainly at an alleged $350,000 contract about to be let for toilet kits for members of the forestry army.

Trading in gold bullion future contracts in New York was proposed yesterday by a group of industrial and banking leaders. The metals branch of the new Commodities Exchange, Inc., was regarded as the most likely centre for the market if it is formed.
A sale of stock to an investor at a market price known to the seller to be maintained artificially was adjudged by Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag here yesterday to be a fraud.
With eleven named for the Toboggan Handicap, the Westchester Racing Association's Spring meeting at Belmont Park will begin this afternoon.

PARIS, May 26. -- The testimony in the United States Senate's inquiry into the "House of Morgan" showing that the American bankers escaped the income tax, prompts Le Journal des Debats to protest that American branch banks established in Paris also are escaping taxation which should be applied to them under the French laws.

GENEVA, May 26. -- Unmoved by Norman H. Davis's suggestion yesterday that Japan's proposal to eliminate from the general disarmament convention reference to the Washington and London naval treaties might badly affect public opinion, Naotake Sato, Japan's spokesman here, submitted in writing amendments to this effect today.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The smooth functioning, powerful doubles combination of George Lott and Johnny Van Ryn today blasted the hopes of a hard-fighting Argentine pair and clinched the American-zone Davis Cup final tie for the United States.

Reports on department store and chain store sales in April in the New York Federal Reserve District, contained in the forthcoming monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, show the smallest declines compared with the previous year since December 1931, and March, 1932, respectively the review will say.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., May 26. -- The first automobiles ever to climb Bear Mountain carried Lithgow Osborne, New York State Conservation Commissioner, and delegates attending the national conference on State parks to the summit this noon over the new George W. Perking Memorial Drive.
WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 24:

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- A revised version of the Capper-Marland Bill, under which an Administrator of Petroleum Conservation instead of the Secretary of the Interior would be the regulator of the oil industry, was offered to the Senate Finance Committee today by Senator Capper.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Sales of securities at "cut rates" to favored friends of an issuing house, as revealed in testimony by members of J.P. Morgan Co., will at least be matters of public record under the provisions of the new Securities Bill, passed by Congress and tonight awaiting the signature of President Roosevelt, expected to be affixed tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP). -- The joint Congressional committee investigating the Akron disaster dug deeper into lighter-than-air construction today to learn unofficially that the Macon, sister ship of the Akron, is about 2 per cent overweight, a matter minimized by navy witnesses in structural importance.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP). -- Fundamentalist representatives at the Northern Baptist Convention today failed in a move to put that body on record as repudiating the theology expressed in the book "Re-Thinking Missions," which represented the findings of a study financed by John D. Rockefeller Jr.

Psychology, football and "cool, calm and collected" girls led among the preferences of the graduating class of Fordham University, it was disclosed yesterday with the publication of The Maroon, the university year book.
"This is the time to establish mutual crop insurance benefit, soundly based on historic yields; and Applicable only to land which has been regularly used for wheat production.
Exports and imports into and from the United Staes by classifications during April, as given out by the Department of Commerce, compare as follows with a month ago and a year ago (000 omitted):

Supreme Court Justice Shientag, City College graduate, granted yesterday the application of Jacob Itzkowitz, City College student, of 1,414 President Street, Brooklyn, to change his name to Bakur. In granting the permission Justice Shientag rebuked City Court Justice Charles A. Russell of Brooklyn, who in denying a similar application last week denounced City College as an institution supported by overburdened taxpayers to inculcate Communist doctrines into the students.
BOSTON, May 26 (AP). -- The Red Sox shut off a late attack today to defeat the Indians, 6 to 5, and even the series.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, in speaking at the commencement and class day exercises of the Todhunter School yesterday, called on the graduates to be adventurous in life as well as courageous. In addition to the six members of the graduating class nearly a hundred of the school student body and many of their parents and friends attended.

RYE. N.Y., May 26. -- The New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations at the closing session of its forty-sixth annual convention here this afternoon adopted a resolution denouncing the proposed Federal Home Owners Loan Act after a spirited debate in which Charles O'Connor Hennessy, president of the Savings and Loan Bank of the State of New York, who framed the resolution, triumphed over an opposition which branded his endeavor as "unpatriotic".

Senator George R. Fearon, leader of the Republican minority in the upper house at Albany, in an address before the Republican Club of Oyster Bay last night, opened the fight to enable the Republicans to retain their present precarious control of the State Assembly.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 26. -- Continuing his bid for the metropolitan open golf, championship, Joe Turnesa of the Elmsford Country Club reeled off another sub-par round over the Winged Foot Golf Club's testing west course today and maintained his position as pacemaker at the end of the second round.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Four days before the United States delegation to the World Economic Conference is scheduled to sail for London, the President has not been able to get a Republican member of the House or Senate to serve. High tariff Republicans, both of the regular and the so-called progressive types, are reported to have refused to enter the delegation, because of the move planned by the administration to negotiate reciprocal tariff agreements.

News of the introduction in Congress of an "administration" joint resolution dealing with the gold clause in government and private obligations caused a rapid depreciation of the dollar in foreign exchange yesterday afternoon.

The passage of the Glass Bank Bill, providing for guarantee of bank deposits through a levy of one-half of 1 per cent on deposits of member banks of the Federal Reserve System, has so alarmed bankers here that several of the most important State-chartered members of the Federal Reserve are seriously considering the advisability of withdrawing from the system.

Responsibility in civic affairs was urged upon the graduates of schools and colleges yesterday by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College at the forty-first annual commencement of the Spence School, 22 East Ninety-first Street.

BERLIN, May 26. -- The Boerse was weak and listless today, with scercely any public orders. Sentient among brokers tended toward pessimism, crystallizing about the idea that the French would prevent any effectual action at the Disarmament Conference, and that in consequence the World Economic Conference would be rendered futile.

TOKYO, May 26. -- The gravest clash yet recorded between administrative and professorial ideas of academic freedom led this evening to the resignation of the entire law faculty of Kyoto Imperial University, numbering thirty-nine professors and lecturers.

The Board of Estimate granted its first tax exemption yesterday to the Fred F. French model-housing project known as the Knickerbocker Village, which is to be built on the east-side block bounded by Catherine Monroe, Market and Cherry Streets.

About the best the Yankees were able to do in their opening clash with the White Sox at the Stadium yesterday was to provide a setting whereby Babe Ruth, with a home run, could have tied the score after two had been retired in the ninth.

Plans for National Guard Summer training; camps are in confusion because of uncertainty as to the distribution of funds by the director of the budget, it was said yesterday by Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commandant of the New York National Guard. He disclosed that he went to Washington last week to learn what funds would be available for encampments, but that he had "returned with just as much information as when I left."
