SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 26. -- of natural gas, a great part of which goes to waste In the oil fields of the West, T.H. Kruttschnitt, son of the late railroad operator, Julius Kruttschnitt, has extracted a new fuel and he believes that it will revolutionize transportation.

Boston College triumphed over New York University, 11 -- 9, in a free-scoring baseball game at Ohio Field yesterday. Emil (Buddy) Roy, Eagle ace, was not in his usual brilliant twirling form, but heavy hitting by his team-mates at opportune times enabled him to register his sixth consecutive victory.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Expressing fear that the action of the Senate Appropriations Committee in striking from the Independent Offices Supply Bill the section authorizing the President to modify or cancel air and ocean mail contracts would endanger the proposed postoffice economies, budget officers today planned a sharp fight when the measure is sent to conference.

Recommendations of the dress plan board that an organization representative of the entire industry be created, to be known as the National Dress Manufacturers' Association, were adopted yesterday at a meeting of the general steering committee of the trade held at the Garment Centre Capitol Club.
Parties having an interest in a dozen Manhattan and Bronx properties bought in the holdings at foreclosure auctions yesterday as follows:

Why is it that publication of the "preferred list" of J.P. Morgan Co. caused so much surprise and regret ? We speak not here of the excited and inflammatory cries which have risen in various parts of the country. That a very bad impression has been made no one can doubt.

ALBANY, May 26. -- The Milk Control Board refused today to increase the minimum price of milk in New York City from 11 to 12 cents and from 10 to 11 cents up-State, but deferred to Wednesday final action on a claim by dealers that they were operating "in the red."

DEVON, Pa., May 26. -- After being judged the winner of the Gray Parson trophy for handy hunters in the Devon horse show today, Rollo Reed, owned by Mrs. A.C. Thompson of Elmhurst, Ill., was disqualified.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The House passed today by a vote of 323 to 76 President Roosevelt's industrial recovery bill, combining a farreaching plan for government control of industry with an authorization for a $3,300,000,000 public works program and $700,000,000 in tax levies.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Backed by the administration, a joint resolution was introduced in Congress today to abolish the gold payment clause in all obligations, public and private, with the exception of currency.

ST. LOUIS, May 26 (AP). -- Ernest Orsatti's single scored Dizzy Dean with the winning run in the four-teenth inning today, and the St. Louis Cardinals took the first game of the series with the Phillies, 5 to 4.

LONDON, May 26. -- Sir Austen Chamberlain, former Foreign Secretary, demanded today that Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany repudiate the recent speech by Vice Chancellor Franz von Papen in which the latter said the battlefield was to a man what motherhood was to a woman.
Mr. Bowers Reads Hemingway. Our new Ambassador to Spain must be a man of exceptional nervous endowment or superior diplomatic finesse, or both.

As a sequel to the cut in the rediscount rate, maturity money developed an easy undertone and a fractional contraction in quotation. Offerings were more plentiful and a fair business was done in four months' money at 1 per cent, compared with 1 1/4 previously.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 26. -- Catholics and Protestants paid tribute here today to the memory of the Most Rev. John Francis O'Hern, third Catholic Bishop of Rochester, at a pontifical requiem mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, where he was raised to the Catholic hierarchy only four years ago.

Samuel S. Koenig, veteran chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, will be a candidate for re-election, is prepared to resist any primary fight against him and will support Assembly district leaders favorable to him, if the campaign against him broadens to include them.

The Railroad Credit Corporation wound up yesterday fifteen months' administration of the loan pool derived from the freight surcharges that took effect Jan. 2, 1932, by authorizing loans of $7,500,000 to nine railroads. This brought the total of loans authorized to railroads to about $73,000,000.
Mayor O'Brien has called a special meeting of the Board of Estimate for next Wednesday to consider a ten-cent toll on the four East River bridges and a five-cent tax on all taxicab rides.

Commodities traded on local exchanges felt the impetus of the last-hour rally in other markets and closed with gains in most cases. Earlier in the day, many of the commodities had been lower. Trading was quiet. Cash prices were all higher.

With the cooperation of the iris, which bloomed seasonably this year, the New York Botanical Garden and the American Iris Society announce the opening today of the annual iris exhibition in Bronx Park. About 1,300 varieties will be exhibited on the tree-bordered slope near the motor entrance at Southern Boulevard and Fordham Road.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had determined to order temporary emergency cuts in the rates charged for electricity in the metropolitan area, wherever the earnings of a utility company indicate that it can get along on a reduced revenue.
Obligations outstanding in this country in the amount of $100,000,000,000 are, it is estimated, affected by the resolution introduced in Congress yesterday abrogating the "gold clause."

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The only witness before the Senate subcommittee on Banking and Currency Investigating the banking, financing and securities sales practices of J.P. Morgan Co. today, was George H. Howard of 1,001 Park Avenue, New York City, president of the United Corporation and president of its whollyowned subsidiary, the New York United Corporation.

MEXICO CITY, May 26. -- Minister of Finance Alberto J. Pani announced tonight that the United States and Mexican delegations to the London Economic Conference would work together to procure the rehabilitation of silver in the world markets by means of agreements insuring a regularized demand and stabilizing its price.

The grand jury returned four indictments for kidnapping against twelve members of the Food Workers' Industrial Union, a Communist group, with headquarters at 4 West Eighteenth Street yesterday. It was charged that early in the morning of May 22, the twelve attacked four employes of the Arrow Dairy Company at 118 Hudson Street, destroyed two loads of butter and eggs and took the victims in two taxicabs to the union's headquarters.

Arrangements were made yesterday for sales of two memberships in the New York Stock Exchange, at $160,000 and $164,000. The latter price represented an advance of $14,000 in a week and was the highest since last September, when a seat was sold at $185,000.

An effort is being made by steamship and banking interests in Europe to settle the controversy in the Atlantic Passenger Conference which has developed over the practice of the German member lines of selling passage for "blocked" marks, purchased at 15 per cent below the market price, it was said yesterday.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Henry P. Loomis will sail on the Ile de France today to be abroad until the Autumn.
PHILADELPHIA, May 26 (AP). -- With a fourteen-hit barrage and a 10-to-1 victory the Tigers today ended the Athletics' seven-game winning streak which carried them into the first division.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The President expects to ask Congress soon to grant him powers to raise and lower tariffs within certain limits. He hopes the authority will be granted before the meeting of the World Economic and Monetary Conference at London for its obvious negotiable values there.
The man who made up Charles E. Mitchell's income tax returns testified yesterday as a governent witness at the former banker's trial on the charge of Federal income-tax evasion.
THE complete program of the Salzburg Festival has just been received from abroad. The festival will begin July 28 and extend through Aug. 31, with one or more musical events each day.
AMHERST, Mass., May 27. -- A list of awards at Amherst College was announced today as follows:

The city will exert every possible effort to have the Public Service Commission order, not later than July 1, temporary emergency cuts in the electricity rates of the companies serving consumers here. Corporation Counsel Hilly declared yesterday.

The building trades have joined the increasing number of industries showing improvements over a year ago, with resultant further gains in steel output, which is estimated now to be around 43 per cent of capacity. Throughout all sections of the country, reports of better than seasonal advances in commerce and manufacturing continued.

We find engineers both here and abroad turning to the streamlined train, the economical Diesel engine and cars of aluminum alloys. With Dr. KRUCKENBERG making nearly 150 miles an hour in a Zeppelin car and the "Flying Hamburger" at 90 miles reducing the German highway bus to the status of the tortoise, it was inevitable that a major American road would seek the aid of science in recovering its lost passenger traffic.

WOODBUKY, N.J., May 27. -- Betsy Ross, maker of the first American flag, was the heroine of a stirring romance during the early days of the Republic, a search of forgotten papers disclosed here today.

The special race between C.V. Whitney's Top Flight and S.W. Labrot's Tred Avon, scheduled for Decoration Day, has been declared off due to Top Flight going lame in her work at Belmont Park yesterday morning, it was announced at the track.

Appointment of "commercial counselors" in each important trade region abroad, who would have charge of all commercial activities of the foreign services of the Departments of State and Commerce, is recommended in a report submitted yesterday to the Department of Commerce by the Joint Committee for Foreign Trade Action.

DESPITE the fact that there has been a decade of broadcasting, those directing the ethereal show still wonder if enough time on the American air is being devoted to education. And they do not seem to be convinced that sale of time and rental of facilities is the ideal way to support broadcasting.

Alvin Nashman, 3 years old, was run over and killed and his mother, Mrs. Lillian Nashman of 1,335 East Twelfth Street, Brooklyn, was knocked down about 1:30 P.M. yesterday at the intersection of Coney Island and Caton Avenues, Flatbush, by a Department of Sanitation truck.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP). -- Virtually all of the Northeastern and North Atlantic States are included in the group of sixteen Commonwealths which would gain Federal highway appropriations under the Burnham amendment to the Public Works Bill it the House amendment adopted yesterday becomes law.

To the Editor of The New York Times: During the last three or four years discoveries in Palestine have done much to clear up biblical chronology. An example is the excavation, three or four years ago, of Jericho and Ai, the two towns which were taken and burned by Joshua when he led Israel into Canaan.

OTTAWA, May 27 (Canadian Press). -- Expressing satisfaction in the working of the Imperial Conference agreements, the maintenance of financial stability and the settlement of such problems as railways and pensions, the speech from the throne read at prorogation of Parliament tonight concluded on a note of praise for the courage of the Canadian people.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 27. -- The beginning of June is the promise of a lively season here. Keen interest is being shown in the White Art Colony, which opens next week with the first of a series of exhibitions of paintings and sculpture of the contemporary spirit in the White Art Gallery of the Greenbrier under the direction of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Grauer of Cleveland.

Calling attention to a letter printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES on May 17, signed by I.S., regarding the plight of those who hold guaranteed mortgage certificates, Laurence B. Elliman of the firm of Pease Elliman said: "I have noted with interest the letter of 'I.S.'

LE MARS, Iowa, May 27 (AP). -- Martin Rosburg was sentenced to six months in Plymouth County jail today for his part in the attack and threatened hanging of Judge C.C. Bradley here April 27 by farmers because the judge would not agree to waive all mortgage foreclosure actions pending in his court.

Dr. Joseph S. Maxwell, medical missionary of the United Presbyterian Mission of Philadelphia, returned Friday on the Hamburg-American liner Hamburg after spending four years in Western Abyssinia. He was accompanied by Mrs. Maxwell and their four children.

LONDON. THE more important new American books in fiction and in other literary fields in which the ordinary reader is interested usually receive notice in most of the leading English papers. For reviews of American works of scholarship, especially those issued by university presses, one turns to The Times Literary Supplement.

IN the Luxembourg Gardens, in the very centre of Paris, there was a sparrow's nest. Out of this nest there came one year a white sparrow. Almost as soon as he became aware of the grass with the sun shining on it and the leaves blowing across it, Jimmie learned that he was different from the other sparrows, a lonely while little bird among all the brown little ones.

ABOLITION of the hindrances to commerce, liberation and reorganization of the movements and of the transfers of capital, and finally the re-establishment of an international monetary standard -- this is the series of measures to be taken for world economic recovery.

Whatever else may be said of the Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee's investigation last week into the affairs of J.P. Morgan Co., it was first-rate entertainment, for Wall Street as well as for the rest of the country. To be permitted, even four years later, to look behind the scene of those exhilarating days of 1929 gave a gorgeous thrill.

THE annual Spring festival, the fourteenth of its kind to be held in the Greek theatre of the Bennett School in Millbrook, N.Y., is devoted this year to the "Iphigenia in Tauris" of Euripides, the last performance of which is scheduled for this afternoon.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 27. -- Bolivia would accept peace provided it were not imposed, but negotiated freely, the Bolivian Government has replied to the League of Nations Council. The reply says:
WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The administration Securities Bill, designed to protect the investing public by means of publicity concerning stock issues, was signed today by President Roosevelt.
Frank Clemenzo, proud commodore of the canine fleet, was aroused from his berth early yesterday by the fog-horn barks of Vulcania and Saturnia, two of his six Airedales.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP). -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the Reading Company to regain its control of the Central Railroad Company of New Jersey.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 27. -- Yale's lacrosse team closed its season today with a victory over Harvard, 9 -- 4. Captain Nelson and Glick excelled for Yale on the attack and Train was a tower of strength defensively for the Elis.

The Police Department, in ceremonies held before the bronze me- morial plagues in the corridor of headquarters, paid its annual tribute yesterday to members who died in military service during the World War or who were killed more recently in line of duty.

Several members of Congregation Shearith Israel will make their annual pilgrimage Tuesday to a tiny plot on the Bowery, the oldest Jewish cemetery in the United States. It was consecrated in 1656 and maps of that period listed it as being "outside the city."

Two years ago, at the end of ten years of a "new" program, Antioch College paused to take stock. Its purposes and methods, and the degree to which they had permeated the lives and actions of the whole college community, were examined by special faculty committees as a basis for further development.

WILEY POST, who, with Harold Gatty, encircled the globe in 8 days, 15 hours and 51 minutes in 1931, proposes to get away alone next month on much the same route. This time, however, Wiley says he is "going as passenger."

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The drive to put 274,000 jobless young men to work in the forest camps by July 1 is progressing more rapidly than called for by the schedule issued on May 12, Robert Fechner, director of Emergency Conservation Work, reported to President Roosevelt today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 16. -- Enthusiasm and good nature predominated at the election just held. Color was furnished by the antics of some of the candidates.

W.C. FIELDS, the veteran comedian who appears at the Paramount this week in "International House," was born in Philadelphia, and at the age of 11 ran away to become an actor. Four years later he got his first acting job, doing a juggling turn on the stage of an Atlantic city beer garden for $5 a week.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 27. -- Holy Cross vanquished Yale today before a crowd of 2,500, defeating the Blue nine by 8 to 4. Joe Mulligan, pitching ace for the Crusaders, held the Elis hitless and scoreless until the seventh inning. He allowed only four hits and struck out nine.
PHILADELPHIA, May 27. -- Two justices of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court whose names appeared in the list of favored customers of J.P. Morgan Co. were called upon today by Governor Pinchot to resign.

ISTANBUL, May 25. -- It is no longer a new thing for a country to apply to American experts for advice in reorganizing a particular branch of its economic life. Turkey already has taken advantage of such counsel in connection with its customs and railways.

The Shipping Board has approved the new agreement drafted by the United States Intercoastal Conference to regulate its operations in the service between the principal Atlantic and Pacific Coast ports, it was announced yesterday.
BROADCASTERS have formulated plans to bring a number of symphony organizations to the microphone this Summer.

NEW YORK CITY finances are again in a critical condition. The city has outstanding, in the hands of banks and private investors, some $236,000,000 of short-term obligations maturing in June. It can redeem some of them in hard cash; the rest it must renew, or else default.
Making its final home stand of the season, Fordham University's baseball nine registered its sixth straight triumph by vanquishing Boston College, 10 to 8, at Fordham Field yesterday.

The annual bridge tournament for the benefit of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children will be held the afternoons of June 7, 14, 21 and 28 at the home of Mrs. Harold E. Talbott in Old Westbury, L.I., under the direction of Alfred M. Gruenther.

Another step in the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board's drive to oust the racketeering element from the legal beer and wine business will be taken tomorrow, when the board meets to resume its consideration of brewery permits.

Endorsing the recent survey made by the State of Ohio regarding methods of expenditure for public works under the $3,300,000,000 proposed public works program, Robert D. Kuhn, president of the Construction League, says in the current issue of the Architectural Forum that as long as the government is about to spend vast sums of money on useful public works the whole program should be put on a new basis.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 27. -- The Cornell University Law School will confer the degree of Bachelor of Laws upon nineteen graduates at the commencement exercises here on June 1. Because of the imminence of bar examinations, the law school commencement is held before the general university ceremonies.

With its setting a natural amphitheatre, the Tuxedo Horse Show each Spring provides one of the most delightful exhibitions of the outdoor season. Tuxedo Park is at its best in early June, and to a delightful environment is added a hospitality that attracts leading exhibitors from this section.

ADMIRERS of Rudyard Kipling seem to outnumber those of any other living writer. At least they are more vocal. Over six years ago the Kipling Society was founded in London to do him honor and to spread the Kipling gospel.

SLOWING down or stopping a steamer involves the use of an elaborate system of engine telegraphs connecting the bridge with the engine room. If the predictions of Dr. E.F.W. Alexanderson, consulting engineer of the General Electric Company, are realized, there will be less shifting of handles to signs reading "half speed," "full speed ahead," and "stop" on the bridge and less dramatic clanging of bells.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The article by H.H. Bennett, entitled "Huge Waste by Erosion: The Nation Begins a Survey," brings to public attention a subject of vast economic and social importance that has been overlooked generally, to the great detriment of the entire country.

David Edward Town, chairman of the executive committee of the Hearst Corporations and chairman of the board of the International Magazine Company, died yesterday at his home, 55 Central Park West, after a short illness. Death was caused by leucaemia, a blood infection.

GARRISON, N.Y., May 27. -- In a brief address delivered here today at the closing exercises of the Malcolm Gordon School, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, told the six boys who had completed the school's course that they should "put into their lives as much of the joy of living as possible."
BOSTON, May 27. -- Franklin D. Roosevelt and his sons borrowed a yawl last Summer, when the national campaign was just beginning, and cruised from New Haven to Portsmouth.

COLUMBUS, May 27 (AP). -- The militant fundamentalist faction of the Presbyterian Church in the United States suffered a stinging defeat in the General Assembly today, when an overwhelming vote of confidence was given to the church's Board of Foreign Missions.

LONDON. SOME rather unpleasant surprises are in store for a number of Hollywood's film-makers unless they mind their ps and qs in the matter of what may be somewhat euphemistically described as sex-appeal.

YEARS ago the late Sir John Murray, famous for his work in oceanography, remarked that if it were possible to drill a core of only 500 feet out of the bottom of the ocean we would have a record of almost all geologic time. In the light of some work done by Professor J.A. Cushman, this hypothesis seems to be true.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 27. -- Motorcycle Patrolman Dudley Gerow, 28 years old, of 25 Mitchell Place, this city, was placed in the county jail at East View this afternoon charged with first-degree robbery. His police record of five years on the Westchester County Park force included some acts of heroism.

GOLD today is the most talked-about thing in the world. There are gold famines in many countries, and business in those lands is more or less paralyzed. There is a huge concentration of gold in the United States, but the country is off the gold standard.

TWO situations involving revolutionary consequences are apparent in American broadcasting, warned C.M. Jansky Jr., consulting radio engineer of Washington, D.C., in a report to the National Advisory Council on Radio in Education.

The increasing number of tenement vacancies in Manhattan is due largely to the decentralization movement which has been in progress in recent years in practically all large centres of population in this country, in the opinion of the land utilization committee of the New York Building Congress.

THAT the first ten days of the Roosevelt administration met and vanquished the Crisis of the Great Depression is the thesis set forth by "George Grey" -- a pen-name that conceals nobody knows what writing personality -- in this booklet.

Samuel Kantor, political lieutenant of Alderman William Solomon, Tammany leader of the Seventeenth Assembly District, was freed yesterday in bail of $10,000. He had passed Friday night in the Federal House of Detention following his arrest in the Hotel Mayflower.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 27. -- Riding the old Olympic shell in which other Navy oarsmen won world honors in 1920, the varsity crew of the United States Naval Academy finished one of its most successful seasons of modern years today when it nosed out Pennsylvania and Harvard in rough waters to take the Charles Francis Adams Cup.

A LIVING presentation of the relationship between nature and design is given in the exhibition. "Plant Forms in Ornament," at the Metropolitan Museum, which will be open until Nov. 10. Growing trees in pots, cut flowers and aquatic blooms in a large central pool are grouped with pottery, glass, fabrics, rugs, costumes and jewelry in which these plant forms appear, transmuted from living growths into decorative motifs.

MR. CHARLES I. GLICKSBERG'S purpose in "Walt Whitman and the Civil War" is to edit, without revision, and place before the publie a number of fugitive articles and manuscripts by Whitman which either deal with or belong to the period.
CHICAGO, May 27. -- Bradley-bred fillies ran one-two in the $3,000 added Illinois Oaks today, feature at Washington Park.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- In many respects the most important happening during the Senate Banking and Currency Committee's four-day inquiry this week into private banking practices was a sharp round of applause. It came Friday when Ferdinand Pecora, the committee's counsel, responded vigorously to Senator Glass.

Sap's a-runnin'! That means concentrated activity throughout the "sugar bush" of Northeastern United States and neighboring Canadian Provinces, says a bulletin from the National Geographic Society. Sap buckets are brought out, and sleds with tanks mounted on them glide into the sugar maple forests.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 20 amounted to 531,618 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 523 cars, or 0.1 per cent, more than for the preceding week and 15,990 cars, or 3.1 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year.

Many in society are interested in plans for the annual Toc H benefit entertainment, an institution among shipboard parties here, which is to be held the night of June 5 on board the liner Berengaria. Committees now are being formed for the event and an entertainment program, beginning with dinner and continuing through a cabaret performance, dancing, a treasure hunt and late supper, is under way.

Four big interscholastic meets, headed by the C.H.S.A.A. championships, will engage the attention of New York City's scholastic track and field fans this week, which will be one of the busiest weeks of the current season for the city's schoolboy track athletes.
Police Commissioner Bolan announced yesterday a policy of speedy transfer for captains and inspectors who did not conform to his standards of satisfactory police service.

Harold Herrick, who was president of the Niagara Fire Insurance Company from 1896 until his retirement in 1916, died suddenly of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Lawrence, L.I., where he had lived for fifty-four years. His age was 79.

ARDSLEY, N.Y., May 27. -- Adolph Lewisohn, financier and philanthropist, celebrated his eighty-fourth birthday here tonight at his home, Heatherdell Farm. A dinner was held in his honor with about twenty-five persons present. They included his son, Sam A. Lewisohn, his daughter, Mrs. Arthur Lehman and a majority of his fifteen grandchildren.

CHICAGO, May 27. -- The portals of The Century og Progress Exposition, Chicago's second world's fair, were thrown open to the peoples of all nations this morning. There were happy crowds, miles of pageantry, roaring cannon and bombs which, bursting in a cloudless sky, released hundreds of American flags.

The progress of pupils in schools in Wew York City depends so much on neighborhood conditions that if those are known it is possible to predict closely what the rate of progress in a particular school will be, according to Dr. J.B. Maller of the Institute of School Experimentation of Teachers College, Columbia University, who has presented the results of a study in the latest issue of the Teachers College Record.
LONDON, May 26. -- The British Government and people are depressed at the moment by new problems, which they see crowding in endlessly upon them.

THERE is something magical about accessories today, for with their aid one can transform almost any costume. What is more, they are an integral part of the style picture. For example, manufacturers of jewelry have made bracelets to imitate pique and linen, and necklaces of flax to be worn with linen gowns.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 27. -- Syr- acuse played well behind Lefty Kiffney today to score an unexpected 5-1 victory over Colgate in the third game of the series. The Maroon won both previous encounters.

To the Music Editor: In today's TIMES, under the heading "The Composer's Lot," Mr. Downes writes on the problems of the composer. Mr. Downes has concluded, probably because of the nature of my article, that I expect special consideration for the composer.

Activities in industry and trade in forty cities in the United States were 15 per cent greater this month than in April, according to a survey made last week by Fenner, Beane Ungerleider, one of the largest "wire houses" having membership in the New York Stock Exchange.

BERLIN, May 27. -- The Boerse wound up the week with a placid session, which periodically lapsed into stagnation. There was considerable discussion of the foreign reaction to the American currency plans and abolition of interest payments in gold, while the effect of President Roosevelt's telephonic contact with Sir John Simon on the disarmament conference also was freely discussed, the prevailing impression being that the Geneva negotiations had received fresh impetus.
Amusing rhymes that characterize the English sovereigns from William the Conqueror.

Building and loan associations paid about $700,000,000 to their investing and borrowing members during the first four months of 1933, according to a report by the United States Building and Loan League.

IT is the purpose of Eva Turner Clark to prove by the topical allusions embedded in it that William Shakespeare's "Love's Labour's Lost" was really the work of Edward de Vere, Earl of Oxford, and that it was written in 1578.

WASHINGTON. ANOTHER step has been taken toward international cooperation through the service which will be rendered by the International Relief Union to countries overwhelmed by disaster. Functioning on much the same lines as those of the disaster service of the American Red Cross, it will operate with the active assistance of the Red Cross societies of member countries, under the aegis of the League of Nations.

Because Tuesday will be Memorial Day, virtually all of the pastors will preach today sermons in laudation of those who made the supreme sacrifice in the Civil War, the Spanish-American War and the World War.

AT the age of 19 I acted the part of Uncle Tom in the old play dramatized from Mrs. Stowe's epochal story. Filled with the errors of a youthful artistic indiscretion that burst from every pore, my acting, I now feel, must have been something rather terrible.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Improvement in business conditions continued during the week ended on May 20, and the progress made so far in May indicates that the month will record the first advance in business activity over the corresponding month of the preceding year since the down trend started in 1929, according to the weekly report made public today by the Commerce Department.

RECENT years have brought an increasing number of books that tell of experiences "behind these walls" -- prison walls in one or another part of the country. While the experiences, the situations, the immediate surroundings are of a considerable variety there is in all of them an impressive and ghastly similarity, for they proclaim with one voice the brutal, stupid, criminal character so frequent among those who rule with absolute power behind the prison walls.

COMPLETION of the Nazi program for establishing a National Evangelical Church in the Reich, under State domination, would raise the number of established churches in Europe to nine, the same number that existed before the Spanish National Assembly decided that "no official religion exists" in that country.

Because every one of the company's fifty-four contract players is scheduled or at work in forthcoming productions. Paramount has gone outside for seven players to fill gaps in current casts. Fay Wray and Neil Hamilton have been engaged for parts with Gary Cooper in "One Sunday Afternoon."

With every man in the line-up except one of the three pitchers hitting safely at least once, the Manhattan College baseball team defeated City College, 6 -- 2, yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium, squaring the annual home-and-home series. City College beat the Jaspers, 7 -- 1, in the other game.

VIENNA, May 26. -- However much it may be divided against itself politically, Southeastern Europe is going to make a brave effort to present a common front at the World Economic and Monetary Conference.
TRENTON, N.J., May 27. -- A New York City patrolman today took first prize in the eighth annual interstate police pistol competition here today.

While every other government in the world was running on a deficit, last year, that of Venezuela was not only operated on a balanced budget but increased its treasury surplus by more than a million dollars, according to cabled advices received by the Venezuelan Consul General in New York.

PARIS. CHHANEL has not put a single Autumn piece in her whole mid-season collection. She has concentrated on creating "frocks to bloom like gigantic flowers against the verdant backgrounds" that form the decor for so many of the signal occasions of the "big season" -- Ascot, the Derby the Prix de Diane at Chantilly, the Grand Prix and others.

International motor-boat racing in Florida next Winter was assured yesterday when word was received in a cable from Italy sent by George H. Townsend that a number of European drivers had given promises they would bring boats to this country.

The current week will mark the opening for the Summer season of three beach clubs which for the last few years have been popular resorts of members of society here and on Long Island. The opening celebrations at two of the clubs are concurrent with the Memorial Day holiday.

ENGLAND, which has sent to America more lecturers than there were soldiers in the army of Cornwallis, has extended a great deal of good to this country through these literary legionaires. The somewhat challenging ideas they have delivered about our ways invite a gratitude that has not always been accorded.

THIS is one of those infrequent books which are always certain to be read with delight by a very large number of people. It is the diary kept from 1869 to 1872 by a young Chicago girl and only recently discovered by a member of her family.

The movement to oust Samuel S. Koenig as chairman of the New York County Republican Committee assumed tangible form yesterday. A body known as the Organization of Regular Republicans for Change in County Leadership opened headquarters in the Chanin Building, 122 East Forty-second Street.

BERLIN, May 6. WELL, here it is. The State Playhouse in Berlin has been "coordinated" by the Hitler government. Franz Ulbrich, formerly general manager of the Weimar Theater, has been put in charge of this governmentally subsidized house and as adviser on the playreading Hanns Johst, the dramatist, has been appointed.

Representative BECK of Pennsylvania has been nursing the Constitution almost ever since we can remember. In spite of his helpful ministrations, the unfortunate patient's case seems to be hopeless. In a debate on the Industrial Recovery Bill Dr. BECK painted mournfully and curiously the work of ruin and the ruin of the work:

CHICAGO, May 25. -- President Robert M. Hutchins of the University of Chicago and the heads of other educational institutions in Illinois are vigorously on the defensive against a bill which has passed the State Senate, the intent of which is to cut off from State appropriations and the right of tax exemption any school, college or university permitting the teaching of seditious matter.

WINDSOR, Conn., May 27. -- Loomis's track team had little difficulty in defeating Deerfield and Williston, 65 1-6, 27 5-6 and 24 points respectively, in the annual triangular meet today. The victory of the Loomis half-mile relay team was the feature since the quartet lowered the school record a full second.

PARIS, May 27. -- Hitlerism, in the days before it seized power, was for Germans, and in the eyes of France no less, the embodiment of Nationalist exaltation. It breathed the spirit of revenge and violent hatred toward the forces which opposed or seemed to oppose the program of the national awakening which the National Socialist party was determined to pursue at all costs.

TORONTO, May 27. -- Canada's experience with the sales tax, which so many in the United States are advocating instead of increased in come taxes and other imposts, has proved satisfactory to business men in general and painless to the consumer.

It has been a curious phenomenon of late that so many novelists have turned their backs on the confusion of contemporary life and have sought their themes in the American past. Evelyn Scott, Leonard Ehrlich, Merie Colby, Gilbert Gabriel, LeRoy McLend -- these are only a few of the writers of superior calibre who have chosen a historical background, and particularly a nineteenth-century background, for their stories.

THE title of this little book may seem flippant and frivolous at first sight, but the book is far from being either. Instead, it is a serious, extremely earnest and quite convincing contribution to the two sciences of philology and ethnology.

Results of referenda in the first six States to vote on prohibition have encouraged hope of early repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. In no case thus far has the decision been close. Majorities which ranged from 3 to 1 in Michigan to 8 to 1 in New York have surpassed the most sanguine expectations of those who favor restoration of liquor control to the States.

Wolver Hollow, the country place of Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin in Upper Brookville, L.I., will be opened to the public the afternoon of June 4 for the benefit of the New York Women's League for Animals. Mrs. Iselin will be assisted in receiving by Mrs. Phillips Alien Clark, vice president of the league.

PALO ALTO, Cal. A RATHER tired yet stout and obviously healthy gentleman is poking around the Stanford University campus these days. He is decidedly self-effacing; more than expert at avoiding what might be called semi-public appearances.
Thomas M. Farley, Democratic leader of the Fourteenth Assembly District and former Sheriff, gave his annual May party in Central Park yesterday for 40,000 children and their mothers.
WHEN Jan Kubelik first visited America and astounded the public by his phenomenal virtuosity, the then young violinist modestly acknowledged Ottokar Sevcik as the author of his success.

Winning the senior quarter-mile run in the time of 0:49.6, Edward Brown of St. John's Prep furnished the outstanding record-breaking performance of the dozen made during the sixteenth annual Athletic Association of Private Schools track and field championship meet at Baker Field yesterday.

WEST POINT, May 27. -- Graduation week at the Military Academy will begin on June 5. Diplomas and commissions will be awarded to 347 graduates on June 13, the last day of the exercises, in the open air at the base of Battle Monument.

An important series of orchestral concerts to be given through the Summer in the Casino in Playland Park at Rye is projected by the Musicians Symphony Orchestra, which, recently completed its second season in the Metropolitan Opera House.

Francis Dykes, vice president and treasurer of the Dykes Lumber Company of 131 West Twenty-fourth Street, Manhattan, died yesterday morning at his home, 835 Castle Point Terrace, Hoboken, N. J., after a fortnight's illness of heart disease.
Al Smith took his wife and "the kids" to Coney Island yesterday, in the good, old-fashioned way, "down the bay on the Iron Steamboat."

A WORD is always a beguiling thing that will lure you into far, strange quests if you but give it opportunity and attention. As you trace backward the trail it has followed as it evolved into the form and meaning in which it now takes its part in our daily speech you are by turns amused, startled, edified.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 27. -- Reserves of building and loan associations in New Jersey have averaged an increase of nearly 150 per cent since the new orders covering the organizations were issued last March, William H. Kelly, State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, said today in addressing the closing session of the twenty-fifth annual convention of the New Jersey Building and Loan League in the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "The origin of legal tender among English-speaking people," said Edward Atkinson, "was the decree of an English King making it a penal offense to refuse the King's money after he had debased it."

PRINCETON, N.J., May 27. -- Johnny Jackson held Princeton to four scattered hits as Penn handed the Tigers their eighth straight league setback in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game today. The score was 6 to 1.

Prominent Italians in New York have subscribed to the varied entertainment to be given next Thursday night on board the Rex for the benefit of the Columbus Hospital. The program has been arranged by members of the junior auxiliary of the hospital.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 27. -- By staging a spectacular uphill fight when her cause appeared almost hopeless, Miss Helen Hicks of the Inwood Club on Long Island, former national champion, regained the women's metropolitan title at Cherry Valley today when she defeated Miss Maureen Orcutt of the White Beeches Club in New Jersey by 2 up in a 36-hole match.

Further liberalization of the $2,000,000,000 plan for refinancing home mortgages, now before Congress, is proposed by D.E. McAvoy, chairman of the Long Island division of the Home Mortgage Advisory Board, in order that more distressed property holders may come within the scope of the measure.

New York State is conducting an experiment in milk control which will be closely watched by the entire country. "Dip into the milk situation and "you find it involves economics, health, "business practices, production, stor"age, transportation and many other "elements," says Chairman BALDWIN of the new State Milk Control Board.
PHILADELPHIA, May 27 (AP). -- Twice interrupted by rain the Athletics defeated the Tigers in the deciding game of the series today, 5 to 2.

Total expense in the department store field last year rose 10 per cent to a new high at 38.5 per cent of sales as against 35 per cent in 1931, according to the study of departmental merchandising and operating results of department and specialty stores during 1932, just completed by the controllers' congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- A charge was made today by Senator Couzens that some persons were trying to undermine the investigation of J.P. Morgan Co. through attacks on the character of Ferdinand Pecora, counsel for the Banking and Currency Committee.

BARCELONA, May 25. -- The President of the world's most powerful republic saluted the President of the world's most unpretentious State this week. The salutation was from President Roosevelt of the United States and was addressed to Senor Roc Palleres, President, or more officially, Sindic of Andorra.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 27. -- Popular awards for two scholarships given by the Van Emburgh School of Art, 171 Sycamore Avenue, North Plainfield, to students, one in the Fine Art Department, the other in the Commercial Art Department, and the awards made by an exhibition jury composed of John F. Carlson, Dudley Gloyne Summers and Lew E. Davis, have been announced.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., May 27. -- Twenty-one choice polo ponies brought a total of $30,395 at auction today held on Post's Polo Field. C.B. Wrightsman, an annual visitor from Houston, Texas, paid the highest price of the day, $3,700, for Pichon.

CINCINNATI, May 27. -- Red Lucas, the powerful pinch-hitting pitcher of the Reds, kept the Dodgers' losing streak intact today by hitting a home run off Ray Benge with two mates on base in the sixth. It gave the Reds three runs and they finished ahead, 4 to 3.

As in the previous week, municipal bonds and warrants composed the majority of the announcements made last week of loans to be paid in May and future months before their due dates. The total for May is now $17,520,000, compared with $65,341,000 last month, and $15,904,000 in May, 1932, at corresponding dates.

BERLIN, May 27 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- Some of the reactions to the question of national minority rights for the Jews of Germany are to be seen in answers to a questionnaire circularized among Jewish leaders by the newspaper Israelitische Familienblatt of Hamburg.

Thousands of persons, encouraged by fair skies at the time of their departure, left the city yesterday by train, motor, airplane and steamer for a Memorial Day holiday. At the same time arrangements were completed for the many formal observances in the metropolitan area.

These are still critical days. The administration is asking for more and more power in a supreme effort to prevent an economic collapse. Confidence and cooperation are vital factors underlying recovery -- and here, for partisan reasons, for the chance of making a wild charge, for the mere hysterical pleasure of upsetting delicate and well-laid plans -- headlines blurt out that the people have lost faith in Woodin.

ONE of the most beautiful estates in America will be dedicated in perpetuity to science next Friday, when the country place of Compton, in Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, becomes officially the Morris Arboretum of the University of Pennsylvania.

KRISTOFFER LYNGE, a handsome, broad-shouldered Greenlander whose bronze skin, sleek black hair and sparkling dark brown eyes betray the original Eskimo race, while his regular features suggest the addition of European blood, is the editor of one of the strangest papers in the world.

INDIANAPOLIS. THE men who race the cars on the Speedway are constantly trying to devise new ways of building up speed and adding safety as a compensating factor. Each year brings new ways of trying to cheat the clock.

GENEVA, May 26. -- Events of the past week have produced more optimism than Geneva has known for some time, although much less than might reasonably have beer expected. Geneva is characteristically pessimistic, an attitude reflected in the skepticism or apathy with which she receives many developments which, even from her own peculiar viewpoint, are hopeful.

THE chemists have been telling us these many years that the synthetic age has dawned. Even now we have metals like aluminum and sodium and a few hundred alloys that nature forgot to make when the earth was a cooling but still glowing ball.

BACK on Broadway after sixteen months in Hollywood, Lee Tracy displayed as his principal acquisitions a California tan and an ambition to rest. He lounged snugly on one of the plump green-leathered divans in the sanctum sanctorum of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer offices and began the conversation by expressing a distaste for the title of his latest film, "The Nuisance," which has since made its bow at the Capitol.

CAMBRIDGE, MASS. WHEN President Roosevelt last week appointed Professor Oliver Mitchell Wentworth Sprague of Harvard to be financial and economic adviser to the United States Government he selected a man who is perhaps more familiar with international banking and finance than any other in the nation.
PARIS, May 20. -- Mark Twain once complained that the ordinary Paris guide didn't know the difference between a fresco and a fireplug.
BOSTON, May 27 (AP). -- Wesley Ferrell, the Indians' pitching ace, shut-out the Red Sox today, 6 -- 0, and drove in two of the runs himself. Boston outhit Cleveland, nine to seven.

Three hospitals and two institutions for the blind receive sums totaling $30,000 under the will of Leah J. Simpson, widow of Angel J. Simpson, retired lawyer and former member of the firm of Simpson Cardozo, it was disclosed yesterday when her will was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court.
CHICAGO. WITHOUT too taxing effort contriving size of gargantuan variety, a world's fair exhibition of paintings and sculpture might, alas, easily let the public down on the score of quality.

TO those of us who have witnesaed the tragedies of countless individuals during the period of the world depression, the idea that tragedy is impossible in modern literature may seem a trifle strained and unnatural. Yet this idea has been presented not without plausibility by Joseph Wood Krutch and the New Humanists.

The acquisition of more than 4,000 acres of land, containing some famous trout streams, as announced yesterday by Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne, is but another step in the efforts of the State to keep pace with the sportsmen.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 27. -- A goal by Stewart Iglehart on a free shot Just at the final bell enabled Harold Talbott's White quartet to gain an 8-to-8 tie with Devereux Milburn's Red outfit in a practice game on Hitchcock Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

ROME, May 26. -- Despite one international conference after another Europe has been showing scant ability to move toward stability, but several events of the last few days have aroused strong hopes for the near future.

BOWIE, Md., May 27. -- The Chesapeake Bay Purse, an allowance affair at a mile and a sixteenth, beaded the week-end care at Bowie today, and D.A. Wood's Indian Runner had enough left at the finish of the journey to stall off Don Pedro and take the winner's share of the purse with a margin of a length and a quarter to his credit.

BUFFALO, May 25. -- Western New York has been one of the most conspicuous centres of the agitation over the price of milk. It has been the scene of the only serious rioting by milk farmers that has occurred in this State. It has produced vigorous threats of further striking, leading to the fixing of a legal price for producers.
CHERBOURG, May 20. -- President Albert Lebrun will, on July 30, officially inaugurate the new $2,500,000 maritime station which has been constructed particularly for American tourists.

GENEVA. IN solving by a division of labor the problem of how to have his Secretary of State in Washington and keep him in Europe, too. President Roosevelt met only one of the issues which the machine age and its short-cut "Geneva" diplomacy have forced on the United States.

WHILE the Century of Progress Exposition opened with fanfares in Chicago, the season in the New York galleries continued, with a number of exhibitions of more than passing interest. Young artists made debuts and shows rather retrospective in nature also claimed attention.

BOSTON, May 24. -- Business conditions in New England are better. Leaders in almost every line say outright that during the past few weeks there has been a decided upturn. They are not unduly optimistic, however. They admit uncertainty as to whether the upturn is temporary or permanent.

HERE is all Lewis Carroll's published verse, with various hitherto unprinted juvenilia from the original manuscript of "Useful and Instructive Poetry" (1845), The Rectory Magazine (1850) and other sources. Here are the Oxford pieces, some properly donnish.

OMAHA, Neb., May 24. -- When the patronage activities of Arthur F. Mullen, Democratic National committeeman for Nebraska, reached out for the Federal Land Bank at Omaha they stirred up a hornet's nest and the buzzing can be heard all over the eight land bank districts which includes Iowa, Nebraska, South Dakota and Wyoming.

Entries for the Gibson Island race, this year's ocean thrash, have reached a figure that assures a large fleet starting from New London, Conn., on June 24 on the long windjamming expedition down the coast and up Chesapeake Bay to the finish line, about eighteen miles below Baltimore.
Members of the New York Stock Exchange were advised yesterday of an amendment to its ruling of Aug. 3, 1952, affecting purchases of bonds, as follows:

By the steps taken last week in purchasing $25,000,000 of United States Government securities and in reducing the rediscount rates of the Federal Reserve Banks of New York and Chicago, the Federal Reserve System indicated its readiness to cooperate with the administration in a program of credit expansion designed to raise prices.

MADISON, N.J., May 27. -- In the presence of a notable gathering of dog fanciers from all sections of the country, the highest award in the seventh annual bench show of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club, held today on the Polo Field of Giralda Farms of Mr. and Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge, was given to the wire-haired fox terrier bitch, Epping Eville of Blarney, owned by John G. Bates of Morristown, N.J.

NEWARK, N.J., May 27. -- The Newark Bears dropped from first place to second today when they lost to Albany, 9 to 5, after raising the 1932 International League and little world's series championship pennants. The defeat also snapped a four-game winning streak.

THE fly in the nursery rhyme was a wary little creature, unwilling to walk into the parlor -- but not quite wary enough, for it was caught in the end. Like the two luckless victims in Miss Frankau's story, however, it appears to have had some premonition of its fate and to have struggled to avoid it:

THE proposed National Industry Recovery measure was being studied by the automoble industry last week with a view to finding out what benefits its application would bring. In the absence of official word from leaders of the industry or from its organization, the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce, discussion centred in what solutions the recovery plan would offer to some of the problems confronting the motor business.
BECAUSE Mohammed does not go to the mountain, the mountain must come to Mohammed." Such was the reply of Mme. Helena Lyolene to the question of what brought her to New York.

The success of Morris and Essex, with its new record for entries in an outdoor dog show, augurs for one of the most successful open-air seasons in the history of the sport in this country. Increases in registrations indicate that breeders of thoroughbred dogs have full faith in the future and intend to be prepared for all demands for pure-bred stock.

DEVON, Pa., May 27. -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney of New York, undaunted by a bad fall from her mount, The Grey Knight, yesterday at the Devon Horse Show, returned to the ring today, and riding the same thoroughbred, won the Clarence H. Geist Challenge Trophy, feature event on the fourth day's card.

New York University will honor seventeen alumni, who have rendered, "unusual service to their alma mater," with the alumni meritorious service award during the commencement exercises on Wednesday, June 7, Malcolm D. Simpson, president of the Alumni Federation, announced yesterday.

SUMTER, S.C., May 25. -- The South Carolina Legislature has finally adjourned after breaking all recent records by staying in session for 128 days. Its outstanding feat was to bring some relief to the property owners without recourse to an administration-sponsored general sales tax.

RICHMOND, Va., May 24. -- Senator Bailey of North Carolina and Senator Glass of Virginia, the former to a larger extent than the latter, have been under fire in recent weeks because of their failure to support some of the important measures in President Roosevelt's legislative program.

THE turf contributes to the broadcasting show this week with the English Derby, the Withers Stakes at Belmont Park and a match race between Top Flight and Tred Avon at the same track. There is a national spelling bee on the calendar and several Memorial Day ceremonies.

SELDOM has the world experienced such a kaleidoscopic change as the last two weeks have presented. In the middle of May the so-called realists were insisting that a new world war was inevitable. Today the heavy thundering has stopped, and although there are many black clouds still hovering on the horizon the atmosphere has distinctly cleared.

TELEVISION in an interesting form hides in the laboratories, obediently marking time for better economic days, but the radio industry shirks its duty in not introducing the elusive images to the public now, according to John W.L. Hogan, wireless inventor and past president of the Radio Institute of Radio Engineers.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., May 27 (AP). -- Captain Rodney W. Hey, 49, South American explorer and owner of an 800,000-acre ranch in Peru, which he was seeking to colonize, committed suicide today, police said, by swallowing poison after his wife's disclosure that she had ceased to love him and had found "another ideal."

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Governor Lehman of New York expressed the hope today that the National Industrial Recovery act would be adopted speedily. He pledged his State to "cooperate to the utmost" in a program to get men back to jobs on public works projects which the bill is intended to stimulate.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- A mighty United States Davis Cup team completed a clean sweep of its matches on this side of the Atlantic, recording a 4-0 victory over Argentina and losing its only battle to a heavy rain that drowned out the day's final singles contest a the Chevy Chase Club.

All staples traded on local exchanges rose vigorously yesterday in sympathy with the general trend, with several making new high records for the year to date. Trading volumes were heavy. In the cash markets new high levels were reached in eight groups, and prices touched the old high marks in nearly all other cases.

OAK RIDGE, N.J., May 27. -- Max Schmeling, preparing for his fifteen-round bout with Max Baer at the Yankees Stadium on June 8, today swapped punches with Jack Dempsey in a three-minute round that proved a highly entertaining session to a crowd of 3,000.

PASSAIC, N.J., May 27. -- A violent explosion virtually wrecked a gasoline barge as it was pumping gasoline from its tanks into those of the Solar Oil Company on the River Road near the Lyndhurst Bridge here at 2:55 o'clock this afternoon.

CHICAGO. WITH trumpet blasts and speeches which were literally heard round the world, Chicago yesterday hurled the challenge of A Century of Progress in the face of more than three years of depression.

DALLAS, Texas, May 23. -- The Texas Democracy is on the anxious seat. Expecting a lion's share of Federal patronage, it has received so far only what many think is hardly enough to satisfy a canary. What aggravates the situation is that the confusion and uncertainty that have existed since patronage became available continue to exist without promise of any early clarification.

TOKYO, May 13. -- Litvinov's offer to sell the Chinese Eastern Railway to Japan, or to Manchukuo as the protege of Japan, is as symbolical an act as the hauling down of a flag or the surrender by a commander of his sword.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 27. -- At the annual Smith College field day today the faculty defeated the students at baseball, 12 -- 4. All-Smith teams were announced in various sports.

While the advance in the listed bond market yesterday was not so sharp as that of stocks, many representative domestic corporation bonds climbed 1 to more than 3 points on the Stock Exchange and a few issues did even better. Foreign loans were steady to firm and United States Government bonds held their ground well in the two-hour trading period.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 27. -- Army and Navy, resuming relations in a track and field meet for the first time since 1928, met today on a fast track, the cadets triumphing by 76 to 50. Five thousand persons witnessed the events. New academy records were established in the pole vault and low hurdle events.
The school that taught the brewers of the United States the scientific way to make good beer celebrated its golden anniversary at the Hotel Astor last night, and it was a joyful reunion.

Mayor O'Brien indicated yesterday that the Sinking Fund Commission, of which he is chairman ex-officio, would take no action on the proposal to convert the Chrystie-Forsyth area into a children's playground until the city had decided whether to go ahead with its projected model housing development.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 27. -- Prince Charming, a bay gelding owned by the Warfield Farms, carried off the hunter championship as the fifth annual Boulder Brook Club horse show came to a close on the club grounds today. The reserve ribbon went to another Warfield entry, the brown gelding Chamik taking this award.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., May 27. -- Lawrenceville captured first place in the fifteenth annual track and field championships for New Jersey prep schools today by rolling up a total of 47 1/4 points to 38 3/4 for Peddie and 35 1/2 for St. Benedict's.
WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Adjournment of Congress on June 10 was the goal set today at a conference between President Roosevelt and Senator Robinson of Arkansas, Democratic floor leader.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Senate opponents of the abandonment of a neutral position by the United States in future international conflicts merely by Presidential edict won what they regarded as an important victory today when a compromise was reached that enabled the Foreign Relations Committee to report the arms embargo resolution in an amended form.

THREE very different items make up the week's budget of news. These are without any attempt at order or merit: The latest album of Gregorian Chants, Stokowski's "Rheingold" excerpts and the American activities of the Telefunken Company.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 27. -- With returns in from more than half the State in the election for seventeen delegates at large to the State prohibition repeal convention, the candidates favoring elimination of national prohibition were leading by a vote of more than 3 to 1.

ROME, May 27. -- In the week that has passed since the proposed Four-Power Pact was agreed on here by representatives of Britain, France, Germany and Italy, negotiations have taken place on one point that was left in suspense. This point concerned inclusion in the pact of an article dealing with treaty revision and reference to Article XVI of the League of Nations Convenant, dealing with sanctions.

CHICAGO, May 26. -- While some hard feelings remain as an aftermath of Wisconsin's bitterly fought six-day milk strike, the air has been cleared and the viewpoint of both sides enlightened. Belief obtains that the lessons of the strike will be fruitful for good.

Of the first thirty-two railroads to report their earnings in April, nine teen showed improvement in their net operating results, compared with April, 1932. Only four of this group had reported like results to March. Sixteen of the thirty-two roads increased their net income in April while three reduced their operating deficits.

President Roosevelt and Congress were urged to continue appropriations for national defense, in a resolution adopted at the last meetind of the New York Society Standing Committee of the Military and Naval Officers World War.

THERE is a message in this novel and the story and characters have been invented solely to proclaim it. However, there is so much sincerity, and the message is so timely, that a great deal of bad art can be partially condoned.

Cash dividend payments by the companies of the Standard Oil group for the second quarter of this year are estimated at $34,160,135, compared with $32,406,332 in the preceding quarter and $46,278,873 in the second quarter of 1932, according to figures compiled by Carl H. Pforzheimer Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., May 27. -- On a high, tree-grown point overlooking the Hudson, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt unveiled this afternoon a bronze tablet in memory of Stephen Tyng Mather, first director of the National Park Service.

In a small valley high up in the North Carolina mountains a score of boys have been hard at work these last few months crushing rock with a machine borrowed from the North Carolina Highway Department and casting concrete molds for a new pipe line.

Any concerted action by the copper industry looking toward the solution of some of its immediate problems is considered unlikely until Congress acts finally on the Industrial Recovery Bill. In the meantime, the movements for suspension of operations during the Summer, further curtailment of output and "blocking" of the surplus stocks of the metal above ground are being held in abeyance.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent brief visits of the famous Polish General Roman Gorecki, head of the Fidac, to several cities in America has caused many to inquire about the Fidac.

THE recent award of the American Institute of Steel Construction for the three bridges adjudged to be the most beautiful spans built in the United States or Canada in 1932 and the celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the opening of the Brooklyn Bridge, have served to focus attention anew on the many examples of excellent work in this field.

Carlos Saladrigas, ABC delegate to the Cuban revolutionary junta here, said yesterday that the ABC was working in complete accord with the junta. The ABC is the secret terrorist organization which has been fighting President Machado's secret police in Cuba for more than a year.

THIS short but brilliant revaluation of the life, career and ideals of "the six-foot commercial Viking" who, to quote the author still further, was inspired by a vision of Britannia wearing seven-league boots and carrying a pot of red paint," differs from previous biographies of Cecil Rhodes in that it is written from the viewpoint of a generation that is becoming increasingly world-conscious rather than nation, race or class partisan.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The administration proposal to delete the gold payment clause from all obligations, private and public, has raised for the government a possibility of legal action from foreign holders of United States securities who demand payment in the equivalent of gold.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP). -- Women's organizations divided sharply today before a Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on the merits of a resolution by Senator Townsend of Delaware stipulating by law equal rights for men and women. The resolution proposes a constitutional amendment to insure against any discrimination between the sexes.

WHEN the directors of Chiago's big new exposition decided that they needed a brief history at Chicago for their expected millions of visitors they wisely turned to Henry Justin Smith, a newspaper man of long experience, who in spite of everything loves his native city and who has already won his spurs as its historian.

TO classify "Cosmopolis" as a novel of contemporary school life would be like listing "Gulliver's Travels" with the travel books. Though a school provides the dominating physical background, and though all the characters are in some way related to the school -- as masters, pupils, parents and purveyors to student needs -- the theme is much broader than these considerations would seem to indicate.

ELIMINATION of Yale's famous Tap Day as an academic spectacle is a reminder that "old college customs," which in general are made and unmade with considerable facility, do sometimes endure an unconscionable long time, in spite of origins most often quaintly accidental and trivial.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 27. -- The New York University baseball team repulsed the New York Athletic Club, 16 to 6, at Travers Island today. The college team piled up an early lead and maintained it to the finish.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- President Roosevelt issued an executive order today authorizing the Board of Trustees of the Postal Savings System to buy $100,000,000 additional government bonds or other securities.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27. -- As the climax of one of the most brilliant rowing seasons in the last decade. Princeton won the collegiate varsity 150-pound race and the Joseph Wright Challenge Cup in the modified American Henley on the Schuylkill today.

ROME, May 27. -- Unfavorable weather reports received from Labrador and Greenland have induced General Italo Balbo, Italy's Minister of Aeronautics, to postpone the date for the departure from Rome of the twenty-four seaplanes which he will command on a flight to the world fair in Chicago.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 27. Winners of prizes and fellowships at Smith College have been announced as follows:

A high mass of requiem, attended by ranking officials of the Police Department, for Lieut. Col. Bernard Barney) A. Flood, chief of the criminal identification department of the A.E.F. and retired police detective, who died suddenly in Paris on May 14, took place yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Malachy, 241 West Forty-ninth Street.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 25. -- Governor George White is engaged in fighting a hard battle with the Ohio General Assembly over the sales and income tax propositions. It is too early to say whether he is to win it eventually or to lose it, but under trying circumstances he is putting up a stiff battle and no doubt has made progress.

PARIS, May 16. -- Many wellknown New Yorkers have been figuring, these days, in several characteristic activities which mark the growing interest of the Spring season. Some were seen at the reopening of the Restaurant des Ambassadeurs, at the exposition of Chinese art, at the playing of Paderewski in the Palace of Versailles and at the Longchamp races.

Artists and writers have signed a letter sent to John D. Rockefeller Jr., protesting against his dismissal of Diego Rivera, radical Mexican mural painter, from Rockefeller Center. Senor Rivera was painting a mural in the R.C.A. Building which offended members of the Rockefeller family because it included a portrait of Lenin.

HOUGHTON, Mich., Sunday, May 28 (AP). -- Reports reaching here at 12:30 A.M. today said that the passenger steamer George M. Cox, which went aground on Rock of Ages Reef near Isle Royale in Lake Superior early last evening, had rolled over and sunk.

To assure government approval of their cooperative agreements, trade associations must give main consideration to wages and working hours for labor in their industries, leading executives warned here yesterday in discussing various aspects of the Industrial Recovery Bill.

RETAIL trade moved to a higher level in the week under the influence of the very cheerful reports of widespread business improvement, favorable weather and the approaching holiday. Summer apparel was in the lead, but there was an active call also for Summer rugs and certain other home furnishings.

THE audible pictorial version of that once highly popular play, "Peg o' My Heart," which was at the Capitol, is still a good, old-fashioned tale, notwithstanding that it has been brought up to date by Frances Marion.

FLINT, Mich., May 27 (AP). -- A widespread search was under way tonight for Balfe MacDonald, 17, whose disappearance was noted this morning coincident with the discovery that his mother, Mrs. Grace B. MacDonald. a wealthy widow, had been beaten to death in her bedroom.

DUESSELDORF, May 27. -- Half a million Germans, representing mainly the war and post-war generations, are gathered here tonight to do honor to the memory of Albert Leo Schlageter, whom the Germany of national revolution has raised to the pedestal of a national hero and martyr and of "the first soldier of the Third Reich."

In a season in which garden exhibitions have been more popular than ever before, one of the important exhibits will be the opening to the public of the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Field at Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L.I., the afternoon of June 16 for the benefit of the Greenwich House fresh air work.

IT is a common failing in those who write of -- not for -- the theatre to impute, at one time or another, to each of its numerous constituencies a certain indispensable authority. The exaggeration not infrequently indulged is generally recognized as legitimately licensed and accepted for what it is worth.

THE Himalayas, flanking the high plateau of Tibet on the south, have long been a familiar sight to travelers on the plains of India. East of Tibet, rimming the Tibetan plateau on the side toward China, are mountain ranges almost as huge which few white men have seen.

ERNEST BLOCH'S musical setting for the service of the Reformed synagogues is now complete, including orchestration. The work was begun two years ago in California and pursued at intervals in Switzerland, where the composer now lives.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 25. -- Failure of the large city banks in Memphis, Nashville, Chattanooga and Knoxville to absorb the $10,000,000 bond issue authorized to take care of the State's deficit has resulted in the novel plan by which the country banks have been asked to take up parts of the issue equal to the amount due the particular counties in which the banks operate.

LONDON, May 27. -- The British are finding no consolation today in the knowledge that they can pay the next war debt instalment in paper dollars, thereby saving about L2,500,000 compared with last December's payment.

BERLIN, May 27. -- The Rev. Friedrich von Bodelschwingh, widely esteemed Lutheran social settlement worker, was elected First Evangelical Bishop of the Reich tonight by the German Protestant Church groups, which resisted determined efforts of the National Socialist church organization to name a Nazi candidate.

POONA, India, May 27 (AP). -- Apart from a slight return of nausea, the general condition of Mahatma Gandhi on the nineteenth day of his three weeks' fast was good today. He was increasingly weak and seriously exhausted, however.
THE NEW CHAMPIONS. Baseball Throw -- Miss Ann Brebeck, German-American A.C.

THIS somewhat unusual anthology is edited by one who for many years has taught, directly and by correspondence, how to write short stories. It would seem intended, as well as a work for general circulation, as a case book to accompany his textbook, "Narrative Technique."

Dozens of motorists witnessed the rescue of a 10-year-old boy from the currents of the Harlem River near 176th Street at about 5 P.M. yesterday by a motorcycle patrolman who dived from the retaining wall of Harlem River Parkway.

"PRELUDE TO DEPARTURE" is a first novel of unusual distinction. It is written in a sensitive and poetic style, which is nevertheless not lacking in sharpness and point. Mrs. Jerman has chosen a difficult theme, and one which, in the hands of most unpracticed novelists, would have been likely to seem unsympathetic, if not definitely repellent.

ST. PAUL, May 23. -- After about fifteen years of insurgency the Farmer-Labor party of this State naturally has a well-developed technique of protest against the sins and errors of Republicans and Democrats. Minnesota has been watching with a good deal of interest and amusement these past few weeks while the Farmer-Laborites, now in power, use their arsenal of weapons, not on Republicans or Democrats, but on each other.

OUR historical concept of Palestine is so intimately connected with the Bible that we are prone to forget it had a fascinating history for thousands of years before the biblical period commenced. Recent finds of great importance have called attention to the fact that the whole story of Palestine can be understood only through an increased knowledge of prehistoric times.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Despite opposition, an agreement to report the administration's retroactive resolution to cancel the gold clause in all Federal and private contracts was reached today in the Banking Committees of both branches of Congress.

TIENTSIN, Sunday, May 28. -- The tentative North China Chino-Japanese truce was rudely shattered before it was forty-eight hours old when the "Christian General," Feng Yu-siang, boldly raised the banner of revolt and branded General Chiang Kai-shek, the Nanking leader, as a traitor.

THOUGH this book undertakes to tell America's story from Buchanan's last year in office to Franklin Roosevelt's election, its great value lies in its keen and inerrant study of what happened between 1920 and today. Temperamentally Mr. Adams, whatever he may think, and whatever reviewers who know less than he does think, is more essayist than historian.

In the heaviest Saturday trading ever recorded on the Stock Exchange during a rising market, leading issues advanced 1 to 10 1/2 points yesterday. The turnover was 4,311,340 shares, a volume exceeded only by the record of 4,867,530 shares established May 3, 1930, when the market declined.

The hottest day in the city thus far this year sent the mercury yesterday to 86 degrees, drove hundreds of thousands to city and suburban beaches and caused the first heat prostration of the season. The intense heat also was blamed partly for the death of a man in Madison, N.J.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 27. -- The Central Bank of Chile, in a report this afternoon, foresees only slight improvement in trade between Chile and the United States as a result of the reduced exchange value of the dollar.

IN order to obtain a clear interpretation of the new tendencies of the American Government, THE NEW YORK TIMES asked members of the Cabinet and some other close advisers of the administration to answer the following question:

ALTHOUGH these two books deal with the same subject they differ widely in treatment and each one presents its own distinctive viewpoint. From either of them the lover of flowers can get a very great deal of useful and interesting advice and counsel as to how to use cut flowers in order to obtain the most beautiful and effective results.

IN a previous volume O. Fred Boucke, Professor of Economics in Pennsylvania State College, made a general study, historical and critical, of our economic regime, but in this new book he confines his attention to the one theme of the tariff policy of the United States and how it is likely to be influenced by the economic situation and probable economic developments in Europe.

The annual Decoration Day regatta or the New York Rowing Association will get under way at 10 o'clock Tuesday morning on the Harlem River with the junior single gig competition. Two heats will be held, with the first two in each qualifying for the final, which is listed for 1 P.M.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 27. -- Navy carried too many big guns for Army today in their annual baseball game, the Middies winning by 8 to 4 in a game which went into Army's half of the seventh and then was called because of rain.

Here is a detective story that is different. The scene is China, and all the characters are Chinese. Western ideas enter into it only to the extent that they have entered into China of today. The story deals with the adventures of Ming So, the young son of a poor widow, who is taken away by his wealthy uncle to make his fortune in the city.

BERLIN, May 27 (AP). -- Reports of America's proposed statutory departure from gold payments was received with the greatest interest today at the Reichsbank, where two questions were uppermost in the minds of the directors. They were:
