The Abraham Lincoln High School handball team, defending city P.S. A.L. champion, and Samuel J. Tilden High yesterday captured the Group I and Group II titles, respectively, in the Brooklyn-Queens division.

THE Philadelphia Summer Concerts Association, under the direction of Alexander Smallena, conductor, announces performances every night from July 6 to Aug. 30. Among the special features to be presented are the Ninth symphony of Beethoven, the Hall Johnson Choir and ballet.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An illuminating discussion has recently been published on the homicide situation in Mississippi by the Mississippi State Board of Health, which for the first time reveals conclusively facts concerning the racial aspects of this important question.

One result of J.P. Morgan's testimony may be the setting up of a new code of ethics for public officials, that such officials must live within their income, former Representative Fiorelio H. La Guardia said yesterday at a meeting of the Women's Press Club in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Racketeering in adult education, as in other American industries, is already becoming a popular and lucrative sport, especially in the Middle West and the South. So at least the American Association for Adult Education was warned by its director, Morse Cartwright, at its convention at Amherst, Mass., last week.

GENEVA, May 27. -- Chancellor Hitler balked at the proposed terms of the settlement of the Silesian Jewish question submitted him last night and the League Council's hearing on the Bernheim petition, set for today, was postponed until Monday pending negotiations.
Evidence of an upturn in leasing activity in the downtown financial district is reported by Louis W. Abrons, president of the General Realty and Utilities Corporation.

IF the dream of the poet should come true and man were able to soar to heights from which all Europe could be surveyed, he would see the banks of four rivers crowded with history. The Rhine would stand out as the dividing line between two civilizations.

BALTIMORE, May 27. -- Baltimore made it three out of four by taking the final game of the series from Jersey City today, 5 to 3, the victory moved the third-place Orioles to within one-half game of first place. Julius Solters continued his terrific clouting by getting three hits.

VIENNA, May 27. -- The German Government today increased the charge for a tourist visa for Austria to 1,000 marks [about $270], Austria countered by calling home her Minister from Berlin. Diplomatic relations may be broken off.

A comprehensive talk on the management of apartment properties was given recently by Charles J. Quinlan, vice president of the Wood, Dolson firm, before the Real Estate Board of New York. He discussed the subject from all of its business angles, of which the human element forms a large part.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 27. -- Cornell played two airtight games on Soldiers Field today, to blank Harvard twice, 5 -- 0 and 1 -- 0, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League double-header.

SHIPS signaling by means of flags or radio will have a new code, beginning with the first of next year, as a result of international conferences initiated six years ago in Washington. The code has been translated into seven languages -- English, French, Italian, German, Japanese, Spanish and Norwegian -- and it will be adopted simultaneously throughout the world.
THERE are some books which are above praise and build, in a sense, their own monuments. Such a book is Marcel Granet's study of the religious customs and beliefs of ancient China.

HEREDITY is the "Witch's Cauldron" of the second volume of Mr. Phillpotts's notable trilogy. "Bred in the Bone" showed how the different influences which were in their blood affected Peter Bryden and his wife, Avis.

Chicago was holding its first World's Fair, just forty years ago, when the Crimson Rambler made its bow to the American public. This now famous climber had been imported from Japan. It was awarded the gold medal of the National Rose Society and soon became a national favorite.

LOS ANGELES, May 24. -- A blast of dynamite detonating across the desert, a swirl of sand and earth and rock, a cheer from the 10,000 persons who had driven the concrete trail from Los Angeles and other places -- work on the Los Angeles aqueduct is officially under way.

Colleges Live Long. One reason for not taking too gloomy a view of what hard times will do to our colleges is that institutions of higher learning are very hard to kill. Colleges and universities are among our oldest surviving social institutions.

Before the largest crowd of race-goers to gather on any local track this season, Mrs. Isabel Sloan's Okapi won the fortieth running of the Toboggan Handicap, feature on the opening program of the Belmont Park Spring meeting yesterday.

AUTEUIL, France, May 27. -- Miss Elizabeth Ryan, the former California tennis star who was winning tournaments in France as long ago as 1914, today for the third time in four years won a Share in the women's doubles title in the French hard court championships.

A total of $5,496,964 has been made available by the State and Federal governments for unemployment relief in New York City during the current month, the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration reported yesterday. This sum was in addition to the city's own expenditures.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP). -- The Administration Bill granting power to a Federal coordinator to work out economies in railroad operations was passed by the Senate today and sent to the House, where it will encounter opposition because of Senate amendments to prohibit dismissals of employes in effecting retrenchments.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Morice arrived on the Britannic Friday and went to Gray Cottage, Shinnecock Hills, L.I., for the Summer.

THE increasing tide of dissatisfaction aroused as a result of the lengths to which some program sponsors go in their efforts to force sales threatens to seriously impair the efficiency of broadcasting, warned E.A. Weir, director of programs for the Canadian Radio Broadcasting Commission, speaking at the Institute for Education by Radio at Ohio State University.

ONE of the most ambitious and spectacular undertakings of aviation -- the mass flight of a score of big Italian flying boats across the North Atlantic by the island route to Chicago -- is scheduled to start this week. It may be that the actual take-off from Orbetello will be delayed until about June 10, due to ice conditions in the waters of the Iceland and Labrador bases of the route.

Discussing some of the existing real estate conditions, James R. Murphy, realty auctioneer, said yesterday that as soon as liquidation of many "troubled" properties really start, many investors in the metropolitan area will turn toward the purchase of well-located real estate.

ED WYNN'S status in the cinema world was cleared up by the local Metro office the other day. The comedian will leave New York for the Coast the first week in July and production on his first MGM picture will start not later than the middle of that same month.
PARIS, May 26. -- France has been acutely conscious all this last week that she has been thrust into the role of chief villain in the play "Disarmament," which is going on at Geneva.

INTERESTING comparisons of the volume of traffic on Long Island's highways with that on other roads in the United States are given in figures recently gathered by the traffic survey division of the Nassau County Emergency Work Bureau.

Women headed by Mrs. Albert L. Smith have arranged a dinner in behalf of the emergency fund of the New York Nursery and Child's Hospital at the River Club June 6. Reports will be made by committees aiding in the campaign for $100,000 for the institution, which is said to be America's oldest children's hospital and New York's oldest maternity hospital.

AMHERST, Mass., May 27. -- The Amherst College baseball team defeated Springfield College, 3 -- 2, at Pratt Field today. A single by Flash Harroun in the sixth inning scored Hal Warner to give the local nine the victory.
CHICAGO, May 27. -- The following message of President Roosevelt to the World's Fair was conveyed by Postmaster General Farley, who represented the President at the opening today:

IN the earlier days of the "noble experiment" we heard far more of the evil effects of alcohol than we do now. Laennec's cirrhosis of the liver, hobnail liver, gin-drinker's liver, or what is more politely called "portal cirrhosis" in medical circles, has gone down in medical history as one of the outstanding terrible diseases produced by the abuse of alcohol.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange rose $1 a bale yesterday under the heaviest trading in several years. All months went into new high territory for the movement, with July above 9 cents a pound for the first time and March of the new crop 9% cents.
MUCH is said in short compass in the following resolution passed by the United States Chamber of Commerce at its recent annual meeting in Washington:
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 27. -- The Naval Academy made public today the names of twenty-eight midshipmen of the second class and twenty-two of the third class who completed their courses with distinction.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 27. -- The estate of Governor Lehman in Purchase will be shown on Decoration Day in behalf of the Westcheater County Children's Association and the Westchester Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 27. -- With six of the first ten ranking players of the country entered, including two members of the United States Davis Cup team, the annual invitation grass-court tournament of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club got under way today to bring forth the highest grade of tennis to be seen in this section until August.
A dejected cashier for a brokerage house stood yesterday in the line-up at Police Headquarters and told how he stole $125,000 from his employers and lost it all playing "bum tips on the horses."

ROGER FRY has come to be looked upon, at any rate in this country, as a kind of pontifex maximus among the reigning art critics of England. True, there is also Clive Bell, who some years ago set off a shot about "significant form" that was heard around the world.

Organization of Carbon Black Export, Inc., by leading American producers of carbon black was announced yesterday. The Webb Act, under which the project was consummated, permits American manufacturers to form associations for the stabilizing of export prices and establishing sales quotas.

Excellent activity was noted in Summer merchandise during the week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. The unusually large flow of orders and reorders during the latter part of the week was held to indicate splendid consumer response to pre-Decoration Day promotions, which were aided by the seasonable weather prevailing.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Hope that the nations of the Far East "will be able to contribute substantially to the laying of solid foundations for a structure of world peace and prosperity" was expressed in a joint statement issued today by President Roosevelt, Viscount Kikujiro Ishii and Eigo Fukai, deputy governor of the Bank of Japan, at the conclusion of the Japanese mission's visit here in preparation for the London Economic Conference.

Long Island members of the Garden Club of America and members of the Long Island Federated Garden Clubs are cooperating with nurserymen, landscape architects and artists for the Long Island Flower Show for amateur gardeners June 21 and 22 at the Pratt Estate Oval in Glen Cove.

Continuing its rise for the ninth consecutive week, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has advanced to 77.5 from 76.6 in the preceding week. A year ago the number was 66.5. The low point of the depression from which the current movement started was made in the week ended March 18 when the index stood at 60.0.

The State practice of collecting an inheritance tax on real estate held by tenants in entirety was declared unconstitutional yesterday in a decision by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn, which affirmed a previous decision by Surrogate George A. Wingate in Brooklyn.

NICE, May 12. -- Marathon dancing is now being "bootlegged" on the Riviera. Most Cote d'Azur communities nave banned this peculiar form of Terpsichorean art. It is not long ago that a local dance was invaded by indignant citizens, including the Salvation Army, which resulted in its closing.

Revival of inflation talk started by the proposal in the United States to void the gold clause in debt contracts, which sent Wall Street stocks zooming upward yesterday, produced a new buying: wave in all Canadian markets, and stock and commodity prices were carried into new high ground.

Collectors and dealers in postage stamps have been wondering in the last few days how soon the block of four of the 24-cent airmail stamp with the inverted centre, formerly owned by the late Representative Ernest R. Ackerman of New Jersey, will be sold.

THE National Industrial Recovery Bill is designed to effectuate the central need of American life today -- the extensive and permanent re-employment of workers at wages on the comfort level of living. This involves a two-fold program: First, the promotion of order in industry; second, direct government expenditures for public works.

ST. LOUIS, May 27 (AP). -- Unloosing a powerful batting attack as of old, the Cardinals buried the last place Phillies under an avalanche of hits today and took the second game of the series, 10 to 1.

PARIS. M. DUHAMEL, having just finished his long five-volume novel. "Salavin," which constituted a sort of epic of impotent good intentions, has now started on another series. The first volume is called "Le Notaire du Havre" (Mercure de France), and the whole, it seems, will be a novel of the scientific spirit.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 27. -- Mrs. I. Newton Lewis is chairman of the conference committee for the entertainment of visiting delegates at the seventh annual regional conference of the United Daughters of the Confederacy to be held in Greenwich on June 13 and 14.

BERLIN, May 26. -- France's bullets, fired long after the armistice, have bequeathed to Germany a national hero whose memory will be honored throughout the Reich on Sunday on a scale never before accorded to a son of the Fatherland.

ST. LOUIS, May 27 (AP). -- Unloosing a powerful batting attack as of old, the Cardinals buried the last place Phillies under an avalanche of hits today and took the second game of the series, 10 to 1.

Horticulturists at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, who have been concentrating their efforts on the great iris beds there, expect to have this season one of the largest and most comprehensive displays of irises in the history of the garden. The season is early this year and thousands of irises are already in bloom.

IT seems to the arrondissemeat of Nivelles in Belgium, in which the battleground of Waterloo is situated, that some of that site should be used to relieve the cramped housing space of workers in the towns on the western edge. Their Deputy, a Socialist, in a Parliament where Socialists are second in strength, has introduced a bill authorizing home building on the scene of Napoleon's downfall and Wellington's victory.

LISBON, May 16. -- Patrick Gilligan, an old Alaska sourdough who evidently was familiar with gold and gold mining all over the world, rambled into Lisbon some months ago with tales of a golden prospect he discovered some twenty-five years ago in the northern part of Portugal, near Castello Branco.
Thousands of motorists thronged the offices of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles yesterday to renew their driving licenses, which will be required on and after June 1.

"Intellectual Liberty Imperilled" is the title at an article by Dr. Alvin Johnson, director of the New School for Social Research, in the current issue of The American Scholar. He urges American scholars to contribute funds to provide places in American universities for German scholars expelled by the Hitler regime.

With more at stake in the Assembly elections this year than in any similar election in the last twenty years, the Democratic State organization is preparing to wrest from the Republicans their slender margin of two votes in that branch of the Legislature.
MADRID, May 26. -- Militant new Spain, which ignores traditions, has completed for the moment the work of smashing the church.

PARIS, May 27. -- Sir John Simon's statement in the House of Commons yesterday that Great Britain would not consider any further commitments toward guaranteeing European peace met with a storm of criticism in the French press today.

CAPE TOWN. ONCE there was an inland sea called Ngami in the Kalahari Desert. To the east of it stretched an enormous lake known to the natives as Makarikari, and to the west another lake, the Etosha Pan.
WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The war Department issued the following orders today:

The testimony adduced in recent days at the hearings before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee has quite conclusively established that the Federal income tax is only a fair-weather revenue producer and that it is quite ineffectual in times of adverse business conditions.

Declaring that the home rule movement in cities throughout the United States has reached its most critical stage, Professor Joseph D. McGoldrick of Columbia University in his book "Law and Practice of Municipal Home Rule," published by the Columbia University Press, points out that "our judges are no better qualified to establish the rules of the relationship of municipalities to the State than our legislators."

THERE was a time a few days ago when that Joe Cook show seemed to be all settled. Announcements were made and everything. But now Rumor and her allegorical colleagues -- headed by the boy friend, Tecumseh -- are at it again.

GENEVA, May 27. -- The disarmament conference gained much ground today in all questions affecting aviation, the "surprise" weapon to which most fears of a European war in the next few years can be traced.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The TIMES published an article by Russell Owen, giving a resume of the views of various members of President Roosevelt's official family in the effort to define the administration's theory of the relation of government to the people and to explain the so-called new concept of the function and duty of government.

TRENTON, N.J., May 27. -- The concluding sessions of the Republican and Democratic platform conventions will be held here Monday. Tentative drafts of the platforms have been mailed to the delegates by the resolutions committee, and it is expected they will be ratified without change.

RYE, N.Y., May 27. -- Under a fine southwest breeze the opening championship regatta of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound was held today by the American Yacht Club. W.A.W. Stewart Jr.'s 30-foot sloop Phantom and Philip Leboutillier's Alsumar in the first division of the handicap class were victors in the first two groups.

HUMAN beings are seeing-machines, with all the characteristics of machines, and the right to be as efficient as machines. The word "machine" implies that there is internal friction and loss. The word "seeing" involves not only the eyes and their functions and limitations but the psycho-physiological effects as well.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 27. -- The 43-year-old veteran, Willie Macfarlane of the Oak Ridge Golf Club, Tuckahoe, N.Y., brought the metropolitan open golf championship back to the home district today by a sensational finish, with birdie 3's on the two concluding holes that gave him victory by one stroke.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Profits of many millions to the house of Morgan through security flotations and syndicate operations were disclosed today in documents obtained from the files of the banking house by Senate investigators.

The dollar depreciated further in foreign exchange yesterday, responding to the introduction of the administration bill to abrogate the gold clause in government and private bonds. To a large extent the movement represented a misapprehension of the significance of the Steagall resolution, bankers here said yesterday.

Because of the large number of plans submitted in the competition under the auspices of the Phelps Stokes Fund for the design of a typical New York City block of tenements, the jury was unable to reach a decision yesterday on the six cash prizes, totaling $1,300, which are to be awarded.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 27. -- It was a day of upsets and brilliant performances at the Harvard Stadium today as the fifty-seventh annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships came to a close.
For Eastern followers of college rowing there lies ahead now only the annual Yale-Harvard varsity crew race.

With Wall Street reading into the "gold clause" resolution implications which did not, upon its face, appear to be warranted, the markets surged upward yesterday with renewed vigor. Trading on the Stock Exchange made up a total of 4,311,000 shares, a figure that has been exceeded on only one Saturday in the history of the Exchange.

THE struggle for money and the social prestige which it confers is a fantastic conflict. Here is one of many books which describe its influence upon the lives of people who believe in its power. Mr. Krims reviews the unfortunate career of Barry Adams, who combines his aristocratic name in marriage with the potential wealth of Helen Borden, daughter of a socially ambitious, personally unscrupulous capitalist.

THE long-awaited War Memoirs of Lloyd George are to be published in this country by Little, Brown Co. of Boston. The work will run to four volumes, and the first section of two volumes, covering the events which led up to the outbreak of the war and the war years 1914 to 1916, will appear in the Autumn of this year.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP). -- The Joint Congressional Committee which for several months has pondered what economies could be made in veterans expenditures formally reported today that the job had been placed in the hands of the President.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The board of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation approved nine self-liquidating projects today calling for advances of $967,500. Harvey Couch, one of the directors, estimated that the projects would give work directly to 1,000 men and to from three to four times that number in assembling materials necessary for the work.

Four hotels in the Times Square centre have recently given evidence of the value of modernization indicating confidence in renewed business activity. They are respectively, the Claridge and Cadillac, covering the easterly block front on Broadway between Forty-third and Forty-fourth Streets; the Hermitage, on Seventh Avenue adjoining the southwest corner of Forty-second Street, and the Woodstock, on Forty-third Street just east of Broadway.

Enactment of the Federal farm mortgage relief legislation definitely establishes that all joint stock land banks eventually must liquidate, those that can, in an orderly manner, and those that cannot, by means of early receiverships or through readjustment of shrunken assets at the expense of the bondholders, according to a survey completed yesterday by Webster, Kennedy Co., specialists in these securities.

THIS is the story of a neigbborhood. The five houses fronting on The Crescent stand aloof from the world and even from each other. The privacy of the families occupying them is jealously guarded, and such intimacy as exists among them is extremely formal Modern ideas find no foothold in The Crescent excepting in the end house, where young Mrs. Wellington is in open revolt against the general stodginess.

The Women's Swimming Association has announced a number of exhibition and championship meets that will occupy a prominent place on the sports program prior to the women's national outdoor championships at Jones Beach, L.I., July 19 to 22.

Educational segregation only breeds "unwholesome" attitudes in abnormal students and makes subnormal students feel inferior, according to Dr. Carl A. Marsden, winner of one of the two Phi Delta Kappa awards made this year at the New York University School of Education.

MOSCOW, Sunday, May 28. -- According to reports in today's press, the situation along the Chinese Eastern Railway and in Manchuria generally is growing more acute because of bandit raids and insurgent rebellions.

Possible effects of inflation on real estate values and trends will be one of the chief topics of discussion at the annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards opening on June 12 in the Stevens Hotel, Chicago.

DANZIG, May 27. -- Tens of thousands of enthusiastic inhabitants of Danzig listened tonight in streets, halls and other public places to Chancellor Hitler's radio address from Munich appealing to them to give the National Socialists a majority in tomorrow's elections to the Free City's Parliament.

THE open season for the exhibition of student art work is in full swing. The work of 1,700 students is being shown at Cooper Union -- paintings, drawings, plans, scutpture -- and awards to the number of 280 were made at the opening.

Jose de Capriles, New York University's intercollegiate epee champion, and his brother Miguel, of the University Fencers Club, the national three-weapon titleholder, showed the way in the outdoor epee competition at the New York Athletic Club at Travers Island yesterday.

GENEVA, May 28 -- Disarmament prospects are much better than they were a week ago on the eve of Norman H, Davis's statement announcing the willingness of the United States to assume a share of the responsibility for the maintenance of world peace.

"He'll never be able to do it." That seemed to be the consensus wherever track adherents gathered on Saturday morning as they dis- cussed the chances of a double victory by Bill Bonthron of Princeton that afternoon in the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships in the Harvard Stadium.

The Engineers Public Service Company reports for the year ended on April 30 that its consolidated gross earnings were $43,030,958, against $49,464,360 in the preceding year, and its net operating revenue was $19,774,063, against $22,366,950. Net income, after depreciation, underlying dividends, minority interest, taxes and charges, was $3,297,225, which was equal, after preferred dividends, to 51 cents a share on the common stock, comparing with $5,973,459, or $1.91 a share, for the preceding twelve months.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to present the case against Dr. Irving Fisher as to a multiple commodity standard elsewhere referred to as the compensated dollar.

BERLIN, May 28. -- Germany's foreign bank creditors will be informed tomorrow by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, how the Reich and the Reichsbank envisage the future operation of the transfer mechanism for German private long-term and short-term debts abroad.

New York City is rapidly approaching another critical financial situation. The immediate difficulty is the short-term debt, $236,000,000 of which matures in June. Corporate stock notes, issued to finance subways, docks, water supply and other necessary public improvements in these lean times, amount to $58,000,000.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today promulgated the rule that hereafter corporations obtaining loans must reduce excessive salaries paid to their executives or prove they are not excessive. The procedure has already been applied to the Southern Pacific Company in approving its request for a loan of $23,200,000.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Washington hammered Walberg in the eighth inning today for six hits and four runs to overcome Philadelphia, 7 to 4.

CHICAGO, May 28. -- Banks are beginning to advertise, which is taken as a sign of better business. With the Century of Progress,, otherwise known as the World's Pair, open, the stores in the Loop and especially the State Street district are filled and sales are the largest in recent years.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 28 -- To a season of notable achievements that have added greatly to the luster of his reputation, Lester B. Stoefen added perhaps his most luminous conquest today.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Senate investigators were disclosed today to have asked J.P. Morgan Co. to submit additional information about several score of stock syndicate and joint account operations in which the firm reported participating from 1927 to 1931.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The nation's religious forces should be mobilized by the government to help solve its present problems, the Right Rev. James E. Freeman, Episcopal Bishop of Washington, declared in a sermon delivered this afternoon at the annual massing of colors service.
Three defeats in the last week removed Harvard from the running in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League race, and left Yale as the only team with a chance to beat Columbia for the title.

Lou Lubin of the Trinity Club defeated Joseph Ozdoba of Samuel J. Tilden High School, 21 -- 8, 16 -- 21, 21 -- 17, in one of the feature matches as play started yesterday in the metropolitan A.A.U. one-wall handball soft ball singles championship tournament at Raven Hall Bathing Park, Coney Island.

KANSAS CITY, May 28 -- Kidnapped yesterday from her home by two unmasked men, Miss Mary McElroy, 25-year-old daughter of Kansas City's City Manager, Henry F. McElroy, was ransomed by her father today for $30,000, and returned.

AWAY out in San Mateo, Cal., there is a chap who sits down every so often and makes up a box score on major league shut-outs. He has been doing it for years. It was a difficult task, but those determined Dodgers, smarting as a result of their disastrous Western trip, finally scored their first victory of the season over the Giants when they pulled through at 5 to 4 yesterday at Ebbets Field. Incidentally, they snapped a losing streak of five straight.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 28 -- While clergymen attending the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church of the United States of America occupied pulpits throughout Central Ohio today, the Rev. Dr. John McDowell of New York, their new Moderator, delivered two sermons, one over a national radio hook-up and the other at the Broad Street Presbyterian Church of Columbus.

BERKSHIRE HILLS, Mass., May 28 -- Mrs. John Maurice Hastings of Basingstokes, Hants, England, is to be presented at the final court of the season at Buckingham Palace on June 26 by a cousin of Mr. Hastings. Mrs. Hastings is the former Rosemary Crane, sister of Frederick Goodrich Crane of Dalton.

The new land valuation map of Manhattan compiled by the emergency work forces of the Borough President's office in the last two years was made public yesterday by Borough President Samuel Levy. It shows that land in this borough used for building purposes has an aggregate, assessed value of nearly $5,500,000,000.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls last week are given in the appended tabulation:

PARIS, May 28. -- Renewed insistence upon the necessity for monetary stabilization if the World Economic Conference is to prove a success was voiced today by Louis Serre, Minister of Commerce, in an address at Chambery.
Postmaster General James A. Farley reiterated yesterday the intention of the national administration to treat war veterans fairly in making the pension cuts authorized by Congress.

A protest against the dismissal of Jewish judges and lawyers in Germany on grounds of their race and religion has been sent to Secretary of State Hull by fifty-one leading members of the bar here. They requested Secretary Hull to transmit their protest to the German Government, if such action was "consistent with diplomatic usage and precedents."

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Senate inquiry into the affairs of J.P. Morgan Co. will go on no matter what obstructionist tactics are resorted to, Senator Fletcher, chairman of the Committee on Banking and Currency, said today.

EPSOM, England, May 28 -- Princess de Faucigny-Lucinge telegraphed from Paris today that she had decided to scratch her big chestnut colt Rodosto from Wednesday's 153d renewal of the Denfcy, world's greatest classic for 3-year-olds.

PARIS, May 28 -- A monument was unveiled today at Chalons-surMarne to Leon Bourgeois, former Premier, president of the Chamber of Deputies and Senate and permanent delegate to the League of Nations, who died in 1925. Impressive tributes were paid to him by President Albert Lebrun, Foreign Minister Joseph Paul-Boncour, several other Cabinet members and many Senators and Deputies, who stressed the continuity of his work for the organization of peace.

A twenty-four-family apartment house at 78 Congress Street, corner of Sherman Avenue, Jersey City, has been bought for investment by the John D. Webster Realty Corporation of Hoboken. This is the buyer's first purchase of real estate since 1921, when it acquired the southwest corner of Park Avenue and Eleventh Street, Hoboken, according to J.I. Kislak, Inc., the broker.

The Port Authority has always prided itself on the way it has handled real estate operations. These have had to be conducted on no mean scale. The approaches to the George Washington Bridge alone involved acquisition of $10,000,000 worth of private property, including thirty apartment houses and two churches.

Lessons From the Planets. A planetarium for New York City is now seemingly assured, on site granted by the city authorities near the Museum of Natural History and built with money to be lent by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for the purpose of stimulating employment.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Conflicting views on the National Industry Recovery Bill, passed by the House and pending before the Senate Finance Committee, were expressed here today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States and the National Association of Manufacturers.
Dr. Eugene Colligan, president of Hunter College, praised the Roman Catholic Church yesterday as the greatest civilizing agency of the ages and Christ as the greatest exemplar of democracy.

Control of the State as well as the city Republican organization is involved in the fight to oust Samuel S. Koenig as New York County Chairman. The result also may have a bearing on the attitude of the New York delegation to the next Republican National Convention.

The section of the report of the Laymen's Foreign Missions Inquiry published under the title "Rethinking Missions," was interpreted yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Ralph E. Diffendorfer in a sermon at the Madison Avenue Methodist Church, at Sixtieth Street, as propounding a deeper concept of religion.

The first field meet on the reservoir site in Central Park is scheduled for the afternoon of June 24. From 50,000 to 75,000 participants and spectators are expected by its sponsors to celebrate the event.

BERLIN, May 27 -- Reduction in the New York Federal Reserve discount rate had no effect on dollar exchange here; in fact, there was a slight advance by the dollar in some European centres. The reduction in the bank rate was regarded as proof that United States financial authorities do not expect any considerable change in the relations of the dollar to sterling in the immediate future.

Samuel Goldwyn announced yesterday that he had signed contracts with the estate of Emile Zola whereby he obtains the last outstanding European rights to "Nana," which he will film, with Anna Sten in the leading role.

With reports of encouraging retail activity appearing from all parts of the country. Summer apparel was purchased freely in the wholesale markets here last week. The warmer weather spurred the demand for cotton, lightweight silk and sheer dresses.

A request to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to reconsider its $8,000,000 loan for Knickerbocker Village, east side slum elimination project for which tax exemption by the city was voted last week, was announced yesterday by the Federal Grand Jury Association.

The campaign of the American Joint Distribution Committee for a $2,000,000 relief fund for the Jews in Germany is rapidly gaining momentum, it was announced yesterday from national campaign headquarters, 71 West Forty-seventh Street.

HILDESHEIM, Germany, May 28 -- Dr. Friedrich von Winterfeld, leader of the Nationalist party as Dr. Alfred Hugenberg's deputy, declared in a speech here today that the boycott of the Jews had harmed Germany more than its intended victims.

Yosio Ishizuro, Japanese delegate to the Disarmament Conference, is aboard the North German Lloyd liner Europa, due today. Others arriving on the ship from Channel ports include Henry Rogers Winthrop, vice president of the Wabash Railroad: James Simpson, Heinz von Riedemann, William Crocker, Baron Georg von Zedlitz, Charles Morrison, Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Duncan, Joseph Becker, Bernard Ridder, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Wallace and Mr. and Mrs. Jean Hersholt.

NEW HAVEN, May 28. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 61.2, which compares with 60.6 a week ago, 59.5 two weeks ago, 59.2 three weeks ago and 58.6 four weeks ago. The present average is the highest of the year to date; the average of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.
NEWARK, N.J., May 28 (AP) -- The Newark Bears regained the International League lead today by defeating Jersey City in a doubleheader, 3 -- 0 and 2 -- 1, while Toronto divided with Montreal.
Bainbridge Colby, Secretary of State in the Wilson administration, is under consideration by fusion leaders as a candidate for Mayor if Samuel Seabury persists in his determination not to run.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 28 -- Jack Dempsey sparred a round with Max Baer at the latter's training camp at Bader Field today. Baer, preparing to meet Max Schmeling at the Yankee Stadium on June 8, under Dempsey's promotion, appeared in fine shape as he went through two minutes of action with the former world's heavyweight champion.

AUTEUIL, France, May 28 -- Mrs. Dorothy Andrus Burke of Stamford, Conn., scored an unexpected victory over Mile. Ida Adamoff, 23-year-old Russian girl who is ranked No. 2 in France, in the second round of the women's singles of the French hard-court tennis championships in the Roland Garros Stadium today.

TIENTSIN, May 28 -- An analysis of the status of the Peiping-Mukden Railway "reveals a tremendous change since January, 1932, in the most prosperous railway in China. Before the Japanese seizure of Mukden the Peiping-Mukden line, largely financed by British bondholders and a few American investors, boasted a length of 800 miles.

Twenty-one railroad brotherhoods fighting for the introduction of the six-hour day on American railways may take the issue direct to President Roosevelt. This was indicated yesterday by A.F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railway Trainmen and chairman of the Railway Labor Executives Association.

Samuel Unternayer laid the blame for the evils of the American banking system at the door of Congress yesterday. He asserted that the Pujo report in 1913 warned Congress of the very abuses now being exposed. The Pujo report, he continued, showed these faults in the system to be due to lack of regulation and of publicity, but Congress did nothing.

LONDON, May 27 -- Various factors are causing unsettlement in dollar exchange. Up to a week ago the trend was definitely against sterling, this being due to bear covering on moderate commercial demands for dollars and a fair movement of capital toward Wall Street.

TIENTSIN, China, May 28 -- Following the sudden intervention in the North China situation of Feng Yu-hsiang, the "Christian General," well-informed observers question whether he has an understanding with Soviet Russia.

HOUGHTON. Mich., May 28. -- The Coast Guard cutter Crawford arrived here this afternoon with 116 of the passengers and crew of the steamer George M. Cox of Chicago. They were rescued from a lonely lighthouse after the steamer broke its back yesterday on a reef off Isle Royale in northern Lake Superior.

CINCINNATI, May 28 (AP) -- The Reds today shut out the Pirates, 4 to 0, for their first victory of the season over the Pittsburghers, after dropping the first eame of a doubleheader, 4 to 2. Nearly 20,000 saw the contests.

Private capitalistic industry is the only economic organization able to retain the civilized standards of closely populated industrial countries. The opinion is that of Dr. Herbert von Beckerath, Professor of Economics at the University of Bonn, Germany, in his "Modern Industrial Organization."
BOSTON, May 28 (AP) -- The Indians divided a twin bill with the Red Sox today to take three contests of the five-game series.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Most of what are now the great railway systems were conceived with the view not only of serving to transport freight and passengers but as empire builders. Our Hills, Harrimans, Walters and Flaglers were rural planners -- dispersers of factories and farms from the Atlantic to the Pacific Ocean.

Urging that a test be more of the great realities of the Christian religion, the Rev. Dr. John MacNeill, Principal of the Faculty of Theology at McMaster University, Hamilton, Ont., spoke yesterday morning on "Personal Experience of God" at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

GENEVA, May 28. -- Harold Butler, director of the Labor Office in the League of Nations, in his annual report to the International Labor Conference meeting here June 8 concludes that one of the effects of the depression has been to strike a death blow to the doctrine of laissez faire and to reinforce the demand for management in economic affairs.

"The value of good dry flies cannot be overestimated and is appreciated in ratio to the angler's skill and experience," writes R.P. "It is a practical impossibility for even the best of fly fishing experts to make a poorly tied dry fly float properly.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Much is being written today of the Brooklyn Bridge -- of its architectural beauty and as an engineering triumph. Has any one given a thought to the unsightly mess that disgraces its terminal in Manhattan?
Two of twenty youths who fled when patrolmen approached their dice game on a roof tried to leap across a ten-foot areaway yesterday afternoon. Both failed and plunged four stories into a courtyard.

In an interview here yesterday, immediately after his arrival from Washington, Viscount Kikujiro Ishii, head of the Japanese mission to the London Economic Conference, indicated the development of an "idea" toward resolving Japan's difficulties with China, which he may lay before the world soon, possibly at London.

For years that outrun memory Republicans ungrateful for their blessing's have been threatening to throw Mr. SAMUEL S. KOENIG out of his seat as chairman of the New York County Republican Committee. When the malcontents have not been going through their phantom process of ejectment they have pleaded with SAMUEL, almost whimpered, Won't you please get out for the sake of harmony?

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The administration's resolution to cancel the gold clause in all obligations, private and public, will come up in the House tomorrow under a special rule and may also receive consideration in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation in a report issued today stated that up to May 22 it had made cash advances of $2,448,710,246.31. Repayments amounting to $511,844,713.34 had been received, leaving $1,936,865,532.97 outstanding.
Samuel Untermyer's statement discussing the American banking system and the present investigation of J.P. Morgan Co, was as follows:
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 28 -- Howard McMichael sailed his Grey Fox to victory in the first special Sunday race for star class boats conducted by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his article in THE NEW YORK TIMES, Sir Philip Gibbs, writing about the possibility of another war in Europe, has used an unfortunate expression, "intolerable Polish Corridor," from which an unbiased reader might infer that Poland owned a piece of territory to which she had no right and which in order to please Germany should be returned to her.

PITTSBURGH, May 28. -- While a hopeful spirit pervaded the meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute in New York last week, there was conspicuously little public reference to prospects of a further increase in tonnage in the next three months.

The first practical effects of inflation have already been felt among the building trades of New York, according to Alien E. Beals, in the current Dow Service Dally Building Reports, who announced over the week-end further retail price rises in building materials.

NEW ORLEANS, May 28. -- While prices of cotton moved erratically last week, and trading was fairly active, with good trade buying as well as speculation, this demand was offset by liquidation by longs, hedge selling and selling by ring traders, the last of which was followed in most cases by rather active covering.

DUESSELDORF, May 28 -- Albert Leo Schlageter, German officer shot by the French ten years ago as a spy and saboteur and then virtually forgotten by his own countrymen, was glorified today as the first martyr and hero of the Germany of Adolf Hitler and the national revolution.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 28. -- Walter Prichard Eaton, dramatic critic and playwright, has been appointed to the faculty of the department of drama of the Yale School of the Fine Arts to teach Professor George P. Baker's "Drama 47" course in playwriting.

Just about the time that most folks were beginning to fear the great man had run out of his favorite commodity, Babe Ruth delivered a fresh carload of home runs at the Stadium yesterday, each more gorgeous than the other.

The Drug Institute of America, Inc., has been formed to unite all divisions of the $2,000,000,000 drug industry in an effort to maintain fair wages and to end cut-throat competition, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, May 28. -- Strong criticism of the United States is being made in the British press over the Steagall bill to abolish, the obligation to pay debts in gold.

Preaching the baccalaureate sermon for the graduating class of the Scudder School a private Institution for girls at 66 Fifth Avenue, the Rev. Dr. Robert W. Searle. associate pastor of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, declared yesterday morning at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street, that "any civilization which can create and tolerate conditions that are in New York at the present time is not a Godgiven civilization.

Lena the Seal did not join in the diving and follow-the-master games yesterday in the big tank in the Bronx Zoo. She lay on her side on the concrete bank and tears seemed to roll down her whiskered cheeks. Her soft blue eyes were liquid with a look of infinite sadness.

A three-run rally in the eighth inning enabled the New York Athletic Club baseball team to triumph over the St. John's College nine of Brooklyn, 6 -- 5, yesterday at Travers Island. Bob Cochrane of St. John's starred at bat with three doubles, while his teammate, Jack Hill, hit a home run and two singles.
LONDON, May 28 -- The Morgan iniquiry and its disclosures are arousing great interest here. So far as the motives behind the inquiry are concerned, there is considerable mystification.

CHICAGO, May 28. -- Speculative interest in oats remains slow and is influenced largely by action of the wheat and corn markets. The same news that affects other grains is reflected in oats to a certain extent. The fluctuations are narrow and it is difficult to create enthusiasm among speculators in this commodity.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Despite the small Winter wheat crop of this year, the smallest since 1904, the carry-over a year from now will probably be as large as ever if exports remain at their present low level, the Department of Agriculture warned in a bulletin issued yesterday.

POONA, India, May 28 -- Mahatma Gandhi was said by his medical advisers today to be holding his ground and almost certain to survive his three weeks' fast which ends at noon tomorrow. [About 1:30 A.M. today in New York.]

Reuben Fine, champion of the Marshall Chess Club and a member of the United States team which will play at Folkstone next month, played simultaneously against eighteen opponents at the rooms of the Marshall Chess Club yesterday, winning sixteen games.

LONDON, May 28. -- Behind the British Government's much criticized delay in announcing its policy for the forthcoming economic conference is believed to be raging a controversy which is likely to divide the Conservatives, both inside and outside the government.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There seems to be a great deal of misunderstanding regarding the provisions of Public No. 2, popularly known as the Economy Act, recently enacted by the Congress of the United States, and the subsequent regulations promulgated by the President for the administration of this act.

Mayors of fifty large cities have submitted a joint appeal to Congress for financial help from the Federal Government. They assert that "a grave crisis" threatens municipal credit, that many local governments have already defaulted on their bonds and that "within a relatively short time a "large additional number of cities "will be forced to default for the "first time in their history."
NEW YORK. Mrs. Henry Walters will return today from Wilmington, N.C., and will be at the Pierre until she goes to Newport to be with her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. John Russell Pope.

Iowa, Alabama and Mississippi, where dry sentiment has been considered strong, will ratify the amendment for prohibition repeal, according to reports from those States given out yesterday by the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform.

The New York University School of Retailing has awarded sixty-four scholarships with a total value of nearly $25,000 for the academic year 1933-34, Chancellor Elmer Ellsworth Brown announced yesterday.

RYE, N.Y., May 28 -- Two of the twelve-meter racing sloops, the class for which international racing has been planned for next year, today made their first appearance of the season. Their debut was in the American Yacht Club's special regatta.

Consolidation of all relief activities of the city government was recommended yesterday by William Hodson, executive director of the Welfare Council. He suggested also a policy-making "general staff" for all privately supported relief and welfare agencies.

B.C. Cobb, chairman, and W.L. Willkie, president, of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation in the report of the company for 1932, issued today, state that the find it difficult to believe that the Tennessee Valley Authority will build transmission lines, "particularly in view of the fact that this corporation and its subsidiaries have offered to purchase surplus power generated by the government as rapidly as it can be absorbed."

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- "I have not resigned," said Secretary Woodin tonight after returning from a week-end cruise with President Roosevelt. During the trip the two talked over the evidence given before the Senate committee, which showed that Mr. Woodin before he became Secretary was on several of J.P. Morgan Co.'s preferred stock lists.

Sweeping forward under the impetus of the general trend, all commodities traded on local exchanges closed with substantial gains for the last week. Many went into new high ground for the year to date. Trading volumes were small early in the week, but gradually increased.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Crop reports from the Northwestern Spring wheat country are the best in several years. The Winter wheat sections have improved in the Eastern half of Kansas, Nebraska and the Middle West. The crop there, however, is to be a short one.

PARIS, May 27 -- Uncertainty is much greater here concerning the future monetary and financial policy of the United States as visibly inspired by two contradictory tendencies: on the one hand, inflation and currency devaluation, and on the other, the classical theory of budgetary balance and sound finances.

A few weeks ago Mrs. AUGUST BELMONT, whose active part in raising emergency relief funds during the last two years entitles her to speak with authority, urged in planning for the coming year the appointment of a competent study committee to draft a definite, comprehensive welfare plan for the entire city.

VIENNA, May 28. -- The big room in the Chancellor's palace in the Ballhausplatz is bright and cheerful on a sunny morning under the blue sky that Summer brings to Vienna. The big flat-topped desk in the centre is piled high with books and papers that belie the cheerfulness of the room and the morning, for they seem mostly to deal with economics, and economics on the brightest days are dull stuff.

MOUNT EVEREST, May 28 (By Wireless From Base Camp) -- For almost two weeks the expedition, especially at Camp Three [at 21,000 feet], has been severely buffeted by storms due to western disturbances. Perhaps nothing but our Arctic tents and acclimatization would have enabled the members of the party to ride out such weather.
Nemo, a pig-tailed rhesus, took over the Long Island Bird Store at 107 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday for an hour of real monkey business. He was a howling success at it.

BOSTON, May 28. -- Industrial recovery in Massachusetts in the past six or seven weeks has been decidedly strong and in some instances the moat promising in years, according to reports gathered by Orra L. Stone, general manager of the Associated Industries of Massachusetts, from executive committee members who are plant managers in more than thirty types of, manufacturing.
ST. LOUIS, May 28 (AP) -- The Cardinals swept both games of a double-header today with the lastplace Phillies and sailed, into second place in the league standings.

During his Presidential campaign the charge was frequently thrown in Mr. ROOSEVELT'S face that he and his party could not be trusted to maintain a sound currency. It was alleged that the taint of depreciated money was in Democratic blood.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 28 -- A final payment of L500,000 on the Rothschild loan was ready yesterday for remittance early in June, Finance Minister Aranha revealed today.

That Memorial Day should be the occasion for the glorification of peace not war, was the theme of many sermons yesterday morning. Clergymen urged that special efforts to insure peace be made now in connection with the Geneva Disarmament Conference.

The leading vocations selected by students at Long Island University are medicine, teaching, dentistry and law. This was shown by a survey by Dr. Edward J. Sparling, research graduate at Teachers College, Columbia University, made public yesterday.

DANZIG, May 28 -- The Nazis swept the Free City of Danzig in today's election, achieving their long cherished aim of obtaining a controlling majority in the new Volkstag. They polled 108,000 of the total 215,000 votes and with the 1,000 Young German party votes have a 51 per cent majority compared with 16 per cent in the 1930 election.

TORONTO, Ont., May 28. -- The International Nickel Company of Canada reports that its exports of fine nickel and nickel oxide it April were greater than in March, but that in April no nickel in the form of ore or matte was shipped either to the United States or the United Kingdom, whereas in March 1,554,900 pounds, valued at $279,918, went to these countries in that form.

A three-ton truck parked on a Leland Avenue hill in the Bronx left its moorings mysteriously yesterday afternoon, embarking on an eccentric adventure which brought injuries to three persons and ended in the rear of a small candy shop. Another automobile, standing in the path of the runaway truck, was considerably damaged.

In estimating that the national average of steel operations has risen to 43 per cent of ingot capacity, compared with 40 per cent a week ago, the magazine Steel draws attention to the "encouraging broadening of the entire iron and steel market foundation."

The New York Stock Exchange. which announced on Thursday that it would remove from its list on Aug. 23 the preferred and common stocks of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation unless the corporation agreed to issue more detailed reports to stockholders, made public yesterday the last letters to and from the company, which preceded its ultimatum.

Two plans, containing far-reaching innovations in American industrial practice, have been submitted to the members of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association by its board of governors. The submission was made known last night in a statement by Arthur W. Berresford, managing director.

Continuing recovery last week, in trade activities as on the markets, was again alternately ascribed to "inflation talk" and to resumption, now that the banking crisis had been successfully surmounted, of last year's emphatic upward reaction.

Giuseppe Bamboschek will be principal conductor of the new Chicago Opera Company, which announces a series of operatic performances, beginning with "Aida" on Saturday night at the New York Hippodrome.

Opposition to recent proposals for a ten-cent toll on the East River bridges and a five-cent tax on taxicab rides is scheduled for the public hearing on these plans before the Board of Estimate on Wednesday. Numerous business and civic groups, it was indicated yesterday, are marshaling their forces for a strong protest.

ANNAPOLIS, May 28 -- Chaplain Frank H. Lash preached the sermon to the graduates of the Naval Academy this morning. Special significance was given to the sermon as the chaplain's tour of duty at the Academy coincided with the entrance and graduation of the present class.

BARNSTABLE, Mass., May 28 (AP). -- Kenneth Buck, 28 years old, held on charges of kidnapping and extortion in connection with the abduction of Margaret (Peggy) McMath, 10, from the Harwich Centre Grammar School on May 2, today was transferred to the Bridgewater State Hospital for the Criminal insane after he had become violent in his cell.

With the temperature ranging between 74 and 78, which at 5 P.M. was the day's high, New Yorkers turned in thousands to the beaches and the country yesterday. Many of them went for a three-day holiday, made possible because tomorrow is Memorial Day.

ATLANTA, May 28. -- Declaring that the nation's present task of economic reconstruction was "one belonging to youth," Bernard M. Baruch of New York said today that the "debris" of 1929 must be cleared away and a "mass of newfound knowledge" used as servant of mankind.
CHICAGO, May 28 -- The Pantheon, a painting executed as a World War memorial, was dedicated in the midway of the exposition, this afternoon.

CHICAGO, May 28. -- There is not the same bullish feeling in corn as exists in wheat, although corn planting is late and acreage on low ground is expected to be greatly reduced as compared with other years, while at the same time that on high ground is likely to be increased.

The "great American vice" is neither graft, corruption nor vice itself, but indifference to these things, according to the Rev. Dr. Henry H. Tweedy of the Divinity School, Yale University, who spoke at services at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, yesterday.

BERLIN, May 27. -- Indications are that the German business revival, though it still continues, is slackening its pace, which is attributed to disappointment over the non-appearance of Chancellor Hitler's repeatedly promised comprehensive work-creation plan.

CHICAGO, May 28. -- A fight between producers of hogs and packing interests was on part of last week, the packers trying to keep prices down, but succeeding only partly, as sales were made on Friday at $5.10 a hundredweight. The general average showed a 10-cent advance at $5.20.

The Rev. William H. Hird, 83year-old Bishop of the First District of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, was nearly mobbed yesterday afternoon at the close of the annual district conference. Several hundred angry Negroes surged threateningly about him in the Bethel A.M.E. Church, 52-60 West 132d Street, when he announced the transfer of their pastor against their wishes.
WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 26:

Three bonding companies whose agents are accused of having known of an attempt to send proxy defendants in prohibition cases into Federal court must show cause on Thursday why they should not be enjoined from doing further business in that court.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP). -- A report from the Secretary of the Treasury on the income tax assessments and payments by Andrew W. Mellon, former Secretary, and a number of companies allied with the Mellon fortune from 1917 to 1933, was asked today in a resolution introduced by Senator McKellar.
Practically all of the current Broadway attractions will play holiday matinees this afternoon.

George B. Cortelyou, president of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York, is slated for re-election as president of the Edison Electric Institute at the first annual convention of the institute, which will be held in Chicago next week from Monday to Thursday.

Trading on a scale unprecedented in rising markets of the past continued in Wall Street yesterday. Stocks rose to the highest level since Nov. 30, 1931. The gains were smaller, however, than on Friday or Saturday, and several leading issues closed fractionally lower.

Thousands of mourners filed past the bier of the Rev. Dr. George W. Becton, Negro evangelist, in the Salem Methodist Episcopal Church, Seventh Avenue and 129th Street, yesterday. Dr. Becton, a bitter foe of the policy racket, was murdered a week ago in Philadelphia by two white gunmen.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- A plan for expediting the repayment of Reconstruction Finance Corporation loans to railroads, now amounting to some $337,000,000, has been advanced by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the corporation. It provides for a reduction in interest rates on the loans, the amount to be impounded in a special fund which would be returned to the carriers when their loans have been repaid.

GENEVA, May 29. -- According to trustworthy sources, the Little Entente, composed of Yugoslavia, Rumania and Czechoslovakia, has gained the consent of Foreign Minister Paul-Boncour of France to attach to the four-power pact whenever it is signed a letter from him with these safeguards:

Captain F. Mechleriburg, master of the Scandinavian-American liner Frederik VIII, knows where a good ship's anchor with a long chain attached to it can be had free of charge. Moreover, he is willing to give the exact address, or, as seamen put, position, to any one who is interested.

George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, filed suit for more than $500,000 yesterday in Supreme Court against seventeen former directors of the Lexington Surety and Indemnity Company. He charged waste and misappropriation of funds, improper loans, secret bonuses and issuance of false and misleading reports.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 29. -- Forty-two race drivers, undaunted by yesterday's accident which claimed two lives, eagerly await the start of the annual 500-mile automobile race tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 29. -- President Roosevelt will use his treaty-making power to effect a debt settlement with European countries without recourse to Congress, it was learned authoritatively tonight.

Halting traffic long enough to commit murder, four men tossed an unconscious underworld victim out of a sedan at 150 Allen Street about 9:30 o'clock last night, fired two bullets into his head and two into the body, re-entered the sedan and calmly drove away.

TOKYO, May 29. -- Officials who have seen Viscount Ishii's confidential dispatches concerning his talks with President Roosevelt share the impression the press cablegrams have created that the Washington meetings have restored a cordial atmosphere in which cooperation at the World Economic Conference will be made easier.

COPENHAGEN, May 29. -- The new United States Minister, Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen, was received today by King Christian and Queen Alexandrine at Christiansborg Castle, presenting her credentials as the first woman diplomat accredited to Copenhagen.

Stars for Starters. Arcturus, forty light-years away, has kindly obliged by lending its rays to start the Chicago Fair. This is sure to set a fashion. The heavenly bodies will now be tapped for various inaugurations and celebrations.

Dr. T.V. Soong, Chinese Finance Minister, who has been in Washington to confer with President Roosevelt, will sail tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. He will head the Chinese delegation of eleven members to attend the World Economic Conference in London.

The administration's industrial recovery measures and their favorable affect upon business men and the public generally are principal factors in the present improved business outlook, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, said yesterday in issuing a general call to credit executives for the thirty-eighth annual convention and credit congress of industry, to be held in Milwaukee the week of June 19.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with great interest and sympathy the letter which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 22 over the initials "M.C.B."

BUFFALO, May 29 (AP). -- A $300,000,000 suit against Niagara Share Corporation, huge investment company, was filed in Supreme Court here today by an attorney for a member of a stockholders' protective committee. The complaint charges the officers and directors of Niagara Share with "unlawful and deliberate mismanagement and illegal acts."
ROME, May 29. -- Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, German Minister of Education and Propaganda, arrived by train from Berlin today, accompanied by a large retinue and staff of secretaries.

The three principal supporting roles in the John Krimsky-Gifford Cochran film production of Eugene O'Neill's "The Emperor Jones, now being made at the Paramount studio in Astoria, will be played by Dudley Digges, Ruby Elzy and Taylor Gordon.

UNCLE TOM'S CABIN, a revival in three acts and twenty-three scenes. Dramatized by A.L. Aiken from the novel by Harriet Beecher Stowe. Text revised by A. E. Thomas. Staged by Earle Boothe. Settings and costumes by Donald Oenslager; revived by The Players as its twelfth annual revival for an engagement of one week.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 29 (AP). -- Rochester jumped into second place in the International League's scramble for top positions by beating Toronto, 5 to 0, today. It was Rochester's seventh straight victory and the second successive shutout on home soil for Ed Chapman, who registered his third triumph since joining the Wings.

THE HAGUE, May 29. -- The feeling is growing here that in the long run the Dutch guilder will not be able to stay on the gold standard with depreciating currencies all around it. Repeated assurances have been given, however, in governmental and banking circles, that the Netherlands will not abandon the gold standard voluntarily.

Observance of the Memorial Day holiday will cause a suspension of business in Wall Street and in other financial centres today. All markets, the banks and business organizations will be closed until tomorrow morning. The one important domestic market that will remain open today is the New Orleans Cotton Exchange.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- A determined effort probably will be made by the Treasury Department to obtain a wide distribution of the $750,000,000 or more in government securities that will be authorized June 15.

BERLIN, May 29. -- Dr. Hermann Rauschning, who is expected to become the new head of the Danzig Government because of the National Socialists' victory in yesterday's election, issued a statement to the German press here today in which he pledged himself:

To the Editor of The New York Times: As the date for the World Economic Conference draws near there is a wide school of thought both here and abroad which is opposed to efforts at international cooperation for a revival of international trade.

JOE McCARTHY, manager of the Yankees, was talking about big innings. He was still chuckling over the twelve runs the Ruppert Rifles scored in one inning to run off with a ball game that the White Sox considered in their bat bag.

While the enormous volume of trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday was generally ascribed -- and correctly so, no doubt -- to the new inflation fever with which the markets seem to be infected, a substantial foundation for the slow and erratic advance was supplied by the accumulated week-end reports of business improvement.

NOBLE, Pa., May 29. -- In a field of 600 dogs from all parts of the East and South, the noted English setter champion, The Country Gentleman, owned by the Happy Valley Kennels of West Chester, Pa., today was judged best in show at the eleventh annual Huntingdon Valley Kennel Club exhibition.

EPSOM DOWNS, England, May 29. -- All Britain -- at least it seemed that way -- tonight was headed for this quaint little English village where twenty-four of the country's best 3-year-olds, three of them American-owned, will match strides Wednesday for fame and fortune in the 150th running of the Derby.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The administration gold repeal resolution was passed by the House late today by a vote of 283 to 57, or almost five to one. It would cancel the gold clause in all Federal and private obligations, making them payable in legal tender.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Without debate or apparent opposition the Senate passed today another of th cycle of bills by Senator Wagner for relief of unemployment, this measure authorizing a Federally coordinated State employment service.

LONDON, May 29 (Canadian Press). -- Surrey today scored 339 runs for the loss of only three wickets in its game against the touring West Indian cricketers. West Indies had 460 for its first innings and the home team looked dangerous.

The principals of the Atlantic Passenger Conference will meet again in London on Thursday to consider the situation created by the acceptance of "blocked" marks by the Hamburg-American and North German Lloyd lines in payment of passage.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The legal right of Senior Circuit Judge Martin T. Manton to designate himself a District Judge and name receivers for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company and Manhattan Railway Company was upheld today by the Supreme Court.

Seventeen former officers and directors of the Fiscal Bond and Share Corporation of Baltimore, and its two New York subsidiaries, were accused yesterday of "illegal, fraudulent and wasteful transactions" which made the companies insolvent.

Developments yesterday virtually assured the selection of John Joseph McGraw to manage the All-Star National League team that will play an All-Star American League combination in a special game at Comiskey Park, Chicago, July 6, as a feature of the World's Fair sports program.

LONDON, May 29. -- Anglo-Japanese trade relations are approaching a crisis as a result of the flooding of India, Egypt and other British markets with Japanese textiles, and the British Government is seriously considering denunciation of the Anglo-Japanese commercial treaty.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 28 (AP). -- Albany defeated Baltimore, 9 to 8, in the ninth inning today after trailing the Orioles, 7 to 0, at one time. Mike Kreevich scored the deciding run on King's single after being it and stealing second.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 29. -- Choosing Cleveland for the place of their 1934 meeting and voting down every effort to reduce either rate of representation or the frequency of meetings, the 145th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America adjourned today.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 29 (AP). -- Long overdue for a batting splurge, the Bisons picked on Lefty Michaels, an old mate, and whipped the Montreal Royals today, 11 to 6, in a game that was washed out by rain and lightning as the Bisons came to bat for their half of the eighth inning.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Finley Peter Dunne and Miss Margaret Dunne left the Delmonico yesterday to pass the Summer in East Hampton.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP). -- A rise in farm, prices of 17 per cent, the most sensational spiral since the post-war "boom" days of April, 1919, was reported today from April 15 to May 15. The upward sweep has continued since that date.

A liquor syndicate's radio station, which wag located by Department of Justice agents on three previous occasions, but was moved each time before it could be raided, was seized yesterday at Montauk Point, L.I., and three men ware arrested charged with operating it.
New York will pay tribute to its war dead today. There will be solemn ceremonies at the churches and before memorial shafts in the cemeterles and public places.
"Old Gimlet Kye: The Adventures and Reminiscences of Smedley D. Butler," will be published in August by Farrar Rinehart. General Butler was in the city yesterday going over the illustrations.
WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The Supreme Court decision on the American Tobacco payments follows in part:

GENEVA, May 29. -- Germany informed Sean Lester, the League Council's Irish rapporteur, this afternoon that she could not accept his report on the Bernheim petition against anti-Semitism in German Silesia. Francisco Najera, the Mexican President of the Council, has stuck to his decision to call a meeting tomorrow morning.

Howard Inches plans to open the Peterborough (N.H.) Dramatic Festival at the Mariarden colony on July 4. with a presentation of Rachel Crothers's comedy, "When Ladies Meet." The season there will continue for eight weeks. Among the plays to be presented are "Another Language."

A net profit of $5,056,763 on property sold is shown by the New York Central Railroad in its report for 1932. Most of this was apparently realized from the sale of the building at Lexington Avenue and Forty-fifth Street to the government for a postoffice, which, F.E. Williamson, president of the New York Central, reports included a suitable adjustment to Eastern Offices, Inc., for cancellation of an option to lease the property.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 29. -- Mrs. Walter Prichard Eaton was hostess to the Great Barrington Garden Club at Twin Fires, Sheffield, this afternoon. Mrs. Walter Hind of Short Hills, N.J., who is a guest of Mrs. William Felton Barrett at Sky Farm, North Egremont, addressed the club on "Flower Arrangements."

Strollers in Fifty-seventh Street during the noon hour yesterday were surprised to see a chestnut saddle horse mounted by a young woman in skating costume at the doorway of Thrift House, 9 West Fifty-seventh Street.

For the second time in the history of the Intercollegiate A.A. A.A. human eyes have proved fallible in picking the order of finish in a championship race. Upon viewing developed pictures from the Kirby camera-timer yesterday, Gustavus T. Kirby, referee of the intercollegiate title tests at Cambridge on Saturday, revised the placing of three of the five point winners in the 100-meter dash.
CHICAGO, May 29. -- On the three-day showing since A Century of Progress Exposition opened on Saturday, officials stated today that they were confident of the success of the fair.

LONDON, May 29. -- Although not a great deal of business was done the stock market was cheerful and fairly active today. Outstanding was strength in rubbers on a fresh advance in the commodity, although later they reacted with the commodity. British funds were fractionally lower.
POUNDRIDGE, N.Y., May 29. -- A pilot and his passenger were killed today when their plane crashed in a rocky, wooded area In Poundridge, near Kitchawan Lake, about a mile from the Connecticut line.

Despite the rapid advance in the general price level of commodities at wholesale since their low point in March, considerable leeway for further rises exists before inflation of prices would set in, according to a report on "controlled reflation" released yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Outright assessment of a special "re-employment tax" on the basis of income tax returns due next March 15 will be proposed by Senator Connally as a substitute for the increased income levy rates carried in the Industry Recovery Bill as it passed the House Saturday.

All commodities traded on local exchanges, except silver futures, scored good advances in yesterday's trading. In most cases, the openings were irregularly lower, but strength developed quickly. Cash prices continued higher with several making new tops for the year to date.

NEWARK, N.J., May 29. --The names of James Feldman, alleged to be an alias for Max Hassell, slain beer racketeer, and of William J. Egan, former Director of Public Safety of Newark, were linked as occupants of the same suite of rooms at the Carlton Hotel in Washington during the inauguration ceremonies last March, in testimony given at the hearing here today in beer permit revocation procedings against the Harrison Beverage Company.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on May 24 shows increases for the week of $44,000,000 in net demand deposits, $7,000,000 in time deposits and $78,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, and decreases of $17,000,000 in loans and investments and $7,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The President is expected to increase the benefits for those disabled war veterans whose injuries are of service origin by an amount between $15,000,000 and $20,000,000, it was indicated today after a conference at the White House attended by Democratic House members.

Monday, May 29, 1933. Money market was quiet. No changes in quotations were found in any section. Stock Exchange day loans continued at 1 per cent, maturity money 3/4 to 1 1/2 per cent, for the near and distant periods. Business money unchanged in discount.

LOS ANGELES, May 29 (AP). -- Accused of stealing $58,000 from an Allentown (N.J.) bank of which he was a former teller, Morgan N. Buckalew was quoted today by United States Deputy Marshals as saying that he was at the end of a golden trail of pleasure and ready to "face the music."

BERLIN, May 29. -- The meeting of foreign bankers convoked by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, to discuss the transfer of service payments on Germany's private foreign debts got under way at the Reichsbank this morning with a lengthy discussion of the present state of the transfer problem by Dr. Schacht.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- President Roosevelt today unofficially communicated to members of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee his wish that the J.P. Morgan Co. investigation, as well as those to come involving Kuhn, Loeb Co., and Dillon, Read Co., be pushed to the fullest extent.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- J.P. Morgan Co.'s reports to Senate investigators show the firm made nearly $10,000,000 on the sale and underwriting of securities in 1930 and 1931, years in which the bank's partners paid $48,000 in Federal income tax.
