Federal agents arrested Herman Ell Goldsmith, 52 years old, selfstyled "consultant in Federal and State government procedure," yesterday afternoon on a charge of impersonating a government officer.

BERLIN, May 29. -- The Boerse opened the week in a mood of watchful waiting which reduced business to a minimum, but quotations were fairly steady. Somewhat weak at the beginning, the market rallied near the close. Financial circles have become very skeptical regarding both the disarmament and economic conferences and the impending meeting of Germany's creditors in Berlin is another cause for caution.

LOS ANGELES, May 29. -- In the most spectacular upset the welterweight division has known in many years, Jimmy McLarnin of Vancouver, B.C., won the world's welterweight championship tonight when he knocked out Young Corbett of Fresno, Cal., in the first round of their scheduled ten-round bout.

Although active, the listed bond market did not display as much strength yesterday as on several days last week. Utility and industrial bonds averaged better than rails in the domestic group, although several individual issues among the carriers advanced 1 to 6 points.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 29. -- Ruth Nichols, woman flier, of Rye, and her sister and two brothers are suing the Manhattan Company, the Bank of Manhattan Trust Company, and their late uncle, Morton C. Nichols of the Union League Club, New York, contending that the uncle fraudulently disposed of some of the assets of a family trust fund.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, May 30. -- With the advance of the Cantonese Nineteenth Route Army in Southern Hunan and the northern armistice negotiations apparently hanging fire, the greatest significance is attached here to a conference today of government officials at Kuling, a mountain resort outside Kiukiang.

Arrangements have been made for the Second and Third National Investors Corporations to purchase all the shares of their stocks that are owned by the Atlas Corporation. The stockholders of the two investment trusts will pass upon the proposal at a special meeting on Thursday of next week.

PARIS, May 29. -- Former Premier Edouard Herriot gave in Parliament today a full account of his recent trip to Washington, telling of the results of his conversations with President Roosevelt on war debts, the customs truce, armaments and the World Economic Conference.

POONA, India, May 29 (AP). -- Amid the rejoicing of his friends of various religions and castes, Mahatma ' Gandhi today concluded his three-week fast in protest against untouchability extremely weak in body, but proclaiming his increased faith in God.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The huge bonuses paid to George Washington Hill and other officials of the American Tobacco Company must be reviewed by the courts. This action, to ascertain if the bonuses constitute misuse and waste of the corporation's money, was ordered by the Supreme Court today in an opinion by Justice Butler.

RENSSELAER, N.Y., May 29 (AP). -- Firing as they ran, six bandits fled from the Rensselaer County Bank after a daring noon-hour hold-up today, shot and killed one detective, wounded another and escaped in an automobile with $2,000 in cash.

The historic $30,000 Withers, for 3-year-olds, inaugurated in 1874, will have its fifty-eighth running at Belmont Park today, with eleven named for what appears to be one of the most evenly matched fields for this event in recent years.
Ferdinand Pecora said here yesterday that he would return to Washington early today, prepared to resume the Morgan inquiry tomorrow, "where we left off."

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 29. -- At the end of a day marked by the defeat of Keith Gledhill of Santa Barbara, Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, and Lester Stoefen of Los Angeles stood in the final round of the invitation tournament of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club this evening.

PARIS, May 29. -- While the French Senate today was engaged in reinstating disputed economy measures which had been amputated from the budget by the Chamber of Deputies, the general public of Paris and the provinces was indulging in the most widespread demonstration against heavy taxes that has been witnessed since indignation meetings began to multiply some months ago.

The Wheatley Stable entry of Iseult and Edelweiss ran one, two in the Acorn Stakes, $13,175 test for 3-year-old fillies, at Belmont Park yesterday. The score was rather a hollow one after E.R. Bradley's Barn Swallow, winner of the Kentucky Oaks and pre-race favorite, had been withdrawn because of a muddy track.

F. Trubee Davison, president of the American Museum of Natural History, was the guest of honor at a farewell dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria last night given by a group of close friends and associates. He will sail for Africa on June 15, accompanied by Mrs. Davison, to join Mr. and Mrs. Martin Johnson, big game hunters, on a four months' expedition.

With streams low and clear and trout hard to snare, the fly fishermen have come into their own at last. According to reports from the popular spots, the bait fishermen have disappeared and the experienced fly-casters are having all the good luck.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP). -- President Roosevelt told members of the Senate Banking Committee today he wanted their investigation of J.P. Morgan Co. and other private bankers to be pushed forward "without limit."

PHILADELPHIA, May 29. -- Hitlerism was condemned in a resolution adopted by a district convention of the B'nai B'rith Order at its closing sessions here today, while President Roosevelt and the State Department were thanked for their "sympathetic interest" in the plight of German Jews.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Senator La Follette charged in a speech in the Senate today that J.P. Morgan Co. "dominates" the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York. Through the chamber, he contended, the banking firm directs opposition to ratification of the St. Lawrence waterway treaty.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 29. -- The Presbyterian Assembly, without opposition, approved today the election of the following whose names were submitted by nominating committees:

Taxes on motor trucks, buses wagons and pleasure cars, a 1 per cent levy on rents in excess of $100 a month and an increase in the water supply tax were suggested as sources of new city revenue by Samuel Untermyer yesterday. The suggestions were embodied in a letter to Controller Charles W. Berry, made public last night by the Finance Department.

The world has been for many years on the verge of a "nervous breakdown," and the best thing the depression can do is restore normal living, according to Professor C.U. Ariens Kappers, director of the Central Institute for Brain Research of Amsterdam.

The traditional friendliness between the United States and Japan is fundamentally sound and recent events have not shaken the old amicable relations between the two countries, Viscount Kikujiro Ishii, head of the Japanese mission to the World Economic Conference, declared in a radio address broadcast from station WJZ last night.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 29. -- Henry E. Drayton, 79 years old, a retired broker of Pennllyn, Pa., near Philadelphia, testified here today in an action to foreclose a $50,000 mortgage which he holds against the Sands Point (L.I.) property of his son, W. Heyward Drayton 3d, who also lives at Pennllyn.

HANOVER, N.H., May 29. -- The Amos Tuck School of Business and Finance at Dartmouth College observed its graduation ceremonies today, awarding the Master of Commercial Science degree to twenty-five students in Parkhurst Hall.

DEVON, Pa., May 29. -- Weary River, superbly ridden by Miss Caral Gimbel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel of Port Chester, N.Y., after two jump-offs with Miss Julia Whiting's Quick-silver, won the blue ribbon in the class for hunters and jumpers over an international hunters' course at the fifth day of the Devon Horse Show today.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Threats and insulting letters by the score have beaten down upon the head of Senator Carter Glass of Virginia because of his persistent opposition to the methods used in the J.P. Morgan Co. inquiry before the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency.
WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The majority and minority reports of the Banking and Currency Committee on the gold resolution, passed today by the House, follow:
Conditions in both the city and suburban real estate market are slowly but steadily improving.

Determination to prevent the return of anything resembling the old-time saloon was voiced last night by Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, in a radio broadcast over WEAF.

Speculation is the almost inevitable result of over-saving and over-investment, according to the report of the Committee on the Relation of Consumption, Production and Distribution of the American Engineering Council, public service body of the engineering profession.

At the start of her writing career Mary Roberts Rinehart made profit out of poetry. She had contracted diphtheria from her eldest son, Stanley M. Rinehart, now, as president of the firm of Farrar Rinehart, her senior publisher. While she was convalescing she wrote some verse.

CHICAGO, May 29 (AP). -- Mrs. Jack Howard's Ebony Lady, which raced successfully at Miami last Winter, made her bow at Washington Park today by scoring in the Century of Progress Purse after a hard battle with Mr. Joe and Polydorus.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 29. -- A varied program of June week exercises was presented today at the Naval Academy as visitors from all over the nation began to fill Annapolis for the graduation period.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The Federal Emergency Relief Administration announced today grants aggregating $21,659,282 to thirty-one States and Hawaii under the Wagner Act to meet immediate relief needs. Of the preliminary outlay. New York State will receive $6,532,282, and will receive about $2,000,000 additional, the total of about $8,500,000 to be made available before the end of June.
VIENNA, May 29. -- The seventh biennial congress of the International Chamber of Commerce opened today in the Hall of the Vienna Konzerthaus.

TRENTON, N.J., May 29. -- The State Milk Control Board ordered today that, beginning June 1, New Jersey milk dealers must charge not less than 13 cents for Grade A milk sold direct to consumers in quart bottles and 10 cents for other grades.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The amended arms embargo resolution reported out by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Saturday does not meet the views of President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull, but the administration may accept it as the best measure available this late in the session of Congress, the Secretary of State indicated today.
After having been set back nearly $1 a bale early yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward and ended with net gains of 4 to 9 points.

Schenectady, N.Y. Schenectady County, N.Y., has scheduled a new issue of $550,000 emergency relief bonds for award on June 6 at 10 A.M. The bonds will be dated May 1, 1933, and will mature serially from 1935 to 1943. The interest rate is to be bid in multiples of one-tenth of 1 per cent.

Joseph Leblang, cut-rate theatre ticket operator, did not die insolvent, according to four relatives who filed objections yesterday in Surrogates' Court to an accounting of the estate by the widow, Mrs. Tillie Leblang Jasie, as executrix. The accounting showed a deficit of $1,468,488,89.

KANSAS CITY, May 29 (AP) -- While Miss Mary McElroy asserted today that she felt no malice toward the men who kidnapped her and exacted $30,000 in ransom for her release yesterday, her father, H.F. McElroy, City Manager, directed police in a relentless search for the abductors.
WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Movement of vessels follow, all dates are May 27, unless otherwise specified:

After, it was believed, he had suffered a heart attack, William Kley, 45 years old, of 3,033 Weaver Avenue, Baltimore, captain of a private yacht, fell overboard into Pugsley Creek, the Bronx, yesterday. Although under water only a few seconds, Kley was dead when he was brought ashore.

The cost of living in this country showed a decline of 9.3 per cent in April as compared with April, 1932, according to a report made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. A decline of 27.9 per cent for April, 1933, as compared with the corresponding month for 1929 was shown.

AUTEUIL, France, May 29. -- Rain, besetting the French hard court tennis championships for the fourth straight day, washed out Frank Shields's match with Bela von Kehrling, the Hungarian Davis Cup star, today just as the American was in sight of victory.

Seasonal Orders Continue Heavy. Mail orders reaching this market yesterday continued heavy, the volume comparing well with the same day a week ago, according to reports here. The strength of the current demand was interpreted as indicating prolongation of the seasonal demand much further in the coming month than is usually the case.

BERLIN, Tuesday, May 30 (AP). -- A Reichswehr (Army) Department official, roused from bed early today, expressed disbelief in the Austrian report that former Chancellor Kurt von Schleicher had been arrested and imprisoned.

New Jersey, fondly known as the Garden State, is in a fair way to be called the Lake State. A map of Morris, Sussex and Passaic Counties fifteen years ago would have shown comparatively few sheets of water that could be dignified with the name of lake.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Reduction of officer personnel of the army as an economy measure was practically abandoned today as more than 6,000 officers will be required to supervise the Civilian Conservation Corps camps. About half of the officers will be engaged at the 1,300 camps throughout the country for at least six months.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Consideration is being given to the appointment of an additional administrator of the Agricultural Adjustment Act to promote exports of agricultural commodities, Secretary Wallace announced today. At the same time it became known that officials in charge of the government reorganization program were proposing abolition of the foreign agricultural service in the interests of economy.
To the Editor of The New YorK Times : Cannot certain persons in these United States think of business in any other terms but those of the racket?

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- A new era in American finance began today, the ancient rule of "caveat emptor" being changed to "let the seller beware," as the Securities Bill signed by the President on Saturday became immediately effective.

PARIS, May 29. -- With the dollar closing at 21.44 francs, 50 centimes below the last official closing on Friday, and with French opinion convinced President Roosevelt will push it down still further, pessimism regarding the World Economic Conference is becoming more pronounced here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES reports on a paper entitled "Facial Deformities and Abnormalities in Their Relationship to Crime," read by Dr. Carleton Simon to the Academy of Medicine.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- In a burst of activity that brought decisions in sixteen cases and all but cleared its dockets, the Supreme Court today closed its term and recessed until October.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 29. -- Society from Greenwich and many towns and cities in Westchester County, to the number of about 1,000, attended a supper dance at the Greenwich Country Club tonight, for the benefit of the Stepney Fresh Air Home at Stepney, Conn.
An umbrella was the weapon used yesterday by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, to disperse a crowd of about 400 militantly pacifist students.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 29. -- Rear Admiral Thomas C. Hart, superintendent of the Naval Academy, today presented athletic prizes which midshipnien had won during the academic year, including 229 varsity letters, the ceremony taking place in Thompson Stadium.

Despite the smallest crop of Winter wheat since 1904, the Department of Agriculture predicts that the carry-over a year hence will probably be as large as ever, unless exports improve. Production has been curtailed, thanks chiefly to adverse weather, but foreign markets have also dwindled.

Men owe something to their profession. They cannot stand dumb when it is injured at home or degraded abroad. It is for this reason that a group of eminent American lawyers have united in a strong protest to the German Government because of procedures against judges and members of the bar in Germany which have shocked the professional instinct as well as the humane spirit all over the world.

Joseph Schneider, a business agent of the joint board of the Dress and Waistmakers Unions, was shot and critically wounded yesterday as he entered the union offices at 151 West Thirty-third Street. His assailant, a disgruntled union member, was arrested.

ROBERT LOUIS STEVENSON in his "Forest Notes" tells of the capture of a stag in the Forest of Senlis, near Paris, by CHARLES VI, bearing a collar with the inscription, "Caesar mihi hoc donavit." So centuries Lence will travelers in our national parks and even some of our State parks find bronze tablets bearing this inscription :

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The administration's stated reason for repealing the gold clause in millions of dollars in contracts made by and in the United States since 1869 is that public policy requires the step. In slightly varying language this is the same reason given by the State of Mississippi for its bond repudiation, by certain powers for their war-debts default and by the Japanese for fractures of the Nine Power and other treaties.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 29. -- The Nassau Country Club took the lead among the Class A teams in the Long Island interclub series of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association as a result of a 4-to-1 defeat administered to the Salisbury team in today's matches at the Piping Rock Club.

PARIS, May 29. -- A laconic dispatch received here today reported the capture of the notorious Corsican bandit Andre Spada, by the gendarmerie at the village of Coggia. In the absence of details, it would appear there was nothing particularly spectacular about the capture.

BOWIE, Md., May 29 (AP). -- C.V. Whitney's Capsheaf made a runaway of the Glen Burnie Purse, an allowance affair of a mile and seventy yards, the feature at Bowie today, romping home a winner five lengths in front of Standout. Swinhaven was third, two and a half lengths further back.

The Republican Assembly District leaders of New York County, with very few exceptions, rallied yesterday to the support of Samuel S. Koenig, County Chairman. They assured him of their support in the coming primary fight to oust him.

TIENTSIN, May 29. -- The most reliable foreign sources reported today that, despite the continuance of Chino-Japanese truce negotiations, ten Japanese trains from Mukden, Manchuria, loaded with troops, supplies and artillery, reached the town of Kaiping, seventy miles north of Tientsin.

In a thin drizzle, reminiscent of the Quai Voltaire, the first independent sidewalk book-stall in Manhattan was opened yesterday morning at 10 o'clock by the Hop Light Ladies. They are fighting the depression in jaunty uniforms of blue, and smart hats edged in black to match.

Organization of the Railroad Perishable Freight Inspection Agency by the Eastern lines was announced yesterday by D.T. Lawrence, chairman of the Presidents' Traffic Conference. The conference is one of the two committees formed to reduce competitive wastes by the railroads in this region.

GENEVA, May 29. -- The disarmament conference concluded today its discussion of the definition of aggression with the first serious non-Japanese deadlock since President Roosevelt's message proposing a non-aggression pact.

The dollar fell yesterday to within a small fraction of its low record in the exchange market. Despite efforts of the British Exchange Equalization Fund to resist the cheapening of the dollar, the pound sterling rose to $4, as against the year's high price of $4.05, and closed at $3.99, up 1 3/4 cents.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- Although many grain traders here are disposed to take the selling side on sharp bulges, houses with Eastern connections were today aggressive buyers of the active deliveries of wheat on the Board of Trade. They failed to get the market into new ground, however, although the strength in stocks and cotton resulted in caution among sellers.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 30 (AP). -- Adelmar Echeverria, Argentine Davis Cup star, fell before a comparatively unknown opponent today as other favored stars scored easy second-round victories in the Dixie invitation tennis tournament.

LONDON, May 30 -- Tower Green, within the mighty ramparts of Britain's hoary fortress, the Tower of London, went back to the days of the Tudors this morning. With pomp and ritual that have survived six centuries, Field Marshal Lord Milne, former chief of the Imperial General Staff, was installed as constable of the Tower.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP). -- Commander Charles E. Rosendahl, first commander of the ill-fated Akron, testified at the joint Congressional inquiry today that he would have taken a course different from the one which carried the navy airship to disaster off the New Jersey coast April 4.

Several sales of residential properties in various parts of the sub-urban district were reported yesterday, including houses in Westchester and Connecticut and a large site for a dwelling on Long Island.

MOSCOW, May 30 (AP). -- A gigantic statue of Lenin, dwarfing all the thousands now dotting Soviet Russia in honor of the leader of the Bolshevik revolution, will be the crowning glory of the much-talked-of Palace of the Soviets, according to the latest plan.

PARIS, May 30. -- "I would be unfaithful to the 123,000 American soldiers killed in France if I failed to devote all my efforts to my last breath to Franco-American friendship," declared former Premier Herriot today, speaking at a Memorial Day ceremony at the Lafayette Escadrille monument at Garches, near Paris.

MEXICO CITY, May 30. -- Memorial Day was observed in Mexico City this morning in a ceremony at the old American Cemetery, presided over by Ambassador Josephus Daniels and attended by several hundred of his compatriots. Seven American soldiers of the war with Mexico in 1847 are buried there.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., May 30. -- Holiday house parties have brought mid-season gayety to East Hampton this week.

All the important domestic markets with the exception of the New Orleans Cotton Exchange were closed yesterday in observance of Memorial Day. The banks did not open and there were no dealings locally in foreign exchange. Business will be resumed in all centres this morning.

Challenging the leadership of John H. McCooey, Representative Loring M. Black Jr. of Brooklyn made yesterday in Washington formal announcement of his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Mayor. Mr. Black, whose "future availability" for public office was questioned by Mr. McCooey because of his vote against the Roosevelt Economy Bill, declared his intention of entering the Democratic primary.

The restoration of the Pulitzer fountain at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street is to be completed in the Fall. The original design is to be adhered to, with the exception that marble is to replace the deteriorated limestone.

Several suggestions for the reduction of lighterage costs in the harbor have been submitted in the last few days as the result of the Port of New York Authority's recommendation to the Interstate Commerce Commission that the rail-roads be obliged to reduce their port costs through the appointment of a "czar" to supervise their lighterage operations or by other means.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 30. -- Opening the season of the Metropolitan and New Jersey Cricket Association at Warinanco Park today, the eleven of the Staten Island Cricket Club defeated the Veteran St. George team by the score of 88 to 35.

The North German Lioyd liner Europa, with a passenger list that included an American and a Chinese delegation bound for forthcoming conferences in Geneva and London, was held several hours at her Brooklyn pier early this morning by a dense fog that blanketed the harbor.

NEW ORLEANS, May 30. -- Senator Huey P. Long was sued for $250,000 damages today in Baton Rouge by Mrs. Anne E. Pleasant, wife of former Governor Ruffin G. Pleasant. She charges Long defamed her character and had her seized and expelled from the Capitol during the session of the 1932 Legislature.

The long dispute over judicial right and procedure in the case of the Interborough receivership has at last been passed upon by the Supreme Court of the United States. It has upheld the decision of the Circuit Court that Judge MANTON was within the law in designating himself as a District Judge to pass upon the application for receivership.

A presentation in popular form of the results of a nation-wide study of the effects of motion pictures on the minds of children is published today with the title, "Our Movie-Made Children." Henry James Forman wrote the book, which is brought out by Macmillan.

The late DAN O'LEARY covered more ground than the poet WORDSWORTH, who, according1 to DE QUINCEY, traversed a distance as far as seven times around the world. The Irish walker's score is said to have been 300,000 miles. To the exercise the poet, says DE QUINCEY, "was indebted for a life of un"clouded happiness and we for "much of what is most excellent "in his writings."

MOUNT EVEREST, May 30 (By Wireless From Base Camp). -- The assault on the unconquered peak of Mount Everest is under way. P. Wyn-Harris and L.R. Wager have begun the great climb toward the summit and were last seen making good progress at 7 o'clock this, Tuesday, morning [9 . M. Monday, Eastern Daylight Time].

Memorial Day was celebrated throughout New Jersey yesterday with the pomp and martial music of parades, the placing of wreaths on the graves of the war dead, and patriotic speeches calling for a renewal of courage and hope during a peace-time "war."

The text of the recent British court decision under which issuers of gold-clause bonds were permitted to pay in currency was distributed yesterday to members of the Council on Foreign Relations, 45 West Sixty-fifth Street.

PITTSBURGH, May 30 (AP). -- Bill Jurges headed the attack for the Cubs this afternoon, leading them to a 6-to-2 victory over the Pirates after Pittsburgh downed Chicago 2 to 1, in the morning encounter.

While curious children watched from fire-escapes of neighboring tenements and elevated trains rumbled overhead, Jewish Revolutionary patriots were honored yesterday in the little plot on the Bowery which is the second oldest Jewish cemetery in the United States.

BOSTON, May 30 (AP). -- Dr. James V. May of Boston, president of the American Psychiatric Association, declared today that "the attitude of the law makes disinterested and impartial study of mental conditions impossible in court cases."

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP). -- Alma Roach, 12 years old, representing The Akron (Ohio) Beacon-Journal, today won the $500 first prize in the national spelling bee organized by The Louisville Courier-Journal to which local champions were sent by newspapers throughout the counttry.
To Manhattan's varsity crew came its first taste of victory yesterday as the highly successful Memorial Day regatta of the New Tork Rowing Association drew to its close on the Harlem.

KANSAS CITY, Wednesday, May 31 (AP). -- Warden Kirk Prather of the Kansas State Penitentiary told tonight his story of his experience to a representative of The Associated Press and The Kansas City Star.

The pamphlet report of the General Motors Corporation for the quarter ended on March 31 shows that current assets on that date totaled $257,946,908, against $283,258,874 on Dec. 31, 1932. The sum included an investment of $12,500,000 in the capital stock of the National Bank of Detroit but not cash balances in closed banks, which totaled $13,943,878 as of April 25.

A drive by the Pennsylvania Commission of Fisheries has just been started, according to Commissioner Oliver M. Deibler, by which it is hoped to save some of the important fishing streams of the State from further contamination. The drive has been started with the hope that sportsmen will band and help wipe out what, according to Commissioner Deibler, is a menace that threatens almost all of the streams of the State.

John T. Freeman, a 19-year-old coal miner from Blakely, Pa., went to Coney Island yesterday with $50 of his money for a good time. He had earned it with a pick and shovel, and he expected a lot He got it.

PARIS, May 21 (By Mail). -- Seductive styles of the "haughty Nineties" returned to fashion recently with Mirande's exhibition of evening gowns designed with the sweeping flounced skirts and ruched shoulder lines worn by fashionable beauties forty years ago.

The New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking will present certificates to 161 graduates of the class of 1933 at commencement ceremonies tomorrow night in the Brick Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street. George T. Newell of the Manufacturers Trust Company, president of the New York Chapter, will award the prizes, and Arthur Gardner of the Bankers Trust Company will present the certificates.

David B. Costuma, formerly leader of the Nineteenth Assembly District, has been appointed manager of the campaign to oust Samuel S. Koenig from the chairmanship of the New York County Republican Committee. The choice was announced yesterday by James A. Hatch, chairman of the Organization of Regular Republicans for Change in County Leadership.

PARIS, May 30. -- The French Cabinet this morning approved the text of the four-power pact in its present form and issued a communique stating that negotiations regarding it were progressing favorably in Geneva and Rome.

With drumheads swathed in rubber and battle streamers limp and sodden with the rain, a few survivors of the legions that followed Grant to Richmond and Sherman to the sea trudged painfully up Riverside Drive yesterday in the city's principal observance of Memorial Day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent address by Dr. Mary E. Woolley, president of Mount Holyoke College, at the testimonial dinner for Dr. George J. Ryan suggests once more to the world the ever-increasing importance of peace education.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 10. -- The chief result of today's session of the Little Entente conference as revealed in a communique it issued, was the acceptance by the Little Entente of the proposed four-power pact. It was accepted on the strength of assurances from France that the original proposal had undergone important revision, with the result that unanimous action by the League of Nations Council would continue to be required for any revision of treaties.

BERLIN, May 30. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's statement to foreign creditors and bankers on the crisis in the transfer of exchange bad a stimulating influence on today's session of the Boerse, where the impression prevails that a method of readjusting the present procedure of transfers will be found without compelling Germany to take autonomous action.

SOUTH ORANGE. N.J., May 30. -- With mist and twilight blanketing the turf of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, 1,200 limp spectators rose cheering in their seats this evening to pay tribute to the greatest tennis match seen on these courts since William Tilden and Vincent Richards met in the final of the inaugural invitation tournament her in 1925.

American interests in Brazil need have no fear that the proposed new Brazilian Constitution will include provisions that might threaten the security of property and investments held in that country by American citizens.

Chicago Fair Thrives. Postmaster General FARLEY and the star Arcturus between them opened the Chicago Fair. It is therefore no surprise to lean on the basis of the first three days' showing that Chicago is convinced the Century of Progress is a success.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- With prirate long-term investments abroad by Americans totaling $15,252,000,00 at the end of last year, the Commerce Department's Balance of International Payments for 1932 shows that receipts on the long-term capital account were $217,000,000 in excess of payments to foreigners for the year.

STANFORD UNIVERSITY. Cal., May 30. -- Half in and half out of a bathtub in her home on the Stanford University campus, the body of Mrs. Alene Thorpe Lamson, executive secretary of the university Young Women's Christian Association, was discovered today under mysterious circumstances.

Dr. Henry B. Rathbone, chairman of the journalism department at the New York University School of Commerce announced yesterday the winners of seven awards for articles during the school year 1932-33. Competition was open to students majoring in the department of journalism in the day and evening divisions of the university.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The technical advisers who will accompany the American delegation to the World Economic Conference, opening June 12 at London, are men of varied experience. Brief biographies of some at them follow:
BURLINGTON. Vt., May 30. -- The Dartmouth nine pounded out twelve hits off the offerings of John Beckley to defeat the University of Vermont, 11 to 1, in the annual baseball game.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 30 (AP). -- Rochester's winning streak of seven straight was broken by Toronto today when the Leafs won the first game, 6 to 2. behind the hurling of Izzy Goldstein and the bitting of Ike Boone.

Four children between the ages of 9 and 12 years narrowly escaped injury or death late yesterday afternoon when a section of an abandoned tenement houes at 617 East Eighty-seventh Street, in which they were playing, collapsed.

LANSING. Kan., May 30. -- Eleven convicts, eight of them murderers and bank robbers, headed by Wilbur Underbill, 33 years old, known as the most desperate bandit in the Southwest, escaped from the State penitentiary here today. They took with them as hostages the warden, Kirk Prather, and two prison guards.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP). -- The dismissal of E.S. Rochester as secretary of the Federal Oil Conservation Board was attributed in part by Secretary Ickes tonight to a letter which Mr. Rochester wrote to a friend asking aid in finding a job and claiming credit for the board's achievements.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Now that the President has stamped with his approval the inquiry into private banking practices by the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency, the investigation becomes an administration policy. That was the point of the word sent to committee members through one or two of their number, that they are to delve deeply into all related matters, and that if they need help they can get it at the White House.

The Supreme Court decision confirming orders issued by Federal Judge Martin T. Manton in the Interborough receivership case, makes it more imperative than ever that the city intervene as a party, Samuel Untermyer declared yesterday.

The population of the New York retail trading area has increased in the two years since the Federal census to 12,616,300, representing a gain of 561,00, or 4.6 per cent, according to the Merchants Association.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- President Roosevelt joined with his fellow-citizens today in the observance of Memorial Day. He attended the exercises at Arlington National Cemetery, where government officials, diplomats, survivors of the Civil War and leaders of the World War gathered to pay their respects to not only the dead of American wars but also to the victims of the recent crash of the navy dirigible Akron.

Members of the Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation in New York, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia and New Jersey are cooperating with the Delaware committee toward the success of the garden days to be held June 10 and 11 at Nemours, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Irenee du Pont near Wilmington, Del. Many New York members are planning to motor to Wilmington for the exhibition of those notable gardens.

The unseemly incident on Monday at the City College should not discredit the great body of students who are preparing themselves to give to this community something beyond material wealth. The campus of the college lies in the midst of the city.

The bad weather yesterday spoiled New Yorkers' holiday plans, with the result that traffic into the city last night by airplane, railroad and automobile was light, while concessionaires at the comparatively deserted metropolitan beaches reckoned up Memorial Day as a financial loss.

BEACH HAVEN, N.J., May 30. -- Faced by a gray and sluggish sea, an unusually solemn crowd of 5,000 persons stood on the beach front through intermittent rainfall here today at a Memorial Day service dedicated to the seventy-four men who lost their lives in the destruction of the airship Akron during a storm last April 4, and to the two men who were lost in the crash of the rescue blimp J-3.

An attempt by two unidentified thugs to rob a young couple seated in a parked automobile in a quiet neighborhood in Manhattan Beach ended last night in the shooting and killing of a young man. The thugs flung his body out of the machine, forced his woman companion out also andd rove away in the car.
WASHINGTON. May 30. -- Opposition by the National Association of Manufacturers to some provisions of President Roosevelt's industrial recovery bill took definite force today.

AUTEUTL, France, May 30. -- The United States delegation in the singles competition of the French hard-court tennis championships today kept its ranks unbroken, with Frank Shields, Helen Jacobs and Mrs. Dorothy Andrus Burke all registering third-round victories.

Nobody will doubt the courage of The Players in venturing to follow up their previous revival of such plays as "Henry IV" and "Troilus and Cressida" with AIKEN'S acting version of " Uncle Tom's Cabin." Its presentation this week has brought reminiscence of innumerable older-time productions of the play by companies of every sort and description.

BERLIN, May 30. -- A demand that all Jewish aristocrats, as well as all other members of the German nobility whose families show traces of Jewish blood, be deprived of their titles is made by K.G. Deolzenberg, one of the Nazi literary leaders.

MEDFORD, Mass., May 30. -- Announcement of the opening Oct. 3 of the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, to be administered jointly by Tufts College and Harvard University, was made by Tufts autnorities today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 30. -- Through an hour of rain and then a slow, partial clearing the Long Island Sound racing fleet engaged yesterday in the Harlem Yacht Club's fifty-first annual regatta. In the van were two 12-meter sloops, the Norwegian built Cantitoe, under charter to Van Santvoord Merle-Smith and making her first appearance of the season, and the Iris, under charter to Drake H. Sparkman and Olin J. Stephens 2d.

TIENTSIN, May 30 -- After many days of evasions, mystifications and forthright denials that any plan was afoot for early signing of a specific armistice, a group of China's negotiators were actually housed tonight with Japanese delegates at Tangku, near the mouth of the Hai River below Tientsin, where negotiations were proceeding under the guns of Japanese naval craft.

CHICAGO, May 30 (AP). -- New Deal, crack 2-year-old sporting the silks of J. W. Parrish, won the $2,500 added Curran Memorial Stakes at Washington Park today with a driving finish that sent him one length ahead of Swiftsport at the finish.

BERLIN, May 30 -- The practically unanimous condemnation by the Council of the League of Nations of the anti-Semitic policy of the Hitler goverment is met today by a counter-offensive on the part of the government-controlled press against the League and against all protests of Nazi practices.

GENEVA, May 30. -- Germany's anti-Semitic legislation was found to "conflict" with her treaty obligations in Upper Silesia In the report on the petition of Franz Bernheim that Sean Lester submitted to the Council of the League of Nations at a public sitting this morning.

One youth was killed and five others wounded, two of them seriously, late last night when half a dozen gunmen burst into the Castle Cafe at 72 First Street, near First Avenue, and opened fire on ten boys and young men playing cards in the coffee house.

The quarter-of-a-century hold that the New York A.C. has had on the Metropolitan A.A.U. junior track and field championship was broken in the rain and mud at Ulmer Park yesterday when New York University dethroned the Winged Foot Club in the annual junior games by 44 to 32.

A drop of 70,800 barrels last week in the daily average gross production of crude oil in this country is reported by the American Petroleum Institute. The daily average output was 2,634,550 barrels, comparing with 2,705,350 in the week ended on May 20 and 2,169,400 in the week ended on May 28, 1932.
VIENNA, May 30 (AP). -- The seventh congress of the International Chamber of Commerce was enlivened today by a denunciation of what was called the "immoral" monetary behavior of the United States.
More than 1,000 Scotsmen gathered at Ulmer Park, Twenty-fifth and Cropsey Avenues, Brooklyn, yesterday for the annual games of the United Scottish Clans of Greater New York and New Jersey.

IN the wake of the intercollegiate championships held recently in the Harvard Stadium, a bystander might be permitted to marvel at the speed with which runners come -- and go. They come up fast. They look unbeatable. Twelve months later they are hardly in the running.

Lawrence B. Elliman, chairman of the executive committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, denied yesterday that J.P. Morgan Co. was responsible for the Chamber's opposition to ratification of the St. Lawrence waterway treaty. Mr. Elliman is president of Pease Elliman, Inc., a real estate concern.

BERLIN, May 30. -- The revolt against the new Protestant Reich's Bishop, Dr. Friedrich von Bodelschwingh, announced by the "German Christians," who are determined to "coordinate" the Protestant Church with the National Socialist State, assumed a more aggressive form today.

CHICAGO, May 30 (AP). -- After being held practically powerless and defeated, 7 to 2, by Ed Durham in the first game, the Indians broke loose and batted out twenty-three hits at the expense of six White Sox pitchers today to gain a 15-to-8 victory and an even break on their holiday double-header.

BERLIN, May 30 -- Foreign creditor bankers who have come to Berlin to confer with the Reichsbank President, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, on the transfer crisis entered today upon the study of statistics submitted by Dr. Schacht to support his contention that a new transfer procedure must be evolved to prevent the Reichsbank's gold reserves from being wiped out.

East River bridge tolls and an impost on taxicab fares will not be the only revenue projects discussed at the public hearing before the Board of Estimate today, it was indicated last night. Unless Mayor O'Brien specifically limits the discussion to the two proposals recently made in a letter by Samuel Untermyer to Controller Charles W. Berry, various individuals and civic organizations are prepared to urge additional means of raising funds.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 30. -- Cardinal Hayes will break ground for a new group of Marymount College buildings tomorrow morning. Following the blessing of the site on Castle Ridge, the Cardinal will preside at the commencement exercises, addressing the graduates and conferring the degrees.

In an early morning raid yesterday on a flat at 1,433 College Avenue, the Bronx, detectives arrested three men and confiscated an arsenal of weapons usually employed for such underworld affairs as gang wars and bank robberies.
PROVIDENCE, May 30. -- Brown triumphed over Harvard today, 3 to 2, coming from behind in the eighth inning to score two runs and clinch the game.

DEEP RIVER, Conn., May 30. -- Henry Wooley, 29 years old, killed his father with a double-barreled shotgun in their home at 44 Elm Street early tonight. Then he shot himself in the head. He was taken to the Middlesex Hospital at Middle-town, where physicians had little hope for his recovery.

Morris Rothenberg, chairman of the American Administrative Committee of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, made public yesterday an appeal to the Jews of the world, received from London under the signatures of prominent Christian and Jewish friends of Palestine, to open immediately "a Palestine fund for the Jews of Germany."

LONDON, May 30 (Canadian Press). -- The cricket match between the West Indian team and Surrey was drawn today when the visitors had made 160 for 5 wickets in their second innings. They had previously scored 460 in the first innings to 470 for the home team.

Achieving 21 feet and one-half an inch in the senior running broad jump, the concluding event, Joe Hoctor accounted for one of the meet's nine record-breaking performances, became the lone double winner and enabled Iona School of New Rochelle to retain the senior team title in the second annual Manhattan-Bronx-Westchester division C.H.S.A.A. track and field championships at Manhattan Field yesterday.

PASSAIC, N.J., May 30. -- Confidence that President Roosevelt would "swing the axe on the rotten deadwood of our discredited financial set-up" was expressed here today by Major Gen. Smedley D. Butler.

The greatest mistake that the United States could possibly make would be to agree at the London conference to freeze its dollar in a high ratio to already depreciated currencies, according to the Committee for the Nation, headed by James H. Rand Jr.

WINNIPEG, May 30. -- Prices of wheat gained a cent a bushel in trading in the Winnipeg grain markets today. With the United States markets closed, the chief influences were buying by local speculators and the stronger tone of the Liverpool market.

Ten youthful Socialists, including two women, were mobbed and beaten yesterday morning by National Guardsmen and Veterans of Foreign Wars. More than 2,000 persons witnessed the fight, which took place in Mitchel Square, Broadway and 168th Street, just before the annual Memorial Day observance at the war monument there.
The same team that made clean sweeps in the ties with Canada and Argentina will constitute the overseas Davis Cup expedition of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

BOSTON, May 30. -- J. Oliver Beebe, 38, World War hero, Harvard graduate and prominent business man, was instantly killed today when a cabin monoplane in which he was making his first solo flight turned over as he banked too sharply and crashed into the mud flats north of the East Boston Airport.

Several leases in the Times Square district were included in the list of commercial space contracts reported by brokers yesterday. Midtown stores and quarters in the downtown and garment districts also were contracted for by various types of business.
PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (AP). -- The Phillies defeated the Braves, 2 to 1, today in a game called in the seventh inning by rain. A scheduled second game was postponed.

The New York Americans, Eastern champions in the national soccer cup competition, gained their second victory of the season over a picked team of the German-American Soccer Association yesterday at Starlight Park.
"Strike Me Pink" at the Majestic Theatre, will run until Saturday, June 10, according to announcement last night. The show had been scheduled to close with this Saturday night's performance.

BOWIE, Md., May 30. -- In a stirring duel on the homestretch, the Anall Stable's Larranaga, 4-year-old gelding, held to a precarious lead and beat W. R. Coe's Osculator by a head to win the first running of the Memorial Day Handicap at Bowie today.
WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The merits of Lewis W. Douglas for Secretary of the Treasury, should William H. Woodin resign, were debated in the Senate today as an aftermath of the Morgan inquiry.

Although the chemical industry is reluctant to accept some features of the Federal program for industrial recovery, that industry is prepared to go forward promptly with any plan Congress may adopt, it is declared editorially in the June issue of Industrial and Engineering Chemistry.
Security and commodity exchanges will reopsn this morning after having been closed yesterday for the holiday.

NORWICH, Conn., May 30. -- Setting a blazing pace from the start, Paul F. Mundy of the Philadelphia Nativity Catholic Club won the National A.A.U. 15-kilometer championship run at the Norwich Fair Grounds half-mile track today. A capacity crowd of more than 8,000 saw the 22-year-old national ten-mile titleholder cover the distance in 48:42.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- An effort to avert further differences between Senator Glass and his fellow-members on the Senate Banking and Currency Committee during open hearings in the banking investigations was made today by Chairman Fletcher.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The make-up of the American delegation to the World Economic Conference at London was made public at tha White House tonight, with announcement that Senator Couzens, Republican, of Michigan, and Ralph W. Morrison, Democrat, of San Antonio, had accepted appointment as delegates.
Numerous apartment leases for next Fall, in addition to rentals for immediate occupancy, were reported yesterday. The listings included the following:

SPARTA, N.J., May 30. -- Leading all the way, Charley Cabot of New Haven won the Class Frace, feature event of the opening outboard motor-boat regatta of the season for North Jersey lakes on Lake Mohawk today.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. J. Lorimer Worden are at the Pierre to remain until they sail for Europe early in August.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Senator Bone, Democrat of Washington, called upon J.P. Morgan Co. from the Senate floor today to exchange its government bonds for new obligations bearing a lower rate of interest, as a patriotic duty.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The White House refused to concede publicly today that there had been any definite program adopted by President Roosevelt for dealing with the war debt problem, and continued to keep the administration's plans secret.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the present world-wide activity in the promotion of international amity and of President Roosevelt's splendid efforts in that direction, it may appear superfluous or even presumptuous for any mere layman to stress the necessity for it, particularly when the nations I have in mind, the United States and Canada, are probably the two most friendly neighbors on any of the continents.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP). -- An announcement that the administration was preparing to announce increases in compensation to veterans with service-connected disabilities failed to stem a bi-partisan attack in the Senate today.

LONDON, May 30. -- Although London has been advised that the text of the four-power pact will be initialed in Rome tomorrow, it is now more than doubtful whether the actual instrument making it binding can be signed in the near future, if at all.

VIENNA, May 30. -- The question of governmental subsidies for shipping caused a sharp divergence of opinion between United States and British delegates before the transportation committee of the International Chamber of Commerce here today.

LONDON, May 30. -- With Wall Street closed for the Memorial holiday and with the Epsom racing and the near approach of the Whitsun holidays and the economic conference, the stock markets today were irregular, with less activity than yesterday.

TORONTO, May 30. -- J. E. Smallman's speedy 3-year-old daughter of Morvich, Heart Break, responded determinedly under a hard drive in the closing furlong to win by a neck from H. Dirks's Candy Pot at Thorncliffe today. Golden Spur was third in a field of eight.
LONDON, May 30. -- Robert W. Bingham, United States Ambassador, in an address to the Pilgrims tonight, emphasized the recovery in the United States since the inauguration of President Roosevelt.
DETROIT, May 30 (AP). -- The Tigers and Browns broke even in their double-header today, the former winning the first game, 8 to 6. and the nightcap going to the Browns, 3 to 1.

The setting up by the government of public debt adjustment agencies, coupled with regulation of future obligations, as measures for the solution of the nation's debt problems has been recommended by the Twentieth Century Fund. The measures were urged in the final report on the internal debts of the United States prepared by a group or economists under the auspices of the fund and published yesterday in book form by the Macminan Company.
DEVON, Pa., May 30. -- King Vulture, chestnut gelding owned by R. R. M. Carpenter's Dilwyne Farms of Montchanin, Del., was today crowned champion hunter at the close of the Devon Horse Show.

Another Whitney victory was scored in the historic Withers when C.V. Whitney's The Darb, bearing the Eton blue jacket and brown cap made famous by two earlier generations, stepped home first yesterday at Bclmont Park in a field of ten of the best three-year-olds which could be mustered.

Harlem's most zealous worshipers stormed the doors of the Salem Methodist Episcopal Church at Seventh Avenue and 129th Street yesterday in a frantic effort to witness the funeral of their favorite evangelist. Thousands had filed past the coffin in silent tribute the day before.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 30. -- Before a holiday crowd of 3,500 Holy Cross defeated Boston College today by 15 to 1. The game was played in showers.

It is no mere coincidence that, while all the counties in, the Greater City have been preyed upon by racketeers, convictions are more frequent in the Bronx. The Bronx District Attorneys have been vigilant day and night in the pursuit of these gentry, and have built up a system which makes it more difficult for them to escape.

IRVINGTON, N.J., May 30. -- Bicycle riding returned to favor here today when 150 men bent their backs over the handlebars and raced 20.4 miles over rain-drenched pavements on the first Irvington-Maplewood-Millburn bicycle derby in twenty-five years.

Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, was 77 years old yesterday. He observed the anniversary of his birthday in his usual manner, going about his parochial duties, refusing to be interviewed, and discouraging any sort of official celebration by friends or relatives.

BUFFALO, May 30. -- Delegates to the convention of the State Luther League opened their final session today with a dawn patriotic service at McKinley Monument. Edward G. Hildebrand presided and the Rev. Rudolph Schulz of Toledo gave an address.

The police cannot end racketeering without the District Attorney's office directing the work, Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin declares in an article to be published in The Panel, publication of the Association of Grand Jurors of New York County.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 30. -- Cornell vanquished Syracuse in baseball today, 9-2, on nine hits and six Orange errors. It was the Ithacans' second victory over the Orange and it left them undefeated in Central New York competition with Syracuse and Colgate.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 30. -- Eighty persons attended today the annual Memorial Day luncheon at the Lenox Club, which always is the opening event of the season there. Those who had guests included Mrs. A. Newbold Morris, Mrs. John C. Hughes Jr., Mrs. George E. Turnure, Mrs. David T. Dana, Mrs. Henry Hollister Pease, Mrs. R. Jay Flick, Mrs. Carl A. De Gersdorff and Giraud Foster, president of the club.

In the report of the majority of the Banking and Currency Committee of the House, supporting repudiation of what Mr. ROOSEVELT had called the "covenant" to pay the interest on Federal bonds in gold, it is stated that "the Government cannot, by contract or otherwise, divest itself of its sovereign power."

LOS ANGELES, May 30 (AP). -- Still dazed over the startling one-round knockout which swept the world's welterweight crown from his rugged brow, Young Corbett 3d pleaded today for a return match with Jimmy McLarnin, his conqueror.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Outriding a number of things, including a rainstorm, the Yankees triumphed over Washington's pennant aspirants today, 3 to 2, while 15,000 well soaked enthusiasts groaned in unison.

WHITE PLAINS, May 30. -- A future for America in which all classes will cooperate to obtain health, happiness and economic security for every one was outlined in a Memorial Day address in the County Centre here this afternoon by State Senator Seabury C. Mastick.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is something more amusing than flattering to national pride in the government's program of arranging reciprocity trade agreements with other nations. It is apparently assumed that while selling to others is most desirable, buying of them is at best a disagreeable necessity which, if possible, should be avoided.

LANSING, Kan., May 30 (AP) -- Two 17-year-old girls and an invalid mother, kidnapped on their way to decorate a soldier's grave, were held as hostages tonight by one group of the fleeing convicts who escaped from Kansas penitentiary this morning.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- An assertion that the Roosevelt administration, guided by the "brain trust," was "endeavoring to force socialism upon the American people under the guise of industrial democracy" was made by Senator Hatfield, chairman of the Republican Senatorial campaign committee, in a Senate speech this afternoon.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 30. -- The Chilean Government, in contrast with the Argentine conception of neutrality, has decided to leave open to Bolivian traffic Chilean northern ports on the Pacific Coast, the Foreign Office was informed by the Chilean Minister here today.

CHICAGO, May 30.-- The recent rise in stocks has increased the value of market holdings in the estates of four prominent Chicagoans by more than $34,000,000. In two cases at least the increase in values saved the estate from being virtually wiped out by State and Federal inheritance taxes.

MONTREAL. Que., May 30. -- The first report of the Consolidated Paper Corporation, Ltd., and its subsidiaries, which has just gone forward to shareholders, covers the fifteen months from Jan. 1, 1932, when the company came into being, to March 31, last.

LONDON. May 30. -- Robert W. Bingham, United States Ambassador, gave the British people their first taste of the "new deal" tonight with a ringing speech denouncing tariff nationalism and pledging that the American people henceforth would be good neighbors with all the world.

The list of the White Star Olympic, due today from Southampton via Cherbourg, includes Lady Geddes, Mrs. V. Hay, Archdeacon Colston, Snowden A. Fahnestock, Chaffer Khan Djalol and the Misses Marie and Lillian Cadman, daughters of the Rev. S. Parkes Cadman.

ST. LOUIS, May 30 (AP). -- The Cardinals took two close games from Cincinnati today and climbed to within a half game of the league-leading Pirates. St. Louis won the first game, 5 to 4, and the second, 3 to 2.

April was the first month since 1929 in which the farm cash income of the country was greater than that of the corresponding month a year earlier, according to the monthly study by the Corn Industries Research Foundation and the State Street Research Management Corporation.

EPSOM DOWNS, England, May 30. -- Tomorrow's great race is regarded as one of the most open in many years for the reason that no horses of outstanding merit are among the twenty-four entries. Three American-owned horses will compete in the Derby, the world's flat-racing classic, and their chances tonight seem as good as that of the favorite, Lord Woolavington's Man itoba, or the second choice, Lord Derby's Hyperion.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 30. -- President Angell of Yale said in a Memorial Day address at the university that the Civil War taught this country that peace cannot be purchased by isolation. He asserted that the only adequate memorial to the millions killed in war is peace.

PARIS, May 30. -- Premier Daladier tonight brought the budget one stage nearer adoption when in its last night sitting the Chamber voted acceptance of the Senate's text on one of the principal points in dispute, the proposed 5 per cent cut in all governmental expenditures.

Announcement was made yesterday by the New York Telephone Company that under its automatic age limit rule, John S. Kennedy, general secretary of its General Employes' Benefit Committee, which has charge of the pension department as well as of extensive welfare activities, would be retired today.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., May 30. -- The holiday quiet was disturbed here this afternoon when 350 Communists and 75 policemen engaged in a brief but fierce encounter. The battle ended with police uniforms torn, police heads battered, eleven Communists in the police station and five in the hospital, one with a shot in the leg.

A parade ten blocks long wound through Harlem yesterday afternoon with about 6,000 marchers, representing radical and liberal groups, joining in a protest against war. They marched to celebrate the third anniversary of National Youth Day, an observance instituted as a protest against Memorial Day "as fostering the war spirit."

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30. -- Death took the wheel of speeding race cars today as Louis Meyer, 29-year-old driver of Huntington Park, Cal., rode to victory in the 500-mile automobile race over the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, joining rank with Tommy Milton as the only man ever to win the race twice.

Louis Del Gatto, 48 years old, a dealer in cameos who was to go on trial in Kings County Court today for the murder of his wife and five-year-old child, hanged himself in a cell in the Brooklyn City Prison yesterday. He left two notes.

BOSTON, May 30 (AP). -- Bob (Lefty) Grove twice came to the rescue of wilting Philadelphia Athletic pitchers in a double-header with the Boston Red Sox today and as a result the Mackmen won, 7 to 3 and 11 to 8.

Home runs brought joy and then gloom to the Giants and 15.000 intrepid baseball fans yesterday at the Polo Grounds, where the clan of Terry divided a holiday double-header with Max Carey's Brooklyn Dodgers.

TAMPA, Fla., May 31 (AP) -- Barron G. Collier, head of the organization which controls advertising on nearly all subway, elevated and surface car lines of the country, filed in the Federal Court today a petition under a recent act of Congress, requesting an extension of time for payment of his personal obligations.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Representative Byrns of Tennessee, Democratic leader in the House, called on Representative McFadden today to retract his statement on the floor of the House Monday that the gold clause repeal resolution was the work of "Jewish international money-changers."

Bonds called for payment last month before their maturity dates showed a sharp decline from the total in April, but were slightly abovo May, 1932. In all, bonds for $17,520,000 were called, compared with $65,341,000 in the previous month and $15,904,000 in May a year ago.

EPSOM DOWNS, England, May 31 -- Lord Derby's Hyperion, made a 6-1 last-minute favorite despite his short legs, ran away with the Derby in record time today in one of the most decisive victories ever scored in the history of the course.

Search and pursuit by airplane yesterday resulted in the recovery of a 42-foot cabin cruiser that disappeared Sunday from Its mooring off the New Brunswick (N.J.) Yacht Club. The discovery, accomplished by a private plane and a pursuit plane, took place in an inlet off Broad Channel, Jamaica Bay.
The last day for the use of 1932-33 automobile driving licenses brought many thousands of late applicants to the fourteen offices of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles in the city yesterday.

The legality of the Penn Southern Power Company, which was created on May 4 by order of Irwin Kurtz, Federal bankruptcy referee, to hold five of the operating-companies in the Eastern Insull group for the benefit of creditors, was questioned here yesterday by Federal District Judge Alfred C. Coxe.

Dividend announcements in May gave indications of an ending to the long series of monthly curtailments in payments to shareholders by corporations. Payments declared exceeded those of April, and special declarations, such as increases in dividend rates and resumed payments, increased in number over the previous month and a year ago, together with a drop in the number of issues on which payments - were reduced and omitted, compared with April last and May, 1932.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 31 -- With George T. Dunlap Jr., last year's winner, now on his way to England to compete in the British tourneys, the Long Island amateur golf championship, which starts tomorrow at the Garden City Country Club, will be pretty much of an open affair.

The Rev. Dr. Robert A. Ashworth, who was editor of The Baptist, which recently merged with The Christian Century, has been appointed educational secretary of the National Conference of Jews and Christians, with headquarters at 289 Fourth Avenue.

BERLIN, May 31 -- The German delegation to the World Economic Conference will include, in addition to Hjalmar Schacht, President of the Reichsbank, and Dr. Alfred Hugenberg, Minister of Economy; Count Lutz von Schwerin-Krosigk, Minister of Finance; Dr. Erwin Ritter, economic expert of the Foreign Office, and Dr. Otto Wagner, Nazi Federal Commissar for Economics.

A recent Blue Book dealing with decentralization of certain public services in the Federated Malay States is the work of General Sir SAMUEL WILSON. Permanent Under-Secretary of State for the Colonies, he spent several months in Malaya studying a perfect tangle of governmental functions.

Negotiations are pending for the completion of Hampshire House, the thirty-seven-story apartment house and hotel at 150 Central Park South, which was abandoned by the builders in 1931 and since that time has been boarded up and left to the mercy of the elements.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- After weeks of discussion with his advisers regarding government reorganization, President Roosevelt has decided that the sweeping program originally contemplated must be postponed indefinitely.

PASADENA, Cal., May 31-- Professor Alexander Goetz of the California Institute of Technology has devised a method of obtaining a temperature within four degrees of absolute zero on the centigrade scale.
Speyer Co. and the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation will pay today coupons of the HamburgAmerican Line first-mortgage 6 1/2 per cent marine equipment serial gold bonds.

An application, for permission to purchase all the preferred stock of the East Side Omnibus Corporation at par from $550,000 was filed with the Transit Commission yesterday by the Mack Truck Company. The request was set down for public hearing June 9.

The list of the United States liner Washington, due today from the Channel ports on the return trip of her maiden voyage, includes Nicholas Roosevelt, retiring United States Minister to Hungary; Roger C. Treadwell, United States Consul General at Stockholm, and Mrs. Treadwell; Lee Morse, United States commercial attache at Riga; L.L. Smith, American Consul at Prague; T.V. O'Connor, former head of the United States Shipping Board, and Mrs. O'Connor, and:

NEWARK, N.J., May 31 -- A loan of $3,500,000 will be sought by this city from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to complete the city railway now under construction in the old Morris Canal bed. A resolution authorizing Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein to make the application was passed by the City Commission today.

Reports to date indicate that gross revenue of all Class I railroads in April showed, with one exception, the least loss percentage of decline on an annual basis for any month since May, 1930. Operating revenues for April were estimated at 5226,500,000, against $267,816,000 in April, 1932, a decline of 15.4 per cent.

Gold movements in May were reduced to a minimum, the net change having been a grain of $710,200 in the holdings of the United States. The additional metal came from Latin America and China and through a reduction in earmarked gold not shipped abroad. The upturn compared with one of $21.938,000 in April and a loss of $221,262,300 in May, 1932.

After one witness had testified yesterday at the trial of David Dubin, president of the recently revived Cloak and Dress CoveredButton Manufacturers Association, and Philip L. Derketsch, the general manager, on coercion and conspiracy indictments, Derketsch entered a guilty plea.
NEW YORK. Brig. Gen. Cornelius Vanderbilt and his daughter, Mrs. Henry G. Davis, returned yesterday from a Southern cruise.

LONDON, May 31. -- The departure of the United States delegation to the economic conference here was taken by The London Times tonight as occasion to recall that the war debts would continue to be, as they were described by the preparatory committee, "an insuperable barrier to economic and financial reconstruction."

BERLIN, May 31 -- Faced with the prospect of a serious schism within the German Protestant Church over the election of the Rev. Dr. Friedrich von Bodelschwingh to the office of Reich Bishop, both the regular church authorities and the "German Christians" were putting out feelers toward a compromise today.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Opposi- tion to the gasoline tax increase from 1 to 1 3/4 cents to help finance the $3,300,000,000 public works sec- tion of the Recovery Bill was laid before the Finance Committee to- day by F.B. Dow for the American Petroleum Institute and allied organizations.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- A storm of protest over the proposed cuts in veterans' compensation under the Economy Act broke in the Senate today, with Republicans and Democrats participating. At the end of the debate for the day, however, administration leaders were confident that no material danger threatens the readjustment power granted to President Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 27:

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month passed the 100,000,000-share mark for the seventh time in the history of the Exchange. Operations were the heaviest since April, 1930, when sales totaled 111,041,000 shares. The record was established in October, 1929, when sales amounted to 141,668,410 shares.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An editorial in THE TIMES of May 26 compares that part of our Income Tax Law under which the difference between capital gains and losses is algebraically added to and made a part of income, as defined by the law, with the English law, that does not include capital gains and losses, much to the disparagement of the American law.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his article "Divergent Theories of Our Government," published in THE TIMES, Charles Hall Davis expresses the view that certain concepts of the present administration embodied in legislation, enacted or proposed, smack of socialism, and are not in conformity with the basic principles of our national government.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Not being able, for economic reasons, to celebrate Memorial Day as I should like, that is, journey to a little cemetery in Rhode Island and decorate the grave of a deceased Civil War veteran -- my father -- I have instead gone to Riverside Drive to see the parade of a fragment of the Grand Army of the Republic.

The greater part of the assets of Continental Shares, Inc., a huge inestment trust, will be sold at aucion here on June 12 by the Chasa National Bank. These assets had seen deposited as collateral for heavy loans made to the trust In 1931 when the financial empire created by Cyrus B. Eaton, sponsor of the trust, began to, collapse.

What is believed to be a new type of bacteriophage (bacteria-eater) more powerful than any of its kind hitherto found has been discovered at the Aquarium at Battery Park, it was learned yesterday through C.W. Coates, curator of tropical fishes at that institution.
Purchase of two Jersey City apartment houses featured the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

AUTEUIL, France, May 31 -- The only American threat to the men's singles title in the French hard court tennis championships was removed today with the defeat Frank Shields, United States Davis Cup player in 1931 and 1932.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- George H. Howard, president of the United Corporation and of the New York United Corporation, who was on the stand when the Senate Banking and Currency Subcommittees adjourned last Friday, was the first witness when the subcommittee resumed at 11 o'clock this morning.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The War De- partment issued the following orders today:

WORCESTER, England, May 31 (Canadian Press) -- The West Indies ended the first innings of their cricket match against Worcestershire today with a score of 239 and the home team had 58 for loss of four wickets at the close of play.

The rise of prices since early March has been highly selective. There is no evidence of an automatic readjustment all along the line, offsetting depreciation of the dollar in terms of currencies still on gold. On the contrary, some groups of products have soared in value, others have stood practically stationary, still others have actually declined.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The following is the text of an agreement between the General Electric Company and J.P. Morgan Co., on the sale of holdings in the Mohawk Power Corporation to the Morgan firm at $12.000,000 below the market price:

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Indications of widespread improvement in production, sales and employment of manufacturing industries, particularly those producing consumer goods, were contained in a majority of replies from twentyfour national trade associations to a request from Secretary Roper for such information.
Nearly $1,000,000 goes to charities from the estate of Maude Aguilar Leland, the appraisal disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- A contest between powerful elements in the major political parties for control of The Washington Post is rumored here on the eve of the sale of the paper at public auction.

MOSCOW, May 31 (AP) -- The Foreign Office made public today an exchange of notes between the Japanese and Soviet Governments in which the former denied responsibility for reported "unfriendly actions" against the Chinese Eastern Railway.

After adjusting their prices earlier in the day to the higher quotations which prevailed in the outside markets on the Memorial Day holiday, securities and commodities turned downward in the late dealings yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- President Roosevelt today presented the Collier Trophy for 1932 to Glenn L. Martin, president of the Glenn L. Martin Company, as a tribute to his development of the bi-engined, high-speed, weight-carrying airplane.

The twenty-three-story Hotel Paris at the southeast corner of West End Avenue and Ninety-seventh Street was put up at foreclosure auction yesterday and struck down to the Guardian Life Insurance Company on a bid of $200,000.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 31 -- W. Starling Burgess of Darien, naval architect, has leased part of the old Locomobile Company of Amer- ica works in this city and announced today that production of a new design of a stream-lined auto- mobile with three wheels would be started at once.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Officials of the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission made it plain today that the Securities Control Law was in no way retroactive.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 31 -- The award to Harvard University students of eighteen fellowships and scholarships for graduate study was announced tonight, these totaling $27,600. Most of the fellowships are for study abroad. The awards are as follows:

Money market was quiet all day. Business was light and quotations unchanged for all classifications. Stock Exchange call loans continued at 1 per cent, with a fractional shading from this figure applying on counter trades and Federal funds.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A recent article in THE NEW YORK TIMES, quoting from The Cornell Alumni News, takes exception to published statements that Dr. Felix Adler's retirement from Cornell was not because of his radical views but on account of attacks by The Ithaca Democrat.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Chairman Rayburn of the House Interstate Commerce Committee dropped his opposition today to the "laborsaving" clause of the Senate Railroad Control Bill, and expedition of the bill in the House next week is expected to result.

PARIS, May 31. -- Former Secretary of State Henry L. Stimson has accepted the presidency of the Permanent Conciliation Commission, whose creation was provided for in the Locarno Arbitration Convention.

LONDON, May 31 -- The stock markets were cheerful today with the exception of that for South African gold shares, which closed weak on uncertainty as to the proposals for taxation, which led to profit-taking, coupled with an absence of support.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- No variation from the navy's lighterthan-air experimental policy was occasioned by the loss of the Akron, Rear Admiral George R. Marvell, chairman of the Naval General Advisory Board, indicated today to the joint Congressional Committee studying the disaster.

The past month in the New York money market was marked by a moderately large supply of funds and a fairly substantial expansion in the loans and investments of the principal banks, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reports in its monthly review.

The Health Department ban against the retail sale of loose milk in New York City, which affects about 40,000 establishments, became effective at midnight last night. Health Commissioner Wynne said that virtually all milk dealers had announced their readiness to comply with the regulations.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., May 31 -- Being an involuntary guest on a wild ride over unpaved country roads with five convicts on their escape from the penitentiary is not exactly the experience I would choose for a holiday.

In The Manchester Guardian is an account of Dr. W.B. HICKS'S "The School in English and German Fiction." One needn't bother about the German secondary school. Like all other German institutions it will be remodeled to conform to the Hitler-Goering-Goebbels fictions of Nordic enlightenment.

The reduction of incomes of officers and men of the army and navy was blamed yesterday for financial difficulties which caused the Army and Navy Club, one of the oldest military clubs in the nation, to be thrown into bankruptcy.

The Royal Dutch Company for the Working of Petroleum Wells in the Netherlands Indies reported yesterday for 1932 a net income of 28,303,691 florins after expenses, taxes, interest and other charges. This was equivalent, after dividends on the 4 per cent preferred stock, to 5-61 per cent on 503,624,000 florins of ordinary stock.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- What was for some weeks underground disturbance in Congress to which the newspapers and the general public paid little attention has come the surface. It is a spreading revolt against the administration of the Economy Act, particularly with ference to veterans disabled in line of duty.

To Wall Street tape-watchers it seemed yesterday that the share market was yielding, with a great show of resistance, to reactionary influences. There must have been a strong temptation to realize profits, in commodities as well as in stocks, but there were indications also of aggressive speculative operations for the decline.
