Suspension of seven students was the aftermath yesterday of Monday's pacifist demonstration at City College. In announcing the suspensions, Dr. Morton Gottschall, acting dean, declared that "many more" were to follow.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 31 (AP) -- Ellsworth Vines, national singles champion, led a field of stars into the quarter-finals of the Dixie invitation tennis tournament today.

LONDON, May 31 -- Members of the House of Commons who do not favor the British reservation at Geneva concerning the employment of air bombers for police purposes on outlying frontiers thought they detected a change in the government's attitude when Stanley Baldwin, Lord President of the Council, answered a series of questions on the subject in the House today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 31 -- A petition signed by ninety-three prominent members of the alumni and undergraduate bodies of Harvard to retain Edward A. Wachter as sculling coach was sent to William J. Bingbam, Harvard's athletic director, today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Deep-sea fishing for sunken treasure seems invariably to breed and perpetuate romantic legend. One rarely sees newspaper mention of the diving operations upon the wreck of the steamship Merida off the Virginia Capes that does not refer to the $5,000,000 treasure, the "crown jewels of the Empress Carlotta of Mexico," or to the "millions of the Madero family" that are reputed to be in the craft's hull.

The Chase Harris Forbes Corporation, in a letter dated May 27, advises holders of debentures of the Associated Gas and Electric Company originally acquired through it or its predecssor, Harris, Forbes Co., not to deposit their securities at this time under the company's recent offer of an exchange.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 31 -- With graduation exercises to be held tomorrow, a large number of visitous invaded Annapolis today, attending the farewell ball in the evening.

Brooklyn Police Headquarters received a telephone call last night from A. Coukter, Director of Parole at the Western Penitentiary, Pittsburgh, who said he had just received a telephone call from one of two life-term convicts who escaped from that institution on April 27.
CHICAGO, May 31 -- Apprentice Jockey Jack Westrope, 16-year-old rider from Montana, stole the show at Washington Park today, booting home five mounts, three of them in succession.

Russell T. Sherwood, who fled when the Hofstadter committee sought him for an explanation of former Mayor "Walker's financial affairs, is ready to end the game of hide and seek that he has played for twenty-one months, according to a copyrighted story published by The New York American this morning.

Commodity futures moved erratically in trading on local exchanges yesterday. For the most part opening prices represented unusually heavy advances over Monday's close and later heavy profittaking substantially reduced the gains and in some cases created losses.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Exports declined in April to twentytwo of the forty foreign markets of this country and with a combined value of $105,063,412 were about $3,000,000 less than for the preceding month, according to an analysis given out today by the Commerce Department.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Following are replies received by the commerce Department from business associations and trade groups throughout the country in reply to the questionnaire from Secretary Roper on general business conditions:

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey is expected to launch a movement toward higher gasoline prices in the next day or two with the posting of an increase of 3 1/2 cents a gallon at Newark, N.J. The new price will be 16.4 cents a gallon, with a discount of 2 cents a gallon offered for cash.

With operations in the steel industry averaging 41 per cent of the ingot capacity of the mills, compared with 38 per cent a week ago, and an increasing demand, The Iron Age remarks in its weekly review, the industry is rapidly being established on the "firm footing of a sellers' market."

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- A statement that the select lists of J.P. Morgan Co. security holders represented participating underwriters with the Morgan firm and were chosen because they were able to take the risk, was made today before the Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee by George Whitney, Morgan partner.

PARIS, May 31. -- The growing rift between France and Poland received a strong fillip today when from secret sources the French authorities received a report, which they consider reliable, of a Hitlerite plot involving Polish aid.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Democratic leaders began today to put on pressure for quick action on President Roosevelt's National Industry Recovery Bill in the hope of getting it on the statute books before the growing feud between manufacturers and labor upsets the whole plan.

LONDON, May 31 (AP) -- Instructions were received from Sydney today by the Australian delegation at the International Wheat Conference that Australia would not participate in an agreement to limit wheat acreage. The stand failed, however, to disturb the hopeful attitude of the American delegation, and the conference set its advisers to work on a draft program.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Stockholders in the United Corporation, organized by J.P. Morgan Co., who appeared on the select list of those favored by the bankers were named in the record of the Senate investigation today by Ferdinand Pecora, counsel for the Banking and Currency Subcommittee, as follows:

CHICAGO, May 31 -- The wheat market lacked stimulation today, and with favorable weather for the new crops and expectations that the private estimates tomorrow will make a good showing, many local bulls went out of their holdings on the Board of Trade.

Holiday Cut Buyers' Total. Due to the holiday the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended Tuesday showed a large drop in comparison with the figures of the preceding week. However, the total was slightly above the number visiting the market during the same period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

The sale of 3.2 beer and wine became illegal last midnight in about 20,000 lunch rooms, coffee shops, sandwich stands and other places in the State. A ruling outlawing such sales was made public simultaneously at the local and Albany offices of the State Alcoholic Beverge Control Board.

McALESTER, Okla., May 31 (AP) Two prisoners serving life sentences for murder escaped from the Oklahoma penitentiary here late today after kidnapping Tom Baskin, a guard. Baskin later was thrown from the automobile. He was not seriously injured.

David M. Milton, son-in-law of John D. Rockefeller Jr., has extended his interests in the investment-trust field, which he recently entered, by acquiring control of the Equity Corporation from Wallace Groves. Net assets of Equity are about $7,000,000.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, will speak at the commencement exercises of the School of Nursing of the Presbyterian Hospital this afternoon in the garden adjoining the school, at 622 West 168th Street.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- A running fire of description of important world developments went out tonight from the Navy Department through its powerful transmitters for the benefit of American delegates to the London Economic Conference aboard the President Roosevelt.

Sharp increases in the number of licensed fresh-water anglers are noted in several Eastern States, according to latest reports. Maryland, New Jersey and Pennsylvania are among the States which have found their revenues picking up as a result of increased interest and activity among fishermen.

Demonstrations staged by Communists and sympathizers at homerelief stations yesterday, calling for more adequate unemployment relief, culminated in a visit to City Hall of thirty men and women, who presented their grievances to Mayor O'Brien.

The inclusion of new provisions in the covenant of the League of Nations and in the terms of the Kellogg-Briand peace pact, which would "outlaw treaty-breaking and economic aggression as instruments of national policy" was urged yesterday by Viscount Kikujiro Ishii, Japan's chief delegate to the World Economic Conference.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 31 (AP) -- Chester S. Ricker, director of timing and scoring of the 500-mile race run yesterday, announced today that a recheck of the times of the leaders in the race sent Lou Moore of Los Angeles into third place and dropped Chester Gardner of Long Beach, Cal., to fourth position.

A field agent of the Internal Revenue Bureau checked and approved Charles E. Mitchell's income tax return for 1929. This was brought out-yesterday at the banker's tax-evasion trial by Max D. Steuer, counsel for the defense, in support of his contention that Mr. Mitchell is now being made the victim of "mob psychology."

BERLIN, May 31. -- Satisfaction carefully restrained for the present, prevails in the Wilhelmstrasse and the press today over the prospects for the immediate signing of the four-power pact in Rome. According to information here the final text is now being drafted.
"Tattle Tales," the revue in which Frank Fay and Barbara Stanwyck have been touring, will begin its Broadway engagement this evening at the Broadhurst Theatre.

The most important lesson of Memorial Day is the one which President ANGELL suggested in his address at Yale University. The daring, courage, endurance, loyalty, love of country and the other patriotic and martial virtues -- among them many of the finest traits of which humanity is capable -- are not to be forgotten or lightly laid aside.

A complete, constructive financial plan for the city is more important than the personality of a Mayoralty candidate, former Representative Fiorello H. La Guardia told a luncheon forum of the Motion Picture Club of New York at 1,560 Broadway, yesterday.
TANGKU, China, May 31 -- A truce formally terminating the Chino-Japanese hostilities in North China was signed at the Japanese barracks in Tangku this morning.
Edwin Markham, poet, described himself in the Supreme Court yesterday as "impecunious" and dependent for his support on an annuity of $500 a month which stopped eight months ago.

Creation of small farm communities to rehabilitate the unemployed in New York was advocated yesterday by Ralph Borsodi, author and economist, at a meeting of the coordinating committee of the Welfare Council of New York City, held in the Federation Building.

VIENNA, May 31. -- In discussion before the congress of the International Chamber of Commerce here today on the possible return of world currencies to the gold standard, Eliot Wadsworth, president of the Boston Chamber of Commerce and former Assistant Secretary of the United States Treasury, said that extravagant expenditure by the governments of almost all nations was one of the principal causes of the depression.

PARIS, Thursday, June 1 -- The Senate passed at 4 o'clock this morning a modified text of a measure to create a French oil monopoly, ending all danger of the Daladier government falling during the bitterly fought and protracted budgetary debate.

The first award of $500 in the architectural competition of the Phelps Stokes Fund for the most practical and attractive design for a modern housing development in a typical New York tenement block was won yesterday by Richard Hutaff of 103 East Eighty-sixth Street and Severin Stockmar of Staten Island.

Despite increased activity in the stock market and improvement in numerous lines of business, lending rates for money in May, both for call and time loans, were lower than in April and a year ago. Demand for credit was not urgent, with the result that rates are now back to where they were in February.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 31 -- The Meadow Brook Hunt, which for fifty-two years has been following the hounds over the north shore country from Little Neck to the Suffolk County line, has been forced, by the march of progress in home and estate development on Long Island, to extend its hunting country into wilder areas.

With the entire world in a "state of bitter economic war" there is the strongest reason for an agreement to lower trade barriers and stabilize currency exchange, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said here yesterday.
Horatios at the Bridge. Senator COUZENS is going to the London Economic Conference as one of our dele gates and says he is in favor of reasonable tariff con cessions.

The dollar recovered in terms of the gold-standard exchanges yesterday but continued to cheapen in terms of sterling, despite the efforts of the official British control to combat the rise in the pound.

BERLIN, May 31 -- The latent conflict between the National Socialists and the Nationalists, between Chancellor Hitler and Dr. Alfred Hugenberg, his Minister of Economics and Agriculture, which has heretofore been fought behind the formidable facade of the Cabinet of national revolution, is developing into open guerrilla warfare between the two parties.

EPSOM DOWNS, England, May 31 (AP) Hyperion's victory in the one and one-half mile test represented a beautiful bit of cooperation between Tommy Weston, up on the winner, and the veteran Steve Donoghue, winner of six Derbies, who got the mount on Thrapston when J.A. Dewar's Lochiel failed to stand training.

PITTSBURGH, May 31 (AP) -- Charlie Root, veteran right-handed pitcher, was effective with men on the bases as the Chicago Cubs made the most of their seven hits to defeat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5 to 1, today.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- President Roosevelt is opposed to large loans by the Federal Government to cities to help them sustain their financial structure and meet maturing obligations.

After nearly five weeks of discussion by representatives of the principal intercoastal steamship lines, new tariffs on freight moving by water between the Atlantic and Pacific Coast ports have been adopted by the United States Intercoastal Conference.

HARRISBURG, Pa., May 31 -- The legislative sweatshop investigating committee decided today to Start its inquiry at once in the eastern part Pennsylvania and will hold its first hearing in Philadelphia Tuesday. All hearings will be open to the press.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Yankees and Senators engaged in a regular Washington merry-goround today, at the conclusion of which each club was exactly where it had started.

A new collective agreement designed to place the cloak and suit industry in New York in the van of those trades preparing to meet the requirements of the National Industrial Recovery Act was presented yesterday to the International Ladies Garment Workers Union by the Merchants Ladies Garment Association.

TORONTO, Ont., May 31 -- J.E. Smallman's consistent filly Boscobel accounted for her first triumph in Canada when she led home the Hastings Stable's Devout by a length in the featured event at Thorncliffe today. T. Donley's Mild was third.

A hearty endorsement of the farm plan of Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace came from London yesterday in a speech by Major Walter Elliott, British Minister of Agriculture, which was broadcast in this country over a network of stations by the National Broadcasting Company.

The public school teachers who participated in a protest demonstration which interrupted a meeting of the Board of Education on May 24 were suspended without pay yesterday by Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools. The teachers will receive a hearing before the board's law committee on June 13.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 31 (AP) -- Mrs. Eugenia Woodward Jelke was found innocent today of infidelity, but because both she and her husband, F. Frazler Jelke, have practiced "extreme cruelty" toward each other, neither may have a divorce.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today dismissed an application of the St. Louis-Kansas City Short Line Railroad Company for approval of a loan of $35,000,000 with which to build a 236-mile line between the two cities.
MOSCOW, May 31 -- B.M. Iofan, the Soviet architect who has been chosen to draft the final design for the Palace of Soviets, said today that the structure would "dwarf Radio City."
Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, appealed yesterday for increased contributions to the school relief fund this month to enable it to continue its work during the Summer.

HAMILTON, N.Y., May 31 -- Colgate atoned for an early season baseball defeat by defeating Cornell today, 2 -- 1. The game was a pitchers' battle between LaFlamme of Colgate and Williams, with the latter losing when his support flagged in the seventh inning and allowed the home team to score its two runs.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 31 (AP) -- Toronto scored five runs off Tony Kaufmann in the ninth after one man was out to beat the Red Wings today in the series' final, 5 to 4. The victory put Toronto back in second place with Rochester dropping down to third.

In the keenest competitive bidding in the municipal bond market in many weeks Rhode Island awarded $3,500,000 bonds yesterday. Seven syndicates submitted sealed tenders, one headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., obtaining the $3,000,000 3 1/2 per cent relief bonds, due on May 15, 1934 to 1938, at 101.15, and another headed by the Chase National Bank the $500,000 4 per cent reformatory bonds, due on May 15, 1883, at 106.84.

Convened in special session yesterday to obtain the public's reaction to proposals for ten-cent tolls on the East River bridges and a five-cent tax on each taxicab ride, the Board of Estimate heard substantial opposition to both.

Methods employed by the Para- mount Publix Corporation in acquiring theatres throughout the country were described yesterday at a bankruptcy hearing before Federal Referee Henry K. Davis at 140 Nassau Street.

The novel which is said to have had the best sale in Europe since the publication of that other German international success, "All Quiet on the Western Front," is "Little Man, What Now?" It is published here today by Simon Schuster.

It cannot be said that President ROOSEVELT'S move to void the gold contract in Government securities has had what the French call "a good press." Naturally, Republican newspapers, like The Hartford Courant, protest that the President "repudiates his words as "surely as he would have the "Government repudiate its obliga"tions to those who invested in its "securities."

"I have, personally, little doubt that biological research will in due course prove a human virgin birth to be possible," writes the modernist Bishop of Birmingham, England, a Cambridge scholar who has studied the universe through telescopes and with far ranging mathematical formulae, and is at home in most fields of modern science.
City tax collections for the first half of the 1933 levy of $228,000,000 amounted to $95,695,000 at the close of business last Monday evening, Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial disclosed last night.

No material change occurred in May in the small volume of new securities offered to the public in the New York market. Offerings, in the aggregate, were slightly larger than in April, but were less than a third of the total of May a year ago.

The "dangerous effects" on writers which go with the receipt of some $90,000 or more for a bestselling book are discussed by John Erskine, who has written such books himself, in a symposium called "A Century at Progress," edited by Charles A. Beard and published today by Harpers.

Big Bill Tilden said yesterday that he thinks the United States will be beaten again in the battle for the Davis Cup. The fact that the chairman of the American Davis Cup committee, Bernon S. Prentice, declined to have Tilden and his professional partner, Bruce Barnes, work out with the American team in Paris, had no bearing on his deduction. Tilden said.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 1 -- Though the Foreign Office has said Chinese commanders would be expected to suppress the anti-Japanese boycott, the Japanese are not linking the present truce signed yesterday with that problem.
LANSING, Kan., May 31 -- The eleven desperadoes who escaped yesterday from the penitentiary here had vanished tonight in the hill country of Northeastern Oklahoma, long an outlaw retreat.

The price of copper continued to rise yesterday as the result of a large demand from wire and brass fabricators and other consumers. Sales were reported at 7 3/4 cents a pound in the morning, or a quarter cent above Monday's price, and in the afternoon, several deals were closed at 7 7/8 cents.
Regular Republicans, determined to unseat Samuel S. Koenig as chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, joined last night in a demonstration against his continued leadership.

The Central Railroad of New Jersey will become today the only Class I railroad without a president when R.B. White leaves it to become president of the Western Union Telegraph Company. C.E. Ewing, president of the Reading Company, is slated to succeed Mr. White, but his election awaits the completion of court proceedings in which the Heading is engaged.

All six favorites met defeat at Belmont Park yesterday, including Masked Knight in the featured Bellport Purse, where E.R. Bradley's Brother Joe scored his first victory since overcoming his famous stablemate, Burgoo King, in a prep for the Kentucky Derby of 1932.

PALO ALTO, Cal., May 31 (AP) -- Paul Sexson, secretary to former President Hoover, issued the following statement here today in connection with the mention of Mr. Hoover's name at the Senate committee investigation of J.P. Morgan Co.:
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 31 (AP) -- The Bisons made it three out of four over the Royals for the present series and six out of seven this season by taking the final engagement today, 7 to 4.
The text of the address of Viscount Kikujiro Ishii at the Lawyers Club yesterday follows:

Advances in prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange carried March and May contracts above the 10cent level and into new high ground for the season. The rise of 135 points in a week attracted active profit-taking, and a later setback of 25 points left quotations 2 to 7 points higher than on Monday.

PARIS, May 31 -- Jesse Isidor Straus, the new United States Ambassador to France, arrived here today accompanied by his wife. His welcome, both from French officialdom and the American colony, was simple but hearty, for in all minds there was the realization that not since the war has any American Ambassador commenced his duties here in such a critical period for Franco-American relations.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 31 -- Senior Week activities at New Jersey College for Women began tonight when the graduating class held their annual dinner and theatre party, with Doris W. Potter of Newark as chairman. The seniors attended a performance of "Best Sellers" at the Morosco Theatre, in New York.

Paterson, N.J. A new issue of $475,000 city of Paterson (N.J.) 6 par cent water bonds, due on June 1, 1935 to 1973, will be placed on the market today by B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc. The bonds, which are direct obligations of the city and a first charge on the water revenues, will be priced to yield 5.75 per cent.
CHICAGO, May 31 -- Dry goods store executives representing 3,800 leading department and specialty stores in the United States and Canada opened a conference in the Palmer House today.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The administration Farm Credit Bill, designed to supply credit for agricultural production and marketing, was passed unanimously by the House this afternoon.

PARIS, May 31 -- Interest due tomorrow on the French 7 1/2 and 7 per cent bonds issued in the United States in 1921 and 1924 will be paid at the Paris branch of Morgan Co. according to the gold value of the dollar, it was announced today by the French Ministry of Finance. The rate of payment will be 25.52 francs to the dollar.

GENEVA, May 31 -- Norman H. Davis of the United States will leave here tomorrow night for Paris for important disarmament conversations with the French Government and Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, if the latter can arrange to be present.

CHICAGO, June 1 (AP). -- The Cardinals mounted to first place in the National League today on the strength of a fine job of pitching by Dizzy Dean, who held the Cubs to six hits, scoring a 6-to-l triumph.

In a gay and often reckless fashion, "Cocktail Hour," the present film feature at the Radio City Music Hall, narrates the experiences of a successful young woman artist who refuses to he bound by ordinary social conventions. She Is determined, or, rather, obstinate, and her handsome suitor is unable to make her change her mind.

Bonds on the New York Stock Exchange were moderately strong yesterday, with domestic corporation issues generally up for the day and foreign loans irregularly higher. United States Government bonds were irregular, four of the eleven active issues mounting 1-32 to 4-32 point, three holding unchanged and four easing 1-32 to 4-32 point.

After the "corrective reaction" of Wednesday, the market had yesterday what, from the Wall Street viewpoint, was considered a satisfactory rebound. Such influences as were at work were largely favorable. They included the better feeling in speculative circles that resulted from business and industrial expansion, but also the depressing effect of the belief that inflation prospects have been exaggerated.

This week's Federal Reserve reports, published yesterday, reveal a continuance of the favorable trend in the position of the Federal Reserve Banks and their members, a further development of the system's credit-expansion program and a substantial increase in the deposits and earning assets of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City.
LONDON, June 1 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

Babe Ruth autographed dozens of baseballs and acted as auctioneer for the sale of Dobbin Thrift, a riding horse, in the street in front of Thrift House, 9 West Fiftyseventh Street, late yesterday afternoon. When he arrived at 5:30 scores of men and women were storming the charity shop, looking for bargains at the special sale, which had begun at 5.
To the Editor of The New York Times: "The railways can be made the most effective force in the reconstruction of our country," says Lindsay Russell in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- In a dramatic appeal for "practical" consideration of the war debts, Senator Tydings of Maryland advocated today a "lump sum" settlement of the war debts for whatever can be obtained. He Spoke in reply to Senator Robinson of Indiana.

In the last month, for the first time in nearly four years, the volume of trade and industrial production exceeded that of the same month in the previous year, the National City Bank reports in its current bulletin. In this development, combined with the improved international outlook and the more favorable agricultural prospects, both schools of economic thought may find ground for encouragement and for an optimistic attitude, the bank says.
Long Island waters now are beginning to give up other salt water species besides weakfish and pollack. The latter have been running for some time off Montauk and have provided excellent sport.

TRENTON, N.J., June 1. -- In the face of a threat by one of the only two "dry" delegates to contest in the courts the validity of the ratifying resolution, New Jersey's constitutional convention put the State on record today for repeal of national prohibition.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- A press agent "stunt" which Senator Fletcher declared a "shame and an outrage" took place just before the beginning of the Senate investigation of J.P. Morgan Co. today, when a circus press agent brought a midget into the crowded room, walked with her up to Mr. Morgan and sat her in his lap.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- A White House conference on the much disputed Glass-Steagall banking legislation was followed late today by a statement from Senator Glass that the Vandenberg amendment, providing immediate insurance for deposits up to $2,500, would remain in the bill.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 1 (AP). -- Ellsworth Vines, Cliff Sutter, George Lott and Sidney Wood Won their way to the semi-finals of the Dixie invitation tennis tournament today.

INDIANAPOLIS. June 1 (AP). -- Louis Meyer of Huntington Park, Cal., today was presented with $18,000 in money, an automobile and a large trophy as rewards for his record-breaking victory in the 500-mile race last Tuesday.

ABOARD S.S. PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, with American delegation to the London Economic Conference, June 1 (AP). -- Hopes for day and night sessions, limitation of speeches and absence of a petty trading spirit in London in the interests of quick, decisive action were emphasized by Secretary of State Hull tonight in outlining aims of the American delegation to the World Economic Conference.

Peter Lazetta, 16 years old, of 167 East 108th Street and three of his friends had planned to spend Saturday at Coney Island. Instead he will appear in Yorkville Court to answer a charge of purse snatching. Lazetta was arraigned yesterday following his arrest in Central Park with three younger boys the night before.

CAMP 4, MOUNT EVEREST, June 1 (by Wireless From Base Camp). -- P. Wyn-Harris and Laurence Wager, who set out to reach the peak of Mount Everest on Tuesday, returned today without injury after a night at Camp 5 (between 25,600 and 25,700 feet by barometer).

HOLLYWOOD, June 1 (AP). -- Two robbers tonight invaded the apartment of Zeppo Marx, film comedian, robbed Mrs. Marx of $30,000 worth of diamonds, bound and gagged a guest, Allan Miller of New York, and a Negro maid and escaped after imprisoning the actor and Mrs. Marx in a clothes closet.

BERLIN, June 1. -- The great economic relief program on which the Hitler Cabinet has been working for weeks, which is designed to lift Germany out of the economic crisis and meet the hopes of the workers the peasants and even the Industrialists who saw their salvation in the coming of the Third Reich was published today.

The eviction of families and placing of their possessions on the sidewalk have been necessary to prove destitution and to arouse the Home Relief Bureau to relieve such suffering, victims of unemployment testified yesterday.

Thursday, Jane 1, 1933. A cut in bill rates, reducing yields on all maturities by %, and an outside market on Stock Exchange collateral at 1/2, lowest in several months, featured. It was the first revision in bill rates since April 24, and the eleventh change since the peak yields were established on March 13, following the bank holiday.

VIENNA. June 1. -- What has seemed to be an attempt to provide international backing for monopolizing official government news has been blocked here at the annual convention of the International Chamber of Commerce, even before it reached the plenary session.

The first of the monthly Index numbers of commodity prices, compiled by Dun's Review, shows increase of 4 3/4 per cent in the average during May. following an average increase of 4 1/4 per cent in April. As compared with Dun's low average of the present year, reached on March 1, the increase during the three succeeding months has been 9 7/8 per cent.

A special orchestral tribute to the memory of James Loeb, founder of the Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music, will open the institute's annual commencement exercises tonight at its building at 120 Claremont Avenue.

HAVANA, June 1. -- President Machado informally discussed tonight the political and economic situation in Cuba and vehemently declared he had no intention of resigning but would continue as President until May 20, 1935, the legal termination of the Presidential period, according to the Constitution.

CHELSEA, Okla., June 1. -- Bank robbery was added today to charges of kidnapping, motor car theft and a slaying piled up against thirteen fugitive convicts who have left trails of terror from two Kansas and Oklahoma penitentiaries.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 1. -- Mrs. Thomas Hucknall, the Connecticut State champion, carried off the principal honors in the one day tourney of the Women's West- Chester and Fairfield Golf Association at the Knollwood Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Mounting protests against proposed heavy reductions in veterans' benefits resulted tonight in tentative acceptance by Senate leaders of an amendment to the Independent Offices Bill limiting to 25 per cent the reduction in benefits paid to any veteran suffering from service-connected disabilities.

During the campaign, and since, Mr. ROOSEVELT seemed to take seriously the Democratic promise, which he made his own, to save at least 25 per cent of the cost of the Federal Government by abolishing useless offices and consolidating departments and bureaus, and so on.

Robert Ross and Edward Choate have leased the theatre and equipment owned by the Theatre Unit, Inc., at Old Silver Beach, West Falmouth, Mass., and will present there, beginning the first week in July, a saries of nine plays, many of which will be try-outs.

TIENTSIN, June 1. -- Chinese troop retirement, specified in the truce signed at Tangku yesterday, was already getting slowly under way today, and the Japanese authorities declared the movement was satisfactory assurance of good faith.

NEWARK, N.J., June 1. -- The Yankees suffered their first shutout since last season when they dropped a 2-to-O decision today to the Newark Bears at Ruppert Stadium in an exhibition game played in the remarkable time of 64 minutes.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Licensed member banks on May 3 numbered 5.478, while there were 1,211 operating before the holiday which have not so far been licensed to resume full banking activities, according to the monthly bulletin of the Federal Reserve Board, issued today.

The board of trustees of Princeton University will hold a special meeting at Princeton this afternoon to elect a president. From reliable sources it was learned yesterday that Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, Professor of Politics at Princeton, is almost certain to be the choice.

Some idea of the rentals paid for good store locations on and near Broadway in the retail shopping area between Thirty-fourth Street and Times Square is given in announcements of two leases yesterday.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey announced yesterday that with a view to raising gasoline prices to normal levels it would make adjustments today in the quotations on the basis of the cargolot price at seaboard. In areas where quotations have been depressed by a price war, particularly in New Jersey, the move will result in an advance of approximately 3 cents a gallon in the retail price.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Democratic leaders were preparing tonight to write a special oil control provision into the National Industrial Recovery Bill, being convinced now that President Roosevelt favored such a step.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Loan authorizations and actual disbursements by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation during April continued to decrease despite the fact that $46,756.501.12 was authorized for conservators and receivers of banks in an effort to free deposits tied up in closed institutions, according to the monthly report made public today by Congress.

The Republican revolt against the domination of their party in this county by Chairman KOENIG has a double motive. An instinct of self-respect impels a demand for more inspiring and successful leadership. In addition, Republicans now rising against Mr. KOENIG'S control of the organization are looking to the welfare of the city.

The Delaware Electric Power Company announced yesterday that arrangements were being made for the acquisition from the United Gas Improvement Company of 75,000 shares of Delaware Power and Light Company stock, in exchange for Delaware Electric Power stock.

BERLIN, June 1. -- The Boerse was firm and active today. Traders responded to the government's 1,000,000,000 marks public works program with purchases which enabled stocks to register gains up to 6 per cent. The biggest gains were scored by the so-called reconstruction securities, those of the iron, coal, machinery, motor and electric industries being among the leaders.

ST. LOUIS, June 1 (AP). -- Wes Ferrell allowed only three hits and the Cleveland Indians defeated the St. Louis Browns in the first game of the series today, 3 to 1. Young Hank McDonald, making his first start for the Browns, pitched creditably, but was outshone by his more experienced rival.
ANNAPOLIS, June 1. -- The text of the address delivered by President Roosevelt today before the graduating class of the Naval Academy teas as follows:

ALBANY, N.Y., June 1 (AP). -- Albany won from Jersey City, 6 to 4, in the opening game of the series today. Masters pitched good ball for the home team after relieving Milstead in the first inning. The hitting of Powell and Leiber and the fielding of Hack featured.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 1. -- Mrs. William V. Hester Jr. of Glen Cove, who ranked in the national first ten as Miss Lilian Scharman, scored an unexpected victory over Miss Alice Francis of East Orange, N.J., today as the trial matches for the Sears Cup intersectional tennis team got under way at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club.

LONDON. June 1. -- In trying to estimate the course of the economic conference, the Midland Bank's monthly review attaches greatest importance to the indications given of the United States policy and as a consequence concludes that it is to the United States the conference will have to look for leadership.

President ROOSEVELT will scarcely agree with Senator LA FOLLETTE that the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York is con trolled by men corrupted with Mor gan money. This institution of his own State, in existence for 150 years, has many times taken action against measures which threatened to derange the monetary system of this country.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The War Department released the following orders today:

To the Editor of The New York Times: According to "Veteran" in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 27, "the Pension Bureau 'in working overtime reviewing them,' as Mr. Bigelow puts it, is throwing out thousands of disability claims without having accorded the veterans time to present evidence."

The last years of the life of Arnold Bennett, when as one of the great forces in English letters he was receiving the homage of younger writers, finding that Bernard Shaw talked too much and trying to "have a scrap" with Virginia Woolf because of "naughty treatment of me in the press," are described in the final volume of "The Journal of Arnold Bennett," published today by Viking.

PARIS, June 1. -- New York's politics was described as "dirty and vile" by former Health Commissioner Louis I. Harris of New York in speaking today at the weekly luncheon of the American Club In Paris.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 1. -- Big Chief, owned by H.F. Millard of Annville, Pa., and Miss Julia B. Whiting's Quicksilver from Middleburg, Va., turned in two perfect performances in the feature $500 jumper stake event on the opening day of the Wilmington Horse Show at Meadows-on-the-Brandywine near here today.
ANTWERP, June 1. -- A tremendous upswing in the diamond trade is reported here, where 4,000 extra cutters are employed today as compared with last week.

The first move in what promises to be a long legal battle to test the State law. restricting the sale of 3.2 per cent beer and wine, wag taken yesterday. It resulted in a court, order requiring the State and City Alcoholic Beverage Control Boards to show cause next Thursday why licenses should not be issued to cigar and stationery stores, barred under the law from dealing in beer and wine.

THE esteemed Will Irwin, who dives into the past or the future with equal facility, has kindly served up an essay on the curve ball, the topic having come into his mind when he read of the recent death of Phoney Ball Martin, who was credited, in some quarters, with being the first man to throw a curve ball in the history of our national pastime. Mr. Irwin writes:

Simon Legree Depression. Another ten days and Congress will adjourn and Eliza Administration will reach the north bank of the Ohio River, in a state of exhaustion, but safe from the baying bloodhounds of Defiation.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 1. -- The Little Entente conference, which ended tonight, decided at its final session to create an economic council composed of three sections, one for each country and each with five members and technical advisers.

GENEVA, June 1. -- Norman H. Davis, leader of the United States delegation to the disarmament conference, "welcomed" proposals for strengthening supervision of disarmament which France submitted to the conference today.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP). -- A two-run uprising in the thirteenth inning broke up a 5-to-5 tie today and gave the Red Sox a 7-to-5 victory over Washington in the first game of their series.

Russell T. Sherwood emerged from hiding yesterday long enough to say that it was his loyalty to former Mayor Walker that caused him to flee from the Hofstadter committee. It was loyalty to himself, he explained, that had brought him back.

To the Editor of The New York Timss: THE NEW YORK TIMES reports on a paper entitled "Facial Deformities and Abnormalities in Their Relationship to Crime," read by Dr. Carlton Simon to the Academy of Medicine.

Bankers and others must change their outlook to fit into the "new America" now emerging, Dr. Dixon Ryan Fox, Professor of History at Columbia, declared last night. He spoke at commencement exercises for 161 graduates of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking at the Brick Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

Arthur J. Hoffman and George Goodman, the accountants who confessed to thefts of $210,000 from Edward Albert Ridley, aged eccentric, pleaded guilty yesterday to three indictments for grand larceny before Judge George L. Donnellan in General Sessions.

President Roosevelt was "respectfully urged" yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York "to refrain, from any act, under the pressure of existing or future emergency, that would tend to impair the present gold standard under which this country has weathered many storms."

In a letter sent yesterday to heads of the operating divisions of the General Motors Corporation, Alfred P. Sloan, president of the company, authorized an increase of 5 per cent in the wages of employes whenever the chief executives of each division should deem such a step advisable.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation's statement of condition as of the close of business April 30 was as follows:

CHICAGO, June 1. -- An assertion tbat deflation of the country's overexpanded business organization was essential for future prosperity was made today by Sidney R. Baer, vice president of Stix, Baer Fuller Company of St. Louis, before the convention here of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

ANNAPOLIS, June 1. -- President Roosevelt told the graduating class of the Naval Academy today to cultivate the friendship of the people with whom they were thrown in the discharge of their duties, and not to set themselves apart "as a clique with different interests and different ideas from those of the rest of the country."

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 1 (AP). -- The Bisons staged their season's record batting spree today by slamming twenty-two hits for thirtyseven bases and defeating the Rochester Red Wings in the opener of the series, 21 to 8.

Major Chester P. Mills, former State Prohibition Administrator, was named yesterday in an indictment handed to Federal Judge Marcus B. Campbell in Brooklyn. Eight other persons were named in the bill.

Raymond S. Richmond announced his resignation yesterday as Republican leader of the Third Assembly District and from the presidency of the Jackson Heights Republican Club. In a letter to W. Kingsland Macy, State chairman, he scored the party leadership in Queens as "too indecisive and ineffective."

Viscount Kikujiro Ishil, member of the Privy Council of Japan and former Ambassador to the United States, will sail for England today on the White Star liner Olympic to represent Japan at the World Economic and Monetary Conference.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Investigation of a contract for the purchase of 200,000 toilet kits for use by members of the Civilian Conservation Corps was authorized by the Senate today.

CHICAGO, June 1 (AP). -- Hal Price Headley's Technique, a candidate for the $25,000 added American Derby Saturday, given a brisk ride by Jack Westrope, won the best event at Washington Park today, leading Sabula over the line by two lengths.

With advocates of extreme inflation again questioning the intentions of the administration, there was no great amount of zeal yesterday behind the speculative movement in stocks and commodities. The share market managed to hold a substantial part of its recovery, but agricultural staples were slightly lower at the close of a day of hesitation.
Following the advance or 135 points in about a week, prices on the Cotton Exchange reacted yesterday and ended with losses of 3 to 9 points.

VICTORIA, B.C., June 1 (Canadian Press). -- The Pacific Science Congress opened here today with 160 of the leading men of sciences from thirty nations bordering on the Pacific in attendance, and more expected.
SHANGHAI, June 1. -- Considerable improvement in the tense relations of Canton and Nanking resulted today from the signing yesterday of the North China armistice.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP). -- John C. Hackett describing himself as former Special Deputy Police Commissioner of New York, called on Senate Banking Committee members today to file charges against Ferdinand Pecora, committee counsel in the investigation of J.P. Morgan Co.

BUENOS AIRES, June 1. -- The diplomatic relations of Argentina and Bolivia are rapidly becoming strained as a result of frequent protests back and forth. Argentina protested vigorously today on the aerial bombardment of Puerto Casado, Paraguay, several weeks ago.
Roger Q. Williams who flew with Captain Lewis A. Yancey, from Maine to Spain and then to Rome in 1929, revealed yesterday that he planned a round-trip transatlantic flight in July.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- A preferred list of those who were offered Niagara Hudson Power Corporation units was revealed late today when introduced in the record of the Morgan Co. investigation by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee as follows:

The Southern Pacific Company signed yesterday a contract with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation that called for drastic reductions in the salaries of the railroad's officials in return for a loan of $23,200,000. The government decreed the salary adjustments as part of a new rule which it is following in extending help to needy corporations.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- While many professional operators are inclined to view wheat's price bearishly, because of excellent weather for the American and Canadian Spring grain crops, they do not press the selling side hard. An early break today carried prices off 1 3/4 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 1. -- Orders have been issued to release medical supplies for the Bolivian Army which were stopped at the Argentine border town of Pocitos two days ago, according to the Argentine Minister here.

Utica. N.Y. Darby Co. led a field of eight bidders yesterday, winning the award of a new Issue of $866.314 city of Utica (N.Y.) refunding bonds, due on May 15, 1934 to 1953. The price named was 100.24 for the bonds as 4.40s.

Nicholas Roosevelt, retiring United States Minister to Hungary, returned yesterday on the liner Wash ington of the United States Lines Conditions in Central Europe were improving slightly, he said, but the future depended on agreements at the World Economic and Monetary Conference in London this month.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- Arguments were begun today on the defense motion to quash the indictments against nineteen defendants charged with using the mails to defraud in connection with the collapse of the Corporation Securities Company of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Gradual redistribution of the world's gold through the cooperation of central banks and a world-wide 25 per cent coverage for currency in circulation probably will be proposed at the London Economic Conference by the United States delegates, it was revealed here today.

Colonel George A. Nugent of the General Staff Corps of the Army, wartime Brigadier General and recently commander of the Harbor Defenses of Long Island Sound, has been appointed Chief of Staff of the Second Corps Area on the staff of Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 31. unless otherwise specified:

The doctrine that the King can do no wrong was long ago accepted even by democracies. This explains why so much of the time of Congress is taken up with the claims of individuals who otherwise would have no redress for injury.

One of the economies proposed in Washington is abolition of the foreign service of the Department of Agriculture, now costing $350,000 a year. Secretary WALLACE has indicated opposition to this plan. He is aware of the large interest of American agriculture in foreign markets.

PARIS, June 1. -- For the second time within a year Miss Elinor Morse Ryan, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph, J. Ryan of New York and granddaughter of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan, financier, has changed her mind about getting married, it was learned today.
Dr. John L. Elliott was elected senior leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture at a special meeting of the members last night in the society meeting house, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 1. -- Efforts to save Continental Shares, Inc., from the auction block are being considered by stockholders here. They may ask the courts to compel the Chase National Bank of New York to defer its proposed date of the collateral that it holds to satisfy a loan approximating $27,000,000 made to the huge investment company.

Langdon W. Post, recently appointed Assistant Federal Relief Administrator by President Roosevelt, flew from Washington yesterday and started an anti-Tammany Democratic organization of friends and workers, which is expected to grow into a city-wide body to aid in the fusion campaign.

AUTEUIL, France, June 1. -- With Henri Cochet, French Davis Cup ace, leading the way in the defense of his singles title, the field in the French hard-court tennis championships today was narrowed to eight players in each of the men's and women's divisions of play.

Opposition to a ten-cent toll on the city bridges developed yesterday in an executive meeting of the Board of Estimate. Mayor O'Brien called the meeting to consider the proposal for tolls and the other means of raising new revenues suggested to the board on Wednesday.
The Scudder School, 66 Fifth Avenue, will hold its annual commencement this morning in the First Presbyterian Church. Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street. Sixty-four young women will receive diplomas.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Deluged with requests from all parts of the country as to the effective dates of the separate sections of the securities control law, the Federal Trade Commission made it plain today that all sections except those pertaining to the registration of issues with the commission went into effect with the signing of the measure by the President on Saturday.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 1. -- The combination of wind and kneehigh rough proved too much for the majority of the seventy-seven golfers who teed off in the qualifying round of the annual Long Island amateur championship at the Garden City Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- It became evident today, during hours of weary examination, that Ferdinand Pecora, counsel for the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, which is investigating J.P. Morgan Co., is trying to show that in several transactions connected with the formation of the United Corporation attempts were made to avoid payment of income tax by taking advantage of the weakness of the present law.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Overriding opposition by Senators Hastings, Couzens and other Republicans, the Democratic majority in the Senate confirmed Guy T. Helvering of Kansas as Internal Revenue Commissioner today by a vote of 56 to 21.
PARIS, June 1 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Two suspicious fires occurred within three-quarters of an hour on the third and sixth floors of the Washington Irviag High School late yesterday afternoon. One classroom was ruined and alight damage was done to another and to an infirmary.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP). -- Alternate praise and criticism of lighter-than-air ships was put before a Congressional committee today by a succession of witnesses, led by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh.

The contributions to science of the famous bit of chicken heart that has been kept alive at the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research for more than twenty-one years were cited yesterday by Dr. Simon Flexner, director of the institute, to show the importance of not holding down the scientist's insatiable curiosity to immediately, practical ends.
ROME, June 1. -- The four-power pact will be initialed here tomorrow, it is confidently predicted in well-informed circles.

The first-time starter Sation, a 8-year-old gelding by GaletianSalacia, carried the colors of George D. Widener to victory in the nineteenth running of the featured Hollis Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. The test had a value of 51,895 to the winner and the six furlongs were run in the smart time of 1:12 2-5 over a heavy track.

Young athletes who could not see the track they ran on or the crossbar they were trying to clear in the high jump engaged in a field meet yesterday afternoon at the New York Institute for the Kducation of the Blind, 999 Pelham Parkway, the Bronx.

WORCESTER, England, June 1 (Canadian Press). -- The touring West Indians ended the second innings of their cricket game against Worcestershire today with a score of 257 runs. They tallied 239 runs in the first innings, against 215 for the home team.

The executive offices of the Radio Corporation of America will be moved this afternoon from 570 Lexington Avenue to the R.C.A. Building at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, where they will be lodged on the fifty-second and fifty-third floors, three stories under the fifty-sixth floor offices of the John D. Rockefellers, senior and junior.
A number of dinners were given last night in the Roof Garden of the Astor, which was opened formally for the season.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Signs are mulitplying that the early adjournment of Congress will serve a purpose not ordinarily listed in the categories of benefits that come to the country from its recess. Aajournment will release the political community here from a strain as long and severe as anything but a disastrous war period has ever produced.

VIENNA, June 1. -- The International Chamber of Commerce spent most of this morning discussing the Danubian situation. Dr. Bernard Krund of Germany blamed the impossibility of carrying out the recommendations of the Stresa conference for the rehabilitation of the Danubian countries principally on United States opposition.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- Postmaster General Farley has rescinded a ruling issued two years ago by his Republican predecessor. Walter H. Brown, barring newspapers from printing stories about winners of lotteries or sweepstakes. Westbrook Pegleer tells of Mr. Farley's decision in a copyrighted Washington dispatch to The Chicago Tribune.

SAN BERNARDINO. Cal., June 1. -- An army transport plane crashed in a dense fog in Cajon Pass today, taking a toll of three lives. Three other members of the Army Air Corps suffered serious injuries, and one escaped with minor hurts.

Members of the Organization of Regular Republicans for Change in County Leadership prepared yesterday to organize in every Manhattan Assembly district for the primary fight to oust Samuel S. Koenig as chairman of the New York County Republican Commit tee.

TATTLE TALES, a revue In two acts and twenty-nine scenes. Sketches by Frank Fay and Nick Copeland. Music and lyrics by Howard Jackson, Edward Ward, Leo Robins. Ralph Ranger. George Waggoner, U'illard Roolson, Edward Ellscu, Eddie Blenbryer and William Walsh. Musical numbers arranged by John Lonergan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his communication to Controller Berry, Samuel Untermyer suggests as methods of increasing the city's revenue "to lift the present intolerable burdens from real estate and at the same time rehabilitate the credit of the city":

MOSCOW, June 1. -- The biggest tractor plant in the world was officially opened today at Cheliabinsk, in the Ural Mountains. The plant is designed to produce 40,000 60-horsepower caterpillar-type tractors yearly, although this year the production schedule is set at only 2,000.

The armistice signed by Japanese and Chinese brings to an end an undeclared war which has been under way since Sept, 18, 1931, when Japan seized Mukden. No political questions figure in the truce; but we must not be surprised if the discussion of a definite settlement between Tokyo and Nanking begins despite the latter's assertion that the truce is only to secure a breathing spell for the Chinese armies.
Two episodes stood out in sharp contrast yesterday at the trial of Charles E. Mitcbell on charges of income tax evasion.

The annual commencement of the Fieldston School, a unit of the Ethical Culture Schools at Spuyten Duyvil Parkway and Fieldston Road, Riverdale, will be held in the school auditorium at 10:30 this morning.
Announcement was made yesterday by the officials of the Intercollegiate Polo Association of the draw for the championship which starts at the Westchester Country Club at Rye on Saturday, June 10.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- Further delay in the restoration of full loan and cash surrender privileges to life insurance policy holders was forecast today when insurance commissioners representing forty States and four Canadian Provinces met here in the first session of a three-day convention.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Alexander M. Hadden have returned from a motor trip through New England to the Plaza, where they will remain until they sail for Europe.

An operating budget of $133,000 for the academic year 1933-34, about $60,000 less than that of the current year, was adopted yesterday by a special trustees' committee of St. Stephen's College, Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y. St. Stephen's is an Episcopalian college, affiliated with Columbia University, and has slightly fewer than 100 students.

With the announcement yesterday that the collection of taxes by the city was behind only 1.55 per cent as compared with last year, it became known that the Board of Estimate, in executive session yesterday afternoon, had considered a plan for a new form of taxation estimated to yield about $20,000,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- A resolution to investigate the Civil Service Commission was adopted by the House today, 177 to 54, with no Democrats opposing it.
WASHINGTON. June 1. -- Under new Treasury regulations the gold clause has been eliminated from the circular under which Treasury bills are issued.

Adoption of the new building code prepared by the Merchants Association was discussed yesterday before the Aldermanic committee on buildings at City Hall at the first of a series of public hearings which will precede definite action on the code.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The Washington Post was sold under the auctioneer's hammer today for $825,000 to George E. Hamilton Jr., a local attorney representing an undisclosed principal.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- George Whitney, member of the firm of J. P. Morgan Co., was again the witness when the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today resumed its inquiry into banking financing and securities sales practices.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The Bureau or Navigation Issued the following orders today, dated May 29:

Captain Daniel F. McAllister, president of the McAllister Navigation Company, set up his barricades yesterday to protect the honor of the sea, while hardened seamen muttered that the profession had "gone soft." Charges and denials passed back and forth as the waterfront discussed color effects and society cruises.

Sixty-three members of the gradu- , ating class ol the New York Law School, 215 West Twenty-third Street, will receive the degree of Bachelor of Laws at the commencement exercises of the school tonight in the Town Hall, 123 West Fortythird Street.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP). -- The Washington Post for fifty-six years has been one of the outstanding daily newspapers in the capital.

BERLIN, June 1. -- Foreign creditor bankers who are discussing the transfer situation with Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, the President of the Reichsbank, have been asked to the Reichsbank tomorrow, for what may be the final consultation of their present meeting in Berlin.

Harry L. Snyder, president of the New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company: John Blanchfield, statistician of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, and officials of four other public utility companies operating in Queens were before the Queens grand Jury yesterday.

Ten Eastern trunk-line railroads, which have opposed unsuccessfully the right of the Seatrain Lines, Inc., to operate a rail-water-rail service between Hoboken and New Orleans, via Havana, in actions before the Interstate Commerce Commission, brought suit yesterday in United States District Court to prevent the lines' operation.
Two bullets fired by a traffic policeman at a fleeing prisoner at Walker and Centre Streets yesterday afternoon struck and seriously injured a passer-by.

A suit in the name of "the Supervisor of the Town of New Harlem in behalf of the descendants or the patentees of the Town of New Harlem" was filed in Supreme Court yesterday to recover an award of $10,608 for a seventeenth century cemetery taken by New York City for the municipal subway.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP). -- One man, at least, refused, for an ethical reason, an offer to become a select Morgan customer in United Corporation stock.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended May 31, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,208,000,000, a decrease of $35,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $127,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.
Award of Vail Medals for heroism to three of its employes was announced yesterday by the New York Telephone Company.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1. -- Freddy Fitzsimmons felt perfectly at home today in the chill breezes which blew across Baker Bowl, and resumed his winning ways, holding the Phillies to seven hits. The husky Giant right-hander pitched his team to victory over Burt Shotton's athletes by a count of 7 to 2.

A three-month survey of housing conditions, undertaken to promote cleanliness and health, has been completed by the Lower East Side Community Council, it announced yesterday. The survey centred on the six square blocks bounded by Forsyth, Allen, Delancey and East Houston Streets.

Phyllis Cohen, 11 years old, of 969 East Seventh Street, Brooklyn, won the gold medal of the New York Music Week Association's interborough piano contest in the subintermediate department at Steinway Hall Monday, it was announced yesterday, and Ruth Kasowsky of 1,152 Fifty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, won the same distinction among the subseniors.

Four editors of The Campus, undergraduate newspaper at City College, were expelled, one was suspended for thirty days and four others were publicly censured last night at a joint meeting of the executive committee of the Board of Higher Education and the City College administrative committee.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The text of the Morgan partnership agreement reads as follows:

Early Fall Preparations Gain. An increasing tendency to make somewhat earlier preparations on Fall lines is now developing in both the dress and the coat trades. Official, showings of the new lines will not be made until after July 4, but there are indications that the volume of business on Fall lines by retailers operating early will be larger than was the case during the latter half of June a year ago.

The tests of the College Entrance Examination Board will begin on June 19 and close June 24, it was announced yesterday by Thomas S. Fiske, the board's secretary. They will be held at nearly four hundred points in the United States and in Canada, England, France, Germany, Switzerland, Japan and China.

PARIS, June 1. -- Doubts about the results of the World Economic Conference, which have reached the point of black pessimism here, even in official circles, were openly stated in a leading editorial in Le Temps.

Prices moved irregularly yesterday in the local commodity futures markets as profit-taking tempered the rising tendencies. Sugar, silver and cocoa were off on the day, while rubber, silk and hides were higher. Cash prices advanced.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Following is a list of those who were invited by Drexel Co. to subscribe at favorable terms to stock units of the United Corporation, as put into the record today before the Senate committee investigating J. P. Morgan Co.:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 1. -- In the annual awards of Yale prizes, made public today, August Heckscher 2d, '36, of Glen Head, N.Y., received the first McLaughlin Memorial Prize for his essay on "Emerson; Yesterday and Tomorrow," and Henry D. Harfield Jr., '34, of New York City, won the Henry A. Beers Prize in American literature for his essay entitled "Robert Calif, the Puritan GiantKiller."

In a raid early this morning on a duplex penthouse on the twentieth floor of an apartment building at 400 East Fifty-seventh Street, near Sutton Place, the police arrested two men on gambling charges, seized some gambling equipment and ordered four women and two men, who were gathered around a roulette wheel, to leave.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 1. -- Yale stopped rowing on the Housatonic tonight and Manager Myron Young announced the squad which will leave New Haven Sunday for the training quarters at Gales Ferry and the Harvard regatta on the Thames June 16.

"Men of Good-Will," by Jules Romains, is published here today by Alfred A. Knopf. The book has been publicized as "a saga that seeks to surpass the Forsyte in extent and intention, cut deeper than Balzac's vast record of nineteenth century society and encompass a wider scope than 'Jean Christophe.' "
CONCORD, N.H., June 1. -- The Ford Motor Company's net worth was reported at $628,344,180.05, as of Dec. 31, 1932, in a statement of condition filed today with the New Hampshire Secretary of State.

A committee representing holders of more than 25 per cent of the common stock of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation has been formed with the object of inducing the management to comply with the request of the New York Stock Exchange that stockholders receive additional information about the concern's income and assets, it was announced yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with great interest the somewhat acid comments of a number of publicists and readers of your paper on the subject of the Steagall bill to cancel the obligation of payment in gold on all contracts, bonds and other private and public obligations.

All motor vehicles, except taxicabs using city bridges will be taxed by the city in an amount equal to the license tax imposed by the State, and a 5-cent tax will be imposed on all taxicab rides. This agreement was reached yesterday by the Board of Estimate in a secret session called to establish new sources of city revenue.

Dr. Frank Damrosch, after twenty-eight years as director of the Institute of Musical Art has resigned his post, it was announced last night at the commencement exercises of the school. His official connection with the organization ended after the exercises, at which he officiated.

LONDON, June 2 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Chamberlain said in his speech in the House of Commons today that Great Britain would give no quarter in world economic warfare to countries which had taken an aggressive stand against her.

CAMP DIX, N.J., June 2 -- Mystery surrounding the sudden disappearance shortly after midnight of more than a thousand men from newly-formed companies of recruits for the reforestation service, was solved at daybreak this morning, as camp officers, with visions of a wholesale desertion, were about to organize a widespread manhunt by military police and State troopers.

With only one dissenting vote an amendment to the constitution of the Actors Equity Association, stipulating that alien players must become citizens of the United States in order to qualify for resident membership, was adopted at the twentieth annual meeting of the organization yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor.
LONDON, June 2 -- The speed of Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in the House of Commons today on the issues of the World Economic Conference was as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- If the resolution eliminating the gold clause is passed by Congress, reissues of registered government bonds will not contain the provision for payment in gold, Treasury experts said today.
Two captains of Hamburg-American Line ships were in port last night for their last official visit.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP) -- Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell, president of Harvard University, said today that care for the American child's physical welfare has retarded his mental development. Dr. Lowell spoke at the dedication of the 170-acre Morris Arboretum of the University of Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- George Whitney and Thomas S. Lamont, son of Thomas W. Lamont, both members of the firm of J.P. Morgan Co., were the witnesses heard today by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee investigating banking, financing and securities sales practices.

LONG BEACH, Cal., June 2 -- Seven persons were burned to death, nineteen were treated at hospitals for injuries and ten others were missing tonight following a terrific explosion at the Meader Absorption plant of the Richfield Oil Company in the Signal Hill Field near here today.

Prospects of early relief for hold ers of Brazilian and Colombian dollar bonds are discussed in a bulletin of the Institute of International Finance, conducted by the Investment Bankers Association of America in conjunction with New York University.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The center of the Senate inquiry into the House of Morgan, J.P. Morgan himself, could go home and stay there, but he said today he thought he would be back again Monday to "'see the end of this."

The Organization of Regular Republicans for Change in the New York County Leadership took steps yesterday to insure an honest election and count in its primary fight against Samuel S. Koenig, county chairman. Archie O. Dawson, president of the New York Young Republican Club, was appointed chairman of the committee to protect the polls.

Professor LANGMUIR was reported in THE TIMES as saying that to locate a single atom of caesium in a cubic meter of space is equivalent to "finding a small "fly in a hollow sphere the size "of the earth." That suggests the highest imaginable degree of loneliness.

Characterizing the modern talking picture as "the sallow shadow of the stage," Brock Pemberton, playwright and producer, undertook in a debate last night to defend the popularity of the legitimate theatre against the mass appeal of the cinema.

GENEVA, June 2 -- The triangular disarmament talks originally planned for today in Paris will be held there on Wednesday, it was announced here tonight. Norman H. Davis, who will represent the United States, plans to remain here until Tuesday night.

BOSTON, June 2 -- Summer weather came back to Boston today, and the Braves celebrated by trouncing the Dodgers in the first game of a double-header, 6 to 1, behind the high-class pitching of Ed Brandt.

Delays in the administration of funds of the Home Relief Bureau have amounted to denials of aid for weeks and months, unemployed families told a committee of clergymen and social workers investigating relief measures yesterday. A child's life was endangered and a mother and seven children subsisted on macaroni and potatoes for seven months awaiting relief, according to the testimony.

For the third time in twenty-four hours, a fire of incendiary origin was discovered late yesterday afternoon in the Washington Irving High School, 40 Irving Place. Fire Marshal Brophy said he was convinced the fires were started by a pyromaniac.
CHICAGO, June 3 -- A close friend of the late Mayor A. J. Cermak, Menc S. Szymczak, has been active in Cook County Democratic politics for many years.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The most tense moment in the Senate inquiry into the affairs of J.P. Morgan Co. came at the end of today's session, when Ferdinand Pecora, counsel for the Banking and Currency Committee, put Thomas S. Lamont, son of Thomas W. Lamont and also a partner in the firm, on the stand.

With transactions exceeding $20, 000,000, bonds on the Stock Exchange hounded higher yesterday. Domestic corporation issues in general and utilities in particular led the advance, many rising 1 to more than 9 points. Foreign loans, notably German issues, closed higher, and all active United States Governments bonds were up 1-32 to 14-32 point.
The trees of Westchester County are being stripped of their foliage by one of the worst visitations of Spring cankerworms in the county's history.
The annual Salvation Army United Appeal by volunteer workers from many branches of business and industry closed yesterday with total gifts and pledges of $423,523.40.

Several hundred guests thronged the Central Park Casino last night for the annual dance of the New York Newspaper Women's Club. Prominent publishers and their wives were patrons and patronesses for the event and newspapers of the city were represented by special tables.

For the first time since the market recovery started, the broad upward movement on the Stock Exchange yesterday was not associated, even in the prejudiced speculative mind, with the agitation for currency inflation.

Formation of six firms which will have memberships in the New York Stock Exchange has been proposed. Two firms have been dissolved. One of these, Benjamin Jacobson Co., has been succeeded by a new firm with the same name.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The War Department released the following orders today:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 2 -- The largest senior class in the history of New Jersey College for Women will be graduated tomorrow morning when Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, will confer 262 baccalaureate degrees.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A demand that President Roosevelt recall Norman H. Davis from Europe was made today by Representative Tinkham of Massachusetts in a speech in the House. It was based on the ground that the Special Ambassador had been "denounced" many years ago by the Supreme Court as having engaged in "duplicity and fraud for his own benefit."

"Forsaking All Others," starring Tallulah Bankhead, will be the only attraction to close its Broadway run this evening. Early in the week several other productions had scheduled their departures for tonight, but reconsidered later.

LONDON, June 2 -- The plight of British owners of freight vessels has become so bad that a determined effort is being made to obtain agreement on a national plan to stimulate the scrapping of tonnage. Also, agreement is sought on an international plan to encourage further laying up of surplus tonnage.

PARIS, June 2 -- Joseph Paul-Boncour, Foreign Minister, reported to Premier Daladier today on the Geneva end of the fourpower pact negotiations. Afterward a communique was issued stating that the talks had not been terminated and that some difficulties of detail in regard to the text remained to be smoothed out.

CONNIE MACK pushed his hat back a bit off his forehead and said: "Simmons said he liked our pitching? Why, our pitching hasn't been good. By George, it was on account of our pitchers weakening that we had to put Grove in there so often. It was either that or slide right down toward the bottom."

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Carrying $660,000,000 for veterans' compensation, or $170,000,000 more than the administration originally proposed, the $715,740,936 Independent Offices Bill was passed in the Senate tonight without a record vote and will now go to conference with the House.

George McAneny, Sanitation Commissioner, announced yesterday that he had "accepted the resignations" of Deputy Commissioners Michael Laura of Brooklyn and Joseph T. Quinn of Queens from his department. He added that Deputy Commissioner Frank A. Eschmann already had retired.

Abe Durst, 40 years old, of Yonkers, described by police as a beer-runner for Waxey Gordon, New Jersey racketeer, was found dead last night in an automobile abandoned at Paulding and Lydig Avenues, the Bronx. Daniel Kelleher, 13 years old, of 2,109 Lurting Avenue, and Joseph Powers, 17, of 2,115 Hone Avenue, made the discovery.

DETROIT, June 2 (AP) -- Five per cent increases in pay, affecting 130,000 wage earners, were announced today, as officials of the Fisher Body Corporation said they would join the General Motors Corporation in ordering the rise, effective in all divisions of the two organizations.

CLEVELAND, June 2 -- George T. Bishop, president of Continental Shares, Inc., started tonight for New York to confer with bankers and others regarding the situation of the holding company. He said he hoped the proposed sale of many of the company's assets on June 12 could be prevented, and added: "There may be an important announcement tomorrow."

Clergymen and laymen representing the 4O2 parishes composing the United Lutheran Synod of New York will attend the fourth annual convention of the synod at St. John's Church, Buffalo, beginning Monday evening, June 12, and extending through Thursday.

There was a grand clashing of at the Stadium yesterday as the Yankees and Athletics collided in their first joust of a four-game series, but the result was one not usually associated with the sagacious Connie Mack. For, strange to relate, the venerable pilot came out second best and the world's champions carried the day, 5 to 4.

Russell T. Sherwood was served late last night with a subpoena calling upon him to appear before the Federal grand Jury here on Monday morning. The nature of the matter on which he is to be questioned was not officially revealed, but it was recalled that Federal officials had manifested interest in the income-tax returns of former Mayor Walker, for whom Sherwood acted as fiscal agent.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 2 -- As the annual meeting of the National Council of the Boy Scouts of America opened here today, a message was received from President Roosevelt praising scouting as "a vital factor in the life of America."

To the Editor of The New York Times: I took a boy of mine to Bear Mountain last Saturday. In the afternoon I attempted to use the swimming pool. I found that there is a charge for bath of 50 cents. I had to pay a deposit of $1 for the bathing suit, but do not recollect what was charged for its hire.
