KANSAS CITY, June 2 -- Officers seeking the kidnappers of Miss Mary McElroy, 25 years old, who was ransomed for $30,000, struck with startling suddenness in two cities today, arresting eight persons, announcing a confession and moving swiftly toward prosecution.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 2 -- Carleton Tobey and his sister, Miss Ida Louise Tobey of Southold, L.I., with three blue ribbons between them, were the most successful exhibitors during the first day of the annual Tuxedo horse show, held today in the picturesque show ring in Tuxedo Park.

LONDON, June 2 -- Pour new peers were created in the birthday honors list announced today on the eve of the King's 68th birthday, along with many awards to men and women distinguished in public life, music, literature, drama and journalism.
A nation-wide campaign against racketeering got under way last night with a mass meeting at Carnegie Hall.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- A new set of regulations governing the loan and cash surrender privileges of life policyholders, somewhat more liberal than those now in effect, was adopted today by the National Convention of Insurance Commissioners in session at the Edgewater Beach Hotel.

In India, it has been said, there is only one independent sovereign, the British Government, although a complexity of State and Agency administration exists, and ruling dynasties come down from the fourteenth century. There are States within States.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- President Roosevelt advised Representative Hartley of New Jersey in a letter today that he planned to call for a moratorium on small home foreclosures just as soon as the pending home loan mortgage legislation is approved by Congress.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I supplement THE TIMES article concerning the first Jewish cemetery in New York? Mention is made of the stone over the grave of Walter Judah, "a student of physick," aged 20, who lost his life while ministering to the sick during the fearful epidemic which raged in New York City in 1798.

Net loss of the Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., and subsidiaries, excluding Skouras Brothers Enterprises and the St. Louis Amusement Company, for the twenty-six weeks ended on Feb. 25 was $3,442,326. This was after amortization of film costs, depreciation, interest, provision for investments in affiliated companies and losses of companies in equity receivership, minority interest and other charges.

Suspension of five more students yesterday brought the total of those disciplined for participation in Monday's pacifist disturbance at City College to twelve. The suspensions were announced by Dr. Morton Gottschall, acting dean, after a special faculty committee had questioned fifteen suspected of taking part in the demonstration.

Establishing a new record for a non-stop flight across the United States, Captain Frank Hawks landed at Floyd Bennett Field at 11:19 o'clock last night, 13 hours 26 minutes 15 seconds after leaving the Municipal Airport in Los Angeles.
Additional members and aides of the United States, Japanese, Brazilian, Mexican and Cuban delegations to the London Economic Conference sailed for England from New York last night on the Olympic.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- British officialdom is intent upon eventual return to the gold standard, but does not mean to act until events have clearly demonstrated what the proper ratio should be between the pound and the dollar and between the pound and gold, according to Sir Josiah Stamp.

LONDON, June 2 -- The stock markets were quieter on the eve of the Whitsun holiday. The Exchange will be closed until Tuesday. Most of the movements were favorable, except in the Kaffirs, which were again erratic. British funds continued firm.

Summer Accessories Sell Well. An exceptionally active call for women's Summer shoes during the week was reported here yesterday by retail executives. Increased sales volume in this department marked the period as one of the best of the season, with the business shared by most of the leading stores here.

The monthly bulletin of the Federal Reserve Board, published yesterday, summarizes the banking situation as of May 3. On that date 5,478 of the 6,689 member banks had received licenses to reopen, while 1,211 were still closed. Deposits in the institutions which had reopened amounted to $26,100,000,000, while those in the closed banks were $2,619,000,000.

In comparison with last year bank clearings fell behind in the week ended on Wednesday because the coresponding period in 1932 included the first business day of June, when clearances always are heavy. Clearings in twenty-one cities, including New York, were $3,550,806,000 in the past week, against $4,016,846,000 a year ago, or a drop of 11.6 per cent, according to Dun Bradstreet. Inc.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Efforts of houses with Eastern connections to advance wheat prices today on the Board of Trade met little success, as a bearish feeling prevailed among traders here. Lack of outside participation in the market, fears that hedging pressure will start soon against the new Southwestern Winter wheat and the favorable outlook for the Spring wheat crop increased pressure on upturns.

TOKYO, June 2 -- Naval and civil authorities and prominent citizens are exerting themselves to give a good time to Admiral Montgomery M. Taylor and the officers and men of the United States cruiser Houston, flagship of the Asiatic Fleet.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- In a hearing charged with feeling the Senate Military Affairs Committee went deeply today into the question whether the administration directed the purchase of 200,000 kits for members of the Civilian Conservation Corps without competitive bids.

BERLIN, June 2 -- Dr. Joachim Hossenfelder, leader of the Nazi German Christians, warned today that if Dr. Friedrich von Bodwelschwingh, recently elected first Protestant Bishop of the Reich by the church authorities, preached in that capacity here Sunday as announced disorders would be likely to occur.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 2 -- Twenty-eight airplanes, including one owned by Russell Thaw, son of Harry K. Thaw, were destroyed tonight in a fire which razed a large hangar at Roosevelt Field. The total damage was estimated at $500,000.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Large sums out of the Federal Farm Board's $500,000,000 revolving fund were used by the Farmers National Grain Corporation and member associations for the construction and purchase of facilities not authorized by the board, says a report by Controller General McCarl now in the files of the Senate.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Support of President Roosevelt's industrial bill was urged in a resolution adopted at the closing session of the National Retail Dry Goods Association here this afternoon. Thirty-eight thousand retail dry goods stores all over the United States, employing about 6,000,000 persons, were represented at the meeting.
Easy on Pure Science. Dr. SIMON FLEXNER evidently does not believe that ours is a materialistic age in everything. We do not lay gross hands on the snow-white robes of star-eyed science.

AMHERST, Mass., June 2 (AP) -- Five Amherst College freshmen, arrested on charges of mutilating an American flag, were released late today on bail of $200 each furnished by Dwight Morrow Jr., son of the late New Jersey Senator, and Richard MacMeekin, both students.

BERLIN, June 2 -- The advance on the Boerse which began yesterday following publication of the government's economic relief program continued today with Increased momentum and on a broader basis. Stocks of concerns which are expected to profit most from the work-creation program scored gains up to 6 points, building and j heavy industrial securities being the favorites.

ROSLYN, L.I., June 2 -- Mrs. Leo G. Federman of the Glen Oaks Country Club, a former Long Island champion, led a field of thirty-one players today in the first annual women's invitation golf tournament of the Roslyn Harbor Golf Club with a gross score of 83.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 2 -- During the running of the Gibraltar Challenge Bowl Hunt event at the Wilmington Horse Show today Miss Hope Gimbel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel of Port Chester, N.Y., was slightly injured.

RYE, N.Y., June 2 -- Cornelius Shields, in his Aileen, today won the first race of the Interclub Class sloops' Friday afternoon series on Long Island Sound. It was a spirited contest in a fifteen-knot breeze from west-southwest, that backed south-southwest.

To the Editor of The New York Times: What disaster has overtaken the moral sense of our country? In spite of centuries of biblical teaching our rulers seem to prefer the expedient to the right, and no man says them nay. The psalmist indeed wrote, "He that sweareth to his own hurt and changeth not."

The three-story building on the northeast corner of 5th Av. and 51st St., formerly occupied by the Union Club was conveyed by Howard Townsend, Charles K. Beekman and J. Picrpont Morgan, who held the property as joint tenants and not as tenants in common, to the 5th Av. and 51st St. Corp. at an indicated consideration of $1,730,000, and subject to a mortgage on which $2,000,000 is now due.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Following is a list of officers of corporations to whom J.P. Morgan Co. or Drexel Co. or any of their agents made loans or advances from 1927 to 1932, inclusive:

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Almost complete emasculation of the industrial control provisions of the National Recovery Bill was voted tonight by the Senate Finance Committee in an astonishing revolt against administration leadership and extraordinary Presidential powers.

Leasing deals featured realty transactions in Manhattan and the Bronx as reported by brokers yesterday. Three properties in the midtown section were listed under new control, and a Bronx apartment building was purchased by an investor.
ROME, June 2 -- The confident forecasts made yesterday that the four-power pact would be initialed today proved wrong. Every one now expects that the ceremony will be performed early next week.

Offshort fishing has begun and it is attracting a great deal of interest among the salt water clans. Parties in recent days have found the deep sea grounds off Seabright and Elberon, N.J., abundantly supplied with large blackfish and sea bass.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- President Roosevelt today formally accepted from the contractors his new swimming pool built by popular subscription. He will take his first plunge and christen it tomorrow, a ceremony he was prevented from performing today on account of a rush of business.

SCHROON LAKE, N.Y., June 2 -- After asking a rescuer to save his bride of a few days first, Louis H. Gerber, 24, of 2,403 Benson Avenue, Brooklyn, was drowned in Schroon Lake late yesterday afternoon.

Two children were burned to death when fire swept a four-story tenement building at 534 West Fortieth Street about 2 o'clock this morning. Three other children living in the building were treated by an ambulance surgeon for cuts and burns.

GENEVA, June 2 -- The subcommittee on non-recognition of Manchukuo adopted a report today recommending to all members of the League of Nations a series of concrete applications of the Stimson principle of refusal to recognize territorial changes made contrary to treaty obligations.
Seven liners are scheduled to sail for European ports today and two will depart for Southern waters. Only one ship, the President Grant, is due to dock.

BERLIN, June 2 -- The marriage, aid provision of Chancellor Hitler's economic relief program, under which a young husband can borrow 1,000 marks from the government immediately after marriage to get his new household started, aroused considerable speculation today as to whether the scheme would also be available to husbands of the Jewish faith.

With municipal bond prices continuing to mount, thirty-four communities throughout the country will offer new issues for award next week in the amount of $18,687,686, comparing with this week's total of $20,115,648 and the weekly average for the year to date of $12,301,134.

Business on the Stock Exchange yesterday was of such proportions that brokers were prepared to "forget everything." Such a turnover has rarely been witnessed; on only one day previously did the volume reach such a high figure in an advancing market.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 2 (AP) -- Jersey City scored five runs after two were out in the second inning today, which enabled them to beat Albany, 5 to 4, and even the series at one game each. The Senators had the tying run on third base and the winning run on first base when Charles Perkins struck out Gordon Phelps to end the game.

The City Bank Farmers' Trust Company, as plaintiff, yesterday acquired the twelve-story office and store building at 280 Madison Avenue, southwest corner of Fortieth Street, on a bid of $1,000,000. The building was put up at foreclosure sale in the Vesey Street Exchange by Henry Brady, auctioneer, in an action involving a lien of $1,045,050.

LONDON, June 2 -- Surprisingly little variance between the viewpoints of the British and American governments was revealed today when Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, gave the House of Commons the first definite statement of British policy at the World Economic Conference, opening here June 12.

Ben Jeby, recognized by the New York State Athletic Commission as the world's middleweight champion, defeated Al Rossi of Newark in the feature bout of twelve rounds at Fugazy Bowl, formerly the Coney Island Stadium, last night. A crowd of 5,000 persons saw the battle, in which Jeby's title was not at stake.

The lower west side area bounded by Broadway, the Battery and Fourteenth Street was ranked yesterday as second only to Harlem in regard to unfavorable health conditions. This point was brought out in a sociological survey presented before doctors and welfare workers meeting at Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street, to promote "health consciousness" in the neighborhood.

PARIS, June 2 -- The failure of the international oil groups to obtain a limitation of the United States' production level to 2,000,000 barrels a day has resulted in the renunciation by the Rumanian producers of the production limit that they accepted at the International oil conference here last January.

Dr. William Lyon Phelps, Professor of English Literature at Yale University, spoke last night at the commencement of the Horace Mann High School for Girls, Teachers College. Dr. William F. Russell, dean of Teachers College, presided.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 31:

Money market was quiet in business and unchanged in quotations. A little outside money was done on Stock Exchange collateral at 1/2, as on Thursday, also some at 3/4, but the board rate continued at 1 per cent. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were steady.

BERLIN, June 2 -- The German transfer problem and Germany's foreign debts will be brought before the World Economic Conference in London this month, and pending their solution there the German Government next week will call for suspension of the transfer of the service payments on the nation's foreign private indebtedness.

Making a clean sweep of all its matches, the Pomonok Country Club increased its lead in the second section of the Long Island division of the Women's M.G.A. Class B interclub matches yesterday over the Pomonok links. With the Cherry Valley team idle as the result of a bye, Women's National jumped from second place to first in Section 1.

VIENNA, June 2 -- The International Chamber of Commerce today adopted in committee a resolution admitting the advisability of making exceptions to the most-favored-nation clause in trade agreements, after the way had been paved for it by a statement by Clark Minor, president of the International General Electric Company, departing from the traditional American stand on this subject.

Members of ten varsity, junior varsity, freshman and intramural athletic teams were given 186 awards for Spring competition at City College last night. The Sports represented were lacrosse, tennis, track and baseball.

Barnard College opened its senior week last evening with the traditional step-singing by the student body in the quadrangle facing Milbank Hall. The annual senior show, an eighteenth-century comedy by Richard B. Sheridan, entitled "A Trip to Scarborough," was presented later in the Brinckerhoff Theatre, Broadway and 120th Street.

Further sharp advances in a large part of the commodities carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices 1.6 points upward to 92.7 on Monday from 91.1 (revised) on the Tuesday previous. The average for May, reflecting the gains in the weekly figures, rose to 90.5 from 83.8 in April.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter from Charles A. Weil in THE TIMES of May 29 "to present the case against Dr. Irving Fisher as to a multiple commodity standard, elsewhere referred to us the compensated dollar," naturally interested me.

AUTEUIL, France, June 2 -- Henri Cochet today showed he was nearing his top tennis form, which means just about the best in the world, as he trounced the Czechoslovakian internationalist, Roderich Menzel, in straight sets, to enter the semi-final round of the French hard-court championships in defense of his title.

Twelve young pianists will take part tonight in the finals of the annual competition in the Grade A elementary pianoforte class of the New York Music Week Association at Steinway Hall. The contestants were chosen from a group of thirtytwo who competed in the interborough competition last week.

A decision affecting reorganization plans of the property at 10 East Fortieth Street was handed down yesterday by the Appellate Division. The court affirmed an order permitting a bondholders' committee headed by Lee S. Buckingham to intervene in foreclosure proceedings started by the Chase National Bank as trustee under a mortgage made by the 10 East Fortieth Street Corporation.

The Consolidated Electric and Gas Company, which acquired, as of Aug. 1, 1932, certain assets owned formerly by the Central Public Service Corporation and affiliates, reports a consolidated net income of $10,547 for the five months ended on Dec. 31 last, after charges, taxes, depreciation, underlying dividends, minority interest and loss on foreign exchange.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP) -- Formation of a national committee of depositors in restricted and closed banks to "fight for the rights of depositors as distinct from the corporate rights of banks" was announced today.

The greatest indictment against the German people is that it has proved, by the measures of the Hitler dictatorship, that it is incapable of living under a democratic government. Alfred E. Smith, former Governor, declares editorially in the current New Outlook.
CHICAGO, June 2 -- Edwin Markham, 81-year-old poet who wrote "The Man With the Hoe," described himself as a poor business man at a hearing today before Thomas J. Paden, Federal master in chancery.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Jose de Landa have returned from their wedding trip in Bermuda and are with Mrs. de Landa's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John North Willys, at 820 Fifth Avenue. All of them will leave today for the country place of Mr. and Mrs. Willys in Oyster Bay.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated rather feverishly yesterday in a range of a dollar a bale and finished 2 to 12 points higher on a heavy turnover.

With Olympic, national and Intercollegiate champions among the entrants, the New York Athletic Club will stage its 130th track and field games at Travers Island this afternoon. Excellent fields have been assembled by Paul Pilgrim for practically every event and some 5,000 Winged Foot adherents will get a glimpse of the powerful group that the New York A.C. will send to the national championships at Chicago at the end of the month.

OXFORD, England, June 2 -- The successful employment of a new type of "projectile" in probing the atom was mentioned by Lord Rutherford tonight in a lecture before the Junior Scientific Club, attended by Dr. Albert Kinstein and Dr. H. N. Russell of Princeton.

Wilful misapplication of 5300,000 of the funds of the Harriman National Bank and misappropriation of stock valued at the same figure were charged yesterday by the Federal grand jury in a second indictment against Joseph W. Harriman, former president of the bank.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 -- The Giants increased their batting averages at Baker Bowl today at the expense of four Philadelphia pitchers, while burying Burt Shotton's hapless squad under an 11-to-3 defeat.

The long-discussed meeting between Equipoise and Questionnaire, considered the leading handicap stars, now in training, is scheduled for today at Belmont Park, where the historic Metropolitan Handicap will be run for the fortieth time.
PRINCETON. N.J., June 2 -- The Princeton varsity 150-pound crew has entered .the Thames Challenge Cup race of the Royal Henley Regatta to be held in England July 5-3, it was learned tonight.

PASSAIC, N.J., June 2 -- Crowds in Henry Street, in the centre of this city, were startled late tonight when a volley of shots, apparently from a machine gun, was fired from an automobile. One man was killed.
The government closed its income tax case against Charles E. Mitchell yesterday afternoon after presenting evidence for three weeks.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 2 -- A thrilling nineteen-hole match in which Hamilto Wright, member of this year, powerful Yale golf team, finally triumphed after being 4 down and 8 to play, featured today's match-play rounds in the annual Long Island amateur championship at the Garden City Country Club.
BERLIN, June 2 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of May 31 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., June 2 -- Willie Macfarlane of Oak Ridge, winner of the metropolitan open championship last week, accounted for some brilliant golf in the first Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association tourney of the season at the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club today.

ABOARD THE LINER PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT AT SEA, June 2 (AP) -- With whitecaps flashing against the portholes and the ship rolling heavily, the United States delegates to the World Economic Conference assembled tonight in Secretary of State Hull's flower-filled cabin for their first meeting on the trip and decided to split up the various topics on the program of the parley.

In sharply diverging opinions, the Appellate Division voted four to one yesterday to reverse the conviction of John J. Stiglin, former vice squad policeman. Stiglin was prosecuted as a result of the Sea-bury inquiry into the magistrates' courts, and was sentenced to from two and a half to five years in Sing Sing for perjury in prosecuting two women.

Joe Weber of Weber and Fields fame, his wife, Mrs. Lillian Weber, and three friends were injured early yesterday when a taxicab in which they were riding crashed into an elevated pillar at Columbus Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

HELSINGFORS, June 2 -- The detection at Reval by Estonian political police of a secret radio station that was being used to transmit political information to the Ogpu (Soviet Political Police) has led to the arrest of seven Soviet agents.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Estimating that 600,000 unemployed went back to work in April and that jobs increased in May, the American Federation of Labor, in its current survey of business, today appealed again for shorter work hours and increased wages as the only sure procedure to keep business on the upward trend.
PARIS, June 2 -- With the budget finally out of the way, the French Government turned seriously today toward preparations for the World Economic Conference.

Signs multiply that President ROOSEVELT'S program of drastic retrenchment is running into difficulties. Reorganization of the Government departments has been postponed. Perhaps the President will take it up and push it though, as he has power to do, after he gets Congress off his hands.

The ninth "White List" of the Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee was issued yesterday. In an introduction the committee states that although many publishers have had to reduce their Spring lists, the "White List" is exceptionally large.

All commodities rose moderately in yesterday's trading on local exchanges, although for the most part the buoyancy of the security markets was not in evidence. Trading was in good volume. All cash prices advanced, with several new high records established.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On May 31 THE NEW YORK TIMES published a letter from W.E. Russell. Evidently Mr. Russell is mistaken in his facts in respect of the condition of the rolling-stock and the roadbed of the Long Island Railroad.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 2 -- Nineteen certificates were awarded and the annual lists of prizes, scholarships and fellowships in the Yale School of Music were announced tonight by President Angell at the commencement concert.

ST. PAUL, June 2 -- George Von Elm, "business-man golfer," and Jimmy Foulis of Chicago, playing their rounds after a high wind had died, dominated the first eighteen-hole engagement of the $5,000 St. Paul open championship today.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 2 -- A colorful military touch was lent to the thirty-fifth annual Tuxedo horse show, which opened this morning, by the presence of entries from the United States Military Academy at West Point, the horse show team from Fort Myer, Va., and the Essex troop team of Newark, N.J.
Seventy-six students of the Harriette Melissa Mills Training School for Kindergarten and Primary Teachers received diplomas and certificates at the graduation exercises yesterday morning.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 2 -- A team of seven players, one of the strongest to represent New York since the series was started, was named at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club today to defend the Sears Cup in the intersectional tennis competition to be held at the Longwood Cricket Club, Brookline, Mass., next Friday and Saturday.

Tax receipts are off, but not so badly as might have been expected. Allowance must be made for the reduced levy this year, as well as for the prepayment of a small part of the taxes due next November, facilitated by the sale of Controller BERRY'S "baby bonds."

Suit has been started in the Supreme Court attacking as illegal the plan of the Associated Gas and Electric Company for readjustment of $260,000,000 on its outstanding debentures. The plaintiff is Mrs. Elizabeth E. Rabenold, wife of Elwood M. Rabenold, former State Senator, as owner of $165,000 of the 4 1/2 per cent debentures due in 1949.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- President Roosevelt indicated today that the expenses of the government would be reduced by $1,000,000,000 in the next fiscal year, chiefly through the elimination of unnecessary activities and interdepartmental consolidations.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 2 -- Harold Willis Dodds, Professor of Politics and chairman of the administrative board of the School of Public and International Affairs, was elected the fifteenth president of Princeton University at a special meeting of the board of trustees here this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A Federal deficit of about $1,700.000,000 is indicated for June 30, with expenditures reduced by $1,000,000,000 or more and receipts increased about $100,000,000 as compared with the previous fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The climax to ambition achieved, Mrs. Pattie Willis South, the 81-year-old Nicholasville (Ky.) woman who wanted a meal at the White House, was photographed today with Mrs. Roosevelt on its front steps after a luncheon there.

The annual class day exercises of Barnard College will be held Tuesday at 2:30 P.M. in Barnard Hall. Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve will deliver the annual address, it was announced yesterday. Miss Dorothy Crook, chairman of the graduating class, will give the salutatory address and Miss Gena Tenney president of the Undergraduate Association, will deliver the valedictory.

Market values of stocks advanced in May to new high levels for the present movement, and the sessions on the exchanges were reminiscent of the bull market of 1929. The appreciation was smaller, however, than in April, although the trading was on a broader scale, embracing all classes of shares, and the volume of transactions was almost twice as large as in the previous month.

BOSTON, June 3 -- Assailing the "double and equal dishonesty" of wets and drys, Dr. Haven Emerson of New York urgad the New England Health Education Association today to propose that the National Educational Association and American Medical Association jointly prepare an elementary teachers textbook on the effects of alcohol as known to medical science.

NO tradition is better grounded in experience than that a Government's popularity is determined largely by the question whether prices, during its official tenure, are rising on the Stock Exchange and the staple markets, or whether the reverse movement prevails.

While the amendments recently incorporated by the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency in the emergency relief measure, which aims to give relief to distressed home owners, are a great improvement to the bill, points out D.E. McAvoy, chairman of the Long Island Division of the Home Mortgage Advisory Board, he says that to provide the maximum benefit some provisions of a more liberal character should be included.

SOME years ago Dr. Benjamin Bronson of the Noble Hospital, Westfield, Mass., was reading Lieutenant Elisberg's book "On the Bottom" -- a stiring account of the crew, entombed alive, in the foundered submarine S-4. There was an elaborate description of the method whereby air pressure is made to offset water pressure within the suit, so that the diver would not only be saved from drowning but from being crushed.

TO ACCORD Paderewaki a further evidence of its admiration and veneration, the City of Warsaw, capital of the pianist's native Poland, has conferred on him the Prix National de Musique, to quote a French newspaper.

Pointing out that the credit problem provides a "common denominator" for all industries and therefore should be a means for coordinating the various groups, the National Association of Credit Men, through Henry H. Heimann, executive director, yesterday offered a program for the control of credit under the Industrial Recovery Bill, which would insure a high standard of ethics in credit procedure.

It is the contention of Professor Bancroft, In this lucid study, that the works of Conrad embody a solid, definitely systematized philosophy, a thesis in support of which he submits copious analytical illustrations from Conrad's novels, short tales and reminiscences.

BERLIN, June 3 -- The investigation of the fire that destroyed a large part of the interior of the Reichstag Building on Feb. 20 has been completed and the case has been turned over to Attorney General August Karl Werner for prosecution.

PARIS, May 16 THIS week we have had a comedy at the Theatre de Paris which is fairly characteristic of the rather simple and superficial formula which has been adopted by this large theatre since it gave up fashionably dressed melodrama.

WILLIAM MULDOON is dead and sport has lost one of Its heroic figures. The old warrior started in athletics as a wrestler. That was in the Civil War days when he was a soldier, a brawny country boy from a New York farm, and he tossed his camp companions to the turf in succession until he become the champion of the regiment. Later he was to become the champion of the professional wrestling field.

THE aim of this book is to help technically trained men. especially young college graduates, to get jobs, to show them how to tackle the problem by turning the tables on the employer and selling services to him instead of asking him for work. The author is an engineer and manufacturing executive, and during many years of helping" engineering students to find employment has worked out the scheme of applying analytic methods to this problem.

Free lighterage of freight in the port district of New York by railroads whose rail ends are in New Jersey is termed an example of railroad inefficiency and waste in a statement filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission by Milton P. Bauman of the New Jersey Traffic Advisory Committee.

WHEN Mr. Waley began his translation of "The Tale of Genji" he believed that he was "translating by far the greatest novel of the East and one which, even if compared with the fiction of Europe, takes its place as one of the dozen masterpieces of the world."

An important milestone in medical missionary work will be reached with the opening today of the first two units of the new St. Luke's International Medical Centre in Tokyo, Japan. The funds for these two units, which make up roughly one-half of the projected medical centre, were contributed largely by popular subscription in the United States.

"There is only one standard which is familiar to everybody and which can inspire confidence" Thus Neville Chamberlain. British Chancellor of the Exchequer, characterized the gold standard last week, when, after twenty-one months' experience with a currency divorced from gold, he delivered to Parliament the outline of Great Britain's policy for the World Economic Conference.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Authority to use any legal tender to settle government and private obligations now payable only in gold was assured when the Senate, by a vote of 48 to 20 late this afternoon, approved the administration's gold clause repeal resolution.

THERE was once a real Utopia in America, whose happy citizens went share and share alike, in which there was no unemployment of the painful sort. and in which generosity, courage and mercy flowed like the gentle rain from heaven.

THAT there is a border line zigzagging almost 4,000 (exactly 3,973,9) miles clear across our North American Continent, nearly everybody is supposed to know. Many times the world has been told that for more than a century this line has been unfortified by common consent of the people of Canada and the United States.

Under the auspices of the Progressive Education Association's Commission on the Relation of School and College an arrangement has now been completed by which an experimental study involving a group of secondary schools and a large number of leading colleges and universities will be inaugurated next September.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 -- Governor Pinchot's demand for the resignations of two Pennsylvania Supreme Court Justices because their names were found on the "preferred" list of J.P. Morgan Co. caused probably a more genuine stir outside the Commonwealth than within it.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I read Gall Harwood's letter to THE TIMES, which ends as follows: "Of course encouraging birds involves, as a necessary step, discouraging cats!"

RADIO station owners generally have at least three ambitions: to use maximum power, operate on an exclusive wave and use it full-time, sharing with no other transmitter. This week WMCA sees an ambition realized, and WNYC partially.

BAGDAD IRAQ is now occupied in increasing its military and civil air strength. In addition to the Royal Air Force airdromes provided for under the Anglo-Iraqian treaty throughout the country, the government is contemplating setting up civil airports.

BERLIN THIS year's award of the Ralph B. Strasaburger Foundation for the best book whose influence will further a friendly understanding between America and Germany has been given to Professor Friedrich Schonemann's great two-volume work, "Die Vereinigten Staaten von Amerika" (Deutsche Verlagsanstait, Stuttgart).

As a result of the rally in securities in the last few weeks the investment trust business in this country is crystallizing as to purposes and policies faster than it ever had done before. Sponsors of the companies, and many impartial observers as well, say the trusts are now ready to play an important part in behalf of investors in the major security recovery, which they believe to be at hand.

After an afternoon of wrangling yesterday in Hunts Point Palace, Southern Boulevard and 163d Street, the Bronx, about 125 union men finally organized the Central Labor Committee with the avowed purpose of fighting racketeer evils in the recognized building-trade unions.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Hugh S. Johnson, picked for administrator of the pending Industral Recovery Act. today lost a direct appeal to the National Association of Manufacturers for support of the legislation as sent to the Capitol by President Roosevelt.

NEWSPAPER readers last week became familiar with the word butane when they learned that the Southern Pacific has been experimenting with it as a fuel on a three-car train and that there is a chance of its being used to drive the 110-mile-an-hour aluminum streamlined train with which the Union Pacific may regain some of the passenger traffic that it has lost to the highway buses.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 3 -- Yale's rowing equipment was shipped today to the crew quarters at Gales Ferry, and the oarsmen and coaches will follow tomorrow in the yacht of Carll Tucker of New York City, the Migrant.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 3 -- A clean-cut confession, naming three accomplices, was made and signed today by Walter H. McGee, ringleader in the kidnapping of Miss Mary McElroy, 25-year-old daughter of City Manager H.F. McElroy. A possible penalty under Missouri law is hanging.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 1 -- While Governor Eugene Talmadge is holding hundreds of thousands of Georgians as prisoners of hope with an ever-shortening tether of inaction on the question of legalized beer, he has been on what may be called a pardoning and commutation spree of considerable proportions.

THOSE who like to connect the work of artists with the development of their lives doubtless will be interested in noting how many of the masterpieces in the great exhibition at Chicago belong to the youth of the painters.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 3 -- George Lott, Chicago's Davis Cup star, today won the Dixie invitation tennis tournament by defeating Sidney B. Wood Jr. of New York in four hard sets, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 2.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 3 -- A parshelling brigade laid down a heavy barrage of brilliant performances at the Keller course today, but the firing failed to dislodge George Von Elm of Akron and Jimmy Foulis of Chicago from the lead in the $5,000 St. Paul open with their thlrty-six-hole records of 142.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 27 amounted to 541,309 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 9,691 cars, or 1.8 per cent, more than for the preceding week, and 20,060 cars, or 3.8 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, but 169,940 cars, or 23.9 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.
PITTSBURGH, June 3 (AP) -- Jack Quinn went to the rescue of the Cincinnati Reds today and pushed Pittsburgh into a tie with New York for second place in the standing.

THE Arnold Bennett who is revealed in this third and final volume of the "Journal" is, if possible, more than ever a man of the world and a literary figure combined. Previous instalments of this extraordinary series of notations revealed the hardworking young man and the determined mature writer (novelist, playwright, essayist and special-article Journalist) whose primary purpose was "to get there" and stay there.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that loans on securities by its members increased $206,017,250 in May, compared with an increase of only $11,530,607 in April. The total at the close of business on May 31 was $528,509,438. The amount on May 31, 1932, was $300,397,222.

CHICAGO, June 3 (AP) -- Lonnie Warneke turned in his eighth victory of the season today as the Cubs snapped the Cardinals' seven-game winning streak with an 8-to-6 victory before 25,000 fans in the series final. It was only the second defeat in the last fourteen games for the first-place Cards.

IN the vast changes which the "New Deal" is bringing about the Department of the Interior is going to play a large part. The new conception of government; the concern for the "forgotten man." which has turned out to be more than an election promise; the technique of cooperation between government and industry, will all be reflected in this department.

WASHINGTON, Pa., June 3 -- At Washington and Jefferson College's commencement today Secretary Ickes, of the Department of the Interior, delivered the principal address to the 102 members of the graduating class and received the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws.

Wall Street and all the leading cities in Ohio were aroused last week by the news of the proposed auction bythe Chase National Bank of the collateral that it holds against defaulted loans made to Continental Shares, Inc., the holding-investment company through which Cyrus S. Eaton of Cleveland held for a while a dominating position In the steel, rubber, public utility and newsprint industries.
During the past year 40,000 American families paid off the debt on their homes and became outright owners, according to an estimate by the United States Building and Loan League.

James Mattern, Texas pilot, flew from Floyd Bennett Field just after 5 o'clock yesterday morning, bound round the world. He was sighted over Newfoundland, right on his course, about seven hours later.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 -- At a special election on June 27 California will select delegates to the constitutional convention to express the will of the State on the question of repealing the Eighteenth Amendment. As to what that will is nobody has any doubt, least of all the drys.

ALTHOUGH the nation's motorists have had occasion in recent years to exercise th power of their voices in protest against mounting and multiplying taxes imposed upon them, the salvo of deprecation which greeted the proposed three-quarters-of-one-cent per gallon addition to the existing Federal 1-cent levy attained truly stentorian proportions last week.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 1 -- The Riverside Park Jockey Club opened its sixth consecutive Spring meeting a few days ago at its plant, five miles north of Kansas City, in Platte County, the home of Governor Guy B. Park. The largest crowd in its history was there for opening day and passed more than $70,000 through the ticket windows as "donations" for the eight races that were run for substantial purses.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 3 -- The balance of the political parties in Congress is threatened by developments following the Radicals' introduction of a bill for the legalization, of divorce, according to well-informed circles.

Declaring that that tax exemption is a growing menace to the financial resources of the city and that it creates unfair competition, Benjamin Winter, real estate operator, said yesterday: "Like a bombshell within the ranks of already harried real estate owners fell the news that the Board of Estimate had passed the Knickerbocker City plan of Fred F. French for tax exemption.
The fellowship and prize awards to be given this morning at the commencement of the Jewish Institute of Religion, 40 West Sixty-eighth Street, were announced yesterday.
With the appearance yesterday of reactionary tendencies in most speculative markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange broke and ended with losses of 18 to 26 points.

This Summer more than ever, it appears, the real bargain in mind-and-body satisfying vacations may be found on the college campus. Courses under famous professors, food and dwelling often in luxurious academic halls, with a program that frequently includes golf, tennis, swimming, dramatics, hikes, sight-seeing trips and nature study, as well as sports and play schools for the children, all are being offered this year at less than the usual moderate charges.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Expansion of the upward trend of business activity and a rise in stock prices featured the domestic business situation in the week ended on May 27, according to the survey by the Commerce Department made public today.

Seasonal goods, particularly in the drug, cosmetic, confectionery and floor coverings field, were in active demand last week and, in most cases, the volume was ahead of both the previous and the corresponding week of last year, according to the report on business conditions in the metropolitan area prepared especially for THE TIMES by the New York Credit Men's Association.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 3 -- Mrs. George B. St. George of Tuxedo Park today for the second time won the Tuxedo Challenge Cup, the mostly highly valued piece of plate contested for by members at the Tuxedo Horse Show.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Illinois and Indiana are expected to line up with the prohibition repeal States next week. Illinois will elect delegates to a special constitutional convention on Monday, and Indiana will go through a similar process the following day.

MR. L. COLLISON-MORLEY is quite right when he says in the introduction to his book. "The Story of the Borgias," that the chronicle of their lives has the appeal of a detective story. "There is hardly one of the crimes," he writes, "that have been laid to their charge the evidence for which is conclusive.

THERE are now four cryogenic or low temperature laboratories in Europe and four in America. Of these the newest is that of the California Institute of Technology, where Dr. Alexander A. Goetz has again succeeded in liquefying helium, which means the attainment of a temperature of minus 452.1 degrees Fahrenheit, or 7.6 degrees above absolute zero, the temperature of interstellar space.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 -- Deciding that desperate measures were necessary, Manager Bill Terry today threw the weight of his bat and his playing into the Giant cause in both games of a double-header with the Phillies in time to save his team from utter destruction.

Plans for the participation of retailers under the National Industrial Recovery Act began to crystallize during the week, with the action taken by the National Retail Dry Goods Association at its Chicago convention a highlight of the developments.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You say, editorially, of the late Clarence C. Buel: "The idea of obtaining personal descriptions of the outstanding engagements and campaigns written by commanding officers on both sides, with their personal judgment on the merits of the strategy and the reasons for the military results, was Buel's own."

Sales of food have increased more than 5 per cent in restaurants serving beer, according to a report of the Society of Restaurateurs to the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board. The report was made public yesterday by Edward P. Mullooney, chairman of the board.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 3 -- The Harvard Athletic Association today announced the personnel of the Crimson rowing squad which will leave for its training quarters on the Thames in Connecticut tomorrow.

THE country is abloom; rose arbors are bursting into the fullness of their beauty; Madonna lilies are blossoming. It is almost as if nature had entered into a conspiracy with the flowers to provide a romantic background for the Summer bride.

ALLOWING for the holiday and some unseasonal weather, retail trade was well maintained in the week. Summer apparel, shoes and accessories and Summer home-furnishing specialties were the most active lines. Men's wear business improved.
BERLIN, June 3 -- The first response which the economic relief program of the Hitler Government has found in press and public has created an impression of another Nazi victory.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A distinct possibility that the Senate Banking and Currency Committee will not go into the income tax returns of members of J.P. Morgan Co. was evident today. This possibility (almost a probability) was not vouchsafed in any public statement by members of the committee; it may be changed by events before Monday when the hearing will be resumed.

AMONG the screen offerings last week was the Capitol's film. "The Nuisance," in which the alert-minded Lee Tracy demonstrates the tricks of that species of the legal fraternity known as "ambulance chaser." It Is the sort of picture which never misses fire.

LONG BEACH, Cal., June 3 -- Groping through the smoldering embers of yesterday's $3,000,000 oil-field fire, rescue crews today brought out two more bodies, raising the death total to nine persons and reducing to one or two the list of those still missing and presumed dead.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- A warning that prices ought not to be allowed to fall was sounded by Sir Josiah Stamp, director of the Bank of England and president of the London, Midland Scottish Railway, in his address before the Ecoonmic Club of Chicago Thursday night.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A warning against a revival of the railroad policy by which the carriers "went out frankly to cut the throats of their water competitors and made the rates whatever was necessary for the purpose," was expressed today in an Interstate Commerce Commission opinion delivered by Commissioner Joseph B. Eastman.

THE annual meeting of the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce at its headquarters here on June 15 promises to be a significant one for the industry. In addition to discussing the trends and problems of an unusually eventful period, the automobile manufacturers are expected to formulate the industry's stand on the proposed Industrial Control Bill.

VIENNA, June 3 -- The International Chamber of Commerce closed its seventh Congress today by adopting nineteen resolutions, among which was one approving modification of the most-favored-nation clause in trade treaties.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 3 -- ''Governmental measures for the revival of business" will be the subject of four informal lectures to be delivered at the annual commencement of Princeton University, to be held here June 15 to 20. This series of addresses has been arranged by the graduate school and the school of public and international affairs.

NEWARK, N.J., June 3 -- Jack Holt, bay gelding trotter, owned and driven by John W. Van Buskirk of Essex Fells, won the feature event of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey's opening matinee at Weequahic Park today.

Rising prices for securities and commodities in this country have been reflected in virtually all European markets, according to the international stock market indices compiled in Berlin, which are sent to THE NEW YORK TIMES each week.

CINCINNATI, June 2 -- The law college of President Taft, Speakers Uncle Joe Cannon, Champ Clark, Nicholas Longworth and a host of other men who have been prominent in the nation's affairs will celebrate next Friday the 100th anniversary of its founding.

VENICE. FOR centuries in the Middle Ages, Italy was the favorite battlefield of Europe. Now an internal struggle is raging throughout the land. It is the battle between the old and the new, between the memories of a glorious past and the ruthless exigencies of twentieth-century life.

LONDON, June 3 -- The World Economic Conference which opens here Monday, June 12, may decide an issue even more important than the time and method of recovery from the present depression. It may determine the main direction of economic policy for some generations to come.

LONDON, June 3 -- The Italian salvage steamer Artiglio II landed u50,000 [about $200.000] worth of gold from the wrecked liner Egypt at Plymouth today. It is believed that bullion worth another u400,000 remains in the hold of the sunken vessel.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 3 -- Bon Diable, owned by Mrs. John Hay Whitney of New York and Upperville, Va., was judged champion hunter of the Wilmington Horse Show today as the three-day exhibit came to a close.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Our lost frontier is found again. The youth of cities and towns hack away at more trees than they ever thought existed. They push roads through country as wild and as rugged as that of the Western movies which gave them vicarious thrills.

IN inverse ratio to its length is he wisdom of this utterance on poetry. Yet such a statement is superfluous since none who pretend to any literary awareness need be told that whatever comes from the author of "A Shropshire Lad" and "Last Poems" is ipso facto, authoritative.

Superchargers may be allowed on the Gold Cup racing boats as a result of the showing of John Wanamaker's Louisa in the regatta on Lake Garda, Italy, last month, and the planned international contests in Florida next Winter.

Gustave Hartman, former Justice of the City Court, who is regarded as one of the best vote getters among local Republicans, announced yesterday that he would take an active part in the campaign to oust Samuel S. Koenig, as chairman of the New York County Republican Committee.

PARIS, June 3 -- Senator Henry Berenger says in an article published in the Agence Financiere et Economique: "After Roosevelt may come Huey Long, and after Huey Long, who knows?" The French Senator characterizes the changes being undertaken under President Roosevelt as revolutionary.

COATESVILLE, Pa., June 3 (AP) -- A prediction that President Roose velt will be remembered "as the man who broke down the levee and let in a flood of inebriated in iquity" is made in the report of the Board of Temperance of the Philadelphia Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

CORTLAND, N.Y., June 3 -- Once the Industrial Recovery Bill comes into force, the era of rugged individualism and of equal opportunity for all has come to an end, according to Dean John T. Madden of the New York University School of Commerce.

MAGNIFICENT city of mysterious intrigues. Peiping has often risen from the ashes of desolation. Conquered by Chinese, Tatars, Mongols, Manchus, it has sheltered itself for six centuries behind its long and wide crenelated Walls.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 19 -- Foreign expeditions bent upon wrenching the secrets from Brazil's hinterland may enter this country but may not always enter the hinterland, according to a recent government decree. Henceforth an embargo is placed on all national expeditions of a private nature, and obstructions are placed in the way of all foreign expeditions.

Despite somewhat adverse weather conditions, retail trade made a good showing here last week. The month just closed showed the smallest percentage of decline in dollar volume in two years. Several leading stores reported a gain for the month over 1932.

THERE is a rumor (as authoritative as those things go) to the effect that Owen Davis has written another play. When Mr. Davis writes a new play that isn't news exactly, but there you have it. Katharine Cornell is reported more than considerably interested in it, but she will do nothing about it until Mr. McClintic returns from his European tour.

MALVERN, Ark., June 3 (AP) -- A story of a wild 12-hour ride over the greater part of Southern Arkansas was told here today by Austin Adams and Miss Beatrice Garner, who were abducted last night by two men they believed were escaped Kansas convicts.

THE dance, which has held its head extraordinarily high during the lean years we have faced, is apparently eager to be among the earliest harbingers of the upturn which is noted here and there in other lines of activity.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Chile and the United States are In complete agreement on the remedies for the world depression to be advocated at the London Economic Conference, President Roosevelt and Pedro Torres, president of the Bank of Chile, said in a joint statement today.

Methods for insuring proper valuation of real estate in line with changing conditions existing today will be the chief topic for the meeting of the American Institute of Appraisers to be held in the Stevens Hotel, Chicago, on June 13 and 14, as part of the annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

C.V. Whitney's Equipoise moved into seventh place among the world's money-winning thoroughbreds and maintained his eminence at the top of the handicap division when he easily drew off from a field of nine rivals yesterday at Belmont Park in the fortieth running of the historic Metropolitan Handicap.

The will of Mrs. Mary Eliza Blodgett, philanthropist, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday, contained bequests totaling more than $200,000 to eight religious and charitable institutions and specific bequests of nearly $1,000,000 for distant relatives, friends and, employes.

ABOARD THE S.S. PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, at Sea, June 3 -- Foreign loans by nations with large resources were described as an important potential contribution to world recovery by Secretary of State Hull tonight as the American delegates to the London Economic Conference surveyed the tasks ahead.

UNDER the confusing name of Chicago Opera Company, a troupe of singers, under the direction of Alfredo Salmaggi was to open last night a limited engagement at the New York Hippodrome. This Chicago company is no relation or descendant of the moribund Chicago Civic Opera, with which Leider, Lehmann, Kipnis and Schipa were associated.

NEW ORLEANS, May 31 -- The appeal to taxpayers of the city of New Orleans to pay their taxes "to preserve the credit of the city," made in large advertisements this week by Finance Commissioner A. Miles Pratt, has focused attention upon the financial crisis of both the city of New Orleans and the State of Louisiana.

BOSTON, June 3 -- Before a ladies' day crowd of 18,000 the Dodgers and Braves today staged an improved edition of yesterday's entertainment by again dividing a double-header, the Braves once more winning the first game and the Dodgers the night-cap.

IT is misleading to speak of Pitigrilli, as his publishers do, as the "modern Boccaccio." Only in one respect can Pitigrilli be remotely compared to Boccaccio, and that is in his ingenuity in devising plots, startling situations and brillian dialogues for his puppet-like characters.
ANDOVER, Mass., June 3 -- Capturing ten first places and tying for top honors in another of the fourteen events, Andover's track team rolled up a 79-47 victory over Exeter today at Brothers Field.

An alien race will supersede the American people in a few generations unless the present trend is reversed, according to Dr. Clarence G. Campbell, president of the Eugenics Research Association. He delivered the presidential address at the twenty-first annual meeting of the association at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday.

SUMMER group shows began to blossom forth in the galleries last week, supplemented by student work from schools and colleges and art classes. Though the events were notably fewer, they strove manfully to make up for their lack of number by novelty and variety.

News of the Senate Finance Committee's revolt against the administration in the matter of the Industrial Recovery Bill and informal intimations that the excited speculation was being anxiously watched in Washington gave the markets a bad fright yesterday.

LONDON. OUT in the great museum belt of South Kensington. a handsome new building of white Portland stone, which in the ordinary course would have opened shortly in a very modest way, has been overrun for the last six weeks by carpenters who have been hammering its interior out of all comparison to what the architects intended.

A notice for a 20 per cent reduction in the basic rate of pay is expected to be served soon by the railroads on their unions as a result of a conference held in Chicago on Thursday and Friday by a management committee headed by W.R. Thiehoff, general manager of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad.

DETROIT, May 31 -- Consensus of automobile officials here on the value of the Indianapolis Speedway races measured against the fatalities and serious injuries annualy incurred is solidly against continuance of the races under the present condition of the track.
Cardinal Hayes praised the work of the Ladies of Catholic Charity of the New York Archdiocese at the organization's annual conference yesterday. The conference was held in the Hotel Plaza.
MADRID, June 2 -- President Alcala Zamora this week offfered the first check that this Socialist-dominated government has met on its careening way along the road to power.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The State Department took the unusual step of filing a brief in the Warren Corporation case because of the importance of the principle involved in treaty-making powers. The decision handed down in New York today was regarded here as a distinct victory for the State Department.

No. 1, 429 Yards -- Par 4. A comparatively easy starting hole. The fairway narrows and a drive that Is too far to the left is caught by the rough, making the second shot rather difficult. The green is flat.

In the Feature Section of THE TIMES today. Secretary WALLACE argues that the farm problem is peculiarly difficult "because the people of the United "States during the past twelve years "have resolutely refused to face certain "fundamentals." It was logical for us to have an export surplus before the war.

An attempt to present knowledge as a unified whole rather than as separate subjects is being made under a new plan at Lincoln School. The plan, heretofore tentative, is now considered to have passed its experimental stages and will be put into regular use next Fall.

The first of the major heavyweight bouts of the current out-door season will be held this week, when Max Schmeling of Germany, former heavyweight champion of the world, opposes Max Baer of Livermore, Cal., in a fifteen-round battle at the Yankee Stadium on Thursday night.

PARIS, June 1 -- Advance Fall footnotes forecast that Schiaparelli's eelgray will be used for shoes to be worn with lighter gray, navy, red or black costumes. Taupe is also favored. Fawnbrown will be the best combination color, and particularly smart with black kid in new half-and-half types of shoes.

JERUSALEM PALESTINE, that tiny corner in Asia no larger than the State of Rhode Island, is enjoying a period of comparative prosperity and freedom from the woes and worries of depression that are gripping practically all the rest of the world.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 3 -- "The Peace Palace," a drama by Emil Ludwig, will be presented on Monday night as the first of a series of eight plays to be staged at the Westchester County Centre this Summer under the direction of Herbert J. Biberman.

Extending its advance into the tenth consecutive week, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has moved up a full point and a half, to 79.0 from 77.5 in the preceding week. A year ago, when the number was 65.9, the trend was downward.

EUREKA. Nev., May 30 -- To waive or not to waive. Around this familiar phrase thousands of Nevadans have waged an intense and earnest contest for months. At stake are several millions of hard-earned savings in twelve of the State's closed banks.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Bureau of Navigation Issued the following orders today, dated June 1:

Garbage and sewage have lately taken much of the Supreme Court's time. A fortnight ago Chief Justice HUGHES handed down a bristling opinion in support of the court's peremptory order to the State of Illinois to raise the funds required for the completion without further delay of the $139,000,000 sewage disposal works necessary to reduce diversion of the waters of the Great Lakes through the Chicago Drainage Canal.

Tenants making apartment house leases are advised by Clarence M. Lewis of the legal firm of Seligsberg Lewis to examine the customary leasing form carefully to see if it contains an automatic renewal clause. This clause provides that if the tenant does not notify the landlord of his intention to terminate the lease at its expiration date, the tenant is bound for another year at the same rental.

NO part of President Roosevelt's legislative program has excited so much interest among business men as the new Securities Act. This is true in spite of the fact that there has been less public debate about it than has been the case with several other of his measures.
DETROIT, June 3 (AP) -- The White Sox won the final game of the series with the Tigers today, 11 to 6. Bridges, Hogsett and Sorrell, pitching for the Tigers, yielded fifteen hits.

KAREL CAPEK says that he does not like to go traveling Nevertheless, he is the kind of person who should travel a great deal and always write books about his journeys. For he can see a great deal, see it with insight and understanding, and write about it edifyingly with very few words, whereas most travelers see very little that is of consequence and write about it with words in vast numbers.

THE theatrical year ended last evening, not long after 11:59 (Eastern Daylight Saving Time). All up and down Broadway grave producers were resting on their laurels and brown malacca canes. To the East, but not too far over there, actors were packing trunks in preparation for flight into Ye Rustic Playhouses of the nation.

EMPORIA, Kan., May 31 -- Hardly a fortnight ago Assistant Secretary of War Harry Woodring, former Governor of Kansas, called reporters to his office and told them the President had authorized him to announce the New Deal in public works for Kansas.

Explaining his resignation after twenty-eight years as director of the Institute of Musical Art. Dr. Frank Damrosch said yesterday that he would continue his connection with the institute on a day-to-day rather than a year-to-year basis.

SCIENCE is the keynote of the Chicago World's Fair, otherwise known as A Century of Progress. The man who directed the work of selecting and mounting the exhibits which fill the Hall of Science is Dr. Henry Crew. Before he retired from teaching, Dr. Crew occupied in the Northwestern University one of the few chairs for the history of science to be found anywhere.

Brilliant record-breaking performances, especially those of Richard Lundell of Manhattan Prep and Frank Maurier of St. John's Prep, featured the seventh annual city C.H.S.A.A. outdoor track and field championships yesterday at Boys High Field in Brooklyn as Manhattan Prep won the senior division team title for the first time.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 3 -- The activities in the Fernandez and Toledo sectors of the Gran Chaco were marked by minor patrol clashes yesterday, according to a communique today. Bolivian artillery fire was reported active in all sectors, especially in the Nanawa area, and "visible success" was achieved.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 3 -- A.W. (Laddie) Biggs of Huntington Bay and Jack Mackie of Inwood will meet tomorrow in a thirty-six-hole match over the Garden City Country Club course to decide who will be the successor to George T. Dunlap Jr. as Long Island's amateur golf champion.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Europe used to talk much about the Big Four, meaning the great leaders of the Versailles Conference. Now they are talking of the Big Three, meaning thereby Mussolini, Mustafa Kemal and Franklin Roosevelt.

All deciduous trees bear flowers, although the blooms are usually inconspicuous. The small red flowers of the silver maple fire the woods with color in the early Spring. The tiny flowers of the elm cover the branches like a yellow green mist. It is not of these that one thinks when he speaks of "flowering trees."

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was greatly interested in an editorial in THE TIMES commenting on a statement of Secretary Ickes to the effect that if he had anything to do with it there would be no roads in our national parks.

Amid some of the mightiest cannonading yet seen on either bank of the Harlem, 20,000 baseball addicts were thrown into a turmoil at the Stadium yesterday when the Yankees, after taking a fearful drubbing on their own account, turned about and flattened the Athletics for the second successive afternoon, 17 to 11.

AUTEUIL, France, June 3 -- The American champion, Miss Helen Jacobs, seeking the title vacated by Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, today advanced another step in quest of the French hard court singles championship. She rallied to defeat Mme. Jacqueline Goldschmidt, French indoor titleholder, to enter the semifinal round, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3.

SANTO DOMINGO, May 30 -- Eleven farming colonies, established in various parts of the Dominican Republic by President Rafael L. Trujillo, since he took office Aug. 16, 1930, are encouragingly successful, according to the official results for 1932, recently made public.

HAVANA, May 30 -- The wave of nationalism which swept over Cuba at the beginning of 1920, finding expression in a protective tariff wall which was pushed higher each succeeding year, has practically nullified the trade benefits granted the United States under the reciprocity treaty of 1902, and will undoubtedly be a stumbling block in the path of modification of this treaty, now under consideration here and in the United States.
DUBLIN, June 2 -- Two important facts emerge from recent pronouncements of Ministers here.

LONDON, May 27 -- People in the Inner circle of political knowledge often judge events differently from the public. They remain unmoved when public opinion tends to become excited and conversely it happens that they are impressed by an incident which the man in the street believes to be devoid of importance.

LIKE elephants, car buyers are slow to forget. Let them, whether by their own bitter experience or that of their friends, discover a defect in the construction of an automobile which adversely affects its performance, and they are likely to remember it long, sometimes after it has been corrected and "forgotten" at the factory.

PARIS, June 3 -- The Senate has authorized the opening of 2,000 more cafes in France, in spite of protests that there are already too many drinking places and that the health of the nation is being undermined by alcoholism.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The income tax law provisions Imposing a tax on profits from sales of securities and other property not connected with trade or business and the deduction of losses from such transactions are again the foreground of Congressional and public discussion.

The opposition of the National Association of Manufacturers and other groups to the labor and licensing provisions of the National Recovery Act was sharply criticized as "short-sighted and as apt to prove a boomerang, if continued," by Sol Herzog, New York lawyer and counsel to the Congress of Industries, yesterday.

HARTFORD, June 1 -- On the record of Connecticut, one of the two States that never ratified the Eighteenth Amendment, the special election on June 20 for delegates to the repeal ratification convention tentatively scheduled for some time in July should be a sweeping victory for the repeal forces.

BONN, Germany, June 3 -- Prince Wilhelm of Prussia, eldest son of the former Crown Prince, married Fraulein Dorothea von Salviati here today and with this act automatically renounced all claims to the German imperial throne that the monarchists hope to restore at some future time.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Veto of the $715,000,000 Independent Offices Supply Bill was urged upon President Roosevelt today by Lewis Douglas, Director of the Budget, and other officials.

WITH the publication in an English rendering of "Les Hommes de Bonne Volonte," by Jules Romains, it is clear that a French writer of moment has been emerging behind our complacent backs. While we have been acclaiming this novelist and that, a master -- or, at the very least, a near-master -- has quietly made his appearance.

THE two young early Victorians who wrote these letters might be the grandfather and grandmother of the principal characters in Noel Coward's "Cavalcade." Outwardly their lives seem to be placed in a time of incredible changelessness and security.

Leaders in sports, particularly in boxing, paid warm tributes to William Muldoon in statements issued yesterday. Among the many eulogies, one came from Postmaster General James A. Farley, Mr. Muldoon's former associate on the New York State Athletic Commission.

WARSAW, June 1 -- The Nazi victory at Danzig did not surprise Warsaw, as it was not the first time the free city had followed the Reich's example in electing as a Volkstag a miniature Berlin Reichstag.

UNDER the industrial sunshine spread by the upturned curves of business and commodities, the radio industry like the proverbial ground hog is coming out of its economic hole to see or not to see its shadow once again.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- When sixty-six nations bring their representatives together on June 12 in London to find out how their concerted efforts can pull them out of the economic distress afflicting all, sixty-five of the delegations will sit tight until they have heard the sixty-sixth advance its suggestions.

NEW YORK. Vicomtesse Edgar de Bresson and her son, Vicomte Chauncey Depew de Bresson of Paris, who had been at the Plaza, sailed on the Champlain. The Vicomtesse is the former Miss Anne Hegeman, niece of the first Mrs. Chauncey Depew.

JUNE is heralded as the opportune time for the radio industry to sell itself. It is then that the new radio-set styles begin to appear, and plans are formulated for the Autumn-Winter campaign in which the industry strives to sell radios to the public.

THE recent appointment of former Senator Smith W. Brookhart as adviser to the Agricultural Adjustment Administration for the purpose of arranging large-scale bartering with Soviet Russia directs attention to the many transactions that have been made between nations on a non-cash basis in the last few years.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Operations of the special suspense account, or "bankers' pool," as it was popularly known, by which a syndicate headed by J.P. Morgan Co. dealt heavily in securities at the time of the stock market crash in 1929, were described in some detail to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee yesterday by George Whitney, a Morgan partner.

While business on the Stock ExChange was unusually heavy yesterday toe a Saturday, the movement of prices was downward, the decline being the widest since March 21. The reaction was due, so the market apologists insisted, to an impaired technical position, but it was accelerated no doubt by a mystifying dispatch from Washington which Indicated that the administration was concerned over the rapidity of the advance in securities and commodities.

THE World Economic Conferrence, upon which so many hopes depend, meets next week In London. Probably no international gathering in history, with the possible exception of the peace conference In 1919, has been charged with the solution of issues that so vitally affect the future of our Industrial civilization.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I appeal to you for justice! You and your several hundred thousand readers know that for the last two or three years, more or less, I have been urging and insisting upon a uniform size for the delectable (syn. sweet, dainty, luscious) doughnut, and especially upon the uniform size of the doughnut hole and the absolute purity of the materials of which the hole is composed.

Russell T. Sherwood, who had been subpoenaed to appear before a Federal grand jury tomorrow was absent yesterday from his apartment at 311 Harrison Street, East Orange. N.J. A maid there said that he and Mrs. Sherwood had gone away for the week-end.

LONDON, June 3 -- While his colleagues in the British Government were beginning the Whitsuntide holiday, Prime Minister MacDonald flew back to London from Lossiemouth, reaching his Downing Street residence tonight. It is understood the issue of the war debt payment due the United States June 15 was one of the reasons for the Prime Minister's return.

BERLIN, June 2 -- The government of national revolution has just rounded out its fourth month in office. The balance sheet it presents for public scrutiny is chiefly impressvie in that it demonstrates beyond all cavil the regime's unchallenged political control of Germany.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 3 -- Edith Wynne Matthison, actress and head of the drama department at the Bennett School at Millbrook, N.Y., and Mrs. Garret A. Hobart of Paterson, widow of the Vice President of the United States during McKinley's administration, received honorary degrees today at the commencement exercises of New Jersey College for Women.

WASHINGTON FOR the past two months the State, War and Navy Building has been the scene of a most continuous discussions between American experts and the representatives of foreign nations, in preparation for the World Economic Conference which will open in London next week.

HOLLYWOOD. THE musical picture cycle is doomed to die early because of the inability of studios to get novel story ideas and novel forms of treatment, Lou Brock, RKO-Radio's tune-film producer, declared this week when his studio's first harmony effort, "Melody Cruise," was previewed and its second. "Flying Down to Rio," with Fred Astaire, was prepared for the sound stages.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is obvious that the time for action in settlement of the allied countries' debts is now here. No one in or out of official authority has yet shown how confidence can be restored, industry revived and the millions suffering from non-employment or starvation can again be employed so long as these unsettled debts bang like a pall over the whole country.

A LITTLE way south of the Equator in the Western Pacific lies the island of New Ireland, of the Bismarck Archipelago, northeast of Australia, to which It is mandated. It Is a long and narrow Island with a range of mountains through its centre, and on its easterly coast is the village of Lesu, a collection of fifteen hamlets totaling a little over two hundred souls and stretching three miles along the coast.

ROME, June 3 -- Pope Pius addressed a strongly worded encyclical to the Bishops, clergy and people of Spain today in protest against recent Spanish legislation termed injurious and offensive to the Catholic Church.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A favorable report to the Senate of President Roosevelt's national industrial recovery bill, with the essential licensing provisions restored, was the task Democratic leader set for themselves today as the Finance Committee completed its second day of revision of the measure.

Gene Venzke ran one of the most remarkable races of his career at the 130th track and field games of the New York A.C. in the picturesque Travers Island setting yesterday. Paradoxically enough, however, it was a 4:34.6 mile and it was a losing race.

Settling two cases that had threatened to embarrass this country at the World Economic Conference at London, the United States Customs Court ruled yesterday against the special tariff collected on coal imports from Great Britain and Germany.

COPENHAGEN TWO more volumes have now been added to "Skalholt," a novel by Gudmundur Kamban about seventeenth-century Iceland, and herewith the impelling and dramatic portrayel of the great Bishop Brynjolfur Sveinsson draws to a close.

CAREER MAN" really deserves the term "sophisticated" which is certain to be applied to it and which, indeed, has already been applied to it in the publisher's blurb. It has here, however, none of the usual offensive connotations of affectation and self-conscious amartness.

THE NEW YORK TIMES published an article headed "Securities Law Not Retroactive," which stated that officials of the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission, who preferred not to be quoted, had made it plain that although some people in New York had believed that the protective features of the bill, particularly Section 12, might be considered retroactive, such was not the case.
