CHICAGO, June 3 -- Galloping down the stretch before a World's Fair crowd of 30,000 spectators, Mr. Khayyam, the big bay colt owned by J.M. Austin of Old Westbury, L.I., repeated his Wood Memorial triumph over Head Play in the $25,000 added American Derby today, winning off by himself.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 3 -- The Harvard graduates today defeated Yale, 12 -- 5. The victors made eighteen hits, bunching eight for six runs in the ninth. Yale collected nine safeties.

In a controversy between clothing manufacturers of New York and textile finishers, the Appellate Division has upheld an agreement among the finishers that was asserted to be in restraint of trade. This was learned yesterday from a decision in a case brought by the New York Clothing Manufacturers Exchange, Inc., and its members, against the Textile Finishers Association, Inc., and its members.

Although Manhattan is known as the borough of skyscrapers, the average height of buildings oil the island is only five and three-quarter stories, according to a map prepared by emergency workers assigned to Borough President Levy's office.

Shoes in the South. Secretary of Labor PERKINS'S remark about the untapped shoe markets of the South has started something. The local newspapers hasten to assure Miss PERKINS that plenty of shoes are worn in that section, and from the vigor of some of the protests registered it must be so; no foot unprotected by leather would dare to kick so hard.

The delegates of sixty-six countries will be on their way to London the coming week to attend the World Economic Conference which King George will open on the morning of June 12. Economic and monetary troubles from the four corners of the earth are being borne over the seven seas to be laid upon the conference table.

NEW ROCHELLE, June 3 -- The College of New Rochelle opened its preliminary commencement activities today. The conferring of degrees upon 185 graduates will take place Monday, with Cardinal Hayes presiding at the final gathering of the largest class to be graduated from the college.

HERE'S another lively tale of the law's fight against daring cattle thieves in the old Southwest. But this one is a clever and ingenious variation on the old familiar theme. Jake Sands, who ran the Lazy S Bench ranch with a gang of thoroughly bad "hombres," was rustling cattle wholesale from the three neighboring ranches that hemmed him in, but his neighbors could not catch him at it.

PARIS, June 3 -- The French Government has instructed its Ambassador in Tokyo to make new representations to the Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs regarding the City of Tokyo 5 per cent 1912 bonds, it was learned today.

THE war birds of 1917-18 had little chance to wireless to the ground and when they did dots and dashes had to be relied upon. Those in the radio audience who tuned in on Amelia Earhart talking from an airliner over New York with eight different points on Manhattan Island eavesdropped on a demonstration that revealed radio's advance since the World War.

BY way of celebrating the thirtieth anniversary of the founding of the Woodstock colony, the Woodstock Artists Association has put on an important show, a retrospective, some of the work dating back, one is informed, thirty years.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- The navy in ready to start building thirty new ships within ninety days after the Industral Public Works Bill becomes law. This is part of a three-year $230,000,000 construction program.

The persecution of Jewish physicians and scientists by the Nazi government in Germany was denounced yesterday at the final session of the annual convention of Physicians' Square Clubs at the Park Central Hotel.

JULES VERNE ALLEN shows that the cowboy has not yet "gone the way of the longhorn," but still lives and works, "colorful and picturesque as ever," to the number of several thousands in various parts of the West and Southwest.

VIENNA, June 3 -- As delegates to the International Olympic Committee meeting, scheduled for next week, gathered today, there was a distinct movement afoot to cancel the award of the 1936 games to Berlin because of the anti-Semitic movement there.

IT has been bruited abroad by some persons, among them pessimistic music dealers, that the piano, like the opera, is dead; that it has disappeared as a popular music instrument; that it has been replaced in the public esteem by orchestral and other concerts outside the home, and by radio and records within it.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S recent message to the world, in which he urged the nations to hobble the mechanized forces of modem war, drew attention once more to the numerous improvements and developments Mars has made in his machines of destruction since the armistice.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 3 -- Rutgers University will confer about 600 degrees at graduation exercises of its several schools and colleges next week. The four-day commencement program will begin Wednesday evening when the New Jersey College of Pharmacy will grant diplomas to eighty-eight graduates in Newark.
Gene Tunney, former heavyweight boxing champion, in a despatch from Stamford, Conn., to THE NEW YORK TIMES last night, described his visit ten days ago to the bedside of his friend William Muldoon.

PARNASSUS, whose May issue appeared just before Memorial Day, is full of Chicago. "A Century of Progress in Collecting" is contributed by C.J. Bulliet, art critic of The Chicago Daily News, and Almus Pratt Evans writes about "Exposition Architecture: 1893 versus 1933."

THOUGH Miss Jolley was not precisely a governess, she stood in the mixed relation of an old and trusted governess and a maiden aunt to the Daggett family, whose children she had brought up from their earliest years, fending for them and managing them in spite of their father's unworldly abstraction.

IT odd that in the last quarter of a century, when attics have seen ransacked for everything from warming pans to antimacassars, the one thing overlooked until now has been our grandmothers' cookbooks. Whether the supply of spinning wheels and bedspreads gave out, or whether the owners of these antiques suddenly noticed with horror and mortification that the decorators no longer spoke of the spinning wheel as either "amusing" or "intriguing."

The listed bond market moved irregularly lower yesterday, when transactions reached $10,592,000, an unusually large total for a Saturday two-hour session. Aside from railroad bonds, which averaged slightly higher, the tone of the domestic corporation issues was heavy.

STOCKHOLM. ONE of the many interesting questions to be discussed by the thirteenth international congress of the history of art scheduled for Stockholm the first week in September, is the study of a stage when a distinctly national expression emerges in the art of a country.

HERE is a first book by a young poet who shows much promise. Miss Jones uses the lyric form always, but with variety In rhythm and cadence. Her Imagery is individual, her language very apt. She never overstrains an effect, or attempts, amateurishly, the melodramatic or startling.
LONDON, June 3 -- King George V celebrated his sixty-eighth birthday today amid the acclamations of his people, many participating in spontaneous demonstrations before Buckingham Palace.

During the past few days, Europe has visibly been lowering the hopes which she had been fixing upon America. At the time of President ROOSEVELT'S message to all the world, followed up as it soon was by the declarations of his Ambassador at Large, Mr. NORMAN DAVIS, at Geneva, there was almost universal jubilation in Great Britain and on the Continent.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 3 -- R.H. Helsel captured the High Scratch Cup in the regular shoot of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today, breaking 49 out of 5O targets. G. E. Mole took the Handicap cup in a shoot-off, P.E. Gardner winning the second prize.

MOSCOW, June 1 -- An intensive drive has been opened in the last few days to increase coal production. All coal experts will be mobilized and a relentless campaign will be launched against those who curb production in any way.

The Railroad Credit Corporation received applications from sixty-four railroads for loans amounting to $149,241,868, but made loans of only $73,691,368 to fifty-five carriers, according to the last report to be issued by the corporation as a lending organization.

One wonders what would have been the career of the Rev. JOHN MCDOWELL if an accident resulting in the loss of an arm had not made it impossible for him to continue work in the coal mines. That a preacher with a "breaker boy" experience was elected Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church hi title United States is significant of the spirit which pervaded the great body that honored him.

IT is impossible, "says Mr. Gilbert, "to understand the history of the United States without some knowledge of the exploration which was accomplished during the early part of the nineteenth century. This book attempts to draw a picture of the geographical setting of Western America as it appeared to the explorers of that time.

The Rhodes scholarships are now thirty years old. Scattered up and down the United States and Canada are nearly a thousand men who, under the terms of Cecil Rhodes's will, have received an Oxford education. For three days, starting today, they are holding a reunion on the campus of Swartnmore College, at Swarthmore, Pa.

CONCORD, N.H., June 3 -- Entering politics as a career unless one has other resources or business connections to fall back on was termed "too hazardous" by Ogden L. Mills today in speaking at the reunion day luncheon of St. Paul's School.

A drastic reduction in city taxes, a reduction in mortgage interest rates to 4 per cent and a decrease of at least 32,000 in the number of city employes are the remedies suggested by John A. Ward, a New York realty broker, as essential toward relieving the critical financial situation of the city.

STANDARDIZATION has swept away the lace-trimmed white muslin of the sweet girl graduate of bygone years. Today, when she steps up to receive her degree, she is attired in cap and gown prescribed by college authorities. Under the academic robe she wears a simple dress, the plainer the better; her shoes and stockings must be black.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- In response to numerous queries the Federal Trade Commission has issued this explanation as to the new Securities Control Act.

A.E. TAYLOR. Professor of Moral Philosophy in the University of Edinburgh, is a famous student of Plato and author of several books that reveal profound classical scholarship. In this little volume his scholarly methods are shown in careful and extensive documentation and in the wide range of classical knowledge which has furnished him with source material and authority.

THERE is a special quality which suffuses Hans Carossa's writing and somehow obliterates such ordinary factors as characterization and structure. Carossa is a physician; during the war he was a medical officer.

THE recent capture of the Corsican bandit, Andre Spada, should end, it would seem, a chapter replete with romance, brutality and exaggerations. For Spada is supposed to be the last of those outlaws who roamed the island fastnesses as "Robin Hoods," friends to the poor and robbing only the rich -- tourists excepted -- and defying even the military forces of France.

PRAGUE, June 2 -- The note of relief and satisfaction characterizing press comment and public opinion generally in Czechoslovakia concerning the communique from the Little Entente Conference, sitting here this week, is an unmistakable sign that the Little Entente is satisfied that it has escaped a threatening danger.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Federal Reserve Board will have its full complement of members for the first time in the Roosevelt administration, if two nominations sent by the President to the Senate today are confirmed. J.J. Thomas, of Seward, Neb., president of the State Bar Association of Nebraska, and M.S. Szymczzak, City Controller of Chicago, were the nominees.

HARVARD'S retiring president, A. Lawrence Lowell, Newton D. Baker and Louis McHenry Howe, one of President Roosevelt's secretaries, are on the speaker's calendar of radio this week. The Marine Band will broadcast a Pan-American concert, and the Chicago Symphony, assisted by 4,000 voices, will perform Handel's "Messiah."

THE signal concentration of authority, for the most part emergency powers, in President Roosevelt's hands since March 4 has undoubtedly appeared to most citizens as distinctly abnormal. Not a few conservatives have protested against it as dangerous in tendency if not in fact.

General improvement in business Conditions continued last week at a better than seasonal rate. Steel output neared 50 per cent of capacity, with operations stimulated by automobile, railroad and construction requirements.

HERE is a quaint and fascinating book that will delight lovers of France and her ancient story and will offer a strong allure to those who like to delve into intimate stories of life in other centuries. Almost 400 years ago the Sire de Gouberville lived his busy, contented, locally important life on his manor in Normandy, not very far as we moderns count distance, east of Cherbourg.

A FOUK-YEAR cycle in the life of an effeminate chorus boy, handled throughout with deft irony -- this is the story of handsome Larry'e sudden rise to opulent popularity and of his abrupt reversion to the penury in which the opening chapter reveals him.
PHILADELPHIA, June 3 -- Pennsylvania closed its baseball season by losing an Eastern Intercollegiate League game to Dartmouth on Franklin Field today, 5 to 3.

THE eighth annual session of the Bread Loaf Writers Conference will be held at Bread Loaf, Vt., from Aug. 16 to Aug. 30. The staff this year will Include Edith Mirrielees, in charge of work in the short story; Bernard De Voto, the novel; Walter Prichard Katon, drama, essays, articles and feature writing; Robert Hlllyer, verse; Gorham Munson, criticism, and Janet Ayer Fairbank, who will be present for one week as consultant in fiction.

Home owners in many parts of the State may not be acquainted with the provisions of two acts passed in the most recent legislative session which attempt to give some relief to those in real estate difficulties.

The action of the Senate Finance Committee in striking out the licensing provision of the National Recovery Bill aroused protest here yesterday from representatives of twenty-five trade union organizations. The elimination of this controlling force in the bill also evoked resentment from garment manufacturers.

LYNCHBURG, Va., June 3 -- Mrs. Pearl S. Buck, author and graduate of Randolph-Macon Woman's College in the class of '14, advised the alumnae of the college tonight to resolve firmly never to write a novel. But in case they could not resist the urge, she set forth for them a novelist's creed.

Prices moved irregularly yesterday in trading on local commodity exchanges. Silk and hide futures moved higher, while silver, rubber and wool tops were lower. Coffee, sugar and cocoa were not traded, their exchanges being closed on Saturday throughout the Summer.

LONDON, May 19 WE hope." said a lady in the stalls, who appeared to be closely interested in the production of "Heritage" by J.O. Twiss at the Fortune Theatre, "we hope to bring in two publics -- those who like horrors and those who are seriously interested in eugenics," and one of our critics has spoken of the play as live of Ibsen's "Ghosts" rolled into one.

THIS much-talked-of German novel deserves a warm welcome here in Mr. Sutton's fine translation. The humor, sentiment and naturalness of the original were so bound up in the phrasing of the small talk, in the simplicity of its German vernacular, that some of the flavor was sure to be lost.

IN order to form a library along quantitative lines, or on the basis of the rarity of its acquisitions, the chief requirements are time and money. Given these delectable assets, one could proceed to gather an invaluable collection almost blindly, or with no more than a weather eye on one's neighbor, to see how he is getting along.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 3 -- Away to a fine start under the handling of Olin J. Stephens 2d, the 12-meter sloop Iris was the winner in the 12-Meter Class on Long Island Sound today in the championship regatta of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club.

BUFFALO, June 3 -- When the fourth annual convention of the United Lutheran Synod of New York meets here, June 12-15, with ministerial and lay delegates from its 402 churches, it will spend considerable time wrestling with the financial problems of the body.
ROME, June 3 -- A start has been made toward carrying into effect the electrification of the Italian State railroads, announced by Premier Mussolini last October.

A recommendation that imported merchandise manufactured from American raw materials be accorded preferential tariff treatment was placed before administration officials and members of Congress yesterday in a letter from the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., June 3 -- Columbia's baseball team shaded Penn State today 9 to 8 in a weird game. Ray White, the visitors' star pitcher, was hit for thirteen safeties by the Nittany Lion batsmen, but nine errors on the part of the Penn State team enabled Columbia to triumph by its slight margin.

THE twenty-one-day fast of Mahatma Gandhi, completed without any apparent deleterious effect on his system, is by no means an extraordinary feat. His "great fast" of September, 1924, which also lasted twenty-one days, was undertaken at a time when he had barely recovered from a serious operation, and was therefore a remarkable performance.

LONDON THE LONDON TIMES has followed up its reports of the recent trial in Moscow of six engineers of the Metropolitan-Vickers Company with an investigation which owes much to personal statements by Allan Monk-house and John Cushny, two of the three men expelled for their alleged participation in "espionage" and ''sabotage."

IT is a dull month that does not produce some new discovery about the cosmic rays and thus contribute something to clearing up a major mystery of the cosmos. The latest announcements appear in The Physical Review. They come from Professor A.H. Compton of the University of Chicago and from Dr. Thomas J. Johnson of the Bartol Research Foundation in Philadelphia.

Several lots of foreign bonds and two entire industrial loans, together with a sprinkling of municipal bonds, comprised the announcements last week of bonds called for redemption prior to their dates of maturity. The total or bonds called for June is now $6,800,000, compared with $11,219,000 last month and $8,465,000 in June, 1932, at corresponding dates.

The first track and field championship of the Manhattan High School Athletic League went to Haaren High School's team yesterday when it compiled 43 points at George Washington High School Stadium. Stuyvesant was second with 39 and George Washington third with 37.
LONDON, June 2 -- The official silence on both sides of the Atlantic has not concealed the fact that war debts remain perhaps the greatest obstacle to success of the World Economic Conference.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 3 -- Princeton broke a five-game losing streak today, taking both ends of a double-header in defeating Rutgers, 6 -- 2, and the Penn A.C., 5 -- 1.

THE Columbia camera men who photographed the under-water scenes for "Below the Sea," which is now at the Rialto, had their problems. Water acts as a magnifying glass. At a distance of twelve feet from the camera there is a 100 per cent magnification, and a six-foot man appears to be twelve feet tall.

The earnings of Hunter College students in part-time employment have decreased more than 50 per cent during the last college year, according to a statement yesterday by Mrs. Harriet L. Loewenstein, head of the Bureau of Occupations.

THE growing interest in the styles of Queen Victoria's day is shown not only by fashions in women's clothes but in museum exhibits and by the vogue among certain decorators for the use of Victorian motifs in the arrangement of modern interiors.

As today is Pentecost, the feast of the Holy Ghost descending upon the Apostles, one of the greatest anniversaries in the ecclesiastical year, ranking almost with Christmas and Easter, virtually all pastors will preach today on that theme.

The task of keeping trout streams stocked is one of the hardest that fish commissioners face every year. Though hundreds of thousands are put into the waters there never is any certainty that any given stream will produce an abundance of fish for the sportsmen.

SEVERAL hundred homes have been completed in the Grand View Park section of Colonial Heights. Yonkers, N.Y., a development bordering on the Bronx River Parkway a short distance north of Bronxville. The orderly growth of the community has been fostered by the restriction on most of the property to building plots with at least seventy-five feet of street frontage.

LONDON THE subject of this year's Leslie Stephen lecture at Cambridge was "The Name and Nature of Poetry." As it was delivered by the professor of Latin, one might perhaps be pardoned for fearing that it would turn out to be a dry-as-dust academic dissertation, occupied with a study of recondite matters relating to the ancient classics.

THE rabbit-hop season in motordom is on again. Once more the outdoor urge draws prospective drivers in large numbers to the proving grounds, where more gulps of gas are fed to protesting sparks than congested highways could tolerate.

Fred C. Lemmerman, the Queens County representative on the Triborough Bridge Authority, regards resumption of work on the bridge as very essential to the best interests of that borough and its future development. A delegation from the Bridge Authority was in Washington recently conferring with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation regarding a loan to complete the construction of the bridge.

In an opinion declaring that "directors should direct," Supreme Court Justice Black denied yesterday an application by eight directors of the International Match Company to dismiss a $100,000,000 accounting suit against them. The suit alleges misfeasance and malfeasance arising from the domination of the company by the late Ivar Kreuger.

MADRID, June 3 -- The Catholic church opened today its first battle against the lay State, which it had tentatively supported, with a broadside condemning the law on religious congregations which President Alcala Zamora signed yesterday.

THIS admirably edited volume of the vast collection made by Thomas J. Wise of Robert Browning's letters covers the years between 1830 and the poet's death in 1889. The book contains none of the letters to Elizabeth Barrett, this correspondence having been published separately in 1899 by the son.

IN this second and more controversial volume of his magnum opus. Mr. Garvin deals with the turbulent decade 1885 to 1894, during which the parliamentary politics of Great Britain, still a traditional inheritance of the eighteenth century, blew up like a volcano in a final climax of sulphurous dialectic.

THIS is a novel whose sole appeal is to sanctity of subject. The author has built her story round a theme that in the course of centuries, has become so charged with religious emotion as to have lost its originally simple human meaning and to have taken on an almost purely symbolic significance.
Despite many announcements of similar projects, James J. Mattern of Fort Worth, Texas, is the first aviator to attempt a solo flight around the world.

The procedure followed by District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx in obtaining twenty-four convictions in racketeer cases, which was challenged in the Supreme Court, was sustained by the Appellate Division yesterday in a unanimous decision.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 3 -- The Peekskill Military Academy, founded 100 years ago by subscriptions obtained in the village and vicinity began its centennial celebration today with a military review. Class day exercises also were held.

THE John Krimsky-Gifford Cochran picturization of Eugene O'Neill's "The Emperor Jones" is an active production at the Astoria motion-picture studios which formerly housed Paramount's production activities in the East.
WASHINGTON THE farm problem is peculiarly difficult because the people of the United States during the past twelve years have resolutely refused to face certain fundamentals.

Columbia University's 179th commencement program will begin today with the baccalaureate service in St. Paul's Chapel at 4 o'clock. It will conclude on Tuesday evening with the outdoor degree ceremony, to be witnessed by 20,000 persons massed before the Columbia University Library.

On June 5, 1783, a group of curious but incredulous dignitaries gather near Lyons at Annonay, the home of the rich, paper-making MONTGOLFIER brothers, to witness an attempt at rising in the air. Beneath a paper bag 35 feet in diameter a smoky fire is built. The bag distends into a globe, rises to 6,000 feet and sinks to the ground half a mile away.

HERR MARCHWITZA has preempted for the proletariat a certain kind of bigotry that used to go hand in hand with conservatism. "Storm Over the Ruhr" is a novel that is likely to embarrass its radical author, since by its maudlin, narrow-minded and inept statement of the case for the workers in the Ruhr general strike and armed revolt of 1920 it perfectly condemns itself.

GENEVA, June 3 -- Faith in the essentials of the pre-depression American doctrine of prosperity through relatively high wages marks the first annual report of Harold Butler, the new director of the new International Labor Office of the League of Nations, as it did the reports of his predecessor, the late Albert Thomas.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The mystery behind the purchase of 200,000 toilet kits at a price of $1.40 each for the Civilian Conservation Corps, which precipitated a Senatorial investigation to determine the "guilty" administration official, was solved through the story of a persistent salesman who turned a deaf ear to discouragement.

Working control of the $2,000,000,000 Van Sweringen railroad system has been pledged for a $23,350,000 bank loan of the Cleveland Terminals Building Company, it is shown in the company's annual report. The loan has been outstanding since Oct. 31, 1930, but the security behind it was not disclosed until publication of its most recent report.
ALBANY, N.Y., June 3 -- A double by Hal King with the bases loaded in the ninth inning gave Albany two runs and a 5-to-4 victory over Jersey City today in the first game of their double-header.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Mrs. Roosevelt has decided to fly at night as well as by day on her cross-country trip to visit her son, Elliott, in Los Angeles, so as to cut down the time spent in travel, she announced today.

A willingness to turn a larger, share of the company's responsibility over to the junior officers and the conviction that the company is now in a financial condition which warrants its early reopening for business were expressed yesterday by E.C. Jameson, president of the Globe Rutgers Fire Insurance Company.

HERR MARCHWITZA has preempted for the proletariat a certain kind of bigotry that used to go hand in hand with conservatism. "Storm Over the Ruhr" is a novel that is likely to embarrass its radical author, since by its maudlin, narrow-minded and inept statement of the case for the workers in the Ruhr general strike and armed revolt of 1920 it perfectly condemns itself.

GENEVA, June 3 -- Faith in the essentials of the pre-depression American doctrine of prosperity through relatively high wages marks the first annual report of Harold Butler, the new director of the new International Labor Office of the League of Nations, as it did the reports of his predecessor, the late Albert Thomas.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Almost unanimous support for cutting this year's cotton crop at least 20 per cent was expressed at a conference of more than 100 representatives of the cotton industry with officials of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration today.

TORONTO, Ont., June 3 -- Five parties of geologists from the Ontario Department of Mines have gone to Northern Ontario to examine new ground for gold locations which may be developed into producing mines. Government forces under the direction of Charles McCrea, Provincial Minister of Mines, are doing their utmost to increase production.

That the larger well-balanced utility companies will be able to stand the new 3 per cent Federal tax on power sales, which is regarded as virtually assured of passage at this session of Congress, is the opinion expressed by experts familiar with public utility affairs.

Dr. Carlos de la Torre, president of the Cuban revolutionary junta in New York, asserted yesterday that if a plebiscite were held in Cuba President Machado would be defeated by a 100 per cent Opposition vote. This was in reply to a statement by President Machado in Havana last week to the effect that he would receive a majority if a plebiscite were held.

SOMEWHERE among his books the reader may discover an American edition of the poetry of William Wordsworth, edited by Henry Reed. If so, he may have at least an American first edition. The accuracy of its text may be questionable, for at that time there was no international copyright law, and publishers on this side of the Atlantic did pretty much as they liked.
New York University's 101st commencement program will start today at 4 P.M., with baccalaureate services in the chapel of the Gould Memorial Library at University Heights.
NEWARK, N.J., June 3 -- The Bears completed a short home stay today by dividing a double-header with Baltimore, thereby capturing the series from the hard-hitting Orioles.

Disappointed because no authority on foreign trade was named to advise the United States delegation to the World Economic Conference, the joint committee on foreign trade action will petition President Roosevelt this week to name some one of the several export executives attending the Vienna meetings of the International Chamber of Commerce as an adviser to the delegation.

New York City expects to raise $30,000,000 a year toward the cost of its unemployment relief through the new taxes on automobiles, taxicabs and building permits agreed upon by the Board of Estimate in executive session last Friday, it was learned yesterday.

Discussing hotel problems in general, with particular reference to present conditions, Mark M. Jones, a consulting economist, pointed out at a recent meeting of the Hotel Men's Association that the crux of the future situation of hotels probably revolves around the relationship between financial interests, owners and managers.

The statement made late last week in Berlin, by Dr. Hjalmar Schacbt, president of the Relchsbank, that the debt service on Germany's external bonds of all descriptions would probably be suspended is expected to bring about an early proclamation by President Roosevelt setting up the American "Corporation of Foreign Security Holders," lor which" provision "was made in the recently enacted Federal Securities Act of 1933.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Roosevelt and administration leaders hope that Congress will finish the work of the special session by next Saturday or soon thereafter. There is much to be done, however, this being the status of major legislation favored by the administration:
Important among the highway improvements proposed by the Regional Plan of New York and Its Environs is a parkway to connect Riverside Drive and Van Cortlandt Park.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Considerable surprise both in legislative and administrative circles was caused today by the publication in THE NEW YORK TIMES of a report by Controller General McCarl to a special committee of the Senate alleging abuse of Farm Board funds and the use of its loans for purposes other than authorized.

SAMUEL UNTERMYER celebrates on Tuesday seventy-five years of life and fifty-four years of law, matters which in his case, have been and still are pretty much one and the same. For the law has been his one love since he began practice at the age of 21, trying seventy-three cases in his first year and earning fees amounting to $75,000 -- not bad for a young fellow in those days.
WESTFIELD, N.J., June 3 -- Play in the third annual Anne Cumming memorial tournament started today at the Westfield Tennis Club with an entry of thirty-six girls under 18.
PARIS, June 2 -- Despite the tremendous importance of what has been happening beyond France's frontiers, it was internal and not external affairs that preoccupied the French during the last week.

ONE customarily pauses, about this time, to glance back across a completed art season and to draw what conclusions the survey may prompt. It has been in many respects a rather lean and distressful year, due to the protracted depression.

With the finest entry the tournament has drawn in recent years, the sixteenth annual open Brooklyn tennis championship got under way yesterday on the clay courts of the Terrace Club of Flatbush, Avenue I and East Seventeenth Street.

BOSTON, May 31 -- New England is quick to act under the teems of the National Industrial Recovery Bill. True, a bill is not an act, but the universal understanding is that this measure for the cooperation of business and government in promoting the return to normalcy is sure to be a law very soon.

CONTRARY to what one might expect, this book, the first attempt in any language to chronicle all the anti-Bolshevik military efforts during the civil war in Russia and to picture "a conflict so vast that no one man could o o o hope to describe it without loss of proportion In some aspect," is neither the work of a Russian author nor a translation.

The methods adopted by Cleveland and Chicago to rehabilitate slum or neglected areas will be presented by some of the leaders who worked out the details at the convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards opening in Chicago on Monday, June 12.

The national open championship, which gets under way at the North Shore Country Club, Gienview, Ill., on Thursday, will revolve pretty much around one central figure -- Gene Sarazen, stocky New York professional who last year captured both the British and United States open titles.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Legislation to prevent the concentration into a few hands of control of industry and finance is being seriously studied by members of the Senate Banking Committee as a result of the disclosures in the investigation of J.P. Morgan Co.

PARIS THIS season there is a smart evening silhouette for every fashionable fabric. By taking in order the evening materials of the moment and discussing what outstanding couturiers have done with them in the most amusing manner, one can draw a very good picture of what the Autumn stylescape will look like after dark.

KANSAS CITY. June 3 -- In testimony closely paralleling the confession of Walter H. McGee, Miss Mary McElroy told the Federal grand jury today how she was forced from a bath by two men armed with shotguns, taken to a house near Shawnee, Kan., and chained to a wall twenty-nine hours until ransomed by her father.

LONDON, May 18, 1933 THE attitude of London audiences toward the operas of the "Ring," "Tristan" and "Parsifal" finds its only fitting parallel in the national worship of Handel's "Messiah." Some years ago Joachim expressed the opinion that if it was difficult to win the affection of the British public, once won it was impossible to lose it.
ROME, June 3 -- All news received from the extreme north continues extremely discouraging for an early start of General Italo Balbo's flight to Chicago with twenty-four Italian seaplanes.

PARIS, June 3 -- Reports that France Intends soon to relieve Imports from Britain from the 15 per cent surtax were revived today because of the arrival of Montagu Norman, governor of the Bank of England, last night for discussions with officials of the Bank of France.

PITTSBURGH, June 3 (AP) -- Pleading for party harmony and a militant organisation, Postmaster General James A. Farley tonight predicted that the star of Democracy would rise in Pennsylvania, long a Republican stronghold.
WEST POINT, N.Y., June 3 -- Bucknell came from behind to win an eleven-inning game from Army today, 8 to 7. Reznichak's triple with a man on second tied the score for Bucknell in the ninth.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Reports from Washington that Secretary of Agriculture Wallace regarded the upturn in commodity prices as a speculative movement that interfered with the provisions of the Farm Relief Act, combined with reports that control of prices and acreage of wheat would not be attempted in the coming crop year, threw a bombshell today into the ranks of wheat bulls on the Board of Trade.

To the Music Editor: We, the undersigned, have united to form a Composers Protective Society, to reinstate the composer to his rightful place in the world of music. One more society on the scene of modern musical activity can little justify itself unless it embody ideals and aims that set it apart from the existing groups now functioning under one aegis or another on behalf of contemporary music.

OMAHA, Neb., June 1 -- The Middle West saw the ghost of a painful experience walk when the guarantee of bank deposits was revived and incorporated in pending Federal bank legislation. This region was the dog on which the experiment was tried and it emerged from that experiment a pretty badly shaken and disillusioned canine.

With commodities continuing to advance, quotations on some merchandise have been increased to the point where the new price on the finished article lifts it out of its former retail range, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer.

Instead of sending large sums of money to foreign countries for religious work the churches of New York were urged to establish social centres here, where young persons, crowded out of the family apartments, would meet and entertain their friends.

WOMEN miss much that is worth while," says Mrs. Borden: and her desire to participate in the outdoor world of fishing and hunting in which her husband found such fascination led to the experiences of which she tells in this colorful book.
RESURRECTED with modern trimmings, here is a Zenda romance so closely akin to the ancient standby that even the author himself, early in his story, casually remarks the resemblance.

Three hundred youthful mariners went down to Central Park with their ships yesterday to compete in the annual sailboat races. The regatta was held, as usual, on Conservatory Lake, near Seventy-second Street. There were no mishaps.

ONE effect of every period of economic gloom is to set persons with things to sell studying, with far greater fervor than in boom times, the ways and habits of the ultimate consumer -- or possibly it would be better to say the ultimate purchaser.

PARIS, June 3 -- Reports that France Intends soon to relieve Imports from Britain from the 15 per cent surtax were revived today because of the arrival of Montagu Norman, governor of the Bank of England, last night for discussions with officials of the Bank of France.

PITTSBURGH, June 3 (AP) -- Pleading for party harmony and a militant organisation, Postmaster General James A. Farley tonight predicted that the star of Democracy would rise in Pennsylvania, long a Republican stronghold.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Plans for the distribution of the $3,300,000,000 to be made available under the public works section of the proposed Industrial Recovery Bill are being carefully studied by administration officials. Methods best calculated to stimulate business and employment quickly are sought.

CARMEL, N.Y., June 3 -- Prince W., a bay gelding, owned by Gil Stevens of New Canaan, Conn., won the Class A trot and pace at the opening matinee of the season at the driving park today after losing the first heat to Newbrooke Volo, owned by John Brislin of Brooklyn, in 2:11.

THOSE who simply must attend first nights will do their share of commuting this week. For the nearest one -- in fact, the only one in what is whimsically called the metropolitan area -- is up in White Plains. That's tomorrow night, the occasion being the public unveiling in America of Emil Ludwig's "Peace Palace," nee "Versailles."

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- The administration's railroad bill was brought to the point of passage in the House today, unchanged in any major provision, but there were so many absentees that a vote went over until Monday.

OMAHA, Neb., June 1 -- The Middle West saw the ghost of a painful experience walk when the guarantee of bank deposits was revived and incorporated in pending Federal bank legislation. This region was the dog on which the experiment was tried and it emerged from that experiment a pretty badly shaken and disillusioned canine.

With commodities continuing to advance, quotations on some merchandise have been increased to the point where the new price on the finished article lifts it out of its former retail range, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer.

Instead of sending large sums of money to foreign countries for religious work the churches of New York were urged to establish social centres here, where young persons, crowded out of the family apartments, would meet and entertain their friends.

WOMEN miss much that is worth while," says Mrs. Borden: and her desire to participate in the outdoor world of fishing and hunting in which her husband found such fascination led to the experiences of which she tells in this colorful book.
RESURRECTED with modern trimmings, here is a Zenda romance so closely akin to the ancient standby that even the author himself, early in his story, casually remarks the resemblance.

Bill Terry's hustling Giants yesterday broke the recently acquired Dodger habit of splitting double-headers as 32,000 fans looked on at Ebbets Field. Max Carey's athletes went down to defeat, 2 to 0, and 6 to 1, only a home run by Lefty O'Doul saving them from a pair of shut-outs.
The spirit of Pentecost was stressed by the Very Rev. Milo H Gates, dean, in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, yesterday. He said:

With one month, remaining of the current fiscal year, the Federal deficit for 1932-33 stood at $1,684,000,000 on May 31. This figure makes a distinctly favorable showing when compared with a deficit of $2,685,000,000 for the correspending period a year ago.

BERLIN, June 3. -- Dollar exchange in Berlin fluctuated within a narrow range during the week and hardened toward the end. The relative quotations for dollar and sterling hardly changed. The local money market eased slightly after month-end settlement demands were satisfied, but the discount market remained inactive, including Treasury notes.

It has been said that this is repudiation. I am not prepared to controvert that statement. But the bondholder must take his place in the sacrifice which the American people have been enduring. We must cease to pay tribute to the gold standard at the expense of the average citizen of the United States.
ALBANY, N.Y., June 4 (AP). -- Newark scored enough runs in the first inning of each game of today's doubleheader to sweep the twin bill with Albany, 9 to 1 and 4 to 1.

Stanley P. Davies, associate secretary of the State Charities Aid Association, has been chosen general director of the Charity Organization Society, Walter S. Gifford, president of the society, announced yesterday.

ROME, June 4. -- Premier Mussolini, author of the four-power pact. Is waiting from day to day for the delayed agreement to his ten-year plan for European cooperation, not as the founder of fascism or the Dictator of Italy but as an apostle of peace.

MADRID, June 4. -- Although all signs here point to a conflict between church and State, the Bishop of Madrid revealed today that as yet neither the Pope nor the Spanish episcopate has excommunicated President Niceto Alcala Zamora nor members of the Spanish Cortes which passed the drastic law on religious congregations.

With a crowd of 65,000, one of the largest to jam the Stadium. In years, providing the setting, the Yankees swept majestically to a clean sweep of their four-game series with the Athletics by upsettins the Mackmen in both ends of a double-header yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent LL. B., in commenting on Dr. Sparling's analysis of overcrowding in the professions, suggests as a remedy that we inquire "rigidly into the mental and social background of the applicants for admission to all professional schools before matriculation," and on the basis of such inquiries eliminate all but the "fittest."

"The Investor Pays," by Max Lowenthal, just published by Alfred A. Knopf, is a reconstructed record of what happened before and during the greatest receivership in American history, that of the Chicago, Milwaukee St. Paul Railway Company, which occurred in 1925.

It is a long way from Canada to Florida, yet these two extremes present wonderful opportunities for the sportsman-angler For instance, from Boca Grande, Nokomis and Sarasota, Fla., comes word that the tarpon are more abundant than in many years, while from Montreal the report is sent that salmon, speckled trout and lake trout now are biting as never before.

Walter Bosenbaum was enjoying the peaceful Sunday quiet before noon yesterday in his home at 1,077 Sackett Avenue, the Bronx, when he heard a persistent thumping at a window screen. Annoyed, he got up to investigate.

CHICAGO, June 3. -- Steady gains in retail and wholesale business and in manufacturing industries have been reported for May in this district. For five months now this enlargement has been under way, with increased employment and numerous advances in wages announced or under consideration.

One of the major tragedies of civilization is being enacted in Germany where Jews are being oppressed and discriminated against by Chancelor Hitler and his followers, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of the Free Synagogue declared yesterday at the eighth annual commencement exercises of the Jewish Institute of Religion, 40 West Sixty-eighth Street.

Confidence that he will defeat Mayor John P. O'Brlen in the Democratic primary was expressed yesterday by Representative Loring M. Black Jr., who announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Mayor in Washington last week.

A dinner will be given tomorrow night at the River Club to record the progress of the committees engaged in raising an emergency fund for the New York Nursery and Child's Hospital, which is in danger of closing because of a lack of maintenance funds.

For the second week in succession commodities traded on exchanges here moved higher last week, some scoring broad gains. All were steady. In general, however, the commodities were not so buoyant as securities. Trading was in good volume.

Cardinal Hayes was the celebrant of a pontifical mass yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral in observance of Pentecost, which has been called the birthday of the Christian church. The mass was a colorful service almost equal to the pontifical services of Christmas and Easter.

BUENOS AIRES, June 4. -- All commodity markets here continue active, with rising prices as the result of brisk export demand. Last week was the best of this year for cattle sales, prices being strengthened by the demand for hides, tallow and other by-products, which are all selling higher than in recent weeks.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., June 4. -- Jews were advised today by Samuel M. Vauclain, chairman of the board of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, not to worry "about their German friend Hitler or take him seriously."

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- More than 130 trade associations have already made tentative agreements for increased wages and, in many cases, shorter working hours for labor as soon as business is stabilized.
CINCINNATI, June 4 (AP). -- The Cardinals today won the first game of a double-header, 4 to 2, but dropped the second contest to the Reds, 6 to 2, before more than 20,000.

No authentic reports had been received at an early hour this morning of James Mattern, who started Saturday morning on a flight around the world. His first stop was to have been Paris, and his schedule called for his arrival there not later than noon yesterday, New York Time.

Establishment of a Matrimonial Court in Manhattan and the Bronx to speed adjudications and to minimize alimony evils, has been recommended to the Appellate Division in a report by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo, it was learned yesterday.

FRANK ESCHMANN, Deputy Sanitation Commissioner, now retired on a pension at the age of 66 after thirty-four years of service, was a man of peace and modest aspirations. In the heyday of the Schroeder regime he wrote a poem for the spiritual guidance of the white wings in that cheery house organ, "D.S." One stanza of it ran:

"Justice Is not a figure holding a balance and blindfolded, but she holds a scroll in one hand and a cross in the other," said the Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin, pastor of the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.

ABOARD THE S.S. PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, AT SEA, June 4 (AP). -- The biggest danger facing the World Economic Conference was described in quarters close to the United States delegation tonight as the risk of a stalemate as a result of jockeying for position.
PATERSON, N.J., June 4. -- Shot ten times in the face and chest, William Oppenheim, said by the police to be the third Waxey Gordon beer runner killed in three days, was found dead here this morning.
PITTSBURGH, June 4. -- Demand for steel continues to advance over its broad front, no recessions being observed at any point, although nowhere are there any outstanding cases of increases.

A letter urging Governor Lehman to investigate the State Milk Control Board on the ground that it favored dealers and producers to the detriment of the public, was made public yesterday by the Community Councils of the City of New York, Inc.

BOSTON, June 4 (AP). -- The Braves and Phillies divided a double-header before 20,000 fans today, the tailenders taking the opener, 1 to 0, behind Ed Holley's five-hit pitching, and Boston the nightcap, 9 to 6. The box scores:

Sir Basll Thomson, who headed the famous Criminal Investigation Department of New Scotland Yard for eight years, has written a murder mystery called "P.C. Richardson's First Case: A Tale of Scotland Yard." which Doubledday, Doran will publish on June 14.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Extension of a credit of $50,000,000 to the National Government of the Republic of China to purchase American cotton and wheat in the open market was announced tonight by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, as another step in the administration's program to bring about economic recovery.

BERLIN, June 4. -- The first clash of the National Socialist regime with the Catholic church came today with the removal of Dr. Berthold Altaner, Professor of Church History in the Catholic theological faculty of the University of Breslau. He was dismissed by Bernhard Rust, the Prussian Minister of Culture and Education.

The two most dangerous emotions playing over vast aggregations of people today are hatred and avarice, declared Dr. Elmer Ellsworth Brown, retiring chancellor of New York University, yesterday in his fare-well baccalaureate sermon to seniors of the university.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There has been an insistent demand on the part of many people that Congress should "soak the rich," and in an endeavor to secure a larger amount of tax from the larger incomes there has been added from time to time a surtax, and also a tax on capital gains, to prevent people from becoming too rich.

LONDON, June 3. -- It is feared here that speculation is very largely responsible for the improvement in business and that commodities are not going into consumption at anything like a corresponding rate. The impression has been formed that the rise in American prices is of similar character; and it is believed speculation will be responsible for a considerable reaction, unless there is an unexpected and sharp forward movement in international trade.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is true that the city has neglected the Brooklyn Bridge terminus in a disgraceful way. The ugly structure at Park Bow not only spoils the neighborhood, but acts as a Chinese Wall against any improvement to come from the south.
Eleven teams have entered for the first of the season's polo tournaments at the Meadow Brook Club, the Third Westbury Challenge Cup, which starts on Saturday, it was announced yesterday.

LOUVAIN, Belgium, June 4. -- The Louvain University Library's third balustrade was smashed early this morning -- for the second time by the same man, Edmond Felix Morren, a building foreman formerly employed by the American architect, Whitney Warren.

VIENNA, June 4. -- Germany must recognize the equality of Jewish athletes or the 1936 Olympic Games will be held elsewhere than in Berlin, Brig. Gen. Charles Sherrill, United States delegate, said today on his arrival to participate in a meeting of the executive committee of the International Olympic Committee.
Resale of a new Jersey City flat wag included In the New Jersey realty trading reported over the week-end.

A nation-wide appeal to American Jews to assist in developing plans and obtaining means for large-scale Jewish farm colonization in the United States was issued yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the Central Commission for Jewish Colonization at the Hotel McAlpin.
The Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee will disband on Sept. 30, Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the committee, announced yesterday.

An inbound Staten Island ferryboat, with 1,160 passengers aboard, was about 100 feet from the Manhattan slip at South Ferry at 5:40 o'clock yesterday afternoon when Captain Arthur F. Bowman discovered that his pilot-house floor was in flames.

The social activities of the present academic year at Columbia College will be brought to a close tonight with the annual senior promenade in John Jay Hall. The dance will be preceded in the afternoon by the Columbia College class day exercises, during which members of the graduating class will receive prizes and awards for scholastic and personal distinction.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- Several hundred Jewish leaders of fifteen mid-Western States met today at the Standard Club and unanimously approved the campaign of the American Joint Distribution Committee to raise a $2,000,000 relief fund for their coreligionists in Germany.

Hopeful prospect for action toward world recovery by the economic conference opening in London next week was asserted yesterday by Abraham Frowein of Germany, retiring president of the International Chamber of Commerce.

The investing banking organization of Starkweather Co., Inc., made up of former executives and personnel of Harris, Forbes Co. and of the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation, will begin business today, with the main office at 111 Broadway and branches at 292 Madison Avenue and in Baltimore, Buffalo and Atlanta.

Hostilities in the Far East are terminated by a truce between Japanese and Chinese, but the conflict thus brought to a close has not been the bilateral one upon which the attention of the world has been fixed. Japan has been fighting on two fronts-against both China and Russia.

SYRACUSE, June 4. -- Graduates of Syracuse University, numbering 1,040, were warned by Bishop Francis J. McConnell, head of the New York area of the Methodist Episcopal Church, against "easy adjustments to life," in the baccalaureate sermon this morning.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 4. -- Victory of Army over Harvard in their recent mathematics contest by a score of 98 to 112 was announced today by Professor Arnold Dresden of Swarthmore, who prepared the questions and graded the papers.
Plans for stabilizing the printing industry will be discussed in Washington tomorrow with William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, by a committee of Typographical Union 6.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 4. -- Jack Mackie, stalwart son of the Inwood professional and former New York State amateur champion, won the Long Island amateur title today when he defeated Albert W. (Laddie) Biggs, 2 and 1, in a closely fought thirty-six-hole final at the Garden City Country Club.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- The action of the markets on Saturday was attributed to reports from Washington that prices had advanced too fast, causing a rapid reversal of market positions on the part of large Eastern interests which had been the main supporting factors for some time.

NEW HAVEN, June 4. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 62.1, which compares with 61.2 a week ago, 60.6 two weeks ago, 59.5 three weeks ago and 59.2 four weeks ago. The present average is the highest of the year to date; the average of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.

RENO, Nev., June 4 (AP). -- Eugene A. Bowen, former New York restaurant owner, was held in the city jail here today on a charge of assault and battery brought by Mrs. Miriam V. Hostetter Young of Pittsburgh, heiress to the Hostetter fortune.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- Some quarters of the packing industry are reported to be wishing to see higher prices for hogs, as an Increase might prevent the processing tax from being applied under the regulations of the Rarm Relief Act. If prices were marked up materially, the farmer would receive more money for his hogs and all interests would be benefited, without the necessity of the tax.
PARIS. June 4. -- Predicting that the budget deficit would reach 18,000,000,000 francs by the end of this year, the Nationalist newspaper La Liberte says tonight:

Olsen and Johnson, Barbara Newberry and Dorris Groday this evening take the places in "Take a Chance" previously held by Jack Haley, Sid Silvers, June Knight and Mitzi Mayfair. At the same time Harriette Lake substitutes for Lois Moron in "Once in a Lifetime."

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 4 (AP). -- Jimmy Foulis of Chicago sailed over the stretches of the Keller layout with parsmashing golf today to beat George Von Elm and an illstar field in the $5,000 St. Paul open championship. He scored 283 for the seventy-two holes.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., June 4. -- For the third time in his brief career in the show ring, The Great My Own, the striking little black cocker spaniel owned by Leonard J. Buck of New York City, was named as best in the show today.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- The Winter wheat crop's prospects have changed little in the last month, and it is estimated that, barring accidents in the next three months, the United States will raise 627,000,000 bushels, or sufficient for bread and seed for the crop year running from July 1 next to June 30, 1934.

CHICKASHA, Okla., June 4 (AP). -- Highway marauders terrorized motorists of Oklahoma and Arkansas, a desperado accused of abducting twelve persons was arrested and Bob Goodfellow, kidnap victim, was wounded in a gunfight today.

CLEVELAND, June 4 (AP). -- The Indians staged late rallies in both their games with the Tigers today and succeeded in winning the first contest, 2 to 1. Detroit took the second, 4 to 3, when Cleveland's eighth-inning drive fell short by one run.
PITTSFIELD., Mass., June 4. -- There were several diversions In the Berkshire Hills colony during the week-end.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., June 4. -- Stressing as the foremost task of government provision for the destitute, the aged, and the infirm, Governor McNutt of Indiana delivered the baccalaureate address to the graduates of Notre Dame University today.

LONDON, June 3. -- The monetary situation remains extremely easy, so easy, in fact, that large government disbursements have produced no noticeable effect on rates, which for loans and discounts are at nominal levels and incapable of falling much, if any further.

JOHNNY BROACA, late of Yale, joined the Yankees and thereby precipitated a brisk debate. All the facts are not in yet, for Johnny says he is going back again in the Fall to finish out his course. He recently completed his junior year and took his examinations before leaving New Haven for the Bronx.

NEW HAVEN, June 4. -- Opposing a bill passed by the Legislature enabling West Haven to tax Yale athletic properties, President Angell said today that such an act would reverse the historic policy of Connecticut exempting the university from taxation except on real estate from which an annual income is derived.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP). -- In view of a New York Customs Court's decision, lopping the $2 a ton tax from coal imports. General Brice P. Disque said today that an effort would be made to insert in the industrial recovery bill a clause to exclude foreign anthracite altogether.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Loans to farmers' cooperatives from Farm Board funds totaling $2,672,536.97 were authorized in the period from Feb. 28 to April 30, Henry Morgenthau Jr., governor of the Farm Credit Administration, stated today. The Credit Administration succeeded the Farm Board in the reorganization effected by President Roosevelt.

Bankers, brokers, business men -- all former choir boys at old Trinity Church -- resumed their places in the choir stalls of the church yesterday afternoon. They were there to participate in the eleventh annual service of the Trinity Choir Alumni Association.

The Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, pastor of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that Christians should banish utterly their fear of death. Dr. Darlington's mother, Mrs. Ella Louise Bearns Darlington, widow of Bishop James Henry Darlington of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Harrisburg, Pa., and the mother of three clergymen, died Friday night.

Jersey City engaged Baltimore in a double-header at Jersey City yesterday and gained an even break. The home club defeated the Orioles, 6 to 5, in an eleven-inning first game, but was routed in the second contest, 10 to 3.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 4. -- Sixty-four seniors will receive degrees tomorrow at the commencement of Upsala College. The address will be by the Rev. Dr. Gould Wickey, educational director of the United Lutheran Church of America and secretary of the National Lutheran Educational Conference.

Travel on the various transportation, lines entering and leaving the city dropped sharply In 1932, continuing the downward trend of 1931, according to a survey made public yesterday by the Transit Commission.

The women's division of the Architects' Emergency Committee will present an elaborate fashion show on June 25 in the gardens at Sunken Orchard, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. McCann at Oyster Bay for the benefit of unemployed architects and draftsmen.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 4. -- Owners and managers of accumulated capital will be called upon to put it at work in productive enterprises which will employ workers at a living wage, leaving profits to take second place, it the United Lutheran Synod of New York adopts a report of its Inner Mission committee.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., June 4. -- Pleading for internationalism, translation of noble ideas into actions and better spiritual insight into all spheres of life, the Rev. Dr. Willard L. Sperry, dean Of the Harvard Theological School, preached the baccalaureate sermon today to the 121 members of the Swarthmore College graduating class and 1,500 relatives and friends.

MADISON, N.J., June 4. -- Commencement exercises at Drew University will be held on Tuesday in the open air under the oaks of the Mead Hall campus. Degrees will be awarded to seventy-nine students, including ten from foreign countries.

TOKYO, June 4. -- Comparing Dr. Rudolph B. Teusler of Tokyo with Sir Wilfred Grenfell of Labrador, Bishop James De Wolf Perry, representing the Episcopal Church in the United States, at the dedication today of St. Luke's Medical Centre, America's greatest religious and philanthropic enterprise in Japan, said the new hospital building had Dr. Teusler's life woven into it and would always stand as his memorial.
NEW YORK. Vincent Massey, former Canadian Minister to the United States, and Mrs. Massey, are at the Ritz-Carlton.

The banking groups that bold approximately $120,000,000 of the city revenue bills maturing on June 10 are prepared to extend the maturity date, but not beyond Sept. 10, it was indicated yesterday. Their reported intention to fix the new maturity almost on the eve of a municipal election is regarded with serious concern by Tammany Hall and its leaders.
American shipping has improved in recent months in the volume of tonnage actively used, according to Marine Engineering and Shipping Age.

NEW ORLEANS, June 4. -- The volume of business on the Cotton Exchange here last week was the largest for any week this season. Even on Tuesday, Memorial Day, when markets elsewhere were closed, trading was decidedly active, although lacking the usual interchange of buying or selling orders between the markets. In addition to trade-buying and pricefixing there was considerable hedge selling and speculation.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 4. -- Three more practice games were played at the Meadow Brook Club today in preparation for the opening of the club's annual Spring tournaments, which get under way this week. In the feature match, Winston Guest's Templeton quartet got off to an early lead to down the Long Island combination, led by Earle A.S. Hopping, by 7 to 5 on Cochran Field.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his letter published In THE NEW YORK TIMES, W.C.C. forgot to allow for poetic diction when he cited the familiar Bible story that King Solomon "made silver to be in Jerusalem as stones," presumably in support of the untenable thesis that silver is too common to serve as a money metal in this day of enlightenment and of widespread monetary debasements.
LONDON, Monday, June 5. -- Eighteen hours overdue on the first stage of his world flight, James Mattern is feared to have been lost somewhere in the Atlantic.

Developments in the new deal of the Democratic administration were assailed yesterday in the sermon of the Rev. Dr. Charles Wesley Burns, Bishop of the Boston area of the Methodist Episcopal Church. Bishop Burns spoke at the Metropolitan Methodist Episcopal Temple, Seventh Avenue at Thirteenth Street.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 4. -- Present and former international captains led teams against each other today as a new season of high-goal polo opened at the Bands Point Club, and the Sands Point four, headed by the present captain, Thomas Hitchcock Jr., rode to victory over Devereux Milburn's Roslyn quartet, 8 goals to 5.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 4. -- The resignation ot the Right Rev. Mgr. Thomas H. McLaughlin as president of Seton Hall College in South Orange was announced today by the college authorities. The resignation is effective June 7, immediately following the commencement exercises.

One-half of the issued common stock of Select Theatres Corporation will be turned over to owner of debentures, creditors and stockholders of the Shubert Theatre Corporation without cost to them Lee Shubert announced yesterday.

Percy L. Kynaston, fifth seeded player, advanced to the fourth round in the Brooklyn open tennis championship tournament at the Terrace Club, Flatbush, yesterday. Pitted against George Titus in a third round engagement, the former champion was forced into an extra set to triumph at 2 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 9 -- 7.
The Summer theatrical season will generally get under way this week in places as near to and remote from Broadway as White Plains, N.Y., and St. Louis.

AUTEUIL, France, June 4. -- Miss Helen Jacobs, American titleholder, was eliminated in the semi-final round of the French hard court tennis championships today by Mme. Rene Mathieu, first ranking French player, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 3.

ROME, June 4. -- Pope Piua today canonized Andre-Hubert Fournet, a Frenchman who suffered martyrdom in defense of rights of the church during the French Revolution. About 50,000 persons watched the ceremony.

Eight fencers earned the right to represent the metropolitan district in the national outdoor saber championship competition, which will be held at the Century of Progress Exposition in Chicago on June 23 and 24, by surviving the New York sectional eliminations at the New York Athletic Club's Summer grounds at Travers Island yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls last week are given in the appended tabulation:

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP). -- Mrs. Roosevelt was wearing a traveling Suit of dark blue silk, with blouse of figure blue, dark blue hat and low-heeled shoes when she left Washington Airport at 9 A.M., Eastern Standard Time, for the West.

Services in celebration of the departure of thirteen priests of the Maryland-New York Province of the Jesuit Order to missionary duties in the Philippine Islands, were held yesterday at St. Peter's Church, Jersey City. The missionaries will sail this week for services in the leper colonies of Cebu and Cullion and at Aetenao College in Manila where the order maintains an astronomical observatory.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Colonel Clarenco M. Young, for the last four years Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Aeronautics, has resigned. For an appointed servant of one administration to leave when another takes over is neither novel nor exciting, yet the resignation of Colonel Young, who rose to his position from a subordinate office in the aeronautics branch, has been received throughout the aircraft and air transport industry with regret.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 4. -- Horace Havemeyer's twelve-meter sloop Mouette won a hollow victory today in the special races at the Larchmont Yacht Club. Mouette defeated Van S. Merle-Smith's Cantitoe 7 minutes 34 seconds over a fourteen-mile course.

Mayor O'Brien has been asked by the City Affairs Committee to "force" the exclusion of Dr. William F. Doyle from practice before the Board of Standards and Appeals. The committee, in a letter to the Mayor, made public yesterday, said that Dr. Doyle is still a "favored practitioner" before the board.

The prevalent idea of other recent weeks, that "inflation talk" was the single motive power behind the rise in prices, waned perceptibly in last week's markets. This resulted naturally from the fact that no steps have been taken or indicated toward outright currency inflation, yet that the advance on the Stock Exchange and in staple prices went on emphatically.

Asserting that no plan of reorganization of the Associated Telephone Utilities Company can be effected until the bankruptcy proceedings now pending in the United States Court in Delaware have been disposed of, a protective committee for holders of the company's debentures, headed by Malcom C. Rorty, issued a statement yesterday urging the deposit of debentures with it.
Columbia students who will receive bachelors' degrees tomorrow when the university's 179th commencement ends, took part yesterday in the annual baccalaureate service at St. Paul's Chapel.
WASHINGTON, June 4. -- State quotas under which 26,000 men will be selected to join, emergency conservation camps in national and State forests were made public today.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The part played by Louis McHenry Howe, secretary to President Roosevelt, in the award of the contract for toilet kits used by the Civilian Conservation Corps will be explained when he appears before the Senate Military Affairs Committee tomorrow.
WALLA WALLA, Wash., June 4 (AP). -- A batch of sizzling "hot dogs" was what Jimmle Mattern hoped for when he arrived in Europe, the wife of the globe-girdling flier said today, to "make him happy."

Numerous reorders on Summer dresses and continued heavy buying of staple merchandise for Fall featured activity in the wholesale markets here last week. Cotton styles retained their lead, with some price advances made during the week on this merchandise.

DETROIT, June 4 (AP). -- "Nondendritic" steel, made by a process hailed by authoritative observers as one of the two revolutionary methods introduced in the industry in forty-eight years, is to become a commercial product here in a few months.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 4. -- Girded for what is forecast as the bitterest battle in the history of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, 312 delegates will gather Tuesday morning in the organization's hall here for their triennial convention.

A scorching sun, sizzling through a cloudless sky, drove thousands from the city yesterday, thronging the beaches of the metropolitan area with the largest crowds of the year. For the first time the weather made the water fit for bathing. Five drownings and eighteen rescues were reported.

BOSTON, June 4. -- A plea for application of the Ten Commandments to modern life was made this afternoon by the Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving before more than 200 members of tlic graduating class of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and 1,000 guests at the baccalaureate service in Trinity Church.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Every person in the United States Will have to pay $1.25 more in taxes, directly or indirectly, as a result of the action of the Senate in reducing by more than $150,000,000 the proposed cuts in veterans' allowances, Colonel Louis M. Howe, secretary to the President, said tonight in a radio interview.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The President returned to the White House early in the evening after a cruise down the Potomac River with Senator Robinson erf Arkansas, the Democratic leader, during which a program for the quick adjournment of Congress and enactment of the pending Industrial Control-Taxation-Public Works Bill was discussed.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP). -- Washington clung to the heels of the fast-going Yankees today by taking a hard-fought 4-to-3 decision from Boston in thirteen innings. Pipgras of the Red Sox was forced by the heat to give up after twelve rounds of pitching.

VATICAN CITY, June 4. -- Pope Pius entered St. Peter's for the canonization ceremony today in a formal procession, borne aloft on a portable throne on the shoulders of twelve attendants, with two additional attendants walking beside him and gently stirring the air with enormous ostrich feather fans.

A better-than-seasonal average is being struck in new construction work in the metropolitan area, according to a survey just completed by the Dow Service. It reports a definite upturn in new building for the first five months of this year.

Brighter College Years. Commencement week these last three years has been a time to feel sorry for thousands of college men and women. They were being thrown upon a world that offered them so little opportunity.

While WILLIAM MULDOON did not live to be a hundred years old, as his desire was, he will long live in memory. Entellus comes down to us as the aged Sicilian boxer who beat to the earth the young champion Dares. The achievement was celebrated in verse.

BUENOS AIRES, June 4. -- A communique from the Paraguayan War Minister declares that the Bolivians have suffered a general defeat and 1,500 casualties, including many officers, in the last few days of fighting in the Fort Herrera sector.

Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle will preside tonight at the commencement exercises of La Salle Academy at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street. David C. Broderick will give the commencment address. The La Salle Glee Club will sing, and the La Salle Orchestra will play, Arthur G. Curtin, Arthur P. Nesbitt and Charles R. McCabe will speak.
Playing the entire game at a fast pace, the Kerry Gaelic football team routed the selected New York fifteen, 10 to 3, in the second encounter of their series at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 4. -- Grey Fox won the second race of the Star Class Sunday series, sailed today under the auspices of the New Rochelle Yacht Club. Ably handled by her owner, Howard McMichael, she was first in the fleet of thirteen which took part in the racing, beating Paul Shields's Gull by fifty-three seconds and Adrian Iselin's Ace by 1:23.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- President Roosevelt told House leaders tonight at a conference called by him that if the Connally amendment to the Independent Offices Bill, adopted by the Senate and reducing economies in veterans' allowances and pensions, became law, Congress would have to provide higher taxes.

Owen D. Young, Joseph V. McKee and Noel Coward shared the lead in a poll taken among young women students of the Katherine Gibbs School, 247 Park Avenue, to determine their "ideal employer." The students will be graduated Into the business world this week.

The social stress of the present Is restoring new vitality to the Christian church, the Rev. Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell, warden of St. Stephen's College, said yesterday in a sermon at a Pentacost service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., June 4. -- Professor William Starr Myers of Princeton University will speak here tomorrow afternoon at the commencement for seventy-seven students of Peddie School in the First Baptist Church. Horace Roberson, president of the school board of corporators, will present the diplomas.

Equitable Stationery Co., space for stationery shop on ground floor of RCA Building, Rockefeller Center, through John Kreh. inc.; Weihenstephan Corp. of America, distributer In United States for Bayrische Staatsbrauerel (Bavarian States Brevwory), and Roger White, artists' representative, in RKO Building, Rockefeller Center.

A further gain of 4 points in the average rate of steel operations in the last week brought the industry to 47 per cent of theoretical capacity, according to the magazine Steel, which says that, considering some of the capacity is always shut down for repairs, the rate based on actual capacity is now about 50 per cent.

NUREMBERG, Germany, June 4. -- The first National Socialist flying week, which was opened at the airport at Fuerth, near here, today by Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Aviation Minister, in the presence of national, State and municipal authorities and hundreds of thousands of spectators, was marred by a collision in midair of two participating planes in which both pilots were killed.

LONDON, June 4 (By Wireless). -- It has been found that in the short season for an attempt on Mount Everest Europeans can acclimatize themselves up to 24,000 feet so completely that they should be able to make the final dash to the summit of the 29,141-foot peak at about 300 yards an hour.

BERLIN, June 4. -- The Pan-Germanic mission of the Germany of Adolf Hitler was proclaimed a new by the congress of the Folk League for Germanism Abroad, which met during the Whitsuntide holidays at Passau on the Austrian border.

Dr. Harvey N. Davis of Stevens Institute will be the speaker at the commencement exercises of the Horace Mann School for Boys, 231 West 246th Street, this afternoon at 3 o'clock. Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College will preside.

LONDON, June 3. -- It seems unlikely that interest on United Kingdom bonds now held in America will be paid in gold.
