There is, however, little doubt that the matter must come forward in acute form at the economic conference, although doubtless the gold standard itself and not the gold clause will be the greatest difficulty.

The one-story Heights Palace at 549-59 W. 180th St. was sold by Hyman M. Rambach and two others to Arthur Enterprises. Inc., at a price of $200.000, the seller taking back a purchase money mortgage for $192,500, payable June 1, 1943, at 5 1/2 per cent, with the principal to be reduced by quarterly payments In various amounts.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- A disclosure that some members of the firm of J.P. Morgan Co. received straight salaries of $100,000 a year was made authoritatively today. This developed as the Senate committee investigating the international banking house approached a decision on how far it would inquire into the personal income tax returns of Morgan partners.
To the Editor or The New York Times: I derived a great deal of pleasure reading your editorial in your issue of May 31 in reference to the government repudiating the gold clause in its bond issues.

W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, madfe public yesterday a letter to 500 party leaders throughout the State in which he stressed the importance of electing a Republican Assembly and urged early and aggressive action.
ST. LOUIS, June 4 (AP). -- Weak pitching permitted the White Sox to garner a total of thirty-one hits and take both games of a double-header from the Browns today, 13 to 6 and 10 to 2.

BASLE, Switzerland, June 5. -- The Board of Governors of the Bank for International Settlements today went over President Leon Fraser's statement of the World Bank situation on May 31 when it was given out.

Cardinal Hayes will confer degrees this afternoon on 125 graduates of the College of Mount Saint Vincent at the commencement exercises of the, institution to be held in tha Cardinal Hayes Auditorium on the campus.

ABOARD THE S.S. PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, At Sea, June 5. -- A flat 10 per cent cut in all nations' tariffs was disclosed officially today by the United States delegation as an idea being strongly pushed for action at the forthcoming World Economic Conference in London.

Freak thunder and hail storms bombarded upper Manhattan and the Bronx last evening and were followed by a thunderstorm, accompanied by brilliant electrical display, which lashed the entire city shortly after midnight. The thunder and hail storms in the early part of the evening came in from the New Jersey suburbs, where they caused property damage.

In one of the most sweeping indictments ever voted here by a Federal grand jury, the Government of the United States yesterday struck a blow against the Fulton Market fish trust. It named as defendants a local of the American Federation of Labor, twenty-four corporations, fifty-four individuals and three trade associations.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 5. -- Music is needed now more than ever to stimulate courage and "America unafraid is America invincible," Secretary Woodin declared today in an address at Syracuse University's commencement.
Judge Francis V. D. Lloyd, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Newark, N.J., explained to real estate men the workings of his organization at a luncheon held in the Uptown Club yesterday.

With Professors Michael I. Pupin and A.V. Williams Jackson as the guests of honor, members of the class of '83 of Columbia University celebrated their fiftieth annual reunion last night with a dinner at the University Club.
The quotations are for three-four montns paper.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- James Mattern, in his flight across the Atlantic, followed with little deviation the more northern of two routes which he plotted with the assistance of the Hydrographic Office of the Navy Department, according to officers who based their opinion on press reports of his landing's in Europe.

The Continental Bank and Trust Company has announced a reduction in dividend from 30 cents a share quarterly to 20 cents, lowering the annual dividend basis from $1.20, the rate maintained since 1929, to 80 cents a share. The dividend just declared at the lower rate is payable on July 1 to stock of record of June 16.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- Declaring that the United States will not take the lead in disarming, but that "disarmament must proceed equally by all nations at the same time," Representative McSwain, chairman of the House Committee on Military Affairs, urged a "safe and sane" policy of national defense today.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The way in which the Van Sweringen brothers acquired railroads by the formation of holding companies and without using their own funds was sketched today into the record of the Senate committee which is investigating J.P. Morgan Co.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- With the anti-administration revolt apparently subdued, the Senate's Finance Committee voted 12 to 6 today to restore the licensing provisions of the National Industrial Recovery Bill, thus rescinding its action of Friday.
To the Editor of The New York Times: On June 20, 1899, the Surgeon General of the Army, in his report to the Secretary of War, among other things, has the following to say:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial on June 2 regarding the immunity of municipalities in the performance of governmental functions you state that where an individual is injured by a fire truck he has no redress against the municipality.

Turning State's evidence yesterday, Philip L. Derketsch, who last Wednesday pleaded guilty to being a racketeer, accused David Dubin, on trial for conspiracy and coercion, of instigating Derketech to coerce persons to join the Cloak and Dress Covered-Button Manufacturers Association.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., June 5. -- More than 100 American Rhodes scholars, assembled at Swarthmore College for their first reunion, thirty years after the establishment of the scholarships, heard this year's graduating class at Swarthmore advised today by Sir Francis Wylie, former Oxford secretary to the Rhodes trustees in England, to "burn, with the bright flame of conscious living rather than with the dull glow of routine."

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The administration's relief program advanced a step nearer completion today when the Senate adopted 8 liberalized substitute for the Home Mortgage Bill passed by the House, Less than three hours of debate sufficed for action on the bill.

WASHINGTON. June 5. -- The Treasury today submitted to the Department of Justice a list containing the names of more than 1,000 individuals suspected of hoarding gold. Prosecution appeared imminent. About $600,000,000 in gold and gold certificates is still outstanding.

The Warner-First National motion picture studios will produce sixty features, an unprecedented number for this concern, during the new 1933-34 season, according to an announcement yesterday by Jack L. Warner, vice president in charge of production.
KENT, Conn., June 5. -- The twenty-seventh anniversary of Kent School will be celebrated tomorrow in connection with the annual Prize Day exercises and commencement.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on May 31 shows an increase for the week of $133,000,000 in leans, a decrease of $36,000,000 in investments, and an increase of $193,000,000 in net demand deposits.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Without "favored lists" there would be no capital in this country to make possible our great progress in such a short period of time. The so-called favored list is, after all, nothing but a number of select aristocrats who, while gambling on a "long pull" for big returns, are able to endure loss should it occur.

TOKYO, June 5. -- The new St. Luke's Hospital has resulted from the faith and energy of one man, Dr. Rudolph B. Teusler, said Ambassador Joseph C. Grew, striking the keynote of every speech -- Japanese and foreign -- at the formal opening this afternoon.

LONDON, June 5. -- The British Chamber of Shipping has given its members until Saturday to make up their minds whether they favor either of two proposed schemes for control of freight shipping, one involving scrapping of surplus tonnage and the other laying up of vessels.

MILAN, Italy, June 5. -- Declaring his sentiments "as a man and as an artist" were injured by the Nazi attitude toward Jews in Germany, Arturo Toscanini canceled today his contract to direct the presentation of the Wagnerian program of music at the Baireuth festival on June 29.

Generally higher prices ruled in the bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday, although the trading pace was considerably slower than during most of last week. Communications issues led the rise in utility bonds on Western Union-Postal Telegraph merger rumors.

A credit of $50,000,000 over a period of three years has been granted by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Government of China. It will be secured by a first charge on certain Chinese taxes which produced $22,000,000 last year despite hard times and political confusion.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- Hot winds, with temperatures of 100 and higher, in parts of Kansas, Oklahoma and Nebraska affected the Winter wheat crop of those States over the week-end. The heat continued today in most sections. Estimates indicated the losses through premature ripening, blight and other causes might exceed 10,000,000 bushels, while some Kansas City and Southwestern interests said the loss in Kansas might run as high as 20,000,000 bushels.
The refusal of the Board of Education here to reduce the size of classes in city schools to provide jobs for unemployed teachers was upheld yesterday by the State Department of Education in Albany.

PARIS, June 5. -- The various negotiations that have been under way for more than a year designed to give France greater tariff freedom and hence greater bargaining power have made great progress, a communique from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced today.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 5. -- Indiana, in which legislation this year changed from a drastically dry to a most liberal State, will vote tomorrow on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment with some prohibitionists believing the result will show the true trend of the nation on the liquor question.
HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., June 5. -- The Peddie School held its annual commencement in the First Baptist Church here this afternoon. Seventy-seven members of the class of 1933 received diplomas.

Philip Moeller, playwright, director and member of the Theatre Guild's board of managers, will write the libretto for a new opera by Louis Gruenberg, composer of "The Emperor Jones," which was produced at the Metropolitan Opera House for the first time last season.

Making his first appearance in the tournament, Gregory Mangin of Newark, seventh in the national ranking, advanced two rounds in the Brooklyn tennis championship play at the Terrace Club of Flatbush yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 3, unless otherwise specified:

Harvey Drew, 32 years old, of 1,646 West Third Street, Brooklyn, was held without bail yesterday by Magistrate David Hirshfield in Flatbush Court on a charge of attempted extortion. The case will go to the grand jury.

As a result of economies and despite the decreased membership and the small number of musical shows produced since June 3, 1932, the Chorus Equity Association is in a better financial condition this year than last year, it was reported at the annual meeting of the organization yesterday afternoon at its headquarters, 110 West Forty-seventh Street.
Russell T. Sherwood visited Manhattan yesterday under the protection of the United States Government to tell what he knew about the financial affairs of former Mayor Walker and himself.

Mr. HAROLD LASKI, an English professor of political science who has lectured at some American colleges and has a considerable acquaintance among American public men, is telling The Manchester Guardian about "the New Washington" -- the new deal and dispensation now reigning there.
subject-matter of conversation ! A. -- No, I didn't at that particular moment.

PEIPING, June 5. -- The tension in North China began appreciably to lessen today as Japanese artillery started withdrawing to the Great Wall from the line stipulated in the truce and simultaneously Japanese ceased patrolling the Peiping streets.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 5. -- Yale and Harvard's head coaches, Ed Leader and Charley Whiteside, respectively, were at their boat houses about 10 o'clock this morning, eagerly waiting for the varsity oarsmen to put aside their examinations temporarily.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 5. -- The official "promise of marriage" of the Prince of the Asturias, heir-claimant to the Spanish throne, and Senorita Edelmtra San Pedro Ocejo, daughter of a wealthy Cuban merchant, was posted at the City Hall here today.

At the suggestion of representatives of large creditors, the reorganization plan of the Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company may be altered to include a voting trust. The plan is reported to be progressing so satisfactorily that the courts may soon lift the rehabilitation order granted at the request of the New York State Insurance Department and permit the company to resume normal business.

The officers of eleven national women's organizations jointly commended Lewis W. Douglas, Director of the Budget, yesterday for his efforts to cut pensions and war and navy department" expenditures. The endorsement was made at the annual executive meeting of the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War, representing more than 3,000,000 women peace workers, at 600 Lexlngton Avenue.

Lampoons were tossed at authors, publishers and book clubs yesterday at the annual convention of the American Booksellers Association, held at the Hotel Montclair. The convention was for one day only, starting early yesterday morning and lasting through a closing dinner.

The indictment of four officers and a woman employe of the defunct Lexington Surety and Indemnity Company in connection with alleged mismanagement of the concern's affairs was revealed yesterday. The company formerly had offices at 123 William Street.

Hot-Weather Drama. Summer theatres are Opening this week along a wide-flung suburban and vacation front. Beginning with White Plains, on the very edge of New England, this particular region of the Pilgrims' pride will soon be dotted with rustic centres all the way up to Maine, purveying a form of amusement for which the Puritan Fathers had little use.

Pharisees of old were taken to task because they tithed mint, anise and cummin and neglected weightier matters. The same charge will be lodged against Mayor O'BRIEN by those who ponder his program " for increasing the income of the city."

Price movements in commodity futures traded on local exchanges were Irregular yesterday in a narrow range, with the balance of weight on the down side. Silver gained on the day, but in most of the others at least some positions were lower

George Donnelly, who instituted a taxpayer's suit last Aug. 10 in an unsuccessful attempt to forestall the removal proceedings against former Mayor Walker before Governor Roosevelt, committed suicide yesterday. He hanged himself in his home at 2,710 Creston Avenue, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, June 5. -- President Roosevelt was represented today as prepared to meet and break the revolt in his own party against his economy program.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 5. -- Thomas T.C. Gregory, aide to Herbert Hoover as food administrator, was killed early this morning when his motor car crashed through a guard rail of a bridge and into a shallow pond near Napa. A flat tire is blamed for the accident.
CHICAGO, June 5 (AP) -- C.L. King's Mr. Sponge, which raced successfully at Miami last Winter, returned to good form today at Washington Park to win the featured Arcturus Handicap at seven furlonga.

Chicago, Ill. M.S. Szymczak, Controller of Chicago, advised bankers here yesterday that $633,676 was available there for the purchase of the city's 6 per cent refunding bonds of 1933 and asked that holders of the bonds submit tenders to him until Friday for the sale to the city of sufficient bonds to exhaust that sum at prices not exceeding par.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- President Roosevelt was urged to intercede with the German Government on behalf of Jewish victims of the Hitler regime in resolutions adopted here today by the American National Conference Against Racial Persecution in Germany.
The New York Curb Exchange announced yesterday the removal of the following securities from that market:

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 5. -- The Women's National Golf and Tennis Club team, competing in the Class A group of the Long Island interclub matches sponsored by the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, divided the honors in its match with the Salisbury Country Club today and thereby enabled the Nassau Country Club to clinch the team title.

Monday, June 5, 1933. Business in the money market was devoid of feature, except for a small amount of money done in the outside market at 1/2, the ruling rate continuing at 3/4. Stock Exchange charge remained at 1 per cent. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were quiet and unchanged in quotation.

TRENTON, N.J., June 5. -- Termed "regulative" rather than "restrictive," an order was issued today to building and loan associations by William H. Kelly, State Banking and Insurance Commissioner, to govern the creating of reserves and sales of real estate.

Considering the hesitation shown by the market early in the day, the aggressive advance and the 5,000,000-share volume on the New York Stock Exchange surprised Wall Street. Although the turnover was smaller by 1,868,000 shares than on Friday, the last full five-hour day of the previous week, the business was of such volume as to make the brokers happy.
Max Schmeling will complete training preparations today for his fifteen-round bout with Max Baer, which will be held at the Yankee Stadium on Thursday night.
The annual senior ball of Barnard, the final social event of the college for the present academic year, was held last evening in Barnard Hall.

BASLE, June 5. -- The United States may be asked soon by her war debtors to agree to a truce on intergovernmental debts during the World Economic Conference, according to reports here, where the board of the Bank for International Settlements held its monthly meeting today.

NEWARK, N.J., June 5. -- Quick thinking by Clarence Hudson, pilot of the regular 4 o'clock airliner from Newark to Chicago, narrowly averted disaster to the plane and its eleven passengers here this afternoon.

CARDIFF, Wales, June 5 (Canadian Press).-- Glamorgan had piled up 253 runs for the loss of only two wickets in reply to the British West Indies first innings score of 475 at the close of play in their cricket match today.

Bainbridge Colby, former Secretary of State, will be the speaker tonight at commencement exercises of the New York Homeopathic Medical College and Flower Hospital, to be held at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street. Graduation of the School of Nursing of Flower Hospital is included in the program.

Republicans opposed to the leadership of Samuel S. Koenig will make no compromise or deal with any "standpatter," David B. Costuma, campaign manager of the anti-Koenig forces, declared yesterday. They have rejected a proposal, he said, by which Mr. Koenig would retire and name a "dummy" leader.

GENEVA, June 5. -- The German delegation remained very secretive tonight regarding its intention in the meeting of the Council of the League of Nations tomorrow on the Bernheim petition, charging discrimination against Jews in German Upper Silesia.
AUTEUIL. France, June 5. -- Jack Crawford of Australia decisively Defeated Henri Cochet today for the hard-court tennis championship of France, winning in straight sets, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3.

There is a new thrill for the Connecticut angler. Nowadays when he begins dressing a trout he is likely to encounter a red celluloid tag. This may not mean much to him directly, yet it means a great deal to every fisherman indirectly, for the simple reason that that red tag is an indicator.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 5. -- An extension class in the Rutgera University School of Education, composed largely of school teachers, was ordered to repeat an examination because the professor was convinced that several members had cheated during the test, it became known today.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 5. -- The temporary permit issued to Camron Dairy Products, Inc., of Brooklyn, was revoked today by the State Milk Control Board which refused to grant a license to deal in milk, effective June 12.

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher in training in day high schools, in the subjects Indicated, be Issued, as of May 15, 1933, to the following applicants, who have met the eligibility and examination requirements therefor:

BERLIN, June 5. -- While the status of Jewish athletes in the Olympic teams has been under official consideration no decision has been reached although Captain Hans von Tschammer-Osten, Sport Commissioner, in a recent speech declared the 1936 Olympiad would be held in Berlin and that admission to German teams would be governed by the "personal performance of the candidates and their general fitness to represent Germany."
Charles E. Mitchell took the witness stand in his own defense yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 5 (AP). -- Justus F. Craemer of Orange, Cal., president of the National Editorial Association, at the annual convention today warned the editors not to "make the mistake of the past ten years by failing to advance the price of their products along with the price of other commodities."
TRENTON, N.J., June 5. -- The annual appropriations bill, apportioning funds for support of the State Government during the fiscal year beginning July 1, was introduced in the Senate tonight.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In the old days in England there was a king who had a female jester of great wisdom, who both amused and instructed the king with fables.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP). -- Representative Beck of Pennsylvania called upon the nations of the world tonight to protect the German Jew "by the mighty forces of world opinion."

Operations for the advance were resumed yesterday after an early period of indecision during which the market appeared to be uncertain whether to extend the decline that started on Saturday or to follow the upward course which had been marked out in the previous eight or nine weeks.

A second hearing on premium rates to be charged for bonds required by the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board will be held tomorrow morning in the office of George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, at 80 Centre Street.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., June 5. -- Declaring that "we cannot continue much longer in the spirit of the old nationalism," Judge Samuel S. Seabury of New York in a commencement address at Muhlenberg College today warned the eighty-two graduates the world is in danger of another war.

Jersey City defeated Baltimore at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday, 3 to 2, when Guy Cantrell, relief pitcher, passed Ray Gardner with the bases full in the ninth to force over Hank Leiber with the winning run.
WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated June 2:

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 5. -- Cardinal Hayes presided and the Rev. Father T. Lawrason Riggs, director of Catholic activities at Yale University, was the baccalaureate speaker at the commencement exercises this afternoon of the College of New Rochelle at which 185 girls were graduated, the largest class in the history of the college.

When James J. Mattern set down the wheels of his plane in Moscow yesterday morning he was 3 hours and 3 minutes ahead of Post and Gatty, whose record of 8 days, 15 hours and 51 minutes around the globe he is trying to smash. Post and Gatty remained in Moscow 11 1/2 hours, Mattern only 9 hours, 17 minutes, so he left 5 hours and 16 minutes ahead of their record.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- President Roosevelt has notified Senator Glass and Representative Steagall that he will veto the Glass-Steagall banking reform bill if the Vandenberg amendment for an immediate, temporary deposit insurance fund is retained as now written.

OSLO, Norway, June 5. -- Almost twenty-four hours after James Mattern put his monoplane safely down on the perilous pebble beach of the island of Jomfruland at 10:15 A.M. yesterday the Norwegian public heard about it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Our system of national and State parks may soon become antiquated. It originated in days when men had legs instead of wings; in a period when Babbitt scorned a vacation, except for a few days in July or August.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The President's political gift was never better revealed than at his meeting with the House Democratic leaders last night. He presented his economy position in a way which will require the House to make a choice equally painful to its members, but which will maintain the President's budget program whether or not it stands by the party platform.

The Toc H dinner dance and entertainment, an event of the Spring, in New York, took place last night on board the Berengaria at West Fourteenth Street. The party was given in the interest of establishing here a centre for Toc H, a movement of fellowship that derives its peculiar name from the former army telephone code call for Talbot House, a soldiers' Club in Flanders, where the movement began early in the World War.

HONOLULU, June 5. -- Political circles here were pleased today by news from Washington that the House had rejected President Roosevelt's proposal to appoint a mainlander as Hawaiian Governor, but Democrats, while reiterating opposition to the proposal, emphasized they had not acted against it and were willing to abide by the administration's decision.

New York's outstanding police heroes of 1932, living and dead, were honored by the city yesterday. The annual Police Department awards for conspicuous bravery were presented by Mayor O'Brien, posthumously, through their widows, to the seven who fell in action and in person to twelve other members of the force.

LONDON, June 5. -- The belief is growing here that the World Economic Conference will be relatively short, instead of lasting until Christmas, as predicted a few weeks ago. Prime Minister MacDonald is said to hold firmly that speechmaking must not be allowed to swallow up two or three weeks of precious time at the outset of the conference.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 5. -- Charles Smith Maddock 3d, member of a prominent Trenton (N.J.) family and a freshman in the Engineering School at Princeton University, committed suicide early tonight in his room in Campbell Hall. He shot himself through the head with a .22 calibre repeating rifle.
NEW YORK. Princess Marie of Greece has joined Mrs. A. Power Marsh at the Pierre.

Supreme Court Justice James A. Dunne reserved decision in St. George, S.I., yesterday on the taxpayer's action brought by Thomas Venditto of 279 Nelson Avenue, Great Kills, S.I., for an order to compel the removal of ninety bungalows in Wolfe's Pond Park, on Princes Bay.

Plans for the continuation of The Players of "Uncle Tom's Cabin" under the management of an unnamed producer or group are under advisement, it became known last night. A spokesman for the club said a definite arrangement might be expected within the next few days, but would not name the manager with whom the negotiations were being made.

Ernest Bru, a film company official, fell accidentally from the window of his office on the sixth floor of 729 Seventh Avenue and was instantly killed yesterday. A woman, struck by his body, was critically injured.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- Illinois today voted to repeal national prohibition, the ninth State to take such action. Smashing majorities were rolled up over the State for the fifty repeal delegates to the Illinois convention which will be held in Springfield July 10.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seemed appropriate that just at Decoration Day, when our own pariotism bubbles over in feverish jingoism, I should receive from France a proof that many of the French are turning with disgust from belligerence and political chauvinism.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The Rayburn bill, embodying President Roosevelt's plan for reorganization of the railroads under a Federal coordinator, was passed by the House today without a record vote. It was then sent to the Senate for conferences to iron out the slight differences between it and the measure recently approved by the Senate.

Conditions of the American Yacht Club's annual race from Rye to New London, which enable the contesting craft to reach the Thames in time for the YaleHarvard crew contests, were announced yesterday by Edward A. Hodge, chairman of the race committee.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP). -- Fines totaling $11,473,601 and prison, sentences aggregating 2,378 years, 4 months, 8 days have been imposed upon 97,665 persons convicted in New York State of violation of the national prohibition laws since their enactment thirteen years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 (AP). -- Lefty Grove, deserting his role as a relief hurler to start his first game since May 6, today pitched the Athletics out of their four-game losing streak, defeating the Senators, 7 to 4.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- Prices of hogs dropped today 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight under pressure of unexpectedly large receipts. The first estimate of arrivals was 43,000, but It was raised gradually and finally reached 48,000, the largest number since Jan. 30.
Despite mounting opposition, Mayor O'Brien clung firmly yesterday to his plans for raising more than $30,000,000 by new city taxes.
At the annual commencement exercises of the New York Stock Exchange Institute, held last night in the luncheon club of the Exchange, twenty-seven employes were graduated and received diplomas.
ROCHESTER, June 5. -- A denial that the country had "forsaken its national honor" in refusing bond payments in gold was made by Postmaster General Farley in one of three addresses he made here today.

President ROOSEVELT appears to Save taken very quietly the reported uprising in Congress against his authority. He did not make it a personal thing. To the Democratic leaders who came to consult him about the "revolt," he apparently pointed out that it was really against the elementary rules of arithmetic.

One hundred and sixty-one varsity and freshman athletes and candidates for managerial positions at Columbia will receive insignia for participation in the Spring sports program on Morningside Heights, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Edward S. Elliott, director of athletics.
CLEVELAND, June 5 (AP). -- The Tigers pulled a close game with the Indians out of the fire in the ninth inning today and won, 8 to 7.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The Chaco dispute between Bolivia and Paraguay appeared today to have been removed definitely from the jurisdiction of the commission of neutrals here, headed by Francis White. Assistant Secretary of State.

DALLAS, June 5 (AP). -- Mrs. Roosevelt declined to pose for pictures today with Mrs. Miriam A. (Ma) Ferguson, nor was the Democratic Governor of Texas at the table when Mrs. Roosevelt had breakfast at the airport here.

LONDON, June 5 (AP). -- C. Ross Somerville of Canada, holder of the United States amateur golf title, today was viewed as a joint favorite for the British amateur crown with Cyril Tolley, former titleholder, as the lists closed with 268, a near-record field, entered.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The development of the Van Sweringen railroad system, with the aid of J.P. Morgan Co., was outlined this morning by O.P. Van Sweringen of Cleveland, president of the Alleghany Corporation, before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, investigating banking, financing and securities sales practice.

TRENTON. N.J., June 5. -- With Governor Moore holding the Bible and Ernest R. Kerr of the Secretary of State's office administering the oath, James Baker of Jersey City, treasurer of the Democratic State Committee, and Colonel Arthur F. Foran of Flemington, a Republican, took office today as members of the State Highway Commission.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 5 (AP). -- Albany won from Newark, 4 to 3, today behind the splendid relief pitching of Ray Prim. Prim relieved Masters in the second inning with Newark leading, 3 to 0, and Jablonowski on third base with none out, and prevented the Bears from scoring.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 5. -- The Peekskill Military Academy celebrated the centennial of the founding of the school and the 1933 commencement jointly here today at the Ford Auditorium.

This month of commencements and degrees will see nearly 18,000 young men and women going out from the leading colleges and universities of this State alone. The number is somewhat greater than last year because of and not despite the depression; for while college attendance has generally fallen off, more students have remained to complete their undergraduate courses or graduate studies.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 5. -- Degees in religion were conferred today upon Fred Pierce Corson. Brooklyn, district superintendent of of the Methodist Episcopal Church, Doctor of Divinity; Ismar John Peritz, veteran teacher of Syracuse University.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, June 6. -- James Mattern dropped out of the clouds yesterday afternoon on his flight around the world and hurried on this morning, five hours and sixteen minutes ahead of the record of Wiley Post and Harold Gatty at this point.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The House today refused to suspend the rules and approve the administration-supported Rankin bill providing that the Governor of Hawaii need not necessarily be a resident of the islands. The vote of 222 to 114 was two short of the required two-thirds.

Owen Madden will leave Sing Sing prison July 1 on parole, after having served five days less than a year for violation of a previous parole. Announcement of his pending release was made at the prison yesterday by Dr. Joseph Moore, chairman of the State Board of Parole.

About 150 attorneys, the largest assemblage of legal talent to gather in one courtroom here in recent years, was on hand yesterday when the first of the $25-a-share assessment suits against stockholders of the Bank of United States opened before Supreme Court Justice Lydon.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, June 6. -- James Mattern was racing into the black-clouded east early today toward Omsk, Siberia, because Soviet officials had refused him permission to fly the shorter route to Alaska via Yakutsk on account of unfavorable conditions.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 5. -- Rating his mount with rare judgment, Major George S. Patton today won the Individual military championship at the first day of the fifteenth annual West Point Horse Show, riding the Fort Myer Horse Show team's upstanding chestnut gelding Hukupu against some of the best military mounts in the East.
Although prices on the Cotton Exchange lost $1 a bale at one time yesterday, aggressive buying advanced the list nearly $2 a bale in the afternoon, making final gains of 20 to 23 points on the day.

Ray White, captain of Columbia's baseball team, signed with the New York Yankees yesterday. He will report at the Yankee Stadium today and will join the Binghamton team of the New York-Pennsylvania League at Scranton on Thursday.

Members of the Columbia College chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, national honorary fraternity, held their annual open meeting yesterday in Philosophy Hall and heard Dr. Stanley King, president of Amherst College, urge them to take a more active part in politics.

Efforts are being made by the Actors' Equity Association to collect claims amounting to almost $5,000 against Ethel Barrymore, its former first vice president, filed by members of Miss Barrymore's supporting cast in "An Amazing Career," which closed a second road tour in Chicago on May 20.

OSLO, Norway, June 5. -- Residents of Jomfruland who witnessed the landing of James Mattern yesterday said it was a marvelous performance. He struck stones instead of the sandy beach he had expected to find, and stones whirled around him, but did not hit him.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The joint resolution abrogating the gold clause in private and public contracts of the past and future was signed by President Roosevelt late this afternoon immediately upon its receipt from Congress.

The Group Theatre, which will spend several weeks this Summer at Green Mansions, Warrensburg, N.Y., rehearsing plays for Fall presentation, has five scripts with which to work. It is said the plays include "The Pure in Heart," by John Howard Lawson, which was tried out of town by the Theatre Guild last Winter, but was not brought to Broadway.

The steamship Baracoa of the Colombian Steamship Company will sail today from Pier 9, Brooklyn, beginning a freight service to Chicago and Milwaukee. She will be Joined later in the month by the freighter Bolivia on a fortnightly schedule, transporting freight exclusively at present and eventually carrying a limited number of passengers.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Whether an acreage-control program, will be applied to this year's cotton crop under the new Farm Relief Act will probably be decided by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration this week. Secretary Wallace said today.
The statement by Mayor O'Brien yesterday on the city's financial situation follows:

THE Match of the Maxes is only two days away and the Baer That Walks Like a Man is still an unknown quantity. Personally, he seems to prefer it that way. He likes to surprise strangers. He says he often surprises himself.

Kenneth F. Simpson, lawyer and war veteran, was elected unanimously Republican leader of the Fifteenth Assembly District at a meeting of the county committeemen from the district last night. He succeeds Keyes Winter, who was leader of the district for six years until his recent resignation.

How a Roman Catholic home for native girls, established in the Belgian Congo, has become a haven for African brides who object to polygamy is told in the June issua of Catholic Missions, published by the Society for the Propagation of the Faith.

Plaintiffs in foreclosure actions bid in seventeen parcels offered at auction yesterday. Fourteen of the properties were in Manhattan and three in the Bronx. The results of yesterday's auctions and a sale last Saturday were as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- While J.P. Morgan and some of his partners sat near by today displaying little interest in the testimony before the Senate committee, O.P. Van Sweringen related how he and his brother, M.J., one time real estate operators, entered the railroad field in 1916 by purchasing control of the Nickel Plate Railroad from the New York Central for $8,500,000.

Samuel Untermyer, eminent lawyer and public servant without fee or portfolio, will celebrate his seventy-fifth, birthday today in the midst of his family and close friends at Greystone, his estate in Yonkers.
The transcript of the testimony of Charles E. Mitchell yesterday at his trial for alleged evasion of Federal income tax follows:

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- A $350,000,000 public works program for New York State to be 30 per cent subsidized lay the Federal Government under the provisions of the National Industrial Recovery Bill has been laid before the Federal Public Works Administration by Robert Moses, chairman of the New York State Public Works Commission.

NORTH CALDWELL, N.J., June 5. -- A card of 42, 42 -- 84 gave Miss Jane Brooks of Knickerbocker a lead of three strokes in the first round of the fifty-four-hole medal competition for the Women's New Jersey Golf Association closed championship, which began today at the Green Brook Country Club.

"The hour has come in Protestant Christianity when we must heal our divisions, combine our resources and unite our forces in a Cooperative program that will eliminate overlapping in all Christian service," the Rev. Dr. John McDowell, new moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church, declared yesterday afternoon.
BOSTON, June 5 (AP). -- Miss Mary G. Ewing of Brookline has been elected president of The First Church of Christ, Scientist, the mother church announced at its annual meeting today.
Real estate transactions in the metropolitan area during the last two weeks appear to indicate that the market is definitely on the upward trend.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- While J.P. Morgan and some of his partners sat near by today displaying little interest in the testimony before the Senate committee, O.P. Van Sweringen related how he and his brother, M.J., one time real estate operators, entered the railroad field in 1916 by purchasing control of the Nickel Plate Railroad from the New York Central for $8,500,000.

Samuel Untermyer, eminent lawyer and public servant without fee or portfolio, will celebrate his seventy-fifth, birthday today in the midst of his family and close friends at Greystone, his estate in Yonkers.
The transcript of the testimony of Charles E. Mitchell yesterday at his trial for alleged evasion of Federal income tax follows:
The trend in vocational education is toward specialization, concentration and brevity to keep pace with the rapidly changing policies which today face the student of world affairs.

For a good many years the fishermen of the Metropolitan district have centred their attention on saltwater fishing around the more immediate points such as Great South Bay and Great Kills. Within the last few days, however, the anglers have discovered that the sea bass and porgies have come to life in other waters.
Trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday was nervous and fluctuations were frequent in a range of more than a quarter cent, prices ending 12 to 16 points lower on the day.

Starting as a newsboy with a capital of 3 cents, Cyrus H.K. Curtis developed and beaded the Curtis Publishing Company and the Curtis-Martin Newspapers, Inc., with a combined capital of more than $40,000,000 and a gross annual business of more than $100,000,00 in 1930.

BERLIN, June 6. -- The German Government bowed to the verdict of the League of Nations today and declared itself ready to suspend in Upper Silesia all those features of its laws and regulations directed against the Jews that were in conflict with the Geneva convention for the protection of the minorities in that province.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 6 (AP). -- An aggressive campaign to retain Republican control of the Assembly was decided upon here today by Joseph A. McGinnies, Speaker of the lower house, and Senator George R. Fearon, minority leader in the upper house, in a conference with leaders of several counties where close contests are expected.

The rate of decline in the net operating income of 150 Class I railroads wag sharply reduced in April, according to the Bureau of Railway Economics. The decline for April compared with April, 1932, was 6.1 per cent, against a decline of 67.7 per cent in March.

The rise of stocks in May theoretically added $5,658,000,000 to the aggregate quoted market value of all shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange, according to the monthly tabulation issued by the Exchange, malting the total increase $12,773,000,000 from the low point on March 1, 1933.

An Indian boy from the little-explored mountain regions in Southeastern Honduras, who was brought here seven years ago and educated in the public schools, now is going back to his native hills as a member of an expedition to study the culture, language and traditions of his ancestors.

The Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation's management sent yesterday a letter to stockholders asking them not to form an opinion on the company's controversy with the New York Stock Exchange until they had received a statement which would be issued in a few days defending the company's stand.

By bunching hits off Johnny Prudhomme in two big innings. Jersey City defeated Baltimore, 6 to 5, at Jersey City yesterday. The victors thus made it three out of four from the Orioles. Ed Pipgras relieved Charley Perkins in the sixth and held the Orioles scoreless to the finish.

Buyers' Registrations Up. Registration of buyers visiting the market during the week ended yesterday showed a large increase over the figures for the preceding week but remained well behind the number listed in the same period a year ago, according to lists published in THE TIMES.
NEW YORK. Bernon S. Prentice and Miss Clare Prentice have left 609 Park Avenue and are in Rumson, N.J., for the Summer.

Trucking and allied interests represented at a meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania, and civic associations in session at the Hotel Commodore, led the rising wave of protests yesterday against Mayor O'Brien's plan to tax automobiles and coiled tolls on the East River bridges.

BERLIN, June 6. -- Otto Klemperer, one of the principal conductors of the Berlin State Opera, has received notice of cancellation of his contract under the "non-Aryan section" of the Civil Service Act. The contract was to have run until 1937. but Herr Klemperer must retire at the end of the current season early in July.
INDIANAPOLIS, June 6. -- Indiana today became the tenth State to vote in favor of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

It must be a satisfaction to the authorities at Washington, immersed in their vast plans and overwhelming responsibilities, to have at the head of the New York State Public Works Commission a man like ROBERT MOSES. He knows exactly what he wants, has no fear of big undertakings and is always champing at the bit.

The last three of the seven men arrested during a recent investigation of racketeering in the poultry business were sentenced to jail yesterday in Bronx Special Sessions by Justices Walling, Murphy and Gresser.

PARIS, June 6. -- France's delegation to the World Economic Conference, opening in London next Monday, will be one of the strongest there, it became evident today with publication of the list of those appointed. Premier Daladier will head the group during the early discussions, and even after his return to Paris he will hold himself ready to take a plane to London when his presence is required for important decisions.

ABOARD THE S.S. PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT. AT SEA, June 6. -- Senator Key Pittman of Nevada, member of the American delegation now proceeding to the London Economic Conference, discussed today the terms of a plan by which the nations could use silver as a certain percentage of their currency reserve to economize on gold and to raise and stabilize the price of the white metal.
Chief parts of the testimony of Charles E. Mitchell yesterday at his trial in Federal court follow:

ISTANBUL, June 6. -- The Turkish Government has promulgated a new tariff law which temporarily has paralyzed the import trade of Turkey. The law provides a general heavy increase in many duties, particularly on manufactured, goods, and hits importers especially hard because it came into force without previous warming on May 31.
WASHINGTON, June 6. -- A compromise move by the President today to modify veterans' pension reductions apparently failed to stop the House revolt against drastic cuts for service-connected cases.

CHICAGO, June 6 (AP). -- A four-run rally in the eighth inning, in which Koenig's pinch single tied the score and Hendrick's pinch double drove across the winning runs, gave the Cubs a 5-to-3 victory over Pittsburgh today.

NORTH CALDWELL, N.J., June 6. -- Duplicating her first-round card of 42, 42 -- 84, Miss Jane Brooks of Knickerbocker retained a three-stroke lead in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association closed championship at the Green Brook Country Club today.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 6 (AP). -- Newark made it three victories out of four games by winning from Albany today, 6 to 2. Charley Devens and Marvin Duke, Newark pitchers, kept Albany from hitting in the pinches. Devens received credit for the victory, though he was re- placed by Duke in the seventh when the Senators threatened.

The proposal to levy a tax or license fee upon all motor vehicle owners using the city's streets and bridges is contrary to the State law in the opinion of many attorneys and public officials. The city is certain to face a taxpayers suit if it attempts to enforce the new revenue proposals.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Regulations covering the operations of the Federal Securities Act will be ready within two weeks, Charles H. March, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said today. The commission has been deluged with inquiries, and today a committee headed by Baldwin Bane of the commission's counsel was named to work out the details.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- The Wagner Bill creating the United States Employment Service, was signed by President Roosevelt today. Senator Wagner, who sponsored the measure through two sessions of Congress; Secretary Perkins and Representative Peyser of New York witnessed the ceremony.

Cardinal Hayes conferred the degrees and awarded the prizes at the graduation exercises of the College of Mount Saint Vincent yesterday afternoon. Before giving his blessing, he spoke briefly, bidding the graduates: "Go forth and remember that the Church is your mother, and if you lose the relationship of child to mother in regard to the Church, look out for your faith."
ST. LOUIS, June 6 (AP). -- The Browns lost their fourth straight game to the White Sox today. The score was 5 to 3.

KENT. Conn., June 6. -- President Roosevelt, in a letter read today at the annual prize day exercises of Kent School, hailed the forthcoming trip of the Kent crew to England as likely to aid International friendship.

New York politicians, by supporting the tax program of the O'Brien administration, have shown their willingness to do anything for the citizen, except "to get off his back," Samuel Seabury declared yesterday.

Commonwealth of Massachusetts. The Commonwealth of Massachusetts advised bankers here yesterday that it would be in the market today with a new issue of $2,175,000 of notes and that on June 14 it would open bids on an issue of $3,150,000 of bonds.
OMSK, Siberia, June 6. -- I arrived from Moscow at Omsk this afternoon, feeling fine, and rested and am ready to go on to Chita.

The social order rests upon a foundation which is not economic at all but moral, and the "gain-seeking motive," unless it is to bring "grief and disaster" to the world, must be subordinated to ''the ideal of human service," Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, said yesterday afternoon in his address at the university's 179th annual commencement exercises.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Issues of Treasury notes and certificates totaling $900,000,000 were announced today by Secretary Woodin. The proceeds will be used to meet maturing obligations, pay interest and provide funds for emergency purposes.
INDIANAPOLIS, June 6 (AP). -- A bureau to act as a clearing house for national advertisers and the country press was considered today at the convention of the National Editorial Association.

Senator Harrison's tax program, approved on Monday by the Senate Finance Committee, was prepared, it would seem, with the view of penalizing the few remaining corporations that are fortunate enough to be able to pay dividends out of current earnings.

Federal funds for the National Guard Summer encampments finaliy have been released, according to information obtained yesterday from Colonel William R. Wright, Chief of Staff. Annual allotments for all purposes have, however, been cut 50 per cent, he said.
By a vote of 52 to 2 the Board of Aldermen passed the Municipal Assembly bill providing for raising $17,500,000 in new revenue from taxes on motor vehicles and from bridge tolls yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Two-headed snakes were not the most venomous of the monsters discovered by Cotton Mather as he galloped about New England "with his eyes agog and his ears set wide." Observe, please, an experiment in printing-press money described in his "Life of Sir William Phips."

TRENTON, N.J., June 6. -- Bills to carry out the recommendations made by Princeton University's State Survey Commission for Fiscal Reform were passed by the Senate today without a vote being recorded against them.

With speculative interests torn by conflicting influences, yesterday in Wall Street was not a profitable day for many traders. But it was for the brokerage fraternity. In point of volume, the market was one of the best of the recent movement.

ROME, June 6. -- Within twentyfour hours the fate of the fourpower pact after a chain of vicissitudes which have caused hope for it alternately to die and be born anew will have been definitely sealed. At the beginning of today's sitting of the Senate Premier Mussolini rose amid a burst of applause and spoke just a few words, saying:

MOSCOW, June 6. -- James Mattern is supremely confident of establishing a new record for speed in flying around the world, he said in a telephone interview tonight from Omsk across 1,450 miles of Russian and Siberian plains.
Charles Evans Hughes, Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court, is sailing today on the motor ship Augustus of the Italian Line. Others leaving on the ship for Mediterranean ports are:

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 6. -- Prince Charming II, owned by the Warfield Farms of Frederick P. Warfield, Port Chester, N.Y., and ridden by James Maloney today, won the Hunter championship, the leading event on the program of the final day of the fifteenth annual West Point Horse Show.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 6. -- A suburban garden inclosed with a white picket fence covered with red and white climbing roses in the centre of the auditorium of the Woman's Club of Maplewood was the setting for the annual flower show under the auspices of the garden department.
Two estates in Westchester county were reported sold yesterday.

MONTREAL, Que., June 6. -- Improvement in the Canadian newsprint industry is foreseen here as probable from recent legislation in the United States. "There is a growing opinion in Canadian newsprint circles," a financial news service said today, "that the operation of the industrial control legislation that has received the approval of Congress will mean an increase of at least $5 a ton, and possibly more, in prevailing newsprint prices in Canada."
Princeton's varsity polo team tops the special handicap list arranged for the intercollegiate championship which starts Saturday with the Yale-Princeton game at the Westchester Country Club, Rye.

KANSAS CITY, June 6 (AP). -- Charged with kidnapping under the State law which provides death as the maximum penalty, Walter H. McGee and Clarence Click were held without bond tonight in connection with the abduction of Miss Mary McElroy, 25-year-old daughter of City Manager H.F. McElroy.

A wholesale clothing house, A. Schaap Sons of 394 Broadway, made the highest bid for the Brentano Book Stores at auction yesterday. Should their bid of $120,000 for all assets of the bankrupt stores be accepted, officers of the concern said last night, any of the Brentano stores that proved profitable would be continued.

The classes now being graduated from universities and colleges throughout the country have a "glorious opportunity" to create a new or reconstructed civilization "in these next very difficult years," Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College told the 231 members of the Barnard graduating class at the annual class day exercises yesterday afternoon in the Barnard gymnasium.

Among the Summer theatrical companies will be a group organized by Eric Kalkhurst and Alan Brock which will open a season of six plays at the Hackensack (N. J.) Women's Club Auditorium on July 6 with a presentation of Shaw's "Candida," featuring Leona Hogarth.

Expecting "great activities" to follow the signing of the National Industrial Recovery Act. Ernest J. Russell, president of the American Institute of Architects, has asked its members to make State surveys of construction needs. The institute made public yesterday Mr. Russell's letter to its sixty-seven chapter presidents.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 6 Mrs. Marion Turpie Lake, former Long Island and Southern champion, scored an 86 to win the low gross prize in the one-day tourney of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association over the Quaker Ridge Golf Club course today.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Within ten days, unless a deadlock develops between the President and Congress, that body should stand adjourned. Its departure will call for more than the usual postmortems. Indeed, some of these have already begun.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Five toilet kits quoted at less than $1 each were exhibited to the Senate Military Affairs Committee today. They were compared with the $1.40 kits specified in a contract for 200,000 placed with the Be Vier Corporation of New York City by Robert Fechner, director of the Civilian Conservation Corps.

BERLIN, June 6. -- By invitation of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, Professor Wolfgang Koehler, head of the Psychology Institute of the University of Berlin, is on his way to the United States aboard the liner Bremen to attend the association's meeting, to be held at Chicago in connection with that city's Century of Progress Exposition.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 6. -- The varsity crews of Harvard and Yale, preparing for their annual race, engaged in time trials over the four-mile course on the Thames today. It was the first four-mile test of the season for both eights.

In flying round the world JAMES MATTERN is following the route of POST and GATTY, except for such digressions in Siberia as weather conditions require. His purpose is to break their record of eight days fifteen hours and fifty-one minutes.

Daily average gross crude oil production of the United States last week was 2,675,650 barrels, compared with 2,634,550 in the previous week, a rise of 41,100 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gains of 23,000 and 17,800 barrels respectively, in East Texas and Oklahoma were the principal changes.

The latest addition to the list of departing attractions on Saturday night is "Of Thee I Sing." last year's Pulitzer Prize musical show, which will end a return engagement of four weeks at the Imperial Theatre. Other Broadway productions scheduled to close this week are "Strike Me Pink," "Both Your Houses," "The Mask and the Face," "June Moon" and "It's a Wise Child."

The question of unemployment relief was pushed to the fore before the Board of Estimate, sitting as the committee of the whole yesterday. Three groups appeared before it to stress the inadequacy of relief now being granted and demanding an increase in the appropriations.
Resale of a fifty-eight-acre farm estate in Eatontown featured the New Jersey realty deals reported yesterday.
The text of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler's address on "Character, Conduct, Confidence and Credit," at the Columbia University commencement yesterday, follows:

Tuesday, June 6, 1933. Money market was quiet, and rates for all classes of accommodation unchanged. A small amount of outside money was loaned on Governments at 1/2, but otherwise the ruling rate was 3/4. On the board, 1 per cent prevailed.

WASHINGTON, June 6. - Strenuous efforts are being made by the United States and British Governments to arrive at some solution of the war debt instalment of $76,000,000 due June 15. The tentative proposals and counter-propositions are carefully guarded as to their details in both London and Washington.

The receivers for the Wabash Railway are completing a form of agreement under which equipment trust certificates maturing this year and next year would be extended for three years, respectively, from their due dates. The plan, which affects about $12,000,000 of the certificates, has been approved by saving's banks, insurance companies and other large holders of the securities, it was said.

The umbrella with which Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, attempted last week to disperse a pacifist demonstration at the institution became the emblem yesterday of several hundred undergraduate critics of the college administration.

The Caliph of Central Park moved from his town house to his country estate yesterday. Three keepers, one head-keeper, one park commissioner, one deputy park commissioner, a carpenter and several photographers took part in the ceremonies.

President BUTLER'S Commencement address yesterday cannot be described as that of an aloof and cloistered scholar, not knowing what is going on in the world about him. It is, on the contrary, saturated with actuality. It reveals the very form and pressure of the time.

The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway surprised the financial community yesterday by cutting the dividend rate on its 5 per cent preferred stock to 3 per cent. It had paid the full rate in every year since 1900. A dividend of $1.50 was declared, compared with the regular semi-annual dividend of $2.50 paid previously.

The tax program produced on Monday by the Senate Finance Committee to provide $3,300,000,000 for the public works in the National Industrial Recovery Bill, was criticized here yesterday as "unsound" by Dr. Joseph J. Klein, lawyer, Professor of Taxation at City College and senior partner of the accounting firm of Klein, Hinds Finke.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 6. -- Governor Lehman announced tonight that he had cleared the way for negotiations by the City of New York to lease from the War Department the Fort Schuyler reservation for park purposes.

BOSTON, June 6. -- The world is in desperate need of really competent men trained in the fields of science, engineering and architecture and every indication is that our social development will make this need more acute. Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology declared at the commencement exercises today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have long been interested in world peace, not as a question for academic discussion, but from the point of view of discovering and applying those principles essential for its realization.

Twenty properties in Manhattan and the Bronx went to the plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Savings banks which had made loans on the properties figured prominently as successful bidders at the sales.

New York University, through Chancellor Elmer Ellsworth Brown, will confer 4,244 degrees and certificates upon the largest graduating classes in its history at 6 o'clock this evening when it celebrates its 101st commencement at Ohio Field, University Heights.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 6. -- The need for action by State and Federal governments to provide relief in order that the credit of municipalities might be preserved was stressed by Mayor Frank Frankel of Long Beach in his welcoming address as the annual convention of the New York State Conference of Mayors and Municipal Officials began here today.

WITH Max Schmeling and Max Baer resting before their battle, there is a chance to glance westward and note the gathering of the golf cian at the North Shore course in the Chicago district, where the national open championship will get under way tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP). -- An attempt to force Senate approval of a resolution to recognize New York State's power claims in the St. Lawrence seaway development by adding it as an amendment to the administration Public Works Bill was made today by Senator La Follette.

When Henry P. Davison saw prices and production shooting upward in the first months of the war, with foreign governments and even various departments of administration bidding against one another, he conceived the idea of offering the services of J.P. Morgan Co. to coordinate the purchases here of goods for war use.
CINCINNATI, June 6 (AP). -- The Cardinals defeated the Reds, 6 to 2, today in a riotous game marked by a fight between Dizzy Dean of the Cards and Paul Derringer of the Reds.

GENEVA, June 6. -- Norman H. Davis, leader of the United States delegation to the disarmament conference, took for the United States today the strongest stand for the control of armaments and munitions making that it has taken in the fourteen years this subject has been discussed here.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee investigating banking, financing and securities sales practices of J.P. Morgan Co. resumed its inquiry after a delayed start at 12:10 o'clock today with O.P. Van Sweringen of Cleveland, president of the Alleghany Corporation, again testifying.
After completing his explanation of his 1929 and 1930 income tax returns, Charles E. Mitchell was subjected to a two and one-half hour cross-examination yesterday afternoon.

LYNCHBURG, Va., June 6. -- Teaching men and women to use leisure rightly will be far more difficult, though equally if not more important, than to instruct them how to labor efficiently, Dr. John H. Finley of New York told a class of 133 young women graduating at Randolph-Macon Woman's College today.

The Department of Justice, acting on instructions received from Attorney General Homer S. Cummings, took steps yesterday in this district to enforce President Roosevelt's proclamation of April 5, which made the willful hoarding of gold after last May 1 an offense punishable to ten years in prison and a fine of $10,000.

The Giants had a joyful time at Ebbets Field yesterday, defeating the hapless Dodgers for the third straight time, 7 to 2, and thereby retaining their proud position at the top of the league. The defeat dropped the Dodgers into seventh place.

GENEVA, June 6. -- By abstaining from voting, the German Government allowed the Council of the League of Nations this morning to adopt in a binding way the report of Sean Lester holding that the application of anti-Semitic measures in Upper Silesia complained of in the petition of Franz Bernheim violated the convention for the protection of minorities in the region.
Manhattan real estate trading yesterday was confined largely to the west side, where various sales and leases involved both, business and residential buildings.

An army of detectives and patrolmen, 1,250 strong, will be assigned to the Yankee Stadium and its vicinity tomorrow night to protect and direct the crowds going to the Schmeling-Baer fight. Commissioner Bolan completed the police arrangements yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Conferees on the Glass-Steagall Banking Reform Bill met again today to discuss the Vandenberg amendment for immediate deposit insurance, but made no decision. Announcing another meeting tomorrow, Representative Steagall optimistically said he hoped an agreement would be reached.

Carrying out the administration's plan to raise $4,000,000 in new revenue through imposing a 5-cent tax on each taxicab ride, the Board of Aldermen considered a proposed ordinance yesterday which not only imposes the tax but increases the maximum fare for cabs from 40 to 50 cents a mile and makes the person licensing the cab responsible for collecting the tax.

Leading from start to finish, and at the end of the seven furlongs running easily, George D. Widener's Sation again confirmed his claim to class by winning the thirty-third running of the Swift Stakes, feature at Belmont Park yesterday.

Mayor O'Brien's statement on the new city taxes was attacked last night by Samuel Untermyer as a "manifestly evasive and insincere mass of distortion and misinformation." The Mayor is seeking to deceive the public about the city's financial situation "by falsely charging it to the requirements for home and unemployment relief," Mr. Untermyer said.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- The purpose of the Roosevelt administration to use the Industrial Recovery Act to effect a shorter work week generally throughout industry, with a compensatory higher wage, was revealed in an official quarter here today.

PEIPING, June 6. -- The situation in Chahar Province is becoming increasingly serious as conditions indicate the early execution of Lieut. Gen. Kuniaki Koiso's declaration that the Japanese "must occupy Kalgan in order to protect Jehol."
BRYN MAWR, Pa., June 6. -- The elections to the boards of the four major undergraduate organizations at Bryn Mawr College have been announced as follows:

Both branches of Congress have now approved bills embodying the Administration's railway program. The two measures differ at certain points. There has been disagreement particularly over sections intended to limit the discharge of employes in consequence of consolidations in the interest of economy.

MOSCOW, June 6. -- Just twelve hours and twenty-one minutes after leaving Moscow on his flight around the world, James Mattern set his airplane, the Century of Progress, down on the landing field at the Siberian town of Omsk today, 1,450 miles east of Moscow.

ALBANY, June 6. -- The political calendar for 1933 was issued today by Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State, giving the dates for the Fall primaries, conventions and information concerning the election next November.

Going about their chores as one would who had weightier problems in mind, the Yankees seemed it expend no undue effort in riding roughshod over the Red Sox in both ends of a double header as the world's champions concluded their home stand at the Stadium yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP). -- Final approval by the House Judiciary Committee today started a municipal refinancing bill on a legislative course that if completed would round out what is perhaps the broadest extension ever undertaken of the country's bankruptcy laws.

OMSK, Siberia, Wednesday, June 7. -- James Mattern, American roundthe-world flyer, took off toward Chita, Siberia, 1,700 miles east of here, at 1:10 A.M. Moscow Time (6:10 P.M. Tuesday, Eastern Daylight Time).
WASHINGTON, June 6. -- The War Department issued the following orders today.

BUCHAREST, June 6. -- Poland, Rumania, Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Bulgaria, Latvia, Estonia, Greece and Turkey will present at the World Economic Conference in London a common platform with financial and economic planks.

Commencement exercises of the College of the Sacred Heart, Convent Avenue and West 133d Street, will be held this afternoon. Car- dinal Hayes will attend the ceremonies, which will open at 3 o'clock, and will confer the degree of Bachelor of Arts upon thirty-eight young women in the graduating class.

MADISON, N.J., June 6. -- Commencement exercises were held in the seminary chapel of Drew University this morning, seventy-nine graduates receiving their degrees from the Rev. Dr. Arlo Ayres Brown, president of the institution. The commencement speaker was Bishop Edwin H. Hughes of the Washington (D.C.) area of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

1933's Graduate Presidents. President LOWELL of Harvard, Chancellor BROWN of New York University and President KIERAN of Hunter College are among the college heads who are retiring or have already retired from office this year.
Max Schmeling and Max Baer, having completed their training preparations for their fifteen-round bout at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow night, are calmly awaiting the battle.

Prices for commodities traded on local exchanges moved irregularly yesterday. Sugar continued upward and cocoa and silk were higher. Hides and rubber lost ground, while silver and coffee were irregular. Trading was in fair volume. Cash prices were also irregular.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- A searching inquiry into the income-tax records of J.P. Morgan and his score of partners was virtually decided upon today by the Senate committee which has been delving into the operations of the banking firm.

CARDIFF, Wales, June 6 (Ca- nadian Press.) -- The cricket match between the touring British West Indies team and Glamorgan, first-class county eleven, ended in a draw this evening. The scores were: British West Indies, 475, and 26 for two: Glamorgan, 493.

Formation of a committee to represent holders of bonds of the City of Detroit, which are outstanding in the amount of approximately $368,000,000, was announced yesterday. It is headed by B.A. Thompkins, vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, and is composed of men who own or represent substantial amounts of the bonds.

CHICAGO, June 6 (AP). -- Miss Patience, unbeaten filly from the Audley Farm, owned by B.B. Jones of Virginia, made it five victories in a row when the speedy 2-year-old won the feature race at Washington Park today.

The Empire State, training ship of the New York Merchant Marine Academy, with its crew of 143 cadets in charge of Captain Lucien B. Green, sailed from its base at the navy yard in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, outward bound for Bermuda, England, France and Gibraltar.

For the second time in about a month, leading rubber companies have announced advances in the prices of automobile tires. The upturns, which will become effective today in most cases, run to 14 per cent, although the average is about 10 per cent.

The aggregate market value of all listed shares on the New York Stock Exchange advanced from $26,815,110,054 on May 1 to $32,473,061,395 on June 1, a gain of 21.1 per cent, according to the monthly bulletin issued by the Exchange. The increase since April 1, 1933, has been $12,558,000,000, or 63.1 per cent, and since March 1, 1933, the low point, $12,773,000,000, or 64.8 per cent.

The Rev. Dr. Frank N.D. Buchman, organizer of the First Century Christian Fellowship, reported yesterday a great and ever-increasing interest in the movement throughout the United States and Canada. He returned with a group of about forty workers who have been touring the Continent since October.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., June 6. -- An assertion that the last decade had brought greater strides toward world peace than the most ardent dreamer could have hoped for in a century was made today by Newton D. Baker, addressing the American Association of Rhodes Scholars.

ATHENS, Greece, June 6. -- An attempt to assassinate Eleutherios Venizelos, several times Premier of Greece and a leading European statesman for many years, failed late tonight, but shots fired by an assailant wounded M. Venizelos's wife and chauffeur.
WASHINGTON, June 6. -- The Japanese Government today expressed its "hearty response" to President Roosevelt's world peace appeal, made three weeks ago to the rulers and peoples of the world.

The proposal of the British Chamber of Shipping of an international program for the laying-up of merchant tonnage, announced on Monday in London, found little encouragement yesterday among American shipping men. The chamber has submitted the proposal to its members and may take it to the World Economic Conference if sufficient interest is manifested.

Edward W. Burns, the second ranking player in the Brooklyn tennis championship and winner of the title for the past two years, had a close call yesterday in his third-round match on the clay courts of the Terrace Club of Flat-bush.

James J. Mattern still has a good chance to better the world-circling record set by Wiley Post and Harold Gatty. They did not land at Omsk, but were seventy-four hours nine minutes out of New York when they passed over it on the morning of June 26, 1931.

Answers to the so-called "salary grab" suit of H.F. Murray, Queens taxpayer, against Mayor O'Brien, former Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee, Controller Berry and Borougrh President George U. Harvey of Queens have been filed, it was announced yesterday by James E. Finegan, counsel for the plaintiff.

BOLOGNA, Italy, June 6 (AP). -- Charles Hooper Trask, 39 years old, a newspaper man and native of New Jersey, was reported killed today and his wife, Claire, 44 years old, was gravely injured when their automobile left the road and fell over a 45-foot precipice near Bolzano, Trentino, about 150 miles north of here.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP). -- A demand for the resignation or, if not tendered, the impeachment of Secretary Woodin was made in the Senate today by Senator Robinson of Indiana as a result of the disclosures that several years before Mr. Woodin became Secretary of the Treasury he received stock from J.P. Morgan Co. at reduced prices.

Prize awards to students of the Leonardo Da Vinci Art School, 149 East Thirty-fourth Street, were announced last night at the closing exercises of the school. First prizes of $25 each for paintings from life were awarded to Armando Catenare and Vincent Campanella, and second and third prizes of $15 and $10 went to Louis Marotta and Boris Plenkovici.

Greater opportunities for healing exist today than ever before, Bainbridge Colby, former Secretary of State, declared last night at commencement exercises of the New York Homeopathic College and Flower Hospital. He spoke before sixty-eight graduating doctors, fifteen graduates of the Nursing School and an audience of about 1,200 at Town Hall.
OSSINING, N.Y., June 6. -- State policemen and railroad detectives were investigating here today the death of Edward Kerby Sherman, 27 years old, a salesman, of 37 State Street, Bloomfield, N.J.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6 (AP). -- The Philadelphia Athletics' big guns went into action again today and made it two straight over the Washington Senators with an 8-to-4 victory. The triumph advanced the victors from fifth to fourth place.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, June 7. -- Cyrus H.K. Curtis, publisher and philanthropist, who was often characterized as Philadelphia's first citizen, died at 2:10 o'clock this morning at his estate, Lyndon, in suburban Wyncote.

Further testimony as to the condition of the defunct Bank of Unitad States in the period just prior to its closing was given yesterday at the $25 per share assessment suit against stockholders of the bank being tried before Supreme Court Justice Lydon.

LONDON, June 6 (By Wireless). -- Great Britain's half-yearly payment of interest on the American debt is due next week. We have no information about the course the British Government will adopt. Will it honor its bond or will Britain on June 15 be added to the long list of defaulting States?

The mortgage for $2,000,000 held by the Seamen's Bank for Savings from the 5th Av. and 51st St. Corp., Samuel M. Greer, president, on the three-story Union Club building at the northeast corner of 5th Av. and 51st St., has been extended to May 31, 1936, at 5 per cent, but it will be amortized at the rate ot $100,000 semi-annually beginning Aug. 31 of this year.

Developments which indicated a further extension of the industrial recovery shaped the course of the security markets for a time yesterday, but realizing sales and speculation for the decline halted the advance in stocks in the middle of the day.

The highest scholastic honors were awarded to twin brothers yesterday at the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science and College of Engineering Class Day exercises. The brothers, George Leonard Kauer Jr. and Joseph Taylor Kauer, were honored at the services in the Gould Memorial Auditorium, University Heights.

CHICAGO, June 6. -- There was no let-up today in the unfavorable crop and weather reports, but they fell almost flat as influences on the wheat market. The market fluctuated rather slowly within a range of 1 1/8 to 1 1/2 cents a bushel and closed about the bottom with net losses of 1/3 to 3/3 cent.
