GLENVIEW, Ill., June 6 (AP). -- Gene Sarazen may be the man to beat in this year's national open golf championship, starting Thursday over the 6,927-yard layout of the North Shore Golf Club, but the boiling temperatures today on the course, as well as in the locker rooms, developed a consensus that a "dark horse" will gallop out from the pack to win the tournament.

W.S. Farish was elected yesterday chairman of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey at the organization meeting of the directors, following the stockholders' annual meeting in Newark. He has been a director of the company several years and is president of the Humble Oil and Refining Company, a subsidiary.

David Dubin, former president of the Cloak and Dress Covered-Button Manufacturers Association, had just begun his testimony in his defense in General Sessions yesterday on coercion and conspiracy indictments when Judge Corrigan adjourned the trial until today.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 6. -- Claims made by Argentina in a protest against the aerial bombardment of the Paraguayan town of Puerto Casado were rejected by Bolivia today and reference of the dispute to the World Court was suggested if Argentina should fail to agree with Bolivia's reasoning.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP). -- A battle for insertion or the sales tax in the Industry Control Bill brewed today in the Senate as advocates of this levy in both parties arranged their lines on the eve of opening of debate on the measure.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the moving-picture theatre an unfailing source of amusement is the process of photography whereby a tall tower crumbled into dust by dynamite resumes its original condition, a youth who has taken a fancy dive into a pool below hops back out of the water to his position on the diving board, or a steeplechase rider travels backward over the hedge.

W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, wants Samuel Seabury to become arbiter of the anti-Tammany Fusion movement at conferences between groups which will take part in the anti-Tammany fight this Fall.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Following is the supplemental agreement, as introduced into the records of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today, under which the Guaranty Trust Company turned over to the Nickel Plate Securities Corporation common stock of the Nickel Plate road in return for preferred stock in that road, as part of the transaction by which the Van Sweringens first got control of the road and started on their railroad career:

Mme. Rigo, widow of Jancsi Rigo, Hungarian violinist of many adventures and known as Prince Rigo, is a patient in the free ward at the Presbyterian Hospital, it became known yesterday. Destitute and weak from lack of food, she collapsed on the street a few weeks ago and, through a physician who attended her, she was entered as a charity patient at the hospital.

CLEVELAND, June 6 (AP). -- The Tigers won their third game in the current series with Cleveland today by taking advantage of Indian miscues in the late innings. The score was 5 to 2. The setback dropped Cleveland from fourth to fifth place in the race.

Postmaster General FARLEY is the first member of the Cabinet to come to the defense of the Government's voiding of the gold contract in its bonds. He declared on Monday at Rochester that "much nonsense" has been talked about this breach of national good faith.

The steel industry in this country produced 2,001,991 tons of steel ingots in May, the largest total for any month since June, 1931, according to figures issued yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

VIENNA, June 6. -- A resolution establishing the right of Jews, whether Germans or not, to participate in the Olympic Games will be introduced at tomorrow's open session of the Olympic Games Committee here, and it is virtually certain to be passed.

A 2-year-old boy in a baby carriage and a 50-year-old woman seated on a camp stool outside the door of the apartment house in which she lived were killed late yesterday afternoon when an automobile escaped from its driver's control and mounted the sidewalk at Boston Road and East 168th Street, the Bronx.

ATHENS, June 7. -- Police today arrested two men here on suspicion of being connected with the attempt late last night to assassinate former Premier Eleutherior Venizelos, while M. Venizelos was driving to Athens.

CHICAGO, June 7. -- The wheat market acted today in a manner that puzzled the trade. There seemed to be plenty of grain for sale on the bulges, but the breaks met good support and the close was at the top at net gains of 3/4 to 1 cent, July showing the most strength.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP). -- The automobile trend in foreign countries, as well as in the United States, is more and more to the production of the small low-priced car to fit the reduced public pocketbook.

A series of free concerts in the city's parks was begun last night under a State program to provide recreation for the unemployed and at the same time to give employment to white-collar workers. The concerts will employ 375 musicians, many of whom formerly were with leading symphony orchestras.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- The Tennessee River Valley Authority, which will supervise the vast development that includes Muscle Shoals, will soon announce the selection of its chief engineer. The names under consideration are Hugh L. Cooper, consulting engineer of New York; Morris L. Cooke of Philadelphia, a trustee of the Power Authority of the State of New York, and J.L. Savage, chief designing engineer of the Bureau of Reclamation' stationed at Denver.

With Mayor John P. O'Brien's program of city taxes destined to become a dominant issue in the Mayoralty campaign, Alderman Joseph Clark Baldwin is now looked upon as a probable candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen on the anti-Tammany city ticket.

The Board of Transportation will hold a public hearing June 20 on revised contract forms for the advertising and vending concessions on the city's independent subway system. This is the first move to obtain substantial additional revenue from the new system since the board rejected last September all bids received on contracts for the concessions.
Fresh water fishermen are not having any great run of luck these days. From all reports trout fishing has slumped very markedly. There are many reasons for this condition.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- The Civilian Conservation Corps toilet kit investigation conducted by the Senate Military Affairs Committee turned today to a study of prices. The decision was reached at an executive session of an hour.

PARIS, June 7. -- Monetary stability and the solution of the war debts must be attained if the economic war that has been going on for two years is to be ended in London, Finance Minister Georges Bonnet said today at the luncheon of the Anglo-American Press Club, making the first official declaration of the French Government on the World Economic Conference.

What the sophisticates of the stock market call "rotating" went on at a great rate yesterday on the Stock Exchange. Almost every group of stocks received attention in turn. All of them, at some time or another, showed progress. Obviously there was active stimulation by pools and any investing groups which have stocks acquired at higher prices.

When EDWARD BOK proposed to write the life of Mr. CURTIS, it is remembered that the latter said: "I was born and I'm not dead yet. There's nothing more to it." He must have been conscious, however, that there was something more to it in the objective romance of such a career.
A home run by Clancy in the eighth inning with two men on bases gave Jersey City its fourth victory in the five-game series with the Baltimore Orioles yesterday at Jersey City. The score was 5 to 3.

Rehabilitation of industry, in addition to the spreading of work, is one of the major objectives of the National Recovery Act, George A. Sloan, president of the Cotton Textile Institute, declared here yesterday, in answering the objections of some factors in the cotton goods industry that there is no sound reason for recommending a reduction in the hours of labor.

A change is about to be made in the management of the Italian Line in this country which will transfer executive control from the present board of three to the hands of a single director approved by the Italian Government, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 7. -- Edwin Markham, the poet, 81 years old, and Mrs. Alma Newton Anderson, widowed novelist, settled their war of words today before Thomas J. Peden, Federal master in chancery, after brief arbitration. The poet will receive $1,127, and from this is to pay his lawyers.

Although few store chains have reported recently greater totals of sales than those for the same period last year, most of them have shown substantial recovery from their previous decline and are now only slightly below the figures of 1932.
BERLIN, June 7. -- An ordinance decreeing a transfer moratorium on service payments on Germany's foreign debts will be made public tomorrow, to take effect immediately.

VIENNA, June 7. -- Despite a tradition of a hundred years and a special international treaty, the Austro-Bavarian frontier has been closed by German authorities to all Austrians not members of the Nazi party.

Max Schmeling, the German boxer who lost the heavyweight championship of the world to Jack Sharkey last June, and Max Baer, California's heavy-hitting battler, ere ready for their fifteen-round bout tonight at the Yankee Stadium.

A campaign to have the business ethics of the large chain store systems of the country investigated by the Federal Government was begun last night at a meeting of more than 400 members of the Business Independence League, held in the Odd Fellows' Temple, 105 East 106th Street.

With a sound as of a thousand backfires, ALVAN TUFTS FULLER, Governor of Massachusetts from '25 to '29, announced last week that he would be a candidate again in 1934. If he has many enemies in his own party, he is supposed to have many friends among the Democrats.
LONDON, June 7. -- Drinks from all over the world will be available for thirsty delegates between discussions at the economic conference.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- President Roosevelt's approval was understood today to have been given to a compromise on the deposit insurance provisions of the Glass-Steagall Banking Reform legislation. Senator Glass at a White House conference explained the arrangement to the President, Secretary Woodin and Director Douglas of the budget.

CLEVELAND, June 7 (AP). -- In a sixth-inning attack led by Marvin Owen's homer into the right-field stands, Detroit defeated Cleveland, 3 to 1, for the fourth straight time today, ending the current series against the Indians with four out of five victories.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 7. -- President of Seton Hall College in South Orange since 1922, Mgr. Thomas H. McLaughlin delivered today his farewell address as presiding official of the institution before a graduating class of sixtytwo students.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Taking the floor after Senator Wagner had finished his prepared speech explaining the Industry Bill today, Senator Borah declared that in his judgment "this bill is a very advanced step toward the ultimate concentration of wealth."
Following is the text of the address delivered last night by Governor Lehman before the New York State Conference of Mayors at Long Beach:

With speculative activity intensified in all markets, prices again advanced yesterday. Transactions amounted to 6,641,730 shares, which represented one of the three or four busiest days of the year on the Stock Exchange. The net gains in stock were comparatively small because of a selling movement that erased most of the earlier advance.

Gasoline and motor oil concerns, automobile tire manufacturers and makers of candy and gum, soaps and cleansers and soft drinks, as well as several miscellaneous companies, increased their aggregate expenditure for newspaper advertising in 1932, a survey by the Bureau of Advertising, made public yesterday, shows.

A plot to strip valuable oil paint- ings and framed signatures of the Presidents of the United States from the walls of the Brook Club at 111 East Fifty-fourth Street was revealed yesterday by the police. J.P. Morgan, William H. Vanderbilt and Cornelius Vanderbilt are members of the club.

LONDON, June 7. -- In a quiet upstairs room of Claridge's Hotel six men have been sitting daily this week around a green table in the frankest and most intimate discussion of world problems important to the success of this approaching economic conference which proposes to remedy as many of the world's ills as possible but sadly needs some initial impulse to set it going.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 7 (AP). -- The most violent wind, hail and electrical storm to strike Western New York and near-by Ontario in years this afternoon killed five persons, injured at least thirty and caused damage running into the hundreds of thousands.

Attacks on the large salaries paid to some business executives were condemned yesterday by H. A. Hopf, re-elected president of the National Office Management Association, at the concluding session of the annual conference of the organization at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Brentano book stores were sold yesterday to a combination headed by A. Kroch, bookseller, of Chicago, and Stanton Griffiths, private banker here, and the large chain constituting the world's largest retail book outlet will be continued.

So Mayor O'BRIEN'S heralded "Local Law to Relieve the People "of the City of New York From "the Hardships and Suffering "Caused by Unemployment" is not for the relief of the unemployed after all, but for the relief of Tammany Hall from the hardships of retrenchment.

The largest offer of securities made thus far by the Roosevelt Administration has been announced by Secretary WOODIN. It consists of $500,000,000 in five-year notes and $400,000,000 in nine-month certificates. The notes will bear interest at 2 7/8 per cent and the certificates at three-quarters of 1 per cent.

GOSHEN, N.Y., June 7. -- Evalee Hanover, owned by Joseph F. O'Shea of Hackensack, N.J., and driven by Al Drinkwater, won the 2:24 trot, opening event of the three-day meeting of the Bay State circuit today. A record first-day crowd attended.

The world has now reached the point where it can work its way out of the depression but the recovery, to be lasting, must be soundly based and gradual, in the opinion of Frans van Cauwelaert, Belgian Minister of State, leader of the Flemish Catholics in Parliament and former Mayor of Antwerp.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Members of Congress who have talked with the President lately have concluded that he has decided not to send to Congress a request for authority to negotiate tariff agreements with other nations.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 7. -- An exhibition of women's authentic costumes of the last 200 years, together with many headdresses, will open at the Art Association rooms tomorrow. It has been arranged by Miss Katherine Cortazzo. Mrs. Daniel W. Jones has been acting as secretary; Mrs. Francis L.V. Hoppin is in charge of the headdresses, and Mrs. W.W. Covell of the costumes.

Franklin Mott Gunther, former diplomat and now president of the American Institute for Persian Art and Archaeology, will sail tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen with Mrs. Gunther. William T. Tilden 2d and Hans Nuesslein, American and German professional tennis champions, also will sail.

Samuel Seabury argued before the Appellate Division yesterday for the reversal of Justice Valente's decision upholding the Board of Estimate's plan to award the five-year contract for the removal of Brooklyn waste to Samuel Rosoff's Manhattan Garbage and Ash Removal Company.
Federal Reserve Banks throughout the nation were beginning yesterday to receive gold which had been held by hoarders in violation of President Roosevelt's proclamation.

Senator James Couzens of Michigan sailed yesterday for London on the United States liner Washington to join the American delegation to the World Economic Conference. He was accompanied by Mrs. Couzens.
By a decision of the Appellate Division yesterday the owners of bonds of the Libby Hotel failed to win about $200,000 and the creditors of the American Bond and Mortgage Company gained that sum.

ROME, June 7. -- Premier Mussolini announced to the Senate late this afternoon in a speech that avoked crashing cheers, that the four-power pact of cooperation and consultation among Great Britain, France, Germany and Italy had been successfully concluded.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Although the full text of the results of the four-year study made by the Motion-Picture Research Council is not yet available, the advance report as published in newspapers and summarized in the book "Our Movie-Made Children" gives enough information upon which to base a critical judgment.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- The House passed today, by a vote of 237 to 119, the Rankin Bill amending the Hawaiian Organic Act, and authorizing the President to appoint a non-resident Governor of the islands.

HAVANA, June 7. -- President Machado issued a statement tonight giving details of his plans for the constitutional reforms which he is again holding out as an olive branch to the enemies of his regime for solution in a legal manner of the present Cuban political turmoil.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 7 (AP). -- Newark won, 2 to 0, from Albany today when Big Jim Weaver out-pitched Whitey Campbell in a tense duel. Jim Moore accounted for both Newark runs with a home run and a single.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- When the Senate passed the Connally amendment to the Independent Offices Bill, most of its members were not thinking of anything but adding to the government's annual veterans' expenditures $170,000,000 more than the administration's new regulations provided.
The dollar suffered a renewed depreciation in foreign exchange yesterday, reaching 17.6 per cent in terms of the French franc, the lowest value since the abandonment of the gold standard.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Nothing could be more extraordinary than the taxes proposed by Mayor O'Brien at a time when every merchant in New York needs all the help that he can get to keep business going. The Mayor, in the first place, would put a premium on visiting New York.

"Why should we look at the supply of water, milk, bread, meat, soap, steel beams, bricks or a thousand and one other useful staples as anything other than what it is, a service to consumers, through which workers may earn a fair livelihood; employers, fair wages of management; investors, fair return on the necessary capital?"
CHICAGO, June 7 (AP). -- Abraham Bartelstein's Polydorus was only one-fifth of a second behind the Washington Park record for seven furlongs today, winning the Mohawk Purse in impressive style.

National Beauty Parlors, a chain organization, has leased for a long term the second floor of the Hotel Cadillac at the northeast corner of Broadway and Forty-third Street, on Times Square. Edward Gorenstein arranged the lease for the Dasco Realty Corporation.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- The administration's complete satisfaction with the services of Sumner Welles as Ambassador to Cuba was expressed by Acting Secretary of State Phillips today. Mr. Phillips said that reports to the contrary were being published in the Cuban press and that these accounts were untrue.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 7. -- Harvard's varsity baseball team staged a two-run rally in the ninth inning to tie the alumni and won in the eleventh on three passes and a hit, 4 to 3.

NEW HAVEN, June 7 . -- Yale pounded the offerings of Jeff Sawyer for eleven hits in six innings today to defeat the New York A. C. by 5 to 3. Lanahan, who relieved Sawyer, gave one hit and one tally in the two frames he worked.

ST. LOUIS, June 7 (AP). -- The White Sox went into second place in the American League today as a result of defeating the Browns, 4 to 1, while Washington played a tie game with Philadelphia and fell to third place. It was the fifth straight victory for Chicago over the Browns.
In the Same Boat. What are America's defenders on the tariff front doing? British unemployment has gone down for the fourth consecutive month and is now 320,000 below last January.
The New York State Committee of the National Economy League is opposed to any increase in compensation to veterans above the amounts allowed in President Roosevelt's original economy program.

LONDON, June 7. -- The first reaction to publication of the fourpower pact in London tonight is the belief expressed in Laborite quarters that by concluding it the powers are assuming the Geneva arms conference will fail.

BOSTON, June 7 (AP). -- After a two-day break in the National League schedule, the Braves went back to baseball today and defeated Philadelphia, 3 -- 1, in the final game of the series. Cantwell held the Phillies to six hits.

One young woman fell to her death and another narrowly escaped when a skylight collapsed under them at noon yesterday on the roof of the Guardian Life Insurance Company building, 50 Union Square. Both were employes of the insurance company.

As its first step in resisting the decision of the State of Arkansas to refund its $91,000,000 specifically secured highway and bridge bonds by 3 per cent obligations and lump them with various other debts of the State, the recently formed bondholders' protective committee headed by William L. De Bost sent out yesterday a call for deposits of bonds with the Chase National Bank, depository.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts awarded yesterday an issue of $2,175,000 of notes to the First of Boston Corporation. The bankers named a price of par, plus a premium of $13, for the $2,000,000 due May 15, 1934, as 1.38s, and par for the $175,000 due Nov. 22, 1933, as 0.84s.

Bank clearings throughout the country continued in the week ended on Wednesday to run slightly below those of a year ago, although the week-to-week improvement in 1933 has been better than in 1932, according to the weekly tabulation by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Heavy buying of railroad bonds and of many industrial and utility issues sent prices of domestic corporation bonds substantially higher on the Stock Exchange yesterday, lifting THE NEW YORK TIMES averages for all of these groups to new high levels for the year to date.

In weighing the significance of the decisive vote in Indiana for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, the Dry record of that State must not be forgotten. It had repeatedly added severities of its own to the Volstead Act. Legislation striking deep into private rights was enacted, and for a long time the most extreme restrictions and unreasonable penalties were the order of the day in Indiana.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- A determined attempt to adjourn Congress by Saturday night was begun today by the administration, following advices from Capitol Hill that a continuance might jeopardize not only foreign policies but also parts of the recovery program.

With the sharpest increase registered since the upturn started in March, the adjusted index of electric-power production for the week ended June 3 has advanced to 91.3 from 88.2 in the previous week. For the corresponding week last year the number was 85.8.

PARIS, June 7. -- Although bearing in mind that the government may face a serious test when the four-power pact comes up for debate in the Chamber on Friday, France nevertheless welcomes sincerely the possibility of eventual reconciliation with Italy that initialing document at Rome seems to promise.

An increase of 10 per cent in the wages of steel workers, effective on July 1, is under discussion in the steel industry, according to a steel producer. Approval of the increase is dependent upon the passage of the National Industrial Recovery Act and the ratification by the steel industry of certain provisions of the bill, particularly those dealing with maximum hours of employment and minimum wages.

A sharp break in prices of raw sugar futures was the feature of yesterday's trading on the local commodity exchanges. Other staples were somewhat higher, following the general trend in outside markets. Cash prices were higher.

CHICAGO, June 7 (AP). -- The Cubs batted Bill Swift out of the box with a four-run attack in the second inning and added three more in the sixth to defeat the Pirates, 7 to 2, in the final game of the series today. It was the Cubs' third victory in the four games played.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 7. -- When Yale and Harvard's rowing squads arrived at their training quarters last Sunday night, betting on the four-mile varsity race on the Thames June 16 favored Harvard, 10 -- 8. Today the odds were even, the change coming about through the remarkably fast time trial made by Yale upstream last night.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 7. -- Jack Sharkey of Crestmont and Sandy Wiedenmayer of Essex County tied at 157 for the medal in the thirty-six-hole qualifying round of the thirty-second annual New Jersey State amateur golf championship, played today at the Canoe Brook Country Club.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Early indications point to oversubscriptions of the Treasury's $900,000,000 offering in 5-year 2 7/8 per cent notes and 9-month 3/4 per cent certificates. Secretary Woodin said he thought the issues would win favor with investors.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 7. -- The will of William Muldoon, veteran member of the New York State Athletic Commission, disposing of an estate estimated at about $250,000, was filed for probate with Surrogate George A. Slater this afternoon by Charles C. Fenno, his counsel.

LONDON, June 7. -- Simultaneously with the issuance of the report of the Imperial Committee on Economic Consultation and Cooperation, it was announced today that there had been no suggestion of adopting a common empire policy for the World Economic Conference.

Before Somerset Maugham became resigned to "writing not as I should have liked but as I could," he says in his introduction to "Travellers Library," just published by Doubleday, Doran, he ransacked dictionaries for unusual epithets, went to the British Museum and made lists of the names of precious stones, and, in his room, pounded his desk and prayed "for more brains."
LONDON, June 7. -- The following is the official English text of the Mussolini Four-Power Pact for maintenance of peace in Europe for the next ten years as made public here tonight.

Three major obstacles are blocking the way to the firmer establishment of international peace and cooperation and the return of prosperity, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler said yesterday. Dr. Butler, with Mrs. Butler, sailed last night on the Cunarder Berengaria to meet with the European committee of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, of which he is president.
WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Administrators of the public works section of the National Industrial Recovery Bill are planning to call on Governors of the States for an advance construction program.

The Rubber Manufacturers Association announced yesterday that Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War, had been engaged as spe- cial counsel to assist the rubber industry in working out an operating code under the proposed National Industrial Recovery Act.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- The operations of the Van Sweringen brothers in acquiring railroads and in transferring assets from one company to another through temporary holding companies to avoid by legal methods the payment of income taxes were brought out today before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 7. -- Governor Lehman, in an address here tonight, urged that New York State municipalities hasten to take advantage of the pending $3,000,000,000 Federal appropriation for public works.

Mayor O'Brien sent a written demand to his department heads yesterday warning them to cut next year's expenses to the bone and then "to scrape the bone." Meanwhile the public protest increased against imposition of any new taxes before substantial administrative economies were made.

In place of the regular Saturday afternoon performance at the Morosco Theatre, where "Best Sellers" is being given, a special matinee will be held today. This arrangement, which may be continued for the remainder of the engagement, will allow Ernest Truex, who is co-starred with Peggy Wood, to attend the graduation exercises of his son, Philip Truex, at Haverford College.

VIENNA, June 7. -- The German Government having guaranteed as a principle that German Jews would not be excluded from German. Olympic teams, the International Olympic Committee today decided to allow the next Olympic Games in 1936 to be held in Berlin, instead of transferring them elsewhere as would have been done had not the assurance been forthcoming.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP). -- Postmaster General Farley, as Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, expressed gratification today over the repeal votes of Indiana and Illinois.

GLENVIEW, Ill., June 7. -- A withering heat wave, driving the mercury close to the 100 mark forced many of the contestants in the thirty-seventh national open golf championship, which starts tomorrow, either to forsake last-minute practice entirely today, or to curtail their preparation to nine holes.

Consolidated net income of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation for 1932 declined to $364,647 after taxes, interest, amortization, depreciation and other charges from $4,645,893 reported in the preceding year, the annual report issued yesterday.

Melbert B. Gary, who served the New York Homeopathic Medical College and Flower Hospital as a member of the board of trustees from 1896 to 1918 and as president of the board from 1905 to 1918, was honored yesterday at the alumni day exercises of the institution.

Mendicants of all kinds, as well as vendors of pencils, chewing gum and shoe laces, are to be barred henceforth from trains of the B.M. T. subway system. Notice to this effect were posted yesterday in all cars, and guards and other subway employes were ordered to warn all such persons that a second appearance in any B.M.T. train would result in their arrest.
Charles E. Mitchell precipitated a stormy interlude in his incometax trial yesterday by mentioning his wife's exclusion from the witness stand.

CROYDON AIRFIELD, England, Thursday, June 8. -- Captain James A. Mollison and his wife, Amy Johnson, crashed in trying to take off for a non-stop flight to New York at 5:50 A.M. today (12:50 A.M., Eastern Daylight Saving Time).
Many clubs in and about New York City received beer and wine licenses yesterday from, the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board.

Copyright. 1933. by The Chicago Tribune. ABOARD THE S.S. PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, June 7. -- Concluding today a week of daily consultations with technical advisers, the American delegation has completed part of the program of participation in the forthcoming World Economic Conference in London.

Federal Judge Frank J. Coleman signed yesterday an order requiring the Paramount Publix Corporation to show cause on June 14 why Charles D. Hilles, Louis Horowitz and Eugene W. Leake should not be removed as trustees in bankruptcy and why Henry H. Davis should not be discharged from further consideration of the case as Federal referee in bankruptcy.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 7. -- Turning in a sparkling 75, B.W. Read of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company recorded the best gross score at the twelfth annual officers' golf tournament of the Bankers Athletic League of New York over the Hudson River Country Club links today.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Money, not man, has been the "supreme consideration and the justifying end" of policies responsible for the "present tragic condition in this country," according to seven Bishops of the Catholic Church, who outlined today what they believed to be the "only means to reach any permanent recovery and peace."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Noyes is correct in saying that improved price levels have been brought about by the increased confidence of the nation and not by the inflation talk. Confidence had to return somehow, for, after all, we are not economically dead -- and never were.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 7. -- The award of Phi Beta Kappa honors, appointment of fellows and changes in the faculty were announced at Vassar College today by President Henry Noble MacCracken.
NEW HAVEN, June 7. -- Yale's Billy Phelps is "graduating" and he thinks it just about time -- not because he has reached the automatic retirement age of 68, but because he has work to do.

New York sweltered yesterday under the hottest temperature thus far this year, but thunder showers in the early evening brought welcome relief. Severe storms in New Jersey, one of them of near-tornado force, caused injuries to at least two persons and extensive property damage.

Means to facilitate action under the pending Railway Coordination Bill are to be considered at a meeting of the Association of Railway Executives scheduled to be held in Chicago next Thursday. The officials are expected then to pledge their aid in making the measure effective.
Several store properties were included in the New Jersey turnover reported yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It does not seem to have occurred to any one that the collection of tolls on the East River and Harlem River bridges, from those using those bridges only occasionally and who would not find it economical to buy a yearly ticket, would cause terrific traffic jams, especially on holidays and Sundays, when the congestion is bad enough at present?

With Dr. Elmer Ellsworth Brown, who is to retire as chancellor on July 1, presiding, New York University held its 101st commencement exercises yesterday at Ohio Field. Decrees and certificates were awarded to 4,244 persons, the largest number in the history of the university.

MOSCOW, Thursday, June 8. -- James Mattern made a forced landing yesterday at Prokokieff (also known as Prokopievsk) in flying from Omsk for Chita on his flight around the world, it was learned early today.

Opportunities for increasing the rental income of Manhattan buildings are being seized by investors who yesterday acquired by purchase or lease several structures which they plan to renovate. This type of construction work now constitutes the bulk of building activity in the city.

The directors of the Chase National Bank declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 35 cents a share on the capital stock. This compares with 50 cents a share paid previously and places the stock on in annual dividend basis of $1.40. The dividend is payable on July 1 to stockholders of record of June 16.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Occupying the witness stand for the third day before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee investigating banking, financing and securitiessales practices, O.P. Van Sweringen testified today that he and his brother had put into their railroad ventures only $1,000,000 of their own money.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- As a further step in the partnership of government with business, Secretary Roper has begun the formation of a long-range planning committee of business and industrial leaders to advise the administration on questions of economic policy.

Francis H. Sisson, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company and President of the American Bankers Association, told members of the Advertising Club of New York at their weekly luncheon yesterday that improved business had created again a "sellers' market."
Mr. and Mrs. William H. Peck gave a dinner last night in the roof garden of the Pierre for their niece, Miss Ruth Eleanor Roeser, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward N. Roeser. Other guests were:

Both Max Schmeling and Max Baer, who meet tonight in their fifteen-round bout at the Yankee Stadium, expressed confidence, in statements given to THE NEW YORK TIMES last night, of their ability to win the fight. Joe Jacobs, who manages Schmeling, and Ancil Hoffman, who pilots Baer, are equally optimistic.
MOSCOW, Thursday, June 8. -- James Mattern, Texas globe flier, flying to Chita, Siberia, was forced down at Prokopievsk yesterday, about 350 miles east of Novosibirsk, Siberia, it was learned today.

THOSE two exponents of "the fancy," Max Baer and Max Schmeling, are ready for the bell and Promoter Jack Dempsey has everything set for them except the weather. It's a heavyweight fight and a bout that may produce a winner who will be heavyweight champion of the world before the Autumn leaves come whirling down.

GENEVA, June 7. -- Mario Buda, the missing man who played a prominent role in the arrest of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, but whose testimony was never taken, declared here today he planned to return to Massachusetts to clear his name and the names of the two men who were executed for killings in a payroll robbery.

CHICAGO, June 7. -- The recent agreement between Chicago bankers and committees representing bondholders and stockholders of the Middle West Utilities Company whereby certain obligations of the company were to be remitted and a portion of collateral deposited to secure loans returned to the company, was sanctioned today by Federal Judge Walter C. Lindley.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to tell you how greatly I have enjoyed reading the editorials that have recently been appearing in THE TIMES in connection with the government's abandoning its promise to pay in gold.

The Republican majority in the New Jersey Senate, taken to task for neglecting the public business, has redeemed itself by passing bills reorganizing the State's financial system, as recommended by the Princeton Survey. For almost six months the urgency of such legislation was disregarded, and it still remains for the Assembly to heed the responsible leaders.

MILTON, Ont., June 7 (Canadian Press). -- Three pupils and their teacher were recovering tonight from injuries suffered when trapped in a pile of debris that followed ripping off of the roof and collapse of the rear wall of Bell schoolhouse during a violent electrical storm today.

The "lamentable inaccuracy" of all recently published biographies of the late J.P. Morgan and the melancholy end of a mass of valuable source material on the banker's life are discussed by Thomas W. Lament in his newly published biography, "Henry P. Davison."

Money market was dull. Outside money on call loans was done at 3/4, nothing lower, but the Exchange quotation continued at 1 per cent. A little 90-day money traded at 1 per cent; other maturities were neglected. Commercial paper and acceptances were steady.
WASHINGTON, June 7. -- The following Marine Corps changes were announced today:

BERLIN, June 7. -- The Boerse was characterized today by a duller rather than a weaker stock market, in contrast with a fairly lively and firm bond market. Stocks suffered under profit-taking, while new clouds on the international horizon induced caution among buyers, but the losses did not exceed 1 or 2 per cent.
INDIANAPOLIS, June 7. -- Indiana's repeal triumph grew in dimensions today as more complete returns arrived from yesterday's election.

RYE, N.Y., June 7. -- In the last threesome to finish, Leo Kaufmann of Gedney Farm proved to have the winning low-gross score in the one-day tourney of the Westchester County Golf Association at the Westchester Country Club today.

KASSEL, Germany, June 7. -- The inauguration of Prince Philip of Hesse as Nassau Governor of that Province took place here today with much solemnity and the enthusiastic participation of that part of the populace that rejoices at having a scion of its old dynasty at the head of the local government.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 7. -- Puddleduck, with R.O.H. Hill at the tiller, won all of the dinghy races held this evening by the Larchmont Yacht Club. Puddleduck led six rival craft over the finish line five times. The best any other boat was able to get was two second places by Bobbill Jr., sailed by R.H. Goeller.
WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Senator Reed tonight promised a new deal for veterans whose compensation has been cut.
The open season for undergraduate demonstrations at City College ended yesterday with the closing of recitations for the academic year.

Carrying with them President Roosevelt's letter wishing them success, the undefeated eight-oared crew of Kent School and the substitutes and managers sailed last night on the Cunard liner Berengaria to take part in the British Henley.

NEW BRUNSWICK N.J., June 7. -- Reconsideration of the 20 per cent cut in the appropriations for Rutgers University was urged in a telegram sent to Emerson L. Richards, President of the Senate, and Charles A. Otto Jr., Speaker of the House, by the executive committee of the Rutgers board of trustees, and made public here today.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company, as plaintiff in an action against Henry A. Budd and others, involving a lien of $422,509, bought in the five-story building at 572 Fifth Avenue at foreclosure yesterday for $50,000. The sale was held by Henry Brady in the Vesey Street Exchange.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Abandonment permanently of the post of Assistant Secretary of War for Air has been decided on, and its duties will be transferred to Assistant Secretary Woodring of the War Department. Until today some had believed that the post vacated by F. Trubee Davison on March 4 would be refilled.

Cooper Union will award degrees, diplomas and certificates at its seventy-fourth annual commencement tonight to 354 graduates the Institute of Technology, Women's Art School, the Night School of Engineering and the Night School of Art.
PHILADELPHIA, June 7. -- Appeals for minimum-wage legislation were made by social workers and manufacturers today at the legislative investigation of "sweatshops."
A New Rochelle building project featured the Westchester realty trading reported yesterday.

Seventeen persons, most of them city officials, selected by the Oberlaender Trust of the Carl Schurz Memorial Foundation, Inc., of Philadelphia, to study municipal government in Germany, were dinner guests at the Hotel Astor last night, prior to their sailing for Germany on the Deutschland.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Adoption of a compromise plan restoring 154,000 "presumptive" disability cases to the veterans' beneficiary list was predicted by members of the House today after a conference at the White House.

Weakness of the dollar in foreign exchange and strength in the stock and grain markets yesterday influenced prices on the Cotton Exchange. Reports of the most favorable weather so far this season for the cotton crop caused a slight recession early, but selling slackened and a recovery of $1 a bale left the list 5 to 8 points higher on the day.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Leonard M. Thomas of the Carlyle have gone to Newport for the Summer.

Cardinal Hayes conferred degrees yesterday on thirty-eight girl graduates of the acadenmy of the Sacred Heart, Manhattanville, at the commencement exercises in Benziger Gymnasium, Convent Avenue and 133d Street.

PARIS, June 7. -- With the arrival of Ambassador Norman H. Davis in Paris this morning the disarmament centre of gravity has moved here from Geneva. Mr. Davis spent the whole day in consultation with Alien Dulles and Colonel George V. Strong of the United States arms delegation preparing for an assault on France's strongly fortified position tomorrow, with British reinforcements under Captain Anthony Eden and the Marquess of Londonderry joining the attack.

Carrying 132 pounds as a lesser horse might a featherweight, C.V. Whitney's Equipoise yesterday made turf history at Belmont Park when he won the forty-seventh running of the Suburban Handicap. The victor finished eased up in front of such a capable racer as Osculator, which enjoyed a pull of twenty-five pounds over the handicap champion.

DURHAM, N.C., June 7. -- What is needed to make England and America more successful in the long run in business is not so much for business men to be better economists, but business men with "more stability and more moral purpose in life," Sir Josiah Stamp.

PEIPING, June 7. -- The strangest aftermath to the shattering blows which the Japanese Army has struck against the North China defense forces is the fact that the Nanking Government's authority seems more powerful in the Peiping and Tientsin areas than at any time since 1928.

Triples by Douglas Pooley and Al Molanetti featured the 6-to-3 baseball victory scored by St. Francis Prep over Fordham Prep at Fordham Field yesterday in the city C.H.S.A.A. championship final as the Brooklyn school won the title for the first time.
More than 500 Barnard College alumnae gathered on the college campus yesterday to attend the fortieth commencement reunion.

BERLIN, June 7. -- The refusal of Arturo Toscanini, conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, to conduct the Wagner festival at Bayreuth this year because of "painful events which have wounded my feelings as a man and as an artist" has created a profound impression in Germany.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (AP). -- The Washington Senators and Philadelphia Athletics walloped the ball to all corners of Shibe Park today, but failed to reach a decision when a heavy windstorm and darkness broke up the overtime battle in the Athletics' half of the tenth inning, with the Senators leading, 14 to 13.

GLENVIEW, Ill., June 8. -- A cooling breeze that tempered the terrific heat which has prevailed in the Middle West for the last few days brought relief to spectators at the national open golf tourney today.
A home-run epidemic struck the Polo Grounds with violent force yesterday and brought the Giants victory against Burt Shotton's Phillies in a game that had a discouraging start.
About 10 per cent of the forty-year program laid down in 1929 by the Regional Plan of New York and Its Environs has been carried out or officially adopted.
BERLIN, June 8. -- Pending announcement of the extent of the transfer moratorium, the Boerse was extremely dull and Irregular today. Business was entirely in the hands of professional traders.

IT was a 300-hitter in the old Latin Literary League who said sagely: "Tempora mutantur, nos et mutamur in illis." Consider the sad case of Marse Joe McCarthy, erstwhile manager of the Chicago Cubs, now the leader of the Ruppert Rifles.

PARIS, June 8. -- French official import figures issued today for the first four months of 1933 show that France has this year instituted the policy of laying in stocks of raw materials that might not be obtainable or that would be difficult to obtain if the country were economically isolated or in the event of war.
Final awards of gold medals and cups in this season's competition of the New York Music Week Association were announced yesterday.

After a day of steadily increasing heat, the mercury touched 92 degrees at 6:40 o'clock last evening, breaking a thirty-four-year record for June 8. The previous record for the date was 9I.4 degrees in 1899. Record-breaking temperatures were reported in other parts of the country the heat wave extending from the Atlantic to the Rockies.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Senators read with considerable interest today the first literary effort of Senator Tydings, a new book entitled "Counter-Attack," and described as "a battle plan to defeat the depression."

Bernard F. Ridder, publisher of The New York Staats-Zeitung, who has just returned from a visit to Germany, said yesterday that modification of the Hitler government's anti-semitic policy may be expected soon.

Governor Lehman voiced yesterday his determination to keep New York State's health work undiminished despite economic stress. He addressed a luncheon at the Hotel Biltmore, celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the anti-tuberculosis campaign in the State out side of New York City, carried on by the State Department of Health and the State Charities Aid Association.

A foreclosure suit against the Broadway block between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets, comprising the Criterion and Loew's New York theatres and adjoining property in West Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets was filed yesterday in the Supreme Court by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company against the Seneca Holding Corporation and others.
A new star is in the pugilistic firmament today and his name is Max Baer, a larruping thumper from Livermore, Cal.

From the viewpoint of the tape-watcher, the one exciting incident of yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was the abrupt decline in Chicago North Western issues. For a time there was a general and severe reaction in a market which, as some commission houses have been observing, is increasingly "on edge."
WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The War Department Issued the following orders today: Humphrey, Col. C.F. Jr., General Staff Corps 7 days leave.
Eighteen properties in Manhattan and the Bronx were put up at foreclosure auctions yesterday. All were bought in by the plaintiffs, who acted to protect their liens. The results follow:
Historic old St. Paul's Chapel, on Broadway near Fulton Street, blossomed out yesterday with the setting of a Long Island tea party and lawn fete.

GOSHEN, N.Y., June 8. -- Sturdy, a bay colt by Guy Axworthy and The Great Miss Morris, owned by John C. Thompson of New York and driven by Harry Brusie, won the 2-year-old trot today. The colt raced the second mile in exceptionally fast time, 2:11 1/2.

CONVENT STATION, N.J., June 8. -- Representative Mary T. Norton, who received the degree of Doctor of Laws at the College of St. Elizabeth two years ago, addressed the members of the class of 1933 at the commencement exercises this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- An increase of 20 per cent in newspaper advertising linage during April, bringing it within 15 per cent of last year's level, was cited by the Commerce Department today in its survey of current business as evidence of improved business conditions.

Leases of entire buildings in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens were announced by real estate brokers yesterday. Of particular interest was the demand for structures to be used in the manufacture and retailing of beer.
Fishermen are finding the big humpback sea bass biting better than ever these days and there are indications that the run of this species will reach its peak in a very short time.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The partial list of suspected gold hoarders submitted to the Justice Department by the Treasury includes more than 10,000 names, of which 5,505 were from New York City. A total of $29,451,581 was held by the suspected persons in New York, according to the Treasury information, although investigation may show a largeer or smaller amount.
The Shipping Board postponed action yesterday on the bid of Max Thaten of Staten Island for a lease of the Government-owned piers in Hoboken.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Although eleven countries have ratified the Convention for Safety of Life at Sea, and six others have signified their adherence, the United States has taken no action since the adoption of the convention in London four years ago.

RENO, Nev., June 8. -- Elliott Roosevelt, second son of President and Mrs. Roosevelt, has established residence here for a divorce from the former Elizabeth Donner, daughter of William H. Donner, Philadelphia industrialist, on grounds of incompatibility.

The dollar fell yesterday to 81:1 cents in terms of the French franc, a low record. Encouraged by reports that the United States Government viewed with approval the cheapening of its currency, foreign speculators renewed their drive against the dollar, while American merchants holding foreign exchange refrained from converting it into United States money and business men having foreign exchange purchases to make scrambled to buy sterling and other currencies.

CLEVELAND, June 8. -- (AP). -- The Browns pushed the Indians' losing streak up to five straight games today by taking the first game of their series, 5 to 3. An error by Bill Cissell and a home run by Jack Crouch figured in a four-run attack staged by the Browns in the fourth.

Russell T. Sherwood, who ran away nearly two years ago rather than face Samuel Seabury's questioning about former Mayor Walker's affairs, made his second appearance yesterday before a Federal grand jury.

Funds of the London, Liverpool Globe Insurance Company increased u151,190 to u25,566,888 in the year ended on Dec. 31. New insurance in the life department was u1,980,939, an increase of u30,788 from 1931, with net premium Income u819,309.
PARIS, June 8. -- After the three-power talks on disarmament today, it was apparent a more conciliatory atmosphere prevailed.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 8. -- The School of Education of Rutgers University conferred 238 degrees in course and one honorary degree at its commencement exercises in the university gymnasium here this afternoon. For the first time since the School of Education was established in 1923, degrees were conferred at ceremonies separate from those of the men's colleges.

Except for raw hides, which receded in price, commodity futures traded on local exchanges moved yesterday to higher levels in sympathy with other markets. Trading was heavy in several markets and in good volume in the others. Cash prices were irregular.

Atheism was blamed for lack of "tranquillity, hopefulness and the mildness of spiritual suffering" in the city by Mayor O'Brien in a luncheon address yesterday at the Montauk Club, Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn.

PARIS, June 8. -- Confidence that action by France will make President Roosevelt's offers of co-operation with Europe a realty was expressed, today by Jesse Isidor Straus in presenting his credentials as United States Ambassador to President Lebrun on a day when Franco-Anglo-American talks on disarmament were taking place here.
Eight banks here and four banks in other cities were named defendants yesterday in an action filed in Federal Court by the trustees in bankruptcy of the Paramount Publix Corporation.

Rumors of an impending reorganization of the Chicago North Western Railway, which were described later as unfounded by officers of the road, caused a sharp break in its securities yesterday afternoon. Other railroad stocks were affected by the decline.

BERLIN, June 8. -- The Reichsbank tonight formally proclaimed a partial moratorium on the transfer abroad of the service payments on the German private debts. It will be operative July 1 and will remain in effect until the Reichsbank's gold reserves have again reached the level essential to the protection of the German currency and national economy.

Among many rare and distinguished characters now appearing in the Congressional Record the Hon. FINLY H. GRAY of the Tenth Indiana District possesses the singular merit of being periodic. His orbit is completed in sixteen years. As he told the House Tuesday:

NEWPORT, R.I., June 8. -- An innovation at St. George's School this year will be the observance next Wednesday, the day preceding the annual prize day, of "father's day." Fathers of all the boys at the school have been invited to attend.
MOSCOW, Friday, June 9. -- Jamea Mattern took off from Belovo, Siberia, for Krasnoyarsk at 4:10 A.M., Friday, Moscow time (9:10 P.M. Thursday Eastern Daylight Time).

Leon Kraemer, master cracksman for the old Whittemore gang, who escaped from Great Meadow prison last August, was captured yesterday by the police. Unidentified enemies, with a blast of gunfire, pointed the way to his hiding place, a well-furnished three-room flat at 305 East Eighty-eighth Street.
Increased activity in Westchester realty was reported yesterday. Several houses and scattered residential sites were sold and a department store parcel was leased.

GENEVA, June 8. -- The seventeenth conference of the League's International Labor Organization was opened today by Sir Atul Chatterjee of India. He emphasized that in addition to the forty-seven member States represented the United States for the first time was directly associating itself with the work of the conference.

BERLIN, June 8. -- By declaring a partial transfer moratorium today, Germany admitted her inability to pay in foreign currencies either the interest or the amortization charges on some 17,300,000,000 marks [about $4,824,000,000 at current exchange] of foreign indebtedness.

BOSTON, June 8 (AP). -- The Red Sox scored twice in a ninth inning rally to capture the first game of the double header with Washington, by a 4-3 margin today, but were decisively beaten, 12 -- 3, in the second game. The Senators regained second place.

Formal announcement of a plan for extending the maturities of Wabash Railway equipment-trust certificates was made yesterday by A.K. Atkinson, treasurer for the company's receivers. The plan was put forward at the instance of the courts, which directed the company to make further payments for interest or maturity on the certificates.

A conflict between the Russian church authorities in Moscow, headed by the Metropolitan Sergius, and Metropolitan Platon in New York came to light yesterday with a statement from Archbishop Benjamin, who arrived here a fortnight ago as special exarch of the Metropolitan Sergius.

Offering will be made at par today of a new issue of $3,000,000 Boston Metropolitan District (Mass.) 3 1/2 per cent bonds, due on June 1, 1936, by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., Bancamerica-Blair Corporation, Phelps, Fenn Co., G.M.-P. Murphy Co., Darby Co., Graham, Parsons Co. and Washburn, Frost Co. of Boston.

NEWARK, N.J., June 8. -- The Mercer Beasley School of Law will confer the degree of Bachelor of Laws on forty-four students at its commencement exercises tomorrow night in the Newark School of Fine and Industrial Arts. Arthur T. Vanderbilt, chairman of the State Judicial Counsel, will deliver the commencement address.
Max Schmeling weighed 189 1/4 pounds and Max Baer tipped the scales at 203 pounds when they entered the ring for their bout last night at the Yankee Stadium.

The commencement exercises of All Hallows Institute, conducted by the Christian Brothers of Ireland, will be held tonight at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street. Mgr. Patrick N. Breslin will preside. A disarmament debate by the seniors will be a feature.

David Dubin, 41 years old, former president of the Cloak and Dress Covered Button Manufacturers Association, was convicted in Judge Corrigan's part of General Sessions late yesterday afternoon of being a racketeer. He was remanded to the Tombs for sentence on June 20.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP). -- Senate and House conferees agreed today on the administration's $2,000,000,000 Home Mortgage Relief Bill, a part of President Roosevelt's recovery program.

GLENVIEW, Ill., June 8. -- With a brilliant 68, four strokes under par and a stroke below the course record made by Abe Espinosa in the 1928 Western open, Tommy Armour, former Scottish amateur star, took a five-stroke lead in the first eighteen-hole round of the national open championship today at the North Shore Golf Club.
PITTSBURGH, June 8 (AP). -- Eppa Rixey showed his old mastery over the Pirates today and Cincinnati, hammered three Pittsburgh pitchers for an 8-to-2 victory.
BERLIN, June 8. -- The conclusion of the Four-Power pact was acclaimed in Germany today as a defensive victory in a three-month diplomatic battle over the long distance telephone.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 8. -- Cardinal Hayes will confer degrees tomorrow afternoon upon the largest graduating class in the history of Good Counsel College. Clare Gerald Finerty, Philadelphia attorney, will address the graduates at exercises in the college auditorium.

Measured by its price in French francs, the dollar's valuation in the international market has fallen this week to the lowest point since gold payments by the United States were suspended. During the moratorium the extreme depreciation was only about 1 1/2 per cent; in the second half of March the dollar stood virtually at parity.

In announcing a suspension of service on her foreign debt, Germany has her eye on the World Economic Conference, in the opinion of bankers here. Financiers who have in the past had some experience with international conferences say that it is a time-honored piece of German political strategy to prepare a trading position in advance by some arbitrary act or declaration of policy bearing on the subjects destined to be discussed.

The removal of nine investigators employed by the Home Relief Bureau of the Department of Public Welfare was announced yesterday by Commissioner Frank J. Taylor. The investigators were dropped after an inquiry conducted by Mary L. Gibbons, director of the bureau.
A 10-year-old boy was knocked down by Mayor O'Brien's automobile last night while the Mayor was on his way to the Schmeling-Baer fight in the Yankee Stadium.

Sales of cars by the General Motors Corporation's dealers to consumers in the United States totaled 85,969 in May, compared with 71.599 in the preceding month and with 63,500 in May, 1932. It was the largest number for any month since July, 1931.

CHICAGO, June, 8 (AP). -- After a home run by Jonathan Stone had tied the score in the ninth, the Detroit Tigers went on to defeat Chicago, 3 to 2, in the eleventh inning today for their fifth straight victory. The defeat, the White Sox's first in seven games, tumbled them into third place in the American League.

In an offer made yesterday to acquire stock of a subsidiary, the Equity Corporation became the first company to comply in detail with the requirement of the Truth-in-Securities Bill. David M. Milton, son-in-law of John D. Rockefeller Jr., is president of Equity, which offered to exchange its shares for those of the Interstate Equities Corporation.

MADRID, June 8. -- President Niceto Alcala Zamora, acting under pressure from various quarters, today abruptly dismissed Premier Manuel Azana, whose Left Wins coalition government directing Spain's revolutionary destiny for about two years had become increasingly unpopular, as it developed into a virtual dictatorship.
WASHINGTON, June 8. - The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated June 6:

LOS ANGELES, June 8. -- After disclosing that her son, Elliott, would establish residence in Nevada to permit his wife to seek a divorce on the grounds of incompatibility, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt left suddenly at 5:51 A.M. (Pacific Standard Time) today for Washington, D.C.
Salient parts of the testimony of Charles E. Mitchell yesterday at his trial in Federal court follow:

"I have no fault to find with the referee for stopping the fight," Schmeling said in his dressing room after the fight. "The punch that put me on the floor hurt and things might have resulted seriously if Donovan hadn't intervened.

In a quarrel over whether he should continue to support his mother-in-law and sister-in-law, Raymond Irizarry, 33 years old, a laborer, stabbed the two women and his wife to death early today in their third-floor flat at 125 East 110th Street.

Referring to President Roosevelt as a heroic, international figure, R.Fulton Cutting, president of the trustees of Cooper Union, suggested last night to the school's 354 graduates that they adopt him as their model and ideal. More than 2,000 persons packed the Cooper Union auditorium for the commencement exercises.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 8. -- A perfect chip shot at the home green enabled Tommy Goodwin, New York State golf champion, to annex the medal honors today in the first invitation tourney staged by the Gedney Farm Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ending June 7, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,220,000, an increase of $12,000,000 compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $276,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1982.

Man is no longer the only or even the chief subject of medical research, Dr. Simon Flexner, director of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, told the graduating class of the Cornell University Medical College at the thirty-fifth annual commencement yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 8. -- Awards of 175 insignia were announced today by the Yale University Athletic Association. The list included thirty-six major letters.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8. -- Sweltering under a broiling sun, the Yankees and Athletics put on another one of their titanic exhibitions today as they opened a four-game series and for the first time this year the Mackmen carried the day. They managed to win by 14 to 10 after having taken eight straight defeats from the world's champions since the campaign began.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The customary barrier of complete silence with reference to war debts surrounded a call of Sir Ronald Lindsay. British Ambassador, on President Roosevelt today. Apparently orders have been issued that no administration official is to have anything to say about the strenuous efforts being made to prevent debt defaults next Thursday.
BELOVO, Siberia (by telephone to Moscow). June 8. -- Boy, I am going to make this round-the-world dash from New York to New York if I have to cover my whole ship with sheet iron.

Jersey City's winning streak was extended to four straight yesterday at West Side Park, Jersey City, when the Jerseys defeated the Montreal Royals in the opener of a three-game series. The score was 6 to 4. Bill Dietrich was knocked out of the box by the home team's attack in the first two innings.
Among the passengers arriving today on the Cunard liner Aquitania are Lord Belhaven and Stenton Clinton Anderson, president of Rotary International; Channing Pollock, playwright, and the following:

PARIS, June 8. -- Representatives of the United States, France and Britain met today and decided they would continue their conversations during the pause in the disarmament conference in an effort to eradicate the problems that have been obstructing definite decisions at Geneva, which all agreed must be removed.
Brokers' loans rose $64,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $699,000,000. This was the largest volume of brokers' loans since Dec. 2, 1931.

"June Moon," the revival of the Ring Lardner and George S. Kaufman saga of the song writer, starring Harry Rosenthal, is the third attraction to announce an extension of its Broadway engagement, instead of closing tomorrow evening, as had been previously planned.

Business transacted in the corn refining industry in May was the heaviest ever handled for any month on record, according to the Corn Industries Research Foundation. Products of the industry include starches, dextrines, sugars, syrups and other derivatives of American corn which enter into food or are used in manufacturing operations by other industries.
WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Secretary Woodin announced tonight that the government's $1,000,000,000 security issue had been over-subscribed five times.
WASHINGTON, June 8. -- President Roosevelt has publicly expressed his support of the St. Lawrence waterway treaty in a letter to Senator La Follette. This was made public today.

An agreement has been reached between a committee representing American holders of about $25,000,000 of blocked currencies in Brazil and representatives of the Brazilian Government and the Banco de Brazil providing for the payment of the claims.
Some interests in the communications field have not abandoned hope for a consolidation of telegraph companies, despite the elimination of the clause in the railroad bill authorizing such a merger.

Sometimes the best-laid plans do not go agley. The report made last night by the Regional Plan Association shows very considerable progress in carrying the Plan into effect. For four years this association, a voluntary group embracing representation of the city and its environs reaching far out into New Jersey, out across Long Island, up through Westchester and into Connecticut, has labored to demonstrate that the Regional Plan could be made to work.
The New York Stock Exchange has received applications for the listing of the following securities:

Five more police officers -- four lieutenants and a sergeant -- were transferred yesterday by Commissioner Bolan. This was in keeping with his policy of shifting all men, of whatever rank, who do not meet his standard of service. The five were:

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee opened its investigation of banking, financing and securities' sales practices today with O. P. Van Sweringen, president of the Alleghany Corporation, again the Witness.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Not for a number of years has any subject afforded the Senate so good an opportunity for a legalistic and constitutional debate as has the National Industry Recovery Act. It is the custom to lament the passing of the good old days when there was supposedly a race of giants in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- After a thirteen-hour session of the Senate, wherein the administration leaders sought to speed action on the National Industry Recovery Bill, the body adjourned at 11 o'clock tonight.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 3/4 per cent for the best names. Wednesday -- 1 3/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months paper.
LONDON, June 8. -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

TOKYO, June 8. -- In retaliation against the Indian Government's raising of the tariff on cotton piecegoods of non-British manufacture to 75 per cent, a committee of Japanese smnners resolved today to recommend a boycott of Indian raw cotton.

The State Beer Board proceeded rapidly yesterday with the task of issuing licenses for the sale of beer and wine in the city and surrounding counties. No estimate of the number of licenses approved and issued could be obtained officially, but it became known that they totaled about 1,000.

Ernest P. Goodrich, Brooklyn engineer, was appointed yesterday as chief of the Sanitation Department's engineering division by Sanitation Commissioner George McAneny, who described him as the "bestfitted man in the United States for the job."

HAVANA, June 8. -- The military censorship over Cuba's newspapers was re-established this afternoon, following what the government considered an over-enthusiastic interpretation by the press and public of President Machado's declarations yesterday to the effect that Constitutional reform would be speedily adopted and a Vice President appointed by Congress or named by the Supreme Court.

Special defenses disposed of, most of them rejected, the $25-a-share assessment suit against 170 Bank of United States stockholders settled down yesterday to what may be more than a month of wrangling over financial records.

Police Commissioner Bolan told the Forty-second Street Property Owners and Merchants Association yesterday that the city had decided to make a more strenuous campaign against burlesque shows and other performances deemed to be improper.

A mortgage for $110,000 held by the Union Dime Savings Bank from the 114 Morningside Drive Corp. on the six-story apartment house at 114 Morningside Drive has been extended to May 1, 1936, at 5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- President Roosevelt's plan to adjust the controversy in veterans' benefits was completed tonight and, according to a high authority, was sent to the veterans' "steering committee" of the House for approval.

Signing of the Four-Power treaty was naturally made a great event at Rome. There it formally originated. Ardently pushed by MUSSOLINI, its constructive and peaceful aims will be set against the background of his speeches and policies during the early years Of his dictatorship.
The city's bankers agreed yesterday to extend all the city's outstanding securities due in the next few months until Dec.11 at an interest rate of 5 3/4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Government experts are keeping a close watch on the dollar's movements abroad, as well as on the stock market repercussions. One administration economist called attention today to the fact that the quoted prices of many stocks are now higher, in relation to earnings, than they were at the height of the market boom of 1929.
NEW YORK. Justice and Mrs. Pelham St. George Bissell of 270 Park Avenue are at their country home, Wayside, on Merrick Road, Freeport, L.I.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Robert P. Skinner was appointed Ambassador to Turkey today by President Roosevelt. A Republican who entered the consular service at Marseilles in 1897, he was Consul General at Hamburg, Berlin, and London during the war, and is now Minister to Finland.

CHICAGO, June 8. -- Many operators in wheat have sold their holdings on the Board of Trade since the market has failed to respond to the bullish reports of damage to the crop in the West and Southwest. Scattered buying caused today a small early advance which was lost quickly.

A total of $21,511,000 in heavy engineering construction contracts is reported by Engineering News-Record for the week ended June 5. This is a gain of $3,500,000 over the previous week and a total three times as large as awards reported two weeks ago.

GENEVA, June 8. -- Japan upset the Disarmament Conference today by making the prohibition of air bombing depend upon either abolition of aircraft carriers and prohibition of landing platforms on warships or upon receiving some quid pro quo for dropping this condition.
Mayor O'Brien's letter to Winthrop W. Aldrich of the Chase National Bank outlining reductions in the budget, Mr. Aldrich's reply and Controller Berry's official statement follow:

Designed to offset resentment against the old-fashioned slow-moving and noisy trolley car, a 1933 speedier and less noisy model had its first public demonstration in Brooklyn yesterday after three years of experimentation at a cost of $500,000.

Walter C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, probably will be a member of the industrial control board in the event of the passage of the National Industrial Recovery Bill. At the office of the New Jersey company it was said that Mr. Teagle had not definitely accepted a post on the proposed board and would not do so until the passage of the act creating the board.

The legality of the auction sale of the Brentano book stores on Wednesday as conducted by Peter Olney Jr., referee in bankruptcy, will be contested, it was learned yesterday at the offices of Leonard G. Bisco, attorney, who represented the Manufacturers Trust Company, creditors, in the Brentano bankruptcy case.

LONDON, June 8. -- Secretary of State Hull, with the larger part of the United States delegation to the World Economic Congress, arrived in London this evening and the first question put to him when he touched British soil at Plymouth was concerning the debts.

Acute unsettlement in the foreign-exchange market, which reduced the international value of the dollar to the lowest level in memory. surpassed in interest all other financial developments yesterday. No doubt it accounted to some extent for the fresh speculative enthusiasm on the Stock Exchange, where sharply higher prices ruled at one time or another in the course of the day.

CHICAGO, June 8 (AP). --The Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad reported today a profit of $200,000 for May after all charges, including bond interest. It was the first profit this year and contrasted with a deficit of $497,531 in May last year.

Monetary Economic Liquid. Every one says that the sixty-six nations at the London ECONOMIC Conference are standing at the crossroads. They will soon be standing at something else, and that is a seventy-foot bar which has been set up in the basement of the new Geological Museum, where the conference meets.
PASADENA, Cal., June 8. -- A blow to any theory that human life may exist on Mars was delivered today by two astronomers of the Carnegie Institution's Mount Wilson Observatory.

An impressionistic history of the world since the war by George Seldes is published today, three days before the opening of the economic conference in London where solutions to some of the problems of the last fifteen years will be attempted.
WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Conferees on the Railroad Relief Bill reached full agreement today after eliminating an amendment which would authorize the consolidation of telegraph or cable companies.

Members of the Association of National Advertisers, in a closed session yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, refused to accept the Young report on advertising agency compensation, and unanimously voted for a further examination of the subject.

Charles E. Mitchell left the witness stand yesterday afternoon after testifying for three and one-half days. For almost two days he had been under cross-examination by United States Attorney George Z. Medalie; the rest of the time under direct examination by his own counsel, Max D. Steuer.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a student of military history I wish to commend THE TIMES and Mr. Hanson W. Baldwin for the story "If War Should Again Assail the World," which appeared in the issue of June 5.

DARJEELING, India, June 8 (By Wireless). -- A remarkable radio transmission was carried out by members of the radio staff attached to the Mount Everest climbing expedition when Sir John Anderson, Governor of Bengal, spoke to the members of the expedition assembled at the base camp on Mount Everest from the drawing room of the Government House here.

The Appellate Division reserved decision yesterday on the appeal from Supreme Court Justice Valente's ruling, refusing to restrain the Board of Estimate from awarding a contract for the removal of waste in Brooklyn to Samuel Rosoff's Manhattan Garbage and Ash Removal Company.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The Ways and Means Committee was urged today by Major A.V. Dalrymple, director of prohibition, to report favorably the Lea bill permitting the manufacture, transportation and sale of light wines.
The economics of the new deal were reviewed with expressions of apprehension for an hour and a half last night in an address by Dr. Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank.

NEWARK, N.J., June 8. -- Fred Fussell held the league leading Newark Bears to five hits and blanked them 6 to 0, for the Buffalo Bisons in the opening game of their series at Ruppert Stadium today. He performed the feat in spite of three misplays behind him.

ALBANY, June 8. -- (AP). -- The State opened a sweeping investigation of gas and electric light rates today with an announcement by the Public Service Commission that it was prepared to establish emergency rates wherever conditions seemed to warrant.

Holding his opposition at bay throughout the mile route, Mrs. Isabel Sloan's Helianthus yesterday won the featured Harlem Claiming Stakes at Belmont Park by five lengths. The 5-year-old son of Sun Flag returned 8 to 5 to those supporters who made him favorite.

Opposition to Tammany's taxation program continued to grow yesterday. The Fifth Avenue Association, the Merchants Association, the Citizens Budget Commission and the Real Estate Board were unsparing in their criticism. The consensus was that the city should start retrenching before seeking new money to spend.
Cardinal Hayes will ordain thirty-five young priests at 8 o'clock tomorrow morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral. All have just Completed the course at St. Joseph's Theological Seminary, Dunwoodie, N.Y.

The Appellate Division heard argument yesterday on the appeal from the decision of Supreme Court Justice McCook appointing James W. Gerard, Robert McC.
