Marsh and George Frankenthaler as receivers for the S.W. Straus Co. properties now in default to replace the bondholders' committee headed by Lewis H. Pounds.
Store deals featured business leases, announced in large numbers yesterday. Many places were taken for restaurants and the sale of beer.The leases follow:

SUMMIT, N.J., June 8. -- The three-time New Jersey champion, F. Paul Anderson Jr., winner of the State crown in 1930, 1931 and 1932, was dethroned in the present New Jersey title event on his home course today when he lost, 4 and 2, to Dr. Stephen G. Lee Jr. of the Essex Fells Country Club in a second-round match at the Canoe Brook Country Club.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The House Committee on Rules voted a special rule today for consideration of the Sumners bill extending to municipalities and other taxing districts the provisions of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The bill is expected to come up for action tomorrow.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system went to a new high or low figure.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As an investor of many years' standing in the most conservative public utility common stocks, I was very much interested in THE TIMES article concerning the probable effects of imposing a 3 per cent tax for electrical energy on the utility companies instead of on the consumers.

Increased activity in the commercial paper market featured. While the demand was not up to normal, banks are buying choice name, short-time paper at 1 3/4 per cent, less well known, longer dates going at 2@2 1/4. Stock Exchange call loans continued at 1 per cent, with 3/4 prevailing in the counter market.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 8. -- Another athletic trophy has been received by the Harvard Athletic Association, it was announced today, the new cup to be awarded to the outstanding member of the Harvard freshman crew.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 8. -- The commencement of the Westminster Choir School opened this morning with the awarding of thirty degrees of Bachelor of Music, at a service held at the First Presbyterian Church. Dr. John Finley Williamson, president of the school, presented the degrees.

Preliminary steps in the preparation of codes of fair competition for application after the passage of the National Industrial Recovery Bill were taken here yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, the National Tobacco Council and the special fabrics group of the Silk Association of America.

Uncertainty regarding reduction of the cotton acreage and favorable weather throughout the South unsettled sentiment yesterday on the Cotton Exchange. After an early advance of 5 points in prices, rumors that a processing tax is probable under the Farm Act to furnish funds for land leasing caused selling by several mill interests.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A householder supporting a high-salaried staff of servitors finds himself in straits that threaten payment of wages for his crew. What does he do? Rush frantically to his clients, his customers, and say: "You are now paying me to the utmost of your ability, but you must squeeze out more yet so that I shall have enough money to run my house"?

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- O.P. Van Sweringen thawed out in the heat today and became expansive on railroad rates, earnings, his optimism as to business, hope for wise regulation, and appreciation of the advice of J.P. Morgan Co. He was testifying again at the Senate hearing into the affairs of the banking firm.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Improved conditions in Canada and Cuba but some uncertainty concerning Brazil were reported by the Commerce Department today in its weekly survey of foreign business conditions, based on advice from commercial attaches abroad.

First-hand details of the sinking of two ships during a dense tog in the North Sea were brought here last night by the Hamburg-American liner New York, which landed thirty-seven passengers from the Guilford Castle and eleven members of the crew of the four-masted motor schooner Polarstjernen at Southampton on June 2.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor announces that its index number of wholesale prices for the week ending June 3 stands at 63.8 as compared with 63.3 for the week ending May 27, showing an increase of approximately eight-tenths of 1 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP). -- A list of persons especially selected by J.P. Morgan Co. for invitations to buy Johns-Manville stock at 47 1/2 was placed this afternoon in the record of the Senate investigation of the bank. It has been shown that still another list was made up in sale of the stock at 57 1/2.

BERLIN, June 9. -- The defeat of Max Schmeling at the hands of Max Baer was a complete surprise to Germany. But this surprise was almost forgotten as a result of the announcement in the press that Schmeling and Anny Ondra, blond German film star, would be married soon and that the banns will be posted in Charlottenburg tomorrow.
NEW YORK. Sir Josiah and Lady Stamp left the Barclay yesterday for Quebec, and will sail from there for England today on the Empress of Britain.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 9. -- The commencement of Sarah Lawrenco College will be held tomorrow afternoon on the terrace in front of Westlands, former home of William V. Lawrence and now the administration building of the college.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, returned yesterday to New York after a 6,000-mile flight to and from Los Angeles, where she had visited her son, Elliott. She declined to comment further on her son's planned divorce, but scouted a report that he intended to marry Miss Ruth Googin of Fort Worth, Texas.

Several years ago the Metropolitan Museum of Art bought in China the coats of two elaborate eighteenth century court theatre robes. The skirts of these rare and richly embroidered costumes had disappeared during the misfortunes which overtook the royal court of China.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 9. Continuing the brand of golf that brought him the Long Island amateur crown last Sunday Jack Mackle Jr. of Inwood swept to victories in the first two rounds of the Gedney Farm Golf Club invitation tourney today.

MOSCOW, June 9. -- Moscow has received the Four-Power pact with skepticism bordering on hostility. Despite themselves -- or true to themselves -- the Bolsheviki never escape a sneaking anxiety lest any European combination may have ulterior motives directed against the "Socialist Fatherland," even in a case like this, when their Marxist realism exposes the flimsy character of the new agreement.

Ten thoroughbreds, all colts, have been named for the sixty-fifth running at Belmont Park today of the historic Belmont Stakes, mile-and-a-half race for 3-year-olds which annually is regarded as the championship test of the division.

The administration of relief in some small towns up-State came in for scathing criticism yesterday from Clarence E. Ford, Assistant Commissioner of the State Department of Social Welfare, in charge of the medical division. He spoke in a discussion period at the annual conference of State and local tuberculosis and public health committees of the State Charities Aid Association, which ended yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore.

TOYKO, June 9 (AP). -- Viscount Kukipiro Ishii proposed a new Japanese-American arbitration treaty to President Roosevelt when he was in Washington last month, and the President assented to it in principle, the Rengo (Japanese) News Agency said today.
WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The House today passed the Sumners bill extending the provisions of the Federal Bankruptcy Act to municipalities and other taxing districts.

Two new books of plans for international defense against depression are "The Framework of an Ordered Society," by Sir Arthur Salter, and "Counter-Attack" by Millard E. Tydings, United States Senator from Maryland.
WASHINGTON, June 9. -- A Winter wheat crop of 341,017,000 bush- . els was forecast today by the Department of Agriculture on the basis of June 1 conditions, which were 64 per cent of normal.
Foreclosure proceedings were started in Supreme Court yesterday against the building occupied by the Harriman National Bank at Forty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue.

An attack on high salaries and bonuses paid to utility company officials was made before the Public Service Commission at a hearing yesterday. The hearings are to give the commission grounds for ordering a cut in the electricity rates in the metropolitan area.

TAUNTON, England, June 9 (Canadian Press). -- Batting doggedly throughout the day, the County of Somerset today secured a draw in its match with the touring West Indian cricket team. Somerset had secured 323 runs for nine wickets in its second innings when stumps were pulled and the three-day game was over.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- Grains made a sensational advance today on the Board of Trade here. Wheat, corn and oats closed with net gains of nearly 2 cents a bushel. Wheat had the highest finish of the season and equaled the best price reached on the May bulge, while all deliveries of oats were the highest since November, 1931.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To find fault with high-minded men who are exhorting their fellow- citizens to pursue nobler aims and to observe higher standards of conduct is an ungracious proceeding. Yet when these exhortations convey an essentially false view of the causes of general distress, it seems the part of honesty to endeavor to correct their error.

Apparently immune to any potential adverse turn in the trend of political or economic adjustments, commercial and industrial activity is being extended persistently, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc. With the contra-seasonal expansion of trade spectacular in some fields, the reports received this week from the chief centres of production and distribution revealed gains in nearly every part of the country.

The problem which led the Reichsbank to suspend payment abroad of Germany's public and private debts is solely one of "transfer." No doubt is raised at this time of the ability of borrowers to pay in marks. German debtors are not absolved from meeting their obligations when legally due.

Governor LEHMAN in his address at the celebration of the twentyfifth anniversary of the up-State campaign against tuberculosis made a statement that shows his definition and discernment of the duties of his office.

CLEVELAND, June 9 (AP) -- Indictments charging misapplication of funds in relation to the collapse of the Standard Trust Bank of Cleveland were returned by a grand jury today against Alvanley Johnston, Grand Chief of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, and two others.

Yankee Stadium Inspiration. The thermometer at the moment of writing is well on its way to 100. The humidity flows like 3.2 beer in an erstwhile dry State. This may excuse people for in dulging in thoughts on BAER and SCHMELING which they would not care to sponsor in cooler and saner moments.

TRENTON, N.J., June 9. -- An effort to put the New Jersey Taxpayers Association on record at its annual meeting here today in favor of a tax strike unless the Legislature meets demands for reduced governmental spending failed after a sharp debate.

To further the campaign of his department in eradicating the gambling slot machine racket in the city, Police Commissioner James S. Bolan asked the aid of the judiciary and District Attorneys of the five boroughs yesterday. He asked that jail sentences, rather than fines alone, be imposed on convicted offenders.
PARIS, June 9. -- Excerpts of the text of Premier Daladier's statement to the Chamber of Deputies today of the French program for the London Economic Conference are as follows:

BOSTON, June 9 (AP). -- With Southpaw Earl Whitehill holding the Red Sox under control until the ninth inning, the Senators today had an easy task outbatting their hosts for a 7-2 victory in the third game of the current Fenway Park series.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Before Thomas S. Lamont, a member of the firm of J.P. Morgan Co., proceeded with his testimony before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee this morning, John W. Davis, counsel for that firm, said he desired to make a short statement for the "sake of the record."
WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated June 7:

The Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly delayed final action yesterday on Mayor O'Brien's new program to raise $30,000,000 a year in taxes and called a public hearing on the plan for Monday.

The largest increase in factory employment and In payrolls ever recorded in this State took place in the month between the middle of April and the middle of May, it was announced yesterday in the monthly report of the State Labor Department.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Congress will receive no request from President Roosevelt to grant him powers of tariff adjustment for bargaining purposes, he said definitely today. The President said that the lack of this power would in no way interfere with the activities of the United States delegation to the World Economic Conference, which will open Monday.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Here is the balance sheet of J.P. Morgan Co., as of March 31, certified by Price, Waterhouse Co., which was placed today before Senate investigators. It includes Drexel Co., its Philadelphia affiliate.

The Most Rev. James De Wolf Perry, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, will make his first utterance on his tour of the communion's missions in the Orient at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine Sunday morning, June 25, at 11 o'clock.

NORTH ARLINGTON, N.J., June 9. -- Six persons were killed and more than 100 others burned, some seriously, tonight in a series of explosions and resultant fires that wrecked a celluiold factory and destroyed five one-story homes.

Some 400 youngsters, most of them clad in bathing suits and other scanty attire, staged a noisy demonstration outside the West Forty-seventh Street police station early last evening as a protest against police interference with their heat-relief activities.

Testimony by Percy A. Rockefeller on his activities as a director of the International Match Corporation, now bankrupt, was made known yesterday by a transcript filed in the office of Oscar W. Ehrhorn. Federal referee in bankruptcy.

Construction contracts of all types last month increased 37 per cent over the preceding month, but were only about half the total of May 1932, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday, of the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains.

A hold-up man robbed the nineteenth-floor offices of Max Brayer, Inc., wholesale jewelers, at 551 Fifth Avenue yesterday. He bound and gagged a clerk and escaped with uncut diamonds, brooches and bracelets valued roughly at $25,000.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- A reduction of 2 per cent in value of May retail sales in 439 department stores in 211 cities as compared with May, 1932, was shown in a Reserve Board report today. Gains were shown in four districts, no change in the Kansas City district and small losses in the remaining district, including New York.

PARIS, June 9. -- Premier Daladier in a speech to the Chamber of Deputies today that omitted all reference to war debts, outlined the program with which France is going to face the world at the London Economic Conference.

Although brokers began to talk at midday yesterday of speculative apathy, the late rebound was sufficiently vigorous to warm their hearts. Finally they counted it a good day. Business on the Stock Exchange was not so large as on the day before, but was of proportions that would have been called phenomenal a few months ago.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 9. -- Playing under the terrific heat of the mid-day sun, golfers from the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association competed today in a one-day tournament. Only twenty out of the starting field of forty-seven completed the round and posted scores.

Another crisis in city finance has been surmounted, or at least postponed. Even Mayor O'BRIEN admits that the bankers have been "helpful" to the city. That they have been patient and long-suffering, and willing at all times to meet the city half-way, the record of the past few years amply demonstrates.

Following extreme weakness during the forenoon, the bond market on the Stock Exchange rallied yesterday, but failed to regain all of the earlier losses. Public utility bonds, especially, were weak, with sharp declines noted in the obligations of communications companies affected by dissipation of merger prospects under proposed new legislation.

WARSAW, June 9. -- The Polish Government has sent a strong delegation to the London Economic Conference. The group is headed by Colonel Koc. Under-Secretary of Finance, and includes Dr. Waclaw Fajans, chairman of the Bankers Association; Adam Rose, agricultural expert and moving spirit in the Eastern European agrarian bloc, and Leon Baranski, director of the Bank of Poland.
WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The National Industrial Recovery Bill was passed by the Senate tonight, by a vote of 57 to 24; and radical proposals on taxes and tax returns were carried with it.
WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Following is a statement by J.P. Morgan on behalf of his firm, put into the record today of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee:

Pomorski held Jersey City to seven scattered hits and Montreal triumphed, 7 to 1, at Jersey City yesterday to even the series. Ray Gardner's homer saved the losers from a shutout. Winsett, Regan and Pickering of the Royals also hit for the circuit.

For the second year claims incurred on Connecticut fire insurance business increased in 1932. This is revealed in Part I of the annual report by Insurance Commissioner Howard P. Dunham, a summary of which says in part:

PITTSBURGH, June 9 (AP). -- Steve Swetonic gave the Pirates one of their rare exhibitions of good pitching today, and they checked their downward flight with a 2-to-0 victory over the Reds. The triumph kept Pittsburgh safe in third place.
To the Hotel Brevoort, long the seat of French culture in New York, was added yesterday that peculiarly Parisian thing, a sidewalk cafe.

With adjournment of Congress near, the markets responded yesterday to the prospect of early relief from legislative uncertainties. Stocks advanced rapidly in the afternoon, along with the major commodities, and final prices were higher wherever speculative forces operated aggressively.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 9. -- On the eve of a national conference between management and labor on a proposal further to reduce railroad wages, W.W. Atterbury, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, declared at the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration today that "governmental" wagefixing was a serious problem for the railroads.

LONDON. June 9. -- The British Cabinet met today and for two hours discussed imminent problems in which the matter of meeting the $75,950,000 war debt instalment due the United States next Thursday occupied the foreground.

GLENVIEW, Ill., June 9. -- With the exception of Ed Dudley, professional at Bobby Jones's course at Augusta, Ga., all the members of the American Ryder Cup team, which leaves for England next week, survived the thirty-six-hole elimination in the national open golf championship.

A number of shows will close here after their performances this evening. They are "Strike Me Pink" which has been at the Majestic; "The Mask and the Face" at the Guild, the return engagement of "Of Thee I Sing" at the Imperial and the revival of "It's a Wise Child" at the Hudson.
Bonnet Company -- For 1982: Net income, $2,826, equal to 19 cents a share on 14,944 Class A shares, contrasted with $246 loss in 1931.

As a result of the relatively high prices at which new issues of State and municipal bonds have been awarded recently through competitive bidding, thirty-three communities will offer next week new issues in the aggregate of $28,033,353. This is the largest total for any week this year.

A proposal for stabilization of the garment industry, the biggest industry in this city, within the framework of the national Industrial Recovery Act, was made yesterday. It was offered by Leo A. Del Monte, president of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, to the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union at a conference of representatives of the two organizations held at the Hotel New Yorker.
GOSHEN, N.Y., June 9. -- Fast time made under ideal racing conditions featured the four events on the getaway card at the Bay State Circuit meeting today over the Historic Track.

An injunction to prevent the planned sale by the Chase National Bank of most of the assets of Continental Shares, Inc., a huge investment trust, was sought yesterday in Federal Court. Burke Patterson, a holder of 720 shares of the company's stock, began suit to enjoin the auction, scheduled for Monday.

Summer Items Show Spurt. Trade in women's Summer apparel and accessories was excellent during the week, either despite the heat or because of it, retail executives here reported yesterday. Sales of these departments on several days ran ahead of the corresponding days a year ago.

OTTAWA, June 9 (AP). -- In Manitoba and Saskatchewan there are notably better crop prospects than at the same date of last year, according to the crop report issued today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.

Arrangements were made yesterday for the sale of a membership in the New York Stock Exchange at $200,000, an increase of $5,000 from the last previous sale on Wednesday and the highest price since Aug. 14, 1931, when a seat sold at $210,000. The lowest price this year was $90,000.

Torrid heat enveloped New York and the East yesterday. Six persons died and more than forty others were overcome as the city's temperature jumped to 96 degrees at 2 P.M. This was 10 degrees above the record for the date set in 1887 and within 1 degree of the high mark for the month, recorded June 6, 1899.

The sixty-first annual commencement of the Stevens Institute of Technology will be held this after noon in the William Hall Walker Gymnasium on the campus in Hoboken. Henry Goddard Leach, editor of The Forum, will be the commencement speaker.

The directors of the Industrial Rayon Corporation declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share on the capital stock. This increases the annual rate to $3 a share from the $2 rate previously prevailing. The company also announced the election of George N. Armsby of the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation as a director.

THERE is an old saying of open golf championships that the first man to finish with a fairly low score will be the ultimate winner. When the pursuers know exactly what they have to do to tie or win, the pressure is turned on and they start to explode all over the course.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The methods of J.P. Morgan Co., which have been questioned during the Senatorial investigation, were warmly defended by Mr. Morgan in a statement which he put into the record at the end of today's hearing.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to the article in THE TIMES relating to New York's yel- low fever epidemic in 1796, it was most interesting to have the names of the physicians who were mar- tryrs to their calling, as listed by your correspondent Charles Bolduan, M.D.

Dartmouth College, has incurred the displeasure of the National Commission to Advance American Art by employing the Mexican artist Jose Clemente Orozco, one of the most noted of living mural painters, to execute a fresco.

Commodity futures traded on local exchanges were irregular yesterday, some making large gains and others taking relatively large losses. Trading was active in most markets. Leading cash staples advanced, with several new high prices for 1933 recorded.

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 9 (AP). -- The Boston women's tennis team made a clean sweep of the doubles matches, after dividing the six singles contests, to defeat the strong Philadelphia sextet, 6 to 3, in the opening play of the seventh annual Sears Cup intercity competition today at Longwood.
VATICAN CITY, June 9 (AP). -- The Four-Power pact is a "precious assurance to the whole world of a decade of peace," Pope Pius said today in his first public comment on the accord.
WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The following Marine Corps changes were announced today:

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Income taxpayers who have taken losses based upon stock transactions the sole purpose of which was to evade or reduce Federal taxes received a hint today from Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, that should they voluntarily disclose the facts, the disposition of the bureau would be to refrain from criminal prosecution.

Check exchanges at the principal clearing houses of the country in May aggregated $19,996,745.772, a gain of 20 per cent over April, and the largest monthly turnover since last January. Compared with May of last year, however, there was a slight loss of 3.2 per cent.

ST. LOUIS, June 9 (AP). -- Tex Carleton pitched the Cardinals back into first place in the National League today, defeating the Cubs, 12 to 2. It was Carleton's seventh victory of the season against two defeats.

Moving without delay to establish himself more firmly as a successful boxing promoter, Jack Dempsey yesterday launched plans for a world's heavyweight championship bout to be held here or in Chicago in September.
WASHINGTON, June 9. -- About 2,000,000 children are attending Roman Catholic schools, says a report issued today by the United States Office of Education.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Following is the prepared statement which Thomas S. Lamont, a member of the firm of J.P. Morgan Co., read at the beginning of his testimony this morning before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee:

Salt water fishing in the metropolitan district continues to hold the centre of the stage for the average angler. When practically every species begins to appear in the waters from Cape May to Montauk it is difficult to keep the fishermen from the salt water areas.

Several more Summer theatrical organizations announced their plans yesterday. On July 3, F. Cowles Strickland will open the sixth consecutive season of the Berkshire Playhouse at Stockbridge, Mass. Two new plays will be tested there. They are "Gayly I Sin," by Guido Nadzo, which Dwight Deere Wiman controls, and "Love Flies in the Window," by Anne Morrison.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9. -- Two blistering home runs, one by Lou Gehrig and the other by Tony Lazzeri, gave the Yankees a half a dozen runs this afternoon which proved just enough to give the world's champions a 7-to-3 decision over the Athletics to square the current series at one victory apiece.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Moses plan, I feel, does not give proper consideration to the purposes of the Federal Emergency Administration of Public Works, that the money is to be spent in the next two years and most of it in the next year it the maximum number of people are to be put to work.
The Broadway Association made an appeal yesterday to business men along the famous old thoroughfare to join in spruce-up campaign.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The Railroad Relief Bill, intended to restore stability to the chief transportation industry of the nation was passed today through the adop- tion of a conference report by both the House and the Senate. All that now remains to put the measure into operation are the engrossing of the bill and the signature of President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Gold continued in May to flow slowly back from hoards to the Federal Reserve Banks and the Treasury, as the Department of Justice prepared to take action agrainst those who have violated the President's proclamation.

Voluntary poverty has been accepted by a group of seventeen young men graduated from Lutheran theological seminaries in this area, so that they may begin their work at once as Lutheran pastors in the metropolitan area.

MOSCOW, June 9. -- James Mattern landed at Beloye as the Siberian night settled over the steppes, apparently in preference to attempting the hazardous flight over Lake Baikal and the high mountains in that region in darkness.

MADRID, June 9. -- In an attempt to silence the Socialist Trade Union and clear the way for a moderate government President Niceto Alcala Zamora tonight asked the Speaker of the Cortes, Julian Besteiro, one of the labor "big four," to form a Socialist Cabinet, with the aid of other parties if necessary, but he appears to be confident Senor Besteiro would not be able to do so.

The New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad Company, or Nickel Plate, was ordered yesterday to pay $139,050 and interest from last October to the Garden Investing Company, Inc. Justice William Harman Black declined in Supreme Court to countenance its plea that payment now might throw it into bankruptcy and would be against the public interest.

What the Hunter College seniors consider superlative in the way of literary, dramatic and film entertainment was shown yesterday in the returns of a questionnaire. The questionnaire also covered a variety of other opinions.
The 117-mile metropolitan loop highway encircling New York City on a fourteen-mile radius from City Hall is nearly ready for operation over three-fifths of its length.

CHICAGO, June 9 (AP). -- Luke Appling's home run in the fourteenth inning today gave the White Sox a 10-to-9 victory over Detroit. The Sox came from far behind, scoring five runs in the ninth to tie the score and send the game into overtime.
WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The House bloc supporting the cause of World War veterans agreed today to the compromise plan offered by President Roosevelt.
DETROIT, June 9. -- Recent developments in Jewish life are "bleak and hopeless," Rabbi Jonah B. Wise of New York today told more than 600 members of the National Conference of Jewish Social Service.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP). -- Continuance of the one-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax, reduction of local postage from 3 to 2 cents and transfer of the 3 per cent power tax from consumer to producer were virtually upon the law books tonight as the House broke a deadlock of many weeks over the proposals.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP). -- J.P. Morgan Co., in a statement today to Ferdinand Pecora, Senate committee investigator, said the participation of Judge John W. Kephart of Pennsylvania on Morgan selected client lists was on "exactly the same terms" as that of other prominent men who bought stock on invitation.

BERLIN, June 9. -- Awaiting the details of the partial transfer mora- torium proclaimed by the Reichsbank under the authority of the government, which are still to be worked out, German financial writers confine their early observations to stressing the inescapableness of the measure as an obvious plug against the steady leakage of the Reichsbank's gold reserves.

The defense at the trial of Charles E. Mitchell tried yesterday to prove that the government's action in a similar case justified the banker in failing to report as taxable income the $666,666 he received from the National City Company management fund in July, 1929.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Those of us who have been watching conditions among hundreds of families are becoming acutely aware that fresh air outings this season must be virtually periods of physical repair if tragedy is to be averted.

Judge Paul Myron Linebarger former Federal judge and now legal adviser to the Chinese Government, is sailing for Europe today on the French liner Paris. Also on the liner are Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Klein, Dr. Alexis Carrel surgeon of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research; Francois van Cauwelaert, Minister of State of Belgium, and:

Much of the Senate's time is taken by HUEY LONG of Louisiana, an indefatigable orator and controversialist who warns the Senators that they will " have to come in here and listen" to him. His old quarrel with Senator ROBINSON of Arkansas flames up intermittently.

Predictions have varied from day to day about the President's intention to ask, or not to ask, from Congress power to modify the Tariff Law. At last reports he was proposing merely to announce what he proposed to do, presumably on the basis of his constitutional authority.

Nathaniel West's novel about a newspaper man who conducts an advice column in a daily newspaper. "Miss Lonelyhearts," has been taken over from the Liveright list by Harcourt. Brace and is being brought out in a new edition. The book was well received by reviewers and Harcourt, Brace has already planned another new printing.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- Recasting of the financial structure of Armour Co. of Illinois, a $225,000,000 packing concern, with eventual retirement of the company's outstanding preferred, Class A and B shares through an exchange for common stock is under consideration.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced sharply yesterday on a report that $200,000,000 of government funds would be appropriated for leasing land already planted. No definite plan for the withdrawal of land was disclosed, however.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 9. -- S. Parker Gilbert, graduate of Rutgers University in the class of '12, was inducted as a life member of the board of trustees of the university at its commencement meeting this afternoon. Mr. Gilbert was former agent general of reparations under the Dawes Plan and is now a member of the firm of J.P. Morgan Co.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- A new operating force plan and assignment of vessels of the United States Fleet for the fiscal year 1934, under which fleet operations will be drastically curtailed, was issued by the Navy Department today.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 6. -- Jack Sharkey of Crestmont became a finalist in the New Jersey Stats amateur golf championship for the third time in five years at the Canoe Brook Country Club today. Advancing with him to tomorrow's thirty-six-hole match for the title was Robert A. Lester of Baltusrol, who never before was a qualifier in the championship flight.
Mrs. Frank B. Keech gave a luncheon yesterday in the roof garden of the Pierre for Mrs. Ernest Iselin, Mrs. Henry Ashton Crosby, Mrs. C. Whitney Carpenter and Miss Ellen Latrobe.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Former Senator John J. Blaine of Wisconsin, a Republican, who was defeated for renomination last year, was appointed a member of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation board tonight by President Roosevelt to succeed Atlee Pomerene.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The radio speeches of Louis McH. Howe, the President's secretary, figured in Senate debate today when Senator Vandenberg stated that Mr. Howe received $900 net for each Sunday night speech in a fifteen-minute program which cost the broadcasting company $1,500.

PARIS, June 9. -- Berlin's announcement of a transfer moratorium has aroused keen indignation here, although it was fully expected. Though France has lent very little money to Germany, the French public bought the Dawes and Young loan bonds heavily, and it is estimated that French holders collect almost 500,000,000 franca (about $23,850,000 at current exchange) annually in interest from these bonds alone.

Three shipments of Indian, African and American snakes arrived simultaneously yesterday at the Bronx Zoo. Mr. Raymond Ditmars, curator of reptiles; Head Keeper John Toomey and Keeper James Rimmer worked steadily for five hours unloading the crates.

Former Mayor John F. Hylan announced yesterday that he would accept neither a nomination for Borough President of Queens or justice of the Supreme Court, but would run independently for Mayor. There have been reports that Mr. Hylan might be asked to accept nomination for Borough President or of Supreme Court justice.

The Alton, a subsidiary of the Baltimore Ohio, was the first railroad to report for May. It showed a substantial improvement in net returns for the period, reporting a balance of $6,520, against a net loss of $180,773 in May, 1932. The statement follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: According to recent statements from Washington, 120 commercial attaches and trade commissioners will be abolished and the remaining forty-eight attaches will be transferred to the State Department, presumably to work under the direction of the consulates and, of course, subject to diplomatic restrictions.

LONDON, June 9. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, will not be alone in his daring attempt to force the World Economic Conference to consider the problem of Germany's external Indebtedness. Indications today were that he would be backed up by a solid bloc of debtor countries, all of which are groaning under a burden of interest charges that they cannot possibly meet in a world of fallen prices.

Edith Berger, 15-year-old daughter of a cashier, who ran away a week ago, after cashing a $2,500 check her father had entrusted to her, was defiant in Essex Market Court yesterday. She had been summoned to court as a material witness in a grand larceny case against the two men with whom she and another girl were found on Thursday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: When during the Seventies the greatly increased shipments of American grain to Europe caused the farmers of European countries to demand protective tariffs, the Danish farmers refused to ask protection at the expense of others.

GLENVIEW, Ill., June 9. -- Johnny Goodman, Omaha amateur who came into public notice by beating Bobby Jones in the opening round of the national amateur golf championship at Pebble Beach in 1929, went into the lead in the United States open today by setting a new course record of 66, six strokes below par, at the North Shore Club.
BERLIN, June 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of June 7 shows the following: changes in reichsmarks:

HAVANA, June 9. -- All commercial radio broadcasting stations were silenced this afternoon by government authorities while they attempted to locate a pirate station which went on the air from 2:30 to 3:30 P.M., broadcasting propaganda against the Machado regime.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 10 -- The annual matches of the New York State Rifle Association held at Camp Smith in connection with the State matches, New York National Guard and naval militia, under the direction of Executive Officer Lieut. Col. Henry E. Suavet, were concluded today.

BERLIN, June 9 -- Germany is going to London to lay the German debt problem and all that goes with it in the lap of the World Economic Conference. The transitional transfer moratorium proclaimed by the Reichsbank was purely conceived as a preliminary measure destined to impress the conference with the gravity of the transfer problem and the urgent necessity of tackling it.

The new supply of crude oil in April in the United States amounted to 68,223,000 barrels, the smallest for that month since 1926 and a decrease of 9.5 per cent from the 75,408,000 barrels in April, 1932, according to figures compiled by William. J. Kemnitzer, petroleum technologist, from the data of the United States Bureau of Mines.
Joseph E. Widener's Hurryoff, an obscure son of Haste from Blue Grass, was the surprise winner of the sixty-fifth Belmont Stakes run at Belmont Park yesterday before 15,000 persons.

On the last business day before the opening of the World Economic Conference in London, the dollar fell yesterday to a new low in terms of sterling, marks and lire. It showed a net depreciation in terms of all important European exchanges, but failed by a new margin to equal its low record against the gold standard currencies of France, Holland, Belgium and Switzerland.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- With reverberations of its investigation of J.P. Morgan Co. still echoing, the Senate Banking Committee today turned to preparation for inquiries into the operations of other private bankers, including Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Dillon, Read Co.

NEARLY seventy-five years have elapsed since Darwin published his "Origin of Species." Since that time we have become acquainted with Mendel's law of heredity and with an immense amount of experimental work done with plants, fruit flies, mice and guinea pigs which has thrown much light on the mysterious processes that underlie the transmission of physical characteristics and especially on germ plasm.

TOKYO. MAN proposes, God disposes and the Japanese drama goes placidly on. If a hurried traveler may hazard a guess, it is more Japanese than the capital of Japan. Since the earthquake of 1923 Tokyo has become very much the modern city.

THE conference which opens tomorrow in London obviously carries with it the fate of the world more than any conference which has ever met to discuss economic policies. The great conference of Geneva of 1927 consisted of authoritative experts, not governmental delegates; it met in a period of reasonable prosperity; its object was to lay down doctrine which would influence policy, not to take actual decisions itself on policy.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Construction of another airship of the Akron's rank was urged for the navy today by Congressional investigators, at the same time that the lone surviving officer of the Akron disaster was ordered to sea.

More careful production and sales planning, stricter material control, a sloser check on distribution costs and more liberal use of wage incentives are among the steps which business executives will have to take under the National Recovery Act, Charles H. Hatch, vice president of Miller, Franklin Co., management engineers, said here yesterday.

DETROIT, June 10 -- Organized action in medical care was urged today at the annual conference of Community Chests and Councils at Dearborn, Mich., by Michael Davis, director of Julius Rosenwald Fund of Chicago.

Rolling up the splendid total of 193 runs for the loss of eight wickets, the cricketers of the Crescent A.C. Hamilton Club yesterday defeated an eleven of the Staten Island Cricket Club by a margin of 109 runs with two wickets to spare at Livingston, S.I. Batting first, the home team was disposed of for 84, D. Wightman and G. Mangon being top scorers with 20 and 29 respectively.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- William Edward Dodd, Professor of American History at the University of Chicago, was nominated to be Ambassador to Germany by President Roosevelt today, and confirmed by the Senate. His appointment carries on the scholarly standard set by Dr. Jacob Gould Schurman and should be a popular one in Germany, according to diplomatic circles here.

James Roosevelt, eldest son of the President, discussed one aspect of the Industry Recovery Bill in an address at Town Hall last night. He spoke at a forum dealing with the activities of young men in business, education and politics, arranged by the Young Men's Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Samuel T. Ansell, who was counsel for the Senate committee investigating the election of Senator Overton of Louisiana, today filed a petition with the Senate for an investigation of the "behavior" of Senator Huey Long and "his qualifications" to be a Senator.

Egyptologists working under the auspices of the Metropolitan Museum of Art of New York City have found evidence that the principle of the caisson was known and used by the people that inhabited Egypt 4,000 years ago, says Compressed Air Magazine.

While Manhattan is looked upon largely as the centre of commercial activity in New York, about 70 per cent of the building area in the borough still is used for residential purposes, and the island has a larger percentage of park space than any other important population centre in the country, except the Bronx, according to a new map prepared by emergency employes of Borough President Samuel Levy's office.

Trinity Sunday, which is today, will be widely observed, especially by the ritualistic churches. The time for receiving the annual communion, known as "Easter duty," in the Roman Catholic Church expires today, every confirmed person being required by canon law to go to communion at least once a year.

Liens on unpaid realty taxes for the year 1931 in Nassau County, Long Island, will be offered for sale at auction to be held July 3, according to County Treasurer Harry L. Hedger, who reports that the total amount of taxes involved is about $1,240,000, a record for the county.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10 -- A gallery of 35,000 sweltering Philadelphians forgot all about their heat wave today as the Athletics overthrew the Yankees in both ends of a doubleheader. The scores were 9 -- 5 and 8 -- 7.

EIGHTEEN pictures are currently in various stages of production at the Metro-Goldwyn Mayer studios, with twelve more now being prepared for the cameras. These figures represent a new high for production activity at this company's picture plant over the course of the past three and a half years.

The Senate's decision Friday night to tax the income of Federal, State and municipal bonds brought almost a complete halt in business yesterday in municipals. The market for United States Government bonds was also somewhat unsettled.

OFFICIALLY it is prescribed that the new bars authorized by New York State's Alcoholic Beverage Control Board shall be "integral" parts of the restaurant which they serve -- prominent and visible parts. That is as much as to say right off that the new bars will not be like the old bars of happy and horrific American legend.

Higher planned sales, with expense figures about the same or lower than in 1932, will feature store budget plans for the second half of the year, according to retail executives here. Increases in Fall trade of 10 per cent or more over a year ago were regarded as not unlikely, the gain in part depending upon the reaction of consumers to the higher prices which appear to be ahead.

While there is decidedly increasing interest in various forms of large-scale housing operations, the Regional Plan Association, in commenting upon this activity, finds that the recommendations of the regional plan have been observed generally, in a very limited degree.

NEWARK. N.J., June 10 -- Horsemen from the Central New Jersey Horsemen's Association competed with members of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey in an inter-club matinee of harness races at Weequahic Park today.
To the Editor of The New York Times : A significant coincidence seems to be taking shape in the history of the relations between this country and the Dominican Republic.

USE of the robot pilot by Lleut. Commander Frank M. Hawks on his recent flight, breaking the non-stop transcontinental record east-ward, serves to emphasize the growing value of the automatic pilot. Storming along across the procession of the States at 200 miles and more an hour and at an altitude of 10,000 to 15,000 feet the speed flier found himself able to concentrate on navigation and let the robot do the rest.

A permanent injunction restraining Wiliam J. Flynn, Bronx Commissioner of Public Works, and other officials from interfering with curb cuts at a gasoline station, of the Bensky Realty Corporation, has been obtained.

TWO centuries or more ago no one would have thought of attaching the title "A Century of Progress" to either a world's fair or a book, because up to that time, as Professor Beard points out, it had not occurred to very many persons that there was any such thing as progress.

PITTSBURGH, June 10 -- "Child in serious condition at Magee Hospital. Blood transfusion needed. Any patrolman wishing to offer self proceed at once to hospital." This message was heard by Radio Patrolman James McGuire and his partner over the police broadcast as they toured the city in a police car one night this week.

NYACK, N.Y., June 10 -- Governor Lehman, Dr. Frederick W. Parsons, State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, and welfare leaders will participate on Wednesday in laying cornerstones for eleven new building's at Letchworth Village.

E.R. Dibbs, Eastern general sales manager of the home construction division of Sears, Roebuck Co., announces the appointment of the Nassau-Suffolk Lumber and Supply Corporation of Amityville, L.1., as exclusive dealer in Sears homes.

WITH respect to oil we are writing the most amazing chapter in the history of our dealings with our natural resources. We have laid waste our forests, leaving slashings exposed to fire hazards with resultant wanton destruction, not only of potential future forests but of soil fertility.

CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) -- Detroit defeated Chicago, 6 to 4, today to gain the edge in their series. White and Gehringer hit homers for the Tigers and Red Kress got two and Al Simmons one for the White Sox.
GLENVIEW, Ill., June 10 -- Johnny Goodman, winner of the national open championship today, has been one of the country's leading amateurs for the last four years.

An unusual view of the part Japan should play at the London Economic Conference, opening tomorrow, is expressed in the following excerpts from an article by a Japanese banker. The author is a director of the Hypothec Bank of Japan and was formerly president of the Industrial Bank of Japan.

AN obelist, according to the definition which the publisher has been considerate enough to print on the jacket of this book, is a person who harbors suspicion. After the murder in the smoking room of the S. S. Meganaut, en route from New York to Cherbourg, the ship is full of obelists, as why shouldn't it be?

LOUISA MAY ALCOTT and Cornelia Meigs are an ideal combination. Sir Sidney Lee has somewhere said that the aim of biography is the truthful transmission of personality. No one could be better fitted than Miss Meigs to make the personality of "Invincible Louisa" real and vivid and to show how Miss Alcott's books grew inevitably out of her life and experience.

COMPARISON of the lists shows Columbia to be the champion of Mozart. In the Masterworks Series he ranks third in number of albums, beingoutdone only by Beethoven and Schubert -- both of whom acquired considerable bulk in the form of anniversary editions.

Edmund Blunden, one of the best of the Georgian school of poets, a man of letters who has given us crtical essays and even some fiction, turns here in his latest book of verse to reminiscences and memories. Taking as a springboard a quotation from Dante, he presents in a series of lyrics and poetic monologues, the emotions and ideas of "the midway of this our mortal life."

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Suspension of gold payments and expansion of credit as practiced by the Roosevelt Administration are praised as sound and beneficial by Russell C. Leffingwell, a partner in J.P. Morgan Co.

HB. WARNER, who plays one of the principal roles in support of Sylvia Sidney in Theodore Dreiser's "Jennie Gerhardt," now showing at the Paramount, set out in life with on ambition to become a surgeon. He began the study of medicine in London, England, where he was born.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., June 10 -- Camp Tera, the first experimental camp for unemployed women, opened at Lake Tiorati, in the Palisades Interstate Park, this afternoon, when seventeen young women, most of them out of work for more than a year, arrived from New York City.

BUENOS AIRES, June 1 -- The question of what President Rutherford B. Hayes in 1878 considered to be the main branch of the Pilcomayo River will very probably have to be decided by the United States Supreme Court or some equally competent tribunal before Bolivia and Paraguay can agree on what portion of the Chaco Boreal is to be submitted to arbitration for the solution of the present territorial conflict.

MADRID, June 10 -- Somewhere far out over the Atlantic Captain Mariano Barberan, Spanish military aide in the Moroccan war, and Lieutenant Joaquin Collar are flying a dangerous course westward striving for a non-stop distance record.

DETROIT, Mlch, June 10 -- At a general session of the National Conference of Jewish Social Service meeting here today a New York group of workers advocated a protective organization to champion the economic and professional interests of social workers.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., June 10 -- Ortley Patience O'Hollybourne, a Scottish terrier hardly more than a puppy and a comparatively recent arrival on these shores, received the highest honors today at the annual dog show of the North Westchester Kennel Club.

MADRID, June 10 -- Spain was handed over to the proletariat as Indalecio Prieto, former Minister of Public Works, who was a bootblack at the age of 8 as the son of a poor State employe, agreed tonight to become Prenmier.

It is the commonest of remarks that Congress has conferred upon Mr. ROOSEVELT greater and more varied powers than were ever given to a President except in time of war. They are called emergency powers. This means that they are contingent -- not to be used if the emergency is resolved, or if other means of surmounting it come into play quietly.

DETROIT. IT became apparent in Detroit last week that nothing short of a sudden and drastic let-down can keep motor-car production for the first six months of 1933 from approximating 1,000,000 units. A slight increase in production pace over that for the first ten days of June would see the total for the first half actually eclipse this mark.
Lincoln Ellsworth, explorer and leader of the forthcoming Ellsworth Transanarctic Flight Expedition, intends to be in fine trim for the rigors of his flight bisecting the Antarctic continent.

Mr. Friedman's painstaking study confines itself almost wholly to the economic aspects of the Soviet regime. Its conclusions are buttressed by an enormous and carefully gathered mass of data. He approached his task with a broadly based equipment, which includes technical training and a wide experience in finance, business administration and scientific management.

THE average brain volume for the adult white man is taken to be about 1.500 cubic centimeters. Professor T. Wingate Todd of Western Reserve University found that the average among Cleveland's social ineffectives from 1913 to 1917 was within 10 cubic centimeters of 1,480.

LONDON, June 10 -- A racing yacht of special significance has just been launched and is about to be tested against craft of approximately her own size. It is believed this foreshadows a new attack on the America's Cup.

GENEVA, June 10 -- The question of whether the demand for a shorter work week is to be examined by the International Labor Conference under the urgency clause or in ordinary procedure was raised today. By a two-thirds vote the conference could begin now the debate on the forty-hour week or apply the ordinary procedure which foresees only a general debate this year and discussion of the draft convention in 1934.

THE author was recognized as an authority on the South Pole when he published "Antarctica" in 1928. He called it "A Treatise on the Southern Continent." Commander Byrd carried it with him to Little America. It was indispensable because it dealt with full knowledge of the natural features of the regions that had been explored -- with geology, glaciology, meteorology and the marine life.

For the first time, at least in modern history, the oarsmen of Yale and Harvard are assured of two chances against each other this year. Today, in their camps along the sleepy upper stretches of the Thames, the Blue and Crimson are resting preparatory to putting the finishing touches to their training for their regular meeting Friday evening over the historic four miles from Bartlett's Cove to the Railroad Bridge.

OF course, Mr. van Loon's booklet about Holland is as entertaining as it is informative, after the manner of his usual writing. For it is a characteristic van Loon performance, rich with large quantities of interesting information to be imparted, and often whimsical in its viewpoint and its manner of expression.

Surrogate James A. Foley in a decision yesterday, ruled that the estate of Margaret Pulitzer, granddaughter of the late Joseph Pulitzer, founder of The New York World, was not entitled to share in the $5,830,000 trust fund established by him for the benefit of his grandchildren.

COMMENCEMENTS, final recitals for the season and a turn toward lighter music with Jerome Kern's "Show Boat" and the Gilbert-Sullivan "Pinafore" sailing the ethereal waves carry radio through the middle of the June calendar.

HOLLYWOOD. UNITED ARTISTS, dormant since the first of the year, became active this week with the announcement of an enlarged program, the completion of plans for Samuel Goldwyn's new Eddie Cantor film, the acquisition of George Arliss by Darryl Zanuck's recently formed Twentieth Century Pictures, and the progress of Reliance Pictures with "Joe Palooka" ready for the cameras.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 8 -- The sad and complicated business of paying its State debts has Alabama's principal attention now if not its most joyful interest. The business is aggravated by two circumstances which compound the sadness.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Desperate administration, efforts to adjourn Congress tonight suffered defeat when the Senate, after violent argument over last-minute government reorganization orders sent to the Capitol by President Roosevelt, recessed at 11 P.M. until 11 o'clock Monday morning.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 10 -- Finishing the first week of training in a flurry of time trials, the crews of Harvard and Yale rounded off their heavy work today for Friday's regatta.

Justice John L. Walsh of the Supreme Court, in a decision yesterday, deplored the law which he said supposedly allows a plaintiff in a foreclosure action to collect his debt twice. Denying the application of a defendant to set aside the bid of a plaintiff bank and a deficiency judgment, he saw no remedy except in the Legislature.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 10 -- Tommy Goodwill, 20-year-old New York State amateur golf champion, defeated Jack Mackie Jr., Long Island titleholder, by 1 up at the twentieth hole in the final of the Gedney Farm Club invitation tourney today.

IT is one of Liam O'Flaherty's greatest virtues that though his stories move at a swift pace, thrusting his characters into violence and melodrama, the characters themselves are not sacrificed to the plot. They are sometimes real people; at the least, they are vivid and interesting.

INFLATION is on the offensive all along the line. It is invading what until now, presumably, has been an enemy territory without encountering any open resistance, and it is being put in the unusual position where it has to explain and justify its victory.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- Amateur anthropologists interested in race characteristics, students of anatomy and those sociologically inclined may be unreservedly recommended to a Chicago bathing beach as an open-air laboratory affording extraordinary opportunities for observation.

At London tomorrow the delegates of sixty-six nations will begin an ambitious experiment in international collaboration. There is no precedent in size or scope for the World Economic Conference. On no other occasion have representatives of so many countries gathered in one place to discuss questions of common interest to all of them.

CLEVELAND, June 10 (AP) -- Walter Johnson, who probably has watched more Presidents toss opening-game baseballs than any other major leaguer alive, is going to do a little ceremonious heaving himself tomorrow when he becomes manager of the Indians.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- With shouts and cheers, a meeting of about 300 bank officials and depositors in restricted banks adopted resolutions today calling for liberalization of Reconstruction Finance Corporation regulations regarding bank loans.

ROCHESTER, June 10 -- Re-electing William J. Armstrong of Albany State Deputy and all other officers, delegates to the annual convention, of the New York State Council, Knights of Columbus, closed their three-day session here today.

American artists are being brought "into Justified contempt and ridicule" by the action of the National Commission to Advance American Art in placing Dartmouth College on its "regret list" for employing the Mexican mural paint Jose Clemente Orozco to paint a fresco, John Sloan, president of the Society of Independent Artists, charged yesterday.

Syracuse University may have its hordes of rabbits scampering about the grounds to enliven the transcampus trek of students "threading their way wearily to classes" -- as the student newspaper there put it recently -- but Columbia University can boast of a great family of squirrels, a prettier and perhaps less common creature that the cotton tail.
LONDON, June 9 -- Whoever still clings to a belief in international cooperation will hear much that is encouraging during the next week or two.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- No letup occurred today in the flood of unfavorable crop comments on Winter wheat and on oats received on the Board of Trade from the West and Southwest. These with the bullish construction placed on the government report issued late yesterday sent deliveries of wheat and oats to new high prices for the season.

Rising security markets in the last two months, coupled with a great improvement in sentiment, have pulled almost all lines of the insurance business out of the situation which prevailed just before the bank holiday.

A sharp reaction in raw silk futures was the feature of trading on local commodity exchanges yesterday. Others, including raw hides, crude rubber, silver and wool-top futures were higher, while cash prices also gained.

THIS story of India by Frieda Hauswirth Das, author of "Marriage to India" and "Purdah: the Status of Indian Women," centres about a tribe of Hanuman, the sacred gray monkeys that symbolize to the Hindus the unity of life, "the kinship of all living things."

In order to reach the remote sections of rivers throughout the State to plant fish, the Connecticut Fish and Game Commission has hit upon a new system which is expected to increase the number of game fish in all the usually heavily fished rivers.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Memorial Day holiday in the week ended on June 3 tended to reduce the week's total production in some lines, but schedules generally were maintained at a level equaling that of the preceding week, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

IN Great Britain, at the moment, liberalism is at a discount and the dominant gospel is reaction. Mr. Algernon Cecil is himself, as he says, "a reviving Tory," and his one worry is that his wife still insists on being "a surviving Whig."

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The White House is expecting a formal proposal on Monday or Tuesday from the British Government concerning the war debt instalment due next Thursday, it was learned authoritatively tonight. Until such a formal, written proposal is received, one of the Presidential secretaries said, President Roosevelt will make no public declaration on the subject.

WALL, coverings in sun rooms may appropriately suggest the out-of-doors. Scenic wall papers, ancient and modern, are now supplemented by new coverings created by a variation of the photographic-enlarging process.
GLENVIEW, Ill., June 10 -- Johnny Goodman of Omaha today became the fifth amateur in the history of American golf to win the national open championship.

LONDON, June 10 -- There is not the "slightest belief" in the United States that the dollar will be returned to its old gold parity, according to Ralph W. Morrison of Texas, a member of the United States delegation to the World Economic Conference.

To the Editor of The New York Times : Your correspondent In Havana is of course correct when he describes recent tariff increases as pertinent to the amazing decline in our trade, with Cuba and as an obstacle to the proposed revision of the reciprocity treaty.

WHEN short waves stream out from England to be intercepted on the eastern edge of the American continent, the impulses must be amplified and "patched up" electrically before being fed into coast-to-coast broadcasting networks to which many ears may be attuned.

DALLAS, Texas, June 8 -- Texas is evincing an intelligent and unusual interest in the London Economic Conference. It is probably the first time that this State has ever been so curious about any international meeting, and there is a large part of the public that must yet be made to realize how important the London discussions are to their own economic well-being.

LONDON, May 26. SOME of the outstanding entertainments of the past fortnight are already familiar in America, but their fortune in London is nevertheless worth recording. "Music in the Air." which Mr. Cochran has put on the stage of His Majesty's Theatre, had a fairly comfortable but not an eagerly enthusiastic reception.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. William G. Bibb and Mrs. Bibb's daughter, Miss Kate L. Young, of 410 Park Avenue have taken a place in East Hampton for the season.

NEXT Friday will be a national occasion among Swedes everywhere. Swedes who are away from their native granite but within reach of a Swedish legation will array themselves in top hats and frock coats (if they possess these baubles) and thus repair to their legations to sign the visitors' book in honor of their King's seventy-fifth birthday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 10 -- Princeton's ninth-inning bombardment today routed Yale, crashed five runs across the plate, and gave the Tigers a 10-to-7 victory in the opening game of their annual series. The score was tied at 5-all when Princeton spurted.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 10 -- Jack Sharkey, champion of the Crestmont Club for the last three years, today regained the New Jersey amateur golf title, which he held in 1929. He defeated Robert A. Lester of Baltusrol, 6 and 4, in the thirty-six-hole final at the Canoe Brook Country Club.

FOR twenty-two of the hundred years of the life of New York University, covering almost one-fourth of its history, Elmer Ellsworth Brown has been its chancellor. Of its total of seven chancellors his has been the longest administration, and doubtless the university's story would reveal that it has been also the most important in growth, achievement and developing spirit.

STRONG opposition very properly arises whenever a plan for Central Park is put forward in the nature of an encroachment or which tends to disturb its present admirable layout and the rusticity of some of its sections.

PORT WASHINGTON, N.Y., June 10 -- In a light southwesterly zephyr on Long Island Sound today the 12-meter sloop Cantitoe, handled by Van S. Merle-Smith, made a runaway race of a match with the Iris, sailed by Drake H. Sparkman.

BOSTON, June 7 -- Not in the memory of the oldest politician in the Bay State has there been so much talk about an election eighteen months in the future as there has been during the past week. The campaign of 1934 for Governor has not begun in any real sense, but two candidacies have been announced and the voting will not be done until a year from next November.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., June 10 -- The Northern Westchester Kennel Club dog show, under the auspices at the American Kennel Club, was held today at Lawrence Farms, for the benefit of the Northern Westchester District Nursing Association.
To the Editor of The New York Times : In his letter to THE TIMES John D. Connaughton joins issue with Charles Hall Davis in his article, "Divergent Theories of Our Government."

THE next volume of Mark Sullivan's history. "Our Times," to be published in the Fall by Charles Scribner's Sons, will bear the subtitle "Over Here" and will deal with America's participation in the World War and with the events immediately preceding our entry into the conflict.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Forty centuries of religious progress will be depicted in a pageant when "The Romance of a People" is presented on Soldier Field on July 3 as the Jewish contribution to a century of progress.

ONCE the butt of light-hearted comment, the weather man is today an indispensable member of society. His work touches the daily life of the citizen at many points. The sailor, the farmer, the engineer, the industrialist, even the lawyer -- all are dependent upon the weather scientist.

Quick action by a truck driver averted the bombing of his truckload of non-union made shirts yesterday, but an innocent bystander was severely injured when the bomb, hurled smoking from the truck, exploded at his feet.

LEBANON, Pa., June 10 (AP) -- Death won a desperate race today on a little-used back road connecting Reading, Lebanon and Lancaster -- keystone of the beer empire ruled over by the late Max Hassel, shot to death recently in an Elizabeth, N.J., hotel.

RYE, N.Y., June 10 -- A hardriding, swift-moving Princeton four that was alert to seize every opportunity routed Yale's defending champions, 12 to 7, in the opening game of the intercollegiate polo title tournament at the Westchester Country Club today.

THE Child Labor Amendment to the Constitution submitted to the States for ratification in 1924 and rejected by twenty-four of them, has suddenly come into prominence again. Until last January only six States -- Arkansas, Arizona, California, Wisconsin, Montana, and Colorado -- had endorsed this proposal; but since then six others -- Oregon, Washington, North Dakota.

Only a few years ago interstellar space was supposed to be empty -- a perfect vacuum. The theory of the expanding universe has made it necessary to re-examine that assumption. There are skeptics who refuse to believe in a space that is being blown up like a soap bubble and still less, as EDDINGTON holds, in a cosmos that has exploded.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 10 -- Class reunions and Class Day exercises featured the program today in Colgate University's 114th commencement celebration, preceding the baccalaureate sermon tomorrow and the conferring of degrees on Monday.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Over sharp objections from Senator Norris, who called it "a slap in the face to progressive Republicans," the Senate today approved the nomination of Walter Newton, a former secretary to President Hoover, to be a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank board.

Prices all over the city will be increased if Mayor O'Brien's motor vehicle tax program becomes effective, according to several letters of protest received yesterday by the Automobile Merchants Association from business interests.

BORN April 23, 1852. Edwin Markham is now 81 years of age. His last book of poems was "Eighty Songs at Eighty." From a certain day in 1886. when Markham, 34 years old, wrote "The Man With the Hoe" recognition has attached to his name.

RYE, N.Y., June 10 -- Sun Eclipse, the handsome black gelding owned by Mrs. Charles F. Hubbs, climaxed a fine day's performance by winning a championship in the fortieth annual Westchester County Horse Show today at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club.

Stevens Institute of Technology, at its sixty-first annual commencement in Hoboken yesterday, awarded two honorary degrees for work on the autogiro, one for radio development and two for work in smoke abatement.

TORONTO, Ont., June 10 -- The most encouraging reports received from Ontario's gold fields in years, according to the government, are reaching the Parliament Buildings here from government geologists and other sources. Good discoveries and exceptional activity in prospecting are reported by T.F. Sutherland, Deputy Minister of Mines.

An advance in the price of crude oil in the Greater Mid-Continent area is regarded in the industry as imminent. The feeling is that some announcement likely will be made before representatives of oil-producing associations and the American Petroleum Institute meet in Chicago on next Thursday.

The recent victories in England of William Woodward's Brown Betty and Flange have caused the assertion to be made in local racing circles that the chairman of the Jockey Club is the most successful American racing abroad since the days of Pierre Lorillard.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 10 -- Mr. and Mrs. Peter Grimm, Miss Laura Grimm and Peter Grimm Jr. are at the Maidstone Arms and will go to the Maidstone Inn when it opens June 30 to pass the season.

THIS large volume performs a very useful service which, has not been offered in adequate form by any of the host of books which have been written on the Soviets. Its chief value lies in its authoritative survey of Russian economic and social conditions during the years immediately preceding the advent of Bolshevism.

What has become of the "wild young generation" which not long since furrowed so many elderly brows? Where now is the flapper, and where is Flaming Youth, with its hip-flasks, its speedy cars and flamboyant clothes and many tacit declarations of freedom?

MOSCOW, June 9 -- Covering the news in the Soviet Union is not an easy job, as your correspondent has learned to his cost in the last twelve years, but what makes it worse is the perpetual misunderstanding among people at home about the celebrated Bolshevist propaganda and its effects on foreign reporters.

CHICAGO, June 9. ATHARINE CORNELL began a two, possibly three, weeks' engagement in "Alien Corn" at the Harris Theatre last Monday night, to the accompaniment of enthusiasm among both press and public.

BERLIN, June 10 -- The Boerse was quiet and irregular today. Weakness at the opening was caused by an almost complete absence of buyers. This was followed by a recovery when several banks made purchases which traders attributed to investments of blocked marks.
The Giants yesterday achieved their ninth triumph of the season over the Phillies before a crowd of about 7,500 at the Polo Grounds. The score was 5 to 2.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 10 -- The inauguration of Professor Harold Willis Dodds as fifteenth president of Princeton University will take place on June 20 as the final event on the 186th commencement. The exercises will open on June 15.

Moscow. NOTHING is more instructive in the study of cultural and architectural influences than to follow the ancient roads of the migration, one of which is the road to Pamir, "The Roof of the World," in the very heart of Asia.

PITTSBURGH, June 8 -- President Roosevelt's nomination of Carroll Miller of Pittsburgh as a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission appeals to Pennsylvania's sense of justice first; important as is the political fact that this traditionally Republican Commonwealth may receive from a Democratic administration what it sought in vain under Republican administrations, it is secondary.

An option to purchase 3,000 shares of its capital stock at $60 a share has been given to one of its officers by the Lehman Corporation. Notice of the option, granted as of May 10, 1933, and to run until Dec. 31, 1934, has been sent to the New York Stock Exchange in accordance with the agreements under which the stock is listed.

RECORD high temperatures failed to check the high level of retail activity in the week and the stores are moving on to figures for the half month which will exceed those of a year ago. The usual seasonal lines received the best response, but attention is now being called to the breadth of the demand.

Not Quite Pacifist. HITLER impressed Mr. BERNARD RIDDER as eminently a man of peace. HETLER. told Mr. RIDDER that he would not have a single man killed "to gain as much as 100,000 square feet of territory."

The eighty-eighth commencement exercises of Fordham University will start this morning. The Rev. John P. McCaffrey will preach the baccalaureate sermon in the university chapel to about 900 graduates from the College of Arts and Sciences, the Graduate School and the Schools of Sociology and Business.

PARIS, June 9 -- If ever the French reputation for skepticism has justified itself it is doing so now. A veritable pall of pessimism hangs over Paris these days. Your Frenchman just does not see how the World Economic Conference is going to succeed or how disarmament can be attained or government finance straightened out.

Despite high temperatures the volume of local trade was well maintained during the week. About a half dozen of the leading stores here now have a dollar sales volume in excess of the corresponding period a year ago, with others approaching very closely to their 1932 figures.

The mystery in Mr. Beeding's new tale is Incidental to the main theme of the story. Instead of beginning with a murder, it begins with the decision of a spinster of 36 to seek a freer and fuller life than she has hitherto known. By the death of her Invalid mother, whom she has nursed for years, Rosamund Shipley comes into possession of a modest fortune.

Reduction of tariff barriers and a "reasonable compromise in our position on foreign debts" are two of the major points stressed by the American Manufacturers Export Association in a statement of export trade policy sent yesterday to American delegates at the World Economic Conference opening tomorrow in London.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Those whose names appear on the Morgan "favored list" may take heart from a century-old precedent.

Unless money problems interfere, Illinoisans will soon have restored to them a historic site at once one of their most interesting and neglected possessions. That is the old, eminently respectable square building that stands in the centre of Vandalia, the former State Capitol, where Lincoln, Douglas and other Illinois giants first held forth, reports the North American Newspaper Alliance.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange continued to rise yesterday, and an advance of nearly $1 a bale carried the list to within a few points of recent high records. Reports that the Department of Agriculture would use $100,000,000 or $200,000,000 to reduce production brought in heavy over-night buying, and execution of orders by wire-house brokers was a feature of early trading.

The college which perhaps first fully applied the American democratic ideal to higher education celebrates its centenary this week. When colleges In this country admitted men only and largely discriminated against Negroes, Oberlin opened its hand-hewn doors in the midst of the Ohio wilderness to all alike, without distinction as to sex, color or class.

AFTER several years of nerveshattering marriage to a temperamental film star, Harvey Crane, young Southern patrician, returns alone to his Georgia home town, where he is planning divorce proceedings and a second leap into matrimony, his promised one a prim local belle.

As more sober attitudes spread over college student bodies, attention is being increasingly focused on the fraternities. A warning that they are hindering rather than helping was made in an address before the alumni association of Hamilton College, at Clinton, N.Y., yesterday by a prominent New York City alumnus.

BERLIN, June 10 -- The struggle between the more conservative and traditionalist section of German Protestanism, supporting Dr. Friedrich von Bodelschwingh as the Reich Bishop, and the militant Nazi section known as the German Christians, under the leadership of Dr. Hermann Mueller, army chaplain and Chancellor Hitler's confidante, has entered its final phase.

ARTISTS from earliest times have been interested in dress. Before the Greeks, the Minoans; before the Mexicans, the Mayans; modern investigations pushing into prehistoric times find architecture, sculpture, costume. Not until the present century has art turned casual about dress.
DODGE CITY, Kan., May 31 -- Kansas has undertaken to clip the wings of the lobbyists whose influence has been appreciable in every session of the Legislature.
