To the Editor of The New York Times: The Emergency Conservation Committee invites attention to the serious destruction of wild birds and animals of all kinds, large and small, that is unfortunately resulting from the colonization in the forest regions of thousands of men who have no background of knowledge of forest life.

IN the square block of film studios out in Astoria which once hummed with the production activities of Paramount's Eastern unit. Dudley Murphy is manufacturing a talking film version of Eugene O'Neill's "The Emperor Jones" for the Messrs, Krimsky and Cochran, who presented "Maedchen in Uniform'' in this country last year.
LONDON, June 9 -- Cynics in official circles say the world will be saved in spite of the economic conference, not by it.

MOSCOW, June 10 -- When last heard from today Jimmy Mattern, American round-the-world airman was passing over Rukhlovo in Eastern Siberia, about 725 miles short of Khabarovsk, his next landing point. That was at 9:15 this morning, Moscow time [2:15 A.M., Eastern Daylight Time].

RICHMOND, Va., June 8 -- Rushed through the recent General Assembly under circumstances deemed suspicious by certain observers, and viewed with considerble alarm by the evangelically inclined, North Carolina's race track gambling legislation, will shortly be put to the contest of popular referenda in several of the counties immediately concerned.

To the Music Editor: The newly organized Composers Protective Society, which outlined its purposes in your columns last Sunday, will, I hope, enlist the active support not only of the American composer but of all fairminded musicians in this country.

ASOLO, May 14, 1933. FEW would disagree, one thinks, with the proposition that in this machine age the significant new music heard at the Italian concerts sponsored by Mrs. Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge under particularly favorable conditions acquires an added and perhaps unique appeal.

Irregularly lower prices characterized dealing's in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday during the brief trading period, with the turnover of $7,729,900 sizable for a Saturday. Utility bonds were subjected to further pressure, and the rails lost some ground.
Marcel Poffo and Max Parkin, suspected of participation in numerous bank robberies, were found murdered early yesterday in a lonely spot in Harrison, near the Westchester Country Club.

Returning to the business of baseball after a three-game losing streak, followed by a three-day rest, Max Carey's Dodgers defeated the Braves yesterday, 3 to 2, and went into sixth place before a crowd of about 5,000 fans.

WASHINGTON. THE Roosevelt "brain trust" is a snare, if not a delusion. It is a jigsaw puzzle of men, many at the pieces not fitting together. Instead of a professorial oligarchy, it becomes upon examination a reflection of every possible type of thought on financial, sociological and governmental subjects.
America's representation in the men's tennis championships at Wimbledon sailed for England on board the Paris of the French Line yesterday.

DELOS CHAPPELL is the local owner of all those American, rights to Mr. Lionel Hale's "The Naked Lady." He acquired them in advance of the London showing, which starts, by the way, June 22. While the title is still just tentative, the subject-matter of the work is, to hear them tell it, modern and comic.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 10 -- The Industrial Recovery Act was defended on various grounds by two speakers at the concluding session of the anniversary meeting of the Harvard Business School.
Mayor O'Brien was asked yesterday to curb the "profligate waste of city funds" in connection with the building of a clubhouse at Dyker Beach Park, Brooklyn.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In its issue of May 18, Printers' Ink has an editorial on "Sensible Farm Relief," based on a suggestion telegraphed to Secretary Wallace by W.D. Hoard Jr., publisher of Hoard's Dairyman, that, inasmuch as investigation reveals 6,000,000 milk-cows which do not earn their keep, they should be taken out of production and butchered.

PHOENIX, Ariz., June 8 -- Gaul was not more divided than Arizona -- not in a political or civil sense, but in diverse methods of sustaining its people. There are the great mining sections whence comes much of the world's copper supply.

That the real estate mortgage is the most important form of investment in the United States today is indicated by the fact that there are more than $40,000,000,000 of real estate mortgages outstanding in this country at the present time. No other type of investment approaches this figure in size.

Out of the silence with which the Nazi flood has engulfed Germany a few voices have been raised, among them that of Professor Wolfgang Koehler of the University of Berlin, chief exponent of the so called "Gestalt" school in scientific psychology.

NEWARK, N.J., June 10 -- Charlie Devens pulled the Bears out of their slump today with a 6-to-0 shut-out victory over the Bisons in the final game of the series, which saw the visitors take two out of three. By w.inning Newark took undisputed possession of first place.
STONY BROOK, L.I., June 10 -- Two college scholarships were awarded at the eleventh commencement exercises of Stony Brook School this afternoon.

Completion, of the eleventh, volume of the Dictionary of American Biography, with 665 articles reflecting highlights of the nation's Colonial and national life from 1562 almost to the present, was announced yesterday by the American Council of Learned Societies.

LONDON, June 9 -- Two unknown glaciers, a lake probably containing warm water, and a mass of geographical detail for adding to a map that at present contains very little definite information, have already emerged from the survey strips made by the Marquess of Clydesdale and Flight Lieut. D.F. Mclntyre of the Houston Everest expedition on their unauthorized second Mount Everest flight.

PENNSYLVANIA has adopted a new standard of highway signs employing symbols to denote conditions requiring caution, it is announced by Sam S. Lewis, secretary of the Department of Highways. The new signs, now being get up, are designed to give the motorist at a glance the information necessary for his guidance.

WHILE the making or loans by individual citizens of one country to other governments is, and has been for centuries, a common practice, loans by a government to another government have occurred only occasionally.

An article in the Feature Section of today's TIMES describes the revival of interest in the Child Labor Amendment, giving Congress power to "limit, regulate and prohibit the labor of persons "under eighteen." Submitted to the States in June, 1924, and subsequently rejected by twenty-four of them, it has recently made striking progress.

ROME, June 9 -- Though Rome had reason to feel proud of its wonderful network of roads in those bygone centuries when its legions marched to the furthermost corners of the empire, from the viewpoint of twentieth century automobiles these were until recently the worst imaginable.

Record Sales Volume Is Expected in Wholesale Trade This Week. With scores of rug buyers due here to order floor-covering requirements in advance of the 5 per cent price increases going into effect on Thursday and a general buying wave continuing in the wholesale furniture market, homewares volume this week is expected to touch a new high for the Spring season.

A TRANSCONTINENTAL, motor trip by any route is an adventure, and mostly an enjoyable one. Given a good car and ability to curb the urge to hurry forewarned as to the nature of the country to be traversed, and equipped with adequate road information, one may anticipate no unusual difficulties or discomforts.

PERHAPS because all the world, including the authors and readers of novels, has come in recent years to unpleasantly close grips with reality, the hazy and illdefined romanticism of this novel seems more than a little out of date.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Senate tonight adopted a resolution by Senator Bone, Democrat, of Washington, requesting Secretary Woodin to call upon holders to exchange outstanding government bonds for a lower-interest issue entitled, "the New Liberty Loan of 1933."

THE present edition of "Money Versus Man" makes available to American readers a stimulating work published in England two years ago. Its author, Professor Soddy, is one of the world's most eminent radio chemists and the recipient of the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1921.

As an indication that the recovery movement shows even more vigor as it progresses, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity for the week ended June 3 recorded the best increase since the upturn started toward the end of March.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The last rush of legislation almost ruined the annual ball game between the Democrats and Republicans of the House today, but not even the disturbing influence of a summons to a roll-call could prevent the Republicans coming from behind and winning, 18 to 16.

IT comes as something of a surprise, when looking over the record of the season which has just come to an end, to discover that dance activities have declined practically not at all. Whereas the grand total of all performances, large and small, for the season which ended a year ago was 331, this season has managed to achieve 306, which is by far the largest total for any previous season except the last.

Numerous reorders were received during the week for timely merchandise to be featured in special June and July promotions, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. No merchandise, the report adds, is available from the racks at concessions, as prices in all lines are remaining firm.

The eastward trend of development on Long Island is illustrated by the growth in recent years of Islip, Suffolk County's largest township in population and assessed valuation, points out Robertt J. Bartley, consulting engineer of the township, in a discussion of some of the factors which are influencing this growth.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10 -- A sharp rise in the price of Curtis Publishing Company stock on the New York market today caused much discussion here among the relatives and business associates of Cyrus H. K. Curtis, who died three days ago.
LONDON. THE publication of the third volume of Arnold Bennett's "Journals," covering the years from 1921 to 1928, completes the series, and has provoked some Interesting comments on the whole work.

THIS is commencement season and in thousands of schools and colleges of the land black-robed graduates are closing one stage of their education. Commencement oratory flows on, as it did ten years 'ago, a hundred years ago.

OTTAWA, June 8 -- Periodically the subject of titles crops up in Canada, as it did during the recent session of Parliament and as it has at intervals since 1919 when the House of Commons adopted a resolution praying the King to refrain thereafter from "conferring any title of honor or distinction" upon any of his subjects domiciled in the Dominion.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Warfare against racketeers of high finance and racketeers of violence and bloodshed was promised tonight by Attorney General Homer S. Cummings in an address broadcast over a network of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

What is believed to be the first full-time fur exchange in the world was opened recently in London. It has received the appropriate name Beaver Hall, and joins the British capital's other commodity exchanges in occupying an important place in world trade.

WESTFIELD, N.J., June 10 -- Mrs. B.F. Stenz and Ingo Hartmann of New York, champions in 1931, advanced to the semi-finals in the New Jersey State mixed doubles tournament today at the Westfield Tennis Club.
BOSTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Washington Senators took advantage of loose fielding by the Boston Red Sox today, collected twelve hits and left the field with a 7-5 verdict to their credit.

THIS new book of poems by the novelist Willa Gather is in part a reprint of "April Twilights," poems printed in 1903, and in part a new group of later lyrics. Most of Miss Cather's earlier poems are romantic lyrics; the later poems are more realistic and dramatic narratives and songs of the Middle Western scene, the background from which Miss Cather drew her first novels.

TO the Rev. Dr. John McDowell, on his recent election as Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, came scores of congratulatory messages from men of all kinds. College presidents, ecclesiastics, labor leaders, physicians and editors showered him with goodwill.

OAKDALE, L.I., June 10 -- The golden jubilee commencement of La Salle Military Academy will begin tomorrow with a senior class mass. The celebrant will be the Rev. John E. O'Brien, S.T.L., of the class of 83.

THE possibility, discussed from time to time in news dispatches, that Germany may return to a monarchical form of government draws attention to the men who may be considered as contenders for the throne.

NORTH ARLINGTON, N.J., June 10 -- Alexander Schweinzeit, owner of the cellulose sorting plant that blew up last night and devastated this village, was held as a material witness today while vigorous State and local investigation got under way.

The scientific use of microscope, camera and acid has disclosed forgeries of Elizabethan documents, manifest in handwriting and typography, Dr. Samuel A. Tannenbaum, New York psychotherapist and Shakespearian scholar, reports in his studies in "Shakespearian Scraps and Other Elizabethan Fragments" just issued by the Columbia University Press.
PARIS, June 8 -- Ladies day at Chantilly opened the big racing month with the Prix de Diane in style, indicating an enthusiastic return to the old-time elegance. All-white ensembles were in the lead.

Wall Street awaits the opening of the World Economic Conference in London tomorrow without much optimism. Bankers who earlier in the year had high hopes for the outcome feel that the action of the United States in suspending the gold standard and permitting the dollar to take its place with other disorganized exchanges has completely altered the basis of the conference.

There has been some decrease in the death rate charged to the pneumonias, and to the infectious diseases, but in contrast to this trend there has been little change in the death rate charged to neo-natal deaths, including premature birth, injury at birth and other diseases peculiar to early infancy, Health Commissioner Shirley W. Wynne declared recently at a meeting at the New York Academy of Medicine.

While trading on the Stock Exchange was less active yesterday than on the previous Saturday, it was at the rate of almost 7,000,000 shares for a full five-hour day. The market made some headway, but the net advance was small after a moderately heavy realizing movement in the second hour.

PROFESSOR MASON is one of the devoted friends and admirers of Brahms, and this book shows how deep a study and how thoroughgoing a knowledge he has of his works. The modern musical world is tending more and more to a similar friendship and admiration.

This is the twenty-first book of verse by Cale Young Rice, whose selected poems appeared in 1926. Mr. Rice's scene is the South, and of the rich beauty of his land he has, for long, been singing. He is a romantic poet. In his narrative, such as that called Milna, he deals with passionate love and its tragedy.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- As the two branches of Congress swept toward adjournment, there was rapid-fire action on both sides of the Capitol.

The short Interest on the New York Stock Exchange increased 4,524 shares in the period from May 1 to 29, it was announced yesterday. On the latter date it was 1,419,854 shares, against 1,415,330 shares at the beginning of the month.

After racing as a collegian, Bob Modisette, Pacific Coast outboard driver, will compete in the scholastic events in connection with the Eastern Intercollegiate outboard championships to be held on Lake Hopatcong, N.J., on June 24 and 25.

VIENNA, June 9 -- The last week has brought one of the most difficult problems that will face the World Economic Conference -- that of putting Central and Southeastern Europe on its feet again -- somewhat nearer a solution than had seemed possible.

QUEBEC, June 10 (Canadian Press) -- "There are tangible signs of business and economic improvement in Canada and the United States," Sir Josiah Stamp, director of the Bank of England, said here today on sailing for England aboard the liner Empress of Britain.

CIVILIZATION begins with farming. A tribe must settle down for at least a season if it grows what it eats instead of seeking it in forest or stream. Hence, if we can discover whence came the first grains and what they were, we shall go far in tracing civilized man back to his cradle.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Strong criticism of the "persecution" of Jews in Germany was voiced during Senatorial discussion today, precipitated by Senator Robinson of Arkansas, the Democratic floor leader.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 10 -- The Foreign Office instructed the Bolivian delegate to the League of Nations tonight to ask modification in the League Council's original proposal for settling the Chaco conflict. It is believed the proposed modification will not be difficult.

PITTSBURGH, June 10 (AP) -- Bill Swift permitted the Cincinnati Reds to score in only the first and last innings today and the Pirates won, 4 to 3. It was the Bucs' second victory in the three-game series.
THE New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society has received the following cable from Arturo Toscanini dated Florence, June 5:

PARIS, June 4 -- The interest felt in Paris over the forthcoming Barbara Hutton-Prince Alexis Mdivani nuptials recalls the story of the Mdivani family in Paris during the last decade. It was just about ten years ago that General Zachary Mdivani, who died a few months ago, came here with his wife, two daughters and three sons.
MAX ADELBERT BAER put the winning punch on exhibition at the Yankee Stadium and thus another stirring episode was added to the almost incredible career of a roistering blade, a gay caballero.

CLINTON, N.Y., June 10 -- Alumni and trustee meetings and the annual oratorical contest opened Hamilton College's 121st commencement activities today. A trophy cup was presented by the trustees to Elihu Root, '64, former Secretary of State, in honor of his fifty years of service on the board.

The city colleges will expel all radical students rather than imperil the continued existence of the institutions by permitting an "extremely small minority" of the undergraduate body to bring them into disrepute, Mark Eisner, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, said yesterday.

ONE of the major enterprises being contemplated by Fox Films is a talking picture of Charles Dickens's "A Tale of Two Cities." Warner Baxter will be featured in a production and cast on the ample lines of the company's "Cavalcade" and "State Fair."

THIS volume is the contribution of the State Society of the Colonial Dames of America to Georgia's bicentennial; the authors listed above served as a committee for the compilation of the material, which is in the form of a "date book."

AURORA, N.Y., June 10 -- Macmillan Hall, the new $500,000 administration and arts building at Wells College will be dedicated at 11 o'clock tomorrow morning. The building was named in honor of Dr. Kerr Duncan Macmillan, president of the college for twenty years.

"No new taxes without retrenchment," should be the civic slogan today, Harold Riegelman, counsel of the Citizens Budget Commission told the members of the Harlem and Bronx Property Owners Association last week. He called attention to the 1775 slogan of "No taxation without representation," saying that the slogan he previously mentioned was just as sound for today as the earlier demand was 158 years ago.

IN the office of the Commissioner of Jurors, on the third floor of the Hall of Records, there is a large volume whose enclosures are yellow with age. Many of the letters pasted in the book date back eighty years; several carry an earlier date line.

New York wiped its brow and replaced its wilted collar yesterday after an early morning electrical storm had relieved the sweltering city. The storm was accompanied by a sixty-mile wind which did much damage in the metropolitan area.

Alteration work continues to furnish the bulk of the construction business in the Manhattan residential field, and expenditures for this type of improvement are running ahead of last year, according to the first quarterly report submitted to Mayor O'Brien last week by Commissioner Charles S. Kerrigan of the Tenement House Department.

This interesting study of human relationships in Russia today by the wife of Lincoln Steffens is the record of an observer who was greatly impressed by the changes which have been effected by the new regime in the human equation -- changes, one gathers, which she believes are all for the better.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- In a formal report on its inquiry into the purchase of 200,000 toilet kits for reforestation camp workers, the Senate Military Committee today said:
LONDON, June 10 -- The monetary side of the World Economic Conference, which opens Monday, took the lead in preliminary interdelegation talks today.

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 10 (AP) -- The Boston women's tennis team today regained the Sears Cup by defeating New York, 5 matches to 4, at Longwood. It was the sixth Boston victory in seven years of cup play, New York won last year.

"Investment" purchasing, a device by which large corporations throughout the country are evening off the inventory losses they suffered in the slump, accounts for much of the active buying now going on in both raw and finished material markets, George A. Renard, secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, said here yesterday.

Efforts to bring about a consolidation of communications companies were brought to a standstill again last week by Congressional refusal of legislative authority for such a combination. The so-called White Act of Feb. 23, 1927, which made the anti-trust laws applicable to communications companies and added provisions in the spirit of those laws, remains in full force.

The two-year reign of Textile High School as P.S.A.L. baseball champion was terminated yesterday when the George Washington nine scored a 5-4 triumph in a thirteen-inning contest at Washington Stadium.

Unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation increased 55,241 tons last month to 1,929,815 tons on May 31, it was announced yesterday. It was the second consecutive increase, a gain of 23,572 tons in April having reversed a trend of steadily declining backlog.

CHICAGO becomes, for the time being, the centre of art activity in America. The Century of Progress Exposition is in full swing, and last week a series of important conventions got under way. The American Federation of Art held its meetings there on June 8, 9 and 10.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Georgetown University will hold its 134th annual commencement on Monday afternoon, with Martin Conboy, New York lawyer and regent of Georgetown since 1920, making the principal speech.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Not counting the Industrial Recovery Act and Veterans' Appropriation, which remain to be finally acted on, the special session of the Seventy-third Congress has enacted into law twelve major measures, eleven of which were requested by President Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- James J. Doran was appointed today Postoffice Inspector-in-Charge at New York City, succeeding C.H. Clarahan.

This story has the not unusual theme of the wild dog who is tamed and trained by man, but the treatment is fresh and unusual. The son of a Siberian huskie from an Indian village and a timber wolf, he grows into a magnificent creature with a silvery white coat that causes the Indians to name him Silver Chief.

Notice that an influential section of the railroad management group desires a change in the Railway Labor Act was served by W.W. Atterbury, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, in a speech on Friday before the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.

LONDON. ONE of the greatest obstacles to an agreed reduction of armaments has been the simple fact that in Germany there are more than 64,000,000 people and in France only about 41,000,000; and the French cannot forget that, whatever her standing army may be, Germany has more man-power to draw upon.

A world-wide movement to bolster merchant shipping by encouragement of scrapping programs and aid in maintaining necessary tonnage in operation is noted in reports received in shipping circles from observers abroad.

LONDON, June 3 -- It has become a commonplace by now to say that when King George opens the International Monetary and Economic Conference on June 12 he will be Setting in motion the greatest international assembly since Versailles.

OTTAWA, Canada, June 8 -- Gold is where you find it, but prospecting for the yellow metal that has so large a place in world economics is something more than a pleasant outdoor sport if undertaken seriously and intelligently.
MOSCOW, June 10 -- The Spring sowing campaign, which is all-important this year, has been unexpectedly successful. Up to June 5 209,000,000 acres had been sown, or 88.2 per cent of the program.

LONDON, June 10 (Canadian Press) -- The West Indies cricket team scored 382 runs in the first innings of its match with Middlesex today, and had taken two Middlesex wickets for only 14 runs at the close of play.

TOKYO. As the train rolls into Tokyo the traveler sees on his right, above a sea of roofs, a gilded cross on a tower. It is one of the most conspicuous architectural monuments in Tokyo, and a monument to the American spirit as well, for St. Luke's International Hospital and Medical Centre, which it surmounts, is the chief American achievement in Japan.

PARIS. I HAVE already told TIMES readers that I consider Andre Malraux one of the most important of the authors of the generation that is a little over 30 years of age. His new novel, "Condition humaine" (Librairie Gallimard), marks fresh progress beyond its predecessors, by the deeper quality of its ideas as well as by the intentionally dry, clipped simplicity of its style.

THE present little volume embodies three lectures delivered in memory of Alfred Marshall at Cambridge early this year. Their author. Sir Arthur Salter, is a distinguished British economist and the former director of the economic and finance section of the League of Nations.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 10 -- The Rev. Dr. Rush Rhees, for thirty-three years president of the University of Rochester, resigned today.

Dark Secret, a 5-year-old black mare owned by Gilbert C. Barrett Jr. of Hempstead, L.I., carried off the grand championship at the first annual Queens County Horse Show at Hillside Park in Queena yesterday. The show was held for the benefit of the Queensboro Home for the Blind of Richmond Hill.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 10 -- Clear-view Vendetta, big gray gelding owned by Joseph P. Day of Short Hills and exhibited by his daughter, Mrs. Laura Barrett, won its second championship in as many weeks today. He received the rosette in the final event of the seventh annual horse show of the Watchung Riding and Driving Club.
If a person were to insert the following advertisement in a paper he would think he had an almost foolproof formula for guaranteeing results:

The annual exercises in memory of Robert Burns, the poet, were held in Central Park yesterday by a score of Scottish societies. Members of the societies marched from the Caledonian Club, 846 Seventh Avenue, past the Burns statue on the Central Park Mall to the bandstand, where various speakers addressed the gathering.

EXETER, N.H., June 10 -- Phillips Exeter was celebrating a magnificent 3-to-1 baseball victory over Phillips Andover Academy tonight because of effective pitching and hitting by Jack Batten and Tom Bilodeau of the Red and Gray.

Three or four indications are customarily accepted by the business community as showing the trend of general trade. The course of the stock market, though it is watched with interest, is taken with reserve by those who remember that stocks in 1929 rose to the highest prices of our time, exactly a month before the October crash and the beginning of industrial reaction.

CANTON, N.Y., June 10 -- St. Lawrence University will confer honorary degrees Monday on Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, and Edwin Markham, the poet, the Rev. Clarence R. Skinner, dean of the School of Religion at Tufts College, and the Rev. Isaac V. Lobdell of Attleboro, Mass.

BERLIN, June 10 -- The government announced today that as a reprisal against the boycott of German goods declared by Jewish and Socialist organizations in Latvia it was decreeing a boycott against Latvian butter, and further steps might be taken if they were found necessary.

ALTHOUGH airships in America are filled with it. helium is still classed as a "rare" gas. The adjective is applicable. Helium is rarer than gold. The United States, which has a virtual monopoly of it, isolates it from natural gas.

CLINTON, N.Y., June 10 -- Fourteen colleges and universities of the East have agreed upon a plan for conferences with alumni officials of college fraternities to eliminate the "harmfull practices" of college life find increase the usefulness of fraternities.

ON Wednesday eleven cornerstones will be laid at Letch worth Village. The completion of the buildings which will rise from these foundations will also mark the physical completion of the village, which is New York State's home and training centre for its feeble-minded.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Charges of dishonesty against Samuel Insull Sr. and his brother, Martin, were brought today by the receivers for the Middle West Utilities Company, Edward N. Hurley and Charles A. McCulloch. They filed suit in Federal court against the New Amsterdam Casualty Company of New York to recover $100,000 on a brokers' blanket bond protecting the utility company against dishonest acts of employes.

Baltimore shipping and civic interests will ask the Federal Government to deepen the Chesapeake and Delaware waterway to permit transportation by deep-draft vessels and shorten the run between the port to the northern seaboard and to Europe.
GENEVA, June 10 -- The trains for London are crowded these days with delegated secretariat officials and journalists.

Toward the end of the week the hot weather stimulated a better demand for most kinds of berries, peaches, cherries, cantaloupe, honeydew and honeyball melons and watermelons, George G. Royce, director of the New York office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Formation by the Pennsylvania and the Reading Railroads of a new and jointly used South Jersey system out of parallel lines now independently operated by each was authorized today in a decision handed down by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

SO many are the books which have been written about Africa that the Dark Continent seems now as familiar as one's own backyard! Yet each new book, in one way or another, manages to differ from its predecessors, so that one is assured of some element of surprise.

BERLIN, May 15, 1933. ON the evening of May 10 a great mob jammed the Franz Josef Platz, which flanks the Staatsoper, to witness amid the glare of spotlights and the din of brass bands the public burning of a quantity of books.

THE confidence radio showmen now have in short waves and their ability to reach far for programs is revealed in the fact that overtures were made by the sponsors of the Will Rogers's Sunday night program to sign Sir Harry Lauder to fill the spot left vacant by the cowboy philosopher, whose eight-week contract expires on June 18, according to the National Broadcasting Company.

THIS book is like one of those Roman walls that were faced with smooth stone and filled inside with rubble-quantities of fragments from old buildings and monuments. It is not quite so solid. The rubble between these covers is made from the fifteen years of front-page news and backstairs gossip of the world since the war.

A COMPREHENSIVE exposition, done in an admirably judicial and objective manner, of the very serious situation in which that highly important factor in American life, our transportation system, is now enmeshed, is here presented by G, Lloyd Wilson, who holds the Chair of Commerce and Transportation in the University of Pennsylvania.

BOSTON, June 10 -- Harvard's varsity ball nine did some timely hitting at the Boston University commencement festivities at Riverside today, and evened its series with the Pioneers by winning, 3 to 4.

TIMELY, useful and desirable is this booklet as guide, first aid, philosopher and friend for readers who want to understand what that momentous gathering, to convene in London June 12 is about, what it hopes to achieve and what hurdles it will have to clear if it is not to leave the world in a still more hopeless state.

MADRID, June 10 -- Mild, indeed, compared with the encyclical published upon the passage of the Mexican church law was that Pope Pius has issued about Spain. Of course, the Church maintains the strongest possible protest against Spain's anti-ecclesiastical legislation.

The National Recovery Act offers labor the greatest opportunity it has ever had in the United States to exert collective influence on wages, hours and standards of employment, according to "Facts for Workers," a monthly review. The review is published by The Labor Bureau, Inc., 2 West Forty-third Street.

HILLSIDE, N.J., June 10 -- Albert Goldfeder, 34 years old, of 469 Elizabeth Avenue, Newark, was found murdered early today. His body was lying across the road in a lonely section of Oakland Terrace, a development near here. The police of Elizabeth and Newark believed Goldfeder was a small-time beer runner and a victim of racket warfare.

Reaction to this country's move in extending a $50,000,000 credit to China for the purchase of wheat has caused a temporary setback to those working for trade agreements between this couptry and the Soviet, it was stated in trade circles here yesterday.

THE recent recommendation by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo for the establishment of a matrimonial court in Manhattan and the Bronx directs attention to the confused situation in this city regarding alimony and matrimony.

PARIS, June 10 -- French officials are considering the possibility of taking to The Hague court the action of Germany in regard to the transfer moratorium on the Dawes and Young loans, it was reported here today. If this is done, it would be tantamount to repudiation of the Lausanne reparations agreement and a return to the Young plan.
POUGHKEEPSIE, June 10 -- Alumnae meetings and the Class Day exercises opened today the observance of the sixty-eighth commencement exercises of Vassar College.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 10 -- Three more practice games were held at the Meadow Brook Club today in preparation for the Spring tournament season which gets under way tomorrow.

Two records were broken and one was equaled as New Utrecht High School won the city P.S.A.L. senior high school outdoor track and field team championship for the tenth straight year in the annual title meet before 4,000 yesterday at the General George W. Wingate athletic field in Brooklyn.

WE WOODWARD'S return to the novel is celebrated by a volume which contains a little of almost everything. Besides the familiar ingredients which went to make up "Bunk," "Lottery" and "Bread and Circuses" we have some new ones.

The annual commencement exercises of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America will be held at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon in the quadrangle of the seminary at Broadway and 122d Street. The commencement exercises are for the Teachers Institute as well as for the rabbinical department of the seminary.

Settlement houses and welfare agencies throughout the city are cooperating with the civilian Conservation Corps in assisting to piace unemployed youths between the ages of 18 and 25 in reforestation camps.

The Department of Commerce statement of gold exports from the United States in April show that, out of the $16,741,333 sent abroad in that month, France took $9,010,412. Italy $4,802,526. England $2,199,871 and Holland $723,790. Of the $6,768,587 gold imported during April.

With the financial focus shifted to London, Wall Street expects that the course of the markets this week will be shaped to a large extent by preliminary developments at the World Economic Conference. The chief concern at the moment is for the integrity of the American currency, and any development which will hasten the return to the gold standard will be welcomed.

John Lowry, vice president of the Merchants Association and chairman of the committee which drafted the new building code, answered some of the criticism recently made against the code during the public hearing last week before the committee on buildings of the Board of Aldermen.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Subscriptions to the Treasury's recent offering of $900,000,000 in notes and certificates of indebtedness amounted to $5,650,000,000, Secretary Woodin announced today.

The sand-lotters returned yesterday to the Yankee Stadium for the second double-header of the Yankee Sandlot League season. The Schermerhorn Indians beat the Columbus Hill Braves 4 to 1, and the Goodhue Reserves won from the Harlem Lions by a score of 8 to 6.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 10 -- More than 500 alumnae of Mount Holyoke College gathered here today for the pre-commencement events in which the 224 members of the graduating class played the chief part. The commencement exercises will be held Monday.

THE mantle of Seton Merriman would seem to have been bequeathed to Mr. Gielgud; he wears it, however, with a difference. If Merriman's highly polished, cryptic and inferential prose style seemed a fitting vehicle for Secret Service stories of the Europe of the late Nineties, the insouciance and light-hearted speed which characterizes "The Broken Men" is no less typical of young Europe of today.

ST. LOUIS, June 10 (AP) --The Chicago Cubs knocked the St. Louis Cardinals out of first place in the National League race by winning the final game of the series today, 4 to 3. The Giants won from the Phillies and regained the top.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 7 -- Prime Minister Bennett rounding out the busiest year of his busy life in the representation of Canada at the World Economic Conference, which King George will open in London on Monday. Mr. Bennett is accompanied by E.N. Rhodes, his Minister of Finance, and a staff of experts and advisers.

LIKE many another in these days of ferment, Mr. Fels is deeply concerned with the course upon which the changing winds and currents of our time are sending the world, and more especially our own country. It is chiefly of the American trend of affairs and of the purpose beneath that trend that he writes, although be envisages the United States as an integral part of the world.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Sazerac, a 56-to-1 shot, won the seventh running of the Robert M. Sweitzer Handicap, at a mile and a furlong, closing feature of the eighteen-day meeting at Washington Park today, before a surprised crowd of 12,000.

THE motorist in New York City awoke last week to find himself the target for additional taxes. A hard-pressed city administration planned to collect from him and his brother car owners $15,000,000 a year through registration fees equaling the State's.

FIRST published in 1908. "Weeping Cross" was not as widely read as it deserved to be but it has been warmly remembered by a few readers anxious to see the book in print again. Their efforts will be understood and readily commended by new readers.

EVANSTON", Ill., June 10 (AP) -- Three high, school band members were in a hospital here tonight, the most seriously affected of 150 youthful competitors who collapsed in the "marching contest," high point of the national high school band contest's final day program.

Striding easily over the distance of fourteen miles, Mel Porter, representing the Irish-American A.C. of New Jersey, annexed the modified marathon race yesterday sponsored by the Italian daily, Corriere D'America.

WASHINGTON. EXPERTS in coding and decoding messages, backed by the trained operators of American telegraph companies, will keep Secretary Hull and the delegation to the London Economic Conference at all times in close touch with President Roosevelt and the State Department in Washington.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Successful on three roll-calls, administration forces in the House forced the adoption tonight of the Roosevelt compromise plan for reduction of veterans' benefits and sent it to the Senate.

MILWAUKEE, June 10 -- The eighty-fourth annual meeting of the American Medical Association, which has a membership of nearly 100,000, will begin here Monday and will continue through Friday. Thousands of physicians, representing every State and most of the territories and dependencies of the United States, are expected to attend.

Three city P.S.A.L. senior high school championship contests on Saturday not only will wind up the P.S.A.L. activities in New York City for the school year of 1932-33, but also virtually will bring scholastic competition in the metropolitan district to a halt until next September and the advent of the 1933-34 school year.

INCOME statements of the nations -- that is, the balance of in ternational payments throughout the world -- will receive attention at the World Economic Conference which opens in London tomorrow. The balance sheet of the United States for 1932 has just been made public by the Department of Commerce.

TAXING the bachelor is an old device; now the Nazis propose to use it to relieve the economic distress of young couples in Germany. If the plan, which is incorporated in the general relief program, is adopted, the German bachelor will contribute toward a fund known as "marriage aid," from which subsidies will be granted to couples under specified conditions.

LITTLE ROCK, June 8 -- With the railroads of Arkansas conducting an apparent winning fight against the motor truck, forcing it out of competition by loading it with stringent regulations, a new danger confronts them in the proposed construction of a canal to connect the Arkansas River at Little Rock with the White River at De Valls Bluff.

A WEEK ago last night at the Hippodrome a season of popular-priced opera opened with Verdi's "Aida" as the offering. The opera was presented with, a cast of fair and sometimes more than fair ability, an orchestra which should be larger, a competent chorus, and conductors who put life into the performance.

BOSTON, June 10 -- Dr. Bancroft Beatley, Associate Professor of Education at Harvard University, has been elected president of Simmons College to succeed Dr. Henry Lefavour, president of the college since it opened thirty-one years ago. He will take office in September.
The "official" arrival of Summer on June 21 will bring still more hot weather, so Health Commissioner Shirley W. Wynne made public yesterday a list of "hot weather hints."

IT is of little use to tell city picnickers how they may identify poison ivy. They simply sit down in a growth of it, munch their sandwiches and rue their ignorance of elementary botany later. So the doctors bend their effort to discover how they can assuage the itchings and burnings called by them dermatitis.

AMERICAN art, as assembled and presented in the Century of Progress exhibition at the Art Institute in Chicago, needs no fanfare of bugles. For it is -- and therefore does not have to be made to appear -- important.

PARIS, June 10 -- France today followed up Premier Daladier's strong statement of her economic policy at the London Economic Conference with two smashing blows at the flow of international trade in general and at the United States dollar in particular.

The City party is preparing "a gigantic mass meeting of protest" against the Tammany administration, to be held at Madison Square Garden or some other large hall within a week. Samuel Seabury has tentatively accepted an invitation to address the gathering.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 10 (AP) -- The triennial convention of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers expressed unanimous confidence today in the grand chief, Alvanley Johnston, and the secretary-treasurer, James H. Cassell.

ROUEN, June 3 -- American customs, formulas and principles of courtship and marriage received ecclesiastical approbation at the ninth annual convention of the Association for Christian Marriage, which has just ended here.

DANVILLE, Va., June 8 -- Tobacco growers are beginning to feel that the "new deal" is going to benefit them and that three lean years are to be followed by one which will enable them to pull out of the rut of poverty.

VENICE, the commercial me tropolla of the fifteenth century, easily became the publishing centre of the world, once the art of printing had crossed the Alps. Its favorable location insured cheap transportation and the northern Italian towns were already actively engaged in the paper-making industry.

IT is of little use to tell city picnickers how they may identify poison ivy. They simply sit down in a growth of it, munch their sandwiches and rue their ignorance of elementary botany later. So the doctors bend their effort to discover how they can assuage the itchings and burnings called by them dermatitis.

AMERICAN art, as assembled and presented in the Century of Progress exhibition at the Art Institute in Chicago, needs no fanfare of bugles. For it is -- and therefore does not have to be made to appear -- important.

PARIS, June 10 -- France today followed up Premier Daladier's strong statement of her economic policy at the London Economic Conference with two smashing blows at the flow of international trade in general and at the United States dollar in particular.

The City party is preparing "a gigantic mass meeting of protest" against the Tammany administration, to be held at Madison Square Garden or some other large hall within a week. Samuel Seabury has tentatively accepted an invitation to address the gathering.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 10 (AP) -- The triennial convention of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers expressed unanimous confidence today in the grand chief, Alvanley Johnston, and the secretary-treasurer, James H. Cassell.

ROUEN, June 3 -- American customs, formulas and principles of courtship and marriage received ecclesiastical approbation at the ninth annual convention of the Association for Christian Marriage, which has just ended here.

DANVILLE, Va., June 8 -- Tobacco growers are beginning to feel that the "new deal" is going to benefit them and that three lean years are to be followed by one which will enable them to pull out of the rut of poverty.

Hundreds of seamen, forced out of their jobs because of the withdrawal of tonnage from the merchant trade, have turned to fields that range from being artists' models to sewing nautical emblems on the blouses of musical comedy chorus girls.

Interest that has been aroused in coronary thrombosis since the recent deaths of former President Coolidge and Senator Walsh -- the cause of death in each instance being diagnosed as due to this condition, which is a fixed clot of the coronary artery -- has led to a study of thrombosis among the millions of policy holders of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

THE five chapters which comprise this little book are a somewhat expanded version of a series of lectures which the author delivered in April, 1931, at the University of North Carolina, Since Mr. Laski has an international reputation as a brilliant thinker.

DUBLIN, June 9 -- The celebration of the anniversary of the birth of Wolfe Tone, the Protestant patriot who is hailed as the father of Irish republicanism, has produced no end of differences among the divers Republican parties here.
A major shake-up struck the Police Department yesterday, Park Avenue gambling, Commissioner James S. Bolan said, was responsible for one inspector's transfer.

Miss Brenner's "Ten Modern Poets" filled a need, but the present volume is perhaps even more valuable. In a significant preface she explains her reason for writing these studies of the older American poets, citting the "renewed interest in these writers of the nineteenth century, whom a young twentieth century cavalierly rejected.

A PREHISTORIC skeleton turned up in a ditch in Minnesota and tie treasures or a prince hauled out of a tomb in Oaxaca may arouse deep emotion only in the Isolation of museums and archaeological camps; may disturb, with their sense of time's nudge at living elbows, poets and philosophers only; may stir in romantics vague dreams of mysterious scripts and vaults full of Aztec gold.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 10 -- The honorary degree of Doctor of Laws was conferred in absentia upon President Roosevelt at the 167th commencement of Rutgers University here today. Four other honorary awards were made in addition to the 237 bachelor degrees and the fifty advanced degrees that were conferred.

AS express continues to grow. The Railway Express Agency, which handles air express for United Air Lines. Western Air Express, Northwest Air Lines, National Parks Airways and connecting lines, reports that in the first four months of this year shipments were up about 250 per cent.

Sixteen Summer play schools affiliated With the Child Study Association will open their doors to about 2,500 children on July 10. The schools will be open every day from 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., an announcement from the association said yesterday.

Formation of the National Management Council, which includes in its membership the leading engineering and management societies and which is designed to act in an advisory capacity to the individual groups, was announced here yesterday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 10 -- A salute of nineteen guns greeted George H. Dern, Secretary of War, when he arrived at the military academy this afternoon to remain until the graduation exercises Tuesday morning. Secretary Dern was escorted from the south gate to the official residence of Major Gen. William D. Connor, superintendent of the academy, by a troop of cavalry in dress uniform.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Roosevelt submitted to Congress tonight executive orders for reorganizing certain government services, saving an estimated $25,000,000.

TOKYO, June 10 -- Government officials confirmed today reports that Japan was preparing to propose to the United States the conclusion of a treaty of arbitration similar to the one that was in force up to five years ago.

GLENVIEW, Ill., June 10 (AP) -- Ralph Guldahl was steaming down the stretch today as Johnny Goodman lay stretched on a divan in the cool clubhouse of North Shore, guarded by six United States Marines.

WASHINGTON. ATENTION has been focused on the government's income-tax procedure by testimony given at hearings before the Senate Committee on Banking and by the effort in Congress to tighten up the tax provisions.

The revival of business, gains in employment and rising wage scales have reached the point where a substantial increase in national purchasing power has taken place, it is evident from returns from the principal cities of the United States for the last week.

ALTHOUGH intended primarily for textbook use in college courses in sociology, this intimate study of some of the problems immigration has developed in this country will be valuable for any one interested in the fruits of the melting-pot because of the quality of its contents and the scientific, objective character of its treatment, concerned only with getting at fundamental facts and discovering their significance.

ADMITTING that "Below the Sea." a picture now at the Rialto, has its good points, among them being a real surprise toward the close of the narrative, it might have been a far better film had the producers developed the theme of the salvaging of sunken gold more carefully instead of clogging the story with several incidents that seem to be thrown in merely for good measure.

The plan of Mack Trucks, Inc., to purchase $550,000 of preferred stock of the East Side Omnibus Corporation was under fire yesterday at a hearing before the Transit Commission. Robert E. Fulton, vice president of the truck concern, told the commission that he would not produce voluntarily the minutes of a directors' meeting at which, the purchase of the bus company stock was approved.
IN this new novel the author of "Mexican Trail" has produced an adventurous and gripping tale that is rather above the average of the current crop of Western yarns.

PARIS, June 10 -- "It is no longer possible to maintain massive payments from one nation to another," Finance Minister Bonnet said today in an interview with the Paris Soir. "The Lausanne conference solemnly condemned such payments and we remain true to its decisions."

Reporting that a substantial increase in new mortgage loans was made in May on Manhattan real estate over the month of April, the Real Estate Record and Builders Guide states that the total amount of new loans in May aggregated $5,821,532 as against $1,530,766 in April.

LONDON, June 3 -- The recent action of the Oxford Union in twice passing a resolution to the effect that they would not "fight for King and country" lends a more than usual interest to the announcement of the National Peace Congress which is to be held at Oxford in July after an interval of five years.

ALTHOUGH intended primarily for textbook use in college courses in sociology, this intimate study of some of the problems immigration has developed in this country will be valuable for any one interested in the fruits of the melting-pot because of the quality of its contents and the scientific, objective character of its treatment, concerned only with getting at fundamental facts and discovering their significance.

ADMITTING that "Below the Sea." a picture now at the Rialto, has its good points, among them being a real surprise toward the close of the narrative, it might have been a far better film had the producers developed the theme of the salvaging of sunken gold more carefully instead of clogging the story with several incidents that seem to be thrown in merely for good measure.

The plan of Mack Trucks, Inc., to purchase $550,000 of preferred stock of the East Side Omnibus Corporation was under fire yesterday at a hearing before the Transit Commission. Robert E. Fulton, vice president of the truck concern, told the commission that he would not produce voluntarily the minutes of a directors' meeting at which, the purchase of the bus company stock was approved.
IN this new novel the author of "Mexican Trail" has produced an adventurous and gripping tale that is rather above the average of the current crop of Western yarns.

PARIS, June 10 -- "It is no longer possible to maintain massive payments from one nation to another," Finance Minister Bonnet said today in an interview with the Paris Soir. "The Lausanne conference solemnly condemned such payments and we remain true to its decisions."

Reporting that a substantial increase in new mortgage loans was made in May on Manhattan real estate over the month of April, the Real Estate Record and Builders Guide states that the total amount of new loans in May aggregated $5,821,532 as against $1,530,766 in April.

New York University will train medical examiners and toxicologists in a newly formed department of Forensic Medicine at the university and Bellevue Hospital Medical College, Chancellor Elmer Ellsworth Brown announced yesterday.

THE long-planned North American Radio Conference is scheduled to be held in Mexico City beginning July 10, according to invitations issued by the Mexican Government. The purpose is to clear up complications in wave-length allocations between the United States, Canada, Mexico and Cuba.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The dying hours of the first session of the Seventy-third Congress disclosed the administration more firmly entrenched than, any new Federal Government in recent times. Whatever its fate, the administration has generally gotten what it asked of the special session. In either the foreign or domestic field, the President's policies may yield bitter fruit. But his policies, not those of Congress, have been made into law.

PARIS. LITERALLY turning their backs on nudist fashions, elegantes are preparing to dress up for the beaches as Edwardian ladies. That is, at any rate, the first impression gained from the new instep-length beach frocks shown by Paris couturiers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One who has been accustomed to living in a medium-sized town, with convenient schools and moderate local taxes, cannot help but be amazed at the inconvenience and expense to which rural citizens have been subjected in recent years in the matter of schools.

Joseph Weiner, who was being hunted as the reputed boss of poultry racketeers in this city, surrendered yesterday to District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx. With him were James D.C. Murray, his attorney, and a brother. The brother brought $10,000 cash and quickly freed Weiner in bail for that amount.

With a favorable background of industrial news and the assurance of an early adjournment of Congress, the shares market displayed quiet strength yesterday. Wheat led another advance in agricultural staples by selling at the best price in more than two years.

CLEVELAND, June 11 (AP) -- The Indians, playing their first game under the managership of Walter Johnson, barely managed to give the "Big Train" an opening victory today by scoring one run in the tenth inning to defeat the Browns, 1 to 0.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 11 -- The fifty-first training season of the New York National Guard began today at Camp Smith, its largest training headquarters. The Tenth Infantry with 1,130 men arrived under the command of Colonel Charles E. Walsh.

Though he decided not to ask Congress for power to modify the Tariff Law, President ROOSEVELT has indicated that he still strongly favors bilateral agreements with other countries, involving concessions on both sides. Arrangements of this sort are to be sought at an early date and submitted to Congress when it reconvenes.

DETROIT, June 11 -- The National Conference of Jewish Social Service became deadlocked on the selection of a president for the coming year at today's business session. Harry L. Glucksman, New York, executive director of the Jewish "Welfare Board, nominated by petition from the floor, and Jacob Kepecs, superintendent of the Jewish Home Finding Society of Chicago, the regular choice of the nominating committee, each received 135 votes.

PARIS, June 10. -- Dollar weakness caused no surprise here, because all that is happening adds to the conviction that the dollar will depreciate still further. It now seems evident here that the United States is definitely embarked upon credit inflation and that every reasonable means will be employed to cause prices to rise.

DARIEN, Conn., June 11 -- Two men who later confessed to the Darien police that they had recently robbed the homes of wealthy Darien and Greenwich residents of about $18,300 worth of silverware and jewelry were arrested early this morning.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial "The New Libel" you quoted passages from Franklin Roosevelt's closing campaign speech wherein he defended sound "money to be maintained at all hazards," and condemned Mr. Hoover's Des Moines speech as a libel on the credit of this country.

HOUGHTON LAKE VILLAGE, Mich., June 11 (AP) -- Four persons were drowned and the lives of nearly twoscore others were imperiled during a violent windstorm which swept across Houghton Lake late this afternoon.
Five units of clanging fire apparatus were not enough to disrupt the baby contest held yesterday on the lawn of the Bronx Maternity and Women's Hospital.

The fundamental moral value of play for both children and adults was stressed yesterday by the Rev. Paul R. Dickie in a Children's Day sermon at the Bethany Memorial Reformed Church, First Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street, of which he is pastor.

LONDON, June 11 -- Negotiations here for the past two days among bank officials of the United States, Great Britain and France, with the reported view of allowing the World Economic Conference to open with temporarily stabilized currencies, were without result tonight.
NEW YORK. William Durant Campbell of the Plaza will sail for England on Saturday. He and his sister, Miss Edwina Campbell, have a home in Hampshire, England.

CLINTON, N.Y., June 11 -- It is not the man who knows most who can lead best, but "the man whose appeal is "the strongest," President Ferry said in an address to Hamilton seniors today. He told the graduating class that education means more than the accumulation of stray facts.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- In another effort to stimulate business, induce borrowing corporations to effect economies, and to speed up the reorganization and strengthening of the banking system, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation has agreed to reduce interest on loans by one-half of 1 per cent.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- Oats have given the trade a surprise. For months the trade had remained dormant with fluctuations of about 1/2 cent for a week. Last week brought numerous reports of oats heading short and turning yellow and being lightweight on account of intense heat over a large percentage of the best producing section, particularly in Iowa, Nebraska and Kansas.

Other Good Signs. Signs of returning prosparity are not confined to the business pages and the news of rising employment and wages. Familiar traits of the late Golden Age have been breaking out in the public prints:

Restatement of existing anti-war treaties to forbid the use of armed force by any nation on its own initiative was urged yesterday in material made public by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

The Park Association of New York City has written the Board of Estimate opposing any bill that may be introduced before the Municipal Assembly to authorize the leasing of bungalows and campers sites in Wolfe's Pond Park, Princes Bay, S.I.

A tribute to fathers and to the memory of his own, inspired by the new custom of observing June 11 as Children's Day, was voiced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin, pastor of the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue at 105th Street.

WELLINGTON, Texas, June 11 (AP) -- Two machine-gunning motorists today terrorized a farm family, kidnapped two officers and escaped with an injured woman companion after their automobile plunged over a road embankment.
MILWAUKEE, June 11 (AP) -- Eating a big Thanksgiving dinner, scientists have found, not only gives little Johnnie bad dreams, but makes him toss about in his sleep 100 per cent more than usual.

Last night, on the eve of the public hearing on the auto tax legislation at City Hall, the city administration was in a dilemma. It was unwilling to go forward with the taxation program and saw no way to back down.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- In the presence of an overflow throng, the Hall of Religion at the Century of Progress Exposition was dedicated this afternoon. The keynote, sounded by George W. Dixon and echoed by the other speakers, was the spirit of cooperation among various creeds.

Leases of space for retail purposes formed a large part of the commercial rentals reported by brokers yesterday. Store space in Westchester and the Bronx, as well as Manhattan, was included. Several offices in the downtown district also were taken.

It just wasn't in the cards for Hal Schumacher to win yesterday at the Polo Grounds. The Giants' new mound star was striving for his fifth straight victory, but he could not quell the hard-hitting Phillies and they triumphed, 7 to 5, to win their second game in eleven with New York.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 11 -- With today the traditional day of rest for the Yale and Harvard crews in training, the most important development was the change in the weather. After a week of almost unbroken heat, it was clear and cool with a fresh breeze to greet the crewmen as they sailed out on the Sound to spend the day on yachts.

Again Professor MOLEY takes occasion in his Sunday article written for The Herald Tribune to sing low about the World Economic Conference. He begs his fellow-citizens not to expect too much from it. They must consider its difficulties and weigh the likelihood that, beyond a great deal of speech-making and the utterance of pleasing international sentiments, very little will be done at London.

Assuming that they have made no serious error in concluding that the atmosphere of Mars contains much less than 1 per cent of oxygen, Drs. WALTER S. ADAMS and THEODORE DUNHAM Jr. of Mount Wilson have by no means given a quietus to the romanticists who persist in believing that our ruddy neighbor is a living planet.

The teaching and practice of religion in these days is not a light task, Dr. Cyrus Adler, president of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, said yesterday in his address at the thirty-ninth annual commencement exercises. Fifteen new rabbis received degrees.

Three hundred and fifty Fordham College seniors who will receive bachelors' degrees at the eighty-eighth commencement on Wednesday took part in the baccalaureate service yesterday in the university chapel.

Bishop William T. Manning advanced three deacons to the priesthood and ordained nine young men to the deaconate yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street.
Approval by the City Club of the proposed central purchasing department for the city was made known yesterday by release of a letter to the Board of Estimate.

The depression has caused so many to "turn back to the church" that church membership is now the largest in this country's history, according to The Christian Herald's animal report of church statistics, published in the July issue of that magazine.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 11 -- Amassing a high total of 45 points, the Knickerbocker Canoe Club of New York paddled off with the team honors in the annual Hudson River regatta today. It was staged by the Atlantic Division of the American Canoe Association in co-operation with the Palisade Interstate Park Commission.
The Organization of Regular Republicans for Change in the New York County Leadership announced yesterday that it would open headquarters today in six Assembly districts.

MOSCOW, June 11 -- If the Russians were skeptical about the four-power pact they are frankly pessimistic regarding the London Economic Conference -- and this quite apart from the conventional Marxist dogma about "capitalist rivalries," which, according to the Marxist credo, "inevitably lead to war."

GREENWICH, Conn., June 11 -- Seldom does it fall to the lot of a youngster of 15 months to capture the highest award in a leading dog show. Probably it is something entirely new when it wins two days running at two of the most important exhibitions of the Summer season in this country.

BERLIN, June 11 -- Such speculative anticipation as German financial writers devote to the opening of the World Economic Conference tomorrow is occupied mainly with renewed emphasis upon the problem of leveling tariff barriers to facilitate the free flow of goods.

BOSTON, June 11 -- A crowd of 30,000 Bostonians jammed Fenway Park to the exit gates today and saw the Yanks rally to overcome the Red Sox, 8 to 7, then fall before the home club's onslaught, 11 to 9, in a six-inning second encounter.
NEW HAVEN, June 11 -- Six of the outstanding members of the Yale University faculty, whose service totals 163 years, will retire from active teaching this month.

By the President and by the entire country the Senate had distinctly been handed its hat. But that furnished only a new opportunity to talk through it. Senators found parting such "sweet sorrow" that they would fain keep on making speeches till it be norrow.

BERLIN, June 11. -- Provisional statutes governing the administration by the Reichsbank of the conversion fund into which German debtors will make their payments during the operation of the transfer moratorium have been drafted.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 11 -- Racing under conditions which were perfect for small-boat sailing, R.W. Fraser's Black Jack beat two rival Victory class sloops in the special regatta held by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today.

Ira Rae Brown, a bartender in a Yorkville beer, garden, and his wife are under arrest, charged with attempting to extort $4,700 from Mrs. George A. Fuller of 383 Park Avenue. Mrs. Fuller is the widow of George A. Fuller, of the construction company that bears his name.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 11 -- The John Drew Memorial Theatre of Guild Hall was filled last night, when the Guild Hall players presented Augustus Thomas's "Mizzoura," with a cast of fourteen East Hampton amateur players. Among the Summer colony members of the players are Jack Devereaux, who directed the play; Thomas Crane, who managed it, and Miss Ruth B. Moran of the play selecting committee.

LONDON, June 11 -- Two groups of European countries, unlike most of their neighbors, have been able to get together in advance of the opening of the economic conference tomorrow and decide what to ask for in the conference. They are the agrarian countries of Central Europe and the Scandinavian nations.

Detectives trailing a girl bandit and two men companions followed the wrong taxicab yesterday morning. The result was that the bandits got away, a detective got a punch in the jaw and two men were shot accidentally.

The mounting cost of unemployment relief in the city was emphasized yesterday in a report submitted to Frank J. Taylor, Commissioner of Public Welfare. It showed that $17,500,000 was spent for home relief in the first five months of 1933.

The average of New fork City's representation in the Legislature is "regrettably low," the Citizens Union declared yesterday. It made public the annual report of its committee on legislation on the records of the State Senators from New York City.

BERLIN, June 10. -- Thursday's official communique categorically admits the priority of the Dawes and Young loans; also the small cost of service which, even without any export surplus, would be covered by exchange receipts from shipping.

The usual attentive and appreciative audience, but with more than usual display of enthusiasm, assembled at the Little Theatre last evening to assist at the closing performance of the fourth season of the Teatro d'Arte. The attraction was Gino Rocca's three-act drama of Congo life, "Le Liane," a term which taken literally means a jungle plant -- the most indigenous yet errant in all botany -- or symbolically as "ties that bind."

CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- Al Simmons slugged Chicago to a 6 to 1 victory over Detroit in the first game of a double-header today, hitting two homers and driving in all of his team's runs. The Tigers, aided by four errors, took the nightcap, 5 to 3.

A team of cricketers from the Aquitania of the Cunard Line defeated an eleven of the Staten Island Cricket Club by 109 to 86 at Livingston, S.I., yesterday. J. Moffatt was in fine trim with the tat and compiled 58, top score of the match.

CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- Eugene James, 20-year-old jockey, who reached the goal of all riders -- a victory in the Kentucky Derby, on Colonel Edward R. Bradley's Burgoo King last year -- lost his life in Lake Michigan today.

Our glorification of the average man has brought the United States into spiritual bondage, declared Edmund Steimle, son of the Rev. Dr. Augustus Steimle, in a sermon yesterday morning in the Lutheran Church of St. James, Madison Avenue at Seventy-third Street.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls last week are given in the appended tabulation:

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- One year ago, in hot weather, almost 20,000 members of the "Bonus Army" were encamped in the capital city and in the suburbs urging the lost cause of the bonus; today no veterans arc here, but the Congressional excitement over the matter of financial aid for them is equally intense.

Verdi Brothers Cooperage Company, 68 Hudson St., Hoboken, one of the largest manufacturers of beer barrels in the country, brought from, the North Jersey Industrial Terminal a factory site containing about six acres on the north side of State Street, adjoining the Erie Railroad in the North Bergen industrial section.
Toronto scored its seventh and eighth straight victories of the season over Jersey City in a doubleheader at West Side Park yesterday, triumphing by 13 -- 7 and 5 -- 3.

ST. LOUIS, June 11 (AP) -- Snatching victory from an almost certain defeat in the first game, 11 to 7, the Pirates blanked the St. Louis Cardinals, 3 -- 0, in the second game, to sweep a double-header before 21,000 today.

LONDON, June 11 -- The greatest economic clinic of all time will open here tomorrow in an atmosphere in which expectation is the keynote and pessimism a strong undertone of the preliminary utterances. Everybody participating wants so much.
Billy Burke, former national open golf champion, was named last night to the tenth place on the American Ryder Cup team.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- New Jersey has staked out its claim for at least $90,000,000 of the government's $3,300,000,000 public works program.

LONDON, June 11 -- Determined to push the American plan for lifting price levels, delegates of the United States were ready tonight to plunge into the deliberations of the World Economic Conference which opens here tomorrow.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 11 -- "Nothing can make people really more intellectually stupid than a progressive accumulation of facts without wisdom, to interpret the facts and extract their vital meaning," the Rev. Dr. Vivian T. Pomeroy declared today at the Vassar College baccalaureate service.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 11 -- Flashing a strong, steady attack, the Templeton polo team defeated the Sands Point four today, 12 to 7.

Through the magic of new speeds in the air, copies of THE NEW YORK TIMES printed in New York this morning will be read in San Francisco tonight. And this will be accomplished through no special racing flight. Passengers, mails and air express go through from coast to coast with like celerity, now that United Air Lines has opened its new transcontinental service.

NEW HAVEN, June 11 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 62.7, which compares with 62.1 a week ago, 61.2 two weeks ago, 60.6 three weeks ago and 59.5 four weeks ago. The present average is the highest of the year to date; the average of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.
Praise of the Senators who on Saturday denounced Nazi anti-Semitism was expressed yesterday by delegates to the annual convention of the Federation of Polish Jews in America at the Hotel Astor.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- Nine persons, seven of them going skyward as passengers on a sight-seeing trip from the World's Fair, met death today in the flaming wreckage of a giant amphibian airplane in suburban Glenview.
Dropping into seventh place momentarily by losing yesterday's first game to the Braves, the Dodgers rallied to take the closing half of the double-header and pull themselves back into sixth position.

Gustave Wagner bought himself a home at 1,970 Bronxdale Avenue, the Bronx, with money he earned playing the trombone in Edwin Franko Goldman's band and in the Roxy Theatre Orchestra. There, for a time he lived happily with his wife, Louise, and her father, Dr. George Fisher, 76 years old, a retired dentist.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 11 -- Jews throughout America were asked to help finance the emigration of their German brethren to refuges in other lands by speakers here today at the annual convention of the Independent Order B'rith Abraham.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., June 11 -- The Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Oicognani, Apostolic Delegate, conferred the diplomas and made a brief address at the annual commencement of the Newman School here this afternoon. The ceremonies began with a mass at noon offered in a pine grove, followed by a luncheon served on the lawn.

LONDON, June 10. -- It cannot be said that the financial markets are deriving any inspiration from the approaching economic conference. Indeed, as it draws nearer, pessimism concerning its probable achievements increases. This is very largely due to the absence of any lead from the United States on the war debt question.
A young chimpanzee named Gua spent nine months recently in the home of Professor and Mrs. W. N. Kellogg with the same privileges and under the same restrictions as the Kellogg child, Donald.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 11 -- Members of the graduating class of the Yale Divinity School were told today by Professor Carl H. Kraeling that Christian ministers stand today "not above or against, but alongside of men of other professions, which are equally necessary to the conduct of life in this world of ours."

Princeton scored Its first victory of the season in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League Saturday, defeating Yale in the only circuit contest played during the week. The setback ended the Elis' chances of retaining their championship and gave the title to Columbia for the first time since the league was organized.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 11 -- The campaign to keep the Eighteenth Amendment in the Constitution has moved to Dixie, traditional bulwark of prohibition, where Alabama, Arkansas and Tennessee will vote next month on the question of repeal.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 11 -- Mrs. Vanderpoel Adriance was one oF the week-end hostesses entertaining at a contract bridge party at Winona, Williamstown. Mrs. Alfred C. Chapin later poured at the tea.

OAKDALE, L.T., June 11 -- The prediction that scholars would take a greater part in the civic, State and national affairs of the country, made twenty-five years ago by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, today is being carried out, Grover A. Whalen said today in his address to the members of the graduating class of De La Salle Military Academy, of which he is an alumnus.

SCHENECTADY, June 11 -- Ideals are sovereign, while the changing characteristics of the day are unsafe as a foundation, Dean Edward Ellery, acting president, told the graduating class of Union College in the baccalaureate sermon today.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- A substantial record of accomplishments of the various executive departments is disclosed by study of the critical days since President Roosevelt took office.

Henry Pringle, who won the 1932 Pulitzer Prize in biography with his life of Theodore Roosevelt, will spend the next two years working on a biography of William Howard Taft. He is to have access to account and appointment books, the frequent letters written by Mr. Taft to his wife, and copies of letters written in the White House, during the Bull Moose campaign of 1912 and during the World War.

A field of 101 players Is entered for the metropolitan amateur golf championship at the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing on Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday. The pairings and starting times for the qualifying round were announced yesterday by the Metropolitan Golf Association as follows:
