MADRID, June 11 -- President Niceto Alcala Zamora took a strong stand today in this crisis to set the course of the Spanish regime. When Indalecio Prieto, the Socialist leader, arrived at the palace about noon with the list of his government composed of proletarian party members and its sympathizers he was informed it was unacceptable since it did not include a representative of Alejandro Lerroux's Moderate party.
CHICAGO, June 11 -- Two New Yorkers have been tentatively identified among the victims of the World's Fair plane crash and at least one other is believed to have perished.

Leopold Godowsky, composer and pianist, and Roger Sessions, American composer, arrived yesterday on the Italian motorship Vulcania. Both had been in Berlin during the early days of the Hitler administration. They said German music had suffered irreparable damage during the Nazi program.

BALBOA, C.Z., June 11 -- Members of another Cocos Island expedition arrived here today in the schooner Franklyn Bennett with the owner and leader, E.U. Valentine, New York writer, aboard. Mr. Valentine's son, Ronald, a scientist, and Stanley Lewers, an engineer, also of New York, remained on the island.

NOME, Alaska, June 11 -- Crews of ships blocked by ice floes in the Bering Sea and the residents of all the scattered settlements in Western Alaska began today to scan the skies for sight of James Mattern. Volcanic smoke may guide him.

Senator VANDENBERG has a competent sense of humor; but the questions of ethics which he has raised in connection with the appearance before the microphone of Colonel HOWE, the President's secretary, might tempt inquiring minds into the mazes of scholastic subtlety.

CLEVELAND, June 11 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation staved off disaster to the United States in 1932, the most critical year of the depression, said Atlee Pomerene, former chairman of the corporation, in an interview yesterday.

The bass fishermen in this general locality can get busy on Thursday, when the season on this species of game fish opens in New Jersey. It will be fifteen days thereafter, however, before the bass anglers can ply their art in either New York State or Connecticut, both of which Commonwealths are as famous as New Jersey for their bass streams.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- In future discussions of why Congress last night refused to adjourn, despite the President's almost frantic efforts to that end, the blame will probably be laid to his eleventh-hour dispatch of the message on government reorganisation.

PITTSBURGH, June 11. -- Production of steel ingots in May, as officially reported by the American Iron and Steel Institute, was at 34.11 per cent of capacity, which was below all but one of the series of weekly estimates made by various authorities.

The revolutionary tempest that has shaken the church in Russia to its foundations was repeated in stormy miniature here yesterday. It broke out anew at the Church of All Nations, Second Street and Second Avenue, yesterday, in a verbal conflict between the Archbishop Benjamin, special exarch of the Moscow patriarchate, and followers of the Metropolitan Platon, head of the North American Diocese.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 11 -- The first special sailing regatta of the season at the Horseshoe Harbor yacht Club today attracted thirty-two starters. The number included Capecods, dories and wild ducks, as some of the small jib and mainsail boats are called.

NORTH ARLINGTON, N.J., June 11 -- The list of victims of the explosion of a cellulose sorting plant here Friday night reached ton today with the death at West Hudson Hospital in Kearny of Anna d' Aurillo, 6 years old of 277 Crystal Street here.
Five persons were drowned and two prostrated yesterday as the city continued to swelter in temperatures which, though more moderate than in the two previous days, still were far above the average.

PARIS, June 11 -- The departure of Premier Daladier and the rest of the French delegation to the London Economic Conference this morning coincided with a final burst of pessimism in the entire French press and in several important addresses today.

WEST POINT, June 11 -- Baccalaureate exercises were held at the United States Military Academy here today in the cadet chapel, which was thronged with visitors. Secretary of War Dern sat with the family of Major Gen. William D. Connor, superintendent of the academy.

Steel operations increased 1 point last week to 48 per cent of capaci- according to the magazine Steel. The most notable improvement, the magazine says, was a gain of 5 points, to 35 per cent, at Pittsburgh, where four more blast furnaces were started during the week.

Broad advances in silk and silver featured the week's trading on local commodity exchanges. As a result of Saturday's rally all staples except sugar and hides closed higher on the week in heavy trading. Cash prices also moved up.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 11 -- Ideals of richteousness in a disillusioned world were urged upon graduates of the University of Rochester today by the retiring president. Dr. Rush Rhees, in his baccalaureate address.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- A two-sided corn market is in evidence. One group of traders hold that corn is late in getting into the ground and is being planted under conditions likely to result in poor production. These traders believe in higher prices for wheat and are buying corn the supposition being that should wheat advance 5 to 10 cents a bushel more, corn is likely to sympathize to a liberal extent.

With June business far ahead of retailers expectations, reorders for seasonal merchandise were numerous in wholesale apparel markets here last week. Cotton dresses in one-piece and jacket styles were in demand. Buyers also called for dotted swiss and dark eyelet dresses in black, navy and brown dotted with white.

NEWARK, N.J., June 11 -- The new twenty-one-hour plane schedule to the West Coast was started here today by United Airlines with the departure of one of the new low-wing Boeing monoplanes at 12:30 P.M. The plane, with ten passengers on board, was due to arrive at Chicago at 4:40 P.M. and at San Franisco at 6:45 A.M. tomorrow.

Flying the monoplane Columbia, veteran of two transatlantic crossings, Captain J. Errol Boyd and two companions left Floyd Bennett Field yesterday for Port au Prince, Haiti. Planned as a good-will flight the plane was sent away by Charles B. Vincente, Consul General of Haiti in New York and a brother of the President of the island republic.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 11-- Seventy-one major letters were presented to fifty-nine athletes who participated in various sports at the United States Military Academy during the past year, it was announced today.

HAVANA, June 11 (AP) -- Cuban Army aviation officials said today they estimated the total distance of the Spain-to-Cuba non-stop flight by Captain Mariano Barberan and Lieutenant Joaquin Collar as 4,906 miles, of which some 4,500 miles were over water.
The United States and Great Britain must find a way to avoid insistence on either payment or default of the war debts due on Thursday, Walter Lippmann, writer and editor, declared yesterday.
NEWARK, N.J., June 11 -- Taking both games of the double-header with Newark, 6-0 and 3-0, Rochester today went into first place in the International League. The Bears dropped to second place.
CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- Coincident with their battle against repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment prohibition leaders are buttressing defenses around earlier won vietories.

Opposition to the imposition of toll charges on the Harlem and East River Bridges was expressed yesterday by J.J. Hackett Jr., secretary of the First Avenue Association. Confusion incidental to the collection of such bridge taxes would endanger the rental Income of about fifteen modern apartments on Fifty-seventh Street, from Second Avenue to Sutton Place, Mr. Hackett said.
LONDON, June 11 -- The French delegation, headed by Premier Daladier and the Germans, headed by Foreign Minister von Neurath, reached London tonight. They were among the last to arrive.

CINCINNATI, June 11 (AP) -- The Cubs won their first of six games played at Redland Field this season as they defeated the Reds today, 9 to 8, after dropping the first game of a double-header, 5 to 4.

LONDON, June 11 -- The British Government is reported to have made an informal suggestion to the French tonight that they, along with Great Britain, make a partial payment on the debt instalments due the United States Thursday, so as to place the chief debtors on the same footing.

THE Giants will be in Canton, N.Y., today, attending the graduation exercises at St. Lawrence University, where one of Professor Bill Terry's bright young men, Harold Schumacher, will be handed a sheepskin and welcomed into the ranks of the Bachelors of Science.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In all the discussion of gold repudiation there has so far been little or no reference to the part played by the central banking system of the country -- something, by the way, that we did not have in the Nineties.

Passenger traffic on the ships of the United States and American Merchant lines thus far this year shows a large increase over that of a year ago, according to J.P. Mahool, general passenger traffic manager of the Roosevelt Steamship Company, general agent of the lines.

A call to a State-wide conference on public expenditures was sent out yesterday to industrial, business and professional leaders by George W. Wickersham, chairman of the New York State Economic Council. The conference will be held Wednesday at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The dollar's decline on the international market was perhaps last week's outstanding occurrence. This fall to the previously unequaled discount of 19 per cent was noteworthy, not because it affected other domestic markets but because of the very singular character of the situation which it indicated.

Bishop Manning made his thirteenth annual visit yesterday to Welfare Island to confirm patients of the City Home and Neurological and Cancer Hospitals. Those who could walk or use wheel chairs were confirmed at the altar of the Chapel of the Good Shepherd.
Several of the Summer theatre groups which plan to operate in the more or leas remote sections of the adjacent countryside this season will get under way this week. Others already have started.

BERLIN, June 11 -- The organization of "race hygiene" in the new Germany has not progressed much beyond the problematic stage. Special departments for it have been established at the interior ministries of the Reich and Prussia, and medical men, detailed to them as experts, have here and there informed the public of ultimate aims.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- Fat lambs are bringing in the market here the highest prices since June, 1931. The top price last week was $8.75 a hundred pounds, on two days, or $1.75 higher than in the previous week. The week's average of $8.05 compared with $7 in the previous week, $6.25 a year ago, $7.75 two years ago and a five-year average of $12.05.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- With the birth rate now at the lowest level on record and statistics indicating an accelerated decline during 1933, the movement toward a stationary or a declining population in the United States seems to be gaining speed.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Senate investigators of J.P. Morgan Co. today disclosed evidence that members of the firm were directors of eighty-nine corporations and banks, with total assets of more than $20,000,000,000.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- An increasing disposition on the part of virtually all interests to anticipate requirements and at the same time to save money by obtaining good supplies of raw materials and manufactured goods is creating a larger volume of business in all lines.

HAVANA, June 11 -- Cuba welcomed her first transatlantic flyers at 4:40 o'clock this afternoon when the Spanish aviators, Captain Mariano Barberan and Lieutenant Joaquin Collar, landed at the city of Camaguey 39 hours 55 minutes after they had taken off from Seville, Spain.

MUNICH, June 11 -- Almost simultaneously with the proclamation from Catholic pulpits of the bishops' pastoral letter defining the place of the Catholic Church in Germany, the Nazi steamroller today flattened out the Gesellensche, the Catholic journeymen's congress here, after a series of clashes between Nazis and delegates.

BERLIN, June 11 -- The long-awaited pastoral letter of the Catholic Bishops of Germany, issuing from their recent annual conference at Fulda -- the burial place of Saint Boniface, first missionary to the heathen Germans -- and defining the Bishops' attitude toward the new regime in the Reich, was read from every Catholic pulpit today.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Louis McHenry Howe, secretary to President Roosevelt, in his second Sunday night radio address over the National Broadcasting System explained the operations of the Home Loan Bill, which became a law last night with the signature of the President.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., June 11 Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman and family will arrive at Green Harbour, the former Peabody estate on Green Island, about June 18 and expect to stay until the middle of September. The Governor, who is interested in motor-boat racing, has donated a cup for the New York State outboard motor boat championship, to be held July 8 and 9 at the sixth annual Finger Lakes regatta on Seneca Lake.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 11 -- Life is a continuous conquest, a battle internal rather than external, and "when peace comes life is over," President Cutten said in giving the baccalaureate sermon today before the graduating class of 203 at Colgate University.

AMSTERDAM, June 9. -- The Netherlands Bank lost in the last few weeks a considerable amount of gold. On April 18 gold holdings totaled 956,000,000 florins and on June 6 aggregated 835,000,000 gold, but the efflux has now stopped. The cause was only unfounded fears of the country leaving the gold standard.
The Sanitation Department Band, which was dispersed as an economy measure by former Commissioner William Schroeder Jr. last September, will be restored by Commissioner George McAneny.
A sermon on the benefits of laughter was delivered to the Society of Jewish Science, 150 West Eighty-fifth Street, yesterday by Rabbi Morris Lichtenstein.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent bill passed by the Board of Aldermen for an additional tax on motor vehicles caused me to make an Investigation.

DETROIT, June 11 -- Alien T. Burns, executive director of Community Chests and Councils, Inc., today announced a nation-wide mobilization of welfare services for the Fall, to be known as the 1933 Mobilization for Human Welfare. Today's session closed the annual conference of Community Chests and Councils at Dearborn, Mich.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., June 11 -- "Commercialism rampant, what Wordsworth described as 'getting and spending,' " was condemned as a vice of modern civilization here today by Dr. Robert J. Trevorrow, president of Centenary Collegiate Institute, in a baccalaureate sermon delivered to the students who will be graduated from the institute tomorrow.

MUNICH, June 11 -- Menacing Nazi storm troopers prevented Cardinal Faulhaber from holding solemn high mass today in connection with the Catholic journeymen's convention here, whose closing ceremonies were banned by the police after severe clashes last night bettween Nazis and Catholics.

CHICAGO, June 11. -- Grain prices have advanced to the highest level of the season and to the best in several years. Traders who base their opinions and operations on prevailing conditions. virtually ignoring the past, predict higher prices.

AURORA, N.Y., June 11 -- The disgrace of this period is that people should lack the necessities of life in a time of plenty, President MacMillan of Wells College declared today in the baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Under the caption "To Mark Centenary of Oxford Movement" an item appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES which must have given to the casual reader not familiar with the history of this movement more than one erroneous impression.

A round-up of known criminals in the city was begun by the police on Saturday, and by noon yesterday had netted sixteen arrests. Fourteen of those taken into custody were men with police records, and were picked up on vagrancy charges.

MANILA, June 11 -- Senators Manuel Quezon ana Sergio Osmena, when interviewed separately today, specifically denied that a compromise plan on Philippine independence had been reached. Each emphatically asserted that his original position was unchanged.

ALBANY, June 10 -- Governor Lehman in a letter made public today informed Captain Emil Greenberg, chairman of the special milk committee of the Community Councils of New York, that the Governor not only had no authority to prescribe rules for the State Milk Control Board but was unable to appoint a legislative committee to investigate the milk industry.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- President Roosevelt informed House and Senate leaders whom he summoned to a conference at the White House tonight that he would not modify his stand on allowances for veterans and was hopeful that Congress would enact his legislative program and adjourn late Monday night or Tuesday.

TRENTON, N.J., June 11 -- The New Jersey convention of the Continental Congress on Economic Reconstruction, meeting here today, heard Norman Thomas declare that Roosevelt was "no Mussolini" but that his economic program was "extraordinarily like the Italian program."

The Bar Association has been asked to call a special meeting about June 20 to consider resolutions condemning the designation of the Irving Trust Company as the sole receiver in bankruptcy for this district.

There will be nearly 5,000 more graduates this month in the city high schools than there were last June, according to preliminary estimates announced yesterday. The school principals have estimated that 34,012 will be graduated from senior and junior high schools, against 29,032 last year, an increase of 4,980.

Max Schmeling, former heavyweight champion of the world, who was knocked out by Max Baer last Thursday night, will sail for his native Germany tomorrow night aboard the New York of the Hamburg-American Line. Schmeling declared yesterday that he would be married in July to Miss Anny Ondra, a German motion picture and musical comedy actress.

POUGHKEEPSIE. N.Y., June 12. -- Praise for the Roosevelt administration for adapting its mental energies to the solution of national and international problems, for summoning "brains" to the service of Congress and for calling in academic advisers was voiced today by President MacCracken of Vassar College.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- President Roosevelt today addressed 1,000 farm boys from all sections of the country who are members of the Future Farmers of America and enjoined them to devote themselves to their timberlands so as to make timber as much a farm crop as wheat, cotton and potatoes.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Congressional leaders tonight had reconstructed adjournment plans sufficiently to warrant their expectation that the end of the special session would come tomorrow or Wednesday, despite the veiled threat of one or two Senators to stay past the due date of the next war-debt payment on June 15.
Two industries reported yesterday preparations to facilitate expansion of the nation's business under Federal supervision.

The first triple of the Belmont Park meeting, which will end Saturday, was accounted for yesterday by Hank Mills, who got home first with William Ziegler Jr.'s Zipalong, the B.B. Stable's Cabezo and H. C. Phipps's Balios.
Here is real news for trout fishermen. The drought which has interfered with fishing in streams in the Catskills has been broken and the rains have cleared the so-called frog spawn.

The Church Pension Fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church paid annual pensions aggregating $1,22,705.27 in 1932 to 1,662 clergymen their beneficiaries. The total, per cent larger than that of 1931, or the first time passed the 51,00,000 mark despite the depresion.
CANTON. N.Y., June 12. -- Helped by home runs delivered by Terry, Leslie and Ott, the Giants defeated St. Lawrence University today, 12 to 4, in an exhibition game.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., June 12. -- Principles which would serve mankind as charts and compasses for the future were outlined today at the commencement exercises of the Carnegie Institute of Technology by Dr. John C. Merriam, president of the Carnegie Institution in Washington, D.C. Degrees, diplomas and certificates were awarded to 583 graduates at the exercises in Syria Mosque.

Commodities traded on local exchanges moved irregularly yesterday in active trading. Silver, silk, cocoa and coffee scored clear gains. Hides were irregular and sugar and rubber were lower. In the cash markets most prices were higher.

In the largest security auction since 1929 the Chase Bank yesterday realized more than $23,240,000 in selling the collateral behind its loan to Continental Shares, Inc. The loan, originally approximately $33,500,000, had been reduced to about $27,000,000.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- A flag of the National Geographic Society was presented to Lincoln Ellsworth to be taken to the Far South on his forthcoming flight of exploration over the Antarctic Continent. The gift was made by the trustees of the organization at a luncheon in Mr. Ellsworth's honor.

BLAIRSTOWN, N.Y., June 12. -- The Rev. Dr. Robert R. Wicks, dean of the University Chapel, Princeton, was the speaker today at the commencement exercises of Blair Academy, held in the chapel on the campus. He told the thirty-five graduates that the youth of today must find some real interest in life and strive for the "beauty of perfection."

CHICAGO, June 12. -- Directors of the Farmers National Grain Corporation, huge cooperative marketing agency, demanded today that the Federal Government set in motion immediately the relief measures of the Agricultural Adjustment Act.
Manhattan College will confer 224 degrees at its eightieth commencement in Riverdale this afternoon. The academic procession will start at 3:30 o'clock. Bishop John J. Dunn will preside.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Despite the powerful attempt to induce Congress to adjourn before proposals for revision of the war debts arrive from abroad, the issue must probably come to a head in the superheated political atmosphere of the last hours of the session.

BOSTON, Mass., June 12. -- The Boston News Bureau says tonight that while the prospective decentralization of Drug, Inc., may be delayed some time because of legal difficulties growing out of taxes and other matters, some thought has been given to the number and identity of the blocks into which stock of Drug, Inc., numbering 3,501,499 shares, may be split.

The dollar fell here yesterday to a new low value of 80.4 cents in terms of the French franc. In the face of the efforts being made in London to reach an agreement for de facto stabilization of exchanges, the foreign exchange market experienced one of the wildest and most active days since the suspension of the gold standard here.

LONDON, June 12 (By Wireless). -- The opening of the World Economic Conference took place in what might be called a blaze of symbolism, for, curiously, events shaped themselves into significances intensely modern, yet holding ancient forms.

CANTON, N.Y., June 12. -- Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury under President Hoover, told alumni and new graduates of St. Lawrence University here today that centralized Federal control over hundreds of thousands of small businesses would be "not only intolerable, but impracticable."

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Plans to merge the Bureau of Prohibition with the Bureau of Investigation, as an important step in reorganization of the Department of Justice, were announced today by Attorney General Cummings.
NEWARK, N.J., June 12. -- The twenty-fifth commencement of the New Jersey Law School will be held at the Old First Presbyterian Church here tomorrow night when 165 seniors will receive degrees.

Twenty elementary school choruses, comprising about 1,500 children, will meet in the final competition of the season in Town Hall this afternoon at 2 o'clock. The event will mark the end of the season's music contests in public schools under the joint sponsorship of the New York Music Week Association and the Board of Education.

LONDON, June 12. -- The prospects for a world agreement to restrict wheat production do not look bright on this first day of the World Economic Conference. European grain countries have declared in advance their willingness to reduce their output and they believe the first step in this direction should be taken by overseas producers.

An attempt to control the result of the featured Broomstick Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday by tampering with the favorite was frustrated by racing officials and others. An investigation disclosed that the 6-year-old mare Con Amore had been sponged.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Is there not some way whereby Tammany politicians can be enjoined from using the public streets and bridges as speedways, violating speed laws and even going to the length of ordering policemen on motorcycles to escort them?
LONDON, June 12. -- Following is the full text of the speech of King George today opening the World Economic Conference:

LONDON, Tuesday, June 13. -- After a day filled with rumors as to the course of the war debts talks between Washington and London, a meeting of the British Cabinet was abruptly called late last night. It began at 10 Downing Street at 11 P.M. and lasted until almost midnight.

BUFFALO, June 12. -- The church in depression days ranks as a galvanic battery whose force has run down, the Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler of New York City declared tonight in a sermon opening a convention of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, of which he is the president.

A pneumatic-tired railroad car, made by the Austro-Daimler automotive plant in Vienna, Austria, and shipped to this country last month at the direction of E.K. Howe Sons, had a trial run yesterday morning on the tracks of the Long Island Railroad from Jamaica to Babylon.

LONDON, June 12. -- Stabilization of the dollar, the English pound and the French franc for the period of the conference was forecast late today by high financial authorities in close touch with the British delegation. This stabilization, viewed as the first definite accomplishment of the parley, would permit movement of the three currencies within a wide range in order to conciliate opposing views, the authorities said.
Joan Lowell came out of the sea again yesterday.
Jim Browning is still the world's heavyweight wrestling champion, after grappling almost two hours with Jumping Joe Savoldi, former Notre Dame football star, at the Yankee Stadium last night.

PARIS, June 12. -- No decision has yet been taken regarding France's war debt instalment to the United States, due Thursday, it was stated in official quarters today. In any case, since Premier Daladier and half of his Cabinet are now in London, it is there that final decision will be taken.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 12. -- The Roosevelt administration and Christian leaders throughout America are called upon to join in the fight for German Jewish rights as a fight for humanity, in resolutions adopted today by 100 delegates at the annual convention of the Independent Order B'rith Abraham.

LONDON, June 12 (Canadian Press). -- West Indies was well on its way to a smashing victory over Middlesex in their cricket match when the second day's play closed tonight. The scores were: British West Indies, 382 and 251 for five, declared; Middlesex, 178 and 7 for no wickets.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- How the government's $900,000,000 financing was jeopardized by a Senate amendment to the National Industry Recovery Act proposing to tax-exempt securities, and how the Treasury helped to obtain elimination of this amendment was disclosed today.

Time money tightened, all maturities moving up 1/4 and lenders practically withdrew their offerings of sixty-ninety day funds. The firmer undertone was ascribed to the demands made by brokers to meet customers' requirements in the prevailing rise in stocks.

BASE CAMP, Mount Everest, June 12 (via Mount Everest Wireless Station). -- The state of the climbing parties has now made a rest at the base camp essential, as all are slightly frostbitten and all, except Frank S. Smythe, have suffered a slight dilation of the heart.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Amos Tuck French have come from Dexter House, Chester, N.H., and are at the Pierre to meet Mrs. French's sister. Lady Cheylesmore, who is arriving on the Majestic.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP). -- Eugene Meyer, former governor of the Federal Reserve Board, announced tonight that he was the sole stock owner of The Washington Post, which was sold at auction last week for $825,000.

LONDON, June 12. -- Like the conference itself, the broadcast of the King's opening address was the biggest ever organized, hundreds of thousands of kilowatts being expended throughout the world in conveying the speech to millions of listeners.

It has been well understood that President ROOSEVELT'S selection of an Ambassador to represent the United States in Berlin had long given him pause. The difficulty of filling the position became plain after the events in Germany last March, with their sequels. But the wait of three months has ended in the happy choice of Professor WILLIAM E. DODD of Chicago University.
Jersey City lost its third game in a row to Toronto at Jersey City yesterday when the Leafs triumphed by 6 to 3.

DARJEELING, India, June 12. -- The wireless arrangements in connection with the Mount Everest climbing expedition continue to be very satisfactory. Here, where the main station is situated, incoming and outgoing messages for the personnel of the expedition are being sent daily, while cables from London conveying messages to members are cleared in twentyfour hours.

A total of 1,713 steam and motor vessels aggregating 9,452,875 tons constitutes the American coastwise and foreign merchant fleet, and of these 660 vessels of 3,407,790 tons are laid up, according to the quarterly statement of the American Bureau of Shipping.

After its president and the chairman of its board of directors had walked out in protest against what they charged was a meeting packed by Tammany, the New York Young Democratic Club adopted a resolution at the Hotel Shelton last night rescinding and deploring a resolution adopted May 12 which urged the drafting of former Governor Smith for Mayor.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 90 leading cities on June 7 shows increases for the week of $59,000,000 in loans and investments, $65,000,000 in net demand deposits and $12,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, and decreases of $7,000,000 in time deposits, $37,000,000 in government deposits and $16,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks.

PARIS, June 12. -- Western Europe's largest dam, at Sarrana, across the swift flowing Truyere in one of Southern France's picturesque gorges, was inaugurated today in the presence of President Lebrun, who as a young man aspired to an engineering career before he entered politics.
SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 12. -- Mount Holyoke College conferred four honorary degrees, nineteen graduate degrees, and 225 degrees of Bachelor of Arts, at its commencement today.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 12. -- The Long Island Golf Association's president, W. Neal Fulkerson, and the Cherry Valley Club's professional, Jimmy Law, carried off the honors in the association's amateur-professional tourney at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today.

LIMA, Peru, June 12. -- Lima heard a radio broadcast from London for the first time today during the speeches of King George and Prime Minister MacDonald at the opening of the economic conference. The speeches arrived by rebroadcasts through Madrid and Buenos Aires.

An indeterminate term of not more than three years in the penitentiary was imposed yesterday in Special Sessions on Frank Salomone, 58 years old, of 432 East Eleventh Street, because he obtained unemployment relief amounting to $117.50 when his wife had $7,500 on deposit in two banks.

The State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board met in executive session yesterday in its offices at 80 Center Street and approved more than 600 licenses for the retail sales of 3.2 per cent beer and wine. Most of the applications were from chain grocery stores.
Completion of a government post-office purchase and various housing deals comprised the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 12. -- Fifteen members of the Princeton varsity and freshman track teams were awarded Keene Fitzpatrick Medals and 161 athletic insignia were granted in the Spring sports awards announced today by the Princeton Athletic Association.

LONDON, June 12. -- The Marylebone Cricket Club, governing body of the game, tonight denied charges of the Australian Cricket Board of Control that English bowling in last Winter's test matches had been unfair. It warned the Antipodeans that continuance of "barracking" might result in the cessation of test matches between the two countries.

One of the largest and most important investment deals of the year on the east side of Manhattan was closed yesterday when the property at 156 to 164 East Twenty-fourth Street was sold for all cash as a site for a six-story apartment house.
NEWTON, Mass., June 12. -- Boston College won the second game of the series with the Holy Cross Crusaders today, 6 to 5. Each team now has won a game and the play-off will be at Worcester on June 20.

Testimony that a $47,000,000 deficit of the closed Bank of United States had been reduced $1,000,000 since February was given yesterday by Joseph A. Broderick, State Banking Superintendent. He testified at a suit against bank stockholders to collect an assessment of $25 a share.

NEW HAVEN, June 12. -- The Rev. Dr. Horace Bushnell, who, as Hartford pastor, became a national figure as theologian and statesman, was praised at the anniversary exercises of the Yale Divinity School today as "the preachers' preacher, who helped mightily to emancipate his generation from bondage to a traditional theology."

WEST NEWTON, Mass., June 12. -- Miss Dorothy Hunter, the 18-year-old Massachusetts junior champion, assumed the leadership at the half-way mark of the women's Eastern golf championship today. She scored a 78 at the remodeled Brae Burn course.

All sections of the bond market on the Stock Exchange manifested considerable strength yesterday, although the volume of trading was somewhat less than on most days last week. A representative list of domestic corporation bonds advanced 1 to more than 4 points and a few pushed even higher.

MADRID, June 12. -- Manuel Azana, the strong man of the Spanish republic, who abhors the name of dictator, definitely exerted his power by publishing a Cabinet list today which he enforced on President Niceto Alcala Zamora and now intends to use to execute the church laws taking from 80,000 monks and nuns the right to teach and establishing the seizure of church property.

In connection with the twentieth annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards in Chicago this week the first annual meeting will open there today of the American Institution of Real Estate Appraisers. The conference, which will continue for two days, is expected to be attended by 500 experts from all parts of the country.

ST. LOUIS, June 12 (AP). -- Suit against the National Retail Credit Association, with headquarters here, was filed by the government today, an injunction against alleged monopolistic practices of the association being asked.
A veteran of the old navy who helped to form the new will celebrate his seventy-ninth birthday today by trying to keep "reasonably cool" in his Hotel Commodore room.
Nameless the Horse will never walk in green pastures, but neither will he pull a rickety old wagon on blistering days.

A few more Summer theatrical groups announced their plans yesterday. On Aug. 2, H.C. Potter and George Haight will launch the seventh season of the Hampton Players in Southampton, L.I. Besides appearing in Southampton, the company also will be seen in East Hampton, Quogue and West-hampton Beach.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- President Roosevelt served notice on Congress tonight that unless a final compromise on veterans' benefits satisfactory to him was worked out he would deliver a veto message in person and at the same time broadcast it to the nation.
CANTON, N.Y., June 12. -- Hal Schumacher, New York Giants' pitcher, received a B.S. degrees at St. Lawrence University today. His team mates attended the commencement.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Tribute to the leadership of President Roosevelt and to the cooperation with him of all branches of the government in the work of industrial recovery was paid today by Martin Conboy of New Yark in an address at the 134th annual commencement of Georgetown University.
With five members of the Eastern first ten in the lists, the women's New York State tennis championship got under way yesterday on the courts of the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 12. -- Sultry heat again prevailed at the camps of Yale and Harvard today and cut short some of the work planned in preparation for Friday's regatta.

One of the baleful indirect effects of Mayor O'BRIEN'S indefensible program of new city taxes without compensating reductions in expenditures has been to fan the embers of resentment against the payment of all taxes, old and new alike, at the very moment when efforts should be redoubled to collect the large amounts now in arrears.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 12. -- By virtue of halving its match with the Hempstead G.C. team, Pomonok Country Club's representatives today clinched the season's honors of the second division, Class B section, of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- The formation of great corporations to operate in the real estate field was predicted today by Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association Real state Boards, in his annual statement before the board of directors.

LONDON, June 12. -- The inevitable jokes provoked by the meeting of the World Economic Conference in a Geological Museum lost much of their point from the fact that this South Kensington structure is brand new.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 12 (AP). -- Grantham's long triple in the seventh, with two out and the bases full, proved the deciding factor in a loosely played game today and enabled the Reds to defeat the Cubs, 6 to 5, in the third game of their series.
CHICAGO, June 12 (AP). -- A field horse, the Lone Star Stable's Sand-wrack, won the opening-day feature at Lincoln Fields today. The race was the Ravenswood Purse at a mile and a sixteenth.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 12. -- Diplomas were awarded to twenty-two graduates today at the annual comencement at Hackley School. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman of Brooklyn urged the graduates to remember that life's greatest asset "is a clean, wholesome imagination aspiring to new ideals."

BETHLEHEM, Pa., June 12. -- One of the largest classes in its history will be graduated from Lehigh University here tomorrow when 296 degrees will be conferred at the sixty-fifth annual commencement. This list includes four honorary and forty-three masters' degrees.

The regional committees provided for by the railroad bill awaiting President Roosevelt's signature are to be selected at a meeting of the Association of Railway Executives in Chicago on Thursday. The committees are to represent respectively the East, West and Southeast.
RENO, Nev., June 12. -- Mrs. Miriam Hostetter Young obtained a divorce today from Charles Fuller Young, New York broker, at Fallon, Nev.
Two men returning from a picnic in the Bronx were killed yesterday by a bolt of lightning. They had taken refuge under a tree from one of a series of thunderstorms that swept across the city.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- The caution with, which President Roosevelt has treated the war debt question was intensified today, apparently as a result of the failure of Congress to adjourn. A formal proposal is expected from Great Britain tomorrow, but one of the President's advisers intimated late this afternoon that even this official step might not bring any expression of approval or disapproval from the Chief Executive.

LONDON, June 12. -- A near-record field of 287 and a record foreign entry of 34, including 14 leading United States amateurs and professionals, today was announced for the British open golf championship, to be played at St. Andrews, Scotland, July 3-7.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12. -- Seventh place yawned and received the Dodgers again today as they fell before the last-place Phillies, 7 to 4. The Braves, by the much less exhausting process of remaining idle, advanced into sixth position.

GENEVA, N.Y., June 12. -- The opportunity of youth is to put man's mechanical mastery to work in the interest of his ultimate ideals, graduates of Hobart and William Smith Colleges were told here today. The speaker at the joint exercises was Roland S. Morris of Philadelphia, Professor of International Law at the University of Pennsylvania, and former Ambassador to Japan.

Murray C. Harwood, convicted bucket shop operator, failed yesterday in an attempt to commit suicide while he was running down a flight of iron stairs in the old Federal Building on Park Row, with Deputy United States Marshals panting in pursuit.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated irregularly over a range of about $1 a bale for several hours yesterday under active realizing, but the market strengthened in the last hour in sympathy with stocks and grains and closed at gains of 9 to 16 points.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, June 12 (AP). -- Captain. J. Serrol Boyd and two companions, bound from New York to Port au Prince, made a forced landing near St. Marc. Haiti, tonight. Advices reaching here said all were safe.
DETROIT, June 12. -- The National Conference of Social Work opened here today and will continue throughout the week. More than 4,000 delegates are present from all sections of the world.

Speculation B.B to what Equipoise will have to carry in the Brooklyn Handicap if he is to annex the triple crown of Metropolitan, Suburban and Brooklyn has caused many to think that he should have at least 135 pounds up. This would be a three-pound addition over his Suburban weight.
A revival of "The Climax" will open this evening at the Bijou Theatre. The two chief members of the cast are Guy Bates Post and Norma Terris.

Diego Rivera has joined the editorial staff of The Modern Monthly and will act as its art editor, V. F. Calverton announced yesterday. Rivera, whose Rockefeller City and Detroit murals are pictured in the current issue of The Modern Monthly, is now at work on a new cover for the magazine.

Crosby Gaige braved last evening the earthly tremors of Summer along Forty-second Street. They are, as they say, many and various. In an attempt to shove them into their proper places he set forth "Shooting Star," mounting it upon the steaming boards of the Selwyn Theatre.
Commencement exercises of the Fordham University School of Law will be held this afternoon at 4 o'clock on the university campus in the Bronx.

After a stormy session yesterday in which speakers recorded their opposition to Mayor O'Brien's motor vehicle tax program in the ratio of five to one, the Board of Estimate postponed formal action, pending an executive session today.

Week Starts Actively Here. The volume of business received through the mail in this market yesterday was again heavy. Reorders were numerous for Summer apparel and accessories, although there were reports that the record temperatures experienced in many centres last week hampered rather than aided trade.

Four mottled, grayish ladies and gentlemen who arrived in this country May 30 after a journey in a tin can from Saxony made their formal debut before the New York public yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History.

BERLIN, June 12. -- The Boerse opened weak and listless today and remained so until the closing. The volume of business was light and stocks generally sagged, but the average decline was small and the maximum did not exceed 3 points. On such stocks as Bremen Wool and Englehardt Brewery, specai demands produced gains of 2 points each.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 12. -- Frank Dreger, a 61-year-old burglary suspect, was questioned for hours tonight by Barren Hill, District Attorney of Suffolk County, L.I., in the possibility that he was the slayer of Benjamin Ceilings, who was thrown overboard from his yacht Sept. 10, 1931.

HAVANA, June 12. -- Captain Mariano Barberan and Lieutenant Joaquin Collar, the Spanish fliers who landed yesterday at Camaguey City, when their fuel ran short on a nonstop flight from Seville, Spain, brought their plane, the Cuatro Vientos, down at the Camp Columbia army airport this afternoon at 5:10 o'clock.

Whatever may have been the early attitude on the Stock Exchange with respect to the World Economic Conference as a "market stimulus," the feeling in the afternoon, as Wall Street seemed to express it, was that much might be expected. At any rate the swift and broad recovery on the Exchange was associated with the vague London news.
LONDON, June 12. -- Following is the text of Prime Minister MacDonald's opening speech to the World Economic Conference:
WASHINGTON, June 12. -- The text of Secretary Hull's address tolight at the British Government dinner in London was given out by the State Department as follows:

BOSTON, June 12 (AP). -- "The typical man of today finds his greatness in the greatness of the corporation he serves," Dean Roscoe Pound of the Harvard Law School declared today in an address at the Boston University commencement.

Dr. and Mrs. Peter E. de Rees of London, who will sail tomorrow night on the Majestic, gave a farewell dinner last night in the roof garden of the St. Regis. The guests were seated at a long table with a large ship in the centre. In the party were:

ALFRED, N.Y., June 12. -- Governor Herbert H. Lehman, on behalf of New York State, dedicated today the new $175,000 building of the State College of Ceramics at Alfred University and presented it formally to the university. This was his first visit to Alfred.
LONDON, June 12. -- Negotiations for a temporary stabilization of the dollar and pound continued in great secrecy today without concrete result or the loss of patience.

LONDON, June 12. -- The London public, accustomed to pageants and uniforms, was puzzled and unenthuslastic today over the World Economic Conference, which outwardly looked like a somber collection, of all the world's morning coats.

LONDON, June 12. -- This world conference which the League of Nations is holding in London contrasts strongly in some respects with the democratic, "informal" gatherings which the League has held at Geneva.
The round-up of known criminals in the city, begun last Saturday by Commissioner Bolan, netted seven more arrests yesterday, bringing the total to twenty-three.
In the Fossil Cases. The World Monetary and Economic Conference was opened yesterday in the new Geological Museum, South Kensington, London.
The New York Curb Exchange announced yesterday that it had suspended dealings in Pilot Radio and Tube Corporation Class A stock until further notice.

The two Republican Assemblymen from New York City were commended by the committee on legislation of the Citizens Union in its annual report on the individual records of Manhattan and Bronx Assemblymen, made public yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 12. -- In keeping with his announced intention of producing new plays in the spirit of experimental venture, Herbert J. Biberman presented this evening at the Westchester County Centre a drama in three acts, with accompanying dance and musical interludes, entitled "Iron Flowers."
Joseph P. Rend, brother-in-law of Charles E. Mitchell, testified for the defense at the Mitchell trial yesterday.

LONDON, June 12. -- Outspoken criticism of Prime Minister MacDonald's injection of the explosive debt issue at the very outset of the World Economic Conference, from which the topic was barred, was uttered tonight in the ranks of the United States delegates.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Our political leaders are said to believe that a reduction in the gold content of the dollar would give us trade advantages and that a threat of such reduction would enable us to strike a bargain at the international economics conference in London.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 12. -- Degrees of doctor of laws were awarded in absentia today by Colgate University to two men now representing their governments at the world economic conference in London. They are George Leslie Harrison, Governor of the Federal Reserve Bank in New York, and Edgar Rhodes, Canadian Minister of Finance.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 12. -- A new American federalism, ushering in an industrial democracy representative of the great middle class as well as of capital and labor, was envisaged today by Judge Samuel Seabury of New York City in his commencement address at the University of Rochester.

The Chesapeake Corporation has pledged 21.1 per cent of the common stock of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway for bank loans, according to the annual report of the holding company. This discloses that the corporation had 1,617,208 C. O. common shares pledged for loans and accounts payable on Dec. 31, compared with 7,652,655 C. O. shares outstanding.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12. -- The holdings of Cyrus H.K. Curtis in his extensive publishing domain, embracing four newspapers and three magazines, are to be administered by a board of seven trustees under terms of his will filed for probate today at Norristown.

The consideration paid by the Lehigh Valley Railroad for the $8,000,000 Starrett-Lehigh Building acquired last year was the assumption of the $4,500,000 mortgage on the land and building, the annual report of the railroad shows. The property, which is at West Twenty-seventh Street and Thirteenth Avenue, is used by the railroad as a yard.

SCHENECTADY, June 12. -- The bases upon which Woodrow Wilson sought to establish a permanent peace have been rejected by the peoples of the world in the fourteen years since the peace conference, Walter Lippman, political writer, told the graduating class of Union College today.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 12. -- Those members of the Summer colony and others who are interested in duplicate bridge will have an opportunity to join a regular club this Summer. Such an organization is being formed by Mrs. Lorillard Spencer, Mrs. Daniel W. Jones, Mrs. G.F. Elliott and a number of others to be known as the Chat Souris Dinner and Bridge Club.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- A complete agreement on the Glass-Steagall Banking Reform Bill, including a new plan for insurance of deposits, was reached by the conferees this afternoon after two and a half weeks of intensive discussion.

Two mortgage companies have been formed as wholly owned subsidiaries of the United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company in connection with the plan for refinancing mortgage companies whose bonds are secured by mortgages guaranteed by United States Fidelity and Guaranty and by the Maryland Casualty Company.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., June 12. -- Bryn Mawr College will hold its forty-eighth commencement tomorrow morning in Goodhart Hall. Dr. Mary E. Woolley, president of Mount Holyoke College, will deliver the address on "An Age of Power."

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- By a vote of 125 to 29 today the House authorized the Committee on Judiciary to make a sweeping investigation of the bankruptcy and receivership activities of Federal District Courts.

A new issue of $2,000,000 Jackson County (Mo.) court house bonds due serially on Jan. 1, 1942 to 1953, was awarded yesterday to a syndicate comprising the Guaranty Company of New York, N.W. Harris Company, Inc., Mercantile Commerce Company of St. Louis, Boatmen's National Bank of St. Louis, Commerce Trust Company of Kansas City and Stern Brothers Co., Kansas City.

Drunken killings, formally photographed lynching parties and Shakespeare read by camp-fire light are described by Colonel A. A. Anderson in his autobiographical "Experiences and Impressions," published today by Macmillan.

Three neatly dressed young men between the ages of 25 and 30 years were found bound, gagged and stabbed to death late last night in a furnished apartment on the second floor of a five-story tenemen't at 250 East Sixty-fifth Street. They evidently had been slain Saturday or Sunday.

LONDON, June 12. -- The necessity for "economic peace" to open the way for the fullest development of all nations was emphasized tonight by Secretary of State Cordell Hull in an address at the British Government's dinner in honor of the delegates to the World Monetary and Economic Conference.

How can the Senate ever bear to adjourn? Its addiction to its own rambling and everlastingly loquacious habits seems hard to break. On Saturday it put in a long day talking about things in general and particular. Mr. ROOSEVELT'S message on reorganization of the departments came in.

The attack by the Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen of the Westminster Theological Seminary, Philadelphia, and others on the Rev. Dr. Robert E. Speer, senior secretary of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, at the General Assembly of the church at Columbus last month was denounced here yesterday.

MOSCOW, June 12. -- The newspapers Izvestia and Pravda both devote their leading editorials today to the London economic conference. The Pravda asserts that world capitalism is trying simultaneously to raise prices by inflationary methods and to achieve currency stabilization, which are held to be contradictory, or, as the Pravda puts it, an "attempt to square the circle," the phrase which captions the editorial.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Gold hoarders were labeled "slackers" today by Attorney General Cummings in announcing that Department of Justice investigations had "turned up" so far ninety-five persons who refused to surrender $660,601 of gold which they admitted possessing.
AURORA, N.Y., June 12. -- Senior ivy exercises were held on the Wells College campus here today, with Margaret Latimer, president of the graduating class, as speaker.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- President Roosevelt is understood to have indicated to officials of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration at a White House conference today that their decision on policies to be applied to this year's cotton and wheat crops should not be announced until after the adjournment of Congress.

LONDON, June 12. -- Dr. Englebert Dollfuss, Austria's 40-year-old 4-foot 11-inch Chancellor, told an applauding crowd of World Economic Conference newspaper men today how tourists from the English-speaking world, by bolstering Austria's finances, could help keep Hitlerism out of the last stronghold of traditional German culture.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the interests of truth and of the good name of a worthy municipal institution, permit me to correct a seriously unjust impression which is likely to be left by Mr. Lewinson's letter in THE TIMES.

In flying from Seville to Cuba the Spanish-built and Spanish-engined Cuatro Vientos, Captain BARBERAN and Lieutenant COLLAR have broken the record across the Atlantic for distance and time. For the encouragement of aviation Spain needed an achievement like this.

Three investment trusts of the management type have been formed under the sponsorship of John Nickerson Co., Inc., it was announced yesterday. One trust is designed "to provide a sound investment medium"; the second, for "profit potentialities from a diversified list of securities likely to benefit from inflation," and the third, for "large profit possibilities from the securities of a group of public utility companies, the common stocks of which have been drastically liquidated."

NEWARK, June 12. -- Driving Ed Heusser from the mound by a first-inning attack, the Newark Bears defeated the Rochester Red Wings today, 7 to 5, and climbed back into a tie with their opponents for first place in the International League race.

VIENNA, June 12. -- Following upon yesterday's attempts to assassinate Dr. Richard Steidle, Tyrol Helmwehr leader, and Dr. Anton Rintelen, Governor of Styria, Austrian Nazis indulged today in a campaign of violence (in the absence of Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss in London) which resulted in the closing tonight of all the Brown Houses of the Nazis throughout Austria.

While the undercurrent of pessimism which surrounded the World Economic Conference at its opening yesterday cast an occasional shadow over the speculative markets, the Wall Street viewpoint at the close of the day was one of hopefulness.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 12. -- Hospital contracts with groups to supply medical care at a fixed annual rate were decried in a report to the American Medical Association, convening in its eighty-fourth annual session here today, as a form of medical "profiteering."

Monroe Percy Bloch, directing counsel of the Election. Frauds Bureau of the Republican State Committee, charged yesterday that District Attorney Thomas C.T. Crain had been lax in prosecuting persons indicted for election law violations.

David B. Costuma, campaign manager for the group seeking to oust Samuel S. Koenig as chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, charged yesterday that district leaders friendly to Mr. Koenig were removing veteran election inspectors who were opposed to the re-election of the county chairman.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 12. -- Seventy-five representatives of New Jersey labor assembled on the campus of Rutgers University, this afternoon, for their third yearly conference on national economic problems affecting labor. In the first session of the four-day conference, the background material was discussed for this year's topic, "Labor and the World Economic Problem."
Plans to bring more than $8,000,000 worth of French wines into this country on the day prohibition is repealed were disclosed yesterday by Louis H.F. Mouquin.

LONDON, June 12. -- Into the World Economic Conference within an hour of its assembly this afternoon, there crept like Banquo's ghost to the banquet the dreaded spectre of the international war debts. Tonight it is the feature of the headlines under which the newspapers report the opening of this greatest of all international gatherings, called to restore peace and prosperity to a stricken world.

BERLIN, June 12. -- Indications multiply that the National Socialist rulers of Germany, who have conquered all the political, social and economic organizations of the country in their first revolutionary onslaught, now face a severe struggle with the churches.

CHICAGO, June 12 (AP). -- Evidence which authorities said might lead to prosecution of charges of criminal negligence was reported today in inquiries into the crash of a World's Fair sightseeing plane that killed seven men and two women.

David B. Costuma, campaign manager for the group seeking to oust Samuel S. Koenig as chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, charged yesterday that district leaders friendly to Mr. Koenig were removing veteran election inspectors who were opposed to the re-election of the county chairman.

The New York Central reduced its net deficit in May, according to preliminary estimates. The net loss for May is set at about $500,000, against a net loss of $4,000,000 in May, 1932, and $1,800,000 in April this year. Gross revenues in May were ahead of those in May, 1932.

LONDON, June 13 -- The small nations of Europe turned longing eyes tonight toward Rome and a possible bloc under Benito Mussolini's strong-arm dictatorship as the big powers, squabbling over war debts and stabilization, threatened the progress of the World Economic Conference.

Slight Drop in Buyers Here. The number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a slight drop in comparison with the number listed in the preceding week but continued above the total reached in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

The violation committee of the State Board of Optometry, continuing its efforts to stamp out fraudulent advertising and other abuses, held preliminary public hearings at the State Office Building yesterday on ten cases presented by Leo M. Mayer, State Optometry Inspector.

Encouraged by the growing protest against the proposed automobile tax of the O'Brien administration, representatives of anti-Tammany political and civic groups discussed yesterday possible fusion candidates for Mayor. More than twenty-five names received consideration at a luncheon meeting at the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, 65 Liberty Street, but no conclusion was reached.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., June 13 -- A discussion of public affairs of the United States today in terms of ordinary party politics woud be as obsolete as to deal with them in terms of Abolition and Pro-slavery, Union and Secession, Mark Sullivan, political writer, said in the commencement address at Lehigh University here today.

The shortest priced favorite of the New York season thus far, Flying Hour, 1 to 5, won at Belmont Park yesterday in the featured Star Jasmine Purse. Flying Hour, owned by Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords, appears to be one of the fastest fillies in training.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., June 13 -- J.P. Morgan won the silver cup award here this afternoon in the sweet pea section on the first day's judging of the Summer flower show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society. Mrs. Herbert L. Pratt, showing in almost every class, won sixteen first prizes and seven seconds and Mrs. Harrison Williams of Oak Point, Bayville, received four blue ribbons and three reds.

"Stripped," a play from the French of Andre Birabeau and Jean Guitton, will be tested for the Shuberts next week at Parson's Theatre, Hartford. In the cast will be Dudley Hawley, Ethel Morrison and Homer Barton. Four years ago the Shuberts produced on Broadway a play with a similar title, the work of Jane Murfin.

OYSTER BAT, L.I., June 13 -- Mrs. Van Sant Merle-Smith entertained today with a buffet luncheon at the Paddocks, her Summer home in Oyster Bay Cove, for members of the committee who assisted at the all-day exhibit and sale of Near East refugee handwork.

CHATHAM, N.T., June 13 -- Miss Vola, owned by E.F. Espenship of Norristown, Pa., scored in a field of eight entries, taking three straight heats of the 2:13 pace as the Bay State Circuit opened its second meeting today. She covered the mile in 2:08 1/4, 2:09 1/4 and 2:10 1/2 to win the $600 purse.

At the annual meeting of the Humble Oil and Refining Company, which is controlled by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, three directors, all of whom were vice presidents, tendered their resignations yesterday under the terms of the new retirement plan, according to reports from Houston, Texas. They were W.W. Fondren, F.P. Sterling and J.S. Bonner, all of whom had been connected with the Humble Oil Company since its organization in 1917.

LONDON, June 13 -- Young Richard Bonar Law rose during a hushed moment in the House of Commons tonight and told how Stanley Baldwin's acceptance of the terms of the United States for debt settlement in 1923 "almost broke my father's heart."

The Independent Bondholders Committee for Republic of Colombia departmental and municipal bonds, of which former Senator Robert L. Owen of Oklahoma is chairman, issued yesterday a statement that it had been informed unofficially that the Colombian Government planned to pay the coupons due on July 1 on its external bonds, one-third in cash and two-thirds in scrip.

Michael Williams, editor of The Commonweal and president of the Calvert Association, returned yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia from a six weeks' visit to Germany, where he investigated reports of persecution of Jews.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 13 -- The security of the United States is imperiled by politics, pacifists and retrenchment in the national defense program, General Douglas MacArthur, Chief of Staff of the army, told graduates of the military academy this morning.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Provision for a new professional organization of managers of real property, which will undertake sweeping changes in the now-complicated business of making it pay, was voted here today by the directors of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

BALTIMORE, June 13 -- Joining the Federal Government's reforestation camps. If no other work can be found, was suggested to graduates Of Johns Hopkins University today by the president, Dr. Joseph S. Ames; Few of them would; be able to find the jobs for which they had prepared, and reforestation work was preferable to idleness, he said.

Paul R. Meltsner, 28-year-old artist, was awakened yesterday morning in his two-room apartment at 240 West Fourteenth Street by the insistent knocking of misfortune in the guise of a city marshal. In a short time he, his canvases and furniture were resting on the curb two flights below.

After nine straight defeats at the bands of Toronto, Jersey City turned on the Leafs at Jersey City yesterday and wan. 5 to 1, behind the great pitching of Joe Cascarella. Cascarella scattered eight Toronto hits and kept the Leafs away from the plate after the first inning.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 13 -- Another Paraguayan military plan has been upset by the Bolivian Army in a spectacular combat yesterday morning in the vicinity of Isla Poi, according to a Bolivian General Staff communique last night.

VIENNA, June 13 -- The maintenance of public safety in Vienna was taken out of the hands of its Socialist Mayor today and turned over to Federal Police Chief Eugene Seydel as the city continued in an uproar with bombings and other disturbances.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Some prodigious hitting by a trio of Senators against a pair of Philadelphia pitchers today gave Washington its second straight victory over the Athletics, 10 to 6. The result brought the Senators a game nearer the league-leading Yankees.

A wee burglar squeezed through a transom into the shop of Alfred Dunhill of London, Inc., at Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street late Monday night or early yesterday morning and wormed his way out again with $25,000 orth of loot.

The twenty-sixth commencement exercises of the Fordham University School of Law were held yesterday afternoon on the steps of the Physics Building at the south end of the university quadrangle. The Rev. Aloysius J. Hogan, president of Fordham, presided and conferred degrees upon 250 candidates who were presented by Dr. Ignatius M. Wilkinson of the School of Law.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Mrs. Roosevelt returned by plane from New York this morning. Cheerful and unwearied after her transcontinental trip, she held her press conference within an hour.

Dr. George M. Wiley, assistant Commissioner of Education of the State Education Department, will speak tonight at the thirty-fourth commencement exercises of the Savage School for Physical Education. The exercises will be held in the Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.
The Giants played a lot of bad baseball yesterday at the Polo Grounds, but did a lot of good, timely hitting. Thus they managed to dispose of the Boston Braves, 6 to 3, opening a threegame series.

Testifying In Federal court yesterday, Hugh B. Baker, former president of the National City Company, corroborated Charles E. Mitchell's story of the purchase of 28,300 shares of National City Bank stock on Oct. 29, 1929, and of the sale of 10,000 shares on Nov. 4 and 7, 1929.
Flag Day, the anniversary of the adoption by Congress of the national emblem, will be observed in New York today, featured by the annual parade and patriotic exercises.

The coat of the high school system to New York City could be reduced 16 per cent without loss of efficiency by a "proper classification of pupils assisted by adequate motivation in each subject," according to a report to the High School Teachers Association made public yesterday.

LONDON, June 13 -- After a day of rumors and alarms that kept the British House of Commons on tenterhooks it seemed to be pretty well assured late tonight that an acceptable means of bridging over the difficulty of Britain's June debt payment to the United States had been agreed upon and only formal acceptance was needed to close the matter.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The appointment of Professor Robert M. Hutchins of the University of Chicago as chairman of the Advisory Council to be created for the new Federal Employment Service was announced today by Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, together with his acceptance.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., June 13 -- A warning that the world could not "muddle along" much longer without gravely threatening a "break-up of civilization" was sounded today by Dr. Mary E. Woolley, president of Mount Holyoke College, in a commencement address at Bryn Mawr College.

The John Marshall College of Law, Jersey City, N.J., will confer an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws upon Dr. Charles H. Elliott, New Jersey Commissioner of Education, at the commencement exercises this afternoon. The commencement will be held at the State Normal School, Jersey City, at 3 P.M.

LONDON, June 13 -- The World Economic Conference got down to work today. King George's crimson upholstered chair had vanished from the platform which was occupied now only by the chairman and his aides and the conference began to clear off the preliminary speeches that the delegates must deliver before actual proposals can be taken up.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- In the course of the Senate debate on the conference report on the National Industrial Recovery Bill today Senator Clark of Missouri objected to an article in last Monday's NEW YORK TIMES. After asserting that "not more than five or six Senators were prepared to resist adjournment" last Saturday night, the article mentioned several members, including Mr. Clark, who "could have spoken for ten or twelve hours more."

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES this morning appears a letter stating that the depression was caused by the same elements as in previous conditions of the same nature. That is only partially true. The writer's criticism of the present attempt to blend religious truth, economics, politics, , into a uniform pattern is not justified.

Troy, N.Y. Formal offering of a new issue of $1,233,700 city of Troy (N.Y.) 4 1/2 per cent various purposes bonds due from 1934 to 1953 will be made today at prices to yield 3.50 to 4.20 per cent. The offering group comprises Lehman Brothers, the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company of Buffalo; Kean, Taylor Co.; R.H. Moulton Co., Inc., and G.M.-P. Murphy Co.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- With the Prohibition Bureau slated to lose its identity late in the Summer, Attorney General Cummings is working out the details of a plan for merging it with the Justice Department's Bureau of Investigation.

Coffee and wool tops advanced in price yesterday among the commodities traded on local exchanges for future delivery, but silver, cocoa, rubber, hides and silk closed with losses, while sugar was irregularly lower. Most cash prices also were lower.
ST. LOUIS, June 13 (AP) -- Dizzy Dean won a pitching duel with Steve Swetonic and the Cardinals defeated the Pirates today, 4 to 3.

No compromise with President Machado of Cuba for a truce is possible, according to a statement issued here yesterday at the headquarters of the Cuban revolutionary junta in the Hotel Ansonia, by Dr. Carlos de La Torre. former professor of the University of Havana.

Twenty City College students were expelled, eight were suspended for six months and three others were suspended pending further investigation when the college faculty met yesterday to take final disciplinary action against participants In the anti-war disturbance on May 29.

Peter Grimm, chairman, and Harold Riegelman, counsel of the Citizens' Budget Commission, explained its attitude toward salaries and especially teachers' salaries at a meeting of teachers yesterday at the McAlpin.

LONDON, June 13 -- The speeches at today's session of the World Economic Conference adhered for the most part to broad principles, to which virtually everybody subscribed, at least in the abstract. The speakers vied with each other in praising Prime Minister MacDonald's denunciation of economic nationalism.

A sharp relative improvement in production of new life insurance has been reported by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to the United States Department of Commerce. The total was the largest in any month this year and only 15 per cent less than in May, 1932, compared with decreases of 35 per cent for January, 27 for February, 28 for March and 24 for April.
The reproduction of Mount Vernon in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, built last year by the George Washington Bicentennial Commission at a cost of $150,000, has not yet been opened for the season.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Amtorg, the Russian trading agency, has begun efforts to obtain a loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to finance shipment of American agricultural products to that country. No formal application was filed, but it is understood that one may be within a short time.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Industrial Recovery Bill, upon which Congressional action was completed today, is intended to provide Jobs for thousands of idle men and inject new life into sluggish industry.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 -- Burt Shotton's last-place Phillies became a juggernaut today that rolled over Max Carey's hapless Dodgers and drove them deeper into seventh place. The home club's overwhelming margin in run-scoring was 15 to 4.

VIENNA, June 13 -- The measures against the Austrian Nazis forecast last night by Karl Vaugoin, the Minister of War, were carried into effect today after another bomb outrage and further acts of terrorism had occurred during the night and early this morning.

On the same day that he was named a defendant in a Supreme Court action brought by stockholders of investment trusts and other companies in which he had been active, Wallace Groves disclosed yesterday that he had returned to the investment trust field through the purchase of the interest held by Burco, Inc., in the Phoenix Securities Corporation, which at one time was the Prince Whitely Trading Corporation.

LONDON, June 13 -- The British dominions will speak individually, not jointly as a commonwealth, of nations, at the World Economic Conference, but there is no question of the Ottawa agreements, which bind them together economically, being upset by anything done here, Prime Minister Bennett of Canada made clear in a statement this morning.

A sharp increase in failures of manufacturers featured business defaults for the week ended June 8, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. These failures numbered 102, against 84 in the previous week. Retail defaults rose 3 to 253. Declines were shown in the wholesale and jobbing and other commercial groups.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 -- Upward revision of salaries of 2,200 employes and a declaration of a $750,000 dividend on the capital stock, or at the rate of $3,000,000 annually, were announced today by the directorate of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association.
Sales of flats in Jersey City and North Bergen and purchase of a residence in Ridgewood from a builder featured the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

BARNSTABLE, Mass., June 13 (AP) -- Kenneth and Cyril Buck, brothers, charged with the kidnapping of 10-year-old Margaret McMath of Harwichport, heard repeated recitals of the crime in Barnstable Superior Court today as defense counsel strove to bar alleged, confessions.

Bachelor of Arts degrees will be awarded to 584 Hunter College graduates this morning at the sixty-fourth commencement exercises at Carnegie Hall. Certificates of completion of a three-year course for teacher training will be given to 149 students.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I add my congratulations to those of THE TIMES readers who have already expressed their admiration for your editorials on the subject of repudiation? I hope that the voice of THE TIMES will continue to be heard in defense of good faith and sound money just so long as devious policies develop in the mists of Washington.

WEST NEWTON, Mass, June 13 -- A brilliant approach shot on the seventeenth hole which put the ball five feet from the cup paved the way to victory for Miss Charlotte Glutting in the women's Eastern golf championship today.
Swordfish are beginning to ap- pear off Montauk. Three good-sized ones already have been caught, in- dicating that before long the deep- sea game fishing will be on in full swing in that sector.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 13 -- A 17-year-old high school boy outshone America's greatest golf professionals on the links of the Metropolls Country Club today.
Miss Virginia Gildersleeve, dean of Barnard College, and Miss Elizabeth Rhees Butler, sister of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, are sailing tonight for Europe on the White Star liner Majestic.

BERLIN, June 13 -- The church problem, both Protestant and Catholic, remains one of the most difficult for the Hitler government to solve, one thing that is not to be disposed of by a simple "coordination" order.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,709,350 barrels, compared with 2,675,650 barrels in the preceding week, a gain of 33,700, according to the American Petroleum Institute. An increase of 53,800 barrels daily in the average output of Oklahoma and a decrease of 37,050 barrels daily in that of the Conroe field in Texas were the most important changes.

BERLIN, June 13 -- The German Government has instructed its Minister in Vienna "to enter the sharpest protest, reserving all subsequent steps" against the arrest at Linz of Theodor Habicht, Nazi Reichstag member and of late publicity attache of the German diplomatic mission to Austria.
The arrival this morning of the liner Milwaukee and the departure at midnight of the liner New York from Pier 84, North River, will be marked by two changes in the staff of the Hamburg-American Line.

The skyscrapers of New York are so conspicuous as to give rise to the mistaken belief that they are typical of the city's development, and that the average height of buildings here, especially in Manhattan, is far above that of other capitals.

PARIS, June 13 -- With Premier Daladier returning tomorrow from London, it was suggested tonight in official circles that he would seek interviews with Premier Mussolini of Italy and Chancellor Hitler of Germany before the ratification of the Four-Power Pact came up for debate in the French Senate.

MILWAUKEE, June 13 -- An anomaly in American medicine, with overproduction of physicians in the medical schools on the one hand and a poor geographical distribution of physicians on the other, was discussed by Dr. Dean Lewis, new president of the American Medical Association in his inaugural address today.
