WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Administration plans for adjournment of the special session of Congress went to pieces again tonight, crushed between the veterans' bloc in the Senate and threats from the White House that the President would answer with a veto any further attempts to emasculate the administration economy program.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., June 13 -- Diplomas were awarded to the class of '33 of Bordentown Military Institute at commencement exercises in assembly hall this afternoon. The address to the graduates was made by the Rev. Harry L. Everett of Jersey City.

MUNICH, June 13 -- The first plunge into Adolf Hitler's Germany, when made by way of Munich, brings into sharp focus all the contradictions of the revolution, which has the effect of revolving furiously in two opposite directions, taking with it the oddest assortment of hopes and hates ever scrambled together in one political movement.

In tame, old-fashioned, sedentary, snobbish times there was a saying to measure the height of felicity: "Young, handsome and a prince." Princes and kings have faded. The renown of the athlete, a master in major sport, is immensely wider than it was in the great days of Greece, though there is no PINDAR to sing his exploits.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Senate investigators of private banking announced today that officials of Kuhn, Loeb Co. would be called June 26, as their inquiry resumes again where It left off last week with J.P. Morgan Co.

PARIS, June 13 -- L'Ere Nouvelle, a newspaper with which Edouard Herriot is closely associated, delivers today a sharp attack against the United States on the debt question, thus indicating that M. Herriot has changed his mind about the desirability of making the payment due last Dec. 15.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent commencement at Lincoln University, in Pennsylvania, the pioneer institution of the higher education of the Negro and now entering upon its eightieth year of service, emphasized the appropriateness of the title that was given to it -- "a laboratory of leadership."

Five charitable institutions here and abroad will receive bequests totaling more than $50,000 if the estate of Rudolf A. Metz. banker, exceeds $1,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court. Mr. Metz died on June 8.

Arrangements were made yesterday for the sale of three memberships in the New York Stock Exchange, two at $225,000 each and one at $250,000. At the latter price the value of seats in the Exchange showed a gain of $35,000 compared with the previous sale on Monday.

LONDON, June 13 -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichs-bank, met foreign bankers here today for discussion of the future of the short-term German credits covered by the s. andstill agreement. Thursday he will meet the longterm creditors, whose loans are not protected and hence subject to the transfer moratorium suspending payment in foreign currencies.

President ROOSEVELT'S speech to the "future farmers" had the purpose of helping to make practical the forest-mindedness of American youth. The love of trees is instinctive. The author of the idyl of the trees, "The Bride of the Mistletoe," goes so far as to say that there was a time in the history of man when he was completely forest-minded, having nothing but forest knowledge, forest dreams, forest fancies, forest faiths.

ASCOT, England, June 13 -- The renewal of the historic Ascot Stakes at Royal Ascot today almost resulted in the second dead-heat in two years. But the French-bred and English-trained Roi de Paris managed to get the decision by a head over Loose Strife, with Dictum a length and a half back in third place.

A sudden sharp rally in the dollar yesterday mystified the foreignexchange market and contributed toward depressing prices in the securities and commodities markets. Bankers here knew of no better reasons for yesterday's rise of the dollar than for Monday's fall to a low record.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 13 -- The Misses Marguerite Caperton, Katherine Dwyer, Elizabeth Johnston and Virginia and Ellen French will be among the young women who will act as models for the fashion show at the Muenchinger King on the afternoon and evening of June 30.
Police Commissioner Bo Jan, speaking yesterday at a luncheon of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, addressed a message to the rank and file of the department.
Mayor O'Brien said last night that if the city's revenues "broke down" the city would have to appeal to private charitable agencies to help carry on unemployment relief.

The 224 graduates of Manhattan College were warned yesterday against "straying from their religious ideals after a liberal viewpoint," in an address by Supreme Justice Charles B. McLaughlin at the eightieth annual commencement of that institution at Riverdale.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 13 -- C.W. McAlpin, secretary of Princeton University from 1901 to 1917, announced today his intention of offering to the Federal Government a large portion of his estate which adjoins that of the property in Jockey Hollow, which will be dedicated as a part of the Morristown National Park on July 4.
All provisions of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Law become operative at midnight tonight.

Miss Ann Gordon, 63 years old, a former trained nurse, testified yesterday that the late John G. Wendel made a statement more than thirty years ago that Thomas Patrick Morris was his son. Miss Gordon was a defense witness at the General Sessions trial of Morris for conpiring to make a fraudulent claim for a share of the $45,000,000 Wendel estate.

R.B. White, president of the Western Union Telegraph Company since June 1, presided yesterday at the monthly meeting of directors, the first to be held since he took office. Newcomb Carlton, chairman of the board, was unable to be present, as he is recuperating from an illness which overcame him on a recent fishing trip in Northern New York.

Scared Into Prosperity. A managed economy is apparently one m which prosperity is maintain ed by giving people alternate mild cases of fits. If prices have to be raised, as every one wants to see them rise today, the idea is to frighten people away from the dollar and into buying goods by means of inflation.

Joseph C. Hoagland has sold his modern five-story American basement house at 19 East Sixty-sixth Street, it was announced yesterday. This is a limestone dwelling on a lot 20 by 100 feet, between Fifth and Madison Avenues. It contains an electric elevator and is assessed at $115,000, according to the William B. May Company, broker in the deal.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 9 an article, "Russian Church in Conflict Here," in which it is stated that Bishop Benjamin represents the patriarchal church of Russia, to which you refer as the "Old Church," while Archbishop John S. Kedrovsky represents the synodical church of Russia, which you call "New Church."

GREENWICH, Conn., June 13 -- The showing of Greenwich Gardens tomorrow for the benefit of Stratford Hall is being sponsored by a large society group. Members of the Greenwich-Rye unit of the Junior League will be at each garden to act as hostesses.

The protest demonstration that disrupted the meeting of the Board of Education on May 24 had its aftermath in the same room yesterday. Isidore Begun, a teacher in Public School 69, the Bronx, was on trial before the board's law committee for his part in the demonstration.

When President ROOSEVELT and Budget Director DOUGLAS set out to reform veterans' relief, under the broad powers granted them by Congress, they found 1,418,835 names on the list of pensioners. These were divided into three main groups. At one extreme were veterans actually injured or disabled in past wars and the families of those who lost their lives.

Headed for the Yale-Harvard crew races at New London, Conn., on Friday, the advance fleet of sail and motor yachts will get under way today for the run through Long Island Sound. Tonight the sailing craft in the American Yacht Club's race to the Thames will start at 7 P.M.

LONDON, June 13 -- Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss of Austria will return to Vienna tomorrow after having requested the assistance of the great powers in his fight against Nazi terrorism, which has become so acute in his country in the last three days.

Mrs. Reginald C. Vanderbilt gave a dinner last night at the Central Park Casino for the Marquis of Milford Haven, who is here from England. The other guests were Lieut. Commander and Mrs. William D. Thomas, Miss Eleanor Barry, William Rhinelander Stewart, A.C. Blumenthal, Felix Ferry and Lawrence Dowd.

LONDON, June 13 -- A 400,000,000-franc trade agreement between France and Soviet Russia is on the verge of being concluded, it was learned today. (At present exchange this would entail about $20,000,000.)
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 13 -- The two-mile crews of both Yale and Harvard, preparing for their regatta Friday, staged time trials over the upper half of the Thames River course today.

Government control of business is necessary to eliminate the rebel mi- nority in business, to remedy chaotic trade conditions and to pay labor a decent and living wage. Andrew Nelson, chairman, department of accounting, St. John's College, Brooklyn, declared here yesterday.

EDINBURGH, June 13 -- Headed by a fife and drum band, thousands of hunger marchers surrounded the Ministry of Labor offices today and demanded to see Sir Godfrey Collins, Secretary of State for Scotland.
LONDON, June 13 -- A threepoint program to pull the world out of its slump was proposed by Premier Daladier of France at today's session of the World Economic Conference.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Glass-Steagall Banking Bill was swiftly approved in both houses of Congress today. This makes bank reform legislation and deposit insurance an actuality except for the signature of President Roosevelt. Assurance of the President's approval of the measure wag given when he telephoned his congratulations to Senator Glass.

WASHINGTON, June I3 -- Great Britain, in its capacity as America's largest war debtor, Ied the vanguard of nations obligated on June 15 by submitting a formal proposal late this afternoon dealing with the payment due Thursday of $75,950,000.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The honorary degree of Doctor of Laws will be conferred upon President Roosevelt tomorrow morning at the commencement exercises here of the Catholic University of America. Cardinal Hayes of New York, who is a member of the board of trustees of the university, will give the commencement address.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- By a vote of 46 to 39 the Senate this afternoon accepted the conference report on the Industrial Recovery Bill, thereby ending the controversy over the measure providing $3,300,000,000 for putting the idle back to work.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Arthur Cumnock and her sister, Miss Juliana Cutting, are sailing on the Aquitania. They will stay, for several weeks, in London with the Hon. Mrs. Arthur Forbes-Sempill, Mrs. Cuirinock's daughter.

Prime Minister MACDONALD cannot fairly be blamed for mention- ing the war debts in his address at the opening of the Economic Con- ference. He put in the distinct no- tification that the question "cannot be dealt with here." Mr. MACDONALD had previously stated in the House of Commons that the debts would not be discussed at the London meeting.

LONDON, June 13. -- The disagreeable surprise which was caused in the American delegation at the World Economic Conference by Prime Minister MacDonald's reference to war debts in his opening speech yesterday wore away considerably today.

Since 1920 the railways have lost 70 per cent of their passenger traffic to the highways. The loss has continued in good times and bad and is therefore to be reckoned with as something more than temporary. That the railways are thus reckoning with it was demonstrated on the Long Island when an imported automotive, pneumatic-tired railcar spurted at seventy miles an hour between Jamaica and Babylon.
TOKYO, June 13 -- The Cotton Spinners Federation approved today a committee's recommendations for a boycott on Indian cotton. Of sixty-three member firms only two were absent.

DETROIT, June 13 (AP) -- A fine pitching duel between Oral Hildebrand and Tommy Bridges, which saw only four men reach third base in the entire game, ended in a 1-to-0 victory for the Cleveland Indians in the series' opener with Detroit today.

BUFFALO, June 13 -- Charges that the official boards of some of the 429 churches composing the United Lutheran Synod of New York were dipping their hands into the coffers of funds contributed for outside missionary work and using them for the support of the homo church were made today by two of the four officers of the synod at its fifth annual convention.

A mass meeting of protest against the attempt of the Tammany city administration to impose a tax on automobile owners was decided upon last night at a meeting of representatives of civic and automobile associations at the Commodore Hotel.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- The navy's new dirigible, the Macon, carrying ninety persons on her third trial trip out of Akron, Ohio, gave visitors at the Century of Progress Exposition and Chicagoans a thrill early this evening by sailing over the fair grounds and the city for more than an hour.

These orders were issued yesterday: Death Announced. Retired Fireman Denis J. Dee, formerly a member of Engine 69, died June 9. Funeral will take place from the C.F. Moloney Funeral Parlor, 319 E. 28th St., Manhattan, at 9:30 A.M., Wednesday, June 14.

The Paris prize in sculpture of the Beaux Arts Institute of Design, 304 East Forty-fourth Street, has been awarded to Walter Yoffe of 2,464 Washington Avenue. The award was made as the result of a competition, in the final stage of which seventeen models were submitted.

LONDON, June 13 -- Political difficulties remained uppermost in the negotiations for de facto monetary stabilization which continued with slow progress today among Treasury and central bank officials of the United States, Great Britain and France.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Unexpected opposition has developed to vital parts of the agricultural adjustment program proposed by farm leaders and heretofore sponsored by high officials. As a result, doubt has arisen concerning the application of adjustment plans to this year's crops.

NEWARK, N.J., June 13 -- Rochester conquered Newark today, 6 to 4, in the final game of the series and pained undisputed possession of first place in the International League as the Bears dropped to second. The two clubs were tied for the lead prior to today's game.
INTO each life some rain must fall. The following note is offered in evidence with deep regret:

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Colonel George R. Spaulding of the Army Engineers, long an authority on river and harbor improvement projects, has been selected by General Hugh S. Johnson to be Federal Public Works Administrator. With Colonel Henry T. Waite, Colonel Spaulding has been perfecting an organization for the distribution of the $3,300,000,000 public works fund authorized in the Industrial Recovery Bill.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 13 -- The growing importance of recreation as a result of forced or expanded leisure was emphasized in the annual report of the WestChester County Recreation Commission filed today with the Board of Supervisors.
When Euclid lost the nightcap at Belmont Park yesterday, his winning streak of three straight was snapped.
BOSTON, June 13 -- Dusty Cooke, who not so long ago was not deemed good enough to earn his board and keep with the Yankees, bobbed up today to vex the world's champions sorely.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 13 -- Don Johnson made his pitching debut for Princeton today and held Temple to nine scattered singles, the Tigers winning, 2 -- 1, for their fourth successive victory.

The compact, gracefully executed strokes of Miss Norma Taubele were pitted against the varied repertoire and stylish backhand of one of the leading junior players in the metropolitan area yesterday in the women's New York State championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

Dr. Frank Pierrepont Graves, Commissioner of Education of New York State, will deliver the address this afternoon at the eighty-eighth commencement exercises of Fordham University, to be held on the campus at 4 P.M. The exercises are for Fordham College, the Graduate School, Teachers College, School of Sociology and School of Business.

Forty-three sets of major letters were among the 111 awards made to Spring sports athletes at New York University, according to an announcement yesterday by Graduate Manager Albert B. Nixon. The awards recently received the approval of the university's board of athletic control and of the under graduate athletic board.

BOSTON, June 33 -- Massachusetts today became the eleventh State to approve repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment when its voters elected a complete slate of forty-five wet delegates to the State constitutional convention. The repealists won by a ratio of more than 4 to 1.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The United States is the melting pot of the nations. But it has retained a stubborn Anglo-Saxon pride in its political institutions. This is revealed by the last acts of the dying special session of the Seventythird Congress.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 13 (AP) -- The birth rate in New York City was lower in 1932 than in 1931. The decline has continued for several years. According to the Federal Bureau of Census figures for 1932, the only one of the larger cities of the State to have a higher birth rate last year than the previous year was Utica.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an editorial THE TIMES inclines to attribute the "revolt" of Congress against President Roosevelt's essential economy measures needful for balancing of the budget to patronage pressure. "So many Democratic sheep [who] have been looking up to Representatives and Senators, but who have not been fed."
Dr. Walker E. Swift's residence in Ring's End Rd., Darien, Conn., was rented for the Summer to Emerson Whithorne of New York. Kenneth Ives Co. and Herbert Wheeler were the brokers.

An injunction suit to end the bakery workers' strike was heard in Brooklyn yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Albert Conway, who reserved decision on two applications to enjoin Local 505 of the Bakery Workers International Union of America.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Home Owners' Loan Bill was signed by President Roosevelt today in the presence of members of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and Senator Robinson of Arkansas.

Postponement of the time when Congress will adjourn had a depressing effect yesterday upon the speculative markets. The recovery in foreign exchange was also an influence in the direction of lower prices on the Stock Exchange as well as in the commodity markets.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Movements of vessels follow; all dates are June 12 unless otherwise specified:

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- A compact organization directed by General Hugh S. Johnson, former soldier and manufacturer, tonight was ready to employ the extraordinary powers of the Industrial Recovery Act.

Wall Street was "Washington conscious" to an unusual degree yesterday. Everything that came out of the capital was eagerly examined; the delay in adjournment caused many speculators to revise their plans. The turnover on the Stock Exchange exceeded 6,300,000 shares -- one of the biggest day's business of the year.

Major William Kennelly yesterday resigned as president of the New York Athletic Club, and the club's board of governors elected William A. Dalton, first vice president, to succeed him. Major Kennelly offered his resignation to the board a month ago, but it was not accepted until he requested it yes- terday.

BERLIN, June 13 -- The Boerse continued dull and irregular today. Professional traders as well as the public have adopted a waiting attitude pending developments at the Economic Conference. Only investments of blocked mark funds created passing interest in such specialties as iron, electricals, Reichsbank shares and to some extent Dye Trust.

ALBANY, June 13 -- Bernard K. Marcus, former president of the Bank of United States, now serving a term in Sing Sing, will not be transferred to the medium security prison at Walkill, according to Dr. Walter N. Thayer, commissioner of correction.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- The American banking system was defended at the convention of the American Institute of Banking here today by Dr. Harold Stonier of New York, educational director of the institute.

TRENTON, June 13 -- After considering the measure in executive session and deciding not to adopt any of several proposed amendments, the Senate passed tonight the annual appropriations bill as introduced last week. It calls for expenditure of $18,958,897, the smallest sum appropriated during the last ten years and approximately $1,500,000 less than the total recommended by Governor Moore in his budget message.

Andre Maurois arrived here yesterday to spend six weeks in breadlines, in day coaches, at unemployment meetings and in hotel lobbies. From industrial workers, office employes, farmers, from men with and without jobs, he hopes to learn the present temper of America.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 (AP) -- The gas rates of the Southern California Gas Company were reduced by approximately $1,000,000 annually in a formal order of the State Railroad Commission here today.

A large number of seniors at Samuel J. Tilden High School in East Flatbush refused yesterday to sign a pledge of loyalty to the Federal and State Governments required by the Board of Education as a prerequisite to receiving diplomas.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Independently of the general Senate discussion of the British debt payment, Senator Robinson of Arkansas, the Democratic leader, issued today a formal statement generally understood to be semi-official, attacking the critics of President Roosevelt.

The Harriman Memorial Medals for outstanding achievement in American railway safety during 1932 were awarded yesterday to the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company, the Atlantic City Railroad Company and the Texas Mexican Railway Company.

RYE BEACH, N.H., June 14 -- The Summer home of James Roosevelt, son of the President, was badly damaged by fire and water late today. Mrs. Roosevelt and her daughter, Sarah Delano, 1 year old, were not in the home when the fire started.

LOS ANGELES, June 14 (AP) -- A receiver was appointed by the Superior Court today to take over the business interests of the Princes David and Serge Mdivani, both involved in, court actions growing out of marital troubles.

FAIR HAVEN, N.J., June 14 -- Joe Humphries, whose powerful voice has been heard by thousands at major sports events throughout the country before the advent of present amplification systems, is almost totally paralyzed today. An apoplectic stroke which overcame him early yesterday morning left him helpless for seven hours before help arrived.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The request of the Great Northern Rail-road for a three-year loan of $6,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The road proposes to apply the proceeds of the loan toward meeting interest on bonds due July 1 in the amount of $8,824,426.

CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns, losers in ten of their previous twelve games with the White Sox this season, arose today and clouted out a 14-to-1 victory that gave them the series, two games to one.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 14 -- A.F. Whitney, chairman of the Railway Labor Executives Association and president of the Brotherhood of Railway Trainmen, said tonight that the "railroads won't get to first base" in any effort to reduce wages of railroad employes.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- A decision to levy the maximum processing taxes of around 4 cents a pound for cotton and 28 to 30 cents a bushel for wheat to bring about smaller acreages for those crops has been reached by the Roosevelt administration.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The text of President Roosevelt's statement today on Britain's announcement of her intention to pay a part of her debt instalment tomorrow as a token follows:
LONDON, June 14 (AP) -- The vast problem of wheat is entering into the vital discussions of the World Economic Conference.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 14 -- A recent canvass of Congressional sentiment on the problem of World War debt payments to the United States had disclosed a large majority in favor of permitting European nations to default in their payments if they chose to do so, Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, said here tonight.

Mayor O'Brien and Governor Eugene Talmadge of Georgia joined yesterday in urging residents of the city to preserve the spirit of Americanism, symbolized by the nation's flag, at the annual Flag Day exercises held in City Hall Park.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts awarded yesterday a total of $3,150,000 of bonds, consisting of $3,000,000 Metropolitan Water Loan bonds, due on Jan. 1, 1934 to 1963, and $150,000 Metropolitan Sewer Loan bonds, due on Sept. 1, 1933 to 1952.
AKRON, Ohio, June 14 -- Wages went up today for thousands who earn their living in the tire and rubber industry.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Following is the text of Secretary Hull's speech today at the London Economic Conference, as made public by the State Department:

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The text of correspondence exchanged between the Government of the United States and the British Government concerning the debt payment due tomorrow was made public by the State Department today as follows:

Miss Carolyn Roberts of New Rochelle, seventh in the Eastern ranking, gained the remaining bracket in the quarter finals of the women's New York State championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club. In the only singles match of the day, Miss Roberts defeated Miss Mary Parker of Cold Spring Harbor, 6-1, 6-1.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 14 -- St. George's School had its first father's day today and it proved a success. The fathers played at informal sports in the afternoon and joined with the students for supper.

ST. LOUIS, June 14 (AP) -- St. Louis squared the four-game series with Pittsburgh by taking the final game today, 3 to 2. The Cards thus tightened their hold on second place and lengthened their lead over the third-place Pirates to two and one-half games.

BERLIN, June 14 -- Chancellor Hitler, speaking here today to his assembled lieutenants at a periodic meeting of National Socialist leaders, declared that the extension and reinforcement of the Nazi movement was essential in the interest of the new Germany.

FARMINGTON, Conn., June 14 (AP) -- Winchell Smith, the playwright, who died June 10, remembered others of the stage not so fortunate as himself in his will, which, filed for probate today, disposed of an estate estimated at $1,500,000. He set aside 35 per cent of the income of a large trust fund for the aid of needy actors and dramatists.

PITTSBURGH, June 14 -- Charges that W.L. Mellon, nephew of Andrew W. Mellon, defrauded the Federal Government of $2,020,131 in income taxes over a period of five years were made in a suit filed in Federal court today.

The criticism that the city "is wasting the citizens' money by conducting colleges to raise communists" was called unfair and harmful in the baccalaureate address at the Hunter College commencement in Carnegie Hall yesterday by Laurence L. Cassidy, chairman of the administrative committee of the college.

Public utility rate experts, after preliminary study of a decision by the Supreme Court in Albany County, expressed the opinion yesterday that the ruling would block the Public Service Commission in its plan to order temporary rate cuts throughout the State.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- A program to bring out for investment in real estate millions of dollars on deposit in banks, was presented here today by Philip A. Benson, president of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, at the convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

Irregularities in prices of domestic corporation bonds were rather wide on the Stock Exchange yesterday, while United States Government issues and leading foreign loans were generally steady. The volume of trading, $15,025,200, was approximately $1,000,000 less than on Tuesday.
LONDON, June 14 -- The spectre of Hitlerite truculence proved almost as impossible to banish from the World Economic Conference today as the war debt ghost had been on Monday.

Historically far older than New York, Rome is younger in the age composition of its residents, according to "Youthful Cities and Cities of Elders," a study published by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in its statistical bulletin. New York may take heart, however, for among large cities it is "comparatively youthful," says the bulletin.

The newest Italian liner, Conte di Savoia, will sail today for Gibraltar, Cannes, Naples and Genoa with 1,603 passengers, said to be the largest number to sail from New York for Europe in any transatlantic liner this year.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 14 (AP) -- Four star players of the Columbus American Association baseball team were ordered barred and the club was fined $500 today for alleged violation of the association's salary agreement.

MANILA, Thursday, June 15 -- While cheering crowds and shrieking whistles greeted his arrival, Frank Murphy, new Governor General of the Philippines, said in his inaugural address today that acceptances of preferred independence was entirely a Filipino problem on which he would maintain the traditional hands-off policy.
Beer is not enriching the established restaurant in New York City appreciably, sorrowful members of the Society of Restaurateurs testified yesterday at a meeting at the Hotel Astor.
The Roosevelt administration was criticized as having "gone a long way to helping bums and loafers" by Governor Eugene Talmadge of Georgia, in a radio address last night over Station WOR.

When William K. Vanderbilt's yacht, the new motorship Alva, was anchored at Great Palm Island off the coast of Queensland, the tattooed natives on the island were very uneasy. They thought the yacht had a devil aboard whom they must kill.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The war debts became mere statistics today when the President announced his acceptance from Great Britain of a payment of $10,000,000 on its interest obligation of $75,950,000 due tomorrow. After ten years of pretense, the war-debt question officially entered the stage of realism so far as American diplomacy is concerned.

Lord BRYCE in a sketch of the life of EDWARD BOWEN, sometime Master of Harrow, recalled an admonition which he was accustomed to give his students: "Take the "bitter and the sweet as sweet and "bitter come, and play the game." It is the law of chivalric life.
Transfer of 250 patrolmen from easy Jobs at headquarters to street duty is contemplated, it was learned yesterday. Commissioner Bolan has ordered department heads to weed out the men they can spare.

Speculative attention centred again yesterday upon the foreign exchange market where the process of cheapening the dollar was resumed. Simultaneously with the rise in sterling, francs and other currencies there was a sharp recovery in stocks, bonds and commodities.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- In the face of a certain veto, the Senate tonight passed by a vote of 51 to 39 the Steiwer-Cutting amendment to the Independent Offices Bill, imposing restrictions in reductions in veterans' compensations by an estimated total ranging from $100,000,000 to $160,000,000.

Stockholders of six subsidiaries of the Atlas Corporation have received rights to tender their shares in exchange of Atlas stock or warrants until June 27. Two of the ratios of exchange are the same as were granted a year ago, while the four others reflect changed market relations.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Increases of 4.8 per cent in manufacturing employment and 11.5 per cent in payrolls In May were announced today by Secretary Perkins as the administration moved to make effective the industrial regulation-public works legislation designed to accelerate the business upturn.
Small housing properties comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- A Senate openly defiant of a Presidential veto tonight started a new veterans' payment proposal toward a round trip to the White House over a road that already had been paved for its two way journey. An already written veto was awaiting the provision.

An extremely nervous stock market carried the speculative portion of Wall Street from despondency to high hope yesterday. There was a period, early in the day, when it looked as if the "bottom had dropped out,'' as the market-letter writers remarked.

A struggle lasting an hour and one-half finally was rewarded by the netting of a splendid trout on the Beaver Kill above Roscoe early this week. The lucky angler, an ardent dry-fly fisherman from the Bronx, was Lou Schweizer. His catch was a twenty-three-inch brown trout, which weighed four and one-half pounds.

The necessity for further retrenchment in the cost of government, national, State and city, was emphasized yesterday by George W. Wickersham, a former Attorney General of the United States. Mr. Wickersham opened a conference on publie expenditures of the New York State Economic Council at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- High tribute for efforts in behalf of the nation and of humanity was paid to President Roosevelt today as he received the degree of Doctor of Laws from the Catholic University of America.

MILWAUKEE, June 14 -- Evidence that at least five of the glands of internal secretion play an important part in keeping the skeleton in a healthy condition was reported today before the annual meeting of the American Medical Association.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- statewide branch banking, officials said today, will be authorized at the outset in nine States under the GlassSteagall Banking Act, a provision of which recognizes the practice where State laws expressly permit it.
The railroad managements will serve notice on their labor forces today of a demand for a new 12 1/2 per cent wage cut, equivalent to an annual slash of $164,225,500 from the present scales.
Four hundred persona attended the dinner tendered the members of the United States Ryder Cup golf team at the Hotel Roosevelt last night.

Money market continued dull. Business was at a minimum, at no changre in quotations. Stock Exchange call loans were 1 per cent, outside money at a fractional concession. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were quiet.

Revival of shipment of Canadian grain through ports of the United States to points within the United Kingdom is expected to result from conferences held recently by representatives of American exports and customs officials of the British Government, the Port of New York Authority announced yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent editorial THE NEW YORK TIMES said, after referring to the depreciation of some 18 per cent in the American dollar in comparison with French francs and other currencies still maintained at par with gold, "no doubt we shall again hear that this depreciation of the dollar is wholly responsible for the rise in commodity prices and on the Stock Exchange."
WAPHiNGTON, June 14 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated June 12:

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- In the decision to make a "token" payment of $10,000,000 in bullion silver at the rate of 50 cents an ounce on the $75,950,000 debt payment due tomorrow, Great Britain has saved $2,800,000, according to estimates prepared by government officials here today.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Illinois, through Attorney General Otto Kerner, asked the Supreme Court today to reconsider its recent decision in the Lake Michigan diversion cases. It ordered the State to furnish financial assistance to the Chicagro Sanitary District in complying with the court's order.

PARIS, June 14 -- The French Government's answer to Washington's reminder several days ago that the war-debt instalment was due tomorrow will be handed to the State Department at Washington by Ambassador de Laboulaye tomorrow, it was announced here tonight.

The office of the city beer control board was swamped yesterday with a rush of applicants for licenses to dispense 3.2 per cent beer. All of those who have filed with the board their applications before closing time today will be permitted to sell the brew until their licenses are issued or their applications denied.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Cross-cutrents were numerous today in the wheat market on the Board of Trade, scattered longs selling relatively freely, not liking the foreign political news, while a break of 1 7/8 cents a bushel from yesterday's closing price led to free buying by some recent sellers.

COLONEL JOHN REED KILPATRICK (General Staff, A.E.F., during the war), was born in New York City but moved to Tennessee, via Alabama, while still an infant. He grew up near Chattanooga, and old inhabitants of that area report that the chubby Kilpatrick child of those days wore his hair in long and beautiful curls.

CHATHAM, N.Y., June 14 -- Outstripping the field under a masterly drive by Lyman Brusie, Calumet Delco won an impressive straightheat victory this afternoon in the 3-year-old trot for $600. It was the feature event of the Bay State Circuit's second day of light harness racing.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Full cooperation by every State in Federal relief work within its borders was demanded by President Roosevelt in a statement he read before eight Governors and relief executives at a White House conference today.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 14 -- A single system of banks constituting the finest financial structure the United States has even had was predicted here today by J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, as a sequel to the passage of the Glass-Steagall Banking Bill.

BERLIN, June 14 -- The conflict between Berlin and Vienna over the activities of the National Socialists in Austria reached the stage of reprisals today when the Germans arrested Dr. Erwin Wasserbaeck, duly accredited press attache of the Austrian Legation here and ordered him to leave Germany.

FLUSHING, L.I., June 14 -- A four-way tie for the medal featured the 36-hole qualifying round of the Metropolitan Amateur Golf Championship at the Pomonok Country Club today. It was the first time in recent championship history that so many have figured in a deadlock.

Secretary HULL'S address at the Economic Conference was, in effect, a powerful plea for world cooperation. He had nothing but scorn for the "isolationists" who maintain that each nation can, "by bootstrap methods," lift itself out of its troubles.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Reorganization of the Commerce Department's foreign service in the interests of economy will close twenty-one of the fifty-three offices abroad, Secretary Roper announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- With the weather and the Phillies cooling off simultaneously, the Dodgers registered their first victory of the series today, 6 to 3. Furthermore, they regained sixth place in the standing of the league.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- I note with interest the discussion in a Washington article on the editorial page of THE TIMES yesterday of the differences between the parliamentary and representative forms of government. Two further points occur to me.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Calling the navy's custom of transferring airship personnel to sea duty a "mistaken policy," the Congressional committee investigating the crash of the dirigible Akron, suggested today that the navy, before the next session of Congress, "correct the situation" under penalty of losing aircraft operations to a separate navy air corps.

NEWARK, N.J., June 14 -- Charley Devens, former Harvard ace, pitched Newark to a 2-to-0 shut-out over Toronto in the opening game of a double header today. The Maple Leafs captured the nightcap by breaking the 3-all deadlock in the eiphth, winning, 4 to 3.

The National Industrial Recovery Act signifies the beginning of a new epoch for the United States, in which the elimination of poverty and the assurance of profit to industry are the major objectives, according to Nelson B. Gaskill. Mr. Gaskill, who is president of the Lead Pencil Institute and formerly a member of the Federal Trade Commission, addressed 600 members of the National Association of Cost Accountants at their annual convention in the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.
DETROIT, June 14 (AP) -- Fred Marberry ran his string of victories to nine by pitching the Tigers to a 13-to-2 victory over the Indians in the second game of their series today.
Mayor O'Brien conferred medals yesterday on twelve firemen for deeds of valor and merit performed last year. The ceremony took place on the steps of the City Hall at noon.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Cotton consumed in May was reported today by the Census Bureau to have amounted to 620,909 bales of lint and 76,084 of linters, compared with 470,685 and 54,731 in April and 332,372 and 50,941 in May last year.

RYE, N.Y., June 14 -- Bowling along under a brisk northerly wind, eleven yachts started from Scotch Caps buoy tonight for New London, Conn., in the American Yacht Club's annual race through Long Island Sound to the scene of the Yale-Harvard rowing regatta.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 14. -- The Atlantic County Board of Freeholders has followed the lead of Atlantic City and today agreed that the county will accept $102,836 of preferred stock of the Guarantee, Equitable and Bankers Trust Companies in exchange for an equal amount of county funds "frozen" as restricted deposits in those banks.

The application of Mack Trucks, Inc., for permission to purchase the $550,000 issue of preferred stock of the East Side Omnibus Corporation has been withdrawn, the Transit Commisison announced yesterday. William G. Fullen, chairman, who canceled an adjourned hearing on the application, said he did not know why the petition had been withdrawn.

Mrs. Vera Johnson, her mother and two sons were trapped in their apartment on the top floor when fire swept a three-story tenement at 216 Ninth Avenue last night. The two boys, both suffering from burns, were rescued by firemen on extension ladders, but the two women died of burns and suffocation.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Eighty-five members of Congress joined today in presenting a petition to President Roosevelt requesting the appointment of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, Detroit's "radio priest," as an economic adviser to the United States delegation at the London Economic Conference.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The modern scientific detective, armed with dragon's-blood powder, ultraviolet ray apparatus and other devices, is steadily improving his ability to discover latent fingerprint clues invisible to the naked eye, says the United States Bureau of Investigation.

LONDON, June 14 -- Common sense in international politics, which should involve no principles vastly different from those necessary for a good cattle deal, is the philosophy Ralph W. Morrison has brought to the World Economic Conference.

A charge that behind the screen of the controversy between the New York Stock Exchange and the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation foreign chemical interests subsidized by governments abroad are driving to obtain control of the corporation was made in a long letter sent yesterday to its stockholders by Orlando F. Weber, its president, in response to advertisements attempting to align the stockholders against the management.

The first of a series of weekly show-boat cruises on the Hudson River will be made tonight by the steamer Bear Mountain, under the auspices of Mrs. Austin F. Hancock of 1,085 Park Avenue. The boat will leave the Battery at 8 o'clock and stop at West 132d Street, then proceeding up the river and returning about midnight.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., June 14 -- Mrs. Harrison Williams of Bayville won today two ribbons, a blue and a yellow, with her entries of outdoor blooms in the decorative classes in the final judging of the Summer Flower Show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society which closed tonight in the bulb building on the John Scheeper's place.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 14 -- Brown University's baseball team scored its second successive victory over Tale today, 5 to 3, to capture the annual series with the Elis.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 14 -- Dartmouth took the lead in points today, but individual honors went to a Williams boat as the sixth annual championship regatta of the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Asso- ciation got under way at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 14 -- Cornell snapped Princeton's fourgame winning streak today, taking both games of an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League doubleheader by 5 -- 3 and 6 -- 3. The double triumph sent Cornell from sixth place in the league standing to a tie with Harvard for fourth.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If one is kind, one wonders if the latest enunciation of the Milk Control Board is an example of bureaucracy gone mad; if one is unkind, one wonders at the motives of the board in issuing such an order "In the matter of furnishing of ice by milk dealers. It is hereby ordered, that:

BUFFALO, June 14 -- A sharp rebuke to parishes whose official boards had dipped into funds given for outside benevolences and used the money for their running expenses was administered by the United Lutheran Synod of New York this afternoon.

LONDON, June 14 -- The American and British viewpoints, which are destined to play a dominant part in determining the fate of the World Economic Conference, were placed before the delegates today in two lengthy speeches, one by Secretary Hull and the other by Chancellor of the Exchequer Chamberlain.

President ROOSEVELT agrees to accept the British payment of $10,000,000 as "acknowledgment "of the debt pending final settlement." He adds that, under the circumstances, this partial payment cannot be regarded as a default.

Mrs. Anna Woerishoffer, widow of Charles Woerishoffer, Wall Street operator of several decades ago, left gross assets of $13,065,701 and a net estate of $12,584,344, it was shown by a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. She died in Switzerland Aug. 28, 1931.

Mayor O'Brien disclosed last night that he was considering the possibility of using $22,000,000 in rapid transit sinking funds for relief purposes this year or next. During the day the Board of Estimate again delayed action on the $30,000,000 tax program to raise relief funds.
BOSTON, June 14 -- The Yankees were still careening in a most extraordinary manner today as they engaged in another weird encounter with the Red Sox, emerging once again a bad second.
Settlement of the $25 a share assessment suit being pressed in Supreme Court against 170 stockholders of the defunct Bank of United States appeared likely yesterday.
Business on the Cotton Exchange was mainly professional yesterday and prices moved nervously in a 15-point range, ending 1 point higher to 2 points lower than on Tuesday.

LONDON, June 14 -- Many European listeners at the World Economic Conference today were not impressed by Secretary Hull's speech. They disliked its evangelical tone in view of the fact that the economic nationalism which he denounced is regarded in Europe as having been even more characteristic of United States policy in the last decade than of Old World countries.

A man, his wife and an alleged incendiarist, whom they were accused of hiring for $50, were arrested yesterday in the Bronx on charges of attempted arson. Chief Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy said he had found a candle burning amid paper soaked in benzine in the couple's apartment, which is in a fifty-four-family building at 623 East 140th Street.

LONDON, June 14 -- A proposal for a world pact of economic nonaggression, looking toward the abolition of all weapons of economic warfare, was made at the World Economic Conference today by Maxim Litvinoff of Soviet Russia.

LONDON, June 14 -- Following is the text of the address of Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in the House of Commons tonight announcing payment of $10,000,000 to the United States as acknowledgment of the debt instalment due tomorrow:

WEST NEWTON, Mass., June 14 -- Winning six of the last seven matches, the Philadelphia district women's golf team upset New York in the opening Griscom Cup matches at the Brae Burn Country Club today. The score was 10 to 5.

A new high-efficiency, sodiumvapor electric lamp developed In Europe was demonstrated yesterday at the annual meeting of the New York Electrical Society. Engineers believe it will be the street illuminant of the future. Because of its peculiar yellow light, it is said greatly to surpass in efficiency ordinary street-lighting bulbs.

Nazis Against Bible. Pastor KUPTSCHE of West Prussia, express ing the Nazi view about the "Jewish" Bible, declares: "National Socialists will certainly have nothing to do with a church in which the Old Testament is to be preserved as holy writ, as the present reorganizers of the church would have it."

As the climax of a family quarrel, Arthur Bower, 39 years old, a retired navy bandmaster, shot and killed his sister-in-law, Mrs. Grier T. Manning, 32, and then himself at the Manning home at 130-56 228th Street, St. Albans, Queens, yesterday morning, according to the police.

BERLIN, June 14 -- The sagging tendency on the Boerse that began in several issues yesterday gained momentum today. Losses on the stock market ranged up to 5 per cent, and on the bond market up to 2 per cent. The turnover was small, however, and losses were chiefly due to the almost complete absence of buying orders.

Just when did the myth arise that Brother Jonathan, a drefful smart man at home, is a poor critter when he is negotiating with foreigners? History contradicts the legend. In the settlement of international controversies by arbitration the United States has usually been either more fortunate or more astute than the party of the second part.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- After negotiations of several weeks, Secretary Woodin la about ready to authorize a 50 per cent payment to depositors in the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company of New York City.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 14 The crews of Yale and Harvard devoted today's program mainly to conditioning work. All the hard preparation has been ended for the regatta Friday.

RYE, N.Y., June 14 -- Princeton and Harvard, traditional rivals for more than half a century, gained the final round of the intercollegiate polo championship today at the Westchester Country Club and will clash in the final here on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Great Britain's payment of $10,000,000 on her June war-debt instalment of nearly $76,000,000, and President Roosevelt's assertion that the offer did not constitute a default, stirred the Senate into immediate response this afternoon.

E. 56th St., 239-245, 100x100.4; four-story garage; 235 East Fifty-sixth Street Corp. against Kamy Realty Corp.: due, $89,665; costs. $306; taxes, $9,348; prior mortgage, $130,000; to plaintiff for $131,000.

The provision in the Bank Bill for insurance of deposits is a compromise of House and Senate plans. The Vandenberg amendment, which would have set up a temporary system of guarantees on July 1, has been discarded. Unless the President exercises discretionary power given him, and "by proclamation fixes an earlier date," the temporary plan will not become effective until Jan. 1.

THIELLS, N.Y., June 14 -- Further steps toward completion of Letchworth Village, the State's largest institution for mental defectives, was celebrated here in the hills west of Haverstraw today with the laying of eleven cornerstones for the last of the buildings as originally planned.
Joseph P. Rend, brother-in-law of Charles E. Mitchell, testified yesterday that he urged Mrs. Mitchell to buy National City Bank stock in 1929 and offered to help her carry it.

Steel operations this week have risen to 47 per cent of the ingot capacity of the industry, compared with 44 per cent a week ago, according to the weekly review of The Iron Age. Production in the Chicago district is at the rate of 46 per cent, against 42 per cent in the previous week, and in Pittsburgh it is at 35 per cent, against 32.

OMAHA, Neb., June 14 -- Weary after an enthusiastic home town welcome day full of hand-shaking, speeches and noisy parading, Johnny Goodman, national open golf champion, tonight had eyes for only one thing -- the national amateur crown.
NEW YORK. Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Tilney have left the Carlyle for their Summer place in Oyster Bay.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I would like to voice through your columns my protest against the infamous taxes which it is proposed to levy against the motorists, and to ask if our legislators do not realize that all unjust taxation tends to defeat its own ends, and that if levied it will mean the giving up of driving by many whose only pleasure it now is.

Managers Bill Terry of the Giants and Bill McKechnie of the Boston Braves selected the wrong starting pitchers for yesterday's game at the Polo Grounds. But because he discovered his mistake earlier than McKechnie, Memphis Bill overcame his error and had the satisfaction of seeing his Giants win, 8 to 5.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 14 -- With Tommy Hitchcock leading the attack, John Hay Whitney's Greentree quartet advanced into the second round of the third Westbury Challenge Cup tournament by downing the Great Neck polo team, 8 to 7, today, at the Meadow Brook Club.

One of the most encouraging decisions with regard to the future of New York racing was made last night when the directors of the Westchester Racing Association decided to carry on to the fullest in the conduct of the Fall meeting. They will not curtail a single one of the traditional stakes which have for years marked the program.
Sales of housing properties featured realty trading in Manhattan yesterday.

LONDON, June 14 -- "Real if slow progress" on the technical side of de facto monetary stabilization negotiations is reported from both American and French quarters tonight. On the political side, where all agree the heart of the whole question lies, the differences between the French and Americans, however, grew more acute.

Fire Marshal BROPHY'S arrest of two men and a woman charged with attempted arson calls attention again to this ancient and destructive criminal activity. JOHN KENLON once estimated that not less than 25 per cent of the fires in New York City are of incendiary origin.

VIENNA, June 14 -- The indignation in Austria over the terrorist outrages of the last forty-eight hours, which no one, despite National Socialist denials, doubta are the work of members of that party, has been intensified by news of the arrest and expulsion from Germany of Dr. Erwin Wasserbaeck, the Austrian press attache in Berlin.

CINCINNATI, June 14 (AP) -- Charlie Root held the Cincinnati team to two scattered hits today, refused to permit a Redleg to get past second and took the final game of the series for the Cubs by a 7-to-0 score.

LONDON, June 14 -- Ivor Novello's new play, "Proscenium," opened at the Globe Theatre tonight with the author appearing as Gray Ranor, and giving what the critics declare to be the best performance of his career.

BARNSTABLE, Mass., June 14 (AP) -- The defense In the trial of Kenneth Buck, charged with kidnapping Margaret (Peggy) McMath, gained its first advantage today when an alleged second confession was declared inadmissable as evidence.

LONDON, June 14 -- Throughout six hours of speeches to which the World Economic Conference was devoted today, it was not the address of Neville Chamberlain, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, presenting the first really concrete proposals for curing the world's economic ills that stirred the delegates most.

COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday-1 3/4 per cent for the best names. Tuesday-1 3/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-tour months' papsr. * * * May Shoe Output Broke Record. Shoe production during the month of May, according to estimates made in the trade yesterday, reached a figure of approximately 33,000,000 pairs, surpassing the previous peak for the month reached in 1929, when 29,159,000 pairs were turned out.

Futures trading in the principal commodities on local exchanges marked time yesterday in the absence of sufficient information with respect to currency stabilization and other matters under preliminary discussion at the London Economic Conference, and some staples moved moderately lower.

More than 5,000 persons attended the eighty-eighth commencement of Fordham University on the campus in the Bronx yesterday. They were forced to hurry for shelter near the close of the exercises, when rain which had threatened most of the afternoon began to fall.
Opening a five-game series at Jersey City yesterday the Rochester Red Wings won by 13 -- 12 in ten innings.

ideals and achievements of the American Joint Distribution Committee, of which he has been an officer since its inception, and declared that "its sole purpose has always been to relieve suffering humanity wherever the need was greatest."

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the formation of the firm of Mallory, Eisemann Co., effective on July 1. The partnership will be composed, of Franklin I. Mallory, Alex Eisemann, Lawrence Cowen, Charles Smolka and George Archinal.

LONDON, June 14 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Neville Chamberlain spoke as follows in the World Economic Conference today, following a brief review of the world economic history which produced the present chaos:

Winners in the Public School music contests, which were held under the joint sponsorship of the New York Music Week Association and the Board of Education, were announced yesterday. Awards of silver cups will be presented in the Fall.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Great Britain, in a note made public by the State Department today, tendered a partial payment of $10,000,000 on its World War debt instalment of $75,950,000, due tomorrow, and asked for an immediate review of the whole debt. cause this country had made "fabulous fortunes out of the war."

A plan bringing together both factions in the Central Park controversy was agreed upon yesterday by representatives of the Park Association of New York, Park Commissioner Sheehy and the Community Councils, according to a statement by the latter organization.

Irwin Steingut, minority leader of the Assembly frorn John H. McCooey's home district, the Eighteenth in Kings County, received warm praise yesterday for his leadership in the last session. The Citizens Union report on the activities of Kings, Queens and Richmond County Assemblymen added, however, that "his good work was more than counterbalanced by abject subservience to local bosses."

If present trends continue, the New York Central Railroad will have a net income of about $1,000,000 in June, against a loss of $3,068,000 in June, 1932, according to F.E. Williamson, president. Figures submitted yesterday to the board of directors showed a net loss of $388,000 in May, compared with one of $3,963,000 in May, 1932.

LONDON, June 14 (AP) -- The following are the Board of Trade figures for the month of May: Exports of British products, L30,760,000; re-exports, foreign goods, L3,820,000; total exports, L34,580,000; total imports, L57,290,000; excess of imports, L22,710,000.

The outsider in a field of six, Mrs. Isabel Sloan's Snap Back nevertheless was clearly the best in the Ballot Handicap, feature at Belmont Park yesterday, and won by a length and a half at the end of a mile.

The defense rested yesterday afternoon in the income tax trial of Charles E. Mitchell. Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard adjourned court until Monday morning. United States Attorney George Z. Medalie and Max D. Steuer, defense counsel, will sum up the evidence on Monday and Tuesday.

Major crimes decreased to a marked extent in New York City during the first part of 1933. Police Commissioner Bolan asserted yesterday in a radio address broadcast by WNYC. The Police Commissioner's talk was one of a series of reports on city departments directed by Mayor O'Brien.

The desirability of not renominating Mayor John P. O'Brien but naming in his stead some man regarded as a stronger candidate has been discussed in Democratic circles in the last few days, it was learned yesterday. A suggestion that has met with some favor is that Surrogate James A. Foley be named and that Mr. O'Brien be put back in his former place on the Surrogate's bench.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Traders in wheat on the Board of Trade jumped to the conclusion today that the proposed processing tax on that grain when used for domestic purposes would be a bearish factor in the market. This brought general selling, and not until the price had dropped 2 cents a bushel from yesterday's finish was the break checked.

WASHINGTON, Friday, June 16. -- The roll-call in the Senate on the adoption of the majority conference report on the Independent Offices Bill, including the Roosevelt compromise on veterans' allowances, was as follows:

CINCINNATI, June 15. -- Abolition of State and county governments, changing States into mere administrative areas and giving increased Importance to cities, was advocated today by S.E. Leland, member of the Illinois State Tax Commission and Professor of Public Finance, University of Chicago.

Nearly 200,000 additional seats were provided in the city's public schools during the five-year period from 1927 to 1932. These and other figures relating to school population are contained in the annual report of the Superintendent of Schools presented to the Board of Education at its meeting yesterday.

Some of the forestry conditions that are behind the present drive to get 275,000 prospective breadline standees out of the city and into the woods are analyzed in "Forestry, An Economic Challenge," by Arthur Newton Pack, just published by Macmillan.

Jobbers Cut Textile Orders. Dry goods wholesalers reported yesterday that they were cutting down the volume of purchases on goods which have advanced sharply, as they are fairly well covered for the time being. So far they have not encountered any difficulty in passing on goods to retailers, as they have been averaging prices and their accounts have not yet been compelled to pay the full advances on most lines.
BERLIN, June 15. -- Vice Chancellor Franz von Papen and Transport Minister Eltz von Ruedenach took part today in the Catholic Corpus Christi procession, which had a wider radius than ever before.

WATERTOWN, Conn., June 15. -- Two prizes at Taft School have been won by R.V.V. Bradley of Fairfield, onn., it was announced today. They are the 1908 medal for "the senior who has done the most for the school" and the Tale-Taft scholarship.

On June 6 Mayor O'BRIEN explicitly promised the bankers not only to secure $30,000,000 of increased revenue, but to ask the Board of Estimate to apply the $22,000,000 surplus in the rapid transit sinking funds to the reduction of the budget for 1934.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 15. -- Mrs. Walter Prichard Eaton had the best exhibit in the Great Barrington Garden Club flower show and was awarded the club trophy, a pewter bowl. Mrs. Carl A. De Gersdorff excelled in peonies and Mrs. Seaver B. Buck and Mrs. George O. Forbes in floral arrangement.

BERLIN, June 15. -- The preliminary examination of Ernst Torgler, former Communist Reichstag member, and Georgi Dimitroff, Blegoi Siminow Popoff and Basil Constantinoff Taneff, Bulgarian Communists, accused of having set fire to the Reichstag building on Feb. 20, has been concluded and the documents on it have been transmitted to the government prosecuting attorneys in Leipzig.
Brokers reported a few realty deals scattered over Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn yesterday.

Cross-examination of Russell F. Van Doorn, vice president of the Long Island Lighting Company, before the Public Service Commission, revealed yesterday that the company had paid $100,000 in premiums on the life insurance policy of its president, E.L. Phillips.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 15. -- The fresh northerly breeze, with which they started, continuing through the night, the craft in the American Yacht Club's race here for the Yale-Harvard regatta arrived at dawn this morning after sailing from Rye, N.Y., last night.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Reports from London that a stabilization agreement was near occasioned considerable surprise here tonight. Administration officials would say nothing at all of a constructive nature, but Secretary Woodin, in a statement issued at the White House, said the London reports could not be founded on fact, since no stabilization agreement could be reached in London, but would have to be approved in Washington by himself and President Roosevelt.
These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area:

Rochester and Jersey City struggled for thirteen innings yesterday at West Side Park, Jersey City, the Red Wings finally winning with a five-run drive. With two on base Clancy hit a homer for the Jerseys in the last half of the thirteenth, but the visitors' lead was too great.

Organization of industry under the National Industrial Recovery Act moved forward at a rapid pace yesterday, as associations here laid plans to increase wages, shorten working hours and eliminate unfair competition.
DETROIT, June 15. -- There are no radical and drastic cures for economic ills, according to Henry Ford.

Reports from London yesterday of a temporary dollar stabilization agreement, construed by Wall Street as marking the interruption of the government's currency inflation program, brought a sharp rise in the dollar and a drop in prices in the stock and commodity markets.

The Paris Prize awarded annually by the Society of Beaux-Arts Architects, regarded as the most important architectural prize to be had by an American student in this country, was won last night by George Frei, a 22-year-old student of New York University.
WEST NEWTON, Mass., June 15. -- New York's Griscom Cup defenders gained an 8-to-7 victory over Boston in the second of the series of intercity golf matches today at the Brae Burn Country Club.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 15. -- Harvard and Yale rested their varsity, jayvee and freshman shells on the boathouse racks tonight, while the Eli combination crew gained the opening victory of the annual regatta with the Crimson.

Major Thomas G. Lanphier, war flier and former commander of the crack First Pursuit Group of Selfridge Field, Mount Clemens, Mich., has entered the brewing industry. As president of the reformed Flanagan-Nay Brewing Corporation he will move into the vast plant of what has been known recently as the Phoenix Cereal Beverage Company, on Tenth Avenue at Twenty-sixth Street.

VATICAN CITY, June 15. -- The magnificent religious ceremonies concluding the first part of the present holy year reached a climax late this afternoon with a eucharistic procession which wound its way around Bernini's famous colonnade in St. Peter's Square before hundreds of thousands of devout Catholics.
LONDON, June 15 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, In pounds sterling:
CHICAGO, June 15. -- The 210 Class 1 railroads served notice on their 1,000,000 union employes today of a 22 1/2 per cent cut in their basic pay, effective Nov. 1.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 15. -- Miguel de Braganza, son of Princess Miguel de Braganza, who is at her Summer home. The Moorings, was among the twenty-nine graduates who received diplomas at St. George's School yesterday during the annual prize day exercises.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Great changes in the real estate business and allied fields were predicted here today to the thousand delegates attending the twenty-sixth annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards in the Stevens Hotel.

CHICAGO, June 15 (AP). -- Promoted from the relief pitching department to a starting job, Bud Tinning today held the Pirates to four hits as the Cubs won their second shutout victory in two days, 5 to 0.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., June 15. -- Finding a new fount of energy in the "new deal" that brings Sam Leslie to the Dodgers for Lefty O'Doul and Watson Clark, Carey's athletes today hammered out a 9-to-3 victory over the Phils to even the series at two each.

David Belasco, theatrical producer, left a gross estalfe of $1,616,835.22, at the time of his death on May 14, 1931. However, shrinkage in securities, losses in the sale of stocks, payment of debts, legacies and other expenses reduced its value to a net of $621,629, according to an accounting filed in Surrogates' Court yesterday.

The Boston Braves concentrated their offensive in one disastrous Inning yesterday at the Polo oGrounds and beat the Giants in the third and last game of the series between the teams, 7 to 4. The victory was the first for the Braves on their visit here.

In failing yesterday to pay $40,000,000 due on its war debt the French Government held to the position it took last December. Then the Chamber of Deputies "invited the Government to defer payment" on the ground that the Hoover moratorium, the Laval conversations in Washington and the reparation settlement at Lausanne had fundamentally altered the status of the war debt agreements.

GREENPORT, L.I., June 15. -- A firemen's parade and contests were the features of the thirty-eighth annual convention of the Southern New York Volunteer Firemen's Association in this village today. Forty-two fire departments were represented.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Senate conferees, confronted by stubborn House support of President Roosevelt's veterans compromise, submitted a majority report tonight receding from their own broader compensation proposal and opened the way for an early adjournment sine die of the extra session.

CHATHAM, N.Y., June 15. -- His Majesty, by Abbedale, world's champion pacer as a two-year-old, raced true to predictions this afternoon to sweep three heats of the three-year-old pace, the feature of gret-away day In the Bay State Circuit.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- An organization keyed up and ready to swing into action under the direction of Hugh S. Johnson, the administrator, tonight awaited the attaching of President Roosevelt's signature to the Industrial Regulation-Public Works Bill.
WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Payments by foreign nations today on their war debts to the United States dwindled to about 8 per cent of the total of $143,604,856 due under the existing agreements.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended June 14, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,209,000,000, a decrease of 511,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $36,000,000 compared with, the corresponding week in 1932.

The value of modernization work in older buildings, both residential and commercial, in lowering vacancies and permitting such structures to compete successfully with newer quarters is being stressed in the second annual building merchandise exposition now in progress on the twelfth, floor of the Lincoln Building.

A thirty-pound rock fragment, taken from the Areopagus where St. Paul preached his sermon to the Athenians, was presented to Bishop Manning at a ceremony yesterday in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

A Brooklyn high school girl and her father, Benjamin Strauss, were killed yesterday afternoon when they were run down by a delivery truck. The mother of the girl, also in the path of the vehicle, was critically injured.

Three times within a stroke of victory In the second set, Miss Norma Taubele, third ranking player In the Eastern Association went down In defeat yesterday in the New York State championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Norman H. Davis, Ambassador at Large, will return from Europe shortly for a conference with President Roosevelt on the work of the disarmament conference at Geneva, the State Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP). -- A plan for reorganization of more than a score of closed banks in Bergen County, N.J., is being formulated in the reorganization division of the Treasury Department. It is said to call for consolidation of a large number of banks now closed.

In 1925 Mrs. W.H. WADE came to the United States to raise a fund for discovering the cause of leprosy and seeking a cure. Together with her husband, a pathologist in the Philippine Health Service, she was only too familiar with the ravages of a disease which afflicts at least 200,000 natives, Japanese and Chinese.

LONDON, June 15. -- The warmth of the British reception to the arrangement for temporary adjustment of the June debt instalment to the United States has been greatly chilled by the icy blasts of criticism directed upon it from some quarters in the United States.

Is there something In the livestock industry that makes those engaged in it hostile to the improvements of nature and human nature so copiously projected by the sages of the New Deal? The proceedings of the sixty-first annual convention of the Wyoming Stock Growers Association are painful reading for excursionists to Utopia, They show a mind unreconciled to the latest and only authoritative gospels of economic, financial, social and moral recovery.

Two Filipino students of navigation launched in Brooklyn yesterday a thirty-foot sloop in which they intend to sail from the Battery next Sunday on a 15,000-mile voyage to the Philippines via the Atlantic, Mediterranean, Indian Ocean and South China Sea.
Mme. Ernestine Schumann-Heink celebrated her seventy-second birthday yesterday.

LONDON, June 15. -- Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss of Austria, who has been attending the World Economic Conference, will fly to Paris tomorrow en route to Vienna. In Paris he will interview Joseph Paul-Boncour, the French Foreign Minister, and then he will return home with the news that Great Britain, France and Italy have finally consented to issue the $40,000,000 loan promised to Austria at Lausanne.

LONDON, June 15. -- Progress was made today, politically and technically, toward a currency truce. This development greatly gratified the French, British, Americans and all others, who attach prime importance to these negotiations just now.
NOME, Alaska, June 15 (AP). -- James Mattern's around-the-world plane Century of Progress passed the deadline of its fuel capacity on a flight from Siberia to Alaska in silence tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated June 13:

With the dollar rallying sensationally in a confused foreign exchange market, stocks passed yesterday through the severest reaction since the recovery began in March. Other markets, particularly wheat and cotton, were driven downward at the same time under heavy selling movements.
WASHINGTON, Friday, June 16. -- The first session of the Seventy-third Congress adjourned sine die at 1:20 o'clock this morning.

DETROIT, Mich., June 15. -- A State social welfare program coordinating with national reconstruction was presented to the National Conference of Social Work here today by David G. Adie, Commissioner of Social Welfare of the State of New York.

A drive to oust Republican Assembly district leaders holding jobs by the grace of Tammany or who have Tammany affiliations was announced yesterday by David B. Costuma. Mr. Costuma is campaign manager of the group seeking to depose Samuel S. Koenig as New York County chairman.

PARIS, June 15. -- Public opinion demands that the sentiments being expressed by leaders at the London Economic Conference be written into formal agreements for governmental action, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, President of Columbia University, declared today, addressing the American Club of Paris.

A warning against the expectation of protecting "the limited industries, the products of which are not important in volume or equal in excellence to what our foreign customers have," was given by Secretary of State Cordell Hull in a radio address from London broadcast throughout the United States yesterday on the Columbia network.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Announcement that President Roosevelt had agreed to a new naval building program costing $238,000.000, with thirty-two war vessels to be built in the next three years, was made today by Secretary Swanson.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that a two-day conference of leaders of the automotive maintenance industry would be held Monday and Tuesday in the auditorium of the new inland freight terminal at 111 Eighth Avenue to consider means of improving transportation within the port district.
PARIS, June 15. -- For the second time France refused to pay the war debt annuity due to the United States today under the agreement signed in 1926.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Hoping that the National Industrial Recovery measure will solve some of their complex problems, but with mental reservations as to what it may mean in labor costs, the nation's bituminous coal leaders prepared today for consideration of a code of fair practices.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Railroads of the United States had a book valuation of $26,091,310,739 on Dec. 31, 1932. Of this, the Interstate Commerce Commission said today, $10,727,401,013 was in Class I, II and III railroads of the Eastern district.
The retirement of a dean and the resignations of two principals of State normal schools were accepted yesterday by the State Board of Regents at a meeting held at 80 Centre Street.

Bernard Baruch's 2-year-old filly, Watch Her, unseated her rider at the post in the Coy Maid Purse at Belmont Park yesterday, and ran away for a total of more than four miles. Her running came to an end when she plunged through a hedge.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The first sane and clarifying utterance concerning President Roosevelt's "forgotten man" that I have seen in print is the report in THE TIMES of Judge Samuel Seabury's address at the University of Rochester.
LARCHMONT. N.Y., June 15. -- Dartmouth won its first Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association championship today with the close of the two-day regatta conducted by the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Commonwealth of Virginia. The N.W. Harris Company, Inc., bidding alone, topped a list of eight banking groups for the issue of $1,000,000 Commonwealth of Virginia certificates of indebtedness dated July 1, 1933, and due on July 1, 1939, naming a price of 101.067 for the bonds as 3 1/4s.

A customs harbor patrol working in the North River before dawn yesterday seized a shipment of crude opium on the deck of the Italian liner Conte di Savoia at her pier at the foot of Forty-sixth Street and frightened off smugglers in a speed boat.

Earnings of the Pennsylvania Railroad for June will put the company "in the black" after depreciation and all charges, for the first six months of this year, according to advices from Chicago quoting W. W. Atterbury, president. He said that the business outlook appeared promising.
NEW YORK. Halvard H. Bachke, the Norwegian Minister, is at the Waldorf-Astoria.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 15. -- Expansion of the public service activities of the Yale School of Fine Arts was pointed out at the anniversary exercises tonight when awards of fellowships, scholarships, certificates and prizes were made.
