Seventy-eight degrees will be awarded tonight at the commencement exercises of the Newark College of Engineering, to be held in the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company auditorium, 300 Broadway, Newark. Dr. Roy V. Wright, editor, will give the commencement address and President Allan R. Cullimore will present the candidates for degrees and read the honors.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Official condemnation of the Hitler regime in Germany and sympathy for the Jews who have been persecuted by the Nazis was asked of the United States Senate in a resolution introduced tonight by Senator Neely, Democrat, of West Virginia.

Mayor O'Brien went to the Italian liner Conte di Savoia at noon yesterday to bid bon voyage to Bishop John J. Dunn of the New York diocese. Bishop Dunn will represent Cardinal Hayes in the first of three pilgrimages to Rome.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Congress, so far as public interest is concerned, has made the mistake of the boy who cried "wolf" too often. It has stayed too long and its sessions have become anticlimactic. There was plenty of room in all the galleries today as the House hit the veterans' allowance shuttlecock back at the Senate once more.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to the action of the Senate in standing out for the restoration of some hundred and fifty millions of dollars of the proposed cuts in pensions, there are certain aspects of the situation that should be considered by every citizen.

With a view to preventing unsound writing down of assets, the New York Stock Exchange now requires corporations which increase their capital surplus through a change in the par value of their stock to state whether they have any intention of charging off assets against this surplus.

BERLIN, June 15. -- The present stagnation on the Boerse while traders are awaiting developments in London was further increased today by the Catholic holiday. Quotations were dependent on a few scattering orders, and although the general tendency was weak, changes stayed within a point or two.
Governor Herbert H. Lehman and Dr. John H. Finley received yesterday the first honorary degrees to be conferred by Yeshiva College.

Every hunter and sportsman in the country will be vitally interested in the report announced yesterday by the Commissioners of the Department of Interior, National Parks of Canada, which was submitted by J.B. Harkin, one of the commissioners.

Archbishop Benjamin, special emissary from the Moscow patriarchate to the North American Diocese of the Orthodox Russian Church, declared last night that "despite the difficulties and persecutions to which the church in Russia is being subjected religion continues to thrive."

The pension question, which has again set Congress by the ears and held up the President's plans, has many complexities. No one can feel sure of being able to steer his way through all of them. But one thing is absolutely plain. It is that the lining up of the entire Republican vote in the Senate in favor of adding millions more to the pension burden was an unblushing and disgraceful partisan demonstration.
Thousands of new applicants for licenses to sell beer were under consideration at the office here of the State Alcoholic Beverage Commission yesterday as the deadline for applications was reached.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reports a net loss of $854,251 after taxes, charges and depreciation for the first quarter of 1933, comparing with a net loss of $2,555,011 for the last quarter of 1932 and contrasting with a net income of $689,186 reported for the first quarter of last year.

LONDON, June 15. -- The World Economic Conference today finished listening to preliminary speeches and appointed two commissions -- one monetary and one economic -- which will meet tomorrow and begin the detailed work of studying concrete problems.

Bank clearings at twenty-one principal cities in the United States took a clear lead not only for the week but for the month to date over corresponding periods a year ago in the week ended on Wednesday. For the week, seven of the major cities went into the plus column and the total was 6.3 per cent ahead of the corresponding week last year.

An informal meeting of executives of several copper companies was held on Wednesday at which a representative of Major Gen. Hugh Johnson, who will supervise enforcement of the National Industrial Recovery Act, outlined to them the procedure under the act and interpreted some of its provisions.
Small housing parcels again made up most of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

HAVANA, June 15. -- Definite solution of Cuba's stormy political problems appeared to be at band today when it was learned that both the Machado Government and the ABC student revolutionary organization, the most active of the opposition groups, have accepted United States Ambassador Sumner Welles as the mediator of their differences.
The Magistrates' Court investigation of 1930, whose disclosure of vice court conditions laid the groundwork for the city investigation that followed it, came to life again yesterday.

Member banks of the American Bankers Association were urged by wire yesterday to telegraph President Roosevelt asking him to veto the Glass-Steagall Bill. The message to the banks was sent by Francis H. Sisson, president of the association. It read:

MOSCOW, June 15. -- Foreign Commissar Litvinoff's speech before the World Economic Conference yesterday is prominently featured on the front pages of the Soviet press today but without editorial comment, perhaps because it was released by the Tass news agency after last midnight.
WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Cash and securities amounting to well over $1,600,000,000 were turned over at the Treasury Department today at the quarterly financing period.

Despite a denial from the Agricultural Adjustment Administration that a decision had been reached on the processing tax, prices on the Cotton Exchange came under heavy selling pressure yesterday. Contracts appeared early and liquidation increased as trading progressed, reaching its largest proportions in the last hour.

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it had organized a subsidiary to consolidate non-operating real estate properties owned by its subsidiaries in various States. The new subsidiary, which is called the United States Steel Corporation (of Delaware), has filed an application for a charter in Dover, Del. The parent company, which has the same name, is incorporated in New Jersey.

General sale to the public of the city's short-term securities to cut down the 5 3/4 per cent interest rate now charged by the bankers will be laid before the Board of Estimate at an early meeting, Mayor O'Brien said last evening.

Two heroes were acclaimed yesterday at the Pomonok Country Club where match play started in the metropolitan amateur golf championship. The pair to gain the spotlight were Mark J. Stuart of Fox Hills and Robert Lester of Canoe Brook.

New York State plans to offer a new issue of $26,595,000 of bonds to bankers on June 28. It will be its first long-term financing since Dec. 15, 1932. Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, is expected to announce the offering formally this week.

BERLIN, June 15. -- With one accord the German press today turns its batteries against any effort on the part of foreign powers to intervene in the conflict between Berlin and Vienna over the activities of the National Socialists in "German Austria."
All commodities broke sharply in yesterday's trading on local exchanges, reflecting the rally in the dollar in foreign exchange markets and the abrupt drop in security values here. Trading was heavy.
WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates June 14 unless otherwise specified:
Max Gordon will leave tonight for Skowhegan, Me. He will remain there for about six weeks.

So numerous and conflicting were the developments bearing upon the markets yesterday that Wall Street was more or less bewildered. But the incident of overshadowing interest to speculators was the agitated movement in the foreign-exchange market.

LIMA, June 15. -- A protest meeting was held this morning by the National Agricultural Society, which addressed a petition to President Benavides, signed by all the leading growers, merchants and shippers regarding the law imposing new duties on cotton and sugar.

The name "Letchworth," given to the institution for the care of mental defectives near Haverstraw, N.Y., has no personal association for the younger generation. Happily, the "Dictionary of American Biography" has not forgotten the man who bore the name in life.
Planned Weather Helps. Without the complete text of the Industrial Recovery Act it is impossible to say if the weather has been included among the enterprises subjected to regulation and control.
CHICAGO, June 15. -- A code drafted under the National Recovery Act was put before independent producers at a meeting here today called to take steps to rehabilitate the oil industry.

Taking advantage of a further reduction of $44,000,000 in the volume of money in circulation, the Federal Reserve System reduced its purchases of United States Government securities to $20,781,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the weekly report of the system, published yesterday, revealed.

A new American opera, "Helen Retires," with music by George Antheil and libretto by John Erskine, will be produced by the opera school of the Juilliard School of Music next Fall, it was announced yesterday by Mr. Erskine, president of the school.
The trading limit for the major leagues passed last night at midnight after the Giants and the Brooklyn Dodgers had completed one of the major transfers of the baseball year.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 15. -- Harvard made a two-run ninth-inning rally today to beat Dart-mouth, 6 to 5, and to even its Eastern Intercollegiate League series with the Hanover nine.

MANILA, June 15. -- Governor General Frank Murphy, in an interview on his arrival today, remarked the sharp contrast between his recent job as Mayor of the highly industralized city of Detroit and his new duties in the primarily agrarian Philippines, which, he said, necessitates an entirely different approach.

BUFFALO, June 15. -- The Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler, president, and the Rev. Paul Andrew Kirsch, both of New York City, the only full time salaried officers of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, have voluntarily taken a third cut of 10 per cent.

LONDON, June 15. -- The World Economic Conference has got down to work and actual working conditions four days after it assembled. This happy situation was reached this evening on its adjournment for the day and earned this compliment from the chairman, Prime Minister MacDonald:
AUGUSTA, Ga., June 15 (AP). -- Angel Rodriguez is under bond of $20,000 on the counterfeiting charge against him. His wife, Sadie Rodriguez, was held on $5,000 bond.
Samuel Rothstein is a sun worshiper, deep in his old heart, though he goes each morning to the synagogue in the Home of Old Israel at 70 Jefferson Street with the other ancients.

The twenty-seventh commencement of Cathedral College of 462 Madison Avenue, the preparatory department of St. Joseph's Seminary and College at Dunwoodie, was held last night for forty graduates in the Cathedral High School auditorium at 562 Lexington Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Friday, June 16. -- Here is a resume of the Democratic platform and the measures passed during the special session looking to fulfillment of its promises.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been reading your editorials on the gold clause repeal, inflation and dollar debasement with keen interest and I sincerely hope they will bear fruit. Yours is truly a public service.
WASHINGTON, June 15. -- President Roosevelt today approved the plans of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration for paying out large amounts to wheat and cotton farmers agreeing to reduce acreage.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, June 15. -- The Paraguayan Government has sent a note to the the League of Nations accepting a proposal for immediate cessation of hostilities and submission of the Chaco dispute to arbitration under conditions to be fixed by authorities appointed by the League.

Princess Erik of Denmark and her two children, the Countess Alexandra and Count Christian; Joseph E. Widener and Mr. and Mrs. P.A.B. Widener will leave tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Europa for the Channel ports. Others sailing on the ship are:
The Church of St. Matthew and St. Timothy, William N. Shaw, clerk, has extended to June 25. 1936. at 5 per cent, the mortgage for $25,000 held from Emma von Twistern on 327-29 E. 86th St.

FOLKESTONE, England, June 15 (AP). -- The United States team continued in the lead in the International Chess Federation tournament today by scoring 5% points in seven games decided in the fourth and fifth rounds against Poland and Belgium, respectively.

BOSTON, June 15. -- The fortunes of the Yankees touched a new low level today when Manager Joe McCarthy suffered a three-day suspension, from President William Harridge of the American League for his run-in with Umpire Bill Summers yesterday.

The Canadian International Paper Company and subsidiary companies report for 1932 consolidated net earnings of $3,649,798 before charges and reserves, and a net loss of $4,694,522 after these deductions. Gross sales amounted to $30,227,722.

MILWAUKEE, June 15. -- The practice of birth control by the "better elements" of the country may be the cause of much of the present-day troubles, Dr. Barton C. Hirst of Philadelphia told the American Medical Association at its convention here today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I suggest that in the larger postoffices the machine-driven automatic canceling machines be fitted with an imprinting metered attachment which would stamp unstamped envelopes and postcards with the required postage.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As an architect I am naturally supposed to know nothing about economics. Thus qualified, I feel no hesitation in speaking, considering myself in a class with most of our statesmen, Congressmen and economists.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- How much new currency will be issued backed by silver bullion paid by Great Britain as an instalment on its war debt will soon be determined by the Treasury and it is possible that all of it will be used for that purpose.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- General Hugh S. Johnson, chairman of the Industrial Administrative Board, warned industry tonight that a critical economic stage had been reached at which there was danger of relapse from recent improvement because prices had risen faster and further than wages.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Senate Republican leaders today said that they are deeply gratified over having last night achieved party solidarity for the first time in eight years. They referred to the fact that the full list of regular and Progressive Republicans voted as a unit against the administration compromise on veterans' allowances.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Extraordinary powers granted in the first session of the Seventy-third Congress to President Roosevelt are:

Members of the Cuban revolutionary junta in New York met yesterday to consider the mediation plan accepted in Havana by President Machado and the ABC revolutionary society. The plan provides for mediation by Sumner Welles, United States Ambassador to Cuba.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered more than a dollar a bale Yesterday and ended at gains of 19 to 28 points.

There will be next week a comparative lull in new municipal financing as bond issues Aggregating only $6,864.592 will come up for award. This total compares with this week's revised figure of $32,878,353, and with the weekly average for the year thus far of 512,662,833.

WEST NEWTON, Mass., June 16. -- Boston captured the Griscom Cup today for the thirteenth time in the twenty-nine-year history of the women's intercity golf competition. The local team defeated Philadelphia, 10 to 5, in the concluding match of the round-robin series at the Brae Burn Country Club.
NEW YORK. Edward A. Dow, the American Consul General to Chile, with Mrs. Dow and the members of their family, sailed last night and will go to the consulate at Santiago.

BRIARCLIFF, MANOR, N.Y., June 16 -- A prediction that public libraries eventually would take the place of bookstores in the distribution of literature was made here tonight by Joseph W. Lippincott, president of J.B. Lippincott, Philadelphia publishers.

Indications of the usual seasonal slackening were not evident in the reports received this week, which emphasized increasing employment and advancing wages, with plans of Summer closing abandoned as orders make necessary a further widening of schedules and many industries are booked well into the early Fall, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is .reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legral for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers:
VIENNA, June 36. -- There were scenes of unexampled violence today at the meeting of the Lower-Austrian Diet.

Bond prices on the Stock Exchange were depressed further yesterday, with the losses greater than the averages indicate for the reason that they were chiefly in the better-rated issues. In the domestics, railroad bonds in particular were weak, while in the foreigns, dealings were fairly general.
STOCKHOLM, June 16. -- King Gustaf celebrated his seventy-fifth birthday quietly today at the Castle of Tullgarm, near Tresa. The King and Queen of Denmark were among the guests.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The following Marine Corps changes were announced today:

Numerous business leases in the midtown area of Manhattan were reported yesterday. Among the tenants is the Tubize Chatillon Corporation, which, in moving to another floor of the 2 Park Avenue Building, will occupy 9,000 square feet, or double its present space.

Following two tense matches that went to the last green, Mark J. Stuart of Fox Hills and Walter Rothenberg of Winged Foot gained the final of the metropolitan amateur golf championship at the Pomonok Country Club at Flushing yesterday.

Having matched wits in the trading mart just before the bell rang on any further player deals for the season, the Giants and Dodgers carried their argument out on the Polo Grounds yesterday. To the annoyance of slightly more than half the crowd of 7,500 the Brooklyn contingent proved the first to draw a dividend on the transaction.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Members of Congress in large groups were leaving Washington today by train, bus, automobile and airplane, going back to their homes throughout the country with the benediction of President Roosevelt for having done a good job.
CHICAGO, June 16 -- A cheerful picture of the financial outlook in the real estate field was given here today as the convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards ended.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 16 -- For the third consecutive year Harvard won the annual four-mile crew classic with Yale this evening. The Crimson finished one and three-quarter lengths ahead after one of the most dramatic struggles in the eighty-one-year history of the series.

William Hodson, executive director of the Welfare Council of New York City, was elected president last night of the National Conference of Social Work, an organization representing virtually every health and welfare agency in this country.

A code for the operation of the steel industry under the National Industrial Recovery Act is being drafted here by leaders of the industry and probably will be completed in a week or ten days, it was announced yesterday by Robert P. Lamont, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The Seaboard Air Line Railway earned $580,000 from the emergency freight surcharges in 1932, but, because the company was in receivership, it was permitted to retain this sum instead of transferring it to the loan pool of the Railroad Credit Corporation.

Dr. Edgar Stern-Rubarth, editor of Wolff's New Bureau in Germany, arrived here yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Albert Ballin. He said there was no question of equality between Jew and Gentile in Germany, and that the Jews had become a secondary people in that country.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 16 -- Alumni of Princeton University gathered today for their annual class reunions which are held each year on the week-end preceding the commencement activities of the senior class.

Pursuant to the authority of "An Act to Encourage National Industrial Recovery, to Foster Fair Competition and to Provide for the Construction of Certain Useful Public Works and for Other Purposes," approved June 16, 1933, and in order to effectuate Title II -- Public Works and Construction Projects -- thereof:

FOLKESTONE, England, June 16 (AP). -- The United States team remained in the lead in the International Chess Federation tournament today as the sixth round matches were played and several from earlier rounds completed. Czechoslovakia remained in second place, followed by Austria, France, Sweden, Hungary, Lithuania and Poland.
CHICAGO, June 16 (AP). -- The first five batters drove Bill Swift from the mound in the first inning with successive hits today and the Cubs went on to a 9-to-1 victory over the Pirates.
The Annalist reports rises in both its indexes, the weekly index of wholesale commodity prices and the monthly index of business activity, the latter of which covered May.
Among a dozen Manhattan and Bronx properties bid in at foreclosure auctions yesterday was the eighteen-story building at the southeast corner of Broadway and Maiden Lane. The results follow:

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- A check of the 1,256 nominations sent to the Senate by President Roosevelt reveals that not one postmaster was nominated while the administration's legislative program was pending.

VIENNA, June 16. -- Otto Klemperer, who was one of the candidates for the post of conductor of the Vienna State Opera, has accepted an invitation to conduct eighty-four concerts by the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra from October, 1933, to the end of April, 1934.

Simon Guggenheim, president of the American Smelting and Refining Company, will sail with his wife today on the French liner Ile de France. Also aboard will be Sosthenes Behn, chairman of the board of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company; Charles H. Lauru, financial adviser to the Chinese Government, with Mrs. Lauru, and William Travers Jerome, former New York District Attorney.

A seat on the New York Stock Exchange was sold yesterday at this year's high price, $250,000, which was established by a sale made on Wednesday. The Exchange announced that arrangements for the transfer had been made.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:
LONDON, June 16 -- The World Economic Conference went to work in two sections today-monetary and economic, respectively. The monetary commission, as it is called, made the most progress.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Postmaster General Farley, as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, issued a statement tonight, voicing his pride in the record of Congress. His statement read:

MONTREAL, Que., June 16. -- Production of newsprint in Canadian mills in May was 24,017 tons larger than in April, the greatest for any month of this year and only slightly less than in May, 1932. The increase was attributed to an enlarged demand from the United States, the principal market.

PEARY LODGE, Greenland, June 13 -- Our botanist, Herbert Gardner, is searching the warmer southern areas and has occasionally been rewarded by discovering early flowering plants -- the first systematic collection from this part of Greenland.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Complications of unusual character in connection with the application of non-member banks for entrance to the Federal Reserve System arose today.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Assuming unprecedented peacetime control over the nation's economic life. President Roosevelt placed in operation today his sweeping program for recovery from the depression.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16 -- The award of twenty-one prizes for scholarship, including the Sumner Prize of $450 for the best dissertation in the social sciences, was announced today by Harvard University.

Supreme Court Justice William Harmon Black lost yesterday the first round of his legal battle to force the city to pay him his full salary of $25,000 a year. His colleague, Justice John F. Carew, denied his application for a mandamus writ to require the city to pay the full salary rather than the $22,500 which justices get under the city's economy program.

Speaking Their Pieces. It took the London Conference just four days to absorb the preliminary ceremonial oratory discharged by sixty-six nations. The average daily record is better than that, because the speaking did not really hit its stride until the second day.

Friday, June 16, 1933. The money market was dull. Quotations for all classes were unchanged. Stock Exchange call loans were 1 per cent, and Street trades i. Time money, acceptances and commercial paper remained firm.
MOSCOW, June 16. -- Leading editorials in Soviet newspapers were devoted today to Foreign Commissar Litvinoff's speech before the World Economic Conference.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- A marked increase in automotive exports during the first quarter of 1933 is cited as an indication of improved foreign demand for American, products in the regular foreign trade review made public today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Hard times were experienced in the United States a hundred and fifteen years ago. From The Middlesex Gazette, published at Middletown, Conn., we reprint part of an editorial in the issue of Dec. 24, 1818, which reads almost as if written today:

American shipping men expressed concern yesterday over the status of the government's ship subsidy program which will be discussed by the World Economic Conference in London during the next few days. The British delegation to the conference is expected to lead the attack on government aid and no statement has been made by the American delegation to indicate its position.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The article by Judge Finis J. Garrett in THE NEW YORK TIMES, regarding the loans made by the France of Louis XVI to the American Colonies in their struggle for independence is very interesting, especially the statement that the Republic repaid all her loans in full.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- For the third successive afternoon, Apprentice Jack Westrope, who is leading all riders on American tracks in the number of victorious mounts this year, rode three winners at Lincoln Fields today. They increased his total for 1933 to 112.

Direct sale of city securities to the public at interest rates not exdeeding 5 1/2 per cent was authorized by the Board of Estimate yesterday. The action was taken upon the recommendation of Controller Charles W. Berry.

President Roosevelt's success in overcoming his physical handicap was stressed yesterday by Dr. Ira S. Wile, psychiatrist. Dr. Wile spoke to the graduates of the Institution for the Improved Instruction of Deaf-Mutes at 904 Lexington Avenue.

The eighteen-day meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club at Aqueduct will begin this afternoon, with the Queens County Handicap as the featured race. This $2,500 added test of a mile for 3-year-olds and upward has attracted a field of eleven, including Questionnaire and the unbeaten Sation.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The text of Secretary Wallace's statement, announcing plans for levying a processing tax on wheat was as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 -- Prosperity depends largely on cooperation between industry and the government, Henry I. Harriman, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, asserted here today in an address at a centenary luncheon of the Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce.

BOMBAY, June 16 -- Mahatma Gandhi's son, Devidas, was married today to Miss Luxmi Raja Gopal Achariar, the daughter of an all-India Nationalist Congress leader, in the face of a storm of opposition from the Orthodox Hindus in Poona, on the ground that he was breaking all precedent by marrying a woman of higher caste.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15. -- Sweatshop practices such as brought to light by the legislative inquiry into factory conditions in Pennsylvania will be outlawed under operation of the National Industrial Recovery Act, Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, declared today during a visit here to give, the commencement address at the Baldwin School, Bryn Mawr.

BOLIVAR, Mo., June 16 (AP). -- Charles (Pretty Boy) Floyd, notorious Oklahoma outlaw, and a companion, Adam Ricchetti, kidnapped Sheriff Jack Killingsworth here today and drove away in a stolen automobile, eluding pursuit.

DETROIT, June 16. -- A resolution adopted today by more than 1,200 delegates at the National Conference of Social Work assailed the Hitler government's "intolerance, brutality and barbarism against unarmed, innocent and defenseless individuals and groups in Germany."

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Ewing Y. Mitchell, a lawyer of Springfield, Mo., received a recess appointment from President Roosevelt today as Assistant Secretary of Commerce in charge of civil eronautics, in place of Clarence M. Young, who resigned.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- The belief that prices could be regulated by changing the gold content of the dollar was described as "fallacious in principle" today by Fred I. Kent, foreign exchange supervisor attached to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 16 -- Already much interest is being taken in next month's intercollegiate tennis tournament at the Casino, in which Yale and Harvard will represent this country and Oxford and Cambridge will represent England. It will be the ninth tournament of the series.

ALBANY, June 16. -- Justice Staley in Supreme Court today enjoined the Alcoholic Liquor Control Board from enforcing its rule that notices required to be published by licensees should be printed only in daily newspapers, excepting where there were no daily publications.

While the adjournment of Congress, with the better part of the President's legislative program intact, was a distinct relief yesterday, the uncertainty surrounding the status of the dollar was again an unsettling market influence.

When he signed the Industrial Recovery Bill yesterday President ROOSEVELT stated that "history" would probably regard it as "the "most important and far-reaching "legislation ever enacted by the "American Congress." That depends upon the result.

The nine-story apartment house at 178 East Seventieth Street was reported yesterday as having been sold by the Drydock Savings Bank to Eugene J. Lang, architect, who immediately resold it to a syndicate of investors. The plot measures 52 by 100.5 feet.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 16 -- Eight goals by Philip Iglehart, No. 2 on the Aiken Knights, enabled his team to down Winston Guest's Templeton quartet, 10 to 9, in a thrilling second-round match of the Westbury Challenge Cup tournament today at the Meadow Brook Club.
ST. PAUL, June 16 -- William Hamm, aged 39, St. Paul millionaire, was kidnapped yesterday and is being held for $100,000 ransom, it was announced tonight.

Depositors in the 7,000 member banks of the Federal Reserve System throughout the country received no interest yesterday on their demand deposits. This was the first concrete result of the signing of the Glass-Steagall bank bill by President Roosevelt.

After a conference yesterday between Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Beer Board, and Police Commissioner James S. Boland it was made known that Governor Lehman probably would make a statement within a few days outlining the rules for enforcement of the beer laws.

CHICAGO, June 16 (AP). - -Surpassing even the mark of Ralph Metcalfe, Marquette's great Negro sprinter in the 100-yard dash. Jimmy Owens, from East Technical High School of Cleveland, stole the show today in the preliminaries of the national interscholastic track and field championship meet.
Richard C. Patterson Jr., who retired last September as Commissioner of Correction, has informed Republican and fusion leaders that he will not be a candidate for Mayor.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The tenor of the United States notes, drafted today, to the defaulting war-debtor nations remained a mystery tonight. The notes, replying to all debtors, including those who made ''token payments," were gone over carefully by President Roosevelt, Acting Secretary of State Phillips and Assistant Secretary Moley almost up to the time the President left Washington on his vacation trip.

Thomas Patrick Morris, 53 years old, the houge painter who last year filed a claim before Surrogate Foley for a share of the $45,000,000 Wendel estate, was found guilty of conspiracy in General Sessions yesterday. His indictment grew out of the demand of Surrogate Foley that District Attorney Grain lay the matter before the grand jury.
BOSTON, June 16 -- The Circuit Court of Appeals today reversed Federal Judge James A. Lowell's decision granting a writ of habeas corpus to George Crawford, Negro, wanted in Virginia for murder.

"Governors' Night" was celebrated at the Atlantic Beach Club, Atlantic Beach, L.I., last night as the club's first large entertainment of the season. Many dinners were given by the governing board and the members. The event was featured by a special entertainment.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Soon after July 1, Secretary Wallace announced today, the farm relief plan under which wheat growers agreeing to curtail their crops will receive approximately $150,000,000 will become operative.
LONDON, June 16. -- Chancellor Dollfuss bade goodbye today to the World Economic Conference, which made much of him, and to London which had made of him a sort of vestpocket hero.
The quotations are for three-four months paper.

For the third successive year Harvard won its annual crew race with Stale on the Thames River at New London, Conn., last evening. The Crimson captured the seventy-first varsity four-mile contest by a length and three-quarters, coming from behind in the last mile to triumph before a crowd of 35,000.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated June 14:

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is interesting to note that long before the Christian era Plato complained that "whereas in simpler matters, like shoemaking, we think only a specially trained person will serve our purpose, in politics we presume that any one who knows how to get votes knows how to administer a city or a State."

CHICAGO, June 16 -- University of Southern California, by placing ten athletes in the preliminaries today, ranked as a favorite to win the National Collegiate A.A. track and field championships tomorrow night.

BERLIN, June 16 -- Despite a number of favorable factors the Boerse continued weak and listless today. A favorable foreign trade balance, the standstill agreement in London and firm quotations on German loans abroad seemed to provide stimulus at the opening, but stagnation developed soon and resulted in losses of 2 to 3 per cent, especially after traders detected what they believed were sales for foreign account.
New recruits will not be accepted in the Citizens Military Training Camps this Summer, according to a telegram sent by the War Department to the Military Training Camps Association in Chicago.

LONDON, June 16. -- Reports that an agreement on stabilization of the pound and dollar had been reached and might be announced after the Stock Exchange closed tomorrow were again flying arottad London today but were emphatically denied by the United States delegation and British officials.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While motoring to New York from Mount Kisco on June 14 I came upon a dog which had been hit by a motor on Central Avenue, Yonkers. I helped it to the side of the road and then got two policemen from the Second Precinct in Yonkers.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., June 16 -- Class day and commencement exercises for this year's class will be held tomorrow morning, afternoon and evening at Lawrenceville School. At the class day ceremonies in the morning, the ivy oration will be delivered by John H. Heminway of New York, the flag speech by William F. Oechler of Woodhaven, L.I., and the class day speech by Charles P. Kogge of Asbury Park.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Executive orders issued today by President Roosevelt in appointing administrators and special boards under the National Industrial Recovery Act follow:

LONDON, June 16. -- The economic commission of the world conference, the range of whose work covers virtually everything but purely monetary questions, held its first meeting today. It divided its multifarious subjects under four broad headings and asked each nation promptly to submit detailed proposals.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- President Roosevelt today agreed to allot about $9,362,000 for the construction of airplanes for the navy in addition to the proposed construction of thirty-two war vessels authorized under the Industrial Recovery Act.

Supreme Court Justice John L. Walsh reserved decision yesterday on a taxpayer's motion to restrain the city from paying $6,369,000 of tax funds to meet the 1933 interest and amortization charges on bonds issued to finance construction of the Eighth Avenue subway.

Declines in prices continued yesterday on local commodities, although in some cases there were signs of firmness. All staples, however, moved to lower levels in the futures markets, and most of the contract grades were lower. The trading volume subsided somewhat.

Three prominent clergymen from Scotland will preach this Summer in this city and other principal cities of this country. Their visit will be under the auspices of the committee on interchange of preachers and speakers, which consists of representatives of the World Alliance for International Friendship, the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America and the Church Peace Union.

Veteran and high ranking officers of the police department must go to school again. Commissioner Bolan wants a more military bearing on the part of men who have not drilled or walked post with a nightstick for years. Moreover, he plans to have a permanent educational and drill system for inspectors, deputy inspectors, captains, lieutenants and sergeants.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Roosevelt left on his vacation tonight after working hard all day and signing all the important bills passed in the final days of Congress. Following a driving four months, filled with great responsibilities, the President boarded his train soon after 8:30, saying that he felt "tired but happy that Congress has ended its important legislative program so successfully."

LONDON, June 16. -- An agreement reached today between Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, and the foreign bankers' committee, provides for the postponement for the present of repayment of the capital of the German short-term credits covered by the standstill agreement and also that the creditors' committees "will be advised by a consultative committee" to recommend a reduction of interest rates.

Abstention from politics is a fundamental principle of that international society of writers, the P.E.N. From its eleventh congress, held recently in a Yugoslavian town, the German delegates seceded. A motion proposed by the American delegate, HENRY SEIDEL CANBY, deploring chauvinism, and insisting that literature and art be untouched by political passion, was passed.

DERBY, June 16 (Canadian Press). -- The cricket match between the British West Indies and Derby was drawn late today, the time element for the second time this week robbing the West Indies of an apparently sure victory. The scores were: British West Indies, 281 and 346 for eight, declared; Derby, 319 and 125 for five.
JOHN GILPIN'S horse was a staid and sober animal compared to Mr. Bernard Baruch's Watch Her, the foolish filly that put up such a remarkable performance in the Coy Maid Purse at Belmont on Thursday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 -- The Pennsylvania Company and the Pennsylvania Railroad Company were authorized to retain their stock holdings in the Wabash Railway and the Lehigh Valley Railroad in a decision handed down here today by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.

Following her victory of Thursday over Miss Norma Taubele, Mrs. Henry C. Brunie eliminated another of the ranking favorites in ths Women's New York State championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Roosevelt's statement outlining the administration's policy under the Industrial Recovery Act and detailing methods of procedure, was as follows:
Diplomas and awards were presented yesterday to eleven graduates of the New York School for the Deaf at the 115th annual exercises of that institution at 99 Fort Washington Avenue.

Fluke and weakfish have begun to run in Great South Bay in good style, according to reports from Lindenhurst, Bay Shore and vicinity. Weaks weighing three and four pounds already have been taken and smaller ones are running abundantly.

BERLIN. June 16. -- The beginning on Aug. 1 of a year of service at manual labor, made obligatory on German university students by the new government, had a precelebration today in Franz Josef Square, opposite the University of Berlin.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Bids will be asked at once by the Treasury Department on Federal buildings to cost $25,000,000, It was announced today after a conference between Postmaster General Farley and L.W. Robert, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury.

Discrepancies in an inventory and appraisal of the properties of the Long Island Lighting Company were brought out yesterday before the Public Service Commission in its rate investigation. The errors were in favor of the company.

Controller BERRY'S plan to sell city securities over the counter, approved by the Board of Estimate yesterday, has to do broadly with three different kinds of city paper. He proposes a more intensive effort to dispose of the "baby bonds" authorized last Winter as a means of encouraging property owners to anticipate tax payments.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 16 -- A gallant finish by the Harvard junior varsity crow enabled the Crimson to divide the two minor races with Yale on the ruffled waters of the Thames this morning.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP). -- A $14,000,000 profit was declared to the Federal Trade Commission today as having been realized from the sale in 1927 of control holdings of the Laclede Gas Light Company of St. Louis, acquired in 1924.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Any idea that the administration's emergency railroad program makes him "a Federal railroad czar" was repudiated by Joseph B. Eastman, Interstate Commerce Commissioner, in a statement following his appointment today by President Roosevelt as transportation coordinator.

Three city P.S.A.L. senior high school championships -- baseball, handball and golf-are scheduled to be decided today. The title baseball game between Jamaica High of Queens and George Washington High of Manhattan is the outstanding event and is expected to attract 20,000 fans to Ebbets Field.

JERUSALEM, June 16 -- Dr. Chaim Arlosoroff, labor member of the Jewish Agency and head of the political department, was shot dead tonight when walking with his wife in Tel Aviv. The assassins, who are believed to be Communists, escaped.

Senator Royal S. Copeland, who returned from Washington yesterday after adjournment of Congress, declared that as chairman of a special Senate committee to investigate racketeering he will confer within two or three weeks with officials here as the first move in the proposed investigation.

Two orchestral works by American composers, instead of the usual one, will be published this year by the Juilliard School of Music as a result of the school's annual competition, it was announced yesterday. The winners, Nicolai Berezowsky and Sandor Harmati, were born abroad, but have become American citizens.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 16 -- The Princeton Preparatory School held its commencement exercises this morning. The headmaster, Harry B. Fine, awarded the prizes. John Hugh Petherbridge of Haddonfield, gave the valedictory address.

The bonded debt of 248 cities in the United States which reported for both 1931 and 1932 increased $4.95 per capita in 1932, which was the same increase as in 1931, according to C.E. Rightor of the Detroit Bureau of Municipal Research, whose annual compilation was made public yesterday by the National Municipal League.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In Dr. Mary E. Woolley's splendid commencement address at Bryn Mawr College she said that, as one of the American delegates to the Geneva Arms Conference, she had been asked many times why progress toward reduction and limitation was so halting.
The rock hewn from the hill in Athens where St. PAUL preached to an inquiring multitude has carried across the sea to one of the hills of our acropolis a message especially pertinent at this moment:
Ernest Hemingway, who is on a fishing trip off Cuba, has notified his publishers, the Scribners, that the title of his new book of short stories will be "Winner Take Nothing."

Complete plans of the Cape Playhouse, Dennis, Mass., and the South Shore Playhouse, Cohasset, Mass., both conducted by Raymond Moore, were announced yesterday. Opening July 3, the productions will be offered first at Dennis and transferred the next week to Cohasset.

Benjamin Miller, 41 years old, was indicted yesterday on felony and misdemeanor charges. The charges grew out of complaints received by Govenor Lehman last April about Miller's activities as an alleged "fixer" in State compensation cases.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- The railroad labor unions will oppose the proposed 22 1/2 per cent cut in their basic pay "with every force owithin their power," A.F. Whitney, chairman of the Railway Labor Executives Association, said today following a conference with the chiefs of fifteen of the twenty-one standard railroad unions.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP). -- Two Federal agencies worked hard today in fitting together the first cogs in the machinery intended to offer $4,000,000,000 in credit to thousands of foreclosure-threatened farm and home owners.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 16 -- Despite the late starting time of the varsity race and the cool, threatening weather, there was plenty of enthusiasm among the thousands of spectators who saw the Yale-Harvard rowing classic on the Thames early this evening.
BERLIN, June 16 -- The Reich statistical office announced today an increase in Germany's foreign trade for May, which Germans themselves declared to be "surprising."

"Tattle Tales" at the Broadhurst changed its mind, and will not close after tonight's performance as was earlier announced. The plays that do not expect to continue next week are the Players' revival of "Uncle Tom's Cabin" and "Run, Little Chillun." "Best Sellers" is also stopping for a hiatus that is announced as lasting until July 10.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- President Roosevelt indicated today that no proposal, tentative or otherwise, on currency stabilization had been received from the United States delegation at the World Economic Conference.

Prices of gasoline and crude oil were advanced yesterday over a wide area. Gasoline at retail was raised 1 cent a gallon in most of the important areas east of the Rocky Mountains, while crude oil went up approximately 25 cents a barrel in the greater midcontinent area.
GROTON, Mass., June 16 (AP). -- Graduation, day at Groton School today was one of accomplishment for members of the Roosevelt family, all branches of it.

MILWAUKEE, June 16 -- Evidence leading to a new theory on the origin and prevention of the common cold and epidemic influenza was presented here today before the closing sessions of the convention of the American Medical Association.
Trading on the Cotton Exchange was nervous yesterday and the market closed with losses of 15 to 17 points.

A large delegation from New York will attend the twenty-sixth annual convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers, which will open tomorrow in Pittsburgh, with headquarters at the William Penn Hotel. The sessions will continue through Thursday.

TEN days [in Nazi Germany] is not much, and I cannot pretend to arrive at any conclusions. Actually there can be no conclusions to be arrived at yet, for the impression of one day is undone the next, and every one's problem and every one'a misery and every one's happiness in the new regime differs according to circumstances.

HERE is a very interesting book about a person with a life so extraordinarily interesting that there really is no excuse for writing any other sort of book about her -- the more especially, as in her own journals, with their profuse confidences to white paper, this niece of the British Muse of tragedy has herself supplied much of the material.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Joseph B. Eastman, officially called "Federal Coordinator of Transportation" by President Roosevelt, was congratulated on his appointment today by railroad executives and attorneys as he tools up his new duties. He was too busy to see all callers, but one of them, Carl Gray, president of the Union Pacific Railroad, discussed with, him plans for setting up, a regional coordinating committee for the Western district.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 (AP). -- Randy Moore's tenth-inning home run, after his team had tied the count in the eighth, grave the Braves a 3-to-2 victory over the Phillies today and a clean sweep in the day's double-header. Spud Davis Of the Phils hit a home run in the second inning.

IF the institution of marriage is in a bad way, and the consensus of opinion seems to be that it is, it is not for lack of diagnosis, prescription, advice, counsel, first aid, X-rays, expert attention. For there have surely been more books about it and what is the matter with it during recent years than about any other problem of the time, not even excepting agriculture and the menace of machinery.
ST. LOUIS, June 17 (AP). -- Pitcher Ed Wells blew up in the ninth inning today and the Senators scored seven runs to win from the Browns, 10 to 3.

AN important exhibition of arms and armor opened at the Brooklyn Museum last Tuesday and will remain through the Summer months. It covers a wide range, from full suits of armor, such as the ghost of Hamlet's father wore when he revisited the glimpses of the moon at Elsinore, to firearms, lances, shields and sundry bits of equipment deemed essential when knighthood was in flower.
WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 16, unless otherwise specified:

Retail tobacconists will seek a minimum profit of 20 per cent on cigarettes and 25 per cent on cigars and other tobacco under a code tentatively prepared yesterday as required by the National Recovery Act. The retailers met in the Hotel New Yorker and organized the Retail Tobacco Dealers of America, Inc., to formulate the code of business ethics.

CRANFORD, N.J., June 17. -- Clearview Vendetta big gray gelding owned by Joseph P. Day of Short Hills, won its third successive championship within a month when he captured the highest honors at the Cranford Horse Show at Kenilworth today.

Many people consider dahlia growing a difficult art, at which only the initiated can hope to succeed. This is not true. Any one who will follow simple cultural directions can grow dahlias of which he or she may be proud.

HARRIET HENRY, in her latest novel, has taken a very ancient plot, laid it against a background of theatrical New York and bohemian London, dressed it up in a brisk modern idiom, and presented it with a surprising degree of charm and freshness.

WITH considerable perspicacity and no less courage, Herbert J. Biberman in his production of "Iron Flowers" at the Westchester County Centre last week turned to the dance to augment and support a straight dramatic play.

Art may be art to Arthur Branchaud, but alimony is alimony to his wife. If Branchaud cannot sell enough sunsets to keep up the alimony payments then he had better exchange his smock and palette for overalls and a pail, and start painting houses.

LONDON, June 17. -- Economic and political disarmament mingled in the Anglo-American talks at Chequers today. Secretary Hull, James M. Cox and Senator Pittman, after a further conference with Norman H. Davis this morning, had luncheon there with Prime Minister MacDonald.

Tommy Loughran, former world's light-heavyweight champion, will oppose Steve Hamas of Passaic in a ten-round bout at the Yanked Stadium on Wednesday night. The meeting will be the fourth between the pair and is expected to attract a large crowd.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 17. -- Happy Ending, a bay gelding owned by Mrs. Minot A. Howard of Tuckahoe and ridden by Mr. Howard, this afternoon won the hunter championship of the fourth annual Bronxville Club horse show held on the club grounds on California Road at Tuckahoe.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 15 -- Plans to push the fight with renewed vigor and hopes for a majority that will run from 25,000 to 40,000 enlivened the ranks of the repealists in Tennessee this week following the visit Tuesday by Postmaster General Farley to Sewanee to receive the degree of Doctor of Civil Laws from the University of the South.

IT is the good old Summer time again and everybody is trooping off to the great open spaces -- for a day, a week-end, two weeks, or maybe the entire Summer. Whatever the length of her outing, the American girl -- and by that we mean all ages, for aren't we all boys and girls when it comes to playing?

The sudden revival of demand for home furnishings, a development which has brought factories of furniture and floor coverings producers from almost complete idleness to peak production in a period of less than sixty days, can be attributed entirely to the recent upswing in commodity prices, producers and sales executives said here yesterday.
To the Editor of The New York Times: With the greatest enjoyment I read the fairy tale, or shall I say cat tale, of Olive Catelle in THE TIMES.

BUENOS AIRES, June 17. -- Ar- gentina will support the proposed London agreement to limit wheat acreage and Instructions to that effect were cabled to Tomas A. Le Breton this afternoon, according to reliable sources close to the government.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 17. -- Princeton alumni here for their annual class reunions will hold a memorial service for President Emeritus John Grier Hibben tomorrow at 12:15 P.M. Before the service every class of which there is a surviving member will lay a wreath in memory of Dr. Hibben in Memorial Hall in Nassau, Hall.

Some years ago a student or the higher education in the United States made a rough study of the varieties of requirements for the degree of Bachelor of Arts. As I recall it he discovered that there were something over 400 ways in which this degree could be acquired by a discerning student.

WINDSOR, England, June 17. -- Cordell Hull, United States Secretary of State, and his colleagues of the American delegation to the World Economic Conference enjoyed a unique social event today in attending the royal picnic for the family of nations at historic Windsor Castle.

An interesting departure is being planned for the annual field trials of the English Springer Field Trial Association, which will once more be held at Fishers Island, N.Y., beginning on Monday, Oct. 23, and continuing for four days. This year there will be a stake for novice handlers.

During the period of -- little more than thirty years since 1900, the building and loan associations in the United States have financed 6,500,000 homes. The assets of these organizations have increased in the same period from $571,000,000 to $8,800,000,000 at the end of 1930.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 17. -- The commencement of Lawrence ville School was held this afternoon in Edith Memorial Chapel, with the presentation of diplomas to 119 members of the graduating class the largest in the school's history. The address was given by Dr. Wilfred W. Fry, president of the Religious Press Association and a member of the general board of the National Council of the Y.M. C.A., who is president of N.W. Ayer Son.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- President Roosevelt's reforestation program already has lightened the relief load of many cities and has directly benefited more than a million persons, according to Robert Fechner, director of emergency conservation work.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP). -- Dave Komonen of Toronto today led for most of the way to win the National A.A.U. championship marathon in a field of eighty-seven contestants.

ROY HARRIS, American composer, whose concerto for string quartet, piano and clarinet has just been published by the Cos Cob Press, spoke to the radio audience last Wednesday over a nation-wide Columbia hook-up on American music.

THE Stadium concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will open Thursday evening, June 29. Willem van Hoogstraten will conduct. In commemoration of the fiftieth anniversary of Wagner's death and the hundredth of Brahms's birth, the initial program will include the introduction to the third act of "Lohengrin," Siegfried's Rhine Journey, the Prelude and Liebestod from "Tristan," the Prelude to "Die Meistersinger," and Brahms's First symphony.

Most varieties of berries were in lighter receipt the latter part of last week, George G. Royce, director of the local office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets, announced yesterday in his consumers' weekly review of wholesale markets.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 17. -- Ninety-one members of Rutgers Spring sports teams will receive awards, it was announced today by George E. Little, director of physical education.

ROCK carvings, the sculpture of our prehistoric ancestors, continue to interest archaeologists. Recently a sandstone hillside in Palestine yielded carvings of ibexes and cowlike figures, believed by their discoverer, Professor Nelson Glueck of the American School of Oriental Research in Jerusalem, to be of the Neolithic, or New Stone, age.

IT is rose time. It is June, going on July, and the garden, though deep in the red, is spending like a prodigal. Only a couple of months ago the garden was a delicate, hesitant young thing that needed encouragement and health foods and a helping hand.

A furtherance of railroad consolidation in the East was seen yesterday by railroad commentators in two decisions announced by Federal courts in Philadelphia on Friday. One of the decisions permitted the Reading Company to exercise control in the Central Railroad of New Jersey and the other permitted the Pennsylvania Railroad to retain its $106,000,000 investment in the Lehigh Valley and the Wabash.

IN spite of unseasonal weather, retail trade held up quite well during the week, with a number of stores continuing to exceed last year's sales totals. Sportswear and dress accessories, with particular emphasis being laid upon the vogue for white in shoes and other articles, were in the most active demand.
AMONG the dwellings just completed in Westchester County is that of Dean James L. Fitzgerald of Manhattan College, in the Parkhill section of Yonkers.

FRED STONE, who believes that actors are no better than their last performance, goes on the air tonight at 9 o'clock In place of Will Rogers at WJZ. It will be a one-time broadcast for the comedian of "Chin-Chin" and a long list of other Broadway hits.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 17. -- The annual Alumnae Day activities today opened the commencement program of Radcliffe College. The class of 1883, first class to celebrate its fiftieth reunion, has a place of honor in the program. Thirty-seven other classes, down to that of 1932, held reunions.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- The Yankees launched their second invasion of the West at Comiskey Park today with a hitting outburst that pulled them out of their losing streak. Led by the battering Lou Gehrig, they left the imprint of their assault on two White Sox hurlers and buried the Chicagoans under an 8-to-3 defeat.

THE report is spreading that Ed Leader, rowing coach at Yale, is going up to Cambridge to have a look at the Harvard graduation exercises on Thursday. He wants to make sure that certain husky fellows who have caused him no small amount of grief in recent years are finally handed their diplomas at Harvard and ushered out into a cold, cruel world.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Although the right of New York State to impose income taxes, especially the emergency tax of 1 per cent on net incomes without benefit of any personal exemption, regardless of its lack of wisdom, is unquestionable, the method of collecting a part of this tax is a violation of the Fifth Amendment of the Federal Constitution.

BOSTON, June 15. -- The largest Legislature in the United States, with the single exception of the Federal Congress, is making for itself this week a new record for the length of its sessions. The New Hampshire General Court comprises an upper house of twentyfour Senators and a lower house of 418 Representatives.

BERLIN, June 16. -- The collection of the so-called Hitler fund, recently launched, is proceeding apace under the auspices of the Federation of German Industries, of which Dr. Gustav Krupp von Bohlen is chairman.

The passage of the National Industrial Recovery Act, signed by the President on Friday, ushers in important changes in the Federal revenue system; not only does it introduce several new forms of taxation, but by the repeal of parts of the 1932 Revenue Act it rescinds some of the salient ameliorating features of former revenue acts.

BOSTON, June 17 (AP). -- George Earnshaw, returned to the good graces of Connie Mack, led the Athletics to a 15 to 3 victory over the Red Sox in the first game of a doubleheader today. But the Sox took the second encounter, 7 to 5, in eight innings, the game toeing called because of rain.

PARIS, June 17. -- Australia won the first two matches of the European zone semi-finals in its Davis Cup tennis tie with Japan at the Roland Garros Stadium today. Victory in each contest was achieved only after an exhausting five-set struggle.

DUBLIN, June 16. -- Despite pessimistic declarations by Senator Connolly, the hopes of the people and of the government itself are that the World Economic Conference will open the way for satisfactory solution of the present difficulties with Britain.

BOLIVAR, Mo., June 17 (AP). -- Held captive by Charles (Pretty Boy) Floyd, Oklahoma desperado, for more than fourteen hours, Sheriff Jack Killingsworth of Polk County returned home today following his release near Lees Summit, Mo., about twenty miles southeast of Kansas City.

LONDON. THE English reviews of President Roosevelt's "Looking Forward" naturally consist in large measure of summaries of the policies set forth in it. But they are not entirely devoid of interesting comment.

THE radio industry will stage a prosperity campaign the first week in October which will be known as "Radio Progress Week." An intensive sales drive is planned for September and seven days of special broadcasting to begin Oct. 2.

IF you should go tiger hunting and be chased by a man-eating tiger, do not hope to find safety by climbing a tree. For tigers can and do climb trees, says General Burton, who is an expert on the history, the characteristics and the habits of tigers.

AMONG the achievements of President Roosevelt is his emergence as a radio speaker of rare ability. Amid a barrage of legislation his magnetic voice has vibrated in space to clarify for the people the meaning of bank reform, inflation, legal beer, mortgage relief, taxation, and many knotty problems linked with international relations.

The New York Athletic Club put on a dress rehearsal yesterday for the national championships at Chicago a fortnight hence. It was a signal success. Using the forty-first annual Metropolitan A.A.U. track and field title meet at Ohio Field as a preliminary work-out for its midwestern venture, the Winged Foot Club rolled up the huge total of 114 points.

ALTHOUGH ringside classics are not being broadcast right now for fear of reducing the gate receipts, the radio audience is having its opportunity to hear the former champions in more peaceful moods. Recently Gene Tunney was on the air under commercial sponsorship and Jack Dempsey, the promoter, whom the National Broadcasting Company reported wanting $25,000 for the Schmeling-Baer broadcasting rights, has his "Gymnasium" sketch on a network.
The authors of the National Recovery Act have in mind the permanent regimentation of industry under governmental control, Representative James W. Wadsworth declared here yesterday.

Fifteen Years After. Today is the anniversary of the Battle of Waterloo, June 18, 1815. There would be no particular point in recalling an exceedingly familiar date if it were not for the fact that fifteen years after Waterloo was the year 1830.

BERLIN, May 30, 1933. THE age-old, ugly, insipid Verdi operas -- are they the sort of thing the public wants to run to? I call the German operatic repertoire a bad one, unworthy of Germany. Why a Verdi renaissance, anyway -- why in the world not a German opera renaissance?"

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP). -- Heredity is shown in a report of the Carnegie Institution of Washington to be playing an increasingly important part in the health of the human race, because young people, it says, are becoming more particular about whom they marry.

More scientific methods or appraising real estate to reflect changing conditions and possibly further changes in the future are being stressed by real estate men in an effort to forecast trends and to arrive at sound valuations, points out Robert H. Armstrong of the realty firm of Armstrong Armstrong.

Old New Yorkers passing the southwest corner of Park Avenue and Fortieth Street have had the suggestion sharply presented to them that a little bit of old Yorkville has suddenly been transported to that spot close to the Grand Central Terminal and almost in the heart of the towering structures which have made that locality in recent years one of the liveliest business centres on Manhattan Island.

CHICAGO, June 17 (AP). -- Representatives of more than forty crude oil producing companies which supply 95 per cent of the nation's oil today adopted a proposal allowing the President of the United States to fix maximum and minimum prices.

IN three months' travel from London to Moscow, from Athens to Stockholm, attending the theatre constantly, hearing plays in the languages of many peoples, I have been in such storm centres as Berlin, Munich, Moscow and Vienna.
Supreme Court Justice James A. Dunne ruled yesterday that the ninety bungalows and camps in Wolfe's Pond Park on Princes Bay, S.I., were there illegally and would have to go.

Thirty-five drivers representing sixteen colleges and universities will compete in the fourth annual Eastern intercollegiate outboard championships on Lake Hopatcong on Saturday and Sunday. Among the entrants is a four-man team from Yale, which will strive to retain the Samuel Kane Trophy, emblematic of the team championship.

I AM no archaeologist," says Sven Hedin in the story of his life as an explorer. Sir Aurel Stein, who in "On Ancient Central-Asian Tracks." returns to the scenes of many expeditions, is first of all an Orientalist and archaeologist.
HOT SPRINGS, Ark., June 17 (AP). -- The arrest here of Frank Nash was so spectacular that police believed some one had been kidnapped or "taken for a ride."
NEW YORK. Don. Gonzalo Guell, First Secretary of the Cuban Embassy, and Senora de Quell are at the Sherry-Netherland.

MEDFORD, Mass., June 17. -- Andruszkie-wicz achieved a threeyear ambition in his final game as a Tufts College baseball player when he handed the Harvard varsity team a 9-to-2 setback today, allowing only four hits.

Estimated reductions of 10 to 20 per cent in rates for the thirty-fourth annual Summer session of Columbia University were announced yesterday by Director John J. Coss. The Columbia Summer session starts July 10 and ends Aug. 18, a period of six weeks.
WASHINGTON, June 17. -- President Roosevelt's victory over Congress in the clash on veterans' reductions is sending members back to their homes in a more perplexed state of mind than in many years.

CHENGTE, Jehol, May 20. -- There is every indication that plantings of opium in Jehol Province will be greatly increased this season, as a result of the encouragement given opium growers by the Manchukuo Government.
THE musical activities or the Summer of 1933 not only in spite of the depression, but in some measure because of it, will be more extended and various than those of any preceding Summer season.

CLEVELAND, June 15. -- Out of the depression has come in this last month three humanitarian manifestations worthy of note, in a heavily industrialized State where 277,000 families are still being fed and sheltered by charity.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- Two fillies running in the colors of Charles T. Fisher of Detroit finished first and second in the Debutante Stakes at Lincoln Fields track today. The Audley Farm's Miss Patience, which was favored in the mutuel wagering, ran third.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The drive for the greatest governmental retrenchment in our history is on in earnest. While the President takes his vacation, bureau heads are preparing to put into effect the drastic economy plans at the earliest date.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 17. -- Despite a heavy storm in the early afternoon, about 2,000 Princeton alumni marched in the annual alumni parade today. The parade is the outstanding feature of Alumni Day.
A partial recovery came into some of the commodity futures traded on local Exchanges yesterday.

A research into first grade failure conducted by the guidance department of the Wilkes-Barre city schools during the last few years has revealed a crying need for a greater uniformity of standards of achievement -- as long as standaradized achievement is required of pupils -- as well as a need for individual aid to the children who cannot be brought up to these standards by the usual methods of group instruction.

GARDEN furniture this year displays great ingenuity on the part of designers in providing comfort and convenience along with smartness. Easy chairs are equipped with bookrest, footrest and awnings, and may be metamorphosed into rocking chairs by a turn of the wrist.

To the Automobile Editor: IN your issue of June 4 are presented facts and figures which would seem to justify the opposition to the proposed small advance in the Federal gas tax. Like most issues, there are two sides to this one and both have a right to be considered.
WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The War Department issued the following orders today: Rethorst, Col. O.W., Cav., to Minneapolis, Minn.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 17. -- George Parker, Yale's star hurler who lost his first league game of the season a week ago through Princeton's ninth-inning uprising, came back today to shut out the Nassau nine, 6 to 0. The result tied the annual series.

WITH a daily average of thirteen of them, Japan ought to know something about earthquakes. The truth is that it probably knows more than any other country. Its records go back centuries. Seismology in Japan is so big a problem that it has its branches.

June is an excellent time to plant roses, provided plants are obtained which have been kept properly dormant. By selecting the everblooming hybrid teas, one will enjoy several months of bloom in the garden.
LONDON, June 17. -- A gold bloc drive to force stabilization of the dollar and the pound will continue, Finance Minister Georges Bonnet of France said tonight.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 17. -- Smith College commencement activities got under way today with the colorful alumnae parade and the traditional Ivy Day exercises. The Alumnae Fund, presented annually, was given to the college at the alumnae assembly in the afternoon.

The dry goods trade, particularly wholesalers, is fearful that a buying lull will ensue for about thirty days when retailers are faced with the necessity of paying the full price advances on many lines, according to comment in the primary market yesterday.

A heavy rain and hail storm twisted about the city early yesterday afternoon, drenching pedestrians in the midtown district and the Bronx. It swept over parts of Queens and Brooklyn but left Coney Island and many other sections of the city almost untouched.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Beyond the water horizon of Chicago lies a vast stretch of territory that is still America; beyond the water horizon of New York lies Europe. Those two facts explain why the Middle West was slower in developing a world consciousness than the region tributary to New York.

Of a $10,000,000 fund subscribed by Chinese and Koreans living in the United States, only $360,000 reached its intended source, the Cantonese Nineteenth Route Army, famous for its resistance to the Japanese at Shanghai, according to Dr. Kiusic Kimm, secretary of Peiyang University, Tientsin.

PARIS, June 17. -- Premier Daladier in an official statement tonight gave warning that France regarded currency stabilization as a prerequisite to tariff reduction. He also indicated France would demand the organization of a system of limiting production before it would consent to the removal of its quota restrictions.

SIX RKO Radio productions are scheduled for release within the next few weeks. In the probable order of their presentation, they begin with "Tomorrow at Seven," a murder mystery wherein the violence is distributed among an airliner, a transcontinental railroad train and a mansion in the Louisiana swamplands.

SHANGHAI. SINCE Mei Lan fang was not in town, there was no point in ferreting out a Chinese theatre. According to The Chinese Digest, which respects the arts even in wartime, the distinguished Dr. Mei had just attended a rehearsal of Maestro Paci's Chinese ballet and was enthusiastic about the possibilities it suggests for a new form of Chinese theatre.

Defeating the eleven of the WestChester County Cricket Club by a margin of ninety-two runs at Tibbetts Brook Park in Yonkers, the Brooklyn Cricket Club gained 2 points in the annual championship competition of the Metropolitan and New Jersey Cricket Association yesterday.

DETROIT. AS predicted for two successive years, but deferred until this year, automobile manufacturing at last has gained the key position in which it may well prove to be the dominating factor leading toward a return to normal employment and a consequent revival of prosperity in the United States.

The advent of the bass-fishing season in New Jersey on Thursday was not an auspicious one, due to poor weather, but from all reports those anglers who did go out had fair success and saw plenty of signs that fish were in the streams.

DETROIT, Mich., June 17. -- Harry L. Hopkins, Federal emergency relief administrator, addressing the National Conference of Social Work, today declared that the first thousand projects in the government's public works would return to work at least 1,000,000 men by Oct. 1.

EAST NORWICH, L.I., June 17. -- Manha, the handsome bay mare owned by Miss Betty J. West of Old Westbury, L.I., took the hunter championship at the sixth annual Glen Head Junior Horse Show, held on the Vincent F. Clark estate today.

MANILA, May 17. -- With the recent return of the Philippine Trade Mission from an "investigation" of possibilities in Japan and China, it has been revealed that the real object of the trip was not so much to ascertain trade conditions as to establish in neighboring countries the personal and official prestige of members of the Philippine Legislature.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been extremely interested in the articles by William H. Brown relative to doughnut holes. He seems to be ignorant of the splendid work done along this line by Dr. Jonathan P. Phflug, founder and head of the Jonathan P. Phflug Laboratories of Pseudo-Scientific Research at Nightmare, Ariz.
ANOTHER plan for the development of the seven-block Chrystie-Forsyth Street area was submitted several days ago to the Board of Estimate by Maurice Deutsch, architect and engineer.

THE proposed New York Municipal Airport to be located in upper New York Bay lies approximately 1 3/4 miles south of the Battery and 2,000 feet off the Brooklyn shore. The terminal has been designed as a land and seaplane base to the specifications of the Aeronautics Branch of the Department of Commerce; the landplane base meets the requirements for an A-T-A rating, while the seaplane base qualifies for an A-1-A rating.

Recovering their composure after the erratic fluctuations of the previous few days, stocks were mildly encouraging yesterday to speculators for the advance. Business was slow by comparison with other Saturdays during the Spring advance; transactions amounted to 1,567,000 shares, against 2,786,440 a week before.

The close parallel last week between the recovery of the dollar and the fall of stock and commodity prices stimulated the controversy that has been going on among financial experts on the question of whether any real relationship exists between internal prices and the external value of the dollar.

VIENNA, June 17. -- The Nazi campaign to win Austria, which first assumed serious proportions with the unwelcome visit of Dr. Frank, the Bavarian Minister of Justice, to Austria a month ago after he had broadcast a hostile declaration against Austria reached a high point this week with the initiation of terrorist acts.

CHANGES in medical service are proceeding with unusual rapidity these days. The depression is accelerating some of them. Others are being influenced by the reports of the recently disbanded Committee on Costs of Medical Care.

EACH broadcasting station has a personality. By the calibre of the programs they are known. The people who entertain and speak over the station contribute to the character and reputation of the transmitter. The wave vibrating with Presidential addresses, noted symphony orchestras and authoritative lecturers has a different personality than one specializing in studio ensembles, jazz bands and more or less unknown speakers.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 17. -- Through puffs of wind and calms, fifty-six craft competed today in the first regatta of the Long Island Sound championship series at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Ninety-three per cent of 423 New York University students believed themselves able to distinguish a difference in quality among four samples of musical reproduction when no difference actually existed, a report of a test of "blindfold tests" revealed yesterday.

THERE has been no inconsiderable amount of talk about the independence of general trade conditions shown by rare books. It has been confidently asserted by professionals that, unlike the popular modern books whose phenomenal rise in the Twenties was succeeded by a rapid decline in the Thirties, the "real thing," that is, examples of established masterpieces of literature, have remained steadfast, refusing to join in the market rout.

IN a room thirty-five feet underground, in the Bureau of Standards, Washington, D.C., sits Dr. Paul R. Heyl. His job in life is to weigh the earth. Before him is a fused quartz pendulum delicately hung on an agate edge about as sharp as that of a razor.
