MR. RIPLEY'S latest belongs with the better serials from the adventure-story magazines. It is competently written. It will hold you in suspense, and it ends satisfactorily.

AVERY businesslike map of the United States, embellished with tiny thumbnail sketches of museums and universities, tells the story of the College Art Association's traveling exhibition enterprise; tells it with a thoroughness that far transcends light Summer hammock reading and leaves one, as usual, limp before the amazing creative energy of this yare, indefatigable organization.

THE sixteenth season of concerts by the Goldman Band under the direction of Edwin Franko Goldman will begin on the Mall in Central Park tomorrow evening. These are again to be known as the Daniel Guggenheim Memorial Concerts, and are the gift of the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 17. -- Class day exercises of the 117 members of the graduating class and the annual alumni day events opened the commencement exercises of Wesleyan University today.

As college presidents greet their alumni during these reunion days, do they look at them more and more hopefully as the future mass support of alma mater? Certainly the day of gifts in eight figures from fabulously rich individuals seems generally conceded to be past.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 16. -- General business conditions in the Eighth Federal Reserve District are reported running ahead of normal seasonal conditions. Retail trade is active and several large stores state that the turnover is ahead of last year, while rural stores are unanimous in reporting improvement.

Following twenty-eight hours of deliberation -- a record in the Brooklyn Federal Court -- a jury returned verdicts of guilty for three men and acquitted a fourth last night for violation of the Dyer Act. All four were tried for transporting stolen cars here and abroad.
WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated June 15:

The suggestion made last week by Joseph P. Day that President Roosevelt appoint a commission comprising the best economic and financial brains in the United States to study the subject of real estate mortgages from a long-term viewpoint, aroused great interest in realty circles and received much favorable commendation.

FLYING boats of large, very large, dimensions are increasingly conspicuous in the aviation picture these days. From the point of spectacular performance the flying boat will hold a goodly portion of the central foreground this month because of the mass flieht of two dozen Italian craft, under the leadership of General Italo Balbo, Il Duce's Air Minister, from Orbetello to Chicago.

All major business indices showed gains last week. All sections of the country reported increased consumption as well as production, employment and wage scales continued to advance and trends of prices of semi-finished and manufactured goods were upward.

Official returns of the election of delegates to the State convention which will ratify repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment show the State as a whole to have voted wet by almost 8 to 1 and New York City by almost 41 to 1.

BERLIN, June 17. -- The Boerse closed the week in much the same mood of passive inactivity in which it began the period. Professional speculation today displayed a slightly quickened animation, stimulated by the London stand-still agreements, but with public orders virtually absent the turnover was small.

IN the welter of opposition and recrimination engendered by the proposed city levies on motor vehicles one fact stood out significantly last week: the determination of individual owners, automobile organizations and civic and business groups to form a solid front against further special fees and taxes.

The American Bureau of Shipping has completed a survey of American and foreign shipping that combines a historical study of the merchant marine in its relation to the foreign and domestic trade of the nation. The government bureaus that are directly associated with commerce have supplied data and various organizations of ship operators and shipbuilders also have cooperated in rounding out the picture.

Plans for establishing an "express" ticker service to supplement the present high-speed stock ticker system are being considered by the New York Stock Exchange. Quotations would be provided for only as many issues as could be handled without delay, confining them therefore to the most important securities, whereas the present ticker would continue to print transactions in all stocks, including those given on the "express" machine.
Sixty women players have filed entries for the eleventh annual championship of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association that starts tomorrow.

Yesterday was children's day in the parks of the city. Long before noon thousands of boys and girls went to their neighborhood parks and playgrounds to participate in sailboat races, athletic games; doll parades, costume parties and roller skating.

Operation of the Bronx Concourse line of the city's independent subway system will begin at 1 A.M. on July 1, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday. The new link will extend from 205th Street and Bedford Park in the Bronx to its Junction with the present Eighth Avenue line at St. Nicholas Avenue and 145th Street, Manhattan.

Some of the rarest United States gold and silver coins and many unusual bronze and silver pieces of early Greek and Roman coinage and a Jewish shekel and quarter-shekel of the period of the first revolt will be sold by Thomas L. Elder at 8 West Thirty-seventh Street on Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoon.

LONDON. IN the World Economic Conference the two English-speaking powers are playing leading roles. The United States seems, at least for the moment, to be rather less nationalistically inclined than it had been through the last decade; Great Britain decidedly more so.

NEW HAVEN, June 17. -- A twenty-foot horned dinosaur, Monoclonius, which lived in the age of reptiles, about 60,000,000 years ago, has been restored and placed on exhibition in Tale University's Peabody Museum of Natural History by Professor Richard S. Lull, the museum director.
A city-wide campaign against the free running of unmuzzled dogs was started yesterday by the Police Department. It was undertaken at the request of Health Commissioner Shirley W. Wynne.

It is now possible to plant roses at practically every period of the year when the ground is not frozen, points out Stephen Reynolds, who adds that a friend who planted roses on July 4 a year ago picked blossoms from them on Labor Day.

IN Spain under the republican form of government a greater demand for books has developed. Instead of novels, works on sociology, history, economics and politics are being read. This may result from having such distinguished publicists as Jose Ortega y Gasset, Fernando de los Rios and Manuel Azana in dominant positions.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 13. -- Melbourne's triumphs and failures have been reported to the conference now meeting of representatives of the Commonwealth and States, assembled to review the work of the last fiscal year and plan for the next one, which opens July 1.

Natural gas and some oil have been discovered on lands in the south-western part of the State near the Pennsylvania border that the State has acquired for reforestation purposes. Under the terms of a law enacted at the recent session of the Legislature, the Conservation Department has been empowered to lease such lands for gas and oil exploitation.
LONDON, June 17. -- London and the rest of Britain has had the World Economic Conference to thank for the most brilliant social season of the post-war years.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 10 amounted to 364,546 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 56,312 cars, or 11.1 per cent, more than for the preceding week, when loadings were reduced as a result of the observance of Memorial Day.

OPEN betting on horse races, debated in practically ever State Legislature in the country during the Winter and Spring, will be legal in twelve States this year but not in New York. As a result of new laws Oregon, Washington, New Mexico.

Unfair exploitation of the increasing number of young girls who have entered domestic work during the depression was revealed yesterday in a report by the division of junior placement of the State Labor Department. This exploitation has affected both wages and working conditions.

The British, who have not captured their national open golf championship since 1923, when Arthur Havers won, will this year have to face one of the most formidable challenges from across the seas in the long history of the event.

PITTSBURGH, June 17 (AP). -- Babe Herman led an attack against Steve Swetonic's pitching that garnered the Chicago Cubs fourteen hits today, but Earl Grace's single in the eighth inning gave the Pirates the game, 4 to 3.

Behind the brilliant pitching of Fritz Ostermueller and Ira Smith, Rochester captured both ends of a double-header from Jersey City at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday, to make it four out of five in the series. The scores were 9 to 2 and 4 to 0.

THE European cartel has been frequently referred to recently in connection with the National Industrial Recovery Act. By this measure the President is authorized to establish agencies, or utilize existing trade or industrial associations, to compel reforms in industry in respect of working hours, wages, re-employment, and the prevention of unfair competition and disastrous overproduction.

Commencement Week activities at City College will start tomorrow with the traditional Class Night program. They will conclude Wednesday evening when the college will award degrees, diplomas and commissions to about 1,700 graduates at its eighty-seventh annual commencement exercises in the Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

The Staten Island Cricket Club defeated the Veteran St. George C. C. at Livingston, S.I., yesterday, by a amargin of 26 runs with one wicket to spare on totals of 160 to 134. F. Garcia distinguished himself with the bat and was highscore man for the Veterans with 53.

While the Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association championship will be held at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, N.Y., starting tomorrow, another tourney that has assumed an important place on the golfing calendar of these counties will be held in July.

IN the Strong Memorial Hospital, Rochester, N.Y., is Dr. R. Plato Schwartz, whose specialty is the human gait. Day after day he tests rheumatics who have all but forgotten how to walk correctly; the lame and the halt who have been crippled by infantile paralysis and other afflictions; and the fakers who claim to have been injured by automobiles and trolley cars.

EVERY now and then this column takes a genteel pen in hand and writes an item about "As Thousands Cheer." At first Moss Hart and Irving Berlin sat beneath the spotlight. After that the Music Box Theatre had its solitary strutting hour.

After barely qualifying for the event and winning his place in the championship division after a playoff with eight others, Mark J. Stuart of the Fox Hills Club on Staten Island won the metropolitan amateur golf championship yesterday. He defeated Walter J. Rothenberg of the Winged Foot Club, 4 and 3, in the final round at the Pomonok Country Club.

MOSCOW, June 16. -- Despite Foreign Commissar Litvinoff's boast that the "world crisis cannot and does not in any way affect the unbroken development of Soviet economic life," which statement is printed in double type in Soviet newspapers, cold figures issued in the monthly bulletin of the Foreign Trade Commissariat tell their own story.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 17. -- It is reliably reported hero that northern provinces of Argentina show an unfavorable attitude toward the Buenos Aires government for the blockade against Bolivia and that they assert their commerce with Bolivia was large and was keeping at work hundreds of men thus helping those provinces to cope with the economic depression.

HANOVER, N.H., June 17. -- The 446 seniors at Dartmouth College held their class day today on the campus, at the Bema in the college park and at the base of Dartmouth's Old Pine. Alumni classes, in colorful costumes, attended the ceremonies.
ATLANTA, June 17 (AP). -- Party regularity has become an issue again in the South as three States, Alabama, Arkansas and Tennessee, prepare to vote next month on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

LONDON, June 17 (Canadian Press). -- The Minor Counties eleven was dismissed for 253 runs and West Indies had scored 61 for the loss of three wickets at the close of play in their cricket match at Lord's today.
WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The Federal Government, angered by the slaying of a Department of Justice operative in Kansas City, tonight was moving toward stamping out racketeers and gunmen.

James J. Hines, Tammany leader in the Eleventh Assembly District, and Mrs. Ernestine F. Stewart, co-leader in the district which comprises the Morningside section of the west side, led yesterday in the festivities of the annual June Walk of the Monongahela Democratic Club, 292 Manhattan Avenue.

A GOOD many people would like to know what "progressive education" is. Among them are some decidedly progressive educators. Alas, it is not easy to say. Progressives in politics are of many varieties. The same is true of educational progressives.

Foreign exchanges were quiet yesterday and the speculative markets enjoyed a leisurely day, free of excitement. The dollar had a slight recovery in terms of sterling, the franc and other European currencies, but fluctuations were narrow and transactions small, even for a Saturday.

An autobiography which tells everything except when and where the author was born, his schooling, his father's name, the pedigree of his greatgrandmother -- or, if these vital statistics are in the narrative, so concealed or so lightly glossed over that a reader pays no heed -- is, indeed, a novelty.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 14. -- When the vigorous and versatile Orman W. Ewing, president and general manager of an oil company, won the nomination of a Democratic State convention for national committeeman last Summer, he startled political wiseacres of Utah.

WALL STREET is buying itself new neckties. Buying them from a pushcart, to be sure, one of those ambulatory sidewalk markets much more at home on the lower east side than at the lordly corner of Broad and Wall, but buying them.
PARIS, June 10. -- The racing events of the Paris June season have drawn a representative gathering of cosmopolitan society.

BUFFALO, June 15. -- The Industrial Research Department of the Buffalo Chamber of Commerce compiles monthly reports of transactions reflecting the state of business here, which are an authoritative exhibit of the actual situation.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- There was no slackening of the pace of business activity in the week ended on June 10, notwithstanding that the period of the usual seasonal peak has been passed, the Department of Commerce announced today in its weekly survey of domestic business conditions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am writing to protest against the editorials which have appeared attacking the abrogation of the gold clause and referring in uncompromising language to the President's so-called broken campaign promises in this connection.

TO the long, embattled line of books engaged in conflict with the depression Senator Tydings of Maryland adds another, equipped for strenuous fight. It has the value, no small matter for the general reader, of vivid, dramatic presentation, with interludes of thrilling, martial eloquence.

THIS second volume of Memories of Lenin, written by his widow, Nadezhda K. Krupskaya, carries on the story of his activities from the point where the first left off, 1907, and brings it to November, 1917, when the Kerensky government was overthrown and the Soviet regime set up.

AMHERST, Mass., June 17. -- "In the last three months the methods of thinking of an entire nation have changed," Henry T. Rainey, Speaker of the House, told the alumni of Amherst College at their annual dinner today. As a member of the class of '83, he returned for its fiftieth reunion.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- Out of a barrage of flying spikes that shattered four world's records, Louisiana State tonight turned in the most amazing upset of the season by defeating Southern California's Trojans in the National Collegiate A.A. track and field championships at Soldier Field, 58 to 54.

THE Venetian blinds of Stephen Pendrick's boyhood on Ledatock Street are symbols. They stand for a prim, smug, lowermiddle-class respectability invading a workingman's home. When we take our leave of Stephen he is a young man firmly ensconced in the seats of the middle-middle-class of London suburbia, possessor of a semi-detached villa on Acacia Avenue.

Elimination of the funded debt, bank loans and unpaid interest of the Fox Film Corporation through funds from an offering of rights to stockholders to subscribe for new shares is provided in a plan of reorganization which the voting stockholders will be asked to approve at a meeting soon.

Most industries took initial steps last week to line up under the provisions of the Industrial Recovery Act, which was signed by President Roosevelt on Friday. Although a majority of executives had followed the debates on the bill during its progress in Congress, many were reported shocked by some provisions of the bill when they were explained by representatives of General Hugh S. Johnson, administrator of the act.
William Travers Jerome, former District Attorney of New York, who is, now 74 years old, sailed yesterday for Havre on the Ile de France of the French Line. He will spend the Summer in Brittany.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am very much interested in several items in the Japanese newspapers that have just arrived. Those items may, at first glance, seem unimportant; but they are really more or less significant.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 15. -- With the people of Georgia wondering why armed guards were patrolling the State Capitol, State Treasurer George B. Hamilton issued a written statement referring to threats against Governor Talmadge in the case of Angelo Herndon, alleged Communist.

Municipal warrants and bonds were the only additions made last week to the list of loans to be paid in June before their maturity dates; while new announcements of bonds called for payment in future months consisted of three sizable blocks of foreign, railroad and industrial issues, together with small lots of municipal loans.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 17. -- The chief social event here tonight was a dinner at The Elms in celebration of Edward J. Berwind's eighty-fifth birthday anniversary. His house guests for the week-end included former Ambassador and Mrs. James W. Gerard, his nephew, Charles E. Dunlap, and Charles H. Hayden, while many others were present for the dinner.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The European proposal for a temporary stabilization of currencies was contained in a communication from the delegation at London, described as twelve or fifteen pages in length. Officials let this be known to emphasize their assertion that no mere fixation of a price at which stabilization was to be temporarily effected was involved.

SIR BASIL THOMSON should be thoroughly conversant with crime and its detection, for he was for eight years head of the famous C.I.D., New Scotland Yard. It is to be presumed, therefore, that what he writes of the methods of that organization is strictly accurate, even though the story he tells is fiction.

BREATHLESS" is a light romance founded on the familiar but still popular theme of Cinderella and the Prince. Rondy Tilton, a probationer in a hospital, inquisitively answers the summons of the night bell of Kirby Breathless Briggs, a wealthy young patient in the most expensive suite.

LONDON, June 16. -- Outside the white stone building, London traffic soars along Exhibition Road. London's red omnibuses and chunky taxicabs, which are unlike the omnibuses and taxicabs of any other capital, pass in a steady stream.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- With 1,500 delegates and visitors already in the city, the council of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations will open tomorrow afternoon with an executive session at the Stevens Hotel.

To the Music Editor: It was with a great deal of amusement that this writer read the manifesto, so to say, of the newly formed organization, the Composers Protective Society, in a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- The first reaction in the wheat market on the Board of Trade to the announcement today that the processing tax would be applied to wheat soon was that it was bearish, and a rush of selling, partly on stop-loss orders, carried prices off as much as 1 3/4 cent a bushel from yesterday's finish before aggressive buying appeared.
Apartment leasing continues as the most active feature of the real estate market.
LONDON. THERE are prospects of a greatly increased proportion of British pictures being given a show in the United States during the current year.

Representatives of oil marketing and refining associations were called yesterday to meet in Chicago on Thursday to discuss the framing of a code of practices for that industry in conformity with the provisions of the Industrial Recovery Act.

EVERY now and again there happens a poet whom no characterization precisely fits. Robert Herrick was such a poet. William Blake was another. And now, in our own generation. Walter De la Mare is a third.

To the Editor of The New York Times: This letter is brought to you by the first plane arriving at Newark or New York from the Pacific Coast, operated on the new twenty-hour schedule. The pilot through this section is my friend, the famous Jack Knight, who, in 1923, made the initial flight, covering the night section of the route without lights of any sort along the route or at the landing fields, except flares.

The fifty manuscripts which were selected as winners in the fifth annual State and Territorial essay contests of the Gorgas Memorial Institute of Tropical and Preventative Medicine, are now being considered by judges of the national contest, it was announced yesterday.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 17. -- Matthew C. Brush, prominent Wall Street market operator who had earned the social title "America's Richest Bachelor," was married here today to Miss Elizabeth Hunger, who had been his confidential secretary for many years.
The city's plan to sell its securities direct to the public at interest rates up to 5 1/2 per cent was attacked yesterday by Samuel Untermyer as a further impairment of the city's credit.

THE VIKING PRESS has been checking up on some of its German authors who have been scattered by the Hitler regime. Arnold Zweig, who was in Czechoslovakia when Hitler came into power, has gone to Switzerland after vainly trying to reach his family in Berlin.

A large-scale program for public works construction of various types which has been carried forward in France for more than a decade appears to have played an important part in relieving unemployment in that country and aiding in industrial stability, according to John W. Harris of the Hegeman-Harris Company, builders.

BERLIN. IN the Spring of 1930, Professor Alfred Wegener, already renowned in the scientific world because of his theory of the shifting of the continents, voyaged to Greenland with twenty-two companions; a preliminary expedition with three companions had been successfully completed in 1929.

WITH its highly competent cast, clever staging and imaginative direction, the Warner Brothers' latest musical film, "Gold Diggers of 1933," which is now at the Strand, is a good entertainment. It is, however, a pity that the story is so similar to that of other picture, for by this time the cinema-going public must be surfeited with the details of putting on a musical comedy and the discovery of un- expected talent.

TORONTO, Ont., June 17. -- Production of gold in Ontario in May amounted to $3,654,442 from 475,971 tons of ore milled, a decline of $27,359 from the $3,681,801 reported for April, when 449,650 tons were milled. In May, 1932, 469,626 tons of ore were treated, with a recovery valued at $4,079,320.

A President of the United States has just conducted official conversations in the French language with a representative of France. For the first time, an American President has listened intelligently to an address of the Chancellor of the Reich as the German speech came over the international radio.

PEIPING, May 23. -- The oases of Sinkiang are in revolt, and with Moslem Turks successfully wresting control from Chinese officials China is faced with the loss of distant Chinese Turkestan just as in the past eighteen months she has lost Jehol, Kirin, Fengtien and Heilungkiang to the Japanese.

RYE, N.Y., June 17. -- Princeton's team rode to the championship of the Intercollegiate Polo Association on the rain-drenched field of the Westchester Country Club today, turning back Harvard, 10 to 9, in the final-round match.

OMAHA, Neb., June 14. -- The administration's farm relief measure came along too late for specific application to the 1933 wheat crop, but nature stepped in and did in her rather severe and partial way what Secretary Wallace has had in mind doing in a more orderly fashion about crop limitation and solution of the problem of surpluses.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Announcement, set for today by Secretary Wallace, of the cotton acreage reduction plan decided on by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, was postponed until 11 A. M. Monday as the result of protests by Southern Senators and Representatives and agricultural commissioners of the cotton States.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- To coordinate the coordinators is the next great task before the President. Now that Congress has gone and left him with the framework of an entirely new government system, the President must see that its cogs and shafts work reciprocally.. In comparison with this labor, on the success of which the fate of the "'new deal" rests, his political dealings with Congress were child's play.

Urged on by the fervent appeals of 35,000 highly partisan spectators, the Giants and Dodgers struggled through six hours of rain and sunshine at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but reached only one decision.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 17. -- Honorary degrees were awarded for the first time today at the annual commencement convocation of the Graduate School of Brown University, held in Sayles Hall. President Clarence A. Barbour conferred the degree of Doctor of Science upon Dr. Niels Bohr, Professor of Physics in the University of Copenhagen and a Nobel prize winner, and upon Dr. Lipot Fejer, Professor of Mathematics at the University of Budapest.

HANOVER, N.H., June 17. -- Dartmouth's baseball team presented a line-up of new faces today and defeated Cornell, 8 -- 2, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game which broke a tie with the Ithacans for fourth place.

June business has continued at an excellent pace, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. The ready-to-wear markets, contrary to past experience, do not show any accumulation of merchandise, the report said.

While the essential features of the Home Owners Loan Bill, signed last week by President Roosevelt, have been widely discussed during the past few weeks, the Brooklyn Real Estate Board has drawn up some concise definitions on certain phases of the act as a means of helping those who may contemplate seeking aid from the Home Owners Loan Corporation.
LONDON, June 17. -- The World Economic Conference opened in a mood of deep anxiety. The war debt. controversy clouded the prospect. Dollar exchange was fluctuating wildly.

While the reaction in prices of securities last week substantially reduced the unrealized profits in investment as well as speculative accounts, most investment institutions believe it provided a necessary readjustment. This group includes investment trusts, investment counsel and large corporate trustees.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 17. -- Liberal changes in entrance requirements have just been announced at Cornell University. The fixed standard of the past, requiring the applicant to submit fifteen entrance units, has been so modified as to permit greater freedom of selectivity, based on the applicant's individual merit.

THE LITTLE VIRGIN" is a book as charming and as delightfully fresh as its younger heroine, and as wisely experienced as its older one. It is a quietly pleasant story, imparting the same restful sensations that one obtains in the company of friendly, intelligent people who are discussing interesting subjects in quiet voices, with just enough wit and without noisy disagreement.

SEVERAL museums announce new attractions. At the American Museum off Natural History an exhibition of designs based on plant forms (in line with the Summer show at the Metropolitan) is in progress, work supplied by pupils in seven schools of design and three New York City high schools.

LONDON, June 17. -- Dr. Alfred Hugenberg started for Berlin tonight, following disavowal by the German delegation of his statement yesterday to the economic commission of the World Economic Conference. Before he left, the German delegation informed Premier Colijn of Holland, president of the economic commission, that Dr. Hugenberg's memorandum demanding African colonies was entirely unofficial and represented only Dr. Hugenberg's personal views.

THE diplomatic tension between Austria and Germany, the country of birth and the adopted country of Chancellor Hitler, found dramatic expression last week when Chancellor Dollfuss, the smallest and youngest of the dictators of Europe, informed the leading powers of the precarious position Austria was in as a result of the menace of Hitlerism.

WITH the passage of the Industrial Recovery Bill the administration has rounded out its economic program. That program includes supervision of industry, a large program of public works, and regulation of agriculture, banks and railways.

IN this book parents who are wondering whether or not attendance at the movies has any deleterious influence on their children, and all others who feel doubtful as to the entirely wholesome nature of the silver screen, will find answers to many of the questions they have been asking themselves and one another.

APPROACHING the longest day of the year, the broadcasters march across the threshold of Summer to the tunes of the Goldman Band and other musical aggregations that specialize in what the ethereal showmen call "music of a lighter vein."
Contrary to the seasonal decline that is expected at this time of the year, continued improvement featured both retail and wholesale trade here last week.

HERE is the detailed story of an interesting experiment. Professor and Mrs. Kellogg -- he is Associate Professor of Psychology in Indiana University -- took a young chimpanzee into their home and for almost a year reared it carefully under exactly the same environment and by the same methods as conditioned the growth and training of their own small son.

DIFFERENCES of opinion about the uses to which Central Park in New York should be put serve as a reminder that in Europe, to which we go back for models, urban parks for the plain people -- even the very plain people -- are a heritage from a past in which cities provided no open spaces for the commonalty.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 17. -- More than 700 Wellesley alumnae, representing fourteen reunion classes, returned this morning to the scenes of their undergraduate days. Mrs. Anne Maidment Duryea, '18, won the long-distance record by traveling from Honolulu with her 11-year-old daughter to be with her classmates.
Police Commissioner Bolan said yesterday that the police would continue their drive on known criminals, despite the fact that most of those arrested in last week's round-up were released in court.

The fame of BERTRAM THOMAS'S crossing of Rub' Al Khali, the "Empty Quarter" of Southern Arabia, was still the wonder of explorers when H. ST. JOHN PHILBY, a convert to Islam, headed an expedition to make a passage from north to south parallel for the most part to that of THOMAS from south to north.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 14. -- Missouri probably will vote in favor of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment late this Summer, but the dry forces of the State are putting up a last-ditch fight that has the wets, even those most confident of victory, a bit worried.

NEW HAVEN, June 17. -- Yale University's 232d commencement program opened tonight with the presentation of "Much Ado About Nothing" by the Yale University Dramatic Association. The play will be repeated on Tuesday.
WALLKILL, N.Y., June 16. -- "Stone walls do not a prison make, nor iron bars a cage" might easily apply to the new State penal institution here, which began receiving inmates last Fall.

IT is only a generation since Ernst Haeckel's "The Riddle of he Universe" set people to thinking and talking with fresh zest and excitement about its theme. But it is a far cry from this book to that, and in the meantime a great deal of water has flowed under the bridge and out into the ocean of Things-ThatAren't-So.

LONDON, June 17. -- Mrs. Robert W. Bingham, wife of the United States Ambassador, will present thirteen American women, including Miss Henrietta Bingham, daughter of the Ambassador and his first wife, at the fifth and final royal court of the season in Buckingham Palace next Friday.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- Jesse Owens, with three record-smashing performances, today led East Technical High School of Cleveland, Ohio, to the national interscholastic track and field championship at Soldier Field. Owens contributed 30 points, to score the important share of his team's 54 points.

LOOK at the dry cell which suppiles the current for your electric doorbell or your radio set, if you live in the country far from anything that resembles an overhead electric-light system, and you will notice that it has a top covering of pitch.

Asserting that "evolution might have taken the place of revolution" in Germany but for the weaknesses of the Weimar Constitution and the lack of foresight on the part of its political and economic leaders, Friedrich W. von Prittwitz, former Ambassador to the United States, in an article in July Current History captioned "German in Transition," surveys the reasons for the growth of radicalism in Germany since 1918.

Twelve-story buildings in the form of a cross make up the central units of the prize-winning design in the architectural competition held under the auspices of the Phelps Stokes Fund for the "most practical and attractive plan" for a model housing development to rebuild a typical New York tenement block.

HARTFORD, June 17. -- The outdoor pulpit in the new $1,000,000 chapel of Trinity College will be dedicated tomorrow morning in memory of the Rev. Dr. Flavel S. Luther, president of the college from 1904 to 1918. The dedication will be a principal event of Baccalaureate Sunday.

A possibility that repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment may be ratified this year is indicated by a survey made public yesterday by the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, of which Mrs. Charles H. Sabin is chairman.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 (AP). -- Barney Berlinger, displaying his athletic prowess on Franklin Field once again, made almost a personal triumph out of the Middle Atlantic A.A.U. championship track and field meet today.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- The Rosenwald Industrial Museum where the public will be permitted to play with the man-size toys composing the exhibits and learn what makes them go, will be formally opened at an invitation pre-view on Monday. The public will be admitted on and after July 1.
LONDON, June 17. -- After a hard morning's work by Chairman Colijn and members of the Secretariat, the Economic Commission's revised agenda was officially issued. It called for:

MOTOR "villages" have sprung up all around Chicago since the opening of the Century of Progress Exposition to take care of the thousands of tourists flocking to visit the Fair. The "villages" are approved by the exposition committee, but are operated privately, according to standards set by that body.

Trade organizations were warned yesterday to simplify their codes of ethics as much as possible and to concentrate on a few major points, by leading association executives and attorneys who have been examining some of the programs submitted to Washington.

One of the questions discussed at London is the possibility of international action to control the world's supply of wheat. No other agricultural commodity is of equal interest to producers in so many countries. Any action which succeeded in improving prices and helping to maintain them, on a stable level would be of great importance.

TROY, N.Y., June 17. -- Degrees in engineering, science, architecture and business administration were conferred upon 332 graduates, the largest class in the long history of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, at its commencement this afternoon.

THE passage of the administration's bill for the control of industry is the capstone of a legislative performance which in three months has worked out, to a chorus of almost universal approval (except for economies affecting veterans), a genuine revolution in American economic and political life.

Chancellor KIRKLAND, whose service of forty years as head of Vanderbilt University was celebrated last week, was once a teacher of Greek and Latin. He edited the Satires and Epistles of HORACE. If he were publishing another edition, he would no doubt add a footnote in refutation of HORACE'S statement to MAECENAS that no man living is content with the lot which either his choice has given him or chance has thrown in his way.

The full report of the Commerce Department, on this country's balance of international payments for 1932, amplifies the details of what has been going on, but conveys little new information regarding actual trends. It shows that, if we exclude the movement of gold or of investment capital, the year's credit balance on account of all international payments was $131,000,000, compared with $160,000,000 in 1931 and $629,000,000 even in 1930.

Defenders of city P.S.A.L. senior high school team championships did not fare especially well during the 1932-33 school year, which closes this month. Only a few retained their titles, notably two old stand-bys, the New Utrecht track and field squad and Curtis cross-country team.

ALTHOUGH many of the original plans for music at Chicago's "Century of Progress" World's Fair had to be abandoned for economic reasons, this week will bring forth concerts by national choral societies, institutional choirs, university organizations, high school and settlement groups, according to information received last week.

TROY, N.Y., June 17. -- Dixiana Boy, owned by C.E. Saville of Dayton, Ohio, won the saddle horse championship in the concluding event of the three-day Troy horse show tonight. Winning Ways of Mrs. L.L. Roland's Pennypack Valley Farm, Southampton, Pa., consistent winner in the lighter saddle clashes, won reserve honors.

Somewhat ashamed of the markets for their shivery reception of the London dispatches last week, a commission house remarked in one of its circulars that "Wall Street should get used to the Economic Conference." But it did not get used to it.

MIRIAM JORDAN, who may be seen at the Radio City Music Hall this week in "I Loved You Wednesday," was born in the Stamford Hill section of London and was educated privately at Skinner's School for Young Ladies, London.

The extraordinary course of events at Washington since March 4 will long be a subject of discussion -- and of sharp differences of opinion -- among students of government. Already two lines of thought about it are clearly marked. One maintains that never, in peacetime, has this country seen such a display of Executive audacity and usurpation.

There can be little doubt that this book was written as much for the amusement of its six authors as for the entertainment of the general public. Millward Kennedy begins the book by suggesting to John Rhode that "Ask a Policeman" would be an excellent title for a detective story.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Proposals for currency stabilization which have been submitted to President Roosevelt from the World Economic Conference in London are not agreeable to the American Government, Acting Secretary of the Treasury Acheson said today.

AS in his previous books, "The Sciences and Philoso- phy" and "The Philosophical Basis of Biology," the veteran Oxford biologist and philosopher has, in the present one, once more resumed his fight against the forces of materialism.

ST. PAUL, June 17. -- Hope of freeing William Hamm Jr., millionaire president of the Theodore Hamm Brewing Company, held by kidnappers for $100,000 ransom under a threat of death, tomorrow was expressed tonight by H.J. Charles, attorney for the company.

Prices of bonds recovered sharply on the Stock Exchange yesterday during the two-hour trading period. German Government loans rallied sensationally to lead virtually the entire German bond group higher, while in the domestic section railroad and industrial issues led the recovery.

FOLKESTONE, England, June 17 (AP). -- The United States team remained in first place today at the international chess tournament, defeating Great Britain, 3 -- 1, in the seventh round and taking an eighth round match from Estonia by default.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The chasm between debtor nations who have paid in full or in part their June instalments and those who have again defaulted has deepened, as far as future treatment is concerned, war debt correspondence made public today revealed.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 13. -- The agreement for a moratorium on Costa Rica's American and British loans reduced the deficit for 1932 to slightly under 2,000,000 colones, about $400,000. Had the administration attempted to meet the service on foreign loans, the deficit for the year would have been far beyond anything this government has ever had to face.

Two of the big events of the year in yachting will take place this week. They are the New York Yacht Club races off Glen Cove, L. I., and the ocean contest down the coast from New London, Conn., and up Chesapeake Bay to Gibson Island, Md.

There can be little doubt that this book was written as much for the amusement of its six authors as for the entertainment of the general public. Millward Kennedy begins the book by suggesting to John Rhode that "Ask a Policeman" would be an excellent title for a detective story.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Proposals for currency stabilization which have been submitted to President Roosevelt from the World Economic Conference in London are not agreeable to the American Government, Acting Secretary of the Treasury Acheson said today.

AS in his previous books, "The Sciences and Philoso- phy" and "The Philosophical Basis of Biology," the veteran Oxford biologist and philosopher has, in the present one, once more resumed his fight against the forces of materialism.
MARION, Mass., June 17. -- President Roosevelt began tonight his first vacation since he assumed the Presidency, relaxing aboard the tiny schooner Amberjack II.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP). -- A group of American manufacturers, through the American Manufacturers Export Association, is planning a $5,000,000 bank to finance barter with South American countries and to liquidate large sums of frozen credits.

Preparation of a tentative code of fair practice for department stores under the National Industrial Recovery Bill and warnings in important retail circles that price rises by producers are becoming "inordinate," without assurance of corresponding gains for the labor employed, featured retail developments here during the week.

LONDON. WHEN Princess Victoria was a child playing about Kensington Gardens she did not know that she was ever likely to become queen. Her wicked uncle was still enthroned at Windsor; royalty had seldom been so unpopular in the history of the land.
LONDON, June 17. -- The United States delegation has moved to put four points on the agenda of the economic commission of the World Economic Conference:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Only two weeks ago Secretary Perkins made a statement concerning the shoe situation in the South that caused every one down hero to laugh, and now, in her article, "America Rediscovers a Native Art of Cooking," Sheila Hibben makes several generalizations that are surprising to one who has lived in the South all his life.

The present upswing in business has proved strong enough to forestall the seasonal drop usual in trade at this time of year, and should continue to exert a favorable influence until mid-August at least, executives returning yesterday from the annual convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents in Boston last week, said yesterday.

AT the World Economic Conference a determined attack upon the obstacles to economic recovery is being made. It is the consensus that the most important task before this conference is the stabilization of currencies and the increase of world prices.

THE crossing westward of the Atlantic from Seville to Cuba by the modern conquistadors, Barberan and Collar, has focused attention again on the struggle by means of the air for the markets and trade routes of the Latin Americas.

LONDON, June 17 (AP). -- The refusal of representatives of the Netherlands and Switzerland, who together hold 2,500,000,000 gold marks [currently about $710,000,000] of German foreign long-term credits, to accept proposals of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, hampered negotiations over those German obligations today.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP). -- Another step toward the conquest of leprosy was announced today by the Leonard Wood Memorial for eradication of that disease, in the isolation and cultivation of the germ outside the body.
WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The administration of the government's great industrial recovery program will be in full swing before the end of another week.

The sudden stopping of an automobile on the crowded Superhighway at Haynes Avenue, Newark, during the thunderstorm yesterday afternoon, resulted in a collision involving five automobiles, a truck and a motorbus. Six men and five women were injured.

LONDON, June 17. -- The text of the memorandum the United States delegation submitted to the economic commission of the World Economic Conference today, outlining suggested topics for the agenda, follows:

PARIS, June 15. -- Sapphire blue was a favorite color at the French Derby; many velvet coats in this tone, with cornflower-trimmed hats, were seen. A cold snap restored the prestige of fur in all shades; fox scarfs, sable, monkey, ermine were favored in the order mentioned.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- Members of the Railway Labor Executives Association were formulating a reply today to the invitation to meet in Chicago on July 12 for discussion of a 22 1/2 per cent basic pay cut, which the managers propose to put into effect next Nov. 1.
To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems a vain and useless thing to disagree or, which is far more deplorable, to argue about the conversion of Cardinal Newman to the Catholic faith.

A complication in the fusion movement developed yesterday when it became known that Alfred L. Breor, Republican leader of Richmond, intended to propose Justice John F. Hylan for the Republican nomination for Mayor at the conference of Republican county leaders with former Governor Charles S. Whitman, chairman of the Republican Mayoralty Committee.

With Miss Helen Hicks, former national titleholder among the competitors, a field of thirty-six will take part tomorrow in the qualifying round of the Women's Long Island Golf Association championship. The event will be held at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club, Glen Head, L.I.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- The largest and most comprehensive scientific meeting of its kind to be held anywhere will open here Monday in connection with the Century of Progress Exposition. It is the Summer session of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and its forty affiliated societies.

HOLLYWOOD. THE first two weeks of Darryl Zanuck's newly created Twentieth Century Pictures has upset the town. Ten writers were engaged and began work on the season's product. Constance Bennett and George Arliss were taken from studios in which they were considered fixtures.
Kerry Patch, long-shot winner of the Belmont Futurity last Fall, captured the Queens County Handicap, $2,500 added opening-day feature at Aqueduct yesterday.

In an in- troductory chapter he tells how deeply he was impressed by the slogan "Think Imperially." urged upon England half a century ago by Disraeli.

With Miss Helen Hicks, former national titleholder among the competitors, a field of thirty-six will take part tomorrow in the qualifying round of the Women's Long Island Golf Association championship. The event will be held at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club, Glen Head, L.I.

LONDON, June 17. -- The first garden party at Windsor Castle since the World War was given to delegates and officials of the World Economic Conference and their wives this afternoon, nearly 2,000 persons attending.

ROME, June 16. -- In the improved atmosphere created by the fourpower pact, Italy looks for an amicable solution in the not too distant future of the various problems which have embittered Italo-French relations since the war.

THIS Island is an excellent bit to rule a great horse." Thus wrote the redoubtable and often amusing John Smith, historian of early Virginia. The bit was Bermuda; the horse was the naval power of Spain. In "The Adventurers of Bermuda" Mr. Wilkinson shows how the bit was forged by a group of worthy and sometimes unworthy seventeenthcentury gentlemen, and tells also how Bermuda became a springboard for profitable adventuring in the Spanish Main.

The State Beer Board was urged yesterday to appeal from the rulingof Supreme Court Justice Staley in Albany enjoining the board from enforcing its ruling that applicants for licenses to sell beer and wine must advertise in the daily papers.

The gruesome relics of the Judd Gray-Ruth Snyder murder and of the Starr Faithfull case were the subject of a technical paper on forensic medicine read before the American Medical Association last week. The detection of crime may often rest more with the chemist, physicist and bacteriologist than with the police.

Many pastors will preach today on the World Economic Conference being held in London and will point out its bearing on the religious life of the participating nations. Other clergymen will discuss the linking of science and religion, with illustrations from the discussions along that line during the last week.

VIENNA, June 17. -- The assertion that the tension between Austria and Germany over the Nazi question could not be permanent and that there was every reason to believe the present difficulties would be solved on the basis of common sense was made by Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss tonight on his return from London.
PARIS. FALL afternoon fashions point to happy days ahead. They are likely to assume that dressed-up "predepression" air of leisure and prosperity that has been almost totally submerged for some time.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- The largest and most comprehensive scientific meeting of its kind to be held anywhere will open here Monday in connection with the Century of Progress Exposition. It is the Summer session of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and its forty affiliated societies.

AN ardent, globe-trotting traveler is Mr. Wadia of India and the British Empire, author of several books, sometime Professor of English and History at Elphinstone College, Bombay. In an in- troductory chapter he tells how deeply he was impressed by the slogan "Think Imperially." urged upon England half a century ago by Disraeli.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Science's latest hunt for "big game" in the impenetrable "jungle" of the interior of the atom, the nucleus, was described here today by Professor Arthur H. Compton of the University of Chicago, himself a leading "hunter" in the "darkest Africa of matter."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 18 -- The world is crippled by spiritual paralysis and moral inertia and, because it follows a shabby philosophy of life, is steadily drifting toward another dark age, President Angell asserted today in his baccalaureate sermon at Yale University.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Cooler weather and lighter receipts ordinarily would make a higher market for hogs, but last weak, despite the run of 476,000 hogs at eleven markets, or 50,000 fewer than in the previous week, prices moved within a moderate limit.

Homo Americanus loves to work Or loaf for the Government. From the annual report of the Council of the National Civil Service Reform League, published this morning, it appears that more than 3,000,000 persons are on the Federal, State or municipal payrolls.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 18 -- Four goals in the last period carried the Sands Point polo team to victory over Great Neck in a close and well played game at the Sands Point Club today, 11 goals to 8.

FRANKLIN SQUARE, L.I., June 18 -- The close harmony of a mixed chorus against the background of blaring brass marked the opening here today of a three-day festival in celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the Plattdeutsche Volksfest Verein, parent organization of ninety similar groups of German-Americans in Brooklyn and Long Island.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- To sift charges that the National Park Service and companies owned by John D. Rockefeller Jr. are pushing homesteaders off their land in Wyoming, a Senate committee will open an inquiry July 31 at either Jackson or Moran, Wyo.

The Organization of Regular Republicans for Change in the New York County Leadership announced yesterday that it would figrht Samuel S. Koenig, county chairman, in his own baliwick, the Sixth Assembly District. Headquarters will be opened today at 55 Avenue C, opposite the Federal Club, Mr. Koenig's organization, of which he has been leader for more than a quarter of a century.

When that infallible harbinger of Spring, the circus, comes north next year, it is likely to find that Manhattan has already had a circus and that its advance agent is none other than Dr. Walter Damrosch.

With the unseasonable weather affecting retail trade adversely and causing a decline in wholesale orders, stores turned attention last week to Fall apparel lines. The better dress houses are scheduling their showings for shortly after July 4.

LONDON, June 18 -- Delegates of Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Poland, Rumania and Yugoslavia, eight of the ten States represented at the recent Bucharest conference of agrarian countries of Central Europe, held an organization meeting Saturday and decided to hold others from time to time to coordinate their policy for the World Economic Conference.

PITTSBURGH, June 18 -- Heavier production of steel in the next four weeks is expected, with a possibility of a lull thereafter, due to a peculiar situation now existing in the market. Higher prices are expected to be announced for the third quarter of the year, but customers are being permitted to specify on present contracts up to the end of this month, deliveries on the specifications to be completed by July 15.

Since the enactment of the new "Parity" Law on May 12, spokesmen of the large farm organizations have been insisting on the immediate payment of cash bounties. True, the wheat crop is already sown and it is too late to curtail this season's planting unless some of the acreage is plowed under -- which nobody has proposed to do.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 18 -- In a lively northwest breeze that kicked up Long Island Sound this afternoon, fifty-two craft sailed in the special regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club. One of them, Harold Palmer's thirty-footer Alera, landed on Rooster Rock on the westerly side of Hen and Chickens Reef.

Young Gandhi Marries. India's social system is declared to have received a violent jolt when the son of Mahatma GANDHI, who is of the third or merchant caste, was married to a woman of the Brahman caste.

William Rose Benet, in assembling an American auto-anthology of poems, asked the poets to select from their own work the short poem they liked best. He also asked that they send with the poem, in a brief paragraph, some of the reasons for choosing their particular poem, as well as something concerning the circumstances under which it was written.

To the Editor of The New York Times : Several Items have appeared In your paper In which Fort Schuyler has been referred to as an "abandoned" army post. I desire to invite your attention and that of your readers to the fact that Fort Schuyler is the headquarters of the Twenty -ninth Engineer Topographic Battalion, the sole technical organization for producing military maps authorized for the army at the present time.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Traders in wheat are finding the problems confronting the world's grain markets to be the most interesting and complicated since the United States and Canada were called upon to feed Europe during the World War. It is being firmly impressed upon their minds, as well as on other interests, that farmers must get more for their grain to obtain "an even break" in exchanging their products for others of necessary consumption.
THE British amateur golf championship will start this morning over the links of the Royal Liverpool Club (pronounced Hoylake) and a fine time will be had by all.

Alfred E. Smith and Mrs. Charles Cary Rumsey will serve jointly as honorary chairmen of the Citizens Summer Playgrounds Committee, recently organized by the Community Councils of New York City to seek funds to open at least 350 additional playgrounds.

The anti-Tammany fusion forces will renew this week the search for a candidate for Mayor. The search so far has been unsuccessful because of the refusal of Samuel Seabury and Richard C. Patterson Jr. to run.

BERLIN, June 17 -- The Institute for Stuyding Trade Fluctuations considers a setback in German industry is possible. It says the consumption industries are in a vicious circle because only an increase in the amount of wages paid can quicken the demand for goods and an increase in the amount of wages paid depends in turn upon a rivival in industry.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., June 18 -- Edward J. Adamski, characterized by Detective Captain John Creeden of the Philadelphia police as "the slickest burglar and safeman who ever operated in Philadelphia," was arrested the other day during a raid in Camden and brought to the Mount Holly jail for questioning.

TEL AVIV, Palestine, June 18 -- Only 34 years old and facing a brilliant future, Dr. Chaim Arlosoroff, who died the victim of two still unapprehended assassins, was buried here this afternoon. About 70,000 persons marched in the funeral procession, with delegations attending from all parts of the country.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 18 -- Wellesley College will confer 316 bachelor degrees at the fifty-fifth commencement exercises in Alumnae Hall tomorrow morning. The commencement speaker will be James Grover McDonald, chairman of the board of the Foreign Policy Association.

Fighting off four hold-up men with a bottle as his only weapon, Joseph Grabski, 59 years old, proprietor of a beer garden at Grand Avenue and Eighty-third Street, Maspeth, Queens, was shot and killed by one of the thugs late last night.

Getting almost a maximum yield from a minimum amount of effort, the Giants wrenched quite a tense struggle from the Cubs at the Polo Grounds yesterday while a gallery of 20,000 marveled at the ease with which Manager Bill Terry's singular array triumphed.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Efforts to get some of the larger industries operating under the provisions of the National Industrial Recovery Act by early next month are being made by General Hugh S. Johnson, the administrator, who said tonight that he would announce rules and regulations tomorrow for the setting up of trade codes.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Our exports to a dozen leading markets increased, but our imports in the first quarter of 1933 were 31 per cent lower in value than for the first quarter of 1932, and 66 per cent under the 1928-1932 average, according to the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Out of $28,496,690 loaned by the government to farmers' cooperative organizations in May, $27,400,000 went to the American Cotton Cooperative Association of New Orleans, Henry Morgenthau Jr., Governor of the Farm Credit Association, stated this afternoon.

Warning the building trades organizations of the New York and New Jersey areas to assume their share of responsibility in making effective the provisions of the new National Recovery Act, the current Dow Service declares that construction in the metropolitan area already shows a bold upward trend.
BUENOS AIRES. Argentina, June 18 -- The markets here for all agricultural products continued to improve in the last week under sustained export demand at strengthened prices.

BUDAPEST, June 18 -- The entire press devotes much of its space to discussion of what may lie behind the sudden departure of Premier Goemboes for Berlin, which was kept secret until he had actually reached Germany.
CHICAGO, June 18 -- The largest crowd in this city's baseball history saw the Yankees split a double-header with the White Sox at Comiskey Park today.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Many leaders of American Jewry, representing reformed congregations in all parts of the United States, convened here today for the opening council of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations. The meeting, which will last through Thursday, is being held simultaneously with the conventions of the National Federation of Temple Brotherhoods and the National Federation of Temple Sisterhoods.

RYE, N.Y., June 18 -- Mrs. C.B. Ward, owner of the Scotsward Kennels of Florham Park, N.J., today established a record in the annals of the Scottish Terrier Club of America. For the second consecutive year one of her entries won the highest award at the annual specialty exhibition of the organlzation.

BOSTON, June 18 (AP) -- The Braves opened a home stay by dropping a double-header to the Pirates today, 5 to 3 and 4 to 3. The second game was called at the end of the eighth to comply with the Sunday law.

The end of the cigar and cigarette price war and of profit-sharing coupons was foreshadowed yesterday at the close of the two-day conventions of tobacco retailers and distributers at the Hotel New Yorker. Both groups adopted codes of business ethics to regulate the tobacco industry.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 18 There is no place for a "standpatter" in times like these, according to President J.L. McConaughy in his baccalaureate address at Wesleyan University's 101st commencement this morning.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- President Roosevelt was represented tonight as opposed to participation in an international currency stabilization agreement at this time on the theory that a compact on the terms desired by foreign delegates to the World Economic Conference would hamper his domestic recovery program.

NEW ORLEANS, June 18 -- The cotton market here, which had been tending upward for some time, developed a reactionary tendency last week. There were indications of liquidation by a tired long interest and a disposition of professional traders to sell.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls last week follow:

WESTBURY, L. I., June 18 -- Play in the Meadow Brook Club Cups annual twenty-goal handicap polo tournament got under way today on Cochran Field of the Meadow Brook Club as Winston Guest's Templeton quartet rode to an easy 9-to-4 victory over Devereux Milburn's Long Island four in a firstround match.

Women must prepare themselves to take an important place in the "new deal," the Rev. Francis J. Sexton of Mount St. Andrew's Villa. Ridgewood, N.J., told one hundred members of Court Columbia, Catholic Daughters of America at their twenty-ninth annual communion breakfast at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., June 18. -- With a spanking following breeze, the schooner Amberjack II cut a graceful path from Marion today in its first cruise with Skipper Franklin Delano Roosevelt at the helm. Both fair weather and foul came on the heels of a northwest wind, and the first day's progress was cut short by a squall which made it advisable to stop for the night in this harbor.

LONDON, June 17 -- The method adopted for meeting Great Britain's war debt payment and the official statements accompanying it made a very favorable impression upon the City. Default would have been deeply deplored, but at the same time it was felt that full payment could not and should not be made.
HANOVER, N.H., June 18 -- Preeident Hopkins gave the baccalaureate sermon to 446 members of Dartmouth's graduating class today.
CLEVELAND, June 18 (AP) -- The Indians shut out the Red Sox twice today, 7 to 0 and 4 to 0, before a crowd of 18,000.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 18 -- The Long Island flower show for amateur gardeners will open Wednesday afternoon at the Pratt estate oval and will be the largest exhibit ever sponsored by the Federated Garden Clubs of the second district. The North Country Garden Club, of which Mrs. Harold Irving Pratt is president, will be the hostess club.

The Most Rev. James T.G. Hayes, a Jesuit missionary in the Philippines for the last seven years, was consecrated Bishop of the new Diocese of Cagayan, Philippine Islands, yesterday morning in the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street.

Organization of the National Council on Trade Relations to act as an impartial body for the correction of unfair trade practices between producers and distributers under the provision of the National Industrial Recovery Act was announced yesterday by Lucius R. Eastman, president of the American Arbitration Association.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., June 18 -- After motoring from Hyde Park today for her first visit to Camp Tera, the camp for unemployed women at Lake Tiorati, near here, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt expressed, keen disappointment upon learning that there were only thirty women at the camp.

Cool weather continued yesterday, cutting heavily into the attendance at all near-by coast resorts, and bringing the thermometer down to 54. This was just two degrees above the record of June 18, 1920, the chilliest June 18 in the Weather Bureau's history.

IOWA CITY", Iowa, June 18 -- Science, asked to lend a hand in the sports-page argument as to whether starting blocks help a runner get a faster start than ordinary "holes," has given an affirmative opinion.
FRINCETON, N.J., June 18 -- The sophomore reception and dance, final social event of the year at Princeton, will be held tomorrow night in the university gymnasium.
A.S.M. Hutchinson, whose novel, "If Winter Comes," sold 380,000 copies, is author of a new novel. "The Soft Spot," which Little, Brown is to bring out on Aug. 11.

Continued progress in the upbuilding of Palestine was pictured in the annual report of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, submitted yesterday at Geneva to the Secretary General of the League of Nations and to the members of the Permanent Mandates Commission.

The New York Athletic Club completed with estimable thoroughness yesterday its task of rolling up a huge point total in the Metropolitan A.A.U. track and field championships. Winning two of the final three title tests at Travers Island, the Winged Foot athletes picked up an extra 21 points to achieve a new all-time record total of 135 points, the highest in the forty-oneyear-old history of the meet.
NEW YORK. Lady Leslie, now at the Plaza, will sail on the Champlain Saturday to join her husband, Sir Bradford Leslie, in London.

LONDON, June 18 -- Uncertainty prevailed in conference quarters tonight over the possibility of ending the fluctuations of the dollar and the pound while the conference is in session, for all developments could be interpreted as good or bad.

The supremacy of Baroness Maud Levi in the metropolitan women's tennis ranks, asserted in the Eastern and New Jersey championships, was upheld again yesterday when she retained her New York State crown on the courts of the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

BERLIN, June 18 -- Premier Goemboes of Hungary flew to Erfurt with Chancellor Hitler today to review a special division of the Chancellor's Nazi army. Colonel Ernst Roehm, chief of staff of the Hitlerite storm troops, and Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Reich Minister of the Interior, accompanied them.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., June 18 -- Two persons were killed and five critically injured here today when a light sedan crashed into the rear end of a parked circus truck trailer, which, the police say, stuck out into the street and did not have projecting iron pipes properly marked with a warning flag.

Financial attention was divided last week between two incidents -- on the one hand, the laying of their cards on the table by the nations represented at the London Economic Conference; on the other hand, the fall of dollar exchange to a depreciation of nearly 20 per cent, followed by recovery to 16 1/3 per cent discount, then by renewed decline to 17 3/8.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Representative Tinkham, Republican, of Massachusetts, said today In a formal statement he had "officially demanded" the recall of Norman H. Davia as Ambassador at Large during a conference yesterday with Acting Secretary of State Phillips.

SAARBRUECKEN, Saar Basin Territory, June 18 -- A serious situation exists in the Saar Valley. Here is a strange Germany, a Germany without brown shirts, a haven for German refugees echoing all the battle cries now silent from end to end of the Reich.

HOYLAKE, England, June 18 -- On a course baked so hard that Cyril Tolley has been able to reach the green on 500-yard holes with a drive and mashie-niblick pitch, it has been difficult to get a true estimate of form for the British amateur golf championship, which starts on the Hoylake links tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The general level of wholesale prices in May, as computed by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor, showed the third successive increase in recent months, the average as compared with April showing an advance of 3.8 per cent.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 18 -- "Not a recovery but a remaking of our mode of life is the order of the day," Dr. Robert R. Wicks, dean of the Princeton Chapel, said today in his sermon delivered at the baccalaureate service of the graduating class.
Captain Bob Bartlett's schooner Effie M. Morrissey left Staten Island yesterday for a 15,000-mile voyage to the Arctic Sea and return. Her ultimate northern destination is a secret.
The Kerry team, Gaelic football champions of Ireland, brought its tour of the United States to a close yesterday by defeating the New York fifteen at the Yankee Stadium, 15 to 7.

Women interested in furthering the philanthropic work of the Mary Fisher Home have arranged an unusual garden party in its behalf for next Saturday afternoon on the estate of Mrs. A.C. Griffith, in Tenafly, N.J. Members of the Junior Woman's Club of., Tenafly will present Edna St. Vincent Millay's one-act play, "The Princess Marries the Page," in which the Misses Frances Raymond and Lillian O'Neill will take part.

A serious threat to the Roosevelt administration's program for economic recovery is seen by the National Civil Service Reform League in a "clamor for political patronage" which it declares "may prove an insurmountable hurdle to its success."

PARIS, June 18 -- Australia clinched its Davis Cup match with Japan in the semi-final round of the European zone today by scoring its third straight victory. Jack Crawford and Adrian Quist defeated Jiro Satoh and Ryosuka Nunoi in the doubles at Roland Garros Stadium, 7-5, 7-9, 6-3, 3-6, 6-3.

American shipyards axe ready to start work immediately on the construction of the ships that the Navy Department has announced It will build during the next three years, according to H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders.

Jersey City divided a double-header with Buffalo yesterday at West Side Park, Jersey City. The Bisons won the first game, 11 to 3, hitting Babe Phelps heavily, but the Jerseys came back to take the second on Koster's single in the ninth, 6 to 5.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A pamphlet entitled "Dealers In Money," written by Charles Stewart Davison, has just come under my notice, and I think the conclusions reached by the author are worthy of consideration. Mr. Davison says:

LONDON, June 18 -- Every conference has at least one crisis, frequently several. Thus early -- at the end of its first week, to be precise -- the World Economic Conference has reached a dilemma which may develop into a minor or even a major crisis, for it concerns fundamentals.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 8, Fabian Franklin accuses the seven Bishops representing the National Catholic Welfare Conference of making a statement that is "not only untrue but the opposite of the truth," and refers, by implication at least, to their recent pronouncement on the present crisis as "vaporous imaginings of pious sentimentalists."

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- With Connecticut, New Hampshire and Iowa voting Tuesday on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, Dr. F. Scott McBride, general superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League of America, said here tonight that the "real test" would not come until next year.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- The World Fellowship of Faiths, a parliament of religions, held its first meeting at the New England Congregational Church here tonight. Miss Jane Addams of Hull House presided. Prayers of a dozen different faiths were offered, including those of Africans and American Indians.

The things that are eternal in a world of change formed the sermon topic of the Rev. Dr. Charles E. Jefferson, honorary minister of the Broadway Tabernacle, who preached yesterday morning at the Riverside Church.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 18 -- An eleven of the Union County Cricket Club administered the first defeat sustained this season by the cricketers of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club in a fixture of the Metropolitan and New Jersey Cricket Association at Warinanco Park today.
ITHACA, N.Y., June 18 -- The Rev. Dr. Charles W. Gilkey of the University of Chicago preached the baccalaureate sermon this afternoon to nearly 1,200 graduates of Cornell University.

Business activity showed steady improvement during May and the first half of June, according to the monthly report of the conference of statisticians of the National Industrial Conference Board. The advances strengthen the general impression that the tide has turned, it was said, with better sentiment and revived confidence providing the momentum for further gains.
The story of anti-Semitism in Germany, supported by data based on documentary evidence, was published yesterday in the form of a "White Book," covering 112 pages, by the American Jewish Committee.

A return to the ethical, spiritual and political standards, which governed the United States prior to 1850 was urged by the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington. He preached yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street.

Eddie Driggs of Cherry Valley won the play-off for the qualifying medal in this year's metropolitan amateur title golf tourney at the Pomonok Country Club, in Flushing, yesterday. He scored a 75, as compared to 80s for both George Voigt and Eddie Held.
MANILA, June 18 -- Manuel Quezon again confounded the opposition before a demonstrative crowd of several thousand tonight.

BERLIN, June 17 -- It is considered unlikely that the London Economic Conference will seriously affect the fate of Germany's bond creditors. Reduction in tariffs might indeed lead to an increase in the German export surpluses, but it is the belief that bondholders could not benefit therefrom so long as Dr. Schacht, President of the Reichsbank, pursues the plan to appropriate exchange takings for the upbuilding of a new Reichsbank reserve.
"The Ghost Writer," a play by Martin Mooney, will open tonight at the Masque Theatre. Hal Skelly, William Frawley, Ara Gerald and Peggy Conklin are in the cast.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 18 -- In a changing world, one must try to distinguish between the enduring and the temporary. and the personal character of man is one of the essentials, President Lowell declared today in the baccalaureate sermon of Harvard University's commencement exercises.

The charge that the church was doing little in the fight for world peace was denied yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Henry Smith Leiper, foreign secretary of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, speaking as guest preacher in the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, West End Avenue at Seventy-seventh Street.

NOME, Alaska, June 18 (AP) -- Bad weather prevented two navy fliers stationed in the Pribilof Islands, one of them Ensign William A. Moffett Jr., son of the late Rear Admiral Moffett, from taking off today to search for James Mattern, missing around-the-world flier.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Nineday furloughs without pay for postal employes will be put into effect July 1 to save $9,500,000, Postmaster General Farley stated today. The furlough order by the Postmaster General was signed by President Roosevelt on Friday and will continue in effect until Sept. 30.

LONDON, June 18 (AP) -- Norman H. Davis, who left today for Southampton to sail aboard the Bremen for the United States, denied emphatically reports that he intended to resign as President Roosevelt's special envoy abroad.

ROANOKE, Va., June 18 (AP) -- George McGee, alias George L. Jackson, who, the police said, admitted he was waned by kansas City authorities as a participant in the kidnapping of Miss Mary McElroy, daughter of the City Manager of that city, was In custody here today.

NEW HAVEN, June 18 -- Professor Irving Fisher's Index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 63.5, which compares with 62.7 a week ago, 62.1 two weeks ago, 61.2 three weeks ago and 60.6 four weeks ago. The present average is the highest of the year to date; the average of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The Roosevelt administration has postponed action on sugar tariffs pending a full study of proposals for the establishment of a marketing agreement covering the industry. The study will begin formally within a few days.

The bank situation is improving daily and is much better than the public realizes, Louis McHenry Howe, secretary to President Roosevelt, said last night in a radio interview broadcast over a National Broadcasting Company network.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., June 18 -- Twenty-six passengers in a New York bus bound for Wassaic, N.Y., were injured this afternoon when the left front tire of the bus blew out, causing the driver to lose control.
