CHICAGO, June 18 -- Nearly 50,000 Lutherans from all parts of the country gathered at Soldier Field this afternoon in a demonstration of what leaders asserted to be the essential unity of American Lutheranism, despite its apparent divisions.

ST. PAUL, Monday, June 19 -- Relatives and friends of William Hamm, kidnapped brewer, kept vigil through the night for his expected release by abductors to whom had been paid part of the $100,000 ramson they demanded.

AMHERST, Mass., June 18 -- Many alumni as well as students heard the Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving, rector of Trinity Church, Boston, give the baccalaureate sermon to seniors of Amherst College today. He challenged young men to go out into a world troubled by depression and other ills, and rebuild it by surpassing themselves, with achievement, not money, as their goal.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 18 -- The college graduate Is about to enter a world of opportunity, but also one "determined to crush out independence and self respect and to force one into conformity and make one a human being held down by habits," Warden Bernard I. Bell of St. Stephens College declared today in the baccalaureate sermon at "Williams College.

The third week of the Chicago Opera Company's presentations of grand opera at popular prices began last night at the Hippodrome with Gounod's "Faust." And again, as during the past fortnight, the big house, which seats 5,300 people, was filled save for a small fringe of empty seats each side the top balcony.

More Summer theatres will begin their seasons this week, while most of those which have already started with the notable exception of Herbert J. Biberman's theatre at the Westchester County Centre in White Plains, will continue with new bills.
ST. LOUIS, June 18 (AP) -- By splitting with the Washington Senators, the St. Louis Browns stepped out of the American League cellar today to give the lowest berth to the Red Sox.

Katharine Cornell, who is now playing in "Alien Corn" in Chicago, yesterday announced her plans for next season. They are threefold. She will make her first appearance in a Shakespearean role -- offering "Romeo and Juliet" -- she will have a coast-to-coast tour and she will take the first step toward the creation of a repertory company.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- An eleven-point program for the re-opening of banks now operating under restrictions and payment of about 60 per cent to depositors in institutions closed before the banking holiday will soon be presented to President Roosevelt.

KANSAS CITY, June 18 (AP) -- Search for the killers of four peace officers and Frank Nash, an escaped convict, here yesterday spread to a half dozen States tonight, although Federal and local officers had only meager clues on which to work.

NEWARK, June 18 -- The Montreal Royals defeated the Newark Bears in both ends of a double-header at Ruppert Stadium today, taking the first game in the fourteenth inning, 9 to 8, and winning the seven-inning nightcap encounter, 10 to 5.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 18 -- The Rev. Dr. Edward S. Travers, of Rhinebeck, N.Y., delivered the baccalaureate sermon at Trinity College. The New Deal, he warned the senior class, means more than economic adjustments.

The trade winds still are blowing in favor of the Dodgers. Yesterday before a crowd of 10,000 at Ebbets Field Brooklyn downed the last-place Phlllies, 3 to 1, and it was a sharp single by slugging Sam Leslie, erstwhile Giant, that provided the margin of victory.

VIENNA, June 18 -- Comments in the Vienna newspapers this morning that the visit of Premier Goemboes of Hungary to Berlin was the result of recent conversations and a secret meeting between Chancellor Dollfuss of Austria and the Hungarian Premier were flatly denied by the government.

"We must put at the head of "our list those works which are "fully ready to start now," President ROOSEVELT declared. New York can probably meet the preparedness challenge better than any other community in the country. It has a State Public Works Commission with an enterprising chairman who has already submitted a broad program of worth-while public works ready to be initiated at once.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 18 -- John Maynard Keynes, British economist and a member of the British Economic Council, will say tomorrow in the Summer issue of The Yale Review that concentrating national effort on capturing foreign trade, penetrating the economic life of a country by foreign capitalists and submitting a nation's economic life to the fluctuating economic policies of foreign countries do not appear to assure international peace.

To the editor of The New York Times: In the editorial wherein you refer to the royalties earned by the late Wlnchell Smith from his successful plays, you speak of his success, financially, as a moneymaking dramatist. You also kindly refer to the fact that the author left one-third of his estate to various actors'' associations -- "a tribe even less successful in conserving their earnings than the average playwright."

LONDON, June 18 -- Senator Key Pittman issued a statement today denying that the suggestion for a general 10 per cent tariff reduction which was submitted to the economic commission of the World Economic Conference came from the United States delegation.

The Welfare Council, organized eight years ago to bring about cooperation of official and unofficial welfare agencies of every type in this city, has been successful in that aim. Seven hundred organizations are now members of it. Its social service exchange performed the tremendous task last year of clearing more than a million applicants for relief or other forms of social service.

BERLIN, June 17 -- The opening of the World Economic Conference was somewhat disappointing because of the vagueness of the declarations of the delegates. There is some unfavorable comment on Secretary of State Hull's apparent lack of authority to commit the United States on contentious questions.

LONDON, June 18 -- Dr. Alfred Hugenberg's memorandum to the economic commission of the conference here, in which he asked that Germany receive colonial areas in Africa, has aroused widespread comment, chiefly because it was almost immediately explained that the statement of the German Minister of Economics, who Is a Nationalist, not a Nazi, represented neither the view of the Reich's delegation at the conference nor that of the Berlin government.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 18 -- Mr. and Mrs. David McCandless gave a picnic last night at their camp near Craryville, N.Y., in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Delano de Wlndt, who observed their seventeenth wedding anniversary. Mr. and Mrs. McCandless, who have been visiting Mrs. McCandless's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Darlington, at Great Barrington, will open the camp for the Summer tomorrow.

Once more the question of predatory animals is brought to the fore by a State conservation official. Despite the fact that this State has propagated and liberated large quantities of game birds and small game animals, it has been found, as a result of checkups against the reports made by hunters, that a wide discrepancy in the number of survivors is to be noted.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 18 --If liberty is to be a blessing and not a curse, President Barbour of Brown University declared in a baccalaureate address today, "it must be a liberty which serves not the crude egotism of the individual but. the general welfare."

To the Editor of The New York Times : The war debt "token payment" by Britain and the French refusal to pay anything on account of war debts may well give rise to an interesting situation, perhaps designed, in view of our reported policy to Invite those who acknowledge the debts to a conference and exclude from negotiations those nations standing on the proposition that the warndebt obligations are legally invalid.

President ROOSEVELT has frequently made use of metaphors drawn from sport. At the end of his long statement on Friday, explaining the Recovery Act, he made an appeal to " move as one great team to victory." But in at least one matter the agents and spokesmen of the Administration's policy are not showing the most perfected team play.

MOSCOW, June 18 -- Colonel Raymond Robins, who was in Russia in 1917 during the "ten days that shook the world" and who won the confidence of Nicolai Lenin, Leon Trotsky and other Soviet leaders as no other "bourgeois" foreigner did, is back in Moscow after a six weeks' tour of this country.

LONDON, June 18 -- British hopes of bringing prosperity back to the world's freight shipping by schemes involving the scrapping of surplus tonnage and the laying up of vessels were wrecked tonight by an announcement that the British Chamber of Shipping had been unable to obtain sufficient support from its members.

BERLIN, June 18 --The long-drawn-out battle over the Protestant Reich Bishopric between the Evangelical Church Union and the Nazis has been intensified with an announcement by Dr. Hermann Mueller, defeated candidate for the office, and Chancellor Hitler's delegate to the Church Union, that Dr. Friederich von Bodelschwingh can not be regarded as the duly-ordained Reich Bishop and that no Reich Bishopric lawfully exists as yet.

DETROIT, June 18 (AP) -- The Tigers took both ends of a double-header from the Athletics today, scoring two runs in the ninth to win the first, 3 to 2, and making good use of thirteen hits and six Athletic errors to take the nightcap, 11 to 7.

WEST HAMPTON, L.I., June 18 -- John H. McCooey, Democratic leader of Brooklyn, celebrated his sixty-ninth birthday quietly today at the home of his son, Herbert McCooey, on Dune Road here. Mr. McCooey came down yesterday and plans to return to Brooklyn on Tuesday.

PARIS, June 17 -- Satisfaction was shown here when it was learned that the French point of view concerning the paramount importance of stabilizing currencies was generally accepted at the World Economic Conference and that most countries recognized in principle the necessity of stabilization without which it is useless to discuss lowering tariff walls.

A continuing improvement in employment, trade and industrial activity is noted in the current monthly survey of business trends by the International Business Machines Corporation. The material for the survey is based on reports from more than 1,000 of the company's representatives in all parts of the country.
Dwellings comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty trading reported over the week-end.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Business throughout the West and Middle West is making steady gains in sales of all kinds of merchandise, prices of raw materials and manufactured goods are strengthening, and there are prospects of further upturns In numerous lines.

The necessity for an increase in rapid transit fares to pave the way for an early solution of the city's financial problems has been recognized definitely by Tammany Hall. That organization, according to information from usually reliable sources, is prepared to "stand for" an increased fare, provided it is realized after the city election.

The common ground between science and religion lies in their mutual search for truth, the Rev. G. Vincent Runyon told the congregation of the Eighteenth Street Methodist Episcopal Church, 305 West Eighteenth Street, yesterday.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 18 -- Smith College seniors heard the annual baccalaureate sermon delivered today by President Neilson.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 18 -- The League of Nations commission for the administration of Leticia, which arrived at Puerto Boy last night by airplane from Barranquilla, is expected to reach Letitia on June 23, the eve of the expiration of the thirty-day period set for evacuation by Peruvians of the Colombian Amazon River port they seized last September.

LONDON, June 18 -- The Washington correspondent of The London Times has been moved by consideration of the extensive powers granted to President Roosevelt by Congress to write for his paper an estimate of the situation thus created with some interpretative observations as to what this implies and its possible effect.

The activity of President RICHARDS of the New Jersey Senate as a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor next year has aroused the Democrats to the danger of losing the State. Mr. RICHARDS has made some friends among the independent voters by giving his support to policies of Governor MOORE.

American readers of the dispatches from London and Washington must be excused if they feel a little dizzy-headed Last Thursday and Friday they were told jubilantly of an " American victory" at the Economic Conference. Our delegates had captured the chairmanship of the monetary committee, and everything was moving swiftly toward an agreed stabilization of the chief currencies.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 19. -- Before an expected crowd of 8,000 Yale and Harvard tomorrow will open their annual baseball series, which dates from 1868 and in which 166 games have been played. Yale leads in the series with 86 victories to 79 for Harvard, with one tie.

Consideration by the City College chapter of Phi Beta Kappa of a resolution recommending reinstatement of the students expelled from the college for participation in recent anti-war disturbances precipitated a headed debate last night at the Biltmore.

HANOVER, N.H., June 19. -- Dartmouth's baseball team went into third place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League today by defeating Cornell for the second time this season. A commencement-day crowd of 2,000 watched the Green win, 13 to 3.
Beginning with a triple A and ending with a tersely mysterious The Zzyx, the Summer issue of the Manhattan telephone directory is making its 1933 debut to the public today.
The fifty-three-story Lincoln j Building, one of the largest of the Grand Central zone skyscrapers, will be sold at auction on July 11 in the Vesey Street Salesrooms.

WASHINGTON. June 19. -- A "code of fair competition" for the cotton textile industry was submitted today to the Industrial Recovery Administration for approval. It was the first industrial code to be offered under the provisions of the National Industrial Recovery Act, which was enacted only three days ago.
Provision for 166 recreational sites for children is recommended by the Crime Prevention Bureau in a preliminary report on its recent survey of play facilities.

The monthly overhead of R. Hoe Co., Inc., was reduced $78,974.23 in April from $135,825.06, and the balance of unfilled orders as of May 31, 1933, amounted to $518,224, according to a report filed yesterday in the Federal District Court by the Irving Trust Company as temporary equity receiver.
PHILADELPHIA, June 19 (AP). -- The Phillies emerged from a five-game losing streak today, beating the Reds in the opening game of their series, 8 to 7.

In sympathy with the resumption, of the upward movement in speculative markets generally, cotton rose more than a quarter of a cent a pound on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and closed 27 to 32 points higher than on Saturday.

Twelve hundred dress manufacturers and employers in allied trades gathered last night at the Hotel New Yorker to organize for operation under the new National Recovery Act. Messages of approval and best wishes were read from Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor; Governor Lehman, United States Senator Wagner and others.

LONDON, June 19. -- Though disavowed by Senator Pittman, the American suggestions for consideration by the Economic Commission of the World Economic Conference appeared in the official list of conference documents today as "submitted by the American delegation."

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 19. -- A warning that putting economic interests little by little under government control might lead to a form of governmental organization which would be intolerant of opposition and submerge the individual was voiced today by Alanson B. Houghton.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Chairman Hill of the Ways and Means subcommittee investigating Federal taxation, has called a meeting for Wednesday, when plans for the study during the Congressional recess will be made.

Frank A. Doyle, one of the bestknown American labor leaders and for the last twenty-one years a member of the general executive board of the United Garment Workers of America, died on Sunday at his home in Atlantic, Mass. Mr. Doyle had been ill for six months and about two months ago had undergone a major operation.

GENEVA, June 19. -- The delegation to the International Labor Conference walked out today, saying in a statement it would not continue to participate "as long as satisfaction is not given to German protests and justice not done to well-founded complaints of the German delegation."

LONDON, June 19. -- Continuing his analysis of political conditions in the United States which make adherence to a consistent policy difficult for any American President, the Washington correspondent of The London Times lays down four general statements" as an aid to clear thinking and sympathetic understanding of American conditions and their inescapable effect on internal development and foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Direct participation by the administration in the railway wage controversy was indicated today in an announcement by Joseph B. Eastman, coordinator, that he would confer tomorrow with railroad managers and representatives of railroad labor on the situation.

The following story was written exclusively for The Associated Press by William W. Dunn, sales manager for the Theodore Hamm Brewing Company, who negotiated directly with the kidnappers of William Hamm, St. Paul brewer:

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 19 (AP). -- Spurred by heavy rewards and aided by the ready cooperation of the victim, search for the five or six abductors of William Hamm, wealthy brewer, who was released early today after payment of undisclosed ransom, was in full swing tonight.

HOTLAKE, England, June 19. -- John De Forest, wealthy son of a British Baron, who came from nowhere last year to win the British amateur golf title, today lost it just as quickly as the current championship opened over the windswept Royal Liverpool links.
The recent increase in Manhattan dwelling deals was continued yesterday, with two sales in the same east side block reported.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., June 19. -- Walter W. Clark, business man and Member of an old Glens Falls family, died in the Glens Falls Hospital last night from gunshot wounds in the abdomen suffered earlier in the day while hunting squirrels near his Summer home at Kattskill Bay.
WALLINGFORD, Conn., June 19. -- Diplomas will be presented to 139 graduates of the Choate School at the commencement tomorrow by George C. St. John, headmaster of the school.

The first large railroad to report for May, the Chesapeake Ohio, reported yesterday increases in both gross revenue and net income for the month. Of the $792,000 increase in gross, $453,998 was carried to net. The Kansas City Southern tlso reported increases in both gross and net.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Secretary Wallace today moved for destruction of one-fourth of the 1933 cotton crop under the program of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, which calls for holding at least 10,000,000 acres out of cultivation with funds obtained from a processing tax.

In the following story, written exclusively for The Associated Press by William Hamm, president of the Theodore Hamm Brewing Company, he recounts his experiences while held, nearly four days by kidnappers who originally demanded $100,000 ransom:

BERLIN, June 19. -- Tension over Dr. Alfred Hugenberg's place in the government has reached a critical point. His forthcoming discussion with Chancellor Hitler ought to be decisive, and informed opinion is that the Minister of Economy and Agriculture will retire from the Cabinet -- and from practical German politics as well.

Shipping men were generally in agreement yesterday in expressing disapproval of the transfer of the Shipping Board and its operating branch, the Merchant Fleet Corporation, to the supervision of the Department of Commerce, as announced Saturday by President Roosevelt.

BERLIN, June 19. -- The depression that hung over the Boerse all of last week also marked the session today. Without there occurring any notable declines, stocks continued to sag gradually in a very dull market.

MUKDEN. Manchuria. June 19. -- With the Manchukuo authorities apparently impotent before a wave of bandit terrorism that is sweeping the Mukden district and those adjoining, the foreign community here is resorting to special measures to protect lives and properties.

DETROIT, June 19 (AP). -- Robert Moses Grove, who has been pitching principally in a relief role for the Athletics this season, started against the Tigers today, but lasted only six innings. He was charged with loss of the game, which Detroit won, 9 to 4.

LONDON, June 19. -- The London Times is issuing a special gold supplement of twenty-eight pages tomorrow in which gold is considered from such varied points of view as the monetary, romantic, economic and utilitarian.

The curious history of some of the better-known European revolutionaries who talked and wrote before Karl Marx substituted economics for metaphysicis in revolutionary thought is told in "The Romantic Exiles," by Edward Hallett Carr, just published by Stokes.
WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

CAIRO, Egypt, June 19. -- The Egyptian National Museum here will receive one of the richest additions to its collection this year as a result of the discovery intact of four royal Byzantine Nubian tombs in Upper Egypt, south of Abu Simbel.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 19. -- Dr. Arthur S. Dewing declared tonight that his resignation as Professor of Finance at the Harvard Business School, a chair he has held for many years, was the result of attempts by Dean Wallace B. Donham to dictate his teaching methods and interfere with his private affairs.

The plan announced yesterday by Secretary WALLACE casts the Government for a role it has never played before. It has instructed farmers how to grow more and begged them to grow less. It has bought wheat and cotton in order to raise prices by taking a surplus off the market and sold them on the theory that holding a surplus over the market drives prices to lower levels.

A large gathering of jurists, city officials and lawyers participated yesterday in the formal induction ceremony of Peter P. Smith, Brooklyn lawyer, as a justice of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn. Justice Smith was appointed by Governor Lehman to succeed the late Justice Charles J. Druhan.

The Daniel Guggenheim Memorial concerts, given by Edwin Franko Goldman's band, began last night on the Mall in Central Park before a huge audience that extended from the bandstand far beyond the seats to twilight distances, where listeners stood twenty deep and only the more stentorian of Mr. Goldman's instrumental family, the grandfather tubas and the penetrating cornets, could, reach, them.
WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The Department of Agriculture Market News Service was eliminated for economy's sake today, a saving of more than $1,300,000 in the next fiscal year being estimated.

On the understanding that they would net be required to work with W. Kingsland macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, the five Republican county leaders in New York City agreed last night to support the fusion movement and to cooperate with the Republican Mayoralty Committee, headed by former Governor Charles S. Whitman, in the selection of a candidate for Mayor and the other places on the city ticket.

TRENTON, N.J., June 19. -- After twice refusing to resign as State Highway Engineer, Jacob L. Bauer of Princeton was suspended by the State Highway Commission today on six charges preferred by Colonel Arthur F. Foran of Flemington, chairman of the board.
NEW YORK. Julius G. Lay, United States Minister to Honduras, and Mrs. Lay are at the St. Regis.

LONDON, June 19. -- Attempts by four overseas wheat-producing countries to agree on crop restriction reached a deadlock today, despite a hint by Henry Morgenthau Sr. that in the event of failure the United States might be forced to throw its surplus stock of 360,000,000 bushels on the market.

Faith in the continued existence of the free city colleges and in the loyalty of their student bodies was expressed last night by Dr. Louis A. Warsoff, instructor in government at Brooklyn College. He spoke at City College class night exercises in the auditorium of the college's Twenty-third Street building.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 19. -- Seven honorary degrees and 138 degrees in course were awarded today at the 101st commencement of Wesleyan University.

Faith in the continued existence of the free city colleges and in the loyalty of their student bodies was expressed last night by Dr. Louis A. Warsoff, instructor in government at Brooklyn College. He spoke at City College class night exercises in the auditorium of the college's Twenty-third Street building.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 19. -- Seven honorary degrees and 138 degrees in course were awarded today at the 101st commencement of Wesleyan University.

RYE, N.Y., June 19. -- Two Connecticut golfers were the only ones close to women's par in the qualifying round of the Women's WestChester and Fairfield Association championship today. Mrs. Thomas Hucknall of Woodway captured the medal with an 87.

Calling attention to the fact that under the public works section of the National Industrial Recovery Act appropriating $3,300,000,000 for construction work, a great opportunity is opened for the employment of private architects, Ernest J. Russell, president of the American Institute of Architects, said yesterday that the Treasury Department is making plans to use some of the ablest architects and engineers in the country in this Federal program.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 19. -- A field of fifty-five players from twenty-two colleges, by far the most representative yet to gather for this tournament, started out in the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships today on the courts of the Ardsley Club.

With the New York Athletic Club furnishing its greatest strength, the Metropolitan Association of the A. A.U. last night named a team of twenty-one athletes to represent it in the American track and field championships at Chicago on June 29-30 and July 1.

Two hundred friends of Laurence A. Steinhardt, including many of the most prominent figures in Democratic party councils both here and in Washington, attended a farewell dinner in his honor last night at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mr. Steinhardt, a New York attorney, who was a leader in the Roosevelt campaign, will sail for Stockholm on the Ile de France on July 6 to take his post as Minister to Sweden.
As President LOWELL defined the salt of the world, they are those who do not lose their heads in times of public distress or excitement,

Mayor O'Brien sat in the Yankee Stadium yesterday and with a serene smile watched the City Hall Reporters' baseball team take a trouncing from a team of radio personalities. The tally was 12 to 8 against the newspaper men.

Although bond prices on the Stock Exchange did not show as great a percentage of gain as did stocks, the advances in bonds were substantial, particularly in domestic corporation issues. A long list of active domestic bonds rose 1 to 7 points, and a fair-sized group of foreign loans gained a point or more.

Senator Arthur Capper of Kansas said in an interview here yesterday that he looked for increasingly better times. He declared that commodity prices should continue to rise, thus increasing employment and wages.

Continuing to perform in a manner to befuddle critics and opposition alike, the Giants recorded another handsome shut-out at the expense of the Cubs at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The score was 3 to 0, thereby giving Memphis Bill Terry's band the distinction of having blanked the National League champions in eighteen consecutive innings.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The West Side Association of Commerce has submitted to the Board of Estimate some fundamental principles which should control in raising additional revenue for the city. They are as follows:

The Dodgers welcomed the pennant-aspiring Cardinals to Ebbets Field yesterday by scoring their fifth straight triumph over Gabby Street's men, winning the game in the ninth inning, 6 to 5. Manager Carey's men swept the series played in St. Louis.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- Gratitude to President Roosevelt for his attitude of "sympathy for those Jews and others who are suffering under the present German administration" and "abhorrence at the return of medieval prejudices in Germany," were expressed today at the opening session of the council of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 19. -- President Roosevelt's "brain trust" was called a liberating force in American life in the commencement address today by President Remsen B. Ogilby at Trinity College. The "lack of clear-voiced leadership" during the depression came in spite of the colleges and not because of them, he declared.

The disappointment expressed by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt over the small number of women who have thus far been admitted to Camp Tera at Bear Mountain, N.Y., a camp financed by the Federal Government for the housing of unemployed young women, led to a speeding up of recruiting for the camp yesterday.
Jim Fitzsimmons, veteran trainer, who winters his horses at the Aqueduct course, is already the trainer of three winners, and his son of one, even though the meeting has been under way only two days.

The Chicago North Western Railway offered yesterday to holders of $7,724,000 Fremont, Elkhorn Missouri Valley Railroad 6 per cent consolidated-mortgage bonds, due on Oct 1, a maturity payment of 50 per cent in cash and 5O per cent in 5 per cant general-mortgage gold bonds due on Nov. 1, 1987.

HANOVER, N.H., June 19. -- Nine honorary degrees will be conferred at Dartmouth College's 164th commencement exercises tomorrow. The largest class in the history of Dartmouth, numbering 446 seniors. will receive the Bachelor of Arts degree from President Hopkins at outdoor ceremonies in the Bema.

The crude oil price advance that was initiated by the Consolidated Oil Corporation last week was extended yesterday to virtually all fields east of the Rocky Mountains. The Magnolia Petroleum Company, a subsidiary of the Socony-Vacuum Corporation, in addition to meeting the advance of the Consolidated corporation increased prices from 10 to 20 cents a barrel in several important Texas areas.
WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated June 16:

The American Jewish Committee has published a factual summary of the Hitlerite war upon the Jewish population of Germany. It is impossible to read it without carrying away the conviction that the Nazi leaders are guilty of something more than, employing violence and terror.

NEW HAVEN, June 19. -- Caustic attacks upon the bankers of the United States were made today at the annual luncheon of alumni of the Yale Law School by James F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, and John Weston Allen, former Attorney General of Massachusetts.

Captain Constance Alleyne Young of the Eastern territorial headquarters of the Salvation Army was married to Captain William Louis Devoto, who is in charge of the Army's work in St. Albans, Vt., in the Centennial Memorial Temple, 120 West Fourteenth Street, last night.

Not Utterly Expert. But yesterday, as MARC ANTONY could have put it, the word of the expert might have stood against the world. Now Senator PITTMAN announces at the London conference that the plan of a 10 per cent tariff cut did not come from the American delegation, but only from it experts.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- Lou Gehrig got his sixteenth home run of the season at Comiskey Park today, but the blow only made the Yankees' struggle with the White Sox close. With Babe Ruth missing from the line-up, Joe McCarthy's squad dropped its second game of the four played with the Sox, 4 to 3.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Bernard M. Baruch, banker and economist, today entered the Roosevelt administration as an adviser without portfolio, assuming the duties of Assistant Secretary of State Moley while Mr, Moley goes to London to observe the trend of the World Economic Conference.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The ranks of economists, business men and labor were drawn upon today in filling executive and advisory positions in the organization which will help General Hugh S. Johnson, administrator of the National Recovery Act.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent issue of THE TIMES a correspondent stated that the dollar measures value "as the bushel measures volume or the inch length."

Tax exemption will not be granted to model housing projects unless they result In slum clearance and offer low rentals, the State Housing Board was told informally yesterday by members of the Board of Estimate.
LONDON, June 19. -- The text of the resolution dealing with gold and silver presented to a committee of the World Economic Conference today by Senator Key Pittman of Nevada follows:

The names of Herbert Hoover and Representative MacFadden were brought into the testimony yesterday at the General Sessions trial of a woman and four men, all officials of the General Industrial Foundation Corporation. The defendants are: Ernest Suffern, president of the corporation; Herbert W. White, David Dyche, Bonowitz X. Dawson and the latter's wife, Mrs. Emma Dawson, all directors.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- Inflation talk in addition to reports of sensational crop damage brought in a rush of buying today which lifted wheat and corn above 3 cents from Saturday's finish at the extreme. Distant deliveries of corn and all oats and rye futures were selling at a new high for the season.

All commodities traded on local exchanges pushed upward vigorously in yesterday's trading. Buying was generally based on the further decline of the dollar and strength in all outside markets. Trading was restricted by the swiftness with which prices moved.
Bradley Lewis of the SalemCrescent A.C. was credited with two knockouts in the amateur boxing show held at the New York A.C. clubhouse on Travers Island last night before 800.
FKANKFURT-AM-MAIN, June 19. -- The position of the Jew in Nazi Germany is nowhere better illustrated than in the ancient city of Frankfurt-am-Main.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Bids for the construction of sixteen of the thirty-two naval vessels authorized under the public works section of the Industrial Recovery Act will be opened July 26, Henry L. Roosevelt, Acting Secretary of the Navy, announced today.
ST. LOUIS, June 19 (AP) -- The Senators advanced to within a half game of the league-leading Yankees today by winning from the Browns, 10 to 4, while the Tankeea were losing to the White Sox.

Monday, June 19, 1933. Business In money at the opening of the new week developed no change from the quiet state which prevailed last week. Turnover was small and quotations unchanged for all classes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For the benefit of President Roosevelt and the college professors who are advising him, may I quote the remarks of another college professor, the late Francis Bowen of Harvard, in his book "American Political Economy," issued in 1870, when the full consequences of the Civil War inflation were still in effect?

Going steadily from start to finish of the mile, H.C. Phipps'S De Valera yesterday won the featured Woodhaven Purse at Aqueduct in a driving finish. He was hacked down to 7-to-10 favoritism and lasted to win by half a length from Mrs. Isabel Sloan's Inlander.

The waters of the Hudson River off Hoboken were tinged with amber yesterday as 40,000 gallons of rye whisky were pumped from the hold of the good ship Ulster, an "oil" tanker that had been sailing under false colors. A large crowd gathered on shore to sniff the fragrant breezes and to wonder at the mysteries of prohibition enforcement.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 19. -- Class-day exercises were held at Princeton University today. There were more than 1,000 persons in Alexander Hall when Acting President Edward D. Duffield turned over the keys to the university to Burton H. Etherington of Philadelphia, president of the senior class.

NEWARK, N.J., June 19 (AP). -- Norman Kies's home run with two out in the ninth gave the Newark Bears a 7-6 decision over the Montreal Royals today. Kies also drove out a homer in the sixth and got a double and three singles besides for a perfect day at bat.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- An increase of $18,588,000 in the value of May imports to $107,000,000 was announced today by the Commerce Department, marking one of the largest advances in a month's imports since the beginning of the downward trend in 1929.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention, has been called to an informative article on the childlabor amendment by Peter Kihss which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES for June 11, and to the editorial on child labor in the same issue.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 19. -- Diplomas will be presented to 476 members of the graduating class at the annual commencement exercises of Princeton University to be held in front of Nassau Hall tomorrow morning.

Municipal bankers held informal meetings here yesterday to discuss the newly enacted national industrial recovery legislation which is expected to play a much more important role in the municipal bond field than the powers of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation have done.
WASHINGTON, June 19. Movements of vessels follow. All dates are June 19, unless otherwise specified.
WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Every indication here today pointed to a standstill attitude of the United States Government on foreign affairs, awaiting the functioning of the domestic recovery program.

LONDON, June 19. -- There was a strong disposition in the United States delegation today as the World Economic Conference resumed its committee work to minimize the indications of divided counsels that had troubled the minds of the other delegations yesterday.

Harry Daniel Moran, for the last fifteen years superintendent of the Humane Society of New York, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital of pneumonia, which followed appendicitis. He entered the hospital June 7, the day of the burial of David Belais, founder and president pf the society and long his friend, and was operated upon the next day Sorrow at Mr. Belais's death was Relieved to have aggravated Mr. Moran's condition.

Mrs. Kathryn Heinz, widow of Augustus Victor Henry Heinz of Pittsburgh, Was married recently to Detective Thomas F.R. McGuire of the Fifth Avenue jewelry squad, it became known here yesterday. The marriage was performed on the afternoon of June 10 by the Rev. Frank H. Huffman, pastor of the West Side Presbyterian Church of Englewood, N.J.

LONDON, June 19. -- While currency stabilization measures before the World Economic Conference made no progress today, the basis was swiftly laid for a discussion tomorrow of the problem of raising world prices.
The white pillars flanking the nine gray steps leading to the door of Hamilton Grange on Convent Avenue, south of 142d Street, gleamed brightly in the sun yesterday.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 19. -- Coming within two strokes of equalling the course record, Miss Rosalie Knapp, member of the home club, won the medal In the qualifying round of the annual Long Island women's golf championship at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club today.

WASHINGTON. June 19. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on June 14 shows increases for the week of $224,000,000 in net demand deposits, 836,000,000 in loans and investments and $73,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, and decreases of $12,000,000 in time deposits, $23,000,000 in government deposits and $7,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks.

Weather Cuts Wholesale Volume. Cool weather throughout the country last week tended to slow up retail trade, and as a result reorders fell off in the wholesale apparel trade Resident offices reported yesterday that orders mailed in over the week-end showed a marked decline from the preceding Monday.

Fishermen along the New Jersey shore have been reporting goodsized sea bass for some time. This species begins to run in Barnegat and Raritan Bays in late May and within a few weeks works into Jamaica Bay and Great South Bay.

Taxes on business amounting to 1 per cent of the annual gross of any enterprise in the city have been approved by the Board of Estimate committee on revenues. They are to replace Mayor O'Brien's $30,000,000 vehicle tax and bridge toll program, it was reported on excellent authority yesterday.

VIENNA, June 19. -- The Austrian Government tonight outlawed the Nazi party throughout the country. The Cabinet announced that the Nazis were forbidden to engage in any political activity, to form any other political party or to wear the swastika badge or other party emblems.

TRENTON, N.J., June 19. -- A bill to permit the sale of beer in New Jersey on Sundays after 1 P.M. was passed tonight by the Assembly by a vote of 34 to 15. The bill, introduced by Assemblyman Thomas Muir of Union County as an amendment to the temporary beer code, also provides for the sale of beer over bars, which are outlawed by present beer regulations.

L.F. Loree, president of the Delaware Hudson Company and chairman of the Eastern Presidents Conference, took under advisement yesterday the calling of a meeting to appoint an Eastern Regional Advisory Committee, as provided by the National Railroad Coordination Law, signed last week by President Roosevelt.

More than 1,900 men and women have already been helped by the Adjustment Service, headed by Professor John Erskine of Columbia University, to find jobs for which they are best fitted, it was revealed yesterday by Dr. Erskine. The office of the organization is at 17 East 42d Street.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- Sewell S. Combs's 3-year-old filly Nituma scored her first victory of the year when she triumphed by a length over E.R. Bradley's Algeria in the six-furlong Flamingo Purse at Lincoln Fields today. Night Jasmine was third.

After increasing executives' salaries, the New York Edison Company reduced hours and compensation of other employes 8 1-3 per cent on May 1. The salary increases and pay reductions were revealed yesterday in the testimony of F.H. Nickerson, vice president of the utility company, before the Public Service Commission.

LONDON, June 19. -- Proposals by Senator Key Pittman of the United States for a return to monetary stability and the institution of a sort of qualified bimetalism were the feature of this afternoon's session of the subcommittee of the monetary and financial commission dealing with permanent measures for currency rehabilitation.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 19. -- The day is past when problems of public law can be solved by pulling down the law books and marking without other aids the "signposts on the road," Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo of the United States Supreme Court told the alumni of Brown University today.

The list of country boys who became city millionaires might have been, considerably lengthened if farmer fathers were, on the whole, more tolerant of play, it is suggested in "The Rural Community and Social Care Work" by Josephine C. Brown, an officer of the Family Welfare Association of America, which publishes the book.

Driving over nine runs in one big inning, the third, Jersey City defeated Buffalo yesterday at West Side Park, Jersey City, by a score of 11 to 6. Rosenfeld hammered a home run in the sixth and Hank Leiber made three safeties in the course of the game.
CINCINNATI, June 19. -- Washington T. Porter, Cincinnati's second oldest practicing attorney, died late yesterday at his home in Avondale. He was 83 years old.

After the unsettlement on the closing days of last week, the share market gave what Wall Street described as an "excellent account" of itself yesterday. The advance in prices on the Stock Exchange was next to the widest of the year; for a time it was of violent force.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- A new miracle worker of science, the most powerful cannon yet found for liberating relatively enormous stores of energy locked up in the inner core of the atom, was described here today before the American Physical Society.

Today Iowa will elect, on the general-ticket plan, nlnety-nine delegates to the constitutional convention which will ratify or reject repeal, An article is The Palimpsest, monthly magazine of the Historical Society, traces the history of liquor legislation in the State's eighty-odd years of existence.

NANTUCKET HARBOR, Mass.. June 19. -- A persistent nor'wester that blew down yesterday afternoon became so intense this morning that President Roosevelt, skipper of the Amberjack II, took refuge here after five hours of strenuous sailing in Nantucket Sound.

The Yankees met the Athletics in a double-header at the Stadium on Sunday, June 4, and there were approximately 65,000 spectators out to see the fun. Sugar Cain was taking batting practice with the Mackian regulars before the festivities started. It was evident that he was going to do some pitching for the Athletics.

WASHINGTON, Pa., June 19. -- A drive to enforce the rule against athletic scholarships and all forms of athletic subsidization will be made by the Middle Atlantic States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools. This was revealed today when Dr. Ralph C. Hutchinson, president of W. and J., received a letter from the association.

PARIS, June 19. -- Japan won the last two matches of its Davis Cup semi-final tie against Australia at Auteuil today. R. Nunoi defeated Vivian McGrath, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 8, 7-5, and Jiro Satoh scored a wellearned victory over Jack Crawford, Australia's promising young star, in five sets, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 2.

Reducing salaries of Tammany political appointees has become a science in artfulness almost equaling the celebrated shell game of "now you see it and now you don't," Ben Howe, organization director of the City party, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- A new miracle worker of science, the most powerful cannon yet found for liberating relatively enormous stores of energy locked up in the inner core of the atom, was described here today before the American Physical Society.

Today Iowa will elect, on the general-ticket plan, nlnety-nine delegates to the constitutional convention which will ratify or reject repeal, An article is The Palimpsest, monthly magazine of the Historical Society, traces the history of liquor legislation in the State's eighty-odd years of existence.

NANTUCKET HARBOR, Mass.. June 19. -- A persistent nor'wester that blew down yesterday afternoon became so intense this morning that President Roosevelt, skipper of the Amberjack II, took refuge here after five hours of strenuous sailing in Nantucket Sound.

An informal meeting of representatives of the major copper producers was held yesterday. Suggestions for disposing of the surplus Stocks of the metal acted other important problems were discussed. A formal meeting is expected to be held in the next three or four days.

State of Washington. The State of Washington, which has not marketed any long-term bonds since 1927, plans to issue a total of $10,000,000 for welfare relief, according to word received here yesterday. The bonds, due serially in two to twenty years, will constitute general obligations of the State, payable from unlimited taxes, and specifically secured by a part of the State's gasoline taxes.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 19. -- Ignorance of college graduates on details of politics was assailed today by Governor Cross of Connecticut, who said this played "directly into the hands of the unscrupulous politician."
WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The text of the code submitted by the cotton industry today for operation under the Industry Recovery Act was as follows:

The Yankees met the Athletics in a double-header at the Stadium on Sunday, June 4, and there were approximately 65,000 spectators out to see the fun. Sugar Cain was taking batting practice with the Mackian regulars before the festivities started. It was evident that he was going to do some pitching for the Athletics.

WASHINGTON, Pa., June 19. -- A drive to enforce the rule against athletic scholarships and all forms of athletic subsidization will be made by the Middle Atlantic States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools. This was revealed today when Dr. Ralph C. Hutchinson, president of W. and J., received a letter from the association.

PARIS, June 19. -- Japan won the last two matches of its Davis Cup semi-final tie against Australia at Auteuil today. R. Nunoi defeated Vivian McGrath, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 8, 7-5, and Jiro Satoh scored a wellearned victory over Jack Crawford, Australia's promising young star, in five sets, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 2.

Reducing salaries of Tammany political appointees has become a science in artfulness almost equaling the celebrated shell game of "now you see it and now you don't," Ben Howe, organization director of the City party, declared yesterday.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 19. -- Although a respite has been gained in international affairs, none of the underlying causes of conflict have been removed, James G. McDonald, chairman of the Foreign Policy Association, told Wellesley College's graduating class today.

If the buying public would make it its business to find out the wages paid in the production of the things it buys, sweatshop conditions could be largely reduced, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said yesterday.

ITHACA, June 19. -- Extreme nationalism in many parts of the world was characterized by President Livingston Farrand as the most disturbing factor facing Cornell's graduates. He spoke at the university's sixty-fifth commencement, held on Schoellkopf Field.

The dollar depreciated rapidly in foreign exchange yesterday following the administration's disavowal of plans for temporary stabilization. Although the monetary unit stopped short of a record low it retraced all the gains that had been scored last week, when the reports of a stabilization agreements came out of London.
WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The text of Secretary Wallace's statement today on the plan for applying the Agricultural Adjustment Act to this year's cotton crop follows:

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 19. -- One hundred and fifty-seven Bachelor of Arts, two Master of Arts and eight honorary degrees were conferred at the annual commencement of Williams College today. Governor Ely of Massachusetts. Justice Owen J. Roberts of the Supreme Court and the Rev. Carroll Perry, '88, rector of the Episcopal Church at Ipswich, were the commencement speakers, the latter two also receiving honorary degrees.
Max D. Steuer, defense counsel, asked the jury yesterday to exonerate Charles E. Mitchell of the government's charges of evading his 1929 and 1930 income taxes.

MOSCOW, June 19. -- In the first Soviet editorial in denunciation of Hitlerite Germany, the newspaper Pravda tore loose today with a savage attack and blasting sarcasm, culminating with a direct threat to Germany. The London memorandum of Dr. Alfred Hugenberg, Reich Minister of Economy and Agriculture, was the last straw to Soviet patience.

More than 22,000 members of the Cloakmakers Union, affiliated with the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, stopped work yesterday on Fall and Winter garments in obedience to instructions from their leaders, pending the conclusion of a new agreement with the employers.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP). -- Donald H. Sawyer, Administrator of Public Works under the National Recovery Act, and his Cabinet advisory committee went forward with their efforts to get the first of new construction under way next month.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Among a certain class of people there is the opinion that organized railroad workers are receiving fancy wages. Nothing is further from the truth.

There came to Broadway last evening a tatterdemalion little history on the perils of a noble profession. Called simply -- with a conciseness it otherwise lacked -- "The Ghost Writer," it clattered its way across the boards of the Masque Theatre. Martin Mooney was the author, and it has been his boast that of the subject he murmured what be knew.
CLEVELAND, June 19 (AP). -- George Pipgras's five-hit pitching and Warstler's home run enabled the Red Sox to down the Indians, 5 to 2, today.

NANTUCKET, Mass., June 19. -- Threats of a dreaded nor'easter with its fog and gales brought President Roosevelt, into this quaint harbor town today and held him here tonight with the loss of a day in his sailing cruise to Campobello Island, N.B.

LONDON, June 20 -- The world's chief Finance Ministers went to their hotels from South Kensington this evening pondering as to whether Great Britain's demand on the nations in the economic conference to cease deflation meant really to begin inflation, and hoping Neville Chamberlain would soon answer the question.
PARIS, June 20 -- The government has just introduced a bill to increase the tariff on more than 100 products in retaliation against Germany's increased duties on French exports, it was learned today.

Germany shares the belief that world economics can be rebuilt only on a basis of sound national economic policy, Baron Constantin von Neurath, Foreign Minister of Germany and chief of its delegation to the London Economic Conference, said last night in a broadcast over the Columbia network from London.

OBERLIN, Ohio, June 20 (AP) -- A call for the nation to return to self-reliance and initiative was sounded by Dr. Robert A. Millikan, president of the California Institute of Technology, at the close of Oberlin College's five-day celebration of its 100th anniversary today.
LONDON, June 20 (AP) -- A showdown on the stabilization of the dollar will be sought tomorrow by the powerful European gold bloc at the World Economic Conference.

The flawless pitching to which the Giants have become accustomed recently got a trifle out of gear at the Polo Grounds yesterday, and as there was no bristling attack to overcome the defect the Cubs scored their first victory of the current series, 5 to 3.

A further recovery in prices on the Cotton Exchange carried October to 9.61 cents yesterday, when the market came under realizing pressure and a setback of a dollar a bale left the list 9 to 12 points lower than on Monday.

Buyers' Registrations Up. A gain in the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was noted in comparison with the figures for the preceding week and for the same period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

Tommy Loughran, who surrendered the light-heavyweight championship of the world to try his hand as a heavyweight, and Steve Hamas, young battler from Passaic, N.J., will resume their feud tonight when they clash in a ten-round bout at the Yankee Stadium.

ALBANY, June 20 -- No extra session of the Legislature will be called to obtain lower rates for public utilities, nor will Governor Lehman order an investigation of the Public Service Commission at this time as demanded by the Queens County grand jury.

RYE, N.Y., June 20 -- Hard-fought matches involving three of the leading golfers in the tourney marked the first round of match play in the women's Westchester and Fairfield championship at the Westchester Country Club today. One of the favorites, Miss Catherine Singer, twice holder of the title, went down to defeat.

Tuesday, June 20, 1933. Money market was dull. Quotations were unchanged for all classes on a business that was chiefly made up of routine requirements. Stock Exchange call loans were done at 1 per cent and at 3/4, in the counter trading.
The income tax case that was begun against Charles E. Mitchell six weeks ago will go to the jury this noon after Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard delivers his charge to the Jury.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 20 -- George Parker, who blanked Princeton last Saturday, today turned back Harvard, 5 to 3, before a Yale commencement crowd of 7,000, in opening the annual series between the Crimson and the Blue.

CLEVELAND, June 20 (AP). -- The Red Sox bombarded Pitcher Belve Bean in the seventh inning of their game with the Indians today, scored three runs to turn the tide, and won the final game of the series, 9 to 5.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A.M.L., whose letter appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES, is alarmed by the effect deflation will have on his twelve-year-old life insurance policy. He arbitrarily assumes a 50 per cent debasement of the dollar and on this basis builds up a tabulation which leads him to the conclusion that sound business judgment dictates the surrender of his policy now.

Chester R. Dewey, vice chairman of the First Citizens Bank and Trust Company of Utica, N.Y., was elected yesterday president of the Grace National Bank of New York, effective July 17. He will succeed Francis H. McKnight, who resigned on April 24 after six years as president.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 20 -- The flat Eastern drive, which has been enjoying so big a vogue since the ascension of Ellsworth Vines to the tennis throne and the rise of Wilmer Allison, Clifford Sutter and Lester Stoefen to the top flight, did heavy execution today as three more of the favorites j passed out of the Eastern intercollegiate championship on the turf courts of the Ardsley Club.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 20 -- Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell, retiring head of the oldest institute of higher learning in the United States, received a stirring tribute today at ceremonies in the Harvard Stadium marking the culmination of class day festivities.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Through their trade organization the American Institute of Mea Packers, a majority of the meat packing industry has presented tin fundamentals of a proposed trade agreement, covering the marketing of swine, for approval by administrators of the Farm Adjustmen Act.
NEW HAVEN, June 20 -- With all its traditional ceremonies, Yale conferred degrees today on seniors of the undergraduate schools.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 20 -- The Tale University Dramatic Association closed its season with the presentation in the University Theatre tonight of "Much Ado About Nothing." The audience, made up largely of alumni and their friends, gathered for commencement, filled the theatre to capacity.

TRENTON, N.J., June 20 -- A bill to extend operation of temporary beer legislation until Sept. 1 was introduced in the Assembly today by Assemblyman Muir of Union County. Both tin House and Senate are expected to approve it before recessing tomorrow.

Prices for commodities traded on local Exchanges moved in a wide range yesterday, but closed with relatively small changes on the day. Gains were general early in the session, but a reaction later changed the complexion of several of the markets. Cash prices were irregular.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 20 (AP). -- Pursuit of the kidnappers of William Hamm Jr. focused on Northern Minnesota tonight as the millionaire brewer set out to search for the house in which he was held prisoner almost four days before his release yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., June 20 (AP). -- Home-run hitting gave the Bears a double triumph over the Royals today, 6 -- 3 and 6 -- 4. The last game, scheduled for seven innings, went two extra frames and was decided by Saltzgaver's circuit drive with Neun on base after Olson's homer in the sixth with Watwood on base had tied the score.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- The National Federation of Temple Sisterhoods, religious affiliate of the Council or the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, held the centre of interest today at the council convention.

Justice William A. Walling of Bronx Special Sessions, who was accused of antagonism to the District Attorney's office last Friday in a racket case, took a leading part yesterday against an attempt to free Joseph Weiner. Weiner is the reputed boss racketeer of the poultry business.

Fresh weakness in dollar exchange was accompanied yesterday by another advance in stocks and commodities. The movement was interrupted later in the day, however; prices in the domestic security and commodity markets moved lower at the same time that the dollar made a slow recovery against the European currencies.

BANKKOK, June 21 (AP). -- The government of Siam again had changed hands today as a result of a bloodless coup d'etat by the Army and Navy and civilians led by Phya Bahol, commander-in-chief "who resigned his post last week.

BATTLE CREEK, MICH., June 20 (AP). -- Henry A. Dix, who retired as a New York manufacturer several years ago and turned his plant over to his employes, died here today at the age of 83. He had been a patient in the Battle Creek Sanitarium for about two weeks.

NEWARK, N.J., June 20 -- New assignments for a number of assistant priests of his diocese and for fifteen priests ordained by him June 10 were announced today by the Most Rev. Thomas J. Walsh, Bishop of Newark. The new appointments will take effect Saturday.

BUENOS AIRES, June 20 -- The government refused today a congressional request for information as to why Argentina is participating in the wheat conference in London and also refused to reveal the instructions sent to Ambassador Le Breton regarding the limitation of acreage.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- American participation in any monetary international stabilization plan seemed today more remote than ever, but it was made plain at the State Department that this government would deplore any recess or adjournment of the World Monetary and Economic Conference at this time.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- President Roosevelt was revealed today as the directing force behind a proposal for a six-months postponement of the railway wage controversy. The administration attitude was laid before representative groups of management and labor by Joseph B. Eastman, coordinator of transportation.

BRYN MAWR, Pa, June 20 -- Formation at a labor party by workingmen and workingwomen to enact needed reforms into low "and see that they are honestly enforced" was urged today by Dr. M. Cares Thomas, president emeritus of Bryn Mawr College.

Gasoline and crude oil prices were advanced again in some important areas yesterday. The Standard Oil Company of Indiana raised gasoline one cent a gallon throughout its territory, making the second increase of that amount in the last week. The Standard Oil Company of California and other leading marketers on the Pacific Coast advanced gasoline prices 1/2 cent a gallon.

While proposed city taxes on business and vehicles remained under advisement yesterday, the administration struck out in a new direction to raise $250,000 a year through license fees on hostesses, music schools, radio broadcasting schools and similar enterprises.

Eleven charitable religious, educational and social institutions share nearly $400,000 under the will of Miss Margaret Crane Hurlbut, daughter of the late William Henry and Margaret Havens Crane Hurlbut, offered for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

PHIDADELPHIA, June 20 -- The University of Pennsylvania, at its commencement exercises tomorrow, will confer degrees in course upon about 1,550 students from forty-one States and ten foreign countries. The exercises, marking the close of the 193d year, will be held in the Municipal Auditorium.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP). -- Democratic House members, dissatisfied with the way Postmaster General Farley is dispensing patronage, have organized a special committee to obtain for Democrats jobs which are now being held by Republicans.

SALEM, N.H., June 20 -- Betting, on the horses, once considered a depravity in the prim old Granite State that reared Franklin Pierce and Daniel Webster, will be strictly within the law tomorrow when the famous Rockingham Park throws open its gates for the twenty-eight-day race meeting under the parimutuel system.
DETROIT, June 20 (AP). -- The Athletics snapped the Tigers' winning streak today with a 9-to-4 victory after Detroit had taken three straight games, and now hold undisputed possession of fifth place.

LONDON, June 20 (Canadian Press). -- The match between the touring West Indies cricket eleven and the minor counties was drawn at Lord's today after three days of play, when the West Indians failed to complete their second innings.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 20 -- The General Electric Company today announced a 5 per cent increase in wages and salaries. It will be effective July 1 for 5O,OOO employes in the various plants of the company throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Hugh S. Johnson, head of the National Recovery Administration, said today he would appeal to the nation's industrial leaders not to increase prices for several months to counter-balance the wage increases planned in trade agreements.

Frank J. MacMasters of Flushing, a former member of the Cabinet of Borough President Harvey of Queens, is to be reinstated after more than four years. This was ordered in a decision handed down yesterday by Justice James T. Hallinan in the Supreme Court, Queens.

Victor J. Dowling, former Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division and a prominent Catholic layman, sent a message last night to a meeting under the auspices of the American Jewish Congress in which he urged Catholics to unite with Jews to combat Hitlerism.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 20 -- Beneath the gray and weather beaten walls of Nassau Hall, Professor Harold Willis Dodds was inducted into office as the fifteenth president of Princeton University in simple ceremonies following tin 186th commencement exercises this morning.
VIENNA, June 20 -- The Austrian Nazis showed today that they had been prepared for the prohibition of their party newspapers. Early this morning substitute newspapers

One does not ordinarily look to Senator COUZENS for words of wisdom, but he made on Monday the most penetrating observation which came in the dispatches that day from London. The gist of it was that the official attitude at Washington indicates a severe conflict between internationalism and "our national economic programs."

BOSTON, June 20 (AP). -- The Pittsburgh Pirates hammered Tom Zachary so hard in the third inning today that their right-hander, Bill Swift, was able to coast along for a 6-2 victory. It was the visitors' third successive victory over the Braves.

The Board of Transportation is planning to place in operation about Aug. 1 the link of the new subway system extending from Eighth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, Manhattan, to Roosevelt Avenue and Queens Boulevard in Queens. By the same date it expects to begin operating the first Brooklyn link of the new system as far as Church Avenue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Louise Hull Jackson, in her letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, strikes a very responsive chord in at least one feminine bosom. The masculinization of our language has been a source of irritation to me ever since I was old enough to sit up and take notice; it is in constant daily evidence, an oft-repeated, if figurative, blow in the face.

SYRACUSE, June 20 -- Democratic women of New York State were called upon by Postmaster General Farley here today to work toward wresting control of the State Assembly from the Republicans in the Fall campaign.
WASHINGTON. June 20 -- The War Department issued the followlng orders today:

To the Editor of The New York Times: J.D. Phillips should be commended for his very thorough and concise account in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 4 (entitled "Nationailism Hits Our Trade With Cuba", of what Cuba has done in the way of raising revenue by increasing her import duties.

Helianthus, the headstrong son of Sun Flag, won what probably was the closest race of his career when he got home first by a nose over Condescend yesterday at Aqueduct in the featured Dominant Purse. Condescend landed the place by another nose, just beating Blenheim.
STUTTGART, Germany, June 20 -- At Gotteszell at the eastern end of the Swabian Jura is the recently established concentration camp for Wurttemberg's female political prisoners.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Recovered from, his illness, Babe Ruth walloped his fifteenth, home run of the season as he returned to action today. It was one of three circuit drives delivered by Yankee hitters, who overwhelmed the White Sox, 15 to 8.

An additional contingent of thirty unemployed women, many of them jobless for months and all Without resources, was sent to Camp Tera yesterday, it was announced by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration.

Bond prices on the Stock Exchange were pushed sharply higher yesterday in the earlier hours of trading, but the market had to absorb fairly heavy selling late in the day. However, the list closed irregularly higher, with domestic railroad bonds leading, many gaining 1 to 4 points.

Arthur Garfield Hays has written a book entitled "Trial by Prejudice" which Covici, Friede will publish in August. The main part of the book deals with the Mooney-Billings and Scottsboro cases, in both of which Mr. Hays had a part.

The Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System, including the Brooklyn and Queens Transit Corporation, reports for the eleven months ended May 31 a net income of $6,464,362, after taxes, charges, minority interests and other deductions, equivalent, after dividend requirements on 248,353 preferred shares, to $6.87 a share earned on 741,251 shares of "common stock.

In view of the provisions of'the Glass-Steagall Banking Act which prohibits payment of interest by member banks of the Federal Reserve on demand deposits, the United States Treasury has notified depository institutions that hereafter no interest will be required to be paid on daily deposit balances kept by the Treasury with the banks.

PATERSON, N.J., June 20 -- Commencement exercises were held tonight at the Eastside High School Auditorium for the graduates of the Paterson State Normal School. The graduates received their diplomas from the supervisor of teacher training, Edgar F. Bruce.

The oil industry Is showing a quick pick-up as a result of the completion of the production code in Chicago, according to Harry F. Sinclair, chairman of the executive committee of the Consolidated Oil Corporation, who was a representative of the American Petroleum, Institute at the Chicago meeting.

The code of ethics for the retail stores of the country was completed yesterday at a meeting of members of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and will be presented to the board of directors of the group today.

The Board of Higher Education, which has threatened to expel all persistent radicals from city colleges, last night heard demands by the League for Industrial Democracy that the students be permitted to hold political symposiums and affiliate with outside political groups, even in campaign times.

Rentals of apartments in many houses on Park Avenue featured the residential leasing activity reported by brokers yesterday. J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the board of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, took a large duplex suite at 770 Park Avenue through Brown, Wheelock, Harris Co. and Pease Elliman.

New Rochelle, N.Y. A new issue of $300,000 city of New Rochelle (N.Y.) 6 per cent bonds, due serially on June 1, 1936 to 1943, will be offered today by B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc. The issue will be priced to yield 5.25 to 5.50 per cent.

George L. Bacholder, member of the firm of Batchelder Co., stock, brokers, committed suicide last night by jumping out of a window of the company's offices on the fortieth floor of the 60 Wall Tower Building at 70 Pine Street.

The succession of favorable earnings reports by railroads for May continued yesterday with a statement by the Union Pacific showing an increase of four-tenths of 1 per cent in gross revenues and a jump of 173 per cent in net operating income for the month, compared with the same month in 1932.

HANOVER, N.H., June 20 -- President Hopkins conferred honorary degrees today upon Walter Damrosch, musician, and Robert Frost, poet, paying tribute to their qualities before a throng of alumni and friends at the 164th commencement of Dartmouth College.
WASHINGTON, June 20 --The airship Macon will be accepted by the Navy Department on the basis of the showing made in her preliminary trial flight and placed in commission at Akron on Friday.

Agriculture in the British West Indies has first place in the Year Book of 1933. Its prospects are brightening under the stimulus of tariff preferences in empire markets. Other things contribute: the establishment of land settlements that aid peasant proprietors, stabilization of the banana industry, encouragement of citrus production, instruction in packing for the Canadian and European markets, and education in agricultural colleges and farm schools.

The new shipbuilding program of the Navy Department, announced by Secretary Swanson, will provide employment for about 52,000 men for three years in shipyards and allied industries, according to experts in marine construction. The building is expected to place the navy on the authorized treaty basis.

LONDON, June 20 -- The problem of regelating the world's production, of foodstuffs and raw materials so as to raise prices and restore purchasing power to vast rural populations which in turn would stimulate manufacturing was graphically outlined at today's discussion in the economic commission of the World Economic Conference, in which the spokesmen of ten nations participated.

A proposal that John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, be designated by the city as transit "unification czar" was made yesterday to the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate by H.L. Carpenter of the Central Brooklyn Midday Club.

America is "on the way up" and her merchandise standards must keep the pace, according to I.A. Hirschmann, sales and publicity director of Lord Taylor. Mr. Hirschmann will sail today on the Manhattan for a six-week's study of European competition.

Selection of a business man as the fusion candidate for Mayor loomed yesterday as a distinct possibility. This development followed the displacement of W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, as the actual leader of the fusion movement by the five Republican County Chairmen in New York City.

EN ROUTE WITH PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT OFF CAPE COD, June 20 -- Out in the deep, opposite the shores where the Pilgrims landed. President Roosevelt today dramatically outlined economic conference policies to Raymond Moley.

William Reynolds, Republican leader of the Fifth Assembly District, was a witness yesterday before a Federal grand jury which it investigating the disappearance of thirteen members of the Owasco Democratic Club, 132 West 118th Street, indicted for fraud at the polls last November.

LONDON, June 20 -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody and Ellsworth. Vines Jr. today led a parade of Americans through the first and second rounds of the London tennis championships at the Queens Club, played as a tune-up for the more serious competition at Wimbledon starting next week.

LONDON, June 20 -- The United States delegation to the World Economic Conference decided this evening to hold a conference of its own each morning in the interests of unity. The decision probably was influenced by a few plain words from Senator Couzens to the delegates, warning them they must work better together, and particularly must decide which of the two paths they would follow -- a nationalistic policy or international cooperation.

Nominating seventeen athletes yesterday in addition to the fifteen selected by the Metropolitan Association of the A.A.U. on Monday, the New York Athletic Club launched the bid for the retention of its national track and field team championship by entering a team of thirty-two in the American title games at Chicago on June 29 and 30 and July 1.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Treasury is rapidly preparing for its part in carrying out the administration's domestic recovery program.

Announcement was made yesterday by the Youth Guild Synagogue of the opening of the Institute for Adult Education at 125 E. 85th St. The Institute has been dedicated to "the dissemination of Jewish culture among the adult population." Registration is now open on Tuesday and Thursday evenings from 8:30 to 9:30 P.M. Classes will start on July 6.

SANDY HOOK, N.J., June 20 -- A fishing trawler that had been adrift two miles at sea with two men dead and a third unconscious from gas fumes of the motor, was towed ashore here today by coast guardsmen. The survivor, Ferdinand Kaczorowski, 49 years old, of Wildwood, said that the boat had drifted with distress signals raised for nearly twelve hours.

A move to obtain control of the American Investors, Inc., was made yesterday by the Atlas Corporation. Letters were sent to stockholders of American Investors asking for tenders of their stock in exchange for stock of the larger company. If the move is successful, this will be the twenty-second trust to be acquired by Atlas since the Summer of 1930.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Heavy pressure for immediate agreement on fair competition codes was exerted upon basic industries today by the Industrial Recovery Administration, in the belief that success or failure of this major phase of the President's recovery program will have been decided by Labor Day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The current gold situation in the United States evokes certain reflections. American producers of the metal are forbidden by law to export bullion and are thereby forced to accept a nominal $20.67 an ounce for their product.
Hamilton Much at Home. ALEXANDER HAMILTON'S Summer home on Washington Heights is being renovated and restored for preservation as a historical museum.

Judge Joseph E. Corrigan, in imposing sentence on a racketeer in General Sessions yesterday, declared that "by a concerted effort and a slight degree of intelligence on the part of the police and the District Attorney," racketeering in this city could be stopped.

To most committees bearing the title "Advisory" there attaches a suggestion of futility. They are often merely window-dressing. But something more may be expected of the Advisory Boards appointed in connection with the National Recovery Act.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Movements of vesels follow; all dates are June 19, unless otherwise specified.

LONDON, June 20 -- Approval was given today by the subcommittee on monetary rehabilitation at the World Economic Conference to the American advocacy of the earliest practicable stabilization of moneys and of the readoption of the gold standard as an international measure of exchange values.

Herman A. Heydt, lawyer, author, poet, musician, world traveler and bolder of seven academic degrees, will receive his Bachelor of Arts degree tonight at the age of 65. Already the holder of three doctoral degrees, he will fulfill the "ambition" of half a century in receiving a baccalaureate award at the City College commencement exercises.

W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State leader, predicted last night the defeat of Tammany this Fall because of the attempt of the O'Brien administration to saddle the $30,000,000 automobile tax on the city. He spoke before the Brooklyn Young Republican Club in the Towers.
