WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Operations of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, which will disburse $2,200,000,000 for the benefit of small home owners, will require a force estimated at from 5,000 to 7,000 in Washington and in thefield.

BERLIN, June 20 -- The Boerse attempted an upward movement at the opening today and prices rose 2 per cent in some instances. The advance was of short duration, however, being succeeded by renewed lethargy in which most of the gains were lost.

KANE, Pa., June 20 (AP). -- A high school youth accused of kidnapping two women golfers and driving them into a forest at the point of a pistol, told the police today he acted on orders of two men under threat of death.

In Harper's Magazine Professor YANDELL HENDERSON of Yale, assuming that Legislatures apply toxicological standards to statutes for the regulation of traffic in alcoholic beverages, finds that three types of licenses for their sale are indicated by "the peculiar conditions and habits of Americans."

BERLIN, June 20 -- The suppression by the Dollfuss government of all National Socialist organizations and all Nazi activities in Austria brought cries of rage and defiance from the Nazi-controlled press of Germany today.

Smoke damage to lungs, art, clothing and spinach, to trees and blue grass and aviation, is described in prose and quotations from poetry in "Stop That Smoke!", published today by Harpers. The author is Henry Obermeyer, assistant to the vice president of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York City.

TOKYO, June 20 -- Fresh obstacles to the entry of Japanese goods are reported from the British Federated Malay States, which has raised the duties on low-grade products by rates ranging from 30 to 80 per cent.

Albert E. Guimares, who figured in the Dot King murder case and who later was sentenced to three years at Atlanta for using the mails to defraud, was behind bars again yesterday, according to the police.

ABOARD THE MARY ALICE, Via GLOUCESTER, Mass., Wednesday, June 21 -- President Roosevelt brought the Amberjack II into the outer harbor of Gloucester last night at 11:50 o'clock, Daylight Saving Time, after a night cruise from Provincetown.

Ninety players representing seventeen colleges and universities have entered the intercollegiate golf championship which will be played at the Country Club of Buffalo starting on Monday, June 26. The list of entries was announced yesterday by the United States Golf Association, which now sponsors the event.
PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP). -- The Phillies made it three straight over the Reds by winning both ends of a double-header today. The scores were 7 -- 4 and 7 -- 3.

RENO, Nev., June 20 -- Mrs. Alicia Maddox du Pont Glendening of New York, who obtained a divorce in Reno several years ago, was married at noon yesterday to Victor R.T. Liewellyn of London at Glenbrook, Nev., a Lake Tahoe resort.

BERLIN, June 20 -- Reports that Chancellor Hitler has offered Dr. Heinrich Bruening a post in his Cabinet finds no credence in political quarters close to the former Chancellor, where it is declared that the rumors not only are not new but that there is now less foundation for them in view of the recent drift of internal developments, especially as they have affected Catholic interests.

ALBANY, June 20 -- Governor Lehman lost no time in taking action to help get the Federal works program under way in this State. He wired yesterday to Colonel Donald H. Sawyer, Federal Administrator of Public Works, to explain how the Federal fund would be allocated, and expressed his desire to cooperate in every way.

James W. Gerard, who criticized the management of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation two months ago for not giving more complete reports to stockholders, announced yesterday that he had placed himself "squarely behind the management in its fight against foreign domination."
Brooklyn police took unusual precautions yesterday in transferring throe convicted murderers from the Brooklyn city prison to Sing Sing.

PROVINCETOWN. Mass., June 20 -- Without interrupting his cruise or his duties as master of the schooner Amberjack II, President Roosevelt spent two hours today in consultation with Raymond F. Moley, Assistant Secretary of State, who sails from New York tomorrow to serve as the Chief Executive's liaison officer at the World Economic Conference.
NEW YORK. Miss Mary Pearsall Field is leaving the Plaza today to pass the Summer at Lenox, Mass., with Mr. and Mrs. William B. Osgood Field.
GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 20 -- The fate that so frequently befalls a medalist in golf tripped Miss Rosalie Knanp in the opening match-play round of the women's Long Island championship today.

HOYLAKE, England, June 20 -- While a thunderstorm lashed the Royal Liverpool links and sent all except the hardiest onlookers scurrying for cover, C. Ross (Sandy) Somerville and George T. Dunlap Jr., leading North American threats to English golf supremacy, today scored brilliant victories in the third round of the British amateur championship.
Real estate operators who have just returned to the market figured in a sharp upturn in Manhattan activity yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, June 20 -- Captain Mariano Barberan and Lieutenant Joaquin Collar, the Spanish transatlantic fliers, who left Havana at 5:55 this morning for this city, were reported down in the village of Malinche in the State of Puebla tonight.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,611,850 barrels, compared with 2,709,350 in the preceding week, a drop of 97,500 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Declines of 48,100 and 47,050 barrels, respectively, in the daily average output of Oklahoma and East Texas were the most important changes.

The Board of Estimate, as Mayor O'Brien views It, is "an open forum for all our citizens" and "people here can applaud or otherwise express their sentiments as long as they are decent about it." Those are two of the Mayor's "very definite ideas as to what kind of a forum the Board of estimate should be."

General John J. Pershing and Edmund Day, technical adviser to the American delegation to the World Economic Conference in London, will sail today for the Channel ports on the Manhattan of the United States Lines. Three United States vice consuls will be aboard -- T.C. Achilles, Rome; G.W. Ray, London, and L.W. Taylor, Copenhagen.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 20 -- A brilliant fifth-period rally carried the Meadow Brook Ramblers to victory over the Aiken Knights and into the final round of the Third Westbury Challenge Cup polo tournament at the Meadow Brook Club this evening.

The field for the Dwyer, Saturday's feature at Aqueduct, now looks like an eight-horse race, with the Catawba Stable's Mr. Khayyam rated a sure starter, according to Racing Secretary Joe McLennan. The other probable starters are The Darb, Golden Way, War Glory, Nimbus, Union, Balois and Jovius.
CONCORD, N.H., June 20 -- New Hampshire, dry before adoption of the Eighteenth Amendment, voted overwhelmingly for repeal of national prohibition today.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP). -- Possibilities of stabilizing the sugar industry through, a quota system were explored today by domestic sugar refiners at a conference with Dr. John Lee Coulter, member of the Tariff Commission, who is acting for the Agriculture Department under the Farm Adjustment Act.

The bass fishing season has opened in the Province of Quebec and already scores of American anglers are at the scene of action. The Laurentian Lake area has drawn a dozen or more Americans who, the guides say, will not be disappointed, for the lakes are teeming with fighters.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- New knowledge of the mysterious processes in the development of pre-natal life was presented here today before the American Association for the Advancement of Science by Professor Joseph Barcroft, famous physiologist of Cambridge University.

Mayor O'Brien announced yesterday that he would investigate charges by the Joint Committee on Public Relief of laxity in administration at the Home Relief Bureau at Benson and Twenty-fifth Avenues, Brooklyn.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 20 -- President Ada L. Comstock of Radcliffe will complete ten years as president of the college when she awards degrees tomorrow to the class of 1933. Owen D. Young will be the speaker at the exercises, to be held, in Sanders Theatre.

BERLIN, June 20 -- The Reich Federation of German Industries and all other employers' associations in Germany have reconstituted themselves as the Reich Corporation of Industry. This means the disappearance of the federation as an even quasi-independent organization and the insertion of all employers' interests in the all-embracing National Socialist machinery.
The Appellate Division unanimously restrained the city yesterday from awarding a five-year contract for refuse removal in Brooklyn to Samuel Rosoff's Manhattan Ash and Garbage Removal Corporation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The publication in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the interview in Chicago with Dr. Arthur H. Compton just started this morning in happy motion for me. We are all likely to pass over the statements of great scientists, due to an intellectual modesty which we feel becoming to us in the presence of colossal minds.
DES MOINES, June 20 -- Iowa apparently turned on dry traditions of nearly two decades today to become the fourteenth State to register its vote against retention of the Eighteenth Amendment.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Robert Fechner, director of the Civilian Conservation Corps, today announced an executive order approved by President Roosevelt, authorizing the purchase of between six million and eight million acres of timber and farm land in twenty Eastern and Southern States as part of the reforestation program.

The success of the World Economic Conference and recovery of international trade will determine Germany's resumption of transfer payments on her private debts, on which a moratorium recently was declared, Hans Luther, German Ambassador to the United States, told the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce yesterday.

Judge Coxe handed down yesterday a decision in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York upholding the ruling of Irwin Xurtz, referee, in approving the proposed compromise among four bankrupt utility companies formerly controlled by the Insull interests. At the same time he denied petitions for a review of the decision.

LOS ANGELES, June 20 -- The flight of Clifford Sherwood, chess expert and grandnephew of two Connecticut Governors, from police who sought him for the murder yesterday of Gabrielle Andrieux, 28, Hollywood modiste, ended here this morning when he shot himself in his speeding automobile three blocks from the Burbank police station.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Utterly ridiculous," perhaps; "simple" to an extreme, but nothing short of brilliant is Mr. Kaufman's suggestion of a way out of the war debt-disarmament problem, as set forth in THE TIMES last Saturday.

ATLANTA, June 20 (AP) -- A deputy sheriff seeking to serve Governor Talmadge with notice of an injunction suit was arrested by National Guardsmen today as the Governor and the military forces took over complete control of the State Highway Department under the Governor's martial law proclamation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have naturally been interested in the present discussion of taxes, especially here in the city, and feel, considering the present scale of earnings for most of us, a little bitter at the thought of the disproportionately large pay the majority of civic employes are receiving.

The Association of National Advertisers refused to accept the recently published Young report on advertising agency compensation because "the base of the study appears to be too narrow and it gives no light on the legal relationship in the advertiser-agent situation," it was revealed yesterday when the association made public an analysis of the survey by Albert E. Haase.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- A forecast for somewhat unsettled weather and lower temperatures resulted in revising the trend of the grain markets today after wheat had gone to within a fraction of the top levels of the season and the distant futures of corn and all deliveries of oats and rye to new peaks for the season.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 20 (AP). -- After listening to arguments for three hours, the Tennessee Supreme Court today took under advisement the habeas corpus case of Colonel Luke Lea and Luke Lea Jr., who for almost two years have been endeavoring to escape penalties imposed in North Carolina as a result of their conviction of banking law violations.

Unleashing a crushing attack in three innings, the Cardinals yesterday demolished the Dodgers' superiority complex by defeating Carey's men, 15 to 4, and moving a little closer to the first-place Giants.

Of the more than 1,000,000 boys and girls under 16 years of age in New York City, probably not more than 100,000 will have a vacation in the country or at the seashore. The others are dependent upon facilities provided by the public or private agencies for "play outlets."

A protest against the stoppage on July 1 of interest payments on Germany's bonded debt under the moratorium of June 8 was cabled yesterday to Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, by John Foster Dulles on behalf of American bankers who have marketed German dollar bonds.
HARTFORD, Conn., June 20 -- Connecticut voted by a huge majority today for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

After the broad advance of Monday, the share market ran into unavoidable profit-taking yesterday. That was the commission house explanation of the advance and the subsequent decline. The verdict of the market place was that the selling was "taken very Well" Undoubtedly, the bulk of the sales in the latter part of the day represented realizing, as the brokers contended.

Yesterday's renewed fall of the dollar almost to 20 per cent discount from gold parity doubtless indicated the use which speculators have made of the "currency deadlock" at the Economic Conference. An atmosphere of unreality has in fact pervaded the depreciation episode and has spread into the conference.
Restoration of the local 2-cent mail rate, on July 1, is expected to effect large savings for utility companies and other concerns with large mailing lists.

Park supporters from all over the city toured the parks of the Bronx in three buses yesterday. They praised the borough's Park Department for its use of emergency relief labor. The annual trip was under the auspices of the Park Association of New York City and the Bronx Chamber of Commerce.

SALEM, N.H., June 21. -- Thoroughbred horses ran on the famous Rockingham Park track today for the third time in more than a quarter of a century. More than 10,000 persons wagered a total of $87,643 on their speed.

George A. Helme, tobacco manufacturer, who died on April 29, 1931, left gross assets of $4,723,766 and a net estate of $4,267,539, it was shown by a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Securities appraised at $4,187,273 made up the bulk of the assets.

ALBANT, June 21. -- Because of the enactment of the Federal Home Loan Act, Governor Lehman does not consider It necessary to call an extraordinary session of the Legislature to take action for the relief of those who are in danger of losing their homes as a result of tax sales and mortgage foreclosures.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- Representatives of oil refineries met here today to discuss the organization of oil distributers under a code of fair practice as authorized by the National Industrial Recovery Act.

Formation of the three regional committees that will represent the managements under the railroad coordination plan recently enacted into law awaits only the approval by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal co-ordinator of the regional groupings proposed by the Association of Railway Executives, it was learned yesterday.

It is a pity that Chairman MACY should find himself at loggerheads with former Governor WHITMAN, his own appointee as chairman of the Republican Mayoralty Committee. The good faith and intentions of both are to be taken for granted. If they disagree, it is because their aims are different.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- The United States Government is ready to act with the three other large wheat-producing nations in controlling surplus production, or to act independently if these nations "do not see the light," Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace declared here today.

George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance, approved yesterday for use by companies licensed to do business in this State the nation-wide definition of marine insurance adopted recently by the National Convention of Insurance Commissioners in Chicago.

Leadership based on patriotism, courage, intelligence and humility was urged on the largest graduating class in the history of the College of the City of New York last night by Governor Paul V. McNutt of Indiana. He addressed 1,931 candidates for degrees, diplomas, certificates and commissions at the institution's eighty-seventh annual commencement exercises in the Lewisohn Stadium.

It has been said that all the adult inhabitants of the Virgin Islands could be accommodated in the Lewisohn Stadium. Columbia University has more students in the course of a year than the total population of these islands, and more teachers than they have payers of income taxes.

With an aggregate increase of 4.8 per cent in gross, the first six railroads to report earnings for May showed a rise of 95 per cent in net operating income. This result sustained predictions that because of their close hold on expenses the railroads could convert a large proportion of increased revenue into net.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- New evidence garnered in the dark interior of the atom to prove that creation is still going on in the cosmic vastness of interstellar space was presented here tonight by Dr. Robert A. Millikan.

FOLKESTONE, England, June 21. -- The United States clung tonight to the leadership in the international chess tournament after recording a 4-0 victory over the Lithuanian team and splitting with the Hungarians.
A five-race program will be held on election day at Belmont Park by the United Hunts Racing Association, it was announced at Aqueduct yesterday by Secretary Harry Buck.

Tommy Loughran, the Philadelphia phantom, evened his score with Steve Hamas, the hard-hitting Passaic heavyweight, in their ten-round bout at the Yankee Stadium last night. The Philadelphian caried off the decision over the former Penn State athlete after a hard battle that entertained a crowd of 10,000 persons.

MONTCLAIR, N.J. June 21. -- The annual commencement exercises of the Montclair State Teachers College will be held tomorrow afternoon. Dr. Charles H. Elliott, State Commissioner of Education, will confer 200 degrees -- 187 Bachelor of Arts and 13 Master of Arts.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Was apathy responsible for the stalemate in the ratification of the child labor amendment after the first six States voted favorably on it? Let us see.

HAVANA, June 21. -- The early clearing up of Cuba's political tangle came a step closer this afternoon when professors of Havana University, who have for the past three and a half years maintained a firm attitude in opposition to the Machado regime, handed Ambassador Sumner Welles of the United States a memorandum definitely accepting his mediation.

Of the three Victories won on Tuesday for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, that in Iowa is the most significant. Connecticut, voting Wet by a majority of 6 to 1, has never been a prohibition State and did not ratify the constitutional amendment. New Hampshire, giving repeal a 2-to-1 majority, is too much a part of the industrial East to have left much room for doubt.

MANAGER CHARLEY GRIMM of the Chicago Cubs, Boston-bound after a four-day stay in this fair city, found time to say a few parting words on the subject of the National League campaign as far as it has gone. The leader of the Cubs was in no rollicking mood. On the other hand, he was not unduly downcast.

MOSCOW, June 21. -- The Soviet Spring sowing figures, published today, show that 95.4 per cent of the program had been completed by June 15, as compared with 90 per cent up to the same date last year.

Bank clearings in the last week were not only the best of any week in the year to date, but also showed the greatest improvement over the corresponding week of the preceding year since the beginning of the depression. It was also the first time this year that the total for cities outside of New York City has been above that for 1932.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 21. -- Two hundred and seven awards for participation in varsity, junior varsity and freshman sports during the Spring season were announced today by the Harvard Athletic Association.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP). -- Fresh stimulus for administrators of the national recovery legislation came today in reports that cotton spinning operations in May moved at their fastest pace since October, 1929. The statement of the Census Bureau said that in May the domestic mills operated an aggregate of 8,309,664,772 spindle hours, as contrasted with 9,005,849,000 in October, 1929.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 21. -- Most of the honors in the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championship were with Harvard today. The Cantabrigians qualified two men for the semi-finals of the singles and two teams for the penultimate round of the doubles on the turf courts of the Ardsley Club.

The Port of New York Authority has revised its application for a Federal loan to finance the construction of a midtown tunnel between West, Thirty-eigrhth Street and Weehawken. It has reduced its request to $37,500,000 with a view to starting the first of two units as soon as possible.

RYE, N.Y., June 21. -- Mrs. George Hite Jr. of Apawamis continued her steady golf in the second round of the women's Westchester and Fairfield Association championship today. She eliminated another favorite when she defeated the medalist and former Connecticut champion, Mrs. Thomas Hucknall, by 5 and 4.

LONDON, June 21. -- There is a deeper feeling of pessimism among many of the delegations tonight regarding the results that can be extracted from the World Economic Conference than there has been since it assembled.

The newest Macfadden penny restaurant opened its doors yesterday with. Mrs. Anna Roosevelt Call as luncheon guest. The President's daughter joined with Police Commissioner Bolan and others in personal tributes to Bernarr Macfadden for his efforts to aid "the honest hungry."

Work Clothes Prices Up Sharply. With, another advance of $1 a dozen this week, overall prices have moved up more than 60 per cent since the low point of a few months ago. At that time the cheapest price was generally $4.37 1/2 a dozen, while at the present the lowest quotation apparently is $7.12 1/2 a dozen for the same type of goods.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP). -- Formation of the Arkansas Natural Gas Corporation in 1928 through a combination which, returned to the Cities Service Company $4,666,109 more in stock value than its investment in the merging companies was described to the Federal Trade Commission today by Roger E. Barnes, accountant.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 21. -- The North Country Garden Club won the sweepstakes award offered to the garden club receiving the greatest number of blue ribbons in the Long Island Flower Show, which opened here this afternoon in the Pratt estate oval.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 21. -- Yale's nine wound up its series with Harvard today by beating the Crimson, 4 -- 2, before a 6,000 Commencement Day crowd.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If the public does not seem to be vitally concerned over the recent pacifist students' vote at Columbia, Vassar and Smith, it may be on account of its comparative smallness. Less than a third of those polled indicated an unwillingness to fight under any circumstances.

MEXICO CITY, June 21. -- Lieutenant Joacquin Collar, Spanish transatlantic flier, was killed and his companion, Captain Mariano Barberian, was badly injured when their plane crashed into a mountain near the Puebla-Tlaxcala State border, according to unconfirmed reports received here tonight.
Following Tuesday's setback of a dollar a bale, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday and under moderate business closed at gains of 14 to 16 points.

CLEVELAND, June 21 (AP). -- The Indians belted Earnshaw and Walberg of the Athletics for a dozen safe blows today and coasted to an 11-to-1 victory behind Ferrell's effective pitching. Knickerbocker led the Tribe's attack with two triples.

LONDON, June 21. -- Not quite so sure of themselves since that encounter with Johnny Goodman in the United States open, the members of the American Ryder Cup golf team today arrived to prepare for the matches with the British professionals at Southport, Monday and Tuesday.

LONDON, June 21. -- Prime Minister MacDonald in his capacity as chairman of the World Economic Conference sat in at this morning's meeting of the committee of American, Australian, Argentine and Canadian representatives which has been trying to reach an agreement for restriction of wheat production.

Speed as an essential in improving this city's housing through Federal aid was stressed yesterday at a meeting of the executive committee of the Housing Association of the City of New York, Stanley M. Isaacs, chairman.

For the first time since April, 1931, the steel industry is operating this week at 50 per cent of capacity, according to the weekly review of The Iron Age. This compares with 47 per cent a week ago. The operating rate has risen in all the important producing districts. Business continues to ignore the usual seasonal trends.

Many Diverse Opinions. Has there ever been a time when one could meet so many people ending in "ists"? It is no trouble at all to glance through the morning paper and divide up the World's population under any number of headings:

BOSTON, June 21. -- Alfred E. Smith, Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador; Andre de Laboulaye, the French Ambassador, and Governor Cross of Connecticut arrived here tonight, all destined to receive honorary degrees at Harvard tomorrow.

Albany, N.Y. Award of a new issue of $1,461,800 City of Albany (N.Y.) bonds, constituting the largest issue on this week's calendar, was made yesterday to Hallgarten Co. and Ladenburg, Thalmann Co. at their joint bid of 100.64 for the bonds as 3 3/4s.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., June 21. -- The President arose late on the Amberjack II this morning. His first visitors were Captain Ben Pine, skipper of the crack racing and fishing schooner Gertrude Thebaud, and a group of fishing skippers.

TRENTON, N.J., Wednesday, June 22. -- With apparently little prospect of clearing its calendar before sunrise today, the Legislature met last night for what was to be its final session prior to recessing until late in August or early in September.

Possibly many readers of the "silver resolution" proposed by Senator PITTMAN at the Economic Conference were impressed by his self-restraint. Our awn Inflation Bill of May lodged with the President the power not only arbitrarily to fix the ratio of silver to gold but to provide for "unlimited silver coinage" at such ratio.

Professor Raymond C. Moley, Assistant Secretary of State, sailed for London yesterday noon aboard the Manhattan of the United States Lines. While Bernard M. Baruch and other friends were looking for him on the pier he penciled the following statement in the writing room of the ship:

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Secretary Roper holds increasing "tariff pressure" from Canada and Great Britain is primarily responsible for continued migration of American industry to foreign countries in the form of branch plants. He has set forth this view in a report to the Senate.

Twenty-nine of the thirty-four Republican district leaders in Manhattan signed a statement yesterday endorsing the county leadership of Samuel S. Koenig Of the remaining five, two are announced opponents of Mr, Koenig, two others declined to commit themselves and the last was Mr. Koenig, who was present at the meeting at which the signatures were obtained.

STURBRIDGE, Mass., June 21. -- The harness racing at Cedar Lake Park today was keenly contested. The average time for all four races was the lowest in any Bay State circuit meet this year, being better than 2:10.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- The army will graduate ninety-one airplane pilots June 29 from Kelly Field at San Antonio, the War Department announced today. These pilots will have received eight months of primary training at Randolph Field and four months of advanced flying at Kelly Field.

In a game during which umpires' rulings were bitterly disputed on both sides and four men were banished from the field the Cardinals yesterday came from behind to take a 7-to-5 decision from the Dodgers at Ebbets Field. The victory gave Street's men the series, two games to one.

Hank Mills, young rider of the first flight who already had gained triples twice this season, chalked up his third at Aqueduct yesterday. Included among his winners was the Wheatley Stable's Dark Secret, which was first in the featured Olambala Purse.

NEW HAVEN, June 21. -- Yale conferred honorary degrees today on twelve persons and granted diplomas to seniors in the graduate and professional schools in the first of the final events on the commencement program.
NEW YORK. Dr. and Mrs. Rene H. Huvelle of 168 East Seventy-fourth Street, and the members of their family, have left by motor for Chicago and the West.

Mrs. Ella A. Boole of Brooklyn, national president of the W.C. T.U., expressed disappointment yesterday over the results in Iowa, but added that she still did not believe thirty-six States would ratify the repeal amendment.

Police Commissioner Bolan has taken between seventy and seventy-five patrolmen from desk jobs and assigned them to active duty in the precincts since he assumed office, he announced yesterday. The police clerks have been replaced with civilian clerks already employed by the department.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- Directors of the Commonwealth Edison Company, voted today a quarterly dividend of $1 a share, 20 per cent lower than the rate in force last year. Similar dividend reductions, already decided on, will be voted tomorrow or Friday by the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company and the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois.

ROME, June 21. -- An amazing plot to overthrow the government of the oldest and tiniest republic in the world, butcher its leading citizens, seize its treasury and pillage its houses has been revealed by a proclamation addressed by the two Captains Regent of the republic of San Marino to the people of that State.

Savings bankers of New York State met yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria to discuss the Banking Act of 1933 (the Glass-Steagall Bill) and other Federal legislation, such as the Federal Home Loan Act, which affect savings banks and their depositors.

All markets were contrary yesterday. Stocks advanced, declined and then recovered. Commodities moved upward with more emphasis than usual. The net result was a generally higher price level at the end of the day.

The feature of the National Industrial Recovery Act that engaged the unanimous attention of twelve speakers, representing trade associations and leaders of the local textile and needle industries, in a symposium here yesterday, was the elimination of "cut-throat competition."

VIENNA, June 21. -- No terrorist outrages have occurred in Austria in the last twenty-four hours. This is attributed to the prompt and energetic measures that Chancellor Dollfuss took after the incident. Monday night in Krems, where thirty Heimwehr auxiliary policemen were wounded when Nazis threw bombs at them.

The eighty-fourth commencement exercises of De La Salle Institute will take place tonight at 8:30 o'clock at the Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street. The address to the graduates will be given by Dr. James J. Walsh, Catholic author.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Prohibition forces in large centres such as New York, where enforcement is a serious problem, will not be cut so drastically as those where the situation is less difficult, Major A.V. Dalrymple, dry director, said today.

The case of the United States against Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank, on charges of evading payment of his 1929 and 1930 income taxes, went to the jury at 12:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- The game principle for future treatment of war debtors as outlined in correspondence previously published was indicated in five additional dossiers of debt correspondence, with reference to the payments due on June 15, made public by the State Department today.

BERLIN, June 21. -- The Boerse opened today with a wave of selling that drove prices down 3 to 4 per cent, but a recovery toward the close wiped out approximately half of the losses. The heavy selling was attributed to disappointment over the deadlock in the economic and disarmament conferences, while the action against the Nationalist "battle ring organization" contributed to the unsettlement.

Professor Auguste Piccard, scientist, who ascended to the stratosphere, arrived yesterday on the French liner Champlain. He reiterated his belief that the time would come when man will travel between Europe and the Americas in a few hours.
WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Four of the new war craft to be constructed under authority of the Recovery Act have been allocated by the Navy Department.

Few are so credulous as to be deceived by the official explanations of Professor MOLEY'S trip to the London Economic Conference. It is gravely said that he is to furnish "reports" to President ROOSEVELT. As if the cables were not already crowded with such reports.

United States Government bonds pointed higher yesterday in an otherwise irregularly lower bond market on the Stock Exchange. The government issues moved up 2-32 to 6-32 points on the Stock Exchange on transactions of less than $1,000'000 of the total turnover of the listed market of $12,663,000.

HOYLAKE, England, June 21. -- Surviving today in the scramble for the British amateur golf championship and now standing together in the upper half of the fifth round, C. Ross (Sandy) Somervllle of Canada and George T. Dunlap Jr. of the United States approach a golfing collision that will oust one of the two invading threats from the tournament.

A glittering three-hit pitching masterpiece by Freddy Fitzsimmons, embellished by Frank. O'Doul's first home run since changing his playing address to the Polo Grounds, enabled the Giants to gallop off with, the final joust of their series with the Cubs yesterday, 3 to 1.

BERLIN, June 21. -- The Stahlhelm league of veterans was dissolved throughout the Rhineland today. Its reorganization will be carried out by Nazi commissars. The dissolution was said to have become imperative In order to "cleaense the organization of Marxist and Communist elements as well as bad political leaders, and pre "cleanse the organization of Marxorganization."

Twenty-two mechanics selected for outstanding work in the erection of laa Maison Francaise, a unit in Rockefeller Center, received certificates of craftsmanship and gold buttons yesterday. The exercises were held in the building under the auspices of the New York Building Congress.

The centre driveway in Central Park, just west of the Mall, which has been assigned to roller skaters, will be closed to skaters after 7:30 o'clock on four nights of the week during the series of band concerts on the Mall.

LONDON, June 21. -- The strong American contingent, led by the 1932 Wimbledon champions, Ellsworth Vines and Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, carried on through the third round of the London tennis championships today with its ranks almos unbroken.

BERLIN, June 21. -- The National Socialist claim to exclusive control in all matters of organization found reinforced expression today in the summary suppression throughout the Reich of Dr. Alfred Hugenberg's private green-shirted army, the German National Battle Ring, in which about 10,000 young Nationalists were enrolled.
WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates being June 20 unless specified:

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP). -- Cotton spinning operations during May struck their fastest pace since October, 1929, reflecting a revival of buying and increased demand for their products. The Census Bureau announced today that during the month United States mills operated an aggregate of 8,309,664,722 spindle hours.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 22. -- Russian Coast Guards in Kamchatka admit that they shot three Japanese fishermen last Thursday, when the Japanese were trying to land near Cape Origa, for attempting to enter Siberian territory in violation of the law.

LONDON, June 21. -- There was reason to believe today that the United States delegation, in part at least, was swinging toward the British view of recent years that currency stabilization is a good thing, but possible only as part of a general program.
LITTLE HARBOR, N.H., June 21. -- This snug little harbor In a beautiful but lonely setting tonight afforded President Roosevelt the first relaxation of his cruise aboard the Amberjack II.

Brokers reported that their customers were torn yesterday between a desire to take profits and to resume operations for the advance. Bullish influences must have prevailed at the close, because the market was higher. It was apparent, however, that speculators were keeping their accounts under close observation.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- The Civilian Conservation Corps attained a strength of 237,984 on Monday night, with the prospect that it would be about three times the size of the standing army by the end of the month, when enlistments are expected to be about 314,000.

Lord RUTHERFORD once remarked that man may yet date his true advance from the day when he first discovered how to utilize atomic energy. A wise future historian of our age may devote more space to the attempts at breaking up the atom, of which we have heard much of late by way of Chicago, than to our financial crises and political upheavals.

MOSCOW, June 21. -- In death Clara Zetkin will do a last great service for the cause of world socialism, to which she gave her long life. Today her body lies in state in the Hall of Columns, the former Nobles' Club, as Lenin's body lay nine and one-half years ago.

A defense of the plan under which short-term creditors of Germany will continue to receive interest even though long-term bondholders get none was issued yesterday by F. Abbot Goodhue, president of the Bank of the Manhattan Company and chairman of the subcommittee of American banks interested in German standstill credits.

NEWPORT, B.I., June 21. -- Thomas Ridgway of Philadelphia, vice chairman of the Newport Casino tennis committee, will manage the annual invitation tournament in August. Mr. and Mrs. Ridgway are expected soon after the first of the month to open their Summer home, Inchiquin.
LONDON, June 21. -- Senator Pittman's proposal for world stabilization on a gold standard with supplementary use of silver as legal cover was discussed today privately in two subcommittees.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Employment In the United States has increased about 1,629,000 since the end of March, and a comparable increase during the rest of June is expected, according to estimates of the American Federation of Labor.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- After a session in which the question of Jewish, demonstrations against litler's anti-Semitic campaign In Germany caused stormy debate, the convention of the Union at American Hebrew Congregations gave approval today to the Presidential message of its chairman, Ludwig Vogelstein of New York City.

NEWARK, N.J., June 21. -- A comparative statement of combined results of operations for the twelve months ended on May 31 last, issued today by the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, shows for the corporation and its subsidiary concerns gross earnings of $119,736,757, against $133,145,319 in the preceding twelve months, a decrease of $13,408,561.

The official arrival of Summer yesterday revived the demand for straw hats, at least in the vicinity of Madison Square Garden. During the noon hour more than 5,000 men, women and children rushed the entrance to receive a straw hat in exchange for a package of cigarettes.

C.E. Groesbeck, chairman of the board of the United Gas Corporation, told the stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that he expected soon to take up the question of renewal of the $21,250,000 bank loans due on July 20. The company has had no intimation from any bank that such loans would not be renewed, he said.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 21 (AP). -- The former Prince of the Asturias, defying parental opposition and renouncing his rights to the Spanish throne, was married today to Edelmira Sampedro, the daughter of a Cuban merchant.

New York City obtained from the War Department yesterday an extension of the time in which it may continue to dump garbage, ashes and other refuse at sea. The respite came after twenty-four hours of great anxiety to high officials of the Department of Sanitation as a result of what they believe was a typographical error in a legal document.

The New York Clearing House Committee issued yesterday to clearing house banks a ruling reducing the rate of interest payable on time deposits from one-half of 1 per cent to one-quarter of 1 per cent and redefining time deposits as those payable on or after sixty days instead of, as previously, those payable on or after ninety days from the date of demand.

ST. LOUIS, June 21. -- The Yankees played their longest game of the year today before they took a decision from the Browns. For thirteen innings the teams struggled before the Ruppert forces won, 5 to 3, a triumph that was needed to keep the team ahead of the Senators in the league standing.

BERLIN, June 21. -- Dr. Robert Ley, leader of the "German labor front," told a mass meeting of the Nazi shop cells' organization in the Lustgarten tonight that the next job for the Nazi organization was "a ruthless and brutal cleaning up in shops and offices."
DETROIT, June 21 (AP). -- Detroit won the second game of a doubleheader from the Boston Red Sox today, 5 to 3, after losing the opener, 10 to 9.
WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Secretary Roper of the Commerce Department today set up an advisory committee of forty-one business men to help chart the course of the country toward economic recovery.
Judge Goddard's Charge yesterday to the jury in the Charles. E. Mitchell case follows:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 21. -- Business has, failed to discipline itself and no escape from some political control is apparent, Owen D. Young told the graduating class of 236 at Radcliff College today.
NEWARK, N.J., June 21 (AP). -- Norman. Kies's single with the bases full in the thirteenth inning gave the Newark Bears a 4-3 decision over Jersey City today in the series opener.

Contracts for leasing the entire Bronx Terminal Market to a private concern will be submitted to Mayor O'Brien for his approval within the next few days, Market Commissioner Jere F. Ryan announced yesterday. Mr. Ryan said he had received inquiries from several large corporations regarding a lease of the entire plant.

Steps for a complete reorganization of the Silk Association of America, Inc., were taken yesterday at the quarterly meeting, when a committee of six was appointed to draw up plans for a "federated association" to include all allied industries.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 (AP). -- The Phillies made a clean sweep over Cincinnati today, taking the final of the four-game series by 10 to 8. The game started out as a pitching battle between Austin Moore and Stout, but wound up in a slugging match.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 21. -- A list of delinquent taxpayers made public here today by Village Treasurer Charles O. Frederick disclosed that Surrogate George A. Slater of Westchester County and his wife, Mrs. Eva A. Slater, owed $9,726, in back taxes on property they own here.
GLASSBORO, N.J., June 21 -- Commencement exercises here tomorrow evening will be featured by the observance of the tenth anniversary of the Glassboro State Normal School.

LONDON, Juno 21. -- Premier Mussolini of Italy, who has the Austrian situation, very much, on his mind just now, since its development in certain directions might involve considerable embarrassment for Italy, has a new idea for its solution, according to information reaching diplomatic circles in London.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- An agreement between railroads and railway labor suspending their wage reduction controversy until June 30, 1934, out of deference to President Roosevelt's recovery program, was announced tonight by Joseph B. Eastman, the new coordinator of transportation.
WASHINGTON, June 21. -- The Bureau of Navigation Issued the following orders today, dated June 19:

To the Editor of The New York Times: As an American housewife, I was more than surprised to read a few days ago an article in THE NEW YORK TIMES that many girls are being overworked in American homes, and that they are being paid as little as $3 a month, although forced to work from 6:30 A.M. until late at night.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., June 21. -- Economically we have been "both ignorant and lawless," graduates of the University of Pennsylvania were told today by Thomas S. Gates, president of the university and former member of J.P. Morgan Co.

Colonel Arthur F. Foran, William C. Adams and T. Gilbert Pearson have been reappointed as members of the advisory board. Migratory Bird Treaty Act, it was announced yesterday in Washington by Henry C. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture.
Sales and leases in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn yesterday were confined largely to housing properties.

Futures were firm in local commodity markets yesterday. Rubber, silk and wool tops were higher. Cocoa was unchanged, while sugar and coffee were irregular and silver and hides were lower. Trading was for the most part restricted. Cash prices were steady at higher levels.

BARNSTABLE, Mass., June 21 (AP). -- The simply phrased testimony of Margaret (Peggy) McMath and the collapse of Cyril Buck as he took the stand were events at the trial of the Buck brothers in Barnstable Superior Court today.

The equipment of city schools and hospitals already constructed is the city's most urgent need, Mayor O'Brien said last night after the Board of Estimate had devoted the day to discussing a capital outlay program.
WASHINGTON, June 21. -- The State Department today received a telegram addressed to "Bernard M. Baruch, unofficial President of the United States." It said:
The Kansas City Southern Railway passed the dividend on its preferred stock yesterday for the first time since 1907.
Lost: A young brown and white female spaniel, answers to the name Guilda. Finder please return to the Home of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, St. John's and Crotty Avenues, Yonkers.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 21. -- Society of Greenwich is completing plans for the second annual County Fair to be held from June 27 to July 1, inclusive, at the Meadows, located at the foot of the General Israel Putnam Hill in Greenwich.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 21. -- One extra-hole match involving a former titleholder was the outstanding feature of the quarterfinal round in the Long Island women's golf hampionship at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club today.

Included in a large volume of business leases reported yesterday was the rental of 10,000 square feet of additional space in the Hoover Building, at Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, to the Sachs Quality Furniture Company. The store is expanding its facilities, and as a result of this deal has the entire store frontage of the building and four floors.
WASHINGTON. June 31 (AP). -- Thirteen self-liquidating loans, totaling $1,874,000 and providing employment for several hundred men, were approved today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
Most New Yorkers were too busy talking about the temperature and its attendant inconveniences yesterday to notice the official advent of Summer.

LONDON, June 21 (AP). -- The Soviet Russian Delegation submitted to the World Economic Conference today a draft convention embodying its plan for economic non-aggression under which all weapons of economic warfare would be scrapped.
WASHINGTON, June 21. -- A force of between 35,000 and 40,000 will be mobilized to put into effect the administration's emergency program, Postmaster General Farley estimated today.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- No new instructions have been telephoned to the United States delegation at the World Economic Conference, and official Washington places little credence in reports today that Assistant Secretary of State Moley telephoned London, THE NEW YORK TIMES was informed in a high administration quarter tonight.
BOSTON, June 21 (AP). -- After dropping three games In a row to Pittsburgh, the Braves recovered their batting eyes today and took a double-header from the Pirates, 6 to 5 and 5 to 3.

The story methods of O. Henry, who with his followers escaped real life through the use of the drugs "types, local color, plot and the surprise ending," are put under indictment by Edward J. O'Brien, who is sometimes spoken of as "plot-shy," in his introduction to "The Best Short Stories of 1933," published' somewhat before its expected time by Houghton Mifflin.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- The majority for prohibition repeal rolled up in Iowa delighted wet leaders in Washington today. Jouett Snouse, president of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment, declared the margin "astounding," and challenged dry leaders to name three States which favored the retention of prohibition.

BERLIN, June 21. -- German newspapers now picture the United States as the chief trouble-maker at the London conference. This view is particularly prominent in papers representative of German heavy industry, which stress the American refusal to accept temporary currency stabilization.

LONDON, June 21. -- Judging by the discussion today in the subcommittee studying "commercial policy," the World Economic Conference seems likely to defer the question of tariff reductions and attempt first to get an agreement for reduction and ultimate abolition of the ingenious devices for blocking trade that have come into force since 1931.

PARIS. June 21. -- The suggestion that Eugene Frot, the French Minister of Merchant Marine, intends to propose an international shipping agreement for sailing dates and scrapping old tonnage is contained in an article to be published tomorrow in the Journal of the Merchant Marine.

Wednesday, June 21, 1933. An easier undertone in maturity money and commercial paper, with fractional concession in rates In both, departments, featured. Some four months' money was done at 1 per cent, compared with 1 1/4 previously, while' short-term, choice name merchants' paper dropped to 1 1/2 per cent from 1 3/4.
WORCESTER, Mass., June 21. -- Degrees were awarded to 243 graduates at the commencement exercises of Holy Cross College today by Governor Ely.

Mrs. Emma Dawson, one of five defendants accused of conspiring to defraud Mrs. William Patterson, widow of an advertising expert, of $588,000 in Curtis Publishing Company stock, was acquitted yesterday at the direction of Judge Nott. The acquittal was ordered after all the State's evidence had been presented by Joseph.V. Burns, Assistant District Attorney.

LONDON, June 21 (AP). -- The Soviet Russian Delegation submitted to the World Economic Conference today a draft convention embodying its plan for economic non-aggression under which all weapons of economic warfare would be scrapped.
WASHINGTON, June 21. -- A force of between 35,000 and 40,000 will be mobilized to put into effect the administration's emergency program, Postmaster General Farley estimated today.

Singled out from a group in which she was walking, an unemployed young woman was shot and killed last night in the Bronx by an unidentified man who escaped in an automobile that had slowed up at the curb. The motive for the murder completely mystified police officials, but they started a check-up of some of her male friends, searching particularly for a man living in Brooklyn whose identity was not disclosed.

Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, national chairman of the $2,000,000 campaign for the relief of the Jews in Germany being conducted in this country by the German relief campagin of the American Joint Distribution Committee, announced yesterday that more than $600,000 had already been obtained.

Wall Street found it difficult to follow yesterday the vagaries of the markets. The most important movement, so far as the speculative markets were concerned, was in the foreign exchanges. The fact that the dollar and sterling and the franc were out of relation many times was sufficient to unsettle the share and commodity markets.

PARIS, June 22. -- Detailed trade figures for the first five months of 1933, which were issued today, show to what extent France has been favoring her colonies recently. Whereas Imports from other countries dropped 569,000,000 francs under the same period of 1932, imports from France's colonies, protectorates and mandates rose 649,000,000 francs.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 22. -- Commencement exercises of the Concordia Lutheran Collegiate Institute will be held tomorrow night in the Schoenfeld Gymnasium at the Institute. The Rev. F.W. Weidman of Glen Ridge, N.J., will deliver the address to the graduates.

Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, warned the States in an address last night that they must do more than they have been doing for the unemployed if the 18,000,000 now receiving assistance are to be cared for.

Joseph M. Proskauer, former Supreme Court justice, told graduates of the Graduate School for Jewish Social Work yesterday to shun racial solidarity other than cultural and religious. He spoke at the seventh annual commencement of the school at 71 West Forty-seventh Street.

LIMA, Peru, June 22. -- A Peruvian commission left Iquitos yesterday for Leticia, to be on hand upon the arrival of the League of Nations commission which will supervise the transfer of the territory to Colombia.

An ex-Assemblyman, an author and a pharmacist were among 250 World War veterans who answered an advertisement for a job as doorman in a Broadway cafe. Yesterday morning twenty-five selected from that group were interviewed at the Paradise Restaurant, Broadway and Forty-ninth Street.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 22. -- Plowing through Long Island Sound with her lee rail down despite the light air, Gerard B. Lambert's America's Cup yacht Vanitie left Frederick H. Prince's Weetamoe far astern today.

NEWARK, N.J., June 22 (AP). -- Scoring two runs in the first inning and three more in the fourth for a five-run lead, Jersey City evened the series with Newark tonight, winning by 8 to 5. Bob Hasty pitched steady ball for the winners until the ninth, when Cy Perkins pulled him out of trouble.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- Warned to weigh the consequences of a discordant meeting, representatives of the nation's gasoline and oil marketing industry settled down today to the task of drawing up a code for the conduct of their business under the new system of government regulation.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 22. -- The last of the field of sixty-four starters to post his score, Charles Sheldon of Siwanoy was the medal winner in the qualifying round of the Westchester amateur golf championship at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

One of the obligations of the government under the Industrial Recovery Act will be to protect industry by keeping tariff barriers up to the rising-price level, according to Arthur A. Ballantine, former Under Secretary of the Treasury.

The principal local commodities were irregular or weak yesterday. Trading on the exchanges was nervous, reflecting the course of securities and rumors of developments in foreign exchange. Cash prices, on the other ahnd, were generally higher, although some losses were recorded.

All Think Alike. Our dispatch describing Nazi anger in Germany over the suppression of the Nazi movement in Austria is quoted from the Vossische Zeitung. This former outstanding organ of liberal opinion now states that it must be war to the death between the wicked Austrian Government and the Nazi movement.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- New high levels for the season were established today on all deliveries of wheat, corn, oats and rye on a buying wave that swept aside all opposition in the early trading. The general public as well as large and small Eastern and local operators carried September wheat up 3/4 cent to 81 cents at the extreme, the highest price for that future since it went off the board in September 1930.

SALEM, N.H., June 22. -- Mrs. Henry S. Horkheimer's Kanal, a juvenile filly by Mirafel out of Frivol, scored a driving half-length victory over William Ziegler Jr's Zipalong in the featured five-fun-long New England Purse at Rockingham Park today.

CHICAGO, June 22 (AP). -- The Washington Senators took advantage of the wildness of White Sox pitchers and fielders today and made it two in a row, 11 to 4. It was their tenth triumph in their last eleven starts.
The long left arm of Carl Hubbell went on display again at the Polo Grounds yesterday simultaneously with the appearance of the Reds and the result was trouble for the Cincinnatians.

Arguing that the habits of thinking among the unemployed on social and economic questions can hardly be considered altogether satisfactory by those in authority, Osgood Nichols and Comstock Glaser suggest in "Work Camps for America," a new John Day pamphlet, some possible means for turning such thought "now mostly destructive" into "constructive channels."

The whole policy of France at the London conference is based on the view that ultimately factors of a durable increase in prices should be substituted for temporary factors, according to Georges Bonnet, French Finance Minister and chief delegate to London.

BERLIN, June 22. -- The Boerse opened with another downward movement today, but recovered a part of the losses before the close. Only Reichsbank shares were firm, gaining 1 3/4 per cent. Most other securities lost up to 4 per cent on the day.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Slightly more than 1,200,000 persons went back to work during April and May, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said today. Unofficial estimates obtained at the federation headquarters yesterday set the increase from March 31 to June 21 at 1,659,000.
WASHINGTON, June 22. -- "Nevertheless, I still believe in the jury system." This was the comment of Attorney General Cummings today on the acquittal of Charles E. Mitchell.

Retail Council to Consider Code. A meeting of the Retailers National Council, composed of seven retail trade associations, in addition to the National Retail Dry Goods Association, will be held today to consider the code for stores under the recovery act, prepared by the committee of the dry goods group.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 22. -- Mrs. John W. Davis of Locust Valley, exhibiting with the North Country Garden Club, took five blue ribbons today at the Long Island flower show being held here at the Pratt estate oval. The exhibit is under the auspices of amateur gardeners of the Second District of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State and the North Country Garden Club, hostess organization.
A loss of 0.3 points for the week carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices down to 93.4 on Tuesday from 93.7 (revised) the Tuesday previous.

Three six-foot rattlesnakes made an unexpected visit yesterday afternoon to the back yard of Mrs. Edward J. Phillips at 3,135 Corlear Avenue, just two blocks off New York's own Broadway, at 230th Street.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The Department of Justice will save more than $7,000,000 of its appropriation in the coming fiscal year, according to Attorney General Cummings. He made the announcement today after conferring with Budget Bureau officials.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 22. -- A plea for "aa representative central body that would speak with authority for all American Jews" to deal with such crises as the Nazi persecution in Germany was made here tonight at the opening of the Central Conference of American Rabbis.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, head of the Tennessee Valley Authority, has turned over to the Secretary of State a list of all personal property owned by himself and immediate family to serve as a matter of public record during his tenure in directing the great Tennessee River Basin economic and social development.

The savings bankers of New York State plan to establish a trust company from which to borrow money when necessary and a mortgage loan company to which to sell mortgages until the mortgage market returns to more normal conditions.

Edward Corsi, Immigration Commissioner, announced yesterday that the government had made arrangement to repatriate free of charge any stranded seamen in this port who have been in the country illegally less than three years. Through authorization of the commissioner general, Mr. Corsi said, he has written to consuls in New York requesting them to cooperate by prompt issuance of passports to the seamen.

In his letter to the Board of Estimate, President MOSES of the Long Island State Park Commission has left no good reason why the board at today's meeting should not vest title in the rights-of-way for the Long Island parkway extensions. Federal and State Governments have made generous appropriations.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- A broad policy on price fixing, not sanctioned by the Industrial Recovery Administration, will come to the fore in marketing agreements with processors and distributers of farm products now being drafted for submission to the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is reassuring to note with what vigor your editorial pagre deprecates unsound monetary policies. That the President has thrown overboard many of his vaunted campaign assertions has on occasion been aptly pointed out in your columns.

No one can allege that the case against Mr. CHARLES MITCHELL was not ably and even relentlessly pressed in court. The jury was "intelligent," as the Federal District Attorney admits. Judge GODDARD presided with impartiality and let in every scrap of relevant evidence.

A move by an expanding Industrial firm is to occur as a result of a New Jersey realty deal reported yesterday. Building 3 of the Aeolian Company's plant at Garwood has been sold to the Sonoco Investment Company, which is to lease the structure to tha Sonoco Products Company, maker of paper board, cones and tubes used by cotton and silk mills.

Wage increases of 10 per cent affecting between 25,000 and 30,000 men throughout the United States were voted yesterday by the wholesale lighting fixture manufacturers division of the Lighting Fixture Merchants Association. The increases were approved unanimously at a meeting of seventeen manufacturers, who also adopted a code of market practices as required by the provisions of the National Industrial Recovery Act.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 22. -- Two men dominated the 297th commencement of Harvard University today. One was Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell, who is retiring after a quarter of a century at the helm, and the other was Alfred Emanuel Smith, LL. D., an alumnus of the class of 1933.
WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated June 20:

William A. Prendergast, vice president and director of the Long Island Lighting Company, and Eversley Childs, a director, have resigned, it became known yesterday. Mr. Prendergast was receiving a salary of $50,000 a year.

BALTIMORE, June 22. -- Continental Shares, Inc., investment company incorporated in Maryland, founded by Cyrus S. Eaton of Cleveland, was ordered into receivership today by Judge O'Dunne in the Baltimore civil courts. William D. MacMillan, a Baltimore attorney, was appointed receiver.

BERLIN, June 22. -- In pursuit of its coveted goal, the totalitarian or one-party State, the Hitler government today decreed the proscription of the Social Democratic party, the second largest in Germany.

Lionel A. Stagg, 65 years old, one of the smoothest confidence men in the country, was arrested on a fraud charge yesterday afternoon by Detective James J. McKettrick of District Attorney Crain's office. The arrest was made in the office of a director of the Bank of Manhattan at 40 Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Rapid price advances and higher money circulation attributable to the recent growth in the volume of business activity were noted by the Federal Reserve Board today in its monthly bulletin.

A hospital which, refused a patient who could not pay would be condemned by the New York public. But hospitals have expenses which must be met. Patients require meals as well as medicines, surgical supplies and nursing care. The cost of giving such care to 100,000 unemployed and destitute sick who cannot be accommodated in municipal hospitals is said to reach the total of $6,000,000 annually.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- A company Including high officials of the government and members of the diplomatic corps attended the preview tonight of the Gellatly Art Collection, which will be placed on public exhibition tomorrow at the National Gallery of Art.

Police Commissioner James S. Bolan opened last night the fifth annual Boys' Fair, conducted by the Madison Square Boys' Club, at the William Church Osborn playground, foot of East Thirty-first Street. After addressing several hundred boys of the district, the commissioner sampled some biscuits baked on the premises by a boy in the cooking class, and inspected the various hobbbies and handicrafts of the young club members.
BOSTON, June 22 (AP). -- The Braves made it three in a row by defeating the Cubs, 3 to 1, today in the first game of their series behind the seven-hit pitching of Ed Brandt.

LONDON, June 22 (AP). -- The Irish Free State attacked the British Government before the World Economic Conference today on the ground that Britain had imposed a punitive tariff against the Free State. The attack was made by Senator Joseph Connolly, Minister of Lands and Forests, at a meeting of the subcommittee on commercial policy.

Joseph T. Lykes, chairman of the American Steamship Owners Association, in a statement issued yesterday urged that every nation decide for itself the economic value of its merchant ships and the extent to which government aid should be extended to insure the operation of a sufficient merchant fleet.
Special meetings of stockholders of the Fox Film Corporation will be held on July 1 and July 3 to take action on a plan of reorganization, it was announced yesterday.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 22. -- Alfred E. Smith's address at the Harvard Alumni Association exercises today was as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Forty-two men and women have accepted the invitation of Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, to investigate conditions at Kills Island. They will hold their first meeting at the Bar Association Building in New York Monday afternoon.

HOYLAKE, England, June 22. -- George T. Dunlap Jr. of New York gained the quarter finals of the British amateur golf championship today by defeating C. Ross (Sandy) Somerville, Canadian holder of the United States amateur title, 2 and 1.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 22. -- Princeton's varsity 150-Pound crew will sail on the Olympic of the White Star Line tomorrow night to race in the Thames Challenge Cup of the Royal Henley Regatta, to be held in England July 5-8.
LONDON, June 22 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

William N. Doak, Secretary of Labor in the Cabinet of President Hoover, will be asked by the United States Attorney's office in this district to aid the government in its prosecution of his nephew, Ervin F. Brown.

THE big exposition st Chicago, officially opened by a beam of light from Arcturus after the inhabitants of a dizzy globe had been in something of a Dismal Swamp for three or four years, has for its title or slogan or "leitmotif" the impressive phrase, The Century of Progress.

Title companies that foreclose mortgages on homes are not justified in attributing their action to the State Department of Insurance. This became evident yesterday when former Representative F.H. La Guardia made public a letter to that effect from George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance.

Thursday, June 22, 1933. Money market continued dull. A little four months' money was done at 1 per cent, as on. Wednesday, and there was a shading in the counter trading on call loans to 5/8 from 3/4. Otherwise, all other classifications were unchanged in quiet trading.

The State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, at a meeting today, is expected to take up the problem presented by some dealers who complained that the fees demanded by bonding companies for bonds were prohibitively high.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 22 (AP). -- The charge that workers were being "cheated wholesale" on some public works projects created in this State to provide jobs for the unemployed was made here today by Mrs. Lillian R. Sire, head of the Bureau of Labor Welfare of the State Department of Labor.

NEW YORK. Sir Alfred T. Davies, former Secretary of Education for Wales, and Lady Davies are expected today at the Barbizon-Plaza from Silver-mine, Conn., where they have been visiting their son and daughter-in-law.

Control of predatory animals and birds is one of the most controversial topics perennially before those interested in the work of preserving and restoring the wild life of America. Like all such subjects, it has been discussed often and has led to so many different answers that it probably never will be completely settled to everybody's satisfaction.

The New York Stock Exchange has received application for the listing of 1,111,922 shares of the new $10 par value stock of the Commercial Credit Company. Stockholders of the company authorized yesterday a change in the common stock from no par value to $10 par value, approved the retirement of 45,948 shares of common stock and authorized the purchase from time to time of 54,052 additional shares at a price not to exceed $20.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Joseph B. Eastman issued his first order as Coordinator of Transportation today. He divided the railroads of the country into three groups for the purpose of setting up regional coordination committees.

At London the American delegation, under "instructions of the United States Government,"plumped yesterday for the restoration of international trade. Secretary HULL'S resolution called for lowering of tariff barriers as quickly as possible and for the complete removal of "embargoes, import " quotas and various other arbitrary "restrictions."

PARIS, June 22. -- A Parisian throng today made holiday on the occasion of the Greek Orthodox wedding service in the Russian Cathedral, uniting Barbara Woolworth Hutton, American heiress, to Prince Alexis Mdivani of the famous Georgian family.
PARIS, June 22 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

PARIS, June 22. -- President Roosevelt and his "brain trust" were championed today before the American Club in Paris by Jesse Isidor Straus on the occasion of his first appearance as Ambassador before that organization.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 22. -- A three-hit goal by Tommy Hitchcock, with less than thirty seconds of play remaining in the final period, enabled John Hay Whitney's Greentree polo team to defeat the Aknusti quartet, 6 to 5, today on Cochran Field and gain the final of the third Westbury Challenge Cup tournament.

LONDON, June 22. -- The sultry atmosphere of the World Economic Conference was greatly cleared today by two actions, both American -- the issuance of a statement regarding the attitude of the United States toward monetary stabilization and the introduction of a resolution regarding trade barriers and tariffs.
FLORENCE, Ala., June 22. -- Following are excerpts from Judge Barton's opinion, Sent to THE NEW YORK TIMES by The Associated Press correspondent at Athens, Ala.:

WATCHUNG, N.J., June 22. -- State troopers and county authorities were cooperating tonight with Department of Justice agents in a search for the person or persons who early this morning affixed a fifteen-pound bomb to the starting mechanism of an automobile belonging to Representative Charles A. Eaton of the Fifth New Jersey Congressional District.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 22. -- A long-standing golf feud will be renewed at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club tomorrow when Miss Helen Hicks of Inwood and Mrs. R.C. Lake of the Old Country Club meet in the 36-hole final of the women's Long Island championship.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., June 22. -- Francis H. Sisson of New York, president of the American Bankers Association, addressing the Virginia Bankers Association here today, characterized the Glass-Steagall Banking Act as a measure "basically unsound, which will ultimately force its own repeal."
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 22. -- Today was inspection day for the yachts lying in the harbor here waiting for the start of the ocean race to Gibson Island, Md., on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- A clear definition of American policy at the World Monetary and Economic Conference is expected to be made soon in London on the basis of a document Bernard M. Baruch is preparing for submission to Assistant Secretary of State Raymond Moley, who is en route to the conference.

"Do not come to New York if you are unemployed -- you will be better off at home," was the warning issued yesterday by Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, wife of the Goveronor. Mrs. Lehman spoke over the Columbia Broadcasting System on behalf of the Room Registry Committee of the Welfare Council of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The second code of fair competition to be submitted under the National Recovery Act was placed today before General Hugh S. Johnson, the administrator, by the Cast Iron Soil Pipe Manufacturers, representing 95 per cent of the industry.
J. Irving Walsh, twice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, committed suicide in his apartment at 29 Washington Square West yesterday, according to the police.

RYE, N.Y., June 22. -- Miss Frances Snyder of Apawamis, one of the longest hitters in the women's metropolitan golf ranks, today gained the final round in defense of her title as women's Westchester and Fairfield champion.
CLEVELAND, June 22 (AP). -- The Athletics went on a hitting rampage against four Cleveland pitchers today, registering sixteen safe blows to win, 11 to 6.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 22. -- After one of the most hectic days of tennis on record in the history of the event, Harvard still remained in the running for the Eastern intercollegiate championship team trophy this evening, despite twin disasters in the semifinals of the singles and the elimination of one of its combinations in the penultimate round of the doubles.

Norman H. Davls, Ambassador at Large for the United States, returns from Europe today on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. The Bremen has on board many notables, including George L. Harrison, governor of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, accompanied by Dr. Oliver M.W. Sprague, financial adviser to the United States Treasury.

LIMA, Peru, June 22. -- Alleged accomplices of Abelardo Hurtado de Mendoza in the assassination of President Luis M. Sanchez Cerro on April 30 were acquitted today by a specially appointed court-martial which began their trial on June 17. The verdict was unanimous.

W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman and titular leader of his party, and Samuel S. Koenig, Republican chairman of New York County, declared open warfare on each other 'yesterday. Meanwhile, hackers of fusion for the coming municipal election insisted that the factional strife menaced the hope of defeating a Tammany candidate for Mayor in November.
HOYLAKE, England, June 22 (AP). -- The slim, 125-pound Dunlap smiled happily today as he walked off the seventeenth green, victor over the Canadian favorite, Somerville.
The salaries of F.W. Smith as president of the New York Edison Company and as head of two of its affiliates were revealed yesterday as totaling $75,000 annually, as of Dec. 1, 1932.
ST. LOUIS, June 22. -- The Yankees dropped today's game to the Browns at Sportsman's Park and skidded into a tie with the Senators for the American League lead.

SHANGHAI, June 22. -- The great Hwang Ho, the Yellow River, of China, swollen by rapidly rising flood waters, is on the point of breaking through the dikes at Kaifeng and again returning to its old course to the south, which it left eighty-one years ago.

The four-race winning streak of the fleet filly Flying Hour, considered one of the fastest of her sea in training, came to an end yesterday at Aqueduct when Good Advice from the Catawba Stable won the featured Bramble Purse, with Balios a head behind.
NEWARK, N.J., June 22. -- A formal academic procession for the first time will feature the commencement of the New Jersey State Normal School here at the exercises to be held tomorrow morning.

LONDON, June 22. -- The invading American forces dominated the London tennis championships at the Queens Club today. Ellsworth Vines and Mrs. Helen Wills Moody led five of their compatriots through the fourth round to fill seven of the eight positions in the semi-final brackets of the men's and women's singles.

With few changes in fee ownership reported, real estate activity in Manhattan yesterday indicated a preference for leaseholds on the west side, where most trading was done in business and housing properties. Banks, either as agents or principals, figured in some of the deals.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The proposal of Alderman E.J. Sullivan to have the License Commissioner appoint five persons as an examining board of music teachers presents a most serious problem at the present time.

Gas Industry (Reports to American Gas Association) -- April: Revenues of manufactured and natural gas companies aggregated $59,757,000, comparing with $67,570,000 a year before, a decline of 11.6 per cent. Manufactured gas revenues were $32.434,900, down 12.3 per cent, and sales were 30,459,100,000 cubic feet, down 10.6 per cent.

LONDON, June 22. -- An international agreement engineered by the United States for reduction of wheat acreage and limitation of exports tonight was all but closed, with Russia and Argentina definitely committed to participate and only Australia of the great wheat exporters still to be heard from.

President Roosevelt's economic program is an application of the traditional economic thought and ethics of the Catholic Church, it was declared last night by the Rev. Frederic Siedenburg, S.J., at the sixth annual convention of the National Catholic Alumni Federation.

Waterbury, Conn. A new issue of $500,000 city of Waterbury (Conn.) 5 1/2 per cent funding bonds, due serially on May 15, 1934 to 1953, was awarded yesterday to a syndicate comprising Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., the R. F. Griggs Company of Waterbury, and Christianson, McKinnon Co. of Hartford.
