WASHINGTON, June 22. -- A compilation of income-tax provisions of the National Industrial Recovery Act and provisions of that law relating to the 5 per cent tax withheld at the source on corporate dividends was issued today by the Internal Revenue Bureau.

The gray and gloomy old structure downtown known as the Federal Building, scene of much, human drama and tragedy in past years, has never witnessed a more dramatic scene than the acquittal of Charles E. Mitchell yesterday afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In its haste to adjourn, Congress neglected to consider one very important measure to complete the new deal. It should have given all the farmers more land. All that is necessary is to reduce the land content of the acre from 43,560 square feet to 21,780 square feet and every farmer would have twice as many acres as he has now.

Mrs. John E. Berwind gave a dinner last night at the Embassy Club. Her guests included Mr. and Mrs. Pierre C. Cartier, Mrs. Hoppin Pool, Miss Ann Nicholas, Bruce F. E. Harvey, Hamilton Hill Durand and Donald O'Connor.
L.O. Head, in 277 Park Av., through the Worthington Whitehouse Co. and Douglas L. Eillman Co.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Appropriations for the "ordinary" expenses of the government have been reduced $2,840,470,452 since the Democratic party organized the House under the Hoover administration in December, 1931, according to Representative Byrns.
Mrs. Madolyn K. Singer leased the home of Dr. A. Burton Stark at 37 Shadow Lane, Larchmont Park, through Thomas B. Sutton, broker.
Greater protection for buyers of commodities on the instalment plan will be sought by the city in the next few days, it was disclosed yesterday by James A. Higgins, Commissioner of Accounts.

The trend of railroad earnings indicates that the abandonment of further wage-cutting plans may not have the adverse effect on net returns that otherwise might have been expected. Some commentators suggested that if the earnings had continued upward at the present rate many arguments of managements for reduced wages would have been nullified.

Acting with promptitude following the favorable decision by the Federal courts, the directors of the Central Railroad of New Jersey elected yesterday Charles H. Ewing to the presidency of their company. Mr. Ewing is also president of the Reading Company.

ATHENS, Ala., June 22. -- The verdict of guilty returned against Haywood Patterson, one of the Scottsboro Negroes, two months ago by a Morgan County jury of white farmers and tradesmen was set aside today by Circuit Judge James E. Horton, who ordered a new trial.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The War Department informed a committee from New York City today that Fort Schuyler reservation in the Bronx was not open to lease to any one at the present time. The city has been trying for some time to acquire this land for a park.
DETROIT, June 22 (AP). -- A threebase hit by Roy Johnson with two men on bases and two out in the tenth inning gave the Boston Red Sox, a 9-to-7 victory over the Tigers today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Henry A. Wallace in his excellent exposition of the "Purposes of the Farm Act," in THE TIMES, failed to mention explicitly two factors bearing on the situation of which he is informed, and one of which he implies.
Behind a masterful pitching exhibition by Ray Benge, who yielded only four hits, the Dodgers yesterday overpowered the Pirates, 9 to 0, and ascended into fifth place in the league standing.

TRENTON, N.J., June 22. -- The Legislature recessed at 5:15 o'clock this morning after an all night session, until Aug. 29. It was convened early in January but left most of the main business to be transacted in the last few hours.

LONDON, June 22 -- The United States policy became somewhat clearer in the commercial as well as the monetary field today when Secretary of State Hull introduced in the World Economic Conference a resolution advocating the abolition of quotas and other arbitrary restrictions of trade and the reduction of tariffs as "quickly as possible."

The subjoined table shows the highest and lowest points thus far reached in 1933 and in a series of past years for the principal items of the account. All figures except ratio of reserve are in thousand of dollars:

LONDON, June 22. -- The American view on prices was given today in a resolution submitted by Senator James Couzens without comment to the World Economic Conference's committee dealing with immediate recovery measures.

CHANDLER'S COVE, Me., June 22. -- With lazy sailing weather, President Roosevelt passed the Midway Point in his cruise today. Aboard the schooner Amberjack II, he sailed up the rugged New England coast and finally anchored here, ten miles northeast of Portland.

All speculative markets were in some confusion yesterday, largely as the result of an unconfirmed report from Europe that France was preparing to abandon the gold standard. Prices moved within a wide range, closing generally lower. The fifty stocks upon which a composite, index of averages is computed showed a net decline of 2 3/4 points and there was a fractional decline in the price of the major agricultural products.

LONDON, June 22. -- France and Great Britain, which had been insisting upon de facto stabilization of the dollar as a prerequisite to any useful work at the economic conference, came over today to President Roosevelt's view that stabilization must not precede, but should go hand in hand with other emergency measures.

LONDON, June 22. -- Senator Key Pittman told the silver committee of the World Economic Conference today that the United States was interested in silver not primarily from an industrial point of view, or, in other words, from the point of view of the Nevada miners, but from the currency angle -- that is, as a key to trade in the Orient, Mexico and South America.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 22. -- Miss Ann Mitchell, daughter of Mrs. John T.H. Mitchell, gave a dinner-dance tonight at her home, the Castle, Brookside Drive, Greenwich, in honor of Miss C. Ann Vanderhoef and her fiance, Fred H. Booth, of Ottawa, whose marriage is to take place Saturday afternoon.
Teachers of music and dancing organized a protest yesterday against the city's proposal to tax them to raise $250,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Applications of New York officials for inclusion of the Triborough Bridge and Staten Island Tunnel projects in the new public works program are to be referred'back to the State Public Works Administrator for New York for original adjudication, officials here said today.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- The Theory of complementarity, a new theory of knowledge, based on the concepts of modern atomic physics, was presented today for the first time before an American audience by Professor Niels Bohr of the University of copenhagen, originator of the Bohr model of the atom and Nobel Prize winner.

ANDREW JACKSON got his LL.D. at Harvard a hundred years ago and the surviving Federalists howled in wrath. The General wasn't doctored on his merits alone. In accordance with tradition he was honored as a visiting President. Yesterday Governor SMITH became a son-in-law of Harvard, as Mr. EVARTS used to speak of himself.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., June 22 (AP). -- J. Philip Bird of Plainfield, N.J., president for the last twentyone years of the New Jersey Manufacturers Association, ended his life here today. He was 66 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The problem of confining the Yellow River, which is now threatening to return to its old channel, is one of the principal engineering difficulties in China.

The elopement to Elkton, Md., of Orace J. Adams, 22-year-old daughter of a New Bedford (Mass.) textile mill manager, and Justin H. Edgerton, a credit manager of this city, on June 17, ended here yesterday with a city-wide police search for Miss Adams and the arrest of Edgerton as a fugitive from Maryland justice.

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 22. -- Miss Mary Teegarden of Mount Holyoke gained the semi-final round of the college girls' invitation tennis tourney today by scoring an upset. She eliminated Miss Catharine Boyden of Vassar, seeded third in the tournament which is under way at the Longwood Cricket Club.

A first novel by a writer unknown to the public will be named as winner of the Harper Prize Novel contest for 1933-34 on Aug. 1, it was said yesterday. Between seven and eight hundred manuscripts were submitted in the contest and, of these six books were retained for submission to the judges, Sinclair Lewis, Dorothy Canfield and Harry Hansen.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- Once the religious school is restored to priority in Jewish life, "we shall not be wanting for men and women who will restate for us our sacred heritage so that it will be as meaningful for us as it has been for our ancestors," Dr. Joseph Rauch at Louisville declared today before the council of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.
"There has been no terror in Germany," declared Chancellor Hitler of Germany in an interview published yesterday by Collier's Weekly, in which he defends his attitude on the Jewish question.

Tenders of the Class A common stock of the Reliance International Corporation are being requested by the Atlas Corporation, which will give its stock in exchange. This is the second trust so to be approached by Atlas in a week, and if control is acquired it will be the twenty-third to come into the Atlas fold since the Summer of 1930.

The first effects of the prohibition against interest on demand deposits in the new banking act showed up in this week's statement of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, published yesterday.

In a day of wild fluctuations the dollar yesterday fell to a new low since the suspension of the gold standard, only to rally late in the afternoon on widespread rumors that France and the Netherlands were about to follow the United States and Great Britain by cutting their currencies loose from gold.

One result of " economic nationalism," as practiced during recent years, has been to stimulate the expatriation of American industry. How rapidly this has gone forward is indicated by Department of Commerce figures. They show that at the end of 1932 American companies had established 1,819 foreign units and invested $2,178,000,000 in them.

The depression stimulated the mining of gold in all parts of the world. Both in Canada and the United States abandoned mines have been reopened, prospects hurried to the mill stage, and drilling has been pushed to great depths to develop new ore. New gold fields have lately been discovered in tropical Africa.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Reflecting an apparently widespread upward turn in manufacturing and trade, miscellaneous internal receipts for May were the highest for any month since the war, the Internal Revenue Bureau showed today.
DETROIT, June 22 (AP). -- The millions of the late Horace H. Rackham, who made his fortune as one of the original stockholders in the Ford Motor Company, will go to charity.
CAMP 3, MOUNT EVEREST, June 22 (By Wireless via Base Camp.) -- After their immense exertions on the mountain, the expedition's climbing parties are now badly in need of rest.

LONDON, June 22. -- Talk of United States recognition of the Soviet Union grew more serious today when it became known that William C. Bullitt, executive officer of the United States delegation to the World Economic Conference, had an hour's talk with Foreign Commissar Litvinoff.

The Metropolitan Dress Contractors Association voted by acclamation last night to ask Samuel I. Rosenman, former Supreme Court Justice, to direct its reorganization along the lines laid down by the National Industrial Recovery Act.

MEXICO, D.P., June 22. -- A large number of Mexican Army and private airplanes joined in the search today for Captain Mariano Barberan and Lieutenant Joaquin Collar, the Spanish transatlantic fliers who have been missing since they took off Tuesday from Havana for Mexico.

PARIS, June 22. -- The liner Washington sailed today from Havre bearing seventy United States trade commissioners and commercial attaches and their wives and families. The men had been ordered to hasten home and resign.
WASHINGTON, June 22. -- A broad policy aimed at spreading work as widely and quickly as possible was set forth today by President Roosevelt's Cabinet board in charge of public works.
PHILADELPHIA. June 22 (AP). -- The drive of St. Louis toward first place hit a snag today when the last-place Phillies handed the Cardinals a 9-to-3 defeat.

Charles E. Mitchell went to his Summer home at Southampton, L. I., yesterday for "an indefinite stay and a long rest." He declined to give any further information about his plans as he left his town house at 934 Fifth Avenue yesterday morning.

FRANKFORT, Mich., June 23. -- An airplane tragedy in Lake Michigan in which three men lost their lives was revealed tonight when the sole survivor, wife of one of the men, was rescued after clinging to a gasoline tank for thirty-three hours.

For eleven years "Ulysses," by James Joyce, has had wide recognition as a modern classic, but only bootleg sales in English-speaking countries, where some of the words and situations in the book have been considered obscene. Now Bennett Cerf, head of Random House and The Modern Library, wants to publish the book here.

LONDON, June 23 (AP). -- Conservative and Labor members of Parliament joined today in praising President Roosevelt as a man of action and comparing Chancellor of the Exchequer Neville Chamberlain unfavorably to the American Chief Executive.

For seven innings yesterday the Dodgers went out in monotonous order before the baffling slants of Larry French, Pirate southpaw, at Ebbets Field. Starting the eighth, they had no runs and only five hits.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 23. -- Qrville Gilley, missing star witness in the Scottsboro case and sole white man named as having witnessed the alleged attack upon Victoria Price and Ruby Bates by twelve Negroes, has returned to Alabama voluntarily to testify for the State.

Dr. Chaim Weizmann, Zionist leader, arrived yesterday from London on the Cunarder Berengaria to be the guest of honor at Jewish Day on July 3 at the Chicago Century of Progress Exposition. He was welcomed at Quarantine by Rabbi Solomon Goldman of Chicago, who had flown here as the representative of Governor Horner of Illinois.
Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large, came home yesterday on the Bremen for a visit, convinced that his labors abroad for disarmament have not been in vain.

Confident that the steps necessary to formation of an Edge Act bank to finance foreign trade can be completed within a few weeks and the bank put into actual operation within a month, directors of the American Manufacturers Export Association have authorized its president, James D. Mooney, to name a committee within a few days to solicit the backing necessary for the institution.

Ambassador Andre de Laboulaye came to New York yesterday to notify John D. Rockefeller Jr. that the French Republic had elevated him from the rank of commander, which he held heretofore in the Legion of Honor, to the next higher rank of grand officer.

Cardinal Hayes announced yesterday the transfers of nine assistants in Manhattan, seven in the Bronx and one in Westchester County. The Cardinal announced at the same time the appointment as parish assistants of thirty of the young men he ordained a fortnight ago in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
WASHINGTON, June 23. -- The army's allocations of funds in the $135,000,000 construction program recommended for work in army posts included the following:

HOT SPRINGS, Va., June 23 -- Senator Robert J. Bulkley of Ohio, a member of the subcommittee which was instrumental in forcing passage of the Glass-Steagall Bank Act, today answered the criticism of many banking leaders on the guaranteed deposits provision of the measure.

Forty representatives of organizations including in their membership most of the music teachers in New York City adopted unanimously last night a resolution protesting against the proposed taxation of music teachers and schools. They met at Steinway Hall, 113 West Fifty-seventh Street.

The Right Rev. James DeWolf Perry, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, is due to arrive in this city tonight from Vancouver. He arrived there a few days ago from a three months' inspection tour of missionary work in the Orient.

LONDON, June 23. -- The trend toward a much stabler attitude in the World Economic Conference toward the question of stabilizing the dollar was growing today, especially in influential British and French, quarters. This was partly owing to the fact that the real story behind the past fortnight's activities became better known.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (AP) -- The Cardinals' ace, Dizzy Dean, failed to stop the rush of the Phillies, who scored their sixth straight victory today by defeating the Red Birds, 9 to 4.

Bridgeport, Conn. A new issue of $841.000 city of Bridgeport (Conn.) bonds was awarded yesterday to a syndicate composed of Lehman Brothers, the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation, Fhelps, Fenn Co., Hannahs, Ballin Lee, the Bridgeport City Company, the R.F. Griggs Company and Christianson. McKinnon Co.

PULPIT HARBOR, North Haven Island, Me., June 23. -- With her lee rail awash and under full sail, the Amberjack II dashed spray high today while Skipper Roosevelt played hide and seek with the more prosaic craft that constitute his escort. It was a day of days for a yachtsman.

BERLIN, June 23. -- "Nothing short of a combination of three or four foreign powers can crush this new Germany," Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, Chancellor Hitler's "private foreign minister," told a gathering of foreign newspaper men today in the course of a carefully prepared and read statement on the government's foreign policies.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP). -- Testimony that the public paid as high as $28 a share for a stock issue which returned to the Arkansas Natural Gas Corporation an average price of $7.69 a share was given today in the Federal Trade Commission's public utilities investigation.

Arbitration of a business dispute is to bring more activity to the retail clothing centre on lower Broadway. The six-story Marks-Arnheim Building at the southwest corner of Ninth Street has been leased by Sailors' Snug Harbor to Jonas Schainuck, maker and retailer of men's clothing.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 23. -- Feathery air, or a sort of ballet breeze, that danced about without getting anywhere in particular, left the America's Cup yachts Weetamoe and Vanitie and twenty-six other racers floundering about today in the eighty-second annual regatta of the New York Yacht Club.

Wall Street enjoyed yesterday what was, by comparison with most other days of the last two or three months, a restful interlude. The turnover on the Stock Exchange fell to a mere 3,314,000 shares. This was not dull business by any means, but gave the brokers a chance to catch their breath.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Farm Act administrators decided today to establish an office for guarding the interests of consumers.

As a result of the new Federal Banking Act, which prevents members of the Federal Reserve System from paying interest on demand deposit accounts, several New York Stock Exchange firms have discontinued the paying of interest on credit balances of customers.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 23. -- S. Ellsworth Davenport 3d and John F. Ray failed In their attempt to carry off the doubles title and clinch the team trophy for Harvard today in the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships at the Ardsley Club.

Three rough-looking men approached a young man who was roller-skating in Central Park last night and, after an exchange of conversation, subjected him to such a manhandling that his condition at Lenox Hill Hospital later was reported to be critical.
ANDOVER, Mass., June 23. -- Phillips Academy, traditional stronghold of the Greek and Roman classics, made public today a new curriculum in which Latin is no longer compulsory for every student.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 23. -- Brig. Gen. George R. Dyer, as his final official act, reviewed 1,400 Guardsmen at Camp Smith here today. The Tenth Infantry of Albany and the Twenty-seventh Division Quartermaster Train of Brooklyn paraded in his honor as a tribute to his completion of forty-four years of service.

STROUDSBURG, Pa., June 23. -- A division of the country into "ten regional districts instead of forty-eight States was proposed at the conference of the League for Industrial Democracy at Camp Tamiment tonight by Professor Peter H. Odegard of Ohio State University.
TRENTON, N.J., June 23. -- Diplomas will be awarded to a class of 222 young men and women at commencement exercises of the Trenton State Teachers College and Normal School to be held tomorrow.

The General Assembly of Spiritualists, which, is holding its thirty-seventh, annual convention, welcomed the public -- at 50 and 75 cents per person -- to its first open session last night in the Hotel Astor.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., June 23. -- The condition of Mrs. Irene Strauss of Katonah, wife of Samuel Strauss, former treasurer of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was reported as critical tonight at the Northern Westchester Hospital. She was injured in an automobile accident on Tuesday.

A juror acted as examiner of a witness in General Sessions yesterday during the trial of Edward D. Maloney, former State trooper, charged with murder. Maloney is accused of having shot to death Larry Fay, racketeer, in the vestibule of his Casa Blanca night club in West Fifty-sixth Street on New Year's night.

The changes planned for the Frick property at Fifth Avenue and Seventieth Street in connection with ita use as a public art museum will cost $1,000,000, it was learned yesterday, when plans were filed with the Building Department. John Russell Pope, architect, has designed for the trustees of the Krick collection a new art reference library to be erected at 10 and 12 East Seventy-first Street and a one-story addition to the main building.

James S. Alexander, a member of the executive committee of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, who died on July 16, 1932, left an estate of $1,062,215 gross and $1,011,135 net, it was shown by a transfer-tax appraisal filed yesterday.

LONDON, June 23. -- With currency stabilization temporarily removed from the discussions, the commissions, committees and subcommittees of the World Economic Conference continued work today debating problems of a minor nature.

BERLIN, June 23. -- Practical self-effacement of the Reich Federation of Industry and of the labor unions and other employes' associations through "voluntary amalgamation" into an organization to be called the Reich Corporation of Industry has been unmistakably forecast today by Otto Wagener, the Commissar for Economy.

ATLANTA, June 23 (AP). -- The Governor of Georgia today tore up a notification of a suit filed against him in a State Superior Court and threw the fragments at the departing back of the process server.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 1/2 per cent for the best names. Thursday -- 1 1/2 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

LONDON, June 23. -- Ellsworth Vines Jr. and Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, fellow-Californians and Wimbledon champions, today appeared well on their way to new titles, the men's and women's singles of the London championships, as they gained the finals over fellow-American players.

The refusal of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York to join ten other bar associations in attacking the Irving Trust Company's so-called "monopoly in receiverships" at a meeting Thursday night was the subject of speculation yesterday among members of tha bar.

BOSTON, Mass., June 23. -- A loss of $74,861,644.56 last year, as compared with a decrease of $53,586,000 in 1931 was indicated in the annual report for 1932 of the Ford Motor Company, filed with Henry F. Long, State Commissioner of Corporations and Taxation, at the State House here today.

Economic reconstruction and universal, controlled disarmament are of greater importance to Europe at this time than revision of treaties, Dr. Franz Soukup, Socialist president of the Senate of Czechoslovakia and one of the leading political figures of his country, declared yesterday on his arrival on the Berengaria.

SHANGHAI, June 23. -- With the flood peril to millions of people increasing hourly in the valleys of China's two greatest rivers -- the Hwang (Yellow) and Yangtse -- the government at Nanking sent out a call today for an emergency national conference on flood prevention.

A crowd of 4,000 persons filled the St. Nicholas Arena last night to witness an amateur boxing tourney conducted by the Twelfth Assembly District, Democratic County Committee, for the benefit of the poor children of the district.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 23. -- Leaders in the qualifying round of the Westchester amateur golf championship tourney at the Winged Foot Golf Club were eliminated today in the opening rounds of match play.
NEW YORK. Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt left yesterday on their yacht, Winchester, to pass a few days in Newport.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Improved conditions in Canadian trade and a good business tone in the Philippines were reported by the Commerce Department today in its weekly review of foreign business conditions on the basis of advices from its representatives abroad.

PARIS, June 23. -- The United States delegation's definite refusal to consider currency stabilization at the World Economic Conference has produced what the semi-official newspaper, Le Temps, calls tonight "a deplorable impression on France."
Stanley Church, a member of the New Rochelle City Council, sent a letter to Mayor O'Brien yesterday rebuking him for discourtesy and his challenge of Mr. Church's official status.

BERLIN, June 23. -- The decision of Vereinigte Stahlwerke to pay interest on its dollar bonds in paper dollars, announced last night, caused a further slump on the Boerse today. Many securities dropped 4 to 5 per cent and Vereinigte Stahlwerke bonds lost between 6 and 7 per-cent.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The monetary Jam created by the London conference ought not to be used as an excuse for criticizing our delegation or sneering at the conference as a whole.

CLEVELAND, June 23 (AP). -- Paced by Dib Williams, the Athletics defeated the Indians for the second day in a row today, 8 to 4 and drew up to within a few percentage points of the losers in third place.

LONDON, June 23. -- Information reaching the best informed quarters here from sources in Germany which should be reliable is that the great weight of his years, in combination with the nerve-wracking experiences through which he has recently passed, is beginning to tell on the stalwart German President, Field Marshal von Hindenburg.

PEORIA, Ill., June 23 (AP). -- Garrett De Forrest Kinney, former director of State finances, wrote his own climax to an investigation of an alleged $526,000 shortage in his accounts today by shooting himself.
ST. PAUL, June 23 (AP). -- It is "up to the farmers" to make the new Federal laws function in their interests, Secretary Wallace said today.
The Police Academy School of Recruits will graduate 268 men, who will assume the rank of probationary patrolmen at exercises at 3 o'clock tomorrow afternoon in Yankee Stadium.

WATERTOWN, Conn., June 23, -- Upperland, Mrs. Harry Frank Jr.'s brown gelding, today captured the middleweight-hunter test, feature event of the second day of the seventh annual Watertown Horse Show. The program closes tomorrow.
Most members of the trout family are hard fighters, as can be testified to by veterans who have battled all species of the trout in various waters of the world.

THE way thing's are going in baseball, the pitchers will be the first In line asking for salary increases next Spring. Home runs are down. Shutouts are increasing. Low-hit games are common. There is some mystery as to what the manufacturers took out of the ball or put into the ball, but there is no doubt that the pitchers are putting plenty on the ball.

Financial interest was centred to a large extent yesterday in the agricultural staples. Stocks recovered their losses of the day before, but only after early indecision and after wheat and cotton had set them an example by moving confidently upward.

Stimulated by wheat's advance into new high ground and by optimistic views on acreage reduction, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved up a dollar a bale yesterday. Despite scale-selling limits at each point advance, the market absorbed all cotton offered, and March made a new high quotation for the movement at 10.6 cents.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Nothing is more distressing to those who are fighting for decent government in the City of New York than the misstatements made about so-called dissensions within the Fusion ranks. Those genuinely interested in Fusion and the elimination of Tammany are just as harmonious about it today as they were six months ago.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 23. -- The White Plains police are investigating several "mysterious" aspects of a kidnapping story related this morning by Walter Riegel, 18-year-old son of A.H. Riegel, contractor of Ridgeway in the Gedney Farm section of this city, when he returned from an absence of nearly two days.
WASHINGTON, June 23. --The War Department issued the following orders today:

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 23. -- Miss Helen Hicks regained one of her former titles today when she defeated Mrs. Marion Turpie Lake, 2 and 1, in the final round of the women's Long Island golf championship at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club.
HOYLAKE, England, June 23. -- The Hon. Michael Scott today became the hero of the British golfing world by making sure that the British amateur title would remain in the empire's possession.

Business continued its steady gains throughout the country last week and all leading centres of production and distribution reported improvements over the previous week, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc. In production lines manufacturers showed none of the hesitancy that was expected to develop because of uncertainty regarding the application of the processing tax.
Residential, business and farm properties were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 23. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, coated June 21:
Zoo authorities, the police and residents of the Spuyten Duyvil section of the Bronx were relieved yesterday when the mystery of the neighborhood's six-foot rattlesnakes was solved.

LONDON, June 23 (By Wireless). -- It is unfortunate the American delegates to the World Economic Conference could not have been entirely frank when they landed, but unfortunately the American delegation during the first week of the conference was as ignorant of the truth of its situation as though it had come from another planet.

TRENTON, N.J., June 23. -- Mercer County Prosecutor Erwin E. Marshall and Frederick Fitch of the State Department of Institutions and Agencies began today separate investigations into the death yesterday of an East Orange youth in Ten Acres Sanitarium, a Christian Science hospital in Princeton.
WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Movements of vessels follow. All dates are June 22 unless otherwise specified:

It comes as a shock to learn that, as Mr. HOPKINS, the Federal Relief Administrator, declared, many States and cities "are not spending a nickel" for relief of the unemployed. What is meant, doubtless, is that the sums spent for this purpose Toy these States and cities was covered by the amounts appropriated by the Federal Government, allocated to the States, and through the States to the communities.

The chief interest in the municipal bond market next week will centre on the issue of $26,595,000 State of New York bonds which will come up for award on Wednesday. Because of the magnitude of this Issue and the high credit rating of the State's bonds, it is generally expected that the price named for the bonds through competitive bidding will establish the current price level, at least, for the entire municipal market.

The annual garden fete yesterday afternoon at Greentree, the country place of Mrs. Payne Whitney at Manhasset, L.I., for the benefit of the Babies' Milk Fund of the New York Hospital and the Family Welfare Association of Nassau County, attracted more than 2,000 persons.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- Remarkable news from "scouting expeditions" into the "no man's land" of matter, the interior of the atom, was reported here today at the meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Permission for a modified form of price-fixing in air competition codes formulated under the National Industrial Recovery Act appeared to the administration today as the best way out of its first serious difficulty with business over the program for industrial control.

RYE, N.Y., June 23. -- Scoring her first major triumph in four years of play, Miss Betty Pietsch entered the championship circle today by winning the Westchester and Fairfield golf title. She turned back the 1932 champion, Miss Frances Snyder of Apawamis, 6 and 5, at the Westchester Country Club.
Lady Kemp of Toronto will sail tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. Others leaving on the ship include:

The dispute in Parliament over the charge that the British Exchange Equalization Fund is being used to create "inflation" is interesting chiefly as illustrating the elasticity of that word. In the Oxford Dictionary it is defined as "great or undue expansion; increase beyond proper limits, especially of prices, the issue of paper money,"
John F. Hylan, twice elected Mayor on a Democratic ticket, announced yesterday that he would enter the Republican primary in the Fall as a candidate for the Mayoralty.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP). -- Under the leadership of Representative Snell of New York, House Republicans are planning a vigorous campaign to recapture seats in that branch next year.

MOSCOW, June 23. -- The newspapers Pravda and Izvestia devoted half of their front pages today to pictures showing Joseph Stalin and Premier Molotoff bearing an urn containing the ashes of Clara Zetkin to their last resting place in the Kremlin wall and to pictures of the gigantic crowd that filled Red Square and the surrounding streets for miles.

A fashion pageant, followed by a supper-dance and special entertainment features, was given last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Broad Street Hospital. The ballroom was decorated to represent the sports deck of the liner Rex, and a mural scene in the background showed the Rock of Gibraltar.

Prices moved irregularly yesterday in local commodity markets. Cocoa and silk were higher, sugar and rubber uneven, while silver and coffee were lower. Trading was relatively quiet. Several new high records for this year were made in cash prices.

ALBANY, June 23 (AP). -- A plan for controlling the production of milk in New York State by penalizing farmers who overproduce, may be put into effect within a few days, Charles H. Baldwin, chairman of the State Milk Control Board, announced today.

Partly as a result of its first increase in freight revenue in many months, the Pennsylvania Railroad reported Improved net operating income for May. Freight revenue increased $498,000 to 519,656,000.

The Eastern presidents' conference will meet on Tuesday to select a regional railroad committee for the East to act with Joseph B. Eastman, Federal railroad moderator. The decision to hold the meeting followed approval by Mr. Eastman of a grouping of the Eastern lines proposed by the Association of Rail-way Executives.
NEWARK, N.J., June 23 (AP). -- Myril Hoag's 400-foot home run with two on in the eighth inning gave the Bears a 3-1 victory over Jersey City today.
Colonel Lindbergh's gray stone house on Sourland Mountain, near Hopewell, N.J., scene of a shocking tragedy of childhood, will be devoted henceforth to welfare work for children.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Loan authorizations and advances by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation showed another decrease in May, the total being $169,635,492.83 as compared with $205,582,631.38 in April, a drop of $35,947,138.55. The monthly report was made public today by the Clerk of the House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics of the U.S. Department of Labor announces that its index numbers of whole sale prices for the week ending June 17 stands at 64.5 as compared with 64.0 for the week ending June 10, showing an increase of approximately eight-tenths of 1 per cent.

The first phase of the $25 a share assessment action against the 20,800 stockholders of the defunct Bank of United States was closed yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Lydon directed what was tantamount to a judgment against 170 of the largest stockholders of the institution.
SHANGHAI, June 23. -- A declaration of independence for the North China area neutralized under the truce with Japan was issued today by a group of renegade Chinese Generals.
HENDON, England, June 23. -- Great Britain's flying year will culminate this week-end in two air displays that promise to overshadow all previously held.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- To make room for more Democrats, a group of House party leaders appealed today to Postmaster General Farley to recommend an executive order virtually to dismiss about 4,600 Government employes who in the last twelve years, they contend, were "blanketed into" the Civil Service by Presidents Harding, Coolidge and Hoover.
CHICAGO, June 23. -- Barney Ross waded through the merciless fists of Tony Canzoneri tonight to take the lightweight championship of the world from the New York titleholder.
BARNSTABLE, Mass., June 23 (AP). -- The defense of Kenneth Buck, hooded man of the McMath kidnapping, closed today after his aged mother testified in his behalf.

Silas H. Strawn of Chicago, chairman of the American committee of the International Chamber of Commerce, accompanied by Mrs. Strawn and John P. Gregg, manager of the American section of the chamber, returned yesterday on the Cunarder Berengaria.

The Hwang Ho is a river that makes its bed but refuses to lie in it. Ever since the Chinese have had a record of events, the great stream has been spillingg its waters upon the Great Plain either northward or southward of Kaifeng, and using one or the other of its channels on the way to the sea.

DETROIT, June 23. -- In the investigation of the two closed banks, the First National and Guardian National, now being made by Judge Harry B. Keidan, a request will be made of the Treasury Department by the "one-man grand jury" that every officer or agent who had anything to do with the closing of the institutions be sent to Detroit to testify.
Yesterday's TIMES reported three financial items of unusual interest, each offering ground for encouragement.

HOYLAKE, England, June 23 (AP). -- A bewildering twist in the annual battle for the British amateur golf championship brought defeat today to the twin favorites, George T. Dunlap Jr. and Cyril Tolley, leaving in their stead two country gentlemen to play 36 holes tomorrow in the final round for the historic trophy.

MADRID, June 23. -- Rioting broke out in a score of places in Madrid today as gangs raced through the streets, shouting and ripping white banners bearing the emblem of the Sacred Heart off houses and shops and burning them.

Friday, June 23, 1933. Quiet conditions prevailed in all sections of the money market, and quotation for all classifications remained unchanged. Stock Exchange call loans ruled at 1 per cent and Street trades at 1/8@3/4.
An attack upon the projected St. Lawrence seaway from the Great Lakes to the Atlantic as too costly and unlikely to benefit American shippers was made last night by Senator Royal S. Copeland.
CHICAGO, June 23 (AP). -- Washington's fast-traveling Senators ran their streak to eleven victories in twelve games today, making it three in a row over the White Sox. The score was 7 to 3.

Municipal Court Justice Leopold Prince and his symphony orchestra of 100 players will give the first of three outdoor concerts this Summer, tonight on the Mall in Central Park. Compositions by Weber, Handel, Haydn, Rameau, Dvorak and Strauss will be on the program.

At a convention here of delegates from fifty-six Roman Catholic colleges and universities throughout the country, for the declared purpose of formulating "Catholic thought" on the new deal, the Rev. Dr. John A. Ryan, Professor of Political Economy at the Catholic University in Washington, said last night:

A twenty-hour struggle with a swordfish, which, when finally boated, was found to weigh 450 pounds, was disclosed yesterday. The person who hooked this giant sword, the first taken in local waters on rod and reel this season, was Mrs. Oliver C. Grinnell of Bay Shore, L.I., one of the best known woman anglers in this country.
PARIS, June 23 (AP). -- A new system of eliminations for Davis Cup play in the European zone which will reduce the competitors next year to eight nations was announced today.

Mr. Khayyam, winner of three of the season's 3-year-old specials and generally considered the best of the age seen so far, will get the acid test this afternoon when he essays the mile and a half of the Dwyer Stakes at Aqueduct.

After a session or almost six months, with occasional recesses, the New Jersey Legislature adjourned until Aug. 29, when it will meet to make a final disposition of beer legislation. Until Sept. 1 the present methods of selling beer will prevail; by a new enactment the sale of beer will be permitted on Sunday after 1 o'clock in the afternoon.

ALBANY, June 23. -- The names of twenty successful candidates in the State-wide competition for industrial teacher scholarships were announced today by Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education. The contest, an annual one, is designed to obtain men and women with requisite trade and technical qualifications who wish to become teachers.
These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area:
The list of causes for which licenses to sell or brew beer will be revoked was made public yesterday by the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There has been too much talk about who will be the anti-Tammany candidate for Mayor, and not enough emphasis on the principles which should unite the forces for good government.

District Attorney Charles S. Colden of Queens expressed regret yesterday over the refusal of the Governor to call a special session of the Legislature to investigate the Public Service Commission and to obtain lower utility rates.
LONDON, June 23. -- The last of the season's five courts at Buckingham Palace tonight was the most brilliant of all. King George was present for the first time this year.

BERLIN, June 23. -- The bottom of the world depression has been reached and henceforth business will improve if no new political disturbances occur, the German Institute for Business Research asserts in its quarterly review.
Formation or three Stock Exchange firms -- Monahan Cohn, Barry Hughes and Taylor Delaney -- has been proposed, it was announced yesterday. The firm of Logan Bryan is in liquidation.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 23. -- The integration of Jewish racialists and Jewish nationalists in the synagogue is the principal issue before the Jews in America today, Rabbi Isaac Landman of Congregation Both Elohim, Brooklyn, N.Y., told the Central Conference of American Rabbis in the annual conference address here tonight.

Trading in the listed bond market lacked zest yesterday. Domestic corporation issues moved irregularly higher, while leading foreign loans were irregularly lower. United States Government bonds sold off 1-32 to 6-32 point with the exception of the first Liberty 4s, which moved up 1-32.

ST. LOUIS, June 23. -- Five New Jersey labor leaders were found guilty of misuse of their powers after a trial before the general executive board of the International Association of Bridge. Structural and Ornamental Iron Workers here today and were ousted from, membership in the union.
Charlotte (Lottie) Kreisberger Coll, widow of the Bronx gunman, Vincent Coll, who was killed by enemies over a year ago, was arrested with two men in a midtown hotel yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, June 23. -- The question of gradually removing the mass of restrictions, prohibitions and quotas that have choked international trade in recent years was further discussed in the commercial policy committee of the world economic conference today.

Less than six months ago a new college came into being in New York City. Last night its first seventy-one graduates received their degrees in the first commencement exercises, which, for lack of a campus, were held in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ST. LOUIS, June 23. -- The Yankees slugged their way to victory over the Browns, 10 to 6, at Sportsmans Park today in the first game of a twin bill, then lost the nightcap, 5 to 4, and with it the lead in the pennant race. The Senators now lead by half a game.

For twelve days notice was withheld from the police that a woman inmate of the Brooklyn State Hospital for the Insane had been strangled to death accidentally while confined in a "restraining vest," it became known last night.
The Board of Estimate cleared the way yesterday for highway improvements estimated to cost more than $8,000,000 and which Mayor O'Brien said would provide a substantial number of jobs.

NEWARK, N.J., June 23. -- Hijackers disarmed two Federal agents today in a large alcohol plant at 25 Coes Place, loaded 900 gallons of the spirits on a truck and drove away, passing a uniformed policeman on guard at the door. They left the agents' service weapons on a desk before departing.
Storm Jameson's autobiography -- close-knit impressions gathered during her thirty-six years -- is published today by Alfred A. Knopf with the title "No Time Like the Present."

To the Editor of The New York Time: Tour editorial "Impediments to Fusion" discusses certain apparent dissensions within the Republican party. It states: "We are far from blaming Mr. Macy, but is it not in his power to be a good chairman, as he sees his duty, and a good fusionist?"

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 23. -- Forty-two yachts tugged at their cables in the harbor tonight, ready for tomorrow's start in the ocean race to Gibson Island, Md., sponsored by the Gibson Island Yacht Squadron.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- While the American delegates to the World Monetary and Economic Conference have been advancing a program in London, Democratic Senators have been conferring here on conditions for putting the administration's domestic economic program into successful operation.

Almost Yanked Home. A week's notice is short time for American trade commissioners and commercial attaches in Europe to pull up stakes and catch the boat for home and retirement. Seventy officials with their families sailed from Havre on Thursday after doing just that: breaking house leases, disposing of household goods at a sacrifice, removing children from school, and the like.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- The gigantic public works phase of the national recovery program, was set in motion today with allotment of $400,000,000 in road funds to States and Territories, and submission by the War Department of a $135,000,000 program for reconditioning army posts and national cemeteries.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- Public buying in tremendous volume has been attracted to the grain markets in the last two days by what is now regarded by the trade as one of the worst crop calamities in many years.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP). -- Within the next thirty days the Home Loan Bank board hopes to have the Home Owners Loan Corporation going to the relief of mortgage-burdened persons all over the country.

Public utilities in the New York area had an average return of 8.3 per cent on their net worth in 1932, according to testimony introduced yesterday at a hearing of the Public Service Commission. Net worth was defined as "capital stock plus surplus."

CHICAGO, June 23. -- A semblance of peace was restored tonight to the meeting of oil marketing and refining executives when a decision was reached by the code drafting committee to file separate reports on the controversial issues.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 23. -- Police Captain August Winkelmann encountered a pretty "boy" on the street here today and his curiosity brought to an end the masquerade of June Clark of Needham, Mass., who sought freedom and movie fame.

Extracts published in yesterdays TIMES from Judge HORTON'S opinion, in Alabama, setting aside the verdict of guilty against HAYWOOD PATTERSON af being against the weight of evidence and ordering a new trial, can but heighten the great and general respect which he has won.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., June 23. -- A new deal in government by cleaning out "corruption, graft, fraud and extravagance in high places and low" was demanded by Louis Johnson, National Commander of the American Legion, in an address tonight before 500 members Of the organization in the Twelfth district.

DOES Long Beach call you? Do you yearn for the burning sun of St. Jean de Luz? Does the silvery sand of one of Lake Michigan's beaches promise you respite from the heat of your home town? Maybe it is only a sweet pool in an Adirondack stream, or a tiled pool set in an emerald lawn?
PARIS. WEEK-ENDING and commuting are, considered from the sartorial standpoint, two faces of the same coin -- one looking from town toward the country and the other taking just the opposite view.

An increased demand for home accommodations in and around Jackson Heights, Queens, is predicted by Edward A. MacDougall, president of the Queensboro Corporation, following the opening of the new subway link extending from Eigthth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, Manhattan, to Roosevelt Avenue and Queens Boulevard in the Borough of Queens.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Pressure for recognition by the United States of the Soviet Government of Russia came from two sources today, Senator Norris and the United States Board of Trade urging that step be taken to aid economic recovery.

The annual convention of the New York State Bankers Association, which opens tomorrow at Bolton Landing, Lake George, will have before it for discussion the revolutionary changes which confront the banking world as a result of the enactment of the Glass-Steagall bill in the closing days of the special session of Congress.

The function of the government under the Industrial Recovery Act is confined to seeing that the interests of all the people, labor, capital and the consuming public, are projected properly and represented Adequately, Postmaster General James A. Parley said yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, June 24 -- The Yankees did some fast and furious hitting early in this afternoon's closing struggle at Sportsman's Park and vanquished the Browns, 8 to 4.

HOLLYWOOD. ITS annual holiday ended, the Warner Brothers' studio this week began an active season with thirty scripts virtually ready and awaiting the stages. The rumored raid by Darryl Zanuck's recently created Twentieth Century Company upon actors, writers and directors failed to materialize and the studio found itself with the same personnel as last season, with three exceptions, and with three added stars and eight new featured players.

LOS ANGELES, June 24 (AP) -- Dean Bartlett Cromwell, University of Southern California track coach whose team won its fourth straight I.C.A.A.A.A. championship recently and then lost to Louisiana State in the National Collegiate A.A. meet, today picked an all-intercollegiate team.

BERLIN, June 24 -- The newspaper Voelkische Beobachter, Nazi organ, in an editorial on the London conference holds that, besides Germany, only the United States has taken a rational position. The reason for this praise is that, in the newspaper's opinion, "the United States espouses economic nationalism," as the Nazis do.

Rebus-solvers and others who are accustomed to search words for hidden and obscure meanings will agree with the Roosevelt administration that nothing it has said or done justified any one in believing that it favored de facto currency stabilization for the period of the World Economic and Monetary Conference. But a citation of the record will require all fair-minded persons to admit that the administration steadily gave the impression that it did.

THIS is the sixth successive year that the firm of Minton, Balch has opened the season for Summer fiction with a novel from the pen of Alice Grant Rosman. These novels of English upper-middle-class people have won a large following in America -- and deservedly so.

SOUTHWEST HARBOR, Mount Desert Island, Maine, June 24 -- President Roosevelt sailed briskly tonight through twilight and darkness to this port from Pulpit Harbor. He was delayed there until late this afternoon by a dead calm and trouble with the auxiliary motor of his Schooner, the Amberjack II.

THE popular concerts of the Musicians Symphony Orchestra, originally planned to take place in Playland, at Rye, will change their locale to the County Center at White Plains. This spacious auditorium will be transformed into a garden with trees, pools, flowers and plants.

ALL men everywhere want happiness; most men want security. Few things are more interesting than the methods used to bring about these desired results. Those employed by the Chinese, and the ideas of man's relation to the universe which they reflect, are set forth in Professor Harvey's very interesting volume, a book which is the fruit of many years spent in China, as well as of much study of Chinese folklore and beliefs.

DEFINITE assurance of a schedule of sixteen hours from Los Angeles to New York this Summer is now at hand. E.R. Breech, General Motors executive and president of North American Aviation, and Richard W. Robbins, president of Transcontinental and Western Air, have returned from trial flights in the new Northrop transport on the Pacific Coast.
CLEVELAND, June 24 (AP) -- Lefty Grove bagged his tenth victory of the season and put the Philadelphia Athletics into third place in the American League standings today by beating Cleveland, 6 to 2.
PARIS. June 24 (AP) -- The Cabinet unanimously approved today the French stand at the World Economic Conference for the gold standard and for regulation of world production.

A dozen of the youths who dive for coins at the Battery demonstrated their aquatic prowess yesterday afternoon by outdistancing three policemen who took to the water to take them in tow. It was a Pyrrhic victory, however, because the coin divers had to leave their overalls, shirts, shoes and socks behind them when they scurried across Battery Park, headed for home and safety.

Joseph P. Day said yesterday that he was pleased at Everett A. Brett's endorsement of his recommendation that long-term mortgages rather than the short-term loans should prevail more generally in the future, but he did not agree with Mr. Brett's view that the interest rate should be lower than 5 per cent.

MR. MORLEY has not yet gone off the sugar standard. In these new verses about the humor, tenderness and genera dandiness of life in Manhattan his meandering Old Mandarin is very much his same old self. Be wanders about the island making such discoveries as this: that fraudulent electricians stuff nickels behind ruse plugs to keep them from blowing.
TRENTON. N.J., June 24 -- Commissioner William J. Ellis of the State Department of Institutions and Agencies suspended today the right of the Ten Acres Sanitarium, near Princeton, to accept patients.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 24 -- Forty-seven members of the teaching staff of Rutgers University have been dropped, Robert C. Clothier, president, announced today. All are in the colleges for men. The cut in the staff was necessitated by the 20 per cent cut in the appropriation made by the State Legislature on Monday for the university, following a 23 per cent slash last year.

CHICAGO, June 24. -- The most radical of the recent reports of crop deterioration are gradually being confirmed, and a tardy recognition of the sensational losses in small grains in the last three weeks brought in buying that carried all deliveries of wheat, corn, oats, rye and barley to new high levels for the season.
Permanent employment of 2,000,000 men is envisaged in President Roosevelt's plan to stabilize the forest industries under the National Recovery Act, it was learned here yesterday.

One of the factors brought out at the recent Chicago meeting of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers was that some clear distinction should be made between the present day market price of a parcel of real estate and its value as collateral for a loan or other purposes.

Is the most effective college teacher usually also a research worker or one who devotes his whole attention to instruction? On no question is academic opinion probably more sharply divided. Of recent years President Hamilton Holt of Rolling College in Winter Park, Fla., has perhaps been the most outspoken champion of the theory that the professor's job Is to teach and that he cannot serve two masters.

MIDDLE SEPIC RIVER, British New Guinea. IT was trussed like a pig, bound in a net hammock to one long pole, that I arrived in the village of Alitoa, after a two days' carry from the coast. My bearers whooped and shouted as they climbed the last steep slippery incline and deposited me in the middle of an excited crowd, many of whom had never seen a white woman before.

NEWARK, N.J., June 4 -- Humbrooke, trotting mare owned and driven by Jim Hay of South Orange, and Cynara, trotting filly from the Newbrook stables, took the feature races during the matinee of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

The Greenwich Savings Bank at Thirty-sixth Street, Broadway and Sixth Avenue, will celebrate Its 100th anniversary next Saturday. Charles M. Dutcher, its president, recently marked his fiftieth anniversary of service with the bank.

BERLIN. ONE does not like to pack one's vacation suitcase with books that deal with grave problems. Poetry or belleslettres that harmonize with nature are preferable, or a love story of elegiacal cast -- for who does not fall in an elegiacal mood as he lies in a meadow and hears the chirping of the crickets?

THE automobile, which plays so large a role in the national life, figures prominently in the Federal Administration's far-reaching program envisioned in the National Industrial Recovery Act. Under both the industrial and the public works sections of the act the motor car in its varied phases is called upon to contribute vitally toward the country's economic improvement.
LONDON, June 24 -- Stanley Baldwin, Lord Privy Seal, has kept strangely quiet in recent weeks.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- The estate of John R. Fell, Philadelphia and New York, sportsman who died of a knife wound In Solo, Java, on Feb. 21, probably is insolvent, according, to a petition filed with the Orphans' Court here.

DOVER, Del., June 24 -- Delaware's seventeen delegates to the State convention, in a session which lasted less than an hour, ratified the Twenty-first Amendment to the Federal Constitution, which repeals the Eighteenth Amendment.
LONDON. THOUGH George Moore died In January, his remains were not interred until the end bf May, when an urn containing his ashes was buried in a cairn on an islet in Lough Carra, County Mayo.

Six new shelters for hiker will be erected this Summer on the marked trails and old wood roads in the Harriman and Bear Mountain sections of the Palisade Interstate Park, the park commissioners announced yesterday. There are seven shelters in the park now.

CLAUDE RAINS, of the Broadway stage and more particularly of the Theatre Guild, has signed a contract with Universal which will allow him six months in Hollywood and six months on Broadway. Mr. Rains will make his picture debut in the title role of H.G. Wells's "The Invisible Man," which James Whale will put into production this week.

THE following officers and directors were elected at the annual meeting of the College Art Association, which was held in Chicago June 15, 16 and 17: President, Professor John Shapley; vice president, Professor Charles Rufus Morey; secretary, Professor A. Philip McMahon; treasurer, Blake-More Godwin; executive secretary, Audrey McMahon.

WHAT Mr. Maxim has given us in this book is a popular survey of the present state of cosmogony, astronomy, astrophysics, and biology, the whole more or less tied together by an examination of the conditions under which life may exist in the universe and under which it developed on the earth.

The annual June walk of the John A. Hogan Democratic Club from its headquarters at 46 West Street to Battery Park, recruited yesterday 2,500 children of the lower west side. The girls and boys picnicked and played in the park.

FOLKESTONE, England, June 24 (AP) -- The United States team was proclaimed the winner in the joint meeting of the International Chess Federation and the British Chess Federation which came to an end today with the award of prizes at the Town Hall attended by the Mayor.

WILLIAM C. PRESTON died in 1860. at the age of 66, after an active, eminent and influential life. He wrote these reminiscences, which deal only with his younger days, toward the end of his life, with no expectation they would ever be published, but intending them merely for the entertainment and information of a young namesake.
CHICAGO, June 24 (AP). -- Big Brand, owned by T.H. McCaffrey of Latonia, Ky., galloped to victory in the Francis S. Peabody Memorial Handicap, with $3,000 added, before 15,000 spectators today.

ON the basis of a survey of the international labor situation, conducted by the International Labor Office, interesting conclusions with regard to the employment of women have been drawn by Dr. Marguerite Thibert, writing in The International Labor Review.

BERLIN, June 24 -- The progress the German press has made since the Reichstag fire last February in identifying itself with the more emotional aspects of the national revolution was evidenced today in the trumpet blasts of indignation over the reported air raid yesterday afternoon.

At London practice has met theory, and, so far, theory has lost. In theory the statesmen of the world were to have met in the British capital and, in general concessions on national prerogatives, were to have made international plans for the good of the world. But that has not happened yet. There has been a plethora of effort for special advantages; there has been an absence of conciliation.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 24 -- Forty-two yachts of assorted sizes and carrying various rigs cleared this port today to begin the ocean race to Gibson's Island, Md., approximately 475 nautical miles away.

Bonds on the Stock Exchange manifested a moderate degree of strength yesterday, particularly railroad issues, several of which entered new high ground for the year. Leading foreign loans averaged a shade higher, and United States Government bonds closed 4-32 point higher to 3-32 point lower in light trading.
FORTHCOMING BOOKS FICTION "THE SNOWS OF HELICON." H. M. Tomlinson. (Harper Brothers.) August.

Factories in more than a dozen industries will operate at top speed through the normally inactive Summer months this season, due to a sudden trend toward advance buying on the part of retailers, a survey among manufacturers of consumer goods revealed last week.

RICHMOND, Va., June 21 -- The wet tide rolling over these United States from Hoboken to the Golden Gate has engulfed Virginia. Nothing seems more certain at the moment than that the old dominion will go for repeal by a large majority, if and when a referendum is held.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Bureau of Navigation Issued the following orders today, dated June 22:

BARNSTABLE, Mass., June 24 -- Kenneth Buck was convicted tonight by a Cape Cod jury of kidnapping 10-year-old Margaret (Peggy) McMath. He was sentenced to not less than twenty-four and not more than twenty-five years in State prison.

SOME easing down of retail trade was reported last week and not readily accounted for by store executives. This took place toward the middle of the week and for lack of other reasons was explained as a natural reaction from the recent spurt.

THE National Industrial Recovery Act marks, in some respects, the beginning of a new business dispensation. Its effects may be far-reaching. Many implications, even doctrinal heresies, have been read into it by those who are dubious of its orthodoxy in the light of our traditional economic policy.

ONCE again, in "Little Friend," a novelist takes a tour de force into the mind of a child -- but this time not out of concern so much for the child itself, as for the domestic problems of its parents. Herr Lothar, who is a Viennese playwright and critic, has cleverly used the consciousness of the girl,

DALLAS, Texas, June 21 -- The heavy movement of Texas farm products to their many markets has begun. The movement usually continues through December, a seven-month period during which practically the whole farm income of the State is made and, as a consequence, most of the business income directly dependent upon it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is an interesting and pertinent question to ask: What is the greatest possible measure that may be adopted for economic relief and the restoration of prosperity? An attempt is made to answer it in the pamphlet "Up-to-Date History of the Movement to Delegalize War," written by R.W. Van Demark.

WHILE John Henry, that giant legendary figure of the deep South, has been striding through the imaginations of the Negroes for years, it was Roark Bradford who turned imagination into vivid print and John Henry came to life between the covers of a book.

LONDON. ONE of the strangest clauses in the Versailles Peace Treaty, requiring Germany to hand over to England the skull of an African sultan, came up again for discussion the other day in the British Souse of Commons.

LONDON, June 24 -- The World Economic Conference this week suffered a serious setback equal in importance to the encouraging forward impetus it had received last week. In both cases, the principal cause was outside the conference itself and arose out of the position and policy of the United States.
BERLIN, June 24 -- The Boerse session was characterized today by considerable fluctuations which left quotations almost unchanged for the day.

LONDON, June 22 -- The latest political upheaval in Germany, which virtually renders powerless the Nationalist party, by whose aid Adolf Hitler climbed into power, and also eliminates the Socialist party, leaves the National Socialists unchallengeable save by the Catholic Centrists. These happenings have again focused attention upon Europe's sorest spot.

Having destroyed MATTHEW ABNOLD and restored Mr. POPE, Miss EDITH SITWELL has Just been touring tolerantly among" The English Eccentries." The English have been traditionally strong in these characters, no longer so common as they used to be Perhaps the country can't afford them.
The taxing of sales of commodities and of other classes of property for purposes of public finance is of ancient origin. The taxing of retail sales, however, is of comparatively recent introduction.

BERLIN, June 1 ON the Berlin stage the first great swell of "revolution" has receded, leaving the theatre chilled but unpolitical. When the nationalistic Hitler government came in, there was a flutter of dramas that attempted to catch the public in its first enthusiasm for the "Oh, say can you see" spirit.

The Giants wrenched a swift-moving struggle from the Reds at the Polo Grounds yesterday, 5 to 2. That seemed to convince a gathering of 10,000 that the current pace setters in the National League are occupying their present lofty position considerably more through skill and design than mere chance.

LONDON, June 24 (AP) -- Having fought their way through two thrilling weeks of the World Economic Conference, the American delegates, many of whom were new to international deliberations on their arrival here, emerged tonight as experienced campaigners in the give and take of world diplomacy.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- More than 10,000 young men of the Civilian Conservation Corps will be transferred daily from conditioning to forest work camps during the remainder of the month. This will complete the schedule of 274,000 men set by President Roosevelt for the end of June.
James W. Gerard made known yesterday that he planned court action to obtain the right to inspect the books of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation, of which he is a stockholder.

In his address to the graduating class at Ratcliffe College last week Mr. OWEN YOUNG assumed, for hetorical purposes, the guise of " an encrusted specimen of an earlier day." But he at once proceeded to show that he has a mind as fresh as ever, as keen in distinctions, as shrewd in observation, as fruitful in ideas.

Passenger traffic on the Pennsylvania Railroad trains out of New York has increased "substantially" in the past two months and gives indication of a greater expansion in the remainder of the year, according to George Le Boutillier, vice president.

FOR "his encouragement of fundamental research in automotive engineering," Fred M. Zeder, vice president of Chrysler Corporation in charge of engineering, has been awarded the degree of Master of Engineering by the University of Michigan.

ENDLESSLY fascinating, as embodied in the Century of Progress art exhibition in Chicago, is the drama of give-and-take, of relationship and contrast. Especially when, as in this superb collection of pictures, we are provided with a majestic historical vista, art is seen to be alive with clues, each one of which may lead who knows whither.

A ONE-VOLUME history of the world since 1914, even when the narrative runs to more than 650 large pages, is obviously not the place to look for new material. Professor Langsam, however, has done his work with scholarly thoroughness and sound judgment, and a good style makes his book easy reading.
PARIS, June 24 -- Despite the depressing effect of the World Economic Conference, this has been a lively week in Paris.
FRANKFORT, Mich., June 24 -- A dramatic story of self-sacrifice by three men who gave their lives that a woman might live was told by Mrs. Charles Rennie Jr., 27, of Traverse City, Mich., today.

A NEW issue of the monthly magazine Gebrauchsgraphik, or International Advertising Art, with text in both German and English, has just appeared. Besides presenting, always most engagingly, the work of various artists in various fields, the number at hand discusses "Plus a Little Something Some Others Haven't Got," "Young Talent at the Akademie fur Graphische Kunste und Buchgewerbe, Leipzig." "Age and Youth in Advertising" and "Window Display."

HOYLAKE, Eng., June 24 -- The Hon. Michael Scott, at 55 the oldest player ever to win the British amateur golf championship, today maintained the traditional uncertainty of this sporting classic by decisively beating Thomas A. Bourn, a 30-year-old countryman, in the thirty-six-hole final match.

White-faced but nonchalant, Lottie Coll, widow of Vincent Coll, slain gangster, stood under the Klieg lights in the line-up room at Police Headquarters yesterday and exchanged repartee with her questioners.

MILWAUKEE, June 24 -- Philosophers who have attempted to dovetail "the implied creed and implicit character of Judaism with the ideologies of modern Humanism, secular Hebraism and a non-religious-even irreligious-type of nationalism," were denounced by Rabbi Bernard Heller of Ann Arbor, Mich., in an address made before the Central Conference of American Rabbis tonight.

The Railroad Law passed by Congress on June 16 will have its first application this week, a development considered prompt in view of the time often consumed between passage and enforcement of a law. The new law will be applied first to rates and to coordination.
Hugh S. Gibson, who is retiring as United States Ambassador to Belgium to become the Ambassador to Brazil, returned from Europe yesterday on the United States liner President Roosevelt.

At the Lido Country Club, Lido Beach, L.I., not far from the famous seaside golf links and scarcely more than a stone's throw from the ocean, the women's metropolitan clay court tennis championship will start tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- An appeal to unorganized workers of the nation to unite to obtain "all the rights and benefits" of the National Recovery Act went forth today from President William Green of the American Federation of Labor.

Mayor Bernard F. Dickman of St. Louis announced here yesterday that he had asked the Public Works Administration in Washington for $30,000,000 to finance the building of an express highway link through the heart of his city.

BETWEEN the recently ended activities of the regular season and the full swing of a Summer which is exceptional in the extent of its dance program, it is well, perhaps, to pause long enough to consider something of the last year's accomplishment.

VANCOUVER, June 19 -- With the problem of a better deal in world trade being actively sifted at the London Conference, the people of British Columbia, whose trade with the United States has been hard hit by the Smoot-Hawley tariff, are finding it difficult to concentrate on the maneouvres of international statesmen, owing to confusion in their own provincial politics.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 24 -- Members of the New York Athletic Club and their guests, a company of 1,500, attended a carnival held tonight on the lawns of its Travers Island clubhouse, overlooking Long Island Sound. Judge Sydney A. Syme of Bronxville and Gene Sanger headed a large committee of prominent Westchester residents in making arrangements.

LONDON, June 24 -- Ellsworth Vines Jr., the United States and Wimbledon tennis champion, told The Associated Press today he "might seriously consider" an offer of $100,000 to turn professional after this season. But he denied any such offer had been made to him, as reported in New York, and insisted he had no plans whatever to desert amateur tennis.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Two Democratic Governors, swept into power on the tidal wave of the new deal -- the one in Illinois, the other in Wisconsin-are nearing the end of their first experience in handling State Legislatures. Prolonged sessions have marked the efforts of the lawmakers in the adjoining States, but before July 1 they will be happily free from the strain and worry of their duties.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 24 -- F.C. Chapman annexed the High Scratch cup at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today with, a card of 50 straight targets.

MAN does not make war alone but draws into its horrible turmoil his friends and helpers in the animal world, mostly for the assistance they can give him, but sometimes also for the pleasure and solace he can find in their companionship, their devotion and their loyalty.
JOSE ITURBI left the United States the end of April a pianist and seems likely to return a full-fledged conductor according to press dispatches from Mexico City and from his management.

While the new tax provisions incorporated in the National Industrial Recovery Act may in some cases be regarded as both burdensome and Inequitable, their total effect on general industry will be comparatively slight, Dr. Joseph J. Klein of Klein, Hinds Fincke, certified public accountants, declared here yesterday.

Still a bit dazed by the shock of the extraordinary performances at the N.C.A.A. meet, track followers will have to brace themselves again this week-end for another series of dazzling exploits. The American track and field championships will be staged at Soldier Field, Chicago, on Thursday, Friday and Saturday, with practically all of the college winners entered against the picked athletes of the country.

JEROME KERN sailed for England last Friday to set musical wheels in motion on behalf of "One More Spring." He will meet Oscar Hammerstein 2d and the pair of them will create the operatic version of Robert Nathan's novel.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 21 -- Springing into action almost overnight. Arkansas Drys, apparently spurred on by a national organization that is fighting with its back to the wall, have turned back to the doubtful column a traditionally dry State.

BERLIN. WERNER SCHOLZ'S exhibition at the Hartberg Gallery has aroused real enthusiasm in art circles here. Scholz is no meteor suddenly shot across the heavens. His triangular proletarian heads of misery, of defeated workers, of wohegone women, of hollow-cheeked children, still stick in our memory from many an earlier exhibition.

RUMSON, N.J., June 24 -- Champion Gilroy's Chief Topic, a grand English setter owned by W.F. Gilroy of Pittston, Pa., won best-in-show honors and the President's Cup at the annual exhibition of the Monmouth County Kennel Club today on the Harding estate here.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- In the central switchboard of the human brain, the number of individual lines which connect the brain cells one with another has been recently calculated to be represented by the figure of numeral one followed by fifteen million ciphers, the American Association for the Advancement of Science was told today by Professor C. Judson Herrick of the University of Chicago.

PARIS, June 23 -- Urged on by many members of Parliament, by circumstances and by the example of the United States, the French Government may soon take upon itself "full powers" for the reorganization of national finance. Nothing seems to have been decided yet, but the Chamber of Deputies and the press are full of rumors and arguments.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (AP) -- The Phillies and Cardinals split a double-header today, the home team winning the first game, 10-7, to run their string of consecutive triumphs to seven. St. Louis, aided by excellent pitching by Carleton, snapped the victory streak In the second game, 5-1.

A new culture, made up of elements of the cultures of many peoples, is being built up in Palestine by Jews, said Molly Picon, Jewish theatrical star, on her return yesterday with her husband from a three-month trip through Palestine, Russia and other countries.

LONDON, June 24 -- Rain won the opening tilt in the season's first test cricket match between England and the British West Indies today, bringing play to a halt at Lord's after England had scored 43 runs for no wickets.

AMONG the numerous communications reaching this page some time ago, during the preliminary discussions of the murals for Rockefeller Center, two letters stood out, not only for the importance of their contents but for the earnestness and logic with which their message was conveyed.

THIS analysis and portrayal of the personality and achievements of Chief Justice Marshall is made through the perspective afforded by the Alantic Ocean, by the viewpoint of the Scot rather than of the Englishman -- a distinction which carries a decided difference -- and by the author's own judicial attainments and position, as well as by certain prepossessions and prejudices evident throughout the book.
