THE place of music in public-school education, and in some colleges, appears to be Jeopardized today by false ideas of economy. Readjustments of educational budgets are proposed which would relegate music to the place of a fad or a frill which should not be added to the burdens of the taxpayers.

LONDON, June 24 -- A drive for an international accord to raise prices in harmony with the American recovery program was underway in the World Economic Conference tonight as Secretary of State Cordell Hull assailed the sources of suggestions that internal and intergovernmental schemes of action were in conflict.

CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -- Relief Pitcher Bill McAfee quelled a ninth-inning drive today with the tying runs on base to give the league-leading Senators a 7-to-5 victory over the White Sox, their fourth straight in the series.

Both wholesale and retail trade here held to a steady pace during the week and further improvement appeared in many of the markets. Summer apparel and accessories were bought freely and provided major activity in stores.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., June 24 -- Jack Sharkey returned to his training camp tonight with his wife and his manager, Johnny Buckley, from the 200-mile dash to his home in Chestnut Hill, Newton, Mass., for which he broke training early this morning.

HAVANA, June 24 -- High school students here who have long vigorously opposed the Machado regime, this afternoon formally rejected the mediation plans of United States Ambassador Sumner Welles for solving Cuba's political problems. Among the delegation which called on the Ambassador to notify him of the rejection of his memorandum was Humbert O. Wilford, an American who appealed several times to United States diplomatic officials for protection after being detained for anti-administration activities.

DIGGING down through the sands of thirty slow Egyptian centuries, a British expedition has recently uncovered the carven head of a queen whose face, like that of Helen of Troy, might have "launched a thousand ships and burned the topless towers of Illum."

RICHMOND, Va., June 24 -- Virginia's economy program, which under the leadership of Governor Pollard has kept State expenditures rigidly within income, is scheduled for hard going as the second year of the biennium approaches.

With publication of the code of ethics of the National Retail Dry Goods Association tomorrow, rapid completion of the programs of the other retail organizations is expected, as they will probably base the major points of their codes on those contained in the dry goods plan.

The dependent chronically ill in New York City number 1 in every 310 persons, exclusive of those suffering from tuberculosis and mental diseases, it Is disclosed in a survey of chronic disease made by the research bureau of the Welfare Council of New York City, just published by the Columbia University Press.
During the last three months, New York University has received gifts and bequests amounting to $46,328.95, William M. Kingsley, treasurer announced yesterday.

LAKEHURST, N.J., June 24 -- Flying smoothly from Akron, Ohio, to Lakehurst, the airship Macon, new queen of the navy's air fleet, docked at the Naval Air Station here at 7:25 A.M. today. After several hours of manoeuvring in what veteran dirigible men described as a "kid glove landing," the $2,400,000 ship slid into the berth which had been occupied by the ill-fated Akron.

The Shipping Board announced yesterday a more rigid policy in the sale of government-owned tonnage to private operators. Sales will be limited hereafter to cash transactions and purchasers will be obliged to pay the government's price even though they plan to expend additional sums for the improvement of the vessels.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Continued resistance to the usual adverse seasonal factors prevailed in the week ended on June 17, according to the weekly review of domestic business activity made public today by the Department of Commerce.
LEIPZIG, June 24 -- Ten years ago this State was called Red Saxony.

Trading on the Stock Exchange was slightly more active yesterday than on the previous Saturday, but trading was lacking in color and interest. Except for the week-end business reports, which were altogether cheerful, there was little to stimulate the share market.

WASHINGTON. WHILE the schooner Amberjack II sails leisurely up the New England coast, President Roosevelt is relaxing in the easy simplicity of living in a manner which has been denied him ever since he assumed office on March 4.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Summer training cruises of two weeks with pay for 9,411 officers and enlisted men of the Naval Reserve have been approved by Secretary Swanson.

Two large Manhattan office buildings, the well-known Flatiron Building at 175 Fifth Avenue and the skyscraper at 120 "Wall Street, are included in the auction offerings of Edwin J. McDonald for the coming week.

NEWARK, N.J., June 24 -- The Newark Bears took on added steam in their come-back today and bowled over the Jersey City club in both games of their double header, to take an undisputed lead over Rochester for first place. The scores were 7 to 1 and 7 to 3.

With Federal taxation uppermost in the minds of public utility operators in the last few weeks, complete analyses have been made in the various systems to ascertain how these levies can be absorbed. One result of the investigations has been to minimize the fears evident a month and more ago, before the recovery in utility business had been established on broad lines.

In the annual report of the Seventh Avenue Civic Association just issued, mention is made of the efforts which have been and are still being made to effect the removal of unsightly signs from the buildings on and adjacent to the avenue. The physical appearance of the thoroughfare has been considerably improved in the past but W.F. McShane, executive secretary, states that efforts will not be relaxed for additional improvements.

THE result of ten years of television research will be revealed tomorrow by Dr. Vladimir K. Zworykin, the inventor, who has directed the search for television for the RCA-Victor Company. He will lecture before the Institute of Radio Engineers in Chicago.

THIS biography of a partner of the house of Morgan, written by another partner, comes out not inopportunely at a moment when investment banking in general and the Morgan establishment in particular have been under legislative scrutiny.

ORBETELLO, Italy, Sunday, June 25 -- Weather conditions continued unfavorable over Central Europe early today, causing Aviation Minister Italo Baibo to postpone until tomorrow the departure of twenty-five Italian seaplanes on the first leg of their flight to Chicago.

The proposed reorganization of the Fox Film Corporation, which will be voted upon by its stockholders on July 1, is the first move made in the motion-picture industry toward the reduction of burdensome fixed charges.
HENDON, June 24 -- Britain's crack airmen defied death today in order not to disappoint the great crowds that gathered for the spectacular Royal Air Force display.

ALTHOUGH the English poet Walter De la Mare met the American poet George Edward Wood berry but once, in 1915, when Mr. De la Mare came to this country to give at Yale the lecture which Rupert Brooke would have delivered had he lived.

Despite the depression, 1932 was one of the most successful years in the history of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, according to its twenty-third annual report, made public yesterday. Appeals for aid trebled while its income, because of economic conditions, was sharply reduced.

LONDON WITH the World Economic Conference under way, the name of "that wonderful little man Runciman" begins to crop up in the news. It is by no means a new name in England, for the two Runcimans are the most famous father and son in the country.

Today's exhibition of the Trenton Kennel Club on the 112th Field Artillery grounds in Trenton, N.J., completes the dog-show calendar for the first half of 1933. It is the ninety-fourth event under the auspices of the American Kennel Club during the first six months of this year.

Is it part of the American plan of living for cities to provide free education up through the university? The question has been much discussed of late because of the efforts to retrench, and a City Court justice put it in acute form recently when he remarked from the bench:

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 24 -- With the score standing 4 -- 1 against him in the final set of an exhausting three-hour struggle, Albert Horton of Williams rallied to gain an unexpected victory over Richard Murphy of Hamilton College today.

SLEEPERS EAST" belongs to that fictional category in which the characters are passengers on an ocean liner or (as in this instance) a train: when the vessel docks or the train arrives at its terminal the story ends, and the problems raised in the opening chapters have been more or less successfully solved.

THE restoration on July 1 of the two-cent local rate on first-class postage will create peculiar conditions in the New York metropolitan area. A letter carrying a two-cent stamp, mailed in Manhattan, must bear a three-cent stamp if addressed to Brooklyn, Flushing or Staten Island.

DETROIT, Mich., June 21 -- The mystery man of the Democratic administration of Governor William A. Comstock of Michigan is Isaiah Leebove, who has a home and votes in the town of Clare, in the central part of the State, and has a law office at 521 Fifth Avenue, New York City.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Louis Mastriani in a letter to THE TIMES showing that railroad wages have gone down with other costs is correct. It is granted too that while in the year 1920 fixed charges and dividends took only 11.05 per cent in the year 1932 22.2 per cent of gross income went to stockholders and bondholders.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., June 24 -- Full support to new Federal banking legislation was pledged by the Virginia Bankers Association, at the final session of its convention here today.

ALBANY, June 24 (AP). -- Aroused by allegations that workers on public projects in New York State were being "cheated wholesale" by contractors, three departments of the State Government had started investigations today into conditions in scores at labor camps throughout the State.

LONDON, June 24 -- Stanley Baldwin, speaking in Glasgow today, emphasized the necessity for international measures for currency stabilization. He said the World Economic Conference was called mainly to try to agree on remedial measures.

PARIS, June 24 -- To help France's harassed wheat farmers, the Chamber of Deputies after a twenty-hour session passed by an overwhelming vote this morning a measure to fix the minimum price of wheat at 115 francs a metric quintal, which is $1.54 a bushel at the present exchange rate.

THROUGH intelligent direction, artistic photography, cleverly designed settings and efficient acting, "I Loved You Wednesday," the film version of the play by Molly Ricardel and William Du-Bois, is an unusually pleasing entertainment, even though the producers saw fit to treat the story in their own fashion.

DOWN at Manila Village, in the heart of the picturesque bayou country of Louisiana, a location unit from MetroGoldwyn-Mayer has been at work for several weeks gathering material for a motion picture. Although parts of this primitive territory are only a few minutes' ride from one of our most important cities, it is in reality as foreign to America as many of the distant places to which motion-picture companies travel for exotic material.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- President Roosevelt made a direct appeal to the cotton growers of the South today to cooperate in reducing this year's crop by at least 3,000,000 bales. This marked the opening of a drive to win over planters to the adjustment program.

While there is, almost everywhere, a willingness, and even an eagerness, to cooperate with the government in its efforts to hasten the economic recovery, serious difficulties in the practical application of the National Industrial Recovery Act are already seen.

This week marks the final period for the starting of certiorari suits to reduce this year's property assessment values in New York, and many pleas for writs of certiorari are reported scheduled to be filed.

AMID the green of 7,000 templed hills and lake shores, from the High Sierras to the heart of Maine, this week tents will begin to gleam. Springboards win be fastened above delicious depths. And startled salamanders will scurry to cover as mountain trails are cut anew.

ACURIOUS old binding has been going the rounds of the foremost authorities in an effort to establish its identity. About the book which it covers, a Quiatilian published in 1530, there is no mystery at all. The binding was executed with a very fine, unusual tool and colored in vermilion red.

Flushed from his latest triumph over the United States Immigration Bureau, which keeps insisting that a man should have a definite place of abode, C.J. Seymour Baker (Assoc. M. Inst. C.E.; M.Am. Inst. of Mining Engineers; B.C. Land Surveyor) arrived in New York last Monday.

BOSTON, June 21 -- No event of the week in New England is attracting more attention than the Harvard Commencement and the retirement of Abbott Lawrence Lowell from the presidency of the oldest and most famous of American universities.

As administrator of the Henry W. Ranger Fund, the National Academy of Design has spent $230,850 since 1919 for the purchase of 111 paintings by contemporary American artists, it was announced yesterday. These canvases have been allotted by the academy to public art institutions throughout the country.

GREAT NECK, L.I., June 24 -- A crowd of more than 1,500 turned out for the first annual horse show and racing meeting staged by the Lake Success Racing and Horse Show Association on the grounds of the Oaks Hunt Club today.

A man known to the police of several countries as Peter the Lett is reported as being on his way to Paris. He is believed to be the head of a gang of swindlers, but no crime has ever been proved against him. Inspector Maigret is detailed to meet this man at the station and to learn, if possible, what he is up to.

The Public Service Commission denied yesterday the application of Westchester commuters and communities for an immediate temporaray reduction in commutation fares of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad. The commission approved a report submitted by Commissioner George R. Lunn, who found that it lacked legal authority to establish temporary schedules.
Plans for a recapitalization of the New Amsterdam Casualty Company have been sent to stockholders. A special meeting has been called for July 6 to consider the proposals.

ALICE BRADY makes her talking picture debut in "When Ladies Meet" at the Capitol this week. She is the daughter of William A. Brady, the venerable dean of American theatrical producers. Miss Brady was born in New York City in 1892 and as a girl went to school at the St. Elizabeth Convent in Madison, N.J.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Swift Co. asked the District of Columbia Supreme Court today for an extension of one year, to June 15, 1934, in which to dispose of its interests in the packing firm of Libby, McNeill Libby, according to the terms of the modified "packers' consent decree" of June 15, 1932.

THE government subsidy of u17,500 for opera in London has been suspended. This action caused considerable stir in musical circles, provoking a sharp attack from Viscountess Snowden. She insisted that the government was saving the sum granted and losing thereby in entertainment tax a potential u$45,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 17 amounted to 587,931 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 23,385 cars, or 4.1 per cent, more than for the preceding week and 69,533 cars or 13.4 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, but 151,163 cars, or 20.5 per cent fewer than the corresponding week two years ago.

WHEN the Governor of Ohio, standing on the Capitol steps, handed Zoe Glenby $150, the second prize in a State-wide beauty contest, Zoe knew that she had definitely embarked on a career. Henceforth she would capitalize her chief asset-physical beauty.
How the slum dweller of Manhattan lives is revealed in a survey of tenement conditions just completed "by Joseph Platzker, secretary of the East Side Chamber of Commerce.

The 400,000th Brooklyn baby was immunized against diphtheria, yesterday at a baby health festival in the Music Grove, Prospect Park. The event marked the closing of the four-week anti-diphtheria campaign conducted in Brooklyn by the Department of Health, and the Kings County Medical Society.

Announcements of bonds called for redemption before their maturity dates made last week were few, comprising small amounts of municipal loans for payment in the remaining days of June, and retirements for future months, principally foreign government and domestic corporation bonds.

A car containing two young women and their escorts crashed through, a concrete fence at Tenth Avenue and Sixty-second Street, Brooklyn, early this morning, plunged twenty feet to the roof of the Fort Hamilton Parkway station of the B.M.T. subway in the cut below and careened off to the tracks.

Influenced by optimistic reports from Washington concerning progress in the campaign for acreage reduction and by another excited rise in wheat, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced yesterday into new high territory for the year. Although fluctuations held within a range of less than.

THE Chinese have a round god that preserves his balance no matter what happens to him. You may knock him down, but the harder you knock the quicker he will bob up. Stand him on his head and he will roll through 180 degrees to get back to his original placid pose.

THE Composers Protective Society announces the addition of twelve members. These are as follows: A.W. Binder, Franz C. Bornschein, William B. Dinsmore, Arthur Fickenscher, Morton Gould, John Green, Howard Hanson, Harrison Kerr, Bernard Rogers, Dane Rudhyar, William Russell and Edward G. Simon.

Many charming groups of iris are especially suitable for the rock garden. Most of them are unknown in this country, although they are easily grown and can now be bought at nominal prices. One of these groups will be found among the bulbous and tuberous rooted iris.

Indignant at the lack of consideration they claim the United States Department of Commerce has exhibited toward commercial attaches and other representatives stationed in offices closed by the department's economy program, exporters here yesterday prepared to carry their protests to Washington.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- An extension of one month from July 31 was given to corporations today for filing returns and payment of excise tax on capital stock provided in the National Industrial Recovery Act.

STARTING with the query, "Why write another book on ethics?" Richard C. Cabot, who was a Doctor of Medicine before he became also Professor of Social Ethics, comes to an age-old inquiry along fresh avenues of approach. Whether there is such a term in common use as behavioristic ethics, and whether Dr. Cabot would like to have his analysis designated as behavioristic, this writer cannot say; but it would be his own designation.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

THE old Georgian building in City Hall Park in which New York's municipal affairs art conducted has been the scent of many disturbances during the last few weeks. The graceful flight of marble stairs in the dignified columned rotunda has re-echoed to the tread of angry citizens as they have trooped up and made their way to the meetings of the Board of Estimate.

TRUE intellectual achievements have never been made by racial aliens, but always by strictly Aryan Germanic spiritual forces." It requires no high degree of penetration to recognize Adolf Hitler as the author of this pronunciamento, uttered before the German Federation of Medical Associations.

VIENNA, June 24 -- Last Monday's proscription of the National Socialist party has closed one phase of the struggle of the Austrian David and Goliath. It also fulfilled two days ahead of time the promise of Chancellor Dollfuss and the aggressive Minister of War, Karl Vaugoin, that by Midsummer Day the Nazis would have "got theirs."

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 21Scientists seem a bit loath to accept Arkansas as the location of the Garden of Eden, but Arkansas has fig leaves, apples and serpents, and now it has a calendar stone which may turn out to toe the Rosetta stonee of modren archaeology.

George F. Lacombe, president of the Board of Realtors of the Oranges and Maplewood, has, on behalf of the board, requested the five communities comprising the Oranges and Maplewood to adopt resolutions in accordance with the New Jersey laws permitting delinquent taxpayers to pay back taxes, assessments and tax sale certificates, together with interest over a five-year period, with interest on the unpaid balances at 7 per cent.

STROUDSBURG, Pa., June 24. -- "Graft in city politics is due chiefly to the ethics of the business world," said Paul Blanshard, executive director of the City Affairs Committee, in an address today before the annual Summer conference of the League for Industrial Democracy at Camp Tamiment.
HOMER SAINT-GAUDENS, returning from Europe last week, sketched for radio listeners the results of his intensive overseas round-up of art for next season's Carnegie International in Pittsburgh.

WHITE PLAINS, June 24 -- A demand that the Federal Government intensify its retrenchment policy by canceling the tax exemption on government securities was made here today by Louis Johnson, National Commander of the American Legion.

An unofficial check made here last week by export trade authorities revealed that thirty world markets had increased purchases from this country since the first of the year. More than twoscore products were included in the list of American goods which were found by exporters to be in more demand among foreign buyers this year than last.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 24 -- Willie Turnesa, 18-year-old schoolboy, won the Westchester amateur golf championship today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 24 -- After a brisk workout on the Housatonic today. Head Coach Ed Leader announced the personnel of the Yale crew which will compete in the regatta at Long Beach, Cal., July 8.

THE tenants of The Cardinal, an ornate uptown apartment house, were for the most part a sporty, extravagant, somewhat disreputable crowd, whose festive doings stirred a keen curiosity in the simple soul of Janet, switchboard operator of the hostelry from 3 P.M. to 11 in the evening.

BROADCASTING is a harmless pursuit," remarked Colonel Louis McHenry Howe, secretary of President Roosevelt, as he reflected on his recent radio activities in the Roosevelt study in the Sixty-fifth Street home. "My broadcasting on Sunday nights is an experiment.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 24 -- Championship honors in the second annual Plainfield Horse Show, which drew an outstanding entry and a large gathering of spectators today, were won by Will Rogers, a brown gelding, exhibited by Miss Virginia M. Boycott of Newark.

FLORENCE, May, 1933. OF the many addresses and discussions heard during the International Music Convention at Florence, many of them of live practical value, the paper read (in Italian) by Roger Sessions of New York on "Opera in the United States" offers special interest from the American viewpoint.

What constitutes a day's sport at bass fishing? That is a question that many anglers have had put to them. For some a two-hour struggle for a big fellow is all that could be asked. For others, landing as many fish as time will permit means a good day.

The Summer session work at Hunter College will be supplemented this year by a program of extra-curricular activities, it was said yesterday by A. Broderick Cohen, the director. They will include trips to points of interest near the city, addresses by specialists and social events.

DUBLIN, June 23 -- If one interprets the political signs and portents aright, the young people of the Free State are beginning to tire of Parliamentary institutions and are moving in the direction of a dictatorship.

MIAMI, Fla., June 24 -- Dr. Rodolfo Mendez Penate, due here tomorrow from New York to confer with Cuban revolutionary groups on approval of American mediation in the island's political problems, will not be received by the Revolutionary Union for the Liberation of Cuba, the organization voted tonight.

SHOULD Guglieimo Ferrero ever decide to write his autobiography and employ the hypothetical method which has served bun so well in his historical and contemporaneous criticism, he can hardly fail to survey his life from three points of departure:

More interest attaches to the meetings of the sugar trade in Washington on Tuesday, under the provisions of the National Industrial Recovery Act and the Farm Bill, than at any other time since the first meetings in 1930, which resulted in the formulation of the Chadbourne plan.

THE nostalgic yearning for the romance and furbelows of the Nineties that is a part of the depression and an overmechanized age has perhaps had its most amazing-result in the styles of women's clothes. Give any Beau Brummel of that often lamented era a cursory glance at the modes of today and he will swear that the sweet young thing in the latest Paris model is the Gibson girl of his youth.

VIENNA, June 24 -- Alfred Frauenfeld, leader of the Austrian Nazis, was seized today at Villach in Carinthia. It was suspected he was about to cross the border into Italy and the police feared that he might go to Germany in defiance of the refusal of the Austrian Government to grant him permission.

ECONOMIC discussions and explanations of the new laws designed to speed recovery are intermingled with several concerts by the Goldman Band and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony this week. Details of a number of broadcasts are printed here while the outstanding events of the week are listed in the box on the program page in this section.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- A clause asking the Administration to fix marketing prices for petroleum products under the terms of the Industrial Recovery Act was incorporated in the code adopted here today by the oil marketers and refiners.

An attempt to obtain the release on bail of the nine Negroes in the Scottsboro case will be made soon, according to Osmond K. Fraenkel. an attorney for the International Labor Defense. Mr. Fraenkel said he hoped to be able to argue writs of habeas corpus before Judge James E. Horton of Morgan County, Ala., on July 3.

In order to relieve some of the mortgage difficulties of the present time as well as to assist home owners in need of financial advice and help, two committees organized by the Westchester County Realty Board have been doing efficient work.

FURNISHINGS inspired by historical and regional decorative motifs grace many modern homes. The antiquarian inaugurated most of these revivals with his enthusiasm for New England and Southern antiques, early Louisiana furniture. Western pioneer Victorian pieces and the habitant chairs and tables of the North-west.

FROM London comes the long promised announcement that the Delius Society is an accomplished fact -- to the extent that it has been properly organized, under the presidency of Sir Thomas Beecham, has laid out a tentative program, issued its literature and now only awaits the required number of subscriptions, before going ahead with the first album.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Despite the acquittal won by Charles E. Mitchell in his tax evasion trial, the Senate Banking and Currency Subcommittee will continue to develop evidence on method used by prominent men to escape taxes, Chairman Fletcher said today.

A useful historical review of atomic models was presented toy Professor COMPTON at Chicago. It showed that physicists experiment not only with lithium or radium, X-ray tubes or spectroscopes, but also with theories. In one generation we have had a dozen atomic models, each of which was discarded when it failed to fit new discoveries.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Weather and the London Economic Conference permitting, President Roosevelt will be the guest of honor of this year's Institute of Public Affairs which opens at the University of Virginia on July 2.

Initial work in the first reorganization of the financial set-up of a New York City property under emergency legislation adopted at the last session of the State Legislature on recommendation of Governor Lehman were taken last week under the sponsorship of the New York Guaranteed Mortgage Protection Corporation.

CHARLES R. ROGERS, Independent producer for Paramount, has two new projects in mind for Summer production. One is a musical picture, "We're Sitting Pretty," which will feature Jack Haley and Jack Oakie. Mr. Rogers has engaged Jack McGowan to do the book and dialogue, and the popular song-writing team of Gordon and Revel for the music.

OMAHA, Neb., June 21 -- It is estimated that $30,000,000 will be distributed in Kansas and $11,000,000 in Nebraska in wheat crop curtailment bonuses. This is assuming that Secretary Wallace's offer meets a virtual 100 per cent acceptance.

BOSTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Braves today slammed Lon Warneke for a total of 14 hits but wasted so many that they had to go eleven innings to beat the Cubs, 2-1. It was the Tribe's fourth victory in a row, the second straight over the Cubs and the first success it has had against Warneke in two seasons.

A hard-hitting Jamaica team that gained a commanding five-run lead in the first inning defeated George Washington of Manhattan, 15 to 9, for the city P.S.A.L. senior high school baseball championship at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.

MR. EPSTEIN knows what he believes with clear-cut finality and believes it with an utter surety of conviction that rouses one's admiration for its completeness. His belief issues from a great and comprehensive body of knowledge about his subject that is notable for its almost world-wide sweep and its richness of detail, a basis, surely, that commands respect.

THIS year's meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, held at Chicago, brought forth considerably more than the usual three or four hundred papers en subjects that range from stars and atoms to vitamins and archaeology.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having served the American Government, and subsequently the Manchurian Government, in China for many years, I desire to comment on a recent press dispatch which tells how cannibalism is practiced on a wide scale in Shensi Province.

Passing the Titles Around. Young Corbett 3d of Fresno was welterweight champion a month ago. He is welterweight champion no longer. He met James Archibald McLarnin in the ring at Los Angeles and Jimmy of the cherubic countenance flattened the Fresno fighter in the first round.

More than 1,000 children from public and parochial schools, playgrounds and amateur athletic organizations in all parts of the city gathered yesterday at Heckscher Playground, near the southwest corner of Central Park, to compete in running, jumping and other track contests.

This is the title that President BUTLER gave to the " citations" of 400 Americans and 90 residents of other countries upon whom, from 1902 to 1932 inclusive, he conferred the honorary degrees of Columbia University. An earlier collection of this nature is that of Dean ANDREW WEST'S " presentations " for honorary degrees at Princeton.

WHEN Octavian -- who was to become Augustus -- entered Rome after the death of Julius Caesar the sun was surrounded by a brilliant rainbow-tinted ring. Whereby, says Dio Cassius, "the gods Rave no uncertain warning of the troublous times to come."

McCOLL, S.C., June 22 -- Stories of animal freaks have been cropping up rather frequently in South Carolina in recent months. A short time ago the finding of a two-headed rattlesnake came in for a great deal of attention, but now comes the story of a four-legged duck, doubly equipped for land travel but unable to swim.

WASHINGTON. TRY to visualize a soldier, lawyer, manufacturer, statistician, author -- a rattler of swords and maker of plowshares, a man who could write a law that drafted 4,000,000 men into the army with the same understanding of the problems involved as he wrote of the doings of boys at school.

OSLO. ONE of the earliest references to the North in classical literature occurs in the tenth book of the "Odyssey," where Homer, blissfully unmindful of such economic annoyances as unemployment or overproduction, sings of a land with a Summer in which a goatherd coming home at twilight greets a fellow goatherd driving his furry flock out at dawn.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Instead of going on a five-day-week basis tomorrow the field service of the Navy Department and Marine Crop will continue on the present five-and-one-half-day-week basic until further notice. Orders were issued today by Colonel Henry Dr. Roosevelt, Acting Secretary.

BERLIN, June 24 -- The Nazis have taken control of the Protestant Church in Germany. The Rev. Friedrich von Bodelschwingh, who only shortly before Whitsunday was inducted by the church authorities as Reichsbishop, was forced to resign today.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Senator Wheeler today attacked Senator Pittman's silver remonetization resolution presented at the World Economic Conference in London in a statement describing it as "a sad commentary" on the United States delegates' "grasp on the fundamentals underlying the money questions."

ANTHONY ADVERSE" is America's most original contribution. certainly its longest, perhaps indeed its only contribution to the great tradition of the picaresque novel. It has the humors, gusto, gayety. variety of episode and character and more than the range that mark "Gil Bias" and "Roderick Random."

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Differences which were discribed in official circles today as a "first-class he-man fight" are developing between labor and capital over application of the collective bargaining provisions of the National Industrial Recovery Act.

"With the majority of business executives reconciled to a 35 or 36 hour week, acceptance by the government of the cotton, textile industry's program for a 40-hour week would be a "severe blow" to the success of the National Industrial Recovery Act, Sol A. Herzog, counsel to a number of trade associations and to the Congress of Industries, declared here yesterday.

Three tales of the exploits of Simon Templar, also known as the Saint, are here added to the many that have gone before. To those who have already met the Saint it is unnecessary to state that he is a most extraordinary criminal. He is so clever and resourceful that his arch-enemy.

Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy denounced as "busybodies" the critics of his proposed baseball diamonds and athletic fields in the abandoned reservoir site in Central Park yesterday. He expressed the belief that the public supported his policy.

ROME, June 24 -- The Italian press and public are impatient at the flood of words issuing from London, unaccompanied, they feel, by evidence of determination to grapple with the problems the World Economic Conference is called upon to solve.

The arrival of Summer last week witnessed further progress In business recovery throughout the United States, with manufacturing, wholesale and retail trade showing continued gains. Prices were firmer and wage increase and re-employment news came from various sections.

IN January of last Winter there was held in New York City under the auspices of the Power Authority of the State of New York, in association with the Public Service Commissions of the District of Columbia, New York and Pennsylvania, a meeting of the Institute of Public Engineering at which were made addresses by almost a score of eminent engineers discussing especially the cost of the distribution of electricity to domestic and rural consumers.

LONDON, June 24 -- The Ryder Cup golf match will be played on the Southport and Ainsdale course in Lancashire Monday and Tuesday, and unless I am much mistaken just as many people as can possibly be crammed on to that course will be there to see.

Another broad advance in wheat relieved yesterday the tedium of what otherwise would have been a dull and colorless Saturday in the financial and commodity markets. Stocks closed fractionally higher, largely as the result of a late flurry of buying in a few groups of stocks.

CARTWRIGHT, Labrador, June 24 -- The steamer Alice and the icebreaker Ungava, which arrived here Thursday from St. John's, Nfld., were still busy today unloading stores and preparing for the arrival of Italy's transatlantic seaplane flotilla.

THE eight-week season of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium will begin Thursday night at 8:30. The concerts will continue nightly through Aug. 23. Willem van Hoogstraten, Dutch conductor, who has been associated with the Stadium concerts for the last twelve of its sixteen seasons, will conduct the first and last three weeks of this year's performances.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 22 -- Determined to turn the wet tide with a victory in Alabama on July 18, dry forces here are overlooking nothing new or old, imported or domestic, moral or political, technical or practical that may serve the antirepeal purpose.

AS a very young architect struggling for a foothold to New York, Larry McNeil contracted a disastrous secret marriage which ended in his wife's desertion of him for a lover with whom she fled abroad. In justice to the lover, it must be owned, he was unaware that Thelma was Larry's wife, though that circumstance in no degree lightened the blow to Larry's heart.

One of the few places in the world where a bale of cotton conies in one door and goes through all the processes of the modern textile industry, down to becoming finished dresses, is the Textile High School of New York City, which on Tuesday will celebrate its first commencement as a fully accredited school.

On Oct. 6. 1909, a gentleman In cap and gown appeared at the front of University Hall in the Harvard College Yard and made a brief address to an audience of teachers and students and graduates of Harvard, of which the keynote was this sentence:

The more convincing becomes the evidence that financial and industrial recovery is genuinely under way, the more one hears of divergent reasons for It. That a definite turn has come, the customary indices without exception testify. Activities at textile mills in May were the largest of any month since October, 1929.

THE possibilities in adapting stage plays for microphone presentation were never better illustrated than in the recent ethereal production of Jerome Kern's "Show Boat." It proved beyond doubt that to do a good job an hour in needed, whereas several attempts to condense "Show Boat" and other stage successes into half-hour presentations were not as effective.

The journal kept by Lieutenant Zebulon Montgomery Pike on that historic enterprise on which he was sent by President Jefferson in the Autumn of 1806 is well known to students of Western American exploration and early history and is to some extent familiar to general readers because of the thrilling story it carries of courage, daring, fortitude, for it has had several publications.

BUENOS AIRES, June 24 -- Certain prominent Bolivians and Paraguayans resident here have begun conversations with the aim of finding a formula for a solution of the Chaco conflict by direct negotiations between the Bolivian and Paraguayan Governments without other assistance.

PARIS, June 24 -- Since the days of the Captain of Koepenick, Paris has not enjoyed any story out of Germany so much as last night's about Red airplanes over Berlin. Some newspapers head it with sly references to the burning of the Reichstag, "The Flying Dutchman."

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 24 -- In the third and last race of the America's Cup yachts, Weetamoe and Vanitie, on Long Island Sound, the Weetamoe today turned the tables on Vanitie, which had defeated her twice in the New York Yacht Club contests at Glen Cove.

The School Art League of New York City will award medals and scholarships tomorrow afternoon at exercises in the auditorium of the Architectural League Building, 115 East Fortieth Street. The principal address will be made by Julian Clarence Levi, ex-president of the Architectural League.

The semi-annual awards of the Cooperation-in-Government movement were made yesterday to 228 members of the graduating classes of the city's high schools. The awards are made for "straight thinking backed by caution, courage and confidence."

SUMTER, S.C., June 21 -- South Carolina and other Cotton Belt States are hopeful that the cotton farmer will be as quick to act under the Farm Relief Act as the textile manufacturers have acted under the new industrial control legislation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We have read with interest in THE TIMES the report of the address of Dr. Barton C. Hirst before the convention of the American Medical Association, in which he says that the practice of birth control by the "better elements" of the population and the lack of this practice by the less gifted may be the cause of much of the present-day trouble.

THE transatlantic telephone is again playing its part in the international negotiations. The length of overseas conversations between Washington and London, where the economic conference is in progress, and the number, put through each day are part of statistical records not yet obtainable.

Today many of the city's leading pastors will preach their last sermons in their own pulpits until the Fall. Several prominent clergymen have already left on their vacations, but in most churches the last Sunday in June is the traditional day for the final sermons of the season.

PARIS, June 22 -- At the grand steeplechase at Auteuil, which opens the Grande Semaine with traditional sartorial brilliance, the occasion was only slightly dimmed by showers. One fashion leader smartly foiled Pluvius with a white lacquer raincoat having leopard sleeves.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 24 -- Princeton's baseball team Conquered Yale in the play-off game of their traditional series by 5 to 2 today.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., June 24. -- More than 300 members of the Student Young Women's Christian Association, representing most of the Eastern colleges, are having at Silver Bay their annual conference, which will continue through Thursday. The theme is "Adventure for a Modern Christian."

Gross revenues of the first twelve railroads to report for May were about $55,920,000, against $56,280,000 in May, 1932, a decrease of 0.6 per cent, and against $79,912,000 in May, 1931, a drop of 30 per cent. In April their gross was $48,593,000, against $56,468,000 in April, 1932, a fall of 13.9 per cent.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with some degree of amusement in THE TIMES the concern expressed in the letter from Rosalie Edge, secretary of the Emergency Conservation Commission.
ALBANY, June 24 -- Delegates to the State prohibition repeal convention will gather in the Assembly chamber Tuesday morning at 11 o'clock, to vote New York's ratification, to which all are pledged.

BERLIN, June 24 -- Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Reich Minister of the Interior, has chosen Frau Paula Siber of Dusseldorf to speak for womanhood in the National Socialist State. She is the first, perhaps the only, woman to be assigned to a responsible executive position in a governmental Ministry.

One hundred and twelve entrants opened play in the fourth annual Eastern clay court title tennis tourney at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday. Before dusk the first round was almost complete and several players had gone on to the third round.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Faced with a heavy deficit at the end, Friday, of the current fiscal year, the Roosevelt administration is shaping plans to bring about a balance next year of ordinary government receipts and expenditures, exclusive of debt reduction.

The operation of American ships since 1920 has added $2,500,000,000 to the nation's balance of trade, according to a survey prepared by the American Steamship Owners Association. The total freight and passenger costs of the nation for services rendered by steamships of all nations is about $600,000,000 a year, one-third of which is now expended with American ship lines.

FROM the French islands of St. Pierre and Miquelon, lying within sight of the south shore of Newfoundland, a steady stream of liquor flows into the United States. St. Pierre, though only four miles long, cups around a fair harbor, and the town, also named St. Pierre, hugs the protected waterfront.

LONDON, June 24 -- The United States domestic program for business revival is not irreconcilable with international cooperation. Secretary of State Hull said tonight in a brief statement to correspondents who are reporting the World Economic Conference.

When Fleming Stone begins the investigation with which this story deals, he has not a single clue to work from. He is not even sure that a crime has been committed. All he knows is that Corey Maiden died suddenly while on his honeymoon and that ugly rumors are afloat.

An upturn in the sales of small homes in various parts of the metropolitan district, and a revival of residential construction in some suburban sections, constitute an important part of real estate activity this month, according to reports received from brokers and developers.

MAPLEVVOOD, N.J., June 24 -- A best-ball score of 69, two under par, gave the team of Dr. R.R. Lauckner and George Brueckner the first-round leadership in the Maplewood Country Club's first annual invitation tournament today. A field of nineteen teams is competing.

Dr. Hans Luther, German Ambassador, sailed for Europe early today aboard the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. Dr. Luther's name was not on the passenger list and he refused to disclose the object of his journey.

STUTTGART, June 23 -- State Councilor Waldmann of the Wurttemberg Government, in summarizing to administrative officials the guiding principles set forth by Chancellor Hitler at the recent meeting of Nazi lieutenants in Berlin, emphasized this point:

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Republican orators will go to the country in 1934 with the charge that a Democratic Congress has given unconstitutional power to President Roosevelt and that he has infinitely too vast a task for one man to administer.

Bouncing back from two consecutive defeats by the Dodgers, George Gibson'a Pirates yesterday fell upon the Flatbush heroes to crush them under an avalanche of base hits and triumph by the decisive score of 15 to 3.

FOR the past four years unemployment has steadily increased and production declined until it reached a virtual standstill during the bank crisis. During this period our economic structure suffered the most rapid and most complete deflation in history.

LONDON, June 24 -- This week the international negotiations both at the economic and at the disarmament conference enter in some important respects into a new phase. One of them is exemplified by the return to the United States of Ambassador at Large Norman H. Davis and the departure for Europe of Assistant Secretary of State Raymond C. Moley.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 24 -- The Penn A.C. baseball team of Philadelphia defeated the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club nine today, 6 to 2, in an Eastern Athletic Club League contest.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 24 -- Washington is taking an active interest in the sessions of the convention of the Advertising Federation of America here next week.
MOSCOW, June 23 -- In this land of countless contrasts it is perhaps significant that the divisions and differences are marked even more strongly in death than in life.
To the Automobile Editor: I READ with astonishment the letter written by Frederic W. Erickson which appeared in your paper last Sunday. That letter certainly calls for refutation.

Two records for outboard motor boats were announced yesterday by the National Outboard Racing Commission. They were at 35.4 miles an hour for 5 miles in competition in a Class E runabout, made at Stockton, Cal., on May 28, by L.E. Heckendorf, a professional, and another of 36.2 miles at the same distance, also in a Class E runabout at Stockton, by H.B. Purviance, an amateur.
MUNICH, June 23 -- If the National Socialist rulers of Germany achieve their ambition, this city will be revived as the artistic centre of the third Reich.

Flying at speeds up to 190 miles an hour and at altitudes up to 12,000 feet, Lieut. Commander Frank M. Hawks made his debut yesterday as a combination solo speed pilot and radio operator. He was in direct communication with the radio room of THE NEW YORK TIMES throughout the flight.

In round numbers, 8,700,000 people in fourteen States have now voted for and against repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. In the Presidential election of last November some 18,000,000 votes were cast in these same States. The comparative lightness of the vote on the question of repeal has persuaded some of the advocates of national prohibition that thus far we have not had a real test of public sentiment.

Plans for the formation of a bond Exchange by members of the Investment Bankers Association of Canada were outlined by Colonel J. G. Weir, president of the association, in his address at the annual convention of the association at Lucerne-in-Quebec, which was concluded yesterday.

PATERSON, N.J., June 24 -- Johnny Grady of Paterson, running in the colors of the Newark Athletic Club, won two events in the senior track and field championships of the New Jersey Association of the A.A.U. at the Hinchliffe City Stadium today.

An extraordinary collection of crystallized gold dust has been placed on view in Mineral Hall at the Free Natural History Museum of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia. "Limited as is the occurrence of gold in nature, crystals are the rarest form of this element," says a bulletin from the museum.

LATONIA, Ky., June 24 (AP). -- The Everglade Stable's Wise Daughter romped home first in a field of eight in the Clipsetta Stakes, feature race on the opening program today at the Latonia race track. Far Star was second and Penncote third.

DR. WHITING was chief surgeon of Michael J. Heney's organization which constructed the White Pass and Yukon Railway during the last years of the nineteenth century, the first railroad in Alaska, and a few years later held the same position while Mr. Heney was building the Copper River and Northwestern Railway.

Demand for Summer merchandise fell off slightly in the wholesale markets here last week, according to the report prepared especially, for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell. Cotton dresses proved an exception to the general rule and were actively Bought by buyers.

IN "The Investor Pays" a brilliant light is thrown on an importent phase of investment banking practice-that of corporate reorganization. The avowed aim of the book is "to pierce through technicalities and show the Investor what actually happens to his money" when his company is reorganized.

LONDON, June 18 -- To illustrate what we want to say, two examples. The first is what happened the other day at the Derby, the famous British horse race, and perhaps the most famous race in the world. This national event is held annually on the no less famous course at Epsom, to the south of London.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- President Roosevelt's public works administration wound up its first full week of activity today after allocating $638,000,000 for highways and battleships. The balance of the 53,300,000,000 fund remains to be put into Federal, State, city and county projects when administrative organization Is completed.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 24 -- The third annual art exhibition of Miss Zelia De Milhau, Miss Rachel Hartley and George Inness Hartley opened this afternoon at Four Fountains, the Ethel Hunt Tyng Memorial, with a tea at which Mrs. Edward P. Mellon, Mrs. James Terry, Mrs. Hamilton King, Mrs. Howard Dickinson, Mrs. Flora McDonald Wills, Lucien Hamilton Tyng, and Seth Hunt received with, the artists.

HERE is a novel as packed with thrills, hair-breadth escapes, shootings and other forms of violence as a typical Western. But there the resemblance ceases; for the heroes (there are several) include a member of the Long Island millionaire set and three European sophisticates; while, in lieu of a sage-brush or prairie setting, the tale unfolds against a background of Soviet Moscow and Siberia.

AND now we come again to the Summer theatres -- those bearers of the torch freckling the face of the sunburned countryside from Bar Harbor, Me., to Abingdon, Va. Yearly their number increases, so that this season there will be scarcely a resort within the aforementioned area which will not boast its troupe of modern troubadours or be within driving distance -- under the wide and starry sky -- of one.

NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Albert MacClellan Barnes of 775 Park Avenue, accompanied by their two sons, Albert M. Jr. and William J. Barnes, sailed for England to attend the Henley Regatta, where Albert will row with the Hun School crew.

THE new banking act signed by President Roosevelt on June 17 has received a mixed reception. On the whole the public has approved the bill, particularly the provision for guarantee of deposits. Bankers in general are displeased -- small State bankers because they are afraid of the extension of branch banking, and the large member banks because they do not approve of the deposit in surance.

A Bad Trade Practice. When the Book Reviewera Institute of America turns up at Washington with its new code of ethics it is to be hoped that General JOHNSON will bear down with all the weight of the Industrial Recovery Act upon one undesirable trade practice.

PARIS, June 10, 1933. A always, the "Grande Salson" in Paris begins with concerts and ends with spectacles. While waiting for the performances of the two Russian ballet companies, each of whom claim lineal descent from Diaghileff, we have watched a continuous parade of distinguished virtuosi.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- Pennsylvania is not yet an Industrial Utopia. That much is apparent as the legislative investigation of the Commonwealth's sweatshops proceeds from Philadelphia through the anthracite region and prepares to swing southward next week to the seat of the rich farming county of Lancaster.

RECOVERY or disaster -- one or the other, in the opinion of Europe -- may be expected from the London, conference. The nations hope for the best. They hope that out of the conference will come some alleviation of the world's economic and financial crisis.

ALBANY, June 24 -- M. Maldwin Fertig, counsel to Governor Lehman, informed Frank Peer Beal, executive secretary of the Community Councils of the City of New York, today, that Governor Lehman "does not feel there is any need for further executive action" on the complaint of the councils asking the removal of Chairman Milo R. Maltbie of the Public Service Commission.

Sharply advancing prices were mainly responsible for a substantial improvement in business activity in this district over both the previous week and the corresponding week of last year, according to the report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the New York Credit Men's Association.

BEGINNING next Saturday the old order will change for pedestrians walking along highways in this State. They will be required, by the Esmond law passed by the last Legislature, to keep to the left of highways, facing traffic, and to turn to the left instead of the right when appreaching oncoming vehicles.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A loan of $3,200,000 to the Saratoga Springs Authority for construction of additional facilities at New York's health resort was approved today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I agree with Dr. Irving Fisher that if we are to stabilize prices it matters little what year is taken as a base year, which, however, to be equitable, must be the same year as that in which the policy is initiated.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, sat down and talked for more than an hour yesterday with John H. McCooey, Brooklyn leader, and made clear that the policy on local Federal patronage awaited the return of President Roosevelt from his yachting trip.

With many of the rarest mintage dates of United States gold coins on sale, prices were considerably higher yesterday at the closing session of Thomas L. Elder's three-day auction at 8 West Thirty-seventh Street.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., June 21 -- Southern California, the "goody goody" golden curled cherub of the Pacific Southwest, has fallen off the wagon. Our halo is askew. We revel in our 3.2 per cent beer busts. Los Angeles has fired her reform Mayor.
Man o' War's line went marching on in the Dwyer Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday when War Glory, a chestnut son of the superhorse, won the mile and a half test by eight lengths.

IT seems to be a common opinion that the average intelligence of the radio audience is only as high as that of the 13 or 14 year-old child. The same opinion has been held of the movie audience. If such an opinion is held, it is bound to have an influence on the general level of the programs which are prepared for the radio or the movie audience.

DETROIT. THE reflection of the bettered conditions for automobile manufacturing is apparent in expanded factory schedules for June. For the General Motors group it is evidenced in two successive boosts above the original estimate for Buick, making the total increase 38 per cent.

THE recently announced recommendations of the Congressional committee to investigate the destruction of the naval airship Akron, which mean, naval experts hope, a new lease of life for lighter-than-air, have been received with considerable relief by the men who ride the sky in the big bags.

Operating revenues of the Mohawk Valley Company, a New York State public utility holding company in the Associated Gas and Electric System, amounted to $35,046,035 in 1932. This compares with $36,571,701 in 1931. Operating expenses, maintenance, taxes and provision for retirement of fixed capital made a total of $23,186,525, against $23,134,990 in 1931.

Boxing's richest prize, the world's heavyweight championship, will be at stake on Thursday night when Jack Sharkey, holder of the title, and Primo Carnera, giant Italian challenger, engage in a fifteen-round bout at the Long Island City Bowl.

Boxing's richest prize, the world's heavyweight championship, will be at stake on Thursday night when Jack Sharkey, holder of the title, and Primo Carnera, giant Italian challenger, engage in a fifteen-round bout at the Long Island City Bowl.

"Alterations and the rehabilitation of older properties hold the answer to the oft-repeated query, 'What is going to happen to our building trades in New York City?' " said Benjamin Winter yesterday, in discussing the plans he has made for the modernization of his recent purchases and the benefits that will accrue to labor and to owner if large-scale modernization plans are put into effect.

THE sesquicentennial of flight has received little attention by that part of the world concerned with aeronautics. Yet after fifteen or twenty centuries of speculation, with here and there a rare exception in actual research, the year 1783 brought forth the greatest advance in aeronautics, or "aerostatiques," as the art was then known, in its history.

Another very sharp advance in THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity for the week ended June 17 puts it at 91.4, compared with 87.1 for the previous week and 65.9 for the week ended June 18, 1932.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., June 24 -- A stiff southerly wind that whipped the waters of Lake Hopatcong into so rough a condition that racing became unsafe forced the postponement until tomorrow morning of half of today's program in the intercollegiate outboard motorboat championships.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- With gains of substantial proportions in many directions, some made in a normally slack period, industrial production in May scored a 16 per cent increase over March and gave indications that sufficient impetus has been generated to carry business through the usual Summer lull without a setback.
Seamen's welfare agencies along the waterfront report that steamship companies are trying to put as many jobless seamen back to work as possible.

A CENTURY ago the average citizen in America sang more than he does today. Lacking the radio, the musical movie, the phonograph and other of our modern agencies for bringing music to him, he must needs provide in large measure his own concord of, supposedly, sweet sounds.

LONDON, June 25. -- Whatever it may or may not achieve in the strictly economic field-and hopes in that regard now are somewhat brighter than a week ago -- it appears likely the World Economic Conference may justify itself by settling or advancing toward settlement a number of political and politico-economic problems which have been troubling the peace of Europe.

During May the American dollar sold at an average discount of 14.7 per cent in terms of the French franc. According to those who believe that a depreciated currency offers great advantages in competitive world trade, one result should have been a sharp increase of exports and a decline of imports.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP). -- Looking forward to improved business next year, when the government hopes to balance its budget, the Treasury will end its 1933 fiscal year Friday with a deficit of about $1,750,000,000.
BALTIMORE, June 25 (AP). -- Despite a last-Inning rally which produced three runs and ended with the bases loaded, the Bears lost the first game of today's double-header with the Orioles, 5 to 4.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The large majorities in favor of prohibition repeal in the fourteen States that have voted so far are laid to "stay-at-home drys" by F. Scott McBride, general superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League, who issued a statement today.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- Business recovery in the last four months has been the most rapid ever experienced. It has changed from depression and lack of confidence to activity and optimism. The outlook, with few exceptions, is the best known at this season.

The waters used for bathing adjacent to New York City are less polluted this year than last, it was announced yesterday at the office of Dr. Alonzo Blauvelt, assistant sanitary superintendent of the Health Department. The present system of sewage disposal makes it necessary, however, for several areas to be restricted against public bathing.

TOKYO, June 25 (AP). -- A conference in which Japan hopes to eliminate the last vestiges of Russian influence in Manchuria and nullify Russia's position as a strategic factor on the shores of the Pacific Ocean, completing the process begun by the Russo-Japanese War of 1904, is scheduled to open at the Japanese Foreign Office tomorrow afternoon with an address of welcome by Foreign Minister Count Yasuya Uchida.

Most people feel encouraged now, not because they understand or have any great confidence in governmental measures or in the World Economic Conference, but simply because something is being done, said the Rev. Dr. Cleland B. McAfee yesterday.

Demand for seasonal merchandise tapered off in the wholesale apparel markets here last week. The recent period of cool weather, in the opinion of retailers, was responsible for the decline. Despite the slight recession, substantial orders for Summer garments were received.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- General Hugh Johnson, director of the national industrial recovery campaign, called on all employers to attack unemployment by shortening hours and raising wages. In the same breath he declared "wildcat price lifting" would not be tolerated.

Prime Minister MACDONALD showed a certain degree of irritation when he summoned the press correspondents and reproached them for giving misleading reports of the Economic Conference. Secretary HULL on Saturday took up the tale more indirectly and gently.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- Buying of corn was stimulated test week by the advance in wheat and prices rose to a level that induced farmers in Corn Belt States to sell more than 1,500,000 bushels of cash corn for shipment within ten to twenty days at the best prices of the season.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- Public participation on the buying side of all grain markets carried prices up further and faster last week than at any time since the bull movement started about four months ago. Inflation reports, apparently backed by the government, have been helped by unfavorable weather conditions for small grain crops, and deterioration the last few weeks has been more than even the most enthusiastic buyer could expect.

TRENTON, N.J., June 25. -- Looking at his very best, Champion Heather Reveller of Sporran fought his way to the top in the annual dog show of the Trenton Kennel Club today, adding one more victory to the almost countless triumphs he has gained for his owner, S.S. Van Dine of New York City, and his clever handler, William Prentice.
The Summer theatrical season out of town will begin to hit its stride this week, with several more groups getting under way along with those which have already started.

There is no conflict between American domestic and foreign policies and there have not been any differences between members of the American delegation at the World Economic Conference in London, according to Representative Sam D. McReynolds of Tennessee, a member of the delegation.

The selected New York fifteen and the Kerry Gaelic football team engaged in their fourth clash yesterday at Innisfail Park. Before 3,000 spectators, New York beat the champions of Ireland for the first time, 10-7.

The State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration reported yesterday that the total expenditures from local, State and Federal funds for unemployment relief in New York State for May were $12,757,110. This was $277,700 more than was spent in April but $619,564 less than in March.

Winners of the Rebecca Elsberg memorial prizes, awarded semi-annually to two public school pupils, were announced yesterday. The prizes of $200 each are given to the girl and the boy graduating from elementary schools in Manhattan, "who, in the face of economic hardship, are the most outstanding for honorable character and scholarship."

Warning against the danger of international inflationary competition, Prime Minister R.B. Bennett of Canada asserted yesterday in a broadcast from London that substantial agreement must be reached among the nations on stabilization of exchange rates and general monetary policies to insure world recovery.

George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, is expected to explain today before a subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee why he waited until after the bank holiday to act against Joseph W. Harriman, former head of the Harriman National Bank.

LANGLEY FIELD, Va., June 25 (AP). -- Four Langley Field fliers were killed when their bombing plane crashed into the James River near Rushmere late last night. The bodies were found by searchers tonight in the sunken craft.

LONDON, June 25. -- The World Economic Conference will begin its third week tomorrow very much in the spirit of Prime Minister MacDonald's statement to the journalists by coordinating and discussing "with a hopeful heart" such matters as regulation of the supply of primary products and mitigation of quotas, embargoes and tariffs.
BERLIN, June 25. -- As a result of the suppression of the Socialist party throughout Germany, numerous Socialist leaders were placed under "protective" arrest today.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The first major offensive in the government's campaign to increase agricultural purchasing power will be waged this week. The regions chosen for this operation are the cotton and cigar-leaf tobacco producing belts of the country.

LAKE HOPATCONG. N.J., June 25. -- With the surface of the lake showing scarcely a ripple, college and schoolboy drivers attacked existing records with considerable vigor today as the fourth annual intercollegiate outboard motor-boat championship regatta came to a close.

Criticisms aimed at foreign missionaries are nowhere justified, the Righ Rev. James De Wolf Perry, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, declared in an official pronouncement yesterday morning in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

"The only war I ever approved of was the Trojan war; it was fought over a woman and the men knew what they were fighting for," said Professor William Lyon Phelps, of Yale University, in his sermon, "Seeing and Hearing," yesterday morning at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

Holders of $46,000,000 of real estate bonds guaranteed by the National Surety Company were notified yesterday that the special committee of Insurance Commissioners apopinted recently to protect the interests of the bondholders would soon submit a comprehensive plan that would outline the negotiations of the committee.

Most commodities traded on local Exchanges made moderate gains on balance in last week's trading. Throughout the period price movements were irregular, but, except for silver and coffee, the various waves of strength were greater than the selling waves in size.

Professor MELVILLE B. ANDERSON, who died last Thursday in California at the age of 82, will be remembered as a great teacher, though for a longer time no doubt as the translator of DANTE'S "Divine Comedy" in terza rima. He began this great labor of love when, as DANTE said of his own immortal adventure, "half the journey of life was done" (nel mezzo del cammin di nostra vita).

A sweeping condemnation of most of the suggestions made since the end of the war for improving international relations and preserving peace is made by John Bassett Moore, former judge of the Permanent Court of International Justice and authority on international law, in an article appearing today in Foreign Affairs.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Assertions that the National Industrial Recovery Act and other legislation passed at the recent session of Congress would change the system of government and set up State socialism were challenged by Louis McH. Howe, secretary to the President, in a radio talk over the National Broadcasting network tonight.

The authorities of life have not decayed, but have shifted and changed to assume a truer aspect, said the Rev. Dr. George A. Buttrick, pastor of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventy-third Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- A reactionary market for hogs featured last week. Prices moved within a wide range, but not materially different from the previous week except that the top prices were around 10 cents a hundredweight under the week before.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., June 25 (AP). -- Jack Sharkey resumed his preparations for his fifteen-round heavyweight championship bout against Primo Carnera Thursday night with a brisk workout before a big crowd today.

Reconsideration of the Jewish problem by the governments that sought to find a solution for it at Versailles was asked by Dr. Chaim Weizmann, former president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, in an address yesterday. He spoke over a national hook-up of the Columbia Broadcasting system.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 25. -- Within a month a master code of business ethics for the entire American grocery industry will be submitted to the government for approval and cooperation in enforcement. This was decided tonight as leaders of seven national food industry organizations started preparing tentative codes for comparison and amalgamation.

ON BOARD THE MARY ALICE off Mount Desert Island, Me., June 25. -- President Roosevelt today in vited Norman H. Davis to board the schooner Amberjack II for a series of conferences on international affairs, and later sent the destroyer Bernadou off toward Boston to bring the Ambassador al Large on Monday night.
WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Criticizing the administration savagely on many fronts, Representative Snell tonight reviewed the record of Congress's "most extraordinary session in history."

James A. Hatch will oppose Clarence H. Fay for the leadership of the Republicans in the Tenth Assembly District, the anti-Koenig forces announced yesterday. Mr. Hatch is one of the leaders in the movement to oust Samuel S. Koenig as county chairman, occupying the post of chairman of the executive committee of the anti-Koenig group.

SOUTHPORT, England, June 25. -- Captain Walter Hagen led his American Ryder Cup golf team through a final practice session today for the two-day international test against Great Britain's picked professionals, starting tomorrow.

NEW HAVEN, June 25. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 64, which compares with 63.5 a week ago, 62.7 two weeks ago, 62.1 three weeks ago and 61.2 four weeks ago. The present average is the highest of the year to date; the average of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.

"The World's Greatest Ninety-nine Days," just published by Harpers, with an advance sale to one department store here of 2,000 copies, is a clip book of newspaper headlines and cartoons scissored and pasted by Ben Duffy and Harford Powell.

HANOVER, N.H., June 25 (AP). -- The combination of Louis H. Watson and Sam Fry of New York City won the all-American championship contract pairs, the final computed result being announced today after completion of the third session of this event.

The trip which Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and his wife will make to Greenland in the next two or three weeks probably will be extended across the Atlantic to Iceland, and possibly to Denmark, it was reported yesterday. It will be a flight to determine for Pan-American Airways the feasibilit of a northern route to Europe.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 25. -- Endorsing efforts for unity in American Israel to meet the emergency arising out of the German situation, the Central Conference of American Rabbis declared in resolutions today that it was anxious for such unity and pledged its cooperation.

BERLIN, June 25. -- The Central Commission for Home Missions has been seized by August Jaeger, newly appointed Prussian Commissioner for the Protestant church organizations, who authorized two of his Nazi subordinates to manage this organization's affairs.
The full text of the business code prepared by the National Retail Dry Goods Association for submission to Hugh S. Johnson, Administrator of the National Recovery Act, is as follows:

Women interested in the community of St. Johnland in Kings Park, L.I., have arranged a fair and carnival in its behalf to be held Friday afternoon and night on the grounds of the community. One of the features of the evening's entertainment will be the appearance of Miss Cornelia Otis Skinner, who will present groups of her original monologues.

PITTSBURGH, June 25. -- Steel producers still refrain from quoting openly any prices beyond this week and refuse to indicate when announcements are probabe. They have held many meeting to discuss how far they could go, both in drawing up a "code of fair competition" and what they could do thereafter.

Berkeley Bell, playing in defense of his title, won two matches in the Eastern clay court championship tourney at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday. He thrilled the large gallery as he warded off the respective threats of Ernest Kuhn and Anton Von Bernuth and entered the fourth round.

For the coming cinema season, officials of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer announced yesterday that their studios will produce forty-six feature films besides fifty-six two-reel subjects and 104 issues of the Hearst Metrotone news. The list includes six special productions, "Hollywood Party," "Dark to Dawn," "Soviet," a new untitled Marie Dressler picture, "Tarzan and His Mate," and "Two Thieves."

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.T., June 25. -- Dissatisfied with the action of the Westchester Presbytery in ousting the Rev. Archibald Fulton from the pulpit of the Bedford Presbyterian Church, sixty members of the congreation attended today a aervice on the lawn of Dr. Fulton's, home.
LONDON, June 25. -- Fresh efforts by the European gold bloc that would be likely to thwart the spread to Europe of President Roosevelt's price-raising program were decided upon over the weekend.

NEW ORLEANS, June 25. -- The cotton market was active last week and the general trend of prices was upward. New high levels for the season were reached toward the end of the week, when October advanced to 9.65 and December to 9.80.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 25. -- Almost 1,000 persons from Long Island and New York visited Sunken Orchard, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E.F. McCann, this afternoon to view the gardens and see a fashion revue given in aid of the Architects Emergency Committee, under the direction of Mrs. Tuckerman Draper of New York and Newport.

The twentieth World Congress of the International New Thought Alliance convened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. More than 400 delegates, representing New Thought groups and organizations throughout the world, attended the opening session.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The difficulty of fixing a stabilization price for non-gold standard currencies is virtually insurmountable aside from the reluctance of the American administration to even commit itself to the attempt. Any ratios agreed upon would be, at best, only vague approximations of the future course of world trade and capital movements.

The freight traffic of the port of New York will suffer no loss from the opening of the new Illinois waterway, according to shipping men. The canal which was dedicated last week by Secretary of War Dern, linking the Great Lakes and the Gulf of Mexico, may however, weaken the argument of the proponents of the development of the St. Lawrence waterway.

Dr. Fritz Thyssen, German industrialist and a close friend of Chancellor Adolf Hitler, told American radio listeners yesterday that trade was of more vital importance than money itself and that the idea that individuals or nations could sell without buying was "entirely wrong if not absolutely absurd."

LOS ANGELES, June 25. -- A group of scientists, after four years of experiments, announced today a new weather forecasting system which they said had proved 96.1 per cent accurate in telling from twenty-four to forty-eight hours before the weather arrived what the conditions would be in every part of the country.

Playing ineptly and hitting the same way, the Dodgers yesterday dropped the first game of a double-header to the Pirates before 25,000 at Ebbets Field, 5 to 2, but reversed themselves on both counts to take the nightcap, 9 to 1.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Several questions occur on reading the National Industrial Recovery Act and official pronouncements relating to it.
