The Public Service Commission will begin hearings on July 5 on Mayor O'Brien's complaint against the rates of the Bronx Gas and Electric Company. In fixing the hearing date the commission gave the city preference over scores of complaints brought throughout the State against various utility rates.

BOSTON, June 25 (AP). -- Manager Charlie Grimm of the Cubs benched himself before today's double-header with the Braves and his mates hammered out a 12-3 victory in the first game. They dropped the nightcap, 4 to 3, however, losing three of the four-game series.

The full story of former President Hoover's adventure into medieval scholarship, which cost him his spare time for five years and resulted in the translation with voluminous notes of De Re Metallica a Latin classic of mining, If published today.
PARIS, June 25. -- Cappiello, owned by Lady Granard, the former Beatrice Mills, won the sixty-sixth running of the Grand Prix de Paris today at Longchamps. The distance was 3,000 meters.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 25. -- Mouette, the twelve-meter yacht owned by Horace Havemeyer, beat Cantitoe and Iris in the special regatta held by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club on Long Island Sound today.

Representative Randolph Perkins sold to Walter J. McLaren of Bloomfield five parcels of realty located in the Journal Square, Bergen and Greenville sections of Jersey City, with a taxable value of $299,400.

WARWICK, N.Y., June 24. -- After a year of careful organization, a group of New York physicians met here yesterday and outlined plans for a multiple attack on the problem of juvenile delinquency. They were members of the Medical Board of the State Training School for Boys here, a $2,250,000 institution which began operation less than a year ago.

The Police College staged its commencement exercises in the Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon to the accompaniment of three brass bands, rifle and machine-gun fire and the cheers of more than 50,000 spectators.

With prospects of a modified form of price-fixing in fair competition codes under the Recovery Act, building trades and allied interests in this city and vicinity discussed over the week-end the subject of building material prices as they affect the part the builder is to play in the industrial control program.
NEW YORK. Sir Campbell Stuart will return to the Ambassador today from Canada.

BERLIN, June 24. -- The week's developments, both domestic and international, caused a setback in confidence as expressed in an unbroken decline on the Boerse, which brought the majority of stocks below levels of "Jewish boycott panic week."
Alice Is in Conference. "Well, if it isn't Alice," said the Hatter. He jumped up from the table on which were laid out sixty-six green blotters with sixty-six white pads and sixty-six yellow pencils.

An old New Yorker, who has summered and wintered with successive Tammany administrations, was asked the other day if he had not come to have a cumulative and appalling sense of the wickedness of Tammany government. "No," he replied; "the thing "that most depresses me is its stu"pidity."
SAN FRANCISCO, June 25. -- Slight earth tremors were felt throughout a wide area of California and Nevada today.

MONTREAL, June 25 (Canadian Press). -- J. Frank Hilton, fugitive wanted in the United States on liquor charges, was found dead in his apartment here today. Doctors expressed the opinion he died from acute indigestion.

For half an hour yesterday Rivington Street and the other teeming streets about it on the east side were feverishly excited as police conducted a child hunt. Rose Gecker, 3 years old, had been reported kidnapped.

If last week's day-by-day action of prices on the Stock Exchange gave reflection to the trend of ideas at the Economic Conference, their alternating forward and backward movement would appear to picture, accurately enough, the confusion of purpose indicated in the cables.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The text of the speech delivered by General Hugh S. Johnson, Administrator for the National Recovery Administration, tonight over the combined networks of the National and Columbia, Broadcasting Companies was as follows:

CHICAGO, June 25. -- Application by modern psychology of the up-to-date laws of quantum mechanics in probing the mysteries of sensation and consciousness furnishes definite experimental proof that Shakespeare was right in his concept that "we are such stuffs as dreams are made on, and our little life is rounded with a sleep."

An increase in the living costs of wage earners is noted for the first time since September, 1930, in the monthly index of the National Industrial Conference Board, made public yesterday. It was due almost entirely to a substantial rise in food prices and amounted to 0.8 per cent, the index shows.

CLEVELAND, June 25 (AP). -- Thirty thousand fans saw Washington tighten its hold on first place today by defeating the Cleveland Indians in both frames of a double-header, 9 to 0 and 10 to 1. The Senators gained a full game on the Yanks and now lead by a game and a half.

The timid are continually afraid that religion will be killed if its old formulae are questioned, the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie, rector of Grace Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning. "But as a matter of fact," he added, "the only danger to religion is in those who by identifying new learning with heresy make orthodoxy synonymous with ignorance'."

PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 25. -- Giraud Foster, president of the Mahkeenac Boat Club, has offered a cup to the skipper who wins the most sailboat races this Summer. The first race was held this afternoon.

Interest in all kinds of fishing has taken a tremendous jump within the past few weeks. The trout fishing in the East has decreased slightly -- that is, so far as the novice is concerned. Salt water fishing has come to the fore with the arrival in near-by waters of many species which provide sport and food.

With Jim McCloskey holding Albany to three hits, Jersey City conquered the Senators, 4 to 1, to gain an even break in a double-header at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday. Albany won the opener, 4 to 3.

PARIS, June 24. -- It is thought here that accentuation of the dollar's decline is much more likely than its recovery, or even than lengthy stabilization around the present price. The possibility of a heavy drop is even discussed. Everything will naturally depend on the turn the situation takes in the United States.

The Flanagan-Nay Brewing Corp., Thomas G. Lamphier president, gave to the Clinton Trust Co. a trust mortgage for $650,000 on the group of three, four and five story buildings at 262-266 10th Av., 448-460 W. 26th St. and 441-457 W. 25th St., subject to a first mortgage held by the Chemical Bank and Trust Co., as trustee, for $177.500.

Still climbing when so many at one time thought they would never even get their machine off the ground, the Giants put themselves a trifle further beyond reach of their pursuers in the National League race by wrenching two more games away from the Reds at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

The operating rate of the steel industry increased two points last week to 51 per cent of capacity, says the magazine Steel. Pointing put that pig iron backs up this gain in steel production with the resumption of four more blast furnaces, the publication is of the opinion that a further gain in steel operations will be recorded this week.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 25. -- Trailing only for a few moments at the start, Winston Guest's Templeton polo team defeated the Sands Point four, 10 to 9, at the Sands Point Club today.

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP).-- Jimmy Foxx's sixteenth home run of the season, in the tenth inning with Ted Lyons pitching and Bob Johnson on base gave the Athletics a 5 to 3 victory in the second game of their doublehearter today after the White Sox had won the first, 3 to 2.
DETROIT, June 25. -- The experience of being a bench warmer for a reason other than illness or accident overtook Babe Ruth today for the first time since he became a big league star.
LONDON, June 25 (AP). -- Crack interpreters, veterans of many an international parley, scratch their heads at the "Americanisms" heard in the World Economic Conference.

The National Recovery Act would enable many communities to build long-needed public works for about one-third of their cost prior to 1929, it was declared yesterday by Dr. D. B. Steinman, chairman of the New York Metropolitan District of the National Committee for Trade Recovery.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 25 (AP). -- Ellsworth Vines and Mrs. Helen Wills Moody head a strong American cast in the all-England tennis championships opening tomorrow.

LONDON, June 25. -- Soviet-Rumanian non-aggression pact negotiations have been resumed here between Foreign Commissar Litvinott and Foreign Minister Titulescu. The Poles, who signed and ratified their pact with Russia months ago, have been instrumental in bringing the two diplomats together.

Five hundred persons gathered at the Battery yesterday afternoon and watched as the tiny Joventud Filipina -- in which three Filipino youths hope to sail to their native land -- chugged out, under her four-horsepower auxiliary motor, between the stone breakwaters.

More than 200 teachers of printing in the United States and Canada are expected to attend the twelfth annual conference on printing education which will open today at Columbia University. The conference, sponsored by the committee on education of the United Typothetae of America, will continue tomorrow and Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The first decrease in relief expenditures was reported in April, according to statistics from 1,008 relief-giving agencies in 120 cities of 50,000 or more population tabulated by the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 25. -- Greentree, with F.S. Von Stade Jr., C.V. (Sonny) Whitney, Tommy Hitchcock Jr. and John Hay (Jock) Whitney riding in that order, won the Third Westbury Challenge Cup tournament for the second successive year today by downing the Meadow Brook Ramblers, 8 to 6, in the final match on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club.

The text of the proposed Dry Goods Code is printed on Page 2 A tentative code of fair competition for the dry goods, department and specialty stores of the United States was made public yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association. The draft of the code has been submitted for approval to the members of the association, who represent about 3,800 stores with a business of about $3,500,000,000 in sales last year.

MOSCOW, June 25. -- While the world's attention is concentrated on London there has occurred during the past week a crystallization of Soviet policy that may well prove a historical landmark in European affairs.
ST. LOUIS, June 25 (AP). -- The Browns took two games from the Red Sox today and ended up only a half game below the New Englanders in the American League standings.

VATICAN CITY, June 25. -- A bomb exploded soon after noon today at the central gate of St. Peter's Basilica at a time when both the church and the piazza were unusually crowded with Holy Year pilgrims. Four persons were injured, one seriously-an aeronautical engineer, Alexander Sartorio, who received a fractured left thigh.

BERLIN, June 25. -- As a result of the reported appearance of anti-German propaganda airplanes over Berlin Friday, the Reich's aviation authorities have instructed all German airports to exercise vigilance in checking foreign planes traversing German territory wherever it is established that they are not attached to commercial lines, whose machines are of familiar types.

As the new fiscal year approaches, heads are falling in the departments at Washington. Who is to be the next victim of economy? This is the daily thought in the minds of an army of Government employes. Meanwhile, the far more multitudinous host of deserving Democrats is hammering and howling at the gates, and the nervousness of Democratic Congressmen increases.

BUENOS AIRES, June 25. -- The spectacular rise in flaxseed, equivalent to 11 1/2 cents a bushel, was the feature of last week's markets here. After strengthening steadily and slowly since the first of the month, heavy export buying in the last three days of the week suddenly pushed the price to 12.38 pesos a quintal, compared with 11.40 pesos on the previous Saturday.

LONDON, June 24. -- In the view of financial London at the week-end America's attitude to such an essential matter as currency stabilization is hard to understand, and the opinion is growing that Europe must make her own arrangements if the economic conference is to achieve even a modicum of success.

BERLIN, June 24. -- The week's stock market in Berlin underwent an unbroken decline with heavy selling and sharp falls in prices on Friday. Some buying by the Reichsbank with blocked marks took place early in the week, but in general foreigners were out of the market.

Dr. Edward L. Brennan did not split fees in compensation cases with Dr. "William H. Walker, brother of the former Mayor, the City Affairs Committee said in a formal statement issued yesterday. This reversal of the committee's previous position came after Dr. Brennan had submitted his books to the committee.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Administrators of the emergency acts which will give employment to upward of 40,000 non-civil service workers have received an order from President Roosevelt, sent while on cruise, that "no extraordinary salaries shall be paid."

CHICAGO, June 25. -- June drought and unusually high temperatures have made probably the greatest nroads on small grain crops, wheat, oats, rye and barley, that have been known to the trade in years. There are indications that production will be close to the lowest that traders of the present day have known.

Michael Cohen, Philadelphia gunman, arrested on Broadway Saturday night entirely on "a hunch," confessed yesterday, according to the police, that he was involved in the kidnapping of Hilda Brodsky, 9 years old, in Wilmington, Del., on April 15.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The most important task the Legislature faces next year is the reapportionment of the political districts of the State for the Federal Congress and the State Senate and Assembly.

The Republic of Colombia, through its Minister of Finance and Public Credit, Esteban Jaramillo, announced yesterday its inability to continue the debt service on the government and government-guaranteed American dollar bonds "owing to extraordinary and unavoidable expenses for national defense imposed upon it by the invasion of its territory, which gave rise to the recent conflict with Peru."

BERLIN, June 25. -- August Jaeger, newly appointed Nazi commissioner for the Protestant church organizations in Prussia, lost no time today in organizing his official machinery, which is to accomplish the complete coordination of the, Protestant church in Prussia.

The printing industry is drastically "overequipped and undersold," L.S. Downey, former president of the New York Employing Printers Association, declared yeterday before more than 100 teachers of printing from schools throughout the country.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that the Mitchell trial is over, one may properly express the abhorrence felt by every advocate of fair play for the archaic rule, rigorously applied in the Federal courts, which bars a man or his wife as a witness for or against the other in any case, civil or criminal.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Every pledge of the Democratic platform has been fulfilled or is well on the way to fulfillment, Senator Robinson, floor leader, said today in a statement outlining the work accomplished by the administration and Congress in the special session.

BOSTON, June 26 -- Enlistment of the Rotary clubs of the United States in a movement to check increasing vagrancy among boys and young men was voted at a meeting of the United States Assembly of Rotarians at the convention, of Rotary International today.

The Red Barn Theatre of Mrs. Don Marquis at Locust Valley, L.I., will open this evening with a presentation of Elizabeth Risdon in Noel Coward's "Hay Fever." Lowell Gilmore has directed the production.
Perforated and shattered window panes in five business buildings downtown presented a mystery yesterday to detectives of the Beach Street precinct.

SPARKILL, N.Y., June 26 -- Abner Hardy Shoup, 53 years old, was arrested early this morning charged with attempting to set fire to Stonehurst, the home of his family for generations. He is being held at the Rockland County jail at New City on a charge of arson and will have a hearing tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- President Roosevelt's liberalization of compensation allowances for World War veterans suffering actual service-connected disabilities will cost in the neighborhood of $46,000,000. Copies of the modified regulations were forwarded today to the regional offices throughout the country for guidance in calculating future benefits.

Seldom has an honor come more fittingly than the agreement of the delegates to the New York State Convention, to be held in Albany today, that ALFRED E. SMITH should be their chairman. They are to ratify repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment on behalf of this State in response to the overwhelming expression of the people of New York.

A movement to end cut-throat competition in the garment industry and to make it possible for manufacturers to "make a living wage" was begun under the Industrial Recovery Act at a meeting of the Women's Garment Manufacturers Supply Association at the Hotel New Yorker last night.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 26 -- Election of officers and adoption, of a resolution declaring the creation of a Jewish commonwealth in Palestine was the only solution to the Jewish problem concluded today the business of the annual convention here of the Sons of Zion.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For some hundred years, the three lower islands in the East River -- Welfare, Wards and Randalls -- have been used principally for homes, asylums and hospitals for the poor, the sick and the afflicted.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 26 -- Senator Gerald P. Nye, insurgent Republican from North Dakota and author four years ago of a set of "fair trade" bills in Congress, the provisions of which he sees in the Industrial Recovery Act, told the convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers here today that "everything depends now on the honesty and judgment of President Roosevelt and his good fortune in choosing his administrators."

Violent advances in the principal commodities overshadowed all other market developments yesterday. The movement in these markets was the most sensational in recent years. Cotton rose to above 10 cents a pound -- which has been regarded as a pivotal point -- and wheat approached within striking distance of $1 a bushel, also a sentimental market objective.

Rapid decline in earnings and no prospect of improvement in the future are the chief reasons cited by the Long Island Railroad for wishing to abandon its Wading River branch beyond Port Jefferson. This was disclosed yesterday, when the company's application to the Interstate Commerce Commission for a certificate of public convenience and necessity authorizing abandonment was made public here by Alfred A. Gardner, counsel for the road.
The Nassau Country Club team yesterday became the 1933 Class A champion of the Long Island Women's Inter-club Golf League, finishing the season with a total of 15 points.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 26 -- Methods of war annihilate war. Dr. Robert A. Millikan, chairman of the executive council. California Institute of Technology, said in an address on "Science and Internationalism" in Alumnae Hall, Wellesley College, here tonight.
Colonel William Hayward announced yesterday that he had accepted the chairmanship of a committee formed to fight to retain Samuel S. Koenig as Republican county chairman of New York.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- The iconoscope, which duplicates the human eye and is hailed by radio engineers as a revolutionary invention in television, making its use in the home at last practical, was described for the first time here today before the meeting of the Institute of Radio Engineers by Dr. Vladimir K. Zworykin of the RCA-Victor Company's research laboratories at Camden, N.J.
LONDON, June 26 -- Following is the text of Senator James Couzens's speech before the World Economic Conference today:

BERLIN, June 26 -- While the Nazi power, through the machinery directed by the Reich Church Commissioner, August Jaeger, is swiftly taking measures for the regimentation of German Protestantism, the German Evangelical forces behind former Reichsbishop Friedrich von Bodelachwingh are preparing for a final effort to retain at least a remnant of autonomy for the German Protestant Church.

An issue of $8,000,000 State of Minnesota 4 1/4 per cent rural credit bonds, due serially from 1948 to 1952, was bought yesterday from the State Sinking Fund by a group of local banks. The price paid was par and accrued interest. The sale was a private one.
Vincent Coll's widow, Mrs. Lottie Kreisberger Coll, and the two men arrested with her last Friday were charged last night with murder in the first degree.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 26 -- Leonard Hartman of Columbia and Allan Swayze of New York University were among the winners in the opening of the forty-ninth annual national intercollegiate tennis championships at Merion today.

Gross revenues of the first eighteen railroads to report for May were about $93,914,000, against $95,755,000 in May, 1932, a decrease of 1.9 per cent, and against $136,632,000 an May, 1931, a decrease of 31.2 per cent.
ALBANY, June 26 -- Thousands of his former neighbors turned out to welcome Alfred E. Smith today as he arrived to preside over the State repeal convention here tomorrow.

Standards of housing to be adopted and enforced under the Industrial Recovery Act were among questions discussed by housing experts at a conference held yesterday by the National Housing Association at the Russell Sage Foundation headquarters, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

Teachers of printing who have come here from various parts of the United States should take note of a newly found ancestor of our alphabet. It is generally accepted that our letters came to us from Phoenicia by way of Greece, but it has teen recently discovered that this great gift to the West had a remoter origin.

Arthur J. Knorr, production manager of the Capitol Theatre, sliced his drive at the first hole of the Hilcrest Golf Course in Jamaica April 7 last year. It was a decided slice. And it will cost Mr. Knorr several hundred dollars.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 26 -- Sidney Carson of the Kiski School at Saltsburgf, Pa., led a qualifying field of seventy today in the twenty-second annual Eastern interscholastic golf championship over the course of the Greenwich Country Club.

Frederic Kernochan, Chief Justice of the Court of Special Sessions, and George Trosk, Samuel Seabury's chief assistant in the city investigation, gave their support to the work of the Knickerbocker Democrats, anti-Tammany organization, at a meeting last night. The meeting was held in the organization's headquarters at 52 West Eighth Street.

LONDON, June 26 -- The question of modification of the most-favored-nation clause to facilitate bilateral or regional tariff agreements was discussed by the commercial policy committee of the World Economic Conference today.
Senator Royal S. Copeland expressed doubt yesterday that there is any connection between racketeering and politics in New Tork State.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on June 21 shows increases for the week of $284,000,000 in loans and investments, $73,000,000 in time deposits and $475,000,000 in government deposits, and decreases of $384,000,000 in net demand deposits and $82,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The London Economic Conference was instituted, if I am not mistaken, with the idea of smoothing out the economic conflicts that stand in the way of peace, or, in other words, that keep people alarmed and in fear of war.

Edward D. Maloney, 33 years old, former State trooper and Federal prohibition enforcement officer, was found guilty at 7:30 o'clock last night by a Jury in General Sessions of manslaughter in the first degree in the slaying of Larry Fay, racketeer.

SOUTHPORT, England, June 26 (AP) -- Thanks largely to the heroic putting of a player who was almost left off the team -- Billy Burke -- the United States averted a rout today at the hands of the British professionals.

In one of the largest leases of office space negotiated in Manhattan in many months, the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), parent holding company for the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and several operating subsidiaries, rented three floors in the seventy-story RCA building in Rockefeller Center and will move its headquarters there about Aug. 1.

The story of how the New York Clearing House, the United States Treasury Department and the Department of Justice stayed the prosecution of Joseph W. Harriman for nine months after false entries were found on the books of his bank was spread upon, the record of a Senate investigating committee here yesterday.

An advance of 10 cents a bushel in wheat in two days and optimistic reports from Washington regarding the outlook for acreage reduction caused a violent rise in cotton yesterday under the most active trading in several years.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H., June 26 -- John Roosevelt, who has been cruising with the President, expects to arrive on Wednesday at the White Mountain polo ranch, Whitefield, to get in some practice before the first match, which is scheduled for Sunday afternoon at 3 o'clock.

While the stock market made yesterday what Wall Street considers a "good showing," speculative interest all day long was monopolized by the commodity markets. The tendency everywhere was to subordinate the stock market to the commodity markets.

LONDON, June 26 -- Prospects of an agreement for the restriction of wheat production, which seemed so bright toward the end of last week that some London newspapers hailed it as an accomplished fact, today become greatly clouded by the opposition of Australian States to the plan, although the central government seems to approve.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Seeking quick action in putting to work about $100,000,000 for non-Federal projects that would come under the self-liquidating section of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation Act, Donald H. Sawyer, Administrator of Public Works, today asked the R.F.C. for a list of such projects.

The General Sessions trial of four officials of the General Industrial Foundation Corporation on a conspiracy indictment continued yesterday with the testimony of another or the defendants, Bonowitz X. Dawson. The four are accused of having conspired to defraud Mrs. Ella de Bevoise Patterson of Red Bank, N.J., of $588,000 in stock.
Sigmund Tancer, middle-aged jeweler of 48 West Forty-eighth Street, fell to the ground in front of 21 Eldridge Street at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon and shouted for help.

Corliss and Margaret Lament, radically inclined son and daughter-in-law of Thomas W. Lament, sailed last Summer tourist class to spend two months in Russia. Their perhaps facetious friends loaded them down with bon voyage gifts of chocolate to stave off hunger pains.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The United Gas and Electric Company of Jersey City denied, in a petition filed today with the Board of Tax Appeals, the making of $6,656,031 profit in the sale of stock to the Associated Gas and Electric Company.

The best thing about the Chicago Opera Company's "Carmen," which made its appearance last night at the New Tork Hippodrome, was Giuseppe Bamboschek's orchestra. One hastens to add that the principals gave performances on the whole adequate.

VATICAN CITY, June 26 (AP) -- Strained relations between Spain and the Vatican were blamed today by authorities for yesterday's bomb explosion in the portico of St. Peter's, mother church of the Roman Catholic world.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- A District of Columbia judge took under advisement today a motion for dismissal of the $220,000,000 suit against Andrew W. Mellon and other former Treasury officials, which charged they helped foreign steamship companies to defraud the government of income taxes.

No insurmountable obstacle is in sight which may mar the success of the London Economic Conference, Secretary of State Cordell Hull, head of the American delegation, declared last night in London in an interview which was rebroadcast in this country by the National Broadcasting Company.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 26 -- While rain twice interrupted play and later made it impossible to complete the first day's schedule, seven matches were contested and two decided by defaults as the women's metropolitan clay court tennis championships began today at the Lido Country Club.

ALBANY, June 26 (AP) -- Figures showing that wholesale prices of gas and electricity increased from July, 1929, to April, 1933, while other wholesale commodity prices declined heavily, were presented by a Columbia University economist at the resumption today of the Public Service Commission investigation into up-State utilities.
BERLIN, June 26 -- Following a weak opening during which prices declined up to 2 per cent, the Boerse turned firm and active today and closed with gains up to 4 per cent.

LONDON, June 26 -- Americans and others interested in the rehabilitation of silver said today that India's willingness to help in the rehabilitation of silver was the most important event that could have happened to force the program to a successful conclusion.
Two public school principals who have served at least fifty years will retire with the closing of the city's schools for the Summer.

The first failure of plans to reduce excess facilities since the railway coordination principle was enacted into law was disclosed yesterday in a case involving the New York Central and Pennsylvania systems. The case arose from an attempt to coordinate passengertrain service facilities at Buffalo.

Before an audience which included Cardinal Hayes and Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, a comic playlet and several song-and-dance acts were presented yesterday afternoon by boys and girls of the Catholic Institute for the Blind, at Paulding Avenue and 221st Street, the Bronx.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday ...1 1/2 per cent for the best names Friday ......1 1/2 per cent for the best names The quotations are lor three-four months paper.

Customs officials attempted yesterday to solve the mystery of the disappearance of 300 bottles of Whisky, spirits and brandies, 1,187 bottles of beer and 1,000 bottles of wine from the storeroom of the Hamburg-American liner Reliance during her lay-up of three months at a Hoboken pier.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Bullock Jr. have returned to the Lombardy from London, where they went after their marriage on April 5. Mrs. Bullock, who is the former Miss Marie Leontine Graves, was presented at court in London last month.

LONDON, June 26 (AP) -- Effort to put world sugar production back on its feet will be made by Orestes Ferrara, Cuban Secretary of State, in an addres, probably tomorrow, at the beginning of sugar discussions before the subcommittee on commercial policy of the economic commission of the World Economic Conference.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The banking practices of Kuhn, Loeb Co. will be brought under scrutiny when the Senate Banking and Currency Committee resumes its investigation tomorrow morning of Stock Exchange practices.

MARION, Mass., June 26 -- Eighteen crews of schoolboy yachtsmen today began racing in the fourth annual regatta of the Interscholastic Yacht Racing Association. So large was the entry list that it was necessary to split the fleet into two divisions of nine boats each.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 26 -- Advertising's aid in the fight on the depression was asked in messages from President Roosevelt and General Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Act Administrator, read today to delegates attending the national convention of the Advertising Federation of America.
The belief that a Hohenzollern would eventually be restored as monarch of Germany was expressed here last night by James W. Gerard, Ambassador of the United States In Germany before the World War.

Playing his first tournament match since his return from Europe, Frank Shields, fifth in-the national ranking, defeated Reginald Talmage of Brooklyn yesterday in the Eastern clay court championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

ANATOLE FRANCE once shook bands with an especially mad free-verse poet "for fear of wronging beauty in disguise." For a similar reason the American Association for the Advancement of Science listened respectfully to the speculations of Professor HENRI PIERON on thinking, perception and the relation of the mind to the outer world.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 26 -- Don M. Parker, organizer and president of the New York State Golf Association, paired with his son Brewster, aged 16, today to win the eighteenth annual father and son tournament over the Garden City Golf Club course.

MOSCOW, June 26 -- Much sympathy is felt in Moscow for "the victims of the Reichstag fire provocation," as it is called here-the well-known German Communist, Ernst Torgler; the exiled leader of, the Bulgarian Communist party, Georgi Dimitroff, and two fellow countrymen of his, Blegoi S. Popoff and Basil C. Taneff, who are also exiled Communists.

An investigation of labor conditions on American merchant ships has been started by the National Association of American Seamen, 250 West Twenty-third Street, as a result of numerous complaints of favoritism and maltreatment filed by American-born seamen. It was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- A new system for the gasoline and oil business, with the President setting price limits and dealers competing "by the book," was offered to oil refiners and jobbers today. This was the work of sixty marketing association delegates who met here to draft a Recovery Act code.

DETROIT, June 26 -- The sole reason for the closing of the First National and Guardian National Banks was, in his opinion, "a Wall Street plot to get Henry Ford," Herbert R. Wilkin, general manager of the Guardian-Detroit Union group, testified this afternoon in the grand jury bank inquiry before Judge Harry B. Kaidan.

Futures in all commodities traded on local exchanges followed the lead of wheat and cotton yesterday, although in most cases the swings were of smaller proportions. The trading volume increased somewhat over last week. All the cash markets were higher, with wheat and cotton leading into new high ground.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Civilian Conservation Corps is apparently serving as an excellent emergency stop-gap. It is affording a livelihood to thousands of men who would otherwise be applying for aid to local relief agencies. So far, so good. But does not this excellent plan of emergency relief offer an opening for a permanent addition to our social structure?

CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- Professor Robert Morss Lovett of the University of Chicago, author and lecturer, spent an hour in a jail cell today because he espoused the cause of 1,500 garment factory workers striking for higher pay and a shorter working week.

A sharp trembling of the earth, mysterious in origin but of sufficient force to be felt over a wide area, alarmed residents of part of Westchester County and southern Connecticut about 9 A.M. yesterday.

Definite signs of business improvement were noted yesterday by United States customs service employes in convention at the Hotel New Yorker. One speaker condemned the "falsa propaganda" of economy committees and saw the end of the depression as near.

Agricultural commodities Yesterday made their sharpest grains in several years In the various markets throughout the country. On the New York Cotton Exchange cotton prices advanced more than $4 a bale, with all positions closing above 10 cents a pound.
BOSTON, June 26 -- Massachusetts ratified today the proposal to repeal the Eighteenth Amendment. Its convention cast a unanimous vote against prohibition and adjourned within fifty-five minutes.

Conventional balloon practice has merged with conventional submarine practice in preparations for the stratosphere flight to be made in July from Soldiers Field, Chicago, and once the flight gets under way the submarine influence will be emphasized.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 26 -- Mr. and Mrs. George D. Widener will spend the week-end and the Fourth of July at Miramar, the home of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Hamilton Rice. They will have a number of guests over the holiday. Mr. and Mrs. Widener will arrive late in the week and will give a dinner on Sunday.

WILLIAMSVILLE, N.Y., June 26 -- With Sidney W. Noyes Jr. of Dobba Ferry, N.Y., shooting one of the finest rounds of the day, the Yale University golf team today started the defense of its national intercollegiate title.

LONDON, June 26 -- An explanation of the recent unexpected dash of Premier Goemboes of Hungary to Berlin to interview Chancellor Hitler and his announcement on returning to Budapest that Austria's independence was in no danger from Germany was disclosed today in world conference quarters.
The twenty-fifth anniversary of the Crippled Children's East Side School will be observed this morning when fourteen graduates will receive diplomas at the school building at 157 Henry Street.

Bus operation by the East Side Omnibus Corporation over the routes formerly traversed by surface cars of the Second Avenue Railroad Corporation began "officially" yesterday afternoon. Mayor O'Brien started a bus on its way from Chatham Square to Harlem.

Continental gold currencies were weak in the foreign exchange markets yesterday, as the rumor persisted that some major shake-up in the monetary standards of one or more European countries was impending. In their movement, those currencies abandoned the leadership of the pound sterling, which continued to gain over the dollar in nervous trading.

Dr. McBRIDE, general superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League, is not only a cheerful but an ingenious loser and explainer of losses. He has the confidence, the courage, the subtle resourcefulness that national party chairmen used to be supposed to have. Early in June he was inspiring faith in the opponents of repeal.

MEXICO, D.F., June 26 -- The bodies of Captain Mariano Barberan and Lieutenant Joaquin Collar, missing Spanish transatlantic fliers, have been, been found in their wrecked plane near Alacran, the Ministry of the Interior announces. They are believed to have crashed Tuesday while on their way here from Havana.

A total of $9,924,621 was spent for relief in New York City during May and the number of families assisted was 274,464. This was revealed yesterday in the monthly analysis of outdoor relief made public by the Welfare Council. Outdoor relief is relief given to persons in their homes as distinguished from relief to persons in institutions.

LONDON, June 26 -- While the sixty-six nations were deliberating at the Economic Conference, representatives of sixty-odd of these States saw today a great flying demonstration of Britain's newest fighting airplanes, staged at Hendon by the Society of British Aircraft Constructors.

The Drug Institute of America, Inc., plans to include a provision for the maintenance of fair prices in its code of competition for the drug industry. The code is to submitted in the near future in compliance with the Industrial Recovery Act.

TOKYO, June 26 -- The conference to discuss the sale of the Chinese Eastern Railway opened this afternoon with speeches by Count Uchida, Japan's Foreign Minister, Ambassador Yureneff of Russia and General Ting Shih-yuan, Manchukuo's War Minister.

GENEVA, June 26 -- H.B. Butler, director of the International Labor Office, delivered today the closing speech of the labor conference on his report, citing several times, with keen appreciation, the cooperation given by the United States both here and in London in the social and economic field.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- State relief administrations must place the distribution of Federal funds for unemployment relief in charge of public agencies by Aug. 1. Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Emergency Relief Administrator, said today that this ruling prohibited the turning over of Federal funds to a private agency.

Our Laconic Congress. When the laws first enacted by Congress have definitely broken the back of the depression it will mean that prosperity has been restored at an expenditure of 40 hours and 40 minutes of general debate.

BOLTON LANDING, Lake George, N.Y., June 26 -- Bankers should divest themselves of all other business concerns, abandon ambitions to accumulate great fortunes and consecrate themselves to public service in a spirit of trusteeship, A.A. Berle Jr., member of President Roosevelt's so-called "brain trust," told the New York State Bankers Association in convention here today.
The additional compensation recently awarded to members of the vice squad was defended by Police Commissioner Bolan yesterday.

LONDON, June 26 (Canadian Press). -- The West Indies batting collapsed, and scores at the end of today's play in the test cricket match between England and the British West Indies were England 296, West Indies 55 for six wickets.

JUST when they were trying to tell Jack Sharkey that he was too old to win against a younger and bigger Carnera, along came the news that the Hon. Michael Scott, 55 years old, had run a lot of youngsters ragged on the Hoylake links and had strolled off himself with the British amateur golf championship.

ATLANTA, June 26 (AP) -- A race among the States for cotton acreage reduction was on in Dixie tonight A total of 10,000,000 acres must be retired, and from Texas to Virginia, the planters are mapping their plans accordingly.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Modifying a position previously taken, a conference of the dairy industry late tonight asked Secretary Wallace in a resolution to employ the licensing power granted to him in the Farm Adjustment Act only against those branches of the industry where it proves necessary to compel the observance of trade agreements.
Five parcels of Jersey City realty valued for taxation at $361,500 were among the New Jersey transactions reported yesterday.

Many good-hearted people seem to be pained by reports of differences and even bickering's at the World Economic Conference. It appeared to be thought by some that all the delegates would be of one mind, and would instantly embrace each, other and swear eternal friendship.

SOUTHPORT, England, June 26 -- At the end of the first day's play in the Ryder Cup matches, the United States is 1 down in foursomes with eight singles left to play. This may not sound particularly good, but it represented a fine comeback for the Americans nevertheless, for at the end of the morning round a total of 3 down seemed likely enough.

After having been told that many evils had sprung up in the administration of the immigration laws, a committee which will investigate conditions on Ellis Island got down to business yesterday. Subcommittees were designated and an agenda of work agreed upon.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Hoarders will get every opportunity to turn in gold, but if they fail to do so their names will be made public and they will be prosecuted in the Federal courts, Attorney General Cummings announced today.

HAVANA, June 28 -- The pirate radio station of the ABC student revolutionary organization was located by police this afternoon at the home of Dr. Augustine Castellanos, brother of Israel de Castellanos, the head of the National Bureau of Identification, and confiscated, according to the police.

James A. Broderick, State Banking Superintendent, was questioned yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler as to the legality of the sale of the assets of the defunct Bank of Europe Trust Company in the trial of an assessment suit against two stockholders.

LONDON, June 26 -- Senator Pittman's plan for the revaluation of silver cleared a big hurdle today when Sir George Ernest Schuster, financial member of the Executive Council of the Viceroy of India, declared that the Indian Government was prepared to cooperate.

LONDON, June 26 -- Australian objections to the American wheat acreage reduction program was believed tonight to have been met by a formula devised by a conference of United States delegates with Stanley M. Bruce, Australian Commissioner in England.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Prices in the grain markets here soared rapidly today on a wave of buying which engulfed sellers, both large and small, and swelled the total business of the month to date to the largest in the history of the local exchange.
BALTIMORE, June 26 -- Senator William E. Borah of Idaho underwent today a major operation at the Johns Hopkins Hospital here for a condition affecting the urinary organs.
ST. LOUIS, June 26 (AP) -- The Red Sox pounded three pitchers for fifteen hits today and won the third game of the series from the Browns, 13 to 5.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- President Roosevelt is expected to appeal to the voters for quick action on repeal in advance of the elections in Alabama and Arkansas on July 18 and in Tennessee on July 20. This appeal, according to those in his confidence, will be based upon the argument that laws imposing heavy Federal taxes, including those enacted in the recent session, can be repealed if the government can tax liquor.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The Bureau of Navigation Issued the following orderS today, dated June 22:

The New York Curb Exchange has admitted to unlisted trading on a when issued basis the new Class A common stock of the Fox Film Corporation which is to be exchanged for the present shares under the terms of a proposed reorganization.

Crude oil and gasoline prices were advanced further yesterday In several sections of the country. On the Pacific Coast the Standard Oil Company of California raised crude oil prices from 2 to 15 cents a barrel according to grade, and gasoline was put up 1 cent a gallon.
Sea bass are running abundantly off shore from Long Island, latest reports indicate. Anglers over the week-end had all the bass they wanted and in addition took quantities of porgieo and blackfish.

Edward Frederic Benson, British novelist, essayist and historian and third son of the late Archbishop of Canterbury, is the author of "Edward VII," a biography which Longmans, Green will publish in September.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A loan of $650,000 to the American. Museum of Natural History Authority of New York, for construction of a planetarium, was granted by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today just before the corporation transferred to the Emergency Public Works Administration its jurisdiction over self-liquidating projects.

ALBANY, June 26 -- William J. Brown of New York today was named a member of the State Athletic Commission to fill a vacancy caused by the death of William Muldoon. His term is for two years, beginning today.

The thirty-three-story office building at 114-20 Wall Street was bid in at auction yesterday by the New York Life Insurance Company, plaintiff in an action against the Greenmal Holding Corporation. The company's bid of $1,000,000 was the only one made.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 26 -- Paced by H. Ellsworth Vines Jr., the strong American delegation in the British tennis championships today moved through the first round of men's singles with ranks practically unbroken as two weeks of play began on the famous Wimbledon courts.

CHATTANOOGA, June 26 (AP) -- The importance of the editorial department of a newspaper was stressed before the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association today by Tom Wallace, editor of The Louisville Times. He is chairman of the association's editorial affairs committee.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- A picture of Mussolini as a tyrant who suppressed all liberties was presented today before the Norman Waite Harris Foundation at the University of Chicago by Jules Sauerwein, foreign editor of Paris Soir.

SOUTHPORT, England, June 26 -- Amid scenes of mass hysteria which the American golfers never had witnessed in this country previously, Great Britain got a slender grip on the Ryder Cup today by winning two of the four foursomes, halving one and losing one. The score was 2 1/2 to 1 1/2.
CLEVELAND, June 26 (AP) -- Joe Cronln's rampaging Senators continued their triumphant march through the West today, turning in their third successive conquest of the Indians. The score was 4 to 3.

HANKOW, China, June 28 -- A cloudburst in Eastern Kweichow Province has resulted in the destruction of the important city of Tungjen with a great loss of life, according to meager advices reaching here.

LAKEMAN HARBOR, Roque Island, Me., June 26 -- A Bay of Fundy fog, thick as sour cream, settled down over Amberjack II last night, with the result that the President experienced an enforced rest here today.

Controller Charles W. Berry dislosed yesterday that about $2,000,00 of city tax anticipation bonds carrying a 5 1/2 per cent interest rate had been sold from last Thursday to Saturday, with the Rockefellers among the first purchasers.

MOSCOW, June 26 (AP) -- G.I. Sokolnikoff, the Vice Commissar for Foreign Affairs, protested vigorously today to Tamekichi Ota, the Japanese Ambassador, against the alleged action of the Japanese destroyer Tachikaze in entering Soviet waters and sending a landing party ashore to investigate the reported slaying of three Japanese fishermen.

LONDON, June 26 -- Foreign Commissar Litvinoff of the Soviet Union visited Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, at the Foreign Office today on the invitation of the British Government and discussed resumption of Soviet-British trade relations.

The principal strength in the bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday was manifested by railroad issues, many active issues of this group rising 1 to more than 5 points on the day. Domestic industrial and utility bonds averaged higher as groups, but most of the major gains were scored by comparatively infrequently traded issues.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Displaying remarkable speed in a thrilling stretch drive, D.A. Wood's Indian Runner moved up from twelfth place to win by a length and a half over the Brookmeade Stable's Okapi in the seven furlongs of the $5,500 Inaugural Handicap which featured the opening program of Arlington Park's thirty-day meeting today.

Jack Sharkey and Primo Carnera are nearing the end of their training sessions for their battle at the Long Island City Bowl on Thursday night. Sharkey, who will defend his heavyweight championship against the Italian giant in a fifteen-round bout, is tapering off at Orangeburgh, N.Y., while his rival is finishing his preparations at Pompton Lakes, N.J.

A willingness to cooperate with manufacturers and other sources of supply of the retail stores of the country was expressed yesterday at a meeting of members of the National Retail pry Goods Association at the organization's headquarters here.

In the dense fog that had isolated the port since 3 o'clock Sunday afternoon, the Italian liner Roma went aground on Sandy Hook bar just inside the entrance to Ambrose Channel yesterday and was held fast until late last night.

With production rising to the highest level of the year, the adjusted index of automobile production for the week ended June 24 has advanced to 57.2, as against 54.1 in the preceding week and 41.7 for the corresponding week last year.
POTTSTOWN, Pa., June 26 -- The Harry Elkins Widener Memorial Building of Arts and Crafts was dedicated today in connection with the commencement exercises at Hill School.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Secretary Roper met today with a committee of industrial leaders called to advise with the Commerce Department upon emergency steps to end the depression and upon long-range planning to prevent future economic slumps.

MUNICH, June 26 -- The elimination of the Catholic Bavarian People's party, which was dominant in Bavaria up to the national resurgence, is proceeding in typical Nazi fashion, swiftly and with wholesale arrests.
Robby Robertson, contract rider for C.V. Whitney, scored a consecutive triple at Aqueduct yesterday, riding one winner for his employer and two for Mrs. John Hay Whitney.

LONDON, June 26 -- The World Economic Conference opened its third week today with seven commissions, subcommissions and plain committees in session on various aspects of the problems it has met to deal with. Most of these meetings were held in private, where exchanges across the table could be franker and less formal than at public sessions.
SOUTHPORT, England, June 27 -- Great Britain took the Ryder Cup away from America today by a single point, gained by the last putt in the last match on the last green.
PARIS, June 27 -- A decree promulgating a convention to avoid double taxation on imports between France and Italy was published today.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- As July 1 approaches, the date when heavy personnel reductions are scheduled to be made in every Federal department to meet the drastic economies planned for the next fiscal year, indications increase that the blow to the Federal workers will be softened.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 27 -- Four contestants, including the first three seeded players, today reached the quarter-finals of the women's metropolitan clay court tennis singles championship tournament in progress at the Lido Country Club.

"Biography," the current long-run dramatic offering now playing at the Avon Theatre, will continue its engagement at that house until July 15. A matinee next week will be played on July 4 instead of Thursday.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Otto H. Kahn, one of the partners in the private banking firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co. of New York, told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee this afternoon that Norman H. Davis, Ambassador at Large, received two fees amounting to $35,000 in 1925 for promoting Chilean loans.

Nearly 1,000 women delegates, representing 236 Jewish women's organizations in the city, met at the Hotel Astor yesterday and began a nation-wide boycott of German goods and services as a measure of retaliation against the treatment of Jews by the Hitler government.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 27 -- Jack Tidball, University of California at Los Angeles, seeded No. 1, came through with two victories in the national intercollegiate lawn tennis championship at the Merion Cricket Club courts today to gain the fourth round.

Revised Nazi Version. The Hitler candidate to succeed Bishop BODELSCHWINGH as head of the Protestant churches has been conducting services with many innovations of his own. Among other things, he is said to have recast the Lord's Prayer.
RYE, N.Y., June 27 -- Five of Choate School's six representatives continued in the first annual Eastern interscholastic Invitation championship tennis tournament today at the Manursing Island Club.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Despite the quotation of dollar wheat on the Chicago Exchange and even higher prices elsewhere, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today its decision to apply a processing tax of 30 cents a bushel on wheat milling, effective July 9.
When Desmus Collins saw the snake the neighbors advised him to stick to 3.2 beer, but when Mrs. Maude Thompson saw it too, there was nothing left for them but to believe.
LONDON, June 27 -- Australia having failed to agree to wheat acreage restriction, the World Economic Conference decided today to leave the issue for the time being to nature.

The New York Civic Orchestra, under the direction ot Rudolf Thomas, will inaugurate a Saturday morning series of concerts for children at the Brooklyn Museum, beginning next Saturday, in addition to its series now being given Saturday afternoon at the museum at 3 o'clock and Sunday evening at 8:15 at Forest Park, Queens.

A gathering of 8,000 Queens home owners voted last night to go to Albany in a body to present to Governor Lehman a petition for a special session of the Legislature for the enactment of a State home mortgage relief program.

BALTIMORE, June 27 -- Charging that American and British bankers, corporations and individuals had conspired to ruin his business, C. Wilbur Miller, former president of the Dayison Chemical Company, today filed a $5,000,000 damage suit in Superior Court here.

BOSTON, June 27 -- The New York City Rotary Club proposed here today that the international directors supply to Rotarians information and advice conducive to a better understanding of the problems of the economic crisis and a fuller cooperation in their solution.

The New York Central Railroad reported for May a net operating income of $3,293,124, the largest for any month since October. It contrasts with an operating loss of $226,882 in May, 1932. The decline in gross revenues was $645,000, the smallest reported in many months.
In a two-hour struggle Ray Palmer of Malba, L.I., defeated Walter Martin of the Canadian Davis Cup team yesterday in the Eastern tennis championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

Foreign delegates at the Economic Conference must have been relieved and reassured by two American messages to them yesterday. One was forwarded from Ireland by Professor MOLEY, who declared that, so far as he could judge after having been out of touch for a week on the ocean, "definite progress" had already been made at London, fully in line with "the original program."

A commencement service characterized by guests attending as noteworthy for the vigorous and cheerful enthusiasm that marked it was held yesterday at the Crippled Children's East Side School. 157 Henry Street, officially known as P.S. 401, Manhattan.

LAKEMAN BAY, Roque Island, Me., June 27 -- Held by fog in this remote harbor for the second successive day, President Roosevelt spent his time in complete relaxation, reading or joking with, members of his "crew" in the cabin of Amberjack II.
Herowin, next to the outsider in the featured Colonial Purse at Aqueduct yesterday, surprised even his warmest admirers when he ran a race which proved far too much for the four others in the field.

LONDON, June 27 -- Plans for remaining on the gold standard until other countries could return to it were understood to have been discussed secretly today By the economic conference representatives of France, Holland, Switzerland, Belgium and Italy.

Under the fire of a policeman who had routed them from a beer garden at 44-14 Forty-eighth Street, Long Island City, early this morning, three hold-up men flung a wounded companion from their automobile a block away, sped on and escaped.
This is a story about three goats from Texas. Their names are Cactus Jack, Alfalfa Bill and The Kingfish. They are going to live permanently in New York -- in Central Park.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Leaders of capital and labor in the cotton textile mills sat down today with representatives of the consuming public to obtain approval of a model code for the administration of the National Recovery Act, with the expectation of returning millions to employment in American industry in general.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Donald R. Richberg, general counsel for the National Recovery Administration, outlined at the cotton textile hearing today the procedure to be followed.

MARION, Mass., June 27 -- School-boy crews from St. Mark's, South-boro, Mass.; St. Paul's, Concord, N.H., and Lawrenceville, Lawrenceville, N.J., qualified today for the final round of the Interscholastic Yacht Racing Association cham- pionships.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., June 27. -- With 40,000 gallons of gasoline, a collection of scientific instruments and three months' provisions aboard, the Danish tramp steamer Jelling will leave here for Greenland tomorrow to serve as the base for a Pan American Airways expedition under Colonel Charles A.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Preliminary plans for the reabsorption into industry of about 1,000,000 residents of the Tennessee Valley were announced today by Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, chairman of the board of directors. Included are plans for improving the living conditions of about 6,000,000 persons within the sphere of influence of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

Further vigorous advances were made yesterday in all commodities traded on the Ipcal Exchanges. Prices continued to reflect mainly the strength in other markets and the weakness of the dollar. Trading was active. All cash prices were higher.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP). -- J. Henry Roraback, chairman of the Connecticut Republican State Central Committee and a power company executive, testified at a Federal Trade Commission hearing today that his political position "gave some political influence" when he sought charters for his companies from the Connecticut State Legislature.

ADELAIDE, June 27 -- Strong efforts are being made to induce the South Australian Government to change its opposition to the proposed restriction of wheat production. The Premier today received a communication from the Canberra Government explaining its position at the London conference.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The balance of Kuhn, Loeb Co. at the end of each, calendar year from 1927 to 1931, inclusive, was given to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today by Otto H. Kahn. The record is as follows:
LONDON, June 27 (Canadian Press) -- England defeated the West Indies soundly today in the first of the season's three cricket test matches, despite a gallant attempt at a comeback by the visitors.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- General Hugh S. Johnson is attacking his tremendous task of putting millions of people back to work with that directness and simplicity for which he has already become famous in Washington. The public hearing held before him today to develop a code for the textile industry under the Recovery Act was as unprecedented as his methods are in this capital.

Tuesday, June 27, 1933. Except for a small amount of 90day money done at three-fourths of 1 per cent, a fractional decline from the rate which previously ruled, there were no other developments of interest in the day's money market.
DUBLIN, June 27 -- The Dail Eireann passed tonight the second reading of a bill enabling the government to repay Dail loans floated in the United States during 1919 to 1921.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- An electrical "Jacob's Ladder" On which man can climb to the outer reaches of the "ionosphere" 550 miles up and map out with delicate measuring tools the unexplored regions in the three shells of radiant energy surrounding our planet was described today before the Institute of Radio Engineers, meeting here as one of the forty affiliated societies in the Summer session of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- J.P. Ebelhardt's Gift of Roses, under a strenuous ride by Jack Westrope, maintained a fast pace over the six-Furlong route at Arlington Park today to win by three lengths from Morton L. Schwartz's Tickory Tock and equal the track record of 1:10 1-5.

LONDON, June 27 -- The exemption of long-term credits from the German transfer moratorium and the payment of part of the interest in foreign exchange were agreed to by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, at a meeting here today with creditors living in Great Britain, the United States, the Netherlands, Sweden and Switzerland.

BERLIN, June 27 -- The Boerse continued its upward tendency today under the influence of the improvement in the New York and London markets and further indications of continuing betterment in the economic situation. Political news from London and Geneva was disregarded by the buying public, which again was influenced by the government's program for the creation of employment.

The suggestion that Attorney General Cummings should call a conference of all district attorneys, State and Federal, and of police chiefs of the principal cities, together with Governors and legislative leaders to devise means of combating racketeering was made last night by Elvin N. Edwards, District Attorney of Nassau County.

HAVANA, June 27 (AP). -- The Cuban Treasury Department and a bankers' syndicate headed by the Chase National Bank of New York and bondholders agreed today on an arrangement to lengthen payments on Cuba's short-term loans.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Aid to the railroads in financing maintenance and new equipment is being considered by Colonel Sawyer, Administrator of Public Works. The question has been taken up by Colonel Sawyer with Joseph B. Eastman, Coordinator of Railroads, and with A.A. Berle, special advisor to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation on railroad affairs.

Pittsburgh, Pa. The Chemical Bank and Trust Company and Moncure, Biddie Co. of Philadelphia, bidding jointly, obtained the award yesterday of a new issue of $900,000 city of Pittsburgh (Pa.) bonds, topping a field of eleven bidders.

LONDON, June 27 -- On behalf at the Christian churches of the world, the Archbishop of Canterbury appealed to Chancellor Hitler of Germany today for tolerance toward the Jews of Germany at a great mass meeting tonight protesting Nazi treatment of them.

ATLANTIC CITY. N.J., June 27 -- President Roosevelt, his Industrial Recovery Act and the administration, policy received today the unqualified endorsement of organized labor through its spokesman, Matthew Woll, third vice president of the American Federation of Labor. Mr. Woll addressed the National Association of Retail Grocers of the United States, in convention here.

GENEVA, June 27 -- The steering committee of the disarmament conference decided today to recommend to the disarmament conference that it adjourn until Oct. 16 to extend the period in which its president, Arthur Henderson, has been authorized to negotiate solutions of the remaining deadlock.

The International Hydro-Electric System reports for the first quarter of 1933 a consolidated net income of $492,451 after taxes, charges, depreciation, underlying dividends and minority interest, comparing with $1,149,948 earned in the first quarter of 1932.

An advance of about 10 per cert in the price of sulphite pulp used in the manufacture of paper has been made in the last ten days. This became known yesterday at a meeting of a committee of the American Paper and Pulp Association to draw up that industry's code under the National Industrial Recovery Act.

LONDON, June 27 -- Reviewing the work of the conference. The London Times will say tomorrow that differences are in the process of being defined both on matters of principle and points of concrete detail, "toilsome and discouraging but an indispensable process."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 27 -- Members of the Garden Club of Southampton met tonight at four fountains when Mme. Marie de Mare gave an illustrated lecture on "French Gardens, Old and New," under the auspices of the organization.
NEW YORK. Miss Louise B. Scott of 430 Park Avenue will sail Friday on the Majestic to pass the remainder of the Summer in Europe.
The Board of Estimate laid over without date yesterday the application of Thomas F. Dwyer, former Markets Commissioner, for an annual pension of $3,596 after civic workers attacked it.

LONDON, June 27 -- The Washington correspondent of The London Times, who is now in England, has been impelled by the constant humorous references in the British press to the supposed existence of a Roosevelt "brain trust" in the United States with Professor Raymond Moley at the head to devote a column this morning to ridiculing the idea.

CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- Converting four passes issued by Merritt Cain into runs in the second inning, the White Sox went on to an 8-to-3 victory over the Athletics today to even the series at two-all.

Marion Talley, coloratura soprano who is remembered here for her spectacular debut at the Metropolitan Opera House in 1926 as Gilda in "Rigoietto," recently returned to New York for "business reasons," as she declared last night.

The Wholesale Dry Goods Institute will insist on a price differential in favor of wholesalers in any manufacturers' codes, containing provisions for the establishment of minimum prices on specific commodities. This was brought out yesterday at a meeting of the institute's associate membership, composed of mill executives, at the organization's headquarters here.

ST. LOUIS, June 27 (AP) -- Sam Gray, making his first start of the season, weakened in the eighth inning and the Red Sox landed on Ed Wells, who relieved him, for four hits and four runs and won the fourth game of the series from the Browns today, 5 to 4.

While 100-degree temperatures were being recorded in cities in seven States yesterday, New York had a maximum reading of 78 degrees. Although the mean temperature of 72 was only one degree above normal for the day, the humidity made the thermometer an inaccurate measure of comfort here.

BOSTON, June 27 -- The Boston trawler Flow was in collision at 10 o'clock tonight with the freighter Cornerbrook about four miles northeast of Highland Light, off Cape Cod. Two of the Flow's crew were injured.

HAVANA, June 27 -- The possibility of early solution of Cuban political problems received a big impetus today when it was learned that the Union Nacionalista, an outlawed political party, long an avowed foe of the Machado regime, delivered a memorandum to Ambassador Sumner Welles this afternoon accepting his mediation.

When, at the turn of the century, American authors formed the first impermanent trade organization forecasting the present Authors' League of America, they debated long before they admitted women. Inez Haynes Irwin, who is now president of the Authors' League, writes in her new book, "Angels and Amazons." She says:

Some five hundred children's books and magazines, displayed in the main exhibition room of the New York Public Library, are described by ANNE CARROLL MOORE in its Bulletin. These "Children's Books of Yesterday" begin with the beginning -- the ABC books and broadsides of the sixteenth century.

The Juilliard School of Music announced yesterday its 1933 competition for the publication of new orchestra works by American composers. Through its competition the Juilllard School will select a work and pay for the publication of it. The composer is to receive all royalties and fees accruing from the sale or performance of his work.

The Delaware River, dividing New Jersey and Pennsylvania, has been the cause of a great deal of confusion among fresh-water fishermen who have whipped that stream for its bass and other species of game fish.

HOME is where they win the Ryder Cup golf tournament. When they play for the trophy in the United States, the United States team wins. When they play on British soil, the British team wins. It seems a nice, friendly arrangement and the spectators always have the satisfaction of seeing the home team win.
With all the foreign currencies advancing sharply against the dollar, stocks, bonds and commodities rose yesterday to the highest levels of the year and the movement.

LONDON, June 27 -- The stock market generally was cheerful today on a more hopeful outlook for the economic conference. The market also was enlivened by a further rise in commodities, reflecting higher American prices. British funds again were quiet, but foreign bonds were active.

Average wages in the manufacturing industry increased 8.6 per cent in May over April, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday in its monthly report on wage trends. The num- ber of workers increased 4.1 per cent and their hours of work a week 10.7 per cent.
Angelo Caruso, a prisoner in the penitentiary on Welfare Island, was mysteriously stabbed to death yesterday as he returned from noon mess.

BERLIN, June 27 -- Jews will be excluded from the "German labor front," which is now in process of elaboration into a corporative structure that will embrace all the wage-earners in factories, offices and stores, in so far as they are "Aryan," on a scale far exceeding the old trade unions and craft federations.

LONDON, June. 27 -- The World Economic Conference will not fall because it dare not fail, Secretary of State Hull declared today at the Pilgrims' luncheon to the United States delegates, attended by Prime Minister MacDonald and the British delegates.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated June 24:

LONDON, Wednesday, June 28 -- Professor Raymond C. Moley arrived in London at 1 A.M. today. He was met at Paddington Station by Ray Atherton of the United States Embassy and a corps of reporters and photographers, but, while he submitted to being photographed refused to make a further statement than he had already given out at Plymouth.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Diplomatic papers covering the activities of the United States Government from the beginning of 1918 to the Armistice were made public by the State Department today. The papers were published as two volumes, under the title. "Foreign Relations of the United States, 1918, Supplement I, The World War."

A natural adjustment between the dollar and the pound has been developing in the last few weeks, with the result that soon they will be stabilized to the mutual advantage of Great Britain and the United States.

DETROIT, June 27 -- The Yankees hit too many home runs for the Tigers on Navin Field today, three of them, two in succession, carrying the victory influence in a 9-to-8 triumph for the champions. The result pulled them to within one game of the league-leading Senators, who lost.
A city tax on stock transfers of two cents on every $100 share and two cents on each share of undesignated value was proposed yesterday in the Aldermanic branch of the Municipal Assembly.

The board of examiners reports that there have been placed upon the eligible list of holders at licenses to teach in the evening eleraentary schools, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted licenses, as indicated:

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Names of banks and trust companies in which Kuhn, Loeb Co. maintained deposits from 1927 to 1931, inclusive, and the balances as of March 31, 1933, as well as a similar list of foreign banks and trust companies, were given to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today by Otto H. Kahn, as follows:

CHICAGO June 27 -- Murray Humphreys, successor to Al Capone as Chicago's public enemy No. 1, was indicted by the Federal grand jury today on charges of attempting to evade $23,190 in income taxes for the years 1930, 1931 and 1932.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Grain markets forged ahead again today on the Board of Trade and advanced as sensationally as they did yesterday. Wheat crossed the dollar mark and at the top made even a better showing than Monday's, being up as much as 7 3/8 cents at the extreme and 21 5/8 cents above the low on Saturday.

Ralph Borsodi, who has been operating a self-sufficient farm for twelve years, has written a book called "Flight From the City: The Story of a New Way to Family Security," which Harpers will publish. Mr. Borsodi earlier Wrote "This Ugly Civilization," which has been the inspiration for some community efforts toward the development of financial independence on the land.

While the stock market furnished entertainment yesterday, Wall Street was more interested in the succession of "new highs" in the commodities. The speculative element did not know exactly what to make of the movement in the grains.
SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 27 -- Yale's freshman golf captain, Kennedy Parker, staged a sensational finish to capture the medal in the metropolitan Junior golf championship today with a 73.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 27 -- Optimism over what was termed by Edgar Kobak, the president, as "the threshold of a new day" in business pervaded the annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America today in the more than a dozen departmental sessions.

Other signs of improving business find corroboration in gains made by the railways. Loadings of revenue freight for the latest week reported are not only the largest of the year but are well above the figure for the corresponding week of 1932. All but one of the eight major classes of traffic show increases.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- As a stride toward easing economy law cuts into benefits to former soldiers, the Veterans Administration today announced it was reviewing upward of 300,000 individual cases under revised rating schedules.

An offer by the Wood Harmon realty interests of 140 Nassau Street, Manhattan, to build a centre for Brooklyn College on the corporation's land in Flatbush and turn it over to the city in twenty-five year was announced to the Board of Estimate yesterday by Mark Eisner, president of the Board of Higher Education.

LONDON, June 27 -- Although today brought new, distinct steps in the process of clarification of issues through which the World Economic Conference is passing, Prime Minister MacDonald has evidently decided more rapid progress can be made toward definite decisions.

Mrs. Lottie Kreisberger Coll and the two men described as her underlings were indicted yesterday to the Bronx on five counts charging murder in the first degree and four drugstore robberies. The grand jury was in session two hours.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 27 -- Former Ambassador Walter E. Edge, Republican, praised today the policy of President Roosevelt that, he said, "should bring us back to at least something near what we like to call normal times." He expressed the hope, however, that the actual administration of the business affairs of the nation would speedily be returned to private interest and control, under proper regulation.

LONDON, June 27 -- Senator Key Pittman's resolution on a permanent measure for currency rehabilitation advanced almost halfway to success today. The subcommittee on gold reported in favor of its proposals for restricting the circulation of monetary gold and reducing the minimum legal coverage for banks.
A wage dispute between union musicians and the State Emergency Relief Administration has resulted in the temporary discontinuance of the series of free concerts in Queens parks.
BERLIN, June 27 -- Dr. Alfred Hugenberg, Nationalist Minister of Economics and Agriculture, sent his resignation as a member of the Hitler government to President von Hindenburg tonight.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., June 27. -- Bone dry for twenty years, West Virginia voted tonight to cast off prohibition.

The standing of the committee of citizens appointed by Secretary PERKINS to inquire into the administration of our immigration laws guarantees that their investigation will be intelligent and thoroughgoing. The alien may be certain that his case is not in unfriendly hands.

Physical obsolescence constitutes one of the major problems confronting Industry at the present time, particularly because of the plan for industrial control implied in the National Industrial Recovery Act, according to the Standard Statistics Company, which has prepared a survey to discover the extent to which industrial capacity is now obsolescent.

On the theory that Justice should be useful as well as punitive, Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein, in Yorkville court, suspended sentence yesterday for fifteen men who had pleaded guilty to charges of strewing newspapers about Central Park.
