The magistrate made them promise that they would pick up rubbish in the park for an hour to expiate their offense.

F.J. Carr, president of the Controllers' Association of America, has been named Controller of the Tennessee Valley Authority, it was announced here yesterday. The appointment was made by Arthur Morgan, president of Antioch College, who is chairman of the Tennessee Valley Commission.

Women live longer than men, but all annuitants show a pronounced longevity, according to the records of the leading life insurance companies. For this reason the companies are posting increases in their rates for annuities.

ALBANY, June 27 -- New York's ratification of the Twenty-first Amendment to the Federal Constitution, repealing the Eighteenth, was unanimously voted today by the 150 delegates to the State convention.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., June 27 -- Maxwell B. Bassett, a Philadelphia boy, carried off first-place honors and easily broke the world's record for sustained flight by a model airplane powered with a miniature motor at the national championship model airplane meet here tonight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Inflation" is generally used to include not only an increase in the quantity of any of the various forms of money but also an increase of credit. An increase of money or credit, it is assumed, will raise prices in general, because it is an increase of purchasing power.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 -- The American champions of Wimbledon, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody and Ellsworth Vines Jr., today proved their right to the title as they led the way through the second round of the famous championships, Mrs. Moody with a love set victory.

Impressive strength in domestic corporation bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday contrasted with fenerally lower prices for United States Government and foreign loans. Trading was heavy, aggregating $19,517,000, compared with $13,303,700 on the previous day.

Following Monday's violent rise. which added more than $4 a bale to the market price of cotton, a further improvement of 15 points took place in early trading yesterday. This carried October to 10 3/4 cents a pound, compared with 9 3/4 cents on Saturday, but a gain of a full cent a pound in about twentylour hours slowed down the upward movement.

Some 80,000 boys and girls taking courses in art appreciation in New York City's public schools are becoming "very much interested" in the art of printing, Forest Grant, director of arts in the New "York public schools, declared yesterday before more than 100 delegates to the twelfth annual conference on printing education, held at Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Otto H. Kahn, partner of Kuhn, Loeb Co., occupied the witness stand throughout most of the day at the investigation by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee and presented a general cross-section of the firm's code of ethics and financial operations.

The Chesapeake Corporation, one of the holding companies by which the Van Sweringen railroads are controlled, has sold 115,000 shares of Chesapeake Ohio Railway common stock in recent weeks in order to reduce its bank loans. The sale realized about $4,200,000.

WILLIAMSVILE, N.Y., June 27 -- For the third consecutive year and the twentieth time since competition started, golfers from Yale University today won the Maxwell Cup, emblematic of supremacy of the intercollegiate golfing world.
Pierrepont B. Noyes, chairman of the Saratoga Springs Commission, explained yesterday what the $3,200,000 loan obtained last Saturday from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will mean to the spa.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Wild excitement reigned in the wheat pit of the Board of Trade today as the greatest crowd of brokers in its history yelled and gesticulated. They were swamped with buying orders from the public, which, according to veteran traders, has been "making a killing" in the current rise.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Direct relief grants to States for the second quarter ending this month will probably reach $70,000,000 and, most of the $250,000,000 fund to be distributed on the basis of one dollar for every three dollars of State moneys expended will probably be exhausted by January, Harry L. Hopkins, Emergency Belief Administrator, said today.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey announced yesterday an advance of 1/2 cent a gallon In the price of gasoline throughout its territory, excepting Delaware and Pennsylvania but including Louisiana, Arkansas and Tennessee. In New York and New England the company met the rise put into effect the previous day by the Standard Oil Company of New York, Inc.
SHANGHAI, June 27 -- After an attempt was made today to assassinate Admiral Shen Hung-lieh, commander of the Northeast Squadron of the Chinese Navy, the entire squadron of five vessels deserted.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 27 -- The judges for the Lenox Garden Club flower show, which is to open at the Stockbridge Golf Club tomorrow at 2:30 P.M., will be Mrs. Albert Herter, the artist; Mrs. Francis King, author; Mrs. Henry Vaughan, president of North Shore Garden Club, and Professor Clark L. Thayer and Professor A.M. Davis of the Massachusetts State College at Amherst.

Roy Chapman Andrews, explorer, is sailing tonight for Europe on the Cunarder Berengaria. Also aboard will be Gerald Campbell, British Consul General in New York; Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Howard, Benjamin J. Duveen, Mr. and Mrs. S.R. Guggenheim, Sir Richard and Lady Pease, Mr. and Mrs. F.N. Doubleday, Sir Campbell Stuart, Miss Rhoda Duveen, Roscoe Pound, Fanny Ward, actress; Mr. and Mrs. A.G. Milbank, Philip H. Ickelheimer, Mrs. C.H. Marshall and Dewitt E. Untermyer.

The "old experience" of Mr. ROOT attained something of a "prophetic strain" in his speech at the Albany Convention yesterday. Referring to the boast frequently made by prohibitionists since repeal was submitted to the people, that thirteen States would prevent ratification of the new amendment, he declared, "They are mistaken."

The daily average gross crude oil production of the United States last week was 2,513,600 barrels, compared with 2,611,850 barrels in the preceding week, a decline of 98,250 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 224,500 barrels daily in the average output of East Texas and a gain of 123,800 barrels in the dally production of Oklahoma were the most important changes for the week.

Count John Perdicaris of Genoa, Italy, gave a dinner last night in the roof restaurant of the Madison for Mr. and Mrs. Clement M. Keys and Mrs. Arthur Kudner, who will leave today to pass the remainder of the Summer in New Mexico. The other guests were Commander and Mrs. Edward L. Spofford, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Frehoff, Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Sloan, Lawrence McK. Miller, Thomas Walsh and Theodore Towsley.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The names of all corporations engaged in interstate commerce having banking deposits with Kuhn, Loeb Co. in excess of $50,000 during the period from 1927 to 1931, inclusive, were given to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today by Otto H. Kahn as follows:

SAN FRANCISCO, June 27 -- California joined her sister States which have balloted to date, by an overwhelming vote today for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and the end of national prohibition. The vote was running more than 3 to 1 in favor of the twenty-two delegates pledged to erase the dry provision, from the Federal Constitution.
ALBANY, June 27 -- Following is the text of the formal addresses made today before the State convention called to vote repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment:

LONDON, June 27 -- The World Economic Conference had another glimpse of United States domestic politics today when Representative S.D. McReynolds of Tennessee made a speech before the commercial policy committee explaining the divergent views of the Republican and Democratic parties.

Various leases for business expansion were included in the large volume of rental activity reported yesterday. In Manhattan's midtown area the garment trades and allied industries accounted for much of the increased demand for space.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 27 -- California joined her sister States which have balloted to date, by an overwhelming vote today for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and the end of national prohibition. The vote was running more than 3 to 1 in favor of the twenty-two delegates pledged to erase the dry provision, from the Federal Constitution.
ALBANY, June 27 -- Following is the text of the formal addresses made today before the State convention called to vote repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment:

SOUTHPORT, England, June 27 -- No British spectator was more interested in the Ryder Cup matches than the Prince of Wales. He arrived today in time for the final afternoon round and he took the trouble to watch a part of every match played.

Seven charitable institutions in New York and New Orleans receive $250 each under the will of Edgar B. Mayer, filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Six of them will eventually share in half of the residue.

SOUTHPORT, England, June 27 -- The British hung on today to the one priceless point they had won yesterday in foursomes and by that single point they recaptured the Ryder Cup after one of the most exciting days of golf and before the biggest crowd I ever saw on a golf course in my life.

Captain Attilio Frugone, master of the Italian liner Roma, said yesterday that the grounding of the liner in Gedney Channel Monday afternoon was caused by the misjudgment of the Sandy Hook pilot who boarded her outside Ambrose Channel.

In the last twenty-five years the philosophy of the Young Women's Christian Association has changed from one of religious dominance to that of social consciousness, Dr. Grace H. Wilson, research graduate at Teachers College, Columbia University, declares, in a survey, made public yesterday.

The Hamburg-American Line faces a fine of about $10,000 as the result of the mysterious disappearance of nearly 10,000 bottles of beer, wines, whisky and other spirits from the sealed storeroom of the liner Reliance. After a hearing before George Brewer, solicitor of customs, it was announced that no satisfactory explanation had been forthcoming, and that in the absence of one, the line was liable to a fine based on the number of bottles missing.

Paul V. Keyser, committee counsel of the Investment Bankers Association of America, outlined the difficulties that will be encountered under the Federal Securities Act of 1933 in an address yesterday at the annual meeting of the Eastern Group of the National Association of Securities Commissioners in Hartford, Conn. Section 11 of the act, which imposes definite obligations on the underwriters, would, he said, raise a serious question in financing industry.

Despite a sharp drop in building construction and alterations in Manhattan, the number of executives and inspectors in the construction division of the Borough President's office has increased since 1929, Maurice P. Davidson, chairman of the central committee of the City party, charged yesterday.

DETROIT, June 27 -- More interesting developments came out today before the grand jury bank investigation which is being conducted by Judge Harry B. Keidan. Herbert R. Wilkin, general manager of the Guardian Detroit Union group, again charged that the closing of the two largest banks in the city was a plot by "Wall Street and the Morgan group" to "get Henry Ford" through collusion with Federal officials.

Asserting that "the Colombian Government can well afford to meet its obligations in full," the Independent Bondholders Committee for the Republic of Colombia issued a statement yesterday through its secretary, Lawrence E. deS. Hoover, emphasizing what is described as the "relatively good budgetary situation and the strong reserve position of the Central Bank of Colombia.

Jack Sharkey and Primo Carnera brought their training programs to a close yesterday. They now await only the call of the New York State Athletic Commission for the weighing-in ceremony preparatory to their fifteen-round bout at the Long Island City Bowl tomorrow night.

The Cincinnati Reds brought their defeatist complex to Ebbets Field yesterday and Max Carey's Dodgers took advantage of it by trouncing the visitors, 11 to 2. The Reds have won only two of their last thirteen engagements, while the Dodgers have taken nine of their last fourteen.

ALBANY, June 27 -- Colonel Frederick S. Greene, superintendent of public works, asserted that it would be impracticable to apportion Federal funds among the sixty cities with any expectation of prompt employment of labor.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The articles of copartnership of Kuhn, Loeb Co., dated Dec. 31, 1932, were placed in the record of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today by Otto H. Kahn. The partners listed were Mr. Kahn, George W. Bovenizer, Lewis L. Strauss, William Wiseman, Frederick M. Warburg, Gilbert W. Kahn, John M. Schiff, Benjamin J. Buttenwieser, Hugh Knowlton and Elisha Walker.

MILWAUKEE, June 27 -- If the reconstruction of the social order is possible through general social education, "the public schools have an obligation that is all important, Dr. Henry R. Linville of New York, president, told the American Federation of Teachers in his address at the opening of their convention this morning.

MEXICO, D.F., June 27 (AP) -- The city was thrown into confusion tonight with a report that an official government announcement last night confirming the finding of the bodies of Captain Mariano Barberan and Lieutenant Joaquin Collar, Spanish transatlantic fliers, in the wreckage of their plane in the State of Tabasco, was incorrect.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Vir- tually sounding the death knell of intensive or, according to some versions, real prohibition enforcement, Attorney General Cummings ordered the personnel of the Prohibition Bureau slashed nearly in half today.
CLEVELAND, June 27 (AP) -- The Indians interrupted the Senators' sensational pennant march in a dramatic ninth-inning finish today, 7 to 6, clipping off the current winning streak at eight games.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent's report of the announcements of the progress of scientific research in the various fields at the meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science have been models of exposition, clarity of presentation, accuracy of statement and simplification of technical jargon.
BOLTON LANDING, LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., June 27 -- The State Bankers' Association in convention today adopted a resolution opposing the deposit insurance provision of the new Glass-Steagall Act.

Uncertainty in the foreign exchange markets early yesterday was dispelled later, and nearly all foreign currencies resumed their advances against the dollar with a spurt. Closing prices were at the highs for the day.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- For what was said to be the first time in diplomatic history, the United States today renounced jurisdiction in a Western Hemisphere dispute in favor of the League of Nations.

Wheat crossed the "dollar-mark" at Chicago yesterday for this year's delivery, that price not having been quoted since August, 1930. Simultaneously, the New York price of cotton went above 10 cents for the first time since July, 1931. This double achievement has particular interest in that "dollar wheat" and "ten-cent cotton" constituted the traditional pre-war goal of recovery.

BERLIN, June 27 -- Multiplying incidents between the Nazi authorities and the German Catholics throughout the Reich are believed to be the immediate occasion for Vice Chancellor von Papen's hurried trip to Rome.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The wheat processing tax plan announced today was sent by wire to President Roosevelt, as he cruised up the New England coast on the Amberjack II. He signed it yesterday and returned it immediately.

Increase in Buyers Here. Registration of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a gain over the number listed in the preceding week and a larger increase over the total reached in the same period a year ago, according to the lists published In THE TIMES.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Plans for stabilizing sugar prices at a higher level by placing imports under a restrictive quota system will be considered by a steering committee set up tonight by more than two hundred representatives of the industry who met here to draw up a marketing agreement under the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

Mayor O'Brien gave a "pep talk" yesterday to thirty budget examiners about to begin preparation of the 1934 schedules. He urged them to make every possible economy so as to lower the tax rate next year.

The Right Rev. James De Wolf Perry, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, sharply rebuked yesterday the group of laymen in the Albany Diocese who recently attempted, according to the Bishop, to "instruct" him not to attend the annual Catholic Congress to be held in Philadelphia in October.

Major Gen. George Rathbone Dyer, who retired on Saturday as senior Brigadier General of the New York National Guard, was praised last night as "the personification of the citizen-soldier of America" at a dinner in his honor at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Railroad bonds of all shades of credit ratings led the advance yesterday in domestic corporation bonds on the Stock Exchange. Industrial bonds averaged slightly higher on the day and utility issues a shade lower. United States Government bonds, however, continued heavy, closing 5-32 point lower to 2-32 higher in trading that accounted for $1,659,500 of the total transactions in the listed market of $19,876,500.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 28. -- Fumitaka Konoye, a member of the Japanese Imperial family, is among the four survivors left in the running for the famous Presbrey Trophy, emblematic of the Eastern interscholastic golf championship.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 28. -- America's touring tennis forces battled on through the early round of the classic Wimbledon play with three setbacks today, one of them providing the historic tournament with its first sensational upset.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 28. -- Something new in a musical setting for the metropolitan area was tried out for the first time with marked success at the County Centre here tonight with the presentation of the first of a series at garden "pop" concerts.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Details of the participation of Kuhn, Loeb Co. in the sale of $90,000,000 of Chilean bonds to the American pub- lic between 1925 and 1929 were brought out in today's testimony before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee investigating Stock Exchange practices.

Modernism in printing is "the wrong use of good materials," Frederick W. Goudy, designer of over seventy type faces, asserted yesterday. Printers who use a typography which arouses interest and pleasure by its beauty alone are guilty of "typographic impertinence," he said.
Routes to the Long Island City Bowl, scene of the Sharkey-Carnera battle, have been prepared by traffic officials of the Police Department and announced by James S. Bolan, Police Commissioner.

BERLIN, June 28. -- Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Reich Minister of the Interier, addressing the first session of the Experts Council for Race Policy today, urged German women to bring forth strong, healthy children, and promised the government's aid along the lines of better salaries and lower taxes for heads of families of numerous children.

Lindbergh as Economist. Colonel LINDBERGH'S supply ship sailed yesterday from Philadelphia for Greenland. The Colonel and Mrs. LINDBERGH will leave in about a fortnight. The purpose of the expedition is to map a northern air route between this country and Europe.

Jack Isidor Straus, executive vice president of R.H. Macy Co. and son of the new Ambassador to France, is returning today on the French liner Paris, accompanied by Mrs. Straus. Also aboard the Paris are: Charles de Hellig de Balzac, Persian consul at Brussels; Georges Adrian, Baroness James Beyena, Mrs. Raoul Duval, Lecong de Querland, M.M. Mercier, G.L. Morris and Clifford Winant.

BOSTON, June 28 (AP). -- The Cardinals' pennant drive struck a snag today as the Braves swept the three-game series by beating Wild Bill Hallahan and Dazzy Vance to take both ends of a double-header, 4 -- 3 and 3 -- 0. Fred Frankhouse held the Cubs to three hits in the second game.
DETROIT, June 28. -- Babe Ruth returned to action today after his short vacation and led an attack which gave the Yankees a victory over the Tigers, 10 to 7, as the series closed.

LONDON, June 28. -- The five chief gold-standard countries were centring their efforts tonight on getting Great Britain to participate with them in a joint public declaration that the pound would remain pegged to gold, at least for the duration of the World Economic Conference.

Three of the organizers of the General Industrial Foundation Corporation were found guilty yesterday afternoon by a jury in General Sessions of conspiring to defraud Mrs. Ella de Bevoise Patterson, a widow, of Red Bank, N.J., of Curtis Publishing Company stock, originally valued at $588,000.

BERLIN, June 28. -- Chancellor Hitler is about to go to Neudeck for an intimate talk with President von Hindenburg on the vital questions of the day. These, precipitated by the irresistible advance of the National Socialist movement, centre on Dr. Alfred Hugenberg's position in the Cabinet in the face of the self-elimination of his Nationalist party and on the still more delicate church problem.

BERLIN, June 28. -- The Nazi powers, masters of the stagecraft of popular propaganda, made today, the fourteenth anniversary of the signing of the Versailles Treaty, into a red-letter day throughout the Reich, in which mourning for past "disgrace and humiliation" was skillfully blended with rejoicing at the "national resurgence."

LONDON, June 28. -- The Australian Government today instructed Stanley M. Bruce to cooperate with the United States, Canadian and Argentine members of the "Big Four" wheat committee in submitting a definite wheat restriction plan to other producing and consuming countries.

EAST HAMPTON, N.Y., June 28. -- Bobby (Robert T.) Jones arrived here yesterday to visit Mr. and Mrs. Grantland Rice and this morning played in a foursome on the Maidstone links with Mr. Rice, John N. Wheeler and Pinckney Miller.

Supreme Court Justice John L. Walsh denied yesterday the application of William Church Osborn and August Heckscher, as taxpayers, for a temporary injunction restraining the city from paying out of budget funds about $6,000,000 in interest and amortization on Eighth Avenue subway bonds.

The Neptune Association and the Ocean Association of Marine Engineers, the leading unions of merchant marine officers, announced yesterday that they would discontinue operations as separate entities on Friday and would merge in the United Licensed Officers Association.

The astonishing pennant drive of the Giants seemed to be veering sharply off its course at the Polo Grounds yesterday when suddenly it righted itself, leaving all quite calm and serene again on the west bank of the Harlem.
Sales of Jersey City apartment houses by a bank featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

New world records for flying model airplanes were announced yesterday at the National Model Airplane meet, held in the 258th Field Artillery Armory, Kingsbridge Road and Jerome Avenue, the Bronx. The meet closed last night with a dinner in the K. of C. Hotel, at which trophies were awarded the winners of the various events.

The resumption of building work on the Cathedral of St. John the Divine to provide employment was asked of Bishop William T. Manning yesterday by a group of labor leaders. Representatives of seven unions visited the Bishop and inspected the cathedral with him.

BERLIN, June 28. -- Trading on the Boerse opened today with a firm tendency again, but became nervous later and some of the earlier gains were lost at the close. The resignation of Dr. Alfred Hugenberg, Minister of Economics and Agriculture, which had been discounted in advance, had no effect on the prevailing tone.

Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals announced yesterday that he would continue to exercise jurisdiction over the Interborough receivership despite the recent suggestion by the United States Supreme Court that he withdraw.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- It appears to be a fact that key-men of the administration who are on watch here during the absence of the President take literally the statement Assistant Secretary of State Moley issued last night at Plymouth. They do not believe his visit to London is of any greater significance than Dr. Moley says it is.

The prospectus of the $3,000,000 Narragansett Electric Company first-mortgage bonds, series C 5 per cent, due on June 1, 1958, is the first circular relating to public utility financing to supply all details in compliance with the Security Act of 1933.

The situation in Austria may at any moment lead to new troubles in Europe, which may in turn affect world peace, Nicholas Roosevelt, Minister to Hungary during the Hoover administration, said last night in a radio address broadcast by a National Broadcasting Company network.

The Board of Estimate has under consideration a request for Federal aid to the extent of about $95,000,000 to enable the city to complete the construction and equipment of its independent subway system.
Principals -- Jack Sharkey of Boston and Primo Carnera of Italy.

A salesman, a broker, a lawyer, a housewife and a clothing mer- chant are among the six interna- tional winners of the World Bridge Olympic, the results of which were announced yesterday. Not one team of well-known contract experts placed in either the national or international championship list.

Patrolman Peter Gallagher, known to his comrades as "Pewee Pete" -- he is one of the smallest men on the force -- found his cat last night, so he may not have to take twentyone anti-tetanus inoculations after all.

Fall Retail Gain for Mid-West. Fall business in basement stores is expected to gain more in the mid-West and New England than in metropolitan New York, according to opinions expressed yesterday at the luncheon meeting of the basement managers' division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Sales of department stores in the New York Federal Reserve District were only 2 per cent below those a year before, according to the review for May of credit and business conditions by the Federal Reserve agent in New York. At the same time wholesale firms had sales 16 per cent higher.

Money market was quiet, and quotations were unchanged for all classifications. Stock Exchange call loans were 1 per cent, and street trades, 5/8. Some four months' money was done at 1 per cent, but other maturities were neglected. Commercial paper and acceptances were only moderately active.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- The most powerful "battering ram" yet constructed by science for breaking down the walls imprisoning the almost unlimited energy in the inner core of matter has been completed at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 28. -- Albert J. Horton of Williams, recently crowned Eastern intercollegiate singles champion, continued his winning ways in the national intercollegiate lawn tennis championships by beating H.J. Lynch of Princeton in a fourth-round match on the grass courts of the Merion Cricket Club today.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- A gathering of learned scientists at the University of Chicago, meeting to discuss crime at a session of the American Sociological Society and the Society for Social Research, under the auspices of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

CINCINNATI, June 28. -- After efforts had been made to deny him permission to speak, General Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans' Affairs, told the Disabled American Veterans' Convention today that "our country, our President and our people will always deal fairly with your organization."

By the bill which Governor MOORE has just signed, horse-racing will he restored to New Jersey, but only in counties approving it by referendum. The measure was introduced in the interest of Atlantic County -- which obviously means Atlantic City. It was the design of the promoters to adopt at race courses the pari-mutuel system of betting, from which the State would derive revenue.

ALBANY, June 28. -- The famous Roosevelt "brain trust" acquires an international flavor through the appearance of Raymond Moley at the London World Economic Conference. The trade-mark of the small group of the President's economic advisers crossed to Europe with the Assistant Secretary of State, who is "head man" of the "brain trust."

Lincoln Ellsworth, who is going to the Antarctic this Winter to fly across the continent between the Ross and Weddell Seas, has changed his plans and intends to go to New Zealand directly instead of goingfirst to Norway. He and Mrs. Ellsworth will leave San Francisco on July 14, and after a stop of a week at Honolulu, will go to Auckland, New Zealand.

LONDON, June 28. -- The fears of the Central European countries that they might be committing themselves again to a drain on their gold reserves to restore a possible future unfavorable balance of payments delayed approval of the revised gold clause in the Pittman resolution for two hours at this morning's meeting of the economic conference subcommission on permanent financial measures.

LONDON, June 28. -- The financial editor of The London Times, commenting in today's issue on dollar devaluation and its effect on wholesale prices, declares that whereas the price of wheat in Great Britain (which the editor regards as the "world price") has risen about 15 1/2 per cent since the middle of April, when the United States abandoned gold, the rise in America has been 34 per cent.

ROME, June 28. -- Vice Chancellor Franz von Papen of Germany arrived here early this morning accompanied by a secretary and was deep in conversation with Cardinal Pacelli, the Papal Secretary of State, this evening with a view to preparing the ground for the conclusion of a concordat placing the relations between the Holy See and the Reich on a clear and permanent basis.

Measures to improve working conditions of government employes were discussed yesterday at the convention of the National Customs Service Association in the Hotel New Yorker. The convention will have as its first order of business this morning a proposal to affiliate with the American Federation of Labor.

SCARBOROUGH - ON - HUDSON, N.Y., June 28. -- For the first time in the history of the metropolitan junior golf championship, three members of the same family became the dominant figures of the tourney as the Strafaci brothers gained the semi-final round today.
The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times. As reported in THE TIMES, Secretary Wallace, speaking to farmers at St. Paul, said: "The difficulty of any plan for reducing pork production is that neither corn nor hogs can be considered separately. * * * It has been suggested that we might begin immediately to reduce pork tonnage by paying a bonus for light hogs and a penalty for heavies.
PARIS, June 28. -- With the dollar below 20 francs in value and the gold standard countries fighting what is considered a last-ditch battle in London, there is great anxiety in France.
Five favorites met defeat at Aqueduct yesterday, bringing consternation to the form players who had been routed on Monday, when a like number of choices also had failed.

"In one month, with no hesitation whatever, the principal bond 'averages' have recaptured all the ground they yielded with little show of fight in the afterpart of 1932." The American Bankers Association Journal says in its July issue.

Jack Sharkey and Primo Carnera are ready for their fifteen-round bout at the Long Island City Bowl tonight. Sharkey, who won the world's heavyweight championship by defeating Max Schmeling a year ago, will engage in the first defense of his title, under the promotion of the Madison Square Garden Corporation.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., June 28. -- State Senator James J. Coyne and eight other Republican leaders, Including John J. Verona and Patrick O'Malley, were indicted by a Federal grand jury today for conspiracy to violate the election laws. It was the most sweeping action ever taken against political "higher ups" In the county's long history of voting-fraud charges.
WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Otto H. Kahn, senior partner of Kuhn, Loeb Co., told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today that he paid no Federal income taxes for the years 1930, 1931 and 1932.

Speed and simplicity are the most important elements in drawing up codes of ethics under the Industrial Recovery Act, Professor Earl D. Howard, deputy administrator for the apparel industries, declared last night. He addressed the Association of Dress Manufacturers at the Hotel New Yorker.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Reports from abroad that a situation might arise under which France, Holland and other countries would desert the gold standard were studied with great interest in official quarters today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 (AP). -- Bridegroom Bill Jurges, Cubs' shortstop, married this morning celebrated his wedding by hammering six hits today to give himself batting honors in the Cubs' double triumph over the Phillies.
A dual function was forecast yesterday for the committee of railroad presidents to be selected by the Eastern managements today to act in the system headed by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal coordinator.

When the West Side Savings Bank sold to the Madison Av. and 120th St. Corp., Francis Tausend, president, the five-story apartment at the southwest corner of Madison Av. and 120th St. for $40,000, the bank took back a purchase money mortgage for $27,000.
The Army and Navy Club of America is to close its doors tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP). -- A recent order by Secretary Wallace to eliminate the market news service of the Department of Agriculture was rescinded today and plans were announced for continuing the activity on a sharply reduced basis.

ALBANY, June 28. -- Governor Lehman opened the way today for cities of the State to share in the $22,300,000 Federal road funds which will come to the State under the National Industrial Recovery Act.
The Dodgers' hopes that they might make use of the Reds to achieve the first division vanished yesterday when they dropped the first game of a double-header, 8 to 1.

Patrolman William O'Connor, big and brawny, knows his book of regulations by heart but is a bit weak on opera. He admitted as much in West Side Court yesterday when he appeared as complainant against three officials of the Chicago Opera Company.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (UP). -- Progress toward an agreement to stabilize sugar prices at higher levels was reported tonight after a long meeting of leaders of the sugar industry.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read in THE NEW YORK TIMES the text of the trade code drafted for dry-goods stores. As a former sales person in one of the largest stores of this type I should like to express some of my views regarding this code.

Edward Corsi, Commissioner of Immigration, welcomed members of the committee to investigate conditions on Ellis Island, when they arrived yesterday for their first official visit. He suggested physical improvements and changes in the regulations to bring about more humane handling of immigrants and deportees.

NOTTINGHAM, England, June 28 (Canadian Press). -- The British West Indies cricket team was dismissed for a first innings total of 155 runs in its match with Sir Julien Cahn's high-class eleven today. Cahn's team tallied 105 for seven wickets.

Fred Fussell, Albany left-hander, pitched a no-hit game at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday, blanking the Jerseys, 4 to 0. Two bases on balls marred an otherwise perfect mound performance. Only twenty-eight batsman faced the southpaw, one of the passes being followed by a double play.
WASHINGTON, June 28. -- A fresh, brighter chapter in child labor history began today when a rule against employment of children under 16 years of age was written into the cotton textile code.

As belated returns from the speech-precincts fatten the Appendix of the Congressional Record, a lifelong reader of that fascinating publication might almost wonder what year this is. Here are the ancient landmarks of quotation. The New Deal hasn't touched the old poetry.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Heart- ened by the decisive wet victories in West Virginia and California yesterday, anti-prohibition leaders this afternoon again predicted repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment by the end of this year, and prepared to exert all their strength toward capturing Alabama, Arkansas and Tennessee where the question will be voted upon next month.

BALTIMORE, June 28 (AP). -- Rallying behind the fine pitching of Jim Weaver and Charley Devens, plus some high-grade relief pitching by Johnny Murphy, Newark defeated the Baltimore Orioles in both ends of today's double-header, 11 to 5 and 8 to 3.

The Republican group seeking to oust Samuel S. Koenig as county chairman of New York opened fire with its heavy artillery last night at a rally at the Hotel Greystone, Broadway and Ninety-first Street.

KANSAS CITY, June 28 (AP). -- A 20,000,000-acre reduction of the nation's corn land through a processing tax on live stock was suggested here today by Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace to avert overproduction in beef cattle and hogs, which he described as imminent.

The two public school teachers who were charged with disrupting a meeting of the Board of Education on May 24 were dismissed from service yesterday by the board. More than 500 sympathizers and others seeking an audience with the board on the question of appointing substitute teachers remained orderly throughout the meeting.

A partial reconstruction of utility companies formerly controlled by the Insulls was completed yesterday, when the Penn Southern Power Comnany was incorporated in Delaware, with capital of 100,000 no-par shares. The assets will consist of five operating companies in Pennsylvania and several other States formerly controlled by the National Electric Power Company or its subsidiaries.

Relatively simple words are more often misspelled in business than the posers that make trouble for contestants in spelling bees, Miss Adelaide B. Hakes, supervisor of the technical departments at the Katherine Gibbs School, 247 Park Avenue, said yesterday.
PARIS, June 28. -- The bottle to sustain the French franc appeared today to financial experts to be lost and devalorization was regarded as imminent.

While the share market moved around yesterday in a hesitant fashion, it was a fairly representative index to Wall Street sentiment. Opinion turned on the position of the dollar in the foreign exchange market and on the action of the grain markets.

Methods of determining whether the association of members of the New York Stock Exchange with the new open-end management investment trusts is permissible are now being studied by the Stock Exchange. New requirements for this type of trust are expected to be announced soon.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 28. -- The first three seeded players in the women's metropolitan clay court tennis singles championship tourney today won their quarterfinal round matches on the courts of the Lido Country Club.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 28. -- The Leonard S. Morange Post of the American Legion and the Bronxville League for Service staged a "Night of Sport" on Chambers Field, adjoining the Bronxville School Buildings, tonight.
JACK SHARKEY is reported to be confident of retaining his world's heavyweight championship. The Big Flower Man must have his reasons.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- While the public works administration distributed application blanks today in anticipation of requests for loans under the $3,300,000,000 emergency law, the Cabinet advisory board was called into session to consider hours, wages and the class of labor to be employed on projects for which the government will loan money.

Consolidated gross sales of the International Paper and Power Company were $30,031,891 in the first quarter of 1933, comparing with $35,916,838 in the 1932 period, and consolidated net revenue, including other income, was $9,417,657, against $11,361,862, the company announced yesterday.

Conflicting influences were at work yesterday in the share market. The dollar was depressed sharply in the foreign exchange market at the same time that wheat was losing its sensational gain of the day before. The net result was a lower average of prices on the Stock Exchange.

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP). -- The White Sox beat the Athletics, 9 to 8, today, although the Mackmen rallied for three runs in the ninth and had the tying run on third base. The victory gave Chicago the series, three games to two. Jimmy Foxx hit his eighteenth home run of the season.
Included in a large volume of apartment rentals reported yesterday were leases of several large suites. Trading also indicated a demand for apartments on Park Avenue. The rentals follow:

WILLIAMSVILLE, N.Y., June 28. -- Three of the heavy pre-tournament favorites advanced to the quarter-final round of the thirty-seventh national intercollegiate golf tournament today, while two others fell by the wayside in the "suicide" double eighteen-hole test of the first and second rounds.

The American dollar went begging yesterday in all of the foreign exchange markets of the world, and, conversely, in New York the rates of all leading foreign exchange shot up in bewildering fashion. The pound sterling was the pivot on which the market moved.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Drastic retrenchments for the army, curtailment of the air mail service probably by 5,000 miles, and the dropping of 138 employes in the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce have been ordered as part of the administration's economy program.
Andrew McCampbell, prohibition administrator of this district, and about 270 of his staff of 507 enforcement agents, clerks and stenographers will be out of office on Saturday.

Steel operations have expanded this week to 53 per cent of ingot capacity, which represents a three-point gain over last week. In making this estimate The Iron Age remarks that "the upward swing of output, which has been uninterrupted since operations struck a low of 14 per cent in the third week in March, has marked one of the sharpest recoveries in the history of the trade."

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Recent sharp rises in the Exchange prices of wheat and cotton and the effect they were having on farmer acceptance of the agricultural adjustment program were causing grave concern at the Department of Agriculture today.
Gyrations in the grain market yesterday unsettled prices on the Cotton Exchange and after frequent nervous fluctuations in a range of a dollar a bale the list closed at losses of 15 to 20 points.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- The doctrine that "all men are created equal" was challenged here today by Dr. Harry Stack Sullivan, a New York City psychiatrist, in a paper on the "Psychology of Collective Responses to Deprivation" during a round-table conference of the so- ciology section of the American Association for the Advancement of Science at the University of Chi- cago.

The Summer edition of the 1933 Social Register, now being distributed to its subscribers, shows that many families of social prominence are remaining in their city homes during the hot months. Last year showed a large decrease in the number closing their town residences, but this year the situation is even more marked.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Federal funds for highway construction under the $400,000,000 appropriation in the Recovery Act will be ready for distribution to the States Sat- urday under regulations designed to promote the greatest possible employment.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Treasury records and unofficial tabulations showed today that about $34,200,000,000 of the $44,000,000,000 of deposits in banks closed during the March holiday have been released on an unrestricted basis.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 28. -- Declaring that "a change has come over the United States in the last three months," Senator Capper of Kansas told the advertising Federation of America today that advertising would come back first.

CLEVELAND, June 28 (AP). -- Swamping the Indians with nine runs in the first inning, the pacesetting Senators galloped on to an easy victory today, 15 to 2. The triumph was Washington's fourth in the five-game series.

The R.F.C. loan of $3,200,000 to make possible the completion earlier by two years of the building program of the Saratoga Springs Commission is justified apart from its self-liquidating feature. It brings more speedily the medicines essential to the health of many, and for which fewer are now able to go abroad.

Most commodity futures reacted yesterday in trading on local exchanges, after the vigerous rallies of the preceding day. Prices dropped off in sympathy with the grain and securities market. Trading was smaller. Cash prices also receded.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- The lightning fast Soldier Field track that furnished the under-footing for the series of brilliant performances at the National Collegiate A.A. meet a fortnight ago was barren of spike marks today.

During the new 1933-34 season RKO Radio Pictures will distribute fifty-two feature films, presenting such stars of the screen as Constance Bennett, Ann Harding, Katharine Hepburn, Irene Dunne, John and Lionel Barrymore, Leslie Howard, Dolores Del Rio, Richard Dix, Francis Lederer and Zasu Pitts.

The Peerless Motor Car Corporation, which has not manufactured automobiles since the end of 1931, has decided to enter the brewing business, according to information given to the Stock Exchange. The company purposes to sell 178,150 shares of common stock, now in its treasury, to stockholders or other persons, at $3 a share, to provide funds for the alteration of part of its plant in Cleveland, and to provide additional working capital.
Quall are increasing in North and South Carolina, according to a statement issued yesterday by Dr. T. Gilbert Pearson, president of the National Association of Audubon Societies.
The Board of Estimate voted approval yesterday of the new arrangement for relief financing which cuts the city's outlay for relief from $5,000,000 to $3,000,000 a month.

LONDON, June 28. -- Stanley Baldwin, Lord Privy Seal, on the platform of the Friends Meeting House with most of the conservative Ministers in the national Cabinet, today successfully defended the government's India policy when he was challenged by Winston Churchill and others before 1,200 delegates, representing the Central Conservative Council.

DETROIT, June 28. -- Testifying today at Judge Harry B. Keidan's banking investigation, William F. Connolly, receiver for the Detroit Bankers Company, testified that the First National Bank-Detroit can reopen within twenty-four hours and pay 100 per cent to depositors if permitted by the Federal Government.

Although bank clearings in the week ended yesterday were smaller than in the previous week, the total showed a larger percentage of increase from the corresponding period of last year than any other week since the beginning of the depression.

W. 189th St., 608-610. 50x100; five-story apartment: action I: William S. Dempsey against 30 Beekman Place Realty Corp.; due, $16,866; costs. $535; taxes, $875; prior mortgage, $48,000; to plaintiff for $49,000.

LONDON, June 28. -- While the question of an international agreement to restrict wheat output hangs in the balance, the economic conference is going ahead with its survey of the possibilities of concerted control of the production of sugar and other commodities.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter appearing in THE TIMES today in respect to the National Recovery Act throws some very interesting sidelights on this important piece of legislation.

Dr. Henry Moskowitz returned yesterday on the White Star liner Majestic after five weeks abroad. Much of his time, he said, had been spent in Germany investigating the status of the Jews there and also in interviewing Jewish refugees in London and Paris.

Bringing the full power and range of his lusty stroke to bear in an almost perfect first set, Frank Shields defeated Albert Law yester- day in the Eastern tennis championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 4.

LONDON, June 28. -- Efforts were continued outside the World Economic Conference today to move toward monetary stabilization, with the French pressing for a more rigid stabilization of the pound with the franc, since stabilization with the dollar seems still unattainable.

LAKEMAN BAY, Rogue Island, Me., June 28. -- In the privacy of the small cabin of the Amberjack II, Norman H. Davis gave to President Roosevelt today word of "excellent progress" at the Geneva Disarmament Conference and a description of developments more optimistic than any previously reported.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 28. -- A goal by Ed Nichols, four minutes after the start of a sudden-death overtime period, enabled the Eastcott polo team to down the Meadow Brook Ramblers, 8 to 7, today on Cochran Field in the second round of the Meadow Brook Club Cups tournament.

Dr. Chaim Weizmann, former president of the World Zionist Organization and president of the Hebrew University in Palestine, proposed last night to colonize in Palestine 250,000 of the victims of anti-Semitism in Nazi Germany and other lands.

With yesterday's fall of the dollar to 23 3/4 per cent discount in terms of gold currencies the bewilderment surrounding the entire situation naturally increased. That the price of wheat at Chicago should simultaneously have fallen 7 cents a bushel attracted its share of notice; but that was another story.
WASHINGTON, June 28. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:
The sale of a Washington Heights apartment house yesterday marked the return of another operator to active participation in the real estate market.

MILWAUKEE, June 28. -- Prac- tices revealed in the Senate investi- gations disclose that bankers are singularly unfitted to have a dom- inant voice in educational matters, John A. Lapp, formerly of Mar- quette University faculty, told the National Federation of Teachers today.
ST. PAUL, June 28 (AP). -- Relentless heat continued today to torture Central States farmers, whose fields have been deteriorating steadily under scorching sun and lack of rainfall.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Faced with the shortest Winter wheat crop since 1904, the United States probably will not require its growers to reduce their plantings for 1934 under the Agricultural Adjustment Act, unless the representatives of the principal producing countries can agree at London on world acreage reduction.

NEW YORK. The Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Church, with Mrs. Fleming and their daughter, Miss Mary Fleming, will sail on the Roma Saturday for a Mediterranean cruise. Afterward they will go to England for several weeks before returning to New York.

GIBSON ISLAND, Md., Thursday, June 29. -- Seven of the forty-two yachts in the ocean race from New London, Conn., to Gibson Island had arrived up to an early hour this morning. Two others were near the finish line and the rest were still bound upon the ocean outside the Virginia Capes or in the long reach of the Chesapeake, stilled by lack of wind and set back by currents.

GREAT NECK, L.I., June 28. -- The house and grounds of Evermore, the estate of the former Mrs. esse L. Livermore, now Mrs. J. Walter Longcope, were sold at auction today for $168,000, the approximate price of the mortgage. Only one bid was received, and the name of the bidder was not revealed.

BOSTON, June 28. -- An international customs armistice, prohibition of speculation, restoration of the gold standard and stabilization of currency were urged by Maurice DuPerrey, Paris, manufacturer of abrasives, at the third plenary session today of the Rotary International convention.

HUGH RUTTLEDGE, leading the Mount Everest expedition, states in a wireless message of June 22 that his mountaineers are in need of a rest, after several assaults from the highest camp. He admits the climbing difficulties, but apparently it was "fresh snow and terrible winds" that really explained the retreat to a lower altitude.

Jack Sharkey and Prime Carnera expressed confidence on the eve of their fifteen-round bout for the world's heavyweight championship. The rival boxers, in statements given to THE NEW YORK TIMES last night, were hopeful of the outcome and each predicted he would win.

MARION, MASS., June 28. -- E. Dwight Fullerton Jr. and his St. Mark's School crew advanced toward their second Interscholastic Yacht Racing Association championship by winning the first race of the final series for the Mallory trophy, sailed today off the Beverly Yacht Club.

New York State awarded yesterday a new issue of $26,595,000 of bonds at an interest cost of 2.936 per cent, the lowest rate the State has paid on long-term borrowing in its financial history. The issue, for which three major syndicates submitted sealed tenders, went to a group of thirty-six banks and banking houses headed by the Chase National Bank.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 28 -- The "new deal" and Industrial Recovery Act find both business and the public in accord with the governmental policies and its new association with almost every form of industrial, agrarian and economic endeavor, according to Governor Albert C. Ritchie of Maryland.

Yesterday the State of New York sold bonds to the amount of $26,595,000 at a price which will bring the interest rate just under 3 per cent. At the same time the City of New York is having to pay 5 1/2 per cent on short-term bonds which its salesmen are peddling out to citizens for use in payment of taxes next December.

Augustine Duncan, Louise Beaumont, Howard Hall, Angus Duncan, Barry McCullom, Lillian Savin and J.K. Kelly are among the members of the cast who will appear in the Wee Leventhal revival of St. John Ervine's "John Ferguson."

LONDON, June 29. -- The desire of American collectors to acquire more important items from the library of the late Lord Rosebery again was reflected in the bidding at the fourth day's sale of his library from the Durdans, Epsom, at Sotheby's today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Joining the complaint of L.E.W., published in THE TIMES, I would like to state that owing, not exactly to the radio of "a thoughtless person," but to the innumerable loud-speakers heard in courts and alleys. I have lost, in the last three Summers, many hours of study and profitable reading, and even many hours of sleep.

In one of the largest deals of the year Charles Kimmelman Son, operators, purchased from the Manufacturers Trust Company, as liquidators for the International Madison Bank and Trust Company, the twenty-four-story office building at 152 Madison Avenue, north-west corner of Thirty-second Street.

Primo Carnera reached the world's heavyweight Championship throne by way of a circus side-show. The giant Italian, whose great size has been his outstanding characteristic ever since childhood, harbored no intentions of becoming a boxer until four years ago.

The sixteenth season of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra's concerts in Lewisohn Stadium of New York City College began last night before an audience of 14,000, called forth by the opportunity to hear a fine symphony re-create for them works of the two greatest geniuses of post-Beethovian music -- Wagner and Brahms.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- A new method of predicting social and international trends by means of an "attitude scale indicator," was described here today by Professor James T. Russell of the University of Chicago before the sociology section of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Strength in United States Government bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday contrasted with irregularly lower prices for domestic corporation issues and leading foreign loans. Government issues rallied 1-32 to 12-32 point, reversing the trend of the previous few days.
WALTON HEATH, England, June 29. -- The Prince of Wales, conceding seven strokes, beat Lady Astor in the semi-final of the Parliamentary Handicap Golf Tournament today by 2 and 1.

The decline in the dollar against foreign currencies came to an abrupt halt yesterday. Weakness in the pound sterling and the franc were generally attributed here to heavy speculative activity on renewal of the stabilization rumors.

GENEVA, June 29. -- The World Disarmament Conference was adjourned today until Oct. 16, after a short meeting of the general commission. Arthur Henderson, president, stressed that this procedure did not mean delay in the work as he meanwhile would seek to end the deadlocks by private talks.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Scattered liquidation was on again in the grain markets early today, but without the excitement that had marked the pit of late. Good rains fell over a large area in the American and Canadian Northwest, while part of the Illinois, Iowa and Missouri corn belt had heavy rains as the result of thunderstorms.

LONDON, June 29. -- The wild gyrations of the dollar today -- it went as low as 4.41 1/2 to the pound and wound up at 4.29 1/2 -- created a situation that can be described only as a crisis for the World Economic Conference. Throughout the day the issue arising from the necessity for some measures to stabilize not only the dollar, but European currencies, too, transcended all others.

LONDON, June 29. -- It has been decided by the committee of which General C.G. Bruce is the chairman to recall the Mount Everest Climbing Expedition. This decision may appear illogical at first sight, since Hugh Ruttledge, leader of the expedition, concluded his last dispatch with the words:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The statement issued by Representative Bertrand H. Snell, the Republican minority leader of Congress, was worth reading. Coming from a man of Mr. Snell's ability, integrity and love of country, it should have impressed those who read it. Having known Mr. Snell for many years, I take the liberty of commenting on his statement.

Rises Halt Dry Goods Orders. Rapidly advancing dry goods prices, particularly in cotton textiles, have temporarily halted any volume orders by wholesalers, according to comment in jobbing circles yesterday. They expressed the opinion yesterday that mills have been moving up quotations too quickly and that jobbers have been paying for anticipated higher labor costs which have not yet materialized.

LONDON, June 29. -- The spectacle of a society bride vainly attempting to gain entry into fashionable St. Margaret's Church, Westminster, through a crush of well wishers occurred today when Lady Patricia Moore, the only daughter of the Earl and Countess of Drogheda, was married to Sir Paul Latham, Conservative member of Parliament.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 29. -- Many members of the Summer colony attended the second in the series of bridge tournaments held tonight at the club house of the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club. Among those who played were:

A demand that the anti-Koenig group in the Republican party come forward with a candidate to supplant Samuel S. Koenig as Republican County Chairman of New York was voiced yesterday by Colonel William Hayward. Colonel Hayward is chairman of the committee formed to conduct the contest to retain Mr. Koenig.

ROME, June 29. -- The Most Rev. James Anthony Walsh, Superior General of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America, with headquarters at Maryknoll, N.Y., was consecrated as a Titular Bishop today. The ceremony took place in the chapel of the new College of the Sacred Congregation of Propaganda on Janiculum Hill.

The committee organizing the National Tobacco Council, Inc., to integrate the tobacco industry and draft its code under the National Industrial Recovery Act, announced yesterday that its work was virtually complete.

A 35-hour work week, the abolition of child labor, and a minimum wage scale ranging from $38 to $50 a week are provided in the Recovery Act code adopted yesterday by the Retail Manufacturing Furriers of America, Inc.

In the sharpest advance in its history The Annalist Weekly Index of Commodity Prices rose 4.5 points to 97.8 on Tuesday, June 27, from 93.3 the week previous. It now stands 7.2 points above a year ago, and is the highest since Dec. 8, 1931, when it stood at 98.6.
Real estate exempt from city taxation has reached a total assessed valuation of $4,689,803,389 this year, a gain of almost $65,000,000 over the 1932 total.

Mayor O'Brien left his big black car beside a subway kiosk yesterday afternoon, and went for a ride on the city's newest transit facility -- the Bronx Concourse line of the city's independent subway system, which opens to the public at 1 A.M. tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP). -- A four-point plan having as its objective the regaining for veterans of most of the benefits of which they were stripped under the Economy Act was outlined here today at the first of a series of regional conferences of the national rehabilitation committee of the American Legion.
Alfred E. Smith, in his editorial in the current issue of the New Outlook, declares that he cannot understand how the National Industrial Recovery Act possibly can work.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 (AP). -- Batting in all his team's runs with four hits -- two of them home runs -- in four trips to the plate, Chuck Klein, homer-hammering outfielder, made a personal triumph out of the Phillies' 6-to-4 victory over the Pirates today.

Primo Carnera was almost at a loss for words when he reached his dressing room after the fight last night. The young giant was so excited and happy that it was difficult to get anything coherent from him. His English was almost entirely lost and whatever comments he made were in Italian.

The seven little octopl that arrived at the Aquarium on Tuesday were being prepared for pickling yesterday. As may be inferred, the octopi were dead. The exact hour of their demise is not known. They were alive Tuesday; they were dead Wednesday morning; they were very dead yesterday.
SCARBOROUGH - ON - HUDSON, N.Y., June 29. -- Another former caddie became a full fledged golf champion today.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended June 28, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,196,000,000, a decrease of $7,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $158,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The United States is prepared to maintain domestic wheat prices considerably above the world level regardless of the outcome of negotiations now under way at London for increasing the world price through international agreements to reduce acreage.

QUEBEC, June 29. -- An inter-Provincial Royal Commission, with members from Quebec, Ontario and New Brunswick, to study the future of the billion-dollar newsprint industry in Eastern Canada, has been suggested as being the only means of saving the industry itself from extinction and also to save the Provinces concerned a lot of money.

The New York Central Railroad is prepared to accommodate today and tomorrow the largest volume of traffic ever to pass through the Grand Central Terminal. Traffic officials at the Pennsylvania Station reported heavy traffic over the week-end and holiday period would start tonight.
The grand jury, which for six weeks has been investigating racketeering in the Fulton fish market, indicted two labor leaders yesterday. The indictments charged extortion and coercion.

The White Star liner Majestic, which sails tonight for Cherbourg and Southampton, will have among her passengers Justice J.C. McReynolds, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court; Sir Harold B. Kittermaster, Governor of British Honduras; Mrs. William Brown Meloney, editor; Mrs. Herbert Bayard Swope; James Speyer, financier; Robert L. Hague, head of the Standard Shipping Corporation, with Mrs. Hague, the former Mary Lewis, opera singer.

BALTIMORE, June 29 (AP). -- After Jersey City had tied the count in the ninth inning, Joe Sprinz singled to score Solters in Baltimore's half of the final inning to give the Orioles a 4-to-3 victory in the opening game of the series tonight.

School will be out today and there will be no Summer school this year. The hot weather sessions have been swept away in the educational economy wave. Ten weeks of freedom await nearly 1,200,000 children and 35,939 teachers. Classes will resume on Sept. 11.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- The Freudian concept that girls are subconsciously in love with their fathers and boys with their mothers received a measure of corroboration in a study presented here today by Dr. Ross Stagner of, the University of Wisconsin.

The directors of the American Petroleum Institute at a meeting yesterday approved the oil code as drafted by representatives of the producing organizations and refining and marketing organizations in Chicago recently. The code now will be forwarded to Washington, where, it is expected, a public, hearing will be held.
The Public Service Commission announced yesterday it had dismissed the complaint against the labor policies of the Brooklyn Edison Company.

It has all along seemed, and still seems, that Mayor O'BRIEN is entitled to renomination by Tammany Hall. That right and expectation were implicit in his resignation as Surrogate in order to fill out the unexpired term of Mayor WALKER. Tenure of the Mayoralty for more than a single year was implied it not actually promised.

Primo Carnera was twenty minutes late in arriving for the weighing-in ceremonies at the New York State Athletic Commission offices yesterday. Jack Sharkey, who stayed in New York overnight, reached the commission's headquarters at 2 o'clock promptly and registered 201 pounds as he stepped on the scales.

Thirty-one commercial attaches, trade commissioners and assistants who were dismissed from their foreign posts with a week's notice to return home, arrived yesterday on the United States liner Washington.

The statement of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve Bank in New York City announced yesterday for the week ended Wednesday, showed a further loss in demand deposits amounting to $94,000,000. A week ago the drop was $347,000,000 in as much as that week showed the first effects of the ban on interest on demand deposits.

NEWARK, N. J., June 29. -- Mgr. John Aloysius Duffy, vicar-general of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Newark and pastor of St. Joseph's Church, Jersey City, was conscrated today fourth Bishop of the Diocese of Syracuse, N.Y., in the presence of one-third of the hierarchy of the United States.

The Treasury denies that its heads are discussing dollar stabilization. It is explained that there are no new developments on the subject in "Washington." But Washington is not the place for such developments. They will come, if they come, at London and aboard Amberjack II.

Five school children received $200 ch yesterday as winners of the M. Samuel Stern and the Rebecca Elsberg memorial prizes. The awards were made by Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, in his office at 500 Park Avenue.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 29. -- The Lenox Garden Club held its flower show at the Stockbridge Golf and Tennis Club yesterday and today.

Further losses were registered yesterday in most of the commodities traded on local exchanges, although crude rubber and raw hide futures were higher. Trading was moderately active. Cash prices were irregular.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 29. -- Jack Munger, 18-year-old Texan, today won the Presbrey Trophy, emblematic of the Eastern interscholastic golf championship. The new titleholder attends Hill School.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- The serene calm that usually pervades the halls where engineers meet to discuss hydraulics, bridges, power, construction of machines and other problems in applied science was dramatically disturbed here today.
The singular charm which the Giants appear able to exercise almost at will against practically all the other clubs in the National League this year, still refuses to function against the Cardinals.

LONDON, June 29. -- While his thin and abstemious-looking colleague, Georges Bonnet, the French Minister of Finance, was engaged in anxious colloquy with the Prime Ministers of Britain and Holland on the gold standard, Albert Sarraut, the Minister of Colonies, who boasts that he partakes liberally of the joys of the table, laid before a committee of the World Economic Conference this afternoon a really grave problem -- that of the world's underconsumption of wine.
WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Following is the statement on naval policy issued today by Secretary Swanson:
Litigation over the vast estate of Miss Ella V. Von E. Wendel ended yesterday when Surrogate James A. Foley approved a settlement granting more than $2,000,000 to nine distant relatives.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 29. -- Mrs. Michael M. van Beuren this afternoon acted as hostess to members of the Newport Garden Association at her home, Gray Craig, in Middletown. It was the annual meeting election and was followed by tea in the garden.

BERLIN, June 29. -- Quotations on the Boerse fluctuated today, with closing prices virtually unchanged from yesterday. The opening was weak, though losses stayed within 1 per cent and 1 1/2 per cent. Then followed an upward trend, on publication of an optimistic analysis by the Institute for Business Research which reported the biggest employment gain for the first five months since 1929.

Dissolution of Drug, Inc., a $150,000,000 holding company; and the re-establishment of its five principal operating subsidiaries as independent companies were recommended yesterday by the directors of the parent concern. Stockholders Will vote on the proposal on Aug. 7 in Wilmington, Del.

The broadbills are appearing at their old retreat off Fire Island Light and Montauk more plentifully than ever, boat captains resort. However, the anglers who resort only to hook and line in endeavoring to master this swordfish have not taken up the sport with much consistency.

CLEVELAND, June 29. -- The Yankees climbed back into a tie for the leadership in the American League pennant race today when they opened a four-game series with an easy victory over the Indians, while the Senators were losing in Detroit.

A new Munchausen who has roamed the world and tells original tales in a highly individualistic language is introduced by Stella Benson in "Pull Devil, Pull Baker," published today by Harpers. Miss Benson's story-teller calls himself Count de Toulouse Lautrec de Savine, ex-Czar of Bulgaria, and spends most of his time now -- he is nearly 80 -- in charity hospitals in Asia telling stories of what he has seen and done.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date, while total bills discounted reached a new low figure for the year.
WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Movements of vessels follow: all dates are June 28 unless otherwise specified:

Those whose hearts 3.2 wine doesn't make glad can at least take an esthetic pleasure in the thought of the loan exhibition of drinking-vessels that opened in the Hall of the London Vintners Company a few days ago. One likes to think of the long generations of artists that labored to make the shrine worthy of its genial divinity.

BERLIN, June 29. -- Dr. Ludwig Mueller, who took over the Evangelical Church Union and Supreme Council today, dismissed the Rev. Dr. Adalbert Hosemann, administrative director in the Council, and appointed Admiral Meusel in his place.
DETROIT, June 29. -- President Roosevelt will be asked to see to it that Federal officers shall tell why they closed the city's two largest banks, the First National and the Guardian National.
ALBANY, June 29. -- Jeremiah A. Sullivan of West New Brighton was appointed Sheriff of Richmond County by Governor Lehman today to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Reinhard E. Kaltenmeier.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Otto H. Kahn, senior partner of Kuhn, Loeb Co., told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today that he favored a new deal under which there would be governmental supervision of every instrumentality which dealt with money, currency and credit.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Discord entered the ranks of the technocrats today and caused the sudden ending of their convention in the Morrison Hotel at noon. The meeting, which had been called to further technocracy's hopes of curing the ills of the world, began Tuesday morning and was to have lasted until tomorrow noon.

LONDON, June 29. -- The Economic Conference sumcommittee which is considering the gold clauses of Senator Pittman's proposal and other suggestions for the permanent working of the gold standard, unanimously adopted resolutions today recommending the universal establishment of central banks and their close cooperation with each other and the Bank for International Settlements at Basle.
Maurice Wertheim gave to the trustees or the will of Henry D. Winans a mortgage for $9,000, payable June 1, 1936, at 5 per cent on the four-story building at 203 E. 46th St.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Automobile production in the United States was 218,171 cars in May, an increase of 37,504 over April, and was the largest output for any corresponding period since July, 1931, the Commerce Department announced today.

Trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday was slow and somewhat meaningless. The total volume of business was quite large -- it amounted to 4,594,000 shares, compared with 5,506,000 on the day before. There was, at the close of the day, a small net loss in the combined averages, largely as the result of a decline at the close.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- In his testimony before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee this morning, Otto H. Kahn, senior partner of Kuhn, Loeb Co., deplored the capital gains and losses provision of the income tax laws, under which a legal escape is possible of income tax, and suggested that the law ought to be amended.
LONDON, June 29 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Governmental representatives of nations, when approaching the question of revising tariffs, begin such discussions largely from a political viewpoint. The net result is that little has been accomplished except to create further rivalry. A step toward a solution of tariff barriers and restoring trade between nations might be effected in a short time if American statesmen would begin the approach from a practical financial viewpoint.

PARIS, June 29.-- Russell M. Cooper, American student of the University of Higher International Studies of Geneva, Switzerland, has been chosen by an international jury as winner of the essay contest in European universities under the auspices of the New History Society of New York, it was announced here today.

LONDON, June 29. -- The "Big Four" wheat committee worked hard today, drafting a wheat restriction scheme In much statistical detail so Stanley M. Bruce could dispatch it to the Australian Government for submission at Saturday's meeting in Sydney of the Premiers of all Australian States.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- A determined effort was being made by the Industrial Recovery Administration tonight to effect an accord between labor and capital on the basic clauses of the cotton textile code of fair competition, so that the government's first step toward industrial control might be taken with the support of all elements.

CINCINNATI, June 29. -- Immediate removal of General Frank T. Hines as Veterans' Administrator; his assistant, J.C.O. Roberts, and the chief of the medical and hospital staffs in Washington, was "demanded" in a resolution passed by the Disabled American Veterans Convention today and addressed to President Roosevelt.
NEW YORK. Mrs. J. Lorimer Worden of the Fierre will sail tonight on the Majestic to visit her mother, Mrs. George Bowen de Long, in London. Mr. Worden will join his wife in August.

ALBANY, June 29. -- The Public Service Commission will make an effort, in certain cases, to limit utility companies to a 6 per cent return on their investments, George R. Lunn, a member of the commission, said today. He has been presiding at the hearings which the commission is conducting into the affairs of several up-State companies.

The leniency of magistrates in dealing with peddlers and beggars arrested along Forty-second Street was protested yesterday by officers and members of the Forty-second Street Association. They conferred with Chief City Magistrate James E. McDonald at a meeting in his chambers, 300 Mulberry Street.

CAMPOBELLO ISLAND, N.B., June 29. -- Reverting to his status of President of the United States from that of skipper of the Amberjack II, Franklin D. Roosevelt renewed his appeals for world peace today in his first words on foreign soil since he assumed the Presidency.

For years there has been an organized effort for adoption of an amendment to the Federal Constitution that would limit, regulate or prohibit child labor. The proposed amendment submitted to the States for ratification in 1924 was rejected promptly by twenty-four States.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A new naval policy superseding that promulgated Aug. 4, 1931, by Secretary Adams, and calling for an aggressive program to build up the navy to a position "second to none in conformity with treaty provisions," was stated by Secretary Swanson today.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 29. -- Combining a strong net attack with a close backcourt defense and chopping consistently to her opponent's backhand, the Baroness Maud Levi, top-seeded favorite, today gained the final of the women's metropolitan clay court tennis championships at the Lido Country Club.

WASHINGTON. June 29. -- The question of wages and hours of labor, heretofore unmentioned in marketing agreements filed by food industries with the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, will be thoroughly explored prior to final approval of such compacts.
The City Affairs Committee offered to the Board of Education the story of the "thirty-four McQuades" yesterday as a substitute for the "Three Bears."
Queens alone of the five boroughs will receive little benefit from the new local first-class postage rate of 2 cents an ounce that becomes effective tomorrow, postal officials admitted yesterday.

PARIS. June 29. -- Unless there Is an abnormal change in the internal situation in this country, France can easily adhere to the gold standard and avoid devalorization of the franc for at least another six months, it was authoritatively stated today in official quarters.
IT has been warm in Washington recently. That probably explains the following letter, written by a Washington resident who, apparently, was a trifle hot under the collar:
WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

Disturbing reports from abroad of foreign exchange difficulties had some effect yesterday upon the security markets. The popular notion that the dollar is in some kind of a grim and bitter contest with gold-standard currencies is naturally disquieting.
DETROIT, June 29 (AP). -- The Tigers stopped the Senators 5 to 4 in the opening game of their series today by a ninth-inning finish.

Reports or rail earnings for May and traffic figures issued for June were said yesterday to hold out the possibility that net operating income of all the roads in the first six months of 1933 would exceed the total for the same period last year.

About forty railroad presidents representing 95 per cent of the mileage east of the Mississippi and north of the Potomac River met yesterday in the Bankers Club and authorized the formation of two committees to increase the operating efficiency of railroads in this region.
